    
Little
Dorrit
<EOS>
Charles
Dickens
  
1855
-
<EOS>
-1857
  
<EOS>
Information
about
the
source
     
Book
the
First
.
<EOS>
Poverty
 
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
Sun
and
Shadow
 
<EOS>
Thirty
years
ago
,
Marseilles
lay
burning
in
the
sun
,
one
day
.
   
<EOS>
A
blazing
sun
upon
a
fierce
August
day
was
no
greater
rarity
in
southern
France
then
,
than
at
any
other
time
,
before
or
since
.
<EOS>
Everything
in
Marseilles
,
and
about
Marseilles
,
had
stared
at
the
fervid
sky
,
and
been
stared
at
in
return
,
until
a
staring
habit
had
become
universal
there
.
 
<EOS>
Strangers
were
stared
out
of
countenance
by
staring
white
houses
,
staring
white
walls
,
staring
white
streets
,
staring
tracts
of
arid
road
,
staring
hills
from
which
verdure
was
burnt
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
things
to
be
seen
not
fixedly
staring
and
glaring
were
the
vines
drooping
under
their
load
of
grapes
.
 
<EOS>
These
did
occasionally
wink
a
little
,
as
the
hot
air
barely
moved
their
faint
leaves
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
wind
to
make
a
ripple
on
the
foul
water
within
the
harbour
,
or
on
the
beautiful
sea
without
.
 
<EOS>
The
line
of
demarcation
between
the
two
colours
,
black
and
blue
,
showed
the
point
which
the
pure
sea
would
not
pass
;
but
it
lay
as
quiet
as
the
abominable
pool
,
with
which
it
never
mixed
.
 
<EOS>
Boats
without
awnings
were
too
hot
to
touch
;
ships
blistered
at
their
moorings
;
the
stones
of
the
quays
had
not
cooled
,
night
or
day
,
for
months
.
 
<EOS>
Hindoos
,
Russians
,
Chinese
,
Spaniards
,
Portuguese
,
Englishmen
,
Frenchmen
,
Genoese
,
Neapolitans
,
Venetians
,
Greeks
,
Turks
,
descendants
from
all
the
builders
of
Babel
,
come
to
trade
at
Marseilles
,
sought
the
shade
alike
---
taking
refuge
in
any
hiding
-
place
from
a
sea
too
intensely
blue
to
be
looked
at
,
and
a
sky
of
purple
,
set
with
one
great
flaming
jewel
of
fire
.
   
<EOS>
The
universal
stare
made
the
eyes
ache
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
the
distant
line
of
Italian
coast
,
indeed
,
it
was
a
little
relieved
by
light
clouds
of
mist
,
slowly
rising
from
the
evaporation
of
the
sea
,
but
it
softened
nowhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
Far
away
the
staring
roads
,
deep
in
dust
,
stared
from
the
hill
-
side
,
stared
from
the
hollow
,
stared
from
the
interminable
plain
.
 
<EOS>
Far
away
the
dusty
vines
overhanging
wayside
cottages
,
and
the
monotonous
wayside
avenues
of
parched
trees
without
shade
,
drooped
beneath
the
stare
of
earth
and
sky
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
the
horses
with
drowsy
bells
,
in
long
files
of
carts
,
creeping
slowly
towards
the
interior
;
so
did
their
recumbent
drivers
,
when
they
were
awake
,
which
rarely
happened
;
so
did
the
exhausted
labourers
in
the
fields
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
that
lived
or
grew
,
was
oppressed
by
the
glare
;
except
the
lizard
,
passing
swiftly
over
rough
stone
walls
,
and
the
cicala
,
chirping
his
dry
hot
chirp
,
like
a
rattle
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
dust
was
scorched
brown
,
and
something
quivered
in
the
atmosphere
as
if
the
air
itself
were
panting
.
   
<EOS>
Blinds
,
shutters
,
curtains
,
awnings
,
were
all
closed
and
drawn
to
keep
out
the
stare
.
 
<EOS>
Grant
it
but
a
chink
or
keyhole
,
and
<EOS>
it
shot
in
like
a
white
-
hot
arrow
.
 
<EOS>
The
churches
were
the
freest
from
it
.
<EOS>
To
come
out
of
the
twilight
of
pillars
and
arches
---
dreamily
dotted
with
winking
lamps
,
dreamily
peopled
with
ugly
old
shadows
piously
dozing
,
spitting
,
and
begging
---
was
to
plunge
into
a
fiery
river
,
and
swim
for
life
to
the
nearest
strip
of
shade
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
with
people
lounging
and
lying
wherever
shade
was
,
with
but
little
hum
of
tongues
or
barking
of
dogs
,
with
occasional
jangling
of
discordant
church
bells
and
rattling
of
vicious
drums
,
Marseilles
,
a
fact
to
be
strongly
smelt
and
tasted
,
lay
broiling
in
the
sun
one
day
.
<EOS>
In
Marseilles
that
day
there
was
a
villainous
prison
.
 
<EOS>
In
one
of
its
chambers
,
so
repulsive
a
place
that
even
the
obtrusive
stare
blinked
at
it
,
and
left
it
to
such
refuse
of
reflected
light
as
it
could
find
for
itself
,
were
two
men
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
the
two
men
,
a
notched
and
disfigured
bench
,
immovable
from
the
wall
,
with
a
draught
-
board
rudely
hacked
upon
it
with
a
knife
,
a
set
of
draughts
,
made
of
old
buttons
and
soup
bones
,
a
set
of
dominoes
,
two
mats
,
and
two
or
three
wine
bottles
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
all
the
chamber
held
,
exclusive
of
rats
and
other
unseen
vermin
,
in
addition
to
the
seen
vermin
,
the
two
men
.
   
<EOS>
It
received
such
light
as
it
got
through
a
grating
of
iron
bars
fashioned
like
a
pretty
large
window
,
by
means
of
which
it
could
be
always
inspected
from
the
gloomy
staircase
on
which
the
grating
gave
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
broad
strong
ledge
of
stone
to
this
grating
where
the
bottom
of
it
was
let
into
the
masonry
,
three
or
four
feet
above
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
it
,
one
of
the
two
men
lolled
,
half
sitting
and
half
lying
,
with
his
knees
drawn
up
,
and
his
feet
and
shoulders
planted
against
the
opposite
sides
of
the
aperture
.
 
<EOS>
The
bars
were
wide
enough
apart
to
admit
of
his
thrusting
his
arm
through
to
the
elbow
;
and
so
he
held
on
negligently
,
for
his
greater
ease
.
   
<EOS>
A
prison
taint
was
on
everything
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
imprisoned
air
,
the
imprisoned
light
,
the
imprisoned
damps
,
the
imprisoned
men
,
were
all
deteriorated
by
confinement
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
captive
men
were
faded
and
haggard
,
so
the
iron
was
rusty
,
the
stone
was
slimy
,
the
wood
was
rotten
,
the
air
was
faint
,
the
light
was
dim
.
 
<EOS>
Like
a
well
,
like
a
vault
,
like
a
tomb
,
the
prison
had
no
knowledge
of
the
brightness
outside
,
and
would
have
kept
its
polluted
atmosphere
intact
in
one
of
the
spice
islands
of
the
Indian
ocean
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
who
lay
on
the
ledge
of
the
grating
was
even
chilled
.
 
<EOS>
He
jerked
his
great
cloak
more
heavily
upon
him
by
an
impatient
movement
of
one
shoulder
,
and
growled
,
"
To
the
devil
with
this
Brigand
of
a
Sun
that
never
shines
in
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
waiting
to
be
fed
,
looking
sideways
through
the
bars
that
he
might
see
the
further
down
the
stairs
,
with
much
of
the
expression
of
a
wild
beast
in
similar
expectation
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
eyes
,
too
close
together
,
were
not
so
nobly
set
in
his
head
as
those
of
the
king
of
beasts
are
in
his
,
and
they
were
sharp
rather
than
bright
---
pointed
weapons
with
little
surface
to
betray
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
no
depth
or
change
;
they
glittered
,
and
they
opened
and
shut
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
,
and
waiving
their
use
to
himself
,
a
clockmaker
could
have
made
a
better
pair
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
hook
nose
,
<EOS>
handsome
after
its
kind
,
but
too
high
between
the
eyes
by
probably
just
as
much
as
his
eyes
were
too
near
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
rest
,
he
was
large
and
tall
in
frame
,
had
thin
lips
,
where
his
thick
moustache
showed
them
at
all
,
and
a
quantity
of
dry
hair
,
of
no
definable
colour
,
in
its
shaggy
state
,
but
shot
with
red
.
 
<EOS>
The
hand
with
which
he
held
the
grating
(
seamed
all
over
the
back
with
ugly
scratches
newly
healed
)
,
was
unusually
small
and
plump
;
would
have
been
unusually
white
but
for
the
prison
grime
.
<EOS>
The
other
man
was
lying
on
the
stone
floor
,
covered
with
a
coarse
brown
coat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
pig
!
<EOS>
"
growled
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
sleep
when
I
am
hungry
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
one
,
master
,
"
said
the
pig
,
in
a
submissive
manner
,
and
not
without
cheerfulness
;
"
I
can
wake
when
I
will
,
I
can
sleep
when
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
said
it
,
he
rose
,
shook
himself
,
scratched
himself
,
tied
his
brown
coat
loosely
round
his
neck
by
the
sleeves
<EOS>
(
he
had
previously
used
it
as
a
coverlet
)
,
and
sat
down
upon
the
pavement
yawning
,
with
his
back
against
the
wall
opposite
to
the
grating
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
what
the
hour
is
,
"
grumbled
the
first
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
mid
-
day
bells
will
ring
---
in
forty
minutes
.
"
 
<EOS>
When
he
made
the
little
pause
,
he
had
looked
round
the
prison
-
room
,
as
if
for
certain
information
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
clock
.
 
<EOS>
How
is
it
that
you
always
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
say
?
 
<EOS>
I
always
know
what
the
hour
is
,
and
where
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
was
brought
in
here
at
night
,
and
out
of
a
boat
,
but
I
know
where
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
See
here
!
 
<EOS>
Marseilles
harbour
;
"
on
his
knees
on
the
pavement
,
mapping
it
all
out
with
a
swarthy
forefinger
;
"
Toulon
(
where
the
galleys
are
)
,
Spain
over
there
,
Algiers
over
there
.
<EOS>
Creeping
away
to
the
left
here
,
Nice
.
 
<EOS>
Round
by
the
Cornice
to
Genoa
.
 
<EOS>
Genoa
Mole
and
Harbour
.
 
<EOS>
Quarantine
Ground
.
 
<EOS>
City
there
;
terrace
gardens
blushing
with
the
bella
donna
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Porto
Fino
.
<EOS>
Stand
out
for
Leghorn
.
 
<EOS>
Out
again
for
Civita
Vecchia
.
 
<EOS>
so
away
to
---
hey
!
 
<EOS>
there
's
no
room
for
Naples
;
"
he
had
got
to
the
wall
by
this
time
;
"
but
it
's
all
one
;
it
's
in
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
remained
on
his
knees
,
looking
up
at
his
fellow
-
prisoner
with
a
lively
look
for
a
prison
.
 
<EOS>
A
sunburnt
,
quick
,
lithe
,
<EOS>
little
man
,
though
rather
thickset
.
 
<EOS>
Earrings
in
his
brown
ears
,
white
teeth
lighting
up
his
grotesque
brown
face
,
intensely
black
hair
clustering
about
his
brown
throat
,
a
ragged
red
shirt
open
at
his
brown
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Loose
,
seaman
-
like
trousers
,
decent
shoes
,
a
long
red
cap
,
a
red
sash
round
his
waist
,
and
a
knife
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Judge
if
I
come
back
from
Naples
as
I
went
!
 
<EOS>
See
here
,
my
master
!
<EOS>
Civita
Vecchia
,
Leghorn
,
Porto
Fino
,
Genoa
,
Cornice
,
Off
Nice
(
which
is
in
there
)
,
Marseilles
,
you
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
apartment
of
the
jailer
and
his
keys
is
where
I
put
this
thumb
;
and
here
at
my
wrist
they
keep
the
national
razor
in
its
case
---
the
guillotine
locked
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
other
man
spat
suddenly
on
the
pavement
,
and
gurgled
in
his
throat
.
   
<EOS>
Some
lock
below
gurgled
in
its
throat
immediately
afterwards
,
and
then
a
door
crashed
.
 
<EOS>
Slow
steps
began
ascending
the
stairs
;
the
prattle
of
a
sweet
little
voice
mingled
with
the
noise
they
made
;
and
the
prison
-
keeper
appeared
carrying
his
daughter
,
three
or
four
years
old
,
and
a
basket
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
goes
the
world
this
forenoon
,
gentlemen
?
 
<EOS>
My
little
one
,
you
see
,
going
round
with
me
to
have
a
peep
at
her
father
's
birds
.
<EOS>
Fie
,
then
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
birds
,
my
pretty
,
look
at
the
birds
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
sharply
at
the
birds
himself
,
as
he
held
the
child
up
at
the
grate
,
especially
at
the
little
bird
,
whose
activity
he
seemed
to
mistrust
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
your
bread
,
Signor
John
Baptist
,
"
said
he
(
they
all
spoke
in
French
,
but
<EOS>
the
little
man
was
an
Italian
)
;
"
and
if
I
might
recommend
you
not
to
game
---
"
   
"
You
do
n't
recommend
the
master
!
"
said
John
Baptist
,
showing
his
teeth
as
he
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
but
the
master
wins
,
"
returned
the
jailer
,
with
a
passing
look
of
no
particular
liking
at
the
other
man
,
"
and
you
lose
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
quite
another
thing
.
 
<EOS>
You
get
husky
bread
and
sour
drink
by
it
;
and
he
gets
sausage
of
Lyons
,
veal
in
savoury
jelly
,
white
bread
,
strachino
cheese
,
and
good
wine
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
birds
,
my
pretty
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
birds
!
"
said
the
child
.
   
<EOS>
The
fair
little
face
,
touched
with
divine
compassion
,
as
it
peeped
shrinkingly
through
the
grate
,
was
like
an
angel
's
in
the
prison
.
<EOS>
John
Baptist
rose
and
moved
towards
it
,
as
if
it
had
a
good
attraction
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
bird
remained
as
before
,
except
for
an
impatient
glance
at
the
basket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
the
jailer
,
putting
his
little
daughter
on
the
outer
ledge
of
the
grate
,
"
she
shall
feed
the
birds
.
 
<EOS>
This
big
loaf
is
for
Signor
John
Baptist
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
break
it
to
get
it
through
into
the
cage
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
there
's
a
tame
bird
to
kiss
the
little
hand
!
 
<EOS>
This
sausage
in
a
vine
leaf
is
for
Monsieur
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Again
---
this
veal
in
savoury
jelly
is
for
Monsieur
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Again
---
these
three
white
little
loaves
are
for
Monsieur
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
this
cheese
---
again
,
this
wine
---
again
,
this
tobacco
---
all
for
Monsieur
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Lucky
bird
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
child
put
all
these
things
between
the
bars
into
the
soft
,
Smooth
,
well
-
shaped
hand
,
with
evident
dread
---
more
than
once
drawing
back
her
own
and
looking
at
the
man
with
her
fair
brow
roughened
into
an
expression
half
of
fright
and
half
of
anger
.
<EOS>
Whereas
she
had
put
the
lump
of
coarse
bread
into
the
swart
,
scaled
,
knotted
hands
of
John
Baptist
(
who
had
scarcely
as
much
nail
on
his
eight
fingers
and
two
thumbs
as
would
have
made
out
one
for
Monsieur
Rigaud
)
,
with
ready
confidence
;
and
,
when
he
kissed
her
hand
,
had
herself
passed
it
caressingly
over
his
face
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
indifferent
to
this
distinction
,
propitiated
the
father
by
laughing
and
nodding
at
the
daughter
as
often
as
she
gave
him
anything
;
and
,
so
soon
as
he
had
all
his
viands
about
him
in
convenient
nooks
of
the
ledge
on
which
he
rested
,
began
to
eat
with
an
appetite
.
   
<EOS>
When
Monsieur
Rigaud
laughed
,
a
change
took
place
in
his
face
,
that
was
more
remarkable
than
prepossessing
.
 
<EOS>
His
moustache
went
up
under
his
nose
,
and
his
nose
came
down
over
his
moustache
,
in
a
very
sinister
and
cruel
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
the
jailer
,
turning
his
basket
upside
down
to
beat
the
crumbs
out
,
"
I
have
expended
all
the
money
I
received
;
here
is
the
note
of
it
,
and
that
's
a
thing
accomplished
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
as
I
expected
yesterday
,
the
President
will
look
for
the
pleasure
of
your
society
at
an
hour
after
mid
-
day
,
to
-
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
try
me
,
eh
?
"
said
Rigaud
,
pausing
,
knife
in
hand
and
morsel
in
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
said
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
try
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
news
for
me
?
"
asked
John
Baptist
,
who
had
begun
,
contentedly
,
to
munch
his
bread
.
   
<EOS>
The
jailer
shrugged
his
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
of
mine
!
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
lie
here
all
my
life
,
my
father
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
know
!
"
cried
the
jailer
,
turning
upon
him
with
southern
quickness
,
and
gesticulating
with
both
his
hands
and
all
his
fingers
,
as
if
he
were
threatening
to
tear
him
to
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
friend
,
how
is
it
possible
for
me
to
tell
how
long
you
are
to
lie
here
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
I
know
,
John
Baptist
Cavalletto
?
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
life
!
<EOS>
There
are
prisoners
here
sometimes
,
who
are
not
in
such
a
devil
of
a
hurry
to
be
tried
.
"
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
glance
obliquely
at
Monsieur
Rigaud
in
this
remark
;
but
Monsieur
Rigaud
had
already
resumed
his
meal
,
though
not
with
quite
so
quick
an
appetite
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Adieu
,
my
birds
!
"
said
the
keeper
of
the
prison
,
taking
his
pretty
child
in
his
arms
,
and
dictating
the
words
with
a
kiss
.
   
<EOS>
"
Adieu
,
my
birds
!
"
<EOS>
the
pretty
child
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
Her
innocent
face
looked
back
so
brightly
over
his
shoulder
,
as
he
walked
away
with
her
,
singing
her
the
song
of
the
child
's
game
:
        
<EOS>
"
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
!
     
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
that
John
Baptist
felt
it
a
point
of
honour
to
reply
at
the
grate
,
and
in
good
time
and
tune
,
though
a
little
hoarsely
:
        
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
!
     
<EOS>
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
which
accompanied
them
so
far
down
the
few
steep
stairs
,
that
the
prison
-
keeper
had
to
stop
at
last
for
his
little
daughter
to
hear
the
song
out
,
and
repeat
the
Refrain
while
they
were
yet
in
sight
.
<EOS>
Then
the
child
's
head
disappeared
,
and
the
prison
-
keeper
's
head
disappeared
,
but
the
little
voice
prolonged
the
strain
until
the
door
clashed
.
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
finding
the
listening
John
Baptist
in
his
way
before
the
echoes
had
ceased
<EOS>
(
even
the
echoes
were
the
weaker
for
imprisonment
,
and
seemed
to
lag
)
,
reminded
him
with
a
push
of
his
foot
that
he
had
better
resume
his
own
darker
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
man
sat
down
again
upon
the
pavement
with
the
negligent
ease
of
one
who
was
thoroughly
accustomed
to
pavements
;
and
placing
three
hunks
of
coarse
bread
before
himself
,
and
falling
to
upon
a
fourth
,
began
contentedly
to
work
his
way
through
them
as
if
to
clear
them
off
were
a
sort
of
game
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
glanced
at
the
Lyons
sausage
,
and
perhaps
he
glanced
at
the
veal
in
savoury
jelly
,
but
they
were
not
there
long
,
to
make
his
mouth
water
;
Monsieur
Rigaud
soon
dispatched
them
,
in
spite
of
the
president
and
tribunal
,
and
proceeded
to
suck
his
fingers
as
clean
as
he
could
,
and
to
wipe
them
on
his
vine
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
as
he
paused
in
his
drink
to
contemplate
his
fellow
-
prisoner
,
his
moustache
went
up
,
and
his
nose
came
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
the
bread
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
dry
,
<EOS>
but
I
have
my
old
sauce
here
,
"
returned
John
Baptist
,
holding
up
his
knife
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
sauce
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
cut
my
bread
<EOS>
so
---
like
a
melon
.
 
<EOS>
Or
so
---
like
an
omelette
.
 
<EOS>
Or
so
---
like
a
fried
fish
.
 
<EOS>
Or
so
---
like
Lyons
sausage
,
"
said
John
Baptist
,
demonstrating
the
various
cuts
on
the
bread
he
held
,
and
soberly
chewing
what
he
had
in
his
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
cried
Monsieur
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
drink
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
finish
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
no
great
gift
,
for
there
was
mighty
little
wine
left
;
but
Signor
Cavalletto
,
jumping
to
his
feet
,
received
the
bottle
gratefully
,
turned
it
upside
down
at
his
mouth
,
and
smacked
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
the
bottle
by
with
the
rest
,
"
said
Rigaud
.
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
obeyed
his
orders
,
and
stood
ready
to
give
him
a
lighted
match
;
for
he
was
now
rolling
his
tobacco
into
cigarettes
by
the
aid
of
little
squares
of
paper
which
had
been
brought
in
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
thanks
,
my
master
!
"
<EOS>
John
Baptist
said
in
his
own
language
,
and
with
the
quick
conciliatory
manner
of
his
own
countrymen
.
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
arose
,
lighted
a
cigarette
,
put
the
rest
of
his
stock
into
a
breast
-
pocket
,
and
stretched
himself
out
at
full
length
upon
the
bench
.
 
<EOS>
Cavalletto
sat
down
on
the
pavement
,
holding
one
of
his
ankles
in
each
hand
,
and
smoking
peacefully
.
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
some
uncomfortable
attraction
of
Monsieur
Rigaud
's
eyes
to
the
immediate
neighbourhood
of
that
part
of
the
pavement
where
the
thumb
had
been
in
the
plan
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
so
drawn
in
that
direction
,
that
the
Italian
more
than
once
followed
them
to
and
back
from
the
pavement
in
some
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
infernal
hole
this
is
!
"
said
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
breaking
a
long
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
the
light
of
day
.
 
<EOS>
Day
?
 
<EOS>
the
light
of
yesterday
week
,
the
light
of
six
months
ago
,
the
light
of
six
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
So
slack
and
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
came
languishing
down
a
square
funnel
that
blinded
a
window
in
the
staircase
wall
,
through
which
the
sky
was
never
seen
---
nor
anything
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cavalletto
,
"
said
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
suddenly
withdrawing
his
gaze
from
this
funnel
to
which
they
had
both
involuntarily
turned
their
eyes
,
"
you
know
me
for
a
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
surely
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
have
we
been
here
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
,
eleven
weeks
,
to
-
morrow
night
at
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
nine
weeks
and
three
days
,
at
five
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
I
ever
done
anything
here
?
 
<EOS>
Ever
touched
the
broom
,
or
spread
the
mats
,
or
rolled
them
up
,
or
found
the
draughts
,
or
collected
the
dominoes
,
or
put
my
hand
to
any
kind
of
work
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
ever
thought
of
looking
to
me
to
do
any
kind
of
work
?
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
answered
with
that
peculiar
back
-
handed
shake
of
the
right
forefinger
which
is
the
most
expressive
negative
in
the
Italian
language
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
You
knew
from
the
first
moment
when
you
saw
me
here
,
that
I
was
a
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
ALTRO
!
<EOS>
"
returned
John
Baptist
,
closing
his
eyes
and
giving
his
head
a
most
vehement
toss
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
being
,
according
to
its
Genoese
emphasis
,
a
confirmation
,
a
contradiction
,
an
assertion
,
a
denial
,
a
taunt
,
a
compliment
,
a
joke
,
and
fifty
other
things
,
became
in
the
present
instance
,
with
a
significance
beyond
all
power
of
written
expression
,
our
familiar
English
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
right
!
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
And
a
gentleman
I
'll
live
,
and
a
gentleman
I
'll
die
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
my
intent
to
be
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
It
's
my
game
.
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
soul
<EOS>
,
I
play
it
out
wherever
I
go
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
changed
his
posture
to
a
sitting
one
,
crying
with
a
triumphant
air
:
   
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
See
me
!
 
<EOS>
Shaken
out
of
destiny
's
dice
-
box
into
the
company
of
a
mere
smuggler
;
---
shut
up
with
a
poor
little
contraband
trader
,
whose
papers
are
wrong
,
and
whom
the
police
lay
hold
of
besides
,
for
placing
his
boat
(
as
a
means
of
getting
beyond
the
frontier
)
at
the
disposition
of
other
little
people
whose
papers
are
wrong
;
and
he
instinctively
recognises
my
position
,
even
by
this
light
and
in
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
well
done
!
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
I
win
,
however
the
game
goes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
his
moustache
went
up
,
and
his
nose
came
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
hour
now
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
,
with
a
dry
hot
pallor
upon
him
,
rather
difficult
of
association
with
merriment
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
half
-
hour
after
mid
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
 
<EOS>
The
President
will
have
a
gentleman
before
him
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
   
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
on
what
accusation
?
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
now
,
or
never
,
for
I
shall
not
return
here
.
 
<EOS>
Either
I
shall
go
free
,
or
I
shall
go
to
be
made
ready
for
shaving
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
where
they
keep
the
razor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Signor
Cavalletto
took
his
cigarette
from
between
his
parted
lips
,
and
showed
more
momentary
discomfiture
than
might
have
been
expected
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
"
---
Monsieur
Rigaud
stood
up
to
say
it
---
"
I
am
a
cosmopolitan
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
I
own
no
particular
country
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
was
Swiss
---
Canton
de
Vaud
.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
was
French
by
blood
,
English
by
birth
.
<EOS>
I
myself
was
born
in
Belgium
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
citizen
of
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
theatrical
air
,
as
he
stood
with
one
arm
on
his
hip
within
the
folds
of
his
cloak
,
together
with
his
manner
of
disregarding
his
companion
and
addressing
the
opposite
wall
instead
,
seemed
to
intimate
that
he
was
rehearsing
for
the
President
,
whose
examination
he
was
shortly
to
undergo
,
rather
than
troubling
himself
merely
to
enlighten
so
small
a
person
as
John
Baptist
Cavalletto
.
   
<EOS>
"
Call
me
five
-
and
-
thirty
years
of
age
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lived
here
,
and
lived
there
,
and
lived
like
a
gentleman
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
treated
and
respected
as
a
gentleman
universally
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
try
to
prejudice
me
by
making
out
that
I
have
lived
by
my
wits
---
how
do
your
lawyers
live
---
your
politicians
---
your
intriguers
---
your
men
of
the
Exchange
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
kept
his
small
smooth
hand
in
constant
requisition
,
as
if
it
were
a
witness
to
his
gentility
that
had
often
done
him
good
service
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Two
years
ago
I
came
to
Marseilles
.
 
<EOS>
I
admit
that
I
was
poor
;
I
had
been
ill
.
 
<EOS>
When
your
lawyers
,
your
politicians
,
your
intriguers
,
your
men
of
the
Exchange
fall
ill
,
and
have
not
scraped
money
together
,
they
become
poor
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
up
at
the
Cross
of
Gold
,
---
kept
then
by
Monsieur
Henri
Barronneau
---
<EOS>
sixty
-
five
at
least
,
and
in
a
failing
state
of
health
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
lived
in
the
house
some
four
months
when
Monsieur
Henri
Barronneau
had
the
misfortune
to
die
;
---
at
any
rate
,
not
a
rare
misfortune
,
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
happens
without
any
aid
of
mine
,
pretty
often
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
having
smoked
his
cigarette
down
to
his
fingers
'
ends
,
Monsieur
Rigaud
had
the
magnanimity
to
throw
him
another
.
 
<EOS>
He
lighted
the
second
at
the
ashes
of
the
first
,
and
smoked
on
,
looking
sideways
at
his
companion
,
who
,
preoccupied
with
his
own
case
,
hardly
looked
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Monsieur
Barronneau
left
a
widow
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
two
-
and
-
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
gained
a
reputation
for
beauty
,
and
(
which
is
often
another
thing
)
was
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
I
continued
to
live
at
the
Cross
of
Gold
.
<EOS>
I
married
Madame
Barronneau
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
for
me
to
say
whether
there
was
any
great
disparity
in
such
a
match
.
 
<EOS>
Here
I
stand
,
with
the
contamination
of
a
jail
upon
me
;
but
it
is
possible
that
you
may
think
me
better
suited
to
her
than
her
former
husband
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
certain
air
of
being
a
handsome
man
---
which
he
was
not
;
and
a
certain
air
of
being
a
well
-
bred
man
---
which
he
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
mere
swagger
and
challenge
;
but
in
this
particular
,
as
in
many
others
,
blustering
assertion
goes
for
proof
,
half
over
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
it
as
it
may
,
Madame
Barronneau
approved
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
not
to
prejudice
me
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
eye
happening
to
light
upon
John
Baptist
with
this
inquiry
,
that
little
man
briskly
shook
his
head
in
the
negative
,
and
repeated
in
an
argumentative
tone
under
his
breath
,
altro
,
altro
,
altro
,
altro
---
an
infinite
number
of
times
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
came
the
difficulties
of
our
position
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
proud
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
nothing
in
defence
of
pride
,
but
I
am
proud
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
also
my
character
to
govern
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
submit
;
I
must
govern
.
<EOS>
Unfortunately
,
the
property
of
Madame
Rigaud
was
settled
upon
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
insane
act
of
her
late
husband
.
 
<EOS>
More
unfortunately
still
,
she
had
relations
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
wife
's
relations
interpose
against
a
husband
who
is
a
gentleman
,
who
is
proud
,
and
who
must
govern
,
the
consequences
are
inimical
to
peace
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
yet
another
source
of
difference
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
Madame
Rigaud
was
unfortunately
a
little
vulgar
.
 
<EOS>
I
sought
to
improve
her
manners
and
ameliorate
her
general
tone
;
she
(
supported
in
this
likewise
by
her
relations
)
resented
my
endeavours
.
 
<EOS>
Quarrels
began
to
arise
between
us
;
and
,
propagated
and
exaggerated
by
the
slanders
of
the
relations
of
Madame
Rigaud
,
to
become
notorious
to
the
neighbours
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
that
I
treated
Madame
Rigaud
with
cruelty
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
been
seen
to
slap
her
face
---
nothing
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
light
hand
;
and
if
I
have
been
seen
apparently
to
correct
Madame
Rigaud
in
that
manner
,
I
have
done
it
almost
playfully
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
the
playfulness
of
Monsieur
Rigaud
were
at
all
expressed
by
his
smile
at
this
point
,
the
relations
of
Madame
Rigaud
might
have
said
that
they
would
have
much
preferred
his
correcting
that
unfortunate
woman
seriously
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sensitive
and
brave
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
advance
it
as
a
merit
to
be
sensitive
and
brave
,
but
it
is
my
character
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
male
relations
of
Madame
Rigaud
had
put
themselves
forward
openly
,
I
should
have
known
how
to
deal
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
knew
that
,
and
their
machinations
were
conducted
in
secret
;
consequently
,
Madame
Rigaud
and
I
were
brought
into
frequent
and
unfortunate
collision
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
I
wanted
any
little
sum
of
money
for
my
personal
expenses
,
I
could
not
obtain
it
without
collision
---
and
I
,
too
,
a
man
whose
character
it
is
to
govern
!
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
Madame
Rigaud
and
myself
were
walking
amicably
---
I
may
say
like
lovers
---
on
a
height
overhanging
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
An
evil
star
occasioned
Madame
Rigaud
to
advert
to
her
relations
;
I
reasoned
with
her
on
that
subject
,
and
remonstrated
on
the
want
of
duty
and
devotion
manifested
in
her
allowing
herself
to
be
influenced
by
their
jealous
animosity
towards
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Madame
Rigaud
retorted
;
I
retorted
;
Madame
Rigaud
grew
warm
;
I
grew
warm
,
and
provoked
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
admit
it
.
<EOS>
Frankness
is
a
part
of
my
character
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
Madame
Rigaud
,
in
an
access
of
fury
that
I
must
ever
deplore
,
threw
herself
upon
me
with
screams
of
passion
(
no
doubt
those
that
were
overheard
at
some
distance
)
,
tore
my
clothes
,
tore
my
hair
,
lacerated
my
hands
,
trampled
and
trod
the
dust
,
and
finally
leaped
over
,
dashing
herself
to
death
upon
the
rocks
below
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the
train
of
incidents
which
malice
has
perverted
into
my
endeavouring
to
force
from
Madame
Rigaud
a
relinquishment
of
her
rights
;
and
,
on
her
persistence
in
a
refusal
to
make
the
concession
I
required
,
struggling
with
her
---
assassinating
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stepped
aside
to
the
ledge
where
the
vine
leaves
yet
lay
strewn
about
,
collected
two
or
three
,
and
stood
wiping
his
hands
upon
them
,
with
his
back
to
the
light
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
he
demanded
after
a
silence
,
"
have
you
nothing
to
say
to
all
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
ugly
,
"
returned
the
little
man
,
who
had
risen
,
and
was
brightening
his
knife
upon
his
shoe
,
as
he
leaned
an
arm
against
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
<EOS>
John
Baptist
polished
his
knife
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
I
have
not
represented
the
case
correctly
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Al
-
tro
!
"
returned
John
Baptist
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
was
an
apology
now
,
and
stood
for
"
Oh
,
by
no
means
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
then
?
"
   
"
Presidents
and
tribunals
are
so
prejudiced
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
cried
the
other
,
uneasily
flinging
the
end
of
his
cloak
over
his
shoulder
with
an
oath
,
"
let
them
do
their
worst
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Truly
I
think
they
will
,
"
murmured
John
Baptist
to
himself
,
as
he
bent
his
head
to
put
his
knife
in
his
sash
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
on
either
side
,
though
they
both
began
walking
to
and
fro
,
and
necessarily
crossed
at
every
turn
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
sometimes
stopped
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
put
his
case
in
a
new
light
,
or
make
some
irate
remonstrance
;
but
Signor
Cavalletto
continuing
to
go
slowly
to
and
fro
at
a
grotesque
kind
of
jog
-
trot
pace
with
his
eyes
turned
downward
,
nothing
came
of
these
inclinings
.
   
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
the
noise
of
the
key
in
the
lock
arrested
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
The
sound
of
voices
succeeded
,
and
the
tread
of
feet
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
clashed
,
the
voices
and
the
feet
came
on
,
and
the
prison
-
keeper
slowly
ascended
the
stairs
,
followed
by
a
guard
of
soldiers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
"
said
he
,
pausing
for
a
moment
at
the
grate
,
with
his
keys
in
his
hands
,
"
have
the
goodness
to
come
out
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
depart
in
state
,
I
see
?
"
<EOS>
"
Why
,
unless
you
did
,
"
returned
the
jailer
,
"
you
might
depart
in
so
many
pieces
that
it
would
be
difficult
to
get
you
together
again
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
crowd
,
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
and
it
does
n't
love
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
passed
on
out
of
sight
,
and
unlocked
and
unbarred
a
low
door
in
the
corner
of
the
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
he
,
as
he
opened
it
and
appeared
within
,
"
come
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
is
no
sort
of
whiteness
in
all
the
hues
under
the
sun
at
all
like
the
whiteness
of
Monsieur
Rigaud
's
face
as
it
was
then
.
<EOS>
Neither
is
there
any
expression
of
the
human
countenance
at
all
like
that
expression
in
every
little
line
of
which
the
frightened
heart
is
seen
to
beat
.
 
<EOS>
Both
are
conventionally
compared
with
death
;
but
the
difference
is
the
whole
deep
gulf
between
the
struggle
done
,
and
the
fight
at
its
most
desperate
extremity
.
   
<EOS>
He
lighted
another
of
his
paper
cigars
at
his
companion
's
;
put
it
tightly
between
his
teeth
;
covered
his
head
with
a
soft
slouched
hat
;
threw
the
end
of
his
cloak
over
his
shoulder
again
;
and
walked
out
into
the
side
gallery
on
which
the
door
opened
,
without
taking
any
further
notice
of
Signor
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
that
little
man
himself
,
his
whole
attention
had
become
absorbed
in
getting
near
the
door
and
looking
out
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Precisely
as
a
beast
might
approach
the
opened
gate
of
his
den
and
eye
the
freedom
beyond
,
he
passed
those
few
moments
in
watching
and
peering
,
until
the
door
was
closed
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
officer
in
command
of
the
soldiers
;
a
stout
,
serviceable
,
profoundly
calm
man
,
with
his
drawn
sword
in
his
hand
,
smoking
a
cigar
.
 
<EOS>
He
very
briefly
directed
the
placing
of
Monsieur
Rigaud
in
the
midst
of
the
party
,
put
himself
with
consummate
indifference
at
their
head
,
gave
the
word
"
march
!
"
<EOS>
and
so
they
all
went
jingling
down
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
clashed
---
the
key
turned
---
and
a
ray
of
unusual
light
,
and
a
breath
of
unusual
air
,
<EOS>
seemed
to
have
passed
through
the
jail
,
vanishing
in
a
tiny
wreath
of
smoke
from
the
cigar
.
   
<EOS>
Still
,
in
his
captivity
,
like
a
lower
animal
---
like
some
impatient
ape
,
or
roused
bear
of
the
smaller
species
---
the
prisoner
,
now
left
solitary
,
had
jumped
upon
the
ledge
,
to
lose
no
glimpse
of
this
departure
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
yet
stood
clasping
the
grate
with
both
hands
,
an
uproar
broke
upon
his
hearing
;
yells
,
shrieks
,
oaths
,
threats
,
execrations
,
all
comprehended
in
it
,
though
(
as
in
a
storm
)
<EOS>
nothing
but
a
raging
swell
of
sound
distinctly
heard
.
   
<EOS>
Excited
into
a
still
greater
resemblance
to
a
caged
wild
animal
by
his
anxiety
to
know
more
,
the
prisoner
leaped
nimbly
down
,
ran
round
the
chamber
,
leaped
nimbly
up
again
,
clasped
the
grate
and
tried
to
shake
it
,
leaped
down
and
ran
,
leaped
up
and
listened
,
and
never
rested
until
the
noise
,
becoming
more
and
more
distant
,
had
died
away
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
better
prisoners
have
worn
their
noble
hearts
out
so
;
no
man
thinking
of
it
;
not
even
the
beloved
of
their
souls
realising
it
;
great
kings
and
governors
,
who
had
made
them
captive
,
careering
in
the
sunlight
jauntily
,
and
men
cheering
them
on
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
said
great
personages
dying
in
bed
,
making
exemplary
ends
and
sounding
speeches
;
and
polite
history
,
more
servile
than
their
instruments
,
embalming
them
!
   
<EOS>
At
last
,
John
Baptist
,
now
able
to
choose
his
own
spot
within
the
compass
of
those
walls
for
the
exercise
of
his
faculty
of
going
to
sleep
when
he
would
,
lay
down
upon
the
bench
,
with
his
face
turned
over
on
his
crossed
arms
,
and
slumbered
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
submission
,
in
his
lightness
,
in
his
good
humour
,
in
his
short
-
lived
passion
,
in
his
easy
contentment
with
hard
bread
and
hard
stones
,
in
his
ready
sleep
,
in
his
fits
and
starts
,
altogether
a
true
son
of
the
land
that
gave
him
birth
.
   
<EOS>
The
wide
stare
stared
itself
out
for
one
while
;
the
Sun
went
down
in
a
red
,
green
,
golden
glory
;
the
stars
came
out
in
the
heavens
,
and
the
fire
-
flies
mimicked
them
in
the
lower
air
,
as
men
may
feebly
imitate
the
goodness
of
a
better
order
of
beings
;
the
long
dusty
roads
and
the
interminable
plains
were
in
repose
---
and
so
deep
a
hush
was
on
the
sea
,
that
it
scarcely
whispered
of
the
time
when
it
shall
give
up
its
dead
.
    
Chapter
2
.
<EOS>
Fellow
Travellers
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
yesterday
's
howling
over

to
-
day
,
Sir
;

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
but

.
 
<EOS>
Never

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

French

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
we

.
 
<EOS>
It

most

.
 
<EOS>
It

---

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

of

;
and

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Out
!
 
<EOS>
What

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
