,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
other
children
.
 
<EOS>
One
other
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
I
have
inadvertently
touched
upon
a
tender
theme
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
grave
about
it
,
I
am
not
at
all
sorrowful
.
 
<EOS>
It
quiets
me
for
a
moment
,
but
does
not
make
me
unhappy
.
 
<EOS>
Pet
had
a
twin
sister
who
died
when
we
could
just
see
her
eyes
---
exactly
like
Pet
's
---
above
the
table
,
as
she
stood
on
tiptoe
holding
by
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
indeed
,
indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
being
practical
people
,
a
result
has
gradually
sprung
up
in
the
minds
of
Mrs
Meagles
and
myself
which
perhaps
you
may
---
or
perhaps
you
may
not
---
understand
.
 
<EOS>
Pet
and
her
baby
sister
were
so
exactly
alike
,
and
so
completely
one
,
that
in
our
thoughts
we
have
never
been
able
to
separate
them
since
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
of
no
use
to
tell
us
that
our
dead
child
was
a
mere
infant
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
changed
that
child
according
to
the
changes
in
the
child
spared
to
us
and
always
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
As
Pet
has
grown
,
that
child
has
grown
;
as
Pet
has
become
more
sensible
and
womanly
,
her
sister
has
become
more
sensible
and
womanly
by
just
the
same
degrees
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
as
hard
to
convince
me
that
if
I
was
to
pass
into
the
other
world
to
-
morrow
,
I
should
not
,
through
the
mercy
of
God
,
be
received
there
by
a
daughter
,
just
like
Pet
,
as
to
persuade
me
that
Pet
herself
is
not
a
reality
at
my
side
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
understand
you
,
"
said
the
other
,
gently
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
her
,
"
pursued
her
father
,
"
the
sudden
loss
of
her
little
picture
and
playfellow
,
and
her
early
association
with
that
mystery
in
which
we
all
have
our
equal
share
,
but
which
is
not
often
so
forcibly
presented
to
a
child
,
has
necessarily
had
some
influence
on
her
character
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
her
mother
and
I
were
not
young
when
we
married
,
and
Pet
has
always
had
a
sort
of
grown
-
up
life
with
us
,
though
we
have
tried
to
adapt
ourselves
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
advised
more
than
once
when
she
has
been
a
little
ailing
,
to
change
climate
and
air
for
her
as
often
as
we
could
---
especially
at
about
this
time
of
her
life
---
and
to
keep
her
amused
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
as
I
have
no
need
to
stick
at
a
bank
-
desk
now
(
though
I
have
been
poor
enough
in
my
time
<EOS>
I
assure
you
,
or
I
should
have
married
Mrs
Meagles
long
before
)
,
we
go
trotting
about
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
how
you
found
us
staring
at
the
Nile
,
and
the
Pyramids
,
and
the
Sphinxes
,
and
the
Desert
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
;
and
this
is
how
Tattycoram
will
be
a
greater
traveller
in
course
of
time
than
Captain
Cook
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
"
said
the
other
,
"
very
heartily
for
your
confidence
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
mention
it
,
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
,
"
I
am
sure
you
are
quite
welcome
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
Mr
Clennam
,
perhaps
I
may
ask
you
whether
you
have
yet
come
to
a
decision
where
to
go
next
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
such
a
waif
and
stray
everywhere
,
that
I
am
liable
to
be
drifted
where
any
current
may
set
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
extraordinary
to
me
---
if
you
'll
excuse
my
freedom
in
saying
so
---
that
you
do
n't
go
straight
to
London
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
in
the
tone
of
a
confidential
adviser
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
shall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
mean
with
a
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
will
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
to
say
,
"
---
he
coloured
a
little
,
---
"
next
to
none
that
I
can
put
in
action
now
.
 
<EOS>
Trained
by
main
force
;
broken
,
not
bent
;
heavily
ironed
with
an
object
on
which
I
was
never
consulted
and
which
was
never
mine
;
shipped
away
to
the
other
end
of
the
world
before
I
was
of
age
,
and
exiled
there
until
my
father
's
death
there
,
a
year
ago
;
always
grinding
in
a
mill
I
always
hated
;
what
is
to
be
expected
from
me
in
middle
life
?
 
<EOS>
Will
,
purpose
,
hope
?
 
<EOS>
All
those
lights
were
extinguished
before
I
could
sound
the
words
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Light
'em
up
again
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Easily
said
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
son
,
Mr
Meagles
,
of
a
hard
father
and
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
only
child
of
parents
who
weighed
,
measured
,
and
priced
everything
;
for
whom
what
could
not
be
weighed
,
measured
,
and
priced
,
had
no
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Strict
people
as
the
phrase
is
,
professors
of
a
stern
religion
,
their
very
religion
was
a
gloomy
sacrifice
of
tastes
and
sympathies
that
were
never
their
own
,
offered
up
as
a
part
of
a
bargain
for
the
security
of
their
possessions
.
 
<EOS>
Austere
faces
,
inexorable
discipline
,
penance
in
this
world
and
terror
in
the
next
---
<EOS>
nothing
graceful
or
gentle
anywhere
,
and
the
void
in
my
cowed
heart
everywhere
<EOS>
---
this
was
my
childhood
,
if
I
may
so
misuse
the
word
as
to
apply
it
to
such
a
beginning
of
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
though
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
made
very
uncomfortable
by
the
picture
offered
to
his
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
was
a
tough
commencement
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
!
 
<EOS>
You
must
now
study
,
and
profit
by
,
all
that
lies
beyond
it
,
like
a
practical
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
the
people
who
are
usually
called
practical
,
were
practical
in
your
direction
---
"
   
"
Why
,
so
they
are
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
indeed
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
suppose
so
,
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
,
thinking
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
One
can
but
be
practical
,
and
Mrs
Meagles
and
myself
are
nothing
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
unknown
course
is
easier
and
more
helpful
than
I
had
expected
to
find
it
,
then
,
"
said
Clennam
,
shaking
his
head
with
his
grave
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
the
boat
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
boat
was
filled
with
the
cocked
hats
to
which
Mr
Meagles
entertained
a
national
objection
;
and
the
wearers
of
those
cocked
hats
landed
and
came
up
the
steps
,
and
all
the
impounded
travellers
congregated
together
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
then
a
mighty
production
of
papers
on
the
part
of
the
cocked
hats
,
and
a
calling
over
of
names
,
and
great
work
of
signing
,
sealing
,
stamping
,
inking
,
and
sanding
,
with
exceedingly
blurred
,
gritty
,
and
undecipherable
results
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
everything
was
done
according
to
rule
,
and
the
travellers
were
at
liberty
to
depart
whithersoever
they
would
.
   
<EOS>
They
made
little
account
of
stare
and
glare
,
in
the
new
pleasure
of
recovering
their
freedom
,
but
flitted
across
the
harbour
in
gay
boats
,
and
reassembled
at
a
great
hotel
,
whence
the
sun
was
excluded
by
closed
lattices
,
and
where
bare
paved
floors
,
lofty
ceilings
,
and
resounding
corridors
tempered
the
intense
heat
.
<EOS>
There
,
a
great
table
in
a
great
room
was
soon
profusely
covered
with
a
superb
repast
;
and
the
quarantine
quarters
became
bare
indeed
,
remembered
among
dainty
dishes
,
southern
fruits
,
cooled
wines
,
flowers
from
Genoa
,
snow
from
the
mountain
tops
,
and
all
the
colours
of
the
rainbow
flashing
in
the
mirrors
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
bear
those
monotonous
walls
no
ill
-
will
now
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
always
begins
to
forgive
a
place
as
soon
as
it
's
left
behind
;
I
dare
say
a
prisoner
begins
to
relent
towards
his
prison
,
after
he
is
let
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
about
thirty
in
company
,
and
all
talking
;
but
necessarily
in
groups
.
 
<EOS>
Father
and
Mother
Meagles
sat
with
their
daughter
between
them
,
the
last
three
on
one
side
of
the
table
:
on
the
opposite
side
sat
Mr
Clennam
;
a
tall
French
gentleman
with
raven
hair
and
beard
,
of
a
swart
and
terrible
,
not
to
say
genteelly
diabolical
aspect
,
but
who
had
shown
himself
the
mildest
of
men
;
and
a
handsome
young
Englishwoman
,
travelling
quite
alone
,
who
had
a
proud
observant
face
,
and
had
either
withdrawn
herself
from
the
rest
or
been
avoided
by
the
rest
---
nobody
,
herself
excepted
perhaps
,
could
have
quite
decided
which
.
 
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
party
were
of
the
usual
materials
:
travellers
on
business
,
and
travellers
for
pleasure
;
officers
from
India
on
leave
;
merchants
in
the
Greek
and
Turkey
trades
;
a
clerical
English
husband
in
a
meek
strait
-
waistcoat
,
on
a
wedding
trip
with
his
young
wife
;
a
majestic
English
mama
and
papa
,
of
the
patrician
order
,
with
a
family
of
three
growing
-
up
daughters
,
who
were
keeping
a
journal
for
the
confusion
of
their
fellow
-
creatures
;
and
a
deaf
old
English
mother
,
tough
in
travel
,
with
a
very
decidedly
grown
-
up
daughter
indeed
,
which
daughter
went
sketching
about
the
universe
in
the
expectation
of
ultimately
toning
herself
off
into
the
married
state
.
   
<EOS>
The
reserved
Englishwoman
took
up
Mr
Meagles
in
his
last
remark
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
that
a
prisoner
forgives
his
prison
?
"
said
she
,
slowly
and
with
emphasis
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
my
speculation
,
Miss
Wade
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
pretend
to
know
positively
how
a
prisoner
might
feel
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
one
before
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mademoiselle
doubts
,
"
said
the
French
gentleman
in
his
own
language
,
"
it
's
being
so
easy
to
forgive
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Pet
had
to
translate
this
passage
to
Mr
Meagles
,
who
never
by
any
accident
acquired
any
knowledge
whatever
of
the
language
of
any
country
into
which
he
travelled
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
a
pity
,
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
not
credulous
?
"
said
Miss
Wade
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
that
.
 
<EOS>
Put
it
another
way
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
ca
n't
believe
it
easy
to
forgive
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
experience
,
"
she
quietly
returned
,
"
has
been
correcting
my
belief
in
many
respects
,
for
some
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
our
natural
progress
,
I
have
heard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
not
natural
to
bear
malice
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
cheerily
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
been
shut
up
in
any
place
to
pine
and
suffer
,
I
should
always
hate
that
place
and
wish
to
burn
it
down
,
or
raze
it
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
no
more
.
"
<EOS>
"
Strong
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
to
the
Frenchman
;
it
being
another
of
his
habits
to
address
individuals
of
all
nations
in
idiomatic
English
,
with
a
perfect
conviction
that
they
were
bound
to
understand
it
somehow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rather
forcible
in
our
fair
friend
,
you
'll
agree
with
me
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
French
gentleman
courteously
replied
,
"
Plait
-
il
?
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Meagles
returned
with
much
satisfaction
,
"
You
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
My
opinion
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
breakfast
beginning
by
-
and
-
by
to
languish
,
Mr
Meagles
made
the
company
a
speech
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
short
enough
and
sensible
enough
,
considering
that
it
was
a
speech
at
all
,
and
hearty
.
 
<EOS>
It
merely
went
to
the
effect
that
as
they
had
all
been
thrown
together
by
chance
,
and
had
all
preserved
a
good
understanding
together
,
and
were
now
about
to
disperse
,
and
were
not
likely
ever
to
find
themselves
all
together
again
,
what
could
they
do
better
than
bid
farewell
to
one
another
,
and
give
one
another
good
-
speed
in
a
simultaneous
glass
of
cool
champagne
all
round
the
table
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
done
,
and
with
a
general
shaking
of
hands
the
assembly
broke
up
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
The
solitary
young
lady
all
this
time
had
said
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
She
rose
with
the
rest
,
and
silently
withdrew
to
a
remote
corner
of
the
great
room
,
where
she
sat
herself
on
a
couch
in
a
window
,
seeming
to
watch
the
reflection
of
the
water
as
it
made
a
silver
quivering
on
the
bars
of
the
lattice
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
,
turned
away
from
the
whole
length
of
the
apartment
,
as
if
she
were
lonely
of
her
own
haughty
choice
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
it
would
have
been
as
difficult
as
ever
to
say
,
positively
,
whether
she
avoided
the
rest
,
or
was
avoided
.
   
<EOS>
The
shadow
in
which
she
sat
,
falling
like
a
gloomy
veil
across
her
forehead
,
accorded
very
well
with
the
character
of
her
beauty
.
 
<EOS>
One
could
hardly
see
the
face
,
so
still
and
scornful
,
set
off
by
the
arched
dark
eyebrows
,
and
the
folds
of
dark
hair
,
without
wondering
what
its
expression
would
be
if
a
change
came
over
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
could
soften
or
relent
,
appeared
next
to
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
could
deepen
into
anger
or
any
extreme
of
defiance
,
and
that
it
must
change
in
that
direction
when
it
changed
at
all
,
would
have
been
its
peculiar
impression
upon
most
observers
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
dressed
and
trimmed
into
no
ceremony
of
expression
.
 
<EOS>
Although
not
an
open
face
,
there
was
no
pretence
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
self
-
contained
and
self
-
reliant
;
your
opinion
is
nothing
to
me
;
I
have
no
interest
in
you
,
care
nothing
for
you
,
and
see
and
hear
you
with
indifference
"
---
this
it
said
plainly
.
 
<EOS>
It
said
so
in
the
proud
eyes
,
in
the
lifted
nostril
,
in
the
handsome
but
compressed
and
even
cruel
mouth
.
<EOS>
Cover
either
two
of
those
channels
of
expression
,
and
the
third
would
have
said
so
still
.
 
<EOS>
Mask
them
all
,
and
the
mere
turn
of
the
head
would
have
shown
an
unsubduable
nature
.
   
<EOS>
Pet
had
moved
up
to
her
<EOS>
(
she
had
been
the
subject
of
remark
among
her
family
and
Mr
Clennam
,
who
were
now
the
only
other
occupants
of
the
room
)
,
and
was
standing
at
her
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
"
---
she
turned
her
eyes
,
and
Pet
faltered
---
<EOS>
"
expecting
any
one
to
meet
you
here
,
Miss
Wade
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
is
sending
to
the
Poste
Restante
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
he
have
the
pleasure
of
directing
the
messenger
to
ask
if
there
are
any
letters
for
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
him
,
but
I
know
there
can
be
none
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
afraid
,
"
said
Pet
,
sitting
down
beside
her
,
shyly
and
half
tenderly
,
"
that
you
will
feel
quite
deserted
when
we
are
all
gone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
,
"
said
Pet
,
apologetically
and
embarrassed
by
her
eyes
,
"
not
,
of
course
,
that
we
are
any
company
to
you
,
or
that
we
have
been
able
to
be
so
,
or
that
we
thought
you
wished
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
intended
to
make
it
understood
that
I
did
wish
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
.
 
<EOS>
But
---
in
short
,
"
said
<EOS>
Pet
,
timidly
touching
her
hand
as
it
lay
impassive
on
the
sofa
between
them
,
"
will
you
not
allow
Father
to
tender
you
any
slight
assistance
or
service
?
 
<EOS>
He
will
be
very
glad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
glad
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
coming
forward
with
his
wife
and
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
short
of
speaking
the
language
,
I
shall
be
delighted
to
undertake
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
obliged
to
you
,
"
she
returned
,
"
but
my
arrangements
are
made
,
and
I
prefer
to
go
my
own
way
in
my
own
manner
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
to
himself
,
as
he
surveyed
her
with
a
puzzled
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
character
in
that
,
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
much
used
to
the
society
of
young
ladies
,
and
I
am
afraid
I
may
not
show
my
appreciation
of
it
as
others
might
.
 
<EOS>
A
pleasant
journey
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
put
out
her
hand
,
it
seemed
,
but
that
Mr
Meagles
put
out
his
so
straight
before
her
that
she
could
not
pass
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
hers
in
it
,
and
it
lay
there
just
as
it
had
lain
upon
the
couch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
last
good
-
bye
upon
the
list
,
for
Mother
<EOS>
and
I
have
just
said
it
to
Mr
Clennam
here
,
and
<EOS>
he
only
waits
to
say
it
to
Pet
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
 
<EOS>
We
may
never
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
our
course
through
life
we
shall
meet
the
people
who
are
coming
to
meet
us
,
from
many
strange
places
and
by
many
strange
roads
,
"
was
the
composed
reply
;
"
and
what
it
is
set
to
us
to
do
to
them
,
and
what
it
is
set
to
them
to
do
to
us
,
will
all
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
something
in
the
manner
of
these
words
that
jarred
upon
Pet
's
ear
.
 
<EOS>
It
implied
that
what
was
to
be
done
was
necessarily
evil
,
and
it
caused
her
to
say
in
a
whisper
,
"
O
Father
!
"
<EOS>
and
to
shrink
childishly
,
in
her
spoilt
way
,
a
little
closer
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
not
lost
on
the
speaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
pretty
daughter
,
"
she
said
,
"
starts
to
think
of
such
things
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
"
looking
full
upon
her
,
"
you
may
be
sure
that
there
are
men
and
women
already
on
their
road
,
who
have
their
business
to
do
with
YOU
,
and
who
will
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Of
a
certainty
they
will
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
may
be
coming
hundreds
,
thousands
,
of
miles
over
the
sea
there
;
they
may
be
close
at
hand
now
;
they
may
be
coming
,
for
anything
you
know
or
anything
you
can
do
to
prevent
it
,
from
the
vilest
sweepings
of
this
very
town
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
the
coldest
of
farewells
,
and
with
a
certain
worn
expression
on
her
beauty
that
gave
it
,
though
scarcely
yet
in
its
prime
,
a
wasted
look
,
she
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
there
were
many
stairs
and
passages
that
she
had
to
traverse
in
passing
from
that
part
of
the
spacious
house
to
the
chamber
she
had
secured
for
her
own
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
almost
completed
the
journey
,
and
was
passing
along
the
gallery
in
which
her
room
was
,
she
heard
an
angry
sound
of
muttering
and
sobbing
.
 
<EOS>
A
door
stood
open
,
and
within
she
saw
the
attendant
upon
the
girl
she
had
just
left
;
the
maid
with
the
curious
name
.
   
<EOS>
She
stood
still
,
to
look
at
this
maid
.
 
<EOS>
A
sullen
,
passionate
girl
!
<EOS>
Her
rich
black
hair
was
all
about
her
face
,
her
face
was
flushed
and
hot
,
and
as
she
sobbed
and
raged
,
she
plucked
at
her
lips
with
an
unsparing
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Selfish
brutes
!
"
said
the
girl
,
sobbing
and
heaving
between
whiles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
caring
what
becomes
of
me
!
 
<EOS>
Leaving
me
here
hungry
and
thirsty
and
tired
,
to
starve
,
for
anything
they
care
!
 
<EOS>
Beasts
!
<EOS>
Devils
!
 
<EOS>
Wretches
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
poor
girl
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
up
suddenly
,
with
reddened
eyes
,
and
with
her
hands
suspended
,
in
the
act
of
pinching
her
neck
,
freshly
disfigured
with
great
scarlet
blots
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
to
you
what
's
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
signify
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
yes
<EOS>
it
does
;
I
am
sorry
to
see
you
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
sorry
,
"
said
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
glad
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
you
are
glad
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
like
this
but
twice
over
in
the
quarantine
yonder
;
and
both
times
you
found
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Afraid
of
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
seem
to
come
like
my
own
anger
,
my
own
malice
,
my
own
---
<EOS>
whatever
it
is
---
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
ill
-
used
<EOS>
,
I
am
ill
-
used
,
I
am
ill
-
used
!
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
sobs
and
the
tears
,
and
the
tearing
hand
,
which
had
all
been
suspended
together
since
the
first
surprise
,
went
on
together
anew
.
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
stood
looking
at
her
with
a
strange
attentive
smile
.
<EOS>
It
was
wonderful
to
see
the
fury
of
the
contest
in
the
girl
,
and
the
bodily
struggle
she
made
as
if
she
were
rent
by
the
Demons
of
old
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
younger
than
she
is
by
two
or
three
years
,
and
yet
it
's
me
that
looks
after
her
,
as
if
I
was
old
,
and
<EOS>
it
's
she
that
's
always
petted
and
called
Baby
!
 
<EOS>
I
detest
the
name
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
her
!
 
<EOS>
They
make
a
fool
of
her
,
they
spoil
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
thinks
of
nothing
but
herself
<EOS>
,
she
thinks
no
more
of
me
than
if
I
was
a
stock
and
a
stone
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
the
girl
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
patience
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
WON'T
have
patience
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
they
take
much
care
of
themselves
,
and
little
or
none
of
you
,
you
must
not
mind
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
WILL
mind
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Be
more
prudent
.
 
<EOS>
You
forget
your
dependent
position
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
do
some
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
bear
it
<EOS>
;
I
ca
n't
bear
it
;
I
shall
die
if
I
try
to
bear
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
observer
stood
with
her
hand
upon
her
own
bosom
,
looking
at
the
girl
,
as
one
afflicted
with
a
diseased
part
might
curiously
watch
the
dissection
and
exposition
of
an
analogous
case
.
   
<EOS>
The
girl
raged
and
battled
with
all
the
force
of
her
youth
and
fulness
of
life
,
until
by
little
and
little
her
passionate
exclamations
trailed
off
into
broken
murmurs
as
if
she
were
in
pain
.
 
<EOS>
By
corresponding
degrees
she
sank
into
a
chair
,
then
upon
her
knees
,
then
upon
the
ground
beside
the
bed
,
drawing
the
coverlet
with
her
,
half
to
hide
her
shamed
head
and
wet
hair
in
it
,
and
half
,
as
it
seemed
,
to
embrace
it
,
rather
than
have
nothing
to
take
to
her
repentant
breast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
away
from
me
,
go
away
from
me
!
 
<EOS>
When
my
temper
comes
upon
me
,
I
am
mad
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
might
keep
it
off
if
I
only
tried
hard
enough
,
and
sometimes
I
do
try
hard
enough
,
and
at
other
times
I
do
n't
and
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
I
said
!
 
<EOS>
I
knew
when
I
said
it
,
it
was
all
lies
.
<EOS>
They
think
I
am
being
taken
care
of
somewhere
,
and
have
all
I
want
.
   
<EOS>
They
are
nothing
but
good
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
them
dearly
;
no
people
could
ever
be
kinder
to
a
thankless
creature
than
they
always
are
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
,
do
go
away
,
for
I
am
afraid
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
of
myself
when
I
feel
my
temper
coming
,
and
I
am
as
much
afraid
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
from
me
,
and
let
me
pray
and
cry
myself
better
!
"
<EOS>
The
day
passed
on
;
and
again
the
wide
stare
stared
itself
out
;
and
the
hot
night
was
on
Marseilles
;
and
through
it
the
caravan
of
the
morning
,
all
dispersed
,
went
their
appointed
ways
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
ever
by
day
and
night
,
under
the
sun
and
under
the
stars
,
climbing
the
dusty
hills
and
toiling
along
the
weary
plains
,
journeying
by
land
and
journeying
by
sea
,
coming
and
going
so
strangely
,
to
meet
and
to
act
and
react
on
one
another
,
move
all
we
restless
travellers
through
the
pilgrimage
of
life
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
03
.
<EOS>
Home
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
Sunday
evening
in
London
,
gloomy
,
close
,
and
stale
.
<EOS>
Maddening
church
bells
of
all
degrees
of
dissonance
,
sharp
and
flat
,
cracked
and
clear
,
fast
and
slow
,
made
the
brick
-
and
-
mortar
echoes
hideous
.
 
<EOS>
Melancholy
streets
,
in
a
penitential
garb
of
soot
,
steeped
the
souls
of
the
people
who
were
condemned
to
look
at
them
out
of
windows
,
in
dire
despondency
.
 
<EOS>
In
every
thoroughfare
,
up
almost
every
alley
,
and
down
almost
every
turning
,
some
doleful
bell
was
throbbing
,
jerking
,
tolling
,
as
if
the
Plague
were
in
the
city
and
the
dead
-
carts
were
going
round
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
was
bolted
and
barred
that
could
by
possibility
furnish
relief
to
an
overworked
people
.
 
<EOS>
No
pictures
,
no
unfamiliar
animals
,
no
rare
plants
or
flowers
,
no
natural
or
artificial
wonders
of
the
ancient
world
---
all
TABOO
with
that
enlightened
strictness
,
that
the
ugly
South
Sea
gods
in
the
British
Museum
might
have
supposed
themselves
at
home
again
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
to
see
but
streets
,
streets
,
streets
.
<EOS>
Nothing
to
breathe
but
streets
,
streets
,
streets
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
to
change
the
brooding
mind
,
or
raise
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
for
the
spent
toiler
to
do
,
but
to
compare
the
monotony
of
his
seventh
day
with
the
monotony
of
his
six
days
,
think
what
a
weary
life
he
led
,
and
make
the
best
of
it
---
or
the
worst
,
according
to
the
probabilities
.
   
<EOS>
At
such
a
happy
time
,
so
propitious
to
the
interests
of
religion
and
morality
,
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
,
newly
arrived
from
Marseilles
by
way
of
Dover
,
and
by
Dover
coach
the
Blue
-
eyed
Maid
,
sat
in
the
window
of
a
coffee
-
house
on
Ludgate
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
Ten
thousand
responsible
houses
surrounded
him
,
frowning
as
heavily
on
the
streets
they
composed
,
as
if
they
were
every
one
inhabited
by
the
ten
young
men
of
the
Calender
's
story
,
who
blackened
their
faces
and
bemoaned
their
miseries
every
night
.
 
<EOS>
Fifty
thousand
lairs
surrounded
him
where
people
lived
so
unwholesomely
that
fair
water
put
into
their
crowded
rooms
on
Saturday
night
,
would
be
corrupt
on
Sunday
morning
;
albeit
my
lord
,
their
county
member
,
was
amazed
that
they
failed
to
sleep
in
company
with
their
butcher
's
meat
.
 
<EOS>
Miles
of
close
wells
and
pits
of
houses
,
where
the
inhabitants
gasped
for
air
,
stretched
far
away
towards
every
point
of
the
compass
.
<EOS>
Through
the
heart
of
the
town
a
deadly
sewer
ebbed
and
flowed
,
in
the
place
of
a
fine
fresh
river
.
 
<EOS>
What
secular
want
could
the
million
or
so
of
human
beings
whose
daily
labour
,
six
days
in
the
week
,
lay
among
these
Arcadian
objects
,
from
the
sweet
sameness
of
which
they
had
no
escape
between
the
cradle
and
the
grave
---
what
secular
want
could
they
possibly
have
upon
their
seventh
day
?
<EOS>
Clearly
they
could
want
nothing
but
a
stringent
policeman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
sat
in
the
window
of
the
coffee
-
house
on
Ludgate
Hill
,
counting
one
of
the
neighbouring
bells
,
making
sentences
and
burdens
of
songs
out
of
it
in
spite
of
himself
,
and
wondering
how
many
sick
people
it
might
be
the
death
of
in
the
course
of
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
hour
approached
,
its
changes
of
measure
made
it
more
and
more
exasperating
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
quarter
,
it
went
off
into
a
condition
of
deadly
-
lively
importunity
,
urging
the
populace
in
a
voluble
manner
to
Come
to
church
,
Come
to
church
,
Come
to
church
!
<EOS>
At
the
ten
minutes
,
it
became
aware
that
the
congregation
would
be
scanty
,
and
slowly
hammered
out
in
low
spirits
,
<EOS>
They
WON'T
come
,
they
WON'T
come
,
they
WON'T
come
!
 
<EOS>
At
the
five
minutes
,
it
abandoned
hope
,
and
shook
every
house
in
the
neighbourhood
for
three
hundred
seconds
,
with
one
dismal
swing
per
second
,
as
a
groan
of
despair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
said
Clennam
,
when
the
hour
struck
,
and
the
bell
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
But
its
sound
had
revived
a
long
train
of
miserable
Sundays
,
and
the
procession
would
not
stop
with
the
bell
,
but
continued
to
march
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forgive
me
,
"
said
he
,
"
and
those
who
trained
me
.
 
<EOS>
How
I
have
hated
this
day
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
the
dreary
Sunday
of
his
childhood
,
when
he
sat
with
his
hands
before
him
,
scared
out
of
his
senses
by
a
horrible
tract
which
commenced
business
with
the
poor
child
by
asking
him
in
its
title
,
why
he
was
going
to
Perdition
?
---
<EOS>
a
piece
of
curiosity
that
he
really
,
in
a
frock
and
drawers
,
was
not
in
a
condition
to
satisfy
---
and
which
,
for
the
further
attraction
of
his
infant
mind
,
had
a
parenthesis
in
every
other
line
with
some
such
hiccupping
reference
as
2
Ep
Thess
c
iii
,
v
6
&
7
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
sleepy
Sunday
of
his
boyhood
,
when
,
like
a
military
deserter
,
he
was
marched
to
chapel
by
a
picquet
of
teachers
three
times
a
day
,
morally
handcuffed
to
another
boy
;
and
when
he
would
willingly
have
bartered
two
meals
of
indigestible
sermon
for
another
ounce
or
two
of
inferior
mutton
at
his
scanty
dinner
in
the
flesh
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
interminable
Sunday
of
his
nonage
;
when
his
mother
,
stern
of
face
and
unrelenting
of
heart
,
would
sit
all
day
behind
a
Bible
---
bound
,
like
her
own
construction
of
it
,
in
the
hardest
,
barest
,
and
straitest
boards
,
with
one
dinted
ornament
on
the
cover
like
the
drag
of
a
chain
,
and
a
wrathful
sprinkling
of
red
upon
the
edges
of
the
leaves
---
as
if
it
,
of
all
books
!
 
<EOS>
were
a
fortification
against
sweetness
of
temper
,
natural
affection
,
and
gentle
intercourse
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
resentful
Sunday
of
a
little
later
,
when
he
sat
down
glowering
and
glooming
through
the
tardy
length
of
the
day
,
with
a
sullen
sense
of
injury
in
his
heart
,
and
no
more
real
knowledge
of
the
beneficent
history
of
the
New
Testament
than
if
he
had
been
bred
among
idolaters
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
legion
of
Sundays
,
all
days
of
unserviceable
bitterness
and
mortification
,
slowly
passing
before
him
.
"
<EOS>
Beg
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
a
brisk
waiter
,
rubbing
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wish
see
bed
-
room
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
just
made
up
my
mind
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chaymaid
!
"
cried
the
waiter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gelen
box
num
seven
wish
see
room
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
Clennam
,
rousing
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
thinking
of
what
I
said
;
I
answered
mechanically
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
to
sleep
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Deed
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Chaymaid
!
 
<EOS>
Gelen
box
num
seven
,
not
go
sleep
here
,
gome
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
sat
in
the
same
place
as
the
day
died
,
looking
at
the
dull
houses
opposite
,
and
thinking
,
if
the
disembodied
spirits
of
former
inhabitants
were
ever
conscious
of
them
,
how
they
must
pity
themselves
for
their
old
places
of
imprisonment
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
a
face
would
appear
behind
the
dingy
glass
of
a
window
,
and
would
fade
away
into
the
gloom
as
if
it
had
seen
enough
of
life
and
had
vanished
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
the
rain
began
to
fall
in
slanting
lines
between
him
and
those
houses
,
and
people
began
to
collect
under
cover
of
the
public
passage
opposite
,
and
to
look
out
hopelessly
at
the
sky
as
the
rain
dropped
thicker
and
faster
.
 
<EOS>
Then
wet
umbrellas
began
to
appear
,
draggled
skirts
,
and
mud
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
mud
had
been
doing
with
itself
,
or
where
it
came
from
,
who
could
say
?
 
<EOS>
But
it
seemed
to
collect
in
a
moment
,
as
a
crowd
will
,
and
in
five
minutes
to
have
splashed
all
the
sons
and
daughters
of
Adam
.
<EOS>
The
lamplighter
was
going
his
rounds
now
;
and
as
the
fiery
jets
sprang
up
under
his
touch
,
one
might
have
fancied
them
astonished
at
being
suffered
to
introduce
any
show
of
brightness
into
such
a
dismal
scene
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
took
up
his
hat
and
buttoned
his
coat
,
and
walked
out
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
country
,
the
rain
would
have
developed
a
thousand
fresh
scents
,
and
every
drop
would
have
had
its
bright
association
with
some
beautiful
form
of
growth
or
life
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
city
,
it
developed
only
foul
stale
smells
,
and
was
a
sickly
,
lukewarm
,
dirt
-
stained
,
wretched
addition
to
the
gutters
.
   
<EOS>
He
crossed
by
St
Paul
's
and
went
down
,
at
a
long
angle
,
almost
to
the
water
's
edge
,
through
some
of
the
crooked
and
descending
streets
which
lie
(
and
lay
more
crookedly
and
closely
then
)
between
the
river
and
Cheapside
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
,
now
the
mouldy
hall
of
some
obsolete
Worshipful
Company
,
now
the
illuminated
windows
of
a
Congregationless
Church
that
seemed
to
be
waiting
for
some
adventurous
Belzoni
to
dig
it
out
and
discover
its
history
;
passing
silent
warehouses
and
wharves
,
and
here
and
there
a
narrow
alley
leading
to
the
river
,
where
a
wretched
little
bill
,
FOUND
DROWNED
,
was
weeping
on
the
wet
wall
;
he
came
at
last
to
the
house
he
sought
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
brick
house
,
so
dingy
as
to
be
all
but
black
,
standing
by
itself
within
a
gateway
.
 
<EOS>
Before
it
,
a
square
court
-
yard
where
a
shrub
or
two
and
a
patch
of
grass
were
as
rank
(
which
is
saying
much
)
as
the
iron
railings
enclosing
them
were
rusty
;
behind
it
,
a
jumble
of
roots
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
double
house
,
with
long
,
narrow
,
heavily
-
framed
windows
.
 
<EOS>
Many
years
ago
,
it
had
had
it
in
its
mind
to
slide
down
sideways
;
it
had
been
propped
up
,
however
,
and
was
leaning
on
some
half
-
dozen
gigantic
crutches
:
which
gymnasium
for
the
neighbouring
cats
,
weather
-
stained
,
smoke
-
blackened
,
and
overgrown
with
weeds
,
appeared
in
these
latter
days
to
be
no
very
sure
reliance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
changed
,
"
said
the
traveller
,
stopping
to
look
round
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dark
and
miserable
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
A
light
in
my
mother
's
window
,
which
seems
never
to
have
been
extinguished
since
I
came
home
twice
a
year
from
school
,
and
dragged
my
box
over
this
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
went
up
to
the
door
,
which
had
a
projecting
canopy
in
carved
work
of
festooned
jack
-
towels
and
children
's
heads
with
water
on
the
brain
,
designed
after
a
once
-
popular
monumental
pattern
,
and
knocked
.
 
<EOS>
A
shuffling
step
was
soon
heard
on
the
stone
floor
of
the
hall
,
and
the
door
was
opened
by
an
old
man
,
bent
and
dried
,
but
with
keen
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
candle
in
his
hand
,
and
he
held
it
up
for
a
moment
to
assist
his
keen
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mr
Arthur
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
without
any
emotion
,
"
you
are
come
at
last
?
 
<EOS>
Step
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Arthur
stepped
in
and
shut
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
figure
is
filled
out
,
and
set
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
turning
to
look
at
him
with
the
light
raised
again
,
and
shaking
his
head
;
"
but
you
do
n't
come
up
to
your
father
in
my
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
yet
your
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
my
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
as
she
always
is
now
.
 
<EOS>
Keeps
her
room
when
not
actually
bedridden
,
and
has
n't
been
out
of
it
fifteen
times
in
as
many
years
,
Arthur
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
They
had
walked
into
a
spare
,
meagre
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
had
put
the
candlestick
upon
the
table
,
and
,
supporting
his
right
elbow
with
his
left
hand
,
was
smoothing
his
leathern
jaws
while
he
looked
at
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
offered
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
took
it
coldly
enough
,
and
seemed
to
prefer
his
jaws
,
to
which
he
returned
as
soon
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
if
your
mother
will
approve
of
your
coming
home
on
the
Sabbath
,
Arthur
,
"
he
said
,
shaking
his
head
warily
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
have
me
go
away
again
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
the
master
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
what
\I\
would
have
.
<EOS>
I
have
stood
between
your
father
and
mother
for
a
number
of
years
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
pretend
to
stand
between
your
mother
and
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
tell
her
that
I
have
come
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Arthur
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
her
that
you
have
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
wait
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
find
the
room
changed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
took
another
candle
from
a
cupboard
,
lighted
it
,
left
the
first
on
the
table
,
and
went
upon
his
errand
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
short
,
bald
old
man
,
in
a
high
-
shouldered
black
coat
and
waistcoat
,
drab
breeches
,
and
long
drab
gaiters
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
,
from
his
dress
,
have
been
either
clerk
or
servant
,
and
in
fact
had
long
been
both
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
about
him
in
the
way
of
decoration
but
a
watch
,
which
was
lowered
into
the
depths
of
its
proper
pocket
by
an
old
black
ribbon
,
and
had
a
tarnished
copper
key
moored
above
it
,
to
show
where
it
was
sunk
.
 
<EOS>
His
head
was
awry
,
and
he
had
a
one
-
sided
,
crab
-
like
way
with
him
,
as
if
his
foundations
had
yielded
at
about
the
same
time
as
those
of
the
house
,
and
he
ought
to
have
been
propped
up
in
a
similar
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
weak
am
I
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
,
when
he
was
gone
,
"
that
I
could
shed
tears
at
this
reception
!
 
<EOS>
I
,
who
have
never
experienced
anything
else
;
who
have
never
expected
anything
else
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
not
only
could
,
but
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
momentary
yielding
of
a
nature
that
had
been
disappointed
from
the
dawn
of
its
perceptions
,
but
had
not
quite
given
up
all
its
hopeful
yearnings
yet
.
 
<EOS>
He
subdued
it
,
took
up
the
candle
,
and
examined
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
articles
of
furniture
were
in
their
old
places
;
the
Plagues
of
Egypt
,
much
the
dimmer
for
the
fly
and
smoke
plagues
of
London
,
were
framed
and
glazed
upon
the
walls
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
old
cellaret
with
nothing
in
it
,
lined
with
lead
,
like
a
sort
of
coffin
in
compartments
;
there
was
the
old
dark
closet
,
also
with
nothing
in
it
,
of
which
he
had
been
many
a
time
the
sole
contents
,
in
days
of
punishment
,
when
he
had
regarded
it
as
the
veritable
entrance
to
that
bourne
to
which
the
tract
had
found
him
galloping
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
large
,
hard
-
featured
clock
on
the
sideboard
,
which
he
used
to
see
bending
its
figured
brows
upon
him
with
a
savage
joy
when
he
was
behind
-
hand
with
his
lessons
,
and
which
,
when
it
was
wound
up
once
a
week
with
an
iron
handle
,
used
to
sound
as
if
it
were
growling
in
ferocious
anticipation
of
the
miseries
into
which
it
would
bring
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
was
the
old
man
come
back
,
saying
,
"
Arthur
,
I
'll
go
before
and
light
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
followed
him
up
the
staircase
,
which
was
panelled
off
into
spaces
like
so
many
mourning
tablets
,
into
a
dim
bed
-
chamber
,
the
floor
of
which
had
gradually
so
sunk
and
settled
,
that
the
fire
-
place
was
in
a
dell
.
 
<EOS>
On
a
black
bier
-
like
sofa
in
this
hollow
,
propped
up
behind
with
one
great
angular
black
bolster
like
the
block
at
a
state
execution
in
the
good
old
times
,
sat
his
mother
in
a
widow
's
dress
.
   
<EOS>
She
and
his
father
had
been
at
variance
from
his
earliest
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
To
sit
speechless
himself
in
the
midst
of
rigid
silence
,
glancing
in
dread
from
the
one
averted
face
to
the
other
,
had
been
the
peacefullest
occupation
of
his
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
him
one
glassy
kiss
,
and
four
stiff
fingers
muffled
in
worsted
.
<EOS>
This
embrace
concluded
,
he
sat
down
on
the
opposite
side
of
her
little
table
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fire
in
the
grate
,
as
there
had
been
night
and
day
for
fifteen
years
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
kettle
on
the
hob
,
as
there
had
been
night
and
day
for
fifteen
years
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
mound
of
damped
ashes
on
the
top
of
the
fire
,
and
another
little
mound
swept
together
under
the
grate
,
as
there
had
been
night
and
day
for
fifteen
years
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
smell
of
black
dye
in
the
airless
room
,
which
the
fire
had
been
drawing
out
of
the
crape
and
stuff
of
the
widow
's
dress
for
fifteen
months
,
and
out
of
the
bier
-
like
sofa
for
fifteen
years
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
this
is
a
change
from
your
old
active
habits
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
world
has
narrowed
to
these
dimensions
,
Arthur
,
"
she
rep
lied
,
glancing
round
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
for
me
that
I
never
set
my
heart
upon
its
hollow
vanities
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
influence
of
her
presence
and
her
stern
strong
voice
,
so
gathered
about
her
son
,
that
he
felt
conscious
of
a
renewal
of
the
timid
chill
and
reserve
of
his
childhood
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
never
leave
your
room
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
with
my
rheumatic
affection
,
and
what
with
its
attendant
debility
or
nervous
weakness
---
names
are
of
no
matter
now
---
I
have
lost
the
use
of
my
limbs
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
leave
my
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
outside
this
door
for
---
tell
him
for
how
long
,
"
she
said
,
speaking
over
her
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
dozen
year
next
Christmas
,
"
returned
a
cracked
voice
out
of
the
dimness
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
Affery
?
"
said
Arthur
,
looking
towards
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
cracked
voice
replied
that
it
was
Affery
:
and
an
old
woman
came
forward
into
what
doubtful
light
there
was
,
and
kissed
her
hand
once
;
then
subsided
again
into
the
dimness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
able
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
with
a
slight
motion
of
her
worsted
-
muffled
right
hand
toward
a
chair
on
wheels
,
standing
before
<EOS>
a
tall
writing
cabinet
close
shut
up
,
"
I
am
able
to
attend
to
my
business
duties
,
and
I
am
thankful
for
the
privilege
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
great
privilege
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
more
of
business
on
this
day
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
bad
night
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
mother
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
it
snow
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Snow
,
mother
?
 
<EOS>
And
we
only
yet
in
September
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
seasons
are
alike
to
me
,
"
she
returned
,
with
a
grim
kind
of
luxuriousness
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
of
summer
and
winter
,
shut
up
here
.
   
<EOS>
The
Lord
has
been
pleased
to
put
me
beyond
all
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
her
cold
grey
eyes
and
her
cold
grey
hair
,
and
her
immovable
face
,
as
stiff
as
the
folds
of
her
stony
head
-
dress
,
---
her
being
beyond
the
reach
of
the
seasons
<EOS>
seemed
but
a
fit
sequence
to
her
being
beyond
the
reach
of
all
changing
emotions
.
   
<EOS>
On
her
little
table
lay
two
or
three
books
,
her
handkerchief
,
a
pair
of
steel
spectacles
newly
taken
off
,
and
an
old
-
fashioned
gold
watch
in
a
heavy
double
case
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
last
object
her
son
's
eyes
and
her
own
now
rested
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
that
you
received
the
packet
I
sent
you
on
my
father
's
death
,
safely
,
mother
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
knew
my
father
to
show
so
much
anxiety
on
any
subject
,
as
that
his
watch
should
be
sent
straight
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
keep
it
here
as
a
remembrance
of
your
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
until
the
last
,
that
he
expressed
the
wish
;
when
he
could
only
put
his
hand
upon
it
,
and
very
indistinctly
say
to
me
"
your
mother
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
moment
before
,
I
thought
him
wandering
in
his
mind
,
as
he
had
been
for
many
hours
<EOS>
---
I
think
he
had
no
consciousness
of
pain
in
his
short
illness
---
when
I
saw
him
turn
himself
in
his
bed
and
try
to
open
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
your
father
,
then
,
not
wandering
in
his
mind
when
he
tried
to
open
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
sensible
at
that
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
shook
her
head
;
whether
in
dismissal
of
the
deceased
or
opposing
herself
to
her
son
's
opinion
,
was
not
clearly
expressed
.
   
<EOS>
"
After
my
father
's
death
I
opened
it
myself
,
thinking
there
might
be
,
for
anything
I
knew
,
some
memorandum
there
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
as
I
need
not
tell
you
,
mother
,
there
was
nothing
but
the
old
silk
watch
-
paper
worked
in
beads
,
which
you
found
(
no
doubt
)
in
its
place
between
the
cases
,
where
I
found
and
left
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
signified
assent
;
then
added
,
"
No
more
of
business
on
this
day
,
"
and
then
added
,
"
Affery
,
it
is
nine
o'clock
.
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
old
woman
cleared
the
little
table
,
went
out
of
the
room
,
and
quickly
returned
with
a
tray
on
which
was
a
dish
of
little
rusks
and
a
small
precise
pat
of
butter
,
cool
,
symmetrical
,
white
,
and
plump
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
who
had
been
standing
by
the
door
in
one
attitude
during
the
whole
interview
,
looking
at
the
mother
up
-
stairs
as
he
had
looked
at
the
son
down
-
stairs
,
went
out
at
the
same
time
,
and
,
after
a
longer
absence
,
returned
with
another
tray
on
which
was
the
greater
part
of
a
bottle
of
port
wine
(
which
,
to
judge
by
his
panting
,
he
had
brought
from
the
cellar
)
,
a
lemon
,
a
sugar
-
basin
,
and
a
spice
box
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
materials
and
the
aid
of
the
kettle
,
he
filled
a
tumbler
with
a
hot
and
odorous
mixture
,
measured
out
and
compounded
with
as
much
nicety
as
a
physician
's
prescription
.
 
<EOS>
Into
this
mixture
Mrs
Clennam
dipped
certain
of
the
rusks
,
and
ate
them
;
while
the
old
woman
buttered
certain
other
of
the
rusks
,
which
were
to
be
eaten
alone
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
invalid
had
eaten
all
the
rusks
and
drunk
all
the
mixture
,
the
two
trays
were
removed
;
and
the
books
and
the
candle
,
watch
,
handkerchief
,
and
spectacles
were
replaced
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
put
on
the
spectacles
and
read
certain
passages
aloud
from
a
book
---
sternly
,
fiercely
,
wrathfully
---
praying
that
her
enemies
(
she
made
them
by
her
tone
and
manner
expressly
hers
)
might
be
put
to
the
edge
of
the
sword
,
consumed
by
fire
,
smitten
by
plagues
and
leprosy
,
that
their
bones
might
be
ground
to
dust
,
and
that
they
might
be
utterly
exterminated
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
read
on
,
years
seemed
to
fall
away
from
her
son
like
the
imaginings
of
a
dream
,
and
all
the
old
dark
horrors
of
his
usual
preparation
for
the
sleep
of
an
innocent
child
to
overshadow
him
.
   
<EOS>
She
shut
the
book
and
remained
for
a
little
time
with
her
face
shaded
by
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
the
old
man
,
otherwise
still
unchanged
   
in
attitude
;
so
,
probably
,
did
the
old
woman
in
her
dimmer
part
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
sick
woman
was
ready
for
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
will
see
to
your
accommodation
.
 
<EOS>
Only
touch
me
,
for
my
hand
is
tender
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
touched
the
worsted
muffling
of
her
hand
---
<EOS>
that
was
nothing
;
if
his
mother
had
been
sheathed
in
brass
there
would
have
been
no
new
barrier
between

---
and
followed
the
old
man
and
woman
down

stairs
.
   
<EOS>
The
latter
asked
him
,
when
they
were
alone
together
among
the
heavy
shadows
of
the
dining
-
room
,
would
he
have
some

?
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Affery
,
no
supper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
if
you
like
,
"
said
Affery
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
her
tomorrow
's
partridge
in
the
larder
---
her
first
this
year
;
say
the
word
and
<EOS>
I
'll
cook
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
No
,
he
had
not
long
dined
,
and
could
eat
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
something
to
drink
,
then
,
"
said
Affery
;
"
you
shall
have
some
of
her
bottle
of
port
,
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
Jeremiah
that
you
ordered
me
to
bring
it
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
No
;
nor
would
he
have
that
,
either
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
reason
,
Arthur
,
"
said

old
woman
,
bending

,
"
that
because
I
am
afeared
of
my
life
of
'em
,
you
should

.
 
<EOS>
You
've

half
the
property
,

you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
do
n't
you
be
cowed
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
clever
,
Arthur
,
an't
you
?
"
<EOS>
He
nodded
,
as
she
seemed

expect

in

.
"
<EOS>
Then
stand
up
against
them
!
 
<EOS>
She
's
awful
clever
,
and
none
but
a
clever
one
durst
say
a
word
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
HE
'S
a
clever
one
---
<EOS>
oh
,
he
's
a
clever
one
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
he
gives

her
when
he
has
a

,
he

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
husband
does
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
?
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me
shake
from
head
to
foot
,
to
hear

give
it
her
.
 
<EOS>
My
husband
,
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
,
can
conquer
even
your
mother
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
he
be
but
a
clever
one
to
do
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
shuffling
footstep
coming
towards
them
caused
her
to
retreat
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Though
a
tall
,
hard
-
favoured
,
sinewy
old
woman
,
who
in
her
youth
might
have
enlisted
in
the
Foot
Guards
without
much
fear
of
discovery
<EOS>
,
she
collapsed
before
the
little
keen
-
eyed
crab
-
like
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Affery
,
"
said
he
,
"
now
,
woman
,
what
are
you
doing
?
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
you
find
Master
Arthur
something
or
another
to
pick
at
?
"
   
<EOS>
Master
Arthur
repeated
his
recent
refusal
to
pick
at
anything
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
then
,
"
said
the
old
man
;
"
make
his
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Stir
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His
neck
was
so
twisted
that
the
knotted
ends
of
his
white
cravat
usually
dangled
under
one
ear
;
his
natural
acerbity
and
energy
,
always
contending
with
a
second
nature
of
habitual
repression
,
gave
his
features
a
swollen
and
suffused
look
;
and
altogether
,
he
had
a
weird
appearance
of
having
hanged
himself
at
one

or
other
,
and
of
having
gone
about
ever
since
,
halter
and
all
,

some

hand
had
cut

down
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
have
bitter
words
together
to
-
morrow
,
Arthur
;
you
and
your
mother
,
"
said
Jeremiah
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your

given

the
business
on
your

---
which
she

,
though

---
wo

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

the
business
,
and
the
time
came
for
me
to
give

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jeremiah
,
evidently
meaning
Bad
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very

!
 
<EOS>
only
do

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
.
 
<EOS>
I

;
because
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

---
as

---

.
 
<EOS>
Affery
,
woman
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
She

,

"
Yes
,
Jeremiah
.
"
 
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam

,

,

up

.
   
<EOS>
They
mounted
up
and
up
,
through
the
musty

of
an
old
close
house
,
little
used
,
to
a
large

.
 
<EOS>
Meagre

spare
,

,

even

the
rest
,
by

.
<EOS>
Its

were
ugly

out

,
and

,

,

,

,

-

that

in

,
and
a

with
four
bare

,

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
Arthur

long

,

of

,

,

once

,
let

where

.
   
<EOS>
He

Affery
Flintwinch
making

.
   
<EOS>
"
Affery
,

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
She

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
had
introduced
into
the
web
that
his
mind
was
busily
weaving
,
in
that
old
workshop
where
the
loom
of
his
youth
had
stood
,
the
last
thread
wanting
to
the
pattern
.
 
<EOS>
The
airy
folly
of
a
boy
's
love
had
found
its
way
even
into
that
house
,
and
he
had
been
as
wretched
under
its
hopelessness
as
if
the
house
had
been
a
castle
of
romance
.
 
<EOS>
Little
more
than
a
week
ago
at
Marseilles
,
the
face
of
the
pretty
girl
from
whom
he
had
parted
with
regret
,
had
had
an
unusual
interest
for
him
,
and
a
tender
hold
upon
him
,
because
of
some

,
real
or

,
to
this
first
face
that
had
soared

his

into
the
bright

of
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
He
leaned
upon
the
sill
of
the
long
low
window
,
and
looking
out
upon
the
blackened
forest
of
chimneys
again
,
began
to
dream
;
for
it
had
been
the
uniform
tendency
of
this
man
's
life
---
so
much
was
wanting
in
it
to
think
about
,
so
much
that
might
have
been
better
directed
and
happier
to
speculate
upon
---
to
make
him
a
dreamer
,
after
all
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
04
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
has
a
Dream
 
<EOS>
When
Mrs
Flintwinch
dreamed
,
she
usually
dreamed
,
unlike
the
son
of
her
old
mistress
,
with
her
eyes
shut
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
curiously
vivid
dream
that
night
,
and
before
she
had
left
the
son
of
her
old
mistress
many
hours
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
it
was
not
at
all
like
a
dream
;
it
was
so
very
real
in
every
respect
.
 
<EOS>
It
happened
in
this
wise
.
   
<EOS>
The
bed
-
chamber
occupied
by
Mr
and
Mrs
Flintwinch
was
within
a
few
paces
of
that
to
which
Mrs
Clennam
had
been
so
long
confined
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
on
the
same
floor
,
for
it
was
a
room
at
the
side
of
the
house
,
which
was
approached
by
a
steep
descent
of
a
few
odd
steps
,
diverging
from
the
main
staircase
nearly
opposite
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
could
scarcely
be
said
to
be
within
call
,
the
walls
,
doors
,
and
panelling
of
the
old
place
were
so
cumbrous
;
but
it
was
within
easy
reach
,
in
any
undress
,
at
any
hour
of
the
night
,
in
any
temperature
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
head
of
the
bed
and
within
a
foot
of
Mrs
Flintwinch
's
ear
,
was
a
bell
,
the
line
of
which
hung
ready
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
this
bell
rang
,
up
started
Affery
,
and
was
in
the
sick
room
before
she
was
awake
.
   
<EOS>
Having
got
her
mistress
into
bed
,
lighted
her
lamp
,
and
given
her
good
night
,
Mrs
Flintwinch
went
to
roost
as
usual
,
saving
that
her
lord
had
not
yet
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
her
lord
himself
who
became
---
unlike
the
last
theme
in
the
mind
,
according
to
the
observation
of
most
philosophers
---
the
subject
of
Mrs
Flintwinch
's
dream
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
her
that
she
awoke
after
sleeping
some
hours
,
and
found
Jeremiah
not
yet
abed
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
looked
at
the
candle
she
had
left
burning
,
and
,
measuring
the
time
like
King
Alfred
the
Great
,
was
confirmed
by
its
wasted
state
in
her
belief
that
she
had
been
asleep
for
some
considerable
period
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
arose
thereupon
,
muffled
herself
up
in
a
wrapper
,
put
on
her
shoes
,
and
went
out
on
the
staircase
,
much
surprised
,
to
look
for
Jeremiah
.
   
<EOS>
The
staircase
was
as
wooden
and
solid
as
need
be
,
and
Affery
went
straight
down
it
without
any
of
those
deviations
peculiar
to
dreams
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
not
skim
over
it
,
but
walked
down
it
,
and
guided
herself
by
the
banisters
on
account
of
her
candle
having
died
out
.
<EOS>
In
one
corner
of
the
hall
,
behind
the
house
-
door
,
there
was
a
little
waiting
-
room
,
like
a
well
-
shaft
,
with
a
long
narrow
window
in
it
as
if
it
had
been
ripped
up
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
room
,
which
was
never
used
,
a
light
was
burning
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
crossed
the
hall
,
feeling
its
pavement
cold
to
her
stockingless
feet
,
and
peeped
in
between
the
rusty
hinges
on
the
door
,
which
stood
a
little
open
.
 
<EOS>
She
expected
to
see
Jeremiah
fast
asleep
or
in
a
fit
,
but
he
was
calmly
seated
in
a
chair
,
awake
,
and
in
his
usual
health
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
---
hey
?
---
<EOS>
Lord
forgive
us
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
muttered
some
ejaculation
to
this
effect
,
and
turned
giddy
.
   
<EOS>
For
,
Mr
Flintwinch
awake
,
was
watching
Mr
Flintwinch
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
on
one
side
of
the
small
table
,
looking
keenly
at
himself
on
the
other
side
with
his
chin
sunk
on
his
breast
,
snoring
.
 
<EOS>
The
waking
Flintwinch
had
his
full
front
face
presented
to
his
wife
;
the
sleeping
Flintwinch
was
in
profile
.
 
<EOS>
The
waking
Flintwinch
was
the
old
original
;
the
sleeping
Flintwinch
was
the
double
.
 
<EOS>
just
as
she
might
have
distinguished
between
a
tangible
object
and
its
reflection
in
a
glass
,
Affery
made
out
this
difference
with
her
head
going
round
and
round
.
   
<EOS>
If
she
had
had
any
doubt
which
was
her
own
Jeremiah
,
it
would
have
been
resolved
by
his
impatience
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
about
him
for
an
offensive
weapon
,
caught
up
the
snuffers
,
and
,
before
applying
them
to
the
cabbage
-
headed
candle
,
lunged
at
the
sleeper
as
though
he
would
have
run
him
through
the
body
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
sleeper
,
starting
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
made
a
movement
with
the
snuffers
,
as
if
he
would
have
enforced
silence
on
his
companion
by
putting
them
down
his
throat
;
the
companion
,
coming
to
himself
,
said
,
rubbing
his
eyes
,
"
I
forgot
where
I
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
asleep
,
"
snarled
Jeremiah
,
referring
to
his
watch
,
"
two
hours
.
 
<EOS>
You
said
you
would
be
rested
enough
if
you
had
a
short
nap
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
a
short
nap
,
"
said
Double
.
   
<EOS>
"
Half
-
past
two
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
"
muttered
Jeremiah
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
your
hat
?
 
<EOS>
Where
's
your
coat
?
 
<EOS>
Where
's
the
box
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
here
,
"
said
Double
,
tying
up
his
throat
with
sleepy
carefulness
in
a
shawl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
Now
give
me
the
sleeve
---
not
that
sleeve
,
the
other
one
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
as
young
as
I
was
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
had
pulled
him
into
his
coat
with
vehement
energy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
promised
me
a
second
glass
after
I
was
rested
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Drink
it
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Jeremiah
,
"
and
---
choke
yourself
,
I
was
going
to
say
---
but
go
,
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
At
the
same
time
he
produced
the
identical
port
-
wine
bottle
,
and
filled
a
wine
-
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
port
-
wine
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Double
,
tasting
it
as
if
he
were
in
the
Docks
,
with
hours
to
spare
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
health
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
took
a
sip
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
health
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
took
another
sip
.
   
<EOS>
"
His
health
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
took
another
sip
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
all
friends
round
St
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
emptied
and
put
down
the
wine
-
glass
half
-
way
through
this
ancient
civic
toast
,
and
took
up
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
iron
box
<EOS>
some
two
feet
square
,
which
he
carried
under
his
arms
pretty
easily
.
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
watched
his
manner
of
adjusting
it
,
with
jealous
eyes
;
tried
it
with
his
hands
,
to
be
sure
that
he
had
a
firm
hold
of
it
;
bade
him
for
his
life
be
careful
what
he
was
about
;
and
then
stole
out
on
tiptoe
to
open
the
door
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
,
anticipating
the
last
movement
,
was
on
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
The
sequence
of
things
was
so
ordinary
and
natural
,
that
,
standing
there
,
she
could
hear
the
door
open
,
feel
the
night
air
,
and
see
the
stars
outside
.
   
<EOS>
But
now
came
the
most
remarkable
part
of
the
dream
.
 
<EOS>
She
felt
so
afraid
of
her
husband
,
that
being
on
the
staircase
,
she
had
not
the
power
to
retreat
to
her
room
(
which
she
might
easily
have
done
before
he
had
fastened
the
door
)
,
but
stood
there
staring
.
<EOS>
Consequently
when
he
came
up
the
staircase
to
bed
,
candle
in
hand
,
he
came
full
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
astonished
,
but
said
not
a
word
.
<EOS>
He
kept
his
eyes
upon
her
,
and
kept
advancing
;
and
she
,
completely
under
his
influence
,
kept
retiring
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
she
walking
backward
and
he
walking
forward
,
they
came
into
their
own
room
.
<EOS>
They
were
no
sooner
shut
in
there
,
than
Mr
Flintwinch
took
her
by
the
throat
,
and
shook
her
until
she
was
black
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Affery
,
woman
---
Affery
!
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
been
dreaming
of
?
 
<EOS>
Wake
up
,
wake
up
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
---
the
matter
,
Jeremiah
?
"
gasped
Mrs
Flintwinch
,
rolling
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Affery
,
woman
---
Affery
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
getting
out
of
bed
in
your
sleep
,
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
I
come
up
,
after
having
fallen
asleep
myself
,
below
,
and
find
you
in
your
wrapper
here
,
with
the
nightmare
.
<EOS>
Affery
,
woman
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
with
a
friendly
grin
on
his
expressive
countenance
,
"
if
you
ever
have
a
dream
of
this
sort
again
,
it
'll
be
a
sign
of
your
being
in
want
of
physic
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
give
you
such
a
dose
,
old
woman
---
such
a
dose
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
thanked
him
and
crept
into
bed
.
    
<EOS>
Family
Affairs
 
<EOS>
As
the
city
clocks
struck
nine
on
Monday
morning
,
Mrs
Clennam
was
wheeled
by
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
of
the
cut
-
down
aspect
to
her
tall
cabinet
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
unlocked
and
opened
it
,
and
had
settled
herself
at
its
desk
,
Jeremiah
withdrew
---
as
it
might
be
,
to
hang
himself
more
effectually
---
and
her
son
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
any
better
this
morning
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
,
with
the
same
austere
air
of
luxuriousness
that
she
had
shown
over
-
night
when
speaking
of
the
weather
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
be
better
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
well
for
me
,
Arthur
,
that
I
know
it
and
can
bear
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sitting
with
her
hands
laid
separately
upon
the
desk
,
and
the
tall
cabinet
towering
before
her
,
she
looked
as
if
she
were
performing
on
a
dumb
church
organ
.
 
<EOS>
Her
son
thought
so
(
it
was
an
old
thought
with
him
)
,
while
he
took
his
seat
beside
it
.
   
<EOS>
She
opened
a
drawer
or
two
,
looked
over
some
business
papers
,
and
put
them
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
Her
severe
face
had
no
thread
of
relaxation
in
it
,
by
which
any
explorer
could
have
been
guided
to
the
gloomy
labyrinth
of
her
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
speak
of
our
affairs
,
mother
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
inclined
to
enter
upon
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
inclined
,
Arthur
?
 
<EOS>
Rather
,
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Your
father
has
been
dead
a
year
and
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
at
your
disposal
,
and
waiting
your
pleasure
,
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
much
to
arrange
before
I
could
leave
;
and
when
I
did
leave
,
I
travelled
a
little
for
rest
and
relief
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
turned
her
face
towards
him
,
as
not
having
heard
or
understood
his
last
words
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
rest
and
relief
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
glanced
round
the
sombre
room
,
and
appeared
from
the
motion
of
her
lips
to
repeat
the
words
to
herself
,
as
calling
it
to
witness
how
little
of
either
it
afforded
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
mother
,
you
being
sole
executrix
,
and
having
the
direction
and
management
of
the
estate
,
there
remained
little
business
,
or
I
might
say
none
,
that
I
could
transact
,
until
you
had
had
time
to
arrange
matters
to
your
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
accounts
are
made
out
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
them
here
.
 
<EOS>
The
vouchers
have
all
been
examined
and
passed
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
inspect
them
when
you
like
,
Arthur
;
now
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
enough
,
mother
,
to
know
that
the
business
is
completed
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
proceed
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
in
her
frozen
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
our
House
has
done
less
and
less
for
some
years
past
,
and
our
dealings
have
been
progressively
on
the
decline
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
never
shown
much
confidence
,
or
invited
much
;
we
have
attached
no
people
to
us
;
the
track
we
have
kept
is
not
the
track
of
the
time
;
and
we
have
been
left
far
behind
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
not
dwell
on
this
to
you
,
mother
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
necessarily
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
you
mean
,
"
she
answered
,
in
a
qualified
tone
.
"
<EOS>
Even
this
old
house
in
which
we
speak
,
"
pursued
her
son
,
"
is
an
instance
of
what
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
father
's
earlier
time
,
and
in
his
uncle
's
time
before
him
,
it
was
a
place
of
business
---
really
a
place
of
business
,
and
business
resort
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
it
is
a
mere
anomaly
and
incongruity
here
,
out
of
date
and
out
of
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
All
our
consignments
have
long
been
made
to
Rovinghams
'
the
commission
-
merchants
;
and
although
,
as
a
check
upon
them
,
and
in
the
stewardship
of
my
father
's
resources
,
your
judgment
and
watchfulness
have
been
actively
exerted
,
still
those
qualities
would
have
influenced
my
father
's
fortunes
equally
,
if
you
had
lived
in
any
private
dwelling
:
<EOS>
would
they
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
consider
,
"
she
returned
,
without
answering
his
question
,
"
that
a
house
serves
no
purpose
,
Arthur
,
in
sheltering
your
infirm
and
afflicted
---
justly
infirm
and
righteously
afflicted
---
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
speaking
only
of
business
purposes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
what
object
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
coming
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
foresee
,
"
she
returned
,
fixing
her
eyes
upon
him
,
"
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
But
the
Lord
forbid
that
I
should
repine
under
any
visitation
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
sinfulness
I
merit
bitter
disappointment
,
and
I
accept
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
grieve
to
hear
you
speak
like
this
,
though
I
have
had
my
apprehensions
that
you
would
---
"
   
"
You
knew
I
would
.
 
<EOS>
You
knew
ME
,
"
she
interrupted
.
   
<EOS>
Her
son
paused
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
struck
fire
out
of
her
,
and
was
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
relapsing
into
stone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
hear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
anticipated
,
mother
,
that
I
decide
for
my
part
,
to
abandon
the
business
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
take
upon
myself
to
advise
you
;
you
will
continue
it
,
I
see
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
any
influence
with
you
,
I
would
simply
use
it
to
soften
your
judgment
of
me
in
causing
you
this
disappointment
:
to
represent
to
you
that
I
have
lived
the
half
of
a
long
term
of
life
,
and
have
never
before
set
my
own
will
against
yours
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
I
have
been
able
to
conform
myself
,
in
heart
and
spirit
,
to
your
rules
;
I
can
not
say
that
I
believe
my
forty
years
have
been
profitable
or
pleasant
to
myself
,
or
any
one
;
but
I
have
habitually
submitted
,
and
I
only
ask
you
to
remember
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Woe
to
the
suppliant
,
<EOS>
if
such
a
one
there
were
or
ever
had
been
,
who
had
any
concession
to
look
for
in
the
inexorable
face
at
the
cabinet
.
 
<EOS>
Woe
to
the
defaulter
whose
appeal
lay
to
the
tribunal
where
those
severe
eyes
presided
.
 
<EOS>
Great
need
had
the
rigid
woman
of
her
mystical
religion
,
veiled
in
gloom
and
darkness
,
with
lightnings
of
cursing
,
vengeance
,
and
destruction
,
flashing
through
the
sable
clouds
.
 
<EOS>
Forgive
us
our
debts
as
we
forgive
our
debtors
,
was
a
prayer
too
poor
in
spirit
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
Smite
Thou
my
debtors
<EOS>
,
Lord
,
wither
them
,
crush
them
;
do
Thou
as
I
would
do
,
and
Thou
shalt
have
my
worship
:
this
was
the
impious
tower
of
stone
she
built
up
to
scale
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
finished
,
Arthur
,
or
have
you
anything
more
to
say
to
me
?
   
<EOS>
I
think
there
can
be
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
short
,
but
full
of
matter
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
have
yet
something
more
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
upon
my
mind
,
night
and
day
,
this
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
far
more
difficult
to
say
than
what
I
have
said
.
 
<EOS>
That
concerned
myself
;
this
concerns
us
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Us
all
!
 
<EOS>
Who
are
us
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yourself
,
myself
,
my
dead
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
took
her
hands
from
the
desk
;
folded
them
in
her
lap
;
and
sat
looking
towards
the
fire
,
with
the
impenetrability
of
an
old
Egyptian
sculpture
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
knew
my
father
infinitely
better
than
I
ever
knew
him
;
and
his
reserve
with
me
yielded
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
much
the
stronger
,
mother
,
and
directed
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
child
,
I
knew
it
as
well
as
I
know
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
that
your
ascendancy
over
him
was
the
cause
of
<EOS>
his
going
to
China
to
take
care
of
the
business
there
,
while
you
took
care
of
it
here
(
though
I
do
not
even
now
know
whether
these
were
really
terms
of
separation
that
you
agreed
upon
)
;
and
that
it
was
your
will
that
I
should
remain
with
you
until
I
was
twenty
,
and
then
go
to
him
as
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
be
offended
by
my
recalling
this
,
after
twenty
years
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
waiting
to
hear
why
you
recall
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
lowered
his
voice
,
and
said
,
with
manifest
reluctance
,
and
against
his
will
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
ask
you
,
mother
,
whether
it
ever
occurred
to
you
to
suspect
---
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
word
Suspect
,
she
turned
her
eyes
momentarily
upon
her
son
,
with
a
dark
frown
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
suffered
them
to
seek
the
fire
,
as
before
;
but
with
the
frown
fixed
above
them
,
as
if
the
sculptor
of
old
Egypt
had
indented
it
in
the
hard
granite
face
,
to
frown
for
ages
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
that
he
had
any
secret
remembrance
which
caused
him
trouble
of
mind
---
remorse
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
you
ever
observed
anything
in
his
conduct
suggesting
that
;
or
ever
spoke
to
him
upon
it
,
or
ever
heard
him
hint
at
such
a
thing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
what
kind
of
secret
remembrance
you
mean
to
infer
that
your
father
was
a
prey
to
,
"
she
returned
,
after
a
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
speak
so
mysteriously
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
mother
,
"
her
son
leaned
forward
to
be
the
nearer
to
her
while
he
whispered
it
,
and
laid
his
hand
nervously
upon
her
desk
,
"
is
it
possible
,
mother
,
that
he
had
unhappily
wronged
any
one
,
and
made
no
reparation
?
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
at
him
<EOS>
wrathfully
,
she
bent
herself
back
in
her
chair
to
keep
him
further
off
,
but
gave
him
no
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
deeply
sensible
,
mother
,
that
if
this
thought
has
never
at
any
time
flashed
upon
you
,
it
must
seem
cruel
and
unnatural
in
me
,
even
in
this
confidence
,
to
breathe
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
shake
it
off
.
   
<EOS>
Time
and
change
<EOS>
(
I
have
tried
both
before
breaking
silence
)
do
nothing
to
wear
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
,
I
was
with
my
father
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
,
I
saw
his
face
when
he
gave
the
watch
into
my
keeping
,
and
struggled
to
express
that
he
sent
it
as
a
token
you
would
understand
,
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
<EOS>
,
I
saw
him
at
the
last
with
the
pencil
in
his
failing
hand
,
trying
to
write
some
word
for
you
to
read
,
but
to
which
he
could
give
no
shape
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
remote
and
cruel
this
vague
suspicion
that
I
have
,
the
stronger
the
circumstances
that
could
give
it
any
semblance
of
probability
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
Heaven
's
sake
,
let
us
examine
sacredly
whether
there
is
any
wrong
entrusted
to
us
to
set
right
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
can
help
towards
it
,
mother
,
but
you
.
 
<EOS>
"
   
Still
so
recoiling
in
her
chair
that
her
overpoised
weight
moved
it
,
from
time
to
time
,
a
little
on
its
wheels
,
and
gave
her
the
appearance
of
a
phantom
of
fierce
aspect
gliding
away
from
him
,
she
interposed
her
left

,
bent
at
the

with
the

her
hand
towards
her
face
,
between
herself
and
him
,
and
looked
at
him
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
grasping
at
money
and
in
driving
hard
bargains
---
I
have
begun
,
and
I
must
speak
of
such
things
now
,
mother
---
some
one
may
have
been
grievously
deceived
,
injured
,
ruined
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
the
moving
power
of
all
this
machinery
before
my
birth
;
your
stronger
spirit
has
been
infused
into
all
my
father
's
dealings
for
more
than
two
score
years
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
set
these
doubts
at
rest
,
I
think
,
if
you
will
really
help
me
to
discover
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
in
the
hope
that
she
would
speak
.
 
<EOS>
But
her
grey
hair
was
not
more
immovable
in
its
two
folds
,
than
were
her
firm
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
reparation
can
be
made
to
any
one
,
if
restitution
can
be
made
to
any
one
,
let
us
know
it
and
make
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
mother
,
if
within
my
means
,
let
ME
make
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
so
little
happiness
come
of
money
;
it
has
brought
within
my
knowledge
so
little
peace
to
this
house
,
or
to
any
one
belonging
to
it
,
that
it
is
worth
less
to
me
than
to
another
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
buy
me
nothing
that
will
not
be
a
reproach
and
misery
to
me
,
if
I
am
haunted
by
a
suspicion
that
it
darkened
my
father
's
last
hours
with
remorse
,
and
that
it
is
not
honestly
and
justly
mine
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
bell
-
rope
hanging
on
the
panelled
wall
,
some
two
or
three
yards
from
the
cabinet
.
 
<EOS>
By
a
swift
and
sudden
action
of
her
foot
,
she
drove
her
wheeled
chair
rapidly
back
to
it
and

violently
---
still
holding

up
in
its
shield
-
like
posture
,
as
if
he
were
striking
at
her
,
and
she
warding
off
the
blow
.
   
<EOS>
A
girl
came
hurrying
in
,
frightened
.
   
<EOS>
"
Send
Flintwinch
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
a
moment
the
girl
had
withdrawn
,
and
the
old
man
stood
within
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
hammer
and
tongs
,
already
,
you
two
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
coolly
stroking
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
pretty
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Flintwinch
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
mother
,
"
look
at
my
son
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
AM
looking
at
him
,
"
said
Flintwinch
.
   
<EOS>
She
stretched
out
the
arm
with
which
she
had
shielded
herself
,
and
as
she
went
on
,
pointed
at
the
object
of
her
anger
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
very
hour
of
his
return
almost
---
before
the
shoe
upon
his
foot
is
dry
---
he
asperses
his
father
's
memory
to
his
mother
!
 
<EOS>
Asks
his
mother
to
become
,
with
him
,
a
spy
upon
his
father
's
transactions
through
a
lifetime
!
 
<EOS>
Has
misgivings
that
the
goods
of
this
world
which
we
have
painfully
got
together
early

,
with
wear

,
are
so
much

;
and
asks

,

reparation
and

!
"
   
<EOS>
Although

said
this
raging
,
she

in
a

so
far

being
beyond
her
control
that
it
was
even
lower
than
her
usual
tone
.
 
<EOS>
She
also
spoke
with
great
distinctness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Reparation
!
<EOS>
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
truly
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
easy
for
him
to
talk
of
reparation
,
fresh
from
journeying
and
junketing
in
foreign
lands
,
and
living
a

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
But
let
him
look
at
me
,
in
prison
,
and
in
bonds
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
endure
without
murmuring
,
because
it
is
appointed
that
I
shall
so
make
reparation
for
my
sins
.
 
<EOS>
Reparation
!
 
<EOS>
Is
there
none
in
this
room
?
 
<EOS>
Has
there
been
none
here
this
fifteen
years
?
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
was
she
always
balancing
her
bargains
with
the
Majesty
of
heaven
,
posting
up
the
entries
to
her
credit
,
strictly
keeping
her
set
-
off
,
and

her

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
only
remarkable
in
this
,
for
the
force
and
emphasis
with
which
she
did
it
.
 
<EOS>
Thousands
upon
thousands
do
it
,
according
to
their
varying
manner
,
every

.
   
<EOS>
"
Flintwinch
,
give
me
that
book
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
handed
it
to
her
from
the

.
 
<EOS>
She
put
two
fingers
between
the
leaves
,
closed
the
book
upon
them
,
and
held
it
up
to
her
son
in

threatening

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
In
the
days
of
old
,
Arthur
,
treated
of
in
this
commentary
,
there
were
pious
men
,
beloved
of
the
Lord
,
who
would
have
cursed
their
sons
for
less
than
this
:
who
would

sent

forth
,
and

forth
,
if
such
had
supported

,
to
be
avoided
of
God

man
,
and
perish
,
down

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
only
tell
you
that
if
you
ever
renew
that
theme
with
me
,
I
will
renounce
you
;
I
will
so

you
through
that
doorway
,
that
you
had
better
have
been
motherless
from

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
never
see
or
know
you
more
.
 
<EOS>
And
if
,
after

,
you
were
to
come

to
look

lying
dead
,
my

should
bleed
,
if
I
could

,
when
you
came
near
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
part

by

,
and
in

(
monstrous

the
fact

)

some

,
she
handed

book
to
the
old

,
and
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Jeremiah
;
"
premising
that
I
'm
not
going
to
stand
between
you
two
,
will
you
let
me
ask
(
as
I
have
been
called
in
,
and
made
a
third
)
<EOS>
what
is
all
this
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take

of
it
,
"

Arthur
,
finding

left

to

,
"
from
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Let

.
 
<EOS>
What
I
have
said
,
was
said
to
my
mother
only
.
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
returned

old

.
 
<EOS>
"
From
your
mother
?
 
<EOS>
Take
it
from
your
mother
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
But
your
mother
mentioned
that
you
had

suspecting
your
father
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
not
dutiful
,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Who
will
you

suspecting

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
turning

that
it

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
stop

,
"
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let

how

stand
.
 
<EOS>
Have

that

must
n't
lay

?
 
<EOS>
That

?
<EOS>
That

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
him
so
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Exactly
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
tell
him
so
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
had

so
before
,
and
you
tell
