so
now
.
 
<EOS>
Ay
,
ay
!
<EOS>
That
's
right
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
I
stood
between
you
and
his
father
so
long
,
that
it
seems
as
if
death
had
made
no
difference
,
and
I
was
still
standing
between
you
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
will
,
and
<EOS>
so
in
fairness
I
require
to
have
that
plainly
put
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
,
you
please
to
hear
that
you
have
no
right
to
mistrust
your
father
,
and
have
no
ground
to
go
upon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
hands
to
the
back
of
the
wheeled
chair
,
and
muttering
to
himself
,
slowly
wheeled
his
mistress
back
to
her
cabinet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
he
resumed
,
standing
behind
her
:
"
in
case
I
should
go
away
leaving
things
half
done
,
and
so
should
be
wanted
again
<EOS>
when
you
come
to
the
other
half
and
get
into
one
of
your
flights
,
has
Arthur
told
you
what
he
means
to
do
about
the
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
relinquished
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
favour
of
nobody
,
I
suppose
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
glanced
at
her
son
,
leaning
against
one
of
the
windows
.
   
<EOS>
He
observed
the
look
and
said
,
"
To
my
mother
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
She
does
what
she
pleases
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
any
pleasure
,
"
she
said
after
a
short
pause
,
"
could
arise
for
me
out
of
the
disappointment
of
my
expectations
that
my
son
,
in
the
prime
of
his
life
,
would
infuse
new
youth
and
strength
into
it
,
and
make
it
of
great
profit
and
power
,
it
would
be
in
advancing
an
old
and
faithful
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,
the
captain
deserts
the
ship
,
but
you
and
I
will
sink
or
float
with
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,
whose
eyes
glistened
as
if
they
saw
money
,
darted
a
sudden
look
at
the
son
,
which
seemed
to
say
,
"
I
owe
YOU
no
thanks
for
this
;
YOU
have
done
nothing
towards
it
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
told
the
mother
that
he
thanked
her
,
and
that
Affery
thanked
her
,
and
that
he
would
never
desert
her
,
and
that
Affery
would
never
desert
her
.
<EOS>
Finally
,
he
hauled
up
his
watch
from
its
depths
,
and
said
,
"
Eleven
.
<EOS>
Time
for
your
oysters
!
"
<EOS>
and
with
that
change
of
subject
,
which
involved
no
change
of
expression
or
manner
,
rang
the
bell
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Clennam
,
resolved
to
treat
herself
with
the
greater
rigour
for
having
been
supposed
to
be
unacquainted
with
reparation
,
refused
to
eat
her
oysters
when
they
were
brought
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
tempting
;
eight
in
number
,
circularly
set
out
on
a
white
plate
on
a
tray
covered
with
a
white
napkin
,
flanked
by
a
slice
of
buttered
French
roll
,
and
a
little
compact
glass
of
cool
wine
and
water
;
but
she
resisted
all
persuasions
,
and
sent
them
down
again
---
placing
the
act
to
her
credit
,
no
doubt
,
in
her
Eternal
Day
-
Book
.
   
<EOS>
This
refection
of
oysters
was
not
presided
over
by
Affery
,
but
by
the
girl
who
had
appeared
when
the
bell
was
rung
;
the
same
who
had
been
in
the
dimly
-
lighted
room
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
he
had
an
opportunity
of
observing
her
,
Arthur
found
that
her
diminutive
figure
,
small
features
,
and
slight
spare
dress
,
gave
her
the
appearance
of
being
much
younger
than
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
A
woman
,
probably
of
not
less
than
two
-
and
-
twenty
,
she
might
have
been
passed
in
the
street
for
little
more
than
half
that
age
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
her
face
was
very
youthful
,
for
in
truth
there
was
more
consideration
and
care
in
it
than
naturally
belonged
to
her
utmost
years
;
but
she
was
so
little
and
light
,
so
noiseless
and
shy
,
and
appeared
so
conscious
of
being
out
of
place
among
the
three
hard
elders
,
that
she
had
all
the
manner
and
much
of
the
appearance
of
a
subdued
child
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
hard
way
,
and
in
an
uncertain
way
that
fluctuated
between
patronage
and
putting
down
,
the
sprinkling
from
a
watering
-
pot
and
hydraulic
pressure
,
Mrs
Clennam
showed
an
interest
in
this
dependent
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
the
moment
of
her
entrance
,
upon
the
violent
ringing
of
the
bell
,
when
the
mother
shielded
herself
with
that
singular
action
from
the
son
,
Mrs
Clennam
's
eyes
had
had
some
individual
recognition
in
them
,
which
seemed
reserved
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
there
are
degrees
of
hardness
in
the
hardest
metal
,
and
shades
of
colour
in
black
itself
,
so
,
even
in
the
asperity
of
Mrs
Clennam
's
demeanour
towards
all
the
rest
of
humanity
and
towards
Little
Dorrit
,
there
was
a
fine
gradation
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
let
herself
out
to
do
needlework
.
 
<EOS>
At
so
much
a
day
---
or
at
so
little
---
from
eight
to
eight
,
Little
Dorrit
was
to
be
hired
.
 
<EOS>
Punctual
to
the
moment
,
Little
Dorrit
appeared
;
punctual
to
the
moment
,
Little
Dorrit
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
What
became
of
Little
Dorrit
between
the
two
eights
was
a
mystery
.
   
<EOS>
Another
of
the
moral
phenomena
of
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
her
consideration
money
,
her
daily
contract
included
meals
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
an
extraordinary
repugnance
to
dining
in
company
;
would
never
do
so
,
if
it
were
possible
to
escape
.
 
<EOS>
Would
always
plead
that
she
had
this
bit
of
work
to
begin
first
,
or
that
bit
of
work
to
finish
first
;
and
would
,
of
a
certainty
,
scheme
and
plan
---
not
very
cunningly
,
it
would
seem
,
for
she
deceived
no
one
---
to
dine
alone
.
<EOS>
Successful
in
this
,
happy
in
carrying
off
her
plate
anywhere
,
to
make
a
table
of
her
lap
,
or
a
box
,
or
the
ground
,
or
even
as
was
supposed
,
to
stand
on
tip
-
toe
,
dining
moderately
at
a
mantel
-
shelf
;
the
great
anxiety
of
Little
Dorrit
's
day
was
set
at
rest
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
easy
to
make
out
Little
Dorrit
's
face
;
she
was
so
retiring
,
plied
her
needle
in
such
removed
corners
,
and
started
away
so
scared
if
encountered
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
seemed
to
be
a
pale
transparent
face
,
quick
in
expression
,
though
not
beautiful
in
feature
<EOS>
,
its
soft
hazel
eyes
excepted
.
 
<EOS>
A
delicately
bent
head
,
a
tiny
form
,
a
quick
little
pair
of
busy
hands
,
and
a
shabby
dress
---
<EOS>
it
must
needs
<EOS>
have
been
very
shabby
to
look
at
all
so
,
being
so
neat
---
were
Little
Dorrit
as
she
sat
at
work
.
   
<EOS>
For
these
particulars
or
generalities
concerning
Little
Dorrit
,
Mr
Arthur
was
indebted
in
the
course
of
the
day
to
his
own
eyes
and
to
Mrs
Affery
's
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mrs
Affery
had
had
any
will
or
way
of
her
own
,
it
would
probably
have
been
unfavourable
to
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
But
as
"
them
two
clever
ones
"
---
Mrs
Affery
's
perpetual
reference
,
in
whom
her
personality
was
swallowed
up
---
were
agreed
to
accept
Little
Dorrit
as
a
matter
of
course
,
she
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
follow
suit
.
 
<EOS>
Similarly
,
if
the
two
clever
ones
had
agreed
to
murder
Little
Dorrit
by
candlelight
,
Mrs
Affery
,
being
required
to
hold
the
candle
,
would
no
doubt
have
done
it
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
intervals
of
roasting
the
partridge
for
the
invalid
chamber
,
and
preparing
a
baking
-
dish
of
beef
and
pudding
for
the
dining
-
room
,
Mrs
Affery
made
the
communications
above
set
forth
;
invariably
putting
her
head
in
at
the
door
again
after
she
had
taken
it
out
,
to
enforce
resistance
to
the
two
clever
ones
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
have
become
a
perfect
passion
with
Mrs
Flintwinch
,
that
the
only
son
should
be
pitted
against
them
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
day
,
too
,
Arthur
looked
through
the
whole
house
.
 
<EOS>
Dull
and
dark
<EOS>
he
found
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
gaunt
rooms
,
deserted
for
years
upon
years
,
seemed
to
have
settled
down
into
a
gloomy
lethargy
from
which
nothing
could
rouse
them
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
furniture
,
at
once
spare
and
lumbering
,
hid
in
the
rooms
rather
than
furnished
them
,
and
there
was
no
colour
in
all
the
house
;
such
colour
as
had
ever
been
there
,
had
long
ago
started
away
on
lost
sunbeams
---
got
itself
absorbed
,
perhaps
,
into
flowers
,
butterflies
,
plumage
of
birds
,
precious
stones
,
<EOS>
what
not
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
one
straight
floor
from
the
foundation
to
the
roof
;
the
ceilings
were
so
fantastically
clouded
by
smoke
and
dust
,
that
old
women
might
have
told
fortunes
in
them
better
than
in
grouts
of
tea
;
the
dead
-
cold
hearths
showed
no
traces
of
having
ever
been
warmed
but
in
heaps
of
soot
that
had
tumbled
down
the
chimneys
,
and
eddied
about
in
little
dusky
whirlwinds
when
the
doors
were
opened
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
had
once
been
a
drawing
-
room
,
there
were
a
pair
of
meagre
mirrors
,
with
dismal
processions
of
black
figures
carrying
black
garlands
,
walking
round
the
frames
;
but
even
these
were
short
of
heads
and
legs
,
and
one
undertaker
-
like
Cupid
had
swung
round
on
its
own
axis
and
got
upside
down
,
and
another
had
fallen
off
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
Arthur
Clennam
's
deceased
father
had
occupied
for
business
purposes
,
when
he
first
remembered
him
,
was
so
unaltered
that
he
might
have
been
imagined
still
to
keep
it
invisibly
,
as
his
visible
relict
kept
her
room
up
-
stairs
;
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
still
going
between
them
negotiating
.
 
<EOS>
His
picture
,
dark
and
gloomy
,
earnestly
speechless
on
the
wall
,
with
the
eyes
intently
looking
at
his
son
as
they
had
looked
when
life
departed
from
them
,
seemed
to
urge
him
awfully
to
the
task
he
had
attempted
;
but
as
to
any
yielding
on
the
part
of
his
mother
,
he
had
now
no
hope
,
and
as
to
any
other
means
of
setting
his
distrust
at
rest
,
he
had
abandoned
hope
a
long
time
.
   
<EOS>
Down
in
the
cellars
,
as
up
in
the
bed
-
chambers
,
old
objects
that
he
well
remembered
were
changed
by
age
and
decay
,
but
were
still
in
their
old
places
;
even
to
empty
beer
-
casks
hoary
with
cobwebs
,
and
empty
wine
-
bottles
with
fur
and
fungus
choking
up
their
throats
.
<EOS>
There
,
too
,
among
unusual
bottle
-
racks
and
pale
slants
of
light
from
the
yard
above
,
was
the
strong
room
stored
with
old
ledgers
,
which
had
as
musty
and
corrupt
a
smell
as
if
they
were
regularly
balanced
,
in
the
dead
small
hours
,
by
a
nightly
resurrection
of
old
book
-
keepers
.
   
<EOS>
The
baking
-
dish
was
served
up
in
a
penitential
manner
on
a
shrunken
cloth
at
an
end
of
the
dining
-
table
,
at
two
o'clock
,
when
he
dined
with
Mr
Flintwinch
,
the
new
partner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
informed
him
that
his
mother
had
recovered
her
equanimity
now
,
and
that
he
need
not
fear
her
again
alluding
to
what
had
passed
in
the
morning
.
"
<EOS>
And
do
n't
you
lay
offences
at
your
father
's
door
,
Mr
Arthur
,
"
added
Jeremiah
,
"
once
for
all
,
do
n't
do
it
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
we
have
done
with
the
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
had
been
already
rearranging
and
dusting
his
own
particular
little
office
,
as
if
to
do
honour
to
his
accession
to
new
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
He
resumed
this
occupation
when
he
was
replete
with
beef
,
had
sucked
up
all
the
gravy
in
the
baking
-
dish
with
the
flat
of
his
knife
,
and
had
drawn
liberally
on
a
barrel
of
small
beer
in
the
scullery
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
refreshed
,
he
tucked
up
his
shirt
-
sleeves
and
went
to
work
again
;
and
Mr
Arthur
,
watching
him
as
he
set
about
it
,
plainly
saw
that
his
father
's
picture
,
or
his
father
's
grave
,
would
be
as
communicative
with
him
as
this
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Affery
,
woman
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
as
she
crossed
the
hall
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
n't
made
Mr
Arthur
's
bed
when
I
was
up
there
last
.
 
<EOS>
Stir
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Bustle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Arthur
found
the
house
so
blank
and
dreary
,
and
was
so
unwilling
to
assist
at
another
implacable
consignment
of
his
mother
's
enemies
(
perhaps
himself
among
them
)
to
mortal
disfigurement
and
immortal
ruin
,
that
he
announced
his
intention
of
lodging
at
the
coffee
-
house
where
he
had
left
his
luggage
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
taking
kindly
to
the
idea
of
getting
rid
of
him
,
and
his
mother
being
indifferent
,
beyond
considerations
of
saving
,
to
most
domestic
arrangements
that
were
not
bounded
by
the
walls
of
her
own
chamber
,
he
easily
carried
this
point
without
new
offence
.
 
<EOS>
Daily
business
hours
were
agreed
upon
,
which
his
mother
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
and
he
,
were
to
devote
together
to
a
necessary
checking
of
books
and
papers
;
and
he
left
the
home
he
had
so
lately
found
,
with
depressed
heart
.
   
<EOS>
But
Little
Dorrit
?
   
<EOS>
The
business
hours
,
allowing
for
intervals
of
invalid
regimen
of
oysters
and
partridges
,
during
which
Clennam
refreshed
himself
with
a
walk
,
were
from
ten
to
six
for
about
a
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
Little
Dorrit
was
employed
at
her
needle
,
sometimes
not
,
sometimes
appeared
as
a
humble
visitor
:
which
must
have
been
her
character
on
the
occasion
of
his
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
His
original
curiosity
augmented
every
day
,
as
he
watched
for
her
,
saw
or
did
not
see
her
,
and
speculated
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
Influenced
by
his
predominant
idea
,
he
even
fell
into
a
habit
of
discussing
with
himself
the
possibility
of
her
being
in
some
way
associated
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
resolved
to
watch
Little
Dorrit
and
know
more
of
her
story
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
06
.
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
 
<EOS>
Thirty
years
ago
there
stood
,
a
few
doors
short
of
the
church
of
Saint
George
,
in
the
borough
of
Southwark
,
on
the
left
-
hand
side
of
the
way
going
southward
,
the
Marshalsea
Prison
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
stood
there
many
years
before
,
and
it
remained
there
some
years
afterwards
;
but
it
is
gone
now
,
and
the
world
is
none
the
worse
without
it
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
an
oblong
pile
of
barrack
building
,
partitioned
into
squalid
houses
standing
back
to
back
,
so
that
there
were
no
back
rooms
;
environed
by
a
narrow
paved
yard
,
hemmed
in
by
high
walls
duly
spiked
at
top
.
 
<EOS>
Itself
a
close
and
confined
prison
for
debtors
,
it
contained
within
it
a
much
closer
and
more
confined
jail
for
smugglers
.
 
<EOS>
Offenders
against
the
revenue
laws
,
and
defaulters
to
excise
or
customs
who
had
incurred
fines
which
they
were
unable
to
pay
,
were
supposed
to
be
incarcerated
behind
an
iron
-
plated
door
closing
up
a
second
prison
,
consisting
of
a
strong
cell
or
two
,
and
a
blind
alley
some
yard
and
a
half
wide
,
which
formed
the
mysterious
termination
of
the
very
limited
skittle
-
ground
in
which
the
Marshalsea
debtors
bowled
down
their
troubles
.
   
<EOS>
Supposed
to
be
incarcerated
there
,
because
the
time
had
rather
outgrown
the
strong
cells
and
the
blind
alley
.
 
<EOS>
In
practice
they
had
come
to
be
considered
a
little
too
bad
,
though
in
theory
they
were
quite
as
good
as
ever
;
which
may
be
observed
to
be
the
case
at
the
present
day
with
other
cells
that
are
not
at
all
strong
,
and
with
other
blind
alleys
that
are
stone
-
blind
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
the
smugglers
habitually
consorted
with
the
debtors
(
who
received
them
with
open
arms
)
,
except
at
certain
constitutional
moments
when
somebody
came
from
some
Office
,
to
go
through
some
form
of
overlooking
something
which
neither
he
nor
anybody
else
knew
anything
about
.
 
<EOS>
On
these
truly
British
occasions
,
the
smugglers
,
if
any
,
made
a
feint
of
walking
into
the
strong
cells
and
the
blind
alley
,
while
this
somebody
pretended
to
do
his
something
:
and
made
a
reality
of
walking
out
again
as
soon
as
he
had
n't
done
it
---
neatly
epitomising
the
administration
of
most
of
the
public
affairs
in
our
right
little
,
tight
little
,
island
.
   
<EOS>
There
had
been
taken
to
the
Marshalsea
Prison
,
long
before
the
day
when
the
sun
shone
on
Marseilles
and
on
the
opening
of
this
narrative
,
a
debtor
with
whom
this
narrative
has
some
concern
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
,
at
that
time
,
a
very
amiable
and
very
helpless
middle
-
aged
gentleman
,
who
was
going
out
again
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Necessarily
,
he
was
going
out
again
directly
,
because
the
Marshalsea
lock
never
turned
upon
a
debtor
who
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
brought
in
a
portmanteau
with
him
,
which
he
doubted
its
being
worth
while
to
unpack
;
he
was
so
perfectly
clear
---
like
all
the
rest
of
them
,
the
turnkey
on
the
lock
said
---
that
he
was
going
out
again
directly
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
shy
,
retiring
man
;
well
-
looking
,
though
in
an
effeminate
style
;
with
a
mild
voice
,
curling
hair
,
and
irresolute
hands
---
rings
upon
the
fingers
in
those
days
---
which
nervously
wandered
to
his
trembling
lip
a
hundred
times
in
the
first
half
-
hour
of
his
acquaintance
with
the
jail
.
 
<EOS>
His
principal
anxiety
was
about
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
,
sir
,
"
he
asked
the
turnkey
,
"
that
she
will
be
very
much
shocked
,
if
she
should
come
to
the
gate
to
-
morrow
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
gave
it
as
the
result
of
his
experience
that
some
of
'em
was
and
some
of
'em
was
n't
.
 
<EOS>
In
general
,
more
no
than
yes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
like
is
she
<EOS>
,
you
see
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
philosophically
asked
:
"
that
's
what
it
hinges
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
delicate
and
inexperienced
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
"
is
agen
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
so
little
used
to
go
out
alone
,
"
said
the
debtor
,
"
that
I
am
at
a
loss
to
think
how
she
will
ever
make
her
way
here
,
if
she
walks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
P'raps
,
"
quoth
the
turnkey
,
"
she
'll
take
a
ackney
coach
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
irresolute
fingers
went
to
the
trembling
lip
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
she
will
.
 
<EOS>
She
may
not
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
p'raps
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
offering
his
suggestions
from
the
the
top
of
his
well
-
worn
wooden
stool
,
as
he
might
have
offered
them
to
a
child
for
whose
weakness
he
felt
a
compassion
,
"
p'raps
she
'll
get
her
brother
,
or
her
sister
,
to
come
along
with
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
has
no
brother
or
sister
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Niece
,
nevy
,
cousin
,
serwant
,
young
"
ooman
,
greengrocer
.
<EOS>
---
Dash
it
!
   
<EOS>
One
or
another
on
'
em
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
repudiating
beforehand
the
refusal
of
all
his
suggestions
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
---
<EOS>
I
hope
it
is
not
against
the
rules
---
that
she
will
bring
the
children
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
children
?
"
said
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
rules
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
lord
set
you
up
like
a
corner
pin
,
we
've
a
reg'lar
playground
o
'
children
here
.
 
<EOS>
Children
!
 
<EOS>
Why
we
swarm
with
'em
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
a
you
got
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Two
,
"
said
the
debtor
,
lifting
his
irresolute
hand
to
his
lip
again
,
and
turning
into
the
prison
.
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
followed
him
with
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
another
<EOS>
,
"
he
observed
to
himself
,
"
which
makes
three
on
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
your
wife
another
,
I
'll
lay
a
crown
.
 
<EOS>
Which
makes
four
on
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
another
coming
,
I
'll
lay
half
-
a
-
crown
.
 
<EOS>
Which'll
make
five
on
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
go
another
seven
and
sixpence
to
name
which
is
the
helplessest
,
the
unborn
baby
or
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
right
in
all
his
particulars
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
next
day
with
a
little
boy
of
three
years
old
,
and
a
little
girl
of
two
,
and
he
stood
entirely
corroborated
.
   
<EOS>
"
Got
a
room
now
;
have
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
the
turnkey
asked
the
debtor
after
a
week
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
got
a
very
good
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any
little
sticks
a
coming
to
furnish
it
?
"
said
the
turnkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
expect
a
few
necessary
articles
of
furniture
to
be
delivered
by
the
carrier
,
this
afternoon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Missis
and
little
<EOS>
"
uns
a
coming
to
keep
you
company
?
"
asked
the
turnkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
we
think
it
better
that
we
should
not
be
scattered
,
even
for
a
few
weeks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Even
for
a
few
weeks
,
OF
course
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
followed
him
again
with
his
eyes
,
and
nodded
his
head
seven
times
when
he
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
The
affairs
of
this
debtor
were
perplexed
by
a
partnership
,
of
which
he
knew
no
more
than
that
he
had
invested
money
in
it
;
by
legal
matters
of
assignment
and
settlement
,
conveyance
here
and
conveyance
there
,
suspicion
of
unlawful
preference
of
creditors
in
this
direction
,
and
of
mysterious
spiriting
away
of
property
in
that
;
and
as
nobody
on
the
face
of
the
earth
could
be
more
incapable
of
explaining
any
single
item
in
the
heap
of
confusion
than
the
debtor
himself
,
nothing
comprehensible
could
be
made
of
his
case
.
 
<EOS>
To
question
him
in
detail
,
and
endeavour
to
reconcile
his
answers
;
to
closet
him
with
accountants
and
sharp
practitioners
,
learned
in
the
wiles
of
insolvency
and
bankruptcy
;
was
only
to
put
the
case
out
at
compound
interest
and
incomprehensibility
.
 
<EOS>
The
irresolute
fingers
fluttered
more
and
more
ineffectually
about
the
trembling
lip
on
every
such
occasion
,
and
the
sharpest
practitioners
gave
him
up
as
a
hopeless
job
.
   
<EOS>
"
Out
?
"
said
the
turnkey
,
"
he
'll
never
get
out
,
unless
his
creditors
take
him
by
the
shoulders
and
shove
him
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
been
there
five
or
six
months
,
when
he
came
running
to
this
turnkey
one
forenoon
to
tell
him
,
breathless
and
pale
,
that
his
wife
was
ill
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
anybody
might
a
known
she
would
be
,
"
said
the
turnkey
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
intended
,
"
he
returned
,
"
that
she
should
go
to
a
country
lodging
only
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
do
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
good
heaven
,
what
am
I
to
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
waste
your
time
in
clasping
your
hands
and
biting
your
fingers
,
"
responded
the
practical
turnkey
,
taking
him
by
the
elbow
,
"
but
come
along
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
conducted
him
---
trembling
from
head
to
foot
,
and
constantly
crying
under
his
breath
,
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
!
 
<EOS>
while
his
irresolute
fingers
bedabbled
the
tears
upon
his
face
---
up
one
of
the
common
staircases
in
the
prison
to
a
door
on
the
garret
story
.
<EOS>
Upon
which
door
the
turnkey
knocked
with
the
handle
of
his
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
voice
inside
.
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
,
opening
the
door
,
disclosed
in
a
wretched
,
ill
-
smelling
little
room
,
two
hoarse
,
puffy
,
red
-
faced
personages
seated
at
a
rickety
table
,
playing
at
all
-
fours
,
smoking
pipes
,
and
drinking
brandy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
"
here
's
a
gentleman
's
wife
in
want
of
you
without
a
minute
's
loss
of
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
's
friend
was
in
the
positive
degree
of
hoarseness
,
puffiness
,
red
-
facedness
,
all
-
fours
,
tobacco
,
dirt
,
and
brandy
;
the
doctor
in
the
comparative
---
hoarser
,
puffier
,
more
red
-
faced
,
more
all
-
fourey
,
tobaccoer
,
dirtier
,
and
brandier
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
amazingly
shabby
,
in
a
torn
and
darned
rough
-
weather
sea
-
jacket
,
out
at
elbows
and
eminently
short
of
buttons
<EOS>
(
he
had
been
in
his
time
<EOS>
the
experienced
surgeon
carried
by
a
passenger
ship
)
,
the
dirtiest
white
trousers
conceivable
by
mortal
man
,
carpet
slippers
,
and
no
visible
linen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Childbed
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
the
boy
!
"
<EOS>
With
that
the
doctor
took
a
comb
from
the
chimney
-
piece
and
stuck
his
hair
upright
---
which
appeared
to
be
his
way
of
washing
himself
---
produced
a
professional
chest
or
case
,
of
most
abject
appearance
,
from
the
cupboard
where
his
cup
and
saucer
and
coals
were
,
settled
his
chin
in
the
frowsy
wrapper
round
his
neck
,
and
became
a
ghastly
medical
scarecrow
.
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
and
the
debtor
ran
down
-
stairs
,
leaving
the
turnkey
to
return
to
the
lock
,
and
made
for
the
debtor
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
ladies
in
the
prison
had
got
hold
of
the
news
,
and
were
in
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
had
already
taken
possession
of
the
two
children
,
and
were
hospitably
carrying
them
off
;
others
were
offering
loans
of
little
comforts
from
their
own
scanty
store
;
others
were
sympathising
with
the
greatest
volubility
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
prisoners
,
feeling
themselves
at
a
disadvantage
,
had
for
the
most
part
retired
,
not
to
say
sneaked
,
to
their
rooms
;
from
the
open
windows
of
which
some
of
them
now
complimented
the
doctor
with
whistles
as
he
passed
below
,
while
others
,
with
several
stories
between
them
,
interchanged
sarcastic
references
to
the
prevalent
excitement
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
hot
summer
day
,
and
the
prison
rooms
were
baking
between
the
high
walls
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
debtor
's
confined
chamber
,
Mrs
Bangham
,
charwoman
and
messenger
,
who
was
not
a
prisoner
(
though
she
had
been
once
)
,
but
was
the
popular
medium
of
communication
with
the
outer
world
,
had
volunteered
her
services
as
fly
-
catcher
and
general
attendant
.
 
<EOS>
The
walls
and
ceiling
were
blackened
with
flies
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bangham
,
expert
in
sudden
device
,
with
one
hand
fanned
the
patient
with
a
cabbage
leaf
,
and
with
the
other
set
traps
of
vinegar
and
sugar
in
gallipots
;
at
the
same
time
enunciating

<EOS>
His

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

-

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
So

to
call
him
;
and
so
he
was
,
if
more
than
twenty
years
of
residence
gave
him
a
claim
to
the
title
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
small
at
first
,
but
there
was
very
good
company
there
---
among
a
mixture
---
necessarily
a
mixture
---
and
very
good
air
.
   
<EOS>
It
became
a
not
unusual
circumstance
for
letters
to
be
put
under
his
door
at
night
,
enclosing
half
-
a
-
crown
,
two
half
-

,
now
and
then
at
long

even
half
-
a
-
sovereign
,
for
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
the
compliments
of
a
collegian
taking
leave
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
received
the
gifts
as
tributes
,
from
admirers
,
to
a
public
character
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
these
correspondents
assumed
facetious
names
,
as
the
Brick
,
Bellows
,
Old
Gooseberry
,
Wideawake
,
Snooks
,
Mops
,
Cutaway
,
the
Dogs
-
meat
Man
;
but
he
considered
this
in
bad
taste
,
and
was
always
a
little
hurt
by
it
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
fulness
of
time
,
this
correspondence
showing
signs
of
wearing
out
,
and
seeming
to
require
an

on
the

of
the

to
which
in

many

might

equal

the
custom
of
attending
collegians
of
a
certain
standing
,
to
the
gate
,
and
taking
leave

there
.
 
<EOS>
The
collegian
under
treatment
,
after
shaking
hands
,
would
occasionally
stop
to
wrap
up
something
in
a
bit

paper
,
and
would
come
back
again
calling
"
Hi
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
look
round
surprised
.
<EOS>
"
Me
?
<EOS>
"
he
would
say
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
collegian
would
be
up
with
him
,
and
he
would
paternally
add
,
"
What
have
you

?
 
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
forgot
to
leave
this
,
"
the
collegian
would
usually
return
,
"
for
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
sir
,
"
he
would
rejoin
,
"
he
is
infinitely

to
you
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
to
the
last
,
the
irresolute
hand
of
old
would
remain
in
the
pocket
into
which
he
had
slipped
the
money
during
two

three

about
the
yard
,
lest
the
transaction
should
be
too

to
the

.
   
<EOS>
One

he
had

the
place

a

,

who
had

for
a
small

a

before
,
had
"
settled
"
in

,

was

.
<EOS>
The
man
was
a
mere
Plasterer
in

;
had

,

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
God

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
,
"
benignantly

Father

.
   
<EOS>
They

,

,

"
I

!
<EOS>
---
sir
!
"
and
came

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ai

,
"

,

,
"
but
<EOS>
it
's
well
meant
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
had
never
been
offered
tribute
in
copper
yet
.
 
<EOS>
His
children
often
had
,
and
with
his
perfect

it
had
gone
into
the
common

to
buy

that
he
had
eaten
,

that
he

;
but
fustian
splashed
with

,
bestowing
halfpence
on

,
front

,
was
new
.
   
<EOS>
"
How

!
"
<EOS>
he
said
to
the
man
,
and
feebly

.
   
<EOS>
The
Plasterer
turned
him
towards
the
wall
,
that
his

might
not

;
and
the

so

,
and
the

was
so

,
and

,
that
he

than
,
"
I
know
you
meant
it

.
 
<EOS>
Say

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
soul
,
sir
,
"
urged

,
"
I
did
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
do
more
by
you
than
the
rest

'em
do
,
I
fancy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'd

back

,

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Give

,
"
said

,

,
"
and
I
'll

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thank

for

,
thank

!
 
<EOS>
I
shall

you
again
?
"
<EOS>
"
If
I
live
a
week
you
shall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
shook
hands
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
collegians
,
assembled
in
Symposium
in
the
Snuggery
that
night
,
marvelled
what
had
happened
to
their
Father
;
he
walked
so
late
in
the
shadows
of
the
yard
,
and
seemed
so
downcast
.
    
Chapter
07
.
<EOS>
The
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
 
<EOS>
The
baby
whose
first
draught
of
air
had
been
tinctured
with
Doctor
Haggage
's
brandy
,
was
handed
down
among
the
generations
of
collegians
,
like
the
tradition
of
their
common
parent
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
earlier
stages
of
her
existence
,
she
was
handed
down
in
a
literal
and
prosaic
sense
;
it
being
almost
a
part
of
the
entrance
footing
of
every
new
collegian
to
nurse
the
child
who
had
been
born
in
the
college
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
rights
,
"
remarked
the
turnkey
when
she
was
first
shown
to
him
,
"
I
ought
to
be
her
godfather
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
debtor
irresolutely
thought
of
it
for
a
minute
,
and
said
,
"
Perhaps
you
would
n't
object
to
really
being
her
godfather
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
\I\
do
n't
object
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
,
"
if
you
do
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
it
came
to
pass
that
she
was
christened
one
Sunday
afternoon
,
when
the
turnkey
,
being
relieved
,
was
off
the
lock
;
and
that
the
turnkey
went
up
to
the
font
of
Saint
George
's
Church
,
and
promised
and
vowed
and
renounced
on
her
behalf
,
as
he
himself
related
when
he
came
back
,
"
like
a
good
'
un
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
invested
the
turnkey
with
a
new
proprietary
share
in
the
child
,
over
and
above
his
former
official
one
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
began
to
walk
and
talk
,
he
became
fond
of
her
;
bought
a
little
arm
-
chair
and
stood
it
by
the
high
fender
of
the
lodge
fire
-
place
;
liked
to
have
her
company
when
he
was
on
the
lock
;
and
used
to
bribe
her
with
cheap
toys
to
come
and
talk
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
,
for
her
part
,
soon
grew
so
fond
of
the
turnkey
that
she
would
come
climbing
up
the
lodge
-
steps
of
her
own
accord
at
all
hours
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
fell
asleep
in
the
little
armchair
by
the
high
fender
,
the
turnkey
would
cover
her
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
and
when
she
sat
in
it
dressing
and
undressing
a
doll
which
soon
came
to
be
unlike
dolls
on
the
other
side
of
the
lock
,
and
to
bear
a
horrible
family
resemblance
to
Mrs
Bangham
---
he
would
contemplate
her
from
the
top
of
his
stool
with
exceeding
gentleness
.
 
<EOS>
Witnessing
these
things
,
the
collegians
would
express
an
opinion
that
the
turnkey
,
who
was
a
bachelor
,
had
been
cut
out
by
nature
for
a
family
man
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
turnkey
thanked
them
,
and
said
,
"
No
,
on
the
whole
it
was
enough
to
see
other
people
's
children
there
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
what
period
of
her
early
life
the
little
creature
began
to
perceive
that
it
was
not
the
habit
of
all
the
world
to
live
locked
up
in
narrow
yards
surrounded
by
high
walls
with
spikes
at
the
top
,
would
be
a
difficult
question
to
settle
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
was
a
very
,
very
little
creature
indeed
,
when
she
had
somehow
gained
the
knowledge
that
her
clasp
of
her
father
's
hand
was
to
be
always
loosened
at
the
door
which
the
great
key
opened
;
and
that
while
her
own
light
steps
were
free
to
pass
beyond
it
,
his
feet
must
never
cross
that
line
.
 
<EOS>
A
pitiful
and
plaintive
look
,
with
which
she
had
begun
to
regard
him
when
she
was
still
extremely
young
,
was
perhaps
a
part
of
this
discovery
.
   
<EOS>
With
a
pitiful
and
plaintive
look
for
everything
,
indeed
,
but
with
something
in
it
for
only
him
that
was
like
protection
,
this
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
and
the
child
of
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
sat
by
her
friend
the
turnkey
in
the
lodge
,
kept

family
room
,
or
wandered
about
the
prison
-

,
for
the
first
eight

her
life
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
pitiful
and
plaintive
look
for
her
wayward
sister
;
for
her
idle

;
for
the
high
blank

;
for
the
faded
crowd
they
shut
in
;
for
the
games
of
the
prison
children
as
they
whooped
and
ran
,
and
played
at
hide
-
and
-
seek
,
and
made
the
iron
bars
of
the
inner
gateway
"
Home
.
"
   
Wistful
and
wondering
,
she
would
sit
in
summer
weather
by
the
high
fender
in
the
lodge
,
looking
up
at
the
sky
through
the
barred
window
,
until
,
when
she
turned
her
eyes
away
,
bars
of
light
would
arise
between
her
and
her
friend
,
and
she
would
see
him
through
a
grating
,
too
.
<EOS>
"
Thinking
of
the
fields
,
"
the
turnkey
said
once
,
after
watching
her
,
"
ai
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
she
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
they
're
---
over
there
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
with
a

his
key
.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
about
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
anybody
open
them
,
and
shut

?
 
<EOS>
Are
they
locked
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
was
discomfited
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
general
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
very
pretty
,
Bob
?
"
 
<EOS>
She
called
him
Bob
,
by
his
own
particular
request
and
instruction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lovely
.
 
<EOS>
Full
of
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
buttercups
,
and
there
's
daisies
,
and
there
's
"
---
the
turnkey
hesitated
,
being
short
of
floral
nomenclature
<EOS>
---
"
there
's
dandelions
,
and
all

games
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
very
pleasant
to
be
there
,
Bob
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Prime
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
father

there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
"
coughed

turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
O

,
he
was
there
,
sometimes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he

to

there

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
not
particular
,
"
said
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
any
of
the
people
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
glancing
at
the
listless
crowd
within
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
are
you
quite
sure
and
certain
,
Bob
?
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
difficult
point
of
the
conversation
Bob
gave
in
,
and
changed
the
subject
to
hard
-
bake
:
always
his
last
resource
when
he
found
his
little
friend
getting
him
into
a
political
,
social
,
or
theological
corner
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
was
the
origin
of
a
series
of
Sunday
excursions
that
these
two
curious
companions
made
together
.
 
<EOS>
They
used
to
issue
from
the
lodge
on
alternate
Sunday
afternoons
with
great
gravity
,
bound
for
some
meadows
or
green
lanes
that
had
been
elaborately
appointed
by
the
turnkey
in
the
course
of
the
week
;
and
there
she
picked
grass
and
flowers
to
bring
home
,
while
he
smoked
his
pipe
.
 
<EOS>
Afterwards
,
there
were
tea
-
gardens
,
shrimps
,
ale
,
and
other
delicacies
;
and
then
they
would
come
back
hand
in
hand
,
unless
she
was
more
than
usually
tired
,
and
had
fallen
asleep
on
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
In
those
early
days
,
the
turnkey
first
began
profoundly
to
consider
a
question
which
cost
him
so
much
mental
labour
,
that
it
remained
undetermined
on
the
day
of
his
death
.
 
<EOS>
He
decided
to
will
and
bequeath
his
little
property
of
savings
to
his
godchild
,
and
the
point
arose
how
could
it
be
so
"
tied
up
"
as
that
only
she
should
have
the
benefit
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
His
experience
on
the
lock
gave
him
such
an
acute
perception
of
the
enormous
difficulty
of
"
tying
up
"
money
with
any
approach
to
tightness
,
and
contrariwise
of
the
remarkable
ease
with
which
it
got
loose
,
that
through
a
series
of
years
he
regularly
propounded
this
knotty
point
to
every
new
insolvent
agent
and
other
professional
gentleman
who
passed
in
and
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Supposing
,
"
he
would
say
,
stating
the
case
with
his
key
on
the
professional
gentleman
's
waistcoat
;
"
supposing
a
man
wanted
to
leave
his
property
to
a
young
female
,
and
wanted
to
tie
it
up
so
that
nobody
else
should
ever
be
able
to
make
a
grab
at
it
;
how
would
you
tie
up
that
property
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Settle
it
strictly
on
herself
,
"
the
professional
gentleman
would
complacently
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
look
here
,
"
quoth
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Supposing
she
had
,
say
a
brother
,
say
a
father
,
say
a
husband
,
who
would
be
likely
to
make
a
grab
at
that
property
when
she
came
into
it
---
how
about
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
settled
on
herself
,
and
they
would
have
no
more
legal
claim
on
it
than
you
,
"
would
be
the
professional
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
bit
,
"
said
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Supposing
<EOS>
she
was
tender
-
hearted
,
and
they
came
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
your
law
for
tying
it
up
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
deepest
character
whom
the
turnkey
sounded
,
was
unable
to
produce
his
law
for
tying
such
a
knot
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
the
turnkey
thought
about
it
all
his
life
,
and
died
intestate
after
all
.
   
<EOS>
But
that
was
long
afterwards
,
when
his
god
-
daughter
was
past
sixteen
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
half
of
that
space
of
her
life
was
only
just
accomplished
,
when
her
pitiful
and
plaintive
look
saw
her
father
a
widower
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
time
the
protection
that
her
wondering
eyes
had
expressed
towards
him
,
became
embodied
in
action
,
and
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
took
upon
herself
a
new
relation
towards
the
Father
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
,
such
a
baby
could
do
little
more
than
sit
with
him
,
deserting
her
livelier
place
by
the
high
fender
,
and
quietly
watching
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
made
her
so
far
necessary
to
him
that
he
became
accustomed
to
her
,
and
began
to
be
sensible
of
missing
her
when
she
was
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
Through
this
little
gate
,
she
passed
out
of
childhood
into
the
care
-
laden
world
.
   
<EOS>
What
her
pitiful
look
saw
,
at
that
early
time
,
in
her
father
,
in
her
sister
,
in
her
brother
,
in
the
jail
;
how
much
,
or
how
little
of
the
wretched
truth
it
pleased
God
to
make
visible
to
her
;
lies
hidden
with
many
mysteries
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
that
she
was
inspired
to
be
something
which
was
not
what
the
rest
were
,
and
to
be
that
something
,
different
and
laborious
,
for
the
sake
of
the
rest
.
<EOS>
Inspired
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
we
speak
of
the
inspiration
of
a
poet
or
a
priest
,
and
not
of
the
heart
<EOS>
impelled
by
love
and
self
-
devotion
to
the
lowliest
work
in
the
lowliest
way
of
life
!
   
<EOS>
With
no
earthly
friend
to
help
her
,
or
so
much
as
to
see
her
,
but
the
one
so
strangely
assorted
;
with
no
knowledge
even
of
the
common
daily
tone
and
habits
of
the
common
members
of
the
free
community
who
are
not
shut
up
in
prisons
;
born
and
bred
in
a
social
condition
,
false
even
with
a
reference
to
the
falsest
condition
outside
the
walls
;
drinking
from
infancy
of
a
well
whose
waters
had
their
own
peculiar
stain
,
their
own
unwholesome
and
unnatural
taste
;
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
began
her
womanly
life
.
   
<EOS>
No
matter
through
what
mistakes
and
discouragements
,
what
ridicule
(
not
unkindly
meant
,
but
deeply
felt
)
of
her
youth
and
little
figure
,
what
humble
consciousness
of
her
own
babyhood
and
want
of
strength
,
even
in
the
matter
of
lifting
and
carrying
;
through
how
much
weariness
and
hopelessness
,
and
how
many
secret
tears
;
she
drudged
on
,
until
recognised
as
useful
,
even
indispensable
.
 
<EOS>
That
time
came
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
the
place
of
eldest
of
the
three
,
in
all
things
but
precedence
;
was
the
head
of
the
fallen
family
;
and
bore
,
in
her
own
heart
,
its
anxieties
and
shames
.
   
<EOS>
At
thirteen
,
she
could
read
and
keep
accounts
,
that
is
,
could
put
down
in
words
and
figures
how
much
the
bare
necessaries
that
they
wanted
would
cost
,
and
how
much
less
they
had
to
buy
them
with
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
,
by
snatches
of
a
few
weeks
at
a
time
,
to
an
evening
school
outside
,
and
got
her
sister
and
brother
sent
to
day
-
schools
by
desultory
starts
,
during
three
or
four
years
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
instruction
for
any
of
them
at
home
;
but
she
knew
well
---
no
one
better
---
that
a
man
so
broken
as
to
be
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
could
be
no
father
to
his
own
children
.
   
<EOS>
To
these
scanty
means
of
improvement
,
she
added
another
of
her
own
contriving
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
among
the
heterogeneous
crowd
of
inmates
there
appeared
a
dancing
-
master
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
had
a
great
desire
to
learn
the
dancing
-
master
's
art
,
and
seemed
to
have
a
taste
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
At
thirteen
years
old
,
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
presented
herself
to
the
dancing
-
master
,
with
a
little
bag
in
her
hand
,
and
preferred
her
humble
petition
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
please
,
I
was
born
here
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
young
lady
,
are
you
?
"
said
the
dancing
-
master
,
surveying
the
small
figure
and
uplifted
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
can
I
do
for
you
?
"
said
the
dancing
-
master
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
for
me
,
sir
,
thank
you
,
"
anxiously
undrawing
the
strings
of
the
little
bag
;
"
but
if
,
while
you
stay
here
,
you
could
be
so
kind
as
to
teach
my
sister
<EOS>
cheap
---
"
   
"
My
child
,
I
'll
teach
her
for
nothing
,
"
said
the
dancing
-
master
,
shutting
up
the
bag
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
good
-
natured
a
dancing
-
master
as
ever
danced
to
the
Insolvent
Court
,
and
he
kept
his
word
.
 
<EOS>
The
sister
was
so
apt
a
pupil
,
and
the
dancing
-
master
had
such
abundant
leisure
to
bestow
upon
her
<EOS>
(
for
it
took
him
a
matter
of
ten
weeks
to
set
to
his
creditors
,
lead
off
,
turn
the
Commissioners
,
and
right
and
left
back
to
his
professional
pursuits
)
,
that
wonderful
progress
was
made
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
the
dancing
-
master
was
so
proud
of
it
,
and
so
wishful
to
display
it
before
he
left
to
a
few
select
friends
among
the
collegians
,
that
at
six
o'clock
on
a
certain
fine
morning
,
a
minuet
de
la
cour
came
off
in
the
yard
---
the
college
-
rooms
being
of
too
confined
proportions
for
the
purpose
---
in
which
so
much
ground
was
covered
,
and
the
steps
were
so
conscientiously
executed
,
that
the
dancing
-
master
,
having
to
play
the
kit
besides
,
was
thoroughly
blown
.
   
<EOS>
The
success
of
this
beginning
,
which
led
to
the
dancing
-
master
's
continuing
his
instruction
after
his
release
,
emboldened
the
poor
child
to
try
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
watched
and
waited
months
for
a
seamstress
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
fulness
of
time
a
milliner
came
in
,
and
to
her
she
repaired
on
her
own
behalf
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
ma'am
,
"
she
said
,
looking
timidly
round
the
door
of
the
milliner
,
whom
she
found
in
tears
and
in
bed
:
"
<EOS>
but
I
was
born
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Everybody
seemed
to
hear
of
her
as
soon
as
they
arrived
;
for
the
milliner
sat
up
in
bed
,
drying
her
eyes
,
and
said
,
just
as
the
dancing
-
master
had
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
child
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
I
have
n't
got
anything
for
you
,
"
said
the
milliner
,
shaking
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
that
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
please
I
want
to
learn
needle
-
work
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
do
that
,
"
returned
the
milliner
,
"
with
me
before
you
?
 
<EOS>
It
has
not
done
me
much
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
---
whatever
it
is
---
seems
to
have
done
anybody
much
good
who
comes
here
,
"
she
returned
in
all
simplicity
;
"
but
I
want
to
learn
just
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
you
are
so
weak
,
you
see
,
"
the
milliner
objected
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
am
weak
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
are
so
very
,
very
little
,
you
see
,
"
the
milliner
objected
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
afraid
I
am
very
little
indeed
,
"
returned
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
;
and
so
began
to
sob
over
that
unfortunate
defect
of
hers
,
which
came
so
often
in
her
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
milliner
---
who
was
not
morose
or
hard
-
hearted
,
only
newly
insolvent
---
was
touched
,
took
her
in
hand
with
goodwill
,
found
her
the
most
patient
and
earnest
of
pupils
,
and
made
her
a
cunning
work
-
woman
in
course
of
time
.
   
<EOS>
In
course
of
time
,
and
in
the
very
self
-
same
course
of
time
,
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
gradually
developed
a
new
flower
of
character
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
Fatherly
he
grew
as
to
the
Marshalsea
,
and
the
more
dependent
he
became
on
the
contributions
of
his
changing
family
,
the
greater
stand
he
made
by
his
forlorn
gentility
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
same
hand
that
he
pocketed
a
collegian
's
half
-
crown
half
an
hour
ago
,
he
would
wipe
away
the
tears
that
streamed
over
his
cheeks
if
any
reference
were
made
to
his
daughters
'
earning
their
bread
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
over
and
above
other
daily
cares
,
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
had
always
upon
her
the
care
of
preserving
the
genteel
fiction
that
they
were
all
idle
beggars
together
.
   
<EOS>
The
sister
became
a
dancer
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
ruined
uncle
in
the
family
group
---
ruined
by
his
brother
,
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
and
knowing
no
more
how
than
his
ruiner
did
,
but
accepting
the
fact
as
an
inevitable
certainty
---
on
whom
her
protection
devolved
.
<EOS>
Naturally
a
retired
and
simple
man
,
he
had
shown
no
particular
sense
of
being
ruined
at
the
time
when
that
calamity
fell
upon
him
,
further
than
that
he
left
off
washing
himself
when
the
shock
was
announced
,
and
never
took
to
that
luxury
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
very
indifferent
musical
amateur
in
his
better
days
;
and
when
he
fell
with
his
brother
,
resorted
for
support
to
playing
a
clarionet
as
dirty
as
himself
in
a
small
Theatre
Orchestra
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
theatre
in
which
his
niece
became
a
dancer
;
he
had
been
a
fixture
there
a
long
time
when
she
took
her
poor
station
in
it
;
and
he
accepted
the
task
of
serving
as
her
escort
and
guardian
,
just
as
he
would
have
accepted
an
illness
,
a
legacy
,
a
feast
,
starvation
---
anything
but
soap
.
   
<EOS>
To
enable
this
girl
to
earn
her
few
weekly
shillings
,
it
was
necessary
for
the
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
to
go
through
an
elaborate
form
with
the
Father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
is
not
going
to
live
with
us
just
now
,
father
.
 
<EOS>
She
will
be
here
a
good
deal
in
the
day
,
but
she
is
going
to
live
outside
with
uncle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
Why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
uncle
wants
a
companion
,
father
.
 
<EOS>
He
should
be
attended
to
,
and
looked
after
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
companion
?
 
<EOS>
He
passes
much
of
his
time
here
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
attend
to
him
and
look
after
him
,
Amy
,
a
great
deal
more
than
ever
your
sister
will
.
 
<EOS>
You
all
go
out
so
much
;
you
all
go
out
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
to
keep
up
the
ceremony
and
pretence
of
his
having
no
idea
that
Amy
herself
went
out
by
the
day
to
work
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
always
glad
to
come
home
,
father
;
now
,
are
we
not
?
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
Fanny
,
perhaps
besides
keeping
uncle
company
and
taking
care
of
him
,
it
may
be
as
well
for
her
not
quite
to
live
here
,
always
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
born
here
as
I
was
,
you
know
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Amy
,
<EOS>
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
quite
follow
you
,
but
it
's
natural
<EOS>
I
suppose
that
Fanny
should
prefer
to
be
outside
,
and
even
that
you
often
should
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
you
and
Fanny
and
your
uncle
,
my
dear
,
shall
have
your
own
way
.
 
<EOS>
Good
,
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not
meddle
;
do
n't
mind
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
get
her
brother
out
of
the
prison
;
out
of
the
succession
to
Mrs
Bangham
in
executing
commissions
,
and
out
of
the
slang
interchange
with
very
doubtful
companions
consequent
upon
both
;
was
her
hardest
task
.
 
<EOS>
At
eighteen
he
would
have
dragged
on
from
hand
to
mouth
,
from
hour
to
hour
,
from
penny
to
penny
,
until
eighty
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
got
into
the
prison
from
whom
he
derived
anything
useful
or
good
,
and
she
could
find
no
patron
for
him
but
her
old
friend
and
godfather
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Bob
,
"
said
she
,
"
what
is
to
become
of
poor
Tip
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His
name
was
Edward
,
and
Ted
had
been
transformed
into
Tip
,
within
the
walls
.
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
had
strong
private
opinions
as
to
what
would
become
of
poor
Tip
,
and
had
even
gone
so
far
with
the
view
of
averting
their
fulfilment
,
as
to
sound
Tip
in
reference
to
the
expediency
of
running
away
and
going
to
serve
his
country
.
 
<EOS>
But
Tip
had
thanked
him
,
and
said
he
did
n't
seem
to
care
for
his
country
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
"
something
ought
to
be
done
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
I
try
and
get
him
into
the
law
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
so
good
of
you
,
Bob
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
turnkey
had
now
two
points
to
put
to
the
professional
gentlemen
as
they
passed
in
and
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
this
second
one
so
perseveringly
that
a
stool
and
twelve
shillings
a
week
were
at
last
found
for
Tip
in
the
office
of
an
attorney
in
a
great
National
Palladium
called
the
Palace
Court
;
at
that
time
one
of
a
considerable
list
of
everlasting
bulwarks
to
the
dignity
and
safety
of
Albion
,
whose
places
know
them
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Tip
languished
in
Clifford
's
Inns
for
six
months
,
and
at
the
expiration
of
that
term
sauntered
back
one
evening
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
incidentally
observed
to
his
sister
that
he
was
not
going
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
going
back
again
?
"
said
the
poor
little
anxious
Child
of
the
Marshalsea
,
always
calculating
and
planning
for
Tip
,
in
the
front
rank
of
her
charges
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
tired
of
it
,
"
said
Tip
,
"
that
I
have
cut
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tip
tired
of
everything
.
 
<EOS>
With
intervals
of
Marshalsea
lounging
,
and
Mrs
Bangham
succession
,
his
small
second
mother
,
aided
by
her
trusty
friend
,
got
him
into
a
warehouse
,
into
a
market
garden
,
into
the
hop
trade
,
into
the
law
again
,
into
an
auctioneers
,
into
a
brewery
,
into
a
stockbroker
's
,
into
the
law
again
,
into
a
coach
office
,
into
a
waggon
office
,
into
the
law
again
,
into
a
general
dealer
's
,
into
a
distillery
,
into
the
law
again
,
into
a
wool
house
,
into
a
dry
goods
house
,
into
the
Billingsgate
trade
,
into
the
foreign
fruit
trade
,
and
into
the
docks
.
 
<EOS>
But
whatever
Tip
went
into
,
he
came
out
of
tired
,
announcing
that
he
had
cut
it
.
<EOS>
Wherever
he
went
,
this
foredoomed
Tip
appeared
to
take
the
prison
walls
with
him
,
and
to
set
them
up
in
such
trade
or
calling
;
and
to
prowl
about
within
their
narrow
limits
in
the
old
slip
-
shod
,
purposeless
,
down
-
at
-
heel
way
;
until
the
real
immovable
Marshalsea
walls
asserted
their
fascination
over
him
,
and
brought
him
back
.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
the
brave
little
creature
did
so
fix
her
heart
on
her
brother
's
rescue
,
that
while
he
was
ringing
out
these
doleful
changes
,
she
pinched
and
scraped
enough
together
to
ship
him
for
Canada
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
tired
of
nothing
to
do
,
and
disposed
in
its
turn
to
cut
even
that
,
he
graciously
consented
to
go
to
Canada
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
grief
in
her
bosom
over
parting
with
him
,
and
joy
in
the
hope
of
his
being
put
in
a
straight
course
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
dear
Tip
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
too
proud
to
come
and
see
us
,
when
you
have
made
your
fortune
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
!
"
said
Tip
,
and
went
.
   
<EOS>
But
not
all
the
way
to
Canada
;
in
fact
,
not
further
than
Liverpool
.
   
<EOS>
After
making
the
voyage
to
that
port
from
London
,
he
found
himself
so
strongly
impelled
to
cut
the
vessel
,
that
he
resolved
to
walk
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
Carrying
out
which
intention
,
he
presented
himself
before
her
at
the
expiration
of
a
month
,
in
rags
,
without
shoes
,
and
much
more
tired
than
ever
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
another
interval
of
successorship
to
Mrs
Bangham
,
he
found
a
pursuit
for
himself
,
and
announced
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
I
have
got
a
situation
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
really
and
truly
,
Tip
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
do
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
look
anxious
about
me
any
more
,
old
girl
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
Tip
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
know
Slingo
by
sight
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
the
man
they
call
the
dealer
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
chap
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
be
out
on
Monday
,
and
he
's
going
to
give
me
a
berth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
he
a
dealer
in
,
Tip
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Horses
.
 
<EOS>
All
right
!
 
<EOS>
I
shall
do
now
,
Amy
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
lost
sight
of
him
for
months
afterwards
,
and
only
heard
from
him
once
.
 
<EOS>
A
whisper
passed
among
the
elder
collegians
that
he
had
been
seen
at
a
mock
auction
in
Moorfields
,
pretending
to
buy
plated
articles
for
massive
silver
,
and
paying
for
them
with
the
greatest
liberality
in
bank
notes
;
but
it
never
reached
her
ears
.
 
<EOS>
One
evening
she
was
alone
at
work
---
standing
up
at
the
window
,
to
save
the
twilight
lingering
above
the
wall
---
<EOS>
when
he
opened
the
door
and
walked
in
.
   
<EOS>
She
kissed
and
welcomed
him
;
but
was
afraid
to
ask
him
any
questions
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
how
anxious
and
timid
she
was
,
and
appeared
sorry
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
Amy
,
you
'll
be
vexed
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
life
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
to
hear
you
say
so
,
Tip
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
come
back
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
---
yes
.
"
   
"
Not
expecting
this
time
that
what
you
had
found
would
answer
very
well
,
I
am
less
surprised
and
sorry
than
I
might
have
been
,
Tip
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
not
the
worst
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
worst
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
look
so
startled
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
Amy
,
not
the
worst
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
back
,
you
see
;
but
---
DON'T
look
so
startled
<EOS>
---
I
have
come
back
in
what
I
may
call
a
new
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
off
the
volunteer
list
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
now
,
as
one
of
the
regulars
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
say
you
are
a
prisoner
,
Tip
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
,
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
want
to
say
it
,
"
he
returned
in
a
reluctant
tone
;
"
but
if
you
ca
n't
understand
me
without
my
saying
it
,
what
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
for
forty
pound
odd
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
in
all
those
years
,
she
sunk
under
her
cares
.
<EOS>
She
cried
,
with
her
clasped
hands
lifted
above
her
head
,
that
it
would
kill
their
father
if
he
ever
knew
it
;
and
fell
down
at
Tip
's
graceless
feet
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
easier
for
Tip
to
bring
her
to
her
senses
than
for
her
to
bring
him
to
understand
that
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
would
be
beside
himself
if
he
knew
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
The
thing
was
incomprehensible
to
Tip
,
and
altogether
a
fanciful
notion
.
 
<EOS>
He
yielded
to
it
in
that
light
only
,
when
he
submitted
to
her
entreaties
,
backed
by
those
of
his
uncle
and
sister
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
want
of
precedent
for
his
return
;
it
was
accounted
for
to
the
father
in
the
usual
way
;
and
the
collegians
,
with
a
better
comprehension
of
the
pious
fraud
than
Tip
,
supported
it
loyally
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
life
,
and
this
the
history
,
of
the
child
of
the
Marshalsea
at
twenty
-
two
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
still
surviving
attachment
to
the
one
miserable
yard
and
block
of
houses
as
her
birthplace
and
home
,
she
passed
to
and
fro
in
it
shrinkingly
now
,
with
a
womanly
consciousness
that
she
was
pointed
out
to
every
one
.
 
<EOS>
Since
she
had
begun
to
work
beyond
the
walls
,
she
had
found
it
necessary
to
conceal
where
she
lived
,
and
to
come
and
go
as
secretly
as
she
could
,
between
the
free
city
and
the
iron
gates
,
outside
of
which
she
had
never
slept
in
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
Her
original
timidity
had
grown
with
this
concealment
,
and
her
light
step
and
her
little
figure
shunned
the
thronged
streets
while
they
passed
along
them
.
   
<EOS>
Worldly
wise
in
hard
and
poor
necessities
,
she
was
innocent
in
all
things
else
.
 
<EOS>
Innocent
,
in
the
mist
through
which
she
saw
her
father
,
and
the
prison
,
and
the
turbid
living
river
that
flowed
through
it
and
flowed
on
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
life
,
and
this
the
history
,
of
Little
Dorrit
;
now
going
home
upon
a
dull
September
evening
,
observed
at
a
distance
by
Arthur
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
life
,
and
this
the
history
,
of
Little
Dorrit
;
turning
at
the
end
of
London
Bridge
,
recrossing
it
,
going
back
again
,
passing
on
to
Saint
George
's
Church
,
turning
back
suddenly
once
more
,
and
flitting
in
at
the
open
outer
gate
and
little
court
-
yard
of
the
Marshalsea
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
08
.
<EOS>
The
Lock
 
Arthur
Clennam
stood
in
the
street
,
waiting
to
ask
some
passer
-
by
what
place
that
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
suffered
a
few
people
to
pass
him
in
whose
face
there
was
no
encouragement
to
make
the
inquiry
,
and
still
stood
pausing
in
the
street
,
when
an
old
man
came
up
and
turned
into
the
courtyard
.
   
<EOS>
He
stooped
a
good
deal
,
and
plodded
along
in
a
slow
pre
-
occupied
manner
,
which
made
the
bustling
London
thoroughfares
no
very
safe
resort
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dirtily
and
meanly
dressed
,
in
a
threadbare
coat
,
once
blue
,
reaching
to
his
ankles
and
buttoned
to
his
chin
,
where
it
vanished
in
the
pale
ghost
of
a
velvet
collar
.
 
<EOS>
A
piece
of
red
cloth
with
which
that
phantom
had
been
stiffened
in
its
lifetime
was
now
laid
bare
,
and
poked
itself
up
,
at
the
back
of
the
old
man
's
neck
,
into
a
confusion
of
grey
hair
and
rusty
stock
and
buckle
which
altogether
nearly
poked
his
hat
off
.
 
<EOS>
A
greasy
hat
it
was
,
and
a
napless
;
impending
over
his
eyes
,
cracked
and
crumpled
at
the
brim
,
and
with
a
wisp
of
pocket
-
handkerchief
dangling
out
below
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
trousers
were
so
long
and
loose
,
and
his
shoes
so
clumsy
and
large
,
that
he
shuffled
like
an
elephant
;
though
how
much
of
this
was
gait
,
and
how
much
trailing
cloth
and
leather
,
no
one
could
have
told
.
 
<EOS>
Under
one
arm
he
carried
a
limp
and
worn
-
out
case
,
containing
some
wind
instrument
;
in
the
same
hand
he
had
a
pennyworth
of
snuff
in
a
little
packet
of
whitey
-
brown
paper
,
from
which
he
slowly
comforted
his
poor
blue
old
nose
with
a
lengthened
-
out
pinch
,
as
Arthur
Clennam
looked
at
him
.
<EOS>
To
this
old
man
crossing
the
court
-
yard
,
he
preferred
his
inquiry
,
touching
him
on
the
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
stopped
and
looked
round
,
with
the
expression
in
his
weak
grey
eyes
of
one
whose
thoughts
had
been
far
off
,
and
who
was
a
little
dull
of
hearing
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
sir
,
"
said
Arthur
,
repeating
his
question
,
"
what
is
this
place
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
 
<EOS>
This
place
?
"
returned
the
old
man
,
staying
his
pinch
of
snuff
on
its
road
,
and
pointing
at
the
place
without
looking
at
it
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
Marshalsea
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
debtors
'
prison
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
with
the
air
of
deeming
it
not
quite
necessary
to
insist
upon
that
designation
,
"
the
debtors
'
prison
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
turned
himself
about
,
and
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
said
Arthur
,
stopping
him
once
more
,
"
but
<EOS>
will
you
allow
me
to
ask
you
another
question
?
 
<EOS>
Can
any
one
go
in
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any
one
can
go
IN
,
"
replied
the
old
man
;
plainly
adding
by
the
significance
of
his
emphasis
,
"
but
it
is
not
every
one
who
can
go
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
familiar
with
the
place
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
squeezing
his
little
packet
of
snuff
in
his
hand
,
and
turning
upon
his
interrogator
as
if
such
questions
hurt
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
you
to
excuse
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
impertinently
curious
,
but
have
a
good
object
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
the
name
of
Dorrit
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
old
man
most
unexpectedly
,
"
is
Dorrit
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
pulled
off
his
hat
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Grant
me
the
favour
of
half
-
a
-
dozen
words
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
wholly
unprepared
for
your
announcement
,
and
hope
that
assurance
is
my
sufficient
apology
for
having
taken
the
liberty
of
addressing
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
recently
come
home
to
England
after
a
long
absence
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
at
my
mother
's
---
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
in
the
city
---
a
young
woman
working
at
her
needle
,
whom
I
have
only
heard
addressed
or
spoken
of
as
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
felt
sincerely
interested
in
her
,
and
have
had
a
great
desire
to
know
something
more
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
her
,
not
a
minute
before
you
came
up
,
pass
in
at
that
door
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
at
him
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
sailor
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
a
little
disappointed
by
the
shake
of
the
head
that
replied
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
sailor
?
 
<EOS>
I
judged
from
your
sunburnt
face
that
you
might
be
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
in
earnest
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
assure
you
that
I
am
,
and
do
entreat
you
to
believe
that
I
am
,
in
plain
earnest
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
very
little
of
the
world
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
other
,
who
had
a
weak
and
quavering
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
merely
passing
on
,
like
the
shadow
over
the
sun
-
dial
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
worth
no
man
's
while
to
mislead
me
;
it
would
really
be
too
easy
---
too
poor
a
success
,
to
yield
any
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
woman
whom
you
saw
go
in
here
is
my
brother
's
child
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
is
William
Dorrit
;
I
am
Frederick
.
<EOS>
You
say
you
have
seen
her
at
your
mother
's
<EOS>
(
I
know
your
mother
befriends
her
)
,
you
have
felt
an
interest
in
her
,
and
you
wish
to
know

she
does
here
.
 
<EOS>
Come
and
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
went
on
again
,
and
Arthur
accompanied
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
brother
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
pausing
on
the
step
and
slowly
facing
round
again
,
"
has
been
here
many
years
;
and
much
that
happens
even
among
ourselves
,
out
of
doors
,
is
kept
from
him
for
reasons
that
I
need
n't
enter
upon
now
.
 
<EOS>
Be
so
good
as
to
say
nothing
of
my
niece
's
working
at
her
needle
.
 
<EOS>
Be
so
good
as
to
say
nothing
that
goes
beyond
what
is
said
among
us
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
keep
within
our
bounds
,
you
can
not
well
be
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
Now
!
 
<EOS>
Come
and
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
followed
him
down
a
narrow
entry
,
at
the
end
of
which
a
key
was
turned
,
and
a
strong
door
was
opened
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
It
admitted
them
into
a
lodge
or
lobby
,
across
which
they
passed
,
and
so
through
another
door
and
a
grating
into
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
always
plodding
on
before
,
turned
round
,
in
his
slow
,
stiff
,
stooping
manner
,
when
they
came
to
the
turnkey
on
duty
,
as
if
to
present
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
The
turnkey
nodded
;
and
the
companion
passed
in
without
being
asked
whom
he
wanted
.
   
<EOS>
The
night
was
dark
;
and
the
prison
lamps
in
the
yard
,
and
the
candles
in
the
prison
windows
faintly
shining
behind
many
sorts
of
wry
old
curtain
and
blind
,
had
not
the
air
of
making
it
lighter
.
<EOS>
A
few
people
loitered
about
,
but
the
greater
part
of
the
population
was
within
doors
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
taking
the
right
-
hand
side
of
the
yard
,
turned
in
at
the
third
or
fourth
doorway
,
and
began
to
ascend
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
rather
dark
,
sir
,
but
you
will
not
find
anything
in
the
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
paused
for
a
moment
before
opening
a
door
on
the
second
story
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
sooner
turned
the
handle
than
the
visitor
saw
Little
Dorrit
,
and
saw
the
reason
of
her
setting
so
much
store
by
dining
alone
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
brought
the
meat
home
that
she
should
have
eaten
herself
,
and
was
already
warming
it
on
a
gridiron
over
the
fire
for
her
father
,
clad
in
an
old
grey
gown
and
a
black
cap
,
awaiting
his
supper
at
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
A
clean
cloth
was
spread
before
him
,
with
knife
,
fork
,
and
spoon
,
salt
-
cellar
,
pepper
-
box
,
glass
,
and
pewter
ale
-
pot
.
 
<EOS>
Such
zests
as
his
particular
little
phial
of
cayenne
pepper
and
his
pennyworth
of
pickles
in
a
saucer
,
were
not
wanting
.
   
<EOS>
She
started
,
coloured
deeply
,
and
turned
white
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
,
more
with
his
eyes
than
by
the
slight
impulsive
motion
of
his
hand
,
entreated
her
to
be
reassured
and
to
trust
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
found
this
gentleman
,
"
said
the
uncle
---
"
Mr
Clennam
,
William
,
son
of
Amy
's
friend
---
at
the
outer
gate
,
wishful
,
as
he
was
going
by
,
of
paying
his
respects
,
but
hesitating
whether
to
come
in
or
not
.
<EOS>
This
is
my
brother
William
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Arthur
,
very

,
"
that
my
respect
for
your
daughter
may
explain
and
justify
my
desire
to
be
presented
to
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
returned

,
rising
,
taking
his
cap
off
in
the
flat

hand
,
and
so
holding

,
ready
to
put

again
,
"
you
do
me
honour
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
welcome
,
sir
;
"
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Frederick
,
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
sit
down
,
Mr
Clennam
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
black
cap
on
again
as
he
had
taken
it
off
,
and
resumed
his
own
seat
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
wonderful
air
of
benignity
and
patronage
in
his
manner
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
the
ceremonies
with
which
he
received
the
collegians
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
welcome
to
the
Marshalsea
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
welcomed
many
gentlemen
to
these
walls
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
are
aware
<EOS>
---
my
daughter
Amy
may
have
mentioned
that
I
am
the
Father
of
this
place
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
so
I
have
understood
,
"
said
Arthur
,
dashing
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
I
dare
say
,
that
my
daughter
Amy
was
born
here
.
 
<EOS>
A
good
girl
,
sir
,
a
dear
girl
,
and
long
a
comfort
and
support
to

.
 
<EOS>
Amy
,
my
dear
,
put
this
dish
on
;
Mr
Clennam
will
excuse
the
primitive
customs
to
which
we
are
reduced
here
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
a
compliment
to
ask
you
if
you
would
do
me
the
honour
,
sir
,
to
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
returned
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
morsel
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
felt
himself
quite
lost
in
wonder
at
the
manner
of
the
man
,
and
that
the
probability
of
his
daughter
's
having
had

as
to
her

,
should
be
so

.
   
<EOS>
She
filled
his
glass
,
put
all
the
little
matters
on
the
table
ready
to
his
hand
,
and
then
sat
beside
him
while
he
ate

.
<EOS>
Evidently
in
observance
of
their
nightly
custom
,
she
put
some
bread
before
herself
,
and
touched
his
glass
with
her

;
but
Arthur
saw
she
was
troubled
and
took
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Her
look
at
her
father
,
half
admiring
him
and
proud
of
him
,
half
ashamed
for
him
,
all
devoted
and

,
went
to
his

heart
.
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
condescended
towards
his
brother
as
an
amiable
,
well
-
meaning
man
;
a
private
character
,
who
had
not
arrived

.
 
<EOS>
"
Frederick
,
"
said
he
,
"
you
and
Fanny
sup
at
your
lodgings
to
-
night
<EOS>
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
done
with
Fanny
,
Frederick
?
"
<EOS>
"
She
is
walking
with
Tip
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tip
---
as
you
may
know
---
is
my
son
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
a
little

,
and
difficult
to
settle
,
but
his
introduction
to
the
world
was
rather
"
---
he

,

---
"
a

.
 
<EOS>
Your

here
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
my
first
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
could
hardly
have
been
here
since
your

without
my

.
 
<EOS>
It
very
seldom
happens
that
anybody
---
of
any

-
any

---
comes
here
without

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
many

brother
,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
even

.
 
<EOS>
On
a

Sunday
in
term
time
,
it
is
quite
a
Levee
---
quite
a
Levee
.
 
<EOS>
Amy
,
my
dear
,
I
have
been
trying

the

Camberwell
who

me
last

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Frederick
,
do
you
remember
his
name
?
"
<EOS>
Frederick
doubted
if
he
had

.
 
<EOS>
No

could

that
Frederick
was
the
last

upon

to
put

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
"
said
his

,
"
the
gentleman
who
did
that

action
with
so

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Tush
!
 
<EOS>
The
name
has
quite

me
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
as
I
have
happened
to
mention
handsome
and
delicate
action
,
you
may
like
,
perhaps
,
to
know
what
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
,
"
said
Arthur
,
withdrawing
his

from
the
delicate
head
beginning
to
droop
and
the
pale

with
a
new

stealing
over

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
generous
,
and
shows
so
much
fine
feeling
,
that
it
is
almost
a
duty
to
mention
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
at
the
time
that
I
always
would
mention
it
on
every
suitable
occasion
,
without
regard
to
personal
sensitiveness
.
 
<EOS>
A
---
<EOS>
well
---
a
---
it
's
of
no
use
to
disguise
the
fact
---
you
must
know
,
Mr
Clennam
,
that
it
does
sometimes
occur
that
people
who
come
here
desire
to
offer
some
little
---
Testimonial
---
to
the
Father
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
To
see
her
hand
upon

arm
in

half
-

,
and
her
timid

turning

,
was
to
see
a
sad
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
"
he
went
on
in
a
low

,
agitated
,
and
clearing

every

;
"
sometimes
---
hem
---
<EOS>
it
takes
one
shape
and
sometimes
another
;
but
it
is
generally
---
ha
---
Money
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
,
<EOS>
I
can
not
but
confess
it
,
it
is
too
often
---
hem
---
acceptable
.
 
<EOS>
This
gentleman
that
I
refer
to
,
was
presented
to
me
,
Mr
Clennam
,
in
a
manner

gratifying
to
my
feelings
,
and
conversed
not
only
with
great
politeness
,
but
with
great
---
ahem
---
information
.
"
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
though
he
had
finished
his
supper
,
he
was
nervously
going
about
his
plate
with
his

and
fork
,
as
if
some
of
it
were
still
before

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
appeared
from
his
conversation
that
he
had
a
garden
,
though
he
was
delicate
of
mentioning
it
at
first
,
as
gardens
are
---
hem
---
are
not
accessible
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
came
out
,
through
my
admiring
a
very
fine

of
geranium
---
beautiful
cluster
of
geranium
to
be
sure
---
which
he
had
brought
from

.
 
<EOS>
On
my

notice
of
its
rich

,
he
showed

,

,
"
For
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
"
and

to

.
 
<EOS>
But
this
was
---
hem
---
not
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
a
particular
request
,
on
taking

,
that
I
would
remove
the

in
half

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
ha
---
I
did

;
and
I
found
that
it
contained
---
ahem
---
two
guineas
.
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
,
Mr
Clennam
,
I
have
received
---
hem
---
Testimonials
in
many
ways
,
and

many
