of
value
,
and
they
have
always
been
---
ha
---
unfortunately
acceptable
;
but
I
never
was
more
pleased
than
with
this
---
ahem
---
this
particular
Testimonial
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Arthur
was
in
the
act
of
saying
the
little
he
could
say
on
such
a
theme
,
when
a
bell
began
to
ring
,
and
footsteps
approached
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
pretty
girl
of
a
far
better
figure
and
much
more
developed
than
Little
Dorrit
,
though
looking
much
younger
in
the
face
when
the
two
were
observed
together
,
stopped
in
the
doorway
on
seeing
a
stranger
;
and
a
young
man
who
was
with
her
,
stopped
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
My
eldest
daughter
and
my
son
,
Mr
Clennam
.
<EOS>
The
bell
is
a
signal
for
visitors
to
retire
,
and
so
they
have
come
to
say
good
night
;
but
there
is
plenty
of
time
,
plenty
of
time
.
<EOS>
Girls
,
Mr
Clennam
will
excuse
any
household
business
you
may
have
together
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
,
I
dare
say
,
that
I
have
but
one
room
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
only
want
my
clean
dress
from
Amy
,
father
,
"
said
the
second
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
my
clothes
,
"
said
Tip
.
   
<EOS>
Amy
opened
a
drawer
in
an
old
piece
of
furniture
that
was
a
chest
of
drawers
above
and
a
bedstead
below
,
and
produced
two
little
bundles
,
which
she
handed
to
her
brother
and
sister
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mended
and
made
up
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Clennam
heard
the
sister
ask
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
To
which
Amy
answered
"
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
risen
now
,
and
took
the
opportunity
of
glancing
round
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
bare
walls
had
been
coloured
green
,
evidently
by
an
unskilled
hand
,
and
were
poorly
decorated
with
a
few
prints
.
 
<EOS>
The
window
was
curtained
,
and
the
floor
carpeted
;
and
there
were
shelves
and
pegs
,
and
other
such
conveniences
,
that
had
accumulated
in
the
course
of
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
close
,
confined
room
,
poorly
furnished
;
and
the
chimney
smoked
to
boot
,
or
the
tin
screen
at
the
top
of
the
fireplace
was
superfluous
;
but
constant
pains
and
care
had
made
it
neat
,
and
even
,
after
its
kind
,
comfortable
.
<EOS>
All
the
while
the
bell
was
ringing
,
and
the
uncle
was
anxious
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Fanny
,
come
,
Fanny
,
"
he
said
,
with
his
ragged
clarionet
case
under
his
arm
;
"
the
lock
,
child
,
the
lock
!
"
   
<EOS>
Fanny
bade
her
father
good
night
,
and
whisked
off
airily
.
 
<EOS>
Tip
had
already
clattered
down
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said
the
uncle
,
looking
back
as
he
shuffled
out
after
them
,
"
the
lock
,
sir
,
the
lock
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
had
two
things
to
do
before
he
followed
;
one
,
to
offer
his
testimonial
to
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
without
giving
pain
to
his
child
;
the
other
to
say
something
to
that
child
,
though
it
were
but
a
word
,
in
explanation
of
his
having
come
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
,
"
said
the
Father
,
"
to
see
you
down
-
stairs
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
slipped
out
after
the
rest
,
and
they
were
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
on
any
account
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
hurriedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
allow
me
to
---
"
chink
,
chink
,
chink
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said
the
Father
,
"
I
am
deeply
,
deeply
---
<EOS>
"
But
his
visitor
had
shut
up
his
hand
to
stop
the
clinking
,
and
had
gone
down
-
stairs
with
great
speed
.
   
<EOS>
He
saw
no
Little
Dorrit
on
his
way
down
,
or
in
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
two
or
three
stragglers
were
hurrying
to
the
lodge
,
and
he
was
following
,
when
he
caught
sight
of
her
in
the
doorway
of
the
first
house
from
the
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
back
hastily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
forgive
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
speaking
to
you
here
;
pray
forgive
me
for
coming
here
at
all
!
 
<EOS>
I
followed
you
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
so
,
that
I
might
endeavour
to
render
you
and
your
family
some
service
.
<EOS>
You
know
the
terms
on
which
I
and
my
mother
are
,
and
may
not
be
surprised
that
I
have
preserved
our
distant
relations
at
her
house
,
lest
I
should
unintentionally
make
her
jealous
,
or
resentful
,
or
do
you
any
injury
in
her
estimation
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
have
seen
here
,
in
this
short
time
,
has
greatly
increased
my
heartfelt
wish
to
be
a
friend
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
recompense
me
for
much
disappointment
if
I
could
hope
to
gain
your
confidence
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
scared
at
first
,
but
seemed
to
take
courage
while
he
spoke
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
speak
very
earnestly
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
---
<EOS>
but
I
wish
you
had
not
watched
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
understood
the
emotion
with
which
she
said
it
,
to
arise
in
her
father
's
behalf
;
and
he
respected
it
,
and
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Clennam
has
been
of
great
service
to
me
;
I
do
n't
know
what
we
should
have
done
without
the
employment
she
has
given
me
;
I
am
afraid
it
may
not
be
a
good
return
to
become
secret
with
her
;
I
can
say
no
more
to
-
night
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
mean
to
be
kind
to
us
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
thank
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
Let
me
ask
you
one
question
before
I
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
known
my
mother
long
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
two
years
,
sir
,
---
The
bell
has
stopped
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
you
know
her
first
?
 
<EOS>
Did
she
send
here
for
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
does
not
even
know
that
I
live
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
a
friend
,
father
and
I
---
a
poor
labouring
man
,
but
the
best
of
friends
---
and
I
wrote
out
that
I
wished
to
do
needlework
,
and
gave
his
address
.
<EOS>
And
he
got
what
I
wrote
out
displayed
at
a
few
places
where
it
cost
nothing
,
and
Mrs
Clennam
found
me
that
way
,
and
sent
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
gate
will
be
locked
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
tremulous
and
agitated
,
and
he
was
so
moved
by
compassion
for
her
,
and
by
deep
interest
in
her
story
as
it
dawned
upon
him
,
that
he
could
scarcely
tear
himself
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
stoppage
of
the
bell
,
and
the
quiet
in
the
prison
,
were
a
warning
to
depart
;
and
with
a
few
hurried
words
of
kindness
he
left
her
gliding
back
to
her
father
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
remained
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
The
inner
gate
was
locked
,
and
the
lodge
closed
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
little
fruitless
knocking
with
his
hand
,
he
was
standing
there
with
the
disagreeable
conviction
upon
him
that
he
had
got
to
get
through
the
night
,
when
a
voice
accosted
him
from
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Caught
,
eh
?
"
said
the
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
go
home
till
morning
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
you
,
<EOS>
is
it
,
Mr
Clennam
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
voice
was
Tip
's
;
and
they
stood
looking
at
one
another
in
the
prison
-
yard
,
as
it
began
to
rain
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
done
it
,
"
observed
Tip
;
"
you
must
be
sharper
than
that
next
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
locked
in
too
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
am
!
"
said
Tip
,
sarcastically
.
 
<EOS>
"
About
!
 
<EOS>
But
not
in
your
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
belong
to
the
shop
,
only
my
sister
has
a
theory
that
our
governor
must
never
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
why
,
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
I
get
any
shelter
?
"
asked
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
had
I
better
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
get
hold
of
Amy
<EOS>
first
of
all
,
"
said
Tip
,
referring
any
difficulty
to
her
as
a
matter
of
course
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
walk
about
all
night
---
it
's
not
much
to
do
---
than
give
that
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
do
that
,
if
you
do
n't
mind
paying
for
a
bed
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
mind
paying
,
they
'll
make
you
up
one
on
the
Snuggery
table
,
under
the
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
come
along
,
I
'll
introduce
you
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
passed
down
the
yard
,
Arthur
looked
up
at
the
window
of
the
room
he
had
lately
left
,
where
the
light
was
still
burning
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Tip
,
following
his
glance
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
governor
's
.
<EOS>
She
'll
sit
with
him
for
another
hour
reading
yesterday
's
paper
to
him
,
or
something
of
that
sort
;
and
then
she
'll
come
out
like
a
little
ghost
,
and
vanish
away
without
a
sound
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
governor
sleeps
up
in
the
room
,
and
she
has
a
lodging
at
the
turnkey
's
.
 
<EOS>
First
house
there
,
"
said
Tip
,
pointing
out
the
doorway
into
which
she
had
retired
.
 
<EOS>
"
First
house
,
sky
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
She
pays
twice
as
much
for
it
as
she
would
for
one
twice
as
good
outside
.
<EOS>
But
she
stands
by
the
governor
,
poor
dear
girl
,
day
and
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
brought
them
to
the
tavern
-
establishment
at
the
upper
end
of
the
prison
,
where
the
collegians
had
just
vacated
their
social
evening
club
.
 
<EOS>
The
apartment
on
the
ground
-
floor
in
which
it
was
held
,
was
the
Snuggery
in
question
;
the
presidential
tribune
of
the
chairman
,
the
pewter
-
pots
,
glasses
,
pipes
,
tobacco
-
ashes
,
and
general
flavour
of
members
,
were
still
as
that
convivial
institution
had
left
them
on
its
adjournment
.
 
<EOS>
The
Snuggery
had
two
of
the
qualities
popularly
held
to
be
essential
to
grog
for
ladies
,
in
respect
that
it
was
hot
and
strong
;
but
in
the
third
point
of
analogy
,
requiring
plenty
of
it
,
the
Snuggery
was
defective
;
being
but
a
cooped
-
up
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
The
unaccustomed
visitor
from
outside
,
naturally
assumed
everybody
here
to
be
prisoners
---
landlord
,
waiter
,
barmaid
,
potboy
,
and
all
.
<EOS>
Whether
they
were
or
not
,
did
not
appear
;
but
they
all
had
a
weedy
look
.
 
<EOS>
The
keeper
of
a
chandler
's
shop
in
a
front
parlour
,
who
took
in
gentlemen
boarders
,
lent
his
assistance
in
making
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
tailor
in
his
time
,
and
had
kept
a
phaeton
,
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
boasted
that
he
stood
up
litigiously
for
the
interests
of
the
college
;
and
he
had
undefined
and
undefinable
ideas
that
the
marshal
intercepted
a
"
Fund
,
"
which
ought
to
come
to
the
collegians
.
 
<EOS>
He
liked
to
believe
this
,
and
always
impressed
the
shadowy
grievance
on
new
-
comers
and
strangers
;
though
he
could
not
,
for
his
life
,
have
explained
what
Fund
he
meant
,
or
how
the
notion
had
got
rooted
in
his
soul
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
fully
convinced
himself
,
notwithstanding
,
that
his
own
proper
share
of
the
Fund
was
three
and
ninepence
a
week
;
and
that
in
this
amount
he
,
as
an
individual
collegian
,
was
swindled
by
the
marshal
,
regularly
every
Monday
.
<EOS>
Apparently
,
he
helped
to
make
the
bed
,
that
he
might
not
lose
an
opportunity
of
stating
this
case
;
after
which
unloading
of
his
mind
,
and
after
announcing
(
as
it
seemed
he
always
did
,
without
anything
coming
of
it
)
that
he
was
going
to
write
a
letter
to
the
papers
and
show
the
marshal
up
,
he
fell
into
miscellaneous
conversation
with
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evident
from
the
general
tone
of
the
whole
party
,
that
they
had
come
to
regard
insolvency
as
the
normal
state
of
mankind
,
and
the
payment
of
debts
as
a
disease
that
occasionally
broke
out
.
<EOS>
In
this
strange
scene
,
and
with
these
strange
spectres
flitting
about
him
,
Arthur
Clennam
looked
on
at
the
preparations
as
if
they
were
part
of
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
Pending
which
,
the
long
-
initiated
Tip
,
with
an
awful
enjoyment
of
the
Snuggery
's
resources
,
pointed
out
the
common
kitchen
fire
maintained
by
subscription
of
collegians
,
the
boiler
for
hot
water
supported
in
like
manner
,
and
other
premises
generally
tending
to
the
deduction
that
the
way
to
be
healthy
,
wealthy
,
and
wise
,
was
to
come
to
the
Marshalsea
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
tables
put
together
in
a
corner
,
were
,
at
length
,
converted
into
a
very
fair
bed
;
and
the
stranger
was
left
to
the
Windsor
chairs
,
the
presidential
tribune
,
the
beery
atmosphere
,
sawdust
,
pipe
-
lights
,
spittoons
and
repose
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
last
item
was
long
,
long
,
long
,
in
linking
itself
to
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
The
novelty
of
the
place
,
the
coming
upon
it
without
preparation
,
the
sense
of
being
locked
up
,
the
remembrance
of
that
room
up
-
stairs
,
of
the
two
brothers
,
and
above
all
of
the
retiring
childish
form
,
and
the
face
in
which
he
now
saw
years
of
insufficient
food
,
if
not
of
want
,
kept
him
waking
and
unhappy
.
   
<EOS>
Speculations
,
too
,
bearing
the
strangest
relations
towards
the
prison
,
but
always
concerning
the
prison
,
ran
like
nightmares
through
his
mind
while
he
lay
awake
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
coffins
were
kept
ready
for
people
who
might
die
there
,
where
they
were
kept
,
how
they
were
kept
,
<EOS>
where
people
who
died
in
the
prison
were
buried
,
how
they
were
taken
out
,
what
forms
were
observed
,
whether
an
implacable
creditor
could
arrest
the
dead
?
 
<EOS>
As
to
escaping
,
what
chances
there
were
of
escape
?
 
<EOS>
Whether
a
prisoner
could
scale
the
walls
with
a
cord
and
grapple
,
how
he
would
descend
upon
the
other
side
?
 
<EOS>
whether
he
could
alight
on
a
housetop
,
steal
down
a
staircase
,
let
himself
out
at
a
door
,
and
get
lost
in
the
crowd
?
<EOS>
As
to
Fire
in
the
prison
,
if
one
were
to
break
out
while
he
lay
there
?
   
<EOS>
And
these
involuntary
starts
of
fancy
were
,
after
all
,
but
the
setting
of
a
picture
in
which
three
people
kept
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
,
with
the
steadfast
look
with
which
he
had
died
,
prophetically
darkened
forth
in
the
portrait
;
his
mother
,
with
her
arm
up
,
warding
off
his
suspicion
;
Little
Dorrit
,
with
her
hand
on
the
degraded
arm
,
and
her
drooping
head
turned
away
.
   
<EOS>
What
if
his
mother
had
an
old
reason
she
well
knew
for
softening
to
this
poor
girl
!
 
<EOS>
What
if
the
prisoner
now
sleeping
quietly
---
Heaven
grant
it
!
<EOS>
---
by
the
light
of
the
great
Day
of
judgment
should
trace
back
his
fall
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
if
any
act
of
hers
and
of
his
father
's
,
should
have
even
remotely
brought
the
grey
heads
of
those
two
brothers
so
low
!
   
<EOS>
A
swift
thought
shot
into
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
long
imprisonment
here
,
and
in
her
own
long
confinement
to
her
room
,
did
his
mother
find
a
balance
to
be
struck
?
 
<EOS>
"
I
admit
that
I
was
accessory
to
that
man
's
captivity
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
suffered
for
it
in
kind
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
decayed
in
his
prison
:
<EOS>
I
in
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
paid
the
penalty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
When
all
the
other
thoughts
had
faded
out
,
this
one
held
possession
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
fell
asleep
,
she
came
before
him
in
her
wheeled
chair
,
warding
him
off
with
this
justification
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
and
sprang
up
causelessly
frightened
,
the
words
were
in
his
ears
,
as
if
her
voice
had
slowly
spoken
them
at
his
pillow
,
to
break
his
rest
:
"
He
withers
away
in
his
prison
;
I
wither
away
in
mine
;
inexorable
justice
is
done
;
what
do
I
owe
on
this
score
!
"
    
Chapter
09
.
<EOS>
Little
Mother
 
<EOS>
The
morning
light
was
in
no
hurry
to
climb
the
prison
wall
and
look
in
at
the
Snuggery
windows
;
and
when
it
did
come
,
it
would
have
been
more
welcome
if
it
had
come
alone
,
instead
of
bringing
a
rush
of
rain
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
equinoctial
gales
were
blowing
out
at
sea
,
and
the
impartial
south
-
west
wind
,
in
its
flight
,
would
not
neglect
even
the
narrow
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
While
it
roared
through
the
steeple
of
St
George
's
Church
,
and
twirled
all
the
cowls
in
the
neighbourhood
,
it
made
a
swoop
to
beat
the
Southwark
smoke
into
the
jail
;
and
,
plunging
down
the
chimneys
of
the
few
early
collegians
who
were
yet
lighting
their
fires
,
half
suffocated
them
.
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
would
have
been
little
disposed
to
linger
in
bed
,
though
his
bed
had
been
in
a
more
private
situation
,
and
less
affected
by
the
raking
out
of
yesterday
's
fire
,
the
kindling
of
to
-
day
's
under
the
collegiate
boiler
,
the
filling
of
that
Spartan
vessel
at
the
pump
,
the
sweeping
and
sawdusting
of
the
common
room
,
and
other
such
preparations
.
 
<EOS>
Heartily
glad
to
see
the
morning
,
though
little
rested
by
the
night
,
he
turned
out
as
soon
as
he
could
distinguish
objects
about
him
,
and
paced
the
yard
for
two
heavy
hours
before
the
gate
was
opened
.
   
<EOS>
The
walls
were
so
near
to
one
another
,
and
the
wild
clouds
hurried
over
them
so
fast
,
that
it
gave
him
a
sensation
like
the
beginning
of
sea
-
sickness
to
look
up
at
the
gusty
sky
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
,
carried
aslant
by
flaws
of
wind
,
blackened
that
side
of
the
central
building
which
he
had
visited
last
night
,
but
left
a
narrow
dry
trough
under
the
lee
of
the
wall
,
where
he
walked
up
and
down
among
the
waits
of
straw
and
dust
and
paper
,
the
waste
droppings
of
the
pump
,
and
the
stray
leaves
of
yesterday
's
greens
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
haggard
a
view
of
life
<EOS>
as
a
man
need
look
upon
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
relieved
by
any
glimpse
of
the
little
creature
who
had
brought
him
there
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
she
glided
out
of
her
doorway
and
in
at
that
where
her
father
lived
,
while
his
face
was
turned
from
both
;
but
he
saw
nothing
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
too
early
for
her
brother
;
to
have
seen
him
once
,
was
to
have
seen
enough
of
him
to
know
that
he
would
be
sluggish
to
leave
whatever
frowsy
bed
he
occupied
at
night
;
so
,
as
Arthur
Clennam
walked
up
and
down
,
waiting
for
the
gate
to
open
,
he
cast
about
in
his
mind
for
future
rather
than
for
present
means
of
pursuing
his
discoveries
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
the
lodge
-
gate
turned
,
and
the
turnkey
,
standing
on
the
step
,
<EOS>
taking
an
early
comb
at
his
hair
,
was
ready
to
let
him
out
.
<EOS>
With
a
joyful
sense
of
release
he
passed
through
the
lodge
,
and
found
himself
again
in
the
little
outer
court
-
yard
where
he
had
spoken
to
the
brother
last
night
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
string
of
people
already
straggling
in
,
whom
it
was
not
difficult
to
identify
as
the
nondescript
messengers
,
go
-
betweens
,
and
errand
-
bearers
of
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
had
been
lounging
in
the
rain
until
the
gate
should
open
;
others
,
who
had
timed
their
arrival
with
greater
nicety
,
were
coming
up
now
,
and
passing
in
with
damp
whitey
-
brown
paper
bags
from
the
grocers
,
loaves
of
bread
,
lumps
of
butter
,
eggs
,
milk
,
and
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
The
shabbiness
of
these
attendants
upon
shabbiness
,
the
poverty
of
these
insolvent
waiters
upon
insolvency
,
was
a
sight
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
Such
threadbare
coats
and
trousers
,
such
fusty
gowns
and
shawls
,
such
squashed
hats
and
bonnets
,
such
boots
and
shoes
,
such
umbrellas
and
walking
-
sticks
,
never
were
seen
in
Rag
Fair
.
 
<EOS>
All
of
them
wore
the
cast
-
off
clothes
of
other
men
and
women
,
were
made
up
of
patches
and
pieces
of
other
people
's
individuality
,
and
had
no
sartorial
existence
of
their
own
proper
.
 
<EOS>
Their
walk
was
the
walk
of
a
race
apart
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
a
peculiar
way
of
doggedly
slinking
round
the
corner
,
as
if
they
were
eternally
going
to
the
pawnbroker
's
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
coughed
,
they
coughed
like
people
accustomed
to
be
forgotten
on
doorsteps
and
in
draughty
passages
,
waiting
for
answers
to
letters
in
faded
ink
,
which
gave
the
recipients
of
those
manuscripts
great
mental
disturbance
and
no
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
eyed
the
stranger
in
passing
,
they
eyed
him
with
borrowing
eyes
---
hungry
,
sharp
,
speculative
as
to
his
softness
if
they
were
accredited
to
him
,
and
the
likelihood
of
his
standing
something
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
Mendicity
on
commission
stooped
in
their
high
shoulders
,
shambled
in
their
unsteady
legs
,
buttoned
and
pinned
and
darned
and
dragged
their
clothes
,
frayed
their
button
-
holes
,
leaked
out
of
their
figures
in
dirty
little
ends
of
tape
,
and
issued
from
their
mouths
in
alcoholic
breathings
.
   
<EOS>
As
these
people
passed
him
standing
still
in
the
court
-
yard
,
and
one
of
them
turned
back
to
inquire
if
he
could
assist
him
with
his
services
,
it
came
into
Arthur
Clennam
's
mind
that
he
would
speak
to
Little
Dorrit
again
before
he
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
have
recovered
her
first
surprise
,
and
might
feel
easier
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
this
member
of
the
fraternity
(
who
had
two
red
herrings
in
his
hand
,
and
a
loaf
and
a
blacking
brush
under
his
arm
)
,
where
was
the
nearest
place
to
get
a
cup
of
coffee
at
.
 
<EOS>
The
nondescript
replied
in
encouraging
terms
,
and
brought
him
to
a
coffee
-
shop
in
the
street
within
a
stone
's
throw
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
Miss
Dorrit
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
new
client
.
   
<EOS>
The
nondescript
knew
two
Miss
Dorrits
;
one
who
was
born
inside
---
That
was
the
one
!
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
one
?
 
<EOS>
The
nondescript
had
known
her
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
In
regard
of
the
other
Miss
Dorrit
,
the
nondescript
lodged
in
the
same
house
with
herself
and
uncle
.
   
<EOS>
This
changed
the
client
's
half
-
formed
design
of
remaining
at
the
coffee
-
shop
until
the
nondescript
should
bring
him
word
that
Dorrit
had
issued
forth
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
He
entrusted
the
nondescript
with
a
confidential
message
to
her
,
importing
that
the
visitor
who
had
waited
on
her
father
last
night
,
begged
the
favour
of
a
few
words
with
her
at
her
uncle
's
lodging
;
he
obtained
from
the
same
source
full
directions
to
the
house
,
which
was
very
near
;
dismissed
the
nondescript
gratified
with
half
-
a
-
crown
;
and
having
hastily
refreshed
himself
at
the
coffee
-
shop
,
repaired
with
all
speed
to
the
clarionet
-
player
's
dwelling
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
so
many
lodgers
in
this
house
that
the
doorpost
seemed
to
be
as
full
of
bell
-
handles
as
a
cathedral
organ
is
of
stops
.
<EOS>
Doubtful
which
might
be
the
clarionet
-
stop
,
he
was
considering
the
point
,
when
a
shuttlecock
flew
out
of
the
parlour
window
,
and
alighted
on
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
observed
that
in
the
parlour
window
was
a
blind
with
the
inscription
,
MR
CRIPPLES
's
ACADEMY
;
also
in
another
line
,
EVENING
TUITION
;
and
behind
the
blind
was
a
little
white
-
faced
boy
,
with
a
slice
of
bread
-
and
-
butter
and
a
battledore
.
   
<EOS>
The
window
being
accessible
from
the
footway
,
he
looked
in
over
the
blind
,
returned
the
shuttlecock
,
and
put
his
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dorrit
?
"
said
the
little
white
-
faced
boy
(
Master
Cripples
in
fact
)
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
?
 
<EOS>
Third
bell
and
one
knock
.
<EOS>
"
The
pupils
of
Mr
Cripples
appeared
to
have
been
making
a
copy
-
book
of
the
street
-
door
,
it
was
so
extensively
scribbled
over
in
pencil
.
   
<EOS>
The
frequency
of
the
inscriptions
,
"
Old
Dorrit
,
"
and
"
Dirty
Dick
,
"
in
combination
,
suggested
intentions
of
personality
on
the
part
Of
Mr
Cripples
's
pupils
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
ample
time
to
make
these
observations
before
the
door
was
opened
by
the
poor
old
man
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
very
slowly
remembering
Arthur
,
"
you
were
shut
in
last
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
to
meet
your
niece
here
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
he
,
pondering
.
 
<EOS>
"
Out
of
my
brother
's
way
?
 
<EOS>
True
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
come
up
-
stairs
and
wait
for
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Turning
himself
as
slowly
as
he
turned
in
his
mind
<EOS>
whatever
he
heard
or
said
,
he
led
the
way
up
the
narrow
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
was
very
close
,
and
had
an
unwholesome
smell
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
staircase
windows
looked
in
at
the
back
windows
of
other
houses
as
unwholesome
as
itself
,
with
poles
and
lines
thrust
out
of
them
,
on
which
unsightly
linen
hung
;
as
if
the
inhabitants
were
angling
for
clothes
,
and
had
had
some
wretched
bites
not
worth
attending
to
.
<EOS>
In
the
back
garret
---
a
sickly
room
,
with
a
turn
-
up
bedstead
in
it
,
so
hastily
and
recently
turned
up
that
the
blankets
were
boiling
over
,
as
it
were
,
and
keeping
the
lid
open
---
a
half
-
finished
breakfast
of
coffee
and
toast
for
two
persons
was
jumbled
down
anyhow
on
a
rickety
table
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
one
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
mumbling
to
himself
,
after
some
consideration
,
that
Fanny
had
run
away
,
went
to
the
next
room
to
fetch
her
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
,
observing
that
she
held
the
door
on
the
inside
,
and
that
,
when
the
uncle
tried
to
open
it
,
there
was
a
sharp
adjuration
of
"
Do
n't
,
stupid
!
"
and
an
appearance
of
loose
stocking
and
flannel
,
concluded
that
the
young
lady
was
in
an
undress
.
 
<EOS>
The
uncle
,
without
appearing
to
come
to
any
conclusion
,
shuffled
in
again
,
sat
down
in
his
chair
,
and
began
warming
his
hands
at
the
fire
;
not
that
it
was
cold
,
or
that
he
had
any
waking
idea
whether
it
was
or
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
think
of
my
brother
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
when
he
by
-
and
-
by
discovered
what
he
was
doing
,
left
off
,
reached
over
to
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
took
his
clarionet
case
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
glad
,
"
said
Arthur
,
very
much
at
a
loss
,
for
his
thoughts
were
on
the
brother
before
him
;
"
to
find
him
so
well
and
cheerful
.
"
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
<EOS>
"
muttered
the
old
man
,
"
yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
wondered
what
he
could
possibly
want
with
the
clarionet
case
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
want
it
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
discovered
,
in
due
time
,
that
it
was
not
the
little
paper
of
snuff
(
which
was
also
on
the
chimney
-
piece
)
,
put
it
back
again
,
took
down
the
snuff
instead
,
and
solaced
himself
with
a
pinch
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
feeble
,
spare
,
and
slow
in
his
pinches
as
in
everything
else
,
but
a
certain
little
trickling
of
enjoyment
of
them
played
in
the
poor
worn
nerves
about
the
corners
of
his
eyes
and
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
impressed
,
Mr
Dorrit
,
by
all
that
I
have
seen
of
her
and
thought
of
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
brother
would
have
been
quite
lost
without
Amy
,
"
he
returned
.
<EOS>
"
We
should
all
have
been
lost
without
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
very
good
girl
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
She
does
her
duty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
fancied
that
he
heard
in
these
praises
a
certain
tone
of
custom
,
which
he
had
heard
from
the
father
last
night
with
an
inward
protest
and
feeling
of
antagonism
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
they
stinted
her
praises
,
or
were
insensible
to
what
she
did
for
them
;
but
that
they
were
lazily
habituated
to
her
,
as
they
were
to
all
the
rest
of
their
condition
.
 
<EOS>
He
fancied
that
although
they
had
before
them
,
every
day
,
the
means
of
comparison
between
her
and
one
another
and
themselves
,
they
regarded
her
as
being
in
her
necessary
place
;
as
holding
a
position
towards
them
all
which
belonged
to
her
,
like
her
name
or
her
age
.
 
<EOS>
He
fancied
that
they
viewed
her
,
not
as
having
risen
away
from
the
prison
atmosphere
,
but
as
appertaining
to
it
;
as
being
vaguely
what
they
had
a
right
to
expect
,
and
nothing
more
.
   
<EOS>
Her
uncle
resumed
his
breakfast
,
and
was
munching
toast
sopped
in
coffee
,
oblivious
of
his
guest
,
when
the
third
bell
rang
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
Amy
,
he
said
,
and
went
down
to
let
her
in
;
leaving
the
visitor
with
as
vivid
a
picture
on
his
mind
of
his
begrimed
hands
,
dirt
-
worn
face
,
and
decayed
figure
,
as
if
he
were
still
drooping
in
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
She
came
up
after
him
,
in
the
usual
plain
dress
,
and
with
the
usual
timid
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Her
lips
were
a
little
parted
,
as
if
her
heart
beat
faster
than
usual
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
Amy
,
"
said
her
uncle
,
"
has
been
expecting
you
some
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
took
the
liberty
of
sending
you
a
message
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
received
the
message
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
my
mother
's
this
morning
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
not
,
for
it
is
past
your
usual
hour
.
"
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
day
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
wanted
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
Me
to
walk
a
little
way
in
whatever
direction
you
may
be
going
?
 
<EOS>
I
can
then
speak
to
you
as
we
walk
,
both
without
detaining
you
here
,
and
without
intruding
longer
here
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
embarrassed
,
but
said
,
if
he
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
a
pretence
of
having
mislaid
his
walking
-
stick
,
to
give
her
time
to
set
the
bedstead
right
,
to
answer
her
sister
's
impatient
knock
at
the
wall
,
and
to
say
a
word
softly
to
her
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
found
it
,
and
they
went
down
-
stairs
;
she
first
,
he
following
;
the
uncle
standing
at
the
stair
-
head
,
and
probably
forgetting
them
before
they
had
reached
the
ground
floor
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Cripples
's
pupils
,
who
were
by
this
time
coming
to
school
,
desisted
from
their
morning
recreation
of
cuffing
one
another
with
bags
and
books
,
to
stare
with
all
the
eyes
they
had
at
a
stranger
who
had
been
to
see
Dirty
Dick
.
 
<EOS>
They
bore
the
trying
spectacle
in
silence
,
until
the
mysterious
visitor
was
at
a
safe
distance
;
when
they
burst
into
pebbles
and
yells
,
and
likewise
into
reviling
dances
,
and
in
all
respects
buried
the
pipe
of
peace
with
so
many
savage
ceremonies
,
that
,
if
Mr
Cripples
had
been
the
chief
of
the
Cripplewayboo
tribe
with
his
war
-
paint
on
,
they
could
scarcely
have
done
greater
justice
to
their
education
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
this
homage
,
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
offered
his
arm
to
Little
Dorrit
,
and
Little
Dorrit
took
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
go
by
the
Iron
Bridge
,
"
said
he
,
"
where
there
is
an
escape
from
the
noise
of
the
street
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
answered
,
if
he
pleased
,
and
presently
ventured
to
hope
that
he
would
"
not
mind
"
Mr
Cripples
's
boys
,
for
she
had
herself
received
her
education
,
such
as
it
was
,
in
Mr
Cripples
's
evening
academy
.
 
<EOS>
He
returned
,
with
the
best
will
in
the
world
,
that
Mr
Cripples
's
boys
were
forgiven
out
of
the
bottom
of
his
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
did
Cripples
unconsciously
become
a
master
of
the
ceremonies
between
them
,
and
bring
them
more
naturally
together
than
Beau
Nash
might
have
done
if
they
had
lived
in
his
golden
days
,
and
he
had
alighted
from
his
coach
and
six
for
the
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
The
morning
remained
squally
,
and
the
streets
were
miserably
muddy
,
but
no
rain
fell
as
they
walked
towards
the
Iron
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
creature
seemed
so
young
in
his
eyes
,
that
there
were
moments
when
he
found
himself
thinking
of
her
,
if
not
speaking
to
her
,
as
if
she
were
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
seemed
as
old
in
her
eyes
as
she
seemed
young
in
his
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
you
were
so
inconvenienced
last
night
,
sir
,
as
to
be
locked
in
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
unfortunate
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
,
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
had
a
very
good
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
quickly
;
"
she
believed
there
were
excellent
beds
at
the
coffee
-
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
noticed
that
the
coffee
-
house
was
quite
a
majestic
hotel
to
her
,
and
that
she
treasured
its
reputation
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
is
very
expensive
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
but
MY
father
has
told
me
that
quite
beautiful
dinners
may
be
got
there
.
<EOS>
And
wine
,
"
she
added
timidly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Were
you
ever
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
 
<EOS>
Only
into
the
kitchen
to
fetch
hot
water
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
think
of
growing
up
with
a
kind
of
awe
upon
one
as
to
the
luxuries
of
that
superb
establishment
,
the
Marshalsea
Hotel
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
asked
you
last
night
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
how
you
had
become
acquainted
with
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
hear
her
name
before
she
sent
for
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
your
father
ever
did
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
met
her
eyes
raised
to
his
with
so
much
wonder
in
them
<EOS>
(
she
was
scared
when
the
encounter
took
place
,
and
shrunk
away
again
)
,
that
he
felt
it
necessary
to
say
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
reason
for
asking
,
which
I
can
not
very
well
explain
;
but
you
must
,
on
no
account
,
suppose
it
to
be
of
a
nature
to
cause
you
the
least
alarm
or
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
the
reverse
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
think
that
at
no
time
of
your
father
's
life
was
my
name
of
Clennam
ever
familiar
to
him
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
felt
,
from
the
tone
in
which
she
spoke
,
that
she
was
glancing
up
at
him
with
those
parted
lips
;
therefore
he
looked
before
him
,
rather
than
make
her
heart
beat
quicker
still
by
embarrassing
her
afresh
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
they
emerged
upon
the
Iron
Bridge
,
which
was
as
quiet
after
the
roaring
streets
as
though
it
had
been
open
country
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
blew
roughly
,
the
wet
squalls
came
rattling
past
them
,
skimming
the
pools
on
the
road
and
pavement
,
and
raining
them
down
into
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
The
clouds
raced
on
furiously
in
the
lead
-
Coloured
sky
,
the
smoke
and
mist
raced
after
them
,
the
dark
tide
ran
fierce
and
strong
in
the
same
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
seemed
the
least
,
the
quietest
,
and
weakest
of
Heaven
's
creatures
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
put
you
in
a
coach
,
"
said
Clennam
,
very
nearly
adding
"
my
poor
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
hurriedly
declined
,
saying
that
wet
or
dry
made
little
difference
to
her
;
she
was
used
to
go
about
in
all
weathers
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
it
to
be
so
,
and
was
touched
with
more
pity
;
thinking
of
the
slight
figure
at
his
side
,
making
its
nightly
way
through
the
damp
dark
boisterous
streets
to
such
a
place
of
rest
.
<EOS>
"
You
spoke
so
feelingly
to
me
last
night
,
sir
,
and
I
found
afterwards
that
you
had
been
so
generous
to
my
father
,
that
I
could
not
resist
your
message
,
if
it
was
only
to
thank
you
;
especially
as
I
wished
very
much
to
say
to
you
---
"
she
hesitated
and
trembled
,
and
tears
rose
in
her
eyes
,
but
did
not
fall
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
say
to
me
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
hope
you
will
not
misunderstand
my
father
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
judge
him
,
sir
,
as
you
would
judge
others
outside
the
gates
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
there
so
long
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
him
outside
,
but
I
can
understand
that
he
must
have
grown
different
in
some
things
since
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
thoughts
will
never
be
unjust
or
harsh
towards
him
,
believe
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
prouder
air
,
as
the
misgiving
evidently
crept
upon
her
that
she
might
seem
to
be
abandoning
him
,
"
not
that
he
has
anything
to
be
ashamed
of
for
himself
,
or
that
I
have
anything
to
be
ashamed
of
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
only
requires
to
be
understood
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
ask
for
him
that
his
life
may
be
fairly
remembered
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
he
said
was
quite
true
.
 
<EOS>
It
all
happened
just
as
he
related
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
much
respected
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
who
comes
in
,
is
glad
to
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
more
courted
than
anyone
else
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
far
more
thought
of
than
the
Marshal
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
ever
pride
were
innocent
,
it
was
innocent
in
Little
Dorrit
when
she
grew
boastful
of
her
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
often
said
that
his
manners
are
a
true
gentleman
's
,
and
quite
a
study
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
none
like
them
in
that
place
,
but
he
is
admitted
to
be
superior
to
all
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
quite
as
much
why
they
make
him
presents
,
as
because
they
know
him
to
be
needy
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
to
be
blamed
for
being
in
need
,
poor
love
.
 
<EOS>
Who
could
be
in
prison
a
quarter
of
a
century
,
and
be
prosperous
!
"
   
<EOS>
What
affection
in
her
words
,
what
compassion
in
her
repressed
tears
,
what
a
great
soul
of
fidelity
within
her
,
how
true
the
light
that
shed
false
brightness
round
him
!
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
have
found
it
best
to
conceal
where
my
home
is
,
it
is
not
because
I
am
ashamed
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
God
forbid
!
 
<EOS>
Nor
am
I
so
much
ashamed
of
the
place
itself
as
might
be
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
People
are
not
bad
because
they
come
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known
numbers
of
good
,
persevering
,
honest
people
come
there
through
misfortune
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
almost
all
kind
-
hearted
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
would
be
ungrateful
indeed
in
me
,
to
forget
that
I
have
had
many
quiet
,
comfortable
hours
there
;
that
I
had
an
excellent
friend
there
when
I
was
quite
a
baby
,
who
was
very
very
fond
of
me
;
that
I
have
been
taught
there
,
and
have
worked
there
,
and
have
slept
soundly
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
would
be
almost
cowardly
and
cruel
not
to
have
some
little
attachment
for
it
,
after
all
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
relieved
the
faithful
fulness
of
her
heart
,
and
modestly
said
,
raising
her
eyes
appealingly
to
her
new
friend
's
,
"
I
did
not
mean
to
say
so
much
,
nor
have
I
ever
but
once
spoken
about
this
before
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
seems
to
set
it
more
right
than
it
was
last
night
.
<EOS>
I
said
I
wished
you
had
not
followed
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
it
so
much
now
,
unless
you
should
think
<EOS>
---
indeed
I
do
n't
wish
it
at
all
,
unless
I
should
have
spoken
so
confusedly
,
that
---
that
you
can
scarcely
understand
me
,
which
I
am
afraid
may
be
the
case
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
told
her
with
perfect
truth
that
it
was
not
the
case
;
and
putting
himself
between
her
and
the
sharp
wind
and
rain
,
sheltered
her
as
well
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
permitted
now
,
"
he
said
,
"
to
ask
you
a
little
more
concerning
your
father
.
 
<EOS>
Has
he
many
creditors
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
a
great
number
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
detaining
creditors
,
who
keep
him
where
he
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
a
great
number
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
tell
me
---
I
can
get
the
information
,
no
doubt
,
elsewhere
,
if
you
can
not
---
who
is
the
most
influential
of
them
?
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
said
,
after
considering
a
little
,
that
she
used
to
hear
long
ago
of
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
as
a
man
of
great
power
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
commissioner
,
or
a
board
,
or
a
trustee
,
"
or
something
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
lived
in
Grosvenor
Square
,
she
thought
,
or
very
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
under
Government
---
high
in
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
have
acquired
,
in
her
infancy
,
some
awful
impression
of
the
might
of
this
formidable
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
of
Grosvenor
Square
,
or
very
near
it
,
and
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
which
quite
crushed
her
when
she
mentioned
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
can
do
no
harm
,
"
thought
Arthur
,
"
if
I
see
this
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
thought
did
not
present
itself
so
quietly
but
that
her
quickness
intercepted
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
shaking
her
head
with
the
mild
despair
of
a
lifetime
.
 
<EOS>
"
Many
people
used
to
think
once
of
getting
my
poor
father
out
,
but
you
do
n't
know
how
hopeless
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
forgot
to
be
shy
at
the
moment
,
in
honestly
warning
him
away
from
the
sunken
wreck
he
had
a
dream
of
raising
;
and
looked
at
him
with
eyes
which
assuredly
,
in
association
with
her
patient
face
,
her
fragile
figure
,
her
spare
dress
,
and
the
wind
and
rain
,
did
not
turn
him
from
his
purpose
of
helping
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
if
it
could
be
done
,
"
said
she
---
"
and
it
never
can
be
done
now
---
where
could
father
live
,
or
how
could
he
live
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
thought
that
if
such
a
change
could
come
,
it
might
be
anything
but
a
service
to
him
now
.
 
<EOS>
People
might
not
think
so
well
of
him
outside
as
they
do
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
not
be
so
gently
dealt
with
outside
as
he
is
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
not
be
so
fit
himself
for
the
life
outside
as
he
is
for
that
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
for
the
first
time
she
could
not
restrain
her
tears
from
falling
;
and
the
little
thin
hands
he
had
watched
when
they
were
so
busy
,
trembled
as
they
clasped
each
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
new
distress
to
him
even
to
know
that
I
earn
a
little
money
,
and
that
Fanny
earns
a
little
money
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
so
anxious
about
us
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
feeling
helplessly
shut
up
there
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
good
,
good
father
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
let
the
little
burst
of
feeling
go
by
before
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
soon
gone
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
accustomed
to
think
of
herself
,
or
to
trouble
any
one
with
her
emotions
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
but
glanced
away
at
the
piles
of
city
roofs
and
chimneys
among
which
the
smoke
was
rolling
heavily
,
and
at
the
wilderness
of
masts
on
the
river
,
and
the
wilderness
of
steeples
on
the
shore
,
indistinctly
mixed
together
in
the
stormy
haze
,
when
she
was
again
as
quiet
as
if
she
had
been
plying
her

in
his
mother
's
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
be
glad
to
have
your
brother
set
at
liberty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
very
,
very
glad
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
we
will
hope
for
him
at
least
.
 
<EOS>
You
told
me
last
night
of
a
friend
you
had
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
name
was
Plornish
,
Little
Dorrit
said
.
   
<EOS>
And
where
did
Plornish
live
?
 
<EOS>
Plornish
lived
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
"
only
a
plasterer
,
"
Little
Dorrit
said
,
as
a
caution
to

not
to
form
high

expectations
of
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
He
lived
at
the
last
house
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
and
his
name
was
over
a
little
gateway
.
<EOS>
Arthur
took
down
the
address
and
gave
her
his
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
now
done
all
he
sought

do
for
the
present
,
except
that
he
wished
to
leave

with
a

,
and
to
have
something
like

from
her
that
she

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
one
friend
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
putting
up

.
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
take
you
back
---
you
are
going
back
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
going
straight
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
I
take
you
back
,
"
the
word
home
jarred
upon

,
"
let
me

you
to
persuade

that
you
have
another

.
 
<EOS>
I
make
no

,
and
say
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
truly
kind
to
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
need
no
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
walked
back
through
the
miserable
muddy

,
and
among
the
poor
,
mean
shops
,
and
were
jostled
by
the
crowds
of
dirty
hucksters
usual
to
a
poor
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
,
by
the
short
way
<EOS>
,
that
was
pleasant
to
any
of
the
five
senses
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
was
not
a
common
passage
through
common
rain
,
and
mire
,
and
noise
,
to
Clennam
,
having
this
little
,
slender
,
careful
creature
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
How
young
she
seemed
to
him
,
or
how
old
he
to
her
;
or
what
a
secret
either
to
the
other
,
in
that
beginning
of
the
destined
interweaving
of
their
stories
,
matters
not
here
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
her
having
been
born
and
bred
among
these
scenes
,
and
shrinking
through
them
now
,
familiar
yet
misplaced
;
he
thought
of
her
long
acquaintance
with
the
squalid
needs
of
life
,
and
of
her
innocence
;
of
her
solicitude
for
others
,
and
her
few
years
,
and
her
childish
aspect
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
come
into
the
High
Street
,
where
the
prison
stood
,
when
a
voice
cried
,
"
Little
mother
,
little
mother
!
"
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
stopping
and
looking
back
,
an
excited
figure
of
a
strange
kind
bounced
against
them
(
still
crying
"
little
mother
"
)
,
fell
down
,
and
scattered
the
contents
of
a
large

,
filled
with
potatoes
,
in
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Maggy
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
what
a
clumsy
child
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
Maggy
was
not
hurt
,
but
picked
herself
up
immediately
,
and
then
began
to
pick
up
the
potatoes
,
in
which
both
Little
Dorrit
and
Arthur
Clennam
helped
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
picked
up
very
few
potatoes
and
a
great
quantity
of
mud
;
but
they
were
all
recovered
,
and
deposited
in
the
basket
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
then
smeared
her
muddy
face
with
her
shawl
,
and
presenting
it
to
Mr
Clennam
as
a
type
of
purity
,
enabled
him
to
see
what
she
was
like
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
about
eight
-
and
-
twenty
,
with
large
bones
,
large
features
,
large
feet
and
hands
,
large
eyes
and
no
hair
.
 
<EOS>
Her
large
eyes
were
limpid
and
almost
colourless
;
they
seemed
to
be
very
little
affected
by
light
,
and
to
stand
unnaturally
still
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
also
that
attentive
listening
expression
in
her
face
,
which
is
seen
in
the
faces
of
the
blind
;
but
she
was
not
blind
,
having
one
tolerably
serviceable
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
not
exceedingly
ugly
,
though
it
was
only
redeemed
from
being
so
by
a
smile
;
a
good
-
humoured
smile
,
and
pleasant
in
itself
,
but
rendered
pitiable
by
being
constantly
there
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
white
cap
,
with
a
quantity
of
opaque
frilling
that
was
always
flapping
about
,
apologised
for
Maggy
's
baldness
,
and
made
it
so
very
difficult
for
her
old
black
bonnet
to
retain
its
place
upon
her
head
,
that
it
held
on
round
her
neck
like
a
gipsy
's

.
 
<EOS>
A
commission
of
haberdashers
could
alone
have
reported
what
the
rest
of
her
poor
dress
was
made
of
,
but
it
had
a
strong
general
resemblance
to
seaweed
,
with
here
<EOS>
and
there
a
gigantic
tea
-
leaf
.
<EOS>
Her
shawl
looked
particularly
like
a
tea
-
leaf
after
long
infusion
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
looked
at
Little
Dorrit
with
the
expression
of
one
saying
,
"
May
I
ask
who
this
is
?
"
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
whose
hand
this
Maggy
,
still

mother
,
had
begun
to
fondle
,
answered
in
words
(
they
were
under
a

into

the

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
This

Maggy
,

.
"
   
"
Maggy
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Little
mother
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
the
grand
-
daughter
---
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Grand
-
daughter
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
my

,

has

dead

.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
,
how

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ten
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca

,

,
"

Little
Dorrit
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good

,
"

,
transferring

little

.
   
<EOS>
"
Or

,
"
said
Little

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
goes
on

.
"
 
<EOS>
Maggy

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
is
as

as
the
Bank
of
England
.
"
 
<EOS>
Maggy
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
earns

own

.
<EOS>
Entirely
,

!
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
does
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Think

,
Maggy
?
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
taking
her
two

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
from
thousands

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
history
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Little
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
means
me
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
rather

;
"
she
is
very
much

.
 
<EOS>
Her

was
not

;

,
Maggy
?
<EOS>
"

,

of

,

,

"
Gin
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
beat
an

,
and

,
"
Broom
-
handles
and
pokers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
Maggy

ten

,
"

Little
Dorrit
,

"

,

,

ever

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ten

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

hospital
!
 
<EOS>
So

,

?
 
<EOS>
Oh

.
 
<EOS>
Such

Ev'nly

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She

,

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
beds
there
is

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Such

!
 
<EOS>
Such

!
 
<EOS>
Such
d'licious

!
 
<EOS>
Such
Chicking
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
AIN'T
it
<EOS>
a

to
go
and

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
Maggy

there
as

,
"
said

,
in
her

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,

,

---
"
   
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

;
indeed

when

could

---
which

---
"
   
<EOS>
(
Maggy
mighty
grave

.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Her
grandmother
did
not
know
what
to
do
with
her
,
and
for
some
years
was
very
unkind
to
her
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
in
course
of
time
,
Maggy
began
to
take
pains
to
improve
herself
,
and
to
be
very
attentive
and
very
industrious
;
and
by
degrees
was
allowed
to
come
in
and
out
as
often
as
she
liked
,
and
got
enough
to
do
to
support
herself
,
and
does
support
herself
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
clapping
the
two
great
hands
together
again
,
"
is
Maggy
's
history
,
as
Maggy
knows
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
Arthur
would
have
known
what
was
wanting
to
its
completeness
,
though
he
had
never
heard
of
the
words
Little
mother
;
though
he
had
never
seen
the
fondling
of
the
small
spare
hand
;
though
he
had
had
no
sight
for
the
tears
now
standing
in
the
colourless
eyes
;
though
he
had
had
no
hearing
for
the
sob
that
checked
the
clumsy
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
The
dirty
gateway
with
the
wind
and
rain
whistling
through
it
,
and
the
basket
of
muddy
potatoes
waiting
to
be
spilt
again
or
taken
up
,
never
seemed
the
common
hole
it
really
was
,
when
he
looked
back
to
it
by
these
lights
.
 
<EOS>
Never
,
never
!
   
<EOS>
They
were
very
near
the
end
of
their
walk
,
and
they
now
came
out
of
the
gateway
to
finish
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
would
serve
Maggy
but
that
they
must
stop
at
a
grocer
's
window
,
short
of
their
destination
,
for
her
to
show
her
learning
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
read
after
a
sort
;
and
picked
out
the
fat
figures
in
the
tickets
of
prices
,
for
the
most
part
correctly
.
 
<EOS>
She
also
stumbled
,
with
a
large
balance
of
success
against
her
failures
,
through
various
philanthropic
recommendations
to
Try
our
Mixture
,
Try
our
Family
Black
,
Try
our
Orange
-
flavoured
Pekoe
,
challenging
competition
at
the
head
of
Flowery
Teas
;
and
various
cautions
to
the
public
against
spurious
establishments
and
adulterated
articles
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
saw
how
pleasure
brought
a
rosy
tint
into
Little
Dorrit
's
face
when
Maggy
made
a
hit
,
he
felt
that
he
could
have
stood
there
making
a
library
of
the
grocer
's
window
until
the
rain
and
wind
were
tired
.
   
<EOS>
The
court
-
yard
received
them
at
last
,
and
there
he
said
goodbye
to
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Little
as
she
had
always
looked
,
she
looked
less
than
ever
when
he
saw
her
going
into
the
Marshalsea
lodge
passage
,
<EOS>
the
little
mother
attended
by
her
big
child
.
<EOS>
The
cage
door
opened
,
and
when
the
small
bird
,
reared
in
captivity
,
had
tamely
fluttered
in
,
he
saw
it
shut
again
;
and
then
he
came
away
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
Containing
the
whole
Science
of
Government
 
<EOS>
The
Circumlocution
Office
was
(
as
everybody
knows
without
being
told
)
the
most
important
Department
under
Government
.
 
<EOS>
No
public
business
of
any
kind
could
possibly
be
done
at
any
time
without
the
acquiescence
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
Its
finger
was
in
the
largest
public
pie
,
and
in
the
smallest
public
tart
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
equally
impossible
to
do
the
plainest
right
and
to
undo
the
plainest
wrong
without
the
express
authority
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
If
another
Gunpowder
Plot
had
been
discovered
half
an
hour
before
the
lighting
of
the
match
,
nobody
would
have
been
justified
in
saving
the
parliament
until
there
had
been
half
a
score
of
boards
,
half
a
bushel
of
minutes
,
several
sacks
of
official
memoranda
,
and
a
family
-
vault
full
of
ungrammatical
correspondence
,
on
the
part
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
   
<EOS>
This
glorious
establishment
had
been
early
in
the
field
,
when
the
one
sublime
principle
involving
the
difficult
art
of
governing
a
country
,
was
first
distinctly
revealed
to
statesmen
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
foremost
to
study
that
bright
revelation
and
to
carry
its
shining
influence
through
the
whole
of
the
official
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
was
required
to
be
done
,
the
Circumlocution
Office
was
beforehand
with
all
the
public
departments
in
the
art
of
perceiving
---
<EOS>
HOW
NOT
TO
DO
IT
.
   
<EOS>
Through
this
delicate
perception
,
through
the
tact
with
which
it
invariably
seized
it
,
and
through
the
genius
with
which
it
always
acted
on
it
,
the
Circumlocution
Office
had
risen
to
overtop
all
the
public
departments
;
and
the
public
condition
had
risen
to
be
---
what
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
How
not
to
do
it
was
the
great
study
and
object
of
all
public
departments
and
professional
politicians
all
round
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
every
new
premier
and
every
new
government
,
coming
in
because
they
had
upheld
a
certain
thing
as
necessary
to
be
done
,
were
no
sooner
come
in
than
they
applied
their
utmost
faculties
to
discovering
How
not
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
from
the
moment
when
a
general
election
was
over
,
every
returned
man
who
had
been
raving
on
hustings
because
it
had
n't
been
done
,
and
who
had
been
asking
the
friends
of
the
honourable
gentleman
in
the
opposite
interest
on
pain
of
impeachment
to
tell
him
why
it
had
n't
been
done
,
and
who
had
been
asserting
that
it
must
be
done
,
and
who
had
been
pledging
himself
that
it
should
be
done
,
began
to
devise
,
How
it
was
not
to
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
the
debates
of
both
Houses
of
Parliament
the
whole
session
through
,
uniformly
tended
to
the
protracted
deliberation
,
How
not
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
the
royal
speech
at
the
opening
of
such
session
virtually
said
,
My
lords
and
gentlemen
,
you
have
a
considerable
stroke
of
work
to
do
,
and
you
will
please
to
retire
to
your
respective
chambers
,
and
discuss
,
How
not
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
the
royal
speech
,
at
the
close
of
such
session
,
virtually
said
,
My
lords
and
gentlemen
,
you
have
through
several
laborious
months
been
considering
with
great
loyalty
and
patriotism
,
How
not
to
do
it
,
and
you
have
found
out
;
and
with
the
blessing
of
Providence
upon
the
harvest
(
natural
,
not
political
)
,
I
now
dismiss
you
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
is
true
,
but
the
Circumlocution
Office
went
beyond
it
.
   
<EOS>
Because
the
Circumlocution
Office
went
on
mechanically
,
every
day
,
keeping
this
wonderful
,
all
-
sufficient
wheel
of
statesmanship
,
How
not
to
do
it
,
in
motion
.
 
<EOS>
Because
the
Circumlocution
Office
was
down
upon
any
ill
-
advised
public
servant
who
was
going
to
do
it
,
or
who
appeared
to
be
by
any
surprising
accident
in
remote
danger
of
doing
it
,
with
a
minute
,
and
a
memorandum
,
and
a
letter
of
instructions
that
extinguished
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
this
spirit
of
national
efficiency
in
the
Circumlocution
Office
that
had
gradually
led
to
its
having
something
to
do
with
everything
.
 
<EOS>
Mechanicians
,
natural
philosophers
,
soldiers
,
sailors
,
petitioners
,
memorialists
,
people
with
grievances
,
people
who
wanted
to
prevent
grievances
,
people
who
wanted
to
redress
grievances
,
jobbing
people
,
jobbed
people
,
people
who
could
n't
get
rewarded
for
merit
,
and
people
who
could
n't
get
punished
for
demerit
,
were
all
indiscriminately
tucked
up
under
the
foolscap
paper
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
   
<EOS>
Numbers
of
people
were
lost
in
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
<EOS>
Unfortunates
with
wrongs
,
or
with
projects
for
the
general
welfare
(
and
they
had
better
have
had
wrongs
at
first
,
than
have
taken
that
bitter
English
recipe
for
certainly
getting
them
)
,
who
in
slow
lapse
of
time
and
agony
had
passed
safely
through
other
public
departments
;
who
,
according
to
rule
,
had
been
bullied
in
this
,
over
-
reached
by
that
,
and
evaded
by
the
other
;
got
referred
at
last
to
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
never
reappeared
in
the
light
of
day
.
 
<EOS>
Boards
sat
upon
them
,
secretaries
minuted
upon
them
,
commissioners
gabbled
about
them
,
clerks
registered
,
entered
,
checked
,
and
ticked
them
off
,
and
they
melted
away
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
all
the
business
of
the
country
went
through
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
except
the
business
that
never
came
out
of
it
;
and
its
name
was
Legion
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
angry
spirits
attacked
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
parliamentary
questions
were
asked
about
it
,
and
even
parliamentary
motions
made
or
threatened
about
it
by
demagogues
so
low
and
ignorant
as
to
hold
that
the
real
recipe
of
government
was
,
How
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
the
noble
lord
,
or
right
honourable
gentleman
,
in
whose
department
it
was
to
defend
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
put
an
orange
in
his
pocket
,
and
make
a
regular
field
-
day
of
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
he
come
down
to
that
house
with
a
slap
upon
the
table
,
and
meet
the
honourable
gentleman
foot
to
foot
.
<EOS>
Then
would
he
be
there
to
tell
that
honourable
gentleman
that
the
Circumlocution
Office
not
only
was
blameless
in
this
matter
,
but
was
commendable
in
this
matter
,
was
extollable
to
the
skies
in
this
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
he
be
there
to
tell
that
honourable
gentleman
that
,
although
the
Circumlocution
Office
was
invariably
right
and
wholly
right
,
it
never
was
so
right
as
in
this
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
he
be
there
to
tell
that
honourable
gentleman
that
it
would
have
been
more
to
his
honour
,
more
to
his
credit
,
more
to
his
good
taste
,
more
to
his
good
sense
,
more
to
half
the
dictionary
of
commonplaces
,
if
he
had
left
the
Circumlocution
Office
alone
,
and
never
approached
this
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
he
keep
one
eye
upon
a
coach
or
crammer
from
the
Circumlocution
Office
sitting
below
the
bar
,
and
smash
the
honourable
gentleman
with
the
Circumlocution
Office
account
of
this
matter
.
 
<EOS>
And
although
one
of
two
things
always
happened
;
namely
,
either
that
the
Circumlocution
Office
had
nothing
to
say
and
said
it
,
or
that
it
had
something
to
say
of
which
the
noble
lord
,
or
right
honourable
gentleman
,
blundered
one
half
and
forgot
the
other
;
the
Circumlocution
Office
was
always
voted
immaculate
by
an
accommodating
majority
.
   
<EOS>
Such
a
nursery
of
statesmen
had
the
Department
become
in
virtue
of
a
long
career
of
this
nature
,
that
several
solemn
lords
had
attained
the
reputation
of
being
quite
unearthly
prodigies
of
business
,
solely
from
having
practised
,
How
not
to
do
it
,
as
the
head
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
minor
priests
and
acolytes
of
that
temple
,
the
result
of
all
this
was
that
they
stood
divided
into
two
classes
,
and
,
down
to
the
junior
messenger
,
either
believed
in
the
Circumlocution
Office
as
a
heaven
-
born
institution
that
had
an
absolute
right
to
do
whatever
it
liked
;
or
took
refuge
in
total
infidelity
,
and
considered
it
a
flagrant
nuisance
.
   
<EOS>
The
Barnacle
family
had
for
some
time
helped
to
administer
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
The
Tite
Barnacle
Branch
,
indeed
,
considered
themselves
in
a
general
way
as
having
vested
rights
in
that
direction
,
and
took
it
ill
if
any
other
family
had
much
to
say
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
Barnacles
were
a
very
high
family
,
and
a
very
large
family
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
dispersed
all
over
the
public
offices
,
and
held
all
sorts
of
public
places
.
 
<EOS>
Either
the
nation
was
under
a
load
of
obligation
to
the
Barnacles
,
or
the
Barnacles
were
under
a
load
of
obligation
to
the
nation
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
quite
unanimously
settled
which
;
the
Barnacles
having
their
opinion
,
the
nation
theirs
.
   
<EOS>
The
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
who
at
the
period
now
in
question
usually
coached
or
crammed
the
statesman
at
the
head
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
when
that
noble
or
right
honourable
individual
sat
a
little
uneasily
in
his
saddle
by
reason
of
some
vagabond
making
a
tilt
at
him
in
a
newspaper
,
was
more
flush
of
blood
than
money
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
Barnacle
he
had
his
place
,
which
was
a
snug
thing
enough
;
and
as
a
Barnacle
he
had
of
course
put
in
his
son
Barnacle
Junior
in
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
intermarried
with
a
branch
of
the
Stiltstalkings
,
who
were
also
better
endowed
in
a
sanguineous
point
of
view
than
with
real
or
personal
property
,
and
of
this
marriage
there
had
been
issue
,
Barnacle
junior
and
three
young
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
What
with
the
patrician
requirements
of
Barnacle
junior
,
the
three
young
ladies
,
Mrs
Tite
Barnacle
nee
Stiltstalking
,
and
himself
,
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
found
the
intervals
between
quarter
day
and
quarter
day
rather
longer
than
he
could
have
desired
;
a
circumstance
which
he
always
attributed
to
the
country
's
parsimony
.
<EOS>
For
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
,
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
made
his
fifth
inquiry
one
day
at
the
Circumlocution
Office
;
having
on
previous
occasions
awaited
that
gentleman
successively
in
a
hall
,
a
glass
case
,
a
waiting
room
,
and
a
fire
-
proof
passage
where
the
Department
seemed
to
keep
its
wind
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
Mr
Barnacle
was
not
engaged
,
as
he
had
been
before
,
with
the
noble
prodigy
at
the
head
of
the
Department
;
but
was
absent
.
 
<EOS>
Barnacle
Junior
,
however
,
was
announced
as
a
lesser
star
,
yet
visible
above
the
office
horizon
.
   
<EOS>
With
Barnacle
junior
,
he
signified
his
desire
to
confer
;
and
found
that
young
gentleman
singeing
the
calves
of
his
legs
at
the
parental
fire
,
and
supporting
his
spine
against
the
mantel
-
shelf
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
comfortable
room
,
handsomely
furnished
in
the
higher
official
manner
;
an
presenting
stately
suggestions
of
the
absent
Barnacle
,
in
the
thick
carpet
,
the
leather
-
covered
desk
to
sit
at
,
the
leather
-
covered
desk
to
stand
at
,
the
formidable
easy
-
chair
and
hearth
-
rug
,
the
interposed
screen
,
the
torn
-
up
papers
,
the
dispatch
-
boxes
with
little
labels
sticking
out
of
them
,
like
medicine
bottles
or
dead
game
,
the
pervading
smell
of
leather
and
mahogany
,
and
a
general
bamboozling
air
of
How
not
to
do
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
present
Barnacle
,
holding
Mr
Clennam
's
card
in
his
hand
,
had
a
youthful
aspect
,
and
the
fluffiest
little
whisker
,
perhaps
,
that
ever
was
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
downy
tip
was
on
his
callow
chin
,
that
he
seemed
half
fledged
like
a
young
bird
;
and
a
compassionate
observer
might
have
urged
that
,
if
he
had
not
singed
the
calves
of
his
legs
,
he
would
have
died
of
cold
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
superior
eye
-
glass
dangling
round
his
neck
,
but
unfortunately
had
such
flat
orbits
to
his
eyes
and
such
limp
little
eyelids
that
it
would
n't
stick
in
when
he
put
it
up
,
but
kept
tumbling
out
against
his
waistcoat
buttons
with
a
click
that
discomposed
him
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
My
father
's
not
in
the
way
,
and
wo
n't
be
in
the
way
to
-
day
,
"
said
Barnacle
Junior
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
anything
that
I
can
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
(
Click
!
 
<EOS>
Eye
-
glass
down
.
 
<EOS>
Barnacle
Junior
quite
frightened
and
feeling
all
round
himself
,
but
not
able
to
find
it
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
however
to
see
Mr
Barnacle
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
got
any
appointment
,
you
know
,
"
said
Barnacle
Junior
.
   
<EOS>
(
By
this
time
he
had
found
the
eye
-
glass
,
and
put
it
up
again
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
what
I
wish
to
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
Is
this
public
business
?
"
asked
Barnacle
junior
.
   
<EOS>
(
Click
!
 
<EOS>
Eye
-
glass
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
Barnacle
Junior
in
that
state
of
search
after
it
that
Mr
Clennam
felt
it
useless
to
reply
at
present
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
"
said
Barnacle
junior
,
taking
heed
of
his
visitor
's
brown
face
,
"
anything
about
---
Tonnage
---
or
that
sort
of
thing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
Pausing
for
a
reply
,
he
opened
his
right
eye
with
his
hand
,
and
stuck
his
glass
in
it
,
in
that
inflammatory
manner
that
his
eye
began
watering
dreadfully
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Arthur
,
"
it
is
nothing
about
tonnage
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
look
here
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
private
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
really
am
not
sure
.
 
<EOS>
It
relates
to
a
Mr
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
I
tell
you
what
!
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
call
at
our
house
,
if
you
are
going
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
-
four
,
Mews
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
's
got
a
slight
touch
of
the
gout
,
and
is
kept
at
home
by
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
(
The
misguided
young
Barnacle
evidently
going
blind
on
his
eye
-
glass
side
,
but
ashamed
to
make
any
further
alteration
in
his
painful
arrangements
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
call
there
now
.
 
<EOS>
Good
morning
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Young
Barnacle
seemed
discomfited
at
this
,
as
not
having
at
all
expected
him
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
sure
,
"
said
Barnacle
junior
,
calling
after
him
when
he
got
to
the
door
,
unwilling
wholly
to
relinquish
the
bright
business
idea
he
had
conceived
;
"
that
it
's
nothing
about
Tonnage
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
sure
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
such
assurance
,
and
rather
wondering
what
might
have
taken
place
if
it
HAD
been
anything
about
tonnage
,
Mr
Clennam
withdrew
to
pursue
his
inquiries
.
   
<EOS>
Mews
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
,
was
not
absolutely
Grosvenor
Square
itself
,
but
it
was
very
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
hideous
little
street
of
dead
wall
,
stables
,
and
dunghills
,
with
lofts
over
coach
-
houses
inhabited
by
coachmen
's
families
,
who
had
a
passion
for
drying
clothes
and
decorating
their
window
-
sills
with
miniature
turnpike
-
gates
.
<EOS>
The
principal
chimney
-
sweep
of
that
fashionable
quarter
lived
at
the
blind
end
of
Mews
Street
;
and
the
same
corner
contained
an
establishment
much
frequented
about
early
morning
and
twilight
for
the
purchase
of
wine
-
bottles
and
kitchen
-
stuff
.
<EOS>
Punch
's
shows
used
to
lean
against
the
dead
wall
in
Mews
Street
,
while
their
proprietors
were
dining
elsewhere
;
and
the
dogs
of
the
neighbourhood
made
appointments
to
meet
in
the
same
locality
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
there
were
two
or
three
small
airless
houses
at
the
entrance
end
of
Mews
Street
,
which
went
at
enormous
rents
on
account
of
their
being
abject
hangers
-
on
to
a
fashionable
situation
;
and
whenever
one
of
these
fearful
little
coops
was
to
be
let
(
which
seldom
happened
,
for
they
were
in
great
request
)
<EOS>
,
the
house
agent
advertised
it
as
a
gentlemanly
residence
in
the
most
aristocratic
part
of
town
,
inhabited
solely
by
the
elite
of
the
beau
monde
.
   
<EOS>
If
a
gentlemanly
residence
coming
strictly
within
this
narrow
margin
had
not
been
essential
to
the
blood
of
the
Barnacles
,
this
particular
branch
would
have
had
a
pretty
wide
selection
among
,
let
us
say
,
ten
thousand
houses
,
offering
fifty
times
the
accommodation
for
a
third
of
the
money
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Mr
Barnacle
,
finding
his
gentlemanly
residence
extremely
inconvenient
and
extremely
dear
,
always
laid
it
,
as
a
public
servant
,
at
the
door
of
the
country
,
and
adduced
it
as
another
instance
of
the
country
's
parsimony
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
came
to
a
squeezed
house
,
with
a
ramshackle
bowed
front
,
little
dingy
windows
,
and
a
little
dark
area
like
a
damp
waistcoat
-
pocket
,
which
he
found
to
be
number
twenty
-
four
,
Mews
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
sense
of
smell
the
house
was
like
a
sort
of
bottle
filled
with
a
strong
distillation
of
Mews
;
and
when
the
footman
opened
the
door
,
he
seemed
to
take
the
stopper
out
.
   
<EOS>
The
footman
was
to
the
Grosvenor
Square
footmen
,
what
the
house
was
to
the
Grosvenor
Square
houses
.
 
<EOS>
Admirable
in
his
way
,
his
way
was
a
back
and
a
bye
way
.
 
<EOS>
His
gorgeousness
was
not
unmixed
with
dirt
;
and
both
in
complexion
and
consistency
he
had
suffered
from
the
closeness
of
his
pantry
.
 
<EOS>
A
sallow
flabbiness
was
upon
him
when
he
took
the
stopper
out
,
and
presented
the
bottle
to
Mr
Clennam
's
nose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
so
good
as
to
give
that
card
to
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
,
and
to
say
that
I
have
just
now
seen
the
younger
Mr
Barnacle
,
who
recommended
me
to
call
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
footman
(
who
had
as
many
large
buttons
with
the
Barnacle
crest
upon
them
on
the
flaps
of
his
pockets
,
as
if
he
were
the
family
strong
box
,
and
carried
the
plate
and
jewels
about
with
him
buttoned
up
)
pondered
over
the
card
a
little
;
then
said
,
"
Walk
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
required
some
judgment
to
do
it
without
butting
the
inner
hall
-
door
open
,
and
in
the
consequent
mental
confusion
and
physical
darkness
slipping
down
the
kitchen
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
,
however
,
brought
himself
up
safely
on
the
door
-
mat
.
   
<EOS>
Still
the
footman
said
"
Walk
in
,
"
so
the
visitor
followed
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
inner
hall
-
door
,
another
bottle
seemed
to
be
presented
and
another
stopper
taken
out
.
 
<EOS>
This
second
vial
appeared
to
be
filled
with
concentrated
provisions
and
extract
of
Sink
from
the
pantry
.
<EOS>
After
a
skirmish
in
the
narrow
passage
,
occasioned
by
the
footman
's
opening
the
door
of
the
dismal
dining
-
room
with
confidence
,
finding
some
one
there
with
consternation
,
and
backing
on
the
visitor
with
disorder
,
the
visitor
was
shut
up
,
pending
his
announcement
,
in
a
close
back
parlour
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
had
an
opportunity
of
refreshing
himself
with
both
the
bottles
at
once
,
looking
out
at
a
low
blinding
wall
three
feet
off
,
and
speculating
on
the
number
of
Barnacle
families
within
the
bills
of
mortality
who
lived
in
such
hutches
of
their
own
free
flunkey
choice
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barnacle
would
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
Would
he
walk
up
-
stairs
?
 
<EOS>
He
would
,
and
he
did
;
and
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
with
his
leg
on
a
rest
,
he
found
Mr
Barnacle
himself
,
the
express
image
and
presentment
of
How
not
to
do
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barnacle
dated
from
a
better
time
,
when
the
country
was
not
so
parsimonious
and
the
Circumlocution
Office
was
not
so
badgered
.
 
<EOS>
He
wound
and
wound
folds
of
white
cravat
<EOS>
round
his
neck
,
as
he
wound
and
wound
folds
of
tape
and
paper
<EOS>
round
the
neck
of
the
country
.
<EOS>
His
wristbands
and
collar
were
oppressive
;
his
voice
and
manner
were
oppressive
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
large
watch
-
chain
and
bunch
of
seals
,
a
coat
buttoned
up
to
inconvenience
,
a
waistcoat
buttoned
up
to
inconvenience
,
an
unwrinkled
pair
of
trousers
,
a
stiff
pair
of
boots
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
altogether
splendid
,
massive
,
overpowering
,
and
impracticable
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
have
been
sitting
for
his
portrait
to
Sir
Thomas
Lawrence
all
the
days
of
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
?
"
said
Mr
Barnacle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
seated
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
became
seated
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
called
on
me
,
I
believe
,
"
said
Mr
Barnacle
,
"
at
the
Circumlocution
---
"
giving
it
the
air
of
a
word
of
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
syllables
---
"
Office
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
that
liberty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barnacle
solemnly
bent
his
head
as
who
should
say
,
"
I
do
not
deny
that
it
is
a
liberty
;
proceed
to
take
another
liberty
,
and
let
me
know
your
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
to
observe
that
I
have
been
for
some
years
in
China
,
am
quite
a
stranger
at
home
,
and
have
no
personal
motive
or
interest
in
the
inquiry
I
am
about
to
make
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barnacle
tapped
his
fingers
on
the
table
,
and
,
as
if
he
were
now
sitting
for
his
portrait
to
a
new
and
strange
artist
,
appeared
to
say
to
his
visitor
,
"
If
you
will
be
good
enough
to
take
me
with
my
present
lofty
expression
,
I
shall
feel
obliged
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
a
debtor
in
the
Marshalsea
Prison
of
the
name
of
Dorrit
,
who
has
been
there
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
investigate
his
confused
affairs
so
far
as
to
ascertain
whether
it
may
not
be
possible
,
after
this
lapse
of
time
,
to
ameliorate
his
unhappy
condition
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
of
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
has
been
mentioned
to
me
as
representing
some
highly
influential
interest
among
his
creditors
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
correctly
informed
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
being
one
of
the
principles
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
never
,
on
any
account
whatever
,
to
give
a
straightforward
answer
,
Mr
Barnacle
said
,
"
Possibly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
behalf
of
the
Crown
,
may
I
ask
,
or
as
private
individual
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
Circumlocution
Department
,
sir
,
"
Mr
Barnacle
replied
,
"
may
have
possibly
recommended
---
possibly
---
I
can
not
say
---
that
some
public
claim
against
the
insolvent
estate
of
a
firm
or
copartnership
to
which
this
person
may
have
belonged
,
should
be
enforced
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
may
have
been
,
in
the
course
of
official
business
,
referred
to
the
Circumlocution
Department
for
its
consideration
.
<EOS>
The
Department
may
have
either
originated
,
or
confirmed
,
a
Minute
making
that
recommendation
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
assume
this
to
be
the
case
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
Circumlocution
Department
,
"
said
Mr
Barnacle
,
"
is
not
responsible
for
any
gentleman
's
assumptions
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
inquire
how
I
can
obtain
official
information
as
to
the
real
state
of
the
case
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
competent
,
"
said
Mr
Barnacle
,
"
to
any
member
of
the
---
Public
,
"
mentioning
that
obscure
body
with
reluctance
,
as
his
natural
enemy
,
"
to
memorialise
the
Circumlocution
Department
.
 
<EOS>
Such
formalities
as
are
required
to
be
observed
in
so
doing
,
may
be
known
on
application
to
the
proper
branch
of
that
Department
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
is
the
proper
branch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
refer
you
,
"
returned
Mr
Barnacle
,
ringing
the
bell
,
"
to
the
Department
itself
for
a
formal
answer
to
that
inquiry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
my
mentioning
---
"
   
"
The
Department
is
accessible
to
the
---
Public
,
"
Mr
Barnacle
was
always
checked
a
little
by
that
word
of
impertinent
signification
,
"
if
the
---
Public
approaches
it
according
to
the
official
forms
;
if
the
---
Public
does
not
approach
it
according
to
the
official
forms
,
the
---
Public
has
itself
to
blame
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Barnacle
made
him
a
severe
bow
,
as
a
wounded
man
of
family
,
a
wounded
man
of
place
,
and
a
wounded
man
of
a
gentlemanly
residence
,
all
rolled
into
one
;
and
he
made
Mr
Barnacle
a
bow
,
and
was
shut
out
into
Mews
Street
by
the
flabby
footman
.
   
<EOS>
Having
got
to
this
pass
,
he
resolved
as
an
exercise
in
perseverance
,
to
betake
himself
again
to
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
try
what
satisfaction
he
could
get
there
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
went
back
to
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
once
more
sent
up
his
card
to
Barnacle
junior
by
a
messenger
who
took
it
very
ill
indeed
that
he
should
come
back
again
,
and
who
was
eating
mashed
potatoes
and
gravy
behind
a
partition
by
the
hall
fire
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
readmitted
to
the
presence
of
Barnacle
junior
,
and
found
that
young
gentleman
singeing
his
knees
now
,
and
gaping
his
weary
way
on
to
four
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
stick
to
us
in
a
devil
of
a
manner
,
"
Said
Barnacle
junior
,
looking
over
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
---
"
   
"
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
you
must
n't
come
into
the
place
saying
you
want
to
know
,
you
know
,
"
remonstrated
Barnacle
junior
,
turning
about
and
putting
up
the
eye
-
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
,
who
had
made
up

mind
to
persistence
in
one
short

of
words
,
"
the
precise
nature
of
the
claim
of
the
Crown
against
a
prisoner
for
debt
,
named
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
really
are
going
it
at
a
great
pace
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Egad
,
you
have
n't
got
an
appointment
,
"
said
Barnacle
junior
,
as
if
the

were

serious
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
,
"
said
Arthur
,
and
repeated
his
case
.
   
<EOS>
Barnacle
junior
stared
at
him
until
his
eye
-
glass
fell
out
,
and
then
put
it
in
again
and
stared
at

until
it

out
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
right
to
come
this
sort
of
move
,
"
he
then
observed
with
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
You
told

you
did
n't

whether
it
was
public
business
or

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
now
ascertained
that
it
is
public
business
,
"
returned
the
suitor
,
"
and
I
want
to
know
"
---
and
again

his
monotonous

.
   
<EOS>
Its
effect
upon
young
Barnacle
was
to
make

repeat
in
a

,
"
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
SOUL
you
must
n't
come
into
the
place
saying
you
want
to
know
,
you
know
!
"
<EOS>
The
effect
of
that
upon
Arthur
Clennam
was
to
make
him
repeat
his

in
exactly
the
same

and

.
 
<EOS>
The
effect
of
that
upon
young
Barnacle
was
to
make
him
a

of
failure
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
tell

what
.
 
<EOS>
Look

.
 
<EOS>
You
had

the
Secretarial
Department
,
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Jenkinson
,
"
to
the
mashed
potatoes
messenger
,
"
Mr
Wobbler
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
,
who
now
felt
that
he
had
devoted

to
the

of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
must

,

to
another

,
where
that

pointed
out
Mr

's

.
 
<EOS>
He
entered
that

,
and
found
two

sitting
face

at
a

,
one
of

was

a
gun
-

pocket

,
while
the
other
was
spreading

on

with

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wobbler
?
"
inquired
the
suitor
.
   
<EOS>
Both
gentlemen
glanced
at
him
,
and
seemed
surprised
at
his
assurance
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
he
went
,
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
gun
-
barrel
,
who
was
an
extremely
deliberate
speaker
,
"
down
to
his
cousin
's
place
,
and
took
the
Dog
with
him
by
rail
.
 
<EOS>
Inestimable
Dog
.
 
<EOS>
Flew
at
the
porter
fellow
when
he
was
put
into
the
dog
-
box
,
and
flew
at
the
guard
when
he
was
taken

.
 
<EOS>
He
got
half
-
a
-
dozen
fellows
into
a
Barn
,
and
a
good
supply
of
Rats
,
and
timed
the
Dog
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
the
Dog
able
to
do
it
immensely
,
made
the
match
,
and
heavily
backed
the
Dog
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
match
came
off
,
some
devil
of
a
fellow
was
bought
over
,
Sir
,
Dog
was
made
drunk
,
Dog
's
master
was
cleaned
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wobbler
?
"
inquired

.
   
<EOS>
The

who

,

,
"
What

Dog
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Called

Lovely
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Said
the
Dog
was
the
perfect
picture

the
old
aunt
from

he
had
expectations
.
<EOS>
Found
him
particularly
like
her
when
hocussed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wobbler
?
"
said
the

.
   
<EOS>
Both

.
 
<EOS>
The

the
gun
-

,

it
,
on

,
in

,
referred

the
other
;

views
,

in

,
and

and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wobbler
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
<EOS>
then

Mr
Wobbler
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
---
"
and
Arthur
Clennam
again

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
inform

,
"
observed

Wobbler
,
apparently
to

.
<EOS>
"
Never
heard

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing

.
 
<EOS>
Better

Mr
Clive
,
second

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

,
"

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

"
Mister
!
 
<EOS>
Hallo
!
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
"
Shut

.
 
<EOS>
You
're

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

him
to
the
second

on

in

next

.
 
<EOS>
In
that
room
he
found
three
gentlemen
;
number
one
doing
nothing
particular
,
number
two
doing
nothing
particular
,
number
three
doing
nothing
particular
.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
,
however
,
to
be
more

concerned
than
the
others
had
been
in
the
effective

of
the
great

of
the

,
as
there

an
awful
inner

with

door
,
in
which

Circumlocution
Sages

to

,
and

,

going
of
papers
,
almost

;
wherein
another
gentleman
,
number
four
,
was
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
,
---
and
again

case
in

-

.
 
<EOS>
As
number
one
referred
him
to
number
two
,
and
as
number
two
referred
him
to
number
three
,
he
had
occasion
to
state
it
three
times
before
they
all
referred
him
to
number
four
,
to
whom
he
stated

again
.
   
<EOS>
Number
four
was
a
vivacious
,
well
-
looking
,
well
-
dressed
,
agreeable
young
fellow
---
he
was
a
Barnacle
,
but
on
the
more
sprightly
side
of
the

---
and
he
said
in
an
easy

,
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
you
had
better
not
bother

about
it
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
bother

about
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
I
recommend
you
not
to
bother
yourself
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
such
a
new
point
of
view
that
Arthur
Clennam
found
himself
at
a
loss
how

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
I
can

forms
to
fill

.
<EOS>
Lots

'em
here
.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
But
you
'll
never

on

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
it
be
such

work
?
 
<EOS>
Excuse

;
I
am
a

in
England
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say

would
be

,
"
returned
number
four
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
express
an
opinion
about
that
;
I
only
express
an
opinion
about

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

you
'd
go
on

.
<EOS>
However
,

,
you
can

.
 
<EOS>
I

was

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

do

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
That
you

.
 
<EOS>
Then

what
Department
the
contract
was
in
,

'll

all

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
How

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

'll
---
you

ask

.
 
<EOS>
Then

'll

that
Department
(
according

regular
forms
which
you
'll
find
out
)
for

to

this
Department
.
 
<EOS>
If

(
which
you

)
,

,

,

,

this

,
and
then

will
begin
to

that
Department
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
find

when
the
business
passes
through
each
of
these

by
asking
at
both
Departments
till

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
surely
this
is
not
the
way
to
do
the
business
,
"
Arthur
Clennam
could
not
help
saying
.
   
<EOS>
This
airy
young
Barnacle
was
quite
entertained
by
his
simplicity
in
supposing
for
a
moment
that
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
This
light
in
hand
young
Barnacle
knew
perfectly
that
it
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
This
touch
and
go
young
Barnacle
had
"
got
up
"
the
Department
in
a
private
secretaryship
,
that
he
might
be
ready
for
any
little
bit
of
fat
that
came
to
hand
;
and
he
fully
understood
the
Department
to
be
a

-

hocus
pocus
piece
of
machinery
for
the
assistance
of
the
nobs
in
keeping

snobs
.
 
<EOS>
This
dashing
young
Barnacle
,
in
a
word
,
was
likely
to
become
a
statesman
,
and
to
make
a
figure
.
   
<EOS>
"
When

business
is
regularly
before
that
Department
,
whatever

is
,
"
pursued
this
bright
young
Barnacle
,
"
then
you
can
watch
it
from
time
to
time
through
that
Department
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
comes
regularly
before
this
Department
,
then
you
must

it
from
time
to
time
through
this
Department
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
to
refer

right

left
;
and

it
anywhere
,
then
you
'll
have
to
look

up
.
<EOS>
When

comes
back
to
us
at
any

,
then
you
had
better
look
US
up
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
sticks
anywhere
,
you
'll
have
to
try
to
give

a
jog
.
<EOS>
When

about
it
,

about
it
,
and
do
n't

,
why

you
had

---
keep

writing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
looked
very

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
am

to
you

,
"
said

,
"
for

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

all
,
"
replied
this
engaging

Barnacle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Try
the
thing
,

see

it
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
in
your
power
to
give
it

any

,

do

.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
take
a
lot
of
forms
away

you
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
a
lot
of
forms
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
instruction
to
number
two
,
this
sparkling
young
Barnacle
took
a
fresh
handful
of
papers
from
numbers
one
and
three
,
and
carried

into
the

to
offer
to
the
presiding
Idol
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
put
his
forms
in
his
pocket
gloomily
enough
,
and
went
his
way
down
the
long
stone
passage
and
the
long
stone
