.
 
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
the
swing
doors
leading
into
the
street
,
and
was
waiting
,
not
over
patiently
,
for
two
people
who
were
between
him
and
them
to
pass
out
and
let
him
follow
,
when
the
voice
of
one
of
them
struck
familiarly
on
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
the
speaker
and
recognised
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
was
very
red
in
the
face
---
redder
than
travel
could
have
made
him
---
and
collaring
a
short
man
who
was
with
him
,
said
,
"
come
out
,
you
rascal
,
come
Out
!
"
   
<EOS>
it
was
such
an
unexpected
hearing
,
and
it
was
also
such
an
unexpected
sight
to
see
Mr
Meagles
burst
the
swing
doors
open
,
and
emerge
into
the
street
with
the
short
man
,
who
was
of
an
unoffending
appearance
,
that
Clennam
stood
still
for
the
moment
exchanging
looks
of
surprise
with
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
He
followed
,
however
,
quickly
;
and
saw
Mr
Meagles
going
down
the
street
with
his
enemy
at
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
came
up
with
his
old
travelling
companion
,
and
touched
him
on
the
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
choleric
face
which
Mr
Meagles
turned
upon
him
smoothed
when
he
saw
who
it
was
,
and
he
put
out
his
friendly
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
only
just
come
over
from
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
rejoiced
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
.
 
Thank'ee
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Meagles
and
your
daughter
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
as
well
as
possible
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
wish
you
had
come
upon
me
in
a
more
prepossessing
condition
as
to
coolness
.
"
   
<EOS>
Though
it
was
anything
but
a
hot
day
,
Mr
Meagles
was
in
a
heated
state
that
attracted
the
attention
of
the
passersby
;
more
particularly
as
he
leaned
his
back
against
a
railing
,
took
off
his
hat
and
cravat
,
and
heartily
rubbed
his
steaming
head
and
face
,
and
his
reddened
ears
and
neck
,
without
the
least
regard
for
public
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whew
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
dressing
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
comfortable
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am
cooler
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
ruffled
,
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
bit
,
and
I
'll
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
leisure
for
a
turn
in
the
Park
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
much
as
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
along
then
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
you
may
well
look
at
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
happened
to
have
turned
his
eyes
towards
the
offender
whom
Mr
Meagles
had
so
angrily
collared
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
something
to
look
at
,
that
fellow
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
much
to
look
at
,
either
in
point
of
size
or
in
point
of
dress
;
being
merely
a
short
,
square
,
practical
looking
man
,
whose
hair
had
turned
grey
,
and
in
whose
face
and
forehead
there
were
deep
lines
of
cogitation
,
which
looked
as
though
they
were
carved
in
hard
wood
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
decent
black
,
a
little
rusty
,
and
had
the
appearance
of
a
sagacious
master
in
some
handicraft
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
spectacle
-
case
in
his
hand
,
which
he
turned
over
and
over
while
he
was
thus
in
question
,
with
a
certain
free
use
of
the
thumb
that
is
never
seen
but
in
a
hand
accustomed
to
tools
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
keep
with
us
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
in
a
threatening
kind
of
Way
,
"
and
I
'll
introduce
you
presently
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
!
"
   
Clennam
wondered
within
himself
,
as
they
took
the
nearest
way
to
the
Park
,
what
this
unknown
(
who
complied
in
the
gentlest
manner
)
could
have
been
doing
.
 
<EOS>
His
appearance
did
not
at
all
justify
the
suspicion
that
he
had
been
detected
in
designs
on
Mr
Meagles
's
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
nor
had
he
any
appearance
of
being
quarrelsome
or
violent
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
quiet
,
plain
,
steady
man
;
made
no
attempt
to
escape
;
and
seemed
a
little
depressed
,
but
neither
ashamed
nor
repentant
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
a
criminal
offender
,
he
must
surely
be
an
incorrigible
hypocrite
;
and
if
he
were
no
offender
,
why
should
Mr
Meagles
have
collared
him
in
the
Circumlocution
Office
?
 
<EOS>
He
perceived
that
the
man
was
not
a
difficulty
in
his
own
mind
alone
,
but
in
Mr
Meagles
's
too
;
for
such
conversation
as
they
had
together
on
the
short
way
to
the
Park
was
by
no
means
well
sustained
,
and
Mr
Meagles
's
eye
always
wandered
back
to
the
man
,
even
when
he
spoke
of
something
very
different
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
they
being
among
the
trees
,
Mr
Meagles
stopped
short
,
and
said
:
   
"
Mr
Clennam
,
will
you
do
me
the
favour
to
look
at
this
man
?
 
<EOS>
His
name
is
Doyce
,
Daniel
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
suppose
this
man
to
be
a
notorious
rascal
;
would
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
should
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
really
a
disconcerting
question
,
with
the
man
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
would
not
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
suppose
him
to
be
a
public
offender
;
would
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
public
offender
.
 
<EOS>
What
has
he
been
guilty
of
?
 
<EOS>
Murder
,
manslaughter
,
arson
,
forgery
,
swindling
,
house
-
breaking
,
highway
robbery
,
larceny
,
conspiracy
,
fraud
?
 
<EOS>
Which
should
you
say
,
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
,
"
returned
Arthur
Clennam
,
observing
a
faint
smile
in
Daniel
Doyce
's
face
,
"
not
one
of
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
he
has
been
ingenious
,
and
he
has
been
trying
to
turn
his
ingenuity
to
his
country
's
service
.
<EOS>
That
makes
him
a
public
offender
directly
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
looked
at
the
man
himself
,
who
only
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
Doyce
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
is
a
smith
and
engineer
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
in
a
large
way
,
but
he
is
well
known
as
a
very
ingenious
man
.
 
<EOS>
A
dozen
years
ago
,
he
perfects
an
invention
(
involving
a
very
curious
secret
process
)
of
great
importance
to
his
country
and
his
fellow
-
creatures
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
say
how
much
money
it
cost
him
,
or
how
many
years
of
his
life
he
had
been
about
it
,
but
he
brought
it
to
perfection
a
dozen
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Was
n't
it
a
dozen
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
addressing
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
most
exasperating
man
in
the
world
;
he
never
complains
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Rather
better
than
twelve
years
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rather
better
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
you
mean
rather
worse
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
Clennam
,
he
addresses
himself
to
the
Government
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
he
addresses
himself
to
the
Government
,
he
becomes
a
public
offender
!
<EOS>
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
in
danger
of
making
himself
excessively
hot
again
,
"
he
ceases
to
be
an
innocent
citizen
,
and
becomes
a
culprit
.
   
<EOS>
He
is
treated
from
that
instant
as
a
man
who
has
done
some
infernal
action
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
to
be
shirked
,
put
off
,
brow
-
beaten
,
sneered
at
,
handed
over
by
this
highly
-
connected
young
or
old
gentleman
,
to
that
highly
-
connected
young
or
old
gentleman
,
and
dodged
back
again
;
he
is
a
man
with
no
rights
in
his
own
time
,
or
his
own
property
;
a
mere
outlaw
,
whom
it
is
justifiable
to
get
rid
of
anyhow
;
a
man
to
be
worn
out
by
all
possible
means
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
difficult
to
believe
,
after
the
morning
's
experience
,
as
Mr
Meagles
supposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stand
there
,
Doyce
,
turning
your
spectacle
-
case
over
and
over
,
"
cried
Mr
Meagles
,
"
but
tell
Mr
Clennam
what
you
confessed
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
undoubtedly
was
made
to
feel
,
"
said
the
inventor
,
"
as
if
I
had
committed
an
offence
.
 
<EOS>
In
dancing
attendance
at
the
various
offices
,
I
was
always
treated
,
more
or
less
,
as
if
it
was
a
very
bad
offence
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
frequently
found
it
necessary
to
reflect
,
for
my
own
self
-
support
,
that
I
really
had
not
done
anything
to
bring
myself
into
the
Newgate
Calendar
,
but
only
wanted
to
effect
a
great
saving
and
a
great
improvement
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Judge
whether
I
exaggerate
.
 
<EOS>
Now
you
'll
be
able
to
believe
me
when
I
tell
you
the
rest
of
the
case
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
prelude
,
Mr
Meagles
went
through
the
narrative
;
the
established
narrative
,
which
has
become
tiresome
;
the
matter
-
of
-
course
narrative
which
we
all
know
by
heart
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
after
interminable
attendance
and
correspondence
,
after
infinite
impertinences
,
ignorances
,
and
insults
,
my
lords
made
a
Minute
,
number
three
thousand
four
hundred
and
seventy
-
two
,
allowing
the
culprit
to
make
certain
trials
of
his
invention
at
his
own
expense
.
   
<EOS>
How
the
trials
were
made
in
the
presence
of
a
board
of
six
,
of
whom
two
ancient
members
were
too
blind
to
see
it
,
two
other
ancient
members
were
too
deaf
to
hear
it
,
one
other
ancient
member
was
too
lame
to
get
near
it
,
and
the
final
ancient
member
was
too
pig
-
headed
to
look
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
How
there
were
more
years
;
more
impertinences
,
ignorances
,
and
insults
.
 
<EOS>
How
my
lords
then
made
a
Minute
,
number
five
thousand
one
hundred
and
three
,
whereby
they
resigned
the
business
to
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
How
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
in
course
of
time
,
took
up
the
business
as
if
it
were
a
bran
new
thing
of
yesterday
,
which
had
never
been
heard
of
before
;
muddled
the
business
,
addled
the
business
,
tossed
the
business
in
a
wet
blanket
.
 
<EOS>
How
the
impertinences
,
ignorances
,
and
insults
went
through
the
multiplication
table
.
 
<EOS>
How
there
was
a
reference
of
the
invention
to
three
Barnacles
and
a
Stiltstalking
,
who
knew
nothing
about
it
;
into
whose
heads
nothing
could
be
hammered
about
it
;
who
got
bored
about
it
,
and
reported
physical
impossibilities
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
How
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
in
a
Minute
,
number
eight
thousand
seven
hundred
and
forty
,
"
saw
no
reason
to
reverse
the
decision
at
which
my
lords
had
arrived
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
How
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
being
reminded
that
my
lords
had
arrived
at
no
decision
,
shelved
the
business
.
 
<EOS>
How
there
had
been
a
final
interview
with
the
head
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
that
very
morning
,
and
how
the
Brazen
Head
had
spoken
,
and
had
been
,
upon
the
whole
,
and
under
all
the
circumstances
,
and
looking
at
it
from
the
various
points
of
view
,
of
opinion
that
one
of
two
courses
was
to
be
pursued
in
respect
of
the
business
<EOS>
:
that
was
to
say
,
either
to
leave
it
alone
for
evermore
,
or
to
begin
it
all
over
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
which
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
as
a
practical
man
,
I
then
<EOS>
and
there
,
in
that
presence
,
took
Doyce
by
the
collar
,
and
told
him
it
was
plain
to
me
that
he
was
an
infamous
rascal
and
treasonable
disturber
of
the
government
peace
,
and
took
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
brought
him
out
of
the
office
door
by
the
collar
,
that
the
very
porter
might
know
I
was
a
practical
man
who
appreciated
the
official
estimate
of
such
characters
;
and
here
we
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
If
that
airy
young
Barnacle
had
been
there
,
he
would
have
frankly
told
them
perhaps
that
the
Circumlocution
Office
had
achieved
its
function
.
 
<EOS>
That
what
the
Barnacles
had
to
do
,
was
to
stick
on
to
the
national
ship
as
long
as
they
could
.
 
<EOS>
That
to
trim
the
ship
,
lighten
the
ship
,
clean
the
ship
,
would
be
to
knock
them
off
;
that
they
could
but
be
knocked
off
once
;
and
that
if
the
ship
went
down
with
them
yet
sticking
to
it
,
that
was
the
ship
's
look
out
,
and
not
theirs
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
now
you
know
all
about
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
Except
,
which
I
own
does
not
improve
my
state
of
mind
,
that
even
now
you
do
n't
hear
him
complain
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
great
patience
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
,
looking
at
him
with
some
wonder
,
"
great
forbearance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
returned
,
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
have
more
than
another
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
Lord
,
you
have
more
than
I
have
,
though
!
"
cried
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
Doyce
smiled
,
as
he
said
to
Clennam
,
"
You
see
,
my
experience
of
these
things
does
not
begin
with
myself
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
in
my
way
to
know
a
little
about
them
from
time
to
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mine
is
not
a
particular
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
worse
used
than
a
hundred
others
who
have
put
themselves
in
the
same
position
---
than
all
the
others
,
I
was
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
should
find
that
a
consolation
,
if
it
were
my
case
;
but
I
am
very
glad
that
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Understand
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
,
"
he
replied
in
his
steady
,
planning
way
,
and
looking
into
the
distance
before
him
as
if
his
grey
eye
were
measuring
it
,
"
that
it
's
recompense
for
a
man
's
toil
and
hope
;
but
it
's
a
certain
sort
of
relief
to
know
that
I
might
have
counted
on
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
that
quiet
deliberate
manner
,
and
in
that
undertone
,
which
is
often
observable
in
mechanics
who
consider
and
adjust
with
great
nicety
.
 
<EOS>
It
belonged
to
him
like
his
suppleness
of
thumb
,
or
his
peculiar
way
of
tilting
up
his
hat
at
the
back
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
as
if
he
were
contemplating
some
half
-
finished
work
of
his
hand
and
thinking
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Disappointed
?
"
<EOS>
he
went
on
,
as
he
walked
between
them
under
the
trees
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
am
disappointed
.
 
<EOS>
Hurt
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
am
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
only
natural
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
I
mean
when
I
say
that
people
who
put
themselves
in
the
same
position
are
mostly
used
in
the
same
way
---
"
   
"
In
England
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
of
course
I
mean
in
England
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
take
their
inventions
into
foreign
countries
,
that
's
quite
different
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
's
the
reason
why
so
many
go
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
very
hot
indeed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
mean
is
,
that
however
this
comes
to
be
the
regular
way
of
our
government
,
it
is
its
regular
way
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
ever
heard
of
any
projector
or
inventor
who
failed
to
find
it
all
but
inaccessible
,
and
whom
it
did
not
discourage
and
ill
-
treat
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
that
I
ever
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
ever
known
it
to
be
beforehand
in
the
adoption
of
any
useful
thing
?
 
<EOS>
Ever
known
it
to
set
an
example
of
any
useful
kind
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
good
deal
older
than
my
friend
here
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
and
I
'll
answer
that
.
 
<EOS>
Never
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
we
all
three
have
known
,
I
expect
,
"
said
the
inventor
,
"
a
pretty
many
cases
of
its
fixed
determination
to
be
miles
upon
miles
,
and
years
upon
years
,
behind
the
rest
of
us
;
and
of
its
being
found
out
persisting
in
the
use
of
things
long
superseded
,
even
after
the
better
things
were
well
known
and
generally
taken
up
?
"
   
<EOS>
They
all
agreed
upon
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
"
said
Doyce
,
with
a
sigh
,
"
as
I
know
what
such
a
metal
will
do
at
such
a
temperature
,
and
such
a
body
under
such
a
pressure
,
so
I
may
know
(
if
I
will
only
consider
)
,
how
these
great
lords
and
gentlemen
will
certainly
deal
with
such
a
matter
as
mine
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
be
surprised
,
with
a
head
upon
my
shoulders
,
and
memory
in
it
,
that
I
fall
into
the
ranks
with
all
who
came
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
let
it
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
warning
enough
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
put
up
his
spectacle
-
case
,
and
said
to
Arthur
,
"
If
I
do
n't
complain
,
Mr
Clennam
,
I
can
feel
gratitude
;
and
I
assure
you
that
I
feel
it
towards
our
mutual
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Many
's
the
day
,
and
many
's
the
way
in
which
he
has
backed
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stuff
and
nonsense
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
could
not
but
glance
at
Daniel
Doyce
in
the
ensuing
silence
.
   
<EOS>
Though
it
was
evidently
in
the
grain
of
his
character
,
and
of
his
respect
for
his
own
case
,
that
he
should
abstain
from
idle
murmuring
,
it
was
evident
that
he
had
grown
the
older
,
the
sterner
,
and
the
poorer
,
for
his
long
endeavour
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
but
think
what
a
blessed
thing
it
would
have
been
for
this
man
,
if
he
had
taken
a
lesson
from
the
gentlemen
who
were
so
kind
as
to
take
a
nation
's
affairs
in
charge
,
and
had
learnt
How
not
to
do
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
was
hot
and
despondent
for
about
five
minutes
,
and
then
began
to
cool
and
clear
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
make
this
the
better
by
being
grim
.
 
<EOS>
Where
do
you
think
of
going
,
Dan
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
back
to
the
factory
,
"
said
Dan
.
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
we
'll
all
go
back
to
the
factory
,
or
walk
in
that
direction
,
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
wo
n't
be
deterred
by
its
being
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
?
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
go
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
cried
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
went
along
,
certainly
one
of
the
party
,
and
probably
more
than
one
,
thought
that
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
was
no
inappropriate
destination
for
a
man
who
had
been
in
official
correspondence
with
my
lords
and
the
Barnacles
---
and
perhaps
had
a
misgiving
also
that
Britannia
herself
might
come
to
look
for
lodgings
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
some
ugly
day
or
other
,
if
she
over
-
did
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Let
Loose
 
<EOS>
A
late
,
dull
autumn
night
was
closing
in
upon
the
river
Saone
.
 
<EOS>
The
stream
,
like
a
sullied
looking
-
glass
in
a
gloomy
place
,
reflected
the
clouds
heavily
;
and
the
low
banks
leaned
over
here
and
there
,
as
if
they
were
half
curious
,
and
half
afraid
,
to
see
their
darkening
pictures
in
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
flat
expanse
of
country
about
Chalons
lay
a
long
heavy
streak
,
occasionally
made
a
little
ragged
by
a
row
of
poplar
trees
against
the
wrathful
sunset
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
banks
of
the
river
Saone
it
was
wet
,
depressing
,
solitary
;
and
the
night
deepened
fast
.
   
<EOS>
One
man
slowly
moving
on
towards
Chalons
was
the
only
visible
figure
in
the
landscape
.
 
<EOS>
Cain
might
have
looked
as
lonely
and
avoided
.
 
<EOS>
With
an
old
sheepskin
knapsack
at
his
back
,
and
a
rough
,
unbarked
stick
cut
out
of
some
wood
in
his
hand
;
miry
,
footsore
,
his
shoes
and
gaiters
trodden
out
,
his
hair
and
beard
untrimmed
;
the
cloak
he
carried
over
his
shoulder
,
and
the
clothes
he
wore
,
sodden
with
wet
;
limping
along
in
pain
and
difficulty
;
he
looked
as
if
the
clouds
were
hurrying
from
him
,
as
if
the
wail
of
the
wind
and
the
shuddering
of
the
grass
were
directed
against
him
,
as
if
the
low
mysterious
plashing
of
the
water
murmured
at
him
,
as
if
the
fitful
autumn
night
were
disturbed
by
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
glanced
here
,
and
he
glanced
there
,
sullenly
but
shrinkingly
;
and
sometimes
stopped
and
turned
about
,
and
looked
all
round
him
.
<EOS>
Then
he
limped
on
again
,
toiling
and
muttering
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
devil
with
this
plain
that
has
no
end
!
 
<EOS>
To
the
devil
with
these
stones
that
cut
like
knives
!
 
<EOS>
To
the
devil
with
this
dismal
darkness
,
wrapping
itself
about
one
with
a
chill
!
 
<EOS>
I
hate
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
he
would
have
visited
his
hatred
upon
it
all
with
the
scowl
he
threw
about
him
,
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
He
trudged
a
little
further
;
and
looking
into
the
distance
before
him
,
stopped
again
.
<EOS>
"
I
,
hungry
,
thirsty
,
weary
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
imbeciles
,
where
the
lights
are
yonder
,
eating
and
drinking
,
and
warming
yourselves
at
fires
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
the
sacking
of
your
town
;
I
would
repay
you
,
my
children
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
the
teeth
he
set
at
the
town
,
and
the
hand
he
shook
at
the
town
,
brought
the
town
no
nearer
;
and
the
man
was
yet
hungrier
,
and
thirstier
,
and
wearier
,
when
his
feet
were
on
its
jagged
pavement
,
and
he
stood
looking
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
the
hotel
with
its
gateway
,
and
its
savoury
smell
of
cooking
;
there
was
the
cafe
with
its
bright
windows
,
and
its
rattling
of
dominoes
;
there
was
the
dyer
's
with
its
strips
of
red
cloth
on
the
doorposts
;
there
was
the
silversmith
's
with
its
earrings
,
and
its
offerings
for
altars
;
there
was
the
tobacco
dealer
's
with
its
lively
group
of
soldier
customers
coming
out
pipe
in
mouth
;
there
were
the
bad
odours
of
the
town
,
and
the
rain
and
the
refuse
in
the
kennels
,
and
the
faint
lamps
slung
across
the
road
,
and
the
huge
Diligence
,
and
its
mountain
of
luggage
,
and
its
six
grey
horses
with
their
tails
tied
up
,
getting
under
weigh
at
the
coach
office
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
small
cabaret
for
a
straitened
traveller
being
within
sight
<EOS>
,
he
had
to
seek
one
round
<EOS>
the
dark
corner
,
where
the
cabbage
leaves
lay
thickest
,
trodden
about
the
public
cistern
at
which
women
had
not
yet
left
off
drawing
water
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
in
the
back
street
he
found
one
,
the
Break
of
Day
.
 
<EOS>
The
curtained
windows
clouded
the
Break
of
Day
,
but
it
seemed
light
and
warm
,
and
it
announced
in
legible
inscriptions
with
appropriate
pictorial
embellishment
of
billiard
cue
and
ball
,
that
at
the
Break
of
Day
one
could
play
billiards
;
that
there
one
could
find
meat
,
drink
,
and
lodgings
,
whether
one
came
on
horseback
,
or
came
on
foot
;
and
that
it
kept
good
wines
,
liqueurs
,
and
brandy
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
turned
the
handle
of
the
Break
of
Day
door
,
and
limped
in
.
   
<EOS>
He
touched
his
discoloured
slouched
hat
,
as
he
came
in
at
the
door
,
to
a
few
men
who
occupied
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Two
were
playing
dominoes
at
one
of
the
little
tables
;
three
or
four
were
seated
round
the
stove
,
conversing
as
they
smoked
;
the
billiard
-
table
in
the
centre
was
left
alone
for
the
time
;
the
landlady
of
the
Daybreak
sat
behind
her
little
counter
among
her
cloudy
bottles
of
syrups
,
baskets
of
cakes
,
and
leaden
drainage
for
glasses
,
working
at
her
needle
.
   
<EOS>
Making
his
way
to
an
empty
little
table
in
a
corner
of
the
room
behind
the
stove
,
he
put
down
his
knapsack
and
his
cloak
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
raised
his
head
from
stooping
to
do
so
,
he
found
the
landlady
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
can
lodge
here
to
-
night
,
madame
?
"
   
"
Perfectly
!
"
said
the
landlady
in
a
high
,
sing
-
song
,
cheery
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
.
 
<EOS>
One
can
dine
---
<EOS>
sup
---
what
you
please
to
call
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
perfectly
!
"
cried
the
landlady
as
before
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dispatch
then
,
madame
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
Something
to
eat
,
as
quickly
as
you
can
;
and
some
wine
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
exhausted
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
bad
weather
,
monsieur
,
"
said
the
landlady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cursed
weather
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
a
very
long
road
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
cursed
road
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
hoarse
voice
failed
him
,
and
he
rested
his
head
upon
his
hands
until
a
bottle
of
wine
was
brought
from
the
counter
.
 
<EOS>
Having
filled
and
emptied
his
little
tumbler
twice
,
and
having
broken
off
an
end
from
the
great
loaf
that
was
set
before
him
with
his
cloth
and
napkin
,
soup
-
plate
,
salt
,
pepper
,
and
oil
,
he
rested
his
back
against
the
corner
of
the
wall
,
made
a
couch
of
the
bench
on
which
he
sat
,
and
began
to
chew
crust
,
until
such
time
as
his
repast
should
be
ready
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
that
momentary
interruption
of
the
talk
about
the
stove
,
and
that
temporary
inattention
to
and
distraction
from
one
another
,
which
is
usually
inseparable
in
such
a
company
from
the
arrival
of
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
passed
over
by
this
time
;
and
the
men
had
done
glancing
at
him
,
and
were
talking
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
true
reason
,
"
said
one
of
them
,
bringing
a
story
he
had
been
telling
,
to
a
close
,
<EOS>
"
that
's
the
true
reason
why
they
said
that
the
devil
was
let
loose
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
speaker
was
the
tall
Swiss
belonging
to
the
church
,
and
he
brought
something
of
the
authority
of
the
church
into
the
discussion
---
especially
as
the
devil
was
in
question
.
   
<EOS>
The
landlady
having
given
her
directions
for
the
new
guest
's
entertainment
to
her
husband
,
who
acted
as
cook
to
the
Break
of
Day
,
had
resumed
her
needlework
behind
her
counter
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
smart
,
neat
,
bright
little
woman
,
with
a
good
deal
of
cap
and
a
good
deal
of
stocking
,
and
she
struck
into
the
conversation
with
several
laughing
nods
of
her
head
,
but
without
looking
up
from
her
work
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
Heaven
,
then
,
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
the
boat
came
up
from
Lyons
,
and
brought
the
news
that
the
devil
was
actually
let
loose
at
Marseilles
,
some
fly
-
catchers
swallowed
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
not
I.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madame
,
you
are
always
right
,
"
returned
the
tall
Swiss
.
<EOS>
"
Doubtless
you
were
enraged
against
that
man
,
madame
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
yes
,
then
!
"
cried
the
landlady
,
raising
her
eyes
from
her
work
,
opening
them
very
wide
,
and
tossing
her
head
on
one
side
.
"
<EOS>
Naturally
,
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
bad
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
wicked
wretch
,
"
said
the
landlady
,
"
and
well
merited
what
he
had
the
good
fortune
to
escape
.
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
worse
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
madame
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
see
,
"
returned
the
Swiss
,
argumentatively
turning
his
cigar
between
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
have
been
his
unfortunate
destiny
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
have
been
the
child
of
circumstances
.
<EOS>
It
is
always
possible
that
he
had
,
and
has
,
good
in
him
if
one
did
but
know
how
to
find
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
Philosophical
philanthropy
teaches
---
"
   
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
little
knot
about
the
stove
murmured
an
objection
to
the
introduction
of
that
threatening
expression
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
two
players
at
dominoes
glanced
up
from
their
game
,
as
if
to
protest
against
philosophical
philanthropy
being
brought
by
name
into
the
Break
of
Day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
there
,
you
and
your
philanthropy
,
"
cried
the
smiling
landlady
,
nodding
her
head
more
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
Listen
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
woman
,
I.
 
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
of
philosophical
philanthropy
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
what
I
have
seen
,
and
what
I
have
looked
in
the
face
in
this
world
here
,
where
I
find
myself
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
tell
you
this
,
my
friend
,
that
there
are
people
(
men
and
women
both
,
unfortunately
)
who
have
no
good
in
them
---
none
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
are
people
whom
it
is
necessary
to
detest
without
compromise
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
are
people
who
must
be
dealt
with
as
enemies
of
the
human
race
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
are
people
who
have
no
human
heart
,
and
who
must
be
crushed
like
savage
beasts
and
cleared
out
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
but
few
,
I
hope
;
but
I
have
seen
(
in
this
world
here
where
I
find
myself
,
and
even
at
the
little
Break
of
Day
)
that
there
are
such
people
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
not
doubt
that
this
man
---
whatever
they
call
him
,
I
forget
his
name
---
is
one
of
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlady
's
lively
speech
was
received
with
greater
favour
at
the
Break
of
Day
,
than
it
would
have
elicited
from
certain
amiable
whitewashers
of
the
class
she
so
unreasonably
objected
to
,
nearer
Great
Britain
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
faith
!
 
<EOS>
If
your
philosophical
philanthropy
,
"
said
the
landlady
,
putting
down
her
work
,
and
rising

stranger
's

from
her
husband
,
who

,
"
puts

the

such

by
holding

,
in

,

,
take
it
away
from
the
Break
of
Day
,
for
it
is
n't
worth
a
sou
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
placed
the
soup
before
the
guest
,
who
changed
his
attitude
to
a
sitting
one
,
he
looked
her
full

the

,
and
his
moustache
went
up
under
his
nose
,
and
his
nose
came
down
over
his
moustache
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
previous
speaker
,
"
let

back
to

.
 
<EOS>
Leaving

,
gentlemen
,
it

because
the
man
was

on

that

that

devil

.
 
<EOS>
That

how
the

began
to

,
and
what

meant
;
nothing

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
they
call
him
?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Biraud
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rigaud
,
madame
,
"
returned
the
tall
Swiss
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rigaud
!
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
traveller
's
soup
was
succeeded
by
a
dish
of
meat
,
and
that
by
a
dish
of
vegetables
.
 
<EOS>
He
ate
all
that
was
placed
before
him
,
emptied
his
bottle
of
wine
,
called
for
a
glass
of
rum
,
and
smoked
his
cigarette
with
his
cup
of
coffee
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
became
refreshed
,
he
became
overbearing
;
and
patronised
the
company
at
the
Daybreak
in
certain
small
talk
at
which
he
assisted
,
as
if
his
condition
were
far
above
his
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
The
company
might
have
had
other
engagements
,
or
they
might
have
felt
their
inferiority
,
but
in
any
case
they
dispersed
by
degrees
,
and
not
being
replaced
by
other
company
,
left
their
new
patron
in
possession
of
the
Break
of
Day
.
 
<EOS>
The
landlord
was
clinking
about
in
his
kitchen
;
the
landlady
was
quiet
at
her
work
;
and
the
refreshed
traveller
sat
smoking
by
the
stove
,
warming

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
madame
---
that
Biraud
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rigaud
,
monsieur
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Pardon
me
again
---
has
contracted
your
displeasure
,
<EOS>
how
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlady
,
who
had
been
at
one

thinking
within
herself
that
this
was
a
handsome
man
,
at

that
this

,
observed
the
nose
coming
down
and
the

going
up
,
and
strongly

to

.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
was
a
criminal
,
she
said
,
who
had
killed
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ay
,
ay
?
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
life
,
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All

knows

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hah
!
 
<EOS>
And

he

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Monsieur
,
the
law
could
not

it

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Being
all
in

?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlady
of
the
Break
of
Day
looked
at
him
again
,
and
felt
almost
confirmed
in
her
last

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
fine
hand
,
though
,
and
he
turned
it
with

great
show
.
 
<EOS>
She
began
once
more
to
think
that
he
was
not
ill
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
mention
,

---

gentlemen
<EOS>
---
what

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
landlady
shook
her
head
;
it
being
the
first

stage
at
which
her
vivacious

had
ceased
to
nod
it
,
keeping

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
on
the
authority

journals
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
However

might

,
he
had
escaped
his

;
so
much
the
worse
.
   
<EOS>
The
guest
sat
looking
at
her
as
he
smoked
out
his
final
cigarette
,
and
as

sat

bent

her
work
,
with
an

that
might
have
resolved
her

,
and
brought
her
to
a
lasting

on
the
subject
of
his
good

bad
looks
if
she
had
seen

.
 
<EOS>
When
she
did
look
up
,
the
expression
was
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
hand
was
smoothing
his
shaggy
moustache
.
<EOS>
"
May
one
ask
to
be
shown
to
bed
,
madame
?
"
   
<EOS>
Very
willingly
,
monsieur
.
 
<EOS>
Hola
,
my
husband
!
 
<EOS>
My
husband
would
conduct
him
up
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
traveller
there
,
asleep
,
who
had
gone
to
bed
very
early
indeed
,
being
overpowered
by
fatigue
;
but
it
was
a
large
chamber
with
two
beds
in
it
,
and
space
enough
for
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
This
the
landlady
of
the
Break
of
Day
chirpingly
explained
,
calling
between
whiles
,
"
Hola
,
my
husband
!
"
<EOS>
out
at
the
side
door
.
   
<EOS>
My
husband
answered
at
length
,
"
It
is
I
,
my
wife
!
"
and
presenting
himself
in
his
cook
's
cap
,
lighted
the
traveller
up
a
steep
and
narrow
staircase
;
<EOS>
the
traveller
carrying
his
own
cloak
and
knapsack
,
and
bidding
the
landlady
good
night
with
a
complimentary
reference
to
the
pleasure
of
seeing
her
again
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
room
,
with
a
rough
splintery
floor
,
unplastered
rafters
overhead
,
and
two
bedsteads
on
opposite
sides
.
 
<EOS>
Here
"
my
husband
"
put
down
the
candle
he
carried
,
and
with
a
sidelong
look
at
his
guest
stooping
over
his
knapsack
,
gruffly
gave
him
the
instruction
,
"
The
bed
to
the
right
!
"
and
left
him
to
his
repose
.
 
<EOS>
The
landlord
,
whether
he
was
a
good
or
a
bad
physiognomist
,
had
fully
made
up
his
mind
that
the
guest
was
an
ill
-
looking
fellow
.
   
<EOS>
The
guest
looked
contemptuously
at
the
clean
coarse
bedding
prepared
for
him
,
and
,
sitting
down
on
the
rush
chair
at
the
bedside
,
drew
his
money
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
told
it
over
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
must
eat
,
"
he
muttered
to
himself
,
"
but
by
Heaven
I
must
eat
at
the
cost
of
some
other
man
to
-
morrow
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
sat
pondering
,
and
mechanically
weighing
his
money
in
his
palm
,
<EOS>
the
deep
breathing
of
the
traveller
in
the
other
bed
fell
so
regularly
upon
his
hearing
that
it
attracted
his
eyes
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
was
covered
up
warm
,
and
had
drawn
the
white
curtain
at
his
head
,
so
that
he
could
be
only
heard
,
not
seen
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
deep
regular
breathing
,
still
going
on
while
the
other
was
taking
off
his
worn
shoes
and
gaiters
,
and
still
continuing
when
he
had
laid
aside
his
coat
and

,
<EOS>
became
at
length
a
strong
provocative
to
curiosity
,
and
incentive
to
get
a
glimpse
of
the
sleeper
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
The
waking
traveller
,
therefore
,
stole
a
little
nearer
,
and
yet
a
little
nearer
,
and
a
little
nearer
to
the
sleeping
traveller
's
bed
,
until
he
stood
close
beside
it
.
 
<EOS>
Even
then
he
could
not
see
his
face
,
for
he
had
drawn
the
sheet
over
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
regular
breathing
still
continuing
,
he
put
his
smooth
white
hand
(
such
a
treacherous
hand
it
looked
,
as
it
went
creeping
from
him
!
)
<EOS>
to
the
sheet
,
and
gently
lifted
it
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Death
of
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
he
whispered
,
falling
back
,
"
here
's
Cavalletto
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
Italian
,
previously
influenced
in
his
sleep
,
perhaps
,
by
the
stealthy
presence
at
his
bedside
,
stopped
in
his
regular
breathing
,
and
with
a
long
deep
respiration
opened
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
they
were
not
awake
,
though
open
.
 
<EOS>
He
lay
for
some
seconds
looking
placidly
at
his
old
prison
companion
,
and
then
,
all
at
once
,
with
a
cry
of
surprise
and
alarm
,
sprang
out
of
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
Keep
quiet
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
I.
 
<EOS>
You
know
me
?
"
cried
the
other
,
in
a
suppressed
voice
.
   
<EOS>
But
John
Baptist
,
widely
staring
,
muttering
a
number
of
invocations
and
ejaculations
,
tremblingly
backing
into
a
corner
,
slipping
on
his
trousers
,
and
tying
his
coat
by
the
two
sleeves
<EOS>
round
his
neck
,
manifested
an
unmistakable
desire
to
escape
by
the
door
rather
than
renew
the
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
this
,
his
old
prison
comrade
fell
back
upon
the
door
,
and
set
his
shoulders
against
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cavalletto
!
 
<EOS>
Wake
,
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Rub
your
eyes
and
look
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
name
you
used
to
call
me
---
do
n't
use
that
---
Lagnier
,
say
Lagnier
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
,
staring
at
him
with
<EOS>
eyes
opened
to
their
utmost
width
,
made
a
number
of
those
national
,
backhanded
shakes
of
the
right
forefinger
in
the
air
,
as
if
he
were
resolved
on
negativing
beforehand
everything
that
the
other
could
possibly
advance
during
the
whole
term
of
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cavalletto
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
hand
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
Lagnier
,
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Touch
the
hand
of
a
gentleman
!
"
   
<EOS>
Submitting
himself
to
the
old
tone
of
condescending
authority
,
John
Baptist
,
not
at
all
steady
on
his
legs
as
yet
,
advanced
and
put
his
hand
in
his
patron
's
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
Lagnier
laughed
;
and
having
given
it
a
squeeze
,
tossed
it
up
and
let
it
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
were
---
"
faltered
John
Baptist
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
shaved
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
See
here
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Lagnier
,
giving
his
head
a
twirl
;
"
as
tight
on
as
your
own
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
,
with
a
slight
shiver
,
looked
all
round
the
room
as
if
to
recall
where
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
His
patron
took
that
opportunity
of
turning
the
key
in
the
door
,
and
then
sat
down
upon
his
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
holding
up
his
shoes
and
gaiters
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
poor
trim
for
a
gentleman
,
you
'll
say
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
,
you
shall
see
how
Soon
I
'll
mend
it
.
 
<EOS>
Come
and
sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
old
place
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
,
looking
anything
but
reassured
,
sat
down
on
the
floor
at
the
bedside
,
keeping
his
eyes
upon
his
patron
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Lagnier
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
we
might
be
in
the
old
infernal
hole
again
,
<EOS>
hey
?
 
<EOS>
How
long
have
you
been
out
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Two
days
after
you
,
my
master
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
come
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
cautioned
not
to
stay
there
,
and
so
I
left
the
town
at
once
,
and
since
then
I
have
changed
about
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
doing
odds
and
ends
at
Avignon
,
at
Pont
Esprit
,
at
Lyons
;
upon
the
Rhone
,
upon
the
Saone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
rapidly
mapped
the
places
out
with
his
sunburnt
hand
upon
the
floor
.
"
<EOS>
And
where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
,
my
master
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
seemed
to
desire
to
evade
the
question
without
knowing
how
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
Bacchus
!
"
he
said
at
last
,
as
if
he
were
forced
to
the
admission
,
"
I
have
sometimes
had
a
thought
of
going
to
Paris
,
and
perhaps
to
England
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
in
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
I
also
am
going
to
Paris
and
perhaps
to
England
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
go
together
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
nodded
his
head
,
and
showed
his
teeth
;
and
yet
seemed
not
quite
convinced
that
it
was
a
surpassingly
desirable
arrangement
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
'll
go
together
,
"
repeated
Lagnier
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
see
how
soon
I
will
force
myself
to
be
recognised
as
a
gentleman
,
and
you
shall
profit
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
agreed
?
 
<EOS>
Are
we
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
surely
,
surely
!
"
said
the
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
shall
hear
before
I
sleep
---
and
in
six
words
,
for
I
want
sleep
---
how
I
appear
before
you
,
I
,
Lagnier
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
that
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Altro
,
altro
!
 
<EOS>
Not
Ri
---
"
<EOS>
Before
John
Baptist
could
finish
the
name
,
his
comrade
had
got
his
hand
under
his
chin
and
fiercely
shut
up
his
mouth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Death
!
 
<EOS>
what
are
you
doing
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
want
me
to
be
trampled
upon
and
stoned
?
 
<EOS>
Do
YOU
want
to
be
trampled
upon
and
stoned
?
 
<EOS>
You
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
imagine
that
they
would
set
upon
me
,
and
let
my
prison
chum
go
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
think
it
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
was
an
expression
in
his
face
as
he
released
his
grip
of
his
friend
's
jaw
,
from
which
his
friend
inferred
that
if
the
course
of
events
really
came
to
any
stoning
and
trampling
,
Monsieur
Lagnier
would
so
distinguish
him
with
his
notice
as
to
ensure
his
having
his
full
share
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
what
a
cosmopolitan
gentleman
Monsieur
Lagnier
was
,
and
how
few
weak
distinctions
he
made
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
man
,
"
said
Monsieur
Lagnier
,
"
whom
society
has
deeply
wronged
since
you
last
saw
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
am
sensitive
and
brave
,
and
that
it
is
my
character
to
govern
.
 
<EOS>
How
has
society
respected
those
qualities
in
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
shrieked
at
through
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
guarded
through
the
streets
against
men
,
and
especially
women
,
running
at
me
armed
with
any
weapons
<EOS>
they
could
lay
their
hands
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lain
in
prison
for
security
,
with
the
place
of
my
confinement
kept
a
secret
,
lest
I
should
be
torn
out
of
it
and
felled
by
a
hundred
blows
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
carted
out
of
Marseilles
in
the
dead
of
night
,
and
carried
leagues
away
from
it
packed
in
straw
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
not
been
safe
for
me
to
go
near
my
house
;
and
,
with
a
beggar
's
pittance
in
my
pocket
,
I
have
walked
through
vile
mud
and
weather
ever
since
,
until
my
feet
are
crippled
---
look
at
them
!
 
<EOS>
Such
are
the
humiliations
that
society
has
inflicted
upon
me
,
possessing
the
qualities
I
have
mentioned
,
and
which
you
know
me
to
possess
.
 
<EOS>
But
society
shall
pay
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
he
said
in
his
companion
's
ear
,
and
with
his
hand
before
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
here
,
"
he
went
on
in
the
same
way
,
"
even
in
this
mean
drinking
-
shop
,
society
pursues
me
.
 
<EOS>
Madame
defames
me
,
and
her
guests
defame
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
,
too
,
a
gentleman
with
manners
and
accomplishments
to
strike
them
dead
!
 
<EOS>
But
the
wrongs
society
has
heaped
upon
me
are
treasured
in
this
breast
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
all
of
which
John
Baptist
,
listening
attentively
to
the
suppressed
hoarse
voice
,
said
from
time
to
time
,
"
Surely
,
surely
!
"
<EOS>
tossing
his
head
and
shutting
his
eyes
,
as
if
there
were
the
clearest
case
against
society
that
perfect
candour
could
make
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Put
my
shoes
there
,
"
continued
Lagnier
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hang
my
cloak
to
dry
there
by
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Take
my
hat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
obeyed
each
instruction
,
as
it
was
given
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
this
is
the
bed
to
which
society
consigns
me
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Hah
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
stretched
out
his
length
upon
it
,
with
a
ragged
handkerchief
bound
round
his
wicked
head
,
and
only
his
wicked
head
showing
above
the
bedclothes
,
John
Baptist
was
rather
strongly
reminded
of
what
had
so
very
nearly
happened
to
prevent
the
moustache
from
any
more
going
up
as
it
did
,
and
the
nose
from
any
more
coming
down
as
it
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shaken
out
of
destiny
's
dice
-
box
again
into
your
company
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
better
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
profit
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
need
a
long
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
sleep
in
the
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
Baptist
replied
that
he
should
sleep
as
long
as
he
would
,
and
wishing
him
a
happy
night
,
put
out
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
One
might
have
Supposed
that
the
next
proceeding
of
the
Italian
would
have
been
to
undress
;
but
he
did
exactly
the
reverse
,
and
dressed
himself
from
head
to
foot
,
saving
his
shoes
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
so
done
,
he
lay
down
upon
his
bed
with
some
of
its
coverings
over
him
,
and
his
coat
still
tied
round
his
neck
,
to
get
through
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
started
up
,
the
Godfather
Break
of
Day
was
peeping
at
its
namesake
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
,
took
his
shoes
in
his
hand
,
turned
the
key
in
the
door
with
great
caution
,
and
crept
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
was
astir
there
<EOS>
but
the
smell
of
coffee
,
wine
,
tobacco
,
and
syrups
;
and
madame
's
little
counter
looked
ghastly
enough
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
paid
madame
his
little
note
at
it
over
night
,
and
wanted
to
see
nobody
<EOS>
---
wanted
nothing
but
to
get
on
his
shoes
and
his
knapsack
,
open
the
door
,
and
run
away
.
   
<EOS>
He
prospered
in
his
object
.
 
<EOS>
No
movement
or
voice
was
heard
when
he
opened
the
door
;
no
wicked
head
tied
up
in
a
ragged
handkerchief
looked
out
of
the
upper
window
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
sun
had
raised
his
full
disc
above
the
flat
line
of
the
horizon
,
and
was
striking
fire
out
of
the
long
muddy
vista
of
paved
road
with
its
weary
avenue
of
little
trees
,
a
black
speck
moved
along
the
road
and
splashed
among
the
flaming
pools
of
rain
-
water
,
which
black
speck
was
John
Baptist
Cavalletto
running
away
from
his
patron
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
12
.
<EOS>
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
 
<EOS>
In
London
itself
,
though
in
the
old
rustic
road
towards
a
suburb
of
note
where
in
the
days
of
William
Shakespeare
,
author
and
stage
-
player
,
there
were
Royal
hunting
-
seats
---
<EOS>
howbeit
<EOS>
no
sport
is
left
there
now
but
for
hunters
of
men
<EOS>
---
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
was
to
be
found
;
a
place
much
changed
in
feature
and
in
fortune
,
yet
with
some
relish
of
ancient
greatness
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
mighty
stacks
of
chimneys
,
and
a
few
large
dark
rooms
which
had
escaped
being
walled
and
subdivided
out
of
the
recognition
of
their
old
proportions
,
gave
the
Yard
a
character
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
inhabited
by
poor
people
,
who
set
up
their
rest
among
its
faded
glories
,
as
Arabs
of
the
desert
pitch
their
tents
among
the
fallen
stones
of
the
Pyramids
;
but
there
was
a
family
sentimental
feeling
prevalent
in
the
Yard
,
that
it
had
a
character
.
   
<EOS>
As
if
the
aspiring
city
had
become
puffed
up
in
the
very
ground
on
which
it
stood
,
the
ground
had
so
risen
about
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
that
you
got
into
it
down
a
flight
of
steps
which
formed
no
part
of
the
original
approach
,
and
got
out
of
it
by
a
low
gateway
into
a
maze
of
shabby
streets
,
which
went
about
and
about
,
tortuously
ascending
to
the
level
again
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
end
of
the
Yard
and
over
the
gateway
,
was
the
factory
of
Daniel
Doyce
,
often
heavily
beating
like
a
bleeding
heart
of
iron
,
with
the
clink
of
metal
upon
metal
.
<EOS>
The
opinion
of
the
Yard
was
divided
respecting
the
derivation
of
its
name
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
practical
of
its
inmates
abided
by
the
tradition
of
a
murder
;
the
gentler
and
more
imaginative
inhabitants
,
including
the
whole
of
the
tender
sex
,
were
loyal
to
the
legend
of
a
young
lady
of
former
times
closely
imprisoned
in
her
chamber
by
a
cruel
father
for
remaining
true
to
her
own
true
love
,
and
refusing
to
marry
the
suitor
he
chose
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
legend
related
how
that
the
young
lady
used
to
be
seen
up
at
her
window
behind
the
bars
,
murmuring
a
love
-
lorn
song
of
which
the
burden
was
,
"
Bleeding
Heart
,
Bleeding
Heart
,
bleeding
away
,
"
until
she
died
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
objected
by
the
murderous
party
that
this
Refrain
was
notoriously
the
invention
of
a
tambour
-
worker
,
a
spinster
and
romantic
,
still
lodging
in
the
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
forasmuch
as
all
favourite
legends
must
be
associated
with
the
affections
,
and
as
many
more
people
fall
in
love
than
commit
murder
---
which
it
may
be
hoped
,
howsoever
bad
we
are
,
will
continue
until
the
end
of
the
world
to
be
the
dispensation
under
which
we
shall
live
---
the
Bleeding
Heart
,
Bleeding
Heart
,
bleeding
away
story
,
carried
the
day
by
a
great
majority
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
party
would
listen
to
the
antiquaries
who
delivered
learned
lectures
in
the
neighbourhood
,
showing
the
Bleeding
Heart
to
have
been
the
heraldic
cognisance
of
the
old
family
to
whom
the
property
had
once
belonged
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
considering
that
the
hour
-
glass
they
turned
from
year
to
year
was
filled
with
the
earthiest
and
coarsest
sand
,
the
Bleeding
Heart
Yarders
had
reason
enough
for
objecting
to
be
despoiled
of
the
one
little
golden
grain
of
poetry
that
sparkled
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
Down
in
to
the
Yard
,
by
way
of
the
steps
,
came
Daniel
Doyce
,
Mr
Meagles
,
and
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
along
the
Yard
,
and
between
the
open
doors
on
either
hand
,
all
abundantly
garnished
with
light
children
nursing
heavy
ones
,
they
arrived
at
its
opposite
boundary
,
the
gateway
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Arthur
Clennam
stopped
to
look
about
him
for
the
domicile
of
Plornish
,
plasterer
,
whose
name
,
according
to
the
custom
of
Londoners
,
Daniel
Doyce
had
never
seen
or
heard
of
to
that
hour
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
plain
enough
,
nevertheless
,
as
Little
Dorrit
had
said
;
over
a
lime
-
splashed
gateway
in
the
corner
,
within
which
Plornish
kept
a
ladder
and
a
barrel
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
house
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
which
she
had
described
as
his
place
of
habitation
,
was
a
large
house
,
let
off
to
various
tenants
;
but
Plornish
ingeniously
hinted
that
he
lived
in
the
parlour
,
by
means
of
a
painted
hand
under
his
name
,
the
forefinger
of
which
hand
(
on
which
the
artist
had
depicted
a
ring
and
a
most
elaborate
nail
of
the
genteelest
form
)
referred
all
inquirers
to
that
apartment
.
   
<EOS>
Parting
from
his
companions
,
after
arranging
another
meeting
with
Mr
Meagles
,
Clennam
went
alone
into
the
entry
,
and
knocked
with
his
knuckles
at
the
parlour
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
opened
presently
by
a
woman
with
a
child
in
her
arms
,
whose
unoccupied
hand
was
hastily
rearranging
the
upper
part
of
her
dress
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
Mrs
Plornish
,
and
this
maternal
action
was
the
action
of
Mrs
Plornish
during
a
large
part
of
her
waking
existence
.
   
<EOS>
Was
Mr
Plornish
at
home
?
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
a
civil
woman
,
"
not
to
deceive
you
,
he
's
gone
to
look
for
a
job
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
to
deceive
you
"
was
a
method
of
speech
with
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
deceive
you
,
under
any
circumstances
,
as
little
as
might
be
;
but
she
had
a
trick
of
answering
in
this
provisional
form
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
will
be
back
soon
,
if
I
wait
for
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
expecting
him
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
this
half
an
hour
,
at
any
minute
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
Walk
in
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Arthur
entered
the
rather
dark
and
close
parlour
(
though
it
was
lofty
too
)
,
and
sat
down
in
the
chair
she
placed
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
to
deceive
you
,
sir
,
I
notice
it
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
and
I
take
it
kind
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
at
a
loss
to
understand
what
she
meant
;
and
by
expressing
as
much
in
his
looks
,
elicited
her
explanation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
many
that
comes
into
a
poor
place
,
that
deems
it
worth
their
while
to
move
their
hats
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
people
think
more
of
it
than
people
think
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
returned
,
with
an
uncomfortable
feeling
in
so
very
slight
a
courtesy
being
unusual
,
Was
that
all
!
 
<EOS>
And
stooping
down
to
pinch
the
cheek
of
another
young
child
who
was
sitting
on
the
floor
,
staring
at
him
,
asked
Mrs
Plornish
how
old
that
fine
boy
was
?
   
<EOS>
"
Four
year
just
turned
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
IS
a
fine
little
fellow
,
ai
n't
he
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
But
this
one
is
rather
sickly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She
tenderly
hushed
the
baby
in
her
arms
,
as
she
said
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
mind
my
asking
if
it
happened
to
be
a
job
as
you
was
come
about
,
sir
,
would
you
?
"
asked
Mrs
Plornish
wistfully
.
   
<EOS>
She
asked
it
so
anxiously
,
that
if
he
had
been
in
possession
of
any
kind
of
tenement
,
he
would
have
had
it
plastered
a
foot
deep
rather
than
answer
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
obliged
to
answer
No
;
and
he
saw
a
shade
of
disappointment
on
her
face
,
as
she
checked
a
sigh
,
and
looked
at
the
low
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
saw
,
also
,
that
Mrs
Plornish
was
a
young
woman
,
made
somewhat
slatternly
in
herself
and
her
belongings
by
poverty
;
and
so
dragged
at
by
poverty
and
the
children
together
,
that
their
united
forces
had
already
dragged
her
face
into
wrinkles
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
such
things
as
jobs
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
seems
to
me
to
have
gone
underground
,
they
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Herein
Mrs
Plornish
limited
her
remark
to
the
plastering
trade
,
and
spoke
without
reference
to
the
Circumlocution
Office
and
the
Barnacle
Family
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
so
difficult
to
get
work
?
"
asked
Arthur
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Plornish
finds
it
so
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
quite
unfortunate
.
<EOS>
Really
he
is
.
"
<EOS>
Really
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
one
of
those
many
wayfarers
on
the
road
of
life
,
who
seem
to
be
afflicted
with
supernatural
corns
,
rendering
it
impossible
for
them
to
keep
up
even
with
their
lame
competitors
.
   
<EOS>
A
willing
,
working
,
soft
hearted
,
not
hard
-
headed
fellow
,
Plornish
took
his
fortune
as
smoothly
as
could
be
expected
;
but
it
was
a
rough
one
.
 
<EOS>
It
so
rarely
happened
that
anybody
seemed
to
want
him
,
it
was
such
an
exceptional
case
<EOS>
when
his
powers
were
in
any
request
,
that
his
misty
mind
could
not
make
out
how
it
happened
.
<EOS>
He
took
it
as
it
came
,
therefore
;
he
tumbled
into
all
kinds
of
difficulties
,
and
tumbled
out
of
them
;
and
,
by
tumbling
through
life
,
got
himself
considerably
bruised
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
for
want
of
looking
after
jobs
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
lifting
up
her

,
and
searching
for
a
solution
of
the
problem
between
the
bars
of
the
grate
;
"
nor
yet
for
want
of
working
at
them
when
they
are
to
be
got
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
ever
heard
my
husband
complain
of
work
.
"
   
<EOS>
Somehow
or
other
,
this
was
the
general
misfortune
of
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
From
time
to
time
there
were
public
complaints
,
pathetically
going
about
,
of
labour
being
scarce
---
which
certain
people
seemed
to
take
extraordinarily
ill
,
as
though
they
had
an
absolute
right
to
it
on
their
own
terms
---
but
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
though
as
willing
a
Yard
as
any
in
Britain
,
was
never
the
better
for
the
demand
.
<EOS>
That
high
old
family
,
the
Barnacles
,
had
long
been
too
busy
with
their
great
principle
to
look
into
the
matter
;
and
indeed
the
matter
had
nothing
to
do
with
their
watchfulness
in
out
-
generalling
all
other
high
old
families
except
the
Stiltstalkings
.
   
<EOS>
While
Mrs
Plornish
spoke
in
these
words
of
her
absent
lord
,
her
lord
returned
.
 
<EOS>
A
smooth
-
cheeked
,
fresh
-
coloured
,
sandy
-
whiskered
man
of
thirty
.
 
<EOS>
Long
in
the
legs
,
yielding
at
the
knees
,
foolish
in
the
face
,
flannel
-

,
lime
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
Plornish
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
,
"
said
Clennam
,

,
"
to
beg

a
little

with
you
on
the
subject
of
the
Dorrit
family
.
"
   
<EOS>
Plornish
became
suspicious
.
 
<EOS>
Seemed
to
scent
a
creditor
.
 
<EOS>
Said
,
"
Ah
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't

what
satisfaction
he
could
give
any

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

better
,
"
said

,

,
"
than
you

.
<EOS>
"
   
Plornish
observed
,
not
Smiling
in

,
And
yet
he
had
n't
the
pleasure
of
being
acquainted
with
the
gentleman
,
neither
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,
"
I

,

;
through
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
---

,
"
he

,
"
Miss

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
of

,
"

<EOS>
"
Please

,
Sir

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Why
,

,
"

Plornish
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Me

wife
<EOS>
,

Miss
Dorrit
.
"
<EOS>
"
Intimate
!
"

Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
was
so

,
that

in

Yard
by

an

the

's

.
 
<EOS>
The

Hearts
resented
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

---

---
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
And

's

!
 
<EOS>
There

!
 
<EOS>
There
's
a

to

!
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,
"
said

,

,

pitied

,
"
not

Miss
Dorrit
and

dursn't
<EOS>
let

know

they
work

.
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
said
Plornish
,
looking

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dursn't
let
him

,

dursn't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Without

him
for
that
,
"
Clennam
quietly

,
"
I
am
very

.
"
 
<EOS>
The
remark
appeared
to
suggest

Plornish
,
for
the
first

,
that

might

.
 
<EOS>
He

for
a

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

,
"
he

,
"

Mr
Dorrit
is
as

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Considering
the
differences

<EOS>
betwixt

,
more

.
 
<EOS>
But

's
Miss
Dorrit
that

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
how
did
you
introduce

at

mother
's
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Plornish
picked
a
bit
of
lime
out
of
his

,
put
it
between

,
turned
it

like

,
considered
,
found

,

,
"
Sally
,
you

was
,
old

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dorrit
,
"
said
Sally
,
hushing
the

from

,
and
laying

,
"
came

,

,

-

.
<EOS>
"
 
(
Plornish

,
her

,

,

.
)
<EOS>
"
Me

,
No
,

,

-

,
"
(
Plornish

,

,
)
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Which

,
Ho
Miss

!
"
 
<EOS>
(
Plornish

,
Ho
Miss
Dorrit
.
)
<EOS>
"
Have

?
 
<EOS>
No
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,

Plornish
,

,

,
"
(
Plornish

,
)
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Plornish

,
employ

Dorrit
;
and
Mrs

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,

,
"

,
"
and
Pancks
,

.
 
<EOS>
That
<EOS>
,
"

Mr
Plornish
,

appeared

,
"
that

about

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Casby
,
too
!
<EOS>
An
old
acquaintance
of
mine
,

ago
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Plornish
did
not
see
his
road
to
any
comment
on
this
fact
,
and
made
none
.
 
<EOS>
As
there
truly
was
no
reason
why
he
should
have
the
least

in
it
,
Arthur
Clennam
went
on
to
the
present
purport
of
his

;
namely
,
to
make
Plornish
the
instrument
of
effecting
Tip
's

,
with
as

of

,

him
to
possess
any

those
qualities
:
without
doubt
a
very
wide
stretch
of
supposition
.
 
<EOS>
Plornish
,
having
been
made

with
the
cause
of
action
from
the
Defendant
's
own

,
gave
Arthur
to
understand
that
the
Plaintiff
was
a
"
Chaunter
"
---
<EOS>
meaning
,
not
a

,
but

---
and
that
he
(
Plornish
)
considered
that
ten

in
the
pound
"
would
settle
handsome
,
"
and
that
more
would
be
a

.
 
<EOS>
The
Principal
and
instrument
soon
drove
off
together
to
a
stable
-
yard
in
High
Holborn
,
where
a
remarkably
fine
grey
gelding
,
worth
,
at
the
lowest
figure
,
seventy
-
five
guineas
(
not

the
value
of
the
shot
he

for

)
,
was

-

,

run
away
last
week
with
Mrs
Captain
Barbary

Cheltenham
,
who
was
n't
up

a
horse
of
his

,

,

,

on

:
or
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Plornish
,

,

(

)
;

,

.
 
<EOS>

:

augur

business
,

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,
"
Now
,

?
 
<EOS>
Now
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then

,

"
Now
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

"
Now
,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
---

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

---
"
Finding

.
 
<EOS>
He
took

's
card
and
appropriate

.
   
<EOS>
He
was

to
finish
his

at

,
and
his
Principal
was
in

same

.
 
<EOS>
So

Principal
offered
to
set
him
down
at
the
Marshalsea
Gate
,
and
they
drove
in
that
direction
over
Blackfriars
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
On

way
,
Arthur
elicited
from
his
new
friend
a
confused
summary
of
the
interior
life
of
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
They
was
all
hard
up
there
,
Mr
Plornish
said
,
uncommon
hard
up
,
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
he
could
n't
say
how
it
was
;
he
did
n't
know
as
anybody
could
say
how
it
was
;
all
he
know'd
was
,
that
so
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
When
a
man
felt
,
on
his
own
back
and
in
his
own
belly
,
that
poor
he
was
,
that
man
<EOS>
(
Mr
Plornish
gave
it
as
his
decided
belief
)
<EOS>
know'd
<EOS>
well
that
he
was
poor
somehow
or
another
,
and
you
could

talk
it
out
of
him
,
no
more
than
you
could
talk
Beef
into

.
 
<EOS>
Then
you
see
,
some
people
as
was
better
off
said
,
and
a
good
many
such
people
lived
pretty
close
up
to
the
mark
themselves
if
not

it
<EOS>
so
he
'd
heerd
,
that
they
was
"
improvident
"
<EOS>
(
that

)
down

Yard
.
 
<EOS>
For

,
if
they
see

Hampton
Court
in
a
Wan
,
perhaps
once

,
they

,
"
Hallo
!
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
was
poor
,
my
improvident
friend
!
"
 
<EOS>
Why
,
Lord
,
how
hard
it
was
upon
a
man
!
 
<EOS>
What
was
a
man
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
go
mollancholy
mad
,
and
even
if
he
did
,
you
would
n't
be
the
better
for

.
 
<EOS>
In
Mr
Plornish
's

would
be
the

for

.
 
<EOS>
Yet
you
seemed
to
want
to
make
a
man
mollancholy
mad
.
 
<EOS>
You
was
always
at
it
---
if
not

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
What
was
they
a
doing
in
the
Yard
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
take
a
look
at
'em
and
see
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
girls
and
their
mothers
a
working
at
their

,
or

-

,
or
their

,
or
their

making
,
day

and
night
and
day
,
and
not
more
than
able
to
keep
body
and
soul
together
after
all
---
often
not
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
people
of
pretty
well
all
sorts
of
trades
you
could
name
,
all
wanting
to
work
,
and
yet
not
able
to
get

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
old
people
,
after
working
all
their
lives
,
going
and
being
shut
up
in
the
workhouse
,
much
worse
fed
and
lodged
and
treated
altogether
,
than
<EOS>
---
Mr
Plornish
said
manufacturers
,
but
appeared
to
mean
malefactors
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
a
man
did
n't
know
where
to
turn
himself
for
a
crumb
of
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
As

was

blame

,
Mr

did

who
was

for

.
 
<EOS>
He
could
tell
you
who

,
but
he
could

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
HIS

to
find

,
and
who
'd

,

?
 
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
only
know'd
<EOS>
that
it
was
n't
put
right
by
them
<EOS>
what

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
,

,
his
illogical

,
that
if

could

,

for

of

;
so

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,

,

-

,

,
did
Plornish
turn

about

who
was

;
until

.
 
<EOS>
There
,
he
left
his
Principal
alone
;
to
wonder
,
as

rode

,
how
many
thousand
Plornishes
there
might
be
within
a
day
or
two
's
journey
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
playing
sundry
curious
variations
on
the
same
tune
,
which
were
not
known
by
ear
in
that
glorious
institution
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
Patriarchal
 
<EOS>
The
mention
of
Mr
Casby
again
revived
in
Clennam
's
memory
the
smouldering
embers
of
curiosity
and
interest
which
Mrs
Flintwinch
had
fanned
on
the
night
of
his
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
Flora
Casby
had
been
the
beloved
of
his
boyhood
;
and
Flora
was
the
daughter
and
only
child
of
wooden
-
headed
old
Christopher
<EOS>
(
so
he
was
still
occasionally
spoken
of
by
some
irreverent
spirits
who
had
had
dealings
with
him
,
and
in
whom
familiarity
had
bred
its
proverbial
result
perhaps
)
,
who
was
reputed
to
be
rich
in
weekly
tenants
,
and
to
get
a
good
quantity
of
blood
out
of
the
stones
of
several
unpromising
courts
and
alleys
.
<EOS>
After
some
days
of
inquiry
and
research
,
Arthur
Clennam
became
convinced
that
the
case
of
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
was
indeed
a
hopeless
one
,
and
sorrowfully
resigned
the
idea
of
helping
him
to
freedom
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
hopeful
inquiry
to
make
at
present
,
concerning
Little
Dorrit
either
;
but
he
argued
with
himself
that
it
might
---
for
anything
he
knew
---
it
might
be
serviceable
to
the
poor
child
,
if
he
renewed
this
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
hardly
necessary
to
add
that
beyond
all
doubt
he
would
have
presented
himself
at
Mr
Casby
's
door
,
if
there
had
been
no
Little
Dorrit
in
existence
;
for
we
all
know
how
we
all
deceive
ourselves
---
<EOS>
that
is
to
say
,
how
people
in
general
,
our
profounder
selves
excepted
,
deceive
themselves
---
as
to
motives
of
action
.
   
<EOS>
With
a
comfortable
impression
upon
him
,
and
quite
an
honest
one
in
its
way
,
that
he
was
still
patronising
Little
Dorrit
in
doing
what
had
no
reference
to
her
,
he
found
himself
one
afternoon
at
the
corner
of
Mr
Casby
's
street
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Casby
lived
in
a
street
in
the
Gray
's
Inn
Road
,
which
had
set
off
from
that
thoroughfare
with
the
intention
of
running
at
one
heat
down
into
the
valley
,
and
up
again
to
the
top
of
Pentonville
Hill
;
but
which
had
run
itself
out
of
breath
in
twenty
yards
,
and
had
stood
still
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
place
in
that
part
now
;
but
it
remained
there
for
many
years
,
looking
with
a
baulked
countenance
at
the
wilderness
patched
with
unfruitful
gardens
and
pimpled
with
eruptive
summerhouses
,
that
it
had
meant
to
run
over
in
no
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
house
,
"
thought
Clennam
,
as
he
crossed
to
the
door
,
"
is
as
little
changed
as
my
mother
's
,
and
looks
almost
as
gloomy
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
likeness
ends
outside
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
its
staid
repose
within
.
 
<EOS>
The
smell
of
its
jars
of
old
rose
-
leaves
and
lavender
seems
to
come
upon
me
even
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
his
knock
at
the
bright
brass
knocker
of
obsolete
shape
brought
a
woman
-
servant
to
the
door
,
those
faded
scents
in
truth
saluted
him
like
wintry
breath
that
had
a
faint
remembrance
in
it
of
the
bygone
spring
.
 
<EOS>
He
stepped
into
the
sober
,
silent
,
air
-
tight
house
---
one
might
have
fancied
it
to
have
been
stifled
by
Mutes
in
the
Eastern
manner
---
and
the
door
,
closing
again
,
seemed
to
shut
out
sound
and
motion
.
 
<EOS>
The
furniture
was
formal
,
grave
,
and
quaker
-
like
,
but
well
-
kept
;
and
had
as
prepossessing
an
aspect
as
anything
,
from
a
human
creature
to
a
wooden
stool
,
that
is
meant
for
much
use
and
is
preserved
for
little
,
can
ever
wear
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
grave
clock
,
ticking
somewhere
up
the
staircase
;
and
there
was
a
songless
bird
in
the
same
direction
,
pecking
at
his
cage
,
as
if
he
were
ticking
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
parlour
-
fire
ticked
in
the
grate
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
person
on
the
parlour
-
hearth
,
and
the
loud
watch
in
his
pocket
ticked
audibly
.
   
<EOS>
The
servant
-
maid
had
ticked
the
two
words
"
Mr
Clennam
"
so
softly
that
she
had
not
been
heard
;
and
he
consequently
stood
,
within
the
door
she
had
closed
,
unnoticed
.
 
<EOS>
The
figure
of
a
man
advanced
in
life
,
whose
smooth
grey
eyebrows
seemed
to
move
to
the
ticking
as
the
fire
-
light
flickered
on
them
,
sat
in
an
arm
-
chair
,
with
his
list
shoes
on
the
rug
,
and
his
thumbs
slowly
revolving
over
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
old
Christopher
Casby
---
recognisable
at
a
glance
---
as
unchanged
in
twenty
years
and
upward
as
his
own
solid
furniture
---
as
little
touched
by
the
influence
of
the
varying
seasons
as
the
old
rose
-
leaves
and
old
lavender
in
his
porcelain
jars
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
never
was
a
man
,
in
this
troublesome
world
,
so
troublesome
for
the
imagination
to
picture
as
a
boy
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
had
changed
very
little
in
his
progress
through
life
.
 
<EOS>
Confronting
him
,
in
the
room
in
which
he
sat
,
was
a
boy
's
portrait
,
which
anybody
seeing
him
would
have
identified
as
Master
Christopher
Casby
,
aged
ten
:
though
disguised
with
a
haymaking
rake
,
for
which
he
had
had
,
at
any
time
,
as
much
taste
or
use
as
for
a
diving
-
bell
;
and
sitting
(
on
one
of
his
own
legs
)
upon
a
bank
of
violets
,
moved
to
precocious
contemplation
by
the
spire
of
a
village
church
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
same
smooth
face
and
forehead
,
the
same
calm
blue
eye
,
the
same
placid
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
shining
bald
head
,
which
looked
so
very
large
because
it
shone
so
much
;
and
the
long
grey
hair
at
its
sides
and
back
,
like
floss
silk
or
spun
glass
,
which
looked
so
very
benevolent
because
it
was
never
cut
;
were
not
,
of
course
,
to
be
seen
in
the
boy
as
in
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
in
the
Seraphic
creature
with
the
haymaking
rake
,
were
clearly
to
be
discerned
the
rudiments
of
the
Patriarch
with
the
list
shoes
.
   
<EOS>
Patriarch
was
the
name
which
many
people
delighted
to
give
him
.
<EOS>
Various
old
ladies
in
the
neighbourhood
spoke
of
him
as
The
Last
of
the
Patriarchs
.
 
<EOS>
So
grey
,
so
slow
,
so
quiet
,
so
impassionate
,
so
very
bumpy
in
the
head
,
Patriarch
was
the
word
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
accosted
in
the
streets
,
and
respectfully
solicited
to
become
a
Patriarch
for
painters
and
for
sculptors
;
with
so
much
importunity
,
in
sooth
,
that
it
would
appear
to
be
beyond
the
Fine
Arts
to
remember
the
points
of
a
Patriarch
,
or
to
invent
one
.
<EOS>
Philanthropists
of
both
sexes
had
asked
who
he
was
,
and
on
being
informed
,
"
Old
Christopher
Casby
,
formerly
Town
-
agent
to
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
,
"
had
cried
in
a
rapture
of
disappointment
,
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
why
,
with
that
head
,
is
he
not
a
benefactor
to
his
species
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
why
,
with
that
head
,
is
he
not
a
father
to
the
orphan
and
a
friend
to
the
friendless
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
that

,
however
,
he
remained
old
Christopher
Casby
,
proclaimed
by
common
report
rich
in
house
property
;
and
with
that
head
,
he
now
sat
in
his
silent
parlour
.
<EOS>
Indeed
it
would
be
the
height

unreason
to
expect

to
be

without
that
head
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
moved
to
attract

attention
,
and
the
grey

turned

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,
"
<EOS>
I

not

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
I
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
wish
to
see

,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wished
to
pay
my
respects
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Casby
seemed
a
feather
's
weight
disappointed
by
the
last
words
,
having
perhaps
prepared

for
the
visitor
's

to
pay
something
else
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have

the

,

,
"
he

---
"
take
a
chair
<EOS>
,
if

---
have
I

---
?
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
truly
,
yes
,
I
think

!
 
<EOS>
I
believe

am
not

in

?
 
<EOS>
I
think

a

of
whose

to

country
<EOS>
I

Mr

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
Mr
Casby
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
How
have
you
been
since
we
met
?
"
   
<EOS>
Without

to
explain
that
in

some
quarter
of
a
century
he
had

,
Clennam
answered

that

never

,
or
something

;
and
shook

with

"
that

"
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
older
,
Mr

,
"
said
Christopher
Casby
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
---
not
younger
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
wise
remark
he
felt
that
he
was
scarcely
shining
with
brilliancy
,
and
became
aware
that
he
was
nervous
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
respected
father
,
"
said
Mr
Casby
,
"
is
no

!
 
<EOS>
I
was
grieved
to
hear
it
,
Mr
Clennam
,
I
was
grieved
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
replied
in
the
usual
way
that
he
felt
infinitely
obliged
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
time
,
"
said
Mr
Casby
,
"
when
your
parents
and
myself
were
not
on
friendly
terms
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
family
misunderstanding
among
us
.
 
<EOS>
Your
respected
mother
was
rather
jealous
of
her
son
,
maybe
;
when
I
say
her
son
,
I
mean
your
worthy
self
,
your
worthy
self
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
smooth
face
had
a
bloom
upon
it
like
ripe
wall
-
fruit
.
 
<EOS>
What
with
his
blooming
face
,
and
that
head
,
and
his
blue

,
he
seemed
to
be
delivering
sentiments
of
rare

and

.
 
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
his
physiognomical
expression
seemed
to
teem
with
benignity
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
could
have
said
where
the
wisdom
was
,
or
where
the
virtue
was
,
or
where
the
benignity
was
;
but
they
all
seemed
to

somewhere

.
"
<EOS>
Those
times
,
however
,
"
pursued
Mr
Casby
,
"
are
past
and
gone
,
past
and
gone
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
myself
the
pleasure
of
making
a
visit
to
your
respected
mother
occasionally
,
and
of
admiring
the
fortitude
and
strength
of
mind
with
which
she
bears
her
trials
,
bears
her
trials
.
<EOS>
"
 
When
he
made
one
of
these
little

,
sitting
with
his
hands
crossed
before
him
,
he
did
it
with
his

on
one
side
,
and
a

,
as
if
he
had
something
in
his
thoughts
too
sweetly

.
 
<EOS>
As
if

denied

of
uttering

,
lest
he
should
soar
too
high
;
and
his

therefore
preferred

unmeaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
that
you
were
kind

,
"
said
Arthur
,
catching

,
"
to
mention
Little
Dorrit
to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Little
---
Dorrit
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
seamstress
who
was

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Dorrit
?
 
<EOS>
That
's

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
yes
,
yes
!
 
<EOS>
You
call

Little
Dorrit
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
road
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
came
of
the
cross
-
cut
.
 
<EOS>
It
led
no
further
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
Flora
,
"
said
Mr
Casby
,
"
as
you
may
have
heard
probably
,
Mr
Clennam
,
was
married
and
established
in
life
,
several
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
the
misfortune
to
lose
her
husband
when
she
had

a

months
.
 
<EOS>
She
resides
with
me
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
will

,
if
you

you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By

,
"

Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
preferred
the
request
,
if
your

had
not

.
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
this
Mr
Casby
rose
up
in
his
list
shoes
,
and
with
a
slow
,
heavy
step
(
he
was
of
an
elephantine
build
)
,
made
for
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
long
wide
-
skirted
bottle
-
green
coat
on
,
and
a
bottle
-
green
pair
of

,
and
a
bottle
-
green

.
 
<EOS>
The
Patriarchs
were
not
dressed
in
bottle
-
green
broadcloth
,
and
yet
his
clothes
looked
patriarchal
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
left
the
room
,
and
allowed
the
ticking
to
become
audible
again
,
when
a
quick
hand
turned
a
latchkey
in
the
house
-
door
,
opened
it
,
and
shut

.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
afterwards
,
a
quick
and
eager
short
dark
man
came
into
the
room
with
so
much
way
upon
him
that
he
was
within
a
foot
of
Clennam
before
he
could
stop
.
   
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
saw
no
reason
why
he
should
not
say
"
Halloa
!
"
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
"
said
the
short
dark
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not

anything
is

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Mr
Casby
?
<EOS>
"

dark
man
,
looking
about
.
"
<EOS>
He
will

,
if

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
\I\
want
him
?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
This
elicited
a
word
or
two
of
explanation
from
Clennam
,
during
the
delivery
of
which
the
short
dark
man
held
his

and
looked

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
black
and
rusty
iron
grey
;
had
jet

of

;
a

;
wiry

striking

in

,
like
forks
or
hair
-

;
and
a
complexion
that
was
very
dingy
by
nature
,
or
very
dirty
by
art
,
or
a
compound
of
nature
and
art
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
dirty
hands
and
dirty
broken
nails
,
and
looked
as
if
he
had
been
in
the
coals
;
he
was
in
a
perspiration
,
and
snorted
and
sniffed
and
puffed
and
blew
,
like
a
little

steam
-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
he
,
when
Arthur
told
him
how
he
came
to
be
there
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
right
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
should
ask
for
Pancks
,
will
you
be
so
good
as
to
say
that
Pancks
is
come
in
?
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
,
with
a
snort
and
a
puff
,
he
worked
out
by
another
door
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
in
the
old
days
at
home
,
certain
audacious
doubts
respecting
the
last
of
the
Patriarchs
,
which
were
afloat
in
the
air
,
had
,
by
some
forgotten
means
,
come
in
contact
with
Arthur
's
sensorium
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
aware
of
motes
and
specks
of
suspicion
in
the
atmosphere
of
that
time
;
seen
through
which
medium
,
Christopher
Casby
was
a
mere
Inn
signpost
,
without
any
Inn
---
an
invitation
to
rest
and
be
thankful
,
when
there
was
no
place
to
put
up
at
,
and
nothing
whatever
to
be
thankful
for
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
some
of
these
specks
even
represented
Christopher
as
capable
of
harbouring
designs
in
"
that
head
,
"
and
as
being
a
crafty
impostor
.
 
<EOS>
Other
motes
there
were
which
showed
him
as
a
heavy
,
selfish
,
drifting
Booby
,
who
,
having
stumbled
,
in
the
course
of
his
unwieldy
jostlings
against
other
men
,
on
the
discovery
that
to
get
through
life
with
ease
and
credit
,
he
had
but
to
hold
his
tongue
,
keep
the
bald
part
of
his
head
well
polished
,
and
leave
his
hair
alone
,
had
had
just
cunning
enough
to
seize
the
idea
and
stick
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
said
that
his
being
town
-
agent
to
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
was
referable
,
not
to
his
having
the
least
business
capacity
,
but
to
his
looking
so
supremely
benignant
that
nobody
could
suppose
the
property
screwed
or
jobbed
under
such
a
man
;
also
,
that
for
similar
reasons
he
now
got
more
money
out
of
his
own
wretched
lettings
,
unquestioned
,
than
anybody
with
a
less
nobby
and
less
shining
crown
could
possibly
have
done
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
it
was
represented
(
Clennam
called
to
mind
,
alone
in
the
ticking
parlour
)
that
many
people
select
their
models
,
much
as
the
painters
,
just
now
mentioned
,
select
theirs
;
and
that
,
whereas
in
the
Royal
Academy
some
evil

will

,

,

)
,
so
,
in

,

in

.
   
<EOS>
Calling

,

,

,
that

last

,

keeping

and

,

,

;

had

,
and
was
now

in

.
   
<EOS>
The

with

daughter

,

.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
's

no

upon

.
   
<EOS>
Most

will
be
found

to

an
old

.
 
<EOS>
It

no

mind
,
but
<EOS>
exactly

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Such

's

.
 
<EOS>
In

had

,
and
had

<EOS>
That

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
The

.

's

,

"

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Though

.

?
 
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

last

<EOS>
Mr

,
who
was
always
in
a
hurry
,
and
who
referred
at
intervals
to
a
little
dirty
notebook
which
he
kept
beside
him
(
perhaps
containing
the
names
of
the
defaulters
he
meant
to
look
up
by
way
of
dessert
)
,
took
in
his
victuals
much
as
if
he
were
coaling
;
with
a
good
deal
of
noise
,
a
good
deal
of
dropping
about
,
and
a
puff
and
a
snort
occasionally
,
as
if
he
were
nearly
ready
to
steam
away
.
   
<EOS>
All
through
dinner
,
Flora
combined
her
present
appetite
for
eating
and
drinking
with
her
past
appetite
for
romantic
love
,
in
a
way
that
made
Clennam
afraid
to
lift
his
eyes
from
his
plate
;
since
he
could
not
look
towards
her
without
receiving
some
glance
of
mysterious
meaning
or
warning
,
as
if
they
were
engaged
in
a
plot
.
<EOS>
Mr
F
's
Aunt
sat
silently
defying
him
with
an
aspect
of
the
greatest
bitterness
,
until
the
removal
of
the
cloth
and
the
appearance
of
the
decanters
,
when
she
originated
another
observation
---
struck
into
the
conversation
like
a
clock
,
without
consulting
anybody
.
   
<EOS>
Flora
had
just
said
,
"
Mr
Clennam
,
will
you
give
me
a
glass
of
port
for
Mr
F
's
Aunt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
Monument
near
London
Bridge
,
"
<EOS>
that
lady
instantly
proclaimed
,
"
was
put
up
arter
<EOS>
the
Great
Fire
of
London
;
and
the
Great
Fire
of
London
was
not
the
fire
in
which
your
uncle
George
's
workshops
was
burned
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
with
his
former
courage
,
said
,
"
Indeed
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
All
right
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
appearing
to
be
incensed
by
imaginary
contradiction
,
or
other
ill
-
usage
,
Mr
F
's
Aunt
,
instead
of
relapsing
into
silence
,
made
the
following
additional
proclamation
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
hate
a
fool
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
imparted
to
this
sentiment
,
in
itself
almost
Solomonic
,
so
extremely
injurious
and
personal
a
character
by
levelling
it
straight
at
the
visitor
's
head
,
that
it
became
necessary
to
lead
Mr
F
's
Aunt
from
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
quietly
done
by
Flora
;
Mr
F
's
Aunt
offering
no
resistance
,
but
inquiring
on
her
way
out
,
"
What
he
come
there
for
,
then
?
"
<EOS>
with
implacable
animosity
.
   
<EOS>
When
Flora
returned
,
she
explained
that
her
legacy
was
a
clever
old
lady
,
but
was
sometimes
a
little
singular
,
and
"
took
dislikes
"
---
peculiarities
of
which
Flora
seemed
to
be
proud
rather
than
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
As
Flora
's
good
nature
shone
in
the
case
,
Clennam
had
no
fault
to
find
with
the
old
lady
for
eliciting
it
,
now
that
he
was
relieved
from
the
terrors
of
her
presence
;
and
they
took
a
glass
or
two
of
wine
in
peace
.
 
<EOS>
Foreseeing
then
that
the
Pancks
would
shortly
get
under
weigh
,
and
that
the
Patriarch
would
go
to
sleep
<EOS>
,
he
pleaded
the
necessity
of
visiting
his
mother
,
and
asked
Mr
Pancks
in
which
direction
he
was
going
?
   
<EOS>
"
Citywards
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
we
walk
together
?
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
agreeable
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Flora
was
murmuring
in
rapid
snatches
for
his
ear
,
that
there
was
a
time
and
that
the
past
was
a
yawning
gulf
however
and
that
a
golden
chain
no
longer
bound
him
and
that
she
revered
the
memory
of
the
late
Mr
F
and
that
she
should
be
at
home
to
-
morrow
at
half
-
past
one
and
that
the
decrees
of
Fate
were
beyond
recall
and
that
she
considered
nothing
so
improbable
as
that
he
ever
walked
on
the
north
-
west
side
of
Gray's
-
Inn
Gardens
at
exactly
four
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
at
parting
to
give
his
hand
in
frankness
to
the
existing
Flora
---
not
the
vanished
Flora
,
or
the
mermaid
---
but
Flora
would
n't
have
it
,
could
n't
have
it
,
was
wholly
destitute
of
the
power
of
separating
herself
and
him
from
their
bygone
characters
.
 
<EOS>
He
left
the
house
miserably
enough
;
and
so
much
more
light
-
headed
than
ever
,
that
if
it
had
not
been
his
good

to
be
towed
away
,
he
might
,
for
the
first
quarter
of
an
hour
,
have
drifted
anywhere
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
began
to
come
to
himself
,
in
the
cooler
air
and
the
absence
of
Flora
,
he
found
Pancks
at
full
speed
,
cropping
such
scanty
pasturage
of
nails
as
he
could
find
,
and
snorting
at
intervals
.
<EOS>
These
,
in
conjunction
with
one
hand
in
his
pocket
and
his
roughened
hat
hind
side
before
,
were
evidently
the
conditions
under
which
he
reflected
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
fresh
night
!
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
's
pretty
fresh
,
"
assented
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
a
stranger
you
feel
the
climate
more
than
I
do
,
I
dare
say
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
I
have
n't
got
time
to
feel
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
lead
such
a
busy
life
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
always
some
of
'em
to
look
up
,
or
something
to
look
after
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
like
business
,
"
said
Pancks
,
getting
on
a
little
faster
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
a
man
made
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
nothing
else
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
Pancks
put
the
counter
question
,
"
What
else
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
packed
up
,
in
the
smallest
compass
,
a
weight
that
had
rested
on
Clennam
's
life
;
and
he
made
no
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
ask
our
weekly
tenants
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
of
'em
will
pull
long
faces
to
me
,
and
say
,
Poor
as
you
see
us
,
master
,
we
're
always
grinding
,
drudging
,
toiling
,
every
minute
we
're
awake
.
   
<EOS>
I
say
to
them
,
What
else
are
you
made
for
?
 
<EOS>
It
shuts
them
up
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
n't
a
word
to
answer
.
 
<EOS>
What
else
are
you
made
for
?
 
<EOS>
That
clinches
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
dear
,
dear
,
dear
!
"
sighed
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
am
I
,
"
said
Pancks
,
pursuing
his
argument
with
the
weekly
tenant
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
else
do
you
suppose
I
think
I
am
made
for
?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
.
   
<EOS>
Rattle
me
out
of
bed
early
,
set
me
going
,
give
me
as
short
a
time
as
you
like
to
bolt
my
meals
in
,
and
keep
me
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
me
always
at
it
,
and
I
'll
keep
you
always
at
it
,
you
keep
somebody
else
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
you
are
with
the
Whole
Duty
of
Man
in
a
commercial
country
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
When
they
had
walked
a
little
further
in
silence
,
Clennam
said
:
"
Have
you
no
taste
for
anything
,
Mr
Pancks
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
taste
?
"
<EOS>
drily
retorted
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
say
inclination
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
an
inclination
to
get
money
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
if
you
will
show
me
how
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
blew
off
that
sound
again
,
and
it
occurred
to
his
companion
for
the
first
time
that
it
was
his
way
of
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
singular
man
in
all
respects
;
he
might
not
have
been
quite
in
earnest
,
but
that
the
short
,
hard
,
rapid
manner
in
which
he
shot
out
these
cinders
of
principles
,
as
if
it
were
done
by
mechanical
