,
seemed
irreconcilable
with
banter
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
no
great
reader
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
read
anything
but
letters
and

.
 
<EOS>
Never
collect
anything
but
advertisements
relative
to
next
of
kin
.
 
<EOS>
If
that
's
a
taste
,
I
have
got

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
not
of
the
Clennams
of
Cornwall
,
Mr
Clennam
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
ever
heard
of
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
're
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
asked
your
mother
,

.
 
<EOS>
She
has
too
much
character
to
let

escape
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Supposing
<EOS>
I
had

the
Clennams

Cornwall
?
"
<EOS>
"
You
'd
have
heard
of
something
to
your

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
of
little
enough
to
my

for
some

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
Cornish
property
going
a
begging
,

,
and
not
a
Cornish
Clennam
to

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
turn
off
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
Tug
,
suddenly
lightened
,
and
untrammelled
by
having
any
weight
in
tow
,
was
already
puffing
away
into
the
distance
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
crossed
Smithfield
together
,
and
Clennam
was
left
alone
at
the
corner
of
Barbican
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
intention
of
presenting
himself
in
his
mother
's
dismal
room
that
night
,
and
could
not
have
felt
more
depressed
and
cast

if
he
had
been
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
slowly
down
Aldersgate
Street
,
and
was
pondering
his
way
along
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
purposing
to
come
into
one
of
the
great
thoroughfares
for
the
sake
of
their
light
and

,
when
a
crowd
of
people
flocked
towards
him
on
the
same

,
and
he
stood
aside
against
a
shop
to

pass
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
came
up
,
he
made
out
that
they
were
gathered
around
a
something
that
was
carried
on

's

.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
saw
that
it
was
a
litter
,
hastily

of
a
shutter
or
some
such
thing
;
and
a
recumbent

upon
it
,

the

of

in
the

,
and
a
muddy
bundle
carried
by
one
man
,
and
a
muddy
hat
carried
by
another
,
informed
him
that
an
accident
had
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
The
litter
stopped
under
a
lamp
before
it
had
passed
him
half
-
a
-
dozen
paces
,
for
some
readjustment
of
the
burden
;
and
,
the
crowd
stopping
too
,
he
found
himself
in
the
midst
of
the
array
.
   
<EOS>
"
An
accident
going
to
the
Hospital
?
"
he
asked
an
old
man
beside
him
,
who
stood
shaking
his
head
,
inviting
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
along
of
them
Mails
.
 
<EOS>
They
ought
to
be
prosecuted
and
fined
,
<EOS>
them
Mails
.
 
<EOS>
They
come
a
racing
out
of
Lad
Lane
and
Wood
Street
at
twelve
or
fourteen
mile
a
hour
,
them
Mails
do
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
wonder
is
,
that
people
ai
n't
killed
oftener
by
them
Mails
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
person
is
not
killed
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
!
"
said
the
man
,
"
it
an't
for
the
want
of
a
will
in
them
<EOS>
Mails
,
if
he
an't
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
speaker
having
folded
his
arms
,
and
set
in
comfortably
to
address
his
depreciation
of
them
Mails
to
any
of
the

who
would
listen
,
several

,
out
of
pure

with
the

,
confirmed

;
one

saying

,
"
They
're

public

,
them
Mails
,

;
"
another
,
"
I
see
one
on
'em
pull
up
within
half

a
boy
,
last

;
"
another
,
"
I
see

go

a
cat
,

---
and
it
might

your
own

;
"
and
all
representing
,

,
that

he

,
he
could
not

better

against

Mails
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
a
native
Englishman
is
put
to
it
every

,
to

them
Mails
,
"

;
"
and
he
knows

're
a
coming

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

poor

who
do

nothing

'

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
this
a
foreigner
?
"
said
Clennam
,
leaning

to

.
   
<EOS>
In

such

as
"
Frenchman
,

,
"
"
Porteghee
,

,
"
"
Dutchman
,

,
"
"
Prooshan
,

,
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

round
,

of
"
Ah
,
poor
fellow
<EOS>
,
he
says

'll

;
and
no

!
"
 
<EOS>
Clennam
begged
to
be
allowed
to
pass
,
as
he
understood
the
poor
creature
.
<EOS>
He
was
immediately
handed
to
the
front
,
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
he
wants
some
water
,
"
said

,
looking
round
.
 
<EOS>
(
A
dozen
good
fellows
dispersed
to
get
it
.
)
<EOS>
"
Are
you
badly
hurt
,
my
friend
?
"
<EOS>
he

the
man
on
the

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
;
yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
my
leg
,
it
's
my
leg
.
 
<EOS>
But

to

old

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are

!
 
<EOS>
Stay
!
 
<EOS>
See
,
the
water
!
 
<EOS>
Let

.
"
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

black

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>
Earrings
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
surely
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
From

?
"
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

!
 
<EOS>
I

!
 
<EOS>
Almost

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo

.
 
<EOS>
Courage
!
 
<EOS>
You
will

half

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Altro
,
Altro
!
"

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
turned
;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
None

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
hardly

,

;
"
is

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

,

"
He
wo

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

several

.

It

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye
-

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
He

?
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
else
the
matter
,

our

were

.
<EOS>
Clennam
remained
until
everything
possible
to
be
done
had
been
skilfully
and

---
the
poor
belated

in
a

land
movingly
besought
that
favour
of
him
---
and
lingered
by
the
bed
to
which
he
was
in
due

removed
,
until
he
had

.
 
<EOS>
Even

he
wrote
a

on
his
card
,
with
a

to
return
to
-
morrow
,
and
left

to

when
he
should

.
<EOS>
All
these
proceedings
occupied
so
long
that
it
struck
eleven
o'clock
at
night
as
he
came
out
at
the
Hospital
Gate
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hired
a
lodging
for
the
present
in
Covent
Garden
,
and
he
took
the
nearest
way
to
that
quarter
,
by
Snow
Hill
and
Holborn
.
   
<EOS>
Left
to
himself
again
,
after
the
solicitude
and
compassion
of
his
last
adventure
,
he
was
naturally
in
a
thoughtful
mood
.
 
<EOS>
As
naturally
,
he
could
not
walk
on
thinking
for
ten
minutes
without
recalling
Flora
.
 
<EOS>
She
necessarily
recalled
to
him
his
life
,
with
all
its
misdirection
and
little
happiness
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
got
to
his
lodging
,
he
sat
down
before
the
dying
fire
,
as
he
had
stood
at
the
window
of
his
old
room
looking
out
upon
the
blackened
forest
of
chimneys
,
and
turned
his
gaze
back
upon
the
gloomy
vista
by
which
he
had
come
to
that
stage
in
his
existence
.
<EOS>
So
long
,
so
bare
,
so
blank
.
 
<EOS>
No
childhood
;
no
youth
,
except
for
one
remembrance
;
that
one
remembrance
proved
,
only
that
day
,
to
be
a
piece
of
folly
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
misfortune
to
him
,
trifle
as
it
might
have
been
to
another
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
while
all
that
was
hard
and
stern
in
his
recollection
,
remained
Reality
on
being
proved
---
was
obdurate
to
the
sight
and

,
and
relaxed
nothing
of
its
old
indomitable

---
the
one
tender
recollection
of
his
experience
would
not
bear
the
same
test
,
and
melted
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
foreseen
this
,
on
the
former
night
,
when
he
had
dreamed
with
waking

.
 
<EOS>
but
he
had
not
felt
it
then
;
and
he
had
now
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
dreamer
in
such
wise
,
because
he
was
a
man
who
had
,
deep
-
rooted
in
his
nature
,
a
belief
in
all
the
gentle
and
good
things
his
life
had
been
without
.
 
<EOS>
Bred
in
meanness
and
hard

,
this
had
rescued
him
to
be
a
man
of
honourable
mind
and
open

.
 
<EOS>
Bred
in
coldness
and
severity
,
this
had
rescued
him
to
have
a
warm
and
sympathetic
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Bred
in
a
creed
too
darkly
audacious
to
pursue
,
through
its
process
of
reserving
the
making
of
man
in
the
image
of
his
Creator
to
the
making
of
his
Creator
in
the
image
of
an
erring
man
,
this
had
rescued
him
to
judge
not
,
and
in
humility
to
be
merciful
,
and
have
hope
and
charity
.
   
<EOS>
And
this
saved
him
still
from
the
whimpering
weakness
and
cruel
selfishness
of
holding
that
because
such
a
happiness
or
such
a
virtue
had
not
come
into
his
little
path
,
or
worked
well
for
him
,
therefore
it
was
not
in
the
great
scheme
,
but
was
reducible
,
when
found
in

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
A
disappointed
mind
he
had
,
but
a
mind
too
firm
and
healthy
for
such
unwholesome
air
.
<EOS>
Leaving
himself
in
the
dark
,
it
could
rise
into
the
light
,
seeing
it
shine
on
others
and
hailing

.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
,
he
sat
before
his

fire
,
sorrowful
to

upon
the
way
by
which
he

come
to
that
night
,
yet
not

on

way

which
other

.
 
<EOS>
That

have
missed

much
,
and
at
his

life
should
look
so
far
about

for
any
staff
to

company
upon
his

and
cheer
it
<EOS>
,
was
a
just

.
 
<EOS>
He

fire
from

,

,

,

,
"
How

pass

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
To

was
like

in

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
From

,

,

,

,

,
down

this

,
"

Clennam
,
"
what

!
"
   
<EOS>
His

,
and
these
spoken
words
startled

,
and
came
as
if

:
   
"
Little
Dorrit
.
"
    
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
Party
 
Arthur
Clennam
rose
hastily
,
and
saw
her
standing
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
This
history
must
sometimes
see
with
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
,
and
shall
begin
that
course
by
seeing
him
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
looked
into
a
dim
room
,
which
seemed
a
spacious
one
to
her
,
and
grandly
furnished
.
 
<EOS>
Courtly
ideas
of
Covent
Garden
,
as
a
place
with
famous
coffee
-
houses
,
where
gentlemen
wearing
gold
-
laced
coats
and
swords
had
quarrelled
and
fought
duels
;
costly
ideas
of
Covent
Garden
,
as
a
place
where
there
were
flowers
in
winter
at
guineas
a
-
piece
,
pine
-
apples
at
guineas
a
pound
,
and
peas
at
guineas
a
pint
;
picturesque
ideas
of
Covent
Garden
,
as
a
place
where
there
was
a
mighty
theatre
,
showing
wonderful
and
beautiful
sights
to
richly
-
dressed
ladies
and
gentlemen
,
and
which
was
for
ever
far
beyond
the
reach
of
poor
Fanny
or
poor
uncle
;
desolate
ideas
of
Covent
Garden
,
as
having
all
those
arches
in
it
,
where
the
miserable
children
in
rags
among
whom
she
had
just
now
passed
,
like
young
rats
,
slunk
and
hid
,
fed
on
offal
,
huddled
together
for
warmth
,
and
were
hunted
about
<EOS>
(
look
to
the
rats
young
and
old
,
all
ye
Barnacles
,
for
before
God
they
are
eating
away
our
foundations
,
and
will
bring
the
roofs
on
our
heads
!
)
;
teeming
ideas
of
Covent
Garden
,
as
a
place
of
past
and
present
mystery
,
romance
,
abundance
,
want
,
beauty
,
ugliness
,
fair
country
gardens
,
and
foul
street
gutters
;
all
confused
together
,
---
made
the
room
dimmer
than
it
was
in
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
,
as
they
timidly
saw
it
from
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
in
the
chair
before
the
gone
-
out
fire
,
and
then
turned
round
wondering
to
see
her
,
was
the
gentleman
whom
she
sought
.
 
<EOS>
The
brown
,
grave
gentleman
,
who
smiled
so
pleasantly
,
who
was
so
frank
and
considerate
in
his
manner
,
and
yet
in
whose
earnestness
there
was
something
that
reminded
her
of
his
mother
,
with
the
great
difference
that
she
was
earnest
in
asperity
and
he
in
gentleness
.
<EOS>
Now
he
regarded
her
with
that
attentive
and
inquiring
look
before
which
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
had
always
fallen
,
and
before
which
they
fell
still
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
poor
child
!
 
<EOS>
Here
at
midnight
?
"
   
"
I
said
Little
Dorrit
,
sir
,
on
purpose
to
prepare
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
you
must
be
very
much
surprised
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
alone
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
sir
,
I
have
got
Maggy
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Considering
her
entrance
sufficiently
prepared
for
by
this
mention
of
her
name
,
Maggy
appeared
from
the
landing
outside
,
on
the
broad
grin
.
 
<EOS>
She
instantly
suppressed
that
manifestation
,
however
,
and
became
fixedly
solemn
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
have
no
fire
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
---
"
He
was
going
to
say
so
lightly
clad
,
but
stopped
himself
in
what
would
have
been
a
reference
to
her
poverty
,
saying
instead
,
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
so
cold
.
"
   
<EOS>
Putting
the
chair
from
which
he
had
risen
nearer
to
the
grate
,
he
made
her
sit
down
in
it
;
and
hurriedly
bringing
wood
and
coal
,
heaped
them
together
and
got
a
blaze
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
foot
is
like
marble
,
my
child
;
"
he
had
happened
to
touch
it
,
while
stooping
on
one
knee
at
his
work
of
kindling
the
fire
;
"
put
it
nearer
the
warmth
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
thanked
him
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
warm
,
it
was
very
warm
!
 
<EOS>
It
smote
upon
his
heart
to
feel
that
she
hid
her
thin
,
worn
shoe
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
not
ashamed
of
her
poor
shoes
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
her
story
,
and
it
was
not
that
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
a
misgiving
that
he
might
blame
her
father
,
if
he
saw
them
;
that
he
might
think
,
"
why
did
he
dine
to
-
day
,
and
leave
this
little
creature
to
the
mercy
of
the
cold
stones
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
belief
that
it
would
have
been
a
just
reflection
;
she
simply
knew
,
by
experience
,
that
such
delusions
did
sometimes
present
themselves
to
people
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
part
of
her
father
's
misfortunes
that
they
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
Before
I
say
anything
else
,
"
Little
Dorrit
began
,
sitting
before
the
pale
fire
,
and
raising
her
eyes
again
to
the
face
which
in
its
harmonious
look
of
interest
,
and
pity
,
and
protection
,
she
felt
to
be
a
mystery
far
above
her
in
degree
,
and
almost
removed
beyond
her
guessing
at
;
"
may
I
tell
you
something
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
child
.
"
A
slight
shade
of
distress
fell
upon
her
,
at
his
so
often
calling
her
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
surprised
that
he
should
see
it
,
or
think
of
such
a
slight
thing
;
but
he
said
directly
:
"
I
wanted
a
tender
word
,
and
could
think
of
no
other
.
 
<EOS>
As
you
just
now
gave
yourself
the
name
they
give
you
at
my
mother
's
,
and
as
that
is
the
name
by
which
I
always
think
of
you
,
let
me
call
you
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
I
should
like
it
better
than
any
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Dorrit
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Little
mother
,
"
Maggy
(
who
had
been
falling
asleep
)
put
in
,
as
a
correction
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
the
same
,
MaggY
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
,
"
all
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
all
the
same
,
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
Maggy
laughed
,
and
immediately
snored
.
 
<EOS>
In
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
and
ears
,
the
uncouth
figure
and
the
uncouth
sound
were
as
pleasant
as
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
glow
of
pride
in
her
big
child
,
overspreading
her
face
,
when
it
again
met
the
eyes
of
the
grave
brown
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
She
wondered
what
he
was
thinking
of
,
as
he
looked
at
Maggy
and
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
thought
what
a
good
father
he
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
with
some
such
look
,
he
would
counsel
and
cherish
his
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
was
going
to
tell
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
is
,
that
MY
brother
is
at
large
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
was
rejoiced
to
hear
it
,
and
hoped
he
would
do
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
I
was
going
to
tell
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
trembling
in
all
her
little
figure
and
in
her
voice
,
"
is
,
that
I
am
not
to
know
whose
generosity
released
him
---
am
never
to
ask
,
and
am
never
to
be
told
,
and
am
never
to
thank
that
gentleman
with
all
MY
grateful
heart
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
probably
need
no
thanks
,
Clennam
said
.
 
<EOS>
Very
likely
he
would
be
thankful
himself
(
and
with
reason
)
,
that
he
had
had
the
means
and
chance
of
doing
a
little
service
to
her
,
who
well
deserved
a
great
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
I
was
going
to
say
,
sir
,
is
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
trembling
more
and
more
,
"
that
if
I
knew
him
,
and
I
might
,
I
would
tell
him
that
he
can
never
,
never
know
how
I
feel
his

,
and
how
my
good
father
would
feel

.
 
<EOS>
And
what
I
was
going
to
say
,
sir
,
is
,
that
if
I
knew
him
,
and
I
might
---
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
know
him
<EOS>
and
I
must
not
<EOS>
---
I
know
that
!
<EOS>
---
I
would
tell
him
that
I
shall
never
any
more
lie
down
to
sleep
without
having
prayed
to
Heaven
to
bless
him
and
reward

.
 
<EOS>
And
if
I
knew
him
,
and
I
might
,
I
would
go
down
on
my
knees
to
him
,
and
take
his
hand
and
kiss
it
and
ask
him
not
to
draw
it
away
,
but
to
leave
it
---
O
to
leave
it
for
a

---
and
let
my
thankful
tears
fall
on
it
;
for
I
have
no
other
thanks
to
give
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
put
his
hand
to
her
lips
,
and
would
have
kneeled
to
him
,
but
he
gently
prevented
her
,
and
replaced
her
in
her
chair
.
   
<EOS>
Her
eyes
,
and
the
tones
of
her
voice
,
had
thanked
him
far
better
than
she
thought
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
able
to
say
,
quite
as
composedly
as
usual
,
"
<EOS>
There
,
Little
Dorrit
,
there
,
there
,
there
!
 
<EOS>
We
will
suppose
that
you
did
know
this
person
,
and
that
you
might
do
all
this
,
and
that
it
was
all
done
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
tell
me
,
Who
am
quite
another
person
---
who
am
nothing
more
than
the
friend
who
begged
you
to
trust

---
why
you
are
out
at
midnight
,
and
what
it
is
that
brings
you
so
far
through
the
streets
at
this
late

,
<EOS>
my
slight
,
delicate
,
"
child
was
on
his
lips
again
,
"
Little
Dorrit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Maggy
and
I
have
been
to
-
night
,
"
she
answered
,
subduing
herself
with
the
quiet
effort
that
had
long
been
natural
to
her
,
"
to
the
theatre
where
my
sister
is
engaged
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
oh
ai
n't
it
a
Ev'nly
place
,
"
suddenly
interrupted
Maggy
,
who
seemed
to
have
the
power
of
going
to
sleep
and
waking
up
whenever
she
chose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Almost
as
good
as
a
hospital
.
 
<EOS>
Only
there
ai
n't
no
Chicking
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
she
shook
herself
,
and
fell
asleep
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
went
there
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
glancing
at
her
charge
,
"
because
I
like
sometimes
to
know
,
of
my
own
knowledge
,
that
my
sister
is
doing
well
;
and
like
to
see
her
there
,
with
my
own
eyes
,
when
neither
she
nor
Uncle
is
aware
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
very
seldom
indeed
that
I
can
do
that
,
because
when
I
am
not
out
at
work
,
I
am
with
my
father
,
and
even
when
I
am
out
at
work
,
I
hurry
home
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
pretend
to
-
night
that
I
am
at
a
party
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
made
the
confession
,
timidly
hesitating
,
she
raised
her
eyes
to
the
face
,
and
read
its
expression
so
plainly
that
she
answered
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
certainly
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
at
a
party
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She
paused
a
little
under
his
attentive
look
,
and
then
said
,
"
I
hope
there
is
no
harm
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
never
have
been
of
any
use
,
if
I
had
not
pretended
a
little
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
feared
that
he
was
blaming
her
in
his
mind
for
so
devising
to
contrive
for
them
,
think
for
them
,
and
watch
over
them
,
without
their
knowledge
or
gratitude
;
perhaps
even
with
their
reproaches
for
supposed
neglect
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
was
really
in
his
mind
,
was
the
weak
figure
with
its
strong
purpose
,
the
thin
worn
shoes
,
the
insufficient
dress
,
and
the
pretence
of
recreation
and
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
He
asked
where
the
suppositious
party
was
?
 
<EOS>
At
a
place
where
she
worked
,
answered
Little
Dorrit
,
blushing
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
said
very
little
about
it
;
only
a
few
words
to
make
her
father
easy
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
did
not
believe
it
to
be
a
grand
party
---
indeed
he
might
suppose
that
.
<EOS>
And
she
glanced
for
an
instant
at
the
shawl
she
wore
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
first
night
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
that
I
have
ever
been
away
from
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
London
looks
so
large
,
so
barren
,
and
so
wild
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
,
its
vastness
under
the
black
sky
was
awful
;
a
tremor
passed
over
her
as
she
said
the
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
,
"
she
added
,
with
the
quiet
effort
again
,
"
what
I
have
come
to

you
with
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
My
sister
's
having
found
a
friend
,
a
lady
she
has
told
me
of
and
made
me
rather
anxious
about
,
was
the
first
cause
of
my
coming
away
from
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
being
away
,
and
coming
(
on
purpose
)
round
by
where
you
lived
and
seeing
a
light
in
the
window
---
"
   
Not
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
not
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
In
Little
Dorrit
's
eyes
,
the
outside
of
that
window
had
been
a
distant
star
on
other
nights
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
toiled
out
of
her
way
,
tired
and

,
to
look
up
at
it
,
and
wonder

the
grave
,
brown

from
so
far
off
,
who
had
spoken
to
her
as
a
friend
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
were
three
things
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
that
I

I
would
like
to

,
if

.
<EOS>
First
,
what
I

,

never

---
never

---
"
   
"
Hush
,

!
 
<EOS>
That
is
done
with
,
and
disposed

.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
pass
to
the
second
,
"

Clennam
,
smiling
her

away
,
making

,
and

wine
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
---
"
<EOS>
this
is
the
second
thing
,
sir
<EOS>
---
I
think
Mrs
Clennam
must

found

,
and
must

.
 
<EOS>
Where

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Indeed
!
"
returned
Clennam
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
her
,
after
short

,
why
she
supposed
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
replied
Little
Dorrit
,
"
that
Mr
Flintwinch
must
have
watched
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
why
,
Clennam
asked
,
as
he

upon

fire
,
bent
his
brows
,
and
considered
again
;
why
did
she
suppose
that
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
met
him
twice
.
 
<EOS>
Both

near

.
 
<EOS>
Both

,
when
I

.
 
<EOS>
Both

I
thought
(
though

)
,
that
he
hardly

.
"
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
devil
take

!
"
<EOS>
mused
Clennam
,
still
looking
at
the
fire
<EOS>
;
"
it
's
always
on
one
side
.
"
<EOS>
He
roused
himself
to
persuade
her
to
put
some
wine

,
and
to
touch
something
to
eat
---
it

,

---
and
then
said
,

:
"
Is
my
mother
at
all
changed

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
just

.
 
<EOS>
I
wondered
whether
I
had
better

history
.
 
<EOS>
I
wondered
whether
I
might
---
<EOS>
I
mean
,
whether
you
would
like
me
to
tell
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
wondered
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
looking

in

and

her

looked

,
"
whether
you
would
advise
me
what
I
ought
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Dorrit
,
"
said
Clennam
;
and
the
phrase
had
already
begun
,
between
these
two
,
to
stand
for
a
hundred
gentle
phrases
,
according
to
the
varying
tone
and

in

it
was
used
;
"
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
have
some

old
friend
,
Mrs
Affery
.
 
<EOS>
Do
nothing
,
Little
Dorrit
---
except
refresh

with
such
means
as
there
are
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreat
you
to
do
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
I
am
not
hungry
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
as
he

,
"
nor
thirsty
.
<EOS>
---
I
think
Maggy
might
like
something
,
perhaps
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
make
her
find
pockets
presently
for
all
there

here
,
"
said
Clennam
:
"
<EOS>
but
before
we

her
,
there

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not

,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
promise
that
,
unreservedly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
will
sound
strange
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
how
to
say
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
think
it
unreasonable
or
ungrateful
in
me
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
with
returning
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
it
will
be
natural
and
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
afraid
that
I
shall
put
a
wrong
construction
on
it
,
whatever
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
coming
back
to
see
my
father
again
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
so
good
and
thoughtful
as
to
write
him
a
note
,
saying
that
you
are
coming
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
that
was
nothing
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
guess
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
folding
her
small
hands
tight
in
one
another
,
and
looking
at
him
with
all
the
earnestness
of
her
soul
looking
steadily
out
of
her
eyes
,
"
what
I
am
going
to
ask
you
not
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
may
be
wrong
.
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
you
are
not
wrong
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
we
should
want
it
so
very
,
very
badly
that
we
can
not
do
without
it
,
let
me
ask
you
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
Will
,
---
I
Will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
encourage
him
to
ask
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
understand
him
if
he
does
ask
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
give
it
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Save
him
and
spare
him
that
,
and
you
will
be
able
to
think
better
of
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
said
---
not
very
plainly
,
seeing
those
tears
glistening
in
her
anxious
eyes
---
that
her
wish
should
be
sacred
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
what
he
is
,
"
she
said
;
"
you
do
n't
know
what
he
really
is
.
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
,
seeing
him
there
all
at
once
,
dear
love
,
and
not
gradually
,
as
I
have
done
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
so
good
to
us
,
so
delicately
and
truly
good
,
that
I
want
him
to
be
better
in
your
eyes
than
in
anybody
's
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
can
not
bear
to
think
,
"
cried
Little
Dorrit
,
covering
her
tears
with
her
hands
,
"
I
can
not
bear
to
think
that
you
of
all
the
world
should
see
him
in
his
only
moments
of
degradation
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
do
not
be
so
distressed
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
,
Little
Dorrit
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
quite
understood
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
tried
very
much
to
keep
myself
from
saying
this
;
I
have
thought
about
it
,
days
and
nights
;
but
when
I
knew
for
certain
you
were
coming
again
,
I
made
up
my
mind
to
speak
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Not
because
I
am
ashamed
of
him
,
"
she
dried
her
tears
quickly
,
"
but
because
I
know
him
better
than
any
one
does
,
and
love
him
,
and
am
proud
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Relieved
of
this
weight
<EOS>
,
Little
Dorrit
was
nervously
anxious
to
be
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
being
broad
awake
,
and
in
the
act
of
distantly
gloating
over
the
fruit
and
cakes
with
chuckles
of
anticipation
,
Clennam
made
the
best
diversion
in
his
power
by
pouring
her
out
a
glass
of
wine
,
which
she
drank
in
a
series
of
loud
smacks
;
putting
her
hand
upon
her
windpipe
after
every
one
,
and
saying
,
breathless
,
with
her
eyes
in
a
prominent
state
,
"
Oh
,
ai
n't
it
d'licious
!
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
it
hospitally
!
"
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
finished
the
wine
and
these
encomiums
,
he
charged
her
to
load
her
basket
<EOS>
(
she
was
never
without
her
basket
)
with
every
eatable
thing
upon
the
table
,
and
to
take
especial
care
to
leave
no
scrap
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
's
pleasure
in
doing
this
and
her
little
mother
's
pleasure
in
seeing
Maggy
pleased
,
was
as
good
a
turn
as
circumstances
could
have
given
to
the
late
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
gates
will
have
been
locked
long
ago
,
"
said
Clennam
,
suddenly
remembering
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
Maggy
's
lodging
,
"
answered
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
quite
safe
,
quite
well
taken
care
of
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
accompany
you
there
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
I
can
not
let
you
go
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
pray
leave
us
to
go
there
by
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
!
<EOS>
"
begged
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
earnest
in
the
petition
,
that
Clennam
felt
a
delicacy
in
obtruding
himself
upon
her
:
the
rather
,
because
he
could
well
understand
that
Maggy
's
lodging
was
of
the
obscurest
sort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Maggy
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
cheerily
,
"
we
shall
do
very
well
;
we
know
the
way
by
this
time
,
Maggy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
little
mother
;
we
know
the
way
,
"
chuckled
Maggy
.
 
<EOS>
And
away
they
went
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
turned
at
the
door
to
say
,
"
God
bless
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
said
it
very
softly
,
but
perhaps
she
may
have
been
as
audible
above
---
who
knows
!
<EOS>
---
as
a
whole
cathedral
choir
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
suffered
them
to
pass
the
corner
of
the
street
before
he
followed
at
a
distance
;
not
with
any
idea
of
encroaching
a
second
time
on
Little
Dorrit
's
privacy
,
but
to
satisfy
his
mind
by
seeing
her
secure
in
the
neighbourhood
to
which
she
was
accustomed
.
 
<EOS>
So
diminutive
she
looked
,
so
fragile
and
defenceless
against
the
bleak
damp
weather
,
flitting
along
in
the
shuffling
shadow
of
her
charge
,
that
he
felt
,
in
his
compassion
,
and
in
his
habit
of
considering
her
a
child
apart
from
the
rest
of
the
rough
world
,
as
if
he
would
have
been
glad
to
take
her
up
in
his
arms
and
carry
her
to
her
journey
's
end
.
   
<EOS>
In
course
of
time
she
came
into
the
leading
thoroughfare
where
the
Marshalsea
was
,
and
then
he
saw
them
slacken
their
pace
,
and
soon
turn
down
a
by
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
felt
that
he
had
no
right
to
go
further
,
and
slowly
left
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
suspicion
that
they
ran
any
risk
of
being
houseless
until
morning
;
had
no
idea
of
the
truth
until
long
,
long
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
said
Little
Dorrit
,
when
they
stopped
at
a
poor
dwelling
all
in
darkness
,
and
heard
no
sound
on
listening
at
the
door
,
"
Now
,
this
is
a
good
lodging
for
you
,
Maggy
,
and
we
must
not
give
offence
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
we
will
only
knock
twice
,
and
not
very
loud
;
and
if
we
can
not
wake
them
so
,
we
must
walk
about
till
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
Once
,
Little
Dorrit
knocked
with
a
careful
hand
,
and
listened
.
<EOS>
Twice
,
Little
Dorrit
knocked
with
a
careful
hand
,
and
listened
.
<EOS>
All
was
close
and
still
.
 
<EOS>
"
Maggy
,
we
must
do
the
best
we
can
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
be
patient
,
and
wait
for
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
chill
dark
night
,
with
a
damp
wind
blowing
,
when
they
came
out
into
the
leading
street
again
,
and
heard
the
clocks
strike
half
-
past
one
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
only
five
hours
and
a
half
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
we
shall
be
able
to
go
home
.
"
 
<EOS>
To
speak
of
home
,
and
to
go
and
look
at
it
,
it
being
so
near
,
was
a
natural
sequence
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
to
the
closed
gate
,
and
peeped
through
into
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
is
sound
asleep
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
kissing
one
of
the
bars
,
"
and
does
not
miss
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gate
was
so
familiar
,
and
so
like
a
companion
,
that
they
put
down
Maggy
's
basket
in
a
corner
to
serve
for
a
seat
,
and
keeping
close
together
,
rested
there
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
street
was
empty
and
silent
,
Little
Dorrit
was
not
afraid
;
but
when
she
heard
a
footstep
at
a
distance
,
or
saw
a
moving
shadow
among
the
street
lamps
,
she
was
startled
,
and
whispered
,
"
Maggy
,
I
see
some
one
.
<EOS>
Come
away
!
"
 
<EOS>
Maggy
would
then
wake
up
more
or
less
fretfully
,
and
they
would
wander
about
a
little
,
and
come
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
As
long
as
eating
was
a
novelty
and
an
amusement
,
Maggy
kept
up
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
period
going
by
,
she
became
querulous
about
the
cold
,
and
shivered
and
whimpered
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
soon
be
over
,
dear
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
patiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
it
's
all
very
fine
for
you
,
little
mother
,
"
returned
Maggy
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
a
poor
thing
,
only
ten
years
old
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
in
the
dead
of
the
night
,
when
the
street
was
very
still
indeed
,
Little
Dorrit
laid
the
heavy
head
upon
her
bosom
,
and
soothed
her
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
she
sat
at
the
gate
,
as
it
were
alone
;
looking
up
at
the
stars
,
and
seeing
the
clouds
pass
over
them
in
their
wild
flight
---
which
was
the
dance
at
Little
Dorrit
's
party
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
really
was
a
party
!
"
she
thought
once
,
as
she
sat
there
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
was
light
and
warm
and
beautiful
,
and
it
was
our
house
,
and
my
poor
dear
was
its
master
,
and
had
never
been
inside
these
walls
.
   
<EOS>
And
if
Mr
Clennam
was
one
of
our
visitors
,
and
we
were
dancing
to
delightful
music
,
and
were
all
as
gay
and
light
-
hearted
as
ever
we
could
be
!
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
---
"
Such
a
vista
of
wonder
opened
out
before
her
,
that
she
sat
looking
up
at
the
stars
,
quite
lost
,
until
Maggy
was
querulous
again
,
and
wanted
to
get
up
and
walk
.
   
<EOS>
Three
o'clock
,
and
half
-
past
three
,
and
<EOS>
they
had
passed
over
London
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
heard
the
rush
of
the
tide
against
obstacles
;
and
looked
down
,
awed
,
through
the
dark
vapour
on
the
river
;
had
seen
little
spots
of
lighted
water
where
the
bridge
lamps
were
reflected
,
shining
like
demon
eyes
,
with
a
terrible
fascination
in
them
for
guilt
and
misery
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
shrunk
past
homeless
people
,
lying
coiled
up
in
nooks
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
run
from
drunkards
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
started
from
slinking
men
,
whistling
and
signing
to
one
another
at
<EOS>
bye
corners
,
or
running
away
at
full
speed
.
 
<EOS>
Though
everywhere
the
leader
and
the
guide
,
Little
Dorrit
<EOS>
,
happy
for
once
in
her
youthful
appearance
,
feigned
to
cling
to
and
rely
upon
Maggy
.
 
<EOS>
And
more
than
once
some
voice
,
from
among
a
knot
of
brawling
or
prowling
figures
in
their
path
,
had
called
out
to
the
rest
to
"
let
the
woman
and
the
child
go
by
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
the
woman
and
the
child
had
gone
by
,
and
gone
on
,
and
five
had
sounded
from
the
steeples
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
walking
slowly
towards
the
east
,
already
looking
for
the
first
pale
streak
of
day
,
when
a
woman
came
after
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
with
the
child
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
to
Maggy
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
young
---
far
too
young
to
be
there
,
Heaven
knows
!
<EOS>
---
and
neither
ugly
nor
wicked
-
looking
.
 
<EOS>
She
spoke
coarsely
,
but
with
no
naturally
coarse
voice
;
there
was
even
something
musical
in
its
sound
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
with
yourself
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Maggy
,
for
want
Of
a
better
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ca
n't
you
see
,
without
my
telling
you
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
as
I
can
,
"
said
Maggy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Killing
myself
!
 
<EOS>
Now
I
have
answered
you
,
answer
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
with
the
child
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
supposed
child
kept
her
head
drooped
down
,
and
kept
her
form
close
at
Maggy
's
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
thing
!
"
said
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
feeling
,
that
you
keep
her
out
in
the
cruel
streets
at
such
a
time
as
this
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
no
eyes
,
that
you
do
n't
see
how
delicate
and
slender
<EOS>
she
is
?
 
<EOS>
Have
<EOS>
you
no
sense
<EOS>
(
you
do
n't
look
as
if
you
had
much
)
that
you
do
n't
take
more
pity
on
this
cold
and
trembling
little
hand
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
stepped
across
to
that
side
,
and
held
the
hand
between
her
own
two
,
chafing
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Kiss
a
poor
lost
creature
,
dear
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
bending
her
face
,
"
and
tell
me
where
's
she
taking
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
turned
towards
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
my
God
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
recoiling
,
"
you
're
a
woman
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
that
!
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
clasping
one
of
her
hands
that
had
suddenly
released
hers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
had
better
be
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
father
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
a
very
dear
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
home
to
him
,
and
be
afraid
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
go
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
thank
you
first
;
let
me
speak
to
you
as
if
I
really
were
a
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
do
it
,
"
said
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
kind
and
innocent
;
but
you
ca
n't
look
at
me
out
of
a
child
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
never
should
have
touched
you
,
but
I
thought
that
you
were
a
child
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
a

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
No
day
yet
in
the
sky
,
but
there
was
day
in
the
resounding

of
the
streets
;
in
the
waggons
,
carts
,
and

;
in
the
workers
going
to
various

;
in
the

of
early
shops
;
in
the
traffic
at

;
in
the

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
coming
day
in
the
flaring
lights
,
with
a
feebler
colour
in
them
than
they
would
have
had
at
another
time
;
coming
day
in
the
increased
sharpness
of
the
air
,
and
the
ghastly
dying
of
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
They
went
back
again
to
the
gate
,
intending
to
wait
there
now
until
it
should
be
opened
;
but
the
air
was
so
raw
and

that
Little
Dorrit
,
leading

about
in
her

,

.
 
<EOS>
Going
round
by
the
Church
,
she
saw
lights
there
,
and
the
door

;
and
went

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
<EOS>
"
cried

,

<EOS>
"
It
's

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
's
have
a
look

!
"
   
<EOS>
This

to

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

---

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Amy
,

.
 
<EOS>
Born

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
Lord
!
"
 
<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

,

.
 
<EOS>
Again

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Here

.
 
<EOS>
just

!
 
<EOS>
We

Mrs
Bangham

.
 
<EOS>
But

---

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
"
   
<EOS>
Commendingly

he

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
was

,
and
Little
Dorrit
was
soon

with

on
that
sealed
book
of
Fate
,

by

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
Little
Dorrit
's

.
 
<EOS>
The
shame
,

,

,
and

of
the
great
capital
;
the

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This
was

from
which
Little
Dorrit
went
home
,
jaded
,
in
the
first
grey
mist
of
a

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
has
another
Dream
 
<EOS>
The
debilitated
old
house
in
the
city
,
wrapped
in
its
mantle
of
soot
,
and
leaning
heavily
on
the
crutches
that
had
partaken
of
its
decay
and
worn
out
with
it
,
never
knew
a
healthy
or
a
cheerful
interval
,
let
what
would
betide
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
sun
ever
touched
it
,
it
was
but
with
a
ray
,
and
that
was
gone
in
half
an
hour
;
if
the
moonlight
ever
fell
upon
it
,
it
was
only
to
put
a
few
patches
on
its
doleful
cloak
,
and
make
it
look
more
wretched
.
 
<EOS>
The
stars
,
to
be
sure
,
coldly
watched
it
when
the
nights
and
the
smoke
were
clear
enough
;
and
all
bad
weather
stood
by
it
with
a
rare
fidelity
.
 
<EOS>
You
should
alike
find
rain
,
hail
,
frost
,
and
thaw
lingering
in
that
dismal
enclosure
when
they
had
vanished
from
other
places
;
and
as
to
snow
,
you
should
see
it
there
for
weeks
,
long
after
it
had
changed
from
yellow
to
black
,
slowly
weeping
away
its
grimy
life
.
<EOS>
The
place
had
no
other
adherents
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
street
noises
,
the
rumbling
of
wheels
in
the
lane
merely
rushed
in
at
the
gateway
in
going
past
,
and
rushed
out
again
:
making
the
listening
Mistress
Affery
feel
as
if
she
were
deaf
,
and
recovered
the
sense
of
hearing
by
instantaneous
flashes
.
 
<EOS>
So
with
whistling
,
singing
,
talking
,
laughing
,
and
all
pleasant
human
sounds
.
 
<EOS>
They
leaped
the
gap
in
a
moment
,
and
went
upon
their
way
.
<EOS>
The
varying
light
of
fire
and
candle
in
Mrs
Clennam
's
room
made
the
greatest
change
that
ever
broke
the
dead
monotony
of
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
two
long
narrow
windows
,
the
fire
shone
sullenly
all
day
,
and
sullenly
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
On
rare
occasions
it
flashed
up
passionately
,
as
she
did
;
but
for
the
most
part
it
was
suppressed
,
like
her
,
and
preyed
upon
itself
evenly
and
slowly
.
 
<EOS>
During
many
hours
of
the
short
winter
days
,
however
,
when
it
was
dusk
there
early
in
the
afternoon
,
changing
distortions
of
herself
in
her
wheeled
chair
,
of
Mr
Flintwinch
with
his
wry
neck
,
of
Mistress
Affery
coming
and
going
,
would
be
thrown
upon
the
house
wall
that
was
over
the
gateway
,
and
would
hover
there
like
shadows
from
a
great
magic
lantern
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
room
-
ridden
invalid
settled
for
the
night
,
these
would
gradually
disappear
:
Mistress
Affery
's
magnified
shadow
always
flitting
about
,
last
,
until
it
finally
glided
away
into
the
air
,
as
though
she
were
off
upon
a
witch
excursion
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
solitary
light
would
burn
unchangingly
,
until
it
burned
pale
before
the
dawn
,
and
at
last
died
under
the
breath
of
Mrs
Affery
,
as
her
shadow
descended
on
it
from
the
witch
-
region
of
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
Strange
,
if
the
little
sick
-
room
fire
were
in
effect
a
beacon
fire
,
summoning
some
one
,
and
that
the
most
unlikely
some
one
in
the
world
,
to
the
spot
that
MUST
be
come
to
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
,
if
the
little
sick
-
room
light
were
in
effect
a
watch
-
light
,
burning
in
that
place
every
night
until
an
appointed
event
should
be
watched
out
!
 
<EOS>
Which
of
the
vast
multitude
of
travellers
,
under
the
sun
and
the
stars
,
climbing
the
dusty
hills
and
toiling
along
the
weary
plains
,
journeying
by
land
and
journeying
by
sea
,
coming
and
going
so
strangely
,
to
meet
and
to
act
and
react
on
one
another
;
which
of
the
host
may
,
with
no
suspicion
of
the
journey
's
end
,
be
travelling
surely
hither
?
   
<EOS>
Time
shall
show
us
.
 
<EOS>
The
post
of
honour
and
the
post
of
shame
,
the
general
's
station
and
the
drummer
's
,
a
peer
's
statue
in
Westminster
Abbey
and
a
seaman
's
hammock
in
the
bosom
of
the
deep
,
the
mitre
and
the
workhouse
,
the
woolsack
and
the
gallows
,
the
throne
and
the
guillotine
---
the
travellers
to
all
are
on
the
great
high
road
,
but
it
has
wonderful
divergencies
,
and
only
Time
shall
show
us
whither
each
traveller
is
bound
.
   
<EOS>
On
a
wintry
afternoon
at
twilight
,
Mrs
Flintwinch
,
having
been
heavy
all
day
,
dreamed
this
dream
:
   
<EOS>
She
thought
she
was
in
the
kitchen
getting
the
kettle
ready
for
tea
,
and
was
warming
herself
with
her
feet
upon
the
fender
and
the
skirt
of
her
gown
tucked
up
,
before
the
collapsed
fire
in
the
middle
of
the
grate
,
bordered
on
either
hand
by
a
deep
cold
black
ravine
.
 
<EOS>
She
thought
that
as
she
sat
thus
,
musing
upon
the
question
whether
life
was
not
for
some
people
a
rather
dull
invention
,
she
was
frightened
by
a
sudden
noise
behind
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
thought
that
she
had
been
similarly
frightened
once
last
week
,
and
that
the
noise
was
of
a
mysterious
kind
---
a
sound
of
rustling
and
of
three
or
four
quick
beats
like
a
rapid
step
;
while
a
shock
or
tremble
was
communicated
to
her
heart
,
as
if
the
step
had
shaken
the
floor
,
or
even
as
if
she
had
been
touched
by
some
awful
hand
.
 
<EOS>
She
thought
that
this
revived
within
her
certain
old
fears
of
hers
that
the
house
was
haunted
;
and
that
she
flew
up
the
kitchen
stairs
without
knowing
how
she
got
up
,
to
be
nearer
company
.
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
thought
that
on
reaching
the
hall
,
she
saw
the
door
of
her
liege
lord
's
office
standing
open
,
and
the
room
empty
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
went
to
the
ripped
-
up
window
in
the
little
room
by
the
street
door
to
connect
her
palpitating
heart
,
through
the
glass
,
with
living
things
beyond
and
outside
the
haunted
house
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
then
saw
,
on
the
wall
over
the
gateway
,
the
shadows
of
the
two
clever
ones
in
conversation
above
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
then
went
up
-
stairs
with
her
shoes
in
her
hand
,
partly
to
be
near
the
clever
ones
as
a
match
for
most
ghosts
,
and
partly
to
hear
what
they
were
talking
about
.
   
<EOS>
"
None
of
your
nonsense
with
me
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
take
it
from
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
dreamed
that
she
stood
behind
the
door
,
which
was
just
ajar
,
and
most
distinctly
heard
her
husband
say
these
bold
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
Flintwinch
,
"
returned
Mrs
Clennam
,
in
her
usual
strong
low
voice
,
"
there
is
a
demon
of
anger
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
Guard
against
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
whether
there
's
one
or
a
dozen
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
forcibly
suggesting
in
his
tone
that
the
higher
number
was
nearer
the
mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
was
fifty
,
they
should
all
say
,
None
of
your
nonsense
with
me
,
I
wo
n't
take
it
from
you
<EOS>
---
I
'd
make
'em
say
it
,
whether
they
liked
it
or
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
,
you

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
her
strong

.
   
<EOS>
"
Done
?
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dropped
down
upon
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
mean
,
remonstrated
with
you
---
"
   
"
Do

put

into

I
do

,
"
said
Jeremiah
,
sticking

with
tenacious

:
"
I
mean
dropped
down
upon
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
remonstrated
with
you
,
"
she

,
"
because
---
"
   
"
I
wo
n't
have
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jeremiah
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
dropped
down
upon
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dropped
down
upon
you
,
then
,
you
ill
-

man
,
"
<EOS>
(
Jeremiah
chuckled

having

,
)
"

Arthur

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

---
"
   
"
I
wo

!
"
<EOS>
interposed

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
mean
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose

must
leave
you
to

,
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

to
a

who
has

not

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
wo

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
such

.
 
<EOS>
I

I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

I

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
After

,

only

my

,
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This

,

.
 
<EOS>
Because
you
had

cleared
his
father
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
Because
,

about

,

---
"
   
"
Hold

,
Flintwinch
!
"
<EOS>
she

out
in
a

:
"
you
may
go
a
word
too
far
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
seemed
to
think
so
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
pause
,
and
he
had
altered
his

in

,
when
he
spoke
again

:
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
going

tell
you
why
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Because
,

you
took
your
own

,
I
thought

ought

have
taken
the

of
Arthur
's
father
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
's
father
!
 
<EOS>
I

Arthur
's
father
.
 
<EOS>
I
served
Arthur
's
father
's

,
in
this

,

Arthur
's
father

---
was

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

had

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
(

)

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Stand

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

---

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
You
ca

did

.
 
<EOS>

's

?
   
<EOS>
Hey
?
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Come
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

temper
<EOS>
---

ca

<EOS>
You

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Who

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Add

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Justified

<EOS>
I

earth
<EOS>
(

)
,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

wo

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

wo

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
that

wo

.
"
   
<EOS>
Perhaps

Originally

.
 
<EOS>
Descrying

much

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
dreamed

,
as

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Please

,

,
"
Mrs

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Little

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

:
   
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
To

?
"
<EOS>
"
How

"
for

?
<EOS>

,

I
shorn

:

,

"
   
"
Ay
,

!
 
<EOS>
But

---
not

---
nothing

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
Your

and

may

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
I

(

)
through

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
gave

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

!
 
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
dreamed
,
that

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"

"

---

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,
"
For

---
mind

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wherever
she

,
"

Mrs
Clennam
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
After

,

?
"

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Flintwinch
,
"
said

and

,
flashing

that
made
Affery
start
,
"
why
do
you
goad
me
?
 
<EOS>
Look
round
this
room
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
is
any
compensation
for
my
long

within
these

---
not

I
complain

;

I
never

---

this

,
that
while
I

all

change
I
am

the

some

that
I
may

to
avoid

,
why

,

all

,
grudge

that

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
grudge
it
to
you
,
"
returned
Jeremiah
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Let
Little
Dorrit
keep
her
secret
from
me
,
and
do

keep
it
from
me
also
.
 
<EOS>
Let
her
come
and

,
unobserved
and

.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
suffer
,
and
let
me
have
what

belongs
to

condition
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
so
much
,
that
you
torment

like

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
asked

a

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
answered

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Say
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
sound
of
the
wheeled
chair
was
heard
upon
the
floor
,
and
Affery
's
bell
rang
with
a
hasty

.
   
<EOS>
More
afraid
of
her
husband
at
the
moment
than
of
the

in

,
Affery

away
as
lightly

as

as
she
could
,
descended

almost

as

had
ascended

,
resumed

before
the
fire
,
tucked

her

again
,
and
finally
threw
her

over
her

.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
bell
rang
once
more
,
and
then
once
more
,
and
then
kept
on
ringing
;
in
despite
of
which
importunate
summons
,
Affery
still
sat
behind
her
apron
,
recovering
her
breath
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
Mr
Flintwinch
came
shuffling
down
the
staircase
into
the
hall
,
muttering
and
calling
"
Affery
woman
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
all
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
still
remaining
behind
her
apron
,
he
came
stumbling
down
the
kitchen
stairs
,
candle
in
hand
,
sidled
up
to
her
,
twitched
her
apron
off
,
and
roused
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
Jeremiah
!
"
cried
Affery
,
waking
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
start
you
gave
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
been
doing
,
woman
?
"
inquired
Jeremiah
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
rung
for
fifty
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
Jeremiah
,
"
said
Mistress
Affery
,
"
I
have
been
a
-
dreaming
!
"
   
<EOS>
Reminded
of
her
former
achievement
in
that
way
<EOS>
,
Mr
Flintwinch
held
the
candle
to
her
head
,
as
if
he
had
some
idea
of
lighting
her
up
for
the
illumination
of
the
kitchen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
it
's
her
tea
-
time
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
demanded
with
a
vicious
grin
,
and
giving
one
of
the
legs
of
Mistress
Affery
's
chair
a
kick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jeremiah
?
 
<EOS>
Tea
-
time
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
's
come
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
got
such
a
dreadful
turn
,
Jeremiah
,
before
I
went
---
off
a
-
dreaming
,
that
I
think
it
must
be
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yoogh
!
 
<EOS>
Sleepy
-
Head
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
"
what
are
you
talking
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Such
a
strange
noise
,
Jeremiah
,
and
such
a
curious
movement
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
kitchen
here
---
just
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
held
up
his
light
and
looked
at
the
blackened
ceiling
,
held
down
his
light
and
looked
at
the
damp
stone
floor
,
turned
round
with
his
light
and
looked
about
at
the
spotted
and
blotched
walls
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rats
,
cats
,
water
,
drains
,
"
said
Jeremiah
.
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
negatived
each
with
a
shake
of
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Jeremiah
;
I
have
felt
it
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
felt
it
up
-
stairs
,
and
once
on
the
staircase
as
I
was
going
from
her
room
to
ours
in
the
night
---
a
rustle
and
a
sort
of
trembling
touch
behind
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Affery
,
my
woman
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
grimly
,
after
advancing
his
nose
to
that
lady
's
lips
as
a
test
for
the
detection
of
spirituous
liquors
,
"
if
you
do
n't
get
tea
pretty
quick
,
old
woman
,
you
'll
become
sensible
of
a
rustle
and
a
touch
that
'll
send
you
flying
to
the
other
end
of
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
prediction
stimulated
Mrs
Flintwinch
to
bestir
herself
,
and
to
hasten
up
-
stairs
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
for
all
that
,
she
now
began
to
entertain
a
settled
conviction
that
there
was
something
wrong
in
the
gloomy
house
.
 
<EOS>
Henceforth
,
she
was
never
at
peace
in
it
after
daylight
departed
;
and
never
went
up
or
down
stairs
in
the
dark
without
having
her
apron
over
her
head
,
lest
she
should
see
something
.
   
<EOS>
What
with
these
ghostly
apprehensions
and
her
singular
dreams
,
Mrs
Flintwinch
fell
that
evening
into
a
haunted
state
of
mind
,
from
which
it
may
be
long
before
this
present
narrative
descries
any
trace
of
her
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
vagueness
and
indistinctness
of
all
her
new
experiences
and
perceptions
,
as
everything
about
her
was
mysterious
to
herself
<EOS>
she
began
to
be
mysterious
to
others
:
and
became
as
difficult
to
be
made
out
to
anybody
's
satisfaction
as
she
found
the
house
and
everything
in
it
difficult
to
make
out
to
her
own
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
not
yet
finished
preparing
Mrs
Clennam
's
tea
,
when
the
soft
knock
came
to
the
door
which
always
announced
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
looked
on
at
Little
Dorrit
taking
off
her
homely
bonnet
in
the
hall
,
and
at
Mr
Flintwinch
scraping
his
jaws
and
contemplating
her
in
silence
,
as
expecting
some
wonderful
consequence
to
ensue
which
would
frighten
her
out
of
her
five
wits
or
blow
them
all
three
to
pieces
.
   
<EOS>
After
tea
there
came
another
knock
at
the
door
,
announcing
Arthur
.
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
went
down
to
let
him
in
,
and
he
said
on
entering
,
"
Affery
,
I
am
glad
it
's
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
ask
you
a
question
.
<EOS>
"
Affery
immediately
replied
,
"
For
goodness
sake
do
n't
ask
me
nothing
,
Arthur
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
frightened
out
of
one
half
of
my
life
,
and
dreamed
out
of
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
ask
me
nothing
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
which
is
which
,
or
what
is
what
!
"
<EOS>
---
and
immediately
started
away
from
him
,
and
came
near
him
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
having
no
taste
for
reading
,
and
no
sufficient
light
for
needlework
in
the
subdued
room
,
supposing
her
to
have
the
inclination
,
now
sat
every
night
in
the
dimness
from
which
she
had
momentarily
emerged
on
the
evening
of
Arthur
Clennam
's
return
,
occupied
with
crowds
of
wild
speculations
and
suspicions
respecting
her
mistress
and
her
husband
and
the
noises
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
ferocious
devotional
exercises
were
engaged
in
,
these
speculations
would
distract
Mistress
Affery
's
eyes
towards
the
door
,
as
if
she
expected
some
dark
form
to
appear
at
those
propitious
moments
,
and
make
the
party
one
too
many
.
   
<EOS>
Otherwise
,
Affery
never
said
or
did
anything
to
attract
the
attention
of
the
two
clever
ones
towards
her
in
any
marked
degree
,
except
on
certain
occasions
,
generally
at
about
the
quiet
hour
towards
bed
-
time
,
when
she
would
suddenly
dart
out
of
her
dim
corner
,
and
whisper
with
a
face
of
terror
to
Mr
Flintwinch
,
reading
the
paper
near
Mrs
Clennam
's
little
table
:
"
<EOS>
There
,
jeremiah
!
 
<EOS>
Now
!
<EOS>
What
's
that
noise
?
"
   
<EOS>
Then
the
noise
,
if
there
were
any
,
would
have
ceased
,
and
Mr
Flintwinch
would
snarl
,
turning
upon
her
as
if
she
had
cut
him
down
that
moment
against
his
will
,
"
Affery
,
old
woman
,
you
shall
have
a
dose
,
old
woman
,
such
a
dose
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
dreaming
again
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
Nobody
's
Weakness
 
<EOS>
The
time
being
come
for
the
renewal
of
his
acquaintance
with
the
Meagles
family
,
Clennam
,
pursuant
to
contract
made
between
himself
and
Mr
Meagles
within
the
precincts
of
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
turned
his
face
on
a
certain
Saturday
towards
Twickenham
,
where
Mr
Meagles
had
a
cottage
-
residence
of
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
being
fine
and
dry
,
and
any
English
road
abounding
in
interest
for
him
who
had
been
so
long
away
,
he
sent
his
valise
on
by
the
coach
,
and
set
out
to
walk
.
 
<EOS>
A
walk
was
in
itself
a
new
enjoyment
to
him
,
and
one
that
had
rarely
diversified
his
life
afar
off
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
by
Fulham
and
Putney
,
for
the
pleasure
of
strolling
over
the
heath
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
bright
and
shining
there
;
and
when
he
found
himself
so
far
on
his
road
to
Twickenham
,
he
found
himself
a
long
way
on
his
road
to
a
number
of
airier
and
less
substantial
destinations
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
risen
before
him
fast
,
in
the
healthful
exercise
and
the
pleasant
road
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
easy
to
walk
alone
in
the
country
without
musing
upon
something
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
had
plenty
of
unsettled
subjects
to
meditate
upon
,
though
he
had
been
walking
to
the
Land
's
End
.
   
<EOS>
First
,
there
was
the
subject
seldom
absent
from
his
mind
,
the
question
,
what
he
was
to
do
henceforth
in
life
;
to
what
occupation
he
should
devote
himself
,
and
in
what
direction
he
had
best
seek
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
far
from
rich
,
and
every
day
of
indecision
and
inaction
made
his
inheritance
a
source
of
greater
anxiety
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
he
began
to
consider
how
to
increase
this
inheritance
,
or
to
lay
it
by
,
so
often
his
misgiving
that
there
was
some
one
with
an
unsatisfied
claim
upon
his
justice
,
returned
;
and
that
alone
was
a
subject
to
outlast
the
longest
walk
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
there
was
the
subject
of
his
relations
with
his
mother
,
which
were
now
upon
an
equable
and
peaceful
but
never
confidential
footing
,
and
whom
he
saw
several
times
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
a
leading
and
a
constant
subject
:
for
the
circumstances
of
his
life
,
united
to
those
of
her
own
story
,
presented
the
little
creature
to
him
as
the
only
person
between
whom
and
himself
there
were
ties
of
innocent
reliance
on
one
hand
,
and
affectionate
protection
on
the
other
;
ties
of
compassion
,
respect
,
unselfish
interest
,
gratitude
,
and
pity
.
<EOS>
Thinking
of
her
,
and
of
the
possibility
of
her
father
's
release
from
prison
by
the
unbarring
hand
of
death
---
the
only
change
of
circumstance
he
could
foresee
that
might
enable
him
to
be
such
a
friend
to
her
as
he
wished
to
be
,
by
altering
her
whole
manner
of
life
,
smoothing
her
rough
road
,
and
giving
her
a
home
---
he
regarded
her
,
in
that
perspective
,
as
his
adopted
daughter
,
his
poor
child
of
the
Marshalsea
hushed
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
were
a
last
subject
in
his
thoughts
,
and
it
lay
towards
Twickenham
,
its
form
was
so
indefinite
that
it
was
little
more
than
the
pervading
atmosphere
in
which
these
other
subjects
floated
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
crossed
the
heath
and
was
leaving
it
behind
when
he
gained
upon
a
figure
which
had
been
in
advance
of
him
for
some
time
,
and
which
,
as
he
gained
upon
it
,
he
thought
he
knew
.
 
<EOS>
He
derived
this
impression
from
something
in
the
turn
of
the
head
,
and
in
the
figure
's
action
of
consideration
,
as
it
went
on
at
a
sufficiently
sturdy
walk
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
the
man
---
for
it
was
a
man
's
figure
---
pushed
his
hat
up
at
the
back
of
his
head
,
and
stopped
to
consider
some
object
before
him
,
he
knew
it
to
be
Daniel
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Doyce
?
"
said
Clennam
,
overtaking
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
you
again
,
and
in
a
healthier
place
than
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
's
friend
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
that
public
criminal
,
coming
out
of
some
mental
combinations
he
had
been
making
,
and
offering
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
excuse
me
if
I
forget
your
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Readily
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
a
celebrated
name
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
Barnacle
.
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Daniel
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
I
know
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Clennam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
some
hope
,
"
said
Arthur
,
as
they
walked
on
together
,
"
that
we
may
be
going
to
the
same
place
,
Mr
Doyce
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Meaning
Twickenham
?
"
returned
Daniel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
soon
quite
intimate
,
and
lightened
the
way
with
a
variety
of
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
The
ingenious
culprit
was
a
man
of
great
modesty
and
good
sense
;
and
,
though
a
plain
man
,
had
been
too
much
accustomed
to
combine
what
was
original
and
daring
in
conception
with
what
was
patient
and
minute
in
execution
,
to
be
by
any
means
an
ordinary
man
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
first
difficult
to
lead
him
to
speak
about
himself
,
and
he
put
off
Arthur
's
advances
in
that
direction
by
admitting
slightly
,
<EOS>
oh
yes
,
he
had
done
this
,
and
he
had
done
that
,
and
such
a
thing
was
of
his
making
,
and
such
another
thing
was
his
discovery
,
but
it
was
his
trade
,
you
see
,
his
trade
;
until
,
as
he
gradually
became
assured
that
his
companion
had
a
real
interest
in
his
account
of
himself
,
he
frankly
yielded
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
appeared
that
he
was
the
son
of
a
north
-
country
blacksmith
,
and
had
originally
been
apprenticed
by
his
widowed
mother
to
a
lock
-
maker
;
that
he
had
"
struck
out
a
few
little
things
"
at
the
lock
-
maker
's
,
which
had
led
to
his
being
released
from
his
indentures
with
a
present
,
which
present
had
enabled
him
to
gratify
his
ardent
wish
to
bind
himself
to
a
working
engineer
,
under
whom
he
had
laboured
hard
,
learned
hard
,
and
lived
hard
,
seven
years
.
 
<EOS>
His
time
being
out
,
he
had
"
worked
in
the
shop
"
at
weekly
wages
seven
or
eight
years
more
;
and
had
then
betaken
himself
to
the
banks
of
the
Clyde
,
where
he
had
studied
,
and
filed
,
and
hammered
,
and
improved
his
knowledge
,
theoretical
and
practical
,
for
six
or
seven
years
more
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
had
had
an
offer
to
go
to
Lyons
,
which
he
had
accepted
;
and
from
Lyons
had
been
engaged
to
go
to
Germany
,
and
in
Germany
had
had
an
offer
to
go
to
St
Petersburg
,
and
there
had
done
very
well
indeed
---
never
better
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
had
naturally
felt
a
preference
for
his
own
country
,
and
a
wish
to
gain
distinction
there
,
and
to
do
whatever
service
he
could
do
,
there
rather
than
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
he
had
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
at
home
he
had
established
himself
in
business
,
and
had
invented
and
executed
,
and
worked
his
way
on
,
until
,
after
a
dozen
years
of
constant
suit
and
service
,
he
had
been
enrolled
in
the
Great
British
Legion
of
Honour
,
the
Legion
of
the
Rebuffed
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
had
been
decorated
with
the
Great
British
Order
of
Merit
,
the
Order
of
the
Disorder
of
the
Barnacles
and
Stiltstalkings
.
   
<EOS>
"
it
is
much
to
be
regretted
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
that
you
ever
turned
your
thoughts
that
way
,
Mr
Doyce
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
sir
,
true
to
a
certain
extent
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
is
a
man
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
if
he
has
the
misfortune
to
strike
out
something
serviceable
to
the
nation
,
he
must
follow
where
it
leads
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
Had
n't
he
better
let
it
go
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
ca
n't
do
it
,
"
said
Doyce
,
shaking
his
head
with
a
thoughtful
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
put
into
his
head
to
be
buried
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
put
into
his
head
to
be
made
useful
.
 
<EOS>
You
hold
your
life
on
the
condition
that
to
the
last
you
shall
struggle
hard
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Every
man
holds
a
discovery
on
the
same
terms
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
to
say
,
"
said
Arthur
,
with
a
growing
admiration
of
his
quiet
companion
,
"
you
are
not
finally
discouraged
even
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
right
to
be
,
if
I
am
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
thing
is
as
true
as
it
ever
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
When
they
had
walked
a
little
way
in
silence
,
Clennam
,
at
once
to
change
the
direct
point
of
their
conversation
and
not
to
change
it
too
abruptly
,
asked
Mr
Doyce
if
he
had
any
partner
in
his
business
to
relieve
him
of
a
portion
of
its
anxieties
?
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
returned
,
"
not
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
when
I
first
entered
on
it
,
and
a
good
man
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
has
been
dead
some
years
;
and
<EOS>
as
I
could
not
easily
take
to
the
notion
of
another
when
I
lost
him
,
I
bought
his
share
for
myself
and
have
gone
on
by
myself
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
's
another
thing
,
"
he
said
,
stopping
for
a
moment
with
a
good
-
humoured
laugh
in
his
eyes
,
and
laying
his
closed
right
hand
,
with
its
peculiar
suppleness
of
thumb
,
on
Clennam
's
arm
,
"
no
inventor
can
be
a
man
of
business
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
so
the
men
of
business
say
,
"
he
answered
,
resuming
the
walk
and
laughing
outright
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
we
unfortunate
creatures
should
be
supposed
to
want
common
sense
,
but
it
is
generally
taken
for
granted
that
we
do
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
best
friend
I
have
in
the
world
,
our
excellent
friend
over
yonder
,
"
said
Doyce
,
nodding
towards
Twickenham
,
"
extends
a
sort
of
protection
to
me
,
do
n't
you
know
,
as
a
man
not
quite
able
to
take
care
of
himself
?
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
could
not
help
joining
in
the
good
-
humoured
laugh
,
for
he
recognised
the
truth
of
the
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
find
that
I
must
have
a
partner
who
is
a
man
of
business
and
not
guilty
of
any
inventions
,
"
said
Daniel
Doyce
,
taking
off
his
hat
to
pass
his
hand
over
his
forehead
,
"
if
it
's
only
in
deference
to
the
current
opinion
,
and
to
uphold
the
credit
of
the
Works
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
he
'll
find
that
I
have
been
very
remiss
or
confused
in
my
way
of
conducting
them
;
but
that
's
for
him
to
say
---
whoever
he
is
---
not
for
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
chosen
him
yet
,
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
only
just
come
to
a
decision
to
take
one
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
there
's
more
to
do
than
there
used
to
be
,
and
the
Works
are
enough
for
me
as
I
grow
older
.
 
<EOS>
What
with
the
books
and
correspondence
,
and
foreign
journeys
for
which
a
Principal
is
necessary
,
I
ca
n't
do
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
talk
over
the
best
way
of
negotiating
the
matter
,
if
I
find
a
spare
half
-
hour
between
this
and
Monday
morning
,
with
my
---
my
Nurse
and
protector
,
"
said
Doyce
,
with
laughing
eyes
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
sagacious
man
in
business
,
and
has
had
a
good
apprenticeship
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
this
,
they
conversed
on
different
subjects
until
they
arrived
at
their
journey
's
end
.
 
<EOS>
A
composed
and
unobtrusive
self
-
sustainment
was
noticeable
in
Daniel
Doyce
---
a
calm
knowledge
that
what
was
true
must
remain
true
,
in
spite
of
all
the
Barnacles
in
the
family
ocean
,
and
would
be
just
the
truth
,
and
neither
more
nor
less
when
even
that
sea
had
run
dry
---
which
had
a
kind
of
greatness
in
it
,
though
not
of
the
official
quality
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
knew
the
house
well
,
he
conducted
Arthur
to
it
by
the
way
that
showed
it
to
the
best
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
charming
place
(
none
the
worse
for
being
a
little
eccentric
)
,
on
the
road
by
the
river
,
and
just
what
the
residence
of
the
Meagles
family
ought
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
stood
in
a
garden
,
no
doubt
as
fresh
and
beautiful
in
the
May
of
the
Year
as
Pet
now
was
in
the
May
of
her
life
;
and
it
was
defended
by
a
goodly
show
of
handsome
trees
and
spreading
evergreens
,
as
Pet
was
by
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
made
out
of
an
old
brick
house
,
of
which
a
part
had
been
altogether
pulled
down
,
and
another
part
had
been
changed
into
the
present
cottage
;
so
there
was
a
hale
elderly
portion
,
to
represent
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
,
and
a
young
picturesque
,
very
pretty
portion
to
represent
Pet
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
even
the
later
addition
of
a
conservatory
sheltering
itself
against
it
,
uncertain
of
hue
in
its
deep
-
stained
glass
,
and
in
its
more
transparent
portions
flashing
to
the
sun
's
rays
,
now
like
fire
and
now
like
harmless
water
drops
;
which
might
have
stood
for
Tattycoram
.
 
<EOS>
Within
view
was
the
peaceful
river
and
the
ferry
-
boat
,
to
moralise
to
all
the
inmates
saying
:
Young
or
old
,
passionate
or
tranquil
,
chafing
or
content
,
<EOS>
you
,
thus
runs
the
current
always
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
heart
swell
into
what
discord
it
will
,
thus
plays
the
rippling
water
on
the
prow
of
the
ferry
-
boat
ever
the
same
tune
.
 
<EOS>
Year
after
year
,
so
much
allowance
for
the
drifting
of
the
boat
,
so
many
miles
an
hour
the
flowing
of
the
stream
,
here
the
rushes
,
there
the
lilies
,
nothing
uncertain
or
unquiet
,
upon
this
road
that
steadily
runs
away
;
while
you
,
upon
your
flowing
road
of
time
,
are
so
capricious
and
distracted
.
   
<EOS>
The
bell
at
the
gate
had
scarcely
sounded
when
Mr
Meagles
came
out
to
receive
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
had
scarcely
come
out
,
when
Mrs
Meagles
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Meagles
had
scarcely
come
out
,
when
Pet
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
Pet
scarcely
had
come
out
,
when
Tattycoram
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
Never
had
visitors
a
more
hospitable
reception
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
we
are
,
you
see
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
boxed
up
,
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
within
our
own
home
-
limits
,
as
if
we
were
never
going
to
expand
---
that
is
,
travel
---
again
.
 
<EOS>
Not
like
Marseilles
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
No
allonging
and
marshonging
here
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
different
kind
of
beauty
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
said
Clennam
,
looking
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
Lord
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Meagles
,
rubbing
his
hands
with
a
relish
,
"
it
was
an
uncommonly
pleasant
thing
being
in
quarantine
,
was
n't
it
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
I
have
often
wished
myself
back
again
?
 
<EOS>
We
were
a
capital
party
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
Mr
Meagles
's
invariable
habit
.
 
<EOS>
Always
to
object
to
everything
while
he
was
travelling
,
and
always
to
want
to
get
back
to
it
when
he
was
not
travelling
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
was
summer
-
time
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
which
I
wish
it
was
on
your
account
,
and
in
order
that
you
might
see
the
place
at
its
best
,
you
would
hardly
be
able
to
hear
yourself
speak
for
birds
.
<EOS>
Being
practical
people
,
we
never
allow
anybody
to
scare
the
birds
;
and
the
birds
,
being
practical
people
too
,
come
about
us
in
myriads
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
delighted
to
see
you
,
Clennam
<EOS>
(
if
you
'll
allow
me
,
I
shall
drop
the
Mister
)
;
I
heartily
assure
you
,
we
are
delighted
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
had
so
pleasant
a
greeting
,
"
said
Clennam
---
then
he
recalled
what
Little
Dorrit
had
said
to
him
in
his
own
room
,
and
faithfully
added
"
except
once
---
since
we
last
walked
to
and
fro
,
looking
down
at
the
Mediterranean
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
like
a
look
out
,
that
was
,
was
n't
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
a
military
government
,
but
I
should
n't
mind
a
little
allonging
and
marshonging
---
<EOS>
just
a
dash
of
it
---
in
this
neighbourhood
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
Devilish
still
.
"
   
<EOS>
Bestowing
this
eulogium
on
the
retired
character
of
his
retreat
with
a
dubious
shake
of
the
head
,
Mr
Meagles
led
the
way
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
just
large
enough
,
and
no
more
;
was
as
pretty
within
as
it
was
without
,
and
was
perfectly
well
-
arranged
and
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
Some
traces
of
the
migratory
habits
of
the
family
were
to
be
observed
in
the
covered
frames
and
furniture
,
and
wrapped
-
up
hangings
;
but
it
was
easy
to
see
that
it
was
one
of
Mr
Meagles
's
whims
to
have
the
cottage
always
kept
,
in
their
absence
,
as
if
they
were
always
coming
back
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Of
articles
collected
on
his
various
expeditions
,
there
was
such
a
vast
miscellany
that
it
was
like
the
dwelling
of
an
amiable
Corsair
.
<EOS>
There
were
antiquities
from
Central
Italy
,
made
by
the
best
modern
houses
in
that
department
of
industry
;
<EOS>
bits
of
mummy
from
Egypt
(
and
perhaps
Birmingham
)
;
model
gondolas
from
Venice
;
model
villages
from
Switzerland
;
morsels
of
tesselated
pavement
from
Herculaneum
and
Pompeii
,
like
petrified
minced
veal
;
ashes
out
of
tombs
,
and
lava
out
of
Vesuvius
;
Spanish
fans
,
Spezzian
straw
hats
,
Moorish
slippers
,
Tuscan
hairpins
,
Carrara
sculpture
,
Trastaverini
scarves
,
Genoese
velvets
and
filigree
,
Neapolitan
coral
,
Roman
cameos
,
Geneva
jewellery
,
Arab
lanterns
,
<EOS>
rosaries
blest
all
round
by
the
Pope
himself
,
and
an
infinite
variety
of
lumber
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
views
,
like
and
unlike
,
of
a
multitude
of
places
;
and
there
was
one
little
picture
-
room
devoted
to
a
few
of
the
regular
sticky
old
Saints
,
with
sinews
like
whipcord
,
hair
like
Neptune
's
,
wrinkles
like
tattooing
,
and
such
coats
of
varnish
that
every
holy
personage
served
for
a
fly
-
trap
,
and
became
what
is
now
called
in
the
vulgar
tongue
a
Catch
-
em
-
alive
O.
 
Of
these
pictorial
acquisitions
Mr
Meagles
spoke
in
the
usual
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
no
judge
,
he
said
,
except
of
what
pleased
himself
;
he
had
picked
them
up
,
dirt
-
cheap
,
and
people
had
considered
them
rather
fine
.
 
<EOS>
One
man
,
who
at
any
rate
ought
to
know
something
of
the
subject
,
had
declared
that
"
Sage
,
Reading
"
(
a
specially
oily
old
gentleman
in
a
blanket
,
with
a
swan's
-
down
tippet
for
a
beard
,
and
a
web
of
cracks
all
over
him
like
rich
pie
-
crust
)
,
to
be
a
fine
Guercino
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
Sebastian
del
Piombo
there
,
you
would
judge
for
yourself
;
if
it
were
not
his
later
manner
,
the
question
was
,
Who
was
it
?
 
<EOS>
Titian
,
that
might
or
might
not
be
---
perhaps
he
had
only
touched
it
.
 
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
said
perhaps
he
had
n't
touched
it
,
but
Mr
Meagles
rather
declined
to
overhear
the
remark
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
shown
all
his
spoils
,
Mr
Meagles
took
them
into
his
own
snug
room
overlooking
the
lawn
,
which
was
fitted
up
in
part
like
a
dressing
-
room
and
in
part
like
an
office
,
and
in
which
,
upon
a
kind
of
counter
-
desk
,
were
a
pair
of
brass
scales
for
weighing
gold
,
and
a
scoop
for
shovelling
out
money
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

five

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

(

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
In

played

,

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
Who
