be
much
with
so
pliable
and
beautiful
a
creature
,
and
not
yield
to
her
endearing
influence
?
 
<EOS>
Who
could
pass
an
evening
in
the
house
,
and
not
love
her
for
the
grace
and
charm
of
her
very
presence
in
the
room
?
 
<EOS>
This
was
Clennam
's
reflection
,
notwithstanding
the
final
conclusion
at
which
he
had
arrived
up
-
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
In
making
it
,
he
revoked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
are
you
thinking
of
,
my
good
sir
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
astonished
Mr
Meagles
,
who
was
his
partner
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
,
"
returned
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Think
of
something
,
next
time
;
that
's
a
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
Pet
laughingly
believed
he
had
been
thinking
of
Miss
Wade
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
of
Miss
Wade
,
Pet
?
"
asked
her
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
indeed
!
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
Pet
coloured
a
little
,
and
went
to
the
piano
again
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
broke
up
for
the
night
,
Arthur
overheard
Doyce
ask
his
host
if
he
could
give
him
half
an
hour
's
conversation
before
breakfast
in
the
morning
?
 
<EOS>
The
host
replying
willingly
,
Arthur
lingered
behind
a
moment
,
having
his
own
word
to
add
to
that
topic
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Meagles
,
"
he
said
,
on
their
being
left
alone
,
"
do
you
remember
when
you
advised
me
to
go
straight
to
London
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
Perfectly
well
.
"
<EOS>
"
And
when
you
gave
me
some
other
good
advice
which
I
needed
at
that
time
?
"
   
"
I
wo
n't
say
what
it
was
worth
,
"
answered
Mr
Meagles
:
"
<EOS>
but
of
course
I
remember
our
being
very
pleasant
and
confidential
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
acted
on
your
advice
;
and
having
disembarrassed
myself
of
an
occupation
that
was
painful
to
me
for
many
reasons
,
wish
to
devote
myself
and
what
means
I
have
,
to
another
pursuit
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Right
!
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
do
it
too
soon
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
as
I
came
down
to
-
day
,
I
found
that
your
friend
,
Mr
Doyce
,
is
looking
for
a
partner
in
his
business
---
not
a
partner
in
his
mechanical
knowledge
,
but
in
the
ways
and
means
of
turning
the
business
arising
from
it
to
the
best
account
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
with
the
old
business
expression
of
face
that
had
belonged
to
the
scales
and
scoop
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Doyce
mentioned
incidentally
,
in
the
course
of
our
conversation
,
that
he
was
going
to
take
your
valuable
advice
on
the
subject
of
finding
such
a
partner
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
think
our
views
and
opportunities
at
all
likely
to
coincide
,
perhaps
you
will
let
him
know
my
available
position
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
,
of
course
,
in
ignorance
of
the
details
,
and
they
may
be
unsuitable
on
both
sides
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
no
doubt
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
with
the
caution
belonging
to
the
scales
and
scoop
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
they
will
be
a
question
of
figures
and
accounts
---
"
   
"
Just
so
,
just
so
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
with
arithmetical
solidity
belonging
to
the
scales
and
scoop
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
And
I
shall
be
glad
to
enter
into
the
subject
,
provided
Mr
Doyce
responds
,
and
you
think
well
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
at
present
,
therefore
,
allow
me
to
place
it
in
your
hands
,
you
will
much
oblige
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clennam
,
I
accept
the
trust
with
readiness
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
without
anticipating
any
of
the
points
which
you
,
as
a
man
of
business
,
have
of
course
reserved
,
I
am
free
to
say
to
you
that
I
think
something
may
come
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
Of
one
thing
you
may
be
perfectly
certain
.
 
<EOS>
Daniel
is
an
honest
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sure
of
it
that
I
have
promptly
made
up
my
mind
to
speak
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
You
must
guide
him
,
you
know
;
you
must
steer
him
;
you
must
direct
him
;
he
is
one
of
a
crotchety
sort
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
evidently
meaning
nothing
more
than
that
he
did
new
things
and
went
new
ways
;
"
but
he
is
as
honest
as
the
sun
,
and
so
good
night
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Clennam
went
back
to
his
room
,
sat
down
again
before
his
fire
,
and
made
up
his
mind
that
he
was
glad
he
had
resolved
not
to
fall
in
love
with
Pet
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
beautiful
,
so
amiable
,
so
apt
to
receive
any
true
impression
given
to
her
gentle
nature
and
her
innocent
heart
,
and
make
the
man
who
should
be
so
happy
as
to
communicate
it
,
the
most
fortunate
and
enviable
of
all
men
,
that
he
was
very
glad
indeed
he
had
come
to
that
conclusion
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
as
this
might
have
been
a
reason
for
coming
to
the
opposite
conclusion
,
he
followed
out
the
theme
again
a
little
way
in
his
mind
;
to
justify
himself
,
perhaps
.
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
that
a
man
,
"
so
his
thoughts
ran
,
"
who
had
been
of
age
some
twenty
years
or
so
;
who
was
a
diffident
man
,
from
the
circumstances
of
his
youth
;
who
was
rather
a
grave
man
,
from
the
tenor
of
his
life
;
who
knew
himself
to
be
deficient
in
many
little
engaging
qualities
which
he
admired
in
others
,
from
having
been
long
in
a
distant
region
,
with
nothing
softening
near
him
;
who
had
no
kind
sisters
to
present
to
her
;
who
had
no
congenial
home
to
make
her
known
in
;
who
was
a
stranger
in
the
land
;
who
had
not
a
fortune
to
compensate
,
in
any
measure
,
for
these
defects
;
who
had
nothing
in
his
favour
but
his
honest
love
and
his
general
wish
to
do
right
---
<EOS>
suppose
such
a
man
were
to
come
to
this
house
,
and
were
to
yield
to
the
captivation
of
this
charming
girl
,
and
were
to
persuade
himself
that
he
could
hope
to
win
her
;
what
a
weakness
it
would
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
softly
opened
his
window
,
and
looked
out
upon
the
serene
river
.
<EOS>
Year
after
year
so
much
allowance
for
the
drifting
of
the
ferry
-
boat
,
so
many
miles
an
hour
the
flowing
of
the
stream
,
here
the
rushes
,
there
<EOS>
the
lilies
,
nothing
uncertain
or
unquiet
.
   
<EOS>
Why
should
he
be
vexed
or
sore
at
heart
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
his
weakness
that
he
had
imagined
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nobody
's
,
nobody
's
within
his
knowledge
;
why
should
it
trouble
him
?
 
<EOS>
And
yet
it
did
trouble
him
.
<EOS>
And
he
thought
---
who
has
not
thought
for
a
moment
,
sometimes
?
---
that
it
might
be
better
to
flow
away
monotonously
,
like
the
river
,
and
to
compound
for
its
insensibility
to
happiness
with
its
insensibility
to
pain
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Nobody
's
Rival
 
<EOS>
Before
breakfast
in
the
morning
,
Arthur
walked
out
to
look
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
morning
was
fine
<EOS>
and
he
had
an
hour
on
his
hands
<EOS>
,
he
crossed
the
river
by
the
ferry
,
and
strolled
along
a
footpath
through
some
meadows
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
came
back
to
the
towing
-
path
,
he
found
the
ferry
-
boat
on
the
opposite
side
,
and
a
gentleman
hailing
it
and
waiting
to
be
taken
over
.
   
<EOS>
This
gentleman
looked
barely
thirty
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
well
dressed
,
of
a
sprightly
and
gay
appearance
,
a
well
-
knit
figure
,
and
a
rich
dark
complexion
.
 
<EOS>
As
Arthur
came
over
the
stile
and
down
to
the
water
's
edge
,
the
lounger
glanced
at
him
for
a
moment
,
and
then
resumed
his
occupation
of
idly
tossing
stones
into
the
water
with
his
foot
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
his
way
of
spurning
them
out
of
their
places
with
his
heel
,
and
getting
them
into
the
required
position
,
that
Clennam
thought
had
an
air
of
cruelty
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Most
of
us
have
more
or
less
frequently
derived
a
similar
impression
from
a
man
's
manner
of
doing
some
very
little
thing
:
plucking
a
flower
,
clearing
away
an
obstacle
,
or
even
destroying
an
insentient
object
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
's
thoughts
were
preoccupied
,
as
his
face
showed
,
and
he
took
no
notice
of
a
fine
Newfoundland
dog
,
who
watched
him
attentively
,
and
watched
every
stone
too
,
in
its
turn
,
eager
to
spring
into
the
river
on
receiving
his
master
's
sign
.
 
<EOS>
The
ferry
-
boat
came
over
,
however
,
without
his
receiving
any
sign
,
and
when
it
grounded
his
master
took
him
by
the
collar
and
walked
him
into
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
this
morning
,
"
he
said
to
the
dog
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
do
for
ladies
'
company
,
dripping
wet
.
 
<EOS>
Lie
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
followed
the
man
and
the
dog
into
the
boat
,
and
took
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
did
as
he
was
ordered
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
remained
standing
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
towered
between
Clennam
and
the
prospect
.
 
<EOS>
Man
and
dog
both
jumped
lightly
out
as
soon
as
they
touched
the
other
side
,
and
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
was
glad
to
be
rid
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
The
church
clock
struck
the
breakfast
hour
as
he
walked
up
the
little
lane
by
which
the
garden
-
gate
was
approached
.
 
<EOS>
The
moment
he
pulled
the
bell
a
deep
loud
barking
assailed
him
from
within
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
heard
no
dog
last
night
,
"
thought
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
The
gate
was
opened
by
one
of
the
rosy
maids
,
and
on
the
lawn
were
the
Newfoundland
dog
and
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Minnie
is
not
down
yet
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
the
blushing
portress
,
as
they
all
came
together
in
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
said
to
the
master
of
the
dog
,
"
Mr
Clennam
,
sir
,
"
and
tripped
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Odd
enough
,
Mr
Clennam
,
that
we
should
have
met
just
now
,
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
the
dog
became
mute
.
 
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
to
introduce
myself
---
Henry
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
A
pretty
place
this
,
and
looks
wonderfully
well
this
morning
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
manner
was
easy
,
and
the
voice
agreeable
;
but
still
Clennam
thought
,
that
if
he
had
not
made
that
decided
resolution
to
avoid
falling
in
love
with
Pet
,
he
would
have
taken
a
dislike
to
this
Henry
Gowan
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
new
to
you
,
I
believe
?
"
said
this
Gowan
,
when
Arthur
had
extolled
the
place
.
"
<EOS>
Quite
new
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
acquaintance
with
it
only
yesterday
afternoon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Of
course
this
is
not
its
best
aspect
.
 
<EOS>
It
used
to
look
charming
in
the
spring
,
before
they
went
away
last
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
you
to
have
seen
it
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
for
that
resolution
so
often
recalled
,
Clennam
might
have
wished
him
in
the
crater
of
Mount
Etna
,
in
return
for
this
civility
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
it
under
many
circumstances
during
the
last
three
years
,
and
it
's
---
a
Paradise
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
(
at
least
it
might
have
been
,
always
excepting
for
that
wise
resolution
)
like
his
dexterous
impudence
to
call
it
a
Paradise
.
 
<EOS>
He
only
called
it
a
Paradise
because
he
first
saw
her
coming
,
and
so
made
her
out
within
her
hearing
to
be
an
angel
,
Confusion
to
him
!
<EOS>
And
ah
!
 
<EOS>
how
beaming
she
looked
,
and
how
glad
!
 
<EOS>
How
she
caressed
the
dog
,
and
how
the
dog
knew
her
!
 
<EOS>
How
expressive
that
heightened
colour
in
her
face
,
that
fluttered
manner
,
her
downcast
eyes
,
her
irresolute
happiness
!
 
<EOS>
When
had
Clennam
seen
her
look
like
this
?
<EOS>
Not
that
there
was
any
reason
why
he
might
,
could
,
would
,
or
should
have
ever
seen
her
look
like
this
,
or
that
he
had
ever
hoped
for
himself
to
see
her
look
like
this
;
but
still
---
when
had
he
ever
known
her
do
it
!
   
<EOS>
He
stood
at
a
little
distance
from
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
Gowan
when
he
had
talked
about
a
Paradise
,
had
gone
up
to
her
and
taken
her
hand
.
<EOS>
The
dog
had
put
his
great
paws
on
her
arm
and
laid
his
head
against
her
dear
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
laughed
and
welcomed
them
,
and
made
far
too
much
of
the
dog
,
far
,
far
,
too
much
---
that
is
to
say
,
supposing
there
had
been
any
third
person
looking
on
who
loved
her
.
   
<EOS>
She
disengaged
herself
now
,
and
came
to
Clennam
,
and
put
her
hand
in
his
and
wished
him
good
morning
,
and
gracefully
made
as
if
she
would
take
his
arm
and
be
escorted
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
Gowan
had
no
objection
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
he
knew
he
was
too
safe
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
passing
cloud
on
Mr
Meagles
's
good
-
humoured
face
when
they
all
three
(
four
,
counting
the
dog
,
and
he
was
the
most
objectionable
but
one
of
the
party
)
came
in
to
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
it
,
nor
the
touch
of
uneasiness
on
Mrs
Meagles
as
she
directed
her
eyes
towards
it
,
was
unobserved
by
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Gowan
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
even
suppressing
a
sigh
;
"
how
goes
the
world
with
you
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Much
as
usual
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Lion
and
I
being
determined
not
to
waste
anything
of
our
weekly
visit
,
turned
out
early
,
and
came
over
from
Kingston
,
my
present
headquarters
,
where
I
am
making
a
sketch
or
two
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he
told
how
he
had
met
Mr
Clennam
at
the
ferry
,
and
they
had
come
over
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
is
well
,
Henry
?
"
said
Mrs
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
(
Clennam
became
attentive
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
My
mother
is
quite
well
,
thank
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
Clennam
became
inattentive
.
)
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
the
liberty
of
making
an
addition
to
your
family
dinner
-
party
to
-
day
,
which
I
hope
will
not
be
inconvenient
to
you
or
to
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
very
well
get
out
of
it
,
"
he
explained
,
turning
to
the
latter
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
young
fellow
wrote
to
propose
himself
to
me
;
and
as
he
is
well
connected
,
I
thought
you
would
not
object
to
my
transferring
him
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
the
young
fellow
?
"
asked
Mr
Meagles
with
peculiar
complacency
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
one
of
the
Barnacles
.
 
<EOS>
Tite
Barnacle
's
son
,
Clarence
Barnacle
,
who
is
in
his
father
's
Department
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
at
least
guarantee
that
the
river
shall
not
suffer
from
his
visit
.
 
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
set
it
on
fire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
?
"
said
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
Barnacle
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
We
know
something
of
that
family
,
eh
,
Dan
?
 
<EOS>
By
George
,
they
are
at
the
top
of
the
tree
,
though
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
What
relation
will
this
young
fellow
be
to
Lord
Decimus
now
?
 
<EOS>
His
Lordship
married
,
in
seventeen
ninety
-
seven
,
Lady
Jemima
Bilberry
,
who
was
the
second
daughter
by
the
third
marriage
---
<EOS>
no
!
 
<EOS>
There
I
am
wrong
!
 
<EOS>
That
was
Lady
Seraphina
---
<EOS>
Lady
Jemima
was
the
first
daughter
by
the
second
marriage
of
the
fifteenth
Earl
of
Stiltstalking
with
the
Honourable
Clementina
Toozellem
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Now
this
young
fellow
's
father
married
<EOS>
a
Stiltstalking
and
his
father
married
his
cousin
who
was
a
Barnacle
.
   
<EOS>
The
father
of
that
father
who
married
a
Barnacle
,
married
a
Joddleby
.
<EOS>
---
I
am
getting
a
little
too
far
back
,
Gowan
;
I
want
to
make
out
what
relation
<EOS>
this
young
fellow
is
to
Lord
Decimus
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
easily
stated
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
is
nephew
to
Lord
Decimus
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nephew
---
to
---
Lord
---
Decimus
,
"
Mr
Meagles
luxuriously
repeated
with
his
eyes
shut
,
that
he
might
have
nothing
to
distract
him
from
the
full
flavour
of
the
genealogical
tree
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
George
,
you
are
right
,
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Consequently
,
Lord
Decimus
is
his
great
uncle
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
stop
a
bit
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
opening
his

with
a
fresh
discovery
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
on
the
mother
's
side
,
Lady
Stiltstalking
is
his
great
aunt
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
she
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
aye
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
with
much
interest
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
indeed
?
 
<EOS>
We
shall
be
glad
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
entertain
him
as
well
as
we
can
,
in
our
humble
way
;
and
we
shall
not
starve
him
,
I
hope
,
at
all
events
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
beginning
of
this
dialogue
,
Clennam
had
expected
some
great
harmless
outburst
from
Mr
Meagles
,
like
that
which
had
made
him
burst
out
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
holding
Doyce
by
the
collar
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
good
friend
had
a
weakness
which
none
of
us
need
go
into
the
next
street
to
find
,
and
which
no
amount
of
Circumlocution
experience
could
long
subdue
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
looked
at
Doyce
;
but
Doyce
knew
all
about
it
beforehand
,
and
looked
at
his
plate
,
and
made
no
sign
,
and
said
no
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
,
"
said
Gowan
,
to
conclude
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
Clarence
is
a
great
ass
,
but
he
is
one
of
the
dearest
and
best
fellows
that
ever
lived
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
before
the
breakfast
was
over
,
that
everybody
whom
this
Gowan
knew
was
either
more
or
less
of
an
ass
,
or
more
or
less
of
a
knave
;
but
was
,
notwithstanding
,
the
most
lovable
,
the
most
engaging
,
the
simplest
,
truest
,
kindest
,
dearest
,
best
fellow
that
ever
lived
.
 
<EOS>
The
process
by
which
this
unvarying
result
was
attained
,
whatever
the
premises
,
might
have
been
stated
by
Mr
Henry
Gowan
thus
:
"
I
claim
to
be
always
book
-
keeping
,
with
a
peculiar
nicety
,
in
every
man
's
case
,
and
posting
up
a
careful
little
account
of
Good
and
Evil
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
this
so
conscientiously
,
that
I
am
happy
to
tell
you
I
find
the
most
worthless
of
men
to
be
the
dearest
old
fellow
too
:
and
am
in
a
condition
to
make
the
gratifying
report
,
that
there
is
much
less
difference
than
you
are
inclined
to
suppose
between
an
honest
man
and
a
scoundrel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
effect
of
this
cheering
discovery
happened
to
be
,
that
while
he
seemed
to
be
scrupulously
finding
good
in
most
men
,
he
did
in
reality
lower
it
where
it
was
,
and
set
it
up
where
it
was
not
;
but
that
was
its
only
disagreeable
or
dangerous
feature
.
   
<EOS>
It
scarcely
seemed
,
however
,
to
afford
Mr
Meagles
as
much
satisfaction
as
the
Barnacle
genealogy
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
The
cloud
that
Clennam
had
never
seen
upon
his
face
before
that
morning
,
frequently
overcast
it
again
;
and
there
was
the
same
shadow
of
uneasy
observation
of
him
on
the
comely
face
of
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
once
or
twice
when
Pet
caressed
the
dog
,
it
appeared
to
Clennam
that
her
father
was
unhappy
in
seeing
her
do
it
;
and
,
in
one
particular
instance
when
Gowan
stood
on
the
other
side
of
the
dog
,
and
bent
his
head
at
the
same
time
,
Arthur
fancied
that
he
saw
tears
rise
to
Mr
Meagles
's
eyes
as
he
hurried
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
either
the
fact
too
,
or
he
fancied
further
,
that
Pet
herself
was
not
insensible
to
these
little
incidents
;
that
she
tried
,
with
a
more
delicate
affection
than
usual
,
to
express
to
her
good
father
how
much
she
loved
him
;
that
it
was
on
this
account
that
she
fell
behind
the
rest
,
both
as
they
went
to
church
and
as
they
returned
from
it
,
and
took
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
have
sworn
but
that
as
he
walked
alone
in
the
garden
afterwards
,
he
had
an
instantaneous
glimpse
of
her
in
her
father
's
room
,
clinging
to
both
her
parents
with
the
greatest
tenderness
,
and
weeping
on
her
father
's
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
The
latter
part
of
the
day
turning
out
wet
,
they
were
fain
to
keep
the
house
,
look
over
Mr
Meagles
's
collection
,
and
beguile
the
time
with
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
This
Gowan
had
plenty
to
say
for
himself
,
and
said
it
in
an
off
-
hand
and
amusing
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
be
an
artist
by
profession
,
and
to
have
been
at
Rome
some
time
;
yet
he
had
a
slight
,
careless
,
amateur
way
with
him
---
a
perceptible
limp
,
both
in
his
devotion
to
art
and
his
attainments
---
which
Clennam
could
scarcely
understand
.
   
<EOS>
He
applied
to
Daniel
Doyce
for
help
,
as
they
stood
together
,
looking
out
of
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
Mr
Gowan
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
him
here
.
 
<EOS>
Comes
here
every
Sunday
when
they
are
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
artist
,
I
infer
from
what
he
says
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
sort
of
a
one
,
"
said
Daniel
Doyce
,
in
a
surly
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
sort
of
a
one
?
"
asked
Clennam
,
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
has
sauntered
into
the
Arts
at
a
leisurely
Pall
-
Mall
pace
,
"
said
Doyce
,
"
and
I
doubt
if
they
care
to
be
taken
quite
so
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Pursuing
his
inquiries
,
Clennam
found
that
the
Gowan
family
were
a
very
distant
ramification
of
the
Barnacles
;
and
that
the
paternal
Gowan
,
originally
attached
to
a
legation
abroad
,
had
been
pensioned
off
as
a
Commissioner
of
nothing
particular
somewhere
or
other
,
and
had
died
at
his
post
with
his
drawn
salary
in
his
hand
,
nobly
defending
it
to
the
last
extremity
.
 
<EOS>
In
consideration
of
this
eminent
public
service
,
the
Barnacle
then
in
power
had
recommended
the
Crown
to
bestow
a
pension
of
two
or
three
hundred
a
-
year
on
his
widow
;
to
which
the
next
Barnacle
in
power
had
added
certain
shady
and
sedate
apartments
in
the
Palaces
at
Hampton
Court
,
where
the
old
lady
still
lived
,
deploring
the
degeneracy
of
the
times
in
company
with
several
other
old
ladies
of
both
sexes
.
 
<EOS>
Her
son
,
Mr
Henry
Gowan
,
inheriting
from
his
father
,
the
Commissioner
,
that
very
questionable
help
in
life
,
a
very
small
independence
,
had
been
difficult
to
settle
;
the
rather
,
as
public
appointments
chanced
to
be
scarce
,
and
his
genius
,
during
his
earlier
manhood
,
was
of
that
exclusively
agricultural
character
which
applies
itself
to
the
cultivation
of
wild
oats
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
had
declared
that
he
would
become
a
Painter
;
partly
because
he
had
always
had
an
idle
knack
that
way
,
and
partly
to
grieve
the
souls
of
the
Barnacles
-
in
-
chief
who
had
not
provided
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
had
come
to
pass
successively
,
first
,
that
several
distinguished
ladies
had
been
frightfully
shocked
;
then
,
that
portfolios
of
his
performances
had
been
handed
about
o
'
nights
,
and
declared
with
ecstasy
to
be
perfect
Claudes
,
perfect
Cuyps
,
perfect
phaenomena
;
then
,
that
Lord
Decimus
had
bought
his
picture
,
and
had
asked
the
President
and
Council
to
dinner
at
a
blow
,
and
had
said
,
with
his
own
magnificent
gravity
,
"
Do
you
know
,
there
appears
to
me
to
be
really
immense
merit
in
that
work
?
"
<EOS>
and
,
in
short
,
that
people
of
condition
had
absolutely
taken
pains
to
bring
him
into
fashion
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
somehow
,
it
had
all
failed
.
 
<EOS>
The
prejudiced
public
had
stood
out
against
it
obstinately
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
determined
not
to
admire
Lord
Decimus
's
picture
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
determined
to
believe
that
in
every
service
,
except
their
own
,
a
man
must
qualify
himself
,
by
striving
early
and
late
,
and
by
working
heart
and
soul
,
might
and
main
.
 
<EOS>
So
now
Mr
Gowan
,
like
that
worn
-
out
old
coffin
which
never
was
Mahomet
's
nor
anybody
else
's
,
hung
midway
between
two
points
:
jaundiced
and
jealous
as
to
the
one
he
had
left
:
jaundiced
and
jealous
as
to
the
other
that
he
could
n't
reach
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
substance
of
Clennam
's
discoveries
concerning
him
,
made
that
rainy
Sunday
afternoon
and
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
About
an
hour
or
so
after
dinner
time
,
Young
Barnacle
appeared
,
attended
by
his
eye
-
glass
;
in
honour
of
whose
family
connections
,
Mr
Meagles
had
cashiered
the
pretty
parlour
-
maids
for
the
day
,
and
had
placed
on
duty
in
their
stead
two
dingy
men
.
 
<EOS>
Young
Barnacle
was
in
the
last
degree
amazed
and
disconcerted
at
sight
of
Arthur
,
and
had
murmured
involuntarily
,
"
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
upon
my
soul
,
you
know
!
<EOS>
"
before
his
presence
of
mind
returned
.
   
<EOS>
Even
then
,
he
was
obliged
to
embrace
the
earliest
opportunity
of
taking
his
friend
into
a
window
,
and
saying
,
in
a
nasal
way
that
was
a
part
of
his
general
debility
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
,
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
that
fellow
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
friend
of
our
host
's
.
 
None
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
most
ferocious
Radical
,
you
know
,
"
said
Young
Barnacle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
?
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
know
?
"
   
"
Ecod
,
sir
,
he
was
Pitching
into
our
people
the
other
day
in
the
most
tremendous
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Went
up
to
our
place
and
Pitched
into
my
father
to
that
extent
that
it
was
necessary
to
order
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
Came
back
to
our
Department
,
and
Pitched
into
me
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
never
saw
such
a
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
want
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
sir
,
"
returned
Young
Barnacle
,
"
he
said
he
wanted
to
know
,
you
know
!
 
<EOS>
Pervaded
our
Department
---
without
an
appointment
---
and
said
he
wanted
to
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
stare
of
indignant
wonder
with
which
Young
Barnacle
accompanied
this
disclosure
,
would
have
strained
his
eyes
injuriously
but
for
the
opportune
relief
of
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
(
who
had
been
extremely
solicitous
to
know
how
his
uncle
and
aunt
were
)
begged
him
to
conduct
Mrs
Meagles
to
the
dining
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
sat
on
Mrs
Meagles
's
right
hand
,
Mr
Meagles
looked
as
gratified
as
if
his
whole
family
were
there
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
natural
charm
of
the
previous
day
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
The
eaters
of
the
dinner
,
like
the
dinner
itself
,
were
lukewarm
,
insipid
,
overdone
---
and
all
owing
to
this
poor
little
dull
Young
Barnacle
.
<EOS>
Conversationless
at
any
time
,
he
was
now
the
victim
of
a
weakness
special
to
the
occasion
,
and
solely
referable
to
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
under
a
pressing
and
continual
necessity
of
looking
at
that
gentleman
,
which
occasioned
his
eye
-
glass
to
get
into
his
soup
,
into
his
wine
-
glass
,
into
Mrs
Meagles
's
plate
,
to
hang
down
his
back
like
a
bell
-
rope
,
and
be
several
times
disgracefully
restored
to
his
bosom
by
one
of
the
dingy
men
.
 
<EOS>
Weakened
in
mind
by
his
frequent
losses
of
this
instrument
,
and
its
determination
not
to
stick
in
his
eye
,
and
more
and
more
enfeebled
in
intellect
every
time
he
looked
at
the
mysterious
Clennam
,
he
applied
spoons
to
his
eyes
,
forks
,
and
other
foreign
matters
connected
with
the
furniture
of
the
dinner
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
His
discovery
of
these
mistakes
greatly
increased
his
difficulties
,
but
never
released
him
from
the
necessity
of
looking
at
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
And
whenever
Clennam
spoke
,
this
ill
-
starred
young
man
was
clearly
seized
with
a
dread
that
he
was
coming
,
by
some
artful
device
,
<EOS>
round
to
that
point
of
wanting
to
know
,
you
know
.
   
<EOS>
It
may
be
questioned
,
therefore
,
whether
any
one
but
Mr
Meagles
had
much
enjoyment
of
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
however
,
thoroughly
enjoyed
Young
Barnacle
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
mere
flask
of
the
golden
water
in
the
tale
became
a
full
fountain
when
it
was
poured
out
,
so
Mr
Meagles
seemed
to
feel
that
this
small
spice
of
Barnacle
imparted
to
his
table
the
flavour
of
the
whole
family
-
tree
.
 
<EOS>
In
its
presence
,
his
frank
,
fine
,
genuine
qualities
paled
;
he
was
not
so
easy
,
he
was
not
so
natural
,
he
was
striving
after
something
that
did
not
belong
to
him
,
he
was
not
himself
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
strange
peculiarity
on
the
part
of
Mr
Meagles
,
and
where
should
we
find
another
such
case
!
   
<EOS>
At
last
the
wet
Sunday
wore
itself
out
in
a
wet
night
;
and
Young
Barnacle
went
home
in
a
cab
,
feebly
smoking
;
and
the
objectionable
Gowan
went
away
on
foot
,
accompanied
by
the
objectionable
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Pet
had
taken
the
most
amiable
pains
all
day
to
be
friendly
with
Clennam
,
but
Clennam
had
been
a
little
reserved
since
breakfast
<EOS>
---
that
is
to
say
,
would
have
been
,
if
he
had
loved
her
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
gone
to
his
own
room
,
and
had
again
thrown
himself
into
the
chair
by
the
fire
,
Mr
Doyce
knocked
at
the
door
,
candle
in
hand
,
to
ask
him
how
and
at
what
hour
he
proposed
returning
on
the
morrow
?
 
<EOS>
After
settling
this
question
,
he
said
a
word
to
Mr
Doyce
about
this
Gowan
---
who
would
have
run
in
his
head
a
good
deal
,
if
he
had
been
his
rival
.
   
<EOS>
"
Those
are
not
good
prospects
for
a
painter
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
stood
,
chamber
-
candlestick
in
hand
,
the
other
hand
in
his
pocket
,
looking
hard
at
the
flame
of
his
candle
,
with
a
certain
quiet
perception
in
his
face
that
they
were
going
to
say
something
more
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
our
good
friend
a
little
changed
,
and
out

,
after
he
came
this

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
not
his
daughter
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
on
both
sides
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
,
still
looking
at
the
flame
of
his

,
slowly

:
   
<EOS>
"
The
truth
is
,
he
has
twice
taken
his
daughter
abroad
in
the
hope
of
separating
her
from
Mr
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
He
rather
thinks
she
is
disposed
to
like

,
and
he
has
painful

<EOS>
(
I
quite
agree
with
him
,
as
I
dare

do
)
of
the
hopefulness
of
such

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
---
"
Clennam
choked
,
and
coughed
,
and
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
have
taken
cold
,
"
said
Daniel
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
But
without
looking
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
an
engagement
between
them
,
of
course
?
"
said
Clennam
airily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
am
told
,
certainly
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
solicited
on
the
gentleman
's
part
,
but
none
has
been
made
.
 
<EOS>
Since
their
recent
return
,
our
friend
has
yielded
to
a
weekly
visit
,
but
that
is
the
utmost
.
 
<EOS>
Minnie
would
not
deceive
her
father
and
mother
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
travelled
with
them
,
and
I
believe
you
know
what
a
bond
there
is
among
them
,
extending
even
beyond
this
present
life
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
there
is
between
Miss
Minnie
and
Mr
Gowan
,
I
have
no
doubt
we
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
We
see
enough
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
wished
him
Good
Night
in
the
tone
of
a
man
who
had
heard
a
mournful
,
not
to
say
despairing
,
exclamation
,
and
who
sought
to
infuse
some
encouragement
and
hope
into
the
mind
of
the
person
by
whom
it
had
been
uttered
.
 
<EOS>
Such
tone
was
probably
a
part
of
his
oddity
,
as
one
of
a
crotchety
band
;
for
how
could
he
have
heard
anything
of
that
kind
,
without
Clennam
's
hearing
it
too
?
   
<EOS>
The
rain
fell
heavily
on
the
roof
,
and
pattered
on
the
ground
,
and
dripped
among
the
evergreens
and
the
leafless
branches
of
the
trees
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
fell
heavily
,
drearily
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
night
of
tears
.
   
<EOS>
If
Clennam
had
not
decided
against
falling
in
love
with
Pet
;
if
he
had
had
the
weakness
to
do
it
;
if
he
had
,
little
by
little
,
persuaded
himself
to
set
all
the
earnestness
of
his
nature
,
all
the
might
of
his
hope
,
and
all
the
wealth
of
his
matured
character
,
on
that
cast
;
if
he
had
done
this
and
found
that
all
was
lost
;
he
would
have
been
,
that
night
,
unutterably
miserable
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
---
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
the
rain
fell
heavily
,
drearily
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
Lover
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
not
attained
her
twenty
-
second
birthday
without
finding
a
lover
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
the
shallow
Marshalsea
,
the
ever
young
Archer
shot
off
a
few
featherless
arrows
now
and
then
from
a
mouldy
bow
,
and
winged
a
Collegian
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
lover
,
however
,
was
not
a
Collegian
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
sentimental
son
of
a
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
hoped
,
in
the
fulness
of
time
,
to
leave
him
the
inheritance
of
an
unstained
key
;
and
had
from
his
early
youth
familiarised
him
with
the
duties
of
his
office
,
and
with
an
ambition
to
retain
the
prison
-
lock
in
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
succession
was
yet
in
abeyance
,
he
assisted
his
mother
in
the
conduct
of
a
snug
tobacco
business
round
the
corner
of
Horsemonger
Lane
(
his
father
being
a
non
-
resident
turnkey
)
,
which
could
usually
command
a
neat
connection
within
the
College
walls
.
   
<EOS>
Years
agone
,
when
the
object
of
his
affections
was
wo
nt
to
sit
in
her
little
arm
-
chair
by
the
high
Lodge
-
fender
,
Young
John
(
family
name
,
Chivery
)
,
a
year
older
than
herself
,
had
eyed
her
with
admiring
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
played
with
her
in
the
yard
,
his
favourite
game
had
been
to
counterfeit
locking
her
up
in
corners
,
and
to
counterfeit
letting
her
out
for
real
kisses
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
grew
tall
enough
to
peep
through
the
keyhole
of
the
great
lock
of
the
main
door
,
he
had
<EOS>
divers
times
set
down
his
father
's
dinner
,
or
supper
,
to
get
on
as
it
might
on
the
outer
side
thereof
,
while
he
stood
taking
cold
in
one
eye
by
dint
of
peeping
at
her
through
that
airy
perspective
.
   
<EOS>
If
Young
John
had
ever
slackened
in
his
truth
in
the
less
penetrable
days
of
his
boyhood
,
when
youth
is
prone
to
wear
its
boots
unlaced
and
is
happily
unconscious
of
digestive
organs
,
he
had
soon
strung
it
up
again
and
screwed
it
tight
.
 
<EOS>
At
nineteen
,
his
hand
had
inscribed
in
chalk
on
that
part
of
the
wall
which
fronted
her
lodgings
,
on
the
occasion
of
her
birthday
,
"
Welcome
sweet
nursling
of
the
Fairies
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
twenty
-
three
,
the
same
hand
falteringly
presented
cigars
on
Sundays
to
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
and
Father
of
the
queen
of
his
soul
.
   
<EOS>
Young
John
was
small
of
stature
,
with
rather
weak
legs
and
very
weak
light
hair
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
his
eyes
(
perhaps
the
eye
that
used
to
peep
through
the
keyhole
)
was
also
weak
,
and
looked
larger
than
the
other
,
as
if
it
could
n't
collect
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Young
John
was
gentle
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
great
of
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Poetical
,
expansive
,
faithful
.
   
<EOS>
Though
too
humble
before
the
ruler
of
his
heart
to
be
sanguine
,
Young
John
had
considered
the
object
of
his
attachment
in
all
its
lights
and
shades
.
 
<EOS>
Following
it
out
to
blissful
results
,
he
had
descried
,
without
self
-
commendation
,
a
fitness
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Say
things
prospered
,
and
they
were
united
.
 
<EOS>
She
,
the
child
of
the
Marshalsea
;
he
,
the
lock
-
keeper
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fitness
in
that
.
 
<EOS>
Say
he
became
a
resident
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
officially
succeed
to
the
chamber
she
had
rented
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
beautiful
propriety
in
that
.
<EOS>
It
looked
over
the
wall
,
if
you
stood
on
tip
-
toe
;
and
,
with
a
trellis
-
work
of
scarlet
beans
and
a
canary
or
so
,
would
become
a
very
Arbour
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
charming
idea
in
that
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
being
all
in
all
to
one
another
,
there
was
even
an
appropriate
grace
in
the
lock
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
world
shut
out
(
except
that
part
of
it
which
would
be
shut
in
)
;
with
its
troubles
and
disturbances
only
known
to
them
by
hearsay
,
as
they
would
be
described
by
the
pilgrims
tarrying
with
them
on
their
way
to
the
Insolvent
Shrine
;
with
the
Arbour
above
,
and
the
Lodge
below
;
they
would
glide
down
the
stream
of
time
,
in
pastoral
domestic
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
Young
John
drew
tears
from
his
eyes
by
finishing
the
picture
with
a
tombstone
in
the
adjoining
churchyard
,
close
against
the
prison
wall
,
bearing
the
following
touching
inscription
:
"
Sacred
to
the
Memory
Of
JOHN
CHIVERY
,
Sixty
years
Turnkey
,
and
fifty
years
Head
Turnkey
,
Of
the
neighbouring
Marshalsea
,
<EOS>
Who
departed
this
life
,
universally
respected
,
on
the
thirty
-
first
of
December
,
One
thousand
eight
hundred
and
eighty
-
six
,
<EOS>
Aged
eighty
-
three
years
.
 
<EOS>
Also
of
his
truly
beloved
and
truly
loving
wife
,
AMY
,
whose
maiden
name
was
DORRIT
,
Who
survived
his
loss
not
quite
forty
-
eight
hours
,
And
who
breathed
her
last
in
the
Marshalsea
aforesaid
.
 
<EOS>
There
she
was
born
,
There
she
lived
,
There
she
died
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Chivery
parents
were
not
ignorant
of
their
son
's
attachment
 
---
<EOS>
indeed
it
had
,
on
some
exceptional
occasions
,
thrown
him
into
a
state
of
mind
that
had
impelled
him
to
conduct
himself
with
irascibility
towards
the
customers
,
and
damage
the
business
---
but
they
,
in
their
turns
,
had
worked
it
out
to
desirable
conclusions
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Chivery
,
a
prudent
woman
,
had
desired
her
husband
to
take
notice
that
their
john
's
prospects
of
the
Lock
would
certainly
be
strengthened
by
an
alliance
with
Miss
Dorrit
,
who
had
herself
a
kind
of
claim
upon
the
College
and
was
much
respected
there
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Chivery
had
desired
her
husband
to
take
notice
that
if
,
on
the
one
hand
,
their
John
had
means
and
a
post
of
trust
,
on
the
other
hand
,
Miss
Dorrit
had
family
;
and
that
her
<EOS>
(
Mrs
Chivery
's
)
sentiment
was
,
that
two
halves
made
a
whole
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Chivery
,
speaking
as
a
mother
and
not
as
a
diplomatist
,
had
then
,
from
a
different
point
of
view
,
desired
her
husband
to
recollect
that
their
John
had
never
been
strong
,
and
that
his
love
had
fretted
and
worrited
him
enough
as
it
was
,
without
his
being
driven
to
do
himself
a
mischief
,
as
nobody
could
n't
say
he
would
n't
be
if
he
was
crossed
.
 
<EOS>
These
arguments
had
so
powerfully
influenced
the
mind
of
Mr
Chivery
,
who
was
a
man
of
few
words
,
that
he
had
on
sundry
Sunday
mornings
,
given
his
boy
what
he
termed
"
a
lucky
touch
,
"
signifying
that
he
considered
such
commendation
of
him
to
Good
Fortune
,
preparatory
to
his
that
day
declaring
his
passion
and
becoming
triumphant
.
 
<EOS>
But
Young
John
had
never
taken
courage
to
make
the
declaration
;
and
it
was
principally
on
these
occasions
that
he
had
returned
excited
to
the
tobacco
shop
,
and
flown
at
the
customers
.
<EOS>
In
this
affair
,
as
in
every
other
,
Little
Dorrit
herself
was
the
last
person
considered
.
 
<EOS>
Her
brother
and
sister
were
aware
of
it
,
and
attained
a
sort
of
station
by
making
a
peg
of
it
on
which
to
air
the
miserably
ragged
old
fiction
of
the
family
gentility
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
asserted
the
family
gentility
by
flouting
the
poor
swain
as
he
loitered
about
the
prison
for
glimpses
of
his
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Tip
asserted
the
family
gentility
,
and
his
own
,
by
coming
out
in
the
character
of
the
aristocratic
brother
,
and
loftily
swaggering
in
the
little
skittle
ground
respecting
seizures
by
the
scruff
of
the
neck
,
which
there
were
looming
probabilities
of
some
gentleman
unknown
executing
on
some
little
puppy
not
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
not
the
only
members
of
the
Dorrit
family
who
turned
it
to
account
.
   
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
was
supposed
to
know
nothing
about
the
matter
,
of
course
:
his
poor
dignity
could
not
see
so
low
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
took
the
cigars
,
on
Sundays
,
and
was
glad
to
get
them
;
and
sometimes
even
condescended
to
walk
up
and
down
the
yard
with
the
donor
(
who
was
proud
and
hopeful
then
)
,
and
benignantly
to
smoke
one
in
his
society
.
 
<EOS>
With
no
less
readiness
and
condescension
did
he
receive
attentions
from
Chivery
Senior
,
who
always
relinquished
his
arm
-
chair
and
newspaper
to
him
,
when
he
came
into
the
Lodge
during
one
of
his
spells
of
duty
;
and
who
had
even
mentioned
to
him
,
that
,
if
he
would
like
at
any
time
after
dusk
quietly
to
step
out
into
the
fore
-
court
and
take
a
look
at
the
street
,
there
was
not
much
to
prevent
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
did
not
avail
himself
of
this
latter
civility
,
it
was
only
because
he
had
lost
the
relish
for
it
;
inasmuch
as
he
took
everything
else
he
could
get
,
and
would
say
at
times
,
"
Extremely
civil
person
,
Chivery
;
very
attentive
man
and
very
respectful
.
 
<EOS>
Young
Chivery
,
too
;
really
almost
with
a
delicate
perception
of
one
's
position
here
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
well
conducted
family
indeed
,
the
Chiveries
.
 
<EOS>
Their
behaviour
gratifies
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
devoted
Young
John
all
this
time
regarded
the
family
with
reverence
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
dreamed
of
disputing
their
pretensions
,
but
did
homage
to
the
miserable
Mumbo
jumbo
they
paraded
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
resenting
any
affront
from
her
brother
,
he
would
have
felt
,
even
if
he
had
not
naturally
been
of
a
most
pacific
disposition
,
that
to
wag
his
tongue
or
lift
his
hand
against
that
sacred
gentleman
would
be
an
unhallowed
act
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sorry
that
his
noble
mind
should
take
offence
;
still
,
he
felt
the
fact
to
be
not
incompatible
with
its
nobility
,
and
sought
to
propitiate
and
conciliate
that
gallant
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
,
a
gentleman
in
misfortune
---
a
gentleman
of
a
fine
spirit
and
courtly
manners
,
who
always
bore
with
him
<EOS>
---
he
deeply
honoured
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
he
considered
somewhat
vain
and
proud
,
but
a
young
lady
of
infinite
accomplishments
,
who
could
not
forget
the
past
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
instinctive
testimony
to
Little
Dorrit
's
worth
and
difference
from
all
the
rest
,
that
the
poor
young
fellow
honoured
and
loved
her
for
being
simply
what
she
was
.
   
<EOS>
The
tobacco
business
round
the
corner
of
Horsemonger
Lane
was
carried
out
in
a
rural
establishment
one
story
high
,
which
had
the
benefit
of
the
air
from
the
yards
of
Horsemonger
Lane
jail
,
and
the
advantage
of
a
retired
walk
under
the
wall
of
that
pleasant
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
The
business
was
of
too
modest
a
character
to
support
a
life
-
size
Highlander
,
but
it
maintained
a
little
one
on
a
bracket
on
the
door
-
post
,
who
looked
like
a
fallen
Cherub
that
had
found
it
necessary
to
take
to
a
kilt
.
<EOS>
From
the
portal
thus
decorated
,
one
Sunday
after
an
early
dinner
of
baked
viands
,
Young
John
issued
forth
on
his
usual
Sunday
errand
;
not
empty
-
handed
,
but
with
his
offering
of
cigars
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
neatly
attired
in
a
plum
-
coloured
coat
,
with
as
large
a
collar
of
black
velvet
as
his
figure
could
carry
;
a
silken
waistcoat
,
bedecked
with
golden
sprigs
;
a
chaste
neckerchief
much
in
vogue
at
that
day
,
representing
a
preserve
of
lilac
pheasants
on
a
buff
ground
;
pantaloons
so
highly
decorated
with
side
-
stripes
that
each
leg
was
a
three
-
stringed
lute
;
and
a
hat
of
state
very
high
and
hard
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
prudent
Mrs
Chivery
perceived
that
in
addition
to
these
adornments
her
John
carried
a
pair
of
white
kid
gloves
,
and
a
cane
like
a
little
finger
-
post
,
surmounted
by
an
ivory
hand
marshalling
him
the
way
that
he
should
go
;
and
when
she
saw
him
,
in
this
heavy
marching
order
,
turn
the
corner
to
the
right
;
she
remarked
to
Mr
Chivery
,
who
was
at
home
at
the
time
,
that
she
thought
she
knew
which
way
the
wind
blew
.
   
<EOS>
The
Collegians
were
entertaining
a
considerable
number
of
visitors
that
Sunday
afternoon
,
and
their
Father
kept
his
room
for
the
purpose
of
receiving
presentations
.
 
<EOS>
After
making
the
tour
of
the
yard
,
Little
Dorrit
's
lover
with
a
hurried
heart
went
up
-
stairs
,
and
knocked
with
his

at
the
Father
's
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
come
in
!
"
said
a

.
 
<EOS>
The
Father
's
voice
,
her
father
's
,
the
Marshalsea
's
father
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
seated
in
his
black

,
with
his

,
three
-
and
-
sixpence
accidentally
left
on

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Everything
prepared
for
holding
his
Court
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Young
John
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
how
do
you
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
I
thank

,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
John
Chivery
;
yes
.
 
Nothing

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken

,

,
of
---
"
   
"
Eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
always

at
this

,
and
became
amiably

.
   
<EOS>
"
---
A
few
cigars
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
For

,

.
)
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
Young
John
,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

---
 
<EOS>
No
?
 
<EOS>
Well

,

.
 
<EOS>
Put

,

<EOS>
And

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
<EOS>

,

---
 
Miss
;
"
here

<EOS>
"
Miss

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

.
"
<EOS>
"
Indeed

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

's

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
An

.
 
<EOS>
An

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
Amy
has

.
 
<EOS>
She
has

to
the
Iron
Bridge
of
late
,
and
seems
to
like

walk
there

than

.
"
 
<EOS>
He

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
father

not

,
I

,
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
he
comes

.
"
 
<EOS>
Another

of
the
great
hat
,
and
<EOS>
then
Young
John
said
,
rising
,
"
I
am
afraid
I
must
wish
you

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So

?
 
<EOS>
Good

,
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
nay
,
"
with
the
utmost

,
"
never

your
glove
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
Shake
hands
with
it
on
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
no
stranger
here
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
Highly
gratified
by
the
kindness
of
his

,
Young
John
descended
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
way
down
he
met
some
Collegians
bringing
up
visitors
to
be
presented
,
and
at
that
moment
Mr
Dorrit
happened
to
call
over
the
banisters
with
particular
distinctness
,
"
Much
obliged
to
you
for
your
little
testimonial
,
John
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
lover
very
soon
laid
down
his
penny
on
the
tollplate
of
the
Iron
Bridge
,
and
came
upon
it
looking
about
him
for
the
well
-
known
and
well
-
beloved
figure
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
he
feared
she
was
not
there
;
but
as
he
walked
on
towards
the
Middlesex
side
,
he
saw
her
standing
still
,
looking
at
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
absorbed
in
thought
,
and
he
wondered
what
she
might
be
thinking
about
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
piles
of
city
roofs
and
chimneys
,
more
free
from
smoke
than
on
week
-
days
;
and
there
were
the
distant
masts
and
steeples
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
she
was
thinking
about
them
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
mused
so
long
,
and
was
so
entirely
preoccupied
,
that
although
her
lover
stood
quiet
for
what
he
thought
was
a
long
time
,
and
twice
or
thrice
retired
and
came
back
again
to
the
former
spot
,
still
she
did
not
move
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
in
the
end
,
he
made
up
his
mind
to
go
on
,
and
seem
to
come
upon
her
casually
in
passing
,
and
speak
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
was
quiet
,
and
now
or
never
was
the
time
to
speak
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
He
walked
on
,
and
she
did
not
appear
to
hear
his
steps
until
he
was
close
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
said
"
Miss
Dorrit
!
"
<EOS>
she
started
and
fell
back
from
him
,
with
an
expression
in
her
face
of
fright
and
something
like
dislike
that
caused
him
unutterable
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
often
avoided
him
before
---
always
,
indeed
,
for
a
long
,
long
while
.
<EOS>
She
had
turned
away
and
glided
off
so
often
when
she
had
seen
him
coming
toward
her
,
that
the
unfortunate
Young
John
could
not
think
it
accidental
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
hoped
that
it
might
be
shyness
,
her
retiring
character
,
her
foreknowledge
of
the
state
of
his
heart
,
anything
short
of
aversion
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
that
momentary
look
had
said
,
"
You
,
of
all
people
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
rather
have
seen
any
one
on
earth
than
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
but
a
momentary
look
,
inasmuch
as
she
checked
it
,
and
said
in
her
soft
little
voice
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
John
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
she
felt
what
it
had
been
,
as
he
felt
what
it
had
been
;
and
they
stood
looking
at
one
another
equally
confused
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
I
am
afraid
I
disturbed
you
by
speaking
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
rather
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
came
here
to
be
alone
,
and
I
thought
I
was
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
I
took
the

of
walking
this
way
,
because
Mr
Dorrit
chanced
to
mention
,
when
I
called
upon
him
just
now
,
that
you
---
"
   
She
caused
him
more
dismay
than
before
by
suddenly
