,
"
O
father
,
father
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
heartrending
tone
,
and
turning
her
face
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
I
hope
I
do
n't
give
you
any
uneasiness
by
naming
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
I
found
him
very
well
and
in
the
best
of
Spirits
,
and
he
showed
me
even
more
than
his
usual
kindness
;
being
so
very
kind
as
to
say
that
I
was
not
a
stranger
there
,
and
in
all
ways
gratifying
me
very
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
the
inexpressible
consternation
of
her
lover
,
Little
Dorrit
,
with
her
hands
to
her
averted
face
,
and
rocking
herself
where
she
stood
as
if
she
were
in
pain
,
murmured
,
"
O
father
,
how
can
you
!
 
<EOS>
O
dear
,
dear
father
,
how
can
you
,
can
you
,
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
poor
fellow
stood
gazing
at
her
,
overflowing
with
sympathy
,
but
not
knowing
what
to
make
of
this
,
until
,
having
taken
out
her
handkerchief
and
put
it
to
her
still
averted
face
,
she
hurried
away
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
he
remained
stock
still
;
then
hurried
after
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
pray
!
 
<EOS>
Will
you
have
the
goodness
to
stop
a
moment
?
<EOS>
Miss
Amy
,
if
it
comes
to
that
,
let
ME
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
go
out
of
my
senses
,
if
I
have
to
think
that
I
have
driven
you
away
like
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
trembling
voice
and
unfeigned
earnestness
brought
Little
Dorrit
to
a
stop
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
,
"
she
cried
,
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
Young
John
,
who
had
never
seen
her
bereft
of
her
quiet
self
-
command
,
who
had
seen
her
from
her
infancy
ever
so
reliable
and
self
-
suppressed
,
there
was
a
shock
in
her
distress
,
and
in
having
to
associate
himself
with
it
as
its
cause
,
that
shook
him
from
his
great
hat
to
the
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
it
necessary
to
explain
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
be
misunderstood
---
supposed
to
mean
something
,
or
to
have
done
something
,
that
had
never
entered
into
his
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
He
begged
her
to
hear
him
explain
himself
,
as
the
greatest
favour
she
could
show
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
I
know
very
well
that
your
family
is
far
above
mine
.
 
<EOS>
It
were
vain
to
conceal
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
never
was
a
Chivery
a
gentleman
that
ever
I
heard
of
,
and
I
will
not
commit
the
meanness
of
making
a
false
representation
on
a
subject
so
momentous
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Amy
,
I
know
very
well
that
your
high
-
souled
brother
,
and
likewise
your
spirited
sister
,
spurn
me
from
a
height
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
do
is
to
respect
them
,
to
wish
to
be
admitted
to
their
friendship
,
to
look
up
at
the
eminence
on
which
they
are
placed
from
my
lowlier
station
---
for
,
whether
viewed
as
tobacco
or
viewed
as
the
lock
<EOS>
,
I
well
know
it
is
lowly
---
and
ever
wish
them
well
and
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
really
was
a
genuineness
in
the
poor
fellow
,
and
a
contrast
between
the
hardness
of
his
hat
and
the
softness
of
his
heart
(
albeit
,
perhaps
,
of
his
head
,
too
)
,
that
was
moving
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
entreated
him
to
disparage
neither
himself
nor
his
station
,
and
,
above
all
things
,
to
divest
himself
of
any
idea
that
she
supposed
hers
to
be
superior
.
 
<EOS>
This
gave
him
a
little
comfort
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Amy
,
"
he
then
stammered
,
"
I
have
had
for
a
long
time
 
---
ages
they
seem
to
me
---
Revolving
ages
---
a
heart
-
cherished
wish
to
say
something
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
May
I
say
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
involuntarily
started
from
his
side
again
,
with
the
faintest
shadow
of
her
former
look
;
conquering
that
,
she
went
on
at
great
speed
half
across
the
Bridge
without
replying
!
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
---
Miss
Amy
,
I
but
ask
the
question
humbly
---
<EOS>
may
I
say
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
so
unlucky
already
in
giving
you
pain
without
having
any
such
intentions
,
before
the
holy
Heavens
!
 
<EOS>
that
there
is
no
fear
of
my
saying
it
unless
I
have
your
leave
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
be
miserable
alone
<EOS>
,
I
can
be
cut
up
by
myself
,
why
should
I
also
make
miserable
and
cut
up
one
that
I
would
fling
myself
off
that
parapet
to
give
half
a
moment
's
joy
to
!
 
<EOS>
Not
that
that
's
much
to
do
,
for
I
'd
do
it
for
twopence
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
mournfulness
of
his
spirits
,
and
the
gorgeousness
of
his
appearance
,
might
have
made
him
ridiculous
,
but
that
his
delicacy
made
him
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
learnt
from
it
what
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
John
Chivery
,
"
she
returned
,
trembling
,
but
in
a
quiet
way
,
"
since
you
are
so
considerate
as
to
ask
me
whether
you
shall
say
any
more
---
if
you
please
,
no
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Never
,
Miss
Amy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
if
you
please
.
 
Never
.
"
   
"
O
Lord
!
"
gasped
Young
John
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
perhaps
you
will
let
me
,
instead
,
say
something
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
say
it
earnestly
,
and
with
as
plain
a
meaning
as
it
is
possible
to
express
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
think
of
us
,
John
---
I
mean
my
brother
,
and
sister
,
and
me
---
do
n't
think
of
us
as
being
any
different
from
the
rest
;
for
,
whatever
we
once
were
(
which
I
hardly
know
)
<EOS>
we
ceased
to
be
long
ago
,
and
never
can
be
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
much
better
for
you
,
and
much
better
for
others
,
if
you
will
do
that
instead
of
what
you
are
doing
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
dolefully
protested
that
he
would
try
to
bear
it
in
mind
,
and
would
be
heartily
glad
to
do
anything
she
wished
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
me
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
think
as
little
of
me
as
you
can
;
the
less
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
think
of
me
at
all
,
John
,
let
it
only
be
as
the
child
you
have
seen
grow
up
in
the
prison
with
one
set
of
duties
always
occupying
her
;
as
a
weak
,
retired
,
contented
,
unprotected
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
particularly
want
you
to
remember
,
that
when
I
come
outside
the
gate
,
I
am
unprotected
and
solitary
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
try
to
do
anything
she
wished
.
 
<EOS>
But
why
did
Miss
Amy
so
much
want
him
to
remember
that
?
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
,
"
<EOS>
I
know
I
can
then
quite
trust
you
not
to
forget
to
-
day
,
and
not
to
say
any
more
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
so
generous
that
I
know
I
can
trust
to
you
for
that
;
and
I
do
<EOS>
and
I
always
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
show
you
,
at
once
,
that
I
fully
trust
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
this
place
where
we
are
speaking
better
than
any
place
I
know
;
"
her
slight
colour
had
faded
,
but
her
lover
thought
he
saw
it
coming
back
just
then
;
"
and
I
may
be
often
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
is
only
necessary
for
me
to
tell
you
so
,
to
be
quite
sure
that
you
will
never
come
here
again
in
search
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
---
quite
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
might
rely
upon
it
,
said
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
miserable
wretch
,
but
her
word
was
more
than
a
law
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
good
-
bye
,
John
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
hope
you
will
have
a
good
wife
one
day
,
and
be
a
happy
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
will
deserve
to
be
happy
,
and
you
will
be
,
John
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
held
out
her
hand
to
him
with
these
words
,
the
heart
that
was
under
the
waistcoat
of
sprigs
---
<EOS>
mere
slop
-
work
,
if
the
truth
must
be
known
---
swelled
to
the
size
of
the
heart
of
a
gentleman
;
and
the
poor
common
little
fellow
,
having
no
room
to
hold
it
,
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
cry
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
piteously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
,
do
n't
!
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Miss
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
so
he
left
her
:
<EOS>
first
observing
that
she
sat
down
on
the
corner
of
a
seat
,
and
not
only
rested
her
little
hand
upon
the
rough
wall
,
but
laid
her
face
against
it
too
,
as
if
her
head
were
heavy
,
and
her
mind
were
sad
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
affecting
illustration
of
the
fallacy
of
human
projects
,
to
behold
her
lover
,
with
the
great
hat
pulled
over
his
eyes
,
the
velvet
collar
turned
up
as
if
it
rained
,
the
plum
-
coloured
coat
buttoned
to
conceal
the
silken
waistcoat
of
golden
sprigs
,
and
the
little
direction
-
post
pointing
inexorably
home
,
creeping
along
by
the
worst
back
-
streets
,
and
composing
,
as
he
went
,
the
following
new
inscription
for
a
tombstone
in
St
George
's
Churchyard
:
   
<EOS>
"
Here
lie
<EOS>
the
mortal
remains
Of
JOHN
CHIVERY
,
Never
anything
worth
mentioning
,
Who
died
about
the
end
of
the
year
one
thousand
eight
hundred
and
twenty
-
six
,
Of
a
broken
heart
,
Requesting
with
his
last
breath
that
the
word
AMY
might
be
inscribed
over
his
ashes
,
which
was
accordingly
directed
to
be
done
,
By
his
afflicted
Parents
.
"
    
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
in
two
or
three
Relations
 
<EOS>
The
brothers
William
and
Frederick
Dorrit
,
walking
up
and
down
the
College
-
yard
---
of
course
on
the
aristocratic
or
Pump
side
,
for
the
Father
made
it
a
point
of
his
state
to
be
chary
of
going
among
his
children
on
the
Poor
side
,
except
on
Sunday
mornings
,
Christmas
Days
,
and
other
occasions
of
ceremony
,
in
the
observance
whereof
he
was
very
punctual
,
and
at
which
times
he
laid
his
hand
upon
the
heads
of
their
infants
,
and
blessed
those
young
insolvents
with
a
benignity
that
was
highly
edifying
---
the
brothers
,
walking
up
and
down
the
College
-
yard
together
,
were
a
memorable
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Frederick
the
free
,
was
so
humbled
,
bowed
,
withered
,
and
faded
<EOS>
;
William
the
bond
,
was
so
courtly
,
condescending
,
and
benevolently
conscious
of
a
position
;
that
in
this
regard
only
,
if
in
no
other
,
the
brothers
were
a
spectacle
to
wonder
at
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
up
and
down
the
yard
on
the
evening
of
Little
Dorrit
's
Sunday
interview
with
her
lover
on
the
Iron
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
The
cares
of
state
were
over
for
that
day
,
the
Drawing
Room
had
been
well
attended
,
several
new
presentations
had
taken
place
,
the
three
-
and
-
sixpence
accidentally
left
on
the
table
had
accidentally
increased
to
twelve
shillings
,
and
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
refreshed
himself
with
a
whiff
of
cigar
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
walked
up
and
down
,
affably
accommodating
his
step
to
the
shuffle
of
his
brother
,
not
proud
in
his
superiority
,
but
considerate
of
that
poor
creature
,
bearing
with
him
,
and
breathing
toleration
of
his
infirmities
in
every
little
puff
of
smoke
that
issued
from
his
lips
and
aspired
to
get
over
the
spiked
wall
,
he
was
a
sight
to
wonder
at
.
   
<EOS>
His
brother
Frederick
of
the
dim
eye
,
palsied
hand
,
bent
form
,
and
groping
mind
,
submissively
shuffled
at
his
side
,
accepting
his
patronage
as
he
accepted
every
incident
of
the
labyrinthian
world
in
which
he
had
got
lost
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
the
usual
screwed
bit
of
whitey
-
brown
paper
in
his
hand
,
from
which
he
ever
and
again
unscrewed
a
spare
pinch
of
snuff
.
 
<EOS>
That
falteringly
taken
,
he
would
glance
at
his
brother
not
unadmiringly
,
put
his
hands
behind
him
,
and
shuffle
on
<EOS>
so
at
his
side
until
he
took
another
pinch
,
or
stood
still
to
look
about
him
---
perchance
suddenly
missing
his
clarionet
.
<EOS>
The
College
visitors
were
melting
away
as
the
shades
of
night
drew
on
,
but
the
yard
was
still
pretty
full
,
the
Collegians
being
mostly
out
,
seeing
their
friends
to
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
brothers
paced
the
yard
,
William
the
bond
looked
about
him
to
receive
salutes
,
returned
them
by
graciously
lifting
off
his
hat
,
and
,
with
an
engaging
air
,
prevented
Frederick
the
free
from
running
against
the
company
,
or
being
jostled
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
The
Collegians
as
a
body
were
not
easily
impressible
,
but
even
they
,
according
to
their
various
ways
of
wondering
,
appeared
to
find
in
the
two
brothers
a
sight
to
wonder
at
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
little
low
this
evening
,
Frederick
,
"
said
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
matter
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
stared
for
a
moment
,
and
then
dropped
his
head
and
eyes
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
William
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
is
the
matter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
could
be
persuaded
to
smarten
yourself
up
a
little
,
Frederick
---
"
   
"
Aye
,
aye
!
"
said
the
old
man
hurriedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
ca
n't
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
be
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
talk
so
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
glanced
at
a
passing
Collegian
with
whom
he
was
on
friendly
terms
,
as
who
should
say
,
"
An
enfeebled
old
man
,
this
;
but
he
is
my
brother
,
sir
,
my
brother
,
and
the
voice
of
Nature
is
potent
!
"
and
steered
his
brother
clear
of
the
handle
of
the
pump
by
the
threadbare
sleeve
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
would
have
been
wanting
to
the
perfection
of
his
character
as
a
fraternal
guide
,
philosopher
and
friend
,
if
he
had
only
steered
his
brother
clear
of
ruin
,
instead
of
bringing
it
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
William
,
"
said
the
object
of
his
affectionate
consideration
,
"
that
I
am
tired
,
and
will
go
home
to
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Frederick
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
do
n't
let
me
detain
you
;
do
n't
sacrifice
your
inclination
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Late
hours
,
and
a
heated
atmosphere
,
and
years
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Frederick
,
"
weaken
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Frederick
,
"
returned
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
"
<EOS>
do
you
think
you
are
sufficiently
careful
of
yourself
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
your
habits
are
as
precise
and
methodical
<EOS>
as
---
shall
I
say
as
mine
are
?
<EOS>
Not
to
revert
again
to
that
little
eccentricity
which
I
mentioned
just
now
,
I
doubt
if
you
take
air
and
exercise
enough
,
Frederick
.
<EOS>
Here
is
the
parade
,
always
at
your
service
.
 
<EOS>
Why
not
use
it
more
regularly
than
you
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
sighed
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
of
no
use
saying
yes
,
yes
,
my
dear
Frederick
,
"
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
in
his
mild
wisdom
persisted
,
"
unless
you
act
on
that
assent
.
 
<EOS>
Consider
my
case
,
Frederick
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
kind
of
example
.
 
<EOS>
Necessity
and
time
have
taught
me
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
At
certain
stated
hours
of
the
day
,
you
will
find
me
on
the
parade
,
in
my
room
,
in
the
Lodge
,
reading
the
paper
,
receiving
company
,
eating
and
drinking
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
impressed
upon
Amy
during
many
years
,
<EOS>
that
I
must
have
my
meals
(
for
instance
)
punctually
.
 
<EOS>
Amy
has
grown
up
in
a
sense
of
the
importance
of
these
arrangements
,
and
you
know
what
a
good
girl
she
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
brother
only
sighed
again
,
as
he
plodded
dreamily
along
,
"
Hah
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
"
said
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
mildly
rallying
him
---
mildly
,
because
of
his
weakness
,
poor
dear
soul
;
"
you
said
that
before
,
and
it
does
not
express
much
,
Frederick
,
even
if
it
means
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
rouse
you
,
my
good
Frederick
;
you
want
to
be
roused
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
William
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
,
"
returned
the
other
,
lifting
his
dim
eyes
to
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
like
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
said
,
with
a
shrug
of
modest
self
-
depreciation
,
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
might
be
like
me
,
my
dear
Frederick
;
you
might
be
,
if
you
chose
!
"
and
forbore
,
in
the
magnanimity
of
his
strength
,
to
press
his
fallen
brother
further
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
deal
of
leave
-
taking
going
on
in
corners
,
as
was
usual
on
Sunday
nights
;
and
here
and
there
in
the
dark
,
some
poor
woman
,
wife
or
mother
,
was
weeping
with
a
new
Collegian
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
had
been
when
the
Father
himself
had
wept
,
in
the
shades
of
that
yard
,
as
his
own
poor
wife
had
wept
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
many
years
ago
;
and
now
he
was
like
a
passenger
aboard
ship
in
a
long
voyage
,
who
has
recovered
from
sea
-
sickness
,
and
is
impatient
of
that
weakness
in
the
fresher
passengers
taken
aboard
at
the
last
port
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
inclined
to
remonstrate
,
and
to
express
his
opinion
that
people
who
could
n't
get
on
without
crying
,
had
no
business
there
.
 
<EOS>
In
manner
,
if
not
in
words
,
he
always
testified
his
displeasure
at
these
interruptions
of
the
general
harmony
;
and
it
was
so
well
understood
,
that
delinquents
usually
withdrew
if
they
were
aware
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
On
this
Sunday
evening
,
he
accompanied
his
brother
to
the
gate
with
an
air
of
endurance
and
clemency
;
being
in
a
bland
temper
and
graciously
disposed
to
overlook
the
tears
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
flaring
gaslight
of
the
Lodge
,
several
Collegians
were
basking
;
some
taking
leave
of
visitors
,
and
some
who
had
no
visitors
,
watching
the
frequent
turning
of
the
key
,
and
conversing
with
one
another
and
with
Mr
Chivery
.
 
<EOS>
The
paternal
entrance
made
a
sensation
of
course
;
and
Mr
Chivery
,
touching
his
hat
(
in
a
short
manner
though
)
with
his
key
,
hoped
he
found
himself
tolerable
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Chivery
,
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chivery
said
in
a
low
growl
,
"
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
he
was
all
right
.
"
 
<EOS>
Which
was
his
general
way
of
acknowledging
inquiries
after
his
health
when
a
little
sullen
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
visit
from
Young
John
to
-
day
,
Chivery
.
 
<EOS>
And
very
smart
he
looked
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
Mr
Chivery
had
heard
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chivery
must
confess
,
however
,
that
his
wish
was
that
the
boy
did
n't
lay
out
so
much
money
upon
it
.
<EOS>
For
what
did
it
bring
him
in
?
 
<EOS>
It
only
brought
him
in
wexation
.
<EOS>
And
he
could
get
that
anywhere
for
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
vexation
,
Chivery
?
"
asked
the
benignant
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
odds
,
"
returned
Mr
Chivery
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Frederick
going
out
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Chivery
,
my
brother
is
going
home
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
tired
,
and
not
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
,
Frederick
,
take
care
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
my
dear
Frederick
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Shaking
hands
with
his
brother
,
and
touching
his
greasy
hat
to
the
company
in
the
Lodge
,
Frederick
slowly
shuffled
out
of
the
door
which
Mr
Chivery
unlocked
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
showed
the
amiable
solicitude
of
a
superior
being
that
he
should
come
to
no
harm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
so
kind
as
to
keep
the
door
open
a
moment
,
Chivery
,
that
I
may
see
him
go
along
the
passage
and
down
the
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
,
Frederick
!
 
<EOS>
(
He
is
very
infirm
.
)
<EOS>
Mind
the
steps
!
 
<EOS>
(
He
is
so
very
absent
.
)
<EOS>
Be
careful
how
you
cross
,
Frederick
.
 
<EOS>
(
I
really
do
n't
like
the
notion
of
his
going
wandering
at
large
,
he
is
so
extremely
liable
to
be
run
over
.
)
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
and
with
a
face
expressive
of
many
uneasy
doubts
and
much
anxious
guardianship
,
he
turned
his
regards
upon
the
assembled
company
in
the
Lodge
:
so
plainly
indicating
that
his
brother
was
to
be
pitied
for
not
being
under
lock
and
key
,
that
an
opinion
to
that
effect
went
round
among
the
Collegians
assembled
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
receive
it
with
unqualified
assent
;
on
the
contrary
,
he
said
,
No
,
gentlemen
,
no
;
let
them
not
misunderstand
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
brother
Frederick
was
much
broken
,
no
doubt
,
and
it
might
be
more
comfortable
to
himself
(
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
)
to
know
that
he
was
safe
within
the
walls
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
it
must
be
remembered
that
to
support
an
existence
there
during
many
years
,
required
a
certain
combination
of
qualities
---
he
did
not
say
high
qualities
,
but
qualities
---
moral
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
had
his
brother
Frederick
that
peculiar
union
of
qualities
?
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
he
was
a
most
excellent
man
,
a
most
gentle
,
tender
,
and
estimable
man
,
with
the
simplicity
of
a
child
;
but
would
he
,
though
unsuited
for
most
other
places
,
do
for
that
place
?
 
<EOS>
No
<EOS>
;
he
said
confidently
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
And
,
he
said
,
Heaven
forbid
that
Frederick
should
be
there
in
any
other
character
than
in
his
present
voluntary
character
!
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
whoever
came
to
that
College
,
to
remain
there
a
length
of
time
,
must
have
strength
of
character
to
go
through
a
good
deal
and
to
come
out
of
a
good
deal
.
 
<EOS>
Was
his
beloved
brother
Frederick
that
man
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
They
saw
him
,
even
as
it
was
,
crushed
.
 
<EOS>
Misfortune
crushed
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
power
of
recoil
enough
,
not
elasticity
enough
,
to
be
a
long
time
in
such
a
place
,
and
yet
preserve
his
self
-
respect
and
feel
conscious
that
he
was
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
Frederick
had
not
(
if
he
might
use
the
expression
)
Power
enough
to
see
in
any
delicate
little
attentions
and
---
and
 
<EOS>
---
Testimonials
that
he
might
under
such
circumstances
receive
,
the
goodness
of
human
nature
,
the
fine
spirit
animating
the
Collegians
as
a
community
,
and
at
the
same
time
no
degradation
to
himself
,
and
no
depreciation
of
his
claims
as
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
God
bless
you
!
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
homily
with
which
he
improved
and
pointed
the
occasion
to
the
company
in
the
Lodge
before
turning
into
the
sallow
yard
again
,
and
going
with
his
own
poor
shabby
dignity
past
the
Collegian
in
the
dressing
-
gown
who
had
no
coat
,
and
past
the
Collegian
in
the
sea
-
side
slippers
who
had
no
shoes
,
and
past
the
stout
greengrocer
Collegian
in
the
corduroy
knee
-
breeches
who
had
no
cares
,
and
past
the
lean
clerk
Collegian
in
buttonless
black
who
had
no
hopes
,
up
his
own
poor
shabby
staircase
to
his
own
poor
shabby
room
.
   
<EOS>
There
,
the
table
was
laid
for
his
supper
,
and
his
old
grey
gown
was
ready
for
him
on
his
chair
-
back
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
put
her
little
prayer
-
book
in
her
pocket
---
had
she
been
praying
for
pity
on
all
prisoners
and
captives
!
<EOS>
---
and
rose
to
welcome
him
.
   
<EOS>
Uncle
had
gone
home
,
then
?
 
<EOS>
she
asked
@
as
she
changed
his
coat
and
gave
him
his
black
velvet
cap
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
uncle
had
gone
home
.
 
<EOS>
Had
her
father
enjoyed
his
walk
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
not
much
,
Amy
;
not
much
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Did
he
not
feel
quite
well
?
   
<EOS>
As
she
stood
behind
him
,
leaning
over
his
chair
so
lovingly
,
he
looked
with
downcast
eyes
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
An
uneasiness
stole
over
him
that
was
like
a
touch
of
shame
;
and
when
he
spoke
,
as
he
presently
did
,
it
was
in
an
unconnected
and
embarrassed
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Something
,
I
---
hem
!
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
what
,
has
gone
wrong
with
Chivery
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
---
ha
!
---
not
nearly
so
obliging
and
attentive
as
usual
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
It
---
hem
!
<EOS>
---
it
's
a
little
thing
,
but
it
puts
me
out
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
impossible
to
forget
,
"
turning
his
hands
over
and
over
and
looking
closely
at
them
,
"
that
---
hem
!
---
<EOS>
that
in
such
a
life
as
mine
,
I
am
unfortunately
dependent
on
these
men
for
something
every
hour
in
the
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
arm
was
on
his
shoulder
,
but
she
did
not
look
in
his
face
while
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
Bending
her
head
she
looked
another
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
hem
!
<EOS>
---
I
ca
n't
think
,
Amy
,
what
has
given
Chivery
offence
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
generally
so
---
so
very
attentive
and
respectful
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
-
night
he
was
quite
---
quite
short
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Other
people
there
too
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
good
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
if
I
was
to
lose
the
support
and
recognition
of
Chivery
and
his
brother
officers
,
I
might
starve
to
death
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
he
spoke
,
he
was
opening
and
shutting
his
hands
like
valves
;
so
conscious
all
the
time
of
that
touch
of
shame
,
that
he
shrunk
before
his
own
knowledge
of
his
meaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
ha
!
<EOS>
---
I
ca
n't
think
what
it
's
owing
to
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
can
not
imagine
what
the
cause
of
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
Jackson
here
once
,
a
turnkey
of
the
name
of
Jackson
<EOS>
(
I
do
n't
think
you
can
remember
him
,
my
dear
,
you
were
very
young
)
,
and
---
hem
!
<EOS>
---
and
he
had
a
---
brother
,
and
this
---
young
brother
paid
his
addresses
to
---
<EOS>
at
least
,
did
not
go
so
far
as
to
pay
his
addresses
to
---
but
admired
---
respectfully
admired
---
the
---
not
daughter
,
the
sister
---
of
one
of
us
;
a
rather
distinguished
Collegian
;
I
may
say
,
very
much
so
.
 
<EOS>
His
name
was
Captain
Martin
;
and
he
consulted
me
on
the
question
whether
It
was
necessary
that
his
daughter
---
sister
---
should
hazard
offending
the
turnkey
brother
by
being
too
---
ha
!
---
too
plain
with
the
other
brother
.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Martin
was
a
gentleman
and
a
man
of
honour
,
and
I
put
it
to
him
first
to
give
me
his
---
his
own
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Martin
(
highly
respected
in
the
army
)
then
unhesitatingly
said
that
it
appeared
to
him
that
his
---
hem
!
<EOS>
---
sister
was
not
called
upon
to
understand
the
young
man
too
distinctly
,
and
that
she
might
lead
him
on
---
I
am
doubtful
whether
"
lead
him
on
"
was
Captain
Martin
's
exact
expression
:
indeed
I
think
he
said
tolerate
him
---
on
her
father
's
---
I
should
say
,
brother
's
---
account
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
how
I
have
strayed
into
this
story
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
has
been
through
being
unable
to
account
for
Chivery
;
but
as
to
the
connection
between
the
two
,
I
do
n't
see
---
"
   
<EOS>
His
voice
died
away
,
as
if
she
could
not
bear
the
pain
of
hearing
him
,
and
her
hand
had
gradually
crept
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
little
while
there
was
a
dead
silence
and
stillness
;
and
he
remained
shrunk
in
his
chair
,
and
<EOS>
she
remained
with
her
arm
round
his
neck
and
her
head
bowed
down
upon
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
His
supper
was
cooking
in
a
saucepan
on
the
fire
,
and
,
when
she
moved
,
it
was
to
make
it
ready
for
him
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
his
usual
seat
,
she
took
hers
,
and
he
began
his
meal
.
 
<EOS>
They
did
not
,
as
yet
,
look
at
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
he
began
;
laying
down
his
knife
and
fork
with
a
noise
,
taking
things
up
sharply
,
biting
at
his
bread
as
if
he
were
offended
with
it
,
and
in
other
similar
ways
showing
that
he
was
out
of
sorts
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
pushed
his
plate
from
him
,
and
spoke
aloud
;
with
the
strangest
inconsistency
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
does
it
matter
whether
I
eat
or
starve
?
 
<EOS>
What
does
it
matter
whether
such
a
blighted
life
as
mine
comes
to
an
end
,
now
,
next
week
,
or
next
year
?
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
worth
to
anyone
?
 
<EOS>
A
poor
prisoner
,
fed
on
alms
and
broken
victuals
;
a
squalid
,
disgraced
wretch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
,
father
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
he
rose
she
went
on
her
knees
to
him
,
and
held
up
her
hands
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
he
went
on
in
a
suppressed
voice
,
trembling
violently
,
and
looking
at
her
as
wildly
as
if
he
had
gone
mad
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
if
you
could
see
me
as
your
mother
saw
me
,
you
would
n't
believe
it
to
be
the
creature
you
have
only
looked
at
through
the
bars
of
this
cage
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
young
<EOS>
,
I
was
accomplished
,
I
was
good
-
looking
,
I
was
independent
---
by
God
<EOS>
I
was
,
child
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
people
sought
me
out
,
and
envied
me
.
 
<EOS>
Envied
me
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
father
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
tried
to
take
down
the
shaking
arm
that
he
flourished
in
the
air
,
but
he
resisted
,
and
put
her
hand
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
but
a
picture
of
myself
in
those
days
,
though
it
was
ever
so
ill
done
,
you
would
be
proud
of
it
,
you
would
be
proud
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
let
me
be
a
warning
!
 
<EOS>
Let
no
man
,
"
he
cried
,
looking
haggardly
about
,
"
fail
to
preserve
at
least
that
little
of
the
times
of
his
prosperity
and
respect
.
 
<EOS>
Let
his
children
have
that
clue
to
what
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
Unless
my
face
,
when
I
am
dead
,
subsides
into
the
long
departed
look
---
they
say
such
things
happen
,
I
do
n't
know
---
my
children
will
have
never
seen
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
,
father
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
despise
me
,
despise
me
!
 
<EOS>
Look
away
from
me
,
do
n't
listen
to
me
,
stop
me
,
blush
for
me
,
cry
for
me
---
<EOS>
even
you
,
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
Do
it
,
do
it
!
<EOS>
I
do
it
to
myself
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
hardened
now
,
I
have
sunk
too
low
to
care
long
even
for
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
father
,
loved
father
,
darling
of
my
heart
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
was
clinging
to
him
with
her
arms
,
and
she
got
him
to
drop
into
his
chair
again
,
and
caught
at
the
raised
arm
,
and
tried
to
put
it
round
her
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
it
lie
there
,
father
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
me
,
father
,
kiss
me
,
father
!
<EOS>
Only
think
of
me
,
father
,
for
one
little
moment
!
"
   
<EOS>
Still
he
went
on
in
the
same
wild
way
,
though
it
was
gradually
breaking
down
into
a
miserable
whining
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
have
some
respect
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
some
stand
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
quite
trodden
down
.
 
<EOS>
Go
out
and
ask
who
is
the
chief
person
in
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
tell
you
it
's
your
father
.
 
<EOS>
Go
out
and
ask
who
is
never
trifled
with
,
and
who
is
always
treated
with
some
delicacy
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
say
,
your
father
.
 
<EOS>
Go
out
and
ask
what
funeral
here
(
it
must
be
here
<EOS>
,
I
know
it
can
be
nowhere
else
)
will
make
more
talk
,
and
perhaps
more
grief
,
than
any
that
has
ever
gone
out
at
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
say
your
father
's
.
 
<EOS>
Well
then
.
 
<EOS>
Amy
!
<EOS>
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
Is
your
father
so
universally
despised
?
 
<EOS>
Is
there
nothing
to
redeem
him
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
have
nothing
to
remember
him
by
but
his
ruin
and
decay
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
be
able
to
have
no
affection
for
him
when
he
is
gone
,
poor
castaway
,
gone
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
burst
into
tears
of
maudlin
pity
for
himself
,
and
at
length
suffering
her
to
embrace
him
and
take
charge
of
him
,
let
his
grey
head
rest
against
her
cheek
,
and
bewailed
his
wretchedness
.
<EOS>
Presently
he
changed
the
subject
of
his
lamentations
,
and
clasping
his
hands
about
her
as
she
embraced
him
,
cried
,
O
Amy
,
his
motherless
,
forlorn
child
!
 
<EOS>
O
the
days
that
he
had
seen
her
careful
and
laborious
for
him
!
 
<EOS>
Then
he
reverted
to
himself
,
and
weakly
told
her
how
much
better
she
would
have
loved
him
if
she
had
known
him
in
his
vanished
character
,
and
how
he
would
have
married
her
to
a
gentleman
who
should
have
been
proud
of
her
as
his
daughter
,
and
how
(
at
which
he
cried
again
)
<EOS>
she
should
first
have
ridden
at
his
fatherly
side
on
her
own
horse
,
and
how
the
crowd
(
by
which
he
meant
in
effect
the
people
who
had
given
him
the
twelve
shillings
he
then
had
in
his
pocket
)
should
have
trudged
the
dusty
roads
respectfully
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
now
boasting
,
now
despairing
,
in
either
fit
a
captive
with
the
jail
-
rot
upon
him
,
and
the
impurity
of
his
prison
worn
into
the
grain
of
his
soul
,
he
revealed
his
degenerate
state
to
his
affectionate
child
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
else
ever
beheld
him
in
the
details
of
his
humiliation
.
 
<EOS>
Little
recked
the
Collegians
who
were
laughing
in
their
rooms
over
his
late
address
in
the
Lodge
,
what
a
serious
picture
they
had
in
their
obscure
gallery
of
the
Marshalsea
that
Sunday
night
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
classical
daughter
once
---
perhaps
---
who
ministered
to
her
father
in
his
prison
as
her
mother
had
ministered
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
though
of
the
unheroic
modern
stock
and
mere
English
,
did
much
more
,
in
comforting
her
father
's
wasted
heart
upon
her
innocent
breast
,
and
turning
to
it
a
fountain
of
love
and
fidelity
that
never
ran
dry
or
waned
through
all
his
years
of
famine
.
   
<EOS>
She
soothed
him
;
asked
him
for
his
forgiveness
if
she
had
been
,
or
seemed
to
have
been
,
undutiful
;
told
him
,
Heaven
knows
truly
,
that
she
could
not
honour
him
more
if
he
were
the
favourite
of
Fortune
and
the
whole
world
acknowledged
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
his
tears
were
dried
,
and
he
sobbed
in
his
weakness
no
longer
,
and
was
free
from
that
touch
of
shame
,
and
had
recovered
his
usual
bearing
,
she
prepared
the
remains
of
his
supper
afresh
,
and
,
sitting
by
his
side
,
rejoiced
to
see
him
eat
and
drink
.
 
<EOS>
For
now
he
sat
in
his
black
velvet
cap
and
old
grey
gown
,
magnanimous
again
;
and
would
have
comported
himself
towards
any
Collegian
who
might
have
looked
in
to
ask
his
advice
,
like
a
great
moral
Lord
Chesterfield
,
or
Master
of
the
ethical
ceremonies
of
the
Marshalsea
.
   
<EOS>
To
keep
his
attention
engaged
,
she
talked
with
him
about
his
wardrobe
;
when
he
was
pleased
to
say
,
that
Yes
,
indeed
,
those
shirts
she
proposed
would
be
exceedingly
acceptable
,
for
those
he
had
were
worn
out
,
and
,
being
ready
-
made
,
had
never
fitted
him
.
<EOS>
Being
conversational
,
and
in
a
reasonable
flow
of
spirits
,
he
then
invited
her
attention
to
his
coat
as
it
hung
behind
the
door
:
remarking
that
the
Father
of
the
place
would
set
an
indifferent
example
to
his
children
,
already
disposed
to
be
slovenly
,
if
he
went
among
them
out
at
elbows
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
jocular
,
too
,
as
to
the
heeling
of
his
shoes
;
but
became
grave
on
the
subject
of
his
cravat
,
and
promised
her
that
,
when
she
could
afford
it
,
she
should
buy
him
a
new
one
.
   
<EOS>
While
he
smoked
out
his
cigar
in
peace
,
she
made
his
bed
,
and
put
the
small
room
in
order
for
his
repose
.
 
<EOS>
Being
weary
then
,
owing
to
the
advanced
hour
and
his
emotions
,
he
came
out
of
his
chair
to
bless
her
and
wish
her
Good
night
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
he
had
never
once
thought
of
HER
dress
,
her
shoes
,
her
need
of
anything
.
 
<EOS>
No
other
person
upon
earth
,
save
herself
,
could
have
been
so
unmindful
of
her
wants
.
   
<EOS>
He
kissed
her
many
times
with
"
Bless
you
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
MY
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
her
gentle
breast
had
been
so
deeply
wounded
by
what
she
had
seen
of
him
that
she
was
unwilling
to
leave
him
alone
,
lest
he
should
lament
and
despair
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Father
,
dear
,
I
am
not
tired
;
let
me
come
back
presently
,
when
you
are
in
bed
,
and
sit
by
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
asked
her
,
with
an
air
of
protection
,
if
she
felt
solitary
?
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
come
back
by
all
means
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
quiet
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
think
of
me
,
my
dear
,
"
he
said
,
giving
her
his
kind
permission
fully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
back
by
all
means
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
dozing
when
she
returned
,
and
she
put
the
low
fire
together
very
softly
lest
she
should
awake
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
overheard
her
,
and
called
out
who
was
that
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
Amy
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
my
child
,
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
say
a
word
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
raised
himself
a
little
in
his
low
bed
,
as
she
kneeled
beside
it
to
bring
her
face
near
him
;
and
put
his
hand
between
hers
.
 
<EOS>
O
!
 
<EOS>
Both
the
private
father
and
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
were
strong
within
him
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
you
have
had
a
life
of
hardship
here
.
 
<EOS>
No
companions
,
no
recreations
,
many
cares
I
am
afraid
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
think
of
that
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
position
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
able
to
do
much
for
you
;
but
all
I
have
been
able
to
do
,
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
father
,
"
she
rejoined
,
kissing
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
the
twenty
-
third
year
of
my
life
here
,
"
he
said
,
with
a
catch
in
his
breath
that
was
not
so
much
a
sob
as
an
irrepressible
sound
of
self
-
approval
,
the
momentary
outburst
of
a
noble
consciousness
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
I
could
do
for
my
children
---
I
have
done
it
.
 
<EOS>
Amy
,
my
love
,
you
are
by
far
the
best
loved
of
the
three
;
I
have
had
you
principally
in
my
mind
---
whatever
I
have
done
for
your
sake
,
my
dear
child
,
I
have
done
freely
and
without
murmuring
.
"
   
<EOS>
Only
the
wisdom
that
holds
the
clue
to
all
hearts
and
all
mysteries
,
can
surely
know
to
what
extent
<EOS>
a
man
,
especially
a
man
brought
down
as
this
man
had
been
,
can
impose
upon
himself
.
<EOS>
Enough
,
for
the
present
place
,
that
he
lay
down
with
wet
eyelashes
,
serene
,
in
a
manner
majestic
,
after
bestowing
his
life
of
degradation
as
a
sort
of
portion
on
the
devoted
child
upon
whom
its
miseries
had
fallen
so
heavily
,
and
whose
love
alone
had
saved
him
to
be
even
what
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
That
child
had
no
doubts
,
asked
herself
no
question
,
for
she
was
but
too
content
to
see
him
with
a
lustre
<EOS>
round
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
dear
,
good
dear
,
truest
,
kindest
,
dearest
,
were
the
only
words
she
had
for
him
,
as
she
hushed
him
to
rest
.
   
<EOS>
She
never
left
him
all
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
As
if
she
had
done
him
a
wrong
which
her
tenderness
could
hardly
repair
,
she
sat
by
him
in
his
sleep
,
at
times
softly
kissing
him
with
suspended
breath
,
and
calling
him
in
a
whisper
by
some
endearing
name
.
 
<EOS>
At
times
she
stood
aside
so
as
not
to
intercept
the
low
fire
-
light
,
and
,
watching
him
when
it
fell
upon
his
sleeping
face
,
wondered
did
he
look
now
at
all
as
he
had
looked
when
he
was
prosperous
and
happy
;
as
he
had
so
touched
her
by
imagining
that
he
might
look
once
more
in
that
awful
time
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
thought
of
that
time
,
she
kneeled
beside
his
bed
again
,
and
prayed
,
"
O
spare
his
life
!
 
<EOS>
O
save
him
to
me
!
 
<EOS>
O
look
down
upon
my
dear
,
long
-
suffering
,
unfortunate
,
much
-
changed
,
dear
dear
father
!
"
   
<EOS>
Not
until
the
morning
came
to
protect
him
and
encourage
him
,
did
she
give
him
a
last
kiss
and
leave
the
small
room
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
stolen
down
-
stairs
,
and
along
the
empty
yard
,
and
had
crept
up
to
her
own
high
garret
,
<EOS>
the
smokeless
housetops
and
the
distant
country
hills
were
discernible
over
the
wall
in
the
clear
morning
.
<EOS>
As
she
gently
opened
the
window
,
and
looked
eastward
down
the
prison
yard
,
the
spikes
upon
the
wall
were
tipped
with
red
,
then
made
a
sullen
purple
pattern
on
the
sun
as
it
came
flaming
up
into
the
heavens
.
 
<EOS>
The
spikes
had
never
looked
so
sharp
and
cruel
,
nor
the
bars
so
heavy
,
nor
the
prison
space
so
gloomy
and
contracted
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
the
sunrise
on
rolling
rivers
,
of
the
sunrise
on
wide
seas
,
of
the
sunrise
on
rich
landscapes
,
of
the
sunrise
on
great
forests
where
the
birds
were
waking
and
the
trees
were
rustling
;
and
she
looked
down
into
the
living
grave
on
which
the
sun
had
risen
,
with
her
father
in
it
three
-
and
-
twenty
years
,
and
said
,
in
a
burst
of
sorrow
and
compassion
,
"
No
,
no
,
I
have
never
seen
him
in
my
life
!
"
    
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Moving
in
Society
 
<EOS>
If
Young
John
Chivery
had
had
the
inclination
and
the
power
to
write
a
satire
on
family
pride
,
he
would
have
had
no
need
to
go
for
an
avenging
illustration
out
of
the
family
of
his
beloved
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
found
it
amply
in
that
gallant
brother
and
that
dainty
sister
,
so
steeped
in
mean
experiences
,
and
so
loftily
conscious
of
the
family
name
;
so
ready
to
beg
or
borrow
from
the
poorest
,
to
eat
of
anybody
's
bread
,
spend
anybody
's
money
,
drink
from
anybody
's
cup
and
break
it
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
To
have
painted
the
sordid
facts
of
their
lives
,
and
they
throughout
invoking
the
death
's
head
apparition
of
the
family
gentility
to
come
and
scare
their
benefactors
,
would
have
made
Young
John
a
satirist
of
the
first
water
.
   
<EOS>
Tip
had
turned
his
liberty
to
hopeful
account
by
becoming
a
billiard
-
marker
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
troubled
himself
so
little
as
to
the
means
of
his
release
,
that
Clennam
scarcely
needed
to
have
been
at
the
pains
of
impressing
the
mind
of
Mr
Plornish
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
Whoever
had
paid
him
the
compliment
,
he
very
readily
accepted
the
compliment
with
HIS
compliments
,
and
there
was
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
Issuing
forth
from
the
gate
on
these
easy
terms
,
he
became
a
billiard
-
marker
;
and
now
occasionally
looked
in
at
the
little
skittle
-
ground
in
a
green
Newmarket
coat
(
second
-
hand
)
,
with
a
shining
collar
and
bright
buttons
(
new
)
,
and
drank
the
beer
of
the
Collegians
.
   
<EOS>
One
solid
stationary
point
in
the
looseness
of
this
gentleman
's
character
was
,
that
he
respected
and
admired
his
sister
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
The
feeling
had
never
induced
him
to
spare
her
a
moment
's
uneasiness
,
or
to
put
himself
to
any
restraint
or
inconvenience
on
her
account
;
but
with
that
Marshalsea
taint
upon
his
love
,
he
loved
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
rank
Marshalsea
flavour
was
to
be
recognised
in
his
distinctly
perceiving
that
she
sacrificed
her
life
to
her
father
,
and
in
his
having
no
idea
that
she
had
done
anything
for
himself
.
   
<EOS>
When
this
spirited
young
man
and
his
sister
had
begun
systematically
to
produce
the
family
skeleton
for
the
overawing
of
the
College
,
this
narrative
can
not
precisely
state
.
 
<EOS>
Probably
at
about
the
period
when
they
began
to
dine
on
the
College
charity
.
<EOS>
It
is
certain
that
the
more
reduced
and
necessitous
they
were
,
the
more
pompously
the
skeleton
emerged
from
its
tomb
;
and
that
when
there
was
anything
particularly
shabby
in
the
wind
,
the
skeleton
always
came
out
with
the
ghastliest
flourish
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
late
on
the
Monday
morning
,
for
her
father
slept
late
,
and
afterwards
there
was
his
breakfast
to
prepare
and
his
room
to
arrange
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
engagement
to
go
out
to
work
,
however
,
and
therefore
stayed
with
him
until
,
with
Maggy
's
help
,
she
had
put
everything
right
about
him
,
and
had
seen
him
off
upon
his
morning
walk
(
of
twenty
yards
or
so
)
to
the
coffee
-
house
to
read
the
paper
.
   
<EOS>
She
then
got
on
her
bonnet
and
went
out
,
having
been
anxious
to
get
out
much
sooner
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
,
as
usual
,
a
cessation
of
the
small
-
talk
in
the
Lodge
as
she
passed
through
it
;
and
a
Collegian
who
had
come
in
on
Saturday
night
,
received
the
intimation
from
the
elbow
of
a
more
seasoned
Collegian
,
"
Look
out
.
 
<EOS>
Here
she
is
!
"
<EOS>
She
wanted
to
see
her
sister
,
but
when
she
got
round
to
Mr
Cripples
's
,
she
found
that
both
her
sister
and
her
uncle
had
gone
to
the
theatre
where
they
were
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
Having
taken
thought
of
this
probability
by
the
way
,
and
having
settled
that
in
such
case
she
would
follow
them
,
she
set
off
afresh
for
the
theatre
,
which
was
on
that
side
of
the
river
,
and
not
very
far
away
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
almost
as
ignorant
of
the
ways
of
theatres
as
of
the
ways
of
gold
mines
,
and
when
she
was
directed
to
a
furtive
sort
of
door
,
with
a
curious
up
-
all
-
night
air
about
it
,
that
appeared
to
be
ashamed
of
itself
and
to
be
hiding
in
an
alley
,
she
hesitated
to
approach
it
;
being
further
deterred
by
the
sight
of
some
half
-
dozen
close
-
shaved
gentlemen
with
their
hats
very
strangely
on
,
who
were
lounging
about
the
door
,
looking
not
at
all
unlike
Collegians
.
 
<EOS>
On
her
applying
to
them
,
reassured
by
this
resemblance
,
for
a
direction
to
Miss
Dorrit
,
they
made
way
for
her
to
enter
a
dark
hall
---
it
was
more
like
<EOS>
a
great
grim
lamp
gone
out
than
anything
else
---
where
she
could
hear
the
distant
playing
of
music
and
the
sound
of
dancing
feet
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
so
much
in
want
of
airing
that
he
had
a
blue
mould
upon
him
,
sat
watching
this
dark
place
from
a
hole
in
a
corner
,
like
a
spider
;
and
he
told
her
that
he
would
send
a
message
up
to
Miss
Dorrit
by
the
first
lady
or
gentleman
who
went
through
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
lady
who
went
through
had
a
roll
of
music
,
half
in
her
muff
and
half
out
of
it
,
and
was
in
such
a
tumbled
condition
altogether
,
that
it
seemed
as
if
it
would
be
an
act
of
kindness
to
iron
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
she
was
very
good
-
natured
,
and
said
,
"
Come
with
me
;
I
'll
soon
find
Miss
Dorrit
for
you
,
"
Miss
Dorrit
's
sister
went
with
her
,
drawing
nearer
and
nearer
at
every
step
she
took
in
the
darkness
to
the
sound
of
music
and
the
sound
of
dancing
feet
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
they
came
into
a
maze
of
dust
,
where
a
quantity
of
people
were
tumbling
over
one
another
,
and
where
there
was
such
a
confusion
of
unaccountable
shapes
of
beams
,
bulkheads
,
brick
walls
,
ropes
,
and
rollers
,
and
such
a
mixing
of
gaslight
and
daylight
,
that
they
seemed
to
have
got
on
the
wrong
side
of
the
pattern
of
the
universe
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
left
to
herself
,
and
knocked
against
by
somebody
every
moment
,
was
quite
bewildered
,
when
she
heard
her
sister
's
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
good
gracious
,
Amy
,
what
ever
brought
you
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wanted
to
see
you
,
Fanny
dear
;
and
as
I
am
going
out
all
day
to
-
morrow
,
and
knew
you
might
be
engaged
all
day
to
-
day
<EOS>
,
I
thought
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
But
the
idea
,
Amy
,
of
YOU
coming
behind
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
did
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
her
sister
said
this
in
no
very
cordial
tone
of
welcome
,
she
conducted
her
to
a
more
open
part
of
the
maze
,
where
various
golden
chairs
and
tables
were
heaped
together
,
and
where
a
number
of
young
ladies
were
sitting
on
anything
they
could
find
,
chattering
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
young
ladies
wanted
ironing
,
and
all
had
a
curious
way
of
looking
everywhere
while
they
chattered
.
   
<EOS>
just
as
the
sisters
arrived
here
,
a
monotonous
boy
in
a
Scotch
cap
put
his
head
round
a
beam
on
the
left
,
and
said
,
"
Less
noise
there
,
ladies
!
"
and
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
after
which
,
a
sprightly
gentleman
with
a
quantity
of
long
black
hair
looked
round
a
beam
on
the
right
,
and
said
,
"
Less
noise
there
,
darlings
!
"
and
also

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
notion
of
you
among
professionals
,
Amy
,
is
really
the
last
thing
I
could
have
conceived
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
did
you

here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
who
told
you
I
was
here
,
was
so
good
as

bring
me
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Like

quiet

!
 
<EOS>
You
can
make

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
have
managed
it
,
<EOS>
Amy
,
though
I
know
so
much
more
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
family
custom
to
lay
it
down
as
family
law
,
that
she
was
a
plain
domestic
little
creature
,
without
the
great
and
sage
experience
of
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
This
family
fiction
was
the
family
assertion
of
itself
against
her
services
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
make
too
much
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
have
you
got
on
your
mind
,
<EOS>
Amy
?
 
<EOS>
Of
course
you
have
got
something
on
your
mind
about
me
?
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
She
spoke
as
if
her
sister
,
between
two
and
three
years
her
junior
,
were
her
prejudiced
grandmother
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
much
;
but
since
you
told

of
the
lady
who
gave

the

,
Fanny
---
"
   
The
monotonous
boy
put
his
head
round
the
beam
on
the
left
,
and
said
,
"
Look
out
there
,
ladies
!
"
and
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
sprightly
gentleman
with
the
black
hair
as
suddenly
put
his
head
round
the
beam
on
the
right
,
and
said
,
"
Look
out
there
,
darlings
!
"
and
also

.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
all
the
young
ladies
rose
and
began
shaking
their
skirts
out
behind
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Amy
?
"
said
Fanny
,
doing
as
the
rest
did
;
"
what
were
you
going
to
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Since
you
told
me
a
lady
had
given
you
the
bracelet
you
showed
me
,
Fanny
,
I
have
not

easy
on
your

,
and
indeed
want

know

you

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
ladies
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
boy
in
the
Scotch
cap
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
darlings
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
gentleman
with
the
black
hair
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
every
one
gone
in
a
moment
,
and
the
music
and
the
dancing
feet
were
heard
again
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
sat
down
in
a
golden
chair
,
made
quite
giddy
by
these
rapid
interruptions
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
and
the
rest
were
a
long
time
gone
;
and
during
their
absence
a
voice
(
it
appeared
to
be
that
of
the
gentleman
with
the
black
hair
)
was
continually
calling
out
through
the
music
,
"
One
,
two
,
three
,
four
,
five
,
six
---
go
!
 
<EOS>
One
,
two
,
three
,
four
,
five
,
six
---
go
!
 
<EOS>
Steady
,
darlings
!
 
<EOS>
One
,
two
,
three
,
four
,
five
,
six
---
go
!
"
 
<EOS>
Ultimately
the
voice
stopped
,
and
they
all
came
back
again
,
more
or
less
out
of
breath
,
folding
themselves
in
their
shawls
,
and
making
ready
for
the
streets
.
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
moment
,
Amy
,
and
let
them
get
away
before
us
,
"
whispered
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
soon
left
alone
;
nothing
more
important
happening
,
in
the
meantime
,
than
the
boy
looking
round
his
old
beam
,
and
saying
,
"
Everybody
at
eleven
to
-
morrow
,
ladies
!
"
and
the
gentleman
with
the
black
hair
looking
round
his
old
beam
,
and
saying
,
"
Everybody
at
eleven
to
-
morrow
,
darlings
!
<EOS>
"
each
in
his
own
accustomed
manner
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
were
alone
,
something
was
rolled
up
or
by
other
means
got
out
of
the
way
,
and
there
was
a
great
empty
well
before
them
,
looking
down
into
the
depths
of
which
Fanny
said
,
"
Now
,
uncle
!
"
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
as
her
eyes
became
used
to
the
darkness
,
faintly
made
him
out
at
the
bottom
of
the
well
,
in
an
obscure
corner
by
himself
,
with
his
instrument
in
its
ragged
case
under
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
as
if
the
remote
high
gallery
windows
,
with
their
little
strip
of
sky
,
might
have
been
the
point
of
his
better
fortunes
,
from
which
he
had
descended
,
until
he
had
gradually
sunk
down
below
there
to
the
bottom
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
in
that
place
six
nights
a
week
for
many
years
,
but
had
never
been
observed
to
raise
his
eyes
above
his
music
-
book
,
and
was
confidently
believed
to
have
never
seen
a
play
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
legends
in
the
place
that
he
did
not
so
much
as
know
the
popular
heroes
and
heroines
by
sight
,
and
that
the
low
comedian
had
"
mugged
"
at
him
in
his
richest
manner
fifty
nights
for
a
wager
,
and
he
had
shown
no
trace
of
consciousness
.
<EOS>
The
carpenters
had
a
joke
to
the
effect
that
he
was
dead
without
being
aware
of
it
;
and
the
frequenters
of
the
pit
supposed
him
to
pass
his
whole
life
,
night
and
day
,
and
Sunday
and
all
,
in
the
orchestra
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
tried
him
a
few
times
with
pinches
of
snuff
offered
over
the
rails
,
and
he
had
always
responded
to
this
attention
with
a
momentary
waking
up
of
manner
that
had
the
pale
phantom
of
a
gentleman
in
it
:
beyond
this
he
never
,
on
any
occasion
,
had
any
other
part
in
what
was
going
on
than
the
part
written
out
for
the
clarionet
;
in
private
life
,
where
there
was
no
part
for
the
clarionet
,
he
had
no
part
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Some
said
he
was
poor
,
some
said
he
was
a
wealthy
miser
;
but
he
said
nothing
,
never
lifted
up
his
bowed
head
,
never
varied
his
shuffling
gait
by
getting
his
springless
foot
from
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Though
expecting
now
to
be
summoned
by
his
niece
,
he
did
not
hear
her
until
she
had
spoken
to
him
three
or
four
times
;
nor
was
he
at
all
surprised
by
the
presence
of
two
nieces
instead
of
one
,
but
merely
said
in
his
tremulous
voice
,
"
I
am
coming
,
I
am
coming
!
"
and
crept
forth
by
some
underground
way
which
emitted
a
cellarous
smell
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
Amy
,
"
said
her
sister
,
when
the
three
together
passed
out
at
the
door
that
had
such
a
shame
-
faced
consciousness
of
being
different
from
other
doors
<EOS>
:
the
uncle
instinctively
taking
Amy
's
arm
as
the
arm
to
be
relied
on
:
"
<EOS>
so
,
Amy
,
you
are
curious
about
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
pretty
,
and
conscious
,
and
rather
flaunting
;
and
the
condescension
with
which
she
put
aside
the
superiority
of
her
charms
,
and
of
her
worldly
experience
,
and
addressed
her
sister
on
almost
equal
terms
,
had
a
vast
deal
of
the
family
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
interested
,
Fanny
,
and
concerned
in
anything
that
concerns
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
are
,
so
you
are
,
and
you
are
the
best
of
Amys
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
ever
a
little
provoking
,
I
am
sure
you
'll
consider
what
a
thing
it
is
to
occupy
my
position
and
feel

of
being

.
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
care
,
"
said
the
Daughter
of
the
Father

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
None

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Common
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
mildly
looked
at
the
speaker
,
but
did
not
interrupt

.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
took
out
her

,
and
rather

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
born
where

,

,
Amy
,
and
<EOS>
perhaps

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
'll

at
the
cook
's

where
he

.
"
   
<EOS>
They
walked
on
with
him
until
they
came
to
a
dirty
shop
window
in
a
dirty
street
,
which
was
made
almost
opaque
by
the
steam
of
hot

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
But

were
to
be
caught
of
a
roast
leg
of
pork
bursting
into

of
sage
and
onion
in
a
metal
reservoir
full
of
gravy
,
of
an
unctuous
piece
of
roast
beef
and
blisterous
Yorkshire

,
bubbling
hot
in
a
similar

,
of
a
stuffed
fillet
of
veal
in
rapid
cut
,
of
a
ham
in
a
perspiration
with
the
pace
it
was
going
at
,
of
a
shallow
tank
of
baked
potatoes
glued
together
by
their
own
richness
,
of
a
truss
or
two
of
boiled
greens
,
and
other
substantial
delicacies
.
 
<EOS>
Within
,
were
a
few
wooden
partitions
,
behind
which
such
customers
as
found
it
more
convenient
to
take
away
their
dinners
in

than
in
their
hands
,
Packed
their

in

.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
opening
her
reticule
,
as
they
surveyed
these
things
,
produced
from
that
repository
a
shilling
and
handed
it
to
Uncle
.
 
<EOS>
Uncle
,
after
not
looking
at
it
a
little

,
divined

object
,
and
muttering
"
Dinner
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
!
"
slowly
vanished
from
them
into
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Amy
,
"
said
her
sister
,
"

,

Harley

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
air
with
which
she
threw
off
this
distinguished
address
and
the

she

to
her
new

(
which

)
,

;
however
,
she

to

,
and
thither

.
 
<EOS>
Arrived
at
that
grand
destination
,
Fanny
singled
out
the
handsomest
house
,
and
knocking
at
the
door
,
inquired
for
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
The
footman
who
opened
the
door
,
although
he
had
powder
on

head
and
was
backed

by

likewise

,
not
only

Mrs
Merdle
to
be

,
but

Fanny
to

.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
walked
in
,
taking
her
sister
with
her
;
and
they
went
up

stairs
with
powder
going
before
and
powder

,
and
were
left
in
a
spacious

,
one

several

,
where
there
was
a
parrot
on
the
outside
of
a
golden
cage
holding
on
by

,
with
its

in

air
,
and

into
many

-

.
 
<EOS>
This
peculiarity
has
been
observed
in
birds
of
quite
another
feather
,
climbing
upon
golden
wires
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
far
more
splendid
than
anything
Little
Dorrit
had
ever

,
and
would
have
been
splendid
and

in
any

.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
in

her
sister
and
would

,
but
that
Fanny
with

pointed
to
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
The

shook
next

,
and
a

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

was
not
young
and

from
the
hand
of
Nature
,
but
was
young
and
fresh
from
the
hand

her

.
 
<EOS>
She
had
large
unfeeling
handsome
eyes
,
and
dark
unfeeling
handsome
hair
,
and
a
broad
unfeeling
handsome
bosom
,
and
was
made
the
most
of
in
every

.
 
<EOS>
Either
because
she
had
a
cold
,
or
because
it
suited
her
face
,
she

rich

.
 
<EOS>
And

were
an
unfeeling

that

if
,

,

,

,

"

man
,

by

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
,
"

Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
sister
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs

"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

did

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
All

was
usually

because

;

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>
Fanny

No
.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Very

;

.

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,
"

,
<EOS>
as

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

?
"
<EOS>
"
Do

,

"

<EOS>
"
She

"

;
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Society
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
with

,
"
is

(

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
I
wish

was
not
so
arbitrary
<EOS>
,
I
wish

not
so
exacting
 
---
 
<EOS>
Bird
,
be
quiet
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
parrot
had
given
a
most

,
as
if
its
name
were
Society
and
it
asserted
its

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
"
resumed
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
we

as

.
 
<EOS>
We
know

is
hollow

and

and

,
but
unless
we
are
Savages
in

Tropical
seas
<EOS>
(
I

---
most

life
and

,
I
am

)
,

must

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
common
lot
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
is
a
most
extensive
merchant
,
his
transactions
are
on
the
vastest
scale
,
his
wealth
and

are
very

,
but
even
he
---
 
Bird
,

quiet
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
parrot
had
shrieked
another
shriek
;
and
it
filled
up
the
sentence
so
expressively
that
Mrs
Merdle
was
under
no

to
end

.
   
<EOS>
"
Since
your
sister

that

,
"
she

again
,
addressing

Dorrit
,
"
by

the
circumstances
that
are
much
to
her
credit
,
I
can
not
object
to
comply
with
her
request
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
son
(
I
was
first
married
extremely
young
)
of
two
or
three
-
and
-
twenty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fanny
set
her
lips
,
and
her
eyes
looked
half
triumphantly
at
her
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
son
of
two
or
three
-
and
-
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
little
gay
,
a
thing
Society
is
accustomed
to
in
young
men
,
and
he
is
very
impressible
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
inherits
that
misfortune
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
impressible
myself
,
by
nature
.
 
<EOS>
The
weakest
of
creatures
---
my
feelings
are
touched
in
a
moment
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
said
all

,

as

;
quite

;

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
So

.
 
<EOS>
Not

in
our

state
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Society

and

---
 
Bird
,

!
"
<EOS>
The

,

his

<EOS>
"
It

,

,

as
to

---
"
that

.
 
<EOS>
In

stage
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,

,

usually

,

,
where

.

<EOS>
She

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

was

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

ca

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

he
has
undergone
so
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Little
Dorrit
felt
the
injustice
of
this
taunt
rather
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
The
remembrance
of
last
night
added
a
barbed
point
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
nothing
in
reply
,
but
turned
her
chair
from
the
table
towards
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Uncle
,
after
making
one
more
pause
,
blew
a
dismal
wail
and
went
on
again
.
   
<EOS>
Fanny
was
passionate
with
the
tea
-
cups
and
the
bread
as
long
as
her
passion
lasted
,
and
then
protested
that
she
was
the
wretchedest
girl
in
the
world
,
and
she
wished
she
was
dead
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
her
crying
became
remorseful
,
and
she
got
up
and
put
her
arms
round
her
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
tried
to
stop
her
from
saying
anything
,
but
she
answered
that
she
would
,
she
must
!
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
she
said
again
,
and
again
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Amy
,
"
and
"
Forgive
me
,
Amy
,
"
almost
as
passionately
as
she
had
said
what
she
regretted
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
indeed
,
indeed
,
Amy
,
"
she
resumed
when
they
were
seated
in
sisterly
accord
side
by
side
,
"
I
hope
<EOS>
and
I
think
you
would
have
seen
this
differently
,
if
you
had
known
a
little
more
of
Society
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
might
,
Fanny
,
"
said
the
mild
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
while
you
have
been
domestic
and
resignedly
shut
up
there
,
Amy
,
"
pursued
her
sister
,
gradually

to
patronise
,
"
I
have
been
out
,
moving
more
in
Society
,
and
may
have
been
getting
proud
and
spirited
---
more
than
I
ought
to
be
,
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
answered
"
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
O
yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
while
you
have
been
thinking
of
the
dinner
or
the
clothes
,
I
may
have
been
thinking
,
you
know
,
of
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
may
it
not
be
so
,
Amy
?
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
again
nodded
"
Yes
,
"
with
a
more
cheerful
face
than
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Especially
as
we
know
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
that
there
certainly
is
a
tone
in
the
place
to
which
you
have
been
so
true
,
which
does
belong
to
it
,
and
which
does
make
it
different
from
other

of
Society
.
 
<EOS>
So
kiss
me
once
again
,
<EOS>
Amy
dear
,
and
we
will
agree
that
we
may
both
be
right
,
and
that
you
are
a
tranquil
,
domestic
,
home
-

,
good
girl
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
clarionet
had
been
lamenting
most
pathetically
during
this
dialogue
,
but
was
cut
short
now
by
Fanny
's
announcement
that
it
was
time
to
go
;
which
she
conveyed
to
her
uncle
by
shutting
up
his
scrap
of
music
,
and
taking
the
clarionet

.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
parted
from
them
at
the
door
,
and
hastened
back
to
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
It
fell
dark
there
sooner
than
elsewhere
,
and
going
into
it
<EOS>
that
evening
was
like
going
into
a
deep

.
 
<EOS>
The
shadow
of
the
wall
was
on
every

.
 
<EOS>
Not
least
upon
the
figure
in

old

the
black

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
upon

!
"
thought

Dorrit
,
with
the
door
<EOS>
Yet
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
unreasonable
in
Fanny
.
"
    
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
's
Complaint
 
Upon
that
establishment
of
state
,
the
Merdle
establishment
in
Harley
Street
,
Cavendish
Square
<EOS>
,
there
was
the
shadow
of
no
more
common
wall
than
the
fronts
of
other
establishments
of
state
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
Like
unexceptionable
Society
,
the
opposing
rows
of
houses
in
Harley
Street
were
very
grim
with
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
mansions
and
their
inhabitants
were
so
much
alike
in
that
respect
,
that
the
people
were
often
to
be
found
drawn
up
on
opposite
sides
of
dinner
-

,
in
the
shade
of
their
own
loftiness
,
staring
at
the
other
side
of
the
way
with
the
dullness
of
the
houses
.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
knows
how
like
the
street
the
two
dinner
-
rows
of
people
who
take
their
stand
by
the
street
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
The
expressionless
uniform
twenty
houses
,
all
to
be
knocked
at
and
rung
at
in
the
same
form
,
all
approachable
by
the
same
dull
steps
,
all
fended
off
by
the
same
pattern
of
railing
,
all
with
the
same
impracticable
fire
-
escapes
,
the
same
inconvenient
fixtures
in
their
heads
,
and
everything
without
exception
to
be
taken
at
a
high
valuation
---
who
has
not
dined
with
these
?
 
<EOS>
The
house
so
drearily
out
of
repair
,
the
occasional
bow
-
window
,
the
stuccoed
house
,
the
newly
-
fronted
house
,
the
corner
house
with
nothing
but
angular
rooms
,
the
house
with
the

always
down
,
the
house
with
the
hatchment
always
up
,
the
house
where
the
collector
has
called
for
one
quarter
of
an
Idea
,
and
found
nobody
at
home
---
who
has
not
dined
with
these
?
 
<EOS>
The
house
that
nobody
will
take
,
and
is
to
be
had
a
bargain
---
who
does
not
know
her
?
 
<EOS>
The
showy
house
that
was
taken
for
life
by
the
disappointed
gentleman
,
and
which
does
not
suit
him
at
all
---
who
is
unacquainted
with
that
haunted
habitation
?
   
<EOS>
Harley
Street
,
Cavendish
Square
,
was
more
than
aware
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Intruders
there
were
in
Harley
Street
,
of
whom
it
was
not
aware
;
but
Mr
and
Mrs
Merdle
it
delighted
to
honour
.
 
<EOS>
Society
was
aware
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Society
had
said
"
Let
us
license
them
;
let
us
know
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
was
immensely
rich
;
a
man
of
prodigious
enterprise
;
a
Midas
without
the
ears
,
who
turned
all
he
touched
to
gold
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
everything
good
,
from
banking
to
building
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
Parliament
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
City
,
necessarily
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
Chairman
of
this
,
Trustee
of
that
,
President
of
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
The
weightiest
of
men
had
said
to
projectors
,
"
Now
,
what
name
have
you
got
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
got
Merdle
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
the
reply
being
in
the
negative
,
had
said
,
"
Then
I
wo
n't
look
at
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
great
and
fortunate
man
had
provided
that
extensive
bosom
which
required
so
much
room
to
be
unfeeling
enough
in
,
with
a
nest
of
crimson
and
gold
some
fifteen
years
before
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
bosom
to
repose
upon
,
but
it
was
a
capital
bosom
to
hang
jewels
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
wanted
something
to
hang
jewels
upon
,
and
he
bought
it
for
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Storr
and
Mortimer
might
have
married
on
the
same
speculation
.
   
<EOS>
Like
all
his
other
speculations
,
it
was
sound
and
successful
.
 
<EOS>
The
jewels
showed
to
the
richest
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
The
bosom
moving
in
Society
with
the
jewels
displayed
upon
it
,
attracted
general
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
Society
approving
,
Mr
Merdle
was
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
most
disinterested
of
men
,
---
did
everything
for
Society
,
and
got
as
little
for
himself
out
of
all
his
gain
and
care
,
as
a
man
might
.
   
<EOS>
That
is
to
say
,
it
may
be
supposed
that
he
got
all
he
wanted
,
otherwise
with
unlimited
wealth
he
would
have
got
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
desire
was
to
the
utmost
to
satisfy
Society
(
whatever
that
was
)
,
and
take
up
all
its
drafts
upon
him
for
tribute
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
shine
in
company
;
he
had
not
very
much
to
say
for
himself
;
he
was
a
reserved
man
,
with
a
broad
,
overhanging
,
watchful
head
,
that
particular
kind
of
dull
red
colour
in
his
cheeks
which
is
rather
stale
than
fresh
,
and
a
somewhat
uneasy
expression
about
his
coat
-
cuffs
,
as
if
they
were
in
his
confidence
,
and
had
reasons
for
being
anxious
to
hide
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
little
he
said
,
he
was
a
pleasant
man
enough
;
plain
,
emphatic
about
public
and
private
confidence
,
and
tenacious
of
the
utmost
deference
being
shown
by
every
one
,
in
all
things
,
to
Society
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
same
Society
(
if
that
were
it
which
came
to
his
dinners
,
and
to
Mrs
Merdle
's
receptions
and
concerts
)
,
he
hardly
seemed
to
enjoy
himself
much
,
and
was
mostly
to
be
found
against
walls
and
behind
doors
.
 
<EOS>
Also
when
he
went
out
to
it
,
instead
of
its
coming
home
to
him
,
he
seemed
a
little
fatigued
,
and
upon
the
whole
rather
more
disposed
for
bed
;
but
he
was
always
cultivating
it
nevertheless
,
and
always
moving
in
it
---
and
always
laying
out
money
on
it
with
the
greatest
liberality
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
's
first
husband
had
been
a
colonel
,
under
whose
auspices
the
bosom
had
entered
into
competition
with
the
snows
of
North
America
,
and
had
come
off
at
little
disadvantage
in
point
of
whiteness
,
and
at
none
in
point
of
coldness
.
 
<EOS>
The
colonel
's
son
was
Mrs
Merdle
's
only
child
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
of
a
chuckle
-
headed
,
high
-
shouldered
make
,
with
a
general
appearance
of
being
,
not
so
much
a
young
man
as
a
swelled
boy
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
given
so
few
signs
of
reason
,
that
a
by
-
word
went
among
his
companions
that
his
brain
had
been
frozen
up
in
a
mighty
frost
which
prevailed
at
St
john
's
,
New
Brunswick
,
at
the
period
of
his
birth
there
,
and
had
never
thawed
from
that
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Another
by
-
word
represented
him
as
having
in
his
infancy
,
through
the
negligence
of
a
nurse
,
fallen
out
of
a
high
window
on
his
head
,
which
had
been
heard
by
responsible
witnesses
to
crack
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
probable
that
both
these
representations
were
of
ex
post
facto
origin
;
the
young
gentleman
(
whose
expressive
name
was
Sparkler
)
being
monomaniacal
in
offering

to
all

of

,
and
in
remarking
of
every

that
she
was
"
a
doosed
fine
gal
---
well
educated
too
---
with
no
biggodd
nonsense
about
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
son
-
in
-
law
with
these
limited
talents
,
might
have
been
a
clog
upon
another
man
;
but
Mr
Merdle
did
not
want
a
son
-
in
-
law

;
he
wanted
a
son
-

-
law

Society
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
having
been
in
the
Guards
,
and
being
in
the
habit
of
frequenting
all
the

,
and

,
and

,
and
being
well

,
Society
was
satisfied
with
its
son
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
This
happy
result
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
would
have
considered
well

,
though
Mr
Sparkler
had
been
a
more

.
 
<EOS>
And
he
did
not
get
Mr
Sparkler
by
any

for
Society
,

was
.
<EOS>
There

Street

,
while
Little
Dorrit
was
stitching
at

father
's
new
shirts
by

that

;
and

,

,

,
Bishop

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
Bishop
magnate
to

,
"

Mr

has

.
 
<EOS>
They
say
a
hundred
thousand
pounds
.
"
   
<EOS>
Horse
Guards
had
heard
two
.
   
<EOS>
Treasury
had
heard
three
.
   
<EOS>
Bar
,
handling
his
persuasive
double
eye
-
glass
,
was
by
no
means
clear
but
that
it
might
be
four
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
happy
strokes
of
calculation
and
combination
,
the
result
of
which
it
was
difficult
to
estimate
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
instances
of
a
comprehensive
grasp
,
associated
with
habitual
luck
and
characteristic
boldness
,
of
which
an
age
presented
us
but
few
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
was
Brother
Bellows
,
who
had
been
in
the
great
Bank
case
,
and
who
could
probably
tell
us
more
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
Brother
Bellows
put
this
new
success
at
?
   
<EOS>
Brother
Bellows
was
on
his
way
to
make
his
bow
to
the
bosom
,
and
could
only
tell
them
in
passing
that
he
had
heard

stated
,
with
great
appearance
of
truth
,
as
being
worth
,
from
first
to
last
,
half
-
a
-
million
of

.
   
<EOS>
Admiralty
said
Mr
Merdle
was
a
wonderful
man
,
Treasury
said
he
was
a
new
power
in
the
country
,
and
would
be
able
to
buy
up
the
whole
House
of
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
Bishop
said
he
was
glad
to
think
that
this
wealth
flowed
into
the
coffers
of
a
gentleman
who
was
always
disposed
to
maintain
the
best
interests
of
Society
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
himself
was
usually
late
on
these
occasions
,
as
a
man
still
detained
in
the
clutch
of
giant
enterprises
when
other
men
had
shaken
off
their
dwarfs
for
the

.
 
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
,
he
was
the
last

.
 
<EOS>
Treasury
said
Merdle
's
work
punished

.
 
<EOS>

said

<EOS>
Powder
!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Bar

,

<EOS>
Bishop

,

:

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
There

's

on

now

-

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

Chapter

.
<EOS>
A
Puzzle
 
Mr
Clennam

not

in

.
 
<EOS>

on

in

,
but
had
rather
a

in

,
and
to

.
 
<EOS>
An

,

that
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

Mr

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

something
(

)

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
the

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

that

just

and
just

in

,

;
and
that
to
make
a
kind
of
domesticated
fairy
of
her
,
on
the
penalty
of
isolation
at
heart
from
the
only
people
she
knew
,
would
be
but
a
weakness
of
his
own
fancy
,
and
not
a
kind
one
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
her
youthful
and
ethereal
appearance
,
her
timid
manner
,
the
charm
of
her
sensitive
voice
and
eyes
,
the
very
many
respects
in
which
she
had
interested
him
out
of
her
own
individuality
,
and
the
strong
difference
between
herself
and
those
about
her
,
were
not
in
unison
,
and
were
determined
not
to
be
in
unison
,
with
this
newly
presented
idea
.
   
<EOS>
He
told
the
worthy
Mrs
Chivery
,
after
turning
these
things
over
in
his
mind
---
he
did
that
,
indeed
,
while
she
was
yet
speaking
---
that
he
might
be
relied
upon
to
do
his
utmost
at
all
times
to
promote
the
happiness
of
Miss
Dorrit
,
and
to
further
the
wishes
of
her
heart
if
it
were
in
his
power
to
do
so
,
and
if
he
could
discover
what
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
he
cautioned
her
against
assumptions
and
appearances
;
enjoined
strict
silence
and
secrecy
,
lest
Miss
Dorrit
should
be
made
unhappy
;
and
particularly
advised
her
to
endeavour
to
win
her
son
's
confidence
and
so
to
make
quite
sure
of
the
state
of
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Chivery
considered
the
latter
precaution
superfluous
,
but
said
she
would
try
.
 
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
as
if
she
had
not
derived
all
the
comfort
she
had
fondly
expected
from
this
interview
,
but
thanked
him
nevertheless
for
the
trouble
he
had
kindly
taken
.
 
<EOS>
They
then
parted
good
friends
,
and
Arthur
walked
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
crowd
in
the
street
jostling
the
crowd
in
his
mind
,
and
the
two
crowds
making
a
confusion
,
he
avoided
London
Bridge
,
and
turned
off
in
the
quieter

of

Iron
Bridge
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
set
foot
upon
it
,
when
he
saw
Little
Dorrit
walking
on
before

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
pleasant
day
,
with
a
light

blowing
,
and
she
seemed
to
have
that
minute
come
there
for
air
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
her
in
her
father
's
room
within
an
hour
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
timely
chance
,
favourable
to
his
wish
of
observing
her
face
and
manner
when
no

else

.
 
<EOS>
He
quickened
his
pace
;
but
before

,
she

.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
I
startled
you
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

I
knew
the

,
"
she

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
did

,
Little

?
 
<EOS>
You

expected

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
I

---
sounded

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
I

"
   
<EOS>
They

<EOS>
"
It

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

<EOS>
That

These

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
She

;

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
When

,

.
 
<EOS>
Something

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
higher

,

?
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

too

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Machinery

<EOS>

<EOS>
They
began
their

in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
that

.
 
<EOS>
Little
peculiarities
were
easily
to
be
detected
by
experienced
eyes
in
Mr
Doyce
's
way
of
managing
his
affairs
,
but
they
almost
always
involved
some
ingenious
simplification
of
a
difficulty
,
and
some
plain
road
to
the
desired
end
.
 
<EOS>
That
his
papers
were
in
arrear
,
and
that
he
stood
in
need
of
assistance
to
develop
the
capacity
of
his
business
,
was
clear
enough
;
but
all
the
results
of
his
undertakings
during
many
years
were
distinctly
set
forth
,
and
were
ascertainable
with
ease
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
had
been
done
for
the
purposes
of
the
pending
investigation
;
everything
was
in
its
genuine
working
dress
,
and
in
a
certain
honest
rugged
order
.
 
<EOS>
The
calculations
and
entries
,
in
his
own
hand
,
of
which
there
were
many
,
were
bluntly
written
,
and
with
no
very
neat
precision
;
but
were
always
plain
and
directed
straight
to
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
It
occurred
to
Arthur
that
a
far
more
elaborate
and
taking
show
of
business
---
such
as
the
records
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
made
perhaps
---
might
be
far
less
serviceable
,
as
being
meant
to
be
far
less

.
   
<EOS>
Three

days
of

application
tendered
him
master
of
all
the
facts
it
was
essential
to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
was
at

the

,
always

to

any
dim

with

little

.
 
<EOS>

for

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
The
purchase
was
completed
within

month
.
 
<EOS>
It
left
Arthur
in
possession
of
private
personal
means
not

a
few

;
but

opened
to

an

.
 
<EOS>
The
three
friends
dined
together
on
the
auspicious

;
the
factory
and
the
factory
wives
and
children
made
holiday
and

;
even
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
dined
and
was
full
of

.
 
<EOS>
Two

had
barely
gone
by
in
all
,
when
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
had

so
familiar
with
short
-

again
,
that
the

;
when

but

,
DOYCE

;

.
   
<EOS>
The
little

-
house
reserved
for
his
own
occupation
,
was
a
room
of
wood
and

at
the

,
filled
with

,
and

,
and

,
and

,
and

;
which
,
when
they
were
in

with
the

-

,
went

round
as
though
they
had
a
suicidal
mission
to
grind
the
business
to
dust
and
tear
the
factory
to
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
A
communication
of
great
trap
-
doors
in
the
floor
and
roof
with
the
workshop
above
and
the
workshop
below
,
made

light
in
this

,
which

to

's
mind
the
child
's
old
picture

book
,
where
similar
rays
were
the
witnesses
of
Abel
's

.
 
<EOS>
The

were
sufficiently

and

out
from
the
counting
-
house
to
blend
into
a
busy
hum
,
interspersed
with
periodical

and

.
<EOS>
The
patient
figures
at
work
were
swarthy
with
the
filings
of
iron
and
steel
that
danced
on
every
bench
and
bubbled
up
through
every

planking
.
 
<EOS>
The
workshop
was
arrived
at
by
a
step
-
ladder
from
the
outer
yard
below
,
where
it
served
as
a
shelter
for
the
large
grindstone
where
tools
were
sharpened
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
had
at
once
a
fanciful
and
practical
air
in
Clennam
's
eyes
,
which
was
a
welcome
change
;
and
,
as
often

he
raised
them
from
his
first
work
of
getting
the
array
of
business
documents
into
perfect
order
,
he
glanced
at
these
things
with
a
feeling
of
pleasure
in
his
pursuit
that
was
new
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
Raising
his

thus
one
day
,

a
bonnet
labouring
up

step

.
 
<EOS>
The
unusual
apparition
was

by
another

.
 
<EOS>
He

Mr
F
's

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

---
force

The
