turning
his
head
in
a
lumbering
way
towards
Pancks
,
that
assistant
put
up
the
note
-
book
in
which
he
had
been
absorbed
,
and
took
him
in
tow
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
recommend
her
,
you
know
,
"
said
Pancks
;
"
how
could
you
?
<EOS>
You
knew
nothing
about
her
,
you
did
n't
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
was
mentioned
to
you
,
and
you
passed
it
on
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
YOU
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
she
justifies
any
recommendation
,
it
is
much
the
same
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
glad
she
turns
out
well
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
but
it
would
n't
have
been
your
fault
if
she
had
turned
out
ill
.
 
<EOS>
The
credit
's
not
yours
as
it
is
,
and
the
blame
would
n't
have
been
yours
as
it
might
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
You
gave
no
guarantee
.
 
<EOS>
You
knew
nothing
about
her
.
"
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
acquainted
,
then
,
"
said
Arthur
,
hazarding
a
random
question
,
"
with
any
of
her
family
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Acquainted
with
any
of
her
family
?
"
returned
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
should
you
be
acquainted
with
any
of
her
family
?
 
<EOS>
You
never
heard
of
'em
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
be
acquainted
with
people
you
never
heard
of
,
can
you
?
<EOS>
You
should
think
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
the
Patriarch
sat
serenely
smiling
;
nodding
or
shaking
his
head
benevolently
,
as
the
case
required
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
being
a
reference
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
you
know
,
in
a
general
way
,
what
being
a
reference
means
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
your
eye
,
that
is
!
<EOS>
Look
at
your
tenants
down
the
Yard
here
.
 
<EOS>
They
'd
all
be
references
for
one
another
,
if
you
'd
let
'em
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
be
the
good
of
letting
'em
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
no
satisfaction
to
be
done
by
two
men
instead
of
one
.
 
<EOS>
One
's
enough
.
 
<EOS>
A
person
who
ca
n't
pay
,
gets
another
person
who
ca
n't
pay
,
to
guarantee
that
he
can
pay
.
 
<EOS>
Like
a
person
with
two
wooden
legs
getting
another
person
with
two
wooden
legs
,
to
guarantee
that
he
has
got
two
natural
legs
.
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
make
either
of
them
able
to
do
a
walking
match
.
 
<EOS>
And
four
wooden
legs
are
more
troublesome
to
you
than
two
,
when
you
do
n't
want
any
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
concluded
by
blowing
off
that
steam
of
his
.
   
<EOS>
A
momentary
silence
that
ensued
was
broken
by
Mr
F
's
Aunt
,
who
had
been
sitting
upright
in
a
cataleptic
state
since
her
last
public
remark
.
 
<EOS>
She
now
underwent
a
violent
twitch
,
calculated
to
produce
a
startling
effect
on
the
nerves
of
the
uninitiated
,
and
with
the
deadliest
animosity
observed
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
make
a
head
and
brains
out
of
a
brass
knob
with
nothing
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
could
n't
do
it
when
your
Uncle
George
was
living
;
much
less
when
he
's
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
not
slow
to
reply
,
with
his
usual
calmness
,
"
Indeed
,
ma'am
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
surprised
to
hear
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Despite
his
presence
of
mind
,
however
,
the
speech
of
Mr
F
's
Aunt
produced
a
depressing
effect
on
the
little
assembly
;
firstly
,
because
it
was
impossible
to
disguise
that
Clennam
's
unoffending
head
was
the
particular
temple
of
reason
depreciated
;
and
secondly
,
because
nobody
ever
knew
on
these
occasions
whose
Uncle
George
was
referred
to
,
or
what
spectral
presence
might
be
invoked
under
that
appellation
.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
Flora
said
,
though
still
not
without
a
certain
boastfulness
and
triumph
in
her
legacy
,
that
Mr
F
's
Aunt
was
"
very
lively
to
-
day
,
and
she
thought
they
had
better
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
F
's
Aunt
proved
so
lively
as
to
take
the
suggestion
in
unexpected
dudgeon
and
declare
that
she
would
not
go
;
adding
,
with
several
injurious
expressions
,
that
if
"
He
"
---
too
evidently
meaning
Clennam
---
wanted
to
get
rid
of
her
,
"
let
him
chuck
her
out
of
winder
;
"
and
urgently
expressing
her
desire
to
see
"
Him
"
perform
that
ceremony
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
dilemma
,
Mr
Pancks
,
whose
resources
appeared
equal
to
any
emergency
in
the
Patriarchal
waters
,
slipped
on
his
hat
,
slipped
out
at
the
counting
-
house
door
,
and
slipped
in
again
a
moment
afterwards
with
an
artificial
freshness
upon
him
,
as
if
he
had
been
in
the
country
for
some
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
my
heart
,
ma'am
!
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
rubbing
up
his
hair
in
great
astonishment
,
"
is
that
you
?
   
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
looking
charming
to
-
day
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
Favour
me
with
your
arm
,
ma'am
;
we
'll
have
a
little
walk
together
,
you
and
me
,
if
you
'll
honour
me
with
your
company
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
escorted
Mr
F
's
Aunt
down
the
private
staircase
of
the
counting
-
house
with
great
gallantry
and
success
.
 
<EOS>
The
patriarchal
Mr
Casby
then
rose
with
the
air
of
having
done
it
himself
,
and
blandly
followed
:
leaving
his
daughter
,
as
she
followed
in
her
turn
,
to
remark
to
her
former
lover
in
a
distracted
whisper
(
which
she
very
much
enjoyed
)
,
that
they
had
drained
the
cup
of
life
to
the
dregs
;
and
further
to
hint
mysteriously
that
the
late
Mr
F
was
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Alone
again
,
Clennam
became
a
prey
to
his
old
doubts
in
reference
to
his
mother
and
Little
Dorrit
,
and
revolved
the
old
thoughts
and
suspicions
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
in
his
mind
,
blending
themselves
with
the
duties
he
was
mechanically
discharging
,
when
a
shadow
on
his
papers
caused
him
to
look
up
for
the
cause
.
 
<EOS>
The
cause
was
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
With
his
hat
thrown
back
upon
his
ears
as
if
his
wiry
prongs
of
hair
had
darted
up
like
springs
and
cast
it
off
,
with
his
jet
-
black
beads
of
eyes
inquisitively
sharp
,
with
the
fingers
of
his
right
hand
in
his
mouth
that
he
might
bite
the
nails
,
and
with
the
fingers
of
his
left
hand
in
reserve
in
his
pocket
for
another
course
,
Mr
Pancks
cast
his
shadow
through
the
glass
upon
the
books
and
papers
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
asked
,
with
a
little
inquiring
twist
of
his
head
,
if
he
might
come
in
again
?
 
<EOS>
Clennam
replied
with
a
nod
of
his
head
in
the
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
worked
his
way
in
,
came
alongside
the
desk
,
made
himself
fast
by
leaning
his
arms
upon
it
,
and
started
conversation
with
a
puff
and
a
snort
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
F
's
Aunt
is
appeased
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
unfortunate
as
to
have
awakened
a
strong
animosity
in
the
breast
of
that
lady
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
SHE
know
why
?
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
\I\
suppose
not
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
He
took
out
his
note
-
book
,
opened
it
,
shut
it
,
dropped
it
into
his
hat
,
which
was
beside

on
the
desk
,
and
looked
in
at
it
as
it
lay
at
the
bottom
of
the
hat
:
all
with
a
great
appearance
of
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
he
then
began
,
"
I
am
in
want
of
information
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Connected
with
this
firm
?
"
asked
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
what
then
,
Mr
Pancks
?
 
<EOS>
That
is
to
say
,
assuming
that
you
want
it
of
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
;
yes
,
I
want
it
of
you
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
if
I
can
persuade
you
to
furnish
it
.
 
<EOS>
A^
,
B^
,
C^
,
D^.
 
<EOS>
DA^
,
DE^
,
DI^
,
DO^.
 
Dictionary
order
.
   
<EOS>
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
name
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
blew
off
his
peculiar
noise
again
,
and
fell
to
at
his
right
-
hand
nails
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
looked
searchingly
at
him
;
he
returned
the
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
Mr
Pancks
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
name
that
I
want
to
know
about
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
want
to
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whatever
you
can
and
will
tell
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
comprehensive
summary
of
his
desires
was
not
discharged
without
some
heavy
labouring
on
the
part
of
Mr
Pancks
's
machinery
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
singular
visit
,
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
It
strikes
me
as
rather
extraordinary
that
you
should
come
,
with
such
an
object
,
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
all
extraordinary
together
,
"
returned
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
out
of
the
ordinary
course
,
and
yet
be
business
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
it
is
business
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
man
of
business
.
 
<EOS>
What
business
have
I
in
this
present
world
,
except
to
stick
to
business
?
 
<EOS>
No
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
his
former
doubt
whether
this
dry
hard
personage
were
quite
in
earnest
,
Clennam
again
turned
his
eyes
attentively
upon
his
face
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
scrubby
and
dingy
as
ever
,
and
as
eager
and
quick
as
ever
,
and
he
could
see
nothing
lurking
in
it
that
was
at
all
expressive
of
a
latent
mockery
that
had
seemed
to
strike
upon
his
ear
in
the
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
to
put
this
business
on
its
own
footing
,
it
's
not
my
proprietor
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
refer
to
Mr
Casby
as
your
proprietor
?
"
   
<EOS>
Pancks
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
proprietor
.
 
<EOS>
Put
a
case
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
at
my
proprietor
's
I
hear
name
---
name
of
young
person
Mr
Clennam
wants
to
serve
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
name
first
mentioned
to
my
proprietor
by
Plornish
in
the
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
I
go
to
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
I
ask
Plornish
as
a
matter
of
business
for
information
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
Plornish
,
though
six
weeks
in
arrear
to
my
proprietor
,
declines
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
Mrs
Plornish
declines
.
<EOS>
Say
,
both
refer
to
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
Put
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
Pancks
,
"
say
,
I
come
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
here
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
those
prongs
of
hair
sticking
up
all
over
his
head
,
and
his
breath
coming
and
going
very
hard
and
short
,
the
busy
Pancks
fell
back
a
step
(
in
Tug
metaphor
,
took
half
a
turn
astern
)
as
if
to
show
his
dingy
hull
complete
,
then
forged
a
-
head
again
,
and
directed
his
quick
glance
by
turns
into
his
hat
where
his
note
-
book
was
,
and
into
Clennam
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pancks
,
not
to
trespass
on
your
grounds
of
mystery
,
I
will
be
as
plain
with
you
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
ask
two
questions
.
 
<EOS>
First
---
"
   
"
All
right
!
"
said
Pancks
,
holding
up
his
dirty
forefinger
with
his
broken
nail
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
!
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
motive
?
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Exactly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Motive
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
good
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
to
do
with
my
proprietor
;
not
stateable
at
present
,
ridiculous
to
state
at
present
;
but
good
.
   
<EOS>
Desiring
to
serve
young
person
,
name
of
Dorrit
,
"
said
Pancks
,
with
his
forefinger
still
up
as
a
caution
.
 
<EOS>
"
Better
admit
motive
to
be
good
.
"
   
"
Secondly
,
and
lastly
,
what
do
you
want
to
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
fished
up
his
note
-
book
before
the
question
was
put
,
and
buttoning
it
with
care
in
an
inner
breast
-
pocket
,
and
looking
straight
at
Clennam
all
the
time
,
replied
with
a
pause
and
a
puff
,
"
I
want
supplementary
information
of
any
sort
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
could
not
withhold
a
smile
,
as
the
panting
little
steam
-
tug
,
so
useful
to
that
unwieldy
ship
,
the
Casby
,
waited
on
and
watched
him
as
if
it
were
seeking
an
opportunity
of
running
in
and
rifling
him
of
all
he
wanted
before
he
could
resist
its
manoeuvres
;
though
there
was
that
in
Mr
Pancks
's
eagerness
,
too
,
which
awakened
many
wondering
speculations
in
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
little
consideration
,
he
resolved
to
supply
Mr
Pancks
with
such
leading
information
as
it
was
in
his
power
to
impart
him
;
<EOS>
well
knowing
that
Mr
Pancks
,
if
he
failed
in
his
present
research
,
was
pretty

to
find

.
   
<EOS>
He
,

,

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
Throughout

.
 
<EOS>
Knots

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Throughout

,
Mr

's

?

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

between
us
hush
,
for
Arthur
's
sake
<EOS>
I
will
always
be
a
friend
to
you
my
dear
girl
and
in
Arthur
's
name
you
may
always
rely
upon
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
nimble
fingers
laid
aside
the
work
,
and
the
little
figure
rose
and
kissed
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
cold
,
"
said
Flora
,
changing
to
her
own
natural
kind
-
hearted
manner
,
and
gaining
greatly
by
the
change
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
work
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
are
not
well
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
are
not
strong
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
only
that
I
feel
a
little

by
your
kindness
,
and
by
Mr
Clennam
's
kindness
in
confiding
me
to
one
he
has
known
and
loved
so
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
really
my
dear
,
"
said
Flora
,
who
had
a
decided
tendency
to
be
always
honest
when
she
gave
herself
time
to
think
about
it
,
"
it
's
as
well
to
leave
that
alone
now
,
for
I
could
n't
undertake
to
say
after
all
,
but
it
does
n't
signify
lie
down
a
little
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
been
strong
enough
to
do
what
I
want
to
do
,
and
I
shall
be
quite
well
directly
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
,
with
a
faint
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
overpowered
me
with
gratitude
,
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
keep
near
the
window
for
a
moment
I
shall
be
quite
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Flora
opened
a
window
,
sat
her
in
a
chair
by
it
,
and
considerately
retired
to
her
former
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
windy
day
,
and
the
air
stirring
on
Little
Dorrit
's
face
soon
brightened
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
very
few
minutes
she
returned
to
her
basket
of
work
,
and
her
nimble
fingers
were
as
nimble
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Quietly
pursuing
her
task
,
she
asked
Flora
if
Mr
Clennam
had
told
her
where
she
lived
?
 
<EOS>
When
Flora
replied
in
the
negative
,
Little
Dorrit
said
that
she
understood
why
he
had
been
so
delicate
,
but
that
she
felt
sure
he
would
approve
of
her
confiding
her
secret
to
Flora
,
and
that
she
would
therefore
do
so
now
with
Flora
's
permission
.
 
<EOS>
Receiving
an
encouraging
answer
,
she
condensed
the
narrative
of
her
life
into
a
few
scanty
words
about
herself
and
a
glowing
eulogy
upon
her
father
;
and
Flora
took
it
all
in
with
a
natural
tenderness
that
quite
understood
it
,
and
in
which
there
was
no
incoherence
.
   
<EOS>
When
dinner
-
time
came
,
Flora
drew
the
arm
of
her
new
charge
through
hers
,
and
led
her
down
-
stairs
,
and
presented
her
to
the
Patriarch
and
Mr
Pancks
,
who
were
already
in
the
dining
-
room
waiting
to
begin
.
 
<EOS>
(
Mr
F
's
Aunt
was
,
for
the
time
,
laid
up
in
ordinary
in
her
chamber
.
)
<EOS>
By
those
gentlemen
she
was
received
according
to
their
characters
;
the
Patriarch
appearing
to
do
her
some
inestimable
service
in
saying
that
he
was
glad
to
see
her
,
glad
to
see
her
;
and
Mr
Pancks
blowing
off
his
favourite
sound
as
a

.
   
<EOS>
In
that
new
presence
she
would
have
been
bashful
enough
under
any

,
and
particularly
under
Flora
's
insisting
on
her
drinking
a
glass
of
wine
and
eating
of
the
best
that
was
there
;
but
her
constraint
was
greatly
increased
by
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
The

of
that
gentleman
at
first
suggested
to
her
mind
that
he
might
be
a
taker
of
likenesses
,
so
intently

look
at

,
and
so
frequently

he
glance
at
the
little
note
-
book
by

.
<EOS>
Observing
that
he
made

,

,
and
that
he

only
,
she

that

represented
some

of
her
father
's
,
the
balance
due
to
whom
was
noted
in
that
pocket
volume
.
 
<EOS>
Regarded
from
this
point
of
view
Mr
Pancks
's
puffings
expressed
injury
and
impatience
,
and
each
of
his
louder

became
a
demand
for
payment
.
   
<EOS>
But
here

was
undeceived
by

Mr

himself
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
left
the
table
half

,
and
was

.
 
<EOS>
Flora
had
"
gone
to
lie

"
in

,
concurrently
with
which

a

of
something
to

had
broken

in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
Patriarch
was
fast

,
with
his
philanthropic
mouth
open
under
a
yellow
pocket

in

.
 
<EOS>
At

,
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Find

,

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
No
,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Busy
,

,
"
observed

,

<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
   
"
Handkerchiefs
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Shall

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Little

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
"
<EOS>
He

that

,

<EOS>
"
Years

,

?
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
But

?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
.
<EOS>
Hallo
!
"
<EOS>
looking

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

with

?
 
<EOS>
It
's

!
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Why

,

!
"
<EOS>
Her

were

<EOS>
His

on

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

,

"

!
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
He

,
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Deuce
a

!
"
<EOS>
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

's

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

worth
?
 
<EOS>
You
shall
live
to
see
,
Miss
Dorrit
.
"
   
<EOS>
Releasing

,

hair
,

and

,
"
Remember

,
Miss
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
You
shall
live
to
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
could
not

showing
that
she

much

,
if

knowing

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
That
's

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
More

,

<EOS>
"
Not

,
"
said

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

.
 
<EOS>
Never

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
nobody
.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
Take

.
 
<EOS>
Will

,
Miss

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because

.
 
<EOS>
Pancks
the

.
 
<EOS>
I

so

of

,

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
I

you

.
 
<EOS>
Is

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Agreed

---

---

---
"
   
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
no
loss
<EOS>
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

think
,
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Pancks

at

<EOS>
---
he

---

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Is

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye

,
"
faltered

,
whom

greatly
confused
<EOS>
,
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
glanced
at
the
wall
of
the
adjoining
room
,
and
stooped

.
 
<EOS>
"
Honest
creature
,
woman
of
capital
points
,
but
heedless
and
a

,
Miss
Dorrit
.
"
 
With
that
he
rubbed
his
hands
as
if
the
interview
had
been
very
satisfactory
to
him
,
panted
away
to
the
door
,
and
urbanely
nodded
himself
out
again
.
   
<EOS>
If
Little
Dorrit
were
beyond
measure
perplexed
by
this
curious
conduct
on
the
part
of
her
new
acquaintance
,
and
by
finding
herself
involved
in
this
singular
treaty
,
her
perplexity
was
not
diminished
by
ensuing
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
that
Mr
Pancks
took
every
opportunity
afforded
him
in
Mr
Casby
's
house
of
significantly
glancing
at
her
and
snorting
at
her
---
which
was
not
much
,
after
what
he
had
done
already
---
he
began
to
pervade
her
daily
life
.
 
<EOS>
She
saw
him
in
the
street
,
constantly
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
went
to
Mr
Casby
's
,
he
was
always
there
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
went
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
,
he
came
there
on
any
pretence
,
as
if
to
keep
her
in
his
sight
.
 
<EOS>
A
week
had
not
gone
by
,
when
she
found
him
to
her
astonishment
in
the
Lodge
one
night
,
conversing
with
the
turnkey
on
duty
,
and
to
all
appearance
one
of
his
familiar
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Her
next
surprise
was
to
find
him
equally
at
his
ease
within
the
prison
;
to
hear
of
his
presenting
himself
among
the
visitors
at
her
father
's
Sunday
levee
;
to
see
him
arm
in
arm
with
a
Collegiate
friend
about
the
yard
;
to
learn
,
from
Fame
,
that
he
had
greatly
distinguished
himself
one
evening
at
the
social
club
that
held
its
meetings
in
the
Snuggery
,
by
addressing
a
speech
to
the
members
of
the
institution
,
singing
a
song
,
and
treating
the
company
to
five
gallons
of
ale
---
report
madly
added
a
bushel
of
shrimps
.
 
<EOS>
The
effect
on
Mr
Plornish
of
such
of
these
phenomena
as
he
became
an
eye
-
witness
of
in
his
faithful
visits
,
made
an
impression
on
Little
Dorrit
only
second
to
that
produced
by
the
phenomena
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
gag
and
bind
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
only
stare
,
and
sometimes
weakly
mutter
that
it
would
n't
be
believed
down
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
that
this
was
Pancks
;
but
he
never
said
a
word
more
,
or
made
a
sign
more
,
even
to
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
crowned
his
mysteries
by
making
himself
acquainted
with
Tip
in
some
unknown
manner
,
and
taking
a
Sunday
saunter
into
the
College
on
that
gentleman
's
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Throughout
he
never
took
any
notice
of
Little
Dorrit
,
save
once
or
twice
when
he
happened
to
come
close
to
her
<EOS>
and
there
was
no
one
very
near
;
<EOS>
on
which
occasions
,
he
said
in
passing
,
with
a
friendly
look
and
a
puff
of
encouragement
,
"
Pancks
the
gipsy
---
fortune
-
telling
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
worked
and
strove
as
usual
,
wondering
at
all
this
,
but
keeping
her
wonder
,
as
she
had
from
her
earliest
years
kept
many
heavier
loads
,
in
her
own
breast
.
 
<EOS>
A
change
had
stolen
,
and
was
stealing
yet
,
over
the
patient
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Every
day
found
her
something
more
retiring
than
the
day
before
.
 
<EOS>
To
pass
in
and
out
of
the
prison
unnoticed
,
and
elsewhere
to
be
overlooked
and
forgotten
,
were
,
for
herself
,
her
chief
desires
.
   
<EOS>
To
her
own
room
too
,
strangely
assorted
room
for
her
delicate
youth
and
character
,
she
was
glad
to
retreat
as
often
as
she
could
without
desertion
of
any
duty
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
afternoon
times
when
she
was
unemployed
,
when
visitors
dropped
in
to
play
a
hand
at
cards
with
her
father
,
when
she
could
be
spared
and
was
better
away
.
<EOS>
Then
she
would
flit
along
the
yard
,
climb
the
scores
of
stairs
that
led
to
her
room
,
and
take
her
seat
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
Many
combinations
did
those
spikes
upon
the
wall
assume
,
many
light
shapes
did
the
strong
iron
weave
itself
into
<EOS>
,
many
golden
touches
fell
upon
the
rust
,
while
Little
Dorrit
sat
there
musing
.
 
<EOS>
New
zigzags
sprung
into
the
cruel
pattern
sometimes
,
when
she
saw
it
through
a
burst
of
tears
;
but
beautified
or
hardened
still
,
always
over
it
and
under
it
and
through
it
,
she
was
fain
to
look
in
her
solitude
,
seeing
everything
with
that
ineffaceable
brand
.
   
<EOS>
A
garret
,
and
a
Marshalsea
garret
without
compromise
,
was
Little
Dorrit
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
Beautifully
kept
,
it
was
ugly
in
itself
,
and
had
little
but
cleanliness
and
air
to
set
it
off
;
for
what
embellishment
she
had
ever
been
able
to
buy
,
had
gone
to
her
father
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
for
this
poor
place
she
showed
an
increasing
love
;
and
to
sit
in
it
alone
became
her
favourite
rest
.
   
<EOS>
Insomuch
,
that
on
a
certain
afternoon
during
the
Pancks

,
when
she
was
seated
at
her
window
,
and
heard
Maggy
's
well

known
step
coming
up

stairs
,
she
was
very
much
disturbed
by
the

of
being

.
 
<EOS>
As
Maggy
's
step
came
higher
up
and
nearer
,
she

and

;
and
it
was
as

she

when
Maggy
at

.
   
<EOS>
"
Please
,
Little
Mother
,
"
said

,
panting

"
you
must
come

and
see

.
 
<EOS>
He
's
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
,
o
'

Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
See
!
 
<EOS>
I

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
Say
,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"
said

,
"
to

away
,
neither
!
"
   
<EOS>
Maggy
was
very

to

slights
,
and
very

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Putting
both

afore

face
too
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
ca
n't

,

her
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

"

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

of

her

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

,

all

to

,
and
,
<EOS>
at

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>
Her
great
staring
child
tenderly

her
;
and
having

,
and

(
offices

)

her

,
exulted

brighter

,

.
 
<EOS>
Over

chair
,
Maggy
,
with

that
were
not
at

,
dragged
the
box
which
was
her
seat
on
story

,
sat
down

,
hugged
her
own

,
and
said
,
with
a

for

,
and
with

:
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Little
Mother
,
let
's
have
a
good
'
un
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

about
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

's

a
princess
,
"
said

,
"
and
let
her
be
a
reg'lar
one
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
all
belief
,
you
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
considered
for
a

;
and

,
which
was

,

:
   
"
Maggy
,

,

,

<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

---
"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Plenty

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Plenty

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
"

,

<EOS>
"
Was

prime
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
King
had
a
daughter
,

Princess

.
 
<EOS>
When

;

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

Palace
where

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

This

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

(

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

,
and
nobody
for
her
to
look
at
,
so
she
went
in
at
once
to
search
for
the
treasured
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
sign
of
it
to
be
found
anywhere
;
and
then
she
knew
that
the
tiny
woman
had
told
her
the
truth
,
and
that
it
would
never
give
anybody
any
trouble
,
and
that
it
had
sunk
quietly
into
her
own
grave
,
and
that
she
and
it
were
at
rest
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
,
Maggy
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
sunset
flush
was
so
bright
on
Little
Dorrit
's
face
when
she
came
thus
to
the
end
of
her
story
,
that
she
interposed
her
hand
to
shade
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Had
she
got
to
be
old
?
"
<EOS>
Maggy
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
tiny
woman
?
"
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
would
have
been
just
the
same
if
she
had
been
ever
so
old
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
it
raly
!
"
said
Maggy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
suppose
it
would
though
.
"
<EOS>
And
sat
staring
and
ruminating
.
   
<EOS>
She
sat
so
long
with
her
eyes
wide
open
,
that
at
length
Little
Dorrit
,
to
entice
her
from
her
box
,
rose
and
looked
out
of
window
.
<EOS>
As
she
glanced
down
into
the
yard
,
she
saw
Pancks
come
in
and
leer
up
with
the
corner
of
his
eye
as
he
went
by
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
's
he
,
Little
Mother
?
"
said
Maggy
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
joined
her
at
the
window
and
was
leaning
on
her
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
come
in
and
out
often
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
him
called
a
fortune
-
teller
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
doubt
if
he
could
tell
many
people
even
their
past
or
present
fortunes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
n't
have
told
the
Princess
hers
?
"
said
Maggy
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
looking
musingly
down
into
the
dark
valley
of
the
prison
,
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
the
tiny
woman
hers
?
"
said
Maggy
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
with
the
sunset
very
bright
upon
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
let
us
come
away
from
the
window
.
"
    
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Conspirators
and
Others
 
<EOS>
The
private
residence
of
Mr
Pancks
was
in
Pentonville
,
where
he
lodged
on
the
second
-
floor
of
a
professional
gentleman
in
an
extremely
small
way
,
who
had
an
inner
-
door
within
the
street
door
,
poised
on
a
spring
and
starting
open
with
a
click
like
a
trap
;
and
who
wrote
up
in
the
fan
-
light
,
Rugg
,
general
agent
,
accountant
,
debts
recovered
.
   
<EOS>
This
scroll
,
majestic
in
its
severe
simplicity
,
illuminated
a
little
slip
of
front
garden
abutting
on
the
thirsty
high
-
road
,
where
a
few
of
the
dustiest
of
leaves
hung
their
dismal
heads
and
led
a
life
of
choking
.
 
<EOS>
A
professor
of
writing
occupied
the
first
-
floor
,
and
enlivened
the
garden
railings
with
glass
-
cases
containing
choice
examples
of
what
his
pupils
had
been
before
six
lessons
and
while
the
whole
of
his
young
family
shook
the
table
,
and
what
they
had
become
after
six
lessons
when
the
young
family
was
under
restraint
.
 
<EOS>
The
tenancy
of
Mr
Pancks
was
limited
to
one
airy
bedroom
;
he
covenanting
and
agreeing
with
Mr
Rugg
his
landlord
,
that
in
consideration
of
a
certain
scale
of
payments
accurately
defined
,
and
on
certain
verbal
notice
duly
given
,
he
should
be
at
liberty
to
elect
to
share
the
Sunday
breakfast
,
dinner
,
tea
,
or
supper
,
or
each
or
any
or
all
of
those
repasts
or
meals
of
Mr
and
Miss
Rugg
(
his
daughter
)
in
the
back
-
parlour
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Rugg
was
a
lady
of
a
little
property
which
she
had
acquired
,
together
with
much
distinction
in
the
neighbourhood
,
by
having
her
heart
severely
lacerated
and
<EOS>
her
feelings
mangled
by
a
middle
-
aged
baker
resident
in
the
vicinity
,
against
whom
she
had
,
by
the
agency
of
Mr
Rugg
,
found
it
necessary
to
proceed
at
law
to
recover
damages
for
a
breach
of
promise
of
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
The
baker
having
been
,
by
the
counsel
for
Miss
Rugg
,
witheringly
denounced
on
that
occasion
up
to
the
full
amount
of
twenty
guineas
,
at
the
rate
of
about
eighteen
-
pence
an
epithet
,
and
having
been
cast
in
corresponding
damages
,
still
suffered
occasional
persecution
from
the
youth
of
Pentonville
.
 
<EOS>
But
Miss
Rugg
,
environed
by
the
majesty
of
the
law
,
and
having
her
damages
invested
in
the
public
securities
,
was
regarded
with
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
society
of
Mr
Rugg
,
who
had
a
round
white
visage
,
as
if
all
his
blushes
had
been
drawn
out
of
him
long
ago
,
and
who
had
a
ragged
yellow
head
like
a
worn
-
out
hearth
broom
;
and
in
the
society
of
Miss
Rugg
,
who
had
little
nankeen
spots
,
like
shirt
buttons
,
all
over
her
face
,
and
whose
own
yellow
tresses
were
rather
scrubby
than
luxuriant
;
Mr
Pancks
had
usually
dined
on
Sundays
for
some
few
years
,
and
had
twice
a
week
,
or
so
,
enjoyed
an
evening
collation
of
bread
,
Dutch
cheese
,
and
porter
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
one
of
the
very
few
marriageable
men
for
whom
Miss
Rugg
had
no
terrors
,
the
argument
with
which
he
reassured
himself
being
twofold
;
that
is
to
say
,
firstly
,
"
that
it
would
n't
do
twice
,
"
and
secondly
,
"
that
he
was
n't
worth
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Fortified
within
this
double
armour
,
Mr
Pancks
snorted
at
Miss
Rugg
on
easy
terms
.
   
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
,
Mr
Pancks
had
transacted
little
or
no
business
at
his
quarters
in
Pentonville
,
except
in
the
sleeping
line
;
but
now
that
he
had
become
a
fortune
-
teller
,
he
was
often
closeted
after
midnight
with
Mr
Rugg
in
his
little
front
-
parlour
office
,
and
even
after
those
untimely
hours
,
burnt
tallow
in
his
bed
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Though
his
duties
as
his
proprietor
's
grubber
were
in
no
wise
lessened
;
and
though
that
service
bore
no
greater
resemblance
to
a
bed
of
roses
than
was
to
be
discovered
in
its
many
thorns
;
some
new
branch
of
industry
made
a
constant
demand
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
cast
off
the
Patriarch
at
night
,
it
was
only
to
take
an
anonymous
craft
in
tow
,
and
labour
away
afresh
in
other
waters
.
   
<EOS>
The
advance
from
a
personal
acquaintance
with
the
elder
Mr
Chivery
to
an
introduction
to
his
amiable
wife
and
disconsolate
son
,
may
have
been
easy
;
but
easy
or
not
,
Mr
Pancks
soon
made
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
nestled
in
the
bosom
of
the
tobacco
business
within
a
week
or
two
after
his
first
appearance
in
the
College
,
and
particularly
addressed
himself
to
the
cultivation
of
a
good
understanding
with
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
endeavour
he
so
prospered
as
to
lure
that
pining
shepherd
forth
from
the
groves
,
and
tempt
him
to
undertake
mysterious
missions
;
on
which
he
began
to
disappear
at
uncertain
intervals
for
as
long
a
space
as
two
or
three
days
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
prudent
Mrs
Chivery
,
who
wondered
greatly
at
this
change
,
would
have
protested
against
it
as
detrimental
to
the
Highland
typification
on
the
doorpost
but
for
two
forcible
reasons
;
one
,
that
her
John
was
roused
to
take
strong
interest
in
the
business
which
these
starts
were
supposed
to
advance
---
and
this
she
held
to
be
good
for
his
drooping
spirits
;
the
other
,
that
Mr
Pancks
confidentially
agreed
to
pay
her
,
for
the
occupation
of
her
son
's
time
,
at
the
handsome
rate
of
seven
and
sixpence
per
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
proposal
originated
with
himself
,
and
was
couched
in
the
pithy
terms
,
"
If
your
John
is
weak
enough
,
ma'am
,
not
to
take
it
,
that
is
no
reason
why
you
should
be
,
do
n't
you
see
?
 
<EOS>
So
,
quite
between
ourselves
,
ma'am
,
business
being
business
,
here
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
What
Mr
Chivery
thought
of
these
things
,
or
how
much
or
how
little
he
knew
about
them
,
was
never
gathered
from
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
already
remarked
that
he
was
a
man
of
few
words
;
and
it
may
be
here
observed
that
he
had
imbibed
a
professional
habit
of
locking
everything
up
.
 
<EOS>
He
locked
himself
up
as
carefully
as
he
locked
up
the
Marshalsea
debtors
.
 
<EOS>
Even
his
custom
of
bolting
his
meals
may
have
been
a
part
of
an
uniform
whole
;
but
there
is
no
question
,
that
,
as
to
all
other
purposes
,
he
kept
his
mouth
as
he
kept
the
Marshalsea
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
opened
it
without
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
necessary
to
let
anything
out
,
he
opened
it
a
little
way
,
held
it
open
just
as
long
as
sufficed
for
the
purpose
,
and
locked
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
Even
as
he
would
be
sparing
of
his
trouble
at
the
Marshalsea
door
,
and
would
keep
a
visitor
who
wanted
to
go
out
,
waiting
for
a
few
moments
if
he
saw
another
visitor
coming
down
the
yard
,
so
that
one
turn
of
the
key
should
suffice
for
both
,
similarly
he
would
often
reserve
a
remark
if
he
perceived
another
on
its
way
to
his
lips
,
and
would
deliver
himself
of
the
two
together
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
any
key
to
his
inner
knowledge
being
to
be
found
in
his
face
,
the
Marshalsea
key
was
as
legible
as
an
index
to
the
individual
characters
and
histories
upon
which
it
was
turned
.
   
<EOS>
That
Mr
Pancks
should
be
moved
to
invite
any
one
to
dinner
at
Pentonville
,
was
an
unprecedented
fact
in
his
calendar
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
invited
Young
John
to
dinner
,
and
even
brought
him
within
range
of
the
dangerous
(
because
expensive
)
fascinations
of
Miss
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
The
banquet
was
appointed
for
a
Sunday
,
and
Miss
Rugg
with
her
own
hands
stuffed
a
leg
of
mutton
with
oysters
on
the
occasion
,
and
sent
it
to
the
baker
's
---
not
THE
baker
's
but
an
opposition
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
Provision
of
oranges
,
apples
,
and
nuts
was
also
made
.
 
<EOS>
And
rum
was
brought
home
by
Mr
Pancks
on
Saturday
night
,
to
gladden
the
visitor
's
heart
.
<EOS>
The
store
of
creature
comforts
was
not
the
chief
part
of
the
visitor
's
reception
.
 
<EOS>
Its
special
feature
was
a
foregone
family
confidence
and
sympathy
.
 
<EOS>
When
Young
John
appeared
at
half
-
past
one
without
the
ivory
hand
and
waistcoat
of
golden
sprigs
,
the
sun
shorn
of
his
beams
by
disastrous
clouds
,
Mr
Pancks
presented
him
to
the
yellow
-
haired
Ruggs
as
the
young
man
he
had
so
often
mentioned
who
loved
Miss
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
challenging
him
specially
in
that
character
,
"
to
have
the
distinguished
gratification
of
making
your
acquaintance
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Your
feelings
do
you
honour
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
young
;
may
you
never
outlive
your
feelings
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
to
outlive
my
own
feelings
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
who
was
a
man
of
many
words
,
and
was
considered
to
possess
a
remarkably
good
address
;
"
if
I
was
to
outlive
my
own
feelings
,
I
'd
leave
fifty
pound
in
my
will
to
the
man
who
would
put
me
out
of
existence
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Rugg
heaved
a
sigh
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anastatia
,
you
are
no
stranger
to
the
state
of
this
young
man
's
affections
.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
has
had
her
trials
,
sir
"
---
Mr
Rugg
might
have
used
the
word
more
pointedly
in
the
singular
number
---
"
and
she
can
feel
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
,
almost
overwhelmed
by
the
touching
nature
of
this
greeting
,
professed
himself
to
that
effect
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
I
envy
you
,
sir
,
is
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
"
allow
me
to
take
your
hat
---
we
are
rather
short
of
pegs
---
I
'll
put
it
in
the
corner
,
nobody
will
tread
on
it
there
---
<EOS>
What
I
envy
you
,
sir
,
is
the
luxury
of
your
own
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
I
belong
to
a
profession
in
which
that
luxury
is
sometimes
denied
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
replied
,
with
acknowledgments
,
that
he
only
hoped
he
did
what
was
right
,
and
what
showed
how
entirely
he
was
devoted
to
Miss
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
He
wished
to
be
unselfish
;
and
he
hoped
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
wished
to
do
anything
as
laid
in
his
power
to
serve
Miss
Dorrit
,
altogether
putting
himself
out
of
sight
;
and
he
hoped
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
<EOS>
little
that
he
could
do
,
but
he
hoped
he
did
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
taking
him
by
the
hand
,
"
you
are
a
young
man
that
it
does
one
good
to
come
across
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
young
man
that
I
should
like
to
put
in
the
witness
-
box
,
to
humanise
the
minds
of
the
legal
profession
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
brought
your
appetite
with
you
,
and
intend
to
play
a
good
knife
and
fork
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
Young
John
,
"
I
do
n't
eat
much
at
present
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
drew
him
a
little
apart
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
's
case
,
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
at
the
time
when
,
in
vindication
of
her
outraged
feelings
and
her
sex
,
she
became
the
plaintiff
in
Rugg
and
Bawkins
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
could
have
put
it
in
evidence
,
Mr
Chivery
,
if
I
had
thought
it
worth
my
while
,
that
the
amount
of
solid
sustenance
my
daughter
consumed
at
that
period
did
not
exceed
ten
ounces
per
week
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
go
a
little
beyond
that
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
other
,
hesitating
,
as
if
he
confessed
it
with
some
shame
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
in
your
case
there
's
no
fiend
in
human
form
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
with
argumentative
smile
and
action
of
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Observe
,
Mr
Chivery
!
   
<EOS>
No
fiend
in
human
form
!
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
certainly
,
"
Young
John
added
with
simplicity
,
"
I
should
be
very
sorry
if
there
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
sentiment
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
"
is
what
I
should
have
expected
from
your
known
principles
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
affect
my
daughter
greatly
,
sir
,
if
she
heard
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
perceive
the
mutton
,
I
am
glad
she
did
n't
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
on
this
occasion
,
pray
face
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
face
Mr
Chivery
.
 
<EOS>
For
what
we
are
going
to
receive
,
may
we
(
and
Miss
Dorrit
)
be
truly
thankful
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
for
a
grave
waggishness
in
Mr
Rugg
's
manner
of
delivering
this
introduction
to
the
feast
,
it
might
have
appeared
that
Miss
Dorrit
was
expected
to
be
one
of
the
company
.
 
<EOS>
Pancks
recognised
the
sally
in
his
usual
way
,
and
took
in
his
provender
in
his
usual
way
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Rugg
,
perhaps
making
up
some
of
her
arrears
,
likewise
took
very
kindly
to
the
mutton
,
and
it
rapidly
diminished
to
the
bone
.
 
<EOS>
A
bread
-
and
-
butter
pudding
entirely
disappeared
,
and
a
considerable
amount
of
cheese
and
radishes
vanished
by
the
same
means
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
dessert
.
   
<EOS>
Then
also
,
and
before
the
broaching
of
the
rum
and
water
,
came
Mr
Pancks
's
note
-
book
.
 
<EOS>
The
ensuing
business
proceedings
were
brief
but
curious
,
and
rather
in
the
nature
of
a
conspiracy
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
looked
over
his
note
-
book
,
which
was
now
getting
full
,
studiously
;
and
picked
out
little
extracts
,
which
he
wrote
on
separate
slips
of
paper
on
the
table
;
Mr
Rugg
,
in
the
meanwhile
,
looking
at
him
with
close
attention
,
and
Young
John
losing
his
uncollected
eye
in
mists
of
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Pancks
,
who
supported
the
character
of
chief
conspirator
,
had
completed
his
extracts
,
he
looked
them
over
,
corrected
them
,
put
up
his
note
-
book
,
and
held
them
like
a
hand
at
cards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
there
's
a
churchyard
in
Bedfordshire
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
takes
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
it
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Rugg
,
"
if
no
one
bids
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
dealt
him
his
card
,
and
looked
at
his
hand
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
there
's
an
Enquiry
in
York
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
takes
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
good
for
York
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
perhaps
,
"
pursued
Pancks
,
"
you
'll
be
so
obliging
,
John
Chivery
?
"
 
<EOS>
Young
John
assenting
<EOS>
,
Pancks
dealt
him
his
card
,
and
consulted
his
hand
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
Church
in
London
;
I
may
as
well
take
that
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
Family
Bible
<EOS>
;
I
may
as
well
take
that
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
two
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Two
to
me
,
"
repeated
Pancks
,
breathing
hard
over
his
cards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
Clerk
at
Durham
for
you
,
John
,
and
an
old
seafaring
gentleman
at
Dunstable
for
you
,
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
Two
to
me
,
was
it
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
two
to
me
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
Stone
;
three
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
Still
-
born
Baby
;
four
to
me
.
<EOS>
And
all
,
for
the
present
,
told
.
<EOS>
"
When
he
had
thus
disposed
of
his
cards
,
all
being
done
very
quietly
and
in
a
suppressed
tone
,
Mr
Pancks
puffed
his
way
into
his
own
breast
-
pocket
and
tugged
out
a
canvas
bag
;
from
which
,
with
a
sparing
hand
,
he
told
forth
money
for
travelling
expenses
in
two
little
portions
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cash
goes
out
fast
,
"
he
said
anxiously
,
as
he
pushed
a
portion
to
each
of
his
male
companions
,
"
very
fast
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
assure
you
,
Mr
Pancks
,
"
said
Young
John
,
"
that
I
deeply
regret
my
circumstances
being
such
that
I
ca
n't
afford
to
pay
my
own
charges
,
or
that
it
's
not
advisable
to
allow
me
the
time
necessary
for
my
doing
the
distances
on
foot
;
because
nothing
would
give
me
greater
satisfaction
than
to
walk
myself
off
my
legs
without
fee
or
reward
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
young
man
's
disinterestedness
appeared
so
very
ludicrous
in
the
eyes
of
Miss
Rugg
,
that
she
was
obliged
to
effect
a
precipitate
retirement
from
the
company
,
and
to
sit
upon
the
stairs
until
she
had
had
her
laugh
out
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Mr
Pancks
,
looking
,
not
without
some
pity
,
at
Young
John
,
slowly
and
thoughtfully
twisted
up
his
canvas
bag
as
if
he
were
wringing
its
neck
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
,
returning
as
he
restored
it
to
his
pocket
,
mixed
rum
and
water
for
the
party
,
not
forgetting
her
fair
self
,
and
handed
to
every
one
his
glass
.
<EOS>
When
all
were
supplied
,
Mr
Rugg
rose
,
and
silently
holding
out
his
glass
at
arm
's
length
above
the
centre
of
the
table
,
by
that
gesture
<EOS>
invited
the
other
three
to
add
theirs
,
and
to
unite
in
a
general
conspiratorial
clink
.
 
<EOS>
The
ceremony
was
effective
up
to
a
certain
point
,
and
would
have
been
wholly
so
throughout
,
if
Miss
Rugg
,
as
she
raised
her
glass
to
her
lips
in
completion
of
it
,
had
not
happened
to
look
at
Young
John
;
when
she
was
again
<EOS>
so
overcome
by
the
contemptible
comicality
of
his
disinterestedness
as
to
splutter
some
ambrosial
drops
of
rum
and
water
around
,
and
withdraw
in
confusion
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
dinner
without
precedent
,
given
by
Pancks
at
Pentonville
;
and
such
was
the
busy
and
strange
life
Pancks
led
.
<EOS>
The
only
waking
moments
at
which
he
appeared
to
relax
from
his
cares
,
and
to
recreate
himself
by
going
anywhere
or
saying
anything
without
a
pervading
object
,
were
when
he
showed
a
dawning
interest
in
the
lame
foreigner
with
the
stick
,
down
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
   
<EOS>
The
foreigner
,
by
name
John
Baptist
Cavalletto
---
they
called
him
Mr
Baptist
in
the
Yard
---
was
such
a
chirping
,
easy
,
hopeful
little
fellow
,
that
his
attraction
for
Pancks
was
probably
in
the
force
of
contrast
.
 
<EOS>
Solitary
,
weak
,
and
scantily
acquainted
with
the
most
necessary
words
of
the
only
language
in
which
he
could
communicate
with
the
people
about
him
<EOS>
,
he
went
with
the
stream
of
his
fortunes
,
in
a
brisk
way
that
was
new
in
those
parts
.
 
<EOS>
With
little
to
eat
,
and
less
to
drink
,
and
nothing
to
wear
but
what
he
wore
upon
him
,
or
had
brought
tied
up
in
one
of
the
smallest
bundles
that
ever
were
seen
,
he
put
as
bright
a
face
upon
it
as
if
he
were
in
the
most
flourishing
circumstances
when
he
first
hobbled
up
and
down
the
Yard
,
humbly
propitiating
the
general
good
-
will
with
his
white
teeth
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
uphill
work
for
a
foreigner
,
lame
or
sound
,
to
make
his
way
with
the
Bleeding
Hearts
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
they
were
vaguely
persuaded
that
every
foreigner
had
a
knife
about
him
;
in
the
second
,
they
held
it
to
be
a
sound
constitutional
national
axiom
that
he
ought
to
go
home
to
his
own
country
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
thought
of
inquiring
how
many
of
their
own
countrymen
would
be
returned
upon
their
hands
from
divers
parts
of
the
world
,
if
the
principle
were
generally
recognised
;
they
considered
it
particularly
and
peculiarly
British
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
third
place
,
they
had
a
notion
that
it
was
a
sort
of
Divine
visitation
upon
a
foreigner
that
he
was
not
an
Englishman
,
and
that
all
kinds
of
calamities
happened
to
his
country
because
it
did
things
that
England
did
not
,
and
did
not
do
things
that
England
did
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
belief
,
to
be
sure
,
they
had
long
been
carefully
trained
by
the
Barnacles
and
Stiltstalkings
,
who
were
always
proclaiming
to
them
,
officially
,
that
no
country
which
failed
to
submit
itself
to
those
two
large
families
could
possibly
hope
to
be
under
the
protection
of
Providence
;
and
who
,
when
they
believed
it
,
disparaged
them
in
private
as
the
most
prejudiced
people
under
the
sun
.
   
<EOS>
This
,
therefore
,
might
be
called
a
political
position
of
the
Bleeding
Hearts
;
but
they
entertained
other
objections
to
having
foreigners
in
the
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
They
believed
that
foreigners
were
always
badly
off
;
and
though
they
were
as
ill
off
themselves
as
they
could
desire
to
be
,
that
did
not
diminish
the
force
of
the
objection
.
<EOS>
They
believed
that
foreigners
were
dragooned
and
bayoneted
;
and
though
they
certainly
got
their
own
skulls
promptly
fractured
if
they
showed
any
ill
-
humour
,
still
it
was
with
a
blunt
instrument
,
and
that
did
n't
count
.
 
<EOS>
They
believed
that
foreigners
were
always
immoral
;
and
though
they
had
an
occasional
assize
at
home
,
and
now
and
then
a
divorce
case
or
so
,
that
had
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
They
believed
that
foreigners
had
no
independent
spirit
,
as
never
being
escorted
to
the
poll
in
droves
by
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
,
with
colours
flying
and
the
tune
of
Rule
Britannia
playing
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
be
tedious
,
they
had
many
other
beliefs
of
a
similar
kind
.
   
<EOS>
Against
these
obstacles
,
the
lame
foreigner
with
the
stick
had
to
make
head
as
well
as
he
could
;
not
absolutely
single
-
handed
,
because
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
had
recommended
him
to
the
Plornishes
(
he
lived
at
the
top
of
the
same
house
)
,
but
still
at
heavy
odds
.
<EOS>
However
,
the
Bleeding
Hearts
were
kind
hearts
;
and
when
they
saw
the
little
fellow
cheerily
limping
about
with
a
good
-
humoured
face
,
doing
no
harm
,
drawing
no
knives
,
committing
no
outrageous
immoralities
,
living
chiefly
on
farinaceous
and
milk
diet
,
and
playing
with
Mrs
Plornish
's
children
of
an
evening
,
they
began
to
think
that
although
he
could
never
hope
to
be
an
Englishman
,
still
it
would
be
hard
to
visit
that
affliction
on
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
They
began
to
accommodate
themselves
to
his
level
,
calling
him
"
Mr
Baptist
,
"
but
treating
him
like
a
baby
,
and
laughing
immoderately
at
his
lively
gestures
and
his
childish
English
---
more
,
because
he
did
n't
mind
it
,
and
laughed
too
.
 
<EOS>
They
spoke
to
him
in
very
loud
voices
as
if
he
were
stone
deaf
.
 
<EOS>
They
constructed
sentences
,
by
way
of
teaching
him
the
language
in
its
purity
,
such
as
were
addressed
by
the
savages
to
Captain
Cook
,
or
by
Friday
to
Robinson
Crusoe
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
was
particularly
ingenious
in
this
art
;
and
attained
so
much
celebrity
for
saying
"
Me
ope
you
leg
well
soon
,
"
that
it
was
considered
in
the
Yard
but
a
very
short
remove
indeed
from
speaking
Italian
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Mrs
Plornish
herself
began
to
think
that
she
had
a
natural
call
towards
that
language
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
became
more
popular
,
household
objects
were
brought
into
requisition
for
his
instruction
in
a
copious
vocabulary
;
and
whenever
he
appeared
in
the
Yard
ladies
would
fly
out
at
their
doors
crying
"
Mr
Baptist
---
tea
-
pot
!
"
<EOS>
"
Mr
Baptist
---
dust
-
pan
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Baptist
---
flour
-
dredger
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Baptist
---
coffee
-
biggin
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
exhibiting
those
articles
,
and
penetrating
him
with
a
sense
of
the
appalling
difficulties
of
the
Anglo
-
Saxon
tongue
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
this
stage
of
his
progress
,
and
in
about
the
third
week
of
his
occupation
,
that
Mr
Pancks
's
fancy
became
attracted
by
the
little
man
.
 
<EOS>
Mounting
to
his
attic
,
attended
by
Mrs
Plornish
as
interpreter
,
he
found
Mr
Baptist
with
no
furniture
but
his
bed
on
the
ground
,
a
table
,
and
a
chair
,
carving
with
the
aid
of
a
few
simple
tools
,
in
the
blithest
way
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
old
chap
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
pay
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
his
money
ready
,
folded
in
a
scrap
of
paper
,
and
laughingly
handed
it
in
;
then
with
a
free
action
,
threw
out
as
many
fingers
of
his
right
hand
as
there
were
shillings
,
and
made
a
cut
crosswise
in
the
air
for
an
odd
sixpence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
watching
him
,
wonderingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
quick
customer
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
expect
to
receive
it
,
though
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
here
interposed
with
great
condescension
,
and
explained
to
Mr
Baptist
.
 
<EOS>
"
E
please
.
 
<EOS>
E
glad
get
money
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
smiled
and
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
His
bright
face
seemed
uncommonly
attractive
to
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
's
he
getting
on
in
his
limb
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
asked
Mrs
Plornish
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
's
a
deal
better
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
expect
next
week
he
'll
be
able
to
leave
off
his
stick
entirely
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
The
opportunity
being
too
favourable
to
be
lost
,
Mrs
Plornish
displayed
her
great
accomplishment
by
explaining
with
pardonable
pride
to
Mr
Baptist
,
"
E
ope
<EOS>
you
leg
well
soon
.
<EOS>
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
merry
fellow
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
admiring
him
as
if
he
were
a
mechanical
toy
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
does
he
live
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
he
turns
out
to
have
quite
a
power
of
carving
them
flowers
that
you
see
him
at
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Mr
Baptist
,
watching
their
faces
as
they
spoke
,
held
up
his
work
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
interpreted
in
her
Italian
manner
,
on
behalf
of
Mr
Pancks
,
"
E
please
.
 
<EOS>
Double
good
!
<EOS>
"
)
   
"
Can
he
live
by
that
?
"
asked
Mr
Pancks
.
<EOS>
"
He
can
live
on
very
little
,
sir
,
and
it
is
expected
as
he
will
be
able
,
in
time
,
to
make
a
very
good
living
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
got
it
him
to
do
,
and
gives
him
odd
jobs
besides
in
at
the
Works
next
door
---
makes
'em
for
him
,
in
short
,
when
he
knows
he
wants
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
does
he
do
with
himself
,
now
,
when
he
ai
n't
hard
at
it
?
"
said
Mr
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
not
much
as
yet
,
sir
,
on
accounts
I
suppose
of
not
being
able
to
walk
much
;
but
he
goes
about
the
Yard
,
and
he
chats
without
particular
understanding
or
being
understood
,
and
he
plays
with
the
children
,
and
he
sits
in
the
sun
<EOS>
---
he
'll
sit
down
anywhere
,
as
if
it
was
an
arm
-
chair
---
and
he
'll
sing
,
and
he
'll
laugh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Laugh
!
"
echoed
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
looks
to
me
as
if
every
tooth
in
his
head
was
always
laughing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
whenever
he
gets
to
the
top
of
the
steps
at
t'other
end
of
the
Yard
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
he
'll
peep
out
in
the
curiousest
way
!
<EOS>
So
that
some
of
us
thinks
he
's
peeping
out
towards
where
his
own
country
is
,
and
some
of
us
thinks
he
's
looking
for
somebody
he
do
n't
want
to
see
,
and
some
of
us
do
n't
know
what
to
think
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
seemed
to
have
a
general
understanding
of
what
she
said
;
or
perhaps
his
quickness
caught
and
applied
her
slight
action
of
peeping
.
 
<EOS>
In
any
case
he
closed
his
eyes
and
tossed
his
head
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
sufficient
reasons
for
what
he
did
,
and
said
in
his
own
tongue
,
it
did
n't
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Altro
!
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
Altro
?
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
sort
of
a
general
kind
of
expression
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
?
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
Altro
to
you
,
old
chap
.
 
<EOS>
Good
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
Altro
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
in
his
vivacious
way
repeating
the
word
several
times
<EOS>
,
Mr
Pancks
in
his
duller
way
gave
it
him
back
once
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
time
it
became
a
frequent
custom
with
Pancks
the
gipsy
,
as
he
went
home
jaded
at
night
,
to
pass
round
by
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
go
quietly
up
the
stairs
,
look
in
at
Mr
Baptist
's
door
,
and
,
finding
him
in
his
room
,
to
say
,
"
Hallo
,
old
chap
!
 
<EOS>
Altro
!
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Baptist
would
reply
with
innumerable
bright
nods
and
smiles
,
"
Altro
,
signore
,
altro
,
altro
,
altro
!
"
 
<EOS>
After
this
highly
condensed
conversation
,
Mr
Pancks
would
go
his
way
with
an
appearance
of
being
lightened
and
refreshed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
Nobody
's
State
of
Mind
 
<EOS>
If
Arthur
Clennam
had
not
arrived
at
that
wise
decision
firmly
to
restrain
himself
from
loving
Pet
,
he
would
have
lived
on
in
a
state
of
much
perplexity
,
involving
difficult
struggles
with
his
own
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
least
of
these
would
have
been
a
contention
,
always
waging
within
it
,
between
a
tendency
to
dislike
Mr
Henry
Gowan
,
if
not
to
regard
him
with
positive
repugnance
,
and
a
whisper
that
the
inclination
was
unworthy
.
 
<EOS>
A
generous
nature
is
not
prone
to
strong
aversions
,
and
is
slow
to
admit
them
even
dispassionately
;
but
when
it
finds
ill
-
will
gaining
upon
it
,
and
can
discern
between
-
whiles
that
its
origin
is
not
dispassionate
,
such
a
nature
becomes
distressed
.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
Mr
Henry
Gowan
would
have
clouded
Clennam
's
mind
,
and
would
have
been
far
oftener
present
to
it
than
more
agreeable
persons
and
subjects
but
for
the
great
prudence
of
his
decision
aforesaid
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Mr
Gowan
seemed
transferred
to
Daniel
Doyce
's
mind
;
at
all
events
,
it
so
happened
that
it
usually
fell
to
Mr
Doyce
's
turn
,
rather
than
to
Clennam
's
,
to
speak
of
him
in
the
friendly
conversations
they
held
together
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
of
frequent
occurrence
now
;
as
the
two
partners
shared
a
portion
of
a
roomy
house
in
one
of
the
grave
old
-
fashioned
City
streets
,
lying
not
far
from
the
Bank
of
England
,
by
London
Wall
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
had
been
to
Twickenham
to
pass
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
had
excused
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
was
just
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
in
his
head
at
the
door
of
Clennam
's
sitting
-
room
to
say
Good
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
come
in
!
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
you
were
reading
,
"
returned
Doyce
,
as
he
entered
,
"
and
thought
you
might
not
care
to
be
disturbed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
for
the
notable
resolution
he
had
made
,
Clennam
really
might
not
have
known
what
he
had
been
reading
;
really
might
not
have
had
his
eyes
upon
the
book
for
an
hour
past
,
though
it
lay
open
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
shut
it
up
,
rather
quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
they
well
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Doyce
;
"
they
are
well
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
all
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
Daniel
had
an
old
workmanlike
habit
of
carrying
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
in
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
it
out
and
wiped
his
forehead
with
it
,
slowly
repeating
,
"
They
are
all
well
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Minnie
looking
particularly
well
,
I
thought
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any
company
at
the
cottage
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
company
.
"
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
get
on
,
you
four
?
"
asked
Clennam
gaily
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
were
five
of
us
,
"
returned
his
partner
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
was
What's
-
his
-
name
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
there
.
"
<EOS>
"
Who
is
he
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Henry
Gowan
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Clennam
with
unusual
vivacity
,
"
Yes
!
---
<EOS>
I
forgot
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
I
mentioned
,
you
may
remember
,
"
said
Daniel
Doyce
,
"
he
is
always
there
on
Sunday
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
returned
Clennam
;
"
I
remember
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
,
still
wiping
his
forehead
,
ploddingly
repeated
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
there
,
he
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
he
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
And
his
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
there
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Meagles
is
quite
attached
to
---
the
---
dog
,
"
observed
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
"
assented
his
partner
.
 
<EOS>
"
More
attached
to
the
dog
than
I
am
to
the
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
Mr
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
Mr
Gowan
,
most
decidedly
,
"
said
Daniel
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
gap
in
the
conversation
,
which
Clennam
devoted
to
winding
up
his
watch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
are
a
little
hasty
in
your
judgment
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
judgments
---
I
am
supposing
a
general
case
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Of
course
,
"
said
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
so
liable
to
be
influenced
by
many
considerations
,
which
,
almost
without
our
knowing
it
,
are
unfair
,
that
it
is
necessary
to
keep
a
guard
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
For
instance
,
Mr
---
"
   
"
Gowan
,
"
quietly
said
Doyce
,
upon
whom
the
utterance
of
the
name
almost
always
devolved
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
young
and
handsome
,
easy
and
quick
,
has
talent
,
and
has
seen
a
good
deal
of
various
kinds
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
be
difficult
to
give
an
unselfish
reason
for
being
prepossessed
against
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
difficult
for
me
,
I
think
,
Clennam
,
"
returned
his
partner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
bringing
present
anxiety
,
and
,
I
fear
,
future
sorrow
,
into
my
old
friend
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
wearing
deeper
lines
into
my
old
friend
's
face
,
the
nearer
he
draws
to
,
and
the
oftener
he
looks
at
,
the
face
of
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
see
him
with
a
net
about
the
pretty
and
affectionate
creature
whom
he
will
never
make
happy
.
"
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Clennam
,
almost
in
the
tone
of
a
man
in
pain
,
"
that
he
will
not
make
her
happy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
know
,
"
returned
his
partner
,
"
that
the
earth
will
last
another
hundred
years
,
but
we
think
it
highly
probable
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Clennam
,
"
we
must
be
hopeful
,
and
we
must
at
least
try
to
be
,
if
not
generous
<EOS>
(
which
,
in
this
case
,
we
have
no
opportunity
of
being
)
,
just
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
not
disparage
this
gentleman
,
because
he
is
successful
in
his
addresses
to
the
beautiful
object
of
his
ambition
;
and
we
will
not
question
her
natural
right
to
bestow
her
love
on
one
whom
she
finds
worthy
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Maybe
,
my
friend
,
"
said
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
Maybe
also
,
that
she
is
too
young
and
petted
,
too
confiding
and
inexperienced
,
to
discriminate
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
would
be
far
beyond
our
power
of
correction
.
"
   
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
shook
his
head
gravely
,
and
rejoined
,
"
I
fear
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
in
a
word
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
we
should
make
up
our
minds
that
it
is
not
worthy
of
us
to
say
any
ill
of
Mr
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
poor
thing
to
gratify
a
prejudice
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
resolve
,
for
my
part
,
not
to
depreciate
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
so
sure
of
myself
,
and
therefore
I
reserve
my
privilege
of
objecting
to
him
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
if
I
am
not
sure
of
myself
,
I
am
sure
of
you
,
Clennam
,
and
I
know
what
an
upright
man
you
are
,
and
how
much
to
be
respected
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
MY
friend
and
partner
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
shook
his
hand
in
saying
this
,
as
if
there
had
been
something
serious
at
the
bottom
of
their
conversation
;
and
they
separated
.
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
visited
the
family
on
several
occasions
,
and
had
always
observed
that
even
a
passing
allusion
to
Mr
Henry
Gowan
when
he
was
not
among
them
,
brought
back
the
cloud
which
had
obscured
Mr
Meagles
's
sunshine
on
the
morning
of
the
chance
encounter
at
the
Ferry
.
 
<EOS>
If
Clennam
had
ever
admitted
the
forbidden
passion
into
his
breast
,
this
period
might
have
been
a
period
of
real
trial
;
under
the
actual
circumstances
,
doubtless
it
was
nothing
---
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
Equally
,
if
his
heart
had
given
entertainment
to
that
prohibited
guest
,
his
silent
fighting
of
his
way
through
the
mental
condition
of
this
period
might
have
been
a
little
meritorious
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
constant
effort
not
to
be
betrayed
into
a
new
phase
of
the
besetting
sin
of
his
experience
,
the
pursuit
of
selfish
objects
by
low
and
small
means
,
and
to
hold
instead
to
some
high
principle
of
honour
and
generosity
,
there
might
have
been
a
little
merit
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
resolution
not
even
to
avoid
Mr
Meagles
's
house
,
lest
,
in
the
selfish
sparing
of
himself
,
he
should
bring
any
slight
distress
upon
the
daughter
through
making
her
the
cause
of
an
estrangement
which
he
believed
the
father
would
regret
,
there
might
have
been
a
little
merit
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
modest
truthfulness
of
always
keeping
in
view
the
greater
equality
of
Mr
Gowan
's
years
and
the
greater
attractions
of
his
person
and
manner
,
there
might
have
been
a
little
merit
.
 
<EOS>
In
doing
all
this
and
much
more
,
in
a
perfectly
unaffected
way
and
with
a
manful
and
composed
constancy
,
while
the
pain
within
him
(
peculiar
as
his
life
and
history
)
was
very
sharp
,
there
might
have
been
some
quiet
strength
of
character
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
after
the
resolution
he
had
made
,
of
course
he
could
have
no
such
merits
as
these
;
and
such
a
state
of
mind
was
nobody
's
---
nobody
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
made
it
no
concern
of
his
whether
it
was
nobody
's
or
somebody
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
preserved
his
perfect
serenity
of
manner
on
all
occasions
,
as
if
the
possibility
of
Clennam
's
presuming
to
have
debated
the
great
question
were
too
distant
and
ridiculous
to
be
imagined
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
always
an
affability
to
bestow
on
Clennam
and
an
ease
to
treat
him
with
,
which
might
of
itself
(
in
the
supposititious
case
of
his
not
having
taken
that
sagacious
course
)
have
been
a
very
uncomfortable
element
in
his
state
of
mind
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
quite
regret
you
were
not
with
us
yesterday
,
"
said
Mr
Henry
Gowan
,
calling
on
Clennam
the
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
an
agreeable
day
up
the
river
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
he
had
heard
,
Arthur
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
your
partner
?
"
returned
Henry
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
dear
old
fellow
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
great
regard
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
Jove
,
he
is
the
finest
creature
!
"
said
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
fresh
,
so
green
,
trusts
in
such
wonderful
things
!
"
   
<EOS>
Here
was
one
of
the
many
little
rough
points
that
had
a
tendency
to
grate
on
Clennam
's
hearing
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
it
aside
by
merely
repeating
that
he
had
a
high
regard
for
Mr
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
charming
!
 
<EOS>
To
see
him
mooning
along
to
that
time
of
life
,
laying
down
nothing
by
the
way
and
picking
up
nothing
by
the
way
,
is
delightful
.
 
<EOS>
It
warms
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
So
unspoilt
,
so
simple
,
such
a
good
soul
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
life
Mr
Clennam
,
one
feels
desperately
worldly
and
wicked
in
comparison
with
such
an
innocent
creature
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
for
myself
,
let
me
add
,
without
including
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
genuine
also
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
for
the
compliment
,
"
said
Clennam
,
ill
at
ease
;
"
you
are
too
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
so
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
candid
with
you
,
tolerably
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
great
impostor
.
 
<EOS>
Buy
one
of
my
pictures
,
and
I
assure
you
,
in
confidence
,
it
will
not
be
worth
the
money
.
 
<EOS>
Buy
one
of
another
man
's
---
any
great
professor
who
beats
me

---
and
the
chances
are
that
the
more
you

,
the
more
he
'll
impose
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
do
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
All
painters
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Painters
,
writers
,
patriots
,
all
the
rest
who
have
stands
in
the
market
.
 
<EOS>
Give
almost
any
man
I
know
ten
pounds
,
and
he
will
impose
upon
you
to
a
corresponding
extent
;
a
thousand
pounds
---
to
a
corresponding
extent
;
ten
thousand
pounds
---
to
a
corresponding
extent
.
 
<EOS>
So
great
the
success
,
so
great
the
imposition
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
a
capital
world
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Gowan
with
warm

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
jolly
,
excellent
,
lovable
world
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
rather
thought
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
that
the
principle
you
mention
was
chiefly
acted
on
by
---
"
   
"
By
the
Barnacles
?
<EOS>
"
interrupted
Gowan
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
political
gentlemen
who
condescend
to
keep
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
hard
upon
the
Barnacles
,
"
said
Gowan
,
laughing
afresh
,
"
they
are
darling
fellows
!
 
<EOS>
Even
poor
little
Clarence
,
the
born

the
family
,

the
most

!
 
<EOS>
And

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
.
 
<EOS>
Very

,
"
said
Clennam
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
after
all
,
"
cried
Gowan
,
with
that
characteristic

of
his
which
reduced

to

same

,
"
though
I
ca
n't
deny
that
the
Circumlocution
Office
may
ultimately
shipwreck
everybody
and
everything
,
still
,
that
will
probably
not

in
our

---
and

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
very
dangerous
,

,
and
expensive
school
to

who
pay
to
keep
the
pupils
there
,
I
am

,
"
said
Clennam
,
shaking

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
terrible
fellow
,
"
returned
Gowan
,
airily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
understand
how
you
have
frightened
that
little
donkey
,
Clarence
,
the
most
estimable
of
moon
-
calves
(
I
really
love

)
nearly
out
of
his
wits
.
 
<EOS>
But
enough
of
him
,
and
of
all
the
rest
of

.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
present
you
to
my
mother
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
me
the
favour
to
give
me
the
opportunity
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
nobody
's
state
of
mind
,
there
was
nothing
Clennam
would
have
desired
less
,
or
would
have
been
more
at
a
loss
how

avoid
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
mother
lives
in
a
most
primitive

down
in
that
dreary
red
-
brick

at
Hampton
Court
,
"
said
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
If

would
make

,
suggest

own

for
permitting
me
to

there
to
dinner
,
you
would
be
bored
and
she
would
be
charmed
.
 
<EOS>
Really
that
's
the
state
of
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
What
could
Clennam
say
after
this
?
 
<EOS>
His
retiring
character
included
a
great
deal
that
was
simple
in
the
best
sense
,
because
unpractised
and
unused
;
and
in
his
simplicity
and
modesty
,
he
could
only
say
that
he
was
happy
to
place
himself
at
Mr
Gowan
's
disposal
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
he
said
it
,
and
the
day
was
fixed
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
dreaded
day
it
was
on
his
part
,
and
a
very
unwelcome
day
when
it
came
<EOS>
and
they
went
down
to
Hampton
Court
together
.
   
<EOS>
The
venerable
inhabitants
of
that
venerable
pile
seemed
,
in
those
times
,
to
be
encamped
there
like
a
sort
of
civilised
gipsies
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
temporary
air
about
their
establishments
,
as
if
they
were
going
away
the
moment
they
could
get
anything
better
;
there
was
also
a
dissatisfied
air
about
themselves
,
as
if
they
took
it
very
ill
that
they
had
not
already
got
something
much
better
.
<EOS>
Genteel
blinds
and
makeshifts
were
more
or
less
observable
as
soon
as
their
doors
were
opened
;
screens
not
half
high
enough
,
which
made
dining
-
rooms
out
of
arched
passages
,
and
warded
off
obscure
corners
where
footboys
slept
at
nights
with
their
heads
among
the
knives
and
forks
;
<EOS>
curtains
which
called
upon
you
to
believe
that
they
did
n't
hide
anything
;
panes
of
glass
which
requested
you
not
to
see
them
;
many
objects
of
various
forms
,
feigning
to
have
no
connection
with
their
guilty
secret
,
a
bed
;
disguised
traps
in
walls
,
which
were
clearly
coal
-
cellars
;
affectations
of
no
thoroughfares
,
which
were
evidently
doors
to
little
kitchens
.
<EOS>
Mental
reservations
and
artful
mysteries
grew
out
of
these
things
.
<EOS>
Callers
looking
steadily
into
the
eyes
of
their
receivers
,
pretended
not
to
smell
cooking
three
feet
off
;
people
,
confronting
closets
accidentally
left
open
,
pretended
not
to
see
bottles
;
visitors
with
their
heads
against
a
partition
of
thin
canvas
,
and
a
page
and
a
young
female
at
high
words
on
the
other
side
,
made
believe
to
be
sitting
in
a
primeval
silence
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
end
to
the
small
social
accommodation
-
bills
of
this
nature
which
the
gipsies
of
gentility
were
constantly
drawing
upon
,
and
accepting
for
,
one
another
.
   
<EOS>
Some
of
these
Bohemians
were
of
an
irritable
temperament
,
as
constantly
soured
and
vexed
by
two
mental
trials
:
<EOS>
the
first
,
the
consciousness
that
they
had
never
got
enough
out
of
the
public
;
the
second
,
the
consciousness
that
the
public
were
admitted
into
the
building
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
latter
great
wrong
,
a
few
suffered
dreadfully
---
particularly
on
Sundays
,
when
they
had
for
some
time
expected
the
earth
to
open
and
swallow
the
public
up
;
but
which
desirable
event
had
not
yet
occurred
,
in
consequence
of
some
reprehensible
laxity
in
the
arrangements
of
the
Universe
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
's
door
was
attended
by
a
family
servant
of
several
years
'
standing
,
who
had
his
own
crow
to
pluck
with
the
public
concerning
a
situation
in
the
Post
-
Office
which
he
had
been
for
some
time
expecting
,
and
to
which
he
was
not
yet
appointed
.
 
<EOS>
He
perfectly
knew
that
the
public
could
never
have
got
him
in
,
but
he
grimly
gratified
himself
with
the
idea
that
the
public
kept
him
out
.
<EOS>
Under
the
influence
of
this
injury
(
and
perhaps
of
some
little
straitness
and
irregularity
in
the
matter
of
wages
)
,
he
had
grown
neglectful
of
his
person
and
morose
in
mind
;
and
now
beholding
in
Clennam
one
of
the
degraded
body
of
his
oppressors
,
received
him
with
ignominy
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
,
however
,
received
him
with
condescension
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
her
a
courtly
old
lady
,
formerly
a
Beauty
,
and
still
sufficiently
well
-
favoured
to
have
dispensed
with
the
powder
on
her
nose
and
a
certain
impossible
bloom
under
each
eye
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
lofty
with
him
;
so
was
another
old
lady
,
dark
-
browed
and
high
-
nosed
,
and
who
must
have
had
something
real
about
her
<EOS>
or
she
could
not
have
existed
,
but
it
was
certainly
not
her
hair
or
her
teeth
or
her
figure
or
her
complexion
;
so
was
a
grey
old
gentleman
of
dignified
and
sullen
appearance
;
both
of
whom
had
come
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
they
had
all
been
in
the
British
Embassy
way
in
sundry
parts
of
the
earth
,
and
as
a
British
Embassy
can
not
better
establish
a
character
with
the
Circumlocution
Office
than
by
treating
its
compatriots
with
illimitable
contempt
(
else
it
would
become
like
the
Embassies
of
other
countries
)
,
Clennam
felt
that
on
the
whole
they
let
him
off
lightly
.
   
<EOS>
The
dignified
old
gentleman
turned
out
to
be
Lord
Lancaster
Stiltstalking
,
who
had
been
maintained
by
the
Circumlocution
Office
for
many
years
as
a
representative
of
the
Britannic
Majesty
abroad
.
   
<EOS>
This
noble
Refrigerator
had
iced
several
European
courts
in
his
time
,
and
had
done
it
with
such
complete
success
that
the
very
name
of
Englishman
yet
struck
cold
to
the
stomachs
of
foreigners
who
had
the
distinguished
honour
of
remembering
him
at
a
distance
of
a
quarter
of
a
century
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
now
in
retirement
,
and
hence
(
in
a
ponderous
white
cravat
,
like
a
stiff
snow
-
drift
)
was
so
obliging
as
to
shade
the
dinner
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
whisper
of
the
pervading
Bohemian
character
in
the
nomadic
nature
of
the
service
and
its
curious
races
of
plates
and
dishes
;
but
the
noble
Refrigerator
,
infinitely
better
than
plate
or
porcelain
,
made
it
superb
.
 
<EOS>
He
shaded
the
dinner
,
cooled
the
wines
,
chilled
the
gravy
,
and
blighted
the
vegetables
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
other
person
in
the
room
:
a
microscopically
small
footboy
,
who
waited
on
the
malevolent
man
who
had
n't
got
into
the
Post
-
Office
.
 
<EOS>
Even
this
youth
,
if
his
jacket
could
have
been
unbuttoned
and
his
heart
laid
bare
,
would
have
been
seen
,
as
a
distant
adherent
of
the
Barnacle
family
,
already
to
aspire
to
a
situation
under
Government
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
with
a
gentle
melancholy
upon
her
,
occasioned
by
her
son
's
being
reduced
to
court
the
swinish
public
as
a
follower
of
the
low
Arts
,
instead
of
asserting
his
birthright
and
putting
a
ring
through
its
nose
as
an
acknowledged
Barnacle
,
headed
the
conversation
at
dinner
on
the
evil
days
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
that
Clennam
learned
for
the
first
time
what
little
pivots
this
great
world
goes
round
upon
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
John
Barnacle
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
after
the
degeneracy
of
the
times
had
been
fully
ascertained
,
"
if
John
Barnacle
had
but
abandoned
his
most
unfortunate
idea
of
conciliating
the
mob
,
all
would
have
been
well
,
and
<EOS>
I
think
the
country
would
have
been
preserved
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
old
lady
with
the
high
nose
assented
;
but
added
that
if
Augustus
Stiltstalking
had
in
a
general
way
ordered
the
cavalry
out
with
instructions
to
charge
,
she
thought
the
country
would
have
been
preserved
.
   
<EOS>
The
noble
Refrigerator
assented
;
but
added
that
if
William
Barnacle
and
Tudor
Stiltstalking
,
when
they
came
over
to
one
another
and
formed
their
ever
-
memorable
coalition
,
had
boldly
muzzled
the
newspapers
,
and
rendered
it
penal
for
any
Editor
-
person
to
presume
to
discuss
the
conduct
of
any
appointed
authority
abroad
or
at
home
,
he
thought
the
country
would
have
been
preserved
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
agreed
that
the
country
(
another
word
for
the
Barnacles
and
Stiltstalkings
)
wanted
preserving
,
but
how
it
came
to
want
preserving
was
not
so
clear
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
clear
that
the
question
was
all
about
John
Barnacle
,
Augustus
Stiltstalking
,
William
Barnacle
and
Tudor
Stiltstalking
,
Tom
,
Dick
,
or
Harry
Barnacle
or
Stiltstalking
,
because
there
was
nobody
else
but
mob
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
feature
of
the
conversation
which
impressed
Clennam
,
as
a
man
not
used
to
it
,
very
disagreeably
:
making
him
doubt
if
it
were
quite
right
to
sit
there
,
silently
hearing
a
great
nation
narrowed
to
such
little
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
Remembering
,
however
,
that
in
the
Parliamentary
debates
,
whether
on
the
life
of
that
nation
's
body
or
the
life
of
its
soul
,
the
question
was
usually
all
about
and
between
John
Barnacle
,
Augustus
Stiltstalking
,
William
Barnacle
and
Tudor
Stiltstalking
,
Tom
,
Dick
,
or
Harry
Barnacle
or
Stiltstalking
,
and
nobody
else
;
he
said
nothing
on
the
part
of
mob
,
bethinking
himself
that
mob
was
used
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Henry
Gowan
seemed
to
have
a
malicious
pleasure
in
playing
off
the
three
talkers
against
each
other
,
and
in
seeing
Clennam
startled
by
what
they
said
.
 
<EOS>
Having
as
supreme
a
contempt
for
the
class
that
had
thrown
him
off
as
for
the
class
that
had
not
taken
him
on
,
he
had
no
personal
disquiet
in
anything
that
passed
.
 
<EOS>
His
healthy
state
of
mind
appeared
even
to
derive
a
gratification
from
Clennam
's
position
of
embarrassment
and
isolation
among
the
good
company
;
and
if
Clennam
had
been
in
that
condition
with
which
Nobody
was
incessantly
contending
,
he
would
have
suspected
it
,
and
would
have
struggled
with
the
suspicion
as
a
meanness
,
even
while
he
sat
at
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
a
couple
of
hours
the
noble
Refrigerator
,
at
no
time
less
than
a
hundred
years
behind
the
period
,
got
about
five
centuries
in
arrears
,
and
delivered
solemn
political
oracles
appropriate
to
that
epoch
.
 
<EOS>
He
finished
by
freezing
a
cup
of
tea
for
his
own
drinking
,
and
retiring
at
his
lowest
temperature
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Mrs
Gowan
,
who
had
been
accustomed
in
her
days
of
a
vacant
arm
-
chair
beside
her
to
which
to
summon
state
to
retain
her
devoted

,
one
by
one
,
for
short
audiences
as
marks
of
her
especial

,
invited
Clennam
with
a
turn
of
her
fan
to
approach
the
presence
.
 
<EOS>
He
obeyed
,
and
took
the
tripod
recently
vacated
by
Lord
Lancaster
Stiltstalking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
"
apart
from
the
happiness
I
have
in
becoming
known

,
though

this

---
a
mere

---
there

a

which
I
am
dying

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
subject
in
connection
with
which
my
son
first
had
<EOS>
,
I
believe
,
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
inclined
his

,
as
a

to
what

did

.
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
"

,
"

,

really

?
"
   
<EOS>
In
nobody
's

,
he

have
found

very

;
very

to

,

"
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You

!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
flame
of
Henry
's
.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
If

---

.

<EOS>
"
Miss
Meagles
,
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
He

,

"
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Clennam

,
"

,

.

<EOS>
"
Picked

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Found

.
 
<EOS>
Stumbled

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Nobody
's

)
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Really

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

's

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
No

<EOS>
Mrs

,

for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

?
 
<EOS>
No
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No

?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
That
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
Mr

;
and
as

have
been
together
intimately
among
these

,
I

that
a

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
Henry
's

which
---

!
"
<EOS>
shrugging

,
"

,
I
dare

,

,

,

;

,

Amateur
,

---
"
   
<EOS>
As

,
<EOS>
Clennam
,
however
resolute

,
could

that
there

mighty

's

Amateur
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Henry
,
"

,
"
is
self

;

naturally

,
I
can
entertain

,
Mr
Clennam
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
apprehend
the
girl
's

will

;
Henry
might

;
there

:
still
,
he

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
With

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

Arthur
,
"

;

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,

?
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur

<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

I

,

<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
It

,

"
Believe

,

,

.

?
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
Certainty
.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She

;

,

,
as

,
"
Do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
know

will

for

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
At

,

cards
were

,

Henry
Gowan
came

,
"
Mother
,

for

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

thereupon

,

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
had
a
portentously
long

of

mother
,
"
said
Gowan
,
as

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fervently

she
has
not
bored
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
a
little
open
phaeton
for
the
journey
,
and
were
soon
in
it
on
the
road
home
.
 
<EOS>
Gowan
,
driving
,
lighted
a
cigar
;
Clennam
declined
one
.
 
<EOS>
Do
what
he
would
,
he
fell
into
such
a
mood
of
abstraction
that
Gowan
said
again
,
"
I
am
very
much
afraid
my
mother
has
bored
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
he
roused
himself
to
answer
,
"
Not
at
all
!
"
and
soon
relapsed
again
.
   
<EOS>
In
that
state
of
mind
which
rendered
nobody
uneasy
,
his
thoughtfulness
would
have
turned
principally
on
the
man
at
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
thought
of
the
morning
when
he
first
saw
him
rooting
out
the
stones
with
his
heel
,
and
would
have
asked
himself
,
"
Does
he
jerk
me
out
of
the
path
in
the
same
careless
,

way
?
<EOS>
"
He
would
have
thought
,
had
this
introduction
to
his
mother
been
brought
about
by
him
because
he
knew
what
she
would
say
,
and
that
he
could
thus
place

position
before
a
rival
and
loftily
warn

off
,
without
himself
reposing

word

confidence
in

?
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
thought
,
even
if
there
were
no
such
design
as
that
,
had
he
brought
him
there
to
play
with
his
repressed

,
and

?
 
<EOS>
The
current
of
these
meditations
would
have
been
stayed
sometimes

a

,
bearing
a

to
himself
from
his
own
open

,
representing
that
to

,
even

,
was
not

the
high

he

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

have

;
and
looking

catching

's

,
he
would
have
started
as

he
had
done

an

.
   
<EOS>
Then

dark

,

"

,
he

I

,

?
 
<EOS>
How

,

,
in

?
"
 
<EOS>
Thinking
of
her
<EOS>
,
he
would
have
been

with

that

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

;
"
I

mother

.
"
<EOS>
"
Believe

,
not

all
,
"
said
