.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
---
nothing
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
Five
-
and
-
Twenty
 
A
frequently
recurring
doubt
,
whether
Mr
Pancks
's
desire
to
collect
information
relative
to
the
Dorrit
family
could
have
any
possible
bearing
on
the
misgivings
he
had
imparted
to
his
mother
on
his
return
from
his
long
exile
,
caused
Arthur
Clennam
much
uneasiness
at
this
period
.
 
<EOS>
What
Mr
Pancks
already
knew
about
the
Dorrit
family
,
what
more
he
really
wanted
to
find
out
,
and
why
he
should
trouble
his
busy
head
about
them
at
all
,
were
questions
that
often
perplexed
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
not
a
man
to
waste
his
time
and
trouble
in
researches
prompted
by
idle
curiosity
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
a
specific
object
Clennam
could
not
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
And
whether
the
attainment
of
that
object
by
Mr
Pancks
's
industry
might
bring
to
light
,
in
some
untimely
way
,
secret
reasons
which
had
induced
his
mother
to
take
Little
Dorrit
by
the
hand
,
was
a
serious
speculation
.
   
<EOS>
Not
that
he
ever
wavered
either
in
his
desire
or
his
determination
to
repair
a
wrong
that
had
been
done
in
his
father
's
time
,
should
a
wrong
come
to
light
,
and
be
reparable
.
 
<EOS>
The
shadow
of
a
supposed
act
of
injustice
,
which
had
hung
over
him
since
his
father
's
death
,
was
so
vague
and
formless
that
it
might
be
the
result
of
a
reality
widely
remote
from
his
idea
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
if
his
apprehensions
should
prove
to
be
well
founded
,
he
was
ready
at
any
moment
to
lay
down
all
he
had
,
and
begin
the
world
anew
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
fierce
dark
teaching
of
his
childhood
had
never
sunk
into
his
heart
,
so
that
first
article
in
his
code
of
morals
was
,
that
he
must
begin
,
in
practical
humility
,
with
looking
well
to
his
feet
on
Earth
,
and
that
he
could
never
mount
on
wings
of
words
to
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
Duty
on
earth
,
restitution
on
earth
,
action
on
earth
;
these
first
,
as
the
first
steep
steps
upward
.
 
<EOS>
Strait
was
the
gate
and
narrow
<EOS>
was
the
way
;
far
straiter
and
narrower
than
the
broad
high
road
paved
with
vain
professions
and
vain
repetitions
,
motes
from
other
men
's
eyes
and
liberal
delivery
of
others
to
the
judgment
---
all
cheap
materials
costing
absolutely
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
selfish

or

that
rendered
him
uneasy
,
but
a
mistrust
lest
Pancks
might
not
observe
his
part
of
the
understanding
between

,
and
,

any

,
<EOS>
might
take

upon
it
without

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

Pancks
,
and
the

to

that
there

any

that

being
on
that

,
there

times

he

.
 
<EOS>
Labouring
in
this
sea
,
as
all
barks
labour
in
cross

,
he
tossed
about
and
came
to
no

.
   
<EOS>
The
removal
of
Little
Dorrit
herself
from
their

,
did

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
much

,
and
so

in
her
own

,
that
he
began
to
miss

and
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
written
to

to

,

she

,
very

her

,
for

;
but
he
had
not

,
for
what
,
in
their

,
was

.
   
<EOS>
He
returned

one

from
an

her

,
who
had

that

---

---
and

Mr
Meagles
in

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

"
Clennam
!
---

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lost
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

heart

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Would

,

;

;

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
A

;

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Pet

Nobody

<EOS>
An

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Mother

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Clennam

.

!

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
No

,

<EOS>
"
She

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"

"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
with
a
plain
good
faith
that
might
have
commanded
the
belief
of
Mrs
Gowan
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
count
five
-
and
-
twenty
,
Tattycoram
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
again
stroked
his
face
and
shook
his
head
,
with
an
air
of
profound
regret
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
so
used
to
do
it
,
Clennam
,
that
even
then
,
such
a
picture
of
passion
as
you
never
saw
,
she
stopped
short
,
looked
me
full
in
the
face
,
and
counted
(
as
I
made
out
)
to
eight
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
could
n't
control

to
go
any
further
.
 
<EOS>
There
she
broke
down
,
poor
thing
,
and
gave
the
other
seventeen
to
the
four
winds
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
all
burst
out
.
 
<EOS>
She
detested
us
<EOS>
,
she
was
miserable
with
us
,
she
could
n't
bear
it
<EOS>
,
she
would
n't
bear
it
,
she
was
determined
to
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
younger
than
her
young
mistress
,
and
would
she
remain
to
see
her
always
held
up
as
the
only
creature
who
was
young
and
interesting
,
and
to
be
cherished
and

?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
n't
,
she
would
n't
,
she
would
n't
!
 
<EOS>
What
did
we
think
she
,
Tattycoram
,
might
have
been
if
she
had
been
caressed
and
cared
for
in
her
childhood
,
like
her
young
mistress
?
 
<EOS>
As
good
as
her
?
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
fifty
times
as
good
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
pretended
to
be
so
fond
of
one
another
,
we
exulted
over
her
;
that
was
what
we
did
;
we
exulted
over
her
and
shamed
her
.
 
<EOS>
And
all
in
the
house
did
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
They
talked
about
their
fathers
and
mothers
,
and
brothers
and
sisters
;
they
liked
to
drag
them
up
before
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Mrs
Tickit
,
only
yesterday
,
when
her
little
grandchild
was
with
her
,
had
been

by
the

's

<EOS>
(
Tattycoram
)

;
and
had

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
who
did
n't
;
and
who

that

a

to
name

like
a
dog
or

?
 
<EOS>
But
she
did
n't

.
 
<EOS>
She
would

no

from
us
;
she
would
fling
us
her
name
back

,

she

.
 
<EOS>
She

leave
us
that
minute
,
nobody

,
and

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
had

that
he

her

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
well
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

of
no
use

,
with
that

creature
<EOS>
(

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
"
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
"

Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have

hunting

.
 
<EOS>
She
must

gone
very

.
 
<EOS>
I

found
no

her
down

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
 
<EOS>
You

,
"
said
Clennam
,

's

,
"

?
 
<EOS>
I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes

;
I

Mother

;

<EOS>
You

,
"

"
want

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
What

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No

,

?
"

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
The

may

;

,

.
<EOS>
However
,

;

-

's
<EOS>
,

---
"
Clennam
finished

by

,
and

he
was
ready
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
now
summer
-
time
;
a
grey
,
hot
,
dusty
evening
.
 
<EOS>
They
rode
to
the
top
of
Oxford
Street
,
and
there
alighting
,
dived
in
among
the
great
streets
of
melancholy
stateliness
,
and
the
little
streets
that
try
to
be
as
stately
and
succeed
in
being
more
melancholy
,
of
which
there
is
a
labyrinth
near
Park
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
Wildernesses
of
corner
houses
,
with
barbarous
old
porticoes
and
appurtenances
;
horrors
that
came
into
existence
under
some
wrong
-
headed
person
in
some
wrong
-
headed
time
,
still
demanding
the
blind
admiration
of
all
ensuing
generations
and
determined
to
do
so
until
they
tumbled
down
;
frowned
upon
the
twilight
.
 
<EOS>
Parasite
little
tenements
,
with
the
cramp
in
their
whole
frame
,
from
the
dwarf
hall
-
door
on
the
giant
model
of
His
Grace
's
in
the
Square
to
the
squeezed
window
of
the

commanding
the
dunghills
in
the
Mews
,
made
the
evening
doleful
.
 
<EOS>
Rickety
dwellings
of
undoubted
fashion
,
but
of
a
capacity
to
hold
nothing
comfortably
except
a
dismal
smell
,
looked
like
the
last
result
of
the
great
mansions
'
breeding
in
-
and
-
in
;
and
,
where
their
little
supplementary
bows
and

were
supported
on
thin
iron
columns
,
seemed
to
be
scrofulously
resting
upon

.
   
<EOS>
Here
<EOS>
and
there
a
Hatchment
,
with
the
whole
science
of
Heraldry
in
it
,
loomed
down
upon
the
street
,
like
an
Archbishop

on
Vanity
.
 
<EOS>
The
shops
,
few
in
number
,
made
no
show
;
for
popular
opinion
was
as
nothing
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
pastrycook
knew
who
was
on
his
books
,
and
in
that
knowledge
could
be
calm
,
with
a
few

of

-

,
and
half
-
a
-
dozen

of

-

.
 
<EOS>
A
few
oranges
formed
the
greengrocer
's
whole
concession
to
the
vulgar
mind
.
 
<EOS>
A
single
basket
made
of
moss
,
once
containing
plovers
'
eggs
,
held
all
that
the
poulterer
had
to
say
to
the
rabble
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
in
those
streets
seemed
(
which
is
always
the
case
at
that
hour
and

)
to
be
gone
out
to

,
and
nobody
seemed
to
be

had

.
 
<EOS>
On

there
were

with

and
white

,
like

;
and

,
solitary
men
of
recluse

,
each
of
whom
appeared
distrustful
of
all
other

.
 
<EOS>
The
roll
of
carriages
in
the
Park
was
done
for
the
day
;
the
street
lamps
were
lighting
;
and
wicked
little
grooms
in
the
tightest

,

in

answering
to
the

in

,
hung
about
in

,
chewing

and
exchanging
fraudulent

.
 
<EOS>
The
spotted
dogs
who
went
out
with
the
carriages
,
and

were
so
associated
with

that

in

to

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
Here
<EOS>
and
there
was
a
retiring
public
-
house
which
did
not

be
supported
on
the

the

,
and
where
gentlemen
out

were
not

.
   
<EOS>
This
last
discovery
was
made
by
the
two
friends
in

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
was

,

,
<EOS>
known

Miss
Wade
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
the

;
long
,

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
They
inquired

,

,
but
could

.
 
<EOS>
They

up

on

way
,
and
down

,
what
time
<EOS>
two

-

,
announcing

that
had
never

never

,
pitched

;
but
nothing

it
.
 
<EOS>
At
length

stood
at
the
corner
from
which
they
had
begun
,
and
it
had

quite

,
and

no

.
   
<EOS>
It
happened
that
in
the
street
they
had
several

passed
a

,

,
with

,

was
to
let
.
 
<EOS>
The
bills
,
as
a
variety
in

,
almost

a

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

they
kept

house
separated
in

,
or

Mr
Meagles
and
himself
had
twice

in
passing
,
"
It
is
clear
she
do
n't
live
there
,
"
Clennam
now
proposed
that
they
should
go
back
and
try
that
house
before
finally
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
agreed
,
and
back
they
went
.
   
<EOS>
They
knocked
once
,
and
they
rang
once
,
without
any
response
.
   
<EOS>
"
Empty
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
listening
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
more
,
"
said
Clennam
,
and
knocked
again
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
knock
they
heard
a
movement
below
,
and
somebody
shuffling
up
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
The
confined
entrance
was
so
dark
that
it
was
impossible
to
make
out
distinctly
what
kind
of
person
opened
the
door
;
but
it
appeared
to
be
an
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
our
troubling
you
,
"
said
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
can
you
tell

where
Miss
Wade
lives
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
voice
in
the
darkness
unexpectedly

,
"
Lives
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
answer
coming
,
Mr
Meagles
asked
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
is
she
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
After
another

,
"
I
suppose
she
is
,
"
said
the
voice
abruptly
;
"
you
had
better
come
in
,
and
I
'll
ask
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
"
were
summarily
shut
into
the
close
black
house
;
and
the
figure
rustling
away
,
and
speaking
from
a
higher

,
said
,
"
Come
up
,
if
you
please
;
you
ca
n't
tumble
over
anything
.
"
 
<EOS>
They
groped

way
up

stairs

,
which

the
street

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is

,
Clennam
,
"
said

Meagles
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Odd

,
"
assented
Clennam

,
"
but
we
have
succeeded
;
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
a
light
coming
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

was
a
lamp
,
and
the
bearer
was
an
old
woman
:
very
dirty
,
very

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
at
home
,
"
she
said
(
and
the
voice
was
the
same
that
had
spoken

)
;
"
she
'll
come
directly
.
"
<EOS>
Having

,
the
old

dusted

on
her
apron
,
which
she
might
have
done
for
ever
without
cleaning

,
looked
at
the
visitors
with
a
dim
pair
of
eyes
,
and
backed
out
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
whom
they
had
come
to
see
,
if
she
were
the
present
occupant
of
the
house
,
appeared
to
have
taken
up
her
quarters
there
as
she
might
have
established
herself
in
an
Eastern
caravanserai
.
<EOS>
A
small
square
of
carpet
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
a
few
articles
of
furniture
that
evidently
did
not
belong
to
the
room
,
and
a
disorder
of
trunks
and
travelling
articles
,
formed
the
whole
of
her
surroundings
.
 
<EOS>
Under
some
former
regular
inhabitant
,
the
stifling
little
apartment
had
broken
out
into
a
pier
-
glass
and
a
gilt
table
;
but
the
gilding
was
as
faded
as
last
year
's
flowers
,
and
the
glass
was
so
clouded
that
it
seemed
to
hold
in
magic
preservation
all
the
fogs
and
bad
weather
<EOS>
it
had
ever
reflected
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitors
had
had
a
minute
or
two
to
look
about
them
,
when
the
door
opened
and
Miss
Wade
came
in
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
exactly
the
same
as
when
they
had
parted
.
 
<EOS>
just
as
handsome
,
just
as
scornful
,
just
as
repressed
.
 
<EOS>
She
manifested
no
surprise
in
seeing
them
,
nor
any
other
emotion
.
 
<EOS>
She
requested
them
to
be
seated
;
and
declining
to
take
a
seat
herself
,
at
once
anticipated
any
introduction
of
their
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
apprehend
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
I
know
the
cause
of
your
favouring
me
with
this
visit
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
come
to
it
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
cause
then
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
is
Tattycoram
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
supposed
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Miss
Wade
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
will
you
be
so
kind
as
to
say
whether
you
know
anything
of
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Surely
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
she
is
here
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
allow
me
to
make
known
to
you
that
I
shall
be
happy
to
have
her
back
,
and
that
my
wife
and
daughter
will
be
happy
to
have
her
back
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
been
with
us
a
long
time
:
we
do
n't
forget
her
claims
upon
us
,
and
I
hope
we
know
how
to
make
allowances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
hope
to
know
how
to
make
allowances
?
<EOS>
"
she
returned
,
in
a
level
,
measured
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
what
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
my
friend
would
say
,
Miss
Wade
,
"
Arthur
Clennam
interposed
,
seeing
Mr
Meagles
rather
at
a
loss
,
"
for
the
passionate
sense
that
sometimes
comes
upon
the
poor
girl
,
of
being
at
a
disadvantage
.
 
<EOS>
Which
occasionally
gets
the
better
of
better
remembrances
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
broke
into
a
smile
as
she
turned
her
eyes
upon
him
.
"
<EOS>
Indeed
?
"
was
all
she
answered
.
   
<EOS>
She
stood
by
the
table
so
perfectly
composed
and
still
after
this
acknowledgment
of
his
remark
that
Mr
Meagles
stared
at
her
under
a
sort
of

,
and
could
not

look
to
Clennam
to
make

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
awkwardly
enough
,

,
Arthur
said
:
"
Perhaps
it
would
be
well
if
Mr
Meagles
could
see
her
,
Miss
Wade
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
easily
done
,
"
said
she
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
here
,
child
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
had
opened
a
door
while
saying
this
,
and
now
led
the
girl
in
by

hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
curious
to
see
them
standing
together
<EOS>
:
the
girl
with
her
disengaged
fingers
plaiting
the

her
dress
,
half

,
half

;
Miss
Wade
with
her
composed

attentively

her
,
and
suggesting
to
an
observer
,
with

,
in
her

itself
(
as
a
veil
will
suggest
the
form

covers
)
,
the

passion

.
   
<EOS>
"
See
here
,
"
she

,
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
your

,
your

.
 
<EOS>
He
is

to
take
you
back
,
my
dear
,
if
you
are
sensible

the

.
 
<EOS>
You
can
be
,
again
,
a
foil
to
his
pretty
daughter
,
a
slave
to
her
pleasant
wilfulness
,
and
a
toy
in
the
house
showing
the

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
You
can
have
your
droll
name
again
,
playfully
pointing
you
out
and
setting
you
apart
,
as
it
is
right
that
you
should

and

.
 
<EOS>
(
Your
birth
,
you
know
;
you

.
)
<EOS>
You
can
again

shown
to
this

,
Harriet
,
and
kept
before

,
as

of
her

and

.
 
<EOS>
You
can
recover
all
these
advantages
and
many
more
of
the

which
I
dare

start

,

by
telling
these

how
humbled

,

by

.
 
<EOS>
What
do

,

?
 
<EOS>
Will

go
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
girl

,
under

,
had

,

,
raising

and

upon

had
been

up
,
"
I
'd
die
sooner
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
,
still
standing
at
her
side
holding
her
hand
,
looked
quietly
round
and
said
with
a

,
"
Gentlemen
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
do
upon
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Meagles
's
inexpressible
consternation
in
hearing
his
motives
and
actions
so
perverted
,
had
prevented
him
from

any

until

;
but
now

regained

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tattycoram
,
"
said
he
,
"
for
I

,

girl
,
conscious

I
meant
nothing
but

when
I

,
and
conscious
that
you
know

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
!
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
looking

again
,
and
almost
rending

with
the
same

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
now
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
;
"
not
with
that
lady
's
eyes
<EOS>
so
intent

you
,
Tattycoram
<EOS>
,
"
she

,
"
and
that
power
over
you
,

we

;
not

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Tattycoram
,
I
'll

she

,
even
in

I

,

any

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not

you
,
with

my

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

all
in

that

,

,

,
Tattycoram
.
"
   
<EOS>
She

,

,
"
I
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
,
take
me
away
,
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
contention
that
raged
within
her
had
no
softening
in

now
;
it
was
wholly
between
passionate

and

.
 
<EOS>
Her

,
her

her

,

all
setting

against
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
!
"
<EOS>
she
repeated
in
a
low
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'd
be
torn
to
pieces
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
tear
myself
to
pieces
first
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
,
who
had
released
her

,
laid
her

protectingly
on
the
girl
's
neck
for

,
and
then
said
,
looking
round
with
her
former

and
speaking

her

,
"
Gentlemen
!
<EOS>
What
do
you
do
upon
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Tattycoram
,
Tattycoram
!
"

Meagles
,
adjuring
her

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
that

's

,
look

,

is

lies

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

that

's
influence

---
astonishing

,

I

us

---
is

,

.
<EOS>
What
can
you

be

?
 
<EOS>
What
can
come
of

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
alone
here
,
gentlemen
,
"
observed
Miss
Wade
,
with
no

or

.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
anything
you
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Politeness
must
yield
to
this
misguided
girl
,

,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
at
her
present

;
though
I
hope

,
even

the
injury
<EOS>
you
do
her

before

.
<EOS>
Excuse

for

you
in
her
hearing
<EOS>
---
I
must

---
that
you
were

,
and

nothing

common
with
any

when
she

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

what
you
are
,
but
you
do
n't
hide
,
ca
n't
hide
,
what

dark

you
have
within

.
 
<EOS>
If

should

that
you
are
a

,
who
,

,
has

in

(
I

to

)
,
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Wade
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
have

---
Mr
Clennam
,
perhaps

will

friend
---
"
   
"
Not

,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,

.
<EOS>
"
Tattycoram
,
my

,
count

-

-

.
"
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,
this

"
said

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Turn
to
the
friends
you
have
not

.
 
<EOS>
Think
once
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
!
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
,
"
said
the
girl
,
with
her
bosom

,
and
speaking
with
her
hand

,
"
take
me
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tattycoram
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
more
yet
!
 
<EOS>
The
only
thing
I
ask
of
you
in
the
world
,
my
child
!
 
<EOS>
Count
five
-
and
-
twenty
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
put
her
hands
tightly
over
her
ears
,
confusedly
tumbling
down
her
bright
black
hair
in
the
vehemence
of
the
action
,
and
turned
her
face
resolutely
to
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
,
who
had
watched
her
under
this
final
appeal
with
that
strange
attentive
smile
,
and
that
repressing
hand
upon
her
own
bosom
with
which
she
had
watched
her
in
her
struggle
at
Marseilles
,
then
put
her
arm
about
her
waist
as
if
she
took
possession
of
her
for
evermore
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
visible
triumph
in
her
face
when
she
turned
it
to
dismiss
the
visitors
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
it
is
the
last
time
I
shall
have
the
honour
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
<EOS>
as
you
have
spoken
of
not
knowing
what
I
am
,
and
also
of
the
foundation
of
my
influence
here
,
you
may
now
know
that
it
is
founded
in
a
common
cause
.
 
<EOS>
What
your
broken
plaything
is
as
to
birth
,
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
no
name
,
I
have
no
name
.
 
<EOS>
Her
wrong
is
my
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
Mr
Meagles
,
who
sorrowfully
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
As
Clennam
followed
,
she
said
to
him
,
with
the
same
external
composure
and
in
the
same
level
voice
,
but
with
a
smile
that
is
only
seen
on
cruel
faces
:
a
very
faint
smile
,
lifting
the
nostril
,
scarcely
touching
the
lips
,
and
not
breaking
away
gradually
,
but
instantly
dismissed
when
done
with
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
wife
of
your
dear
friend
Mr
Gowan
,
may
be
happy
in
the
contrast
of
her
extraction
to
this
girl
's
and
mine
,
and
in
the
high
good
fortune
that
awaits
her
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
Nobody
's
Disappearance
 
Not
resting
satisfied
with
the
endeavours
he
had
made
to
recover
his
lost
charge
,
Mr
Meagles
addressed
a
letter
of
remonstrance
,
breathing
nothing
but
goodwill
,
not
only
to
her
,
but
to
Miss
Wade
too
.
 
<EOS>
No
answer
coming
to
these
epistles
,
or
to
another
written
to
the
stubborn
girl
by
the
hand
of
her
late
young
mistress
,
which
might
have
melted
her
if
anything
could
<EOS>
(
all
three
letters
were
returned
weeks
afterwards
as
having
been
refused
at
the
house
-
door
)
,
he
deputed
Mrs
Meagles
to
make
the
experiment
of
a
personal
interview
.
 
<EOS>
That
worthy
lady
being
unable
to
obtain
one
,
and
being
steadfastly
denied
admission
,
Mr
Meagles
besought
Arthur
to
essay
once
more
what
he
could
do
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
came
of
his
compliance
was
,
his
discovery
that
the
empty
house
was
left
in
charge
of
the
old
woman
,
that
Miss
Wade
was
gone
,
that
the
waifs
and
strays
of
furniture
were
gone
,
and
that
the
old
woman
would
accept
any
number
of
half
-
crowns
and
thank
the
donor
kindly
,
but
had
no
information
whatever
to
exchange
for
those
coins
,
beyond
constantly
offering
for
perusal
a
memorandum
relative
to
fixtures
,
which
the
house
-
agent
's
young
man
had
left
in
the
hall
.
   
<EOS>
Unwilling
,
even
under
this
discomfiture
,
to
resign
the
ingrate
and
leave
her
hopeless
,
in
case
of
her
better
dispositions
obtaining
the
mastery
over
the
darker
side
of
her
character
,
Mr
Meagles
,
for
six
successive
days
,
published
a
discreetly
covert
advertisement
in
the
morning
papers
,
to
the
effect
that
if
a
certain
young
person
who
had
lately
left
home
without
reflection
,
would
at
any
time
apply
to
his
address
at
Twickenham
,
everything
would
be
as
it
had
been
before
,
and
no
reproaches
need
be
apprehended
.
 
<EOS>
The
unexpected
consequences
of
this
notification
suggested
to
the
dismayed
Mr
Meagles
for
the
first
time
that
some
hundreds
of
young
persons
must
be
leaving
their
homes
without
reflection
every
day
;
for
shoals
of
wrong
young
people
came
down
to
Twickenham
,
who
,
not
finding
themselves
received
with
enthusiasm
,
generally
demanded
compensation
by
way
of
damages
,
in
addition
to
coach
-
hire
there
and
back
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
were
these
the
only
uninvited
clients
whom
the
advertisement
produced
.
 
<EOS>
The
swarm
of
begging
-
letter
writers
,
who
would
seem
to
be
always
watching
eagerly
for
any
hook
,
however
small
,
to
hang
a
letter
upon
,
wrote
to
say
that
having
seen
the
advertisement
,
they
were
induced
to
apply
with
confidence
for
various
sums
,
ranging
from
ten
shillings
to
fifty
pounds
:
not
because
they
knew
anything
about
the
young
person
,
but
because
they
felt
that
to
part
with
those
donations
would
greatly
relieve
the
advertiser
's
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Several
projectors
,
likewise
,
availed
themselves
of
the
same
opportunity
to
correspond
with
Mr
Meagles
;
as
,
for
example
,
to
apprise
him
that
their
attention
having
been
called
to
the
advertisement
by
a
friend
,
they
begged
to
state
that
if
they
should
ever
hear
anything
of
the
young
person
,
they
would
not
fail
to
make
it
known
to
him
immediately
,
and
that
in
the
meantime
if
he
would
oblige
them
with
the
funds
necessary
for
bringing
to
perfection
a
certain
entirely
novel
description
of
Pump
,
the
happiest
results
would
ensue
to
mankind
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
and
his
family
,
under
these
combined
discouragements
,
had
begun
reluctantly
to
give
up
Tattycoram
as
irrecoverable
,
when
the
new
and
active
firm
of
Doyce
and
Clennam
,
in
their
private
capacities
,
went
down
on
a
Saturday
to
stay
at
the
cottage
until
Monday
.
 
<EOS>
The
senior
partner
took
the
coach
,
and
the
junior
partner
took
his
walking
-
stick
.
   
<EOS>
A
tranquil
summer
sunset
shone
upon
him
as
he
approached
the
end
of
his
walk
,
and
passed
through
the
meadows
by
the
river
side
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
that
sense
of
peace
,
and
of
being
lightened
of
a
weight
of
care
,
which
country
quiet
awakens
in
the
breasts
of
dwellers
in
towns
.
<EOS>
Everything
within
his
view
was
lovely
and
placid
.
 
<EOS>
The
rich
foliage
of
the
trees
,
the
luxuriant
grass
diversified
with
wild
flowers
,
the
little
green
islands
in
the
river
,
the
beds
of
rushes
,
the
water
-
lilies
floating
on
the
surface
of
the
stream
,
the
distant
voices
in
boats
borne
musically
towards
him
on
the
ripple
of
the
water
and
the
evening
air
,
were
all
expressive
of
rest
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
occasional
leap
of
a
fish
,
or
dip
of
an
oar
,
or
twittering
of
a
bird
not
yet
at
roost
,
or
distant
barking
of
a
dog
,
or
lowing
of
a
cow
---
in
all
such
sounds
,
there
was
the
prevailing
breath
of
rest
,
which
seemed
to
encompass
him
in
every
scent
that
sweetened
the
fragrant
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
long
lines
of
red
and
gold
in
the
sky
,
and
the
glorious
track
of
the
descending
sun
,
were
all
divinely
calm
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
the
purple
tree
-
tops
far
away
,
and
on
the
green
height
near
at
hand
up
which
the
shades
were
slowly
creeping
,
there
was
an
equal
hush
.
<EOS>
Between
the
real
landscape
and
its
shadow
in
the
water
,
there
was
no
division
;
both
were
so
untroubled
and
clear
,
and
,
while
so
fraught
with
solemn
mystery
of
life
and
death
,
so
hopefully
reassuring
to
the
gazer
's
soothed
heart
,
because
so
tenderly
and
mercifully
beautiful
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
had
stopped
,
not
for
the
first
time
by
many
times
,
to
look
about
him
and
suffer
what
he
saw
to
sink
into
his
soul
,
as
the
shadows
,
looked
at
,
seemed
to
sink
deeper
and
deeper
into
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
slowly
resuming
his
way
,
when
he
saw
a
figure
in
the
path
before
him
which
he
had
,
perhaps
,
already
associated
with
the
evening
and
its
impressions
.
   
<EOS>
Minnie
was
there
,
alone
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
some
roses
in
her
hand
,
and
seemed
to
have
stood
still
on
seeing
him
,
waiting
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
towards
him
,
and
she
appeared
to
have
been
coming
from
the
opposite
direction
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
flutter
in
her
manner
,
which
Clennam
had
never
seen
in
it
before
;
and
as
he
came
near
her
,
it
entered
his
mind
all
at
once
that
she
was
there
of
a
set
purpose
to
speak
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
She
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
said
,
"
You
wonder
to
see
me
here
by
myself
?
 
<EOS>
But
the
evening
is
so
lovely
<EOS>
,
I
have
strolled
further
than
I
meant
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
likely
I
might
meet
you
,
and
that
made
me
more
confident
.
 
<EOS>
You
always
come
this
way
,
do
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
Clennam
said
that
it
was
his
favourite
way
,
he
felt
her
hand
falter
on
his
arm
,
and
saw
the
roses
shake
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
let
me
give
you
one
,
Mr
Clennam
?
 
<EOS>
I
gathered
them
as
I
came
out
of
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
almost
gathered
them
for
you
,
thinking
it
so
likely
I
might
meet
you
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Doyce
arrived
more
than
an
hour
ago
,
and
told
us
you
were
walking
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
own
hand
shook
,
as
he
accepted
a
rose
or
two
from
hers
and
thanked
her
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
now
by
an
avenue
of
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
they
turned
into
it
on
his
movement
or
on
hers
matters
little
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
knew
how
that
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
grave
here
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
but
very
pleasant
at
this
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
along
this
deep
shade
,
and
out
at
that
arch
of
light
at
the
other
end
,
we
come
upon
the
ferry
and
the
cottage
by
the
best
approach
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
In
her
simple
garden
-
hat
and
her
light
summer
dress
,
with
her
rich
brown
hair
naturally
clustering
about
her
,
and
her
wonderful
eyes
raised
to
his
for
a
moment
with
a
look
in
which
regard
for
him
and
trustfulness
in
him
were
strikingly
blended
with
a
kind
of
timid
sorrow
for
him
,
she
was
so
beautiful
that
it
was
well
for
his
peace
---
or
ill
for
his
peace
,
he
did
not
quite
know
which
---
that
he
had
made
that
vigorous
resolution
he
had
so
often
thought
about
.
   
<EOS>
She
broke
a
momentary
silence
by
inquiring
if
he
knew
that
papa
had
been
thinking
of
another
tour
abroad
?
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
had
heard
it
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
She
broke
another
momentary
silence
by
adding
,
with
some
hesitation
,
that
papa
had
abandoned
the
idea
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
,
he
thought
directly
,
"
they
are
to
be
married
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
she
said
,
hesitating
more
timidly
yet
,
and
speaking
so
low
that
he
bent
his
head
to
hear
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
very
much
like
to
give
you
my
confidence
,
if
you
would
not
mind
having
the
goodness
to
receive
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
very
much
liked
to
have
given
it
to
you
long
ago
,
because
---
I
felt
that
you
were
becoming
so
much
our
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
be
otherwise
than
proud
of
it
at
any
time
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
give
it
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
trust
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
never
have
been
afraid
of
trusting
you
,
"
she
returned
,
raising
her
eyes
frankly
to
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
would
have
done
so
some
time
ago
,
if
I
had
known
<EOS>
how
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
scarcely
know
how
,
even
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Gowan
,
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
,
"
has
reason
to
be
very
happy
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
his
wife
and
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
wept
,
as
she
tried
to
thank
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
reassured
her
,
took
her
hand
as
it
lay
with
the
trembling
roses
in
it
on
his
arm
,
took
the
remaining
roses
from
it
,
and
put
it
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
it
seemed
to
him
,
he
first
finally
resigned
the
dying
hope
that
had
flickered
in
nobody
's
heart
so
much
to
its
pain
and
trouble
;
and
from
that
time
he
became
in
his
own
eyes
,
as
to
any
similar
hope
or
prospect
,
a
very
much
older
man
who
had
done
with
that
part
of
life
.
   
<EOS>
He
put
the
roses
in
his
breast
and
they
walked
on
for
a
little
while
,
slowly
and
silently
,
under
the
umbrageous
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
asked
her
,
in
a
voice
of
cheerful
kindness
,
was
there
anything
else
that
she
would
say
to
him
as
her
friend
and
her
father
's
friend
,
many
years
older
than
herself
;
was
there
any
trust
she
would
repose
in
him
,
any
service
she
would
ask
of
him
,
any
little
aid
to
her
happiness
that
she
could
give
him
the
lasting
gratification
of
believing
it
was
in
his
power
to
render
?
   
<EOS>
She
was
going
to
answer
,
<EOS>
when
she
was
so
touched
by
some
little
hidden
sorrow
or
sympathy
---
what
could
it
have
been
?
---
that
she
said
,
bursting
into
tears
again
:
"
<EOS>
O
Mr
Clennam
!
 
<EOS>
Good
,
generous
,
Mr
Clennam
,
pray
tell
me
you
do
not
blame
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
blame
you
?
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
girl
!
 
<EOS>
I
blame
you
?
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
clasping
both
her
hands
upon
his
arm
,
and
looking
confidentially
up
into
his
face
,
with
some
hurried
words
to
the
effect
that
she
thanked
him
from
her
heart
(
as
she
did
,
if
it
be
the
source
of
earnestness
)
,
she
gradually
composed
herself
,
with
now
<EOS>
and
then
a
word
of
encouragement
from
him
,
as
they
walked
on
slowly
and
almost
silently
under
the
darkening
trees
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
now
,
Minnie
Gowan
<EOS>
,
"
at
length
said
Clennam
,
smiling
;
"
will
you
ask
me
nothing
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
very
much
to
ask
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
so
;
I
am
not
disappointed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
how
I
am
loved
at
home
,
and
how
I
love
home
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
hardly
think
it
perhaps
,
dear
Mr
Clennam
,
"
she
spoke
with
great
agitation
,
"
seeing
me
going
from
it
of
my
own
free
will
and
choice
,
but
I
do
so
dearly
love
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
that
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
suppose
I
doubt
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
strange
,
even
to
me
,
that
loving
it
so
much
and
being
so
much
beloved
in
it
,
I
can
bear
to
cast
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
so
neglectful
of
it
,
so
unthankful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
it
is
in
the
natural
progress
and
change
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
All
homes
are
left
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
know
;
but
all
homes
are
not
left
with
such
a
blank
in
them
as
there
will
be
in
mine
when
I
am
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
there
is
any
scarcity
of
far
better
and
more
endearing
and
more
accomplished
girls
than
I
am
;
not
that
I
am
much
,
but
that
they
have
made
so
much
of
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Pet
's
affectionate
heart
was
overcharged
,
and
she
sobbed
while
she
pictured
what
would
happen
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
a
change
papa
will
feel
at
first
,
and
I
know
that
at
first
I
can
not
be
to
him
anything
like
what
I
have
been
these
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
then
,
Mr
Clennam
,
then
more
than
at
any
time
,
that
I
beg
and
entreat
you
to
remember
him
,
and
sometimes
to
keep
him
company
when
you
can
spare
a
little
while
;
and
to
tell
him
that
you
know
I
was
fonder
of
him
when
I
left
him
,
than
I
ever
was
in
all
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
For
there
is
nobody
<EOS>
---
he
told
me
so
himself
when
he
talked
to
me
this
very
day
---
there
is
nobody
he
likes
so
well
as
you
,
or
trusts
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
clue
to
what
had
passed
between
the
father
and
daughter
dropped
like
a
heavy
stone
into
the
well
of
Clennam
's
heart
,
and
swelled
the
water
to
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
cheerily
,
but
not
quite
so

as
he
tried
to
say
,
that
it
should
be
done
---
that
he
gave
her
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
not
speak
of
mama
,
"
said
Pet
,
more
moved
by
,
and
more
pretty
in
,
her
innocent

,
than
Clennam
could
trust
himself
even
to
consider
---
for
which
reason
he
counted
the
trees
between
them
and
the

light
as
they
slowly
diminished
in

---
"
it
is
because
mama
will
understand
me

in
this

,
and
will

my
loss
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
you
know
<EOS>
what
a
dear
,

she
is
,
and
you
will
remember
her

;

?
"
   
<EOS>
Let
Minnie
trust
him
<EOS>
,
Clennam
said
,
let
Minnie
trust
him
to
do
all
she
wished
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
dear
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said

,
"
because
papa
and
one
whom
I
need

,
do
not

,
as

by
-
and
-
by
;
and
because

will

the

,
and

,
and

my

,
to
draw

to
a

of
one
another
,
and
to
be
a
happiness
to
one
another
,
and
to

one
another
,
and
to
love
one
another
,
both
loving
me
so
dearly
;
<EOS>
oh
,
as
you
are
a
kind
,
true
man
!
 
<EOS>
when
I
am
first
separated
from
home
(
I
am
going
a
long
distance
away
)
,
try

papa

a

,

him
before
papa
's

.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
do
this
for
me
,
as
you

a
noble

?
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Pet
!
 
<EOS>
Self
-
deceived
,
mistaken
child
!
 
<EOS>
When
were
such
changes
ever
made
in
men
's
natural
relations
to
one
another
:
when
was
such
reconcilement
of
ingrain
differences
ever
effected
!
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
tried
many
times
by
other
daughters
,
Minnie
;
it
has
never
succeeded
;
nothing
has
ever
come
of
it
but
failure
.
   
<EOS>
So
Clennam
thought
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
did
not
say
;
it
was
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
He
bound
himself
to
do
all
she
asked
,
and
she
knew
full
well
that
he
would
do

.
   
<EOS>
They
were
now
at
the
last
tree

the

.
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
,
and
withdrew

.
 
<EOS>
Speaking

,
and

as
an

to
him
<EOS>
,

:
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

,

---
for

,

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

(

"
   
<EOS>
He

that

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
and
answered
,
Heaven

that
he

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
As

the
innocent

once

,
she

,
"
Good
-
bye
!
"
<EOS>
and
he
repeated

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
taking
leave
of
all
his
old
hopes
---
all
nobody
's
old

.
 
<EOS>
They

next

,
arm
-

:
and

,
like

own

.
   
<EOS>
The

Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
and
Doyce
were

,
speaking
near
the

.
 
<EOS>
Hearing
Pet
's

,
Clennam
called
out
<EOS>
,
"
She
is
here
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
There

;
but
as

they
had
all

,

,

Pet

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
Doyce
,

,
without

,

up
and

on
the

,
in

rising

,
for

;
and
then
Doyce
lingered
behind
,
and
went
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
and
Clennam
walked
up
and
down
together
for
a
few
minutes
more
without
speaking
,
until
at
length
the
former
broke

.
   
<EOS>
"
Arthur
,
"
said
he
,
using
that

,
"
do

my

,
as

up

,

,
that
Pet
's

Mother

as

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

.
<EOS>
"
   
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Arthur
,
"

Meagles
,

,
"
<EOS>
I

-

.
 
<EOS>
I

-

,
<EOS>
my

,

,

<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

,
"
thank

!
"
 
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
little

.
"
   
Mr
Meagles
fell
away
,
and
he
was
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
walked
on
the
river
's
brink
in
the
peaceful

for
some
half
an
hour
,
he
put
his

in

and
tenderly
took

handful
of
roses
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
put
them
to

heart
,
perhaps

,
but
certainly
he
bent
down
on
the

and
gently

on
the
flowing
river
.
 
<EOS>
Pale
and
unreal
in
the
moonlight
,
the
river
floated
them
away
.
<EOS>
The
lights
were
bright
within
doors
when
he
entered
,
and
the
faces
on
which
they
shone
,
his
own
face
not
excepted
,
were
soon
quietly
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
They
talked
of
many
subjects
(
his
partner
never
had
had
such
a
ready
store
to
draw
upon
for
the
beguiling
of
the
time
)
,
and
so
to
bed
,
and
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
flowers
,
pale
and
unreal
in
the
moonlight
,
floated
away
upon
the
river
;
and
thus
do
greater
things
that
once
were
in
our
breasts
,
and
near
our
hearts
,
flow
from
us
to
the
eternal
seas
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Flintwinch
goes
on
Dreaming
 
<EOS>
The
house
in
the
city
preserved
its
heavy
dulness
through
all
these
transactions
,
and
the
invalid
within
it
turned
the
same
unvarying
round
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
Morning
,
noon
,
and
night
,
morning
,
noon
,
and
night
,
each
recurring
with
its
accompanying
monotony
,
always
the
same
reluctant
return
of
the
same
sequences
of
machinery
,
like
a
dragging
piece
of
clockwork
.
   
<EOS>
The
wheeled
chair
had
its
associated
remembrances
and
reveries
,
one
may
suppose
,
as
every
place
that
is
made
the
station
of
a
human
being
has
.
 
<EOS>
Pictures
of
demolished
streets
and
altered
houses
,
as
they
formerly
were
when
the
occupant
of
the
chair
was
familiar
with
them
,
images
of
people
as
they
too
used
to
be
,
with
little
or
no
allowance
made
for
the
lapse
of
time
since
they
were
seen
;
of
these
,
there
must
have
been
many
in
the
long
routine
of
gloomy
days
.
 
<EOS>
To
stop
the
clock
of
busy
existence
at
the
hour
when
we
were
personally
sequestered
from
it
,
to
suppose
mankind
stricken
motionless
when
we
were
brought
to
a
stand
-
still
,
to
be
unable
to
measure
the
changes
beyond
our
view
by
any
larger
standard
than
the
shrunken
one
of
our
own
uniform
and
contracted
existence
,
is
the
infirmity
of
many
invalids
,
and
the
mental
unhealthiness
of
almost
all
recluses
.
   
<EOS>
What
scenes
and
actors
the
stern
woman
most
reviewed
,
as
she
sat
from
season
to
season
in
her
one
dark
room
,
none
knew
but
herself
.
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
with
his
wry
presence
brought
to
bear
upon
her
daily
like
some
eccentric
mechanical
force
,
would
perhaps
have
screwed
it
out
of
her
,
if
there
had
been
less
resistance
in
her
;
but
she
was
too
strong
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
as
Mistress
Affery
was
concerned
,
to
regard
her
liege
-
lord
and
her
disabled
mistress
with
a
face
of
blank
wonder
,
to
go
about
the
house
after
dark
with
her
apron
over
her
head
,
always
to
listen
for
the
strange
noises
and
sometimes
to
hear
them
,
and
never
to
emerge
from
her
ghostly
,
dreamy
,
sleep
-
waking
state
,
was
occupation
enough
for
her
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
fair
stroke
of
business
doing
,
as
Mistress
Affery
made
out
,
for
her
husband
had
abundant
occupation
in
his
little
office
,
and
saw
more
people
than
had
been
used
to
come
there
for
some
years
.
 
<EOS>
This
might
easily
be
,
the
house
having
been
long
deserted
;
but
he
did
receive
letters
,
and
comers
,
and
keep
books
,
and
correspond
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
went
about
to
other
counting
-
houses
,
and
to
wharves
,
and
docks
,
and
to
the
Custom
House
,
"
and
to
Garraway
's
Coffee
House
,
and
the
Jerusalem
Coffee
House
,
and
on
"
Change
;
so
that
he
was
much
in
and
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
began
,
too
,
sometimes
of
an
evening
,
when
Mrs
Clennam
expressed
no
particular
wish
for
his
society
,
to
resort
to
a
tavern
in
the
neighbourhood
to
look
at
the
shipping
news
and
closing
prices
in
the
evening
paper
,
and
even
to
exchange
Small
socialities
with
mercantile
Sea
Captains
who
frequented
that
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
At
some
period
of
every
day
,
he
and
Mrs
Clennam
held
a
council
on
matters
of
business
;
and
it
appeared
to
Affery
,
who
was
always
groping
about
,
listening
and
watching
,
that
the
two
clever
ones
were
making
money
.
   
<EOS>
The
state
of
mind
into
which
Mr
Flintwinch
's
dazed
lady
had
fallen
,
had
now
begun
to
be
so
expressed
in
all
her
looks
and
actions
that
she
was
held
in
very
low
account
by
the
two
clever
ones
,
as
a
person
,
never
of
strong
intellect
,
who
was
becoming
foolish
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
because
her
appearance
was
not
of
a
commercial
cast
,
or
perhaps
because
it
occurred
to
him
that
his
having
taken
her
to
wife
might
expose
his
judgment
to
doubt
in
the
minds
of
customers
,
Mr
Flintwinch
laid
his
commands
upon
her
that
she
should
hold
her
peace
on
the
subject
of
her
conjugal
relations
,
and
should
no
longer
call
him
Jeremiah
out
of
the
domestic
trio
.
 
<EOS>
Her
frequent
forgetfulness
of
this
admonition
intensified
her
startled
manner
,
since
Mr
Flintwinch
's
habit
of
avenging
himself
on
her
remissness
by
making
springs
after
her
on
the
staircase
,
and
shaking
her
,
occasioned
her
to
be
always
nervously
uncertain
when
she
might
be
thus
waylaid
next
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
finished
a
long
day
's
work
in
Mrs
Clennam
's
room
,
and
was
neatly
gathering
up
her
shreds
and
odds
and
ends
before
going
home
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
whom
Affery
had
just
shown
in
,
was
addressing
an
inquiry
to
Mrs
Clennam
on
the
subject
of
her
health
,
coupled
with
the
remark
that
,
"
happening
to
find
himself
in
that
direction
,
"
he
had
looked
in
to
inquire
,
on
behalf

his

,
how
she
found
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
,
with
a
deep
contraction
of
her
brows
,
was
looking
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Casby
knows
,
"
said
she
,
"
that
I
am
not
subject
to
changes
.
 
<EOS>
The
change
that
I
await
here
is
the
great
change
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
ma'am
?
"
returned
Mr
Pancks
,
with
a
wandering
eye
towards
the
figure
of
the
little
seamstress
on
her
knee
picking
threads
and
fraying
of
her
work
from
the
carpet
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
look
nicely
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
bear
what
I
have
to
bear
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
what
you
have
to
do
.
"
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
<EOS>
such
is
my
endeavour
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
often
in
this
direction
,
are
you
not
?
"
asked
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
<EOS>
rather
so
lately
;
I
have
lately
been
round
this
way
a
good
deal
,
owing
to
one
thing
and
another
.
"
<EOS>
"
Beg
Mr
Casby
and
his
daughter
not
to

themselves
,
by
deputy
,
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
When

wish

,
they

am
here

.
 
<EOS>
They

no

to
send
.
 
<EOS>
You

no

to
come
.
"
<EOS>
"
Not
the

,
ma'am
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
really
are
looking
uncommonly

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

.
 
<EOS>
Good
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The

,
and
its

door
,
was
so

that
Mr

did
not
see

.
 
<EOS>
He

with

,

little

again
,
said
"
Good
evening
,
ma
"
am
;
do

come
down
,
Mrs
Affery
<EOS>
,
I
know
the
road
to
the
door
,
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
,
her

on

,

with

;
and
Affery
stood

<EOS>
Slowly

,
Mrs
Clennam
's

turned
from
the
door
by
which
Pancks
had
gone
out
,
to
Little
Dorrit
,
rising

.
 
<EOS>
With

more

,
and
her

,

until

.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
coloured
under
such

,
and
looked
down
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
still
sat
intent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Dorrit
,
"
she

,
when

,
"
what

of
that

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

what
he
has
said
,
he

.
 
<EOS>
But
nothing
rough

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

come
here
to
see

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,

,
"

Little
Dorrit
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

that
he
does

here
to
see

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
why
he
should
come
here
or
anywhere

,
ma'am
,
I
ca

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

,
and
with

,

,
as

upon

.
 
<EOS>
Some

.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
in

had
been
waiting
to

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
She

to

.
 
<EOS>
She

"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
Little

<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
No

"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"

<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

to

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
That

<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

"
   
<EOS>
In

Mistress
Affery

,

.
 
<EOS>
Her

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
as

,
that
the
house
door
might

.
   
<EOS>
On

to

,

,

,

he

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

Dorrit
,
he
passed

,
said

(

)
,
"
Pancks
the

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lord

us
<EOS>
,
here
's
a

and

-
teller
in

!
"
<EOS>
cried

.
<EOS>
"
What
next
!
 
<EOS>
She

,

with
this

,
on
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

were

,
and

was
coming
up

,

some

that

,

-

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

"
Let

!
 
<EOS>
Let

rest
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mistress

,

of
the

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

,

!
"
<EOS>

"
when

!
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Why

as

,

.

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

quantity

hair

---
<EOS>
jet

,

,

---

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
Me

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
Up

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Them
two

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Now
,

,
frankly
 
---
frankness

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
"
Business
-

,

,

?
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Long

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
just
landed
from
the
packet
-
boat
,
as
you
may
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
showed
her
that
his
cloak
was
very
wet
,
and
that
his
boots
were
saturated
with
water
;
she
had
previously
observed
that
he
was
dishevelled
and
sallow
,
as
if
from
a
rough
voyage
,
and
so
chilled
that
he
could
not
keep
his
teeth
from
chattering
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
just
landed
from
the
packet
-
boat
,
madam
,
and
have
been
delayed
by
the
weather
:
the
infernal
weather
!
 
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
this
,
madam
,
some
necessary
business
that
I
should
otherwise
have
transacted
here
within
the
regular
hours
(
necessary
business
because
money
-
business
)
,
still
remains
to
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
if
you
will
fetch
any
authorised
neighbouring
somebody
to
do
it
in
return
for
my
opening
the
door
,
I
'll
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
If
this
arrangement
should
be
objectionable
,
I
'll
---
"
and
with
the
same
smile
he
made
a
significant
feint
of
backing
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
,
heartily
glad
to
effect
the
proposed
compromise
,
gave
in
her
willing
adhesion
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
at
once
requested
her
to
do
him
the
favour
of
holding
his
cloak
,
took
a
short
run
at
the
narrow
window
,
made
a
leap
at
the
sill
,
clung
his
way
up
the
bricks
,
and
in
a
moment
had
his
hand
at
the
sash
,
raising
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
looked
so
very
sinister
,
as
he
put
his
leg
into
the
room
and
glanced
round
at
Mistress
Affery
,
that
she
thought
with
a
sudden
coldness
,
if
he
were
to
go
straight
up
-
stairs
to
murder
the
invalid
,
what
could
she
do
to
prevent
him
?
   
<EOS>
Happily
he
had
no
such
purpose
;
for
he
reappeared
,
in
a
moment
,
at
the
house
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
took
back
his
cloak
and
threw
it
on
,
"
if
you
have
the
goodness
to
---
what
the
Devil
's
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
strangest
of
sounds
.
 
<EOS>
Evidently
close
at
hand
from
the
peculiar
shock
it
communicated
to
the
air
,
yet
subdued
as
if
it
were
far
off
.
 
<EOS>
A
tremble
,
a
rumble
,
and
a
fall
of
some
light
dry
matter
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
Devil
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
,
but
I
've
heard
the
like
of
it
over
and
over
again
,
"
said
Affery
,
who
had
caught
his
arm
.
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
be
a
very
brave
man
,
even
she
thought
in
her
dreamy
start
and
fright
,
for
his
trembling
lips
had
turned
colourless
.
<EOS>
After
listening
a
few
moments
,
he
made
light
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
 
<EOS>
Nothing
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
my
dear
madam
,
I
think
you
spoke
of
some
clever
personage
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
be
so
good
as
to
confront
me
with
that
genius
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
held
the
door
in
his
hand
,
as
though
he
were
quite
ready
to
shut
her
out
again
if
she
failed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
say
anything
about
the
door
and
me
,
then
,
"
whispered
Affery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't
you
stir
from
here
,
or
speak
if
she
calls
,
while
I
run
round
the
corner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
I
am
a
statue
.
"
   
<EOS>
Affery
had
so
vivid
a
fear
of
his
going
stealthily
<EOS>
up
-
stairs
<EOS>
the
moment
her
back
was
turned
,
<EOS>
that
after
hurrying
out
of
sight
,
she
returned
to
the
gateway
to
peep
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
him
still
on
the
threshold
,
more
out
of
the
house
than
in
it
,
as
if
he
had
no
love
for
darkness
and
no
desire
to
probe
its
mysteries
,
she
flew
into
the
next
street
,
and
sent
a
message
into
the
tavern
to
Mr
Flintwinch
,
who
came
out
directly
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
returning
together
---
the
lady
in
advance
,
and
Mr
Flintwinch
coming
up
briskly
behind
,
animated
with
the
hope
of
shaking
her
before
she
could
get
housed
<EOS>
---
saw
the
gentleman
standing
in
the
same
place
in
the
dark
,
and
heard
the
strong
voice
of
Mrs
Clennam
calling
from
her
room
,
"
Who
is
it
?
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Why
does
no
one
answer
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
that
,
down
there
?
"
    
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
The
Word
of
a
Gentleman
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
and
Mrs
Flintwinch
panted
up
to
the
door
of
the
old
house
in
the
twilight
,
Jeremiah
within
a
second
of
Affery
,
the
stranger
started
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Death
of
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
did
you
get
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
to
whom
these
words
were
spoken
,
repaid
the
stranger
's
wonder
in
full
.
 
<EOS>
He
gazed
at
him
with
blank
astonishment
;
he
looked
over
his
own
shoulder
,
as
expecting
to
see
some
one
he
had
not
been
aware
of
standing
behind
him
;
he
gazed
at
the
stranger
again
,
speechlessly
,
at
a
loss
to
know
what
he
meant
;
he
looked
to
his
wife
for
explanation
;
receiving
none
,
he
pounced
upon
her
,
and
shook
her
with
such
heartiness
that
he
shook
her
cap
off
her
head
,
saying
between
his
teeth
,
with
grim
raillery
,
as
he
did
it
,
"
Affery
,
my
woman
,
you
must
have
a
dose
,
my
woman
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
some
of
your
tricks
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
dreaming
again
,
mistress
.
<EOS>
What
's
it
about
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
What
does
it
mean
!
 
<EOS>
Speak
out
or
be
choked
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
only
choice
I
'll
give
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Supposing
Mistress
Affery
to
have
any
power
of
election
at
the
moment
,
her
choice
was
decidedly
to
be
choked
;
for
she
answered
not
a
syllable
to
this
adjuration
,
but
,
with
her
bare
head
wagging
violently
backwards
and
forwards
,
resigned
herself
to
her
punishment
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
however
,
picking
up
her
cap
with
an
air
of
gallantry
,
interposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Permit
me
,
"
said
he
,
laying
his
hand
on
the
shoulder
of
Jeremiah
,
who
stopped
and
released
his
victim
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Excuse
me
.
<EOS>
Husband
and
wife
<EOS>
I
know
,
from
this
playfulness
.
 
<EOS>
Haha
!
 
<EOS>
Always
agreeable
to
see
that
relation
playfully
maintained
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
!
 
<EOS>
May
I
suggest
that
somebody
up
-
stairs
,
in
the
dark
,
is
becoming
energetically
curious
to
know
what
is
going
on
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
reference
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
voice
reminded
Mr
Flintwinch
to
step
into
the
hall
and
call
up
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
,
I
am
here
,
Affery
is
coming
with
your
light
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he
said
to
the
latter
flustered
woman
,
who
was
putting
her
cap
on
,
"
Get
out
with
you
,
and
get
up
-
stairs
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
turned
to
the
stranger
and
said
to
him
,
"
Now
,
sir
,
what
might
you
please
to
want
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
"
I
must
be
so
troublesome
as
to
propose
a
candle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
assented
Jeremiah
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
stand
where
you
are
while
I
get
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
was
standing
in
the
doorway
,
but
turned
a
little
into
the
gloom
of
the
house
as
Mr
Flintwinch
turned
,
and
pursued
him
with
his
eyes
into
the
little
room
,
where
he
groped
about
for
a
phosphorus
box
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
found
it
,
it
was
damp
,
or
otherwise
out
of
order
;
and
match
after
match
that
he
struck
into
it
lighted
sufficiently
to
throw
a
dull
glare
about
his
groping
face
,
and
to
sprinkle
his
hands
with
pale
little
spots
of
fire
,
but
not
sufficiently
to
light
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
taking
advantage
of
this
fitful
illumination
of
his
visage
,
looked
intently
and
wonderingly
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,
when
he
at
last
lighted
the
candle
,
knew
he
had
been
doing
this
,
by
seeing
the
last
shade
of
a
lowering
watchfulness
clear
away
from
his
face
,
as
it
broke
into
the
doubtful
smile
that
was
a
large

in
its
expression
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
so
good
,
"
said
Jeremiah
,
closing
the
house

,
and
taking
a
pretty
sharp
survey
of
the
smiling
visitor
in
his
turn
,
"
as
to
step
into
my
counting
-
house
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
right
,
I
tell
you
!
"
<EOS>
petulantly
breaking
off
to
answer
the
voice
up
-
stairs
,
still
unsatisfied
,
though
Affery
was
there
,
speaking
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

I
tell

it
's
all

?
 
<EOS>
Preserve

woman
,
has
she
no
reason

in

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Timorous
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Timorous
?
"

Mr
Flintwinch
,

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
"
More

than

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Though

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Many
years
an
invalid
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
The
only

of
that

left

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Saying
something

to

that
at

,
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
Here

"
Your

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
MY

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
I
do

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
   
"
We

Blandois
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
stood
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
The
smiling
Mr
Blandois
,
opening

to
get

,

,
with

Mr

were

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
Not

I

<EOS>
take

,

<EOS>

?
"

,

<EOS>

.

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
JUST

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>
"
No

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

)

.

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Probably

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

nose
,
"
I
know
to
the
cost
of
my
head
and
stomach
:
the
detestable
and
intolerable
weather
having
racked
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
me
in
the
plight
in
which
I
came
out
of
the
packet
within
this
half
-
hour
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
been
here
hours
ago
,
and
then
I
should
not
have
to
apologise
<EOS>
---
permit
me
to
apologise
---
for
presenting
myself
so
unreasonably
,
and
frightening
---
<EOS>
no
,
by
-
the
-
bye
<EOS>
,
you
said
not
frightening
;
permit
me
to
apologise
again
---
the
esteemed
lady
,
Mrs
Clennam
,
in
her
invalid
chamber
above
stairs
.
"
   
<EOS>
Swagger
and
an
air
of
authorised
condescension
do
so
much
,
that
Mr
Flintwinch
had
already
begun
to
think
this
a
highly
gentlemanly
personage
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
less
unyielding
with
him
on
that
account
,
he
scraped
his
chin
and
said
,
what
could
he
have
the
honour
of
doing
for
Mr
Blandois
to
-
night
,
out
of
business
hours
?
   
<EOS>
"
Faith
!
"
returned
that
gentleman
,
shrugging
his
cloaked
shoulders
,
"
I
must
change
,
and
eat
and
drink
,
and
be
lodged
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
Have
the
kindness
to
advise
me
,
a
total
stranger
,
where
,
and
<EOS>
money
is
a
matter
of
perfect
indifference
until
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
The
nearer
<EOS>
the
place
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Next
door
,
if
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
was
slowly
beginning
,
"
For
a
gentleman
of
your
habits
,
there
is
not
in
this
immediate
neighbourhood
any
hotel
---
"
when
Mr
Blandois
took
him
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
for
my
habits
!
 
<EOS>
my
dear
sir
,
"
snapping
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
citizen
of
the
world
has
no
habits
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
am
,
in
my
poor
way
,
a
gentleman
,
by
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
deny
,
but
I
have
no
unaccommodating
prejudiced
habits
.
 
<EOS>
A
clean
room
,
a
hot
dish
for
dinner
,
and
a
bottle
of
not
absolutely
poisonous
wine
,
are
all
I
want
tonight
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
want
that
much
without
the
trouble
of
going
one
unnecessary
inch
to
get
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
with
more
than
his
usual
deliberation
,
as
he
met
,
for
a
moment
,
Mr
Blandois
'
shining
eyes
,
which
were
restless
;
"
there
is
a
coffee
-
house
and
tavern
close
here
,
which
,
so
far
,
I
can
recommend
;
but
there
's
no
style
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dispense
with
style
!
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
waving
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
me
the
honour
to
show
me
the
house
,
and
introduce
me
there
(
if
I
am
not
too

)
,
and
I
shall
be
infinitely

.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
upon
this
,
looked
up
his
hat
,
and
lighted
Mr
Blandois
across
the
hall
again
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
put
the
candle
on
a
bracket
,
where
the
dark
old
panelling
almost
served
as
an

for
it
,
he
bethought
himself
of
going
up
to
tell
the
invalid
that
he
would
not

absent
five
minutes
.
<EOS>
"
Oblige
me
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
on
his

,
"
by
presenting
my
card
of
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Do
me
the
favour
to
add
that
I
shall
be
happy
to
wait
on
Mrs
Clennam
,
to
offer
my

,
and
to
apologise
for
having
occasioned
any
agitation
in
this
tranquil
corner
,
if
it
should
suit
her

to
endure

a

for
a
