,
after
he
shall
have
changed
his
wet
clothes
and
fortified
himself
with
something
to
eat
and
drink
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
made
all
despatch
,
and
said
,
on
his
return
,
"
She
'll
be
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
;
but
,
being
conscious
that
her
sick
room
has
no
attractions
,
wishes
me
to
say
that
she
wo
n't
hold
you
to
your
offer
,
<EOS>
in
case
you
should
think
better
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
think
better
of
it
,
"
returned
the
gallant
Blandois
,
"
would
be
to
slight
a
lady
;
to
slight
a
lady
would
be
to
be
deficient
in
chivalry
towards
the
sex
;
and
chivalry
towards
the
sex
is
a
part
of
my
character
!
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
expressing
himself
,
he
threw
the
draggled
skirt
of
his
cloak
over
his
shoulder
,
and
accompanied
Mr
Flintwinch
to
the
tavern
;
taking
up
on
the
road
a
porter
who
was
waiting
with
his
portmanteau
on
the
outer
side
of
the
gateway
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
was
kept
in
a
homely
manner
,
and
the
condescension
of
Mr
Blandois
was
infinite
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
fill
to
inconvenience
the
little
bar
in
which
the
widow
landlady
and
her
two
daughters
received
him
;
it
was
much
too
big
for
the
narrow
wainscoted
room
with
a
bagatelle
-
board
in
it
,
that
was
first
proposed
for
his
reception
;
it
perfectly
swamped
the
little
private
holiday
sitting
-
room
of
the
family
,
which
was
finally
given
up
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
in
dry
clothes
and
scented
linen
,
with
sleeked
hair
,
a
great
ring
on
each
forefinger
and
a
massive
show
of
watch
-
chain
,
Mr
Blandois
waiting
for
his
dinner
,
lolling
on
a
window
-
seat
with
his
knees
drawn
up
,
looked
(
for
all
the
difference
in
the
setting
of
the
jewel
)
fearfully
and
wonderfully
like
a
certain
Monsieur
Rigaud
who
had
once
so
waited
for
his
breakfast
,
lying
on
the
stone
ledge
of
the
iron
grating
of
a
cell
in
a
villainous
dungeon
at
Marseilles
.
   
<EOS>
His
greed
at
dinner
,
too
,
was
closely
in
keeping
with
the
greed
of
Monsieur
Rigaud
at
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
His
avaricious
manner
of
collecting
all
the
eatables
about
him
,
and
devouring
some
with
his
eyes
while
devouring
others
with
his
jaws
,
was
the
same
manner
.
 
<EOS>
His
utter
disregard
of
other
people
,
as
shown
in
his
way
of
tossing
the
little
womanly
toys
of
furniture
about
,
flinging
favourite
cushions
under
his
boots
for
a
softer
rest
,
and
crushing
delicate
coverings
with
his
big
body
and
his
great
black
head
,
had
the
same
brute
selfishness
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
softly
moving
hands
that
were
so
busy
among
the
dishes
had
the
old
wicked
facility
of
the
hands
that
had
clung
to
the
bars
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
could
eat
no
more
,
and
sat
sucking
his
delicate
fingers
one
by
one
and
wiping
them
on
a
cloth
,
there
wanted
nothing
but
the
substitution
of
vine
-
leaves
to
finish
the
picture
.
   
<EOS>
On
this
man
,
with
his
moustache
going
up
and
his
nose
coming
down
in
that
most
evil
of
smiles
,
and
with
his
surface
eyes
looking
as
if
they
belonged
to
his
dyed
hair
,
and
had
had
their
natural
power
of
reflecting
light
stopped
by
some
similar
process
,
Nature
,
always
true
,
and
never
working
in
vain
,
had
set
the
mark
,
Beware
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
her
fault
,
if
the
warning
were
fruitless
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
never
to
blame
in
any
such
instance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
,
having
finished
his
repast
and
cleaned
his
fingers
,
took
a
cigar
from
his
pocket
,
and
,
lying
on
the
window
-
seat
again
,
smoked
it
out
at
his
leisure
,
occasionally
apostrophising
the
smoke
as
it
parted
from
his
thin
lips
in
a
thin
stream
:
   
<EOS>
"
Blandois
,
you
shall
turn
the
tables
on
society
,
my
little
child
.
<EOS>
Haha
!
 
<EOS>
Holy
blue
,
you
have
begun
well
,
Blandois
!
 
<EOS>
At
a
pinch
,
an
excellent
master
in
English
or
French
;
a
man
for
the
bosom
of
families
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
quick
perception
,
you
have
humour
<EOS>
,
you
have
ease
,
you
have
insinuating
manners
,
you
have
a
good
appearance
;
in
effect
,
you
are
a
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
you
shall
live
,
my
small
boy
,
and
a
gentleman
you
shall
die
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
win
,
however
the
game
goes
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
all
confess
your
merit
,
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
subdue
the
society
which
has
grievously
wronged
you
,
to
your
own
high
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
high
spirited
by
right
and
by
nature
,
my
Blandois
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
such
soothing
murmurs
did
this
gentleman
smoke
out
his
cigar
and
drink
out
his
bottle
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Both
being
finished
,
he
shook
himself
into
a
sitting
attitude
;
and
with
the
concluding
serious
apostrophe
,
"
Hold
,
then
!
 
<EOS>
Blandois
,
you
ingenious
one
,
have
all
your
wits
about
you
!
"
arose
and
went
back
to
the
house
of
Clennam
and
Co.
   
<EOS>
He
was
received
at
the
door
by
Mistress
Affery
,
who
,
under
instructions
from
her
lord
,
had
lighted
up
two
candles
in
the
hall
and
a
third
on
the
staircase
,
and
who
conducted
him
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
Tea
was
prepared
there
,
and
such
little
company
arrangements
had
been
made
as
usually
attended
the
reception
of
expected
visitors
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
slight
on
the
greatest
occasion
,
never
extending
beyond
the
production
of
the
China
tea
-
service
,
and
the
covering
of
the
bed
with
a
sober
and
sad
drapery
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
rest
,
there
was
the
bier
-
like
sofa
with
the
block
upon
it
,
and
the
figure
in
the
widow
's
dress
,
as
if
attired
for
execution
;
the
fire
topped
by
the
mound
of
damped
ashes
;
the
grate
with
its
second
little
mound
of
ashes
;
the
kettle
and
the
smell
of
black
dye
;
all
as
they
had
been
for
fifteen
years
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
presented
the
gentleman
commended
to
the
consideration
of
Clennam
and
Co.
 
Mrs
Clennam
,
who
had
the
letter
lying
before
her
,
bent
her
head
and
requested
him
to
sit
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
very
closely
at
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
but
natural
curiosity
.
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
sir
,
for
thinking
of
a
disabled
woman
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
Few
who
come
here
on
business
have
any
remembrance
to
bestow
on
one
so
removed
from
observation
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
idle
to
expect
that
they
should
have
.
 
<EOS>
Out
of
sight
,
out
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
am
grateful
for
the
exception
,
I
do
n't
complain
of
the
rule
.
 
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
Blandois
,
in
his
most
gentlemanly
manner
,
was
afraid
he
had
disturbed
her
by
unhappily
presenting
himself
at
such
an
unconscionable
time
.
 
<EOS>
For
which
he
had
already
offered
his
best
apologies
to
Mr
---
he
begged
pardon
---
but
by
name
had
not
the
distinguished
honour
---
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Flintwinch
has
been
connected
with
the
House
many
years
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
was
Mr
Flintwinch
's
most
obedient
humble
servant
.
 
<EOS>
He
entreated
Mr
Flintwinch
to
receive
the
assurance
of
his
profoundest
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
husband
being
dead
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
and
my
son
preferring
another
pursuit
<EOS>
,
our
old
House
has
no
other
representative
in
these
days
than
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
   
"
What
do
you
call
yourself
?
"
<EOS>
was
the
surly
demand
of
that
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
the
head
of
two
men
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
sex
disqualifies
me
,
"
she
proceeded
with
merely
a
slight
turn
of
her
eyes
in
jeremiah
's
direction
,
"
from
taking
a
responsible
part
in
the
business
,
even
if
I
had
the
ability
;
and
therefore
Mr
Flintwinch
combines
my
interest
with
his
own
,
and
conducts
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
what
it
used
to
be
;
but
some
of
our
old
friends
(
principally
the
writers
of
this
letter
)
have
the
kindness
not
to
forget
us
,
and
we
retain
the
power
of
doing
what
they
entrust
to
us
as
efficiently
as
we
ever
did
.
 
<EOS>
This
however
is
not
interesting
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
English
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Faith
,
madam
,
no
<EOS>
;
I
am
neither
born
nor
bred
in
England
.
 
<EOS>
In
effect
,
I
am
of
no
country
,
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
stretching
out
his
leg
and
smiting
it
:
"
I
descend
from
half
-
a
-
dozen
countries
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
much
about
the
world
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
.
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
madam
,
I
have
been
here
and
there
and
everywhere
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
ties
,
probably
.
 
<EOS>
Are
not
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
with
an
ugly
fall
of
his
eyebrows
,
"
I
adore
your
sex
,
but
I
am
not
married
---
never
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
,
who
stood
at
the
table
near
him
,
pouring
out
the
tea
,
happened
in
her
dreamy
state
to
look
at
him
as
he
said
these
words
,
and
to
fancy
that
she
caught
an
expression
in
his
eyes
which
attracted
her
own
eyes
so
that
she
could
not
get
them
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
effect
of
this
fancy
was
to
keep
her
staring
at
him
with
the
tea
-
pot
in
her
hand
,
not
only
to
her
own
great
uneasiness
,
but
manifestly
to
his
,
too
;
and
,
through
them
both
,
to
Mrs
Clennam
's
and
Mr
Flintwinch
's
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
a
few
ghostly
moments
supervened
,
when
they
were
all
confusedly
staring
without
knowing
why
.
   
<EOS>
"
Affery
,
"
her
mistress
was
the
first
to
say
,
"
what
is
the
matter
with
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Mistress
Affery
,
with
her
disengaged
left
hand
extended
towards
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
good
woman
mean
?
"
cried
Mr
Blandois
,
turning
white
,
hot
,
and
slowly
rising
with
a
look
of
such
deadly
wrath
that
it
contrasted
surprisingly
with
the
slight
force
of
his
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
is
it
possible
to
understand
this
good
creature
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
NOT
possible
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
screwing
himself
rapidly
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
do
n't
know
what
she
means
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
an
idiot
,
a
wanderer
in
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
She
shall
have
a
dose
,
she
shall
have
such
a
dose
!
 
<EOS>
Get
along
with
you
,
my
woman
,
"
he
added
in
her
ear
,
"
get
along
with
you
,
while
you
know
you
're
Affery
,
and
before
you
're
shaken
to
yeast
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
,
sensible
of
the
danger
in
which
her
identity
stood
,
relinquished
the
tea
-
pot
as
her
husband
seized
it
,
put
her
apron
over
her
head
,
and
in
a
twinkling
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
gradually
broke
into
a
smile
,
and
sat
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
excuse
her
,
Mr
Blandois
,
"
said
Jeremiah
,
pouring
out
the
tea
himself
,
"
she
's
failing
and
breaking
up
<EOS>
;
that
's
what
she
's
about
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
take
sugar
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
"
   
"
Thank
you
,
no
tea
for
me
.
<EOS>
---
Pardon
<EOS>
my
observing
it
,
but
that
's
a
very
remarkable
watch
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
tea
-
table
was
drawn
up
near
the
sofa
,
with
a
small
interval
between
it
and
Mrs
Clennam
's
own
particular
table
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
in
his
gallantry
had
risen
to
hand
that
lady
her
tea
(
her
dish
of
toast
was
already
there
)
,
and
it
was
in
placing
the
cup
conveniently
within
her
reach
that
the
watch
,
lying
before
her
as
it
always
did
,
attracted
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
looked
suddenly
up
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
be
permitted
?
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
old
-
fashioned
watch
,
"
he
said
,
taking
it
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heavy
for
use
,
but
massive
and
genuine
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
partiality
for
everything
genuine
.
 
<EOS>
Such
as
I
am
,
I
am
genuine
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Hah
!
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
's
watch
with
two
cases
in
the
old
fashion
.
 
<EOS>
May
I
remove
it
from
the
outer
case
?
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Aye
?
 
<EOS>
An
old
silk
watch
-
lining
,
worked
with
beads
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
seen
these
among
old
Dutch
people
and
Belgians
.
 
<EOS>
Quaint
things
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
old
-
fashioned
,
too
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
so
old
as
the
watch
,
I
think
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Extraordinary
how
they
used
to
complicate
these
cyphers
!
"
remarked
Mr
Blandois
,
glancing
up
with
his
own
smile
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
is
this
D*N*F
?
<EOS>
It
might
be
almost
anything
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Those
are
the
letters
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
who
had
been
observantly
pausing
all
this
time
with
a
cup
of
tea
in
his
hand
,
and
his
mouth
open
ready
to
swallow
the
contents
,
began
to
do
so
:
always
entirely
filling
his
mouth
before
he
emptied
it
at
a
gulp
;
and
always
deliberating
again
before
he
refilled
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
D*N*F
was
some
tender
,
lovely
,
fascinating
fair
-
creature
<EOS>
,
I
make
no
doubt
,
"
observed
Mr
Blandois
,
as
he
snapped
on
the
case
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
adore
her
memory
on
the
assumption
.
 
<EOS>
Unfortunately
for
my
peace
of
mind
,
I
adore
but
too
readily
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
a
vice
,
it
may
be
a
virtue
,
but
adoration
of
female
beauty
and
merit
constitutes
three
parts
of
my
character
,
madam
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
had
by
this
time
poured
himself
out
another
cup
of
tea
,
which
he
was
swallowing
in
gulps
as
before
,
with
his
eyes
directed
to
the
invalid
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
heart
-
free
here
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
she
returned
to
Mr
Blandois
.
<EOS>
"
Those
letters
are
not
intended
,
I
believe
,
for
the
initials
of
any
name
.
"
   
"
Of
a
motto
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
casually
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
a
sentence
.
 
<EOS>
They
have
always
stood
,
I
believe
,
for
Do
Not
Forget
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
naturally
,
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
replacing
the
watch
and
stepping
backward
to
his
former
chair
,
"
you
do
not
forget
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
finishing
his
tea
,
not
only
took
a
longer
gulp
than
he
had
taken
yet
,
but
made
his
succeeding
pause
under
new
circumstances
:
that
is
to
say
,
with
his
head
thrown
back
and
his
cup
held
still
at
his
lips
,
while
his
eyes
were
still
directed
at
the
invalid
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
that
force
of
face
,
and
that
concentrated
air
of
collecting
her
firmness
or
obstinacy
,
which
represented
in
her
case
what
would
have
been
gesture
and
action
in
another
,
as
she
replied
with
her
deliberate
strength
of
speech
:
"
<EOS>
No
,
sir
,
I
do
not
forget
.
 
<EOS>
To
lead
a
life
as
monotonous
as
mine
has
been
during
many
years
,
is
not
the
way
to
forget
.
 
<EOS>
To
lead
a
life
of
self
-
correction
is
not
the
way
to
forget
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sensible
of
having
(
as
we
all
have
,
every
one
of
us
,
all
the
children
of
Adam
!
)
<EOS>
offences
to
expiate
and
peace
to
make
<EOS>
,
does
not
justify
the
desire
to
forget
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
have
long
dismissed
it
,
and
I
neither
forget
nor
wish
to
forget
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
who
had
latterly
been
shaking
the
sediment
at
the
bottom
of
his
tea
-
cup
,
round
and
round
,
here
gulped
it
down
,
and
putting
the
cup
in
the
tea
-
tray
,
as
done
with
,
turned
his
eyes
upon
Mr
Blandois
as
if
to
ask
him
what
he
thought
of
that
?
   
<EOS>
"
All
expressed
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Blandois
,
with
his
smoothest
bow
and
his
white
hand
on
his
breast
,
"
by
the
word
"
naturally
,
"
which
I
am
proud
to
have
had
sufficient
apprehension
and
appreciation
<EOS>
(
but
without
appreciation
I
could
not
be
Blandois
)
to
employ
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
she
returned
,
"
if
I
doubt
the
likelihood
of
a
gentleman
of
pleasure
,
and
change
,
and
politeness
,
accustomed
to
court
and
to
be
courted
---
"
   
"
Oh
madam
!
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
<EOS>
If
I
doubt
the
likelihood
of
such
a
character
quite
comprehending
what
belongs
to
mine
in
my
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
obtrude
doctrine
upon
you
,
"
she
looked
at
the
rigid
pile
of
hard
pale
books
before
her
,
"
(
for
you
go
your
own
way
,
and
the
consequences
are
on
your
own
head
)
<EOS>
,
I
will
say
this
much
:
<EOS>
that
I
shape
my
course
by
pilots
,
strictly
by
proved
and
tried
pilots
,
under
whom
I
can
not
be
shipwrecked
<EOS>
---
can
not
be
---
and
that
if
I
were
unmindful
of
the
admonition
conveyed
in
those
three
letters
,
I
should
not
be
half
as
chastened
as
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
curious
how
she
seized
the
occasion
to
argue
with
some
invisible
opponent
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
with
her
own
better
sense
,
always
turning
upon
herself
and
her
own
deception
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
forgot
my
ignorances
in
my
life
of
health
and
freedom
,
I
might
complain
of
the
life
to
which
I
am
now
condemned
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
do
;
I
never
have
done
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
forgot
that
this
scene
,
the
Earth
,
is
expressly
meant
to
be
a
scene
of
gloom
,
and
hardship
,
and
dark
trial
,
for
the
creatures
who
are
made
out
of
its
dust
,
I
might
have
some
tenderness
for
its
vanities
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
such
tenderness
.
<EOS>
If
I
did
not
know
that
we
are
,
every
one
,
the
subject
(
most
justly
the
subject
)
of
a
wrath
that
must
be
satisfied
,
and
against
which
mere
actions
are
nothing
,
I
might
repine
at
the
difference
between
me
,
imprisoned
here
,
and
the
people
who
pass
that
gateway
yonder
.
<EOS>
But
I
take
it
as
a
grace
and
favour
to
be
elected
to
make
the
satisfaction
I
am
making
here
,
to
know
what
I
know
for
certain
here
,
and
to
work
out
what
I
have
worked
out
here
.
 
<EOS>
My
affliction
might
otherwise
have
had
no
meaning
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
I
would
forget
,
and
I
do
forget
,
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
I
am
contented
,
and
say
it
is
better
with
me
than
with
millions
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
spoke
these
words
,
she
put
her
hand
upon
the
watch
,
and
restored
it
to
the
precise
spot
on
her
little
table
which
it
always
occupied
.
 
<EOS>
With
her
touch
lingering
upon
it
,
she
sat
for
some
moments
afterwards
,
looking
at
it
steadily
and
half
-
defiantly
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
,
during
this
exposition
,
had
been
strictly
attentive
,
keeping
his
eyes
fastened
on
the
lady
,
and
thoughtfully
stroking
his
moustache
with
his
two
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
had
been
a
little
fidgety
,
and
now
struck
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
,
there
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
quite
understood
,
Mrs
Clennam
,
and
you
have
spoken
piously
and
well
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
,
I
suspect
,
is
not
of
a
pious
cast
.
"
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
sir
!
"
that
gentleman
protested
,
snapping
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
pardon
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
part
of
my
character
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sensitive
,
ardent
,
conscientious
,
and
imaginative
.
 
<EOS>
A
sensitive
,
ardent
,
conscientious
,
and
imaginative
man
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
must
be
that
,
or
nothing
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
an
inkling
of
suspicion
in
Mr
Flintwinch
's
face
that
he
might
be
nothing
,
as
he
swaggered
out
of
his
chair
<EOS>
(
it
was
characteristic
of
this
man
,
as
it
is
of
all
men
similarly
marked
,
that
whatever
he
did
,
he
overdid
,
though
it
were
sometimes
by
only
a
hairsbreadth
)
,
and
approached
to
take
his
leave
of
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
what
will
appear
to
you
the
egotism
of
a
sick
old
woman
,
sir
,
"
she
then
said
,
"
though
really
through
your
accidental
allusion
,
I
have
been
led
away
into
the
subject
of
myself
and
my
infirmities
.
 
<EOS>
Being
so
considerate
as
to
visit
me
<EOS>
,
I
hope
you
will
be
likewise
so
considerate
as
to
overlook
that
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
compliment
me
,
if
you
please
.
"
 
<EOS>
For
he
was
evidently
going
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Flintwinch
will
be
happy
to
render
you
any
service
,
and
I
hope
your
stay
in
this
city
may
prove
agreeable
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
thanked
her
,
and
kissed
his
hand
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
an
old
room
,
"
he
remarked
,
with
a
sudden
sprightliness
of
manner
,
looking
round
when
he
got
near
the
door
,
"
I
have
been
so
interested
that
I
have
not
observed
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
genuine
old
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
genuine
old
house
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
with
her
frozen
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
place
of
no
pretensions
,
but
a
piece
of
antiquity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Faith
!
"
cried
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
Mr
Flintwinch
would
do
me
the
favour
to
take
me
through
the
rooms
on
my
way
out
,
he
could
hardly
oblige
me
more
.
 
<EOS>
An
old
house
is
a
weakness
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
many
weaknesses
,
but
none
greater
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
and
study
the
picturesque
in
all
its
varieties
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
called
picturesque
myself
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
no
merit
to
be
picturesque
<EOS>
---
I
have
greater
merits
,
perhaps
---
but
I
may
be
,
by
an
accident
.
 
<EOS>
Sympathy
,
sympathy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
beforehand
,
Mr
Blandois
,
that
you
'll
find
it
very
dingy
and
very
bare
,
"
said
Jeremiah
,
taking
up
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
worth
your
looking
at
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Blandois
,
smiting
him
in
a
friendly
manner
on
the
back
,
only
laughed
;
so
the
said
Blandois
kissed
his
hand
again
to
Mrs
Clennam
,
and
they
went
out
of
the
room
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
care
to
go
up
-
stairs
?
"
<EOS>
said
Jeremiah
,
on
the
landing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
Mr
Flintwinch
;
if
not
tiresome
to
you
,
I
shall
be
ravished
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
therefore
,
wormed
himself
up
the
staircase
,
and
Mr
Blandois
followed
close
.
 
<EOS>
They
ascended
to
the
great
garret
bed
-
room
which
Arthur
had
occupied
on
the
night
of
his
return
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
,
Mr
Blandois
!
"
said
Jeremiah
,
showing
it
,
"
I
hope
you
may
think
that
worth
coming
so
high
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
I
confess
I
do
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
being
enraptured
,
they
walked
through
other
garrets
and
passages
,
and
came
down
the
staircase
again
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
Mr
Flintwinch
had
remarked
that
he
never
found
the
visitor
looking
at
any
room
,
after
throwing
one
quick
glance
around
,
but
always
found
the
visitor
looking
at
him
,
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
discovery
in
his
thoughts
,
he
turned
about
on
the
staircase
for
another
experiment
.
 
<EOS>
He
met
his
eyes
directly
;
and
on
the
instant
of
their
fixing
one
another
,
the
visitor
,
with
that
ugly
play
of
nose
and
moustache
,
laughed
(
as
he
had
done
at
every
similar
moment
since
they
left
Mrs
Clennam
's
chamber
)
<EOS>
a
diabolically
silent
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
As
a
much
shorter
man
than
the
visitor
,
Mr
Flintwinch
was
at
the
physical
disadvantage
of
being
thus
disagreeably
leered
at
from
a
height
;
and
as
he
went
first
down
the
staircase
,
and
was
usually
a
step
or
two
lower
than
the
other
,
this
disadvantage
was
at
the
time
increased
.
 
<EOS>
He
postponed
looking
at
Mr
Blandois
again
until
this
accidental
inequality
was
removed
by
their
having
entered
the
late
Mr
Clennam
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
then
twisting
himself
suddenly
round
upon
him
,
he
found
his
look
unchanged
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
admirable
old
house
,
"
smiled
Mr
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
mysterious
.
<EOS>
Do
you
never
hear
any
haunted
noises
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Noises
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
see
any
devils
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
grimly
screwing
himself
at
his
questioner
,
"
not
any
that
introduce
themselves
under
that
name
and
in
that
capacity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
 
<EOS>
A
portrait
here
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
Still
looking
at
Mr
Flintwinch
,
as
if
he
were
the
portrait
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
portrait
,
sir
,
as
you
observe
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
the
subject
,
Mr
Flintwinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
deceased
.
 
<EOS>
Her
husband
.
"
<EOS>
"
Former
owner
of
the
remarkable
watch
,
perhaps
?
"
said
the
visitor
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
who
had
cast
his
eyes
towards
the
portrait
,
twisted
himself
about
again
,
and
again
found
himself
the
subject
of
the
same
look
and
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr
Blandois
,
"
he
replied
tartly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
his
,
and
his
uncle
's
before
him
,
and
Lord
knows
who
before
him
;
and
that
's
all
I
can
tell
you
of
its
pedigree
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
strongly
marked
character
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
our
friend
up
-
stairs
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Jeremiah
,
twisting
himself
at
the
visitor
again
,
as
he
did
during
the
whole
of
this
dialogue
,
like
some
screw
-
machine
that
fell
short
of
its
grip
;
for
the
other
never
changed
,
and
he
always
felt
obliged
to
retreat
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
a
remarkable
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Great
fortitude
---
great
strength
of
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
must
have
been
very
happy
,
"
said
Blandois
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
demanded
Mr
Flintwinch
,
with
another
screw
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
shook
his
right
forefinger
towards
the
sick
room
,
and
his
left
forefinger
towards
the
portrait
,
and
then
,
putting
his
arms
akimbo
and
striding
his
legs
wide
apart
,
stood
smiling
down
at
Mr
Flintwinch
with
the
advancing
nose
and
the
retreating
moustache
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
happy
as
most
other
married
people
,
I
suppose
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
secrets
in
all
families
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Secrets
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Blandois
,
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
it
again
,
my
son
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
replied
Mr
Flintwinch
,
upon
whom
he
had
swelled
himself
so
suddenly
that
Mr
Flintwinch
found
his
face
almost
brushed
by
the
dilated
chest
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
there
are
secrets
in
all
families
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
there
are
,
"
cried
the
other
,
clapping
him
on
both
shoulders
,
and
rolling
him
backwards
and
forwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
 
<EOS>
you
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
So
there
are
!
 
<EOS>
Secrets
!
 
<EOS>
Holy
Blue
!
 
<EOS>
There
are
the
devil
's
own
secrets
in
some
families
,
Mr
Flintwinch
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
,
after
clapping
Mr
Flintwinch
on
both
shoulders
several
times
,
as
if
in
a
friendly
and
humorous
way
he
were
rallying
him
on
a
joke
he
had
made
,
he
threw
up
his
arms
,
threw
back
his
head
,
hooked
his
hands
together
behind
it
,
and
burst
into
a
roar
of
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
for
Mr
Flintwinch
to
try
another
screw
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
his
laugh
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
favour
me
with
the
candle
a
moment
,
"
he
said
,
when
he
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
have
a
look
at
the
husband
of
the
remarkable
lady
.
<EOS>
Hah
!
<EOS>
"
holding
up
the
light
at
arm
's
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
decided
expression
of
face
here
too
,
though
not
of
the
same
character
.
 
<EOS>
Looks
as
if
he
were
saying
,
what
is
it
---
<EOS>
Do
Not
Forget
---
<EOS>
does
he
not
,
Mr
Flintwinch
?
   
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
sir
,
he
does
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
returned
the
candle
,
he
looked
at
him
once
more
;
and
then
,
leisurely
strolling
out
with
him
into
the
hall
,
declared
it
to
be
a
charming
old
house
indeed
,
and
one
which
had
so
greatly
pleased
him
that
he
would
not
have
missed
inspecting
it
for
a
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
Throughout
these
singular
freedoms
on
the
part
of
Mr
Blandois
,
which
involved
a
general
alteration
in
his
demeanour
,
making
it
much
coarser
and
rougher
,
much
more
violent
and
audacious
than
before
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
whose
leathern
face
was
not
liable
to
many
changes
,
preserved
its
immobility
intact
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
now
appearing
perhaps
,
to
have
been
left
hanging
a
trifle
too
long
before
that
friendly
operation
of
cutting
down
,
he
outwardly
maintained
an
equable
composure
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
brought
their
survey
to
a
close
in
the
little
room
at
the
side
of
the
hall
,
and
he
stood
there
,
eyeing
Mr
Blandois
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
are
so
well
satisfied
,
sir
,
"
was
his
calm
remark
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
expect
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
seem
to
be
quite
in
good
spirits
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
admirable
spirits
,
"
returned
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
"
Word
of
honour
!
 
<EOS>
never
more
refreshed
in
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
have
presentiments
,
Mr
Flintwinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
sure
that
I
know
what
you
mean
by
the
term
,
sir
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
,
in
this
case
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
undefined
anticipations
of
pleasure
to
come
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
I
'm
sensible
of
such
a
sensation
at
present
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
with
the
utmost
gravity
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
should
find
it
coming
on
,
I
'll
mention
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
,
"
said
Blandois
,
"
I
,
my
son
,
have
a
presentiment
to
-
night
that
we
shall
be
well
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
find
it
coming
on
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
N
-
no
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
,
deliberately
inquiring
of
himself
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
strong
presentiment
that
we
shall
become
intimately
acquainted
.
<EOS>
---
You
have
no
feeling
of
that
sort
yet
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
,
taking
him
by
both
shoulders
again
,
rolled
him
about
a
little
in
his
former
merry
way
,
then
drew
his
arm
through
his
own
,
and
invited
him
to
come
off
and
drink
a
bottle
of
wine
like
a
dear
deep
old
dog
as
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
Without
a
moment
's
indecision
,
Mr
Flintwinch
accepted
the
invitation
,
and
they
went
out
to
the
quarters
where
the
traveller
was
lodged
,
through
a
heavy
rain
which
had
rattled
on
the
windows
,
roofs
,
and
pavements
,
ever
since
nightfall
.
 
<EOS>
The
thunder
and
lightning
had
long
ago
passed
over
,
but
the
rain
was
furious
.
 
<EOS>
On
their
arrival
at
Mr
Blandois
'
room
,
a
bottle
of
port
wine
was
ordered
by
that
gallant
gentleman
;
who
(
crushing
every
pretty
thing
he
could
collect
,
in
the
soft
disposition
of
his
dainty
figure
)
coiled
himself
upon
the
window
-
seat
,
while
Mr
Flintwinch
took
a
chair
opposite
to
him
,
with
the
table
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Blandois
proposed
having
the
largest
glasses
in
the
house
,
to
which
Mr
Flintwinch
assented
.
 
<EOS>
The
bumpers
filled
,
Mr
Blandois
,
with
a
roystering
gaiety
,
clinked
the
top
of
his
glass
against
the
bottom
of
Mr
Flintwinch
's
,
and
the
bottom
of
his
glass
against
the
top
of
Mr
Flintwinch
's
,
and
drank
to
the
intimate
acquaintance
he
foresaw
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
gravely
pledged
him
,
and
drank
all
the
wine
he
could
get
,
and
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
Mr
Blandois
clinked
glasses
(
which
was
at
every
replenishment
)
,
Mr
Flintwinch
stolidly
did
his
part
of
the
clinking
,
and
would
have
stolidly
done
his
companion
's
part
of
the
wine
as
well
as
his
own
:
being
,
except
in
the
article
of
palate
,
a
mere
cask
.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
Mr
Blandois
found
that
to
pour
port
wine
into
the
reticent
Flintwinch
was
,
not
to
open
him
but
to
shut
him
up
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
had
the
appearance
of
a
perfect
ability
to
go
on
all
night
;
or
,
if
occasion
were
,
all
next
day
and
all
next
night
;
whereas
Mr
Blandois
soon
grew
indistinctly
conscious
of
swaggering
too
fiercely
and
boastfully
.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
terminated
the
entertainment
at
the
end
of
the
third
bottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
draw
upon
us
to
-
morrow
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
with
a
business
-
like
face
at
parting
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
Cabbage
,
"
returned
the
other
,
taking
him
by
the
collar
with
both
hands
,
"
I
'll
draw
upon
you
;
have
no
fear
.
 
<EOS>
Adieu
,
my
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
Receive
at
parting
;
"
here
he
gave
him
a
southern
embrace
,
and
kissed
him
soundly
on
both
cheeks
;
"
the
word
of
a
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
By
a
thousand
Thunders
,
you
shall
see
me
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
not
present
himself
next
day
,
though
the
letter
of
advice
came
duly
to
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Inquiring
after
him
at
night
,
Mr
Flintwinch
found
,
with
surprise
,
that
he
had
paid
his
bill
and
gone
back
to
the
Continent
by
way
of
Calais
.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
Jeremiah
scraped
out
of
his
cogitating
face
a
lively
conviction
that
Mr
Blandois
would
keep
his
word
on
this
occasion
,
and
would
be
seen
again
.
    
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Spirit
 
<EOS>
Anybody
may
pass
,
any
day
,
in
the
thronged
thoroughfares
of
the
metropolis
,
some
meagre
,
wrinkled
,
yellow
old
man
(
who
might
be
supposed
to
have
dropped
from
the
stars
,
if
there
were
any
star
in
the
Heavens
dull
enough
to
be
suspected
of
casting
off
so
feeble
a
spark
)
,
creeping
along
with
a
scared
air
,
as
though
bewildered
and
a
little
frightened
by
the
noise
and
bustle
.
 
<EOS>
This
old
man
is
always
a
little
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
ever
a
big
old
man
,
he
has
shrunk
into
a
little
old
man
;
if
he
were
always
a
little
old
man
,
he
has
dwindled
into
a
less
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
His
coat
is
a
colour
,
and
cut
,
that
never
was
the
mode
anywhere
,
at
any
period
.
 
<EOS>
Clearly
,
it
was
not
made
for
him
,
or
for
any
individual
mortal
.
 
<EOS>
Some
wholesale
contractor
measured
Fate
for
five
thousand
coats
of
such
quality
,
and
Fate
has
lent
this
old
coat
to
this
old
man
,
as
one
of
a
long
unfinished
line
of
many
old
men
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
always
large
dull
metal
buttons
,
similar
to
no
other
buttons
.
 
<EOS>
This
old
man
wears
a
hat
,
a
thumbed
and
napless
and
yet
an
obdurate
hat
,
which
has
never
adapted
itself
to
the
shape
of
his
poor
head
.
 
<EOS>
His
coarse
shirt
and
his
coarse
neckcloth
have
no
more
individuality
than
his
coat
and
hat
;
they
have
the
same
character
of
not
being
his
---
of
not
being
anybody
's
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
this
old
man
wears
these
clothes
with
a
certain
unaccustomed
air
of
being
dressed
and
elaborated
for
the
public
ways
;
as
though
he
passed
the
greater
part
of
his
time
in
a
nightcap
and
gown
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
,
like
the
country
mouse
in
the
second
year
of
a
famine
,
come
to
see
the
town
mouse
,
and
timidly
threading
his
way
to
the
town
-
mouse
's
lodging
through
a
city
of
cats
,
this
old
man
passes
in
the
streets
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
on
holidays
towards
evening
,
he
will
be
seen
to
walk
with
a
slightly
increased
infirmity
,
and
his
old
eyes
will
glimmer
with
a
moist
and
marshy
light
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
little
old
man
is
drunk
.
<EOS>
A
very
small
measure
will
overset
him
;
he
may
be
bowled
off
his
unsteady
legs
with
a
half
-
pint
pot
.
 
<EOS>
Some
pitying
acquaintance
---
chance
acquaintance
very
often
---
has
warmed
up
his
weakness
with
a
treat
of
beer
,
and
the
consequence
will
be
the
lapse
of
a
longer
time
than
usual
before
he
shall
pass
again
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
little
old
man
is
going
home
to
the
Workhouse
;
and
on
his
good
behaviour
they
do
not
let
him
out
often
(
though
methinks
they
might
,
considering
the
few
years
<EOS>
he
has
before
him
to
go
out
in
,
under
the
sun
)
;
and
on
his
bad
behaviour
they
shut
him
up
closer
than
ever
in
a
grove
of
two
score
and
nineteen
more
old
men
,
every
one
of
whom
smells
of
all
the
others
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
's
father
,
---
a
poor
little
reedy
piping
old
gentleman
,
like
a
worn
-
out
bird
;
who
had
been
in
what
he
called
the
music
-
binding
business
,
and
met
with
great
misfortunes
,
and
who
had
seldom
been
able
to
make
his
way
,
or
to
see
it
or
to
pay
it
,
or
to
do
anything
at
all
with
it
but
find
it
no
thoroughfare
,
---
had
retired
of
his
own
accord
to
the
Workhouse
which
was
appointed
by
law
to
be
the
Good
Samaritan
of
his
district
(
without
the
twopence
,
which
was
bad
political

)
,
on
the
settlement
of
that
execution
which
had
carried
Mr
Plornish
to
the
Marshalsea
College
.
<EOS>
Previous
to
his
son
-
in
-
law
's
difficulties
coming
to
that
head
,
Old
Nandy
<EOS>
(
he
was
always
so
called
in
his
legal

,
but
he
was
Old
Mr
Nandy
among
the
Bleeding

)
<EOS>
had

the
Plornish

,
and
taken

.
 
<EOS>
He

when

should

upon

son

;

,

,
he

,

,
one

these

in

.
   
<EOS>
But
no

in

,
and
no

that
never

mode
,
and
no
Old
Men
's

for

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
was
as

of
her
father
's

as
she

possibly

if

.
 
<EOS>
She

as

as

.
 
<EOS>
The
poor

old
man
knew
some

,
long

,
about
Chloe
,
and
Phyllis
,
and
Strephon
being
wounded

the

;
and

there

no
such

at
the

as

wherein

would
discharge

of

,
like

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
On
his
"
days
out
,
"
those

in

pollard
old

,
"

,

,

,

,
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
Then

would
give

Chloe
,

if

,
Phyllis
also
---
Strephon
he

---

,

.
   
<EOS>
If

Court

,
nay
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here

,
"

<EOS>
"
Father

.
 
<EOS>
Ai

?
 
<EOS>
Father
's

than
ever
<EOS>
;
you

,

.

<EOS>
As

Mr
Plornish
,

married

Mr
Nandy
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
"
For

,
"

"

-

music

've

?
<EOS>
That
's

is
,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Nandy
had
a
patron
:
one

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
patron
who
in
a
certain

way
---
an

,
as
if
he
constantly
took
an

to
witness
that

than

,
on

---
was

good

.
<EOS>
Old
Nandy
had
been
several
times
to
the
Marshalsea
College
,
communicating
with
his
son
-
in
-
law
during

;
and
had
happily

to

,
and
had
by

in

much

,

of
the
Father
of
that

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
in
the
habit
of
receiving
this
old
man
as
if
the
old
man
held
of
him
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
made

and

,
as
if

came
in
with
his

from
some

district
where
the

were
in

.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if

he
could
by

sworn
but
that
the
old

was
an
ancient

his
,
who
had

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
he
spoke

his

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
and
in

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
Workhouse
,
sir
,
the
Union
;
no

,
no

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Most

!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
Old
Nandy
's
birthday
,
and
they
let
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
about

his

,
or

kept

;
for

.
 
<EOS>
He

along

as
usual

Bleeding

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss

,
"

"

!
 
<EOS>
Ai

?
 
<EOS>
And

!
"
   
<EOS>
Little

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
In

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here

"
John

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
While

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

is
really
infamous
.
<EOS>
You
bad
little
thing
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
it
disgrace
anybody
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
very
gently
,
"
to
take
care
of
this
poor
old
man
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
miss
,
"
returned
her
sister
,
"
and
you
ought
to
know
it
does
.
<EOS>
And
you
do
know
it
does
,
and
you
do
it
because
you
know
it
does
.
<EOS>
The
principal
pleasure
of
your
life
is
to
remind
your
family
of
their
misfortunes
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
next
great
pleasure
of
your
existence
is
to
keep
low
company
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
however
,
if
you
have
no
sense
of
decency
,
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
please
to
allow
me
to
go
on
the
other
side
of
the
way
,
unmolested
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
,
she
bounced
across
to
the
opposite

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
disgrace
,
who
had
been
deferentially
bowing
a
pace
or
two
off
<EOS>
(
for
Little
Dorrit
had
let
his
arm
go
in
her

,
when
Fanny

)
,
and
who
had
been

and
cursed
by
impatient

for

,
rejoined
his
companion
,
rather

,
and
said
,
"
I
hope
nothing
's
wrong
with
your

father
,
Miss
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
there
's
nothing
the
matter
in
the
honoured
family
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
arm
again
,
Mr
Nandy
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
soon
be
there
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
she
talked
to
him
as
she
had
talked
before
,
and
they
came
to
the
Lodge
and
found
Mr
Chivery
on
the
lock
,
and
went
in
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
it
happened
that
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
was
sauntering
towards
the
Lodge
at
the
moment
when
they
were
coming
out
of
it
,
entering
the
prison
arm
in
arm
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
spectacle
of
their
approach
met
his
view
,
he
displayed
the
utmost
agitation
and
despondency
of
mind
;
and
---
altogether
regardless
of
Old
Nandy
,
who
,
making
his
reverence
,
stood
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
as
he
always
did
in
that
gracious
presence
---
turned
about
,
and
hurried
in
at
his
own
doorway
and
up
the
staircase
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
the
old
unfortunate
,
whom
in
an
evil
hour
she
had
taken
under
her
protection
,
with
a
hurried
promise
to
return
to
him
directly
,
Little
Dorrit
hastened
after
her
father
,
and
,
on
the
staircase
,
found
Fanny
following
her
,
and
flouncing
up
with
offended
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
The
three
came
into
the
room
almost
together
;
and
the
Father
sat
down
in
his
chair
,
buried
his
face
in
his
hands
,
and
uttered
a
groan
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
proper
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
,
afflicted
Pa
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
hope
you
believe
me
,
Miss
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
father
?
"
cried
Little
Dorrit
,
bending

.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
made
you
unhappy
,
father
?
 
<EOS>
Not
I
,
I

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
hope
,

!
 
<EOS>
I
dare

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
"
---
Fanny
paused

---
"
<EOS>
you
Common
-

little
<EOS>
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
You

!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped

angry

with

,

,
"
Amy
,
I

you

.
<EOS>
But
you
have
cut
me
to

.
"
<EOS>
"
Innocent
in
intention
!
"
the
implacable
Fanny
struck
in
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stuff
in
intention
!
 
<EOS>
Low
in
intention
!
 
<EOS>
Lowering
of
the
family
in
intention
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Little
Dorrit
,
pale

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
forgive
me
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
how
it
is
,
that
I

not
do

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
it
is
,
you
prevaricating
little
piece
of
goods
!
"
cried
Fanny
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
how
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
already
,
<EOS>
so
do
n't
fly
in
the
face
of
Providence
by
attempting
to
deny
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Amy
,
"
said
the
father
,
passing
his
pocket

handkerchief
several

across

face
,
and
then
grasping

in

,
"
I
have
done
what
I

to
keep
you

here
;
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

have

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

;
you
may

.
 
<EOS>
I

no

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
endured
everything
here
<EOS>
but
humiliation
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
have
happily
been
spared
---
until
this

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
his

unclosed

,
and
he

his
pocket

.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
on

,
with

,

.
 
<EOS>
Coming

,

pocket

.
   
<EOS>
"
Humiliation
<EOS>
I
have
happily
been
spared
until
this

.
 
<EOS>
Through

there

that
---
Spirit

,

that
---
that

,

,
in

,

---
ha
---
humiliation
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
day
,
this
minute
,
I
have
keenly

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
!
 
<EOS>
How
could

be

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Careering
and

with
a
Pauper
!
"
<EOS>
(
air
-
gun
again
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
dear
father
,
"

,
"
I
do

for
having
wounded
your
dear
heart
---
no
!
 
<EOS>
Heaven

I
do
n't
!
"
<EOS>
She

in
quite
an

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
nothing
but
beg
and

and
overlook

.
 
<EOS>
But

I

you

the
old
man

,
and
took

him
,

,
I

,
father
<EOS>
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

not

,
dear
love
!
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
her

,
"
for
anything

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Fanny
,

,

,
and
to
say
---
as
this
young
lady
always

when

,

half

---
that
she

.
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
in

took
his

daughter
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
!
 
<EOS>
Say

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
,
"
with

,
"
I
---
shall

able

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

<EOS>
the

reed
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

---
ha
---

Spirit
.
<EOS>
Becoming

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
"

"

<EOS>

---

---
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
smiling
!
<EOS>
---
arm

---
<EOS>
O

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
This
reference
to
the
coat
of
no

and
no

,
the
unfortunate

gasped

,
in

,

with

<EOS>
His

found

,

,

Fanny
(

,

Come

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Young
John
!
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What

,
Young
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,

,

,

with

<EOS>
,
I

,

,

,

.

<EOS>
The

Indeed

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
The

,

<EOS>
---

"

"

"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

No

<EOS>

<EOS>
Say

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

,
I

.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Chivery
junior
went
his
way
,
having
spontaneously

on
the
spot
an
entirely
new

for

,
to
the
effect
that
Here
lay
the
body
of
John
Chivery
,
<EOS>
Who
,
Having
at
such
a
date
,
Beheld
the
idol
of
his
life
,
In
grief
and
tears
,
And
feeling
unable
to
bear
the
harrowing
spectacle
,
Immediately
repaired
to
the
abode
of
his
inconsolable
parents
,
And
terminated
his
existence
by
his
own
rash
act
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
,
Amy
!
"
said
the
Father
,
when
Young
John
had
closed
the
door
,
"
let
us
say
no
more
about
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
last
few
minutes
had
improved
his
spirits
remarkably
,
and
he
was
quite
lightsome
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
my
old
pensioner
all
this
while
?
 
<EOS>
We
must
not
leave
him
by
himself
any
longer
,
or
he
will
begin
to
suppose
he
is
not
welcome
,
and
that
would
pain
me
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
fetch
him
,
my
child
,
or
shall
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
would
n't
mind
,
father
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
trying
to

her

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
will
go
,
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
;
your

are
rather

.
   
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
<EOS>
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

about

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
Go

,
Amy
,
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would

in

,
Father
,
"

Dorrit
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
far

Mr

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
fie
,

,
<EOS>
my

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
is

---

.
 
<EOS>
A
little
reserved
at
times
;
but
I
will
say
extremely
gentlemanly
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
think
of
your
not
being
here
to
receive
Mr
Clennam
,
my
dear
,
especially
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
So
go
and
freshen
yourself
up
,
<EOS>
Amy
;
go
and
freshen
yourself
up
,
like
a
good
girl
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
directed
,
Little
Dorrit
dutifully
rose
and
obeyed
:
only
pausing
for
a
moment
as
she
went
out
of
the
room
,
to
give
her
sister
a
kiss
of
reconciliation
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
that
young
lady
,
feeling
much
harassed
in
her
mind
,
and
having
for
the
time
worn
out
the
wish
with
which
she
generally
relieved
it
,
conceived
and
executed
the
brilliant
idea
of
wishing
Old
Nandy
dead
,
rather
than
that
he
should
come
bothering
there
like
a
disgusting
,
tiresome
,
wicked
wretch
,
and
making
mischief
between
two
sisters
.
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
even
humming
a
tune
,
and
wearing
his
black
velvet
cap
a
little
on
one
side
,
<EOS>
so
much
improved
were
his
spirits
,
went
down
into
the
yard
,
and
found
his
old
pensioner
standing
there
hat
in
hand
just
within
the
gate
,
as
he
had
stood
all
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Nandy
!
"
said
he
,
with
great
suavity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
up
-
stairs
,
Nandy
;
you
know
the
way
;
why
do
n't
you
come
up
-
stairs
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
went
the
length
,
on
this
occasion
,
of
giving
him
his
hand
and
saying
,
"
How
are
you
,
Nandy
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
pretty
well
?
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
that
vocalist
returned
,
"
I
thank
you
,
honoured
sir
<EOS>
,
I
am
all
the
better
for
seeing
your
honour
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
they
went
along
the
yard
,
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
presented
him
to
a
Collegian
of
recent
date
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
old
acquaintance
of
mine
,
sir
,
an
old
pensioner
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
said
,
"
Be
covered
,
my
good
Nandy
;
put
your
hat
on
,
"
with
great
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
His
patronage
did
not
stop
here
;
for
he
charged
Maggy
to
get
the
tea
ready
,
and
instructed
her
to
buy
certain
tea
-
cakes
,
fresh
butter
,
eggs
,
cold
ham
,
and
shrimps
:
to
purchase
which
collation
<EOS>
he
gave
her
a
bank
-
note
for
ten
pounds
,
laying
strict
injunctions
on
her
to
be
careful
of
the
change
.
 
<EOS>
These
preparations
were
in
an
advanced
stage
of
progress
,
and
his
daughter
Amy
had
come
back
with
her
work
,
when
Clennam
presented
himself
;
whom
he
most
graciously
received
,
and
besought
to
join
their
meal
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
my
love
,
you
know
Mr
Clennam
even
better
than
I
have
the
happiness
of
doing
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
,
my
dear
,
you
are
acquainted
with
Mr
Clennam
.
"
 
<EOS>
Fanny
acknowledged
him
haughtily
;
the
position
she
tacitly
took
up
in
all
such
cases
being
that
there
was
a
vast
conspiracy
to
insult
the
family
by
not
understanding
it
,
or
sufficiently
deferring
to
it
,
and
here
was
one
of
the
conspirators
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
Mr
Clennam
,
you
must
know
,
is
an
old
pensioner
of
mine
,
Old
Nandy
,
a
very
faithful
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
He
always
spoke
of
him
as
an
object
of
great
antiquity
,
but
he
was
two
or
three
years
younger
than
himself
.
)
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
Plornish
,
I
think
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
my
daughter
Amy
has
mentioned
to
me
that
you
know
poor
Plornish
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
yes
!
"
said
Arthur
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
this
is
Mrs
Plornish
's
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
be
more
glad
if
you
knew
his
many
good
qualities
,
Mr
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
come
to
know
them
through
knowing
him
,
"
said
Arthur
,
secretly
pitying
the
bowed
and
submissive
figure
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
holiday
with
him
,
and
he
comes
to
see
his
old
friends
,
who
are
always
glad
to
see
him
,
"
observed
the
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
.
   
<EOS>
Then
he
added
behind
his
hand
,
(
"
Union
,
poor
old
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Out
for
the
day
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
Maggy
,
quietly
assisted
by
her
Little
Mother
,
had
spread
the
board
,
and
the
repast
was
ready
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
hot
weather
and
the
prison
very
close
,
the
window
was
as
wide
open
as
it
could
be
pushed
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
Maggy
will
spread
that
newspaper
on
the
window
-
sill
,
my
dear
,
"
remarked
the
Father
complacently
and
in
a
half
whisper
to
Little
Dorrit
,
"
my
old
pensioner
can
have
his
tea
there
,
while
we
are
having
ours
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
with
a
gulf
between
him
and
the
good
company
of
about
a
foot
in
width
,
standard
measure
,
Mrs
Plornish
's
father
was
handsomely
regaled
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
had
never
seen
anything
like
his
magnanimous
protection
by
that
other
Father
,
he
of
the
Marshalsea
;
and
was
lost
in
the
contemplation
of
its
many
wonders
.
   
<EOS>
The
most
striking
of
these
was
perhaps
the
relishing
manner
in
which
he
remarked
on
the
pensioner
's
infirmities
and
failings
,
as
if
he
were
a
gracious
Keeper
making
a
running
commentary
on
the
decline
of
the
harmless
animal
he
exhibited
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
ready
for
more
ham
yet
,
Nandy
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
how
slow
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
(
His
last
teeth
,
"
he
explained
to
the
company
,
"
are
going
,
poor
old
boy
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
At
another
time
,
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
No
shrimps
,
Nandy
?
"
and
on
his
not
instantly
replying
,
observed
,
(
"
His
hearing
is
becoming
very
defective
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
be
deaf
directly
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
At
another
time
he
asked
him
,
"
Do
you
walk
much
,
Nandy
,
about
the
yard
within
the
walls
of
that
place
of
yours
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
;
<EOS>
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
any
great
liking
for
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
to
be
sure
,
"
he
assented
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
natural
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he
privately
informed
the
circle
(
"
Legs
going
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
Once
he
asked
the
pensioner
,
in
that
general
clemency
which
asked
him
anything
to
keep
him
afloat
,
how
old
his
younger
grandchild
was
?
   
<EOS>
"
John
Edward
,
"
said
the
pensioner
,
slowly
laying
down
his
knife
and
fork
to
consider
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
old
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Let
me
think
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
tapped
his
forehead
(
"
Memory
weak
.
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
John
Edward
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
really
forget
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
say
at
this
minute
,
sir
,
whether
it
's
two
and
two
months
,
or
whether
it
's
two
and
five
months
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
one
or
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
distress
yourself
by
worrying
your
mind
about
it
,
"
he
returned
,
with
infinite
forbearance
.
 
<EOS>
(
"
Faculties
evidently
decaying
---
old
man
rusts
in
the
life
he
leads
!
"
)
   
<EOS>
The
more
of
these
discoveries
that
he
persuaded
himself
he
made
in
the
pensioner
<EOS>
,
the
better
he
appeared
to
like
him
;
and
when
he
got
out
of
his
chair
after
tea
to
bid
the
pensioner
good
-
bye
,
on
his
intimating
that
he
feared
,
honoured
sir
,
his
time
was
running
out
,
he
made
himself
look
as
erect
and
strong
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
call
this
a
shilling
,
Nandy
,
you
know
,
"
he
said
,
putting
one
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
call
it
tobacco
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Honoured
sir
,
I
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
shall
buy
tobacco
.
 
<EOS>
My
thanks
and
duty
to
Miss
Amy
and
Miss
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
night
,
Mr
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
mind
you
do
n't
forget
us
,
you
know
,
Nandy
,
"
said
the
Father
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
come
again
,
mind
,
whenever
you
have
an
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
come
out
without
seeing
us
,
or
we
shall
be
jealous
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Nandy
.
 
<EOS>
Be
very
careful
how
you
descend
the
stairs
,
Nandy
;
they
are
rather
uneven
and
worn
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
stood
on
the
landing
,
watching
the
old
man
down
:
and
when
he
came
into
the
room
again
,
said
,
with
a
solemn
satisfaction
on
him
,
"
<EOS>
A
melancholy
sight
<EOS>
that
,
Mr
Clennam
,
though
one
has
the
consolation
of
knowing
that
he
does
n't
feel
it
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
old
fellow
is
a
dismal
wreck
.
<EOS>
Spirit
broken
and
gone
---
pulverised
---
crushed
out
of
him
,
sir
,
completely
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Clennam
had
a
purpose
in
remaining
,
he
said
what
he
could
responsive
to
these
sentiments
,
and
stood
at
the
window
with
their
enunciator
,
while
Maggy
and
her
Little
Mother
washed
the
tea
-
service
and
cleared
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
noticed
that
his
companion
stood
at
the
window
with
the
air
of
an
affable
and
accessible
Sovereign
,
and
that
,
when
any
of
his
people
in
the
yard
below
looked
up
,
his
recognition
of
their
salutes
just
stopped
short
of
a
blessing
.
   
<EOS>
When
Little
Dorrit
had
her
work
on
the
table
,
and
Maggy
hers
on
the
bedstead
,
Fanny
fell
to
tying
her
bonnet
as
a
preliminary
to
her
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
,
still
having
his
purpose
,
still
remained
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
door
opened
,
without
any
notice
,
and
Mr
Tip
came
in
.
<EOS>
He
kissed
Amy
as
she
started
up
to
meet
him
,
nodded
to
Fanny
,
nodded
to
his
father
,
gloomed
on
the
visitor
without
further
recognition
,
and
sat
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tip
,
dear
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
mildly
,
shocked
by
this
,
"
do
n't
you
see
---
"
   
"
Yes
,
I
see
,
<EOS>
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
refer
to
the
presence
of
any
visitor
you
have
here
---
I
say
,
if
you
refer
to
that
,
"
answered
Tip
,
jerking
his
head
with
emphasis
towards
his
shoulder
nearest
Clennam
,
"
I
see
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
you
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
,
"
added
the
lofty
young
man
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
"
that
visitor
will
understand
me
,
when
I
say
that
's
all
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
suppose
the
visitor
will
understand
that
he
has
n't
used
me
like
a
gentleman
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
that
,
"
observed
the
obnoxious
personage
referred
to
with
tranquillity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
then
,
to
make
it
clearer
to
you
,
sir
,
I
beg
to
let
you
know
that
when
I
address
what
I
call
a
properly
-
worded
appeal
,
and
an
urgent
appeal
,
and
a
delicate
appeal
,
to
an
individual
,
for
a
small
temporary
accommodation
,
easily
within
his
power
---
easily
within
his
power
,
mind
!
<EOS>
---
and
when
that
individual
writes
back
word
to
me
that
he
begs
to
be
excused
,
I
consider
that
he
does
n't
treat
me
like
a
gentleman
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
who
had
surveyed
his
son
in
silence
,
no
sooner
heard
this
sentiment
,
than
he
began
in
angry
voice
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
---
"
But
his
son
stopped
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
ask
me
how
I
dare
,
father
,
because
that
's
bosh
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
fact
of
the
line
of
conduct
I
choose
to
adopt
towards
the
individual
present
,
you
ought
to
be
proud
of
my
showing
a
proper
spirit
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
so
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
proper
spirit
?
"
said
the
Father
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
a
proper
spirit
;
a
becoming
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
come
to
this
that
my
son
teaches
me
---
ME
---
spirit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
let
us
bother
about
it
,
father
,
or
have
any
row
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
fully
made
up
my
mind
that
the
individual
present
has
not
treated
me
like
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
's
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
there
is
not
an
end
of
it
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
Father
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
there
shall
not
be
an
end
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
made
up
your
mind
?
 
<EOS>
You
have
made
up
your
mind
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
good
of
keeping
on
like
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
returned
the
Father
,
in
a
great
heat
,
"
you
had
no
right
to
make
up
your
mind
to
what
is
monstrous
,
to
what
is
---
ha
---
immoral
,
to
what
is
---
hum
---
parricidal
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
Mr

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
counted
as

,

by
.
    
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
More
Fortune
-
Telling
 
Maggy
sat
at
her
work
in
her
great
white
cap
with
its
quantity
of
opaque
frilling
hiding
what
profile
she
had
<EOS>
(
she
had
none
to
spare
)
,
and
her
serviceable
eye
brought
to
bear
upon
her
occupation
,
on
the
window
side
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
What
with
her
flapping
cap
,
and
what
with
her
unserviceable
eye
,
she
was
quite
partitioned
off
from
her
Little
Mother
,
whose
seat
was
opposite
the
window
.
<EOS>
The
tread
and
shuffle
of
feet
on
the
pavement
of
the
yard
had
much
diminished
since
the
taking
of
the
Chair
,
the
tide
of
Collegians
having
set
strongly
in
the
direction
of
Harmony
.
 
<EOS>
Some
few
who
had
no
music
in
their
souls
,
or
no
money
in
their
pockets
,
dawdled
about
;
and
the
old
spectacle
of
the
visitor
-
wife
and
the
depressed
unseasoned
prisoner
still
lingered
in
corners
,
as
broken
cobwebs
and
such
unsightly
discomforts
draggle
in
corners
of
other
places
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
quietest
time
the
College
knew
,
saving
the
night
hours
when
the
Collegians
took
the
benefit
of
the
act
of
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
occasional
rattle
of
applause
upon
the
tables
of
the
Snuggery
,
denoted
the
successful
termination
of
a
morsel
of
Harmony
;
or
the
responsive
acceptance
,
by
the
united
children
,
of
some
toast
or
sentiment
offered
to
them
by
their
Father
.
 
<EOS>
Occasionally
,
a
vocal

more
sonorous
than
the
generality
informed
the
listener
that
some
boastful
bass
was
in
blue
water
,
or
in
the

field
,
or
with
the

,
or
on
the
mountain
,
or
among
the
heather
;
but
the
Marshal
of
the
Marshalsea
knew
better
,
and
had
got
him
hard
and
fast
.
   
<EOS>
As
Arthur
Clennam
moved
to
sit
down
by
the
side
of
Little
Dorrit
,
she
trembled
so
that
she
had
much
ado
to
hold
her
needle
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
gently
put
his
hand
upon
her
work
,
and
said
,
"
Dear
Little
Dorrit
,
let
me
lay
it
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
yielded

to

,
and
he

.
 
<EOS>
Her

were
then
nervously

,
but
he

one

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
seldom

,
Little

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
heard

to
-
day
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
by
mere

,

your

with

.
 
<EOS>
Why
not

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I

.
 
<EOS>
Or

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
generally

now
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
He

her

little

---
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
your

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

was
now

beyond
her

.
 
<EOS>
Softly

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
own

,
"

<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
looked
round

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Such

<EOS>
She

"
You

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

-

,

<EOS>

,

"

,

?

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
"
Nor

?
 
<EOS>
Nor

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
He

"
<EOS>
To

I

,

.
   
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

had
.
 
<EOS>
I
must

of
you
.
<EOS>
Who

!
"
   
<EOS>
He
never

that
she
saw

no

.
<EOS>
He
never

.
   
<EOS>
"
But

I

,
"
he

,
"
and

I
will
not

own

for

.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,

Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Let

,
that
,

,

,

had

little

far

,

---
that
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Flora
.
 
<EOS>
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

think
---
"
   
"
I

,
"

,

to
herself
than
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
wonder
at
it
a
little
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Clennam
,
abiding
by
the
feeling
that
had
fallen
on
him
in
the
avenue
on
the
night
of
the
roses
,
the
feeling
that
he
was
an
older
man
,
who
had
done
with
that
tender
part
of
life
,
"
I
found
out
my
mistake
,
and
I
thought
about
it
a
little
---
in
short
,
a
good
deal
---
and
got
wiser
.
 
<EOS>
Being
wiser
,
I
counted
up
my
years
and
considered
what
I
am
,
and
looked
back
,
and
looked
forward
,
and
found
that
I
should
soon
be
grey
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
that
I
had
climbed
the
hill
,
and
passed
the
level
ground
upon
the
top
,
and
was
descending
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
he
had
known
the
sharpness
of
the
pain
he
caused
the
patient
heart
,
in
speaking
thus
!
 
<EOS>
While
doing
it
,
too
,
with
the
purpose
of
easing
and
serving
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
found
that
the
day
when
any
such
thing
would
have
been
graceful
in
me
,
or
good
in
me
,
or
hopeful
or
happy
for
me
or
any

in
connection
with
me
,
was
gone
,
and
would
never
shine
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
O
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
known
,
if
he
had
known
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
seen
the
dagger
in
his
hand
,
and
the
cruel

it

in

of
his
Little
Dorrit
!
   
<EOS>
"
All
that
is
over
,
and
I
have
turned

.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
I
speak

this
to
Little
Dorrit
?
 
<EOS>
Why
do
I
show
you
,
my
child
,
the
space
of
years
that
there
is
between

,
and
recall
to

that
I
have
passed
,
by
the

your
whole

,
the
time

is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
you
trust
me
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
Because
you
know
that
nothing
can
touch
you
without

me
;
that
nothing
can
make
you
happy
or
unhappy
,
but
it
must
make
me
,
who
am
so

you
,
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
heard
the
thrill
in
her

,
he
saw
her
earnest

,
he
saw
her
clear
true
eyes
,
he
saw
the
quickened
bosom
that
would
have
joyfully

itself
before
him
to
receive
a
mortal
wound
directed
at
his
breast
,
with
the
dying

,
"
I
love
him
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
remotest
suspicion
of
the
truth
never

upon

mind
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
He
saw
the
devoted
little
creature
with
her
worn

,
in
her
common

,
in
her

a

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
For

assuredly
,
Little
Dorrit
,
but

another

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

,
I

the

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
I

the

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
Why

?
 
<EOS>
Tell

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
My

here
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
much

,
"

<EOS>
"
So

that

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
<EOS>
no

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Secret
?
 
<EOS>
No
,

,
"
said

in

<EOS>
They

more

<EOS>
All

<EOS>
"
I

!
 
<EOS>
Little

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
 
<EOS>
How

,
"

,
"

<EOS>
Whoever

Princess

?
 
<EOS>
\I\
never

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
For

,

"
<EOS>
cried

,

.
   
<EOS>
Arthur

Dorrit
for

<EOS>
But

Tale

she

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
she
well

that
,
she
never
forgot
it
<EOS>
,

second

---

.
   
<EOS>
"
Little
Dorrit
,
"

,

,

in

,
"
another

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
wanted

to

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

me
,
who
,
for

matter

,
might

father
or

.
 
<EOS>
Always
think

me
as
quite
an

.
 
<EOS>
I
know

in

,
and

nothing

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
I

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

---

"
   
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may

,

Dorrit
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She

,
after

,

<EOS>
The

he
remembered

well
,

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Entrust

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O

,

!
 
<EOS>
But
,
O

,
O

,
O

!
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

?
 
<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Almost

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
"
When

-

,

,

,

,

,

Dorrit
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
She
seemed

catch

---
that

,

,

---
and

,

,
"
Yes
,
Mr
Clennam
;
yes
,

may
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
crazy
staircase
,
usually
not
slow
to
give
notice
when
any

was

,
here
creaked

,

,

-
engine
with

,
were

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
which
it

,
it
laboured
with

;
and
,
after

at
the
door
,
it
sounded
as
if
it
were
stooping
down
and
snorting
in
at
the

.
   
<EOS>
Before
Maggy
could
open
the
door
,
Mr
Pancks
,
opening
it
from
without
,
stood
without
a
hat
and
with
his

in
the

,
looking

Clennam
and
Little
Dorrit
,
over
her

.
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
lighted

in

,
and
brought
with

airs
of
ale
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pancks
the
gipsy
,
"
he
observed
out

,
<EOS>
"
fortune
-
telling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
stood
dingily

,
and
breathing
hard
at
them
,
with
a
most
curious
air
;
as
if
,

of

his

's

,

the

of
the

,
the
Marshal
,
all

,

Collegians
.
 
<EOS>
In

self
-

he
put
his
cigar
to
his
lips
(
being
evidently
no

)
,
and
took
such
a
pull
at
it
,
with
his
right
eye
shut
up
tight
for
the
purpose
,
that
he
underwent
a

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
But

that

,

still
essayed
to

,
"
Pa
-
ancks
the
gi
-
ipsy
,
fortune
-
telling
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
spending
the
evening
with
the
rest
of
'
em
,
"
said
Pancks
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
singing
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
taking
a
part
in
White
sand
and
grey
sand
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
take
any
part
in
anything
.
 
<EOS>
It
's

the
same
,
if
you
're

.
"
   
<EOS>
At

to

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
soon
perceived
that
though

might

a

the

(

)
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

,
Miss

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought

would

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
I

here
,
from
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
How

,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam

,
and
said

<EOS>
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
Gay
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stop
a
minute
,
or
I
shall
be
missed
,
and
I
do

'em
to

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Eh
,
Miss
Dorrit
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
seemed

;

<EOS>
"
I
have
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I

Dorrit

in

,
and
<EOS>

,
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Eh

?
"
   
<EOS>
His

.
 
<EOS>
His

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in

-

that

expected
to

sparks

.

"
Capital

,
"

.
<EOS>
---

?
"
   
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
's
Complaint
 
Resigning
herself
to
inevitable
fate
by
making
the
best
of
those
people
,
the
Miggleses
,
and
submitting
her
philosophy
to
the
draught
upon
it
,
of
which
she
had
foreseen
the
likelihood
in
her
interview
with
Arthur
,
Mrs
Gowan
handsomely
resolved
not
to
oppose
her
son
's
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
progress
to
,
and
happy
arrival
at
,
this
resolution
,
she
was
possibly
influenced
,
not
only
by
her
maternal
affections
but
by
three
politic
considerations
.
   
<EOS>
Of
these
,
the
first
may
have
been
that
her
son
had
never
signified
the
smallest
intention
to
ask
her
consent
,
or
any
mistrust
of
his
ability
to
dispense
with
it
;
the
second
,
that
the
pension
bestowed
upon
her
by
a
grateful
country
(
and
a
Barnacle
)
would
be
freed
from
any
little
filial
inroads
,
when
her
Henry
should
be
married
to
the
darling
<EOS>
only
child
of
a
man
in
very
easy
circumstances
;
the
third
,
that
Henry
's
debts
must
clearly
be
paid
down
upon
the
altar
-
railing
by
his
father
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
When
,
to
these
three
-
fold
points
of
prudence
there
is
added
the
fact
that
Mrs
Gowan
yielded
her
consent
the
moment
she
knew
of
Mr
Meagles
having
yielded
his
,
and
that
Mr
Meagles
's
objection
to
the
marriage
had
been
the
sole
obstacle
in
its
way
all
along
,
it
becomes
the
height
of
probability
that
the
relict
of
the
deceased
Commissioner
of
nothing
particular
,
turned
these
ideas
in
her
sagacious
mind
.
   
<EOS>
Among
her
connections
and
acquaintances
,
however
,
she
maintained
her
individual
dignity
and
the
dignity
of
the
blood
of
the
Barnacles
,
by
diligently
nursing
the
pretence
that
it
was
a
most
unfortunate
business
;
that
she
was
sadly
cut
up
by
it
;
that
this
was
a
perfect
fascination
under
which
Henry
laboured
;
that
she
had
opposed
it
for
a
long
time
,
but
what
could
a
mother
do
;
and
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
already
called
Arthur
Clennam
to
bear
witness
to
this
fable
,
as
a
friend
of
the
Meagles
family
;
and
she
followed
up
the
move
by
now
impounding
the
family
itself
for
the
same
purpose
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
interview
she
accorded
to
Mr
Meagles
,
she
slided
herself
into
the
position
of
disconsolately
but
gracefully
yielding
to
irresistible
pressure
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
utmost
politeness
and
good
-
breeding
,
she
feigned
that
it
was
she
---
not
he
---
who
had
made
the
difficulty
,
and
who
at
length
gave
way
;
and
that
the
sacrifice
was
hers
---
not
his
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
feint
,
with
the
same
polite
dexterity
<EOS>
,
she
foisted
on
Mrs
Meagles
,
as
a
conjuror
might
have
forced
a
card
on
that
innocent
lady
;
and
,
when
her
future
daughter
-
in
-
law
was
presented
to
her
by
her
son
,
she
said
on
embracing
her
,
"
My
dear
,
what
have
you
done
to
Henry
that
has
bewitched
him
so
!
"
<EOS>
at
the
same
time
allowing
a
few
tears
to
carry
before
them
,
in
little
pills
,
the
cosmetic
powder
on
her
nose
;
as
a
delicate
but
touching
signal
that
she
suffered
much
inwardly
for
the
show
of
composure
with
which
she
bore
her
misfortune
.
   
<EOS>
Among
the
friends
of
Mrs
Gowan
(
who
piqued
herself
at
once
on
being
Society
,
and
on
maintaining
intimate
and
easy
relations
with
that
Power
)
,
Mrs
Merdle
occupied
a
front
row
.
 
<EOS>
True
,
the
Hampton
Court
Bohemians
,
without
exception
,
turned
up
their
noses
at
Merdle
as
an
upstart
;
but
they
turned
them
down
again
,
by
falling
flat
on
their
faces
to
worship
his
wealth
.
 
<EOS>
In
which
compensating
adjustment
of
their
noses
,
they
were
pretty
much
like
Treasury
,
Bar
,
and
Bishop
,
and
all
the
rest
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
To
Mrs
Merdle
,
Mrs
Gowan
repaired
on
a
visit
of
self
-
condolence
,
after
having
given
the
gracious
consent
aforesaid
.
 
<EOS>
She
drove
into
town
for
the
purpose
in
a
one
-
horse
carriage
irreverently
called
at
that
period
of
English
history
,
a
pill
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
It
belonged
to
a
job
-
master
in
a
small
way
,
who
drove
it
himself
,
and
who
jobbed
it
by
the
day
,
or
hour
,
to
most
of
the
old
ladies
in
Hampton
Court
Palace
;
but
it
was
a
point
of
ceremony
,
in
that
encampment
,
that
the
whole
equipage
should
be
tacitly
regarded
as
the
private
property
of
the
jobber
for
the
time
being
,
and
that
the
job
-
master
should
betray
personal
knowledge
of
nobody
but
the
jobber
in
possession
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
Circumlocution
Barnacles
,
who
were
the
largest
job
-
masters
in
the
universe
,
always
pretended
to
know
of
no
other
job
but
the
job
immediately
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
was
at
home
,
and
was
in
her
nest
of
crimson
and
gold
,
with
the
parrot
on
a
neighbouring
stem
watching
her
with
his
head
on
one
side
,
as
if
he
took
her
for
another
splendid
parrot
of
a
larger
species
.
 
<EOS>
To
whom
entered
Mrs
Gowan
,
with
her
favourite
green
fan
,
which
softened
the
light
on
the
spots
of
bloom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
soul
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
tapping
the
back
of
her
friend
's
hand
with
this
fan
after
a
little
indifferent
conversation
,
"
you
are
my
only
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
That
affair
of
Henry
's
that
I
told
you
of
,
is
to
take
place
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
how
does
it
strike
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
dying
to
know
,
because
you
represent
and
express
Society
so
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
reviewed
the
bosom
which
Society
was
accustomed
to
review
;
and
having
ascertained
that
show
-
window
of
Mr
Merdle
's
and
the
London
jewellers
'
to
be
in
good
order
,
replied
:
   
"
<EOS>
As
to
marriage
on
the
part
of
a
man
,
my
dear
,
Society
requires
that
he
should
retrieve
his
fortunes
by
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Society
requires
that
he
should
gain
by
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Society
requires
that
he
should
found
a
handsome
establishment
by
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Society
does
not
see
,
otherwise
,
what
he
has
to
do
with
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
Bird
,
be
quiet
!
"
   
<EOS>
For
the
parrot
on
his
cage
above
them
,
presiding
over
the
conference
as
if
he
were
a
judge
(
and
indeed
he
looked
rather
like
one
)
,
had
wound
up
the
exposition
with
a
shriek
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cases
there
are
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
delicately
crooking
the
little
finger
of
her
favourite
hand
,
and
making
her
remarks
neater
by
that
neat
action
;
"
cases
there
are
where
a
man
is
not
young
or
elegant
,
and
is
rich
,
and
has
a
handsome
establishment
already
.
 
<EOS>
Those
are
of
a
different
kind
.
 
<EOS>
In
such
cases
---
"
   
Mrs
Merdle
shrugged
her
snowy
shoulders
and
put
her
hand
upon
the
jewel
-
stand
,
checking
a
little
cough
,
as
though
to
add
,
"
why
,
a
man
looks
out
for
this
sort
of
thing
,
my
dear
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
the
parrot
shrieked
again
,
and
she
put
up
her
glass
to
look
at
him
,
and
said
,
"
Bird
!
 
<EOS>
Do
be
quiet
!
"
<EOS>
"
But
,
young
men
,
"
resumed
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
and
by
young
men
you
know
what
I
mean
,
my
love
---
I
mean
people
's
sons
who
have
the
world
before
them
---
they
must
place
themselves
in
a
better
position
towards
Society
by
marriage
,
or
Society
really
will
not
have
any
patience
with
their
making
fools
of
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Dreadfully
worldly
all
this
sounds
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
leaning
back
in
her
nest
and
putting
up
her
glass
again
,
"
does
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
true
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
with
a
highly
moral
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
it
is
not
to
be
disputed
for
a
moment
,
"
returned
Mrs
Merdle
;
"
because
Society
has
made
up
its
mind
on
the
subject
,
and
there
is
nothing
more
to
be
said
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
were
in
a
more
primitive
state
,
if
we
lived
under
roofs
of
leaves
,
and
kept
cows
and
sheep
and
creatures
instead
of
banker
's
accounts
(
which
would
be
delicious
;
my
dear
,
I
am
pastoral
to
a
degree
,
by
nature
)
,
well
and
good
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
do
n't
live
under
leaves
,
and
keep
cows
and
sheep
and
creatures
.
 
<EOS>
I
perfectly
exhaust
myself
sometimes
,
in
pointing
out
the
distinction
to
Edmund
Sparkler
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
,
looking
over
her
green
fan
when
this
young
gentleman
's
name
was
mentioned
,
replied
as
follows
:
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
you
know
the
wretched
state
of
the
country
---
those
unfortunate
concessions
of
John
Barnacle
's
!
<EOS>
---
and
you
therefore
know
the
reasons
for
my
being
as
poor
as
Thingummy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
church
mouse
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
suggested
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
thinking
of
the
other
proverbial
church
person
---
Job
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Either
will
do
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
idle
to
disguise
,
consequently
,
that
there
is
a
wide
difference
between
the
position
of
your
son
and
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
add
,
too
,
that
Henry
has
talent
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Which
Edmund
certainly
has
not
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
with
the
greatest
suavity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
and
that
his
talent
,
combined
with
disappointment
,
"
Mrs
Gowan
went
on
,
"
has
led
him
into
a
pursuit
which
---
ah
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
<EOS>
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Such
being
Henry
's
different
position
,
the
question
is
what
is
the
most
inferior
class
of
marriage
to
which
I
can
reconcile
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
was
so
much
engaged
with
the
contemplation
of
her
arms
(
beautiful
-
formed
arms
,
and
the
very
thing
for
bracelets
)
,
that
she
omitted
to
reply
for
a
while
.
 
<EOS>
Roused
at
length
by
the
silence
,
she
folded
the
arms
,
and
with
admirable
presence
of
mind
looked
her
friend
full
in
the
face
,
and
said
interrogatively
,
"
<EOS>
Ye
-
es
?
 
<EOS>
And
then
?
"
   
"
And
then
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
not
quite
so
sweetly
as
before
,
"
I
should
be
glad
to
hear
what
you
have
to
say
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
parrot
,
who
had
been
standing
on
one
leg
since
he
screamed
last
,
burst
into
a
fit
of
laughter
,
bobbed
himself
derisively
up
and
down
on
both
legs
,
and
finished
by
standing
on
one
leg
again
,
and
pausing
for
a
reply
,
with
his
head
as
much
awry
as
he
could
possibly
twist
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sounds
mercenary
to
ask
what
the
gentleman
is
to
get
with
the
lady
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
;
"
but
Society
is
perhaps
a
little
mercenary
,
you
know
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
From
what
I
can
make
out
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
"
I
believe
I
may
say
that
Henry
will
be
relieved
from
debt
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Much
in
debt
?
"
asked
Mrs
Merdle
through
her
eyeglass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
tolerably
,
I
should
think
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
   
<EOS>
"
Meaning
the
usual
thing
;
I
understand
;
just
so
,
"
Mrs
Merdle
observed
in
a
comfortable
sort
of
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
that
the
father
will
make
them
an
allowance
of
three
hundred
a
-
year
,
or
perhaps
altogether
something
more
,
which
,
in
Italy
---
"
   
"
Oh
!
 
Going
to
Italy
?
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
Henry
to
study
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
be
at
no
loss
to
guess
why
,
my
dear
.
   
<EOS>
That
dreadful
Art
---
<EOS>
"
   
True
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
hastened
to
spare
the
feelings
of
her
afflicted
friend
.
 
<EOS>
She
understood
.
 
<EOS>
Say
no
more
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
shaking
her
despondent
head
,
"
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
"
repeated
Mrs
Gowan
,
furling
her
green
fan
for
the
moment
,
and
tapping
her
chin
with
it
<EOS>
(
it
was
on
the
way
to
being
a
double
chin
;
might
be
called
a
chin
and
a
half
at
present
)
,
"
that
's
all
!
 
<EOS>
On
the
death
of
the
old
people
,
I
suppose
there
will
be
more
to
come
;
but
how
it
may
be
restricted
or
locked
up
,
I
do
n't
