.
<EOS>
And
as
to
that
,
they
may
live
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
they
are
just
the
kind
of
people
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Mrs
Merdle
,
who
really
knew
her
friend
Society
pretty
well
,
and
who
knew
what
Society
's
mothers
were
,
and
what
Society
's
daughters
were
,
and
what
Society
's
matrimonial
market
was
,
and
how
prices
ruled
in
it
,
and
what
scheming
and
counter
-
scheming
took
place
for
the
high
buyers
,
and
what
bargaining
and
huckstering
went
on
,
thought
in
the
depths
of
her
capacious
bosom
that
this
was
a
sufficiently
good
catch
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
,
however
,
what
was
expected
of
her
,
and
perceiving
the
exact
nature
of
the
fiction
to
be
nursed
,
she
took
it
delicately
in
her
arms
,
and
put
her
required
contribution
of
gloss
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
is
all
,
my
dear
?
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
heaving
a
friendly
sigh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
The
fault
is
not
yours
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
nothing
to
reproach
yourself
with
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
exercise
the
strength
of
mind
for
which
you
are
renowned
,
and
make
the
best
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
The
girl
's
family
have
made
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
"
of
course
,
the
most
strenuous
endeavours
to
---
as
the
lawyers
say
---
to
have
and
to
hold
Henry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
they
have
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
persisted
in
every
possible
objection
,
and
have
worried
myself
morning
,
noon
,
and
night
,
for
means
to
detach
Henry
from
the
connection
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
you
have
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
all
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
All
has
broken
down
beneath
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
Am
<EOS>
I
justified
in
at
last
yielding
my
most
reluctant
consent
to
Henry
's
marrying
among
people
not
in
Society
;
or
,
have
I
acted
with
inexcusable
weakness
?
"
   
<EOS>
In
answer
to
this
direct
appeal
,
Mrs
Merdle
assured
Mrs
Gowan
(
speaking
as
a
Priestess
of
Society
)
that
she
was
highly
to
be
commended
,
that
she
was
much
to
be
sympathised
with
,
that
she
had
taken
the
highest
of
parts
,
and
had
come
out
of
the
furnace
refined
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mrs
Gowan
,
who
of
course
saw
through
her
own
threadbare
blind
perfectly
,
and
who
knew
that
Mrs
Merdle
saw
through
it
perfectly
,
and
who
knew
that
Society
would
see
through
it
perfectly
,
came
out
of
this
form
,
notwithstanding
,
as
she
had
gone
into
it
,
with
immense
complacency
and
gravity
.
   
<EOS>
The
conference
was
held
at
four
or
five
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
when
all
the
region
of
Harley
Street
,
Cavendish
Square
,
was
resonant
of
carriage
-
wheels
and
double
-
knocks
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
reached
this
point
when
Mr
Merdle
came
home
from
his
daily
occupation
of
causing
the
British
name
to
be
more
and
more
respected
in
all
parts
of
the
civilised
globe
capable
of
the
appreciation
of
world
-
wide
commercial
enterprise
and
gigantic
combinations
of
skill
and
capital
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
though
nobody
knew
with
the
least
precision
what
Mr
Merdle
's
business
was
,
except
that
it
was
to
coin
money
,
these
were
the
terms
in
which
everybody
defined
it
on
all
ceremonious
occasions
,
and
which
it
was
the
last
new
polite
reading
of
the
parable
of
the
camel
and
the
needle
's
eye
to
accept
without
inquiry
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
gentleman
who
had
this
splendid
work
cut
out
for
him
,
Mr
Merdle
looked
a
little
common
,
and
rather
as
if
,
in
the
course
of
his
vast
transactions
,
he
had
accidentally
made
an
interchange
of
heads
with
some
inferior
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
He
presented
himself
before
the
two
ladies
in
the
course
of
a
dismal
stroll
through
his
mansion
,
which
had
no
apparent
object
but
escape
from
the
presence
of
the
chief
butler
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
he
said
,
stopping
short
in
confusion
;
"
I
did
n't
know
there
was
anybody
here
but
the
parrot
.
"
   
<EOS>
However
,
as
Mrs
Merdle
said
,
"
You
can
come
in
!
"
<EOS>
and
as
Mrs
Gowan
said
she
was
just
going
,
and
had
already
risen
to
take
her
leave
,
he
came
in
,
and
stood
looking
out
at
a
distant
window
,
with
his
hands
crossed
under
his
uneasy
coat
-
cuffs
,
clasping
his
wrists
as
if
he
were
taking
himself
into
custody
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
attitude
he
fell
directly
into
a
reverie
from
which
he
was
only
aroused
by
his
wife
's
calling
to
him
from
her
ottoman
,
when
they
had
been
for
some
quarter
of
an
hour
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
turning
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
repeated
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
I
suppose
,
that
you
have
not
heard
a
word
of
my
complaint
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
complaint
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
that
you
were
suffering
from
a
complaint
.
 
<EOS>
What
complaint
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
complaint
of
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
A
complaint
of
me
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
<EOS>
---
what
have
I
---
what
may
you
have
to
complain
of
in
me
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
"
 
<EOS>
In
his
withdrawing
,
abstracted
,
pondering
way
,
it
took
him
some
time
to
shape
this
question
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
kind
of
faint
attempt
to
convince
himself
that
he
was
the
master
of
the
house
,
he
concluded
by
presenting
his
forefinger
to
the
parrot
,
who
expressed
his
opinion
on
that
subject
by
instantly
driving
his
bill
into
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
saying
,
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
with
his
wounded
finger
in
his
mouth
,
"
that
you
had
a
complaint
against
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
complaint
which
I
could
scarcely
show
the
justice
of
more
emphatically
,
than
by
having
to
repeat
it
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
might
as
well
have
stated
it
to
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
far
better
have
stated
it
to
the
bird
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
at
least
have
screamed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
want
me
to
scream
,
Mrs
Merdle
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
taking
a
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
n't
know
,
"
retorted
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
but
that
you
had
better
do
that
,
<EOS>
than
be
so
moody
and
distraught
.
 
<EOS>
One
would
at
least
know
that
you
were
sensible
of
what
was
going
on
around
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
man
might
scream
,
and
yet
not
be
that
,
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
heavily
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
might
be
dogged
,
as
you
are
at
present
,
without
screaming
,
"
returned
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
true
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
wish
to
know
the
complaint
I
make
against
you
,
it
is
,
in
so
many
plain
words
,
that
you
really
ought
not
to
go
into
Society
unless
you
can
accommodate
yourself
to
Society
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,
so
twisting
his
hands
into
what
hair
he
had
upon
his
head
that
he
seemed
to
lift
himself
up
by
it
as
he
started
out
of
his
chair
,
cried
:
"
<EOS>
Why
,
in
the
name
of
all
the
infernal
powers
,
Mrs
Merdle
,
who
does
more
for
Society
than
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
these
premises
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
   
<EOS>
Do
you
see
this
furniture
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
look
in
the
glass
and
see
yourself
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
the
cost
of
all
this
,
and
who
it
's
all
provided
for
?
 
<EOS>
And
yet
will
you
tell
me
that
I
ought
n't
to
go
into
Society
?
 
<EOS>
I
,
who
shower
money
upon
it
in
this
way
?
 
<EOS>
I
,
who
might
always
be
said
---
to
---
to
---
to
harness
myself
to
a
watering
-
cart
full
of
money
,
and
go
about
saturating
Society
every
day
of
my
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
do
n't
be
violent
,
Mr
Merdle
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Violent
?
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
enough
to
make
me
desperate
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
half
of
what
I
do
to
accommodate
Society
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
anything
of
the
sacrifices
I
make
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
"
returned
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
that
you
receive
the
best
in
the
land
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
you
move
in
the
whole
Society
of
the
country
.
<EOS>
And
I
believe
I
know
(
indeed
,
not
to
make
any
ridiculous
pretence
about
it
,
I
know
I
know
)
who
sustains
you
in
it
,
Mr
Merdle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
retorted
that
gentleman
,
wiping
his
dull
red
and
yellow
face
,
"
I
know
that
as
well
as
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
were
not
an
ornament
to
Society
,
and
if
I
was
not
a
benefactor
to
Society
,
you
and
I
would
never
have
come
together
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
say
a
benefactor
to
it
,
I
mean
a
person
who
provides
it
with
all
sorts
of
expensive
things
to
eat
and
drink
and
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
to
tell
me
that
I
am
not
fit
for
it
after
all
I
have
done
for
it
---
after
all
I
have
done
for
it
,
"
repeated
Mr
Merdle
,
with
a
wild
emphasis
that
made
his
wife
lift
up
her
eyelids
,
"
after
all
---
all
!
---
to
tell
me
I
have
no
right
to
mix
with
it
after
all
,
is
a
pretty
reward
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
answered
Mrs
Merdle
composedly
,
"
that
you
ought
to
make
yourself
fit
for
it
by
being
more
degage
,
and
less
preoccupied
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
positive
vulgarity
in
carrying
your
business
affairs
about
with
you
as
you
do
.
"
<EOS>
"
How
do
I
carry
them
about
,
Mrs
Merdle
?
"
asked
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
carry
them
about
?
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
yourself
in
the
glass
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
involuntarily
turned
his
eyes
in
the
direction
of
the
nearest
mirror
,
and
asked
,
with
a
slow
determination
of
his
turbid
blood
to
his
temples
,
whether
a
man
was
to
be
called
to
account
for
his
digestion
?
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
physician
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
does
me
no
good
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
changed
her
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
said
she
,
"
your
digestion
is
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
speak
of
your
digestion
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
of
your
manner
.
"
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
returned
her
husband
,
"
<EOS>
I
look
to
you
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
supply
manner
,
and
I
supply
money
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
expect
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
reposing
easily
among
her
cushions
,
"
to
captivate
people
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
you
to
take
any
trouble
upon
yourself
,
or
to
try
to
be
fascinating
.
 
<EOS>
I
simply
request
you
to
care
about
nothing
---
or
seem
to
care
about
nothing
---
as
everybody
else
does
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
ever
say
I
care
about
anything
?
"
asked
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
?
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Nobody
would
attend
to
you
if
you
did
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
show
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Show
what
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
I
show
?
"
demanded
Mr
Merdle
hurriedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
told
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
show
that
you
carry
your
business
cares
an
projects
about
,
instead
of
leaving
them
in
the
City
,
or
wherever
else
they
belong
to
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Or
seeming
to
.
<EOS>
Seeming
would
be
quite
enough
:
I
ask
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Whereas
you
could
n't
be
more
occupied
with
your
day
's
calculations
and
combinations
than
you
habitually
show
yourself
to
be
,
if
you
were
a
carpenter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
carpenter
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Merdle
,
checking
something
like
a
groan
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
so
much
mind
being
a
carpenter
,
Mrs
Merdle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
my
complaint
is
,
"
pursued
the
lady
,
disregarding
the
low
remark
,
"
that
it
is
not
the
tone
of
Society
,
and
that
you
ought
to
correct
it
,
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
doubt
of
my
judgment
,
ask
even
Edmund
Sparkler
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
door
of
the
room
had
opened
,
and
Mrs
Merdle
now
surveyed
the
head
of
her
son
through
her
glass
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Edmund
;
we
want
you
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
who
had
merely
put
in
his
head
and
looked
round
the
room
without
entering
(
as
if
he
were
searching
the
house
for
that
young
lady
with
no
nonsense
about
her
)
,
upon
this
followed
up
his
head
with
his
body
,
and
stood
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
To
whom
,
in
a
few
easy
words
adapted
to
his
capacity
,
Mrs
Merdle
stated
the
question
at
issue
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
,
after
anxiously
feeling
his
shirt
-
collar
as
if
it
were
his
pulse
and
he
were
hypochondriacal
,
observed
,
"
That
he
had
heard
it
noticed
by
fellers
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
Sparkler
has
heard
it
noticed
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
with
languid
triumph
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
doubt
everybody
has
heard
it
noticed
!
"
<EOS>
Which
in
truth
was
no
unreasonable
inference
;
seeing
that
Mr
Sparkler
would
probably
be
the
last
person
,
in
any
assemblage
of
the
human
species
,
to
receive
an
impression
from
anything
that
passed
in
his
presence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Edmund
Sparkler
will
tell
you
,
I
dare
say
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
waving
her
favourite
hand
towards
her
husband
,
"
how
he
has
heard
it
noticed
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
after
feeling
his
pulse
as
before
,
"
could
n't
undertake
to
say
what
led
to
it
---
'cause
memory
desperate
loose
.
 
<EOS>
But
being
in
company
with
the
brother
of
a
doosed
fine
gal
---
well
educated
too
---
with
no
biggodd
nonsense
about
her
<EOS>
---
at
the
period
alluded
to
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
the
sister
,
"
remarked
Mrs
Merdle
,
a
little
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
the
brother
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Did
n't
say
a
word
,
ma'am
,
"
answered
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
silent
a
feller
as
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Equally
hard
up
for
a
remark
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Somebody
said
something
,
"
returned
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
who
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
(
"
Assure
you
I
do
n't
in
the
least
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
But
tell
us
what
it
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
referred
to
his
pulse
again
,
and
put
himself
through
some
severe
mental
discipline
before
he
replied
:
   
"
<EOS>
Fellers
referring
to
my
Governor
---
expression
not
my
own
---
occasionally
compliment
my
Governor
in
a
very
handsome
way
on
being
immensely
rich
and
knowing
---
perfect
phenomenon
of
Buyer
and
Banker
and
that
---
but
say
the
Shop
sits
heavily
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
Say
he
carried
the
Shop
about
,
on
his
back
rather
---
like
Jew
clothesmen
with
too
much
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
rising
,
with
her
floating
drapery
about
her
,
"
is
exactly
my
complaint
.
 
<EOS>
Edmund
,
give
me
your
arm
up
-
stairs
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,
left
alone
to
meditate
on
a
better
conformation
of
himself
to
Society
,
looked
out
of
nine
windows
in
succession
,
and
appeared
to
see
nine
wastes
of
space
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
thus
entertained
himself
he
went
down
-
stairs
,
and
looked
intently
at
all
the
carpets
on
the
ground
-
floor
;
and
then
came
up
-
stairs
again
,
and
looked
intently
at
all
the
carpets
on
the
first
-
floor
;
as
if
they
were
gloomy
depths
,
in
unison
with
his
oppressed
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Through
all
the
rooms
he
wandered
,
as
he
always
did
,
like
the
last
person
on
earth
who
had
any
business
to
approach
them
.
 
<EOS>
Let
Mrs
Merdle
announce
,
with
all
her
might
,
that
she
was
at
Home
ever
so
many
nights
in
a
season
,
she
could
not
announce
more
widely
and
unmistakably
than
Mr
Merdle
did
that
he
was
never
at
home
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
he
met
the
chief
butler
,
the
sight
of
which
splendid
retainer
always
finished
him
.
 
<EOS>
Extinguished
by
this
great
creature
,
he
sneaked
to
his
dressing
-
room
,
and
there
remained
shut
up
until
he
rode
out
to
dinner
,
with
Mrs
Merdle
,
in
her
own
handsome
chariot
.
 
<EOS>
At
dinner
,
he
was
envied
and
flattered
as
a
being
of
might
,
was
Treasuried
,
Barred
,
and
Bishoped
,
as
much
as
he
would
;
and
an
hour
after
midnight
came
home
alone
,
and
being
instantly
put
out
again
in
his
own
hall
,
like
a
rushlight
,
by
the
chief
butler
,
went
sighing
to
bed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
A
Shoal
of
Barnacles
 
<EOS>
Mr
Henry
Gowan
and
the
dog
were
established
frequenters
of
the
cottage
,
and
the
day
was
fixed
for
the
wedding
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
to
be
a
convocation
of
Barnacles
on
the
occasion
,
in
order
that
that
very
high
and
very
large
family
might
shed
as
much
lustre
on
the
marriage
as
so
dim
an
event
was
capable
of
receiving
.
   
<EOS>
To
have
got
the
whole
Barnacle
family
together
would
have
been
impossible
for
two
reasons
.
 
<EOS>
Firstly
,
because
no
building
could
have
held
all
the
members
and
connections
of
that
illustrious
house
.
 
<EOS>
Secondly
,
because
wherever
there
was
a
square
yard
of
ground
in
British
occupation
under
the
sun
or
moon
,
with
a
public
post
upon
it
,
sticking
to
that
post
was
a
Barnacle
.
 
<EOS>
No
intrepid
navigator
could
plant
a
flag
-
staff
upon
any
spot
of
earth
,
and
take
possession
of
it
in
the
British
name
,
but
to
that
spot
of
earth
,
so
soon
as
the
discovery
was
known
,
the
Circumlocution
Office
sent
out
a
Barnacle
and
a
despatch
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
the
Barnacles
were
all
over
the
world
,
in
every
direction
---
despatch
-
boxing
the
compass
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
while
the
so
-
potent
art
of
Prospero
himself
would
have
failed
in
summoning
the
Barnacles
from
every
speck
of
ocean
and
dry
land
on
which
there
was
nothing
(
except
mischief
)
to
be
done
and
anything
to
be
pocketed
,
it
was
perfectly
feasible
to
assemble
a
good
many
Barnacles
.
 
<EOS>
This
Mrs
Gowan
applied
herself
to
do
;
calling
on
Mr
Meagles
frequently
with
new
additions
to
the
list
,
and
holding
conferences
with
that
gentleman
when
he
was
not
engaged
(
as
he
generally
was
at
this
period
)
in
examining
and
paying
the
debts
of
his
future
son
-
in
-
law
,
in
the
apartment
of
scales
and
scoops
.
   
<EOS>
One
marriage
guest
there
was
,
in
reference
to
whose
presence
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
felt
a
nearer
interest
and
concern
than
in
the
attendance
of
the
most
elevated
Barnacle
expected
;
though
he
was
far
from
insensible
of
the
honour
of
having
such
company
.
 
<EOS>
This
guest
was
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
But
Clennam
had
made
a
promise
he
held
sacred
,
among
the
trees
that
summer
night
,
and
,
in
the
chivalry
of
his
heart
,
regarded
it
as
binding
him
to
many
implied
obligations
.
 
<EOS>
In
forgetfulness
of
himself
,
and
delicate
service
to
her
on
all
occasions
,
he
was
never
to
fail
;
to
begin
it
,
he
answered
Mr
Meagles
cheerfully
,
"
I
shall
come
,
of
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
partner
,
Daniel
Doyce
,
was
something
of
a
stumbling
-
block
in
Mr
Meagles
's
way
,
the
worthy
gentleman
being
not
at
all
clear
in
his
own
anxious
mind
but
that
the
mingling
of
Daniel
with
official
Barnacleism
might
produce
some
explosive
combination
,
even
at
a
marriage
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
The
national
offender
,
however
,
lightened
him
of
his
uneasiness
by
coming
down
to
Twickenham
to
represent
that
he
begged
,
with
the
freedom
of
an
old
friend
,
and
as
a
favour
to
one
,
that
he
might
not
be
invited
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
,
"
said
he
,
"
as
my
business
with
this
set
of
gentlemen
was
to
do
a
public
duty
and
a
public
service
,
and
as
their
business
with
me
was
to
prevent
it
by
wearing
my
soul
out
<EOS>
,
I
think
we
had
better
not
eat
and
drink
together
with
a
show
of
being
of
one
mind
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
was
much
amused
by
his
friend
's
oddity
;
and
patronised
him
with
a
more
protecting
air
of
allowance
than
usual
,
when
he
rejoined
:
"
Well
,
well
,
Dan
,
you
shall
have
your
own
crotchety
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
Mr
Henry
Gowan
,
as
the
time
approached
,
Clennam
tried
to
convey
by
all
quiet
and
unpretending
means
,
that
he
was
frankly
and
disinterestedly
desirous
of
tendering
him
any
friendship
he
would
accept
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
treated
him
in
return
with
his
usual
ease
,
and
with
his
usual
show
of
confidence
,
which
was
no
confidence
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Clennam
,
"
he
happened
to
remark
in
the
course
of
conversation
one
day
,
when
they
were
walking
near
the
Cottage
within
a
week
of
the
marriage
,
"
I
am
a
disappointed
man
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
know
already
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
said
Clennam
,
a
little
embarrassed
,
"
I
scarcely
know
how
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
returned
Gowan
,
"
I
belong
to
a
clan
,
or
a
clique
,
or
a
family
,
or
a
connection
,
or
whatever
you
like
to
call
it
,
that
might
have
provided
for
me
in
any
one
of
fifty
ways
,
and
that
took
it
into
its
head
not
to
do
it
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
So
here
I
am
,
a
poor
devil
of
an
artist
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
was
beginning
,
"
But
on
the
other
hand
---
"
when
Gowan
took
him
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
good
fortune
of
being
beloved
by
a
beautiful
and
charming
girl
whom
I
love
with
all
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
(
"
Is
there
much
of
it
?
"
<EOS>
Clennam
thought
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
thought
it
,
felt
ashamed
of
himself
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
of
finding
a
father
-
in
-
law
who
is
a
capital
fellow
and
a
liberal
good
old
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
I
had
other
prospects
washed
and
combed
into
my
childish
head
when
it
was
washed
and
combed
for
me
,
and
I
took
them
to
a
public
school
when
I
washed
and
combed
it
for
myself
,
and
I
am
here
without
them
,
and
thus
I
am
a
disappointed
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
thought
(
and
as
he
thought
it
,
again
felt
ashamed
of
himself
)
,
was
this
notion
of
being
disappointed
in
life
,
an
assertion
of
station
which
the
bridegroom
brought
into
the
family
as
his
property
,
having
already
carried
it
detrimentally
into
his
pursuit
?
 
<EOS>
And
was
it
a
hopeful
or
a
promising
thing
anywhere
?
   
<EOS>
"
Not
bitterly
disappointed
,
I
think
,
"
he
said
aloud
.
"
<EOS>
Hang
it
,
no
;
not
bitterly
,
"
laughed
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
people
are
not
worth
that
---
though
they
are
charming
fellows
,
and
I
have
the
greatest
affection
for

.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
's
pleasant
to
show
them
that
I
can
do
without
them
,
and
that
they
may
all
go
to
the
Devil
.
<EOS>
And
besides
,
again
,
most
men
are
disappointed
in
life
,
somehow
or
other
,
and
influenced
by
their
disappointment
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
dear
good
world
,
and
I
love
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
lies
fair
before
you
now
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fair
as
this
summer
river
,
"
cried
the
other
,
with
enthusiasm
,
"
and
by
Jove
I
glow
with
admiration
of
it
,
and
with
ardour
to
run
a
race
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
best
of
old
worlds
!
 
<EOS>
And
my
calling
!
 
<EOS>
The
best
of
old
callings
,
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Full
of
interest
and
ambition
,
I
conceive
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
imposition
,
"
added
Gowan
,
laughing
;
"
we
wo
n't
leave
out
the
imposition
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
not
break
down
in
that
;
but
there
,
my
being
a
disappointed
man
may
show
itself
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
not
be
able
to
face
it
out
gravely
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Between
you
and
me
,
I
think
there
is
some
danger
of
my
being
just
enough
soured
not
to
be
able
to
do
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
do
what
?
"
asked
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
keep
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
To
help
myself
in
my
turn
,
as
the
man
before
me
helps
himself
in
his
,
and
pass
the
bottle
of
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
To
keep
up
the
pretence
as
to
labour
,
and
study
,
and
patience
,
and
being
devoted
to
my
art
,
and
giving
up
many

to
it
,
and
abandoning
many

for
it
,
and
living
in
it
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
---
in
short
,
to
pass
the
bottle
of
smoke
according
to
rule
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
well
for
a
man
to
respect
his
own
vocation
,
whatever
it
is
;
and
to
think
himself
bound
to
uphold
it
,
and
to
claim
for
it
the
respect
it
deserves
;
is
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
Arthur
reasoned
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
your
vocation
,
Gowan
,
may
really
demand
this
suit
and
service
.
 
<EOS>
I
confess
<EOS>
I
should
have
thought
that
all
Art
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
good
fellow
you
are
,
Clennam
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed

other
,
stopping
to

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
capital
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
never
been
disappointed
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
easy
to
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
so
cruel
if
he
had
meant
it
,
that
Clennam
firmly
resolved
to
believe
he
did
not
mean
it
.
 
<EOS>
Gowan
,
without
pausing
,
laid
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
laughingly
and
lightly
went
on
:
   
<EOS>
"
Clennam
,
I
do
n't
like
to
dispel
your
generous
visions
,
and
I
would
give
any
money
(
if
I
had
any
)
,
to
live
in
such
a
rose
-
coloured
mist
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
I
do
in
my
trade
,
I
do
to
sell
.
 
<EOS>
What
all
we
fellows
do
,
we
do
to
sell
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
did
n't
want
to
sell
it
for
the
most
we
can
get
for
it
,
we
should
n't
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Being
work
,
it
has
to
be
done
;
but
it
's
easily
enough
done
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
rest
is
hocus
-
pocus
.
   
<EOS>
Now
here
's
one
of
the
advantages
,
or
disadvantages
,
of
knowing
a
disappointed
man
.
 
<EOS>
You
hear
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Whatever
he
had
heard
,
and
whether
it
deserved
that
name
or
another
,
it
sank
into
Clennam
's
mind
.
 
<EOS>
It
so
took
root
there
,
that
he
began
to
fear
Henry
Gowan
would
always
be
a
trouble
to
him
,
and
that
so
far
he
had
gained
little
or
nothing
from
the
dismissal
of
Nobody
,
with
all
his
inconsistencies
,
anxieties
,
and
contradictions
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
a
contest
still
always
going
on
in
his
breast
between
his
promise
to
keep
Gowan
in
none
but
good
aspects
before
the
mind
of
Mr
Meagles
,
and
his
enforced
observation
of
Gowan
in
aspects
that
had
no
good
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
could
he
quite
support
his
own
conscientious
nature
against
misgivings
that
he
distorted
and
discoloured
himself
,
by
reminding
himself
that
he
never
sought
those
discoveries
,
and
that
he
would
have
avoided
them
with
willingness
and
great
relief
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
never
could
forget
what
he
had
been
;
and
he
knew
that
he
had
once
disliked
Gowan
for
no
better
reason
than
that
he
had
come
in
his
way
.
   
<EOS>
Harassed
by
these
thoughts
,
he
now
began
to
wish
the
marriage
over
,
Gowan
and
his
young
wife
gone
,
and
himself
left
to
fulfil
his
promise
,
and
discharge
the
generous
function
he
had
accepted
.
 
<EOS>
This
last
week
was
,
in
truth
,
an
uneasy
interval
for
the
whole
house
.
<EOS>
Before
Pet
,
or
before
Gowan
,
Mr
Meagles
was
radiant
;
but
Clennam
had
more
than
once
found
him
alone
,
with
his
view
of
the
scales
and
scoop
much
blurred
,
and
had
often
seen
him
look
after
the
lovers
,
in
the
garden
or
elsewhere
when
he
was
not
seen
by
them
,
with
the
old
clouded
face
on
which
Gowan
had
fallen
like
a
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
arrangement
of
the
house
for
the
great
occasion
,
many
little
reminders
of
the
old
travels
of
the
father
and
mother
and
daughter
had
to
be
disturbed
and
passed
from
hand
to
hand
;
and
sometimes
,
in
the
midst
of
these
mute
witnesses
,
to
the
life
they
had
had
together
,
even
Pet
herself
would
yield
to
lamenting
and
weeping
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Meagles
,
the
blithest
and
busiest
of
mothers
,
went
about
singing
and
cheering
everybody
;
but
she
,
honest
soul
,
had
her
flights
into
store
rooms
,
where
she
would
cry
until
her
eyes
were
red
,
and
would
then
come
out
,
attributing
that
appearance
to
pickled
onions
and
pepper
,
and
singing
clearer
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Tickit
,
finding
no
balsam
for
a
wounded
mind
in
Buchan
's
Domestic
Medicine
,
suffered
greatly
from
low
spirits
,
and
from
moving
recollections
of
Minnie
's
infancy
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
latter
was
powerful
with
her
,
she
usually
sent
up
secret
messages
importing
that
she
was
not
in
parlour
condition
as
to
her
attire
,
and
that
she
solicited
a
sight
of
"
her
child
"
in
the
kitchen
;
there
,
she
would
bless
her
child
's
face
,
and
bless
her
child
's
heart
,
and
hug
her
child
,
in
a
medley
of
tears
and
congratulations
,
chopping
-
boards
,
rolling
-
pins
,
and
pie
-
crust
,
with
the
tenderness
of
an
old
attached
servant
,
which
is
a
very
pretty
tenderness
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
But
all
days
come
that
are
to
be
;
and
the
marriage
-
day
was
to
be
,
and
it
came
;
and
with
it
came
all
the
Barnacles
who
were
bidden
to
the
feast
.
<EOS>
There
was
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
,
from
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
Mews
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
,
with
the
expensive
Mrs
Tite
Barnacle
NEE
Stiltstalking
,
who
made
the
Quarter
Days
so
long
in
coming
,
and
the
three
expensive
Miss
Tite
Barnacles
,
double
-
loaded
with
accomplishments
and
ready
to
go
off
,
and
yet
not
going
off
with
the
sharpness
of
flash
and
bang
that
might
have
been
expected
,
but
rather
hanging
fire
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Barnacle
junior
,
also
from
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
leaving
the
Tonnage
of
the
country
,
which
he
was
somehow
supposed
to
take
under
his
protection
,
to
look
after
itself
,
and
,
sooth
to
say
,
not
at
all
impairing
the
efficiency
of
its
protection
by
leaving
it
alone
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
engaging
Young
Barnacle
,
deriving
from
the
sprightly
side
of
the
family
,
also
from
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
gaily
and
agreeably
helping
the
occasion
along
,
and
treating
it
,
in
his
sparkling
way
,
as
one
of
the
official
forms
and
fees
of
the
Church
Department
of
How
not
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
three
other
Young
Barnacles
from
three
other
offices
,
insipid
to
all
the
senses
,
and
terribly
in
want
of
seasoning
,
doing
the
marriage
as
they
would
have
"
done
"
the
Nile
,
Old
Rome
,
the
new
singer
,
or
Jerusalem
.
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
greater
game
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
himself
,
in
the
odour
of
Circumlocution
---
with
the
very
smell
of
Despatch
-
Boxes
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
there
was
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
,
who
had
risen
to
official
heights
on
the
wings
of
one
indignant
idea
,
and
that
was
,
My
Lords
,
that
I
am
yet
to
be
told
that
it
behoves
a
Minister
of
this
free
country
to
set
bounds
to
the
philanthropy
,
to
cramp
the
charity
,
to
fetter
the
public
spirit
,
to
contract
the
enterprise
,
to
damp
the
independent
self
-
reliance
,
of
its
people
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
,
in
other
words
,
that
this
great
statesman
was
always
yet
to
be
told
that
it
behoved
the
Pilot
of
the
ship
to
do
anything
but
prosper
in
the
private
loaf
and
fish
trade
ashore
,
the
crew
being
able
,
by
dint
of
hard
pumping
,
to
keep
the
ship
above
water
without
him
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
sublime
discovery
in
the
great
art
How
not
to
do
it
,
Lord
Decimus
had
long
sustained
the
highest
glory
of
the
Barnacle
family
;
and
let
any
ill
-
advised
member
of
either
House
but
try
How
to
do
it
by
bringing
in
a
Bill
to
do
it
,
that
Bill
was
as
good
as
dead
and
buried
when
Lord
Decimus
Tite
Barnacle
rose
up
in
his
place
and
solemnly
said
,
soaring
into
indignant
majesty
as
the
Circumlocution
cheering
soared
around
him
,
that
he
was
yet
to
be
told
,
My
Lords
,
that
it
behoved
him
as
the
Minister
of
this
free
country
,
to
set
bounds
to
the
philanthropy
,
to
cramp
the
charity
,
to
fetter
the
public
spirit
,
to
contract
the
enterprise
,
to
damp
the
independent
self
-
reliance
,
of
its
people
.
 
<EOS>
The
discovery
of
this
Behoving
Machine
was
the
discovery
of
the
political
perpetual
motion
.
 
<EOS>
It
never
wore
out
,
though
it
was
always
going
round
and
round
in
all
the
State
Departments
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
,
with
his
noble
friend
and
relative
Lord
Decimus
,
was
William
Barnacle
,
who
had
made
the
ever
-
famous
coalition
with
Tudor
Stiltstalking
,
and
who
always
kept
ready
his
own
particular
recipe
for
How
not
to
do
it
;
sometimes
tapping
the
Speaker
,
and
drawing
it
fresh
out
of
him
,
with
a
"
First
,
I
will
beg

,

,
to
inform

House
what
Precedent
we
have
for
the
course
into
which
the
honourable
gentleman
would

us
;
"
sometimes
asking
the
honourable
gentleman
to
favour

with

the
Precedent
;
sometimes
telling
the
honourable
gentleman
that
he
(
William
Barnacle
)
would
search
for
a
Precedent
;
and
oftentimes
crushing
the
honourable
gentleman
flat
on
the
spot
by
telling
him
there
was
no
Precedent
.
 
<EOS>
But
Precedent
and
Precipitate
were
,
under
all
circumstances
,
the
well
-
matched
pair
of
battle
-

of
this
able
Circumlocutionist
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
that
the
unhappy
honourable
gentleman
had
been
trying
in
vain
,
for
twenty
-
five
years
,
to
precipitate
William
Barnacle
into
this
---
William
Barnacle
still
put
it
to
the
House
,
and
(
at
second
-
hand

)
to
the
country
,
whether
he
was
to
be

into
this
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
that
it
was
utterly
irreconcilable
with
the
nature
of
things
and
course
of
events
that
the
wretched
honourable
gentleman
could
possibly
produce
a
Precedent
for
this
---
William
Barnacle
would
nevertheless
thank
the
honourable
gentleman
for
that
ironical

,
and
would
close
with
him
upon
that
issue
,
and
would
tell

to

that
there
Was
NO
Precedent
for

.
 
<EOS>
It
might
perhaps
have
been
objected
that
the
William
Barnacle
wisdom
was
not
high
wisdom
or
the
earth
it
bamboozled
would
never
have
been
made
,
or
,
if
made
in
a

,
would
have

blank
mud
.
 
<EOS>
But
Precedent
and
Precipitate
together
frightened
all
objection
out
of
most
people
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
,
too
,
was
another
Barnacle
,
a
lively
one
,
who
had
leaped
through
twenty
places
in
quick
succession
,
and
was
always
in
two
or
three
at
once
,
and
who
was
the
much
-
respected
inventor
of
an
art
which
he
practised
with
great
success
and
admiration
in
all
Barnacle
Governments
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
,
when
he
was
asked
a
Parliamentary
question
on
any
one
topic
,
to
return
an
answer
on
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
done
immense
service
,
and
brought
him
into
high
esteem
with
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
,
too
,
was
a
sprinkling
of
less
distinguished
Parliamentary
Barnacles
,
who
had
not
as
yet
got
anything
snug
,
and
were
going
through
their
probation
to
prove
their
worthiness
.
<EOS>
These
Barnacles
perched
upon
staircases
and
hid
in
passages
,
waiting
their
orders
to
make
houses
or
not
to
make
houses
;
and
they
did
all
their
hearing
,
and
ohing
,
and
cheering
,
and
barking
,
under
directions
from
the
heads
of
the
family
;
and
they
put
dummy

on
the
paper
in
the
way
of
other
men
's

;
and
they
stalled
disagreeable

off
until
late
in
the
night
and
late
in
the
session
,
and
then
with
virtuous
patriotism
cried
out
that
it
was
too
late
;
and
they
went
down
into
the
country
,
whenever
they
were
sent
,
and
swore
that
Lord
Decimus
had
revived

from
a

,
and
commerce

a
fit
,
and
had
doubled
the

,

,
and
prevented
no
end

.
 
<EOS>
Also
these
Barnacles
were
dealt
,
by

the
family
,
like
so
many
cards
below
the
court
-
cards
,
to

;
where

,
and
buttered

on

.
 
<EOS>
And
they
stood
,
under
similar

,

all

;
and

turned

,
on

,
to
let

;
and
they
fetched
and

,
and

and

,
and

,
and

of

,

were

in

.
 
<EOS>
And
there
was
not
a
list
,
in

the
Circumlocution
Office
,
of

that

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

necessarily
but

,

,

Legion
!
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
Barnacle
(

)

,

Decimus
Tite

.
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

that

,

Family

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Then
Gowan

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

:

.
 
<EOS>
Then

could

,

<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

"

,

"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
And

,

;

:

.
   
<EOS>
The
said

now

,

(

,

,

;

that

,

.
   
<EOS>
A

father
and
mother

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

called

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
Arthur
,
"

"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
---

the
company
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
had

,

.
 
<EOS>

It

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
high
company
!
"
    
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
What
was
behind
Mr
Pancks
on
Little
Dorrit
's
Hand
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
time
that
Mr
Pancks
,
in
discharge
of
his
compact
with
Clennam
,
revealed
to
him
the
whole
of
his
gipsy
story
,
and
told
him
Little
Dorrit
's
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
was
heir
-
at
-
law
to
a
great
estate
that
had
long
lain
unknown
of
,
unclaimed
,
and
accumulating
.
 
<EOS>
His
right
was
now
clear
,
nothing
interposed
in
his
way
,
the
Marshalsea
gates
stood
open
,
the
Marshalsea
walls
were
down
,
a
few
flourishes
of
his
pen
,
and
he
was
extremely
rich
.
   
<EOS>
In
his
tracking
out
of
the
claim
to
its
complete
establishment
,
Mr
Pancks
had
shown
a
sagacity
that
nothing
could
baffle
,
and
a
patience
and
secrecy
that
nothing
could
tire
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
when
you
and
I
crossed
Smithfield
that
night
,
and
I
told
you
what
sort
of
a
Collector
<EOS>
I
was
,
that
this
would
come
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
little
thought
,
sir
,
when
I
told
you
you
were
not
of
the
Clennams
of
Cornwall
,
that
I
was
ever
going
to
tell
you
who
were
of
the
Dorrits
of
Dorsetshire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
went
on
to
detail
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
having
that
name
recorded
in
his
note
-
book
,
he
was
first
attracted
by
the
name
alone
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
having
often
found
two
exactly
similar
names
,
even
belonging
to
the
same
place
,
to
involve
no
traceable
consanguinity
,
near
or
distant
,
he
did
not
at
first
give
much
heed
to
this
,
except
in
the
way
of
speculation
as
to
what
a
surprising
change
would
be
made
in
the
condition
of
a
little
seamstress
,
if
she
could
be
shown
to
have
any
interest
in
so
large
a
property
.
<EOS>
How
he
rather
supposed
himself
to
have
pursued
the
idea
into
its
next
degree
,
because
there
was
something
uncommon
in
the
quiet
little
seamstress
,
which
pleased
him
and
provoked
his
curiosity
.
   
<EOS>
How
he
had
felt
his
way
inch
by
inch
,
and
"
Moled
it
out
,
sir
"
<EOS>
(
that

's

)
,
grain

.
 
<EOS>
How

,
and
to

,

<EOS>

"

"

.

Her

.

<EOS>

him
from
here
,
to
tell
him
of
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
That
brought
her
back
.
 
<EOS>
Her

were
closing
,
but
they
opened
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
all
the
good
-
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not

the
wonderful
good
-
fortune
,
my
dear
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Shall

?
"
   
<EOS>
Her

shaped
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
father
will
be
no
beggar

free
.
 
<EOS>
He

want
for

.
 
<EOS>
Shall

?
 
<EOS>
Remember
!
 
<EOS>
He

nothing
of
it
;
we

to

,

,
to

of

!
"
   
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
He
held
her
in

,
and
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
will

a
rich

.
 
<EOS>
He

a

.
 
<EOS>
A
great

his

;

all

.
 
<EOS>
Bravest

children
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
As

Father
!
 
<EOS>
Father
!
<EOS>
Father
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
Upon

Flora
returned
to

,
and

,

that

,

;

F

.

F

<EOS>

<EOS>
Little

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
when

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

substituted

,

he

,

how

,

of

.
 
<EOS>
Seeing

her

could
realise

,

;
and
so
they

in

to

the

.
   
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

-

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,
<EOS>

that
the
Father
was

.
 
<EOS>
Within

,

.
   
<EOS>
Little

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
His

were
in

,
and

had
just

;

no

,
by

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,
but
not
with
his
usual

;
and

daughter
,
who

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Father
!
 
<EOS>
I

this

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
Mr
Clennam
,
father
.
 
<EOS>
He

!
 
<EOS>

,

---

,

<EOS>
---
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Her

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
To

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

?

?
 
<EOS>

---
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

the

---
the

---
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

;

,

,

with

,

in
the
long

of
his

<EOS>

and

;
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

as

.
 
<EOS>
I

love
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

poor

.
 
<EOS>
O
my
dear
,
<EOS>
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
O
father
,
father
!
<EOS>
O
thank
God
,
thank
God
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
yielded
himself
to
her
kisses
and
caresses
,
but
did
not
return

,
except
that
he
put
an
arm
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
<EOS>
did
he
say
one
word
.
 
<EOS>
His
steadfast
look
was
now
divided
between
her
and
Clennam
,
and
he
began
to
shake
as
if
he
were
very
cold
.
 
<EOS>
Explaining
to
Little
Dorrit
that
he
would
run
to
the
coffee
-
house
for
a
bottle
of
wine
<EOS>
,
Arthur
fetched
it
with
all
the

he
could
use
.
 
<EOS>
While
it
was
being
brought
from
the

to
the
bar
,

asked
him
what
had
happened
;
when
he
hurriedly
informed

that
Mr
Dorrit
had
succeeded
to
a
fortune
.
   
<EOS>
On
coming
back
with
the
wine
in
his
hand
,
he
found
that
she
had
placed
her
father
in
his

,
and
had

his
shirt
and

.
 
<EOS>
They
filled
a
tumbler
with
wine
,
and
held
it
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
swallowed
a
little
,
he
took
the
glass
himself
and
emptied
it
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
that
,
he
leaned
back
in
his
chair
and
cried
,
with
his
handkerchief
before
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
After
this
had
lasted
a
while
Clennam
thought
it
a
good
season
for
diverting
his
attention
from
the
main
surprise
,
by
relating
its
details
.
 
<EOS>
Slowly
,
therefore
,
and
in
a
quiet
tone
of
voice
,
he
explained
them
as
best
he
could
,
and
enlarged
on
the
nature
of
Pancks
's
service
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
shall
be
---
ha
---
he
shall
be
handsomely
recompensed
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Father
,
starting
up
and
moving
hurriedly
about
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Assure
yourself
,
Mr
Clennam
,
that
everybody
concerned
shall
be
---
ha
---
shall
be
nobly

.
 
<EOS>
No
one
,
my
dear
sir
,
shall

that

against

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
repay
the
---
hum
---
the
advances
I
have
had
from
you
,
sir
,
with
peculiar

.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
to
be
informed
at
your
earliest

,
what
advances
you
have
made
my
son
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
no
purpose
in
going
about
the
room
,
but
he
was
not
still
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
,
"
he
said
,
"
shall
be
remembered
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not

from
here
in
anybody
's

.
 
<EOS>
All
the
people
who
have
been
---
ha
---
well

and
my

,
shall
be

.
<EOS>
Chivery
shall
be
rewarded
.
 
<EOS>
Young
John
shall
be
rewarded
.
 
<EOS>
I
particularly

,
and
intend
,
to
act
munificently
,
Mr
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
,
"
said
Arthur
,

,
"
to
supply
any
present
contingencies
,
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought

best
to
bring

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
at

,
what
I

not

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Exceedingly

,
but
well

---
well

.
"
 
<EOS>
His

closed

.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
so

<EOS>

---
ha
---
all

.
"
   
<EOS>
His

<EOS>
"
It
will

,

.
 
<EOS>
Something

Maggy

,

---
ha
---
barely

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

---
poor

,

him
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

---
<EOS>
hum
---
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

he
had

,
that
he

.
   
<EOS>
He
was
still

about
the
room
,
with

,
when

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
They

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
hum
---
ha
---
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>
Amy
<EOS>

,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Fasten

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Button
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

---
ha
---
it

,
buttoned
.
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

then
,

and
his

for

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
Collegians
cheered
him
very
heartily
,
and
he
kissed
his
hand
to
them
with
great
urbanity
and
protection
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
withdrew
into
the
room
again
,
he
said
"
Poor
creatures
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
tone
of
much
pity
for
their
miserable
condition
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
deeply
anxious
that
he
should
lie
down
to
compose
himself
.
 
<EOS>
On
Arthur
's
speaking
to
her
of
his
going
to
inform
Pancks
that
he
might
now
appear
as
soon
as
he
would
,
and
pursue
the
joyful
business
to
its
close
,
she
entreated
him
in
a

to
stay
with
her
until
her
father
should
be
quite
calm
and
at
rest
.
 
<EOS>
He
needed
no
second
entreaty
;
and
she
prepared
her
father
's
bed
,
and
begged
him
to
lie
down
.
 
<EOS>
For
another
half
-
hour
or
more
he
would
be
persuaded
to
do
nothing
but
go
about
the
room
,
discussing
with

the
probabilities
for
and
against
the
Marshal
's
allowing
the
whole

the
prisoners
to
go
to
the
windows
of
the
official
residence
which

the
street
,
to
see

and

for

in

---
which
,
he
said
,
he

would
be
a
Sight
for

.
 
<EOS>
But
gradually
he
began
to
droop
and
tire
,
and
at
last
stretched
himself
upon
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
She
took
her
faithful

beside

,
fanning

and
cooling
his

;
and
he

falling

(
always
with
the
money
in

)
,
when
he
unexpectedly

and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
understand
,
my
dear
sir
,
<EOS>
that
I
could
---
ha
---
could
pass

Lodge
at

,

---
hum
---

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think

,
Mr
Dorrit
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
At

again
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
but

,

,
"
Clennam

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,

,
"
he

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

!
 
<EOS>
How

suppose
,
sir
,
that
an
hour
is
to
a
man
who
is
choking
for

air
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
his
last

for
that

;
as
,

some
more

and
querulously

that
he
could
n't

,
he
slowly

.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
had
abundant
occupation
for
his

,
as

the

room
watching
the
father
on

,
and
the
daughter
fanning

.
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
been
thinking
too
.
 
<EOS>
After
softly

his
grey

aside
,
and
touching
his

,
she
looked

Arthur
,
who
came
nearer

,
and
pursued

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

.
 
<EOS>
All
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
the

for

he
had

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There

something
of

in

;
something
that
was

.
 
<EOS>
He
wondered

,

:
   
"
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
?
 
<EOS>
Most

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
know
I
ought
to
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
are
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
seems

me
hard
,
"
said

Dorrit
,
"
that

have

,

all

as

.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
hard
that
he
should
pay
in
life
and

both
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
child
---
"
Clennam
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
know
I
am
wrong
,
"
she
pleaded
timidly
,
"
do
n't
think
any
worse
of
me
;
it
has
grown
up
with
me
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
prison
,
which
could
spoil
so
many
things
,
had
tainted
Little
Dorrit
's
mind
no
more
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
Engendered
as
the
confusion
was
<EOS>
,
in
compassion
for
the
poor
prisoner
,
her
father
,
it
was
the
first
speck
Clennam
had
ever
seen
,
it
was

last

Clennam
ever

,
of
the
prison

upon
her
.
   
<EOS>
He
thought
this
,
and
forebore

say

word
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
thought
,
her
purity
and
goodness
came
before
him
in
their
brightest
light
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
spot
made
them
the
more
beautiful
.
   
<EOS>
Worn

with
her
own

,
and
yielding
to

of
the
room
,
her

failed
in
its
fanning

,
and
her

dropped

on
the

at
her
father
's

.
<EOS>
Clennam
rose
softly
,
opened
and
closed
the
door
without
a
sound
,
and
passed
from
the
prison
,
carrying
the
quiet
with
him
into
the
turbulent
streets
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
The
Marshalsea
becomes
an
Orphan
 
<EOS>
And
now
the
day
arrived
when
Mr
Dorrit
and
his
family
were
to
leave
the
prison
for
ever
,
and
the
stones
of
its
much
-
trodden
pavement
were
to
know
them
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
The
interval
had
been
short
,
but
he
had
greatly
complained
of
its
length
,
and
had
been
imperious
with
Mr
Rugg
touching
the
delay
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
high
with
Mr
Rugg
,
and
had
threatened
to
employ
some
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
requested
Mr
Rugg
not
to
presume
upon
the
place
in
which
he
found
him
,
but
to
do
his
duty
,
sir
,
and
to
do
it
with
promptitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
told
Mr
Rugg
that
he
knew
what
lawyers
and
agents
were
,
and
that
he
would
not
submit
to
imposition
.
 
<EOS>
On
that
gentleman
's
humbly
representing
that
he
exerted
himself
to
the
utmost
,
Miss
Fanny
was
very
short
with
him
;
desiring
to
know
what
less
he
could
do
,
when
he
had
been
told
a
dozen
times
that
money
was
no
object
,
and
expressing
her
suspicion
that
he
forgot
whom
he
talked
to
.
   
<EOS>
Towards
the
Marshal
,
who
was
a
Marshal
of
many
years
'
standing
,
and
with
whom
he
had
never
had
any
previous
difference
,
Mr
Dorrit
comported
himself
with
severity
.
 
<EOS>
That
officer
,
on
personally
tendering
his
congratulations
,
offered
the
free
use
of
two
rooms
in
his
house
for
Mr
Dorrit
's
occupation
until
his
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
thanked
him
at
the
moment
,
and
replied
that
he
would
think
of
it
;
but
the
Marshal
was
no
sooner
gone
than
he
sat
down
and
wrote
him
a
cutting
note
,
in
which
he
remarked
that
he
had
never
on
any
former
occasion
had
the
honour
of
receiving
his
congratulations
(
which
was
true
,
though
indeed
there
had
not
been
anything
particular
to
congratulate
him
upon
)
,
and
that
he
begged
,
on
behalf
of
himself
and
family
,
to
repudiate
the
Marshal
's
offer
,
with
all
those
thanks
which
its
disinterested
character
and
its
perfect
independence
of
all
worldly
considerations
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
Although
his
brother
showed
so
dim
a
glimmering
of
interest
in
their
altered
fortunes
that
it
was
very
doubtful
whether
he
understood
them
<EOS>
,
Mr
Dorrit
caused
him
to
be
measured
for
new
raiment
by
the
hosiers
,
tailors
,
hatters
,
and
bootmakers
whom
he
called
in
for
himself
;
and
ordered
that
his
old
clothes
should
be
taken
from
him
and
burned
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
and
Mr
Tip
required
no
direction
in
making
an
appearance
of
great
fashion
and
elegance
;
and
the
three
passed
this
interval
together
at
the
best
hotel
in
the
neighbourhood
---
though
truly
,
as
Miss
Fanny
said
,
the
best
was
very
indifferent
.
 
<EOS>
In
connection
with
that
establishment
,
Mr
Tip
hired
a
cabriolet
,
horse
,
and
groom
,
a
very
neat
turn
out
,
which
was
usually
to
be
observed
for
two
or
three
hours
at
a
time
gracing
the
Borough
High
Street
,
outside
the
Marshalsea
court
-
yard
.
 
<EOS>
A
modest
little
hired
chariot
and
pair
was
also
frequently
to
be
seen
there
;
in
alighting
from
and
entering
which
vehicle
,
Miss
Fanny
fluttered
the
Marshal
's
daughters
by
the
display
of
inaccessible
bonnets
.
   
<EOS>
A
great
deal
of
business
was
transacted
in
this
short
period
.
<EOS>
Among
other
items
,
Messrs
Peddle
and
Pool
,
solicitors
,
of
Monument
Yard
,
were
instructed
by
their
client
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
to
address
a
letter
to
Mr
Arthur
Clennam
,
enclosing
the
sum
of
twenty
-
four
pounds
nine
shillings
and
eightpence
,
being
the
amount
of
principal
and
interest
computed
at
the
rate
of
five
per
cent
.
 
<EOS>
per
annum
,
in
which
their
client
believed
himself
to
be
indebted
to
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
In
making
this
communication
and
remittance
,
Messrs
Peddle
and
Pool
were
further
instructed
by
their
client
to
remind
Mr
Clennam
that
the
favour
of
the
advance
now
repaid
(
including
gate
-
fees
)
had
not
been
asked
of
him
,
and
to
inform
him
that
it
would
not
have
been
accepted
if
it
had
been
openly
proffered
in
his
name
.
 
<EOS>
With
which
they
requested
a
stamped
receipt
,
and
remained
his
obedient
servants
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
deal
of
business
had
likewise
to
be
done
,
within
the
so
-
soon
-
to
-
be
-
orphaned
Marshalsea
,
by
Mr
Dorrit
so
long
its
Father
,
chiefly
arising
out
of
applications
made
to
him
by
Collegians
for
small
sums
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
To
these
he
responded
with
the
greatest
liberality
,
and
with
no
lack
of
formality
;
always
first
writing
to
appoint
a
time
at
which
the
applicant
might
wait
upon
him
in
his
room
,
and
then
receiving
him
in
the
midst
of
a
vast
accumulation
of
documents
,
and
accompanying
his
donation
(
for
he
said
in
every
such
case
,
"
it
is
a
donation
,
not
a
loan
"
)
with
a
great
deal
of
good
counsel
:
to
the
effect
that
he
,
the
expiring
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
,
hoped
to
be
long
remembered
,
as
an
example
that
a
man
might
preserve
his
own
and
the
general
respect
even
there
.
   
<EOS>
The
Collegians
were
not
envious
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
that
they
had
a
personal
and
traditional
regard
for
a
Collegian
of
so
many
years
'
standing
,
the
event
was
creditable
to
the
College
,
and
made
it
famous
in
the
newspapers
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
more
of
them
thought
,
too
,
than
were
quite
aware
of
it
,
that
the
thing
might
in
the
lottery
of
chances
have
happened
to
themselves
,
or
that
something
of
the
sort
might
yet
happen
to
themselves
some
day
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
it
very
well
.
<EOS>
A
few
were
low
at
the
thought
of
being
left
behind
,
and
being
left
poor
;
but
even
these
did
not
grudge
the
family
their
brilliant
reverse
.
 
<EOS>
There
might
have
been
much
more
envy
in
politer
places
.
<EOS>
It
seems
probable
that
mediocrity
of
fortune
would
have
been
disposed
to
be
less
magnanimous
than
the
Collegians
,
who
lived
from
hand
to
mouth
---
from
the
pawnbroker
's
hand
to
the
day
's
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
They
got
up
an
address
to
him
,
which
they
presented
in
a
neat
frame
and
glass
(
though
it
was
not
afterwards
displayed
in
the
family
mansion
or
preserved
among
the
family
papers
)
;
and
to
which
he
returned
a
gracious
answer
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
document
he
assured
them
,
in
a
Royal
manner
,
that
he
received
the
profession
of
their
attachment
with
a
full
conviction
of
its
sincerity
;
and
again
generally
exhorted
them
to
follow
his
example
---
which
,
at
least
in
so
far
as
coming
into
a
great
property
was
concerned
<EOS>
,
there
is
no
doubt
they
would
have
gladly
imitated
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
the
same
occasion
of
inviting
them
to
a
comprehensive
entertainment
,
to
be
given
to
the
whole
College
in
the
yard
,
and
at
which
he
signified
he
would
have
the
honour
of
taking
a
parting
glass
to
the
health
and
happiness
of
all
those
whom
he
was
about
to
leave
behind
.
   
<EOS>
He
did
not
in
person
dine
at
this
public
repast
<EOS>
(
it
took
place
at
two
in
the
afternoon
,
and
his
dinners
now
came
in
from
the
hotel
at
six
)
,
but
his
son
was
so
good
as
to
take
the
head
of
the
principal
table
,
and
to
be
very
free
and
engaging
.
 
<EOS>
He
himself
went
about
among
the
company
,
and
took
notice
of
individuals
,
and
saw
that
the
viands
were
of
the
quality
he
had
ordered
,
and
that
all
were
served
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
whole
,
he
was
like
a
baron
of
the
olden
time
in
a
rare
good
humour
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
conclusion
of
the
repast
,
he
pledged
his
guests
in
a
bumper
of
old
Madeira
;
and
told
them
that
he
hoped
they
had
enjoyed
themselves
,
and
what
was
more
,
that
they
would
enjoy
themselves
for
the
rest
of
the
evening
;
that
he
wished
them
well
;
and
that
he
bade
them
welcome
.
   
<EOS>
His
health
being
drunk
with
acclamations
,
he
was
not
so
baronial
after
all
but
<EOS>
that
in
trying
to
return
thanks
he
broke
down
,
in
the
manner
of
a
mere
serf
with
a
heart
in
his
breast
,
and
wept
before
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
great
success
,
which
he
supposed
to
be
a
failure
,
he
gave
them
"
Mr
Chivery
and
his
brother
officers
;
"
whom
he
had
beforehand
presented
with
ten
pounds
each
,
and
who
were
all
in
attendance
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chivery
spoke
to
the
toast
,
saying
,
What
you
undertake
to
lock
up
,
lock
up
;
but
remember
that
you
are
,
in
the
words
of
the
fettered
African
,
a
man
and
a
brother
ever
.
 
<EOS>
The
list
of
toasts
disposed
of
<EOS>
,
Mr
Dorrit
urbanely
went
through
the
motions
of
playing
a
game
of
skittles
with
the
Collegian
who
was
the
next
oldest
inhabitant
to
himself
;
and
left
the
tenantry
to
their
diversions
.
   
<EOS>
But
all
these
occurrences
preceded
the
final
day
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
the
day
arrived
when
he
and
his
family
were
to
leave
the
prison
for
ever
,
and
when
the
stones
of
its
much
-
trodden
pavement
were
to
know
them
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Noon
was
the
hour
appointed
for
the
departure
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
approached
,
there
was
not
a
Collegian
within
doors
,
nor
a
turnkey
absent
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
class
of
gentlemen
appeared
in
their
Sunday
clothes
,
and
the
greater
part
of
the
Collegians
were
brightened
up
as
much
as
circumstances
allowed
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
flags
were
even
displayed
,
and
the
children
put
on
odds
and
ends
of
ribbon
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
himself
,
at
this
trying
time
,
preserved
a
serious
but
graceful
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
Much
of
his
great
attention
was
given
to
his
brother
,
as
to
whose
bearing
on
the
great
occasion
he
felt
anxious
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Frederick
,
"
said
he
,
"
if
you
will
give
me
your
arm
we
will
pass
among
our
friends
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
right
that
we
should
go
out
arm
in
arm
,
my
dear
Frederick
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
said
Frederick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
,
my
dear
Frederick
---
if
you
could
,
without
putting
any
great
constraint
upon
yourself
,
throw
a
little
(
pray
excuse
me
,
Frederick
)
,
a
little
Polish
into
your
usual
demeanour
---
"
   
"
William
,
William
,
"
said
the
other
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
it
's
for
you
to
do
all
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
.
 
<EOS>
All
forgotten
,
forgotten
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
returned
William
,
"
for
that
very
reason
,
if
for
no
other
,
you
must
positively
try
to
rouse
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
What
you
have
forgotten
you
must
now
begin
to
recall
,
my
dear
Frederick
.
<EOS>
Your
position
---
"
   
"
Eh
?
"
said
Frederick
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
position
,
my
dear
Frederick
.
"
   
"
Mine
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
looked
first
at
his
own
figure
,
and
then
at
his
brother
's
,
and
then
,
drawing
a
long
breath
,
cried
,
"
Hah
,
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
"
<EOS>
"
Your
position
,
my
dear
Frederick
,
is
now
a
fine
one
.
 
<EOS>
Your
position
,
as
my
brother
,
is
a
very
fine
one
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
know
that
it
belongs
to
your
conscientious
nature
to
try
to
become
worthy
of
it
,
my
dear
Frederick
,
and
to
try
to
adorn
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
no
discredit
to
it
,
but
to
adorn
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
William
,
"
said
the
other
weakly
,
and
with
a
sigh
,
"
I
will
do
anything
you
wish
,
my
brother
,
provided
it
lies
in
my
power
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
be
so
kind
as
to
recollect
what
a
limited
power
mine
is
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
you
wish
me
to
do
to
-
day
,
brother
?
 
<EOS>
Say
what
it
is
,
only
say
what
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Frederick
,
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
worth
troubling
so
good
a
heart
as
yours
with
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
trouble
it
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
finds
it
no
trouble
,
William
,
to
do
anything
it
can
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
William
passed
his
hand
across
his
eyes
,
and
murmured
with
august
satisfaction
,
"
Blessings
on
your
attachment
,
my
poor
dear
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
Then
he
said
aloud
,
"
Well
,
my
dear
Frederick
,
if
you
will
only
try
,
as
we
walk
out
,
to
show
that
you
are
alive
to
the
occasion
 
---
that
you
think
about
it
---
"
   
"
What
would
you
advise
me
to
think
about
it
?
"
returned
his
submissive
brother
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
my
dear
Frederick
,
how
can
I
answer
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
can
only
say
what
,
in
leaving
these
good
people
,
I
think
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
"
cried
his
brother
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
will
help
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
find
that
I
think
,
my
dear
Frederick
,
and
with
mixed
emotions
in
which
a
softened
compassion
predominates
,
What
will
they
do
without
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
returned
his
brother
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
think
that
as
we
go
,
What
will
they
do
without
my
brother
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
things
!
<EOS>
What
will
they
do
without
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Twelve
o'clock
having
just
struck
,
and
the
carriage
being
reported
ready
in
the
outer
court
-
yard
,
the
brothers
proceeded
down
-
stairs
arm
-
in
-
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
(
once
Tip
)
,
and
his
sister
Fanny
followed
,
also
arm
-
in
-
arm
;
Mr
Plornish
and
Maggy
,
to
whom
had
been
entrusted
the
removal
of
such
of
the
family
effects
as
were
considered
worth
removing
,
followed
,
bearing
bundles
and
burdens
to
be
packed
in
a
cart
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
were
the
Collegians
and
turnkeys
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
were
Mr
Pancks
and
Mr
Rugg
,
come
to
see
the
last
touch
given
to
their
work
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
was
Young
John
making
a
new
epitaph
for
himself
,
on
the
occasion
of
his
dying
of
a
broken
heart
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
was
the
Patriarchal
Casby
,
looking
so
tremendously
benevolent
that
many
enthusiastic
Collegians
grasped
him
fervently
by
the
hand
,
and
the
wives
and
female
relatives
of
many
more
Collegians
kissed
his
hand
,
nothing
doubting
that
he
had
done
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
was
the
man
with
the
shadowy
grievance
respecting
the
Fund
which
the
Marshal
embezzled
,
who
had
got
up
at
five
in
the
morning
to
complete
the
copying
of
a
perfectly
unintelligible
history
of
that
transaction
,
which
he
had
committed
to
Mr
Dorrit
's
care
,
as
a
document
of
the
last
importance
,
calculated
to
stun
the
Government
and
effect
the
Marshal
's
downfall
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
was
the
insolvent
whose
utmost
energies
were
always
set
on
getting
into
debt
,
who
broke
into
prison
with
as
much
pains
as
other
men
have
broken
out
of
it
,
and
who
was
always
being
cleared
and
complimented
;
while
the
insolvent
at
his
elbow
---
a
mere
little
,
snivelling
,
striving
tradesman
,
half
dead
of
anxious
efforts
to
keep
out
of
debt
---
found
it
a
hard
matter
,
indeed
,
to
get
a
Commissioner
to
release
him
with
much
reproof
and
reproach
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
was
the
man
of
many
children
and
many
burdens
,
whose
failure
astonished
everybody
;
in
the
yard
,
was
the
man
of
no
children
and
large
resources
,
whose
failure
astonished
nobody
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
were
the
people
who
were
always
going
out
to
-
morrow
,
and
always
putting
it
off
;
there
,
were
the
people
who
had
come
in
yesterday
,
and
who
were
much
more
jealous
and
resentful
of
this
freak
of
fortune
than
the
seasoned
birds
.
<EOS>
There
,
were
some
who
,
in
pure
meanness
of
spirit
,
cringed
and
bowed
before
the
enriched
Collegian
and
his
family
;
there
,
were
others
who
did
so
really
because
their
eyes
,
accustomed
to
the
gloom
of
their
imprisonment
and
poverty
,
could
not
support
the
light
of
such
bright
sunshine
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
were
many
whose
shillings
had
gone
into
his
pocket
to
buy
him
meat
and
drink
;
but
none
who
were
now
obtrusively
<EOS>
Hail
fellow
well
met
!
 
<EOS>
with
him
,
on
the
strength
of
that
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
rather
to
be
remarked
of
the
caged
birds
,
that
they
were
a
little
shy
of
the
bird
about
to
be
so
grandly
free
,
and
that
they
had
a
tendency
to
withdraw
themselves
towards
the
bars
,
and
seem
a
little
fluttered
as
he
passed
.
   
<EOS>
Through
these
spectators
the
little
procession
,
headed
by
the
two
brothers
,
moved
slowly
to
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
yielding
to
the
vast
speculation
how
the
poor
creatures
were
to
get
on
without
him
,
was
great
,
and
sad
,
but
not
absorbed
.
 
<EOS>
He
patted
children
on
the
head
like
Sir
Roger
de
Coverley
going
to
church
,
he
spoke
to
people
in
the
background
by
their
Christian
names
,
he
condescended
to
all
present
,
and
seemed
for
their
consolation
to
walk
encircled
by
the
legend
in
golden
characters
,
"
Be
comforted
,
my
people
!
 
<EOS>
Bear
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
last
three
honest
cheers
announced
that
he
had
passed
the
gate
,
and
that
the
Marshalsea
was
an
orphan
.
 
<EOS>
Before
they
had
ceased
to
ring
in
the
echoes
of
the
prison
walls
,
the
family
had
got
into
their
carriage
,
and
the
attendant
had
the
steps
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Then
,
and
not
before
,
"
Good
Gracious
!
"
cried
Miss
Fanny
all
at
once
,
"
<EOS>
Where
's
Amy
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
father
had
thought
she
was
with
her
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
had
thought
she
was
"
somewhere
or
other
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
They
had
all
trusted
to
finding
her
,
as
they
had
always
done
,
quietly
in
the
right
place
at
the
right
moment
.
 
<EOS>
This
going
away
was
perhaps
the
very
first
action
of
their
joint
lives
that
they
had
got
through
without
her
.
   
<EOS>
A
minute
might
have
been
consumed
in
the
ascertaining
of
these
points
,
when
Miss
Fanny
,
who
,
from
her
seat
in
the
carriage
,
commanded
the
long
narrow
passage
leading
to
the
Lodge
,
flushed
indignantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
do
say
,
Pa
,
"
cried
she
,
"
that
this
is
disgraceful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
disgraceful
,
Fanny
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
say
,
"
she
repeated
,
"
this
is
perfectly
infamous
!
 
<EOS>
Really
almost
enough
,
even
at
such
a
time
as
this
,
to
make
one
wish
one
was
dead
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
that
child
Amy
,
in
her
ugly
old
shabby
dress
,
which
she
was
so
obstinate
about
,
Pa
,
which
I
over
and
over
again
begged
and
prayed
her
to
change
,
and
which
she
over
and
over
again
objected
to
,
and
promised
to
change
to
-
day
,
saying
she
wished
to
wear
it
as
long
as
ever
she
remained
in
there
with
you
---
which
was
absolutely
romantic
nonsense
of
the
lowest
kind
---
here
<EOS>
is
that
child
Amy
disgracing
us
to
the
last
moment
and
at
the
last
moment
,
by
being
carried
out
in
that
dress
after
all
.
 
<EOS>
And
by
that
Mr
Clennam
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
offence
was
proved
,
as
she
delivered
the
indictment
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
appeared
at
the
carriage
-
door
,
bearing
the
little
insensible
figure
in
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
has
been
forgotten
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
tone
of
pity
not
free
from
reproach
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ran
up
to
her
room
(
which
Mr
Chivery
showed
me
)
and
found
the
door
open
,
and
that
she
had
fainted
on
the
floor
,
dear
child
.
 
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
have
gone
to
change
her
dress
,
and
to
have
sunk
down
overpowered
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
the
cheering
,
or
it
may
have
happened
sooner
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
of
this
poor
cold
hand
,
Miss
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
it
fall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
Miss
Dorrit
,
bursting
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
know
what
to
do
,
if
you
will
give
me
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Amy
,
open
your
eyes
,
that
's
a
love
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Amy
,
Amy
,
I
really
am
so
vexed
and
ashamed
!
 
<EOS>
Do
rouse
yourself
,
darling
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
why
are
they
not
driving
on
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
Pa
,
do
drive
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
attendant
,
getting
between
Clennam
and
the
carriage
-
door
,
with
a
sharp
"
By
your
leave
,
sir
!
"
bundled
up
the
steps
,
and
they
drove
away
.
     
<EOS>
Book
the
Second
.
<EOS>
Riches
    
Fellow
Travellers
 
<EOS>
In
the
autumn
of
the
year
,
Darkness
and
Night
were
creeping
up
to
the
highest
ridges
of
the
Alps
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
vintage
time
in
the
valleys
on
the
Swiss
side
of
the
Pass
of
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
and
along
the
banks
of
the
Lake
of
Geneva
.
   
<EOS>
The
air
there
was
charged
with
the
scent
of
gathered
grapes
.
<EOS>
Baskets
,
troughs
,
and
tubs
of
grapes
stood
in
the
dim
village
doorways
,
stopped
the
steep
and
narrow
village
streets
,
and
had
been
carrying
all
day
along
the
roads
and
lanes
.
 
<EOS>
Grapes
,
split
and
crushed
under
foot
,
lay
about
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
carried
in
a
sling
by
the
laden
peasant
woman
toiling
home
,
was
quieted
with
picked
-
up
grapes
;
the
idiot
sunning
his
big
goitre
under
the
leaves
of
the
wooden
chalet
by
the
way
to
the
Waterfall
,
sat
Munching
grapes
;
the
breath
of
the
cows
and
goats
was
redolent
of
leaves
and
stalks
of
grapes
;
the
company
in
every
little
cabaret
were
eating
,
drinking
,
talking
grapes
.
 
<EOS>
A
pity
that
no
ripe
touch
of
this
generous
abundance
could
be
given
to
the
thin
,
hard
,
stony
wine
,
which
after
all
was
made
from
the
grapes
!
   
<EOS>
The
air
had
been
warm
and
transparent
through
the
whole
of
the
bright
day
.
 
<EOS>
Shining
metal
spires
and
church
-
roofs
,
distant
and
rarely
seen
,
had
sparkled
in
the
view
;
and
the
snowy
mountain
-
tops
had
been
so
clear
that
unaccustomed
eyes
,
cancelling
the
intervening
country
,
and
slighting
their
rugged
heights
for
something
fabulous
,
would
have
measured
them
as
within
a
few
hours
easy
reach
.
 
<EOS>
Mountain
-
peaks
of
great
celebrity
in
the
valleys
,
whence
no
trace
of
their
existence
was
visible
sometimes
for
months
together
,
had
been
since
morning
plain
and
near
in
the
blue
sky
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
when
it
was
dark
below
,
though
they
seemed
solemnly
to
recede
,
like
spectres
who
were
going
to
vanish
,
as
the
red
dye
of
the
sunset
faded
out
of
them
and
left
them
coldly
white
,
they
were
yet
distinctly
defined
in
their
loneliness
above
the
mists
and
shadows
.
<EOS>
Seen
from
these
solitudes
,
and
from
the
Pass
of
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
which
was
one
of
them
,
the
ascending
Night
came
up
the
mountain
like
a
rising
water
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
at
last
rose
to
the
walls
of
the
convent
of
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
it
was
as
if
that
weather
-
beaten
structure
were
another
Ark
,
and
floated
on
the
shadowy
waves
.
   
<EOS>
Darkness
,
outstripping
some
visitors
on
mules
,
had
risen
thus
to
the
rough
convent
walls
,
when
those
travellers
were
yet
climbing
the
mountain
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
heat
of
the
glowing
day
when
they
had
stopped
to
drink
at
the
streams
of
melted
ice
and
snow
,
was
changed
to
the
searching
cold
of
the
frosty
rarefied
night
air
at
a
great
height
,
so
the
fresh
beauty
of
the
lower
journey
had
yielded
to
barrenness
and
desolation
.
 
<EOS>
A
craggy
track
,
up
which
the
mules
in
single
file
scrambled
and
turned
from
block
to
block
,
as
though
they
were
ascending
the
broken
staircase
of
a
gigantic
ruin
,
was
their
way
now
.
 
<EOS>
No
trees
were
to
be
seen
,
nor
any
vegetable
growth
save
a
poor
brown
scrubby
moss
,
freezing
in
the
chinks
of
rock
.
 
<EOS>
Blackened
skeleton
arms
of
wood
by
the
wayside
pointed
upward
to
the
convent
as
if
the
ghosts
of
former
travellers
overwhelmed
by
the
snow
haunted
the
scene
of
their
distress
.
 
<EOS>
Icicle
-
hung
caves
and
cellars
built
for
refuges
from
sudden
storms
,
were
like
so
many
whispers
of
the
perils
of
the
place
;
never
-
resting
wreaths
and
mazes
of
mist
wandered
about
,
hunted
by
a
moaning
wind
;
and
snow
,
the
besetting
danger
of
the
mountain
,
against
which
all
its
defences
were
taken
,
drifted
sharply
down
.
   
<EOS>
The
file
of
mules
,
jaded
by
their
day
's
work
,
turned
and
wound
slowly
up
the
deep
ascent
;
the
foremost
led
by
a
guide
on
foot
,
in
his
broad
-
brimmed
hat
and
round
jacket
,
carrying
a
mountain
staff
or
two
upon
his
shoulder
,
with
whom
another
guide
conversed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
speaking
among
the
string
of
riders
.
 
<EOS>
The
sharp
cold
,
the
fatigue
of
the
journey
,
and
a
new
sensation
of
a
catching
in
the
breath
,
partly
as
if
they
had
just
emerged
from
very
clear
crisp
water
,
and
partly
as
if
they
had
been
sobbing
,
kept
them
silent
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
a
light
on
the
summit
of
the
rocky
staircase
gleamed
through
the
snow
and
mist
.
 
<EOS>
The
guides
called
to
the
mules
,
the
mules
pricked
up
their
drooping
heads
,
the
travellers
'
tongues
were
loosened
,
and
in
a
sudden
burst
of
slipping
,
climbing
,
jingling
,
clinking
,
and
talking
,
they
arrived
at
the
convent
door
.
   
<EOS>
Other
mules
had
arrived
not
long
before
,
some
with
peasant
riders
and
some
with
goods
,
and
had
trodden
the
snow
about
the
door
into
a
pool
of
mud
.
 
<EOS>
Riding
-
saddles
and
bridles
,
pack
-
saddles
and
strings
of
bells
,
mules
and
men
,
lanterns
,
torches
,
sacks
,
provender
,
barrels
,
cheeses
,
kegs
of
honey
and
butter
,
straw
bundles
and
packages
of
many
shapes
,
were
crowded
confusedly
together
in
this
thawed
quagmire
and
about
the
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Up
here
in
the
clouds
,
everything
was
seen
through
cloud
,
and
seemed
dissolving
into
cloud
.
 
<EOS>
The
breath
of
the
men
was
cloud
,
the
breath
of
the
mules
was
cloud
,
the
lights
were
encircled
by
cloud
,
speakers
close
at
hand
were
not
seen
for
cloud
,
though
their
voices
and
all
other
sounds
were
surprisingly
clear
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
cloudy
line
of
mules
hastily
tied
to
rings
in
the
wall
,
one
would
bite
another
,
or
kick
another
,
and
then
the
whole
mist
would
be
disturbed
:
with
men
diving
into
it
,
and
cries
of
men
and
beasts
coming
out
of
it
,
and
no
bystander
discerning
what
was
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
this
,
the
great
stable
of
the
convent
,
occupying
the
basement
story
and
entered
by
the
basement
door
,
outside
which
all
the
disorder
was
,
poured
forth
its
contribution
of
cloud
,
as
if
the
whole
rugged
edifice
were
filled
with
nothing
else
,
and
would
collapse
as
soon
as
it
had
emptied
itself
,
leaving
the
snow
to
fall
upon
the
bare
mountain
summit
.
   
<EOS>
While
all
this
noise
and
hurry
were
rife
among
the
living
travellers
,
there
,
too
,
silently
assembled
in
a
grated
house
half
-
a
-
dozen
paces
removed
,
with
the
same
cloud
enfolding
them
and
the
same
snow
flakes
drifting
in
upon
them
,
were
the
dead
travellers
found
upon
the
mountain
.
 
<EOS>
The
mother
,
storm
-
belated
many
winters
ago
,
still
standing
in
the
corner
with
her
baby
at
her
breast
;
the
man
who
had
frozen
with
his
arm
raised
to
his
mouth
in
fear
or
hunger
,
still
pressing
it
with
his
dry
lips
after
years
and
years
.
<EOS>
An
awful
company
,
mysteriously
come
together
!
 
<EOS>
A
wild
destiny
for
that
mother
to
have
foreseen
!
 
<EOS>
"
Surrounded
by
so
many
and
such
companions
upon
whom
I
never
looked
,
and
never
shall
look
,
I
and
my
child
will
dwell
together
inseparable
,
on
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
outlasting
generations
who
will
come
to
see
us
,
and
will
never
know
our
name
,
or
one
word
of
our
story
but
the
end
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
living
travellers
thought
little
or
nothing
of
the
dead
just
then
.
 
<EOS>
They
thought
much
more
of
alighting
at
the
convent
door
,
and
warming
themselves
at
the
convent
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Disengaged
from
the
turmoil
,
which
was
already
calming
down
as
the
crowd
of
mules
began
to
be
bestowed
in
the
stable
,
they
hurried
shivering
up
the
steps
and
into
the
building
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
smell
within
,
coming
up
from
the
floor
,
of
tethered
beasts
,
like
the
smell
of
a
menagerie
of
wild
animals
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
strong
arched
galleries
within
,
huge
stone
piers
,
great
staircases
,
and
thick
walls
pierced
with
small
sunken
windows
---
fortifications
against
the
mountain
storms
,
as
if
they
had
been
human
enemies
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
gloomy
vaulted
sleeping
-
rooms
within
,
intensely
cold
,
but
clean
and
hospitably
prepared
for
guests
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
there
was
a
parlour
for
guests
to
sit
in
and
sup
<EOS>
in
,
where
a
table
was
already
laid
,
and
where
a
blazing
fire
shone
red
and
high
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
room
,
after
having
had
their
quarters
for
the
night
allotted
to
them
by
two
young
Fathers
,
the
travellers
presently
drew
round
the
hearth
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
in
three
parties
;
of
whom
the
first
,
as
the
most
numerous
and
important
,
was
the
slowest
,
and
had
been
overtaken
by
one
of
the
others
on
the
way
up
.
 
<EOS>
It
consisted
of
an
elderly
lady
,
two
grey
-
haired
gentlemen
,
two
young
ladies
,
and
their
brother
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
attended
(
not
to
mention
four
guides
)
,
by
a
courier
,
two
footmen
,
and
two
waiting
-
maids
:
which
strong
body
of
inconvenience
was
accommodated
elsewhere
under
the
same
roof
.
<EOS>
The
party
that
had
overtaken
them
,
and
followed
in
their
train
,
consisted
of
only
three
members
:
one
lady
and
two
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
The
third
party
,
which
had
ascended
from
the
valley
on
the
Italian
side
of
the
Pass
,
and
had
arrived
first
,
were
four
in
number
:
a
plethoric
,
hungry
,
and
silent
German
tutor
in
spectacles
,
on
a
tour
with
three
young
men
,
his
pupils
,
all
plethoric
,
hungry
,
and
silent
,
and
all
in
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
These
three
groups
sat
round
the
fire
eyeing
each
other
drily
,
and
waiting
for
supper
.
 
<EOS>
Only
one
among
them
,
one
of
the
gentlemen
belonging
to
the
party
of
three
,
made
advances
towards
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Throwing
out
his
lines
for
the
Chief
of
the
important
tribe
,
while
addressing
himself
to
his
own
companions
,
he
remarked
,
in
a
tone
of
voice
which
included
all
the
company
if
they
chose
to
be
included
,
that
it
had
been
a
long
day
,
and
that
he
felt
for
the
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
feared
one
of
the
young
ladies
was
not
a
strong
or
accustomed
traveller
,
and
had
been
over
-
fatigued
two
or
three
hours
ago
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
observed
,
from
his
station
in
the
rear
,
that
she
sat
her
mule
as
if
she
were
exhausted
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
,
twice
or
thrice
afterwards
,
done
himself
the
honour
of
inquiring
of
one
of
the
guides
,
when
he
fell
behind
,
how
the
lady
did
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
been
enchanted
to
learn
that
she
had
recovered
her
spirits
,
and
that
it
had
been
but
a
passing
discomfort
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
trusted
(
by
this
time
he
had
secured
the
eyes
of
the
Chief
,
and
addressed
him
)
<EOS>
he
might
be
permitted
to
express
his
hope
that
she
was
now
none
the
worse
,
and
that
she
would
not
regret
having
made
the
journey
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
,
I
am
obliged
to
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
Chief
,
"
is
quite
restored
,
and
has
been
greatly
interested
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
New
to
mountains
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
insinuating
traveller
.
   
<EOS>
"
New
to
---
ha
---
to
mountains
,
"
said
the
Chief
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
familiar
with
them
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
the
insinuating
traveller
assumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
---
hum
---
tolerably
familiar
.
 
<EOS>
Not
of
late
years
.
 
<EOS>
Not
of
late
years
,
"
replied
the
Chief
,
with
a
flourish
of
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
The
insinuating
traveller
,
acknowledging
the
flourish
with
an
inclination
of
his
head
,
passed
from
the
Chief
to
the
second
young
lady
,
who
had
not
yet
been
referred
to
otherwise
than
as
one
of
the
ladies
in
whose
behalf
he
felt
so
sensitive
an
interest
.
   
<EOS>
He
hoped
she
was
not
incommoded
by
the
fatigues
of
the
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Incommoded
,
certainly
,
"
returned
the
young
lady
,
"
but
not
tired
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
insinuating
traveller
complimented
her
on
the
justice
of
the
distinction
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
what
he
had
meant
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
Every
lady
must
doubtless
be
incommoded
by
having
to
do
with
that
proverbially
unaccommodating
animal
,
the
mule
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
had
,
of
course
,
"
said
the
young
lady
,
who
was
rather
reserved
and
haughty
,
"
to
leave
the
carriages
and
fourgon
at
Martigny
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
impossibility
of
bringing
anything
that
one

to
this
inaccessible
place
,
and
the
necessity
of
leaving
every
comfort
behind
,
is
not
convenient
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
savage
place
indeed
,
"
said
the
insinuating
traveller
.
   
<EOS>
The
elderly
lady
,
who
was
a
model
of
accurate
dressing
,
and
whose
manner
was
perfect
,
considered
as
a
piece
of
machinery
,
here
interposed
a
remark
in
a
low

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
like
other
inconvenient
places
,
"
she
observed
,
"
it
must
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
place
much
spoken
of
,
it
is
necessary
to
see
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
least
objection
to
seeing
it
<EOS>
,
I
assure
you
,
Mrs
General
,
"
returned
the
other
,
carelessly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
madam
,
"
said
the
insinuating
traveller
,
"
have
visited
this
spot
before
?
"
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
here
before
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
commend
you
,
my
dear
,
"
to
the
former
young
lady
,
"
to
shade
your
face
from
the
hot
wood
,
after
exposure
to
the
mountain
air
and
snow
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
too
,
my
dear
,
"
to
the
other
and
younger
lady
,
who
immediately
did
so
;
while
the
former
merely
said
,
"
Thank
you
,
Mrs
General
,
I
am
Perfectly
comfortable
,
and
prefer
remaining
as
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
brother
,
who
had
left
his
chair
to
open
a
piano
that
stood
in
the
room
,
and
who
had
whistled
into
it
and
shut
it
up
again
,
now
came
strolling
back
to
the
fire
with
his
glass
in
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dressed
in
the
very
fullest
and
completest
travelling
trim
.
 
<EOS>
The
world
seemed
hardly
large
enough
to
yield
him
an
amount
of
travel
proportionate
to
his
equipment
.
   
<EOS>
"
These
fellows
are
an
immense
time
with
supper
,
"
he
drawled
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
they
'll
give
us
!
 
<EOS>
Has
anybody
any
idea
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
roast
man
,
I
believe
,
"
replied
the
voice
of
the
second
gentleman
of
the
party
of
three
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
not
.
 
<EOS>
What
d'ye
mean
?
<EOS>
"
he
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
as
you
are
not
to
be
served
for
the
general
supper
,
perhaps
you
will
do
us
the
favour
of
not
cooking
yourself
at
the
general
fire
,
"
returned
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
who
was
standing
in
an
easy
attitude
on
the
hearth
,
cocking
his
glass
at
the
company
,
with
his
back
to
the
blaze
and
his
coat
tucked
under
his
arms
,
something
as
if
he
were
Of
the
Poultry
species
and
were
trussed
for
roasting
,
lost
countenance
at
this
reply
;
he
seemed
about
to
demand
further
explanation
,
when
it
was
discovered
---
through
all
eyes
turning
on
the
speaker
---
that
the
lady
with
him
,
who
was
young
and
beautiful
,
had
not
heard
what
had
passed
through
having
fainted
with
her
head
upon

shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
the
gentleman
in
a
subdued

,
"
I
had
best
carry
her

to
her
room
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
call
to
some
one
to
bring

light
?
"
<EOS>
addressing

,
"
and
to
show

?
 
<EOS>
In
this
strange
rambling
place
I
do
n't
know
that
I
could
find
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
let
me
call
my
maid
,
"
cried
the
taller
of
the
young

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
let
me
put
this
water
to
her
lips
,
"
said
the
shorter
,
who
had
not
spoken
yet
.
   
<EOS>
Each
doing
what
she
suggested
,
there
was
no
want
of
assistance
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
when
the
two
maids
came
in
(
escorted

the
courier
,
lest
any
one
should
strike
them
dumb
by
addressing
a
foreign
language
to

on
the

)
,
there

a

of
too

.
<EOS>
Seeing

,
and
saying
as
much
in

slighter

of
the

,
the
gentleman
put
his
wife
's
arm
over
his
shoulder
,
lifted
her
up
,
and
carried
her
away
.
   
<EOS>
His
friend
,
being
left
alone
with
the
other
visitors
,
walked
slowly
up
and
down
the
room
without
coming
to
the
fire

,
pulling
his
black
moustache
in
a
contemplative
manner
,
as
if
he
felt
himself
committed
to
the
late
retort
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
subject
of
it
was
breathing
injury
in
a
corner
,
the
Chief
loftily
addressed
this
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
friend
,
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
is
---
ha
---
is
a

;
and
,
in

,
is

fully

of
what

owes
to
---
hum
---
to
---
<EOS>
but
we
will
waive
that
,
we
will

that
.
 
<EOS>
Your
friend
is
a
little
impatient
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
so
,
sir
,
"
returned

other
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
having
had
the
honour
of
making
that
gentleman
's

at
the
hotel
at
Geneva
,
where
we
and
much

some

,
and

exchanging

,
I
can

nothing
---
<EOS>
no
,
not

from
one
of

appearance
and
station
,

---
detrimental

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
no

,

,

hearing

.
 
<EOS>
In

that
your
friend
has
shown

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
make
that

,
because
it
is
not
to

that
my

,

by

---
ha
---

---
hum
---

,

on
the

.
 
<EOS>
Which
,
in

,
I
---
ha
---
for
all
are
---
hum
---
equal
on
these

---
I
consider
