.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
there
it
ends
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
your
son
's
obedient
servant
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
son
to
receive
the

of
my
profound

.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
sir
,
I
may
admit
,
freely

,
that
my
friend
is
sometimes

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
lady
is
your
friend
's
wife
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
lady
is
my
friend
's
wife
,
sir
.
"
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
handsome
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
she
is
peerless
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
still
in
the
first
year
of
their
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
still
partly
on
a
marriage
,
and
partly
on
an
artistic
,
tour
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
friend
is
an
artist
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
replied
by
kissing
the
fingers
of
his
right
hand
,
and
wafting
the
kiss
the
length
of

arm
towards
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
As
who
should
say
,
I
devote
him
to
the
celestial

as
an
immortal
artist
!
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
is
a
man
of
family
,
"
he
added
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
connections
are
of
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
more
than
an
artist
:
he
is
highly
connected
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
,
in
effect
,
have
repudiated
his
connections
,
proudly
,
impatiently
,
<EOS>
sarcastically
(
I
make
the
concession
of
both

)
;
but
he
has
them
.
 
<EOS>
Sparks
that
have
been
struck
out
during
our
intercourse
have
shown
me
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
,
"
said
the
lofty
gentleman
,
with
the
air
of
finally
disposing
of
the
subject
,
"
that
the
lady
's
indisposition
may
be
only
temporary
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
I
hope
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mere
fatigue
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
altogether
mere
fatigue
,
sir
,
for
her
mule
stumbled
to
-
day
,
and
she
fell
from
the
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
She
fell
lightly
,
and
was
up
again
without
assistance
,
and
rode
from
us
laughing
;
but
she
complained
towards
evening
of
a
slight
bruise
in
the
side
.
 
<EOS>
She
spoke
of
it
more
than
once
,
as
we
followed
your
party
up
the
mountain
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
head
of
the
large
retinue
,
who
was
gracious
but
not
familiar
,
appeared
by
this
time
to
think
that
he
had
condescended
more
than
enough
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
no
more
,
and
there
was
silence
for
some
quarter
of
an
hour
until
supper
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
supper
came
one
of
the
young
Fathers
<EOS>
(
there
seemed
to
be
no
old
Fathers
)
to
take
the
head
of
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
the
supper
of
an
ordinary
Swiss
hotel
,
and
good
red
wine
grown
by
the
convent
in
more
genial
air
was
not
wanting
.
 
<EOS>
The
artist
traveller
calmly
came
and
took
his
place
at
table
when
the
rest
sat
down
,
with
no
apparent
sense
upon
him
of
his
late
skirmish
with
the
completely
dressed
traveller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
he
inquired
of
the
host
,
over
his
soup
,
"
has
your
convent
many
of
its
famous
dogs
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Monsieur
,
it
has
three
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
three
in
the
gallery
below
.
 
<EOS>
Doubtless
the
three
in
question
.
<EOS>
"
The
host
,
a
slender
,
bright
-
eyed
,
dark
young
man
of
polite
manners
,
whose
garment
was
a
black
gown
with
strips
of
white
crossed
over
it
like
braces
,
and
who
no
more
resembled
the
conventional
breed
of
Saint
Bernard
monks
than
he
resembled
the
conventional
breed
of
Saint
Bernard
dogs
,
replied
,
doubtless
those
were
the
three
in
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
think
,
"
said
the
artist
traveller
,
"
I
have
seen
one
of
them
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
possible
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
dog
sufficiently
well
known
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
might
have
easily
seen
him
in
the
valley
or
somewhere
on
the
lake
,
when
he
(
the
dog
)
had
gone
down
with
one
of
the
order
to
solicit

for
the
convent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
is
done
in
its
regular
season
of
the
year
,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
was
right
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
never
without
a
dog
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
is
very
important
.
"
<EOS>
Again
Monsieur
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
was
very
important
.
 
<EOS>
People
were
justly
interested
in
the
dog
.
 
<EOS>
As
one
of
the
dogs
celebrated
everywhere
,
Ma'amselle
would
observe
.
   
<EOS>
Ma'amselle
was
a
little
slow
to
observe
it
,
as
though
she
were
not
yet
well
accustomed
to
the
French
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
,
however
,
observed
it
for
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
him
if
he
has
saved
many
lives
?
"
<EOS>
said
,
in
his
native
English
,
the
young
man
who
had
been
put
out
of
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
The
host
needed
no
translation
of

question
.
 
<EOS>
He
promptly
replied
in
French
,
"
No
.
 
Not
this
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
the
same
gentleman
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
,
"
returned
the
host
composedly
,
"
give
him
the
opportunity
and
he
will
do
it
without
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
,
I
am
well
convinced
,
"
smiling
sedately
,
as
he
cut
up
the
dish
of
veal
to
be
handed
round
,
on
the
young
man
who
had
been
put
out
of
countenance
,
"
that
if
you
,
Monsieur
,
would
give
him
the
opportunity
,
he
would
hasten
with
great
ardour
to
fulfil
his
duty
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
artist
traveller
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
The
insinuating
traveller
(
who
evinced
a
provident
anxiety
to
get
his
full
share
of
the
supper
)
,
wiping
some
drops
of
wine
from
his
moustache
with
a
piece

bread
,
joined
the
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
becoming
late
in
the
year
,
my
Father
,
"
said
he
,
"
for
tourist
-
travellers
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
late
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
two
or
three
weeks
,
at
most
,
and
we
shall
be
left
to
the
winter
snows
.
"
<EOS>
"
And
then
,
"
said
the
insinuating
traveller
,
"
for
the
scratching
dogs
and
the
buried
children
,
according
to
the
pictures
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
,
"
said
the
host
,
not
quite
understanding
the
allusion
.
<EOS>
"
How
,
then
the
scratching
dogs
and
the
buried
children
according
to
the
pictures
?
"
   
The
artist
traveller
struck
in
again
before
an
answer
could
be
given
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
,
"
he
coldly
inquired
across
the
table
of
his

,
"
that
none
but
smugglers
come
this
way
in
the
winter
or
can

any

business
this
way
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Holy
blue
!
 
<EOS>
No
;
never
heard
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
they
know
the
signs
of
the
weather
tolerably
well
,
they
do
n't
give
much
employment
to
the
dogs
---
who
have
consequently
died
out
rather
---
though
this
house
of
entertainment
is
conveniently
situated
for
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Their
young
families
,
I
am
told
,
they
usually
leave
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
grand
idea
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
artist
traveller
,
unexpectedly
rising
into
a
tone
of
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
sublime
idea
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
finest
idea
in
the
world
,
and
brings
tears
into
a
man
's
eyes
,
by
Jupiter
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
went
on
eating
his
veal
with
great
composure
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
enough
of
mocking
inconsistency
at
the
bottom
of
this
speech
to
make
it
rather
discordant
,
though
the
manner
was
refined
and
the
person
well
-
favoured
,
and
though
the
depreciatory
part
of
it
was
so
skilfully
thrown
off
as
to
be
very
difficult
for
one

acquainted

the
English
language
to
understand
,
or
,
even
understanding
,
to
take
offence
at
:
<EOS>
so
simple
and
dispassionate
was
its
tone
.
 
<EOS>
After
finishing
his
veal
in
the
midst
of
silence
,
the
speaker
again
addressed
his
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
,
"
said
he
,
in
his
former
tone
,
"
at
this
gentleman
our
host
,
not
yet
in
the
prime
of
life
,
who
in
so
graceful
a
way
and
with
such
courtly
urbanity
and
modesty
presides
over
us
!
 
<EOS>
Manners
fit
for
a
crown
!
 
<EOS>
Dine
with
the
Lord
Mayor
of
London
(
if
you
can
get
an

)
and
observe
the
contrast
.
 
<EOS>
This
dear
fellow
,
with
the
finest
cut
face
I
ever
saw
,
a
face
in
perfect
drawing
,
leaves
some
laborious
life
and
comes
up
here
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
many
feet
above
the
level
of
the
sea
,
for
no
other
purpose
on
earth
(
except
enjoying
himself
,
I

,
in
a
capital

)
than
to
keep
an
hotel
for
idle
poor
devils
like
you
and
me
,
and
leave
the
bill
to
our
consciences
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
is
n't
it
a
beautiful
sacrifice
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
we
want
more
to
touch
us
?
 
<EOS>
Because
rescued
people
of
interesting
appearance
are
not
,
for
eight
or
nine
months
out

every

,
holding
on
here
<EOS>
round
the
necks
of
the
most

of
dogs
carrying

,
shall

?
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
Bless
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
great
place
,
a
glorious
place
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
chest
of
the
grey
-
haired
gentleman
who
was
the
Chief
of
the
important
party
,
had
swelled
as
if
with
a

against
his
being
numbered
among
poor

.
 
<EOS>
No

had
the
artist
traveller
ceased
speaking
than
he
himself
spoke
with
great
dignity
,
as
having
it
incumbent
on
him
to
take
the
lead
in
most
places
,
and
having
deserted
that
duty
for
a

.
   
<EOS>
He
weightily
communicated
his
opinion
to
their
host
,
that
his
life
must
be
a
very
dreary
life
here
in
the
winter
.
   
<EOS>
The
host
allowed
to
Monsieur
that
it
was
a
little
monotonous
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
difficult
to
breathe
for
a
length
of
time
consecutively
.
<EOS>
The
cold
was
very
severe
.
 
<EOS>
One
needed
youth
and
strength
to
bear
it
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
having
them
and
the
blessing
of
Heaven
---
   
<EOS>
Yes
,
that
was
very
good
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
the
confinement
,
"
said
the
grey
-
haired
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
many
days
,
even
in
bad
weather
,
when
it
was
possible
to
walk
about
outside
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
custom
to
beat
a
little
track
,
and
take

there
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
space
,
"
urged

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
small
.
 
<EOS>
So
---
ha
---
very
limited
.
"
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
would
recall
to

that
there
were
the
refuges
to
visit
,
and
that
tracks
had
to
be
made
to
them
also
.
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
still
urged
,
on
the
other
hand
,
that
the
space
was
so
---
ha
---
hum
---
so
very
contracted
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
that
,
it
was
always
the
same
,
always
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
With
a
deprecating
smile
,
the
host
gently
raised
and
gently
lowered
his
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
true
,
he
remarked
,
but
permit
him
to
say
that
almost
all
objects
had
their
various
points
of
view
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
and
<EOS>
he
did
not
see
this
poor
life
of
his
from
the
same
point
of
view
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
was
not
used
to
confinement
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
---
ha
---
yes
,
very
true
,
"
said
the
grey
-
haired
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
receive
quite
a
shock
from
the
force
of
the
argument
.
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
,
as
an
English
traveller
,
surrounded
by
all
means
of
travelling
pleasantly
;
doubtless
possessing
fortune
,
carriages
,
and
servants
---
   
"
Perfectly
,
perfectly
.
 
<EOS>
Without
doubt
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
could
not
easily
place
himself
in
the
position
of
a
person
who
had
not
the
power
to
choose
,
I
will
go
here
to
-
morrow
,
or
there
next
day
;
I
will
pass
these
barriers
,
I
will
enlarge
those
bounds
.
<EOS>
Monsieur
could
not
realise
,
perhaps
,
how
the
mind
accommodated
itself
in
such
things
to
the
force
of
necessity
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
,
"
said
Monsieur
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
---
ha
---
not
pursue
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
You
are
---
hum
---
quite
accurate
,
I
have
no
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
say
no
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
supper
having
come
to
a
close
,
he
drew
his
chair
away
as
he
spoke
,
and
moved
back
to
his
former
place
by
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
very
cold
at
the
greater
part
of
the
table
,
the
other
guests
also
resumed
their
former
seats
by
the
fire
,
designing
to
toast
themselves
well
before
going
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
host
,
when
they
rose
from
the
table
,
bowed
to
all
present
,
wished
them
good
night
,
and
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
But
first
the
insinuating
traveller
had
asked
him
if
they
could
have
some
wine
made
hot
;
and
as
he
had
answered
Yes
,
and
had
presently
afterwards
sent
it
in
,
that
traveller
,
seated
in
the
centre
of
the
group
,
and
in
the
full
heat
of
the
fire
,
was
soon
engaged
in
serving
it
out
to
the
rest
.
   
<EOS>
At
this
time
,
the
younger
of
the
two
young
ladies
,
who
had
been
silently
attentive
in
her
dark
corner
(
the
fire
-
light
was
the
chief
light
in
the
sombre
room
,
the
lamp
being
smoky
and
dull
)
to
what
had
been
said
of
the
absent
lady
,
glided
out
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
at
a
loss
which
way
to
turn
when
she
had
softly
closed
the
door
;
but
,
after
a
little
hesitation
among
the
sounding
passages
and
the
many
ways
,
came
to
a
room
in
a
corner
of
the
main
gallery
,
where
the
servants
were
at
their
supper
.
 
<EOS>
From
these
she
obtained
a
lamp
,
and
a
direction
to
the
lady
's
room
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
up
the
great
staircase
on
the
story
above
.
 
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
the
bare
white
walls
were
broken
by
an
iron
grate
,
and
she
thought
as
she
went
along
that
the
place
was
something
like
a
prison
.
 
<EOS>
The
arched
door
of
the
lady
's
room
,
or
cell
,
was
not
quite
shut
.
 
<EOS>
After
knocking
at
it
two
or
three
times
without
receiving
an
answer
,
she
pushed
it
gently
open
,
and
looked
in
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
lay
with
closed
eyes
on
the
outside
of
the
bed
,
protected
from
the
cold
by
the
blankets
and
wrappers
with
which
she
had
been
covered
when
she
revived
from
her
fainting
fit
.
 
<EOS>
A
dull
light
placed
in
the
deep
recess
of
the
window
,
made
little
impression
on
the
arched
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
timidly
stepped
to
the
bed
,
and
said
,
in
a
soft
whisper
,
"
Are
you
better
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
had
fallen
into
a
slumber
,
and
the
whisper
was
too
low
to
awake
her
.
 
<EOS>
Her
visitor
,
standing
quite
still
,
looked
at
her
attentively
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
pretty
,
"
she
said
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
so
beautiful
a
face
.
 
<EOS>
O
how
unlike
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
curious
thing
to
say
,
but
it
had
some
hidden
meaning
,
for
it
filled
her
eyes
with
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
must
be
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
he
spoke
of
her
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
very
easily
be
wrong
on
any
other
subject
,
but
not
on
this
,
not
on
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
quiet
and
tender
hand
she
put
aside
a
straying
fold
of
the
sleeper
's
hair
,
and
then
touched
the
hand
that
lay
outside
the
covering
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
look
at
her
,
"
she
breathed
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
see
what
has
affected
him
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
not
withdrawn
her
hand
,
when
the
sleeper
opened
her
eyes
and
started
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
be
alarmed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
only
one
of
the
travellers
from
downstairs
.
<EOS>
I
came
to
ask
if
you
were
better
,
and
if
I
could
do
anything
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
have
already
been
so
kind
as
to
send
your
servants
to
my
assistance
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
<EOS>
I
;
that
was
my
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
better
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Much
better
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
only
a
slight
bruise
,
and
has
been
well
looked
to
,
and
is
almost
easy
now
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
me
giddy
and
faint
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
hurt
me
before
;
but
at
last
it
overpowered
me
all
at
once
.
"
<EOS>
"
May
I
stay
with
you
until
some
one
comes
?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
like
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
it
,
for
it
is
lonely
here
;
but
I
am
afraid
you
will
feel
the
cold
too
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mind
cold
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
delicate
,
if
I
look
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She
quickly
moved
one
of
the
two
rough
chairs
to
the
bedside
,
and
sat
down
.
<EOS>
The
other
as
quickly
moved
a
part
of
some
travelling
wrapper
from
herself
,
and
drew
it
over
her
,
so
that
her
arm
,
in
keeping
it
about
her
,
rested
on
her
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
so
much
the
air
of
a
kind
nurse
,
"
said
the
lady
,
smiling
on
her
,
"
that
you
seem
as
if
you
had
come
to
me
from
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
dreaming
of
home
when
I
woke
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
Of
my
old
home
,
I
mean
,
before
I
was
married
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
before
you
were
so
far
away
from
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
much
farther
away
from
it
than
this
;
but
then
I
took
the
best
part
of
it
with
me
,
and
missed
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
solitary
as
I
dropped
asleep
here
,
and
,
missing
it
a
little
,
wandered
back
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sorrowfully
affectionate
and
regretful
sound
in
her
voice
,
which
made
her
visitor
refrain
from
looking
at
her
for
the
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
curious
chance
which
at
last
brings
us
together
,
under
this
covering
in
which
you
have
wrapped
me
,
"
said
the
visitor
after
a
pause
;
"
for
do
you
know
,
I
think
I
have
been
looking
for
you
some
time
.
"
<EOS>
"
Looking
for
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
have
a
little
note
here
,
which
I
was
to
give
to
you
whenever
I
found
you
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
it
.
 
<EOS>
Unless
I
greatly
mistake
,
it
is
addressed
to
you
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
took
it
,
and
said
yes
,
and
read
it
.
 
<EOS>
Her
visitor
watched
her
as
she
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
short
.
 
<EOS>
She
flushed
a
little
as
she
put
her
lips
to
her
visitor
's
cheek
,
and
pressed
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
dear
young
friend
to
whom
he
presents
me
,
may
be
a
comfort
to
me
at
some
time
,
he
says
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
truly
a
comfort
to
me
the
first
time
I
see
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
do
n't
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
hesitating
---
"
<EOS>
perhaps
you
do
n't
know
my
story
?
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
never
told
you
my
story
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
why
should
he
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
scarcely
the
right
to
tell
it
myself
at
present
,
because
I
have
been
entreated
not
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
not
much
in
it
,
but
it
might
account
to
you
for
my
asking
you
not
to
say
anything
about
the
letter
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
saw
my
family
with
me
,
perhaps
?
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
<EOS>
---
I
only
say
this
to
you
---
are
a
little
proud
,
a
little
prejudiced
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
take
it
back
again
,
"
said
the
other
;
"
and
then
my
husband
is
sure
not
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
see
it
and
speak
of
it
,
otherwise
,
by
some
accident
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
put
it
in
your
bosom
again
,
to
be
certain
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
did
so
with
great
care
.
 
<EOS>
Her
small
,
slight
hand
was
still
upon
the
letter
,
when
they
heard
some
one
in
the
gallery
outside
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
promised
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
rising
,
"
that
I
would
write
to
him
after
seeing
you
(
I
could
hardly
fail
to
see
you
sooner
or
later
)
,
and
tell
him
if
you
were
well
and
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
better
say
you
were
well
and
happy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
yes
!
 
<EOS>
Say
<EOS>
I
was
very
well
and
very
happy
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
I
thanked
him
affectionately
,
and
would
never
forget
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
see
you
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
we
are
sure
to
meet
again
before
very
long
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
Both
of
them
were
hurried
and
fluttered
as
they
exchanged
this
parting
,
and
as
the
visitor
came
out
of
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
expected
to
meet
the
lady
's
husband
approaching
it
;
but
the
person
in
the
gallery
was
not
he
:
it
was
the
traveller
who
had
wiped
the
wine
-
drops
from
his
moustache
with
the
piece
of
bread
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
heard
the
step
behind
him
,
he
turned
round
---
for
he
was
walking
away
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
His
politeness
,
which
was
extreme
,
would
not
allow
of
the
young
lady
's
lighting
herself
down
-
stairs
,
or
going
down
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
her
lamp
,
held
it
so
as
to
throw
the
best
light
on
the
stone
steps
,
and
followed
her
all
the
way
to
the
supper
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
She
went
down
,
not
easily
hiding
how
much
she
was
inclined
to
shrink
and
tremble
;
for
the
appearance
of
this
traveller
was
particularly
disagreeable
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
sat
in
her
quiet
corner
before
supper
imagining
what
he
would
have
been
in
the
scenes
and
places
within
her
experience
,
until
he
inspired
her
with
an
aversion
that
made
him
little
less
than
terrific
.
   
<EOS>
He
followed
her
down
with
his
smiling
politeness
,
followed
her
in
,
and
resumed
his
seat
in
the
best
place
in
the
hearth
.
 
<EOS>
There
with
the
wood
-
fire
,
which
was
beginning
to
burn
low
,
rising
and
falling
upon
him
in
the
dark
room
,
he
sat
with
his
legs
thrust
out
to
warm
,
drinking
the
hot
wine
down
to
the
lees
,
with
a
monstrous
shadow
imitating
him
on
the
wall
and
ceiling
.
   
<EOS>
The
tired
company
had
broken
up
,
and
all
the
rest
were
gone
to
bed
except
the
young
lady
's
father
,
who
dozed
in
his
chair
by
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
The
traveller
had
been
at
the
pains
of
going
a
long
way
up
-
stairs
to
his
sleeping
-
room
to
fetch
his
pocket
-
flask
of
brandy
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
them
so
,
as
he
poured
its
contents
into
what
was
left
of
the
wine
,
and
drank
with
a
new
relish
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
,
sir
,
if
you
are
on
your
way
to
Italy
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
grey
-
haired
gentleman
had
roused
himself
,
and
was
preparing
to
withdraw
.
 
<EOS>
He
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
also
!
"
said
the
traveller
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
hope
to
have
the
honour
of
offering
my
compliments
in
fairer
scenes
,
and
under
softer
circumstances
,
than
on
this
dismal
mountain
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
bowed
,
distantly
enough
,
and
said
he
was
obliged
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
poor
gentlemen
,
sir
,
"
said
the
traveller
,
pulling
his
moustache
dry
with
his
hand
,
for
he
had
dipped
it
in
the
wine
and
brandy
;
"
we
poor
gentlemen
do
not
travel
like
princes
,
but
the
courtesies
and
graces
of
life
are
precious
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
To
your
health
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
I
thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
health
of
your
distinguished
family
---
of
the
fair
ladies
,
your
daughters
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
I
thank
you
again
,
I
wish
you
good
night
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
are
our
---
ha
---
our
people
in
attendance
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
close
by
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Permit
me
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
traveller
,
rising
and
holding
the
door
open
,
as
the
gentleman
crossed
the
room
towards
it
with
his
arm
drawn
through
his
daughter
's
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
repose
!
 
<EOS>
To
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
once
more
!
 
<EOS>
To
to
-
morrow
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
kissed
his
hand
,
with
his
best
manner
and
his
daintiest
smile
,
the
young
lady
drew
a
little
nearer
to
her
father
,
and
passed
him
with
a
dread
of
touching
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
insinuating
traveller
,
whose
manner
shrunk
,
and
whose
voice
dropped
when
he
was
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
they
all
go
to
bed
,
why
I
must
go
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
in
a
devil
of
a
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
One
would
think
the
night
would
be
long
enough
,
in
this
freezing
silence
and
solitude
,
if
one
went
to
bed
two
hours
hence
.
"
   
<EOS>
Throwing
back
his
head
in
emptying
his
glass
,
he
cast
his
eyes
upon
the
travellers
'
book
,
which
lay
on
the
piano
,
open
,
with
pens
and
ink
beside
it
,
as
if
the
night
's
names
had
been
registered
when
he
was
absent
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
it
in
his
hand
,
he
read
these
entries
.
        
<EOS>
William
Dorrit
,
Esquire
     
Frederick
Dorrit
,
Esquire
     
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
     
<EOS>
Miss
Dorrit
     
<EOS>
Miss
Amy
Dorrit
     
<EOS>
Mrs
General
     
and
Suite
.
     
<EOS>
From
France
to
Italy
.
        
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Henry
Gowan
.
     
<EOS>
From
France
to
Italy
.
   
<EOS>
To
which
he
added
,
in
a
small
complicated
hand
,
ending
with
a
long
lean
flourish
,
not
unlike
a
lasso
thrown
at
all
the
rest
of
the
names
:
        
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
Paris
.
     
<EOS>
From
France
to
Italy
.
   
<EOS>
And
then
,
with
his
nose
coming
down
over
his
moustache
and
his
moustache
going
up
and
under
his
nose
,
repaired
to
his
allotted
cell
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
02
.
<EOS>
Mrs
General
 
<EOS>
It
is
indispensable
to
present
the
accomplished
lady
who
was
of
sufficient
importance
in
the
suite
of
the
Dorrit
Family
to
have
a
line
to
herself
in
the
Travellers
'
Book
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
was
the
daughter
of
a
clerical
dignitary
in
a
cathedral
town
,
where
she
had
led
the
fashion
until
she
was
as
near
forty
-
five
as
a
single
lady
can
be
.
 
<EOS>
A
stiff
commissariat
officer
of
sixty
,
famous
as
a
martinet
,
had
then
become
enamoured
of
the
gravity
with
which
she
drove
the
proprieties
four
-
in
-
hand
through
the
cathedral
town
society
,
and
had
solicited
to
be
taken
beside
her
on
the
box
of
the
cool
coach
of
ceremony
to
which
that
team
was
harnessed
.
 
<EOS>
His
proposal
of
marriage
being
accepted
by
the
lady
<EOS>
,
the
commissary
took
his
seat
behind
the
proprieties
with
great
decorum
,
and
Mrs
General
drove
until
the
commissary
died
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
their
united
journey
,
they
ran
over
several
people
who
came
in
the
way
of
the
proprieties
;
but
always
in
a
high
style
and
with
composure
.
   
<EOS>
The
commissary
having
been
buried
with
all
the
decorations
suitable
to
the
service
<EOS>
(
the
whole
team
of
proprieties
were
harnessed
to
his
hearse
,
and
they
all
had
feathers
and
black
velvet
housings
with
his
coat
of
arms
in
the
corner
)
,
Mrs
General
began
to
inquire
what
quantity
of
dust
and
ashes
was
deposited
at
the
bankers
'
.
 
<EOS>
It
then
transpired
that
the
commissary
had
so
far
stolen
a
march
on
Mrs
General
as
to
have
bought
himself
an
annuity
some
years
before
his
marriage
,
and
to
have
reserved
that
circumstance
in
mentioning
,
at
the
period
of
his
proposal
,
that
his
income
was
derived
from
the
interest
of
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
consequently
found
her
means
so
much
diminished
,
<EOS>
that
,
but
for
the
perfect
regulation
of
her
mind
,
she
might
have
felt
disposed
to
question
the
accuracy
of
that
portion
of
the
late
service
which
had
declared
that
the
commissary
could
take
nothing
away
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
affairs
it
occurred
to
Mrs
General
,
that
she
might
"
form
the
mind
,
"
and
eke
the
manners
of
some
young
lady
of
distinction
.
 
<EOS>
Or
,
that
she
might
harness
the
proprieties
to
the
carriage
of
some
rich
young
heiress
or
widow
,
and
become
at
once
the
driver
and
guard
of
such
vehicle
through
the
social
mazes
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
's
communication
of
this
idea
to
her
clerical
and
commissariat
connection
was
so
warmly
applauded
that
,
but
for
the
lady
's
undoubted
merit
,
it
might
have
appeared
as
though
they
wanted
to
get
rid
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Testimonials
representing
Mrs
General
as
a
prodigy
of
piety
,
learning
,
virtue
,
and
gentility
,
were
lavishly
contributed
from
influential
quarters
;
and
one
venerable
archdeacon
even
shed
tears
in
recording
his
testimony
to
her
perfections
(
described
to
him
by
persons
on
whom
he
could
rely
)
,
though
he
had
never
had
the
honour
and
moral
gratification
of
setting
eyes
on
Mrs
General
in
all
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
delegated
on
her
mission
,
as
it
were
by
Church
and
State
,
Mrs
General
,
who
had
always
occupied
high
ground
,
felt
in
a
condition
to
keep
it
,
and
began
by
putting
herself
up
at
a
very
high
figure
.
<EOS>
An

of
some
duration
elapsed
,
in
which
there
was
no
bid
for
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
a

-

,

,
opened

the
lady
;
and
as

was
a

of
Mrs
General
(
<EOS>
but
certainly
one
or
the
other
)
to

as

were

more

,
the

Mrs
General
until

upon

to
form
his
daughter
's

.
   
<EOS>
The

Mrs
General
about

,
in

she
made

,
and

most

that

it

see
with
other

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,
that
Mrs
General
was
a

.
   
<EOS>
The
phoenix
was
to
let
,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's

,
as

,

"
Mrs
General
.
"
   
<EOS>
Pursuing

,

<EOS>
"

"

"

ha

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
But

(

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

any

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
being
an
article

that

which

that
it
is
worth

,

made

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
conceded
that
high
privilege
,
and
here
she
was
.
   
<EOS>
In
person
,
Mrs
General
,
including
her
skirts
which
had
much
to
do
with
it
,
was
of
a
dignified
and
imposing
appearance
;
ample
,
rustling
,
gravely
voluminous
;
always
upright
behind
the
proprieties
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
have
been
taken
---
had
been
taken
---
to
the
top
of
the
Alps
and
the
bottom
of
Herculaneum
,
without
disarranging
a
fold
in
her
dress
,
or
displacing
a
pin
.
 
<EOS>
If
her
countenance
and
hair
had
rather
a
floury
appearance
,
as
though
from
living
in
some
transcendently
genteel
Mill
,
it
was
rather
because
she
was
a
chalky
creation
altogether
,
than
because
she
mended
her
complexion
with
violet
powder
,
or
had
turned
grey
.
 
<EOS>
If
her
eyes
had
no
expression
,
it
was
probably
because
they
had
nothing
to
express
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
few
wrinkles
,
it
was
because
her
mind
had
never
traced
its
name
or
any
other
inscription
on
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
A
cool
,
waxy
,
blown
-
out
woman
,
who
had
never
lighted
well
.
<EOS>
Mrs
General
had
no
opinions
.
 
<EOS>
Her
way
of
forming
a
mind
was
to
prevent
it
from
forming
opinions
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
little
circular
set
of
mental
grooves
or
rails
on
which
she
started
little
trains
of
other
people
's
opinions
,
which
never
overtook
one
another
,
and
never
got
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
Even
her
propriety
could
not
dispute
that
there
was
impropriety
in
the
world
;
but
Mrs
General
's
way
of
getting
rid
of
it
was
to
put
it
out
of
sight
,
and
make
believe
that
there
was
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
another
of
her
ways
of
forming
a
mind
---
to
cram
all
articles
of
difficulty
into
cupboards
,
lock
them
up
,
and
say
they
had
no
existence
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
easiest
way
,
and
,
beyond
all
comparison
,
the
properest
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
was
not
to
be
told
of
anything
shocking
.
 
<EOS>
Accidents
,
miseries
,
and
offences
,
were
never
to
be
mentioned
before
her
.
<EOS>
Passion
was
to
go
to
sleep
in
the
presence
of
Mrs
General
,
and
blood
was
to
change
to
milk
and
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
that
was
left
in
the
world
,
when
all
these
deductions
were
made
,
it
was
Mrs
General
's
province
to
varnish
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
formation
process
of
hers
,
she
dipped
the
smallest
of
brushes
into
the
largest
of
pots
,
and
varnished
the
surface
of
every
object
that
came
under
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
cracked
it
was
,
the
more
Mrs
General
varnished
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
varnish
in
Mrs
General
's
voice
,
varnish
in
Mrs
General
's
touch
,
an
atmosphere
of
varnish
round
Mrs
General
's
figure
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
's
dreams
ought
to
have
been
varnished
---
if
she
had
any
---
lying
asleep
in
the
arms
of
the
good
Saint
Bernard
,
with
the
feathery
snow
falling
on

house
-
top
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
03
.
<EOS>
On
the
Road
 
<EOS>
The
bright
morning
sun
dazzled
the
eyes
,
the
snow
had
ceased
,
the
mists
had
vanished
,
the
mountain
air
was
so
clear
and
light
that
the
new
sensation
of
breathing
it
was
like
the
having
entered
on
a
new
existence
.
 
<EOS>
To
help
the
delusion
,
the
solid
ground
itself
seemed
gone
,
and
the
mountain
,
a
shining
waste
of
immense
white
heaps
and
masses
,
to
be
a
region
of
cloud
floating
between
the
blue
sky
above
and
the
earth
far
below
.
   
<EOS>
Some
dark
specks
in
the
snow
,
like

upon
a
little

,
beginning
at
the
convent
door
and
winding
away
down

descent
in
broken

which
were
not
yet
pieced
together
,
showed
where
the
Brethren
were
at
work
in
several
places
clearing
the
track
.
<EOS>
Already
the
snow
had
begun
to
be
foot
-
thawed
again
about
the
door
.
<EOS>
Mules
were
busily

out
,
tied
to
the
rings
in
the
wall
,
and
laden
;
strings
of
bells
were
buckled
on
,
burdens
were
adjusted
,
the
voices

and

musically
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
earliest
had
even
already

;
and
,
both

the
level

the
dark
water
near
the

,
and

downward

of

's

,
little

of

and

,
reduced

around
,
went
with

pleasant

.
   
<EOS>
In

-
room
of
last

,
a
new

,

upon
the

ashes
of

old

,
shone

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

for
his

from

had

up

,
together

several

which

chiefly

strong

of

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
and
Blandois
of
Paris
had
already

,
and

up

,

.
<EOS>
"
Gowan
,

?
"

,

,
Esquire

book
,

<EOS>
"

is

<EOS>
If

my
while

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
How

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Fortunately

,
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

(

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Natural
,

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Nonsense
,

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

ca

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
angry
!
<EOS>
"
returned
that

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
patience
"
(
which

)
.

"

,

,
"

,

"

?
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Never

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Amy
will

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,
this
Mrs
Gowan
before

,

.

"

"

"

"
has

---
any
---
ha
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
However

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whose

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pa
,

"

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,

"

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
Little

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Of

!
 
<EOS>
I

!
 
<EOS>
And

,
Pa
,
I
do
declare
once

all
"
---
this

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Is

,

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
Are

?
 
<EOS>
Are

never
to

?
 
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Amy
,
"
observed

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
that
,
upon

,

,

man

.
 
<EOS>
And
who
,
"
he

low

minded
thief
,
you
know
,
or
he
never
could
have
conducted

as

.
<EOS>
"
   
"

,
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
Can

by

?
 
<EOS>
Never
.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
a

,
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

;
"

,

"
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
for

,

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

---

!
"
<EOS>
"
Father
---
Edward
---

"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

ca

.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

,

"

"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

,

---
ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Down
.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,

,

my

.
 
<EOS>
We

ha

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

---
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

,

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

hum

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

---
ha
---

Mr
Clennam
<EOS>
(
it

)

,
"
here

---
ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
I

---
ha
---

.
<EOS>
If

,

,
I

not
for

---
ha
---

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
---
Mrs
General
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

of
the
lady
whom
he
announced
,
to
take

at
the
breakfast
-
table
,
terminated

.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
the
courier
announced
that
the
valet
,
and
the
footman
,
and
the
two
maids
,
and
the
four
guides
,
and
the
fourteen
mules
,
were
in
readiness
;
so
the
breakfast
party
went
out
to
the
convent
door
to
join
the
cavalcade
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
stood
aloof
with
his
cigar
and
pencil
,
but
Mr
Blandois
was
on
the
spot
to
pay
his
respects
to
the
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
gallantly
pulled
off
his
slouched
hat
to
Little
Dorrit
,
she
thought
he
had
even
a
more
sinister
look
,
standing
swart
and
cloaked
in
the
snow
,
than
he
had
in
the
fire
-
light
over
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
both
her
father
and
her
sister
received
his
homage
with
some
favour
,
she
refrained
from
expressing
any
distrust
of
him
,
lest
it
should
prove
to
be
a
new
blemish
derived
from
her
prison
birth
.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
as
they
wound
down
the
rugged
way
while
the
convent
was
yet
in
sight
,
she
more
than
once
looked
round
,
and
descried
Mr
Blandois
,
backed
by
the
convent
smoke
which
rose
straight
and
high
from
the
chimneys
in
a
golden
film
,
always
standing
on
one
jutting
point
looking
down
after
them
.
 
<EOS>
Long
after
he
was
a
mere
black
stick
in
the
snow
,
she
felt
as
though
she
could
yet
see
that
smile
of
his
,
that
high
nose
,
and
those
eyes
that
were
too
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
even
after
that
,
when
the
convent
was
gone
and
some
light
morning
clouds
veiled
the
pass
below
it
,
the
ghastly
skeleton
arms
by
the
wayside
seemed
to
be
all
pointing
up
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
More
treacherous
than
snow
,
perhaps
,
colder
at
heart
,
and
harder
to
melt
,
<EOS>
Blandois
of
Paris
by
degrees
passed
out
of
her
mind
,
as
they
came
down
into
the
softer
regions
.
 
<EOS>
Again
the
sun
was
warm
,
again
the
streams
descending
from
glaciers
and
snowy
caverns
were
refreshing
to
drink
at
,
again
they
came
among
the
pine
-
trees
,
the
rocky
rivulets
,
the
verdant
heights
and
dales
,
the
wooden
chalets
and
rough
zigzag
fences
of
Swiss
country
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
way
so
widened
that
she
and
her
father
could
ride
abreast
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
to
look
at
him
,
handsomely
clothed
in
his
fur
and
broadcloths
,
rich
<EOS>
,
free
,
numerously
served
and
attended
,
his
eyes
roving
far
away
among
the
glories
of
the
landscape
,
no
miserable
screen
before
them
to
darken
his
sight
and
cast
its
shadow
on
him
,
was
enough
.
   
<EOS>
Her
uncle
was
so
far
rescued
from
that
shadow
of
old
,
that
he
wore
the
clothes
they
gave
him
,
and
performed
some
ablutions
as
a
sacrifice
to
the
family
credit
,
and
went
where
he
was
taken
,
with
a
certain
patient
animal
enjoyment
,
which
seemed
to
express
that
the
air
and
change
did
him
good
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
other
respects
,
save
one
,
he
shone
with
no
light
but
such
as
was
reflected
from
his
brother
.
<EOS>
His
brother
's
greatness
,
wealth
,
freedom
,
and
grandeur
,
pleased
him
without
any
reference
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Silent
and
retiring
,
he
had
no
use
for
speech
when
he
could
hear
his
brother
speak
;
no
desire
to
be
waited
on
,
so
that
the
servants
devoted
themselves
to
his
brother
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
noticeable
change
he
originated
in
himself
,
was
an
alteration
in
his
manner
to
his
younger
niece
.
 
<EOS>
Every
day
it
refined
more
and
more
into
a
marked
respect
,
very
rarely
shown
by
age
to
youth
,
and
still
more
rarely
susceptible
,
one
would
have
said
,
of
the
fitness
with
which
he
invested
it
.
 
<EOS>
On
those
occasions
when
Miss
Fanny
did
declare
once
for
all
,
he
would
take
the
next
opportunity
of
baring
his
grey
head
before
his
younger
niece
,
and
of
helping
her
to
alight
,
or
handing
her
to
the
carriage
,
or
showing
her
any
other
attention
,
with
the
profoundest
deference
.
<EOS>
Yet
it
never
appeared
misplaced
or
forced
,
being
always
heartily
simple
,
spontaneous
,
and
genuine
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
would
he
ever
consent
,
even
at
his
brother
's
request
,
to
be
helped
to
any
place
before
her
,
or
to
take
precedence
of
her
in
anything
.
 
<EOS>
So
jealous
was
he
of
her
being
respected
,
that
,
on
this
very
journey
down
from
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
he
took
sudden
and
violent
umbrage
at
the
footman
's
being
remiss
to
hold
her
stirrup
,
though
standing
near
when
she
dismounted
;
and
unspeakably
astonished
the
whole
retinue
by
charging
at
him
on
a
hard
-
headed
mule
,
riding
him
into
a
corner
,
and
threatening
to
trample
him
to
death
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
a
goodly
company
,
and
the
Innkeepers
all
but
worshipped
them
.
 
<EOS>
Wherever
they
went
,
their
importance
preceded
them
in
the
person
of
the
courier
riding
before
,
to
see
that
the
rooms
of
state
were
ready
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
herald
of
the
family
procession
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
travelling
-
carriage
came
next
:
containing
,
inside
,
Mr
Dorrit
,
Miss
Dorrit
,
Miss
Amy
Dorrit
,
and
Mrs
General
;
outside
,
some
of
the
retainers
,
and
(
in
fine
weather
)
<EOS>
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
for
whom
the
box
was
reserved
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
chariot
containing
Frederick
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
and
an
empty
place
occupied
by
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
in
wet
weather
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
fourgon
with
the
rest
of
the
retainers
,
the
heavy
baggage
,
and
as
much
as
it
could
carry
of
the
mud
and
dust
which
the
other
vehicles
left
behind
.
   
<EOS>
These
equipages
adorned
the
yard
of
the
hotel
at
Martigny
,
on
the
return
of
the
family
from
their
mountain
excursion
.
 
<EOS>
Other
vehicles
were
there
,
much
company
being
on
the
road
,
from
the
patched
Italian
Vettura
---
like
the
body
of
a
swing
from
an
English
fair
put
upon
a
wooden
tray
on
wheels
,
and
having
another
wooden
tray
without
wheels
put
atop
of
it
---
to
the
trim
English
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
another
adornment
of
the
hotel
which
Mr
Dorrit
had
not
bargained
for
.
 
<EOS>
Two
strange
travellers
embellished
one
of
his
rooms
.
   
<EOS>
The
Innkeeper
,
hat
in
hand
in
the
yard
,
swore
to
the
courier
that
he
was
blighted
,
that
he
was
desolated
,
that
he
was
profoundly
afflicted
,
that
he
was
the
most
miserable
and
unfortunate
of
beasts
,
that
he
had
the
head
of
a
wooden
pig
.
 
<EOS>
He
ought
never
to
have
made
the
concession
,
he
said
,
but
the
very
genteel
lady
had
so
passionately
prayed
him
for
the
accommodation
of
that
room
to
dine
in
,
only
for
a
little
half
-
hour
,
that
he
had
been
vanquished
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
half
-
hour
was
expired
,
the
lady
and
gentleman
were
taking
their
little
dessert
and
half
-
cup
of
coffee
,
the
note
was
paid
,
the
horses
were
ordered
,
they
would
depart
immediately
;
but
,
owing
to
an
unhappy
destiny
and
the
curse
of
Heaven
,
they
were
not
yet
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
could
exceed
Mr
Dorrit
's
indignation
,
as
he
turned
at
the
foot
of
the
staircase
on
hearing
these
apologies
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
that
the
family
dignity
was
struck
at
by
an
assassin
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
sense
of
his
dignity
,
which
was
of
the
most
exquisite
nature
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
detect
a
design
upon
it
when
nobody
else
had
any
perception
of
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
His
life
was
made
an
agony
by
the
number
of
fine
scalpels
that
he
felt
to
be
incessantly
engaged
in
dissecting
his
dignity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
reddening
excessively
,
"
that
you
have
<EOS>
---
ha
---
had
the
audacity
to
place
one
of
my
rooms
at
the
disposition
of
any
other
person
?
"
   
<EOS>
Thousands
of
pardons
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
host
's
profound
misfortune
to
have
been
overcome
by
that
too
genteel
lady
.
 
<EOS>
He
besought
Monseigneur
not
to
enrage
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
on
Monseigneur
for
clemency
.
 
<EOS>
If
Monseigneur
would
have
the
distinguished
goodness
to
occupy
the
other
salon
especially
reserved
for
him
,
for
but
<EOS>
five
minutes
,
all
would
go
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
occupy
any
salon
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
leave
your
house
without
eating
or
drinking
,
or
setting
foot
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
How
do
you
dare
to
act
like
this
?
 
<EOS>
Who
am
I
that
you
---
ha
---
separate
me
from
other
gentlemen
?
"
   
<EOS>
Alas
!
 
<EOS>
The
host
called
all
the
universe
to
witness
that
Monseigneur
was
the
most
amiable
of
the
whole
body
of
nobility
,
the
most
important
,
the
most
estimable
,
the
most
honoured
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
separated
Monseigneur
from
others
,
it
was
only
because
he
was
more
distinguished
,
more
cherished
,
more
generous
,
more
renowned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
tell
me
so
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Dorrit
,
in
a
mighty
heat
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
affronted
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
heaped
insults
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
?
 
<EOS>
Explain
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ah
,
just
Heaven
,
then
,
how
could
the
host
explain
himself
when
he
had
nothing
more
to
explain
;
when
he
had
only
to
apologise
,
and
confide
himself
to
the
so
well
-
known
magnanimity
of
Monseigneur
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
panting
with
anger
,
"
that
you
separate
me
---
ha
---
from
other
gentlemen
;
that
you
make
distinctions
between
me
and
other
gentlemen
of
fortune
and
station
.
 
<EOS>
I
demand
of
you
,
why
?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
know
on
---
ha
---
what
authority
,
on
whose
authority
.
 
<EOS>
Reply
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Explain
.
 
<EOS>
Answer
why
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Permit
the
landlord
humbly
to
submit
to
Monsieur
the
Courier
then
,
that
Monseigneur
,
ordinarily
so
gracious
,
enraged
himself
without
cause
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
why
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
the
Courier
would
represent
to
Monseigneur
,
that
he
deceived
himself
in
suspecting
that
there
was
any
why
,
but
the
why
his
devoted
servant
had
already
had
the
honour
to
present
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
genteel
lady
---
   
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
cried
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
hear
no
more
of
the
very
genteel
lady
;
I
will
hear
no
more
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
this
family
---
my
family
---
a
family
more
genteel
than
any
lady
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
treated
this
family
with
disrespect
;
you
have
been
insolent
to
this
family
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
ruin
you
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
---
send
for
the
horses
,
pack
the
carriages
,
I
'll
not
set
foot
in
this
man
's
house
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
No
one
had
interfered
in
the
dispute
,
which
was
beyond
the
French
colloquial
powers
of
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
and
scarcely
within
the
province
of
the
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
,
however
,
now
supported
her
father
with
great
bitterness
;
declaring
,
in
her
native
tongue
,
that
it
was
quite
clear
there
was
something
special
in
this
man
's
impertinence
;
and
that
she
considered
it
important
that
he
should
be
,
by
some
means
,
forced
to
give
up
his
authority
for
making
distinctions
between
that
family
and
other
wealthy
families
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
reasons
of
his
presumption
could
be
,
she
was
at
a
loss
to
imagine
;
but
reasons
he
must
have
,
and
they
ought
to
be
torn
from
him
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
guides
,
mule
-
drivers
,
and
idlers
in
the
yard
,
had
made
themselves
parties
to
the
angry
conference
,
and
were
much
impressed
by
the
courier
's
now
bestirring
himself
to
get
the
carriages
out
.
<EOS>
With
the
aid
of
some
dozen
people
to
each
wheel
,
this
was
done
at
a
great
cost
of
noise
;
and
then
the
loading
was
proceeded
with
,
pending
the
arrival
of
the
horses
from
the
post
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
very
genteel
lady
's
English
chariot
being
already
horsed
and
at
the
inn
-
door
,
the
landlord
had
slipped
up
-
stairs
to
represent
his
hard
case
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
notified
to
the
yard
by
his
now
coming
down
the
staircase
in
attendance
on
the
gentleman
and
the
lady
,
and
by
his
pointing
out
the
offended
majesty
of
Mr
Dorrit
to
them
with
a
significant
motion
of
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
detaching
himself
from
the
lady
,
and
coming
forward
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
man
of
few
words
and
a
bad
hand
at
an
explanation
---
but
lady
here
is
extremely
anxious
that
there
should
be
no
Row
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
---
a
mother
of
mine
,
in
point
of
fact
---
wishes
me
to
say
that
she
hopes
no
Row
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
still
panting
under
his
injury
,
saluted
the
gentleman
,
and
saluted
the
lady
,
in
a
distant
,
final
,
and
invincible
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
but
really
---
here
,
old
feller
;
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
gentleman
's
way
of
appealing
to
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
on
whom
he
pounced
as
a
great
and
providential
relief
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
you
and
I
try
to
make
this
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
so
very
much
wishes
no
Row
.
"
   
<EOS>
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
led
a
little
apart
by
the
button
,
assumed
a
diplomatic
expression
of
countenance
in
replying
,
"
Why
you
must
confess
,
that
when
you
bespeak
a
lot
of
rooms
beforehand
,
and
they
belong
to
you
,
it
's
not
pleasant
to
find
other
people
in
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
other
,
"
I
know
it
is
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
admit
it
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
let
you
and
I
try
to
make
it
all
right
,
and
avoid
Row
.
 
<EOS>
The
fault
is
not
this
chap
's
at
all
,
but
my
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
Being
a
remarkably
fine
woman
with
no
bigodd
nonsense
about
her
---
well
educated
,
too
<EOS>
---
she
was
too
many
for
this
chap
.
 
<EOS>
Regularly
pocketed
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
that
's
the
case
---
"
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Assure
you
"
pon
my
soul
<EOS>
"
tis
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
"
said
the
other
gentleman
,
retiring
on
his
main
position
,
"
why
Row
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
"
said
the
lady
from
the
doorway
,
"
I
hope
you
have
explained
,
or
are
explaining
,
to
the
satisfaction
of
this
gentleman
and
his
family
that
the
civil
landlord
is
not
to
blame
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Assure
you
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Edmund
,
"
perfectly
paralysing
myself
with
trying
it
on
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
looked
steadfastly
at
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
for
some
seconds
,
and
suddenly
added
,
in
a
burst
of
confidence
,
"
Old
feller
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
all
right
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
after
all
,
"
said
the
lady
,
gracefully
advancing
a
step
or
two
towards
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
but
that
I
had
better
say
myself
,
at
once
,
that
I
assured
this
good
man
<EOS>
I
took
all
the
consequences
on
myself
of
occupying
one
of
a
stranger
's
suite
of
rooms
during
his
absence
,
for
just
as
much
(
or
as
little
)
time
as
I
could
dine
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
the
rightful
owner
would
come
back
so
soon
,
nor
had
I
any
idea
that
he
had
come
back
,
or
I
should
have
hastened
to
make
restoration
of
my
ill
-
gotten
chamber
,
and
to
have
offered
my
explanation
and
apology
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
in
saying
this
---
"
   
For
a
moment
the
lady
,
with
a
glass
at
her
eye
,
stood
transfixed
and
speechless
before
the
two
Miss
Dorrits
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
Miss
Fanny
,
in
the
foreground
of
a
grand
pictorial
composition
,
formed
by
the
family
,
the
family
equipages
,
and
the
family
servants
,
held
her
sister
tight
under
one
arm
to
detain
her
on
the
spot
,
and
with
the
other
arm
fanned
herself
with
a
distinguished
air
,
and
negligently
surveyed
the
lady
from
head
to
foot
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
,
recovering
herself
quickly
---
for
it
was
Mrs
Merdle
<EOS>
and
she
was
not
easily
dashed
---
went
on
to
add
that
she
trusted
in
saying
this
,
she
apologised
for
her
boldness
,
and
restored
this
well
-
behaved
landlord
to
the
favour
that
was
so
very
valuable
to
him
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
on
the
altar
of
whose
dignity
all
this
was
incense
,
made
a
gracious
reply
;
and
said
that
his
people
should
---
ha
---
countermand
his
horses
,
and
he
would
---
hum
<EOS>
---
overlook
what
he
had
at
first
supposed
to
be
an
affront
,
but
now
regarded
as
an
honour
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
the
bosom
bent
to
him
;
and
its
owner
,
with
a
wonderful
command
of
feature
,
addressed
a
winning
smile
of
adieu
to
the
two
sisters
,
as
young
ladies
of
fortune
in
whose
favour
she
was
much
prepossessed
,
and
whom
she
had
never
had
the
gratification
of
seeing
before
.
   
<EOS>
Not
so
,
however
,
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
This
gentleman
,
becoming
transfixed
at
the
same
moment
as
his
lady
-
mother
,
could
not
by
any
means
unfix
himself
again
,
but
stood
stiffly
staring
at
the
whole
composition
with
Miss
Fanny
in
the
Foreground
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
mother
saying
,
"
Edmund
,
we
are
quite
ready
;
will
you
give
me
your
arm
?
"
<EOS>
he
seemed
,
by
the
motion
of
his
lips
,
to
reply
with
some
remark
comprehending
the
form
of
words
in
which
his
shining
talents
found
the
most
frequent
utterance
,
but
he
relaxed
no
muscle
.
 
<EOS>
So
fixed
was
his
figure
,
that
it
would
have
been
matter
of
some
difficulty
to
bend
him
sufficiently
to
get
him
in
the
carriage
-
door
,
if
he
had
not
received
the
timely
assistance
of
a
maternal
pull
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
no
sooner
within
than
the
pad
of
the
little
window
in
the
back
of
the
chariot
disappeared
,
and
his
eye
usurped
its
place
.
 
<EOS>
There
it
remained
as
long
as
so
small
an
object
was
discernible
,
and
probably
much
longer
,
staring
(
as
though
something
inexpressibly
surprising
should
happen
to
a
codfish
)
like
an
ill
-
executed
eye
in
a
large
locket
.
   
<EOS>
This
encounter
was
so
highly
agreeable
to
Miss
Fanny
,
and
gave
her
so
much
to
think
of
with
triumph
afterwards
,
that
it
softened
her
asperities
exceedingly
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
procession
was
again
in
motion
next
day
,
she
occupied
her
place
in
it
with
a
new
gaiety
;
and
showed
such
a
flow
of
spirits
indeed
,
that
Mrs
General
looked
rather
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
glad
to
be
found
no
fault
with
,
and
to
see
that
Fanny
was
pleased
;
but
her
part
in
the
procession
was
a
musing
part
,
and
a
quiet
one
.
 
<EOS>
Sitting
opposite
her
father
in
the
travelling
-
carriage
,
and
recalling
the
old
Marshalsea
room
,
her
present
existence
was
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
she
saw
was
new
and
wonderful
,
but
it
was
not
real
;
it
seemed
to
her
as
if
those
visions
of
mountains
and
picturesque
countries
might
melt
away
at
any
moment
,
and
the
carriage
,
turning
some
abrupt
corner
,
bring
up
with
a
jolt
at
the
old
Marshalsea
gate
.
   
<EOS>
To
have
no
work
to
do
was
strange
,
but
not
half
so
strange
as
having
glided
into
a
corner
where
she
had
no
one
to
think
for
,
nothing
to
plan
and
contrive
,
no
cares
of
others
to
load
herself
with
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
as
that
was
,
it
was
far
stranger
yet
to
find
a
space
between
herself
and
her
father
,
where
others
occupied
themselves
in
taking
care
of
him
,
and
where
she
was
never
expected
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
this
was
so
much
more
unlike
her
old
experience
than
even
the
mountains
themselves
,
that
she
had
been
unable
to
resign
herself
to
it
,
and
had
tried
to
retain
her
old
place
about
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
spoken
to
her
alone
,
and
had
said
that
people
---
ha
---
people
in
an
exalted
position
,
my
dear
,
must
scrupulously
exact
respect
from
their
dependents
;
and
that
for
her
,
his
daughter
,
Miss
Amy
Dorrit
,
of
the
sole
remaining
branch
of
the
Dorrits
of
Dorsetshire
,
to
be
known
to
---
hum
---
to
occupy
herself
in
fulfilling
the
functions
of
---
ha
hum
---
a
valet
,
would
be
incompatible
with
that
respect
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
my
dear
,
he
---
ha
---
he
laid
his
parental
injunctions
upon
her
,
to
remember
that
she
was
a
lady
,
who
had
now
to
conduct

with
---
hum
---
a
proper

,
and
to
preserve
the
rank
of
a
lady
;
and
consequently
he
requested
her
to
abstain
from
doing
what
would
occasion
---
ha
---
unpleasant
and
derogatory
remarks
.
<EOS>
She
had
obeyed
without
a
murmur
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
it
had
been
brought
about
that
she
now
sat
in
her
corner
of
the
luxurious
carriage
with
her
little
patient
hands
folded
before
her
,
quite
displaced

from
the
last
point
of
the
old
standing
ground
in
life
on
which
her
feet
had
lingered
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
from
this
position
that
all
she
saw
appeared
unreal
;
the
more
surprising

scenes
,

they
resembled
the
unreality
of
her
own
inner

as
she
went
through
its
vacant

all
day

.
 
<EOS>
The
gorges
of
the
Simplon
,
its
enormous
depths
and
thundering

,
the
wonderful
road
,
the
points
of
danger
where
a
loose
wheel
or
a
faltering
horse
would
have
been
destruction
,
the
descent
into
Italy
,
the
opening
of
that
beautiful
land
as
the
rugged
mountain
-
chasm
widened
and
let
them
out
from
a
gloomy
and
dark
imprisonment
---
<EOS>
all
a
dream
---
<EOS>
only
the
old
mean
Marshalsea
<EOS>
a
reality
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
even
the
old
mean
Marshalsea
was
shaken
to
its
foundations
when
she
pictured
it
without
her
father
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
scarcely
believe
that
the
prisoners
were
still
lingering
in
the
close
yard
,
that
the
mean
rooms
were
still
every
one
tenanted
,
and
that
the
turnkey
still
stood
in
the
Lodge
letting
people
in
and
out
,
all
just
as
she
well
knew
it
to
be
.
   
<EOS>
With
a
remembrance
of
her
father
's
old
life
in
prison
hanging
about
her
like
the
burden
of
a
sorrowful
tune
,
Little
Dorrit
would
wake
from
a
dream
of
her
birth
-
place
into
a
whole
day
's
dream
.
 
<EOS>
The
painted
room
in
which
she
awoke
,
often
a
humbled
state
-
chamber
in
a
dilapidated
palace
,
would
begin
it
;
with
its
wild
red
autumnal
vine
-

overhanging
the
glass
,
its
orange
-
trees
on
the
cracked
white
terrace
outside
the
window
,
a
group
of
monks
and
peasants
in
the
little
street
below
,
misery
and
magnificence
wrestling
with
each
other
upon
every
rood
of
ground
in
the
prospect
,
no
matter
how
widely
diversified
,
and
misery
throwing
magnificence
with
the
strength
of
fate
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
would
succeed
a
labyrinth
of
bare
passages
and
pillared

,
with
the
family
procession
already
preparing
in
the
quadrangle
below
,
through
the
carriages
and
luggage
being
brought
together
by
the
servants
for
the
day
's
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Then
breakfast
in
another
painted
chamber
,
damp
-
stained
and
of
desolate

;
and
then
the
departure
,
which
,
to
her
timidity
and
sense
of
not
being
grand
enough
for
her
place
in
the
ceremonies
,
was
always
an
uneasy
thing
.
 
<EOS>
For
then
the
courier
(
who
himself
would
have
been
a
foreign
gentleman
of
high
mark
in
the
Marshalsea
)
would
present

to

all

;
and
then

father
's
valet
would

;
and
then
Fanny
's
maid
,
and
her
own
maid
(
who
was

weight
on

Dorrit
's
mind
---
absolutely
made
her
cry
at
first
<EOS>
,
she
knew

little
what

do

her
)
,

in

;
and
then
her
brother
's
man
would
complete

master
's
