;
and
then
her
father
would
give
his
arm
to
Mrs
General
,
and
her
uncle
would
give
his
to
her
,
and
,
escorted
by
the
landlord
and
Inn
servants
,
they
would
swoop
down
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
a
crowd
would
be
collected
to
see
them
enter
their
carriages
,
which
,
amidst
much
bowing
,
and
begging
,
and
prancing
,
and
lashing
,
and
clattering
,
they
would
do
;
and
so
they
would
be
driven
madly
through
narrow
unsavoury
streets
,
and
jerked
out
at
the
town
gate
.
   
<EOS>
Among
the
day
's
unrealities
would
be
roads
where
the
bright
red
vines
were
looped
and
garlanded
together
on
trees
for
many
miles
;
woods
of
olives
;
white
villages
and
towns
on
hill
-
sides
,
lovely
without
,
but
frightful
in
their
dirt
and
poverty
within
;
crosses
by
the
way
;
deep
blue
lakes
with
fairy
islands
,
and
clustering
boats
with
awnings
of
bright
colours
and
sails
of
beautiful
forms
;
vast
piles
of
building
mouldering
to
dust
;
hanging
-
gardens
where
the
weeds
had
grown
so
strong
that
their
stems
,
like
wedges
driven
home
,
had
split
the
arch
and
rent
the
wall
;
stone
-
terraced
lanes
,
with
the
lizards
running
into
and
out
of
every
chink
;
beggars
of
all
sorts
everywhere
:
pitiful
,
picturesque
,
hungry
,
merry
;
children
beggars
and
aged
beggars
.
 
<EOS>
Often
at
posting
-
houses
and
other
halting
places
,
these
miserable
creatures
would
appear
to
her
the
only
realities
of
the
day
;
and
many
a
time
,
when
the
money
she
had
brought
to
give
them
was
all
given
away
,
she
would
sit
with
her
folded
hands
,
thoughtfully
looking
after
some
diminutive
girl
leading
her
grey
father
,
as
if
the
sight
reminded
her
of
something
in
the
days
that
were
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Again
,
there
would
be
places
where
they
stayed
the
week
together
in
splendid
rooms
,
had
banquets
every
day
,
rode
out
among
heaps
of
wonders
,
walked
through
miles
of
palaces
,
and
rested
in
dark
corners
of
great
churches
;
where
there
were
winking
lamps
of
gold
and
silver
among
pillars
and
arches
,
kneeling
figures
dotted
about
at
confessionals
and
on
the
pavements
;
where
there
was
the
mist
and
scent
of
incense
;
where
there
were
pictures
,
fantastic
images
,
gaudy
altars
,
great
heights
and
distances
,
all
softly
lighted
through
stained
glass
,
and
the
massive
curtains
that
hung
in
the
doorways
.
 
<EOS>
From
these
cities
they
would
go
on
again
,
by
the
roads
of
vines
and
olives
,
through
squalid
villages
,
where
there
was
not
a
hovel
without
a
gap
in
its
filthy
walls
,
not
a
window
with
a
whole
inch
of
glass
or
paper
;
where
there
seemed
to
be
nothing
to
support
life
,
nothing
to
eat
,
nothing
to
make
,
nothing
to
grow
,
nothing
to
hope
,
nothing
to
do
but
die
.
   
<EOS>
Again
they
would
come
to
whole
towns
of
palaces
,
whose
proper
inmates
were
all
banished
,
and
which
were
all
changed
into
barracks
:
<EOS>
troops
of
idle
soldiers
leaning
out
of
the
state
windows
,
where
their
accoutrements
hung
drying
on
the
marble
architecture
,
and
showing
to
the
mind
like
hosts
of
rats
who
were
(
happily
)
eating
away
the
props
of
the
edifices
that
supported
them
,
and
must
soon
,
with
them
,
be
smashed
on
the
heads
of
the
other
swarms
of
soldiers
and
the
swarms
of
priests
,
and
the
swarms
of
spies
,
who
were
all
the
ill
-
looking
population
left
to
be
ruined
,
in
the
streets
below
.
   
<EOS>
Through
such
scenes
,
the
family
procession
moved
on
to
Venice
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
it
dispersed
for
a
time
,
as
they
were
to
live
in
Venice
some
few
months
in
a
palace
(
itself
six
times
as
big
as
the
whole
Marshalsea
)
on
the
Grand
Canal
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
crowning
unreality
,
where
all
the
streets
were
paved
with
water
,
and
where
the
deathlike
stillness
of
the
days
and
nights
was
broken
by
no
sound
but
the
softened
ringing
of
church
-
bells
,
the
rippling
of
the
current
,
and
the
cry
of
the
gondoliers
turning
the
corners
of
the
flowing
streets
,
Little
Dorrit
,
quite
lost
by
her
task
being
done
,
sat
down
to
muse
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
began
a
gay
life
,
went
here
and
there
,
and
turned
night
into
day
;
but
she
was
timid
of
joining
in
their
gaieties
,
and
only
asked
leave
to
be
left
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
would
step
into
one
of
the
gondolas
that
were
always
kept
in
waiting
,
moored
to
painted
posts
at
the
door
---
when
she
could
escape
from
the
attendance
of
that
oppressive
maid
,
who
was
her
mistress
,
and
a
very
hard
one
---
and
would
be
taken
all
over
the
strange
city
.
 
<EOS>
Social
people
in
other
gondolas
began
to
ask
each
other
who
the
little
solitary
girl
was
whom
they
passed
,
sitting
in
her
boat
with
folded
hands
,
looking
so
pensively
and
wonderingly
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
Never
thinking
that
it
would
be
worth
anybody
's
while
to
notice
her
or
her
doings
,
Little
Dorrit
,
in
her
quiet
,
scared
,
lost
manner
,
went
about
the
city
none
the
less
.
   
<EOS>
But
her
favourite
station
was
the
balcony
of
her
own
room
,
overhanging
the
canal
,
with
other
balconies
below
,
and
none
above
.
<EOS>
It
was
of
massive
stone
darkened
by
ages
,
built
in
a
wild
fancy
which
came
from
the
East
to
that
collection
of
wild
fancies
;
and
Little
Dorrit
was
little
indeed
,
leaning
on
the
broad
-
cushioned
ledge
,
and
looking
over
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
liked
no
place
of
an
evening
half
so
well
,
she
soon
began
to
be
watched
for
,
and
many
eyes
in
passing
gondolas
were
raised
,
and
many
people
said
,
There
was
the
little
figure
of
the
English
girl
who
was
always
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Such
people
were
not
realities
to
the
little
figure
of
the
English
girl
;
such
people
were
all
unknown
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
watch
the
sunset
,
in
its
long
low
lines
of
purple
and
red
,
and
its
burning
flush
high
up
into
the
sky
:
so
glowing
on
the
buildings
,
and
so
lightening
their
structure
,
that
it
made
them
look
as
if
their
strong
walls
were
transparent
,
and
they
shone
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
watch
those
glories
expire
;
and
then
,
after
looking
at
the
black
gondolas
underneath
,
taking
guests
to
music
and
dancing
,
would
raise
her
eyes
to
the
shining
stars
.
 
<EOS>
Was
there
no
party
of
her
own
,
in
other
times
,
on
which
the
stars
had
shone
?
 
<EOS>
To
think
of
that
old
gate
now
!
 
<EOS>
She
would
think
of
that
old
gate
,
and
of
herself
sitting
at
it
in
the
dead
of
the
night
,
pillowing
Maggy
's
head
;
and
of
other
places
and
of
other
scenes
associated
with
those
different
times
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
she
would
lean
upon
her
balcony
,
and
look
over
at
the
water
,
as
though
they
all
lay
underneath
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
got
to
that
,
she
would
musingly
watch
its
running
,
as
if
,
in
the
general
vision
,
it
might
run
dry
,
and
show
her
the
prison
again
,
and
herself
,
and
the
old
room
,
and
the
old
inmates
,
and
the
old
visitors
:
all
lasting
realities
that
had
never
changed
.
    
Chapter
04
.
<EOS>
A
Letter
from
Little
Dorrit
 
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
   
<EOS>
I
write
to
you
from
my
own
room
at
Venice
,
thinking
you
will
be
glad
to
hear
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
you
can
not
be
so
glad
to
hear
from
me
as
I
am
to
write
to
you
;
for
everything
about
you
is
as
you
have
been
accustomed
to
see
it
,
and
you
miss
nothing
---
unless
it
should
be
me
,
which
can
only
be
for
a
very
little
while
together
and
very
seldom
---
while
everything
in
my
life
is
so
strange
,
and
I
miss
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
were
in
Switzerland
,
which
appears
to
have
been
years
ago
,
though
it
was
only
weeks
,
I
met
young
Mrs
Gowan
,
who
was
on
a
mountain
excursion
like
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
She
told
me
she
was
very
well
and
very
happy
.
 
<EOS>
She
sent
you
the
message
,
by
me
,
that
she
thanked
you
affectionately
and
would
never
forget
you
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
quite
confiding
with
me
,
and
I
loved
her
almost
as
soon
as
I
spoke
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
is
nothing
singular
in
that
;
who
could
help
loving
so
beautiful
and
winning
a
creature
!
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
wonder
at
any
one
loving
her
.
 
<EOS>
No
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
It
will
not
make
you
uneasy
on
Mrs
Gowan
's
account
<EOS>
,
I
hope
---
<EOS>
for
I
remember
that
you
said
you
had
the
interest
of
a
true
friend
in
her
---
if
I
tell
you
that
I
wish
she
could
have
married
some
one
better
suited
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
seems
fond
of
her
,
and
of
course
she
is
very
fond
of
him
,
but
I
thought
he
was
not
earnest
enough
---
I
do
n't
mean
in
that
respect
---
I
mean
in
anything
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
keep
it
out
of
my
mind
that
if
I
was
Mrs
Gowan
(
what
a
change
that
would
be
,
and
how
I
must
alter
to
become
like
her
!
)
<EOS>
I
should
feel
that
I
was
rather
lonely
and
lost
,
for
the
want
of
some
one
who
was
steadfast
and
firm
in
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
I
even
thought
she
felt
this
want
a
little
,
almost
without
knowing
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
mind
you
are
not
made
uneasy
by
this
,
for
she
was
"
very
well
and
very
happy
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
looked
most
beautiful
.
   
<EOS>
I
expect
to
meet
her
again
before
long
,
and
indeed
have
been
expecting
for
some
days
past
to
see
her
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
ever
be
as
good
a
friend
to
her
as
I
can
for
your
sake
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
you
think
little
of
having
been
a
friend
to
me
when
I
had
no
other
(
not
that
I
have
any
other
now
,
for
I
have
made
no
new
friends
)
,
but
<EOS>
I
think
much
of
it
,
and
I
never
can
forget
it
.
   
<EOS>
I
wish
I
knew
---
but
it
is
best
for
no
one
to
write
to
me
---
how
Mr
and
Mrs
Plornish
prosper
in
the
business
which
my
dear
father
bought
for
them
,
and
that
old
Mr
Nandy
lives
happily
with
them
and
his
two
grandchildren
,
and
sings
all
his
songs
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
quite
keep
back
the
tears
from
my
eyes
when
I
think
of
my
poor
Maggy
,
and
of
the
blank
<EOS>
she
must
have
felt
at
first
,
however
kind
they
all
are
to
her
,
without
her
Little
Mother
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
go
and
tell
her
,
as
a
strict
secret
,
with
my
love
,
that
she
never
can
have
regretted
our
separation
more
than
I
have
regretted
it
?
 
<EOS>
And
will
you
tell
them
all
that
I
have
thought
of
them
every
day
,
and
that
my
heart
is
faithful
to
them
everywhere
?
 
<EOS>
O
,
if
you
could
know
how
faithful
,
you
would
almost
pity
me
for
being
so
far
away
and
being
so
grand
!
   
<EOS>
You
will
be
glad
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
to
know
that
my
dear
father
is
very
well
in
health
,
and
that
all
these
changes
are
highly
beneficial
to
him
,
and
that
he
is
very
different
indeed
from
what
he
used
to
be
when
you
used
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
improvement
in
my
uncle
too
,
I
think
,
though
he
never
complained
of
old
,
and
never
exults
now
.
<EOS>
Fanny
is
very
graceful
,
quick
,
and
clever
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
natural
to
her
to
be
a
lady
;
she
has
adapted
herself
to
our
new
fortunes
with
wonderful
ease
.
   
<EOS>
This
reminds
me
that
I
have
not
been
able
to
do
so
,
and
that
I
sometimes
almost
despair
of
ever
being
able
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
that
I
can
not
learn
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
is
always
with
us
,
and
we
speak
French
and
speak
Italian
,
and
she
takes
pains
to
form
us
in
many
ways
.
<EOS>
When
I
say
we
speak
French
and
Italian
,
I
mean
they
do
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
me
,
I
am
so
slow
that
I
scarcely
get
on
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
begin
to
plan
,
and
think
,
and
try
,
all
my
planning
,
thinking
,
and
trying
go
in
old
directions
,
and
I
begin
to
feel
careful
again
about
the
expenses
of
the
day
,
and
about
my
dear
father
,
and
about
my
work
,
and
then
I
remember
with
a
start
that
there
are
no
such
cares
left
,
and
that
in
itself
is
so
new
and
improbable
that
it
sets
me
wandering
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
the
courage
to
mention
this
to
any
one
but
you
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
the
same
with
all
these
new
countries
and
wonderful
sights
.
<EOS>
They
are
very
beautiful
,
and
they
astonish
me
,
but
I
am
not
collected
enough
---
not
familiar
enough
with
myself
,
if
you
can
quite
understand
what
I
mean
---
to
have
all
the
pleasure
in
them
that
I
might
have
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
knew
before
them
,
blends
with
them
,
too
,
so
curiously
.
 
<EOS>
For
instance
,
when
we
were
among
the
mountains
,
I
often
felt
(
I
hesitate
to
tell
such
an
idle
thing
,
<EOS>
dear
Mr
Clennam
,
even
to
you
)
as
if
the
Marshalsea
must
be
behind
that
great
rock
;
or
as
if
Mrs
Clennam
's
room
where
I
have
worked
so
many
days
,
and
where
I
first
saw
you
,
must
be
just
beyond
that
snow
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
one
night
when
I
came
with
Maggy
to
your
lodging
in
Covent
Garden
?
<EOS>
That
room
I
have
often
and
often
fancied
I
have
seen
before
me
,
travelling
along
for
miles
by
the
side
of
our
carriage
,
when
I
have
looked
out
of
the
carriage
-
window
after
dark
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
shut
out
that
night
,
and
sat
at
the
iron
gate
,
and
walked
about
till
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
often
look
up
at
the
stars
,
even
from
the
balcony
of
this
room
,
and
believe
that
I
am
in
the
street
again
,
shut
out
with
Maggy
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
same
with
people
that
I
left
in
England
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
go
about
here
in
a
gondola
,
I
surprise
myself
looking
into
other
gondolas
as
if
I
hoped
to
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
overcome
me
with
joy
to
see
them
,
but
I
do
n't
think
it
would
surprise
me
much
,
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
fanciful
times
,
I
fancy
that
they
might
be
anywhere
;
and
I
almost
expect
to
see
their
dear
faces
on
the
bridges
or
the
quays
.
   
<EOS>
Another
difficulty
that
I
have
will
seem
very
strange
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
seem
very
strange
to
any
one
but
me
,
and
does
even
to
me
:
I
often
feel
the
old
sad
pity
for
---
I
need
not
write
the
word
---
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Changed
as
he
is
,
and
inexpressibly
blest
and
thankful
as
I
always
am
to
know
it
,
the
old
sorrowful
feeling
of
compassion
comes
upon
me
sometimes
with
such
strength
that
I
want
to
put
my
arms
<EOS>
round
his
neck
,
tell
him
how
I
love
him
,
and
cry
a
little
on
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
glad
after
that
,
and
proud
and
happy
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
that
I
must
not
do
this
;
that
he
would
not
like
it
,
that
Fanny
would
be
angry
,
that
Mrs
General
would
be
amazed
;
and
so
I
quiet
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
in
doing
so
,
I
struggle
with
the
feeling
that
I
have
come
to
be
at
a
distance
from
him
;
and
that
even
in
the
midst
of
all
the
servants
and
attendants
,
he
is
deserted
,
and
in
want
of
me
.
   
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
I
have
written
a
great
deal
about
myself
,
but
I
must
write
a
little
more
still
,
or
what
I
wanted
most
of
all
to
say
in
this
weak
letter
would
be
left
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
these
foolish
thoughts
of
mine
,
which
I
have
been
so
hardy
as
to
confess
to
you
because
I
know
you
will
understand
me
if
anybody
can
,
and
will
make
more
allowance
for
me
than
anybody
else
<EOS>
would
if
you
can
not
---
in
all
these
thoughts
,
there
is
one
thought
scarcely
ever
---
never
---
out
of
my
memory
,
and
that
is
that
I
hope
you
sometimes
,
in
a
quiet
moment
,
have
a
thought
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
tell
you
that
as
to
this
,
I
have
felt
,
ever
since
I
have
been
away
,
an
anxiety
which
I
am
very
anxious
to
relieve
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
afraid
that
you
may
think
of
me
in
a
new
light
,
or
a
new
character
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
do
that
,
I
could
not
bear
that
---
it
would
make
me
more
unhappy
than
you
can
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
break
my
heart
to
believe
that
you
thought
of
me
in
any
way
that
would
make
me
stranger
to
you
than
I
was
when
you
were
so
good
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
pray
and
entreat
of
you
is
,
that
you
will
never
think
of
me
as
the
daughter
of
a
rich
person
;
that
you
will
never
think
of
me
as
dressing
any
better
,
or
living
any
better
,
than
when
you
first
knew
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
will
remember
me
only
as
the
little
shabby
girl
you
protected
with
so
much
tenderness
,
from
whose
threadbare
dress
you
have
kept
away
the
rain
,
and
whose
wet
feet
you
have
dried
at
your
fire
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
will
think
of
me
(
when
you
think
of
me
at
all
)
,
and
of
my
true
affection
and
devoted
gratitude
,
always
without
change
,
as
of
your
poor
child
,
               
LITTLE
DORRIT
.
   
<EOS>
PS
.
<EOS>
---
Particularly
remember
that
you
are
not
to
be
uneasy
about
Mrs
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
Her
words
were
,
"
Very
well
and
very
happy
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
looked
most
beautiful
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
05
.
<EOS>
Something
Wrong
<EOS>
Somewhere
 
<EOS>
The
family
had
been
a
month
or
two
at
Venice
,
when
Mr
Dorrit
,
who
was
much
among
Counts
and
Marquises
,
and
had
but
scant
leisure
,
set
an
hour
of
one
day
apart
,
beforehand
,
for
the
purpose
of
holding
some
conference
with
Mrs
General
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
he
had
reserved
in
his
mind
arriving
,
he
sent
Mr
Tinkler
,
his
valet
,
to
Mrs
General
's
apartment
(
which
would
have
absorbed
about
a
third
of
the
area
of
the
Marshalsea
)
,
to
present
his
compliments
to
that
lady
,
and
represent
him
as
desiring
the
favour
of
an
interview
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
that
period
of
the
forenoon
when
the
various
members
of
the
family
had
coffee
in
their
own
chambers
,
some
couple
of
hours
before
assembling
at
breakfast
in
a
faded
hall
which
had
once
been
sumptuous
,
but
was
now
the
prey
of
watery
vapours
and
a
settled
melancholy
,
Mrs
General
was
accessible
to
the
valet
.
 
<EOS>
That
envoy
found
her
on
a
little
square
of
carpet
,
so
extremely
diminutive
in
reference
to
the
size
of
her
stone
and
marble
floor
that
she
looked
as
if
she
might
have
had
it
spread
for
the
trying
on
of
a
ready
-
made
pair
of
shoes
;
or
as
if
she
had
come
into
possession
of
the
enchanted
piece
of
carpet
,
bought
for
forty
purses
by
one
of
the
three
princes
in
the
Arabian
Nights
,
and
had
that
moment
been
transported
on
it
,
at
a
wish
,
into
a
palatial
saloon
with
which
it
had
no
connection
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
,
replying
to
the
envoy
,
as
she
set
down
her
empty
coffee
-
cup
,
that
she
was
willing
at
once
to
proceed
to
Mr
Dorrit
's
apartment
,
and
spare
him
the
trouble
of
coming
to
her
(
which
,
in
his
gallantry
,
he
had
proposed
)
,
the
envoy
threw
open
the
door
,
and
escorted
Mrs
General
to
the
presence
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
a
walk
,
by
mysterious
staircases
and
corridors
,
from
Mrs
General
's
apartment
,
 
---
hoodwinked
by
a
narrow
side
street
with
a
low
gloomy
bridge
in
it
,
and
dungeon
-
like
opposite
tenements
,
their
walls
besmeared
with
a
thousand
downward
stains
and
streaks
,
as
if
every
crazy
aperture
in
them
had
been
weeping
tears
of
rust
into
the
Adriatic
for
centuries
---
to
Mr
Dorrit
's
apartment
:
with
a
whole
English
house
-
front
of
window
,
a
prospect
of
beautiful
church
-
domes
rising
into
the
blue
sky
sheer
out
of
the
water
which
reflected
them
,
and
a
hushed
murmur
of
the
Grand
Canal
laving
the
doorways
below
,
where
his
gondolas
and
gondoliers
attended
his
pleasure
,
drowsily
swinging
in
a
little
forest
of
piles
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
in
a
resplendent
dressing
-
gown
and
cap
---
the
dormant
grub
that
had
so
long
bided
its
time
among
the
Collegians
had
burst
into
a
rare
butterfly
---
rose
to
receive
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
A
chair
to
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
An
easier
chair
<EOS>
,
sir
;
what
are
you
doing
,
what
are
you
about
,
what
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
leave
us
!
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
General
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
I
took
the
liberty
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
"
Mrs
General
interposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
quite
at
your
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
had
my
coffee
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
---
I
took
the
liberty
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
again
,
with
the
magnificent
placidity
of
one
who
was
above
correction
,
"
to
solicit
the
favour
of
a
little
private
conversation
with
you
,
because
I
feel
rather
worried
respecting
my
---
ha
---
my
younger
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
have
observed
a
great
difference
of
temperament
,
madam
,
between
my
two
daughters
?
"
   
<EOS>
Said
Mrs
General
in
response
,
crossing
her
gloved
hands
(
she
was
never
without
gloves
,
and
they
never
creased
and
always
fitted
)
,
"
There
is
a
great
difference
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
to
be
favoured
with
your
view
of
it
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
a
deference
not
incompatible
with
majestic
serenity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
"
has
force
of
character
and
self
-
reliance
.
<EOS>
Amy
,
none
.
"
   
<EOS>
None
?
 
<EOS>
O
Mrs
General
,
ask
the
Marshalsea
stones
and
bars
.
 
<EOS>
O
Mrs
General
,
ask
the
milliner
who
taught
her
to
work
,
and
the
dancing
-
master
who
taught
her
sister
to
dance
.
 
<EOS>
O
Mrs
General
,
Mrs
General
,
ask
me
,
her
father
,
<EOS>
what
I
owe
her
;
and
hear
my
testimony
touching
the
life
of
this
slighted
little
creature
from
her
childhood
up
!
   
<EOS>
No
such
adjuration
entered
Mr.
 
Dorrit
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Mrs
General
,
seated
in
her
usual
erect
attitude
on
her
coach
-
box
behind
the
proprieties
,
and
he
said
in
a
thoughtful
manner
,
"
True
,
madam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
"
be
understood
to
say
,
observe
,
that
there
is
nothing
to
improve
in
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
is
material
there
---
<EOS>
perhaps
,
indeed
,
a
little
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
be
kind
enough
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
to
be
---
ha
---
more
explicit
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
quite
understand
my
elder
daughter
's
having
---
<EOS>
hum
---
too
much
material
.
 
<EOS>
What
material
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
"
at
present
forms
too
many
opinions
.
   
<EOS>
Perfect
breeding
forms
none
,
and
is
never
demonstrative
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Lest
he
himself
should
be
found
deficient
in
perfect
breeding
,
Mr
Dorrit
hastened
to
reply
,
"
Unquestionably
,
madam
,
you
are
right
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs
General
returned
,
in
her
emotionless
and
expressionless
manner
,
"
I
believe
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
aware
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
that
my
daughters
had
the
misfortune
to
lose
their
lamented
mother
when
they
were
very
young
;
and
that
,
in
consequence
of
my
not
having
been
until
lately
the
recognised
heir
to
my
property
,
they
have
lived
with
me
as
a
comparatively
poor
,
though
always
proud
,
gentleman
,
in
---
ha
hum
---
retirement
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
"
lose
sight
of
the
circumstance
.
"
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
pursued
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
of
my
daughter
Fanny
,
under
her
present
guidance
and
with
such
an
example
constantly
before
her
---
"
   
<EOS>
(
Mrs
General
shut
her
eyes
.
)
    
<EOS>
---
"
I
have
no
misgivings
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
adaptability
of
character
in
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
younger
daughter
,
Mrs
General
,
rather
worries
and
vexes
my
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
inform
you
that
she
has
always
been
my
favourite
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
accounting
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
"
for
these
partialities
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
---
no
,
"
assented
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
madam
,
I
am
troubled
by
noticing
that
Amy
is
not
,
so
to
speak
,
one
of
ourselves
.
 
<EOS>
She
does
not
Care
to
go
about
with
us
;
she
is
lost
in
the
society
we
have
here
;
our
tastes
are
evidently
not
her
tastes
.
 
<EOS>
Which
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
summing
up
with
judicial
gravity
,
"
is
to
say
,
in
other
words
,
that
there
is
something
wrong
in
---
ha
---
Amy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
we
incline
to
the
supposition
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
with
a
little
touch
of
varnish
,
"
that
something
is
referable
to
the
novelty
of
the
position
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
madam
,
"
observed
Mr
Dorrit
,
rather
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
daughter
of
a
gentleman
,
though
---
ha
---
himself
at
one
time
comparatively
far
from
affluent
---
comparatively
---
and
herself
reared
in
---
hum
---
retirement
,
need
not
of
necessity
find
this
position
so
very
novel
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
"
true
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
I
took
the
liberty
"
<EOS>
(
he
laid
an
emphasis
on
the
phrase
and
repeated
it
,
as
though
he
stipulated
,
with
urbane
firmness
,
that
he
must
not
be
contradicted
again
)
<EOS>
,
"
I
took
the
liberty
of
requesting
this
interview
,
in
order
that
I
might
mention
the
topic
to
you
,
and
inquire
how
you
would
advise
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
"
I
have
conversed
with
Amy
several
times
since
we
have
been
residing
here
,
on
the
general
subject
of
the
formation
of
a
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
expressed
herself
to
me
as
wondering
exceedingly
at
Venice
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
mentioned
to
her
that
it
is
better
not
to
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
pointed
out
to
her
that
the
celebrated
Mr
Eustace
,
the
classical
tourist
,
did
not
think
much
of
it
;
and
that
he
compared
the
Rialto
,
greatly
to
its
disadvantage
,
with
Westminster
and
Blackfriars
Bridges
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
not
add
,
after
what
you
have
said
,
that
I
have
not
yet
found
my
arguments
successful
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
me
the
honour
to
ask
me
what
to
advise
.
 
<EOS>
It
always
appears
to
me
(
if
this
should
prove
to
be
a
baseless
assumption
,
I
shall
be
pardoned
)
,
that
Mr
Dorrit
has
been
accustomed
to
exercise
influence
over
the
minds
of
others
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
---
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
I
have
been
at
the
head
of
---
ha
of
a
considerable
community
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
right
in
supposing
that
I
am
not
unaccustomed
to
---
an
influential
position
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
"
to
be
so
corroborated
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
therefore
the
more
confidently
recommend
that
Mr
Dorrit
should
speak
to
Amy
himself
,
and
make
his
observations
and
wishes
known
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Being
his
favourite
,
besides
,
and
no
doubt
attached
to
him
,
she
is
all
the
more
likely
to
yield
to
his
influence
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
anticipated
your
suggestion
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
<EOS>
but
---
ha
---
was
not
sure
that
I
might
---
hum
---
not
encroach
on
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
my
province
,
Mr
Dorrit
?
"
said
Mrs
General
,
graciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
mention
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
with
your
leave
,
madam
,
"
resumed
Mr
Dorrit
,
ringing
his
little
bell
to
summon
his
valet
,
"
I
will
send
for
her
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
Mr
Dorrit
wish
me
to
remain
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
if
you
have
no
other
engagement
,
you
would
not
object
for
a
minute
or
two
---
"
   
"
Not
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
Tinkler
the
valet
was
instructed
to
find
Miss
Amy
's
maid
,
and
to
request
that
subordinate
to
inform
Miss
Amy
that
Mr
Dorrit
wished
to
see
her
in
his
own
room
.
 
<EOS>
In
delivering
this
charge
to
Tinkler
,
Mr
Dorrit
looked
severely
at
him
,
and
also
kept
a
jealous
eye
upon
him
until
he
went
out
at
the
door
,
mistrusting
that
he
might
have
something
in
his
mind
prejudicial
to
the
family
dignity
;
that
he
might
have
even
got
wind
of
some
Collegiate
joke
before
he
came
into
the
service
,
and
might
be
derisively
reviving
its
remembrance
at
the
present
moment
.
 
<EOS>
If
Tinkler
had
happened
to
smile
,
however
faintly
and
innocently
,
nothing
would
have
persuaded
Mr
Dorrit
,
to
the
hour
of
his
death
,
but
that
this
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
As
Tinkler
happened
,
however
,
very
fortunately
for
himself
,
to
be
of
a
serious
and
composed
countenance
,
he
escaped
the
secret
danger
that
threatened
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
on
his
return
---
when
Mr
Dorrit
eyed
him
again
---
he
announced
Miss
Amy
as
if
she
had
come
to
a
funeral
,
he
left
a
vague
impression
on
Mr
Dorrit
's
mind
that
he
was
a
well
-
conducted
young
fellow
,
who
had
been
brought
up
in
the
study
of
his
Catechism
by
a
widowed
mother
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
you
have
just
now
been
the
subject
of
some
conversation
between
myself
and
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
We
agree
that
you
scarcely
seem
at
home
here
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
---
how
is
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
father
,
I
require
a
little
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
is
a
preferable
mode
of
address
,
"
observed
Mrs
General
.
<EOS>
"
Father
is
rather
vulgar
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
Papa
,
besides
,
gives
a
pretty
form
to
the
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Papa
,
potatoes
,
poultry
,
prunes
,
and
prism
are
all
very
good
words
for
the
lips
:
especially
prunes
and
prism
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
find
it
serviceable
,
in
the
formation
of
a
demeanour
,
if
you
sometimes
say
to
yourself
in
company
---
on
entering
a
room
,
for
instance
---
Papa
,
potatoes
,
poultry
,
prunes
and
prism
,
prunes
and
prism
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
my
child
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
attend
to
the
---
hum
---
precepts
of
Mrs
General
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Little
Dorrit
,
with
a
rather
forlorn
glance
at
that
eminent
varnisher
,
promised
to
try
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
say
,
Amy
,
"
pursued
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
that
you
think
you
require
time
.
 
<EOS>
Time
for
what
?
"
   
<EOS>
Another
pause
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
become
accustomed
to
the
novelty
of
my
life
,
was
all
I
meant
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
with
her
loving
eyes
upon
her
father
;
whom
she
had
very
nearly
addressed
as
poultry
,
if
not
prunes
and
prism
too
,
in
her
desire
to
submit
herself
to
Mrs
General
and
please
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
frowned
,
and
looked
anything
but
pleased
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
he
returned
,
"
it
appears
to
me
,
I
must
say
,
that
you
have
had
abundance
of
time
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
---
you
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
disappoint
me
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
has
conquered
any
such
little
difficulties
,
and
---
hum
---
why
not
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
do
better
soon
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
returned
her
father
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
ha
---
I
most
devoutly
hope
so
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
for
you
,
in
order
that
I
might
say
---
hum
---
impressively
say
,
in
the
presence
of
Mrs
General
,
to
whom
we
are
all
so

for
obligingly

present

,
on
---
ha
---
on
this

,
"
Mrs
General
shut

,
"
that
I
---
ha
hum
---
am
not

you
.
 
<EOS>
You
make
Mrs
General
's
a

.
<EOS>
You
---
ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
You

(

Mrs
General
)
<EOS>
been

;
I

---
hum
---

;

I

---
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
ha
---
I

,
that

better
to
 
---
hum
---
circumstances
,
and
dutifully

what
becomes
your
---
your

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
even
a

usual
,
being
excited

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

---
ha
---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
That

,
on
being
again

;
then
,

,

:
"
<EOS>
If
Miss
Amy
Dorrit
will
direct

to
,
and
will
accept
of
my
poor

in
,
the
formation

a
surface
,
Mr.
Dorrit
will

.
 
<EOS>
May

take

remarking
,
as
an
instance

,
that
it

to

vagrants

the

I
have
seen
bestowed
upon
them
by
a
very
dear
young
friend
of

?
<EOS>
They
should
not
be
looked
at
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
disagreeable
should

at
.
 
<EOS>
Apart
from
such
a
habit
standing
in
the
way
of
that

of
surface
which
is
so
expressive
of
good

,
it
hardly

with
refinement
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
A
truly
refined
mind
will
seem
to
be
ignorant
of
the
existence
of
anything
that
is
not
perfectly
proper
,
placid
,
and
pleasant
.
"
<EOS>
Having
delivered
this

,
Mrs
General
made
a
sweeping
obeisance
,
and
retired
with
an
expression
of
mouth
indicative
of
Prunes
and
Prism
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
whether
speaking
or
silent
,
had
preserved
her
quiet
earnestness
and
her
loving
look
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
not
been
clouded
,
except
for
a
passing
moment
,
until
now
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
that
she
was
left
alone
with
him
the
fingers
of
her
lightly
folded
hands
were
agitated
,
and
there
was
repressed
emotion
in
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
Not
for
herself
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
feel
a
little
wounded
,
but
her
care
was
not
for
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Her
thoughts
still
turned
,
as
they
always
had
turned
,
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
A
faint
misgiving
,
which
had
hung
about
her
since
their
accession
to
fortune
,
that
even
now
she
could
never
see
him
as
he
used
to
be
before
the
prison
days
,
had
gradually
begun
to
assume
form
in
her

.
 
<EOS>
She
felt
that
,
in
what
he
had
just
now
said
to
her
and
in
his
whole
bearing
towards
her
,
there
was
the
well

shadow
of
the
Marshalsea
wall
.
 
<EOS>
It
took
a
new
shape
,
but
it
was
the
old
sad
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
She
began
with
sorrowful
unwillingness
to
acknowledge
to
herself
that
she
was
not
strong
enough
to
keep
off
the
fear
that
no
space
in
the
life
of
man
could
overcome
that
quarter
of
a
century
behind
the
prison
bars
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
blame
to
bestow
upon
him
,
therefore
:
nothing
to
reproach
him
with
,
no
emotions
in
her
faithful

but
great
compassion
and
unbounded

.
   
<EOS>
This
is
why
it
was
,
that
,
even
as
he
sat
before
her
on
his
sofa
,
in
the

of
a
bright
Italian

,
the

city

and
the

of
an
old

,
she
saw
him
at
the
moment
in
the
long
-

of
his

,
and
wished
to
take
her

,
and
comfort

,
and
be
again
full
of
confidence
with

,
and

to

.
 
<EOS>
If
he
divined
what
was
in
her

,
his
own
were
not
in

with
it
.
   
<EOS>
After
some
uneasy
moving
in
his
seat
,
he
got
up
and
walked
about
,
looking
very
much

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anything
else
you
wish

me
,
dear
father
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
 
Nothing
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry

have
not

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to

,
more

,
to

as
you
wish
to
what
surrounds
me
 
---
<EOS>
for

I
have

all
along
,
though
I
have
failed
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
---
ha
---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hurt

,

!
 
<EOS>
I
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

a
---
hum
---
a

,
"

,

,
"

,

I

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>
You

---
hum
---
you

---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
The

"

"
 
<EOS>
But

herself
.
   
<EOS>
There

in

touch

to

that
she
had
not
foreseen
,
or

.
 
<EOS>
He

to

in

,

,
which

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

---
ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
hum
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
ha
hum
---

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
I

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

---
ha
---

<EOS>

---

---

same
and

?
"
   
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
"
Accordingly
,

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

---
hum

.
   
<EOS>
You

ca

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

lady
 
---
ha
---
Mrs
General
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
Is

that

should

for

?
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding

,
he
continued
to
defend

,
without
any

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
hum
<EOS>
---
I
necessarily

that

within

,

I
---
ha
---
should
render

,

,
what
I

.
 
<EOS>
Am
I

?
 
<EOS>
Do

complain

own

?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Principally
for
---
ha
hum
---
your
sake
,
Amy
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
last

plainly
appeared
,
from
his

of

,
to
have
just

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
I
was
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
---
ha
---
am
determined
to
be
,
whatever
is
advanced
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

that
my
daughter
,

---
hum
---
lap

,
should

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
she
should
 
<EOS>
---
ha
---
systematically

what
the
rest
of
us
blot

;
and
seem
---
<EOS>
hum
<EOS>
---
I
had

said
positively

---
to

to
wealthy

that
she

born

---
ha
hum
---
a

to

.
 
<EOS>
But

no

---
<EOS>
ha
---
not

,
in
my

,
and
yet

,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I

;
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

I
wish

,

of
Mrs
General
,
to
form
a
---
hum
---
a
surface
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
for
your
sake
that
I
wish
you
to
have
a
---
ha
---
truly
refined
mind
,
and
(
in
the
striking
words
of
Mrs
General
)
to
be
ignorant
of
everything
that
is
not
perfectly
proper
,
placid
,
and
pleasant
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
been
running
down
by
jerks
,
during
his
last
speech
,
like
a
sort
of
ill
-
adjusted
alarum
.
 
<EOS>
The
touch
was
still
upon
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
silent
;
and
after
looking
about
the
ceiling
again
for
a
little
while
,
looked
down
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
Her
head
drooped
,
and
he
could
not
see
her
face
;
but
her
touch
was
tender
and
quiet
,
and
in
the
expression
of
her
dejected
figure
there
was
no
blame
---
nothing
but
love
.
 
<EOS>
He
began
to
whimper
,
just
as
he
had
done
that
night
in
the
prison
when
she
afterwards
sat
at
his
bedside
till
morning
;
exclaimed
that
he
was
a
poor
ruin
and
a
poor
wretch
in
the
midst
of
his
wealth
;
and
clasped
her
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
hush
,
my
own
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Kiss
me
!
<EOS>
"
was
all
she
said
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
tears
were
soon
dried
,
much
sooner
than
on
the
former
occasion
;
and
he
was
presently
afterwards
very
high
with
his
valet
,
as
a
way
of
righting
himself
for
having
shed
any
.
   
<EOS>
With
one
remarkable
exception
,
to
be
recorded
in
its
place
,
this
was
the
only
time
,
in
his
life
of
freedom
and
fortune
,
when
he
spoke
to
his
daughter
Amy
of
the
old
days
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
now
,
the
breakfast
hour
arrived
;
and
<EOS>
with
it
Miss
Fanny
from
her
apartment
,
and
Mr
Edward
from
his
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
Both
these
young
persons
of
distinction
were
something
the
worse
for
late
hours
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Miss
Fanny
,
she
had
become
the
victim
of
an
insatiate
mania
for
what
she
called
"
going
into
society
;
"
and
would
have
gone
into
it
head
-
foremost
fifty
times
between
sunset
and
sunrise
,
if
so
many
opportunities
had
been
at
her
disposal
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Edward
,
he
,
too
,
had
a
large
acquaintance
,
and
was
generally
engaged
(
for
the
most
part
,
in
diceing
circles
,
or
others
of
a
kindred
nature
)
,
during
the
greater
part
of
every
night
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
gentleman
,
when
his
fortunes
changed
,
had
stood
at
the
great
advantage
of
being
already
prepared
for
the
highest
associates
,
and
having
little
to
learn
:
so
much
was
he
indebted
to
the
happy
accidents
which
had
made
him
acquainted
with
horse
-
dealing
and
billiard
-
marking
.
   
<EOS>
At
breakfast
,
Mr
Frederick
Dorrit
likewise
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
old
gentleman
inhabited
the
highest
story
of
the
palace
,
where
he
might
have
practised
pistol
-
shooting
without
much
chance
of
discovery
by
the
other
inmates
,
his
younger
niece
had
taken
courage
to
propose
the
restoration
to
him
of
his
clarionet
,
which
Mr
Dorrit
had
ordered
to
be
confiscated
,
but
which
she
had
ventured
to
preserve
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
some
objections
from
Miss
Fanny
,
that
it
was
a
low
instrument
,
and
that
she
detested
the
sound
of
it
,
the
concession
had
been
made
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
then
discovered
that
he
had
had
enough
of
it
,
and
never
played
it
,
now
that
it
was
no
longer
his
means
of
getting
bread
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
insensibly
acquired
a
new
habit
of
shuffling
into
the
picture
-
galleries
,
always
with
his
twisted
paper
of
snuff
in
his

(
much
to
the

of
Miss

,
who
had

that

might
not

,
which
he
had

)
;
and
of
passing
hours
and

before
the
portraits
of
renowned

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
never

out
what
his
dazed

saw

;
whether

,

whether

confusedly
identified

with

that
was

,
like
the
strength
of

own

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
paid
his

to
them
with
great

,
and
clearly
derived

from

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
Little
Dorrit
happened
one

to

.
 
<EOS>
It
so

his

that
she
often

afterwards
,
and
the
greatest

of
which
the
old
man
had
shown
himself

since

,
arose
out
of

,
when
he
would

about
for

from

,
and

,
in

,

to

.
   
<EOS>
It

that
,

,

seen
in

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
Little

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

,

,
"
<EOS>
Brother
!
 
<EOS>
I
protest
against

!
"
   
<EOS>
If

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

's

,
and

,
with

fig
half

.
   
<EOS>
"
Brother
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
man
,
conveying

into

,
"
I
protest
against

!
 
<EOS>
I
love
you
;
you
know
I
love
you
dearly
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
many
years
I
have
never
been
untrue
to

in

.
 
<EOS>
Weak
as
I
am
,
I
would
at
any

ill
of

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
brother
,
brother
,
brother
,
I
protest
against
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was

<EOS>
such

was
capable
.
 
<EOS>
His

,
his

,

had

,
started

again
,
and

in

that
made

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Frederick
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is

?
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Have

?
 
<EOS>
Have

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Uncle
?
<EOS>
"

,

,
"
why

?
 
<EOS>
What

I

?
"
   
"
Done
?
"
returned

old

,

's

,
"
where
's

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Where

than

?
 
<EOS>
How

in

?
   
<EOS>
For

,
you
false
girl
,
for
shame
!
"
<EOS>
"
I
love
Amy
,
"
cried

,

,
"
as

I

---
better

.
 
<EOS>
I

n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
as
grateful
to
Amy
,
and
as
fond
of
Amy
,
as
it
's
possible
for
any
human
being
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
was
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
so
wickedly
wronged
.
 
<EOS>
And
only
because
I
am
anxious
for
the
family
credit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
winds
with
the
family
credit
!
"
cried
the
old
man
,
with
great
scorn
and
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
I
protest
against
pride
.
<EOS>
I
protest
against
ingratitude
.
 
<EOS>
I
protest
against
any
one
of
us
here
who
have
known
what
we
have
known
,
and
have
seen
what
we
have
seen
,
setting
up
any
pretension
that
puts
Amy
at
a
moment
's
disadvantage
,
or
to
the
cost
of
a
moment
's
pain
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
know
that
it
's
a
base
pretension
by
its
having
that
effect
.
 
<EOS>
It
ought
to
bring
a
judgment
on
us
.
 
<EOS>
Brother
,
I
protest
against
it
in
the
sight
of
God
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
his
hand
went
up
above
his
head
and
came
down
on
the
table
,
it
might
have
been
a
blacksmith
's
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
moments
'
silence
,
it
had
relaxed
into
its
usual
weak
condition
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
round
to
his
brother
with
his
ordinary
shuffling
step
,
put
the
hand
on
his
shoulder
,
and
said
,
in
a
softened
voice
,
"
William
,
my
dear
<EOS>
,
I
felt
obliged
to
say
it
;
forgive
me
,
for
I
felt
obliged
to
say
it
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
went
,
in
his
bowed
way
,
out
of
the
palace
hall
,
just
as
he
might
have
gone
out
of
the
Marshalsea
room
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
Fanny
had
been
sobbing
and
crying
,
and
still
continued
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Edward
,
beyond
opening
his
mouth
in
amazement
,
had
not
opened
his
lips
,
and
had
done
nothing
but
stare
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
also
had
been
utterly
discomfited
,
and
quite
unable
to
assert
himself
in
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
was
now
the
first
to
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
,
never
,
never
was
so
used
!
"
<EOS>
she
sobbed
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
anything
so
harsh
and
unjustifiable
,
so
disgracefully
violent
and
cruel
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
,
kind
,
quiet
little
Amy
,
too
,
what
would
she
feel
if
she
could
know
that
she
had
been
innocently
the
means
of
exposing
me
to
such
treatment
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
never
tell
her
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
<EOS>
good
darling
,
I
'll
never
tell
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
helped
Mr
Dorrit
to
break
his
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
---
ha
---
approve
of
your
resolution
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
---
ha
hum
---
much
better
not
to
speak
of
this
to
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
---
hum
<EOS>
---
it
might
distress
her
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
it
would
distress
her
greatly
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
considerate
and
right
to
avoid
doing
so
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
---
ha
---
keep
this
to
ourselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
cruelty
of
Uncle
!
"
cried
Miss
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
,
I
never
can
forgive
the
wanton
cruelty
of
Uncle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
recovering
his
tone
,
though
he
remained
unusually
pale
,
"
I
must
request
you
not
to
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
remember
that
your
uncle
is
---
ha
---
not
what
he
formerly
was
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
remember
that
your
uncle
's
state
requires
---
hum
---
great
forbearance
from
us
,
great
forbearance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
"
cried
Fanny
,
piteously
,
"
it
is
only
charitable
to
suppose
that
there
Must
be
something
wrong
in
him
somewhere
,
or
he
never
could
have
so
attacked
Me
,
of
all
the
people
in
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
returned
Mr
Dorrit
in
a

,
"
you
know
,
with
his
innumerable
good
points
,
what
a
---
hum
---
wreck
your
uncle
is
;
an
(
]
I
entreat

by
the
fondness
that
I
have
for

,
and
by
the

that
you
know
I
have

shown
him
,
to
---
ha
---
to
draw
your
own

,
and
to
spare
my
brotherly
feelings
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
ended
the
scene
;
Edward
Dorrit
,
Esquire
,
saying
nothing
throughout
,
but
looking
,
to
the
last
,
perplexed
and
doubtful
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
awakened
much
affectionate
uneasiness
in
her
sister
's
mind
that
day
by
passing
the
greater
part
of
it
in
violent
fits
of
embracing
her
,
and
in
alternately
giving
her
brooches
,
and
wishing
herself
dead
.
    
Chapter
06
.
<EOS>
Something
<EOS>
Right
<EOS>
Somewhere
 
To
be
in
the
halting
state
of
Mr
Henry
Gowan
;
to
have
left
one
of
two
powers
in
disgust
;
to
want
the
necessary
qualifications
for
finding
promotion
with
another
,
and
to
be
loitering
moodily
about
on
neutral
ground
,
cursing
both
;
is
to
be
in
a
situation
unwholesome
for
the
mind
,
<EOS>
which
time
is
not
likely
to
improve
.
 
<EOS>
The
worst
class
of
sum
worked
in
the
every
-
day
world
is
cyphered
by
the
diseased
arithmeticians
who
are
always
in
the
rule
of
Subtraction
as
to
the
merits
and
successes
of
others
,
and
never
in
Addition
as
to
their
own
.
   
<EOS>
The
habit
,
too
,
of
seeking
some
sort
of
recompense
in
the
discontented
boast
of
being
disappointed
,
is
a
habit
fraught
with
degeneracy
.
 
<EOS>
A
certain
idle
carelessness
and
recklessness
of
consistency
soon
comes
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
bring
deserving
things
down
by
setting
undeserving
things
up
is
one
of
its
perverted
delights
;
and
there
is
no
playing
fast
and
loose
with
the
truth
,
in
any
game
,
without
growing
the
worse
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
In
his
expressed
opinions
of
all
performances
in
the
Art
of
painting
that
were
completely
destitute
of
merit
,
Gowan
was
the
most
liberal
fellow
on
earth
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
declare
such
a
man
to
have
more
power
in
his
little
finger
(
provided
he
had
none
)
,
than
such
another
had
(
provided
he
had
much
)
in
his
whole
mind
and
body
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
objection
were
taken
that
the
thing
commended
was
trash
,
he
would
reply
,
on
behalf
of
his
art
,
"
My
good
fellow
,
what
do
we
all
turn
out
but
trash
?
 
<EOS>
I
turn
out
nothing
else
,
and
I
make
you
a
present
of
the
confession
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
To
make
a
vaunt
of
being
poor
was
another
of
the
incidents
of
his
splenetic
state
,
though
this
may
have
had
the
design
in
it
of
showing
that
he
ought
to
be
rich
;
just
as
he
would
publicly
laud
and
decry
the
Barnacles
,
lest
it
should
be
forgotten
that
he
belonged
to
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
these
two
subjects
were
very
often
on
his
lips
;
and
he
managed
them
so
well
that
he
might
have
praised
himself
by
the
month
together
,
and
not
have
made
himself
out
half
so
important
a
man
as
he
did
by
his
light
disparagement
of
his
claims
on
anybody
's
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
Out
of
this
same
airy
talk
of
his
,
it
always
soon
came
to
be
understood
,
wherever
he
and
his
wife
went
,
that
he
had
married
against
the
wishes
of
his
exalted
relations
,
and
had
had
much
ado
to
prevail
on
them
to
countenance
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
made
the
representation
,
on
the
contrary
seemed
to
laugh
the
idea
to
scorn
;
but
it
did
happen
that
,
with
all
his
pains
to
depreciate
himself
,
he
was
always
in
the
superior
position
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
days
of
their
honeymoon
,
Minnie
Gowan
felt
sensible
of
being
usually
regarded
as
the
wife
of
a
man
who
had
made
a
descent
in
marrying
her
,
but
whose
chivalrous
love
for
her
had
cancelled
that
inequality
.
   
<EOS>
To
Venice
they
had
been
accompanied
by
Monsieur
Blandois
of
Paris
,
and
at
Venice
Monsieur
Blandois
of
Paris
was
very
much
in
the
society
of
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
first
met
this
gallant
gentleman
at
Geneva
,
Gowan
had
been
undecided
whether
to
kick
him
or
encourage
him
;
and
had
remained
for
about
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
,
so
troubled
to
settle
the
point
to
his
satisfaction
,
that
he
had
thought
of
tossing
up
a
five
-
franc
piece
on
the
terms
,
"
Tails
,
kick
;
heads
,
encourage
,
"
and
abiding
by
the
voice
of
the
oracle
.
<EOS>
It
chanced
,
however
,
that
his
wife
expressed
a
dislike
to
the
engaging
Blandois
,
and
that
the
balance
of
feeling
in
the
hotel
was
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
it
,
Gowan
resolved
to
encourage
him
.
   
<EOS>
Why
this
perversity
,
if
it
were
not
in
a
generous
fit
?
---
which
it
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
Gowan
,
very
much
the
superior
of
Blandois
of
Paris
,
and
very
well
able
to
pull
that
prepossessing
gentleman
to
pieces
and
find
out
the
stuff
he
was
made
of
,
take
up
with
such
a
man
?
 
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
he
opposed
the
first
separate
wish
he
observed
in
his
wife
,
because
her
father
had
paid
his
debts
and
it
was
desirable
to
take
an
early
opportunity
of
asserting
his
independence
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
second
place
,
he
opposed
the
prevalent
feeling
,
because
with
many
capacities
of
being
otherwise
,
he
was
an
ill
-
conditioned
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
a
pleasure
in
declaring
that
a
courtier
with
the
refined
manners
of
Blandois
ought
to
rise
to
the
greatest
distinction
in
any
polished
country
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
a
pleasure
in
setting
up
Blandois
as
the
type
of
elegance
,
and
making
him
a
satire
upon
others
who
piqued
themselves
on
personal
graces
.
 
<EOS>
He
seriously
protested
that
the
bow
of
Blandois
was
perfect
,
that
the
address
of
Blandois
was
irresistible
,
and
that
the
picturesque
ease
of
Blandois
would
be
cheaply
purchased
(
if
it
were
not
a
gift
,
and
unpurchasable
)
for
a
hundred
thousand
francs
.
 
<EOS>
That
exaggeration
in
the
manner
of
the
man
which
has
been
noticed
as
appertaining
to
him
and
to
every
such
man
,
whatever
his
original
breeding
,
as
certainly
as
the
sun
belongs
to
this
system
,
was
acceptable
to
Gowan
as
a
caricature
,
which
he
found
it
a
humorous
resource
to
have
at
hand
for
the
ridiculing
of
numbers
of
people
who
necessarily
did
more
or
less
of
what
Blandois
overdid
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
he
had
taken
up
with
him
;
and
thus
,
negligently
strengthening
these
inclinations
with
habit
,
and
idly
deriving
some
amusement
from
his
talk
,
he
had
glided
into
a
way
of
having
him
for
a
companion
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
though
he
supposed
him
to
live
by
his
wits
at
play
-
tables
and
the
like
;
though
he
suspected
him
to
be
a
coward
,
while
he
himself
was
daring
and
courageous
;
though
he
thoroughly
knew
him
to
be
disliked
by
Minnie
;
and
though
he
cared
so
little
for
him
,
after
all
,
that
if
he
had
given
her
any
tangible
personal
cause
to
regard
him
with
aversion
,
he
would
have
had
no
compunction
<EOS>
whatever
in
flinging
him
out
of
the
highest
window
in
Venice
into
the
deepest
water
of
the
city
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
would
have
been
glad
to
make
her
visit
to
Mrs
Gowan
,
alone
;
but
as
Fanny
,
who
had
not
yet
recovered
from
her
Uncle
's
protest
,
though
it
was
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
of
age
,
pressingly
offered
her
company
,
the
two
sisters
stepped
together
into
one
of
the
gondolas
under
Mr
Dorrit
's
window
,
and
,
with
the
courier
in
attendance
,
were
taken
in
high
state
to
Mrs
Gowan
's
lodging
.
 
<EOS>
In
truth
,
their
state
was
rather
too
high
for
the
lodging
,
which
was
,
as
Fanny
complained
,
"
fearfully
out
of
the
way
,
"
and
which
took
them
through
a
complexity
of
narrow
streets
of
water
,
which
the
same
lady
disparaged
as
"
mere
ditches
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
house
,
on
a
little
desert
island
,
looked
as
if
it
had
broken
away
from
somewhere
else
,
and
had
floated
by
chance
into
its
present
anchorage
in
company
with
a
vine
almost
as
much
in
want
of
training
as
the
poor
wretches
who
were
lying
under
its
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
The
features
of
the
surrounding
picture
were
,
a
church
with
hoarding
and
scaffolding
about
it
,
which
had
been
under
suppositious
repair
so
long
that
the
means
of
repair
looked
a
hundred
years
old
,
and
had
themselves
fallen
into
decay
;
a
quantity
of
washed
linen
,
spread
to
dry
in
the
sun
;
a
number
of
houses
at
odds
with
one
another
and
grotesquely
out
of
the
perpendicular
,
like
rotten
pre
-
Adamite
cheeses
cut
into
fantastic
shapes
and
full
of
mites
;
and
a
feverish
bewilderment
of
windows
,
with
their
lattice
-
blinds
all
hanging
askew
,
and
something
draggled
and
dirty
dangling
out
of
most
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
first
-
floor
of
the
house
was
a
Bank
---
a
surprising
experience
for
any
gentleman
of
commercial
pursuits
bringing
laws
for
all
mankind
from
a
British
city
---
where
two
spare
clerks
,
like
dried
dragoons
,
in
green
velvet
caps
adorned
with
golden
tassels
,
stood
,
bearded
,
behind
a
small
counter
in
a
small
room
,
containing
no
other
visible
objects
than
an
empty
iron
-
safe
with
the
door
open
,
a
jug
of
water
,
and
a
papering
of
garland
of
roses
;
but
who
,
on
lawful
requisition
,
by
merely
dipping
their
hands
out
of
sight
,
could
produce
exhaustless
mounds
of
five
-
franc
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
Below
the
Bank
was
a
suite
of
three
or
four
rooms
with
barred
windows
,
which
had
the
appearance
of
a
jail
for
criminal
rats
.
 
<EOS>
Above
the
Bank
was
Mrs
Gowan
's
residence
.
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
that
its
walls
were
blotched
,
as
if
missionary
maps
were
bursting
out
of
them
to
impart
geographical
knowledge
;
notwithstanding
that
its
weird
furniture
was
forlornly
faded
and
musty
,
and
that
the
prevailing
Venetian
odour
of
bilge
water
and
an
ebb
tide
on
a
weedy
shore
was
very
strong
;
the
place
was
better
within
,
than
it
promised
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
opened
by
a
smiling
man
like
a
reformed
assassin
---
a
temporary
servant
---
who
ushered
them
into
the
room
where
Mrs
Gowan
sat
,
with
the
announcement
that
two
beautiful
English
ladies
were
come
to
see
the
mistress
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
,
who
was
engaged
in
needlework
,
put
her
work
aside
in
a
covered
basket
,
and
rose
,
a
little
hurriedly
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
was
excessively
courteous
to
her
,
and
said
the
usual
nothings
with
the
skill
of
a
veteran
.
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
was
extremely
sorry
,
"
proceeded
Fanny
,
"
to
be
engaged
to
-
day
(
he
is
so
much
engaged
here
,
our
acquaintance
being
so
wretchedly
large
!
)
;
and
particularly
requested
me
to
bring
his
card
for
Mr
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
may
be
sure
to
acquit
myself
of
a
commission
which
he
impressed
upon
me
at
least
a
dozen
times
,
allow
me
to
relieve
my
conscience
by
placing
it
on
the
table
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Which
she
did
with
veteran
ease
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
charmed
to
understand
that
you
know
the
Merdles
.
 
<EOS>
We
hope
it
may
be
another
means
of
bringing
us
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
friends
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
"
of
Mr
Gowan
's
family
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
had
the
pleasure
of
a
personal
introduction
to
Mrs
Merdle
,
but
I
suppose
I
shall
be
presented
to
her
at
Rome
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
"
returned
Fanny
,
with
an
appearance
of
amiably
quenching
her
own
superiority
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
'll
like
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
her
very
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
see
,
"
said
Fanny
,
with
a
frank
action
of
her
pretty
shoulders
,
"
in
London
one
knows
every
one
.
 
<EOS>
We
met
her
on
our
way
here
,
and
,
to
say
the
truth
,
papa
was
at
first
rather
cross
with
her
for
taking
one
of
the
rooms
that
our
people
had
ordered
for
us
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
of
course
,
that
soon
blew
over
,
and
we
were
all
good
friends
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
the
visit
had
as
yet
given
Little
Dorrit
no
opportunity
of
conversing
with
Mrs
Gowan
,
there
was
a
silent
understanding
between
them
,
which
did
as
well
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
at
Mrs
Gowan
with
keen
and
unabated
interest
;
the
sound
of
her
voice
was
thrilling
to
her
;
nothing
that
was
near
her
,
or
about
her
,
or
at
all
concerned
her
,
escaped
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
quicker
to
perceive
the
slightest
matter
here
,
than
in
any
other
case
---
but
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
quite
well
,
"
she
now
said
,
"
since
that
night
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
?
"
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
always
well
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
timidly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
yes
,
thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
reason
for
her
faltering
and
breaking
off
,
other
than
that
Mrs
Gowan
had
touched
her
hand
in
speaking
to
her
,
and
their
looks
had
met
.
 
<EOS>
Something
thoughtfully
apprehensive
in
the
large
,
soft
eyes
,
had
checked
Little
Dorrit
in
an
instant
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
that
you
are
a
favourite
of
my
husband
's
,
and
that
I
am
almost
bound
to
be
jealous
of
you
?
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
blushing
,
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
will
tell
you
,
if
he
tells
you
what
he
tells
me
,
that
you
are
quieter
and
quicker
of
resource
than
any
one
he
ever
saw
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
speaks
far
too
well
of
me
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
that
;
but
I
do
n't
at
all
doubt
that
I
must
tell
him
you
are
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
never
be
forgiven
,
if
I
were
to
let
you
---
and
Miss
Dorrit
---
go
,
without
doing
so
.
 
<EOS>
May
I
?
 
<EOS>
You
can
excuse
the
disorder
and
discomfort
of
a
painter
's
studio
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
inquiries
were
addressed
to
Miss
Fanny
,
who
graciously
replied
that
she
would
be
beyond
anything
interested
and
enchanted
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
went
to
a
door
,
looked
in
beyond
it
,
and
came
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
Henry
the
favour
to
come
in
,
"
said
she
,
"
<EOS>
I
knew
he
would
be
pleased
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
first
object
that
confronted
Little
Dorrit
,
entering
first
,
was
Blandois
of
Paris
in
a
great
cloak
and
a
furtive
slouched
hat
,
standing
on
a
throne
platform
in
a
corner
,
as
he
had
stood
on
the
Great
Saint
Bernard
,
when
the
warning
arms
seemed
to
be
all
pointing
up
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
recoiled
from
this
figure
,
as
it
smiled
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
"
said
Gowan
,
coming
from
his
easel
behind
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
doing
duty
as
a
model
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
am
making
a
study
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
saves
me
money
to
turn
him
to
some
use
.
 
<EOS>
We
poor
painters
have
none
to
spare
.
"
   
<EOS>
Blandois
of
Paris
pulled
off
his
slouched
hat
,
and
saluted
the
ladies
without
coming
out
of
his
corner
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
pardons
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
the
Professore
here
is
so
inexorable
with
me
,
that
I
am
afraid
to
stir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stir
,
then
,
"
said
Gowan
coolly
,
as
the
sisters
approached
the
easel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
the
ladies
at
least
see
the
original
of
the
daub
,
that
they
may
know
what
it
's
meant
for
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
stands
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
A
bravo
waiting
for
his
prey
,
a
distinguished
noble
waiting
to
save
his
country
,
the
common
enemy
waiting
to
do
somebody
a
bad
turn
,
an
angelic
messenger
waiting
to
do
somebody
a
good
turn
---
<EOS>
whatever
you
think
he
looks
most
like
!
"
<EOS>
"
Say
,
Professore
Mio
,
a
poor
gentleman
waiting
to
do
homage
to
elegance
and
beauty
,
"
remarked
Blandois
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
say
,
Cattivo
Soggetto
Mio
,
"
returned
Gowan
,
touching
the
painted
face
with
his
brush
in
the
part
where
the
real
face
had
moved
,
"
a
murderer
after
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
Show
that
white
hand
of
yours
,
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
Put
it
outside
the
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
it
still
.
"
   
<EOS>
Blandois
'
hand
was
unsteady
;
but
he
laughed
,
and
that
would
naturally
shake
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
formerly
in
some
scuffle
with
another
murderer
,
or
with
a
victim
,
you
observe
,
"
said
Gowan
,
putting
in
the
markings
of
the
hand
with
a
quick
,
impatient
,
unskilful
touch
,
"
and
these
are
the
tokens
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Outside
the
cloak
,
man
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Corpo
di
San
Marco
,
what
are
you
thinking
of
?
"
   
<EOS>
Blandois
of
Paris
shook
with
a
laugh
again
,
so
that
his
hand
shook
more
;
now
he
raised
it
to
twist
his
moustache
,
which
had
a
damp
appearance
;
and
now
he
stood
in
the
required
position
,
with
a
little
new
swagger
.
   
<EOS>
His
face
was
so
directed
in
reference
to
the
spot
where
Little
Dorrit
stood
by
the
easel
,
that
throughout
he
looked
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
Once
attracted
by
his
peculiar
eyes
,
she
could
not
remove
her
own
,
and
they
had
looked
at
each
other
all
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
trembled
now
;
Gowan
,
feeling
it
,
and
supposing
her
to
be
alarmed
by
the
large
dog
beside
him
,
whose
head
she
caressed
in
her
hand
,
and
who
had
just
uttered
a
low
growl
,
glanced
at
her
to
say
,
"
He
wo
n't
hurt
you
,
Miss
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
of
him
,
"
she
returned
in
the
same
breath
;
"
but
will
you
look
at
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
In
a
moment
Gowan
had
thrown
down
his
brush
,
and
seized
the
dog
with
both
hands
by
the
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
Blandois
!
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
be
such
a
fool
as
to
provoke
him
!
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
and
the
other
place
too
,
he
'll
tear
you
to
bits
!
 
<EOS>
Lie
down
!
   
<EOS>
Lion
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
my
voice
,
you
rebel
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great
dog
,
regardless
of
being
half
-
choked
by
his
collar
,
was
obdurately
pulling
with
his
dead
weight
against
his
master
,
resolved
to
get
across
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
crouching
for
a
spring
at
the
moment
when
his
master
caught
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lion
!
 
<EOS>
Lion
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
up
on
his
hind
legs
,
and
it
was
a
wrestle
between
master
and
dog
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
back
!
 
<EOS>
Down
,
Lion
!
 
<EOS>
Get
out
of
his
sight
,
Blandois
!
 
<EOS>
What
devil
have
you
conjured
into
the
dog
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
nothing
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Get
out
of
his
sight
or
I
ca
n't
hold
the
wild
beast
!
 
<EOS>
Get
out
of
the
room
!
 
<EOS>
By
my
soul
,
he
'll
kill
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
dog
,
with
a
ferocious
bark
,
made
one
other
struggle
as
Blandois
vanished
;
then
,
in
the
moment
of
the
dog
's
submission
,
the
master
,
little
less
angry
than
the
dog
,
felled
him
with
a
blow
on
the
head
,
and
standing
over
him
,
struck
him
many
times
severely
with
the
heel
of
his
boot
,
so
that
his
mouth
was
presently
bloody
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
get
you
into
that
corner
and
lie
down
,
"
said
Gowan
,
"
or
I
'll
take
you
out
and
shoot
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Lion
did
as
he
was
ordered
,
and
lay
down
licking
his
mouth
and
chest
.
 
<EOS>
Lion
's
master
stopped
for
a
moment
to
take
breath
,
and
then
,
recovering
his
usual
coolness
of
manner
,
turned
to
speak
to
his
frightened
wife
and
her
visitors
.
 
<EOS>
Probably
the
whole
occurrence
had
not
occupied
two
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
Minnie
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
he
is
always
good
-
humoured
and
tractable
.
 
<EOS>
Blandois
must
have
irritated
him
,
---
made
faces
at
him
.
<EOS>
The
dog
has
his
likings
and
dislikings
,
and
Blandois
is
no
great
favourite
of
his
;
but
I
am
sure
you
will
give
him
a
character
,
Minnie
,
for
never
having
been
like
this
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
Minnie
was
too
much
disturbed
to
say
anything
connected
in
reply
;
Little
Dorrit
was
already
occupied
in
soothing
her
;
Fanny
,
who
had
cried
out
twice
or
thrice
,
held
Gowan
's
arm
for
protection
;
Lion
,
deeply
ashamed
of
having
caused
them
this
alarm
,
came
trailing
himself
along
the
ground
to
the
feet
of
his
mistress
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
furious
brute
,
"
said
Gowan
,
striking
him
with
his
foot
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
do
penance
for
this
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
struck
him
again
,
and
yet
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
pray
do
n't
punish
him
any
more
,
"
cried
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hurt
him
.
 
<EOS>
See
how
gentle
he
is
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
her
entreaty
,
Gowan
spared
him
;
and
he
deserved
her
intercession
,
for
truly
he
was
as
submissive
,
and
as
sorry
,
and
as
wretched
as
a
dog
could
be
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
easy
to
recover
this
shock
and
make
the
visit
unrestrained
,
even
though
Fanny
had
not
been
,
under
the
best
of
circumstances
,
the
least
trifle
in
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
In
such
further
communication
as
passed
among
them
before
the
sisters
took
their
departure
,
Little
Dorrit
fancied
it
was
revealed
to
her
that
Mr
Gowan
treated
his
wife
,
even
in
his
very
fondness
,
too
much
like
a
beautiful
child
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
so
unsuspicious
of
the
depths
of
feeling
which
she
knew
must
lie
below
that
surface
,
that
she
doubted
if
there
could
be
any
such
depths
in
himself
.
 
<EOS>
She
wondered
whether
his
want
of
earnestness
might
be
the
natural
result
of
his
want
of
such
qualities
,
and
whether
it
was
with
people
as
with
ships
,
that
,
in
too
shallow
and
rocky
waters
,
their
anchors
had
no
hold
,
and
they
drifted
anywhere
.
   
<EOS>
He
attended
them
down
the
staircase
,
jocosely
apologising
for
the
poor
quarters
to
which
such
poor
fellows
as
himself
were
limited
,
and
remarking
that
when
the
high
and
mighty
Barnacles
,
his
relatives
,
who
would
be
dreadfully
ashamed
of
them
,
presented
him
with
better
,
he
would
live
in
better
to
oblige
them
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
water
's
edge
they
were
saluted
by
Blandois
,
who
looked
white
enough
after
his
late

,
but
who
made
very
light
of
it
notwithstanding
,
---
laughing
at
the
mention
of
Lion
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving

together
under
the

of
vine

,
Gowan
idly

from

into

,
and
Blandois
lighting
a

,
the
sisters
were
paddled
away
in
state

had
come
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
not
glided
on
for
many
minutes
,
when
Little
Dorrit
became
aware
that
Fanny
was
more

appeared

,
and

through

in

.
   
<EOS>
As

attended

in

;
sometimes

;
and

;
and

no

,

?
   
<EOS>

"
That

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Young

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Little

.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
well

.

.

.

.
 
<EOS>
By

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

"

.
"

.

<EOS>
Miss

,

,

<EOS>

Dante
---

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
He

Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,
or
