,
and
not
feeling
herself
this
year
quite
up
to
visiting
about
at
people
's
places
,
had
resolved
to
have
a
touch
at
Rome
,
where
a
woman
like
herself
,
with
a
proverbially
fine
appearance
,
and
with
no
nonsense
about
her
,
could
n't
fail
to
be
a
great
acquisition
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Merdle
,
he
was
so
much
wanted
by
the
men
in
the
City
and
the
rest
of
those
places
,
and
was
such
a
doosed
extraordinary
phenomenon
in
Buying
and
Banking
and
that
,
that
Mr
Sparkler
doubted
if
the
monetary
system
of
the
country
would
be
able
to
spare
him
;
though
that
his
work
was
occasionally
one
too
many
for
him
,
and
that
he
would
be
all
the
better
for
a
temporary
shy
at
an
entirely
new
scene
and
climate
,
Mr
Sparkler
did
not
conceal
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
himself
,
Mr
Sparkler
conveyed
to
the
Dorrit
family
that
he
was
going
,
on
rather
particular
business
,
wherever
they
were
going
.
   
<EOS>
This
immense
conversational
achievement
required
time
,
but
was
effected
.
 
<EOS>
Being
effected
,
Mr
Dorrit
expressed
his
hope
that
Mr
Sparkler
would
shortly
dine
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
received
the
idea
so
kindly
that
Mr
Dorrit
asked
what
he
was
going
to
do
that
day
,
for
instance
?
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
going
to
do
nothing
that
day
(
his
usual
occupation
,
and
one
for
which
he
was
particularly
qualified
)
,
he
was
secured
without
postponement
;
being
further
bound
over
to
accompany
the
ladies
to
the
Opera
in
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
At
dinner
-
time
Mr
Sparkler
rose
out
of
the
sea
,
like
Venus
's
son
taking
after
his
mother
,
and
made
a
splendid
appearance
ascending
the
great
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
If
Fanny
had
been
charming
in
the
morning
,
she
was
now
thrice
charming
,
very
becomingly
dressed
in
her
most
suitable
colours
,
and
with
an
air
of
negligence
upon
her
that
doubled
Mr
Sparkler
's
fetters
,
and
riveted
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
are
acquainted
,
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
said
his
host
at
dinner
,
"
with
---
ha
---
Mr
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Henry
Gowan
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
mother
and
my
mother
are
cronies
in
fact
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
thought
of
it
,
Amy
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
a
patronage
as
magnificent
as
that
of
Lord
Decimus
himself
,
"
you
should
have
despatched
a
note
to
them
,
asking
them
to
dine
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
our
people
could
have
---
ha
---
fetched
them
,
and
taken
them
home
.
 
<EOS>
We
could
have
spared
a
---
hum
---
gondola
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
to
have
forgotten
this
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
remind
me
of
them
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
not
without
doubts
how
Mr
Henry
Gowan
might
take
their
patronage
;
but
she
promised
not
to
fail
in
the
reminder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
does
Mr
Henry
Gowan
paint
---
ha
---
Portraits
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
opined
that
he
painted
anything
,
if
he
could
get
the
job
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
no
particular
walk
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
stimulated
by
Love
to
brilliancy
,
replied
that
for
a
particular
walk
a
man
ought
to
have
a
particular
pair
of
shoes
;
as
,
for
example
,
shooting
,
shooting
-
shoes
;
cricket
,
cricket
-
shoes
.
<EOS>
Whereas
,
he
believed
that
Henry
Gowan
had
no
particular
pair
of
shoes
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
speciality
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
This
being
a
very
long
word
for
Mr
Sparkler
,
and
his
mind
being
exhausted
by
his
late
effort
,
he
replied
,
"
No
,
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
seldom
take
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
very
agreeable
to
me
to
present
a
gentleman
so
connected
,
with
some
---
ha
---
Testimonial
of
my
desire
to
further
his
interests
,
and
develop
the
---
hum
---
germs
of
his
genius
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
must
engage
Mr
Gowan
to
paint
my
picture
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
result
should
be
---
ha
---
mutually
satisfactory
,
I
might
afterwards
engage
him
to
try
his
hand
upon
my
family
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
exquisitely
bold
and
original
thought
presented
itself
to
Mr
Sparkler
,
that
there
was
an
opening
here
for
saying
there
were
some
of
the
family
(
emphasising
"
some
"
in
a
marked
manner
)
to
whom
no
painter
could
render
justice
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
for
want
of
a
form
of
words
in
which
to
express
the
idea
,
it
returned
to
the
skies
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
more
to
be
regretted
as
Miss
Fanny
greatly
applauded
the
notion
of
the
portrait
,
and
urged
her
papa
to
act
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
surmised
,
she
said
,
that
Mr
Gowan
had
lost
better
and
higher
opportunities
by
marrying
his
pretty
wife
;
and
Love
in
a
cottage
,
painting
pictures
for
dinner
<EOS>
,
was
so
delightfully
interesting
,
that
she
begged
her
papa
to
give
him
the
commission
whether
he
could
paint
a
likeness
or
not
:
though
indeed
both
she
and
Amy
knew
he
could
,
from
having
seen
a
speaking
likeness
on
his
easel
that
day
,
and
having
had
the
opportunity
of
comparing
it
with
the
original
.
<EOS>
These
remarks
made
Mr
Sparkler
(
as
perhaps
they
were
intended
to
do
)
nearly
distracted
;
for
while
on
the
one
hand
they
expressed
Miss
Fanny
's
susceptibility
of
the
tender
passion
,
she
herself
showed
such
an
innocent
unconsciousness
of
his
admiration
that
his
eyes
goggled
in
his
head
with
jealousy
of
an
unknown
rival
.
   
<EOS>
Descending
into
the
sea
again
after
dinner
,
and
ascending
out
of
it
at
the
Opera
staircase
,
preceded
by
one
of
their
gondoliers
,
like
an
attendant
Merman
,
with
a
great
linen
lantern
,
they
entered
their
box
,
and
Mr
Sparkler
entered
on
an
evening
of
agony
.
 
<EOS>
The
theatre
being
dark
,
and
the
box
light
,
several
visitors
lounged
in
during
the
representation
;
in
whom
Fanny
was
so
interested
,
and
in
conversation
with
whom
she
fell
into
such
charming
attitudes
,
as
she
had
little
confidences
with
them
,
and
little
disputes
concerning
the
identity
of
people
in
distant
boxes
,
that
the
wretched
Sparkler
hated
all
mankind
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
two
consolations
at
the
close
of
the
performance
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
him
her
fan
to
hold
while
she
adjusted
her
cloak
,
and
it
was
his
blessed
privilege
to
give
her
his
arm
down
-
stairs
again
.
 
<EOS>
These
crumbs
of
encouragement
<EOS>
,
Mr
Sparkler
thought
,
would
just
keep
him
going
;
and
it
is
not
impossible
that
Miss
Dorrit
thought
so
too
.
   
<EOS>
The
Merman
with
his
light
was
ready
at
the
box
-
door
,
and
other
Mermen
with
other
lights
were
ready
at
many
of
the
doors
.
 
<EOS>
The
Dorrit
Merman
held
his
lantern
low
,
to
show
the
steps
,
and
Mr
Sparkler
put
on
another
heavy
set
of
fetters
over
his
former
set
,
as
he
watched
her
radiant
feet
twinkling
down
the
stairs
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
loiterers
here
,
was
Blandois
of
Paris
.
 
<EOS>
He
spoke
,
and
moved
forward
beside
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
in
front
with
her
brother
and
Mrs
General
<EOS>
(
Mr
Dorrit
had
remained
at
home
)
,
but
on
the
brink
of
the
quay
they
all
came
together
.
 
<EOS>
She
started
again
to
find
Blandois
close
to
her
,
handing
Fanny
into
the
boat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gowan
has
had
a
loss
,
"
he
said
,
"
since
he
was
made
happy
to
-
day
by
a
visit
from
fair
ladies
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
loss
?
"
repeated
Fanny
,
relinquished
by
the
bereaved
Sparkler
,
and
taking
her
seat
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
loss
,
"
said
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
dog
Lion
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
hand
was
in
his
,
as
he
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
,
"
said
Blandois
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
?
"
echoed
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
noble
dog
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Faith
,
dear
ladies
!
"
said
Blandois
,
smiling
and
shrugging
his
shoulders
,
"
somebody
has
poisoned
that
noble
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
as
dead
as
the
Doges
!
"
    
Chapter
07
.
<EOS>
Mostly
,
Prunes
and
Prism
 
Mrs
General
,
always
on
her
coach
-
box
keeping
the
proprieties
well
together
,
took
pains
to
form
a
surface
on
her
very
dear
young
friend
,
and
Mrs
General
's
very
dear
young
friend
tried
hard
to
receive
it
.
 
<EOS>
Hard
as
she
had
tried
in
her
laborious
life
to
attain
many
ends
,
she
had
never
tried
harder
than
she
did
now
,
to
be
varnished
by
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
her
anxious
and
ill
at
ease
to
be
operated
upon
by
that
smoothing
hand
,
it
is
true
;
but
she
submitted
herself
to
the
family
want
in
its
greatness
as
she
had
submitted
herself
to
the
family
want
in
its
littleness
,
and
yielded
to
her
own
inclinations
in
this
thing
no
more
than
she
had
yielded
to
her
hunger
itself
,
in
the
days
when
she
had
saved
her
dinner
that
her
father
might
have
his
supper
.
   
<EOS>
One
comfort
that
she
had
under
the
Ordeal
by
General
was
more
sustaining
to
her
,
and
made
her
more
grateful
than
to
a
less
devoted
and
affectionate
spirit
,
not
habituated
to
her
struggles
and
sacrifices
,
might
appear
quite
reasonable
;
and
,
indeed
,
it
may
often
be
observed
in
life
,
<EOS>
that
spirits
like
Little
Dorrit
do
not
appear
to
reason
half
as
carefully
as
the
folks
who
get
the
better
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
continued
kindness
of
her
sister
was
this
comfort
to
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
to
her
that
the
kindness
took
the
form
of
tolerant
patronage
;
she
was
used
to
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
to
her
that
it
kept
her
in
a
tributary
position
,
and
showed
her
in
attendance
on
the
flaming
car
in
which
Miss
Fanny
sat
on
an
elevated
seat
,
exacting
homage
;
she
sought
no
better
place
.
 
<EOS>
Always
admiring
Fanny
's
beauty
,
and
grace
,
and
readiness
,
and
not
now
asking
herself
how
much
of
her
disposition
to
be
strongly
attached
to
Fanny
was
due
to
her
own
heart
,
and
how
much
to
Fanny
's
,
she
gave
her
all
the
sisterly
fondness
her
great
heart
contained
.
   
<EOS>
The
wholesale
amount
of
Prunes
and
Prism
which
Mrs
General
infused
into
the
family
life
,
combined
with
the
perpetual
plunges
made
by
Fanny
into
society
,
left
but
a
very
small
residue
of
any
natural
deposit
at
the
bottom
of
the
mixture
.
 
<EOS>
This
rendered
confidences
with
Fanny
doubly
precious
to
Little
Dorrit
,
and
heightened
the
relief
they
afforded
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
said
Fanny
to
her
one
night
when
they
were
alone
,
after
a
day
so
tiring
that
Little
Dorrit
was
quite
worn
out
,
though
Fanny
would
have
taken
another
dip
into
society
with
the
greatest
pleasure
in
life
,
"
I
am
going
to
put
something
into
your
little
head
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
guess
what
it
is
,
I
suspect
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
that
's
likely
,
dear
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
I
'll
give
you
a
clue
,
child
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
General
.
"
   
<EOS>
Prunes
and
Prism
,
in
a
thousand
combinations
,
having
been
wearily
in
the
ascendant
all
day
---
everything
having
been
surface
and
varnish
and
show
without
substance
---
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
looked
as
if
she
had
hoped
that
Mrs
General
was
safely
tucked
up
in
bed
for
some
hours
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
can
you
guess
,
Amy
?
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Unless
I
have
done
anything
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
rather
alarmed
,
and
meaning
anything
calculated
to
crack
varnish
and
ruffle
surface
.
   
<EOS>
Fanny
was
so
very
much
amused
by
the
misgiving
,
that
she
took
up
her
favourite
fan
<EOS>
(
being
then
seated
at
her
dressing
-
table
with
her
armoury
of
cruel
instruments
about
her
,
most
of
them
reeking
from
the
heart
of
Sparkler
)
,
and
tapped
her
sister
frequently
on
the
nose
with
it
,
laughing
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
our
Amy
,
our
Amy
!
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
timid
little
goose
our
Amy
is
!
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
nothing
to
laugh
at
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
am
very
cross
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
it
is
not
with
me
,
Fanny
,
I
do
n't
mind
,
"
returned
her
sister
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
mind
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
and
so
will
you
,
Pet
,
when
I
enlighten
you
.
 
<EOS>
Amy
,
has
it
never
struck
you
that
somebody
is
monstrously
polite
to
Mrs
General
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
is
polite
to
Mrs
General
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
---
"
   
"
Because
she
freezes
them
into
it
?
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
that
;
quite
different
from
that
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Has
it
never
struck
you
,
Amy
,
that
Pa
is
monstrously
polite
to
Mrs
General
.
"
   
<EOS>
Amy
,
murmuring
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
looked
quite
confounded
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
I
dare
say
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
Amy
.
 
And
remember
my
words
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
has
designs
on
Pa
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Fanny
,
do
you
think
it
possible
that
Mrs
General
has
designs
on
any
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
think
it
possible
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
she
has
designs
on
Pa.
 
<EOS>
And
more
than
that
,
I
tell
you
Pa
considers
her
such
a
wonder
,
such
a
paragon
of
accomplishment
,
and
such
an
acquisition
to
our
family
,
that
he
is
ready
to
get
himself
into
a
state
of
perfect
infatuation
with
her
at
any
moment
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
opens
a
pretty
picture
of
things
,
I
hope
?
 
<EOS>
Think
of
me
with
Mrs
General
for
a
Mama
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
did
not
reply
,
"
Think
of
me
with
Mrs
General
for
a
Mama
;
"
but
she
looked
anxious
,
and
seriously
inquired
what
had
led
Fanny
to
these
conclusions
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
,
my
darling
,
"
said
Fanny
,
tartly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
might
as
well
ask
me
how
I
know
when
a
man
is
struck
with
myself
!
 
<EOS>
But
,
of
course
I
do
know
.
 
<EOS>
It
happens
pretty
often
:
<EOS>
but
I
always
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
this
in
much
the
same
way
,
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
never
heard
Papa
say
anything
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
anything
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
,
darling
child
,
what
necessity
has
he
had
,
yet
awhile
,
to
say
anything
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
never
heard
Mrs
General
say
anything
?
"
<EOS>
"
My
goodness
me
,
Amy
,
"
returned
Fanny
,
"
is
she
the
sort
of
woman
to
say
anything
?
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
perfectly
plain
and
clear
that
she
has
nothing
to
do
at
present
but
to
hold
herself
upright
,
keep
her
aggravating
gloves
on
,
and
go
sweeping
about
?
 
<EOS>
Say
anything
!
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
the
ace
of
trumps
in
her
hand
at
whist
,
she
would
n't
say
anything
,
child
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
come
out
when
she
played
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
you
may
be
mistaken
,
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
may
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
yes
,
I
MAY
be
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
but
I
am
not
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
am
glad
you
can
contemplate
such
an
escape
,
my
dear
,
and
<EOS>
I
am
glad
that
you
can
take
this
for
the
present
with
sufficient
coolness
to
think
of
such
a
chance
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me
hope
that
you
may
be
able
to
bear
the
connection
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
be
able
to
bear
it
,
and
I
should
not
try
.
   
<EOS>
I
'd
marry
young
Sparkler
first
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
you
would
never
marry
him
,
Fanny
,
under
any
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
my
dear
,
"
rejoined
that
young
lady
with
exceeding
indifference
,
"
I
would
n't
positively
answer
even
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
knowing
what
might
happen
.
 
<EOS>
Especially
as
I
should
have
many
opportunities
,
afterwards
,
of
treating
that
woman
,
his
mother
,
in
her
own
style
.
 
<EOS>
Which
I
most
decidedly
should
not
be
slow
to
avail
myself
of
,
Amy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
No
more
passed
between
the
sisters
then
;
but
what
had
passed
gave
the
two
subjects
of
Mrs
General
and
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
great
prominence
in
Little
Dorrit
's
mind
,
and
<EOS>
thenceforth
she
thought
very
much
of
both
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
,
having
long
ago
formed
her
own
surface
to
such
perfection
that
it
hid
whatever
was
below
it
(
if
anything
)
,
no
observation
was
to
be
made
in
that
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
undeniably
very
polite
to
her
and
had
a
high
opinion
of
her
;
but
Fanny
,
impetuous
at
most
times
,
might
easily
be
wrong
for
all
that
.
   
<EOS>
Whereas
,
the
Sparkler
question
was
on
the
different
footing
that
any
one
could
see
what
was
going
on
there
,
and
Little
Dorrit
saw
it
and
pondered
on
it
with
many
doubts
and
wonderings
.
   
<EOS>
The
devotion
of
Mr
Sparkler
was
only
to
be
equalled
by
the
caprice
and
cruelty
of
his
enslaver
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
would
prefer
him
to
such
distinction
of
notice
,
that
he
would
chuckle
aloud
with
joy
;
next
day
,
or
next
hour
,
she
would
overlook
him
so
completely
,
and
drop
him
into
such
an
abyss
of
obscurity
,
that
he
would
groan
under
a
weak
pretence
of
coughing
.
 
<EOS>
The
constancy
of
his
attendance
never
touched
Fanny
:
though
he
was
so
inseparable
from
Edward
,
that
,
when
that
gentleman
wished
for
a
change
of
society
,
he
was
under
the
irksome
necessity
of
gliding
out
like
a
conspirator
in
disguised
boats
and
by
secret
doors
and
back
ways
;
though
he
was
so
solicitous
to
know
how
Mr
Dorrit
was
,
that
he
called
every
other
day
to
inquire
,
as
if
Mr
Dorrit
were
the
prey
of
an
intermittent
fever
;
though
he
was
so
constantly
being
paddled
up
and
down
before
the
principal
windows
,
that
he
might
have
been
supposed
to
have
made
a
wager
for
a
large
stake
to
be
paddled
a
thousand
miles
in
a
thousand
hours
;
though
whenever
the
gondola
of
his
mistress
left
the
gate
,
the
gondola
of
Mr
Sparkler
shot
out
from
some
watery
ambush
and
gave
chase
,
as
if
she
were
a
fair
smuggler
and
he
a
custom
-
house
officer
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
probably
owing
to
this
fortification
of
the
natural
strength
of
his
constitution
with
so
much
exposure
to
the
air
,
and
the
salt
sea
,
that
Mr
Sparkler
did
not
pine
outwardly
;
but
,
whatever
the
cause
,
he
was
so
far
from
having
any
prospect
of
moving
his
mistress
by
a
languishing
state
of
health
,
that
he
grew
bluffer
every
day
,
and
that
peculiarity
in
his
appearance
of
seeming
rather
a
swelled
boy
than
a
young
man
,
became
developed
to
an
extraordinary
degree
of
ruddy
puffiness
.
   
<EOS>
Blandois
calling
to
pay
his
respects
,
Mr
Dorrit
received
him
with
affability
as
the
friend
of
Mr
Gowan
,
and
mentioned
to
him
his
idea
of
commissioning
Mr
Gowan
to
transmit
him
to
posterity
.
 
<EOS>
Blandois
highly
extolling
it
,
it
occurred
to
Mr
Dorrit
that
it
might
be
agreeable
to
Blandois
to
communicate
to
his
friend
the
great
opportunity
reserved
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Blandois
accepted
the
commission
with
his
own
free
elegance
of
manner
,
and
swore
he
would
discharge
it
before
he
was
an
hour
older
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
imparting
the
news
to
Gowan
,
that
Master
gave
Mr
Dorrit
to
the
Devil
with
great
liberality
some
round
dozen
of
times
(
for
he
resented
patronage
almost
as
much
as
he
resented
the
want
of
it
)
,
and
was
inclined
to
quarrel
with
his
friend
for
bringing
him
the
message
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
a
defect
in
my
mental
vision
,
Blandois
,
"
said
he
,
"
but
may
I
die
if
I
see
what
you
have
to
do
with
this
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Death
of
my
life
,
"
replied
Blandois
,
"
nor
I
neither
,
except
that
I
thought
I
was
serving
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
putting
an
upstart
's
hire
in
his
pocket
?
"
said
Gowan
,
frowning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
your
other
friend
to
get
his
head
painted
for
the
sign
of
some
public
-
house
,
and
to
get
it
done
by
a
sign
-
painter
.
<EOS>
Who
am
I
,
and
who
is
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Professore
,
"
returned
the
ambassador
,
"
and
who
is
Blandois
?
"
   
<EOS>
Without
appearing
at
all
interested
in
the
latter
question
,
Gowan
angrily
whistled
Mr
Dorrit
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
next
day
,
he
resumed
the
subject
by
saying
in
his
off
-
hand
manner
and
with
a
slighting

,
"
Well
,
Blandois
,
when
shall
we
go
to
this
Maecenas
of
yours
?
   
<EOS>
We
journeymen
must
take
jobs
when
we
can
get
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
shall
we
go
and
look
after
this
job
?
"
<EOS>
"
When
you
will
,
"
said
the
injured
Blandois
,
"
as
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
I
to
do
with
it
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
tell
you
what
it
is
to
me
,
"
said
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bread
and
cheese
.
<EOS>
One
must
eat
!
 
<EOS>
So
come
along
,
my
Blandois
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
received
them
in
the
presence
of
his
daughters
and
of
Mr
Sparkler
,
who
happened
,
by
some
surprising
accident
,
to
be
calling
there
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
Sparkler
?
"
said
Gowan
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
have
to
live
by
your
mother
wit
,
<EOS>
old
boy
<EOS>
,
I
hope
you
may
get
on
better
than
I
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
then
mentioned
his
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Gowan
,
laughing
,
after
receiving
it
gracefully
enough
,
"
I
am
new
to
the
trade
,
and
not
expert
at
its
mysteries
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
ought
to
look
at
you
in
various
lights
,
tell
you
you
are
a
capital
subject
,
and
consider
when
I
shall
be
sufficiently
disengaged
to
devote
myself
with
the
necessary
enthusiasm
to
the
fine
picture
I
mean
to
make
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
,
"
and
he
laughed
again
,
"
I
feel
quite
a
traitor
in
the
camp
of
those
dear
,
gifted
,
good
,
noble
fellows
,
my
brother
artists
,
by
not
doing
the
hocus
-
pocus
better
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
not
been
brought
up
to
it
,
and
it
's
too
late
to
learn
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
fact
is
,
I
am
a
very
bad
painter
,
but
not
much
worse
than
the
generality
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
going
to
throw
away
a
hundred
guineas
or
<EOS>
so
,
I
am
as
poor
as
a
poor
relation
of
great
people
<EOS>
usually
is
,
and
I
shall
be
very
much
obliged
to
you
,
if
you
'll
throw
them
away
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
do
the
best
I
can
for
the
money
;
and
if
the
best
should
be
bad
,
why
even
then
,
you
may
probably
have
a
bad
picture
with
a
small
name
to
it
,
instead
of
a
bad
picture
with
a
large
name
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
tone
,
though
not
what
he
had
expected
,
on
the
whole
suited
Mr
Dorrit
remarkably
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
showed
that
the
gentleman
,
highly
connected
,
and
not
a
mere
workman
,
would
be
under
an
obligation
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
expressed
his
satisfaction
in
placing
himself
in
Mr
Gowan
's
hands
,
and
trusted
that
he
would
have
the
pleasure
,
in
their
characters
of
private
gentlemen
,
of
improving
his
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
forsworn
society
since
I
joined
the
brotherhood
of
the
brush
<EOS>
(
the
most
delightful
fellows
on
the
face
of
the
earth
)
,
and
am
glad
enough
to
smell
the
old
fine
gunpowder
now
and
then
,
though
it
did
blow
me
into
mid
-
air
and
my
present
calling
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
not
think
,
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
and
here
he
laughed
again
in
the
easiest
way
,
"
that
I
am
lapsing
into
the
freemasonry
of
the
craft
---
<EOS>
for
it
's
not
so
;
upon
my
life
I
ca
n't
help
betraying
it
wherever
I
go
,
though
,
by
Jupiter
,
I
love
and
honour
the
craft
with
all
my
might
---
if
I
propose
a
stipulation
as
to
time
and
place
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
could
erect
no
---
hum
---
suspicion
of
that
kind
on
Mr
Gowan
's
frankness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Again
you
are
very
good
,
"
said
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
,
I
hear
you
are
going
to
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
Rome
,
having
friends
there
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
begin
to
do
you
the
injustice
I
have
conspired
to
do
you
,
there
---
not
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
all
be
hurried
during
the
rest
of
our
stay
here
;
and
though
there
's
not
a
poorer
man
with
whole
elbows
in
Venice
,
than
myself
,
I
have
not
quite
got
all
the
Amateur
out
of
me
yet
---
comprising
the
trade
again
<EOS>
,
you
see
!
<EOS>
---
and
ca
n't
fall
on
to
order
,
in
a
hurry
,
for
the
mere
sake
of
the
sixpences
.
<EOS>
"
These
remarks
were
not
less
favourably
received
by
Mr
Dorrit
than
their
predecessors
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
the
prelude
to
the
first
reception
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Gowan
at
dinner
,
and
they
skilfully
placed
Gowan
on
his
usual
ground
in
the
new
family
.
   
<EOS>
His
wife
,
too
,
they
placed
on
her
usual
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
understood
,
with
particular
distinctness
,
that
Mrs
Gowan
's
good
looks
had
cost
her
husband
very
dear
;
that
there
had
been
a
great
disturbance
about
her
in
the
Barnacle
family
;
and
that
the
Dowager
Mrs
Gowan
,
nearly
heart
-
broken
,
had
resolutely
set
her
face
against
the
marriage
until
overpowered
by
her
maternal
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
likewise
clearly
understood
that
the
attachment
had
occasioned
much
family
grief
and
dissension
.
 
<EOS>
Of
honest
Mr
Meagles
no
mention
was
made
;
except
that
it
was
natural
enough
that
a
person
of
that
sort
should
wish
to
raise
his
daughter
out
of
his
own
obscurity
,
and
that
no
one
could
blame
him
for
trying
his
best
to
do
so
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
interest
in
the
fair
subject
of
this
easily
accepted
belief
was
too
earnest
and
watchful
to
fail
in
accurate
observation
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
see
that
it
had
its
part
in
throwing
upon
Mrs
Gowan
the
touch
of
a
shadow
under
which
she
lived
,
and
she
even
had
an
instinctive
knowledge
that
there
was
not
the
least
truth
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
had
an
influence
in
placing
obstacles
in
the
way
of
her
association
with
Mrs
Gowan
by
making
the
Prunes
and
Prism
school
excessively
polite
to
her
,
but
not
very
intimate
with
her
;
and
Little
Dorrit
,
as
an
enforced
sizar
of
that
college
,
was
obliged
to
submit
herself
humbly
to
its
ordinances
.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
there
was
a
sympathetic
understanding
already
established
between
the
two
,
which
would
have
carried
them
over
greater
difficulties
,
and
made
a
friendship
out
of
a
more
restricted
intercourse
.
 
<EOS>
As
though
accidents
were
determined
to
be
favourable
to
it
,
they
had
a
new
assurance
of
congeniality
in
the
aversion
which
each
perceived
that
the
other
felt
towards
Blandois
of
Paris
;
an
aversion
amounting
to
the
repugnance
and
horror
of
a
natural
antipathy
towards
an
odious
creature
of
the
reptile
kind
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
passive
congeniality
between
them
,
besides
this
active
one
.
 
<EOS>
To
both
of
them
,
Blandois
behaved
in
exactly
the
same
manner
;
and
to
both
of
them
his
manner
had
uniformly
something
in
it
,
which
they
both
knew
to
be
different
from
his
bearing
towards
others
.
 
<EOS>
The
difference
was
too
minute
in
its
expression
to
be
perceived
by
others
,
but
they
knew
it
to
be
there
.
 
<EOS>
A
mere
trick
of
his
evil
eyes
,
a
mere
turn
of
his
smooth
white
hand
,
a
mere
hair's
-
breadth
of
addition
to
the
fall
of
his
nose
and
the
rise
of
the
moustache
in
the
most
frequent
movement
of
his
face
,
conveyed
to
both
of
them
,
equally
,
a
swagger
personal
to
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
he
had
said
,
"
I
have
a
secret
power
in
this
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
had
never
been
felt
by
them
both
in
so
great
a
degree
,
and
never
by
each
so
perfectly
to
the
knowledge
of
the
other
,
as
on
a
day
when
he
came
to
Mr
Dorrit
's
to
take
his
leave
before
quitting
Venice
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
was
herself
there
for
the
same
purpose
,
and
he
came
upon
the
two
together
;
the
rest
of
the
family
being
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
had
not
been
together
five
minutes
,
and
the
peculiar
manner
seemed
to
convey
to
them
,
"
You
were
going
to
talk
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
Behold
me
here
to
prevent
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gowan
is
coming
here
?
"
said
Blandois
,
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
replied
he
was
not
coming
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
coming
!
"
said
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
"
Permit
your
devoted
servant
,
when
you
leave
here
,
to
escort
you
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
:
I
am
not
going
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
going
home
!
"
said
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
am
forlorn
.
"
   
<EOS>
That
he
might
be
;
but
he
was
not
so
forlorn
as
to
roam
away
and
leave
them
together
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
entertaining
them
with
his
finest
compliments
,
and
his
choicest
conversation
;
but
he
conveyed
to
them
,
all
the
time
,
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
dear
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
Behold
me
here
expressly
to
prevent
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
conveyed
it
to
them
with
so
much
meaning
,
and
he
had
such
a
diabolical
persistency
in
him
,
that
at
length
,
Mrs
Gowan
rose
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
offering
his
hand
to
Mrs
Gowan
to
lead
her
down
the
staircase
,
she
retained
Little
Dorrit
's
hand
in
hers
,
with
a
cautious
pressure
,
and
said
,
"
No
,
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
will
please
to
see
if
my
boatman
is
there
,
I
shall
be
obliged
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
left
him
no
choice
but
to
go
down
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
,
hat
in
hand
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Gowan
whispered
:
   
"
<EOS>
He
killed
the
dog
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
Mr
Gowan
know
it
?
"
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
whispered
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
knows
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
look
towards
me
;
look
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
turn
his
face
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
knows
it
,
but
I
am
sure
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
think
so
,
"
Little
Dorrit
answered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Henry
likes
him
,
and
he
will
not
think
ill
of
him
;
he
is
so
generous
and
open
himself
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
and
I
feel
sure
that
we
think
of
him
as
he
deserves
.
 
<EOS>
He
argued
with
Henry
that
the
dog
had
been
already
poisoned
when
he
changed
so
,
and
sprang
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Henry
believes
it
,
but
we
do
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
he
is
listening
,
but
ca
n't
hear
.
   
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
my
love
!
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
last
words
were
spoken
aloud
,
as
the
vigilant
Blandois
stopped
,
turned
his
head
,
and
looked
at
them
from
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
Assuredly
he
did
look
then
,
though
he
looked
his
politest
,
as
if
any
real
philanthropist
could
have
desired
no
better
employment
than
to
lash
a
great
stone
to
his
neck
,
and
drop
him
into
the
water
flowing
beyond
the
dark
arched
gateway
in
which
he
stood
.
 
<EOS>
No
such
benefactor
to
mankind
being
on
the
spot
,
he
handed
Mrs
Gowan
to
her
boat
,
and
stood
there
until
it
had
shot
out
of
the
narrow
view
;
when
he
handed
himself
into
his
own
boat
and
followed
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
sometimes
thought
,
and
now
thought
again
as
she
retraced
her
steps
up
the
staircase
,
that
he
had
made
his
way
too
easily
into
her
father
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
so
many
and
such
varieties
of
people
did
the
same
,
through
Mr
Dorrit
's
participation
in
his
elder
daughter
's
society
mania
,
that
it
was
hardly
an
exceptional
case
.
<EOS>
A
perfect
fury
for
making
acquaintances
on
whom
to
impress
their
riches
and
importance
,
had
seized
the
House
of
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
on
the
whole
,
to
Little
Dorrit
herself
,
that
this
same
society
in
which
they
lived
,
greatly
resembled
a
superior
sort
of
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
Numbers
of
people
seemed
to
come
abroad
,
pretty
much
as
people
had
come
into
the
prison
;
through
debt
,
through
idleness
,
relationship
,
curiosity
,
and
general
unfitness
for
getting
on
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
brought
into
these
foreign
towns
in
the
custody
of
couriers
and
local
followers
,
just
as
the
debtors
had
been
brought
into
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
They
prowled
about
the
churches
and
picture
-
galleries
,
much
in
the
old
,
dreary
,
prison
-
yard
manner
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
usually
going
away
again
to
-
morrow
or
next
week
,
and
rarely
knew
their
own
minds
,
and
seldom
did
what
they
said
they
would
do
,
or
went
where
they
said
they
would
go
:
in
all
this
again
,
very
like
the
prison
debtors
.
 
<EOS>
They
paid
high
for
poor
accommodation
,
and
disparaged
a
place
while
they
pretended
to
like
it
:
which
was
exactly
the
Marshalsea
custom
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
envied
when
they
went
away
by
people
left
behind
,
feigning
not
to
want
to
go
:
and
that
again
was
the
Marshalsea
habit
invariably
.
 
<EOS>
A
certain
set
of
words
and
phrases
,
as
much
belonging
to
tourists
as
the
College
and
the
Snuggery
belonged
to
the
jail
,
was
always
in
their
mouths
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
precisely
the
same
incapacity
for
settling
down
to
anything
,
as
the
prisoners
used
to
have
;
they
rather
deteriorated
one
another
,
as
the
prisoners
used
to
do
;
and
they
wore
untidy
dresses
,
and
fell
into
a
slouching
way
of
life
:
still
,
always
like
the
people
in
the
Marshalsea
.
   
<EOS>
The
period
of
the
family
's
stay
at
Venice
came
,
in
its
course
,
to
an
end
,
and
they
moved
,
with
their
retinue
,
to
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
Through
a
repetition
of
the
former
Italian
scenes
,
growing
more
dirty
and
more
haggard
as
they
went
on
,
and
bringing
them
at
length
to
where
the
very
air
was
diseased
,
they
passed
to
their
destination
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
residence
had
been
taken
for
them
on
the
Corso
,
and
there
they
took
up
their
abode
,
in
a
city
where
everything
seemed
to
be
trying
to
stand
still
for
ever
on
the
ruins
of
something
else
---
except
the
water
,
which
,
following
eternal
laws
,
tumbled
and
rolled
from
its
glorious
multitude
of
fountains
.
   
<EOS>
Here
it
seemed
to
Little
Dorrit
that
a
change
came
over
the
Marshalsea
spirit
of
their
society
,
and
that
Prunes
and
Prism
got
the
upper
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
was
walking
about
St
Peter
's
and
the
Vatican
on
somebody
else
's
cork
legs
,
and
straining
every
visible
object
through
somebody
else
's
sieve
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
said
what
anything
was
,
but
everybody
said
what
the
Mrs
Generals
,
Mr
Eustace
,
or
somebody
else
said
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
body
of
travellers
seemed
to
be
a
collection
of
voluntary
human
sacrifices
,
bound
hand
and
foot
,
and
delivered
over
to
Mr
Eustace
and
his
attendants
,
to
have
the
entrails
of
their
intellects
arranged
according
to
the
taste
of
that
sacred
priesthood
.
 
<EOS>
Through
the
rugged
remains
of
temples
and
tombs
and
palaces
and
senate
halls
and
theatres
and
amphitheatres
of
ancient
days
,
hosts
of
tongue
-
tied
and
blindfolded
moderns
were
carefully
feeling
their
way
,
incessantly
repeating
Prunes
and
Prism
in
the
endeavour
to
set
their
lips
according
to
the
received
form
.
<EOS>
Mrs
General
was
in
her
pure
element
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
had
an
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
formation
of
surface
going
on
around
her
on
an
amazing
scale
,
and
it
had
not
a
flaw
of
courage
or
honest
free
speech
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
Another
modification
of
Prunes
and
Prism
insinuated
itself
on
Little
Dorrit
's
notice
very
shortly
after
their
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
They
received
an
early
visit
from
Mrs
Merdle
,
who
led
that
extensive
department
of
life
in
the
Eternal
City
that
winter
;
and
the
skilful
manner
in
which
she
and
Fanny
fenced
with
one
another
on
the
occasion
,
almost
made
her
quiet
sister
wink
,
like
the
glittering
of
small
-
swords
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
delighted
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
to
resume
an
acquaintance
so
inauspiciously
begun
at
Martigny
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
At
Martigny
,
of
course
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Charmed
,
I
am
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
from
my
son
Edmund
Sparkler
,
that
he
has
already
improved
that
chance
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
returned
quite
transported
with
Venice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
"
returned
the
careless
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Was
he
there
long
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
might
refer
that
question
to
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
turning
the
bosom
towards
that
gentleman
;
"
Edmund
having
been
so
much
indebted
to
him
for
rendering
his
stay
agreeable
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
pray
do
n't
speak
of
it
,
"
returned
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
Papa
had
the
pleasure
of
inviting
Mr
Sparkler
twice
or
thrice
,
---
but
it
was
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
so
many
people
about
us
,
and
kept
such
open
house
,
that
if
he
had
that
pleasure
,
it
was
less
than
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
except
---
ha
---
as
it
afforded
me
unusual
gratification
to
---
hum
---
show
by
any
means
,
however
slight
and
worthless
,
the
---
ha
,
hum
---
high
estimation
in
which
,
in
---
ha
---
common
with
the
rest
of
the
world
,
I
hold
so
distinguished
and
princely
a
character
as
Mr
Merdle
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
bosom
received
this
tribute
in
its
most
engaging
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Merdle
,
"
observed
Fanny
,
as
a
means
of
dismissing
Mr
Sparkler
into
the
background
,
"
is
quite
a
theme
of
Papa
's
,
you
must
know
,
Mrs
Merdle
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
---
ha
---
disappointed
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
to
understand
from
Mr
Sparkler
that
there
is
no
great
---
hum
---
probability
of
Mr
Merdle
's
coming
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
indeed
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
he
is
so
much
engaged
and
in
such
request
,
<EOS>
that
I
fear
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
not
been
able
to
get
abroad
for
years
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
Miss
Dorrit
<EOS>
,
I
believe
have
been
almost
continually
abroad
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
<EOS>
yes
,
"
drawled
Fanny
,
with
the
greatest
hardihood
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
immense
number
of
years
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
should
have
inferred
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
,
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
trust
,
however
,
"
resumed
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
that
if
I
have
not
the
---
hum
---
great
advantage
of
becoming
known
to
Mr
Merdle
on
this
side
of
the
Alps
or
Mediterranean
,
I
shall
have
that
honour
on
returning
to
England
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
honour
I
particularly
desire
and
shall
particularly
esteem
.
"
<EOS>
"
Mr
Merdle
,
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
,
who
had
been
looking
admiringly
at
Fanny
through
her
eye
-
glass
,
"
will
esteem
it
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
no
less
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
still
habitually
thoughtful
and
solitary
though
no
longer
alone
,
at
first
supposed
this
to
be
mere
Prunes
and
Prism
.
<EOS>
But
as
her
father
when
they
had
been
to
a
brilliant
reception
at
Mrs
Merdle
's
,
harped
at
their
own
family
breakfast
-
table
on
his
wish
to
know
Mr
Merdle
,
with
the
contingent
view
of
benefiting
by
the
advice
of
that
wonderful
man
in
the
disposal
of
his
fortune
,
she
began
to
think
it
had
a
real
meaning
,
and
to
entertain
a
curiosity
on
her
own
part
to
see
the
shining
light
of
the
time
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
08
.
<EOS>
The
Dowager
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
is
reminded
that
"
It
Never
Does
"
 
While
the
waters
of
Venice
and
the
ruins
of
Rome
were
sunning
themselves
for
the
pleasure
of
the
Dorrit
family
,
and
were
daily
being
sketched
out
of
all
earthly
proportion
,
lineament
,
and
likeness
,
by
travelling
pencils
innumerable
,
the
firm
of
Doyce
and
Clennam
hammered
away
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
and
the
vigorous
clink
of
iron
upon
iron
was
heard
there
through
the
working
hours
.
   
<EOS>
The
younger
partner
had
,
by
this
time
,
brought
the
business
into
sound
trim
;
and
the
elder
,
left
free
to
follow
his
own
ingenious
devices
,
had
done
much
to
enhance
the
character
of
the
factory
.
 
<EOS>
As
an
ingenious
man
,
he
had
necessarily
to
encounter
every
discouragement
that
the
ruling
powers
for
a
length
of
time
had
been
able
by
any
means
to
put
in
the
way
of
this
class
of
culprits
;
but
that
was
only
reasonable
self
-
defence
in
the
powers
,
since
How
to
do
it
must
obviously
be
regarded
as
the
natural
and
mortal
enemy
of
How
not
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
was
to
be
found
the
basis
of
the
wise
system
,
by
tooth
and
nail
upheld
by
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
of
warning
every
ingenious
British
subject
to
be
ingenious
at
his
peril
:
of
harassing
him
,
obstructing
him
,
inviting
robbers
(
by
making
his
remedy
uncertain
,
and
expensive
)
to
plunder
him
,
and
at
the
best
of
confiscating
his
property
after
a
short
term
of
enjoyment
,
as
though
invention
were
on
a
par
with
felony
.
 
<EOS>
The
system
had
uniformly
found
great
favour
with
the
Barnacles
,
and
that
was
only
reasonable
,
too
;
for
one
who
worthily
invents
must
be
in
earnest
,
and
the
Barnacles
abhorred
and
dreaded
nothing
half
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
That
again
was
very
reasonable
;
since
in
a
country
suffering
under
the
affliction
of
a
great
amount
of
earnestness
,
there
might
,
in
an
exceeding
short
space
of
time
,
be
not
a
single
Barnacle
left
sticking
to
a
post
.
   
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
faced
his
condition
with
its
pains
and
penalties
attached
to
it
,
and
soberly
worked
on
for
the
work
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
cheering
him
with
a
hearty
co
-
operation
,
was
a
moral
support
to
him
,
besides
doing
good
service
in
his
business
relation
.
 
<EOS>
The
concern
prospered
,
and
the
partners
were
fast
friends
.
<EOS>
But
Daniel
could
not
forget
the
old
design
of
so
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
reason
to
be
expected
that
he
should
;
if
he
could
have
lightly
forgotten
it
,
he
could
never
have
conceived
it
,
or
had
the
patience
and
perseverance
to
work
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
So
Clennam
thought
,
when
he
sometimes
observed
him
of
an
evening
looking
over
the
models
and
drawings
,
and
consoling
himself
by
muttering
with
a
sigh
as
he
put
them
away
again
,
that
the
thing
was
as
true
as
it
ever
was
.
   
<EOS>
To
show
no
sympathy
with
so
much
endeavour
,
and
so
much
disappointment
,
would
have
been
to
fail
in
what
Clennam
regarded
as
among
the
implied
obligations
of
his
partnership
.
 
<EOS>
A
revival
of
the
passing
interest
in
the
subject
which
had
been
by
chance
awakened
at
the
door
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
originated
in
this
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
his
partner
to
explain
the
invention
to
him
;
"
having
a
lenient
consideration
,
"
he
stipulated
,
"
for
my
being
no
workman
,
Doyce
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
workman
?
<EOS>
"
said
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
have
been
a
thorough
workman
if
you
had
given
yourself
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
as
good
a
head
for
understanding
such
things
as
I
have
met
with
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
totally
uneducated
one
,
I
am
sorry
to
add
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
,
"
returned
Doyce
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
you
say
that
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
of
sense
who
has
been
generally
improved
,
and
has
improved
himself
,
can
be
called
quite
uneducated
as
to
anything
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
particularly
favour
mysteries
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
as
soon
,
on
a
fair
and
clear
explanation
,
be
judged
by
one
class
of
man
as
another
,
<EOS>
provided
he
had
the
qualification
I
have
named
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
"
said
Clennam
---
"
<EOS>
this
sounds
as
if
we
were
exchanging

,
but
we
know
we
are
not
<EOS>
---
I
shall
have
the
advantage
of
as
plain
an
explanation
as
can
be
given
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Daniel
,
in
his
steady
even
way
,
"
I
'll
try
to
make
it
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
the
power
,
often
to
be
found
in
union
with
such
a
character
,
of
explaining
what
he
himself
perceived
,
and
meant
,
with
the
direct
force
and
distinctness
with
which
it
struck
his
own
mind
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
of
demonstration
was
so
orderly
and
neat
and
simple
,
that
it
was
not
easy
to
mistake
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
something
almost
ludicrous
in
the
complete
irreconcilability
of
a
vague
conventional
notion
that
he
must
be
a
visionary
man
,
with
the
precise
,
sagacious
travelling
of
his
eye
and
thumb
over
the
plans
,
their
patient
stoppages
at
particular
points
,
their
careful
returns
to
other
points
whence
little
channels
of
explanation
had
to
be
traced
up
,
and
his
steady
manner
of
making
everything
good
and
everything
sound
at
each
important
stage
,
before
taking
his
hearer
on
a
line's
-
breadth
further
.
 
<EOS>
His
dismissal
of
himself
from
his
description
,
was
hardly
less
remarkable
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
said
,
I
discovered
this
adaptation
or
invented
that
combination
;
but
showed
the
whole
thing
as
if
the
Divine
artificer
had
made
it
,
and
he
had
happened
to
find
it
;
so
modest
he
was
about
it
,
such
a
pleasant
touch
of
respect
was
mingled
with
his
quiet
admiration
of
it
,
and
so
calmly
convinced
he
was
that
it
was
established
on
irrefragable
laws
.
   
<EOS>
Not
only
that
evening
,
but
for
several
succeeding
evenings
,
Clennam
was
quite
charmed
by
this
investigation
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
he
pursued
it
,
and
the
oftener
he
glanced
at
the
grey
head
bending
over
it
,
and
the
shrewd
eye
kindling
with
pleasure
in
it
and
love
of
it
---
instrument
for
probing
his
heart
though
it
had
been
made
for
twelve
long
years
---
the
less
he
could
reconcile
it
to
his
younger
energy
to
let
it
go
without
one
effort
more
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
said
:
   
"
Doyce
,
it
came
to
this
at
last
---
that
the
business
was
to
be
sunk
with
Heaven
<EOS>
knows
how
many
more
wrecks
,
or
begun
all
over
again
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
Doyce
,
"
that
's
what
the
noblemen
and
gentlemen
made
of
it
after
a
dozen
years
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
pretty
fellows
too
!
"
said
Clennam
,
bitterly
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
usual
thing
!
<EOS>
"
observed
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
not
make
a
martyr
of
myself
,
when
I
am
one
of
so
large
a
company
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Relinquish
it
,
or
begin
it
all
over
again
?
"
mused
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
exactly
the
long
and
the
short
of
it
,
"
said
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
my
friend
,
"
cried
Clennam
,
starting
up
and
taking
his
work
-
roughened
hand
,
"
it
shall
be
begun
all
over
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
Doyce
looked
alarmed
,
and
replied
in
a
hurry
---
for
him
,
"
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
Better
put
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
Far
better
put
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
heard
of
,
one
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
put
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
You
forget
,
my
good
Clennam
;
I
HAVE
put
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Doyce
,
"
returned
Clennam
,
"
at
an
end
as
far
as
your
efforts
and
rebuffs
are
concerned
,
I
admit
,
but
not
as
far
as
mine
are
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
younger
than
you
:
<EOS>
I
have
only
once
set
foot
in
that
precious
office
,
and
I
am
fresh
game
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
try
them
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
do
exactly
as
you
have
been
doing
since
we
have
been
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
add
(
as
I
easily
can
)
to
what
I
have
been
doing
,
the
attempt
to
get
public
justice
done
to
you
;
and
,
unless
I
have
some
success
to
report
,
you
shall
hear
no
more
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
was
still
reluctant
to
consent
,
and
again
and
again
urged
that
they
had
better
put
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
natural
that
he
should
gradually
allow
himself
to
be
over
-
persuaded
by
Clennam
,
and
should
yield
.
 
<EOS>
Yield
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
So
Arthur
resumed
the
long
and
hopeless
labour
of
striving
to
make
way
with
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
   
<EOS>
The
waiting
-
rooms
of
that
Department
soon
began
to
be
familiar
with
his
presence
,
and
he
was
generally
ushered
into
them
by
its
janitors
much
as
a
pickpocket
might
be
shown
into
a
police
-
office
;
the
principal
difference
being
that
the
object
of
the
latter
class
of
public
business
is
to
keep
the
pickpocket
,
while
the
Circumlocution
object
was
to
get
rid
of
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
was
resolved
to
stick
to
the
Great
Department
;
and
so
the
work
of
form
-
filling
,
corresponding
,
minuting
,
memorandum
-
making
,
signing
,
counter
-
signing
,
counter
-
counter
-
signing
,
referring
backwards
and
forwards
,
and
referring
sideways
,
crosswise
,
and
zig
-
zag
,
recommenced
.
   
<EOS>
Here
arises
a
feature
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
not
previously
mentioned
in
the
present
record
.
 
<EOS>
When
that
admirable
Department
got
into
trouble
,
and
was
,
by
some
infuriated
members
of
Parliament
whom
the
smaller
Barnacles
almost
suspected
of
labouring
under
diabolic
possession
,
attacked
on
the
merits
of
no
individual
case
,
but
as
an
Institution
wholly
abominable
and
Bedlamite
;
then
the
noble
or
right
honourable
Barnacle
who
represented
it
in
the
House
,
would
smite
that
member
and
cleave
him
asunder
,
with
a
statement
of
the
quantity
of
business
(
for
the
prevention
of
business
)
done
by
the
Circumlocution
Office
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
that
noble
or
right
honourable
Barnacle
hold
in
his
hand
a
paper
containing
a
few
figures
,
to
which
,
with
the
permission
of
the
House
,
he
would
entreat
its
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
the
inferior
Barnacles
exclaim
,
obeying
orders
,
"
Hear
,
Hear
,
Hear
!
"
and
"
Read
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
would
the
noble
or
right
honourable
Barnacle
perceive
,
sir
,
from
this
little
document
,
which
he
thought
might
carry
conviction
even
to
the
perversest
mind
(
Derisive
laughter
and
cheering
from
the
Barnacle
fry
)
,
that
within
the
short
compass
of
the
last
financial
half
-
year
,
this
much
-
maligned
Department
(
Cheers
)
had
written
and
received
fifteen
thousand
letters
(
Loud
cheers
)
,
had
written
twenty
-
four
thousand
minutes
(
Louder
cheers
)
,
and
thirty
-
two
thousand
five
hundred
and
seventeen
memoranda
(
Vehement
cheering
)
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
an
ingenious
gentleman
connected
with
the
Department
,
and
himself
a
valuable
public
servant
,
had
done
him
the
favour
to
make
a
curious
calculation
of
the
amount
of
stationery
consumed
in
it
during
the
same
period
.
 
<EOS>
It
formed
a
part
of
this
same
short
document
;
and
he
derived
from
it
the
remarkable
fact
that
the
sheets
of
foolscap
paper
it
had
devoted
to
the
public
service
would
pave
the
footways
on
both
sides
of
Oxford
Street
from
end
to
end
,
and
leave
nearly
a
quarter
of
a
mile
to
spare
for
the
park
(
Immense
cheering
and
laughter
)
;
while
of
tape
---
red
tape
---
it
had
used
enough
to
stretch
,
in
graceful
festoons
,
from
Hyde
Park
Corner
to
the
General
Post
Office
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
amidst
a
burst
of
official
exultation
,
would
the
noble
or
right
honourable
Barnacle
sit
down
,
leaving
the
mutilated
fragments
of
the
Member
on
the
field
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
,
after
that
exemplary
demolition
of
him
,
would
have
the
hardihood
to
hint
that
the
more
the
Circumlocution
Office
did
,
the
less
was
done
,
and
that
the
greatest
blessing
it
could
confer
on
an
unhappy
public
would
be
to
do
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
With
sufficient
occupation
on
his
hands
,
now
that
he
had
this
additional
task
---
such
a
task
had
many
and
many
a
serviceable
man
died
of
before
his
day
---
Arthur
Clennam
led
a
life
of
slight
variety
.
 
<EOS>
Regular
visits
to
his
mother
's
dull
sick
room
,
and
visits
scarcely
less
regular
to
Mr
Meagles
at
Twickenham
,
were
its
only
changes
during
many
months
.
   
<EOS>
He
sadly
and
sorely
missed
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
prepared
to
miss
her
very
much
,
but
not
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
to
the
full
extent
only
through
experience
,
what
a
large
place
in
his
life
was
left
blank
when
her
familiar
little
figure
went
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
,
too
,
that
he
must
relinquish
the
hope
of
its
return
,
understanding
the
family
character
sufficiently
well
to
be
assured
that
he
and
she
were
divided
by
a
broad
ground
of
separation
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
interest
he
had
had
in
her
,
and
her
old
trusting
reliance
on
him
,
were
tinged
with
melancholy
in
his
mind
:
so
soon
had
change
stolen
over
them
,
and
so
soon
had
they
glided
into
the
past
with
other
secret
tendernesses
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
received
her
letter
he
was
greatly
moved
,
but
did
not
the
less
sensibly
feel
that
she
was
far
divided
from
him
by
more
than
distance
.
 
<EOS>
It
helped
him
to
a
clearer
and
keener
perception
of
the
place
assigned
him
by
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
he
was
cherished
in
her
grateful
remembrance
secretly
,
and
that
they
resented
him
with
the
jail
and
the
rest
of
its
belongings
.
   
<EOS>
Through
all
these
meditations
which
every
day
of
his
life
crowded
about
her
,
he
thought
of
her
otherwise
in
the
old
way
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
his
innocent
friend
,
his
delicate
child
,
his
dear
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
This
very
change
of
circumstances
fitted
curiously
in
with
the
habit
,
begun
on
the
night
when
the
roses
floated
away
,
of
considering
himself
as
a
much
older
man
than
his
years
really
made
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
regarded
her
from
a
point
of
view
which
in
its
remoteness
,
tender
as
it
was
,
he
little
thought
would
have
been
unspeakable
agony
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
speculated
about
her
future
destiny
,
and
about
the
husband
she
might
have
,
with
an
affection
for
her
which
would
have
drained
her
heart
of
its
dearest
drop
of
hope
,
and
broken
it
.
   
<EOS>
Everything
about
him
tended
to
confirm
him
in
the
custom
of
looking
on
himself
as
an
elderly
man
,
from
whom
such
aspirations
as
he
had
combated
in
the
case
of
Minnie
Gowan
(
though
that
was
not
so
long
ago
either
,
reckoning
by
months
and
seasons
)
,
were
finally
departed
.
 
<EOS>
His
relations
with
her
father
and
mother
were
like
those
on
which
a
widower
son
-
in
-
law
might
have
stood
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
twin
sister
who
was
dead
had
lived
to
pass
away
in
the
bloom
of
womanhood
,
and
he
had
been
her
husband
,
the
nature
of
his
intercourse
with
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
would
probably
have
been
just
what
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
This
imperceptibly
helped
to
render
habitual
the
impression
within
him
,
that
he
had
done
with
,
and
dismissed
that
part
of
life
.
   
<EOS>
He
invariably
heard
of
Minnie
from
them
,
as
telling
them
in
her
letters
how
happy
she
was
,
and
how
she
loved
her
husband
;
but
inseparable
from
that
subject
,
he
invariably
saw
the
old
cloud
on
Mr
Meagles
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
had
never
been
quite
so
radiant
since
the
marriage
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
quite
recovered
the
separation
from
Pet
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
same
good
-
humoured
,
open
creature
;
but
as
if
his
face
,
from
being
much
turned
towards
the
pictures
of
his
two
children
which
could
show
him
only
one
look
,
unconsciously
adopted
a
characteristic
from
them
,
it
always
had
now
,
through
all
its
changes
of
expression
,
a
look
of
loss
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
One
wintry
Saturday
when
Clennam
was
at
the
cottage
,
the
Dowager
Mrs
Gowan
drove
up
,
in
the
Hampton
Court
equipage
which
pretended
to
be
the
exclusive
equipage
of
so
many
individual
proprietors
.
<EOS>
She
descended
,
in
her
shady
ambuscade
of
green
fan
,
to
favour
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
with
a
call
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
both
do
,
Papa
and
Mama
Meagles
?
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
encouraging
her
humble
connections
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
when
did
you
last
hear
from
or
about
my
poor
fellow
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
poor
fellow
was
her
son
;
and
this
mode
of
speaking
of
him
politely
kept
alive
,
without
any
offence
in
the
world
,
the
pretence
that
he
had
fallen
a
victim
to
the
Meagles
'
wiles
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
dear
pretty
one
?
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
later
news
of
her
than
I
have
?
"
   
<EOS>
Which
also
delicately
implied
that
her
son
had
been
captured
by
mere
beauty
,
and
under
its
fascination
had
forgone
all
sorts
of
worldly
advantages
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
without
straining
her
attention
on
the
answers
she
received
,
"
it
's
an
unspeakable
comfort
to
know
they
continue
happy
.
 
<EOS>
My
poor
fellow
is
of
such
a
restless
disposition
,
and
has
been
so
used
to
roving
about
,
and
to
being
inconstant
and
popular
among
all
manner
of
people
,
that
it
's
the
greatest
comfort
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
they
're
as
poor
as
mice
,
Papa
Meagles
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
fidgety
under
the
question
,
replied
,
"
I
hope
not
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
they
will
manage
their
little
income
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
my
dearest
Meagles
!
"
returned
the
lady
,
tapping
him
on
the
arm
with
the
green
fan
and
then
adroitly
interposing
it
between
a

and
the
company
,
"
how
can
you
,
as
a
man
of
the
world
and
one

most
business
-
like
of
human

---
for
you
know
you
are
business
-
like
,
and
a
great
deal
too
much
for
us
who
are
not
---
"
   
<EOS>
(
Which
went
to
the
former
purpose
,
by
making
Mr
Meagles
out
to
be
an
artful
schemer
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
---
How
can
you
talk
about
their
managing
their
little
means
?
 
<EOS>
My
poor
dear
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
his
managing
hundreds
!
 
<EOS>
And
the
sweet
pretty
creature
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
notion
of
her
managing
!
 
<EOS>
Papa
Meagles
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
gravely
,
"
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
to
admit
,
then
,
that
Henry
certainly
does
anticipate
his
means
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
good
man
---
I
use
no
ceremony
with
you
,
because
we
are
a
kind
of
relations
;
---
positively
,
Mama
Meagles
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs
Gowan
cheerfully
,
as
if
the
absurd
coincidence
then
flashed
upon
her
for
the
first

,
"
a
kind
of
relations
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
good
man
,
in
this
world
none
of
us
can
have
everything
our
own
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
again
went
to
the
former
point
,
and
showed
Mr
Meagles
with
all
good
breeding
that
,
so
far
,
he
had
been
brilliantly
successful
in
his
deep
designs
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
thought
the
hit
so
good
<EOS>
a
one
,
that
she
dwelt
upon
it
<EOS>
;
repeating
"
Not
everything
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
in
this
world
we
must
not
expect
everything
,
Papa
Meagles
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
may
I
ask
,
ma'am
,
"
retorted
Mr
Meagles
,
a
little

in

,
"
who
does
expect
everything
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nobody
,
nobody
!
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
say
---
but
you
put
me

.
 
<EOS>
You
interrupting
Papa
,
what
was
I
going
to
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
Drooping
her
large
green
fan
,
she
looked

at
Mr
Meagles
while
she
thought
about
it
;
a
performance
not
tending
to
the
cooling
of
that
gentleman
's
rather
heated

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
be
sure
!
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
remember
that
my
poor
fellow
has
always
been
accustomed

expectations
.
 
<EOS>
They
may
have
been
realised
,
or

not

---
"
   
"
Let

say
,

,
may
not

,
"

Mr

.
   
<EOS>
The

for

gave

an

;
but
tossed

with

,

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
makes
no
difference
.
 
<EOS>
My
poor
fellow
has
been
accustomed
to
that
sort
of
thing
,
and
of
course
you

it
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
myself
always
clearly
foresaw
the
consequences
,
and
am
not
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
must
not
be
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
ca
n't
be
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
Must
have
been
prepared
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
looked
at
his
wife
and
at
Clennam
;
bit

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now

's
my
poor
fellow
,
"
Mrs

,
"
receiving

he

to

in

of
a

,
and
all

attendant
on
such

!
 
<EOS>
Poor
Henry
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
ca
n't
be
helped
now
;
it
's
too
late
to

now
.
<EOS>
Only
do

,

Meagles
,
as

discovery
;

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too

,

?
"
said

Meagles
,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,

!
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Too

's

.
 
<EOS>
They

fast

,

ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
There
,
there
!
 
<EOS>
I
know

!
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
tell

,
Papa
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
What
was
it
<EOS>
I
said

?
 
<EOS>
That

comfort
they
continued

.
 
<EOS>
It

will

.
 
<EOS>
It

Pretty
One
will

,

.
 
<EOS>
Papa

Mama
Meagles
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
,

!
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
Truly
,
having
by
this

everything

in

,

that

of

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Meagles
had
submitted
to
a

from
Mrs
Meagles
,
and

from
Clennam
,
he
would
have
left
her
in
the

of
this

.
 
<EOS>
But
Pet
was
the
darling
and
pride
of
his
heart
;
and
if
he
could
ever
have
championed
her
more

,

,
than
in

when
she
was
the
sunlight
of
his

,
it
would
have
been
now
,
when
,
as
its
daily
grace
and

,
she
was
lost
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Gowan
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
I
have
been
a
plain
man
all
my

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
to
try
---
no

whether
on

,

else
,
or
both
---
any
genteel
mystifications
,
I
should
probably
not
succeed
in
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
Meagles
,
"
returned
the
Dowager
,
with
an

,
but
with
the
bloom

her

standing
out

usual
as
the
neighbouring
surface
became

,
"
probably

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
my

madam
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
at

,
"
I

,

,
ask

played
off

.
"
<EOS>
"
Mama
Meagles
,
"
observed
Mrs
Gowan
,
"
your
good
man
is
incomprehensible
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
turning
to
that
worthy
lady
was
an
artifice
to
bring
her
into
the
discussion
,
quarrel

her
,
and
vanquish

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
interposed
to
prevent
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
said
he
,
"
you
are
inexpert
,
my
dear
,
and
it
is

.
 
<EOS>
Let
me

you
to
remain
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
Mrs
Gowan
,
come
!
<EOS>
Let
us
try
to
be
sensible
;
let
us

to
be
good

;
let
us

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
pity
Henry
,
and
I
wo
n't
pity
<EOS>
Pet
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
be
one
-
sided
,
<EOS>
my
dear
madam
;
it
's
not
considerate
,
it
's
not

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
us
say
that
we
hope
Pet
will
make
Henry
happy
,
or
even
that
we
hope
Henry
will
make
Pet
happy
,
"
(
Mr
Meagles
himself
did
not

as
he
spoke

words
,
)
<EOS>
"
but
let
us
hope

will
make

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
and
there
leave

,
father
,
"
said
Mrs
Meagles
the
kind

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
mother
,
no
,
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
,
"
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
quite

it
there
;
I
must
say
just

-

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gowan
,
I
hope
I
am
not
over
-
sensitive
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
do

look

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed

do

,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,

great

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

a

---

---

hurt
?
"
asked
Mr
Meagles
at

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Say

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

,
"

Meagles
,
"
because
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
I

to

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

,
"

,
"
for

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
that

state
---
"
   
"
Now
,

Meagles
,
Papa

,
"

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

state
---
<EOS>
not

,
<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Arthur
!
 
<EOS>
Do

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

"

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
Some

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

O
,

"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

---
"
That

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

I

,
"

,

by

,
"

,
more

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

attributed

my

here
,
in

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

(
as

)
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
?
 
<EOS>
Very

!
 
<EOS>
Now
Papa
and
Mama
Meagles
both
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
here

;
"
allow
me

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
another
word
upon
its

.
 
<EOS>
I
will
only
say
that
it
is
an
additional

of
what
one

all

;
that
this

never

---
as

fellow
himself
would

,
that

never

---
in

,

never

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles

,
What
kind

?
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
in

,
"
said
Mrs
Gowan
,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,
"
Permit

,

---
"
   
"
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why

!
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

,
and

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

never
does
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Dowager
here

,
rather

any

,

therewith

.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
stepped

to
the
Pill
-
Box
which
was
at
the
service
of
all

in
Hampton
Court

;
and
she
got

with

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Thenceforth
the
Dowager
,
with
a
light
and
careless

,
often
recounted
to
her
particular
acquaintance
how
,
after
a
hard
trial
,
she
had
found
it
impossible
to
know
those
people
who
belonged
to
Henry
's
wife
,
and
who
had
made
that
desperate
set
to
catch
him
.
<EOS>
Whether
she
had
come
to
the
conclusion
beforehand
,
that
to
get
rid
of
them
would
give
her
favourite
pretence
a
better
air
,
might
save
her
some
occasional

,
and
could
risk
no
loss
(
the
pretty
creature
being
fast
married
,
and
her
father
devoted
to
her
)
,
was
best
known
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Though
this
history
has
its
opinion
on
that
point
too
,
and
decidedly
in
the
affirmative
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
09
.
<EOS>
Appearance
and
Disappearance
 
"
Arthur
,
my
dear
boy
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
on
the
evening
of
the
following
day
,
"
Mother
and
I
have
been
talking
this
over
,
and
we
do
n't
feel
comfortable
in
remaining
as
we
are
.
 
<EOS>
That
elegant
connection
of
ours
---
that
dear
lady
who
was
here
yesterday
---
"
   
"
I
understand
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
that
affable
and
condescending
ornament
of
society
,
"
pursued
Mr
Meagles
,
"
may
misrepresent
us
,
we
are
afraid
.
 
<EOS>
We
could
bear
a
great
deal
,
Arthur
,
for
her
sake
;
but
we
think
we
would
rather
not
bear
that
,
if
it
was
all
the
same
to
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
proceeded
Mr
Meagles
<EOS>
"
it
might
put
us
wrong
with
our
son
-
in
-
law
,
it
might
even
put
us
wrong
with
our
daughter
,
and
it
might
lead
to
a
great
deal
of
domestic
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
,
do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
,
"
returned
Arthur
,
"
there
is
much
reason
in
what
you
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
glanced
at
Mrs
Meagles
,
who
was
always
on
the
good
and
sensible
side
;
and
a
petition
had
shone
out
of
her
honest
face
that
he
would
support
Mr
Meagles
in
his
present
inclinings
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
we
are
very
much
disposed
,
are
Mother
and
I
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
to
pack
up
bags
and
baggage
and
go
among
the
Allongers
and
Marshongers
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
,
we
are
very
much
disposed
to
be
off
,
strike
right
through
France
into
Italy
,
and
see
our
Pet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't
think
,
"
replied
Arthur
,
touched
by
the
motherly
anticipation
in
the
bright

of
Mrs
Meagles
<EOS>
(
she
must
have
been
very
like
her
daughter
,
once
)
,
"
that
you
could
do
better
.
 
<EOS>
And
if
you
ask
me
for
my
advice
,
it
is
that
you
set
off
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
really
,
though
?
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
this
is
being
backed
in
an
idea
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mother
,
with
a
look
which
thanked
Clennam
in
a
manner
very
agreeable
to
him
,
answered
that
it
was
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
besides
,
Arthur
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
the
old
cloud
coming
over
his
face
,
"
that
my
son
-
in
-
law
is
already
in
debt
again
,
and
that
I
suppose
I
must
clear
him
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
as
well
,
even
on
this
account
,
that
I
should
step
over
there
,
and
look
him
up
in
a
friendly
way
.
 
<EOS>
Then
again
,
here
's
Mother
foolishly
anxious
(
and
yet
naturally
too
)
about
Pet
's
state
of
health
,
and
that
she
should
not
be
left
to
feel
lonesome
at
the
present
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
undeniably
a
long
way
off
,
Arthur
,
and
a
strange
place
for
the
poor
love
under
all
the
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Let
her
be
as
well
cared
for
as
any
lady
in
that
land
,
still
it
is
a
long
way
off
.
 
<EOS>
just
as
Home
is
Home
though
it
's
never
<EOS>
so
Homely
,
why
you
see
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
adding
a
new
version
to
the
proverb
,
"
Rome
is
Rome
,
though
it
's
never
so
Romely
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
perfectly
true
,
"
observed
Arthur
,
"
and
all
sufficient
reasons
for
going
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
think
so
;
it
decides
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mother
,
my
dear
,
you
may
get
ready
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
lost
our
pleasant
interpreter
<EOS>
(
she
spoke
three
foreign
languages
<EOS>
beautifully
,
Arthur
;
you
have
heard
her
many
a
time
)
,
and
you
must
pull
me
through
it
,
Mother
,
as
well
as
you
can
.
   
<EOS>
I
require
a
deal
of
pulling
through
,
Arthur
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
a
deal
of
pulling
through
.
 
<EOS>
I
stick
at
everything

-

---
<EOS>
and
I
stick
at

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,
"
there
's
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I

boy
,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
Cavallooro
(
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

"
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
They
agreed
that
the

;

Clennam

,

to
Henry

when

With
;

.
<EOS>
Clennam
did

of

upon

,

and

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Within

for

in

---
or

,

---

Father

,
Mrs

,

,

,

's

.
   
<EOS>
As
he
had
a

,
he
seldom

.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
he
went
down
alone
from
Saturday

;
sometimes

;
sometimes

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
On

"

"

<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

"

"

<EOS>

Coram

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
   
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Exactly
.
 
<EOS>
Well

"

.
 
<EOS>
just

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
a

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You

so

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

;
thoughts

!
<EOS>
---

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
He

?
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

,

between

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
Without

,

;

.
<EOS>
He
was

Strand
,

-

was

,

the

-

,

by

,
burst

one

another
,
like
<EOS>
so

coming

-

,
---

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
and

some

,
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
Immediately
,

saw

---
a

,
but

so

---
Tattycoram
and
a

of

:
a

,

,

as

,

.
 
<EOS>
His

were

a
man
on

,
and

have
very
recently
joined
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
In

down
(
being
much

)
,
listening

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

saw

face
;
as

on
the

in

,
without

Clennam
's

.
   
<EOS>
He
had

,
and

,

girl
,

ceased
,
and

obstructed
stream
of

.
 
<EOS>
Still

and

girl
,

,
and
Clennam

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
He
had
hardly

the

(
though

)
,
when

was

as

.
 
<EOS>
They
turned
short
into
the
Adelphi
,
---
the
girl
evidently
leading
,
---
and
went
straight

,
as
if

were
going
to
the
Terrace
which
overhangs
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
always
,
to
this
day
,
a
sudden
pause
in
that
place
to
the
roar
of
the
great
thoroughfare
.
 
<EOS>
The
many
sounds
become
so
deadened
that
the
change
is
like
putting
cotton
in
the
ears
,
or
having
the
head
thickly
muffled
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
time
the
contrast
was
far
greater
;
there
being
no
small
steam
-
boats
on
the
river
,
no
landing
places
but
slippery

stairs
and
foot
-

,
no

on
the
opposite
bank
,
no
hanging
bridge
or
fish
-
market
near
at
hand
,
no
traffic
on
the
nearest
bridge
of
stone
,
nothing
moving
on
the
stream
<EOS>
but
watermen
's
wherries
and
coal
-
lighters
.
 
<EOS>
Long
and
broad
black
tiers
of
the
latter
,
moored
fast
in
the
mud
as
if
they
were
never
to
move
again
,
made
the
shore
funereal
and
silent
after
dark
;
and
kept
what
little
water
-
movement
there
was
,
far
out
towards
mid
-
stream
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
hour
later
than
sunset
,
and
not
least
at
that
hour
when
most
of
the
people
who
have
anything
to

at
home
are
going
home
to

,
and
when

who
have
nothing
have

to

,
it
was
a

and
looked
on
a

scene
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
hour
when
Clennam
stopped
at
the
corner
,
observing
the
girl
and
the
strange
man
as
they
went
down
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
's
footsteps
were
so
noisy
on
the
echoing
stones
that
he
was
unwilling
to
add
the
sound
of
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
they
had
passed
the
turning
and
were
in
the
darkness
of
the
dark
corner
leading
to
the
terrace
,
he
made
after
them
with
such
indifferent
appearance
of
being
a
casual
passenger
on
his
way
,
as
he
could
assume
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
rounded
the
dark
corner
,
they
were
walking
along
the
terrace
towards
a
figure
which
was
coming
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
seen
it
by
itself
,
under
such
conditions
of
gas
-
lamp
,
mist
,
and
distance
,
he
might
not
have
known
it
at
first
sight
,
but
with
the
figure
of
the
girl
to
prompt
him
,
he
at
once
recognised
Miss
Wade
.
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
at
the
corner
,
seeming
to
look
back
expectantly
up
the
street
as
if
he
had
made
an
appointment
with
some
one
to
meet
him
there
;
but
he
kept
a
careful
eye
on
the
three
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
came
together
,
the
man
took
off
his
hat
,
and
made
Miss
Wade
a
bow
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
appeared
to
say
a
few
words
as
though
she
presented
him
,
or
accounted
for
his
being
late
,
or
early
,
or
what
not
;
and
then
fell
a
pace
or
so
behind
,
by
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
and
the
man
then
began
to
walk
up
and
down
;
the
man
having
the
appearance
of
being
extremely
courteous
and
complimentary
in
manner
;
Miss
Wade
having
the
appearance
of
being
extremely
haughty
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
came
down
to
the
corner
and
turned
,
she
was
saying
,
   
"
If
I
pinch
myself
for
it
,
sir
,
that
is
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
Confine
yourself
to
yours
,
and
ask
me
no
question
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
Heaven
,
ma'am
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
,
making
her
another
bow
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
my
profound
respect
for
the
strength
of
your
character
,
and
my
admiration
of
your
beauty
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
neither
the
one
nor
the
other
from
any
one
,
"
said
she
,
"
and
certainly
not
from
you
of
all
creatures
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
with
your
report
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
pardoned
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
with
an
air
of
half
abashed
gallantry
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
paid
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
that
is
all
you
want
.
"
   
<EOS>
Whether
the
girl
hung
behind
because
she
was
not

business
,
or
as
already
knowing
enough
about
it
,
Clennam
could
not

.
 
<EOS>
They
turned
and
she
turned
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
away
at
the
river
,
as
she
walked
with
her
hands

before
her
;
and
that
was
all
he
could
make
of
her
without

.
 
<EOS>
There
happened
,
by
good

,
to
be
a
lounger
really
waiting
for
some
one
;
and
he
sometimes

over

water
,
and
sometimes
came

the
dark
corner
and
looked

street
,
rendering
Arthur
less

.
   
<EOS>
When
Miss
Wade
and
the
man

,
she
was

"
You
must
wait
until
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
pardons
?
<EOS>
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
faith
!
 
<EOS>
Then
it
's

to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell

I
must

it
before
I
can
give

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
She
stopped
in
the
roadway
,
as

to
put
an
end
to
the
conference
.
<EOS>
He
of
course
stopped
too
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
girl
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
little
inconvenient
,
"
said

man
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
little
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Holy
Blue
!
 
<EOS>
that
's
nothing
in
such
a
service
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
without
money
to
-
night
,
by

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
good
banker
in
this
city
,
but
I
would
not
wish
to
draw
upon
the
house
until
the
time
when
I
shall
draw
for
a
round

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Harriet
,
"
said

Wade
,
"
arrange
with
him
---
this
gentleman
here
---
for
sending
him
some
money
to
-
morrow
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
said
it
with
a
slur
of
the
word
gentleman
which
was
more
contemptuous
than
any
emphasis
,
and
walked
slowly
on
.
<EOS>
The
man
bent
his
head
again
,
and
the
girl
spoke
to
him
as
they
both
followed
her
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
ventured
to
look
at
the
girl
as
they
Moved
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
note
that
her
rich
black
eyes
were
fastened
upon
the
man
with
a
scrutinising
expression
,
and
that
she
kept
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
as
they
walked
side
by
side
to
the
further
end
of
the
terrace
.
   
<EOS>
A
loud
and
altered
clank
upon
the
pavement
warned
him
,
before
he
could
discern
what
was
passing
there
,
that
the
man
was
coming
back
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
lounged
into
the
road
,
towards
the
railing
;
and
the
man
passed
at
a
quick
swing
,
with
the
end
of
his
cloak
thrown
over
his
shoulder
,
singing
a
scrap
of
a
French
song
.
   
<EOS>
The
whole
vista
had
no
one
in
it
now
but
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
lounger
had
lounged
out
of
view
,
and
Miss
Wade
and
Tattycoram
were
gone
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
ever
bent
on
seeing
what
became
of
them
,
and
on
having
some
information
to
give
his
good
friend
,
Mr
Meagles
,
he
went
out
at
the
further
end
of
the
terrace
,
looking
cautiously
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
rightly
judged
that
,
at
first
at
all
events
,
they
would
go
in
a
contrary
direction
from
their
late
companion
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
saw
them
in
a
neighbouring
bye
-
street
,
which
was
not
a
thoroughfare
,
evidently
allowing
time
for
the
man
to
get
well
out
of
their
way
.
 
<EOS>
They
walked
leisurely
arm
-
in
-
arm
down
one
side
of
the
street
,
and
returned
on
the
opposite
side
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
came
back
to
the
street
-
corner
,
they
changed
their
pace
for
the
pace
of
people
with
an
object
and
a
distance
before
them
,
and
walked
steadily
away
.
<EOS>
Clennam
,
no
less
steadily
,
kept
them
in
sight
.
   
<EOS>
They
crossed
the
Strand
,
and
passed
through
Covent
Garden
(
under
the
windows
of
his
old
lodging
where
dear
Little
Dorrit
had
come
that
night
)
,
and
slanted
away
north
-
east
,
until
they
passed
the
great
building
whence
Tattycoram
derived
her
name
,
and
turned
into
the
Gray
's
Inn
Road
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
was
quite
at
home
here
,
in
right
of
Flora
,
not
to
mention
the
Patriarch
and
Pancks
,
and
kept
them
in
view
with
ease
.
 
<EOS>
He
was

to
wonder
where
they
might
be
going
next
,
when
that

was
lost
in
the

with

saw

turn
into
the
Patriarchal
street
.
 
<EOS>
That
wonder
was
in
its
turn
swallowed
up
on
the
greater
wonder
with
which
he
saw

stop
at
the
Patriarchal
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
low

knock
at
the
bright

,
a

light
into
the
road
from
the
opened
door
,
a
brief
pause
for
inquiry
and
answer
and
the
door
was

,
and
they
were

.
   
<EOS>
After
looking

the
surrounding
objects
for

he

not
in

,
and

,
Arthur
knocked
at

.
 
<EOS>
It

opened
by
the
usual
maid

,
and
she

him
up
at

,
with
her
usual

,
to
Flora
's

.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
one
with
Flora
but
Mr
F
's
Aunt
,
which

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Bending

,

,

F
's

"

,

F

wo
