touch
it
for
a
length
of
time
;
sometimes
she
's
so
poor
that
she
must
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
writhes
under
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
A
woman
more
angry
,
passionate
,
reckless
,
and
revengeful
never
lived
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
for
money
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Said
she
had
peculiar
occasion
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
observed
Clennam
musing
,
"
<EOS>
I
by
chance
know
what
occasion
---
I
mean
into
whose
pocket
the
money
is
to
go
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
a
compact
,
I
recommend
that
party
to
be
exact
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
trust
myself
to
that
woman
,
young
and
handsome
as
she
is
,
if
I
had
wronged
her
;
no
,
not
for
twice
my
proprietor
's
money
!
 
<EOS>
Unless
,
"
Pancks
added
as
a
saving
clause
,
"
I
had
a
lingering
illness
on
me
,
and
wanted
to
get
it
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
,
hurriedly
reviewing
his
own
observation
of
her
,
found
it
to
tally
pretty
nearly
with
Mr
Pancks
's
view
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
wonder
is
to
me
,
"
pursued
Pancks
,
"
that
she
has
never
done
for
my
proprietor
,
as
the
only
person
connected
with
her
story
she
can
lay
hold
of
.
 
<EOS>
Mentioning
<EOS>
that
,
I
may
tell
you
,
between
ourselves
,
that
I
am
sometimes
tempted
to
do
for
him
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
started
and
said
,
"
Dear
me
,
Pancks
,
do
n't
say
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Understand
me
,
"
said
Pancks
,
extending
five
cropped
coaly
finger
-
nails
on
Arthur
's
arm
;
"
I
do
n't
mean
,
cut
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
But
by
all
that
's
precious
,
if
he
goes
too
far
,
I
'll
cut
his
hair
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
exhibited
himself
in
the
new
light
of
enunciating
this
tremendous
threat
,
Mr
Pancks
,
with
a
countenance
of
grave
import
,
snorted
several
times
and
steamed
away
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
The
Dreams
of
Mrs
Flintwinch
thicken
 
The
shady
waiting
-
rooms
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
where
he
passed
a
good
deal
of
time
in
company
with
various
troublesome
Convicts
who
were
under
sentence
to
be
broken
alive
on
that
wheel
,
had
afforded
Arthur
Clennam
ample
leisure
,
in
three
or
four
successive
days
,
to
exhaust
the
subject
of
his
late
glimpse
of
Miss
Wade
and
Tattycoram
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
able
to
make
no
more
of
it
and
no
less
of
it
,
and
in
this
unsatisfactory
condition
he
was
fain
to
leave
it
.
   
<EOS>
During
this
space
he
had
not
been
to
his
mother
's
dismal
old
house
.
   
<EOS>
One
of
his
customary
evenings
for
repairing
thither
now
coming
round
<EOS>
,
he
left
his
dwelling
and
his
partner
at
nearly
nine
o'clock
,
and
slowly
walked
in
the
direction
of
that
grim
home
of
his
youth
.
   
<EOS>
It
always
affected
his
imagination
as
wrathful
,
mysterious
,
and
sad
;
and
his
imagination
was
sufficiently
impressible
to
see
the
whole
neighbourhood
under
some
tinge
of
its
dark
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
went
along
,
upon
a
dreary
night
,
the
dim
streets
by
which
he
went
,
seemed
all
depositories
of
oppressive
secrets
.
 
<EOS>
The
deserted
counting
-
houses
,
with
their
secrets
of
books
and
papers
locked
up
in
chests
and
safes
;
the
banking
-
houses
,
with
their
secrets
of
strong
rooms
and
wells
,
the
keys
of
which
were
in
a
very
few
secret
pockets
and
a
very
few
secret
breasts
;
the
secrets
of
all
the
dispersed
grinders
in
the
vast
mill
,
among
whom
there
were
doubtless
plunderers
,
forgers
,
and
trust
-
betrayers
of
many
sorts
,
whom
the
light
of
any
day
that
dawned
might
reveal
;
he
could
have
fancied
that
these
things
,
in
hiding
,
imparted
a
heaviness
to
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
shadow
thickening
and
thickening
as
he
approached
its
source
<EOS>
,
he
thought
of
the
secrets
of
the
lonely
church
-
vaults
,
where
the
people
who
had
hoarded
and
secreted
in
iron
coffers
were
in
their
turn
similarly
hoarded
,
not
yet
at
rest
from
doing
harm
;
and
then
of
the
secrets
of
the
river
,
as
it
rolled
its
turbid
tide
between
two
frowning
wildernesses
of
secrets
,
extending
,
thick
and
dense
,
for
many
miles
,
and
warding
off
the
free
air
and
the
free
country
swept
by
winds
and
wings
of
birds
.
   
<EOS>
The
shadow
still
darkening
as
he
drew
near
the
house
,
the
melancholy
room
which
his
father
had
once
occupied
,
haunted
by
the
appealing
face
<EOS>
he
had
himself
seen
fade
away
with
him
when
there
was
no
other
watcher
by
the
bed
,
arose
before
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Its
close
air
was
secret
.
 
<EOS>
The
gloom
,
and
must
,
and
dust
of
the
whole
tenement
,
were
secret
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
heart
of
it
his
mother
presided
,
inflexible
of
face
,
indomitable
of
will
,
firmly
holding
all
the
secrets
of
her
own
and
his
father
's
life
,
and
austerely
opposing
herself
,
front
to
front
,
to
the
great
final
secret
of
all
life
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
turned
into
the
narrow
and
steep
street
from
which
the
court
of
enclosure
wherein
the
house
stood
opened
,
when
another
footstep
turned
into
it
behind
him
,
and
so
close
upon
his
own
that
he
was
jostled
to
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
As
his
mind
was
teeming
with
these
thoughts
,
the
encounter
took
him
altogether
unprepared
,
so
that
the
other
passenger
had
had
time
to
say
,
boisterously
,
"
Pardon
!
 
<EOS>
Not
my
fault
!
"
<EOS>
and
to
pass
on
before
the
instant
had
elapsed
which
was
requisite
to
his
recovery
of
the
realities
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
When
that
moment
had
flashed
away
,
he
saw
that
the
man
striding
on
before
him
was
the
man
who
had
been
so
much
in
his
mind
during
the
last
few
days
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
casual
resemblance
,
helped
out
by
the
force
of
the
impression
the
man
made
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
man
;
the
man
he
had
followed
in
company
with
the
girl
,
and
whom
he
had
overheard
talking
to
Miss
Wade
.
   
<EOS>
The
street
was
a
sharp
descent
and
was
crooked
too
,
and
the
man
(
who
although
not
drunk
had
the
air
of
being
flushed
with
some
strong
drink
)
went
down
it
so
fast
that
Clennam
lost
him
as
he
looked
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
no
defined
intention
of
following
him
,
but
with
an
impulse
to
keep
the
figure
in
view
a
little
longer
,
Clennam
quickened
his
pace
to
pass
the
twist
in
the
street
which
hid
him
from
his
sight
.
 
<EOS>
On
turning
it
,
he
saw
the
man
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Standing
now
,
close
to
the
gateway
of
his
mother
's
house
,
he
looked
down
the
street
:
but
it
was
empty
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
projecting
shadow
large
enough
to
obscure
the
man
;
there
was
no
turning
near
that
he
could
have
taken
;
nor
had
there
been
any
audible
sound
of
the
opening
and
closing
of
a
door
.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
concluded
that
the
man
must
have
had
a
key
in
his
hand
,
and
must
have
opened
one
of
the
many
house
-
doors
and
gone
in
.
   
<EOS>
Ruminating
on
this
strange
chance
and
strange
glimpse
,
he
turned
into
the
court
-
yard
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
by
mere
habit
,
towards
the
feebly
lighted
windows
of
his
mother
's
room
,
his
eyes
encountered
the
figure
he
had
just
lost
,
standing
against
the
iron
railings
of
the
little
waste
enclosure
looking
up
at
those
windows
and
laughing
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
many
vagrant
cats
who
were
always
prowling
about
there
by
night
,
and
who
had
taken
fright
at
him
,
appeared
to
have
stopped
when
he
had
stopped
,
and
were
looking
at
him
with
eyes
by
no
means
unlike
his
own
from
tops
of
walls
and
porches
,
and
other
safe
points
of
pause
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
only
halted
for
a
moment
to
entertain
himself
thus
;
he
immediately
went
forward
,
throwing
the
end
of
his
cloak
off
his
shoulder
as
he
went
,
ascended
the
unevenly
sunken
steps
,
and
knocked
a
sounding
knock
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
's
surprise
was
not
so
absorbing
but
that
he
took
his
resolution
without
any
incertitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
up
to
the
door
too
,
and
ascended
the
steps
too
.
 
<EOS>
His
friend
looked
at
him
with
a
braggart
air
,
and
sang
to
himself
.
        
<EOS>
"
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
;
     
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
which
he
knocked
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
impatient
,
sir
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
life
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
stranger
,
"
it
's
my
character
to
be
impatient
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sound
of
Mistress
Affery
cautiously
chaining
the
door
before
she
opened
it
,
caused
them
both
to
look
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
opened
it
a
very
little
,
with
a
flaring
candle
in
her
hands
and
asked
who
was
that
,
at
that
time
of
night
,
with
that
knock
!
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Arthur
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
added
with
astonishment
,
seeing
him
first
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
you
sure
?
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
Lord
save
us
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
"
she
cried
out
,
seeing
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Him
again
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
true
!
 
<EOS>
Him
again
,
dear
Mrs
Flintwinch
,
"
cried
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Open
the
door
,
and
let
me
take
my
dear
friend
Jeremiah
to
my
arms
!
<EOS>
Open
the
door
,
and
let
me
hasten
myself
to
embrace
my
Flintwinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
at
home
,
"
cried
Affery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fetch
him
!
"
cried
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fetch
my
Flintwinch
!
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
it
is
his
old
Blandois
,
who
comes
from
arriving
in
England
;
tell
him
that
it
is
his
little
boy
who
is
here
,
his
cabbage
,
his
well
-
beloved
!
 
<EOS>
Open
the
door
,
beautiful
Mrs
Flintwinch
,
and
in
the
meantime
let
me
to
pass
up
-
stairs
,
to
present
my
compliments
---
homage
of
Blandois
---
to
my
lady
!
 
<EOS>
My
lady
lives
always
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
well
.
   
<EOS>
Open
then
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
Arthur
's
increased
surprise
,
Mistress
Affery
,
stretching
her
eyes
wide
at
himself
,
as
if
in
warning
that
this
was
not
a
gentleman
for
him
to
interfere
with
,
drew
back
the
chain
,
and
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
without
ceremony
,
walked
into
the
hall
,
leaving
Arthur
to
follow
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Despatch
then
!
 
<EOS>
Achieve
then
!
 
<EOS>
Bring
my
Flintwinch
!
 
<EOS>
Announce
me
to
my
lady
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
stranger
,
clanking
about
the
stone
floor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
tell
me
,
Affery
,
"
said
Arthur
aloud
and
sternly
,
as
he
surveyed
him
from
head
to
foot
with
indignation
;
"
who
is
this
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
tell
me
,
Affery
,
"
the
stranger
repeated
in
his
turn
,
"
who
---
ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
---
who
is
this
gentleman
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
voice
of
Mrs
Clennam
opportunely
called
from
her
chamber
above
,
"
Affery
,
let
them
both
come
up
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
,
come
straight
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Arthur
?
"
exclaimed
Blandois
,
taking
off
his
hat
at
arm
's
length
,
and
bringing
his
heels
together
from
a
great
stride
in
making
him
a
flourishing
bow
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
son
of
my
lady
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
all
-
devoted
of
the
son
of
my
lady
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
looked
at
him
again
in
no
more
flattering
manner
than
before
,
and
,
turning
on
his
heel
without
acknowledgment
,
went
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
visitor
followed
him
up
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
took
the
key
from
behind
the
door
,
and
deftly
slipped
out
to
fetch
her
lord
.
   
<EOS>
A
bystander
,
informed
of
the
previous
appearance
of
Monsieur
Blandois
in
that
room
,
would
have
observed
a
difference
in
Mrs
Clennam
's
present
reception
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
not
one
to
betray
it
;
and
her
suppressed
manner
,
and
her
set
voice
,
were
equally
under
her
control
.
 
<EOS>
It
wholly
consisted
in
her
never
taking
her
eyes
off
his
face
from
the
moment
of
his
entrance
,
and
in
her
twice
or
thrice
,
when
he
was
becoming
noisy
,
swaying
herself
a
very
little
forward
in
the
chair
in
which
she
sat
upright
,
with
her
hands
immovable
upon
its
elbows
;
as
if
she
gave
him
the
assurance
that
he
should
be
presently
heard
at
any
length
he
would
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
did
not
fail
to
observe
this
;
though
the
difference
between
the
present
occasion
and
the
former
was
not
within
his
power
of
observation
.
   
<EOS>
"
Madame
,
"
said
Blandois
,
"
do
me
the
honour
to
present
me
to
Monsieur
,
your
son
.
 
<EOS>
It
appears
to
me
,
madame
,
that
Monsieur
,
your
son
,
is
disposed
to
complain
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
polite
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Arthur
,
striking
in
expeditiously
,
"
whoever
you
are
,
and
however
you
come
to
be
here
,
if
I
were
the
master
of
this
house
<EOS>
I
would
lose
no
time
in
placing
you
on
the
outside
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
not
,
"
said
his
mother
,
without
looking
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Unfortunately
for
the
gratification
of
your
unreasonable
temper
,
you
are
not
the
master
,
Arthur
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
make
no
claim
to
be
,
mother
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
object
to
this
person
's
manner
of
conducting
himself
here
,
and
object
to
it
so
much
,
that
if
I
had
any
authority
here
I
certainly
would
not
suffer
him
to
remain
a
minute
,
I
object
on
your
account
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
case
of
objection
being
necessary
,
"
she
returned
,
"
I
could
object
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
And
of
course
I
should
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
subject
of
their
dispute
,
who
had
seated
himself
,
laughed
aloud
,
and
rapped
his
legs
with
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
right
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
always
intent
on
Blandois
,
however
directly
she
addressed
her
son
,
"
to
speak
to
the
prejudice
of
any
gentleman
(
least
of
all
a
gentleman
from
another
country
)
,
because
he
does
not
conform
to
your
standard
,
or
square
his
behaviour
by
your
rules
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
the
gentleman
may
,
on
similar
grounds
,
object
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
returned
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
on
a
former
occasion
<EOS>
brought
a
letter
of
recommendation
to
us
from
highly
esteemed
and
responsible
correspondents
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
perfectly
unacquainted
with
the
gentleman
's
object
in
coming
here
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
entirely
ignorant
of
it
,
and
can
not
be
supposed
likely
to
be
able
to
form
the
remotest
guess
at
its
nature
;
"
her
habitual
frown
became
stronger
,
as
she
very
slowly
and
weightily
emphasised
those
words
;
"
but
,
when
the
gentleman
proceeds
to
explain
his
object
,
as
I
shall
beg
him
to
have
the
goodness
to
do
to
myself
and
Flintwinch
,
when
Flintwinch
returns
,
it
will
prove
,
no
doubt
,
to
be
one
more
or
less
in
the
usual
way
of
our
business
,
which
it
will
be
both
our
business
and
our
pleasure
to
advance
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
be
nothing
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
madame
!
"
said
the
man
of
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
she
assented
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
is
acquainted
with
Flintwinch
;
and
when
the
gentleman
was
in
London
last
,
I
remember
to
have
heard
that
he
and
Flintwinch
had
some
entertainment
or
good
-
fellowship
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
in
the
way
of
knowing
much
that
passes
outside
this
room
,
and
the
jingle
of
little
worldly
things
beyond
it
does
not
much
interest
me
;
but
I
remember
to
have
heard
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Right
,
madame
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
true
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
laughed
again
,
and
whistled
the
burden
of
the
tune
he
had
sung
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
Arthur
,
"
said
his
mother
,
"
the
gentleman
comes
here
as
an
acquaintance
,
and
no
stranger
;
and
it
is
much
to
be
regretted
that
your
unreasonable
temper
should
have
found
offence
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
regret
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
so
to
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
say
so
,
I
know
;
therefore
I
say
it
for
myself
and
Flintwinch
,
since
with
us
two
the
gentleman
's
business
lies
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
key
of
the
door
below
was
now
heard
in
the
lock
,
and
the
door
was
heard
to
open
and
close
.
 
<EOS>
In
due
sequence
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
appeared
;
on
whose
entrance
the
visitor
rose
from
his
chair
,
laughing
loud
,
and
folded
him
in
a
close
embrace
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
goes
it
,
my
cherished
friend
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
goes
the
world
,
my
Flintwinch
?
 
<EOS>
Rose
-
coloured
?
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
better
,
so
much
the
better
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
you
look
charming
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
you
look
young
and
fresh
as
the
flowers
of
Spring
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
good
little
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Brave
child
,
brave
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
While
heaping
these
compliments
on
Mr
Flintwinch
,
he
rolled
him
about
with
a
hand
on
each
of
his
shoulders
,
until
the
staggerings
of
that
gentleman
,
who
under
the
circumstances
was
dryer
and
more
twisted
than
ever
,
were
like
those
of
a
teetotum
nearly
spent
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
presentiment
,
last
time
,
that
we
should
be
better
and
more
intimately
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
coming
on
you
,
Flintwinch
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
yet
coming
on
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
sir
,
"
retorted
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
unusually
.
 
<EOS>
Had
n't
you
better
be
seated
?
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
calling
for
some
more
of
that
port
,
sir
,
I
guess
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Little
joker
!
 
<EOS>
Little
pig
!
"
cried
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
And
throwing
Mr
Flintwinch
away
,
as
a
closing
piece
of
raillery
,
he
sat
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
amazement
,
suspicion
,
resentment
,
and
shame
,
with
which
Arthur
looked
on
at
all
this
,
struck
him
dumb
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
who
had
spun
backward
some
two
or
three
yards
under
the
impetus
last
given
to
him
,
brought
himself
up
with
a
face
completely
unchanged
in
its
stolidity
except
as
it
was
affected
by
shortness
of
breath
,
and
looked
hard
at
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
whit
less
reticent
and
wooden
was
Mr
Flintwinch
outwardly
,
than
in
the
usual
course
of
things
:
<EOS>
the
only
perceptible
difference
in
him
being
that
the
knot
of
cravat
which
was
generally
under
his
ear
,
had
worked
round
to
the
back
of
his
head
:
where
it
formed
an
ornamental
appendage
not
unlike
a
bagwig
,
and
gave
him
something
of
a
courtly
appearance
.
<EOS>
As
Mrs
Clennam
never
removed
her
eyes
from
Blandois
(
on
whom
they
had
some
effect
,
as
a
steady
look
has
on
a
lower
sort
of
dog
)
,
so
Jeremiah
never
removed
his
from
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
they
had
tacitly
agreed
to
take
their
different
provinces
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
in
the
ensuing
silence
,
Jeremiah
stood
scraping
his
chin
and
looking
at
Arthur
as
though
he
were
trying
to
screw
his
thoughts
out
of
him
with
an
instrument
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
little
,
the
visitor
,
as
if
he
felt
the
silence
irksome
,
rose
,
and
impatiently
put
himself
with
his
back
to
the
sacred
fire
which
had
burned
through
so
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
Mrs
Clennam
said
,
moving
one
of
her
hands
for
the
first
time
,
and
moving
it
very
slightly
with
an
action
of
dismissal
:
   
<EOS>
"
Please
to
leave
us
to
our
business
,
Arthur
.
"
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
do
so
with
reluctance
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
with
what
,
"
she
returned
,
"
or
with
what
not
.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
leave
us
.
 
<EOS>
Come
back
at
any
other
time
when
you
may
consider
it
a
duty
to
bury
half
an
hour
wearily
here
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
held
up
her
muffled
fingers
that
he
might
touch
them
with
his
,
according
to
their
usual
custom
,
and
he
stood
over
her
wheeled
chair
to
touch
her
face
with
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
,
then
,
that
her
cheek
was
more
strained
than
usual
,
and
that
it
was
colder
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
followed
the
direction
of
her
eyes
,
in
rising
again
,
towards
Mr
Flintwinch
's
good
friend
,
Mr
Blandois
,
Mr
Blandois
snapped
his
finger
and
thumb
with
one
loud
contemptuous
snap
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
leave
your
---
your
business
acquaintance
in
my
mother
's
room
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
with
a
great
deal
of
surprise
and
a
great
deal
of
unwillingness
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
person
referred
to
snapped
his
finger
and
thumb
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
mother
.
"
   
"
Good
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
friend
once
,
my
good
comrade
Flintwinch
,
"
said
Blandois
,
standing
astride
before
the
fire
,
and
so
evidently
saying
it
to
arrest
Clennam
's
retreating
steps
,
that
he
lingered
near
the
door
;
"
I
had
a
friend
once
,
who
had
heard
so
much
of
the
dark
side
of
this
city
and
its
ways
,
that
he
would
n't
have
confided
himself
alone
by
night
with
two
people
who
had
an
interest
in
getting
him
under
the
ground
---
my
faith
!
 
<EOS>
not
even
in
a
respectable
house
like
this
---
unless
he
was
bodily
too
strong
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
Bah
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
poltroon
,
my
Flintwinch
!
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
A
cur
,
sir
.
"
   
"
Agreed
!
 
<EOS>
A
cur
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
would
n't
have
done
it
,
my
Flintwinch
,
unless
he
had
known
them
to
have
the
will
to
silence
him
,
without
the
power
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
n't
have
drunk
from
a
glass
of
water
under
such
circumstances
---
not
even
in
a
respectable
house
like
this
,
my
Flintwinch
---
unless
he
had
seen
one
of
them
drink
first
,
and
swallow
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
Disdaining
to
speak
,
and
indeed
not
very
well
able
,
for
he
was
half
-
choking
,
Clennam
only
glanced
at
the
visitor
as
he
passed
out
.
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
saluted
him
with
another
parting
snap
,
and
his
nose
came
down
over
his
moustache
and
his
moustache
went
up
under
his
nose
,
in
an
ominous
and
ugly
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
Heaven
's
sake
,
Affery
,
"
whispered
Clennam
,
as
she
opened
the
door
for
him
in
the
dark
hall
,
and
he
groped
his
way
to
the
sight
of
the
night
-
sky
,
"
what
is
going
on
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
Her
own
appearance
was
sufficiently
ghastly
,
standing
in
the
dark
with
her
apron
thrown
over
her
head
,
and
speaking
behind
it
in
a
low
,
deadened
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
ask
me
anything
,
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
in
a
dream
for
ever
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
went
out
,
and
she
shut
the
door
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
up
at
the
windows
of
his
mother
's
room
,
and
the
dim
light
,
deadened
by
the
yellow
blinds
,
seemed
to
say
a
response
after
Affery
,
and
to
mutter
,
"
Do
n't
ask
me
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
A
Letter
from
Little
Dorrit
 
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
   
<EOS>
As
I
said
in
my
last
that
it
was
best
for
nobody
to
write
to
me
,
and
as
my
sending
you
another
little
letter
can
therefore
give
you
no
other
trouble
than
the
trouble
of
reading
it
(
perhaps
you
may
not
find
leisure
for
even
that
,
though
I
hope
you
will
some
day
)
,
I
am
now
going
to
devote
an
hour
to
writing
to
you
again
.
 
<EOS>
This
time
,
I
write
from
Rome
.
   
<EOS>
We
left
Venice
before
Mr
and
Mrs
Gowan
did
,
but
they
were
not
so
long
upon
the
road
as
we
were
,
and
did
not
travel
by
the
same
way
,
and
so
when
we
arrived
we
found
them
in
a
lodging
here
,
in
a
place
called
the
Via
Gregoriana
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
you
know
it
.
   
<EOS>
Now
I
am
going
to
tell
you
all
I
can
about
them
,
because
I
know
that
is
what
you
most
want
to
hear
.
 
<EOS>
Theirs
is
not
a
very
comfortable
lodging
,
but
perhaps
I
thought
it
less
so
when
I
first
saw
it
than
you
would
have
done
,
because
you
have
been
in
many
different
countries
and
have
seen
many
different
customs
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
it
is
a
far
,
far
better
place
---
millions
of
times
---
than
any
I
have
ever
been
used
to
until
lately
;
and
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
do
n't
look
at
it
with
my
own
eyes
,
but
with
hers
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
would
be
easy
to
see
that
she
has
always
been
brought
up
in
a
tender
and
happy
home
,
even
if
she
had
not
told
me
so
with
great
love
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
Well
,
it
is
a
rather
bare
lodging
up
a
rather
dark
common
staircase
,
and
it
is
nearly
all
a
large
dull
room
,
where
Mr
Gowan
paints
.
 
<EOS>
The
windows
are
blocked
up
where
any
one
could
look
out
,
and
the
walls
have
been
all
drawn
over
with
chalk
and
charcoal
by
others
who
have
lived
there
before
---
<EOS>
oh
,
---
I
should
think
,
for
years
!
   
<EOS>
There
is
a
curtain
more
dust
-
coloured
than
red
,
which
divides
it
,
and
the
part
behind
the
curtain
makes
the
private
sitting
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
first
saw
her
there
she
was
alone
,
and
her
work
had
fallen
out
of
her
hand
,
and
she
was
looking
up
at
the
sky
shining
through
the
tops
of
the
windows
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
not
be
uneasy
when
I
tell
you
,
but
it
was
not
quite
so
airy
,
nor
so
bright
,
nor
so
cheerful
,
nor
so
happy
and
youthful
altogether
as
I
should
have
liked
it
to
be
.
   
<EOS>
On
account
of
Mr
Gowan
's
painting
Papa
's
picture
(
which
I
am
not
quite
convinced
I
should
have
known
from
the
likeness
if
I
had
not
seen
him
doing
it
)
,
I
have
had
more
opportunities
of
being
with
her
since
then
than
I
might
have
had
without
this
fortunate
chance
.
<EOS>
She
is
very
much
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Very
much
alone
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
about
the
second
time
I
saw
her
?
 
<EOS>
I
went
one
day
,
when
it
happened
that
I
could
run
round
by
myself
,
at
four
or
five
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
then
dining
alone
,
and
her
solitary
dinner
had
been
brought
in
from
somewhere
,
over
a
kind
of
brazier
with
a
fire
in
it
,
and
she
had
no
company
or
prospect
of
company
,
that
I
could
see
,
but
the
old
man
who
had
brought
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
telling
her
a
long
story
(
of
robbers
outside
the
walls
being
taken
up
by
a
stone
statue
of
a
Saint
)
,
to
entertain
her
---
as
he
said
to
me
when
I
came
out
,
"
because
he
had
a
daughter
of
his
own
,
though
she
was
not
so
pretty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
ought
now
to
mention
Mr
Gowan
,
before
I
say
what
little
more
I
have
to
say
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
admire
her
beauty
,
and
he
must
be
proud
of
her
,
for
everybody
praises
it
,
and
he
must
be
fond
of
her
,
and
I
do
not
doubt
that
he
is
---
but
in
his
way
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
his
way
,
and
if
it
appears
as
careless
and
discontented
in
your
eyes
as
it
does
in
mine
,
I
am
not
wrong
in
thinking
that
it
might
be
better
suited
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
does
not
seem
so
to
you
,
I
am
quite
sure
I
am
wholly
mistaken
;
for
your
unchanged
poor
child
confides
in
your
knowledge
and
goodness
more
than
she
could
ever
tell
you
if
she
was
to
try
.
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
be
frightened
,
I
am
not
going
to
try
.
<EOS>
Owing
(
as
I
think
,
if
you
think
so
too
)
to
Mr
Gowan
's
unsettled
and
dissatisfied
way
,
he
applies
himself
to
his
profession
very
little
.
   
<EOS>
He
does
nothing
steadily
or
patiently
;
but
equally
takes
things
up
and
throws
them
down
,
and
does
them
,
or
leaves
them
undone
,
without
caring
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
have
heard
him
talking
to
Papa
during
the
sittings
for
the
picture
,
I
have
sat
wondering
whether
it
could
be
that
he
has
no
belief
in
anybody
else
,
because
he
has
no
belief
in
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
so
?
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
you
will
say
when
you
come
to
this
!
 
<EOS>
I
know
how
you
will
look
,
and
I
can
almost
hear
the
voice
in
which
you
would
tell
me
on
the
Iron
Bridge
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Gowan
goes
out
a
good
deal
among
what
is
considered
the
best
company
here
---
though
he
does
not
look
as
if
he
enjoyed
it
or
liked
it
when
he
is
with
it
---
and
she
sometimes
accompanies
him
,
but
lately
she
has
gone
out
very
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
have
noticed
that
they
have
an
inconsistent
way
of
speaking
about
her
,
as
if
she
had
made
some
great
self
-
interested
success
in
marrying
Mr
Gowan
,
though
,
at
the
same
time
,
the
very
same
people
,
would
not
have
dreamed
of
taking
him
for
themselves
or
their
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
goes
into
the
country
besides
,
to
think
about
making
sketches
;
and
in
all
places
where
there
are
visitors
,
he
has
a
large
acquaintance
and
is
very
well
known
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
all
this
,
he
has
a
friend
who
is
much
in
his
society
both
at
home
and
away
from
home
,
though
he
treats
this
friend
very
coolly
and
is
very
uncertain
in
his
behaviour
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
(
because
she
has
told
me
so
)
,
that
she
does
not
like
this
friend
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
so
revolting
to
me
,
too
,
that
his
being
away
from
here
,
at
present
,
is
quite
a
relief
to
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
more
to
hers
!
   
<EOS>
But
what
I
particularly
want
you
to
know
,
and
why
I
have
resolved
to
tell
you
so
much
while
I
am
afraid
it
may
make
you
a
little
uncomfortable
without
occasion
,
is
this
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
so
true
and
so
devoted
,
and
knows
so
completely
that
all
her
love
and
duty
are
his
for
ever
,
that
you
may
be
certain
she
will
love
him
,
<EOS>
admire
him
,
praise
him
,
and
conceal
all
his
faults
,
until
she
dies
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
she
conceals
them
,
and
always
will
conceal
them
,
even
from
herself
.
   
<EOS>
She
has
given
him
a
heart
that
can
never
be
taken
back
;
and
however
much
he
may
try
it
<EOS>
,
he
will
never
wear
out
its
affection
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
the
truth
of
this
,
as
you
know
everything
,
far
far
better
than
I
;
but
I
can
not
help
telling
you
what
a
nature
she
shows
,
and
that
you
can
never
think
too
well
of
her
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
not
yet
called
her
by
her
name
in
this
letter
,
but
we
are
such
friends
now
that
I
do
so
when
we
are
quietly
together
,
and
she
speaks
to
me
by
my
name
---
<EOS>
I
mean
,
not
my
Christian
name
,
but
the
name
you
gave
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
began
to
call
me
Amy
,
I
told
her
my
short
story
,
and
that
you
had
always
called
me
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
the
name
was
much
dearer
to
me
than
any
other
,
and
so
she
calls
me
Little
Dorrit
too
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
have
not
heard
from
her
father
or
mother
yet
,
and
may
not
know
that
she
has
a
baby
son
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
born
only
two
days
ago
,
and
just
a
week
after
they
came
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
made
them
very
happy
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
must
tell
you
,
as
I
am
to
tell
you
all
,
that
I
fancy
they
are
under
a
constraint
with
Mr
Gowan
,
and
that
they
feel
as
if
his
mocking
way
with
them
was
sometimes
a
slight
given
to
their
love
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
<EOS>
but
yesterday
,
when
I
was
there
,
that
I
saw
Mr
Meagles
change
colour
,
and
get
up
and
go
out
,
as
if
he
was
afraid
that
he
might
say
so
,
unless
he
prevented
himself
by
that
means
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
am
sure
they
are
both
so
considerate
,
good
-
humoured
,
and
reasonable
,
that
he
might
spare
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
hard
in
him
not
to
think
of
them
a
little
more
.
   
<EOS>
I
stopped
at
the
last
full
stop
to
read
all
this
over
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
at
first
as
if
I
was
taking
on
myself
to
understand
and
explain
so
much
,
that
I
was
half
inclined
not
to
send
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
thought
it
over
a
little
,
I
felt
more
hopeful
for
your
knowing
at
once
that
I
had
only
been
watchful
for
you
,
and
had
only
noticed
what
I
think
I
have
noticed
,
because
I
was
quickened
by
your
interest
in
it
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
you
may
be
sure
that
is
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
I
have
done
with
the
subject
in
the
present
letter
,
and
have
little
left
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
We
are
all
quite
well
,
and
Fanny
improves
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
hardly
think
how
kind
she
is
to
me
,
and
what
pains
she
takes
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
a
lover
,
who
has
followed
her
,
first
all
the
way
from
Switzerland
,
and
then
all
the
way
from
Venice
,
and
who
has
just
confided
to
me
that
he
means
to
follow
her
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
much
confused
by
his
speaking
to
me
about
it
,
but
he
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
to
say
,
but
at
last
I
told
him
that
I
thought
he
had
better
not
.
 
<EOS>
For
Fanny
<EOS>
(
but
I
did
not
tell
him
this
)
is
much
too
spirited
and
clever
to
suit
him
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
he
said
he
would
,
all
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
lover
,
of
course
.
   
<EOS>
If
you
should
ever
get
so
far
as
this
in
this
long
letter
,
you
will
perhaps
say
,
Surely
Little
Dorrit
will
not
leave
off
without
telling
me
something
about
her
travels
,
and
surely
it
is
time
she
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
indeed
,
but
I
do
n't
know
what
to
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Since
we
left
Venice
we
have
been
in
a
great
many
wonderful
places
,
Genoa
and
Florence
among
them
,
and
have
seen
so
many
wonderful
sights
,
that
I
am
almost
giddy
when
I
think
what
a
crowd
they
make
.
   
<EOS>
But
you
can
tell
me
so
much
more
about
them
than
I
can
tell
you
,
that
why
should
I
tire
you
with
my
accounts
and
descriptions
?
   
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
as
I
had
the
courage
to
tell
you
what
the
familiar
difficulties
in
my
travelling
mind
were
before
,
I
will
not
be
a
coward
now
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
my
frequent
thoughts
is
this
:
---
 
Old
as
these
cities
are
,
their
age
itself
is
hardly
so
curious
,
to
my
reflections
,
as
that
they
should
have
been
in
their
places
all
through
those
days
when
I
did
not
even
know
of
the
existence
of
more
than
two
or
three
of
them
,
and
when
I
scarcely
knew
of
anything
outside
our
old
walls
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
melancholy
in
it
,
and
I
do
n't
know
why
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
went
to
see
the
famous
leaning
tower
at
Pisa
,
it
was
a
bright
sunny
day
,
and
it
and
the
buildings
near
it
looked
so
old
,
and
the
earth
and
the
sky
looked
so
young
,
and
its
shadow
on
the
ground
was
so
soft
and
retired
!
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
at
first
think
how
beautiful
it
was
,
or
how
curious
,
but
I
thought
,
"
O
how
many
times
when
the
shadow
of
the
wall
was
falling
on
our
room
,
and
when
that
weary
tread
of
feet
was
going
up
and
down
the
yard
---
<EOS>
O
how
many
times
this
place
was
just
as
quiet
and
lovely
as
it
is
to
-
day
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
quite
overpowered
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
heart
was
so
full
that
tears
burst
out
of
my
eyes
,
though
I
did
what
I
could
to
restrain
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
the
same
feeling
often
---
often
.
   
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
since
the
change
in
our
fortunes
,
though
I
appear
to
myself
to
have
dreamed
more
than
before
,
I
have
always
dreamed
of
myself
as
very
young
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
very
old
,
you
may
say
.
<EOS>
No
,
but
that
is
not
what
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
always
dreamed
of
myself
as
a
child
learning
to
do
needlework
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
dreamed
of
myself
as
back
there
,
seeing
faces
in
the
yard
little
known
,
and
which
<EOS>
I
should
have
thought
I
had
quite
forgotten
;
but
,
as
often
as
not
,
I
have
been
abroad
here
---
in
Switzerland
,
or
France
,
or
Italy
---
somewhere
where
we
have
been
---
yet
always
as
that
little
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
dreamed
of
going
down
to
Mrs
General
,
with
the
patches
on
my
clothes
in
which
I
can
first
remember
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
over
and
over
again
<EOS>
dreamed
of
taking
my
place
at
dinner
at
Venice
when
we
have
had
a
large
company
,
in
the
mourning
for
my
poor
mother
which
I
wore
when
I
was
eight
years
old
,
and
wore
long
after
it
was
threadbare
and
would
mend
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
a
great
distress
to
me
to
think
how
irreconcilable
the
company
would
consider
it
with
my
father
's
wealth
,
and
how
I
should
displease
and
disgrace
him
and
Fanny
and
Edward
by
so
plainly
disclosing
what
they
wished
to
keep
secret
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
not
grown
out
of
the
little
child
in
thinking
of
it
;
and
at
the
self
-
same
moment
I
have
dreamed
that
I
have
sat
with
the
heart
-
ache
at
table
,
calculating
the
expenses
of
the
dinner
,
and
quite
distracting
myself
with
thinking
how
they
were
ever
to
be
made
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
dreamed
of
the
change
in
our
fortunes
itself
;
I
have
never
dreamed
of
your
coming
back
with
me
that
memorable
morning
to
break
it
;
I
have
never
even
dreamed
of
you
.
   
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
it
is
possible
that
I
have
thought
of
you
---
and
others
---
so
much
by
day
,
that
I
have
no
thoughts
left
to
wander
round
you
by
night
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
must
now
confess
to
you
that
I
suffer
from
home
-
sickness
---
that
I
long
so
ardently
and
earnestly
for
home
,
as
sometimes
,
when
no
one
sees
me
,
to
pine
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
bear
to
turn
my
face
further
away
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
heart
is
a
little
lightened
when
we
turn
towards
it
,
even
for
a
few
miles
,
and
with
the
knowledge
that
we
are
soon
to
turn
away
again
.
 
<EOS>
So
dearly
do
I
love
the
scene
of
my
poverty
and
your
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
O
so
dearly
,
O
so
dearly
!
   
<EOS>
Heaven
knows
when
your
poor
child
will
see
England
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
all
fond
of
the
life
here
(
except
me
)
,
and
there
are
no
plans
for
our
return
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
father
talks
of
a
visit
to
London
late
in
this
next
spring
,
on
some
affairs
connected
with
the
property
,
but
I
have
no
hope
that
he
will
bring
me
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
get
on
a
little
better
under
Mrs
General
's
instruction
,
and
I
hope
I
am
not
quite
so

as

used

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
begun
to
speak
and
understand
,
almost

,
the
hard

I
told

about
.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

<EOS>
God

.
<EOS>

He

Chapter

.
<EOS>
In

Great

is
holden
 
<EOS>
The
famous
name
of
Merdle
became
,
every
day
,
more
famous
in
the
land
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
knew
that
the
Merdle
of
such
high
renown
had
ever
done
any
good
to
any
one
,
alive
or
dead
,
or
to
any
earthly
thing
;
nobody
knew
that
he
had
any
capacity
or
utterance
of
any
sort
in
him
,
which
had
ever
thrown
,
for
any
creature
,
the
feeblest
farthing
-
candle
ray
of
light
on
any
path
of
duty
or
diversion
,
pain
or
pleasure
,
toil
or
rest
,
fact
or
fancy
,
among
the
multiplicity
of
paths
in
the
labyrinth
trodden
by
the
sons
of
Adam
;
nobody
had
the
smallest
reason
for
supposing
the
clay
of
which
this
object
of
worship
was
made
,
to
be
other
than
the
commonest
clay
,
with
as
clogged
a
wick
smouldering
inside
of
it
as
ever
kept
an
image
of
humanity
from
tumbling
to
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
All
people
knew
(
or
thought

knew
)
that
he
had
made
himself
immensely
rich
;
and
,
for
that
reason
alone
,
prostrated
themselves
before
him
,
more
degradedly
and
less
excusably
than
the
darkest
savage
creeps
out
of
his
hole
in
the
ground
to
propitiate
,
in
some
log
or
reptile
,
the
Deity
of
his
benighted
soul
.
   
<EOS>
Nay
,
the
high
priests
of
this
worship
had
the
man
before
them
as
a
protest
against
their
meanness
.
 
<EOS>
The
multitude
worshipped
on
trust
---
though
always
distinctly
knowing
why
---
but
the
officiators
at
the
altar
had
the
man
habitually
in
their
view
.
 
<EOS>
They
sat
at
his
feasts
,
and
he
sat
at
theirs
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
spectre
always
attendant
on
him
,
saying
to
these
high
priests
,
"
Are
such
the
signs
you
trust
,
and
love
to
honour
;
this
head
,
these
eyes
,
this
mode
of
speech
,
the
tone
and
manner
of
this
man
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
levers
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
and
the
rulers
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
When

-

-
dozen

fall
out

ears
,
it
seems
that
mother
earth
can
give

no

.
 
<EOS>
Does
your
qualification

in
the
superior

of
men
which
accepts
,
courts
,
and
puffs
this
man
?
 
<EOS>
Or
,

to
judge
aright
the
signs
I
never
fail
to
show
you
when
he
appears
among
you
<EOS>
,
is
your
superior

your
qualification
?
"
 
<EOS>
Two
rather
ugly
questions
these
,
always
going
about
town
with
Mr
Merdle
;
and
there
was
a
tacit
agreement
that
they
must

.
 
<EOS>
In
Mrs
Merdle
's
absence
abroad
,
Mr

still

the
great
house
open
for
the
passage
through

of

stream
Of
visitors
.
 
<EOS>
A

these
took
affable

.
 
<EOS>
Three
or
four
ladies
of
distinction

used
to

,
"
Let

.
 
<EOS>
Whom

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Our
dear
Merdle
would
then

;
and
would

among
the
company
at
table
and

his
drawing
-
rooms

,
only
remarkable
for

to
have
nothing
to
do

the

beyond

in

.
   
<EOS>
The
Chief
Butler
,
the
Avenging
Spirit
of
this
great
man
's
life
,
relaxed
nothing
of
his

.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
on
at
these
dinners
when
the
bosom
was
not
there
,
as
he

on
at
other
dinners
when
the
bosom
was
there
;
and
his
eye
was
a
basilisk
to
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
hard
man
,
and
would
never
bate
an
ounce
of
plate
or
a

wine
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
not
allow

dinner
to
be

,
unless
it
was
up
to
his
mark
.
 
<EOS>
He
set
forth
the
table
for
his
own
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
guests
chose
to
partake
of
what
was
served
,
he
saw
no
objection
;
but
it
was
served
for
the

of
his
rank
.
 
<EOS>
As

"
I
have
accepted
office
to
look
at
this
which

now
before

,
and
to
look
at
nothing
less
than
this
.
"
 
<EOS>
If
he
missed
the
presiding
bosom
,

was
as
a
part
of
his
own
state
of
which
he
was
,
from

,

.
 
<EOS>
just

-
piece
,
or

choice

-

,

to
the
Banker
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
issued

for

Barnacle

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
was
to

,
Mr

,

;

,

of

Chief
,
were

.
<EOS>
It
was
understood
to
be
a
great

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
was
going
to
take

the
Barnacles
.
 
<EOS>
Some
delicate

had

noble
Decimus
---

Barnacle
of
engaging

had
decided

.
 
<EOS>
jobbery
was
suspected

the
malicious
;
perhaps

that

,

have

---
for

,

country
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
had
written
to
this

spouse
of
hers
,
whom
it
was
heresy
to
regard
as
anything
less
than
all
the
British
Merchants
since

days
of
Whittington
rolled

,
and

had

this

of
hers
,
several

from
Rome
,
in
quick

,
urging
upon
him

that
now

the

to
provide

Edmund
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
had
shown

that
the
case
of
Edmund
was
urgent
,
and
that
infinite
advantages
might
result
from
his
having
some
good
thing
directly
.
 
<EOS>
In
the

of
Mrs

's

on
this

,
there
was
only
one
mood
,
the
Imperative
;
and
that
Mood
had
only
one
Tense
,
the
Present
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
's
verbs
were
so
pressingly
presented
to
Mr
Merdle
to
conjugate
,
that
his
sluggish
blood
and
his
long
coat
-
cuffs
became
quite
agitated
.
   
<EOS>
In
which
state
of

,
Mr
Merdle
,
evasively
rolling
his
eyes
round
the
Chief
Butler
's
shoes
without
raising

to
the
index
of
that

's

,
had

of

:
not

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
The
Chief
Butler
had
signified
,
in

,
that
he
had
no
objection
to
look
on
at
the
most
expensive
thing
in
that
way
that
could
be
done
;
and
the
day
of
the
dinner
was
now
come
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
stood
in
one
of
his
drawing
-
rooms
,
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
waiting
for
the
arrival
of

important

.
 
<EOS>
He
seldom
or
never
took
the
liberty
of
standing
with

back
to

fire
unless

.
 
<EOS>
In
the

of
the
Chief
Butler
,

could
not

deed
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
clasped
himself

in
that
constabulary

of
his
,
and
have
paced
up

down

hearthrug
,
or

about
among
the
rich

of

,
if

oppressive

had
appeared

.
 
<EOS>
The
sly
shadows
which
seemed

,
and

,
were
sufficient

of
his

.
   
<EOS>
They

even
more
than

,
if

uncomfortable

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
's
right

was
filled
with
the
evening
paper
,
and
the
evening
paper
was
full
of
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
His

,

,

Bank
,

.
 
<EOS>
The
wonderful
Bank
,
of

he
was
the
chief
projector
,

,
and
manager
,
was
the
latest

many
Merdle

.
 
<EOS>
So

Merdle
withal
,
in

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
Behold

!
 
<EOS>
The

;

Bar

.
 
<EOS>
Bar
,

;

<EOS>
With

.
 
<EOS>
Bar

.
 
<EOS>
Bar
was

man

;

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

"
<EOS>

"

"

?

,

,

<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
These
words
brought
them
to
the

,

Merdle

.
 
<EOS>
So

mouth
,
that
Bar
explained
himself
to
have
been
quoting
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
"
Assuredly
not
one
of
our
Westminster
Hall
authorities
,
"
said

,
"
but
still
no
despicable
one
to
a
man
possessing
the
largely
-
practical
Mr
Merdle
's
knowledge
of
the
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
looked
as
if
he
thought
he
would
say
something
,
but
subsequently
looked
as
if
he
thought
he
would
n't
.
 
<EOS>
The
interval
afforded
time
for
Bishop
to
be
announced
.
<EOS>
Bishop
came
in
with
meekness
,
and
yet
with
a
strong
and
rapid
step
as
if
he
wanted
to
get
his
seven
-
league
dress
-

on
,
and
go
round
the
world
to

.
<EOS>
Bishop
had
no
idea
that
there
was
anything
significant
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
most
remarkable
trait
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
crisp
,
fresh
,
cheerful
,
affable
,
bland
;
but
so

.
   
<EOS>
Bar
sidled
up
to
prefer
his
politest

in

to
the

of
Mrs
Bishop
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bishop
had
been
a

in

article
of

at
a

,
but
otherwise

.
 
<EOS>
Young
Mr
Bishop
was
also

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
down
,
with
his
young
wife
and
little

,
at
his

of

.
 
<EOS>
The

of
the
Barnacle
Chorus
dropped
in
next
,
and
Mr
Merdle
's

dropped
in
next
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
,
who
had
a
bit
of
one
eye
and
a
bit
of
his
double
eye
-
glass
for
every
one
who
came
in
at
the
door
,
no
matter
with
whom
he
was
conversing
or
what
he
was

about
,
got
among
them
all
by
some
skilful
means
,
without
being
seen
to
get
at
them
,
and
touched
each
individual
gentleman
of
the
jury
on
his
own
individual
favourite
spot
.
 
<EOS>
With
some
of
the
Chorus
,
he
laughed
about
the
sleepy
member
who
had
gone
out
into
the
lobby
the
other
night
,
and
voted
the
wrong
way
:
<EOS>
with
others
,
he
deplored
that
innovating
spirit
in
the
time
which
could
not
even
be
prevented
from
taking
an
unnatural
interest
in
the
public

and
the

:
with

he
had
a
word

say
about
the

;
he

also
a

to

,

a
professional

of

and

---
but

in

he

of
the

art
(
jury

)
---

,
and

had

that

Bar
to
---
eh
?
---
<EOS>
well
,
Bar

;
Bar

,

,
Physician
would

.
 
<EOS>
Without

where

disagreed
,
it

,

,
that

---

,

?
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Fortified

,
he
could
venture
to
say

;
and
now
Bar
's
mind
was
relieved
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
,
who
,
like
Dr

's

,
had
only

and

,
had

.
 
<EOS>
This
eminent

and
Mr
Merdle
,
seated
diverse

and
with
ruminating

on
a
yellow

in

,

,
bore

to

in

over

.
   
<EOS>
But
now
,
Lord
Decimus
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
The
Chief

,
who
up

this

had
limited

to
a

usual

by

(
and
that
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
being
an

,
a

member
of
the
Lower

who
was
the
last
fish

,

.
   
<EOS>
Lord

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
was

,

Bishop
,

Bar
,

,

Tite

,

,

his

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
,
though
one
of
the

of
the
earth
,
was
not
remarkable
for
ingratiatory

,
and

had
coached

up

of
noticing
all

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

this

,
his

composed
himself
into
the
picture
after
Cuyp
,
and
made
a
third

in

.
   
<EOS>
Bar
,
who
felt
that
he
had

all
the
rest
of

jury
and
must
now
lay
hold
of
the
Foreman
,
soon

,
double

-

.
 
<EOS>
Bar
tendered
the
weather
,
as
a
subject
neatly
aloof
from
official

,
for
the

's

.
 
<EOS>
Bar
said
that
he
was
told
(
as
everybody
always
is

,
though
who
tells

,
and
why
,
will

)
,
that

no
wall
-

this

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
had
not
heard

amiss
of
his
peaches
,
but
rather
believed
,
if
his
people
were

,
he
was
to
have
no

.
 
<EOS>
No
apples
?
 
<EOS>
Bar
was
lost
in

and

.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
all
one
to
him
,
in
reality
,
if

a
pippin
on
the
surface
of

,
but
his
show

in
this

question
was

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
to
what
,
Lord
Decimus
---
for
we

loved
to

,
and
could
never

might

to

---
to

,
Lord
Decimus
,

?
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
could
not

to

any

about

.
 
<EOS>
This
might
have
stopped
another
man
;
but
Bar
,
sticking
to
him
fresh
as

,
said
,
"
As
to
pears
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
Long
after
Bar
got
made
Attorney
-
General
,
this
was
told
of
him
as

master
-

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Decimus
had
a
reminiscence
about
a
pear
-
tree
formerly
growing
in
a
garden
near
the
back
of
his
dame
's
house
at
Eton
,
upon
which
pear
-
tree
the
only

of
his
life
perennially

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
joke
of
a
compact
and
portable
nature
,
turning
on
the
difference
between
Eton
pears
and
Parliamentary
pairs
;
but
it
was
a
joke
,
a
refined
relish
of
which
would
seem
to
have
appeared
to
Lord
Decimus
impossible
to
be
had
without
a
thorough
and
intimate

with
the
tree
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
the
story
at
first
had
no
idea
of
such
a
tree
,
sir
,
then
gradually
found
it
in
winter
,
carried
it
through
the
changing
season
,
saw
it
bud
,
saw
it
blossom
,
saw
it
bear
fruit
,
saw
the
fruit
ripen
;
in
short
,
cultivated
the
tree
in
that
diligent

minute

before
it
got
out
of
the
bed
-
room

to
steal
the
fruit
,
that
many

had
been
offered
up
by
belated

for
the

having
been
planted
and

prior
to
Lord
Decimus
's

.
 
<EOS>
Bar
's
interest
in
apples
was
so
overtopped
by
the

in
which
he
pursued
the
changes
of
these

,
from

"
Your
mentioning
pears
recalls
to

a
pear
-

,
"
down

,
"
<EOS>
And

pass
,
through

,
from
Eton

to
Parliamentary

,
"
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
By

,
Bar
felt
that
he
had
secured
the
Foreman
,
and
might
go
to
dinner
with

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
dinner
to
provoke
an

,
though
he
had
not
had

.
<EOS>
The
rarest
dishes
,
sumptuously
cooked
and
sumptuously
served
;
the
choicest

;
the
most

;
marvels
of

in

,

and

;

delicious
to
the

of

,

,

,
were

into
its

.
 
<EOS>
O
,
what
a
wonderful
man
this
Merdle
,
what
a

man
,
what
a
master
man
,
how

and

---
in

,
what
a
rich
man
!
   
<EOS>
He
took
his
usual
poor
eighteenpennyworth
of
food
in
his
usual
indigestive
way
,
and
had
as
little
to
say
for
himself
as
ever
a
wonderful
man
had
.
 
<EOS>
Fortunately
Lord
Decimus
was
one
of
those
sublimities
who
have
no
occasion
to
be
talked
to
,
for
they
can
be
at
any
time
sufficiently
occupied
with
the

of
their
own

.
 
<EOS>
This
enabled
the
bashful
young
Member
to
keep
his
eyes
open
long
enough
at
a
time
to
see
his

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
whenever
Lord
Decimus
spoke
,

shut

again
.
   
<EOS>
The
agreeable
young
Barnacle
,
and
Bar
,
were
the
talkers
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
Bishop
would
have
been
exceedingly
agreeable

,
but
that
his

stood
in

way
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
soon
left
behind
.
 
<EOS>
When
there
was
any
little
hint
of
anything
being
in

wind
,

.
 
<EOS>
Worldly

were
too
much
for
him
;
he
could
n't

out

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
observable
when
Bar
said
,
incidentally
,
that
he
was
happy
to
have
heard
that
we
were

have

of
enlisting

the

,
the
sound

---
not

or

,
but
thoroughly

and

---
of
our

Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
Ferdinand
Barnacle
laughed
,
and
said
<EOS>
oh
yes
,
he
believed
so
.
 
<EOS>
A
vote
was
a
vote
,
and
always
acceptable
.
   
<EOS>
Bar
was
sorry
to
miss
our
good
friend
Mr
Sparkler
to
-
day
,
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
away
with
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
returned
that

,
slowly

out

a
long

,
in
the

he
had
been
fitting

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not

for
him
to
be

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
magic
name
of
Merdle
,
"
said
Bar
,
with
the
jury
droop
,
"
no

will

for

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
---
yes
---
I
believe

,
"

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
the
people
in
my
interest
down
there
will
not

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Model
people
!
"
said
Bar
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
approve
of
them
,
"
said
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
people
of
those
other
two
places
,
now
,
"
pursued
Bar
,
with
a
bright

in
his
keen

,
as
it
slightly
turned
in
the
direction
of
his
magnificent
neighbour
;
"
we
lawyers
are
always
curious
,
always

,
always
picking
up
odds
and
ends
for
our
patchwork
minds
,
since
there
is
no

when
and
where
they
may
fit
into

;
---
the
people
of
those
other
two
places
now
?
 
<EOS>
Do
they
yield
so
laudably
to
the
vast
and
cumulative

of
such

and
such
renown
;
do
those
little
rills
become
absorbed
so
quietly
and

,
and
,
as
it
were
by
the

natural

,
so
beautifully
,
in
the

of
the
majestic

as
it

upon
its

way
enriching
the

lands
;
that
their
course
is
perfectly
to
be
calculated
,
and

to
be
predicated
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,
a
little
troubled
by
Bar
's
eloquence
,
looked
fitfully
about
the
nearest
salt
-

for
some

,
and
then
said
hesitating
:
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
perfectly
aware
,

,
of

to
Society
.
 
<EOS>
They
will
return
anybody
I
send
to

for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cheering
to
know
,
"
said
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cheering
to
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
three
places
in
question
were
three
little
rotten
holes
in
this
Island
,
containing
three
little
ignorant
,
drunken
,

,
dirty
,
out
-
of
-
the
-

,
that
had
reeled
into
Mr
Merdle
's

.
 
<EOS>
Ferdinand
Barnacle
laughed
in
his
easy
way
,
and
airily
said
they
were
a
nice
set
of
fellows
.
 
<EOS>
Bishop
,
mentally
perambulating
among
paths
of
peace
,
was
altogether
swallowed
up
in
absence
of
mind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
asked
Lord
Decimus
,
casting
his
eyes
around

"
what

story

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

Fixes

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

<EOS>
Bishop
,

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lord

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

P*Q

!

,

,

!
<EOS>
Another

!
 
<EOS>
Bar
was

,

.
 
<EOS>
Would

?
 
<EOS>
(

,

,

)
   
<EOS>

,

,

small
topics
,
while
everybody
's
thoughts
and
eyes
were
secretly
straying
towards
the
secluded
pair
.
 
<EOS>
The
Chorus
were
excessively
nervous
,
perhaps
as
labouring
under
the
dreadful
apprehension
that
some
good
thing
was
going
to
be
diverted
from
them
!
 
<EOS>
Bishop
alone
talked
steadily
and
evenly
.
 
<EOS>
He
conversed
with
the
great
Physician
on
that
relaxation
of
the
throat
with
which
young
curates
were
too
frequently
afflicted
,
and
on
the
means
of
lessening
the
great
prevalence
of
that
disorder
in
the
church
.
<EOS>
Physician
,
as
a
general
rule
,
was
of
opinion
that
the
best
way
to
avoid
it
was
to
know
how
to
read
,
before
you
made
a
profession
of
reading
.
 
<EOS>
Bishop
said
dubiously
,
did
he
really
think
so
?
 
<EOS>
And
Physician
said
,
decidedly
,
<EOS>
yes
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
Ferdinand
,
meanwhile
,
was
the
only
one
of
the
party
who
skirmished
on
the
outside
of
the
circle
;
he
kept
about
mid
-
way
between
it
and
the
two
,
as
if
some
sort
of
surgical
operation
were
being
performed
by
Lord
Decimus
on
Mr
Merdle
,
or
by
Mr
Merdle
on
Lord
Decimus
,
and
his
services
might
at
any
moment
be
required
as
Dresser
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
Lord
Decimus
called
to
him
"
Ferdinand
!
"
and
he
went
,
and
took
his
place
in
the
conference
for
some
five
minutes
more
.
 
<EOS>
Then
a
half
-
suppressed
gasp
broke
out
among
the
Chorus
;
for
Lord
Decimus
rose
to
take
his
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Again
coached
up
by
Ferdinand
to
the
point
of
making
himself
popular
,
he
shook
hands
in
the
most
brilliant
manner
with
the
whole
company
,
and
even
said
to
Bar
,
"
I
hope
you
were
not
bored
by
my
pears
?
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
Bar
retorted
,
"
Eton
,
my
lord
,
or
Parliamentary
?
"
<EOS>
neatly
showing
that
he
had
mastered
the
joke
,
and
delicately
insinuating
that
he
could
never
forget
it
while
his
life
remained
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
grave
importance
that
was
buttoned
up
in
Mr
Tite
Barnacle
,
took
itself
away
next
;
and
Ferdinand
took
himself
away
next
,
to
the
opera
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
rest
lingered
a
little
,
marrying
golden
liqueur
glasses
to
Buhl
tables
with
sticky
rings
;
on
the
desperate
chance
of
Mr
Merdle
's
saying
something
.
 
<EOS>
But
Merdle
,
as
usual
,
oozed
sluggishly
and
muddily
about
his
drawing
-
room
,
saying
never
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
day
or
two
it
was
announced
to
all
the
town
,
that
Edmund
Sparkler
,
Esquire
,
son
-
in
-
law
of
the
eminent
Mr
Merdle
of
worldwide
renown
,
was
made
one
of
the
Lords
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
;
and
proclamation
was
issued
,
to
all
true
believers
,
that
this
admirable
appointment
was
to
be
hailed
as
a
graceful
and
gracious
mark
of
homage
,
rendered
by
the
graceful
and
gracious
Decimus
,
to
that
commercial
interest
which
must
ever
in
a
great
commercial
country
---
and
all
the
rest
of
it
,
with
blast
of
trumpet
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
bolstered
by
this
mark
of
Government
homage
,
the
wonderful
Bank
and
all
the
other
wonderful
undertakings
went
on
and
went
up
;
and
gapers
came
to
Harley
Street
,
Cavendish
Square
,
only
to
look
at
the
house
where
the
golden
wonder
lived
.
   
<EOS>
And
when
they
saw
the
Chief
Butler
looking
out
at
the
hall
-
door
in
his
moments
of
condescension
,
the
gapers
said
how
rich
he
looked
,
and
wondered
how
much
money
he
had
in
the
wonderful
Bank
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
if
they
had
known
that
respectable
Nemesis
better
,
they
would
not
have
wondered
about
it
,
and
might
have
stated
the
amount
with
the
utmost
precision
.
    
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
The
Progress
of
an
Epidemic
 
That
it
is
at
least
as
difficult
to
stay
a
moral
infection
as
a
physical
one
;
that
such
a
disease
will
spread
with
the
malignity
and
rapidity
of
the
Plague
;
that
the
contagion
,
when
it
has
once
made
head
,
will
spare
no
pursuit
or
condition
,
but
will
lay
hold
on
people
in
the
soundest
health
,
and
become
developed
in
the
most
unlikely
constitutions
:
is
a
fact
as
firmly
established
by
experience
as
that
we
human
creatures
breathe
an
atmosphere
.
 
<EOS>
A
blessing
beyond
appreciation
would
be
conferred
upon
mankind
,
if
the
tainted
,
in
whose
weakness
or
wickedness
these
virulent
disorders
are
bred
,
could
be
instantly
seized
and
placed
in
close
confinement
(
not
to
say
summarily
smothered
)
before
the
poison
is
communicable
.
   
<EOS>
As
a
vast
fire
will
fill
the
air
to
a
great
distance
with
its
roar
,
so
the
sacred
flame
which
the
mighty
Barnacles
had
fanned
caused
the
air
to
resound
more
and
more
with
the
name
of
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
deposited
on
every
lip
,
and
carried
into
every
ear
.
 
<EOS>
There
never
was
,
<EOS>
there
never
had
been
,
there
never
again
should
be
,
such
a
man
as
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
,
as
aforesaid
,
knew
what
he
had
done
;
but
everybody
knew
him
to
be
the
greatest
that
had
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
Down
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
where
there
was
not
one
unappropriated
halfpenny
,
as
lively
an
interest
was
taken
in
this
paragon
of
men
as
on
the
Stock
Exchange
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
,
now
established
in
the
small

in

at

,

,

and
Maggy
acting
as

,
habitually
held
forth
about
him
over
the
counter
in

with
her

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Plornish
,
who
had
a
small
share
in
a
small
builder
's
business
in
the
neighbourhood
,
said
,
trowel
in

,
on
the

and
on
the

,
that
people

Mr

was
the

,

,

that

all

,
and
to
bring
us
all

home
as
much
as
we

,
mind
you
,
fur
toe
be
brought
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
sole
lodger
of
Mr
and

was

,
for

.
 
<EOS>
The
female

,
when

for
ounces

,
and

,

,
That

,

,

,

,
that

's

would

.
 
<EOS>
That
how

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

they

,

her
son
by
a

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

that

,

that

.
   
<EOS>
So
rife

potent
was
the
fever
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
that
Mr
Pancks
's
rent
-
days
caused
no
interval
in
the
patients
.
 
<EOS>
The
disease
took
the
singular
form
,
on
those
occasions
,
of
causing
the
infected
to
find
an
unfathomable
excuse
and
consolation
in
allusions
to
the
magic
name
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
!
"
Mr
Pancks
would
say
,
to
a
defaulting

.
 
<EOS>
"
Pay
up
!
   
<EOS>
Come
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
got
it
,
Mr
Pancks
,
"
Defaulter
would
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
the
truth
,
sir
,
when
I
say
I
have
n't
got
so
much
as

sixpence
of

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
wo
n't
do
,

,
"
Mr
Pancks
would

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
expect

will
do
;
do

?
"
<EOS>
Defaulter
would

,
with

low

"
No
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
do

.
 
<EOS>
Pay
up
!
 
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Defaulter
would
make
answer
,
"
Ah
,
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
the
rich

whose

---
if
my
name
was
Merdle
,
sir
---
I
'd
soon
pay
up
,
and
be
glad
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dialogues
on
the
rent
-
question
usually
took
place
at
the
house
-
doors
or
in
the
entries
,
and
in
the
presence
of
several
deeply
interested
Bleeding
Hearts
.
 
<EOS>
They
always
received
a
reference
of
this
kind
with
a
low
murmur
of
response
,
as
if
it
were
convincing
;
and
the
Defaulter
,
however
black
and
discomfited
before
,
always
cheered
up
a
little
in
making
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
Mr
Merdle
,
sir
,
you
would
n't
have
cause
to
complain
of
me
then
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
believe
me
!
"
<EOS>
the
Defaulter
would
proceed
with
a
shake
of
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
pay
up
so
quick
then
,
Mr
Pancks
,
that
you
should
n't
have
to
ask
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
response
would
be
heard
again
here
,
implying
that
it
was
impossible
to
say
anything
fairer
,
and
that
this
was
the
next
thing
to
paying
the
money
down
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
would
be
now
reduced
to
saying
as
he
booked

case
,
"
Well
!
 
<EOS>
You
'll
have
the
broker
in
,
and

;
that
's
what
'll

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

use
talking

me
about
Mr
Merdle
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
Mr
Merdle
,
any

than
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
the
Defaulter
would
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
wish
you
were
him
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
response
would
take
this
up
quickly
;
replying
with
great
feeling
,
"
Only
wish
you
were
him
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
be
easier
with
us
<EOS>
if
you

Mr
Merdle
,
sir
,
"
the
Defaulter
would
go

,
"
and

be
better
for
all

.
 
<EOS>
Better
for
our
sakes
,
and
better
for

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
have
to
worry
no
one
,

,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

you
'd

others

,
too
<EOS>
,
you
would
,
if

Mr
Merdle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
in
whom
these
impersonal
compliments
produced
an
irresistible
sheepishness
,
never
rallied
after
such
a
charge
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
only
bite
his
nails
and
puff
away
to
the
next
Defaulter
.
 
<EOS>
The
responsive
Bleeding
Hearts
would
then
gather
round
the
Defaulter
whom
he
had
just
abandoned
,
and
the
most
extravagant
rumours
would
circulate
among
them
,
to
their
great
comfort
,
touching
the
amount
of
Mr
Merdle
's
ready
money
.
   
<EOS>
From
one
of
the
many
such
defeats
of
one
of
many
rent
-
days
,
Mr
Pancks
,
having
finished
his
day
's
collection
,
repaired
with
his
note
-
book
under
his
arm
to
Mrs
Plornish
's
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
's
object
was
not
professional
,
but
social
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
had
a
trying
day
,
and
wanted
a
little
brightening
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
he
was
on
friendly
terms
with
the
Plornish
family
,
having
often
looked
in
upon
them
at
similar
seasons
,
and
borne
his
part
in
recollections
of
Miss
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
's
shop
-
parlour
had
been
decorated
under
her
own
eye
,
and
presented
,
on
the
side
towards
the
shop
,
a
little
fiction
in
which
Mrs
Plornish
unspeakably
rejoiced
.
 
<EOS>
This
poetical
heightening
of
the
parlour
consisted
in
the
wall
being
painted
to
represent
the
exterior
of
a
thatched
cottage
;
the
artist
having
introduced
(
in
as
effective
a
manner
as
he
found
compatible
with
their
highly
disproportionate
dimensions
)
<EOS>
the
real
door
and
window
.
 
<EOS>
The
modest
sunflower
and
hollyhock
were
depicted
as
flourishing
with
great
luxuriance
on
this
rustic
dwelling
,
while
a
quantity
of
dense
smoke
issuing
from
the
chimney
indicated
good
cheer
within
,
and
also
,
perhaps
,
that
it
had
not
been
lately
swept
.
 
<EOS>
A
faithful
dog
was
represented
as
flying
at
the
legs
of
the
friendly
visitor
,
from
the
threshold
;
and
a
circular
pigeon
-
house
,
enveloped
in
a
cloud
of

,
arose
from
behind
the
garden
-
paling
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
door
(
when
it
was
shut
)
,
appeared
the
semblance
of
a
brass
-
plate
,
presenting
the
inscription
,
Happy
Cottage
,
T
and
M
Plornish
;
<EOS>
the
partnership
expressing
man
and
wife
.
 
<EOS>
No
Poetry
and
no
Art
ever
charmed
the
imagination
more
than
the
union
of
the
two
in
this
counterfeit
cottage
charmed
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
to
her
that
Plornish
had
a
habit
of
leaning
against
it
as
he
smoked
his
pipe
after
work
,
when
his
hat
blotted
out
the
pigeon
-
house
and
all
the
pigeons
,
when
his
back
swallowed
up
the
dwelling
,
when
his
hands
in
his
pockets
uprooted
the
blooming
garden
and
laid
waste
the
adjacent
country
.
<EOS>
To
Mrs
Plornish
,
it
was
still
a
most
beautiful
cottage
,
a
most
wonderful
deception
;
and
it
made
no
difference
that
Mr
Plornish
's
eye
was
some
inches
above
the
level
of
the
gable
bed
-
room
in
the
thatch
.
 
<EOS>
To
come
out
into
the
shop
after
it
was
shut
,
and
hear
her
father
sing
a
song
inside
this
cottage
,
was
a
perfect
Pastoral
to
Mrs
Plornish
,
the
Golden
Age
revived
.
 
<EOS>
And
truly
if
that
famous
period
had
been
revived
,
or
had
ever
been
at
all
<EOS>
,
it
may
be
doubted
whether

have
produced
many

than
the

.
   
<EOS>
Warned
of
a
visitor
by

the
shop

,
Mrs

came

Happy

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

you
,
Mr
Pancks
,
"
said

,
"
<EOS>
for

's
quite
your
regular

;
ai

?
 
<EOS>
Here

,
you

,

,
like

.
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't

looking

?
 
<EOS>
Father
's

you
was
a
customer
<EOS>
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

"

,

<EOS>
"
He

us

Plornish

<EOS>
"
John

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
An't

,

,

"
   
<EOS>
Mr

?
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

,

West

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

was

,

the
elder
Master
Plornish
just

.
 
<EOS>
Examining

,

in

,

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"
Very

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
John

Nandy
trotted

,
much

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,
who
was

before
the
old

,
lest

might

,
was

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

that

is

,
"
said
Mrs

,

;
"
and
has

.
 
<EOS>
The
only

that
stands
in

way
,

,

Credit
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
drawback
,
rather

by
most

who
engaged
in

with
the

of
Bleeding

Yard
,
was
a
large

-
block
in
Mrs

's

.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Dorrit
had
established
her
in
the

,
the
Bleeding
Hearts
had
shown
an

in

,
that
did
honour
to
human
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Recognising
her
claim
upon
their
generous
feelings
as
one
who
had
long
been
a
member

their
community
,
they
pledged

,
with
great
feeling
,
<EOS>
to
deal
with
Mrs
Plornish
,
come
what
would
and
bestow
their

on
no

.
 
<EOS>
Influenced
by
these
noble

,
they
had
even
gone
out

their
way
to
purchase
little

in
the

and

line
to
which
they
were
unaccustomed
;
saying
to
one
another
,
that
if
they
did
stretch
a

,
was
it
not
for
a
neighbour
and
a
friend
,
and
for
whom
ought
a
point

be

if
not
for
such
?
 
<EOS>
So
stimulated
,
the
business
was
extremely
brisk
,
and
the
articles
in
stock
went
off
with
the

celerity
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
if
the
Bleeding
Hearts
had
but
paid
,
the

would
have
been

;
whereas
,
by
reason
of
their

to
owing
,
the

actually
realised
had
not

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
making
a
very
porcupine
of
himself
by

in
the

this

,
when
old

,
re

,

Mr

,
who
seemed

have
met

something
that

.
 
<EOS>
All
three
going
into
the
shop
,
and

,
then

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
First
,

was
observed

the

,

shop

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
he
came

,
and
went

down

;

,

,

went
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

no

,
when

.
 
<EOS>
The

was

,
when
his

,
from

,

,

Doyce

,
end

,

had

.
 
<EOS>
He

out

,
as
he
might

,

,

<EOS>
"
Hallo
,

!
"

<EOS>
"
Altro
,

!
 
<EOS>
What
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,
or

,

,

.
<EOS>

E

<EOS>

"
E
ope

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Enough
,

.
 
<EOS>
Leave

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

so

,

:
<EOS>
the
rather
as
the
tea
had
been
drawing

some

.
 
<EOS>
But

not
the
less
surprised
and

;

,

had

since

of
the
little

,
like

.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
,
now
better
dressed
than
of
yore
,

,
had

,
which

were

by

of

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
no

was
said
about

,
though
much
appeared
to
be
thought
on
all

:
by
no

the
two
young
Plornishes
,
who
partook
of
the

as
if
their
eating
the
bread
and

were
rendered
almost
superfluous
by
the
painful
probability
of
the
worst
of
men
shortly
presenting
himself
for
the
purpose
of
eating
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
by
degrees
began
to
chirp
a
little
;
but
never
stirred
from
the
seat
he
had
taken
behind
the
door
and
close
to
the
window
,
though
it
was
not
his
usual
place
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
the
little
bell
rang
,
he
started
and
peeped
out

,
with
the
end
of
the
little
curtain
in

hand
and
the
rest
before
his
face
;
evidently
not
at
all
satisfied
but
that
the
man
he
dreaded
had
tracked
him
through
all
his
doublings
and
turnings
,
with
the

of
a

.
   
<EOS>
The
entrance
,
at
various
times
,
of
two
or
three

and
of
Mr

,
gave
Mr
Baptist
just
enough
of
this
employment
to
keep
the

of
the
company
fixed
upon

.
 
<EOS>
Tea
was
over
,
and
the
children
were
abed
,
and
Mrs
Plornish
was
feeling
her
way
to
the
dutiful
proposal
that
her
father
should
favour
them
with
Chloe
,
when
the
bell
rang
again
,
and
Mr
Clennam
came
in
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
had
been
poring
late
over
his
books
and
letters
;
for
the
waiting
-
rooms
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
ravaged
his
time
sorely
.
   
<EOS>
Over
and
above
that
,
he
was
depressed
and
made
uneasy
by
the
late
occurrence
at
his
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
worn
and
solitary
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
so
,
too
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
was
returning
home
from
his
counting
-
house
by
that
end
of
the
Yard
to
give
them
the
intelligence
that
he
had
received
another
letter
from
Miss
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
The
news
made
a
sensation
in
the
cottage
which
drew
off
the
general
attention
from
Mr
Baptist
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
,
who
pushed
her
way
into
the
foreground
immediately
,
would
have
seemed
to
draw
in
the
tidings
of
her
Little
Mother
equally
at
her
ears
,
nose
,
mouth
,
and
eyes
,
but
that
the
last
were
obstructed
by
tears
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
particularly
delighted
when
Clennam
assured
her
that
there
were
hospitals
,
and
very
kindly
conducted
hospitals
,
in
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
rose
into
new
distinction
in
virtue
of
being
specially
remembered
in
the
letter
.
<EOS>
Everybody
was
pleased
and
interested
,
and
Clennam
was
well
repaid
for
his
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
tired
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
make
you
a
cup
of
tea
,
"
said
Mrs
Plornish
,
"
if
you
'd
condescend
to
take
such
a
thing
in
the
cottage
;
and
many
thanks
to
you
,
too
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
for
bearing
us
in
mind
so
kindly
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Plornish
deeming
it
incumbent
on
him
,
as
host
,
to
add
his
personal
acknowledgments
,
tendered
them
in
the
form
which
always
expressed
his
highest
ideal
of
a
combination
of
ceremony
with
sincerity
.
   
<EOS>
"
John
Edward
Nandy
,
"
said
Mr
Plornish
,
addressing
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
too
often
that
you
see
unpretending
actions
without
a
spark
of
pride
,
and
therefore
when
you
see

give
grateful

unto
the
same
,
being
that
if
you
do
n't
,
and
live
to
want
'em
<EOS>
,
it
follows
serve
you
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Nandy
replied
:
   
"
I
am
heartily
of
your
opinion
,
Thomas
,
and
which
<EOS>
your
opinion
is
the
same
as
mine
,
and
therefore
no
more
words
and
not
being
backwards
with
that
opinion
,
which
opinion
giving
it
as
yes
,
Thomas
,
yes
,
is
the
opinion
in
which
yourself
and
me
must
ever
be
unanimously
jined
by
all
,
and
where
there
is
not
difference
of
opinion
<EOS>
there
can
be
none
but
one
opinion
,
which
fully
no
,
Thomas
,
Thomas
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
,
with
less
formality
,
expressed
himself
gratified
by
their
high
appreciation
of
so
very
slight
an
attention
on
his
part
;
and
explained
as
to
the
tea
that
he
had
not
yet
dined
,
and
was
going
straight
home
to
refresh
after
a
long
day
's
labour
,
or
he
would
have
readily
accepted
the
hospitable
offer
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pancks
was
somewhat
noisily
getting
his
steam
up
for
departure
,
he
concluded
by
asking
that
gentleman
if
he
would
walk
with
him
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
said
he
desired
no
better
engagement
,
and
the
two
took
leave
of
Happy
Cottage
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
come
home
with
me
,
Pancks
,
"
said
Arthur
,
when
they
got
into
the
street
,
"
and
will
share
what
dinner
or
supper
there
is
,
it
will
be
next
door
to
an
act
of
charity
;
for
I
am
weary
and
out
of
sorts
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
me
to
do
a
greater
thing
than
that
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
when
you
want
it
done
,
and
I
'll
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Between
this
eccentric
personage
and
Clennam
,
a
tacit
understanding
and
accord
had
been
always
improving
since
Mr
Pancks
flew
over
Mr
Rugg
's
back
in
the
Marshalsea
Yard
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
carriage
drove
away
on
the
memorable
day
of
the
family
's
departure
,
these
two
had
looked
after
it
together
,
and
had
walked
slowly
away
together
.
<EOS>
When
the
first
letter
came
from
little
Dorrit
,
nobody
was
more
interested
in
hearing
of
her
than
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
letter
,
at
that
moment
in
Clennam
's
breast
-
pocket
,
particularly
remembered
him
by
name
.
 
<EOS>
Though
he
had
never
before
made
any
profession
or
protestation
to
Clennam
,
and
though
what
he
had
just
said
was
little
enough
as
to
the
words
in
which
it
was
expressed
,
Clennam
had
long
had
a
growing
belief
that
Mr
Pancks
,
in
his
own
odd
way
,
was
becoming
attached
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
strings
intertwining
made
Pancks
a
very
cable
of
anchorage
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
alone
,
"
Arthur
explained
as
they
walked
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
partner
is
away
,
busily
engaged
at
a
distance
on
his
branch
of
our
business
,
and
you
shall
do
just
as

like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
did
n't
take
particular
notice
of
little
Altro
just
now
;
did
you
?
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
Why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
bright
fellow
,
and
I
like
him
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
has
gone
amiss
with
him
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
any
idea
of
any
cause
that
can
have
overset
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
!
 
<EOS>
None
<EOS>
whatever
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
gave
his
reasons
for
the
inquiry
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
was
quite
unprepared
for
them
,
and
quite
unable
to
suggest
an

of
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
'll
ask
him
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
as
he
's
a
stranger
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
him
what
?
"
returned
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
he
has
on
his
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ought
first
to
see
for
myself
that
he
has
something
on
his
mind
,
I
think
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
him
in
every
way
<EOS>
so
diligent
,
so
grateful
(
for
little
enough
)
,
and
so
trustworthy
,
that
it
might
look
like
suspecting
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
would
be
very
unjust
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
You
ought
n't
to
be
anybody
's
proprietor
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
much
too
delicate
.
"
<EOS>
"
For
the
matter
of
that
,
"
returned
Clennam
laughing
,
"
I
have
not
a
large
proprietary
share
in
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
His
carving
is
his
livelihood
.
 
<EOS>
He
keeps
the
keys
of
the
Factory
,
watches
it
every
alternate
night
,
and
acts
as
a
sort
of
housekeeper
to
it
generally
;
but
we
have
little
work
in
the
way
of
his
ingenuity
,
though
we
give
him
what
we
have
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
rather
his
adviser
than
his
proprietor
.
 
<EOS>
To
call
me
his
standing
counsel
and
his
banker
would
be
nearer
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
Speaking
of
being
his
banker
,
is
it
not
curious
,
Pancks
,
that
the
ventures
which
run
just
now
in
so
many
people
's
heads
,
should
run
even
in
little
Cavalletto
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ventures
?
"
retorted
Pancks
,
with
a
snort
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ventures
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
These
Merdle
enterprises
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
Investments
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
know
you
were
speaking
of
investments
.
<EOS>
"
His
quick
way
of
replying
caused
Clennam
to
look
at
him
,
with
a
doubt
whether
he
meant
more
than
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
accompanied
,
however
,
with
a
quickening
of
his
pace
and
a
corresponding
increase
in
the
labouring
of
his
machinery
,
Arthur
did
not
pursue
the
matter
,
and
they
soon
arrived
at
his
house
.
   
<EOS>
A
dinner
of
soup
and
a
pigeon
-
pie
,
served
on
a
little
round
table
before
the
fire
,
and
flavoured
with
a
bottle
of
good
wine
,
oiled
Mr
Pancks
's
works
in
a
highly
effective
manner
;
so
that
when
Clennam
produced
his
Eastern
pipe
,
and
handed
Mr
Pancks
another
Eastern
pipe
,
the
latter
gentleman
was
perfectly
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
They
puffed
for
a
while
in
silence
,
Mr
Pancks
like
a
steam
-
vessel
with
wind
,
tide
,
calm
water
,
and
all
other
sea
-
going
conditions
in
her
favour
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
first
to
speak
,
and
he
spoke
thus
:
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Investments
is
the
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,
with
his
former
look
,
said
"
Ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
back
to
it
,
you
see
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
you
are
going
back
to
it
,
"
returned
Clennam
,
wondering
why
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was

a
curious
thing
that
they
should
run
in
little
Altro
's
head
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
said
Pancks
as
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
Was

that
how
you
put
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
what
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
 
<EOS>
But
think
of
the
whole
Yard
having
got

.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
their
all
meeting
me
with
it
,
on
my

,
here
and

.
 
<EOS>
Whether
they
pay
,
or
whether
they
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Merdle
,
Merdle
,
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Always
Merdle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
strange
how
these
runs
on
an
infatuation
prevail
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
An't
it
?
"
<EOS>
returned
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
After

for
a
minute
or

,
more

than

with
his
recent

,
he
added
:
"
Because
you
see
these
people
do
n't
understand
the
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
,
"
assented

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
,
"
cried
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Know
nothing
of
figures
.
 
<EOS>
Know
nothing
of
money
questions
.
 
<EOS>
Never
made
a
calculation
.
 
<EOS>
Never
worked
it
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
they
had
---
"
Clennam
was
going
on
to

;
when
Mr

,
without

,

so
far

all

usual

,
nasal

,
that
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
they
had
?
"
repeated
Pancks
in
an
inquiring

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
---
spoke
,
"
said
Arthur
,
hesitating
what
name
to
give
the
