.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
in
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
had
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
they
had
,
"
observed
Clennam
,
who
was
a
little
at
a
loss
how
to
take
his
friend
,
"
why
,
I
suppose
they
would
have
known
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
so
,
Mr
Clennam
?
<EOS>
"
Pancks
asked
quickly
,
and
with
an
odd
effect
of
having
been
from
the
commencement
of
the
conversation
loaded
with
the
heavy
charge
he
now
fired
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
're
right
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
They
do
n't
mean
to
be
,
but
they
're
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Right
in
sharing
Cavalletto
's
inclination
to
speculate
with
Mr
Merdle
?
"
   
"
Per
-
fectly
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
gone
into
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
made
the
calculations
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
worked
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
safe
and
genuine
.
"
<EOS>
Relieved
by
having
got
to
this
,
Mr
Pancks
took
as
long
a
pull
as
his
lungs
would
permit
at
his
Eastern
pipe
,
and
looked
sagaciously
and
steadily
at
Clennam
while
inhaling
and
exhaling
too
.
   
<EOS>
In
those
moments
,
Mr
Pancks
began
to
give
out
the
dangerous
infection
with
which
he
was
laden
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
manner
of
communicating
these
diseases
;
it
is
the
subtle
way
in
which
they
go
about
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
,
my
good
Pancks
,
"
asked
Clennam
emphatically
,
"
that
you
would
put
that
thousand
pounds
of
yours
,
let
us
say
,
for
instance
,
out
at
this
kind
of
interest
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Already
done
it
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
took
another
long
inhalation
,
another
long
exhalation
,
another
long
sagacious
look
at
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
Mr
Clennam
,
I
've
gone
into
it
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
man
of
immense
resources
---
enormous
capital
---
government
influence
.
<EOS>
They
're
the
best
schemes
afloat
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
safe
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
certain
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
returned
Clennam
,
looking
first
at
him
gravely
and
then
at
the
fire
gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
"
<EOS>
Pancks
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
what
you
ought
to
do
yourself
!
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
do
as
I
do
?
"
   
<EOS>
Of
whom
Mr
Pancks
had
taken
the
prevalent
disease
,
he
could
no
more
have
told
than
if
he
had
unconsciously
taken
a
fever
.
 
<EOS>
Bred
at
first
,
as
many
physical
diseases
are
,
in
the
wickedness
of
men
,
and
then
disseminated
in
their
ignorance
,
these
epidemics
,
after
a
period
,
get
communicated
to
many
sufferers
who
are
neither
ignorant
nor
wicked
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
might
,
or
might
not
,
have
caught
the
illness
himself
from
a
subject
of
this
class
;
but
in
this
category
he
appeared
before
Clennam
,
and
the
infection
he
threw
off
was
all
the
more
virulent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
have
really
invested
,
"
Clennam
had
already
passed
to
that
word
,
"
your
thousand
pounds
,
Pancks
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
sir
!
"
replied
Pancks
boldly
,
with
a
puff
of
smoke
.
"
<EOS>
And
only
wish
it
ten
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Clennam
had
two
subjects
lying
heavy
on
his
lonely
mind
that
night
;
the
one
,
his
partner
's
long
-
deferred
hope
;
the
other
,
what
he
had
seen
and
heard
at
his
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
relief
of
having
this
companion
,
and
of
feeling
that
he
could
trust
him
,
he
passed
on
to
both
,
and
both
brought
him
round
again
,
with
an
increase
and
acceleration
of
force
,
to
his
point
of
departure
.
   
<EOS>
It
came
about
in
the
simplest
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Quitting
the
investment
subject
,
after
an
interval
of
silent
looking
at
the
fire
through
the
smoke
of
his
pipe
,
he
told
Pancks
how
and
why
he
was
occupied
with
the
great
National
Department
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
hard
case
it
has
been
,
and
a
hard
case
it
is
on
Doyce
,
"
he
finished
by
saying
,
with
all
the
honest
feeling
the
topic
roused
in
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hard
indeed
,
"
Pancks
acquiesced
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
manage
for
him
,
Mr
Clennam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Manage
the
money
part
of
the
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
As
well
as
I
can
.
"
   
"
Manage
it
better
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Recompense
him
for
his
toils
and
disappointments
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
the
chances
of
the
time
.
<EOS>
He
'll
never
benefit
himself
in
that
way
,
patient
and
preoccupied
workman
.
 
<EOS>
He
looks
to
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
my
best
,
Pancks
,
"
returned
Clennam
,
uneasily
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
to
duly
weighing
and
considering
these
new
enterprises
of
which
I
have
had
no
experience
,
I
doubt
if
I
am
fit
for
it
,
I
am
growing
old
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Growing
old
?
"
cried
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
!
"
   
There
was
something
so
indubitably
genuine
in
the
wonderful
laugh
,
and
series
of
snorts
and
puffs
,
engendered
in
Mr
Pancks
's
astonishment
at
,
and
utter
rejection
of
,
the
idea
,
that
his
being
quite
in
earnest
could
not
be
questioned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Growing
old
?
"
cried
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
,
hear
,
hear
!
 
<EOS>
Old
?
 
<EOS>
Hear
him
,
hear
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
positive
refusal
expressed
in
Mr
Pancks
's
continued
snorts
,
no
less
than
in
these
exclamations
,
to
entertain
the
sentiment
for
a
single
instant
,
drove
Arthur
away
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
was
fearful
of
something
happening
to
Mr
Pancks
in
the
violent
conflict
that
took
place
between
the
breath
he
jerked
out
of
himself
and
the
smoke
he
jerked
into
himself
.
 
<EOS>
This
abandonment
of
the
second
topic
threw
him
on
the
third
.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
,
old
,
or
middle
-
aged
,
Pancks
,
"
he
said
,
when
there
was
a
favourable
pause
,
"
I
am
in
a
very
anxious
and
uncertain
state
;
a
state
that
even
leads
me
to
doubt
whether
anything
now
seeming
to
belong
to
me
,
may
be
really
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
how
this
is
?
<EOS>
Shall
I
put
a
great
trust
in
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
,
sir
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
if
you
believe
me
worthy
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
's
short
and
sharp
rejoinder
,
confirmed
by
the
sudden
outstretching
of
his
coaly
hand
,
was
most
expressive
and
convincing
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
shook
the
hand
warmly
.
   
<EOS>
He
then
,
softening
the
nature
of
his
old
apprehensions
as
much
as
was
possible
consistently
with
their
being
made
intelligible
and
never
alluding
to
his
mother
by
name
,
but
speaking
vaguely
of
a
relation
of
his
,
confided
to
Mr
Pancks
a
broad
outline
of
the
misgivings
he
entertained
,
and
of
the
interview
he
had
witnessed
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
listened
with
such
interest
that
,
regardless
of
the
charms
of
the
Eastern
pipe
,
he
put
it
in
the
grate
among
the
fire
-
irons
,
and
occupied
his
hands
during
the
whole
recital
in
so
erecting
the
loops
and

of
hair
all
over

,
that
he
looked
,
when
it
came
to
a

,
like
a
journeyman
Hamlet
in
conversation
with
his
father
's
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Brings
me
back
,
sir
,
"
was
his

then
,
with
a
startling
touch
on
Clennam
's
knee
,
"
brings
me
back
,
sir
,
to
the
Investments
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
anything
of
your
making
yourself
poor
to
repair
a
wrong
you
never
committed
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
you
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
must
be
himself
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
say
this
,
fearing
you
may
want
money
to
save
your
own
blood
from
exposure
and
disgrace
---
make
as
much
as
you
can
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
shook
his
head
,
but
looked
at
him
thoughtfully
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
as
rich
as
you
can
,
sir
,
"
Pancks
adjured
him
with
a
powerful
concentration
of
all
his
energies
on
the
advice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
as
rich
as
you
honestly
can
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
your
duty
.
 
<EOS>
Not
for
your
sake
,
but
for
the
sake
of
others
.
 
<EOS>
Take
time
by
the
forelock
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Doyce
(
who
really
is
growing
old
)
depends
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
Your
relative
depends
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
depends
upon
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
well
!
"
returned
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
for
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
word
more
,
Mr
Clennam
,
"
retorted
Pancks
,
"
and
then
enough
for
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
you
leave
all
the
gains
to
the
gluttons
,
knaves
,
and
impostors
?
 
<EOS>
Why
should
you
leave
all
the
gains
that
are
to
be
got
to
my
proprietor
and
the
like
of
him
?
 
<EOS>
Yet
you
're
always
doing

.
 
<EOS>
When
I

you
,
I
mean
such
men
as
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
know

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
see
it
every

my

.
 
<EOS>
I
see
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
It
's
my
business
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
say
,
"
urged
Pancks
,
"
Go
in
and
win
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
what
of
Go
in
and
lose
?
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
be
done
,
sir
,
"
returned
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
looked
into
it
.
<EOS>
Name
up
everywhere
---
immense
resources
---
enormous

---
<EOS>
great

---
high

---
government

.
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
be
done
!
"
   
<EOS>
Gradually
,
after
this
closing
exposition
,
Mr
Pancks
subsided
;
allowed
his
hair
to
droop
as
much
as
it
ever
would
droop
on
the
utmost
persuasion
;
reclaimed
the
pipe
from
the
fire
-
irons
,
filled
it
anew
,
and
smoked
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
They
said
little
more
;
but
were
company
to
one
another
in
silently
pursuing
the
same
subjects
,
and
did
not
part
until
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
On
taking
his
leave
,
Mr
Pancks
,
when
he
had
shaken
hands
with
Clennam
,
worked
completely
round
him
before
he
steamed
out
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
Arthur
received
as
an
assurance
that
he
might
implicitly
rely
on
Pancks
,
if
he
ever
should
come
to
need
assistance
;
either
in
any
of
the
matters
of
which
they
had
spoken
that
night
,
or
any
other
subject
that
could
in
any
way
affect
himself
.
   
<EOS>
At
intervals
all
next
day
,
and
even
while
his
attention
was
fixed
on
other
things
,
he
thought
of
Mr
Pancks
's
investment
of
his
thousand
pounds
,
and
of
his
having
"
looked
into
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
Mr
Pancks
's
being
so
sanguine
in
this
matter
,
and
of
his
not
being
usually
of
a
sanguine
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
the
great
National
Department
,
and
of
the
delight
it
would
be
to
him
to
see
Doyce
better
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
the
darkly
threatening
place
that
went
by
the
name
of
Home
in
his
remembrance
,
and
of
the
gathering
shadows
which
made
it
yet
more
darkly
threatening
than
of
old
.
 
<EOS>
He
observed
anew
that
wherever
he
went
,
he
saw
,
or
heard
,
or
touched
,
the
celebrated
name
of
Merdle
;
he
found
it
difficult
even
to
remain
at
his
desk
a
couple
of
hours
,
without
having
it
presented
to
one
of
his
bodily
senses
through
some
agency
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
He
began
to
think
it
was
curious
too
that
it
should
be
everywhere
,
and
that
nobody
but
<EOS>
he
should
seem
to
have
any
mistrust
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Though
indeed
he
began
to
remember
,
<EOS>
when
he
got
to
this
,
even
he
did
not
mistrust
it
;
he
had
only
happened
to
keep
aloof
from
it
.
   
<EOS>
Such
symptoms
,
when
a
disease
of
the
kind
is
rife
,
are
usually
the
signs
of
sickening
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
Taking
Advice
 
<EOS>
When
it
became
known
to
the
Britons
on
the
shore
of
the
yellow
Tiber
that
their
intelligent
compatriot
,
Mr
Sparkler
,
was
made
one
of
the
Lords
of
their
Circumlocution
Office
,
they
took
it
as
a
piece
of
news
with
which
they
had
no
nearer
concern
than
with
any
other
piece
of
news
---
any
other
Accident
or
Offence
---
in
the
English
papers
.
 
<EOS>
Some
laughed
;
some
said
,
by
way
of
complete
excuse
,
that
the
post
was
virtually
a
sinecure
,
and
any
fool
who
could
spell
his
name
was
good
enough
for
it
;
some
,
and
these
the
more
solemn
political
oracles
<EOS>
,
said
that
Decimus
did
wisely
to
strengthen
himself
,
and
that
the
sole
constitutional
purpose
of
all
places
within
the
gift
of
Decimus
,
was
,
that
Decimus
should
strengthen
himself
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
bilious
Britons
there
were
who
would
not
subscribe
to
this
article
of
faith
;
but
their
objection
was
purely
theoretical
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
practical
point
of
view
,
they
listlessly
abandoned
the
matter
,
as
being
the
business
of
some
other
Britons
unknown
,
somewhere
,
or
nowhere
.
 
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
at
home
,
great
numbers
of
Britons
maintained
,
for
as
long
as
four
-
and
-
twenty
consecutive
hours
,
that
those
invisible
and
anonymous
Britons
"
ought
to
take
it
up
;
"
and
that
if
they
quietly
acquiesced
in
it
,
they
deserved
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
what
class
the
remiss
Britons
were
composed
,
and
where
the
unlucky
creatures
hid
themselves
,
and
why
they
hid
themselves
,
and
how
it
constantly
happened
that
they
neglected
their
interests
,
when
so
many
other
Britons
were
quite
at
a
loss
to
account
for
their
not
looking
after
those
interests
,
was
not
,
either
upon
the
shore
of
the
yellow
Tiber
or
the
shore
of
the
black
Thames
,
made
apparent
to
men
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
circulated
the
news
,
as
she
received
congratulations
on
it
,
with
a
careless
grace
that
displayed
it
to
advantage
,
as
the
setting
displays
the
jewel
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
said
,
Edmund
had
taken
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
wished
him
to
take
it
,
and
he
had
taken
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
hoped
Edmund
might
like
it
,
but
really
she
did
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
keep
him
in
town
a
good
deal
,
and
he
preferred
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
it
was
not
a
disagreeable
position
---
and
it
was
a
position
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
denying
that
the
thing
was
a
compliment
to
Mr
Merdle
,
and
was
not
a
bad
thing
for
Edmund
if
he
liked
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
just
as
well
that
he
should
have
something
to
do
,
and
it
was
just
as
well
that
he
should
have
something
for
doing
it
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
would
be
more
agreeable
to
Edmund
than
the
army
,
remained
to
be
seen
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
the
Bosom
;
accomplished
in
the
art
of
seeming
to
make
things
of
small
account
,
and
really
enhancing
them
in
the
process
.
 
<EOS>
While
Henry
Gowan
,
whom
Decimus
had
thrown
away
,
went
through
the
whole
round
of
his
acquaintance
between
the
Gate
of
the
People
and
the
town
of
Albano
,
vowing
,
almost
(
but
not
quite
)
with
tears
in
his
eyes
,
that
Sparkler
was
the
sweetest
-
tempered
,
simplest
-
hearted
,
altogether
most
lovable
jackass
that
ever
grazed
on
the
public
common
;
and
that
only
one
circumstance
could
have
delighted
him
(
Gowan
)
more
,
than
his
(
the
beloved
jackass
's
)
getting
this
post
,
and
that
would
have
been
his
(
Gowan
's
)
getting
it
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
the
very
thing
for
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
do
,
and
he
would
do
it
charmingly
;
there
was
a
handsome
salary
to
draw
,
and
he
would
draw
it
charmingly
;
it
was
a
delightful
,
appropriate
,
capital
appointment
;
and
he
almost
forgave
the
donor
his
slight
of
himself
,
in
his
joy
that
the
dear
donkey
for
whom
he
had
so
great
<EOS>
an
affection
was
so
admirably
stabled
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
his
benevolence
stop
here
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
pains
,
on
all
social
occasions
,
to
draw
Mr
Sparkler
out
,
and
make
him
conspicuous
before
the
company
;
and
,
although
the
considerate
action
always
resulted
in
that
young
gentleman
's
making
a
dreary
and
forlorn
mental
spectacle
of
himself
,
the
friendly
intention
was
not
to
be
doubted
.
   
<EOS>
Unless
,
indeed
,
it
chanced
to
be
doubted
by
the
object
of
Mr
Sparkler
's
affections
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Fanny
was
now
in
the
difficult
situation
of
being
universally
known
in
that
light
,
and
of
not
having
dismissed
Mr
Sparkler
,
however
capriciously
she
used
him
.
<EOS>
Hence
,
she
was
sufficiently
identified
with
the
gentleman
to
feel
compromised
by
his
being
more
than
usually
ridiculous
;
and
hence
,
being
by
no
means
deficient
in
quickness
,
she
sometimes
came
to
his
rescue
against
Gowan
,
and
did
him
very
good
service
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
while
doing
this
,
she
was
ashamed
of
him
,
undetermined
whether
to
get
rid
of
him
or
more
decidedly
encourage
him
,
distracted
with
apprehensions
that
she
was
every
day
becoming
more
and
more
immeshed
in
her
uncertainties
,
and
tortured
by
misgivings
that
Mrs
Merdle
triumphed
in
her
distress
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
tumult
in
her
mind
,
it
is
no
subject
for
surprise
that
Miss
Fanny
came
home
one
night
in
a
state
of
agitation
from
a
concert
and
ball
at
Mrs
Merdle
's
house
,
and
on
her
sister
affectionately
trying
to
soothe
her
,
<EOS>
pushed
that
sister
away
from
the
toilette
-
table
at
which
she
sat
angrily
trying
to
cry
,
and
declared
with
a
heaving
bosom
that
she
detested
everybody
,
and
she
wished
she
was
dead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Fanny
,
what
is
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Matter
,
you
little
Mole
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
not
the
blindest
of
the
blind
,
you
would
have
no
occasion
to
ask
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
daring
to
pretend
to
assert
that
you
have
eyes
in
your
head
,
and
yet
ask
me
what
's
the
matter
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
Mr
Sparkler
,
dear
?
"
<EOS>
"
Mis
-
ter
Spark
-
ler
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Fanny
,
with
unbounded
scorn
,
as
if
he
were
the
last
subject
in
the
Solar
system
that
could
possibly
be
near
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Miss
Bat
,
it
is
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
Immediately
afterwards
,
she
became
remorseful
for
having
called
her
sister
names
;
declaring
with
sobs
that
she
knew
she
made
herself
hateful
,
but
that
everybody
drove
her
to
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
are
well
to
-
night
,
dear
Fanny
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stuff
and
nonsense
!
"
replied
the
young
lady
,
turning
angry
again
;
"
I
am
as
well
as
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
might
say
better
,
and
yet
make
no
boast
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Little
Dorrit
,
not
seeing
her
way
to
the
offering
of
any
soothing
words
that
would
escape
repudiation
,
deemed
it
best
to
remain
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
Fanny
took
this
ill
,
too
;
protesting
to
her
looking
-
glass
,
that
of
all
the
trying
sisters
a
girl
could
have
,
she
did
think
the
most
trying
sister
was
a
flat
sister
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
knew
she
was
at
times
a
wretched
temper
<EOS>
;
that
she
knew
she
made
herself
hateful
;
that
when
she
made
herself
hateful
,
nothing
would
do
her
half
the
good
as
being
told
so
;
but
that
,
being
afflicted
with
a
flat
sister
,
she
never
WAS
told
so
,
and
the
consequence
resulted
that
she
was
absolutely
tempted
and
goaded
into
making
herself
disagreeable
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
(
she
angrily
told
her
looking
-
glass
)
,
she
did
n't
want
to
be
forgiven
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
right
example
,
that
she
should
be
constantly
stooping
to
be
forgiven
by
a
younger
sister
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
Art
of
it
---
that
she
was
always
being
placed
in
the
position
of
being
forgiven
,
whether
she
liked
it
or
not
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
she
burst
into
violent
weeping
,
and
,
when
her
sister
came
and
sat
close
at
her
side
to
comfort
her
,
said
,
"
Amy
,
you
're
an
Angel
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
I
tell
you
what
,
my
Pet
,
"
said
Fanny
,
when
her
sister
's
gentleness
had
calmed
her
,
"
it
now
comes
to
this
;
that
things
can
not
and
shall
not
go
on
as
they
are
at
present
going
on
,
and
that
there
must
be
an
end
of
this
,
one
way
or
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
announcement
was
vague
,
though
very
peremptory
,
Little
Dorrit
returned
,
"
Let
us
talk
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
my
dear
,
"
assented
Fanny
,
as
she
dried
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
talk
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
rational
again
now
,
and
you
shall
advise
me
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
advise
me
,
my
sweet
child
?
"
   
<EOS>
Even
Amy
smiled
at
this
notion
,
but
she
said
,
"
I
will
,
Fanny
,
as
well
as
I
can
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
dearest
Amy
,
"
returned
Fanny
,
kissing
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
anchor
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
embraced
her
Anchor
with
great
affection
,
Fanny
took
a
bottle
of
sweet
toilette
water
from
the
table
,
and
called
to
her
maid
for
a
fine
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
dismissed
that
attendant
for
the
night
,
and
went
on
to
be
advised
;
dabbing
her
eyes
and
forehead
from
time
to
time
to
cool
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
Fanny
began
,
"
our
characters
and
points
of
view
are
sufficiently
different
(
kiss
me
again
,
my
darling
)
,
to
make
it
very
probable
that
I
shall
surprise
you
by
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
am
going
to
say
,
my
dear
,
is
,
that
notwithstanding
our
property
,
we
labour
,
socially
speaking
,
under
disadvantages
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
quite
understand
what
I
mean
,
Amy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
I
shall
,
"
said
Amy
,
mildly
,
"
after
a
few
words
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
what
I
mean
is
,
that
we
are
,
after
all
,
newcomers
into
fashionable
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
Fanny
,
"
Little
Dorrit
interposed
in
her
zealous
admiration
,
"
no
one
need
find
that
out
in
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
child
,
perhaps
not
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
though
it
's
most
kind
and
most
affectionate
in
you
,
you
precious
girl
,
to
say
so
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
she
dabbed
her
sister
's
forehead
,
and
blew
upon
it
a
little
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
you
are
,
"
resumed
Fanny
,
"
as
is
well
known
,
the
dearest
little
thing
that
ever
was
!
 
<EOS>
To
resume
,
my
child
.
 
<EOS>
Pa
is
extremely
gentlemanly
and
extremely
well
informed
,
but
he
is
,
in
some
trifling
respects
,
a
little
different
from
other
gentlemen
of
his
fortune
:
partly
on
account
of
what
he
has
gone
through
,
poor
dear
:
partly
,
I
fancy
,
on
account
of
its
often
running
in
his
mind
that
other
people
are
thinking
about
that
,
while
he
is
talking
to
them
.
<EOS>
Uncle
,
my
love
,
is
altogether
unpresentable
.
 
<EOS>
Though
a
dear
creature
to
whom
I
am
tenderly
attached
,
he
is
,
socially
speaking
,
shocking
.
 
<EOS>
Edward
is
frightfully
expensive
and
dissipated
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
that
there
is
anything
ungenteel
in
that
itself
---
far
from
it
---
<EOS>
but
I
do
mean
that
he
does
n't
do
it
well
,
and
that
he
does
n't
,
if
I
may
so
express
myself
,
get
the
money's
-
worth
in
the
sort
of
dissipated
reputation
that
attaches
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
Edward
!
"
sighed
Little
Dorrit
,
with
the
whole
family
history
in
the
sigh
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
poor
you
and
me
,
too
,
"
returned
Fanny
,
rather
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
!
 
<EOS>
Then
,
my
dear
,
we
have
no
mother
,
and
we
have
a
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
tell
you
again
,
darling
,
that
Mrs
General
,
if
I
may
reverse
a
common
proverb
and
adapt
it
to
her
,
is
a
cat
in
gloves
who
WILL
catch
mice
.
 
<EOS>
That
woman
,
I
am
quite
sure
and
confident
,
will
be
our
mother
-
in
-
law
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
hardly
think
,
Fanny
---
"
Fanny
stopped
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
argue
with
me
about
it
,
Amy
,
"
said
she
,
"
because
I
know
better
.
"
 
<EOS>
Feeling
that
she
had
been
sharp
again
<EOS>
,
she
dabbed
her
sister
's
forehead
again
,
and
blew
upon
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
resume
once
more
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
It
then
becomes
a
question
with
me
<EOS>
(
I
am
proud
and
spirited
,
<EOS>
Amy
,
as
you
very
well
know
:
too
much
so
,
I
dare
say
)
whether
I
shall
make
up
my
mind
to
take
it
upon
myself
to
carry
the
family
through
.
"
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
asked
her
sister
,
anxiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
said
Fanny
,
without
answering
the
question
,
"
submit
to
be
mother
-
in
-
lawed
by
Mrs
General
;
and
I
will
not
submit
to
be
,
in
any
respect
whatever
,
either
patronised
or
tormented
by
Mrs
Merdle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
laid
her
hand
upon
the
hand
that
held
the
bottle
of
sweet
water
,
with
a
still
more
anxious
look
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
,
quite
punishing
her
own
forehead
with
the
vehement
dabs
she
now
began
to
give
it
,
fitfully
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
he
has
somehow
or
other
,
and
how
is
of
no
consequence
,
attained
a
very
good
position
,
no
one
can
deny
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
is
a
very
good
connection
,
no
one
can
deny
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
the
question
of
clever
or
not
clever
,
I
doubt
very
much
whether
a
clever
husband
would
be
suitable
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
submit
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
be
able
to
defer
to
him
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
my
dear
Fanny
!
"
expostulated
Little
Dorrit
,
upon
whom
a
kind
of
terror
had
been
stealing
as
she
perceived
what
her
sister
meant
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
loved
any
one
,
all
this
feeling
would
change
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
loved
any
one
,
you
would
no
more
be
yourself
,
but
you
would
quite
lose
and
forget
yourself
in
your
devotion
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
loved
him
,
Fanny
---
"
Fanny
had
stopped
the
dabbing
hand
,
and
was
looking
at
her
fixedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
O
,
indeed
!
"
cried
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
?
 
<EOS>
Bless
me
,
how
much
some
people
know
of
some
subjects
!
 
<EOS>
They
say
every
one
has
a
subject
,
and
I
certainly
seem
to
have
hit
upon
yours
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
you
little
thing
,
I
was
only
in
fun
,
"
dabbing
her
sister
's
forehead
;
"
but
do
n't
you
be
a
silly
puss
,
and
do
n't
you
think
flightily
and
eloquently
about
degenerate
impossibilities
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'll
go
back
to
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Fanny
,
let
me
say
first
,
that
I
would
far
<EOS>
rather
we
worked
for
a
scanty
living
again
than
I
would
see
you
rich
and
married
to
Mr
Sparkler
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
you
say
,
my
dear
?
"
retorted
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
of
course
,
I
will
let
you
say
anything
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
constraint
upon
you
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
together
to
talk
it
over
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
marrying
Mr
Sparkler
,
I
have
not
the
slightest
intention
of
doing
so
to
-
night
,
my
dear
,
or
to
-
morrow
morning
either
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
at
some
time
?
"
   
"
At
no
time
,
for
anything
I
know
at
present
,
"
answered
Fanny
,
with
indifference
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
suddenly
changing
her
indifference
into
a
burning
restlessness
,
she
added
,
"
You
talk
about
the
clever
men
,
you
little
thing
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
very
fine
and
easy
to
talk
about
the
clever
men
;
but
where
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
them
anywhere
near
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Fanny
,
so
short
a
time
---
"
   
"
Short
time
or
long
time
,
"
interrupted
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
impatient
of
our
situation
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
our
situation
,
and
very
little
would
induce
me
to
change
it
.
 
<EOS>
Other
girls
,
differently
reared
and
differently
circumstanced
altogether
,
might
wonder
at
what
I
say
or
may
do
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
driven
by
their
lives
and
characters
;
I
am
driven
by
mine
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
my
dear
Fanny
<EOS>
,
you
know
that
you
have
qualities
to
make
you
the
wife
of
one
very
superior
to
Mr
Sparkler
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
my
dear
Amy
,
"
retorted
Fanny
,
parodying
her
words
,
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
I
wish
to
have
a
more
defined
and
distinct
position
,
in
which
I
can
assert
myself
with
greater
effect
against
that
insolent
woman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
therefore
---
forgive
my
asking
,
Fanny
---
therefore
marry
her
son
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Fanny
,
with
a
triumphant
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
many
less
promising
ways
of
arriving
at
an
end
than
that
,
MY
dear
.
<EOS>
That
piece
of
insolence
may
think
,
now
,
that
it
would
be
a
great
success
to
get
her
son
off
upon
me
,
and
shelve
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
perhaps
,
she
little
thinks
how
I
would
retort
upon
her
if
I
married
her
son
.
   
<EOS>
I
would
oppose
her
in
everything
,
and
compete
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
make
it
the
business
of
my
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fanny
set
down
the
bottle
when
she
came
to
this
,
and
walked
about
the
room
;
always
stopping
and
standing
still
while
she
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
thing
I
could
certainly
do
,
my
child
:
I
could
make
her
older
.
<EOS>
And
I
would
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
followed
by
another
walk
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
talk
of
her
as
an
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
pretend
to
know
 
---
if
I
did
n't
,
but
I
should
from
her
son
---
all
about
her
age
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
should
hear
me
say
,
<EOS>
Amy
:
affectionately
,
quite
dutifully
and
affectionately
:
how
well
she
looked
,
considering
her
time
of
life
.
<EOS>
I
could
make
her
seem
older
at
once
,
by
being
myself
so
much
younger
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
not
be
as
handsome
as
she
is
;
I
am
not
a
fair
judge
of
that
question
,
I
suppose
;
but
I
know
I
am
handsome
enough
to
be
a
thorn
in
her
side
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
would
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
sister
,
would
you
condemn
yourself
to
an
unhappy
life
for
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
n't
be
an
unhappy
life
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
the
life
I
am
fitted
for
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
by
disposition
,
or
whether
by
circumstances
,
is
no
matter
;
I
am
better
fitted
for
such
a
life
than
for
almost
any
other
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
of
a
desolate
tone
in
those
words
;
but
,
with
a
short
proud
laugh
she
took
another
walk
,
and
after
passing
a
great
looking
-
glass
came
to
another
stop
.
   
<EOS>
"
Figure
!
 
<EOS>
Figure
,
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
The
woman
has
a
good
figure
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
give
her
her
due
,
and
not
deny
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
is
it
so
far
beyond
all
others
that
it
is
altogether
unapproachable
?
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
I
am
not
so
sure
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Give
some
much
younger
woman
the
latitude
as
to
dress
that
she
has
,
being
married
;
and
we
would
see
about
that
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
Something
in
the
thought
that
was
agreeable
and
flattering
,
brought
her
back
to
her
seat
in
a
gayer
temper
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
her
sister
's
hands
in
hers
,
and
clapped
all
four
hands
above
her
head
as
she
looked
in
her
sister
's
face
laughing
:
   
"
<EOS>
And
the
dancer
,
Amy
,
that
she
has
quite
forgotten
---
the
dancer
who
bore
no
sort
of
resemblance
to
me
,
and
of
whom
I
never
remind
her
,
<EOS>
oh
dear
<EOS>
no
!
---
should
dance
through
her
life
,
and
dance
in
her
way
,
to
such
a
tune
as
would
disturb
her
insolent
placidity
a
little
.
<EOS>
just
a
little
,
my
dear
Amy
,
just
a
little
!
"
   
<EOS>
Meeting
an
earnest
and
imploring
look
in
Amy
's
face
,
she
brought
the
four
hands
down
,
and
laid
only
one
on
Amy
's
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
argue
with
me
,
child
,
"
she
said
in
a
sterner
way
,
"
because
it
is
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
I
understand
these
subjects
much
better
than
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
nearly
made
up
my
mind
,
but
it
may
be
.
<EOS>
Now
we
have
talked
this
over
comfortably
,
and
may
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
You
best
and
dearest
little
mouse
,
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
those
words
Fanny
weighed
her
Anchor
,
and
---
having
taken
so
much
advice
---
left
off
being
advised
for
that
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
Thenceforward
,
Amy
observed
Mr
Sparkler
's
treatment
by
his
enslaver
,
with
new
reasons
for
attaching
importance
to
all
that
passed
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
times
when
Fanny
appeared
quite
unable
to
endure
his
mental
feebleness
,
and
when
she
became
so
sharply
impatient
of
it
that
she
would
all
but
dismiss
him
for
good
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
other
times
when
she
got
on
much
better
with
him
;
when
he
amused
her
,
and
when
her
sense
of
superiority
seemed
to
counterbalance
that
opposite
side
of
the
scale
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Sparkler
had
been
other
than
the
faithfullest
and
most
submissive
of
swains
,
he
was
sufficiently
hard
pressed
to
have
fled
from
the
scene
of
his
trials
,
and
have
set
at
least
the
whole
distance
from
Rome
to
London
between
himself
and
his
enchantress
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
no
greater
will
of
his
own
than
a
boat
has
when
it
is
towed
by
a
steam
-
ship
;
and
he
followed
his
cruel
mistress
through
rough
and
smooth
,
on
equally
strong
compulsion
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
,
during
these
passages
,
said
little
to
Fanny
,
but
said
more
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
,
as
it
were
,
forced
to
look
at
her
through
her
eye
-
glass
,
and
in
general
conversation
to
allow
commendations
of
her
beauty
to
be
wrung
from
her
by
its
irresistible
demands
.
<EOS>
The
defiant
character
it
assumed
when
Fanny
heard
these
extollings
(
as
it
generally
happened
that
she
did
)
,
was
not
expressive
of
concessions
to
the
impartial
bosom
;
but
the
utmost
revenge
the
bosom
took
was
,
to
say
audibly
,
"
A
spoilt
beauty
---
but
with
that
face
and
shape
,
who
could
wonder
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
about
a
month
or
six
weeks
after
the
night
of
the
new
advice
,
when
Little
Dorrit
began
to
think
she
detected
some
new
understanding
between
Mr
Sparkler
and
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
as
if
in
attendance
to
some
compact
,
scarcely
ever
spoke
without
first
looking
towards
Fanny
for
leave
.
 
<EOS>
That
young
lady
was
too
discreet
ever
to
look
back
again
;
but
,
if
Mr
Sparkler
had
permission
to
speak
,
she
remained
silent
;
if
he
had
not
,
she
herself
spoke
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
it
became
plain
whenever
Henry
Gowan
attempted
to
perform
the
friendly
office
of
drawing
him
out
,
that
he
was
not
to
be
drawn
.
 
<EOS>
And
not
only
that
,
but
Fanny
<EOS>
would
presently
,
without
any
pointed
application
in
the
world
,
chance
to
say
something
with
such
a
sting
in
it
that
Gowan
would
draw
back
as
if
he
had
put
his
hand
into
a
bee
-
hive
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
yet
another
circumstance
which
went
a
long
way
to
confirm
Little
Dorrit
in
her
fears
,
though
it
was
not
a
great
circumstance
in
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
's
demeanour
towards
herself
changed
.
 
<EOS>
It
became
fraternal
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
when
she
was
in
the
outer
circle
of
assemblies
---
at
their
own
residence
,
at
Mrs
Merdle
's
,
or
elsewhere
---
she
would
find
herself
stealthily
supported
round
the
waist
by
Mr
Sparkler
's
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
never
offered
the
slightest
explanation
of
this
attention
;
but
merely
smiled
with
an
air
of
blundering
,
contented
,
good
-
natured
proprietorship
,
which
,
in
so
heavy
a
gentleman
,
was
ominously
expressive
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
at
home
one
day
,
thinking
about
Fanny
with
a
heavy
heart
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
a
room
at
one
end
of
their
drawing
-
room
suite
,
nearly
all
irregular
bay
-
window
,
projecting
over
the
street
,
and
commanding
all
the
picturesque
life
and
variety
of
the
Corso
,
both
up
and
down
.
 
<EOS>
At
three
or
four
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
English
time
,
the
view
from
this
window
was
very
bright
and
peculiar
;
and
Little
Dorrit
used
to
sit
and
muse
here
,
much
as
she
had
been
used
to
while
away
the
time
in
her
balcony
at
Venice
.
<EOS>
Seated
thus
one
day
,
she
was
softly
touched
on
the
shoulder
,
and
Fanny
said
,
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Amy
dear
,
"
and
took
her
seat
at
her
side
.
 
<EOS>
Their
seat
was
a
part
of
the
window
;
when
there
was
anything
in
the
way
of
a
procession
going
on
,
they
used
to
have
bright
draperies
hung
out
of
the
window
,
and
used
to
kneel
or
sit
on
this
seat
,
and
look
out
at
it
,
leaning
on
the
brilliant
colour
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
procession
that
day
,
and
Little
Dorrit
was
rather
surprised
by
Fanny
's
being
at
home
at
that
hour
,
as
she
was
generally
out
on
horseback
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Amy
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
what
are
you
thinking
of
,
little
one
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
was
thinking
of
you
,
Fanny
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
?
 
<EOS>
What
a
coincidence
!
 
<EOS>
I
declare
here
's
some
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
not
thinking
of
this
some
one
else
too
;
were
you
,
Amy
?
"
   
<EOS>
Amy
HAD
been
thinking
of
this
some
one
else
too
;
for
it
was
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
not
say
so
,
however
,
as
she
gave
him
her
hand
.
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
came
and
sat
down
on
the
other
side
of
her
,
and
she
felt
the
fraternal
railing
come
behind
her
,
and
apparently
stretch
on
to
include
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
little
sister
,
"
said
Fanny
with
a
sigh
,
"
I
suppose
you
know
what
this
means
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
as
beautiful
as
she
's
doated
on
,
"
stammered
Mr
Sparkler
---
"
and
there
's
no
nonsense
about
her
<EOS>
---
it
's
arranged
---
"
   
"
You
need
n't
explain
,
Edmund
,
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
pet
,
"
proceeded
Fanny
,
"
on
the
whole
,
we
are
engaged
.
<EOS>
We
must
tell
papa
about
it
either
to
-
night
or
to
-
morrow
,
according
to
the
opportunities
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
's
done
,
and
very
little
more
need
be
said
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Fanny
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
with
deference
,
"
I
should
like
to
say
a
word
to
Amy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
Say
it
for
goodness
'
sake
,
"
returned
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
convinced
,
my
dear
Amy
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
that
if
ever
there
was
a
girl
,
next
to
your
highly
endowed
and
beautiful
sister
,
who
had
no
nonsense
about
her
---
"
   
"
We
know
all
about
that
,
Edmund
,
"
interposed
Miss
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
that
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
go
on
to
something
else
besides
our
having
no
nonsense
about
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
assure
you
,
Amy
,
that
nothing
can
be
a
greater
happiness
to
myself
,
myself
---
next
to
the
happiness
of
being
so
highly
honoured
with
the
choice
of
a
glorious
girl
who
has
n't
an
atom
of
---
"
   
"
Pray
,
Edmund
,
pray
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Fanny
,
with
a
slight
pat
of
her
pretty
foot
upon
the
floor
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
you
're
quite
right
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
know
I
have
a
habit
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
wished
to
declare
was
,
that
nothing
can
be
a
greater
happiness
to
myself
,
myself
-
next
to
the
happiness
of
being
united
to
pre
-
eminently
the
most
glorious
of
girls
---
than
to
have
the
happiness
of
cultivating
the
affectionate
acquaintance
of
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
not
myself
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
manfully
,
"
be
up
to
the
mark
on
some
other
subjects
at
a
short
notice
,
and
I
am
aware
that
if
you
were
to
poll
Society
the
general
opinion
would
be
that
I
am
not
;
but
on
the
subject
of
Amy
<EOS>
I
am
up
to
the
mark
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
kissed
her
,
in
witness
thereof
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
knife
and
fork
and
an
apartment
,
"
proceeded
Mr
Sparkler
,
growing
,
in
comparison
with
his
oratorical
antecedents
,
quite
diffuse
,
"
will
ever
be
at
Amy
's
disposal
.
 
<EOS>
My
Governor
,
I
am
sure
,
will
always
be
proud
to
entertain
one
whom
I
so
much
esteem
.
 
<EOS>
And
regarding
my
mother
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
who
is
a
remarkably
fine
woman
,
with
---
"
   
"
Edmund
,
Edmund
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Fanny
,
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
submission
,
my
soul
,
"
pleaded
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
have
a
habit
of
it
,
and
I
thank
you
very
much
,
my
adorable
girl
,
for
taking
the
trouble
to
correct
it
;
but
my
mother
is
admitted
on
all
sides
to
be
a
remarkably
fine
woman
,
and
she
really
has
n't
any
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
may
be
,
or
may
not
be
,
"
returned
Fanny
,
"
but
pray
<EOS>
do
n't
mention
it
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
in
fact
,
you
have
nothing
more
to
say
,
Edmund
;
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
far
from
it
,
my
adorable
girl
,
"
answered
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
I
apologise
for
having
said
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
perceived
,
by
a
kind
of
inspiration
,
that
the
question
implied
had
he
not
better
go
?
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
withdrew
the
fraternal
railing
,
and
neatly
said
that
he
thought
he
would
,
with
submission
,
take
his
leave
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
go
without
being
congratulated
by
Amy
,
as
well
as
she
could
discharge
that
office
in
the
flutter
and
distress
of
her
spirits
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
was
gone
,
she
said
,
"
O
Fanny
,
Fanny
!
"
and
turned
to
her
sister
in
the
bright
window
,
and
fell
upon
her
bosom
and
cried
there
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
laughed
at
first
;
but
soon
laid
her
face
against
her
sister
's
and
cried
too
---
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
last
time
<EOS>
Fanny
ever
showed
that
there
was
any
hidden
,
suppressed
,
or

in
her
on
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
hour
the
way
she
had
chosen
lay
before
her
,
and
she
trod
it
with
her
own
imperious
self
-
willed
step
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
No
just
Cause
or
Impediment
why
these
Two
Persons
should
not
be
joined
together
 
Mr
Dorrit
,
on
being
informed
by
his
elder
daughter
that
she
had
accepted
matrimonial
overtures
from
Mr
Sparkler
,
to
whom
she
had
plighted
her
troth
,
received
the
communication
at
once
with
great
dignity
and
with
a
large
display
of
parental
pride
;
his
dignity
dilating
with
the
widened
prospect
of
advantageous
ground
from
which
to
make
acquaintances
,
and
his
parental
pride
being
developed
by
Miss
Fanny
's
ready
sympathy
with
that
great
object
of
his
existence
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
her
to
understand
that
her
noble
ambition
found
harmonious
echoes
in
his
heart
;
and
bestowed
his
blessing
on
her
,
as
a
child
brimful
of
duty
and
good
principle
,
self
-
devoted
to
the
aggrandisement
of
the
family
name
.
   
<EOS>
To
Mr
Sparkler
,
when
Miss
Fanny
permitted
him
to
appear
,
Mr
Dorrit
said
,
he
would
not
disguise
that
the
alliance
Mr
Sparkler
did
him
the
honour
to
propose
was
highly
congenial
to
his
feelings
;
both
as
being
in
unison
with
the
spontaneous
affections
of
his
daughter
Fanny
,
and
as
opening
a
family
connection
of
a
gratifying
nature
with
Mr
Merdle
,
the
master
spirit
of
the
age
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
also
,
as
a
leading
lady
rich
in
distinction
,
elegance
,
grace
,
and
beauty
,
he
mentioned
in
very
laudatory
terms
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
it
his
duty
to
remark
<EOS>
(
he
was
sure
a
gentleman
of
Mr
Sparkler
's
fine
sense
would
interpret
him
with
all
delicacy
)
,
that
he
could
not
consider
this
proposal
definitely
determined
on
,
until
he
should
have
had
the
privilege
of
holding
some
correspondence
with
Mr
Merdle
;
and
of
ascertaining
it
to
be
so
far
accordant
with
the
views
of
that
eminent
gentleman
as
that
his
(
Mr
Dorrit
's
)
daughter
would
be
received
on
that
footing
which
her
station
in
life
and
her
dowry
and
expectations
warranted
him
in
requiring
that
she
should
maintain
in
what
he
trusted
he
might
be
allowed
,
without
the
appearance
of
being
mercenary
,
to
call
the
Eye
of
the
Great
World
.
<EOS>
While
saying
this
,
which
his
character
as
a
gentleman
of
some
little
station
,
and
his
character
as
a
father
,
equally
demanded
of
him
,
he

not

so

as
to

that

in

and

,
and
that

thanked
Mr
Sparkler
for
the

to

.
 
<EOS>
He
concluded
with
some
further
and
more
general

on
the
---
ha
---
character
of
an
independent

,
and
the
---
hum
---
character
of
a

too

.
<EOS>
To

,

's

very
much
as
he
would

three

half

from

in
the

that
were
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
finding

stunned
by
the
words
thus
heaped
upon

,
made

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

object
of

shut

up
like

box

spring

,

.
   
<EOS>
Proceeding

to

the
Bosom
,
Mr

was
received

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
had
heard

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

a

.
 
<EOS>
Society

not

a

.
 
<EOS>
Still
,

,

(
we

,
Mr

!
)
,
that

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
That

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
At

,

had

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

had
observed

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Though
,

,
Mr

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

<EOS>

;
"

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

see
-
saw
of
Mr

Mrs

,
so
that

sent

,

,
and

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
He
remarked
with

,
that
he
must

,

,

(

)
,
that
such

as
Mr

's
,
apart

of

rest

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
are

,
"

in

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
But
I

in
my

about

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
threw
in

here
,
to
the

that
business
,
like
the
time
which
was
precious
in

,
was
made
for
slaves
;
and
that

Mrs
Merdle
,
who
ruled
all
hearts
at
her

,
to
have

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
laughed
,
and
conveyed
to
Mr
Dorrit
an
idea
that
the
Bosom
flushed
---
which
was
one
of
her
best
effects
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
so
much
,
"
she
then

,
"
merely
because
Mr
Merdle
has

Edmund
,

.
 
<EOS>
Edmund
's
public
position
<EOS>
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
His

.
 
<EOS>
In
my

for
business
,
I

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

again

,
in

,
the

that
business
was
below

ken
of

and

.
 
<EOS>
He
then
mentioned
his
intention
,
as

and

,
of
writing
to
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

with

---

,
which
was

---
and

a

letter
by
the
next

to
the
eighth

.
   
<EOS>
In
his

,
as
in
his

and

on
the
great
question
to
which

,
Mr

surrounded
the
subject
with

,
as
writing
-

embellish

-

-

:
where

into

,

,

,

,

of

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he

,
to
enable
Mr
Merdle
to
make

decent

of

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
replied
to

accordingly
.
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
replied
to
Mr
Merdle
;
Mr
Merdle
replied
to
Mr
Dorrit
;
and
it
was
soon
announced
that
the

powers
had

.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
and

,
Miss

burst

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
<EOS>
and
not

,

Mr

in

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
No

that
want

,

,
and
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,

"

<EOS>
I

"

"
   
"
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
"

.

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tired
,
"

"
of
---

---
Mrs

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Quite

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

"

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

General
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
returned
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
<EOS>
I
am
amazed
,
I
am
displeased
by
this
---
hum
---
this
capricious
and
unintelligible

of
animosity
towards
---
ha
---
Mrs
General
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
not
,

,
papa
,
"

,
"
call
it
animosity
,
because
I
assure
you
I
do
not

Mrs
General
worth
my
animosity
.
"
   
<EOS>
At

,
Mr
Dorrit
rose

with
a

of
severe

,
and
remained

in

daughter
.
<EOS>
His

,
turning

on

,
and
now

,
and
now

,
said
,
"
Very

,
papa
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
truly
sorry
if
you
do
n't

;
but
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

,
and
I

not
Amy
,
and
I
must

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"

,

,
"

to

,

General
,

,

---
hum
---

,
the
---
ha
---

;
if
I
---
ha
---

,

---
<EOS>
hum
---

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"
Fanny

,
"

make

as

,
I
have
in

.
 
<EOS>
I

upon

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
,
Fanny
sat
down
with

which
,
in

junction

,

;
and

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
General
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tinkler
,

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
seeing

,

"
How

,

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,
"

,

---
"
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

---
<EOS>
hum
---

.
 
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
MY

,

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
In

,
Mr

perhaps

was

.
 
<EOS>
However

,
Mrs
General
's

,
coming
along
---
one

said

---

.
 
<EOS>
Albeit
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
General
,
"

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,

---
ha

---
"
   
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
---

my

now

---
"
   
Mrs

,
who

Mrs
General
,

<EOS>
"
---

---

<EOS>

ha
---

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

General
,

,
"
is

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
Miss
Fanny

,
as

,
"
You

.
"
)
   
<EOS>
"
Miss

,

.
 
<EOS>
When
free

the

of

,
"
Mrs
General
closed
her

word
,
as
if
she
could

,
and
see
anybody
;
"
when

of
near

;
and

proud

;

.
   
<EOS>
I

Miss
Dorrit
will
allow

to
offer
her
my
best

.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mrs
General
stopped
,
and
added

,
for

,
"
Papa
,
potatoes
,
poultry
,
Prunes
,

prism
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
she

,
"
is

;
and
for

attention
,
and

,
of

Miss
Dorrit

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

,
"
they

---
<EOS>
inexpressibly

.
 
<EOS>
The

that
you
have
no

to

,
Mrs
General
,
quite

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
"

,
"

,
Mrs

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
changed
her

,
as
to
the
right

being
uppermost
and
the

,
with

Prunes

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
Mrs
General
,
"
said
Fanny
,
returning

with
one
in

there
was
no

those

,
"
will
of

the
highest

;

,

of
course

perfect

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

your
great

will
not

,
and
I

papa

not

,
to
my

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
that

,
Mrs
General
,

.
 
<EOS>
The

have
so

,
Mrs
General
,
as

this
confidence
,
are
,
I

,
of
the
most

;
but

n't

.
 
<EOS>
The

on

have

me
,
that
I
feel
I
must
not
lay
claim
to
it
when

is

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
wholly
papa
's
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
deeply

to
you
for
your

and
patronage
,
but
it
was
papa
who
asked
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
to
thank
you
,
Mrs
General
,
for
relieving
my
breast
of
a
great
weight
by
so
handsomely
giving
your
consent
to
my
engagement
,
but
you
have
really
nothing
to
thank

for
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
always
approve
of
my
proceedings
after
I
have
left
home
and
that
my
sister
also
may
long
remain
the
favoured

of
your

,
Mrs
General
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
address
,
which
was
delivered
in
her
politest
manner
,
Fanny
left
the
room
with
an
elegant
and
cheerful
air
---
to
tear
up
-
stairs
with
a
flushed
face
as
soon
as
she
was
out
of
hearing
,
pounce
in
upon
her
sister
,
call
her
a
little
Dormouse
,
shake
her
for
the
better
opening
of
her
eyes
,
tell
her
what
had
passed
below
,
and
ask
her
what
she
thought
of
Pa
now
?
   
<EOS>
Towards
Mrs
Merdle
,
the
young
lady
comported
herself
with
great
independence
and
self
-
possession
;
but
not
as
yet
with
any
more
decided
opening
of
hostilities
.
 
<EOS>
Occasionally
they
had
a
slight
skirmish
,
as
when
Fanny
considered
herself
patted
on
the
back
by
that
lady
,
or
as
when
Mrs
Merdle
looked
particularly
young
and
well
;
but
Mrs
Merdle
always
soon
terminated
those
passages
of
arms
by
sinking
among
her
cushions
with
the
gracefullest
indifference
,
and
finding
her
attention
otherwise
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
Society
(
for
that
mysterious
creature
sat
upon
the
Seven
Hills
too
)
found
Miss
Fanny
vastly
improved
by
her
engagement
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
much
more
accessible
,
much
more
free
and
engaging
,
much
less
exacting
;
insomuch
that
she
now
entertained
a
host
of
followers
and
admirers
,
to
the
bitter
indignation
of
ladies
with
daughters
to
marry
,
who
were
to
be
regarded
as
Having
revolted
from
Society
on
the
Miss
Dorrit
grievance
,
and
erected
a
rebellious
standard
.
 
<EOS>
Enjoying
the
flutter
she
caused
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dorrit
not
only
haughtily
moved
through
it
in
her
own
proper
person
,
but
haughtily
,
even
Ostentatiously
,
led
Mr
Sparkler
through
it
too
:
seeming
to
say
to
them
all
,
"
If
I
think
proper
to
march
among
you
in
triumphal
procession
attended
by
this
weak
captive
in
bonds
,
rather
than
a
stronger
one
,
that
is
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
Enough
that
I
choose
to
do
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
for
his
part
,
questioned
nothing
;
but
went
wherever
he
was
taken
,
did
whatever
he
was
told
,
felt
that
for
his
bride
-
elect
to
be
distinguished
was
for
him
to
be
distinguished
on
the
easiest
terms
,
and
was
truly
grateful
for
being
so
openly
acknowledged
.
   
<EOS>
The
winter
passing
on
towards
the
spring
while
this
condition
of
affairs
prevailed
,
it
became
necessary
for
Mr
Sparkler
to
repair
to
England
,
and
take
his
appointed
part
in
the
expression
and
direction
of
its
genius
,
learning
,
commerce
,
spirit
,
and
sense
.
<EOS>
The
land
of
Shakespeare
,
Milton
,
Bacon
,
Newton
,
Watt
,
the
land
of
a
host
of
past
and
present
abstract
philosophers
,
natural
philosophers
,
and
subduers
of
Nature
and
Art
in
their
myriad
forms
,
called
to
Mr
Sparkler
to
come
and
take
care
of
it
,
lest
it
should
perish
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
unable
to
resist
the
agonised
cry
from
the
depths
of
his
country
's
soul
,
declared
that
he
must
go
.
   
<EOS>
It
followed
that
the
question
was
rendered
pressing
when
,
where
,
and
how
Mr
Sparkler
should
be
married
to
the
foremost
girl
in
all
this
world
with
no
nonsense
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
Its
solution
,
after
some
little
mystery
and
secrecy
,
Miss
Fanny
herself
announced
to
her
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
child
,
"
said
she
,
seeking
her
out
one
day
,
"
I
am
going
to
tell
you
something
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
only
this
moment
broached
;
and
naturally
I
hurry
to
you
the
moment
it
IS
broached
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
marriage
,
Fanny
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
precious
child
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
do
n't
anticipate
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
impart
my
confidence
to
you
,
you
flurried
little
thing
,
in
my
own
way
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
your
guess
,
if
I
answered
it
literally
,
I
should
answer
no
.
 
<EOS>
For
really
it
is
not
my
marriage
that
is
in
question
,
half
as
much
as
it
is
Edmund
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
looked
,
and
perhaps
not
altogether
without
cause
,
somewhat
at
a
loss
to
understand
this
fine
distinction
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
no
difficulty
,
"
exclaimed
Fanny
,
"
and
in
no
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
wanted
at
any
public
office
,
or
to
give
any
vote
anywhere
else
.
   
<EOS>
But
Edmund
is
.
 
<EOS>
And
Edmund
is
deeply
dejected
at
the
idea
of
going
away
by
himself
,
and
,
indeed
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
like
that
he
should
be
trusted
by
himself
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
if
it
's
possible
---
and
it
generally
is
---
to
do
a
foolish
thing
,
he
is
sure

do

.
"
   
<EOS>

,
the

<EOS>
"
It

Edmund
's

.
 
<EOS>
However

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

!
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

?

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

"

"
   
"

"

"

---

(

!
"
<EOS>
Little

received

without

but

.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
,
as
it
were
,
formally
wound
up
her

life
and
arranged
her
worldly
affairs
,
Fanny
proceeded
with
characteristic

to
prepare
for
the
serious
change
in
her
condition
.
   
<EOS>
The
preparation
consisted
in
the
despatch
of
her
maid
to
Paris
under
the
protection
of
the
Courier
,
for
the
purchase
of
that
outfit
for
a
bride
on
which
it
would
be
extremely
low
,
in
the
present
narrative
,
to
bestow
an
English
name
,
but
to
which
(
on
a
vulgar
principle
it
observes
of
adhering
to
the
language
in
which
it
professes
to
be
written
)
<EOS>
it
declines
to
give
a
French
one
.
 
<EOS>
The
rich
and
beautiful
wardrobe
purchased
by
these
agents
,
in
the
course
of
a
few
weeks
made
its
way
through
the
intervening
country
,
bristling
with
custom
-
houses
,
garrisoned
by
an
immense
army
of
shabby
mendicants
in
uniform
who
incessantly
repeated
the
Beggar
's
Petition
over
it
,
as
if
every
individual
warrior
among
them
were
the
ancient
Belisarius
:
and
of
whom
there
were
so
many
Legions
,
that
unless
the
Courier
had
expended
just
one
bushel
and
a
half
of
silver
money
relieving
their
distresses
,
they
would
have
worn
the
wardrobe
out
before
it
got
to
Rome
,
by
turning
it
over
and
over
.
<EOS>
Through
all
such
dangers
,
however
,
it
was
triumphantly
brought
,
inch
by
inch
,
and
arrived
at
its
journey
's
end
in
fine
condition
.
   
<EOS>
There
it
was
exhibited
to
select
companies
of
female
viewers
,
in
whose
gentle
bosoms
it
awakened
implacable
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
Concurrently
,
active
preparations
were
made
for
the
day
on
which
some
of
its
treasures
were
to
be
publicly
displayed
.
 
<EOS>
Cards
of
breakfast
-
invitation
were
sent
out
to
half
the
English
in
the
city
of
Romulus
;
the
other
half
made
arrangements
to
be
under
arms
,
as
criticising
volunteers
,
at
various
outer
points
of
the
solemnity
.
<EOS>
The
most
high
and
illustrious
English
Signor
Edgardo
Dorrit
,
came
post
through
the
deep
mud
and
ruts
(
from
forming
a
surface
under
the
improving
Neapolitan
nobility
)
,
to
grace
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
hotel
and
all
its
culinary
myrmidons
,
were
set
to
work
to
prepare
the
feast
.
 
<EOS>
The
drafts
of
Mr
Dorrit
almost
constituted
a
run
on
the
Torlonia
Bank
.
 
<EOS>
The
British
Consul
had
n't
had
such
a
marriage
in
the
whole
of
his
Consularity
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
came
,
and
the
She
-
Wolf
in
the
Capitol
might
have
snarled
with
envy
to
see
how
the
Island
Savages
contrived
these
things
now
-
a
-
days
.
<EOS>
The
murderous
-
headed
statues
of
the
wicked
Emperors
of
the
Soldiery
,
whom
sculptors
had
not
been
able
to
flatter
out
of
their
villainous
hideousness
,
might
have
come
off
their
pedestals
to
run
away
with
the
Bride
.
 
<EOS>
The
choked
old
fountain
,
where
erst
the
gladiators
washed
,
might
have
leaped
into
life
again
to
honour
the
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
The
Temple
of
Vesta
might
have
sprung
up
anew
from
its
ruins
,
expressly
to
lend
its
countenance
to
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
Might
have
done
;
but
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
Like
sentient
things
---
even
like
the
lords
and
ladies
of
creation
sometimes
---
might
have
done
much
,
but
did
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
The
celebration
went
off
with
admirable
pomp
;
monks
in
black
robes
,
white
robes
,
and
russet
robes
stopped
to
look
after
the
carriages
;
wandering
peasants
in
fleeces
of
sheep
,
begged
and
piped
under
the
house
-
windows
;
the
English
volunteers
defiled
;
the
day
wore
on
to
the
hour
of
vespers
;
the
festival
wore
away
;
the
thousand
churches
rang
their
bells
without
any
reference
to
it
;
and
St
Peter
denied
that
he
had
anything
to
do
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
But
by
that
time
the
Bride
was
near
the
end
of
the
first
day
's
journey
towards
Florence
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
peculiarity
of
the
nuptials
that
they
were
all
Bride
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
noticed
the
Bridegroom
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
noticed
the
first
Bridesmaid
.
 
<EOS>
Few
could
have
seen
Little
Dorrit
(
who
held
that
post
)
for
the
glare
,
even
supposing
many
to
have
sought
her
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
the
Bride
had
mounted
into
her
handsome
chariot
,
incidentally
accompanied
by
the
Bridegroom
;
and
after
rolling
for
a
few
minutes
smoothly
over
a
fair
pavement
,
had
begun
to
jolt
through
a
Slough
of
Despond
,
and
through
a
long
,
long
avenue
of
wrack
and
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
Other
nuptial
carriages
are
said
to
have
gone
the
same
road
,
before
and
since
.
   
<EOS>
If
Little
Dorrit
found
herself
left
a
little
lonely
and
a
little
low
that
night
,
nothing
would
have
done
so
much
against
her
feeling
of
depression
as
the
being
able
to
sit
at
work
by
her
father
,
as
in
the
old
time
,
and
help
him
to
his
supper
and
his
rest
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
was
not
to
be
thought
of
now
,
when
they
sat
in
the
state
-
equipage
with
Mrs
General
on
the
coach
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
supper
!
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Dorrit
had
wanted
supper
,
there
was
an
Italian
cook
and
there
was
a
Swiss
confectioner
,
who
must
have
put
on
caps
as
high
as
the
Pope
's
Mitre
,
and
have
performed
the
mysteries
of
Alchemists
in
a
copper
-
saucepaned
laboratory
below
,
before
he
could
have
got
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
sententious
and
didactic
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
simply
loving
,
he
would
have
done
Little
Dorrit
more
good
;
but
she
accepted
him
as
he
was
---
when
had
she
not
accepted
him
as
he
was
!
<EOS>
---
and
made
the
most
and
best
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
at
length
retired
.
<EOS>
Her
retirement
for
the
night
was
always
her
frostiest
ceremony
,
as
if
she
felt
it
necessary
that
the
human
imagination
should
be
chilled
into
stone
to
prevent
its
following
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
gone
through
her
rigid
preliminaries
,
amounting
to
a
sort
of
genteel
platoon
-
exercise
,
she
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
then
put
her
arm
<EOS>
round
her
father
's
neck
,
to
bid
him
good
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
taking
her
by
the
hand
,
"
this
is
the
close
of
a
day
,
that
has
---
ha
---
greatly
impressed
and
gratified
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
A
little
tired
you
,
dear
,
too
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
<EOS>
no
:
I
am
not
sensible
of
fatigue
when
it
arises
from
an
occasion
<EOS>
so
---
hum
---
replete
with
gratification
of
the
purest
kind
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
was
glad
to
find
him
in
such
heart
,
and
smiled
from
her
own
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
he
continued
,
"
this
is
an
occasion
---
ha
---
teeming
with
a
good
example
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
good
example
,
my
favourite
and
attached
child
 
---
hum
---
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
fluttered
by
his
words
,
did
not
know
what
to
say
,
though
he
stopped
as
if
he
expected
her
to
say
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
he
resumed
;
"
your
dear
sister
,
our
Fanny
,
has
contracted
ha
hum
---
a
marriage
,
eminently
calculated
to
extend
the
basis
of
our
---
ha
---
connection
,
and
to
---
hum
---
consolidate
our
social
relations
.
 
<EOS>
My
love
,
I
trust
that
the
time
is
not
far
distant
when
some
---
ha
---
eligible
partner
may
be
found
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
stay
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
and
pray
that
I
may
stay
with
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
want
nothing
but
to
stay
and
take
care
of
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
said
it
like
one
in
sudden
alarm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
Amy
,
Amy
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
weak
and
foolish
,
weak
and
foolish
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
---
ha
---
responsibility
imposed
upon
you
by
your
position
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
to
develop
that
position
,
and
be
---
<EOS>
hum
 
---
worthy
of
that
position
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
taking
care
of
me
;
I
can
---
ha
---
take
care
of
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Or
,
"
he
added
after

,
"
<EOS>
if
I
should
need
to
be
taken

of
,
I
---
hum
---
can
,
with
the
---
ha
---
blessing
of
Providence
,
be
taken
care
of
<EOS>
,
I
---
ha
hum
---
I
can
not
,
<EOS>
my
dear
child
,
think
of
engrossing
,
and
---
ha
---
as
it
were
,
sacrificing
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
O
what
a
time
of
day
at
which
to
begin
that
profession
of
self
-

;
at
which
to
make

,

an
air
of

;
at
which
to
believe

,
if
such

could
be
!
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
positively
say
I
can
not
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
ha
---
must
not
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
---
hum
---
conscience
would
not
allow
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
,
my
love
,
take
the
opportunity
afforded
by
this
gratifying
and
impressive
occasion
of
---
ha
---
solemnly

,
that
it
is
now
a
cherished

and

of
mine
to
see
you
---
ha
---
eligibly
<EOS>
(
I
repeat
eligibly
)
married
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
I
am
well
persuaded
that
if
the
topic
were
referred
to
any
person
of
superior
social
knowledge
,
of
superior

and
sense
---
let
us
say
,
for
instance
,
to
---
ha
---
Mrs
General
---
that
there
would
not
be
two
opinions
as
to
the
---
hum
---
affectionate
character
and
propriety
of
my

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
know
your
loving
and
dutiful
nature
from
---
hum
---
from
experience
,
I
am
quite
satisfied
that
it
is
necessary
to
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
---
hum
---
<EOS>
no
husband
to
propose
at
present
,
my
dear
:
<EOS>
I
have
not
even
one
in
view
.
 
<EOS>
I
merely
wish
that
we
should
---
ha
---
understand
each
other
.
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
my
dear
and
sole
remaining
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
.
   
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
If
the
thought
ever
entered
Little
Dorrit
's
head
that
night
,
that
he
could
give
her
up
lightly
now
in
his
prosperity
,
and
when
he
had
it
in
his
mind
to
replace
her
with
a
second
wife
,
she
drove
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
Faithful
to
him
<EOS>
still
,
as
in
the
worst
times
through
which
she
had
borne
him
single
-
handed
,
she
drove
the
thought
away
;
and
entertained
no
harder
reflection
,
in
her
tearful
unrest
,
than
that
he
now
saw
everything
through
their
wealth
,
and
through
the
care
he
always
had
upon
him
that
they
should
continue
rich
,
and
grow
richer
.
   
<EOS>
They
sat
in
their
equipage
of
state
,
with
Mrs
General
on
the
box
,
for
three
weeks
longer
,
and
then
he
started
for
Florence
to
join
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
would
have
been
glad
to
bear
him
company
so
far
,
only
for
the
sake
of
her
own
love
,
and
then
to
have
turned
back
alone
,
thinking
of
dear
England
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
though
the
Courier
had
gone
on
with
the
Bride
,
the
Valet
was
next
in
the
line
;
and
the
succession
would
not
have
come
to
her
,
as
long
as
any
one
could
be
got
for
money
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
took
life
easily
---
as
easily
,
that
is
,
as
she
could
take
anything
---
when
the
Roman
establishment
remained
in
their
sole
occupation
;
and
Little
Dorrit
would
often
ride
out
in
a
hired
carriage
that
was
left
them
,
and
alight
alone
and
wander
among
the
ruins
of
old
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
The
ruins
of
the
vast
old
Amphitheatre
,
of
the
old
Temples
,
of
the
old
commemorative
Arches
,
of
the
old
trodden
highways
,
of
the
old
tombs
,
besides
being
what
they
were
,
to
her
were
ruins
of
the
old
Marshalsea
---
ruins
of
her
own
old
life
---
ruins
of
the
faces
and
forms
that
of
old
peopled
it
---
ruins
of
its
loves
,
hopes
,
cares
,
and
joys
.
 
<EOS>
Two
ruined
spheres
of
action
and
suffering
were
before
the
solitary
girl
often
sitting
on
some
broken
fragment
;
and
in
the
lonely
places
,
under
the
blue
sky
,
she
saw
them
both
together
.
   
<EOS>
Up
,
then
,
would
come
Mrs
General
;
taking
all
the
colour
out
of
everything
,
as
Nature
and
Art
had
taken
it
out
of
herself
;
writing
Prunes
and
Prism
,
in
Mr
Eustace
's
text
,
wherever
she
could
lay
a
hand
;
looking
everywhere
for
Mr
Eustace
and
company
,
and
seeing
nothing
else
;
scratching
up
the
driest
little
bones
of
antiquity
,
and
bolting
them
whole
without
any
human
visitings
---
like
a
Ghoule
in
gloves
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
Getting
on
 
The
newly
married
pair
,
on
their
arrival
in
Harley
Street
,
Cavendish
Square
,
London
,
were
received
by
the
Chief
Butler
.
 
<EOS>
That
great
man
was
not
interested
in
them
,
but
on
the
whole
endured
them
.
 
<EOS>
People
must
continue
to
be
married
and
given
in
marriage
,
or
Chief
Butlers
would
not
be
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
As
nations
are
made
to
be
taxed
,
so
families
are
made
to
be
butlered
.
 
<EOS>
The
Chief
Butler
,
no
doubt
,
reflected
that
the
course
of
nature
required
the
wealthy
population
to
be
kept
up
,
on
his
account
.
   
<EOS>
He
therefore
condescended
to
look
at
the
carriage
from
the
Hall
-
door
without
frowning
at
it
,
and
said
,
in
a
very
handsome
way
,
to
one
of
his
men
,
"
<EOS>
Thomas
,
help
with
the
luggage
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
even
escorted
the
Bride
up
-
stairs
into
Mr
Merdle
's
presence
;
but
this
must
be
considered
as
an
act
of
homage
to
the
sex
(
of
which
he
was
an
admirer
,
being
notoriously
captivated
by
the
charms
of
a
certain
Duchess
)
,
and
not
as
a
committal
of
himself
with
the
family
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
was
slinking
about
the
hearthrug
,
waiting
to
welcome
Mrs
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
His
hand
seemed
to
retreat
up
his
sleeve
as
he
advanced
to
do
so
,
and
he
gave
her
such
a
superfluity
of
coat
-
cuff
that
it
was
like
being
received
by
the
popular
conception
of
Guy
Fawkes
.
<EOS>
When
he
put
his
lips
to
hers
,
besides
,
he
took
himself
into
custody
by
the
wrists
,
and
backed
himself
among
the
ottomans
and
chairs
and
tables
as
if
he
were
his
own
Police
officer
,
saying
to
himself
,
"
Now
,
none
of
that
!
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
I
've
got
you
,
you
know
,
and
you
go
quietly
along
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
,
installed
in
the
rooms
of
state
---
the
innermost
sanctuary
of
down
,
silk
,
chintz
,
and
fine
linen
---
felt
that
so
far
her
triumph
was
good
,
and
her
way
made
,
step
by
step
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
before
her
marriage
,
she
had
bestowed
on
Mrs
Merdle
's
maid
with
an
air
of
gracious
indifference
,
in
Mrs
Merdle
's
presence
,
a
trifling
little
keepsake
(
bracelet
,
bonnet
,
and
two
dresses
,
all
new
)
about
four
times
as
valuable
as
the
present
formerly
made
by
Mrs
Merdle
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
now
established
in
Mrs
Merdle
's
own
rooms
,
to
which
some
extra
touches
had
been
given
to
render
them
more
worthy
of
her
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
mind
's
eye
,
as
she
lounged
there
,
surrounded
by
every
luxurious
accessory
that
wealth
could
obtain
or
invention
devise
,
she
saw
the
fair
bosom
that
beat
in
unison
with
the
exultation
of
her
thoughts
,
competing
with
the
bosom
that
had
been
famous
so
long
,
outshining
it
,
and
deposing
it
.
 
<EOS>
Happy
?
 
<EOS>
Fanny
must
have
been
happy
.
 
<EOS>
No
more
wishing
one
's
self
dead
now
.
   
<EOS>
The
Courier
had
not
approved
of
Mr
Dorrit
's
staying
in
the
house
of
a
friend
,
and
had
preferred
to
take
him
to
an
hotel
in
Brook
Street
,
Grosvenor
Square
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
ordered
his
carriage
to
be
ready
early
in
the
morning
that
he
might
wait
upon
Mr
Dorrit
immediately
after
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Bright
the
carriage
looked
,
sleek
the
horses
looked
,
gleaming
the
harness
looked
,
luscious
and
lasting
the
liveries
looked
.
 
<EOS>
A
rich
,
responsible
turn
-
out
.
 
<EOS>
An
equipage
for
a
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
Early
people
looked
after
it
as
it
rattled
along
the
streets
,
and
said
,
with
awe
in
their
breath
,
"
There
he
goes
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
he
went
,
until
Brook
Street
stopped
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
forth
from
its
magnificent
case
came
the
jewel
;
not
lustrous
in
itself
,
but
quite
the
contrary
.
   
<EOS>
Commotion
in
the
office
of
the
hotel
.
 
<EOS>
Merdle
!
 
<EOS>
The
landlord
,
though
a
gentleman
of
a
haughty
spirit
who
had
just
driven
a
pair
of
thorough
-
bred
horses
into
town
,
turned
out
to
show
him
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
clerks
and
servants
cut
him
off
by
back
-
passages
,
and
were
found
accidentally
hovering
in
doorways
and
angles
,
that
they
might
look
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Merdle
!
 
<EOS>
O
ye
sun
,
moon
,
and
stars
,
the
great
man
!
 
<EOS>
The
rich
man
,
who
had
in
a
manner
revised
the
New
Testament
,
and
already
entered
into
the
kingdom
of
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
could
have
any
one
he
chose
to
dine
with
him
,
and
who
had
made
the
money
!
   
<EOS>
As
he
went
up
the
stairs
,
people
were
already
posted
on
the
lower
stairs
,
that
his
shadow
might
fall
upon
them
when
he
came
down
.
 
<EOS>
So
were
the
sick
brought
out
and
laid
in
the
track
of
the
Apostle
---
who
had
NOT
got
into
the
good
society
,
and
had
NOT
made
the
money
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
dressing
<EOS>
-
gowned
and
newspapered
,
was
at
his
breakfast
.
<EOS>
The
Courier
,
with
agitation
in
his
voice
,
announced
"
Miss
Mairdale
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's
overwrought
heart
bounded
as
he
leaped
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,
this
is
---
ha
---
indeed
an
honour
.
 
<EOS>
Permit
me
to
express
the
---
hum
---
sense
,
the
high
sense
,
I
entertain
of
this
---
ha
hum
---
highly
gratifying
act
of
attention
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
well
aware
,
sir
,
of
the
many
demands
upon
your
time
,
and
its
---
ha
---
enormous
value
,
"
Mr
Dorrit
could
not
say
enormous
roundly
enough
for
his
own
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
should
---
ha
---
at
this
early
hour
,
bestow
any
of
your
priceless
time
upon
me
,
is
---
ha
---
a
compliment
that
I
acknowledge
with
the
greatest
esteem
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
positively
trembled
in
addressing
the
great
man
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
uttered
,
in
his
subdued
,
inward
,
hesitating
voice
,
a
few
sounds
that
were
to
no
purpose
whatever
;
and
finally
said
,
"
I
am
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Truly
kind
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
visitor
was
seated
,
and
was
passing
his
great
hand
over
his
exhausted
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
well
,
I
hope
,
Mr
Merdle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
well
as
I
---
<EOS>
yes
,
I
am
as
well
as
I
usually
am
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
occupations
must
be
immense
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
Tolerably
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
---
Oh
dear
no
,
there
's
not
much
the
matter
with
me
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
looking
round
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
dyspeptic
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
hinted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
am
well
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
black
traces
on
his
lips
where
they
met
,
as
if
a
little
train
of
gunpowder
had
been
fired
there
;
and
he
looked
like
a
man
who
,
if
his
natural
temperament
had
been
quicker
,
would
have
been
very
feverish
that
morning
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
and
his
heavy
way
of
passing
his
hand
over
his
forehead
,
had
prompted
Mr
Dorrit
's
solicitous
inquiries
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
Mr
Dorrit
insinuatingly
pursued
,
"
I
left
,
as
you
will
be
prepared
to
hear
,
the
---
ha
---
observed
of
all
observers
,
the
---
hum
---
admired
of
all
admirers
,
the
leading
fascination
and
charm
of
Society
in
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
looking
wonderfully
well
when
I
quitted
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
is
generally
considered
a
very
attractive
woman
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
is
,
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sensible
of
her
being
SO
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
can
be
otherwise
?
<EOS>
"
responded
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
turned
his
tongue
in
his
closed
mouth
---
it
seemed
rather
a
stiff
and
unmanageable
tongue
---
moistened
his

,
passed
his
hand
over
his
forehead
again
,
and
looked
all

room

,
principally
under

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
"
he
said
,
looking
Mr
Dorrit
in

for
the
first

,
and
immediately

to

of
Mr
Dorrit
's

;
"
if
we
speak
of
attractions
,
your
daughter
ought
to
be
the
subject
of
our
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
extremely
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
Both
in
face
and
figure
,
she
is
quite
uncommon
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
young
people
arrived
last
night
,
I
was
really
surprised
to
see
such
charms
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's

was
such
that
he
said
---
ha
---
he
could
not
refrain
from
telling
Mr
Merdle
verbally
,
as
he
had
already
done
by
letter
,
what
honour
and

he
felt
in
this
union
of
their
families
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
offered
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
looked
at
the
hand
for
a
little
while
,
took
it
on
his
for
a
moment
as
if
his
were
a
yellow
salver
or
fish
-
slice
,
and
then
returned
it
to
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
would
drive
round
the
first
thing
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
to
offer

services
,
in

;
and

I
hope

to
-
day
,
and
every
day
when
you
are
not
better
engaged
during
your
stay
in
town
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
enraptured
by
these
attentions
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
stay
long
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
at
present
the
intention
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
of
 
---
ha
---
exceeding
a
fortnight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
very
short
stay
,
after
so
long
a
journey
,
"
returned
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
the
truth
is
---
ha
---
my
dear
Mr
Merdle
,
that
I
find
a
foreign
life
so

to

,
that
I
---
hum
---
have
but
<EOS>
two

.
 
<EOS>
First
,

---
ha
---
the

---
ha
 
---
privilege

now

;

,

---
hum
---

,

,

,
of
---

,

---

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

,
"

can

any

to

,
you

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's
speech
had
had
more
hesitation
in
it
than
usual
,
as
he
approached
the
ticklish
topic
,
for
he
was
not
perfectly
clear
how
so

might
take

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
doubts
whether
reference
to
any
individual
capital
,
or

,
might
not
seem
a
wretchedly
retail

to
so
wholesale

.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
relieved
by
Mr
Merdle
's

of

,

caught
at

,
and
heaped

upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
---
ha
---
dared
,
"
said
Mr

,
"
I

,

---
hum
---
vast

.
<EOS>
Though

,

,

---
ha
,
hum
---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Very

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Most

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
it

,
"

,
"
be

---

---
"
   
"
Of

,

!
"

Mr
Dorrit
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
---
Unless

.
 
<EOS>
At

are

to
term
a
very
long
figure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
laughed
in
the

of

spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Long
figure
.
 
<EOS>
Good
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Very
expressive
to
be
sure
!
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
I
do

in

own

the

some
preference
<EOS>
---
people

would

favour
---
as

my

and

.
"
<EOS>
"
And
public
spirit
and

,
"
Mr
Dorrit

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,

dry
,

,

;

,
"
As

sort

for

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
how
I
can
exert

(
for
people
are
jealous
,
and
it
is

)
,
to
your

.
"
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"

Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"
said
Mr

,
"
there

;

;
there

be
unimpeached
and
unimpeachable

;
or

could
not

on
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
hailed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
"
said
Mr

,
"
I
can
only

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
perceive
.
 
<EOS>
To
a

,
"
observed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Defined
extent
.
 
<EOS>
And
perfectly
above
-
board
.
 
<EOS>
As

my

,

,
"
said

Merdle
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
That
,
such

it
is
---
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Such
as
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
(
Mr
Dorrit
could
not
bear
the
faintest
appearance
of
its
being
depreciated
,
even

Mr
Merdle
himself
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
---
That
,
there

nothing

between

-
man
to
prevent
my

with
,
if
I

.
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
now
deeply

upon
a
dust
-
cart
that
was
passing

windows
,
"
shall
be
at
your
command
whenever
you
think
proper
.
"
   
<EOS>
New
acknowledgments
from
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
New
passages
of
Mr
Merdle
's
hand
over
his
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
Calm
and
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Contemplation
of
Mr
Dorrit
's
waistcoat
buttons
by
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
time
being
rather
precious
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
suddenly
getting
up
,
as
if
he
had
been
waiting
in
the
interval
for
his
legs
<EOS>
and
they
had
just
come
,
"
I
must
be
moving
towards
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
Can
I
take
you
anywhere
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
happy
to
set
you
down
,
or
send
you
on
.
<EOS>
My
carriage
is
at
your
disposal
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
bethought
himself
that
he
had
business
at
his
banker
's
.
<EOS>
His
banker
's
was
in
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
fortunate
;
Mr
Merdle
would
take
him
into
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
surely
,
he
might
not
detain
Mr
Merdle
while
he
assumed
his
coat
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
he
might
and
must
;
Mr
Merdle
insisted
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Dorrit
,
retiring
into
the
next
room
,
put
himself
under
the
hands
of
his
valet
,
and
in
five
minutes
came
back
glorious
.
   
<EOS>
Then
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
Allow
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Take
my
arm
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
leaning
on
Mr
Merdle
's
arm
,
did
Mr
Dorrit
descend
the
staircase
,
seeing
the
worshippers
on
the
steps
,
and
feeling
that
the
light
of
Mr
Merdle
shone
by
reflection
in
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
carriage
,
and
the
ride
into
the
City
;
and
the
people
who
looked
at
them
;
and
the
hats
that
flew
off
grey
heads
;
and
the
general
bowing
and
crouching
before
this
wonderful
mortal
the
like
of
which
prostration
of
spirit
was
not
to
be
seen
---
<EOS>
no
,
by
high
Heaven
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
worth
thinking
of
by
Fawners
of
all
denominations
---
in
Westminster
Abbey
and
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
put
together
,
on
any
Sunday
in
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
rapturous
dream
to
Mr
Dorrit
to
find
himself
set
aloft
in
this
public
car
of
triumph
,
making
a
magnificent
progress
to
that
befitting
destination
,
the
golden
Street
of
the
Lombards
.
   
<EOS>
There
Mr
Merdle
insisted
on
alighting
and
going
his
way
a
-
foot
,
and
leaving
his
poor
equipage
at
Mr
Dorrit
's
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
dream
increased
in
rapture
when
Mr
Dorrit
came
out
of
the
bank
alone
,
and
people
looked
at
him
in
default
of
Mr
Merdle
,
and
when
,
with
the
ears
of
his
mind
,
he
heard
the
frequent
exclamation
as
he
rolled
glibly
along
,
"
A
wonderful
man
to
be
Mr
Merdle
's
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
dinner
that
day
,
although
the
occasion
was
not
foreseen
and
provided
for
,
a
brilliant
company
of
such

!
 
<EOS>
I
know
this
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
in
my
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
intimately

with
a
gentleman
of
good
family
(
but
in
indifferent

)
,
of
whom
I
am
a
---
hum
---
patron
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
my
humble
and

is
the
more
,
"
said
Flora
,
"
that
in

back
you
will

to
look

all

and

and

for
<EOS>
he

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Pray
,

,
"

,

"
who

?
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
I

Monsieur

?
 
<EOS>
Is

---
hum
---
<EOS>
some
---
ha
---

<EOS>
Is

---
ha
---

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,
"

of
women

his

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Clennam
and
<EOS>
Co.
 
a
---
hum
---
a
mother
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

looked
as

.
 
<EOS>
Neither

's

of
Mr

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Which
compound
of
man

woman
,
no

,

,

,

,

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

,

,
"

that

you
would
look
for
this
Mr
Blandois
high

.
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Flora

.
   
<EOS>
"
With

"

"

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
so

<EOS>

's

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Dorrit
,
who

to

room

,

to

had
summoned
back

which
jarred
with
the
Merdle
dinner
-

.
 
<EOS>
He
wrote
and
sent

brief

excusing
himself
for
that
day
,
and
ordered
dinner
presently
in
his
own

at

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
another
reason
for
this
.
 
<EOS>
His
time
in
London
was
very
nearly
out
,
and
was
anticipated
by
engagements
;
his
plans
were
made
for
returning
;
and
he
thought
it
behoved
his
importance
to
pursue
some

into
the
Blandois
disappearance
,
and
be
in
a

to
carry
back
to
Mr
Henry
Gowan
the

.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
resolved
that
he
would
take

of
that

's

to
go
down
to
Clennam
and
Co
's
,
easily
to
be
found
by
the
direction
set
forth
in
the
handbill
;
and
see
the
place
,
and
ask

there

.
   
<EOS>
Having

as

as
the

and

Courier
would

,
and

for
his
better

from
Mrs
Finching
,
he
set

in

-

.
 
<EOS>
The
deep
bell
of
St
Paul
's
was
striking
nine
as
he
passed
under
the
shadow
of
Temple
Bar
,
headless
and
forlorn
in
these
degenerate
days
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
approached
his
destination
through
the
by
-
streets
and
water

,
that
part
of
London
seemed
to
him
an
uglier
spot
at
such

hour
than
he
had
ever
supposed
it
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Many
long
years
had
passed
since
he
had
seen
it
;
he
had
never
known
much
of
it
;
and
it
wore
a
mysterious
and
dismal

in
his

.
 
<EOS>
So
powerfully
was
his
imagination
impressed
by
it
,
that
when
his
driver
stopped
,
after
having
asked
the
way
more
than
once
,
and
said
to
the
best
of
his
belief
this
was
the
gateway
they
wanted
,
Mr
Dorrit
stood
hesitating
,
with
the
coach
-
door
in
his
hand
,
half
afraid
of
the
dark
look
of
the
place
.
   
<EOS>
Truly
,
it
looked
as
gloomy
that
night
as
even
it
had
ever
looked
.
<EOS>
Two
of
the
handbills
were
posted
on
the
entrance
wall
,
one
on
either
side
,
and
as
the
lamp
flickered
in
the
night
air
,
shadows
passed
over

,
not
unlike
the
shadows
of
fingers
following

lines
.
 
<EOS>
A
watch
was
evidently
kept
upon
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Dorrit
paused
,
a
man
passed
in
from
over
the
way
,
and
another
man
passed
out
from
some
dark
corner
within
;
and
both
looked
at
him
in

,
and
both
remained

.
   
<EOS>
As

was
only
one
house
in

,
there
was
no
room
for
uncertainty
,
so

went

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dim

in

on

first

.
 
<EOS>
The
door
gave
back
a
dreary
,

,
as

the
house
were
empty
;
but
it
was

,
for
a
light
was
visible
,
and
a
step
was
audible
,
almost

.
 
<EOS>
They
both
came
to
the
door
,
and
a
chain
grated
,
and
a
woman
with
her

thrown

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
said
the
woman
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
much

by
this

,
replied
that
he
was
from
Italy
,
and
that
he
wished
to
ask
a
question
relative
to
the
missing
person
,
whom
he

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hi
!
"
<EOS>
cried

woman
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Jeremiah
!
"
   
<EOS>
Upon

,

,
whom

thought

identified

,
as
the
rusty

.
 
<EOS>
The
woman
was
Under

the
dry

man
,
for

,
