.
 
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"

;

<EOS>

Who

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>
"
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
?
"
<EOS>
Mr

"
Ha
---

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

---

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.

.

<EOS>
Mr

;

.
 
<EOS>
While

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

a
---
hum
---

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
searching
look
turned

to
the
floor
,
after
taking
Mr
Flintwinch
's
face
in

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,

by

that
he
was
the
questioned
instead

,
applied

to
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
---
ha
---
a
gentleman
of

,
at
present

in
Italy
with
my

,
my

,

---
hum
---
my

.
 
<EOS>
Being
in
London
for

on
affairs
connected
with
---
ha
---
my
estate
,
and
hearing

this

,
I

,
because

---
ha
hum
---
an
English

shall

,
who
has
been
in

of
close

with
Monsieur
Blandois
.
<EOS>
Mr
Henry
Gowan
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
know
the
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
heard
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
said
it
,
and
Mr
Flintwinch
echoed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Wishing
to
---
ha
---
make
the
narrative
coherent
and
consecutive
to
him
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
may
I
ask
---
say
,
three

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thirty
,
if
you
choose
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
known
Monsieur
Blandois
long
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Not
a
twelvemonth
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
here
,
will
refer
to
the
books
and
tell

when
,
and
by

at
Paris
he

.
<EOS>
If

,
"
Mrs

,
"

to

.
<EOS>
It

poor
satisfaction
to
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
him
often
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Twice
.
 
<EOS>
Once
before
,
and
---
"
"
That

,
"
suggested
Mr
Flintwinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
once
.
"
   
"
Pray
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
a

fancy
upon

as
he

,
that
he
was
in
some
superior

in
the
Commission

;
"
pray
,
madam
,
<EOS>

---
ha
---

,

---
hum
---
know
---
to
know
---
Was
Monsieur
Blandois
here
on
business
on
the
night
indicated
in
this
present
sheet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
what
he
called
business
,
"
returned
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
---
ha
---
excuse
me
---
is
its
nature
to
be
communicated
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
evidently
impracticable
to
pass
the
barrier
of
that
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
question
has
been
asked
before
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
and
the
answer
has
been
,
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
n't
choose
to
publish
our
transactions
,
however
unimportant
,
to
all
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
We
say
,
No
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
he
took
away
no
money
with
him
,
for
example
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
took
away
none
of
ours
,
sir
,
and
got
none
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
observed
Mr
Dorrit
,
glancing
from
Mrs
Clennam
to
Mr
Flintwinch
,
and
from
Mr
Flintwinch
to
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
you
have
no
way
of
accounting
to
yourself
for
this
mystery
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
suppose
so
?
"
rejoined
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
Disconcerted
by
the
cold
and
hard

,
Mr
Dorrit
was
unable
to
assign
any
reason
for
his
supposing
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
account
for
it
,
sir
,
"
she

after
an

Mr

's

,
"
by
having
no
doubt
that
he
is
travelling
somewhere
,
or
hiding
somewhere
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
---
ha
---
why
he
should
hide
anywhere
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
exactly
the
same
<EOS>
No
as
before
,
and
put
another
barrier
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
asked
me
if
I
accounted
for
the
disappearance
to
myself
,
"
Mrs
Clennam
sternly
reminded
him
,
"
not
if
I
accounted
for
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
pretend
to
account
for
it
to
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
understand
it
to
be
no
more
my
business
to
do
that
,
than
it
is
yours
to
require
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
answered
with
an
apologetic
bend
of
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
stepped
back
,
preparatory
to
saying
he
had
no
more
to
ask
,
he
could
not
but
observe
how
gloomily
<EOS>
and
fixedly
she
sat
with
her
eyes
fastened
on
the
ground
,
and
a
certain
air
upon
her
of
resolute
waiting
;
also
,
how
exactly
the
self
-
same
expression
was
reflected
in
Mr
Flintwinch
,
standing
at
a
little
distance
from
her
chair
,
with
his
eyes
also
on
the
ground
,
and
his
right
hand
softly
rubbing
his
chin
.
   
<EOS>
At
that
moment
,
Mistress
Affery
(
of
course
,
the
woman
with
the
apron
)
dropped
the
candlestick
she
held
,
and
cried
out
,
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
O
good
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
there
it
is
again
.
 
<EOS>
Hark
,
Jeremiah
!
 
<EOS>
Now
!
"
   
<EOS>
If
there
were
any
sound
at
all
,
it
was
so
slight
that
she
must
have
fallen
into
a
confirmed
habit
of
listening
for
sounds
;
but
Mr
Dorrit
believed
he
did
hear
a
something
,
like
the
falling
of
dry
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
The
woman
's
terror
,
for
a
very
short
space
,
seemed
to
touch
the
three
;
and
they
all
listened
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
was
the
first
to
stir
.
 
<EOS>
"
Affery
,
my
woman
,
"
said
he
,
sidling
at
her
with
his
fists
clenched
,
and
his
elbows
quivering
with
impatience
to
shake
her
,
"
you
are
at
your
old
tricks
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
be
walking
in
your
sleep
next
,
my
woman
,
and
playing
the
whole
round
of
your
distempered
antics
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
have
some
physic
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
have
shown
this
gentleman
out
,
I
'll
make
you
up
such
a
comfortable
dose
,
my
woman
;
such
a
comfortable
dose
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
did
not
appear
altogether
comfortable
in
expectation
to
Mistress
Affery
;
but
Jeremiah
,
without
further
reference
to
his
healing
medicine
,
took
another
candle
from
Mrs
Clennam
's
table
,
and
said
,
"
Now
,
sir
;
shall
I
light
you
down
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
professed
himself
obliged
,
and
went
down
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
shut
him
out
,
and
chained
him
out
,
without
a
moment
's
loss
of
time
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
again
passed
by
the
two
men
<EOS>
,
one
going
out
and
the
other
coming
in
;
got
into
the
vehicle
he
had
left
waiting
,
and
was
driven
away
.
   
<EOS>
Before
he
had
gone
far
,
the
driver
stopped
to
let
him
know
that
he
had
given
his
name
,
number
,
and
address
to
the
two
men
,
on
their
joint
requisition
;
and
also
the
address
at
which
he
had
taken
Mr
Dorrit
up
,
the
hour
at
which
he
had
been
called
from
his
stand
and
the
way
by
which
he
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
This
did
not
make
the
night
's
adventure
run
any
less
hotly
in
Mr
Dorrit
's
mind
,
either
when
he
sat
down
by
his
fire
again
,
or
when
he
went
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
All
night
he
haunted
the
dismal
house
,
saw
the
two
people
resolutely
waiting
,
heard
the
woman
with
her
apron
over
her
face
cry
out
about
the
noise
,
and
found
the
body
of
the
missing
Blandois
,
now
buried
in
the
cellar
,
and
now
bricked
up
in
a
wall
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
A
Castle
in
the
Air
 
Manifold
are
the
cares
of
wealth
and
state
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's
satisfaction
in
remembering
that
it
had
not
been
necessary
for
him
to
announce
himself
to
Clennam
and
Co.
,
or
to
make
an
allusion
to
his
having
had
any
knowledge
of
the
intrusive
person
of
that
name
,
had
been
damped
over
-
night
,
while
it
was
still
fresh
,
by
a
debate
that
arose
within
him
whether
or
no
he
should
take
the
Marshalsea
in
his
way
back
,
and
look
at
the
old
gate
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
decided
not
to
do
so
;
and
had
astonished
the
coachman
by
being
very
fierce
with
him
for
proposing
to
go
over
London
Bridge
and
recross
the
river
by
Waterloo
Bridge
---
a
course
which
would
have
taken
him
almost
within
sight
of
his
old
quarters
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
for
all
that
,
the
question
had
raised
a
conflict
in
his
breast
;
and
,
for
some
odd
reason
or
no
reason
,
he
was
vaguely
dissatisfied
.
 
<EOS>
Even
at
the
Merdle
dinner
-
table
next
day
,
he
was
so
out
of
sorts
about
it
that
he
continued
at
intervals
to
turn
it
over
and
over
,
in
a
manner
frightfully
inconsistent
with
the
good
society
surrounding
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
him
hot
to
think
what
the
Chief
Butler
's
opinion
of
him
would
have
been
,
if
that
illustrious
personage
could
have
plumbed
with
that
heavy
eye
of
his
the
stream
of
his
meditations
.
   
<EOS>
The
farewell
banquet
was
of
a
gorgeous
nature
,
and
wound
up
his
visit
in
a
most
brilliant
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Fanny
combined
with
the
attractions
of
her
youth
and
beauty
,
a
certain
weight
of
self
-
sustainment
as
if
she
had
been
married
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
could
leave
her
with
a
quiet
mind
to
tread
the
paths
of
distinction
,
and
wished
---
<EOS>
but
without
abatement
of
patronage
,
and
without
prejudice
to
the
retiring
virtues
of
his
favourite
child
---
that
he
had
such
another
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
he
told
her
at
parting
,
"
our
family
looks
to
you
to
---
ha
---
assert
its
dignity
and
---
hum
<EOS>
---
maintain
its
importance
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
will
never
disappoint
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
papa
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
you
may
rely
upon
that
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
My
best
love
to
dearest
Amy
,
and
<EOS>
I
will
write
to
her
very
soon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
convey
any
message
to
---
ha
---
anybody
else
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Mr
Dorrit
,
in
an
insinuating

.
   
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
"
said
Fanny
,
before
whom
Mrs
General
instantly

,
"
no
,
I
thank

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
very
kind
,
Pa
,
but
I
must

excused
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
other
message
to
send
<EOS>
,
I
thank
you
,
dear
papa
,
that
it
would

to
you
to
take
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
parted
in
an
outer
drawing
-
room
,
where
only
Mr
Sparkler
waited
on
his
lady
,
and
dutifully
bided
his
time
for
shaking
hands
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Sparkler
was
admitted
to
this
closing

,
Mr
Merdle
came
creeping
in
with
not
much
more
appearance
of
arms
in
his

than
if
he
had
been
the
twin
brother
of
Miss
Biffin
,
and
insisted
on
escorting
Mr
Dorrit
down
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
All
Mr
Dorrit
's
protestations
being
in
vain
,
he
enjoyed
the
honour
of
being
accompanied
to
the
hall
-
door
by
this
distinguished
man
,
who
(
as
Mr
Dorrit
told
him
in
shaking
hands
on
the
step
)
<EOS>
had
really
overwhelmed
him
with
attentions
and
services
during
this
memorable
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
they
parted
;
Mr
Dorrit
entering
his
carriage
with
a
swelling
breast
,
not
at
all
sorry
that
his
Courier
,
who
had
come
to
take
leave
in
the
lower
regions
,
should
have
an
opportunity
of
beholding
the
grandeur
of
his
departure
.
   
<EOS>
The
aforesaid
grandeur
was
yet
full
upon
Mr
Dorrit
when
he
alighted
at
his
hotel
.
 
<EOS>
Helped
out
by
the
Courier
and
some
half
-
dozen
of
the
hotel
servants
,
he
was
passing
through
the
hall
with
a
serene
magnificence
,
when
lo
!
 
<EOS>
a
sight
presented
itself
that
struck
him
dumb
and
motionless
.
 
<EOS>
John
Chivery
,
in
his
best
clothes
,
with
his
tall
hat
under
his
arm
,
his
ivory
-
handled
cane
genteelly
embarrassing
his
deportment
,
and
a
bundle
of
cigars
in
his
hand
!
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
young
man
,
"
said
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
This
young
man
has
persisted
in
waiting
,
sir
,
saying
you
would
be
glad
to
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
glared
on
the
young
man
,
choked
,
and
said
,
in
the
mildest
of
tones
,
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Young
John
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
Young
John
,
I
think
;
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
Young
John
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
ha
---
thought
it
was
Young
john
!
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
young
man
may
come
up
,
"
turning
to
the
attendants
,
as

passed

:
"
oh
yes
,
he
may
come
up
.
 
<EOS>
Let
Young
John
follow
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
speak
to
him
above
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
followed
,
smiling
and
much
gratified
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
's
rooms
were
reached
.
 
<EOS>
Candles
were
lighted
.
 
<EOS>
The
attendants
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
turning
round
upon
him
and
seizing
him
by
the
collar
when
they
were
safely
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
amazement
and
horror
depicted
in
the
unfortunate
john
's
face
---
for
he
had
rather
expected
to
be
embraced
next
---
were
of
that
powerfully
expressive
nature
that
Mr
Dorrit
withdrew
his
hand
and
merely
glared
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
do
this
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
presume
to
come
here
?
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
insult
me
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
insult
you
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Insult
me
.
 
<EOS>
Your
coming
here
is
an
affront
,
an
impertinence
,
an
audacity
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
wanted
here
.
   
<EOS>
Who
sent
you
here
?
 
<EOS>
What
---
ha
---
the
Devil
do
you
do
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
sir
,
"
said
Young
John
,
with
as
pale
and

as
ever
had

to
Mr

's
in
his

---
even

:
"
I
thought
,

,
you
might
n't
object
to
have
the

to
accept
a
bundle
---
"
   
"
Damn
your
bundle
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Dorrit
,
in
irrepressible
rage
.
<EOS>
"
I
---
hum
---
do
n't
smoke
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
humbly
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
used
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
that

,
"
cried
Mr
Dorrit
,
quite

,
"
and
I
'll
take
the
poker
to
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Chivery
backed
to
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
sir
!
"
cried
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
Confound
you
,
   
sit
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Chivery
dropped
into
the
chair
nearest
the
door
,
and
Mr
Dorrit
walked
up
and
down
the
room
;
rapidly
at
first
;
then
,
more
slowly
.
<EOS>
Once
,
he
went
to
the
window
,
and
stood
there
with
his
forehead
against
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
All
of
a
sudden
,
he
turned
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
What
else
did
you
come
for
,
Sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
else
in
the
world
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Only
to
say
,
Sir
,
that
I
hoped
you
was
well
,
and
only
to
ask
if
Miss
Amy
was
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
to
you
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
to
me
,
sir
,
by
rights
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
lessening
the
distance
<EOS>
betwixt
us
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
it
's
a
liberty
,
sir
,
<EOS>
but
I
never
thought
you
'd
have
taken
it
ill
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
and
honour
,
sir
,
"
said
Young
John
,
with
emotion
,
"
in
my
poor
way
,
I
am
too
proud
to
have
come
<EOS>
,
I
assure
you
,
if
I
had
thought
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
ashamed
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
back
to
the
window
,
and
leaned
his
forehead
against
the
glass
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
turned
,
he
had
his
handkerchief
in
his
hand
,
and
he
had
been
wiping
his
eyes
with
it
,
and
he
looked
tired
and
ill
.
   
<EOS>
"
Young
John
,
I
am
very
sorry
to
have
been
hasty
with
you
,
but
---
ha
---
some
remembrances
are
not
happy
remembrances
,
and
---
hum
---
you
should
n't
have
come
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
that
now
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
Chivery
;
"
but
I
did
n't
before
,
and
Heaven
knows
I
meant
no
harm
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
---
<EOS>
hum
---
<EOS>
sure
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
hand
,
Young
John
,
give
me
your
hand
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
gave
it
;
but
Mr
Dorrit
had
driven
his
heart
out
of
it
,
and
nothing
could
change
his
face
now
,
from
its
white
,
shocked
look
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
slowly

with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
again
,
Young
John
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
---
but
I
'd
rather
stand
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
sat
down
instead
.
 
<EOS>
After
painfully
holding
his
head
a
little
while
,
he
turned
it
to
his
visitor
,
and
said
,
with
an
effort
to
be
easy
:
   
"
<EOS>
And
how
is
your
father
,
Young
John
?
 
<EOS>
How
---
ha
---
how
are
they
all
,
Young
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
They
're
all
pretty
well
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
not
any
ways
complaining
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
in
your
---
ha
---
old
business
<EOS>
I
see
,
John
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Partly
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
my
"
---
John
hesitated
a
little
---
"
father
's
business
likewise
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
---
ha
hum
---
go
upon
the
ha
---
"
   
"
Lock
,

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Much
to

,
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
;
we
're

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

,

ARE

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At

,
Young
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mostly

all

of
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

that

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay

,

---
ha
---

.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Leave

,

,

---
ha
---

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
John
put

,
with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
a

,
Young

;
stay

.
 
<EOS>
It

---
ha
---

---
hum
---

,

ha

---

---

---

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
many
of
them
<EOS>
,
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
ha
---
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
His

that

was
a

writing

,
and
wrote

.
 
<EOS>
It

one

.
 
<EOS>
He
folded

,
put
it
in
Young
john
's

,
and
pressed

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

'll
---
ha
---
overlook
---
hum
---
<EOS>
what

,
John
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
in
any
ways
<EOS>
bear

,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
But
nothing
while
John
was
there
could
change

's

to
its

and

,
or

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
John
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
giving

a

,
and

,
"
<EOS>
I
hope

---
ha
---
agree

;
and

in

,

---
hum
---

---
ha
---
once
I
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
"
returned
John
Chivery
,
"
in
my
poor

way
,
sir
,
I
'm
too
proud
and

to
do

,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
not
too
proud
and
honourable
to
listen
at
the
door
that
he
might
ascertain
for
himself
whether
John
really
went
straight
out
,
or
lingered
to
have
any
talk
with
any
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
doubt
that
he
went
direct
out
at
the
door
,
and
away
down
the
street
with
a
quick
step
.
 
<EOS>
After
remaining
alone
for
an
hour
,
Mr
Dorrit
rang
for
the
Courier
,
who
found
him
with
his
chair
on
the
hearth
-
rug
,
sitting
with
his
back
towards
him
and
his
face
to
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
take
that
bundle
of
cigars
to
smoke
on
the
journey
,
if
you
like
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
a
careless

his

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
---
brought
by
---
hum
---
little
offering
from
---
ha
---
son
of
old
tenant
of
mine
.
"
   
<EOS>
Next
morning
's
sun
saw
Mr
Dorrit
's
equipage
upon
the
Dover
road
,
where
every
red
-
jacketed
postilion
was
the
sign
of
a
cruel
house
,
established
for
the
unmerciful
plundering
of
travellers
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
business
of
the
human
race
,
between
London
and
Dover
,
being
spoliation
,
Mr
Dorrit
was
waylaid
at
Dartford
,
pillaged
at
Gravesend
,
rifled
at
Rochester
,
fleeced
at
Sittingbourne
,
and
sacked
at
Canterbury
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
it
being
the
Courier
's
business
to
get
him
out
of
the
hands
of
the
banditti
,
the
Courier
brought
him
off
at
every
stage
;
and
so
the
red
-
jackets
went
gleaming
merrily
along
the
spring
landscape
,
rising
and
falling
to
a
regular
measure
,
between
Mr
Dorrit
in
his
snug
corner
and
the
next
chalky
rise
in
the
dusty
highway
.
   
<EOS>
Another
day
's
sun
saw
him
at
Calais
.
 
<EOS>
And
having
now
got
the
Channel
between
himself
and
John
Chivery
,
he
began
to
feel
safe
,
and
to
find
that
the
foreign
air
was
lighter
to
breathe
than
the
air
of
England
.
   
<EOS>
On
again
by
the
heavy
French
roads
for
Paris
.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
quite
recovered
his
equanimity
,
Mr
Dorrit
,
in
his
snug
corner
,
fell
to
castle
-
building
as
he
rode
along
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evident
that
he
had
a
very
large
castle
in
hand
.
 
<EOS>
All
day
long
he
was
running
towers
up
,
taking
towers
down
,
adding
a
wing
here
,
putting
on
a
battlement
there
,
looking
to
the
walls
,
strengthening
the
defences
,
giving
ornamental
touches
to
the
interior
,
making
in
all
respects
a
superb
castle
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
preoccupied
face
so
clearly
denoted
the
pursuit
in
which
he
was
engaged
,
that
every
cripple
at
the
post
-
houses
,
not
blind
,
who
shoved
his
little
battered
tin
-
box
in
at
the
carriage
window
for
Charity
in
the
name
of
Heaven
,
Charity
in
the
name
of
our
Lady
,
Charity
in
the
name
of
all
the
Saints
,
knew
as
well
what
work
he
was
at
,
as
their
countryman
Le
Brun
could
have
known
it
himself
,
though
he
had
made
that
English
traveller
the
subject
of
a
special
physiognomical
treatise
.
   
<EOS>
Arrived
at
Paris
,
and
resting
there
three
days
,
Mr
Dorrit
strolled
much
about
the
streets
alone
,
looking
in
at
the
shop
-
windows
,
and
particularly
the
jewellers
'
windows
.
 
<EOS>
Ultimately
,
he
went
into
the
most
famous
jeweller
's
,
and
said
he
wanted
to
buy
a
little
gift
for
a
lady
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
charming
little
woman
to
whom
he
said
it
---
a
sprightly
little
woman
,
dressed
in
perfect
taste
,
who
came
out
of
a
green
velvet
bower
to
attend
upon
him
,
from
posting
up
some
dainty
little
books
of
account
which
one
could
hardly
suppose
to
be
ruled
for
the
entry
of
any
articles
more
commercial
than
kisses
,
at
a
dainty
little
shining
desk
which
looked
in
itself
like
a
sweetmeat
.
   
<EOS>
For
example
,
then
,
said
the
little
woman
,
what
species
of
gift
did
Monsieur
desire
?
 
<EOS>
A
love
-
gift
?
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
smiled
,
and
said
,
Eh
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
he
know
?
<EOS>
It
was
always
possible
;
the
sex
being
so
charming
.
 
<EOS>
Would
she
show
him
some
?
   
<EOS>
Most
willingly
,
said
the
little
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Flattered
and
enchanted
to
show
him
many
.
 
<EOS>
But
pardon
!
 
<EOS>
To
begin
with
,
he
would
have
the
great
goodness
to
observe
that
there
were
love
-
gifts
,
and
there
were
nuptial
gifts
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
,
these
ravishing
ear
-
rings
and
this
necklace
so
superb
to
correspond
,
were
what
one
called
a
love
-
gift
.
<EOS>
These
brooches
and
these
rings
,
of
a
beauty
so
gracious
and
celestial
,
were
what
one
called
,
with
the
permission
of
Monsieur
,
nuptial
gifts
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
would
be
a
good
arrangement
,
Mr
Dorrit
hinted
,
smiling
,
to
purchase
both
,
and
to
present
the
love
-
gift
first
,
and
to
finish
with
the
nuptial
offering
?
   
<EOS>
Ah
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
said
the
little
woman
,
laying
the
tips
of
the
fingers
of
her
two
little
hands
against
each
other
,
that
would
be
generous
indeed
,
that
would
be
a
special
gallantry
!
 
<EOS>
And
without
doubt
the
lady
so
crushed
with
gifts
would
find
them
irresistible
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
not
sure
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
for
example
,
the
sprightly
little
woman
was
very
sure
of
it
,
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Dorrit
bought
a
gift
of
each
sort
,
and
paid
handsomely
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
strolled
back
to
his
hotel
afterwards
,
he
carried
his
head
high
:
having
plainly
got
up
his
castle
now
to
a
much
loftier
altitude
than
the
two
square
towers
of
Notre
Dame
.
   
<EOS>
Building
away
with
all
his
might
,
but
reserving
the
plans
of
his
castle
exclusively
for
his
own
eye
,
Mr
Dorrit
posted
away
for
Marseilles
.
 
<EOS>
Building
on
,
building
on
,
busily
,
busily
,
from
morning
to
night
.
 
<EOS>
Falling
asleep
,
and
leaving
great
blocks
of
building
materials
dangling
in
the
air
;
waking
again
,
to
resume
work
and
get
them
into
their
places
.
 
<EOS>
What
time
the
Courier
in
the
rumble
,
smoking
Young
john
's
best
cigars
,
left
a
little
thread
of
thin
light
smoke
behind
---
perhaps
as
he
built
a
castle
or
two
with
stray
pieces
of
Mr
Dorrit
's
money
.
   
<EOS>
Not
a
fortified
town
that
they
passed
in
all
their
journey
was
as
strong
,
not
a
Cathedral
summit
was
as
high
,
as
Mr
Dorrit
's
castle
.
<EOS>
Neither
the
Saone
nor
the
Rhone
sped
with
the
swiftness
of
that
peerless
building
;
nor
was
the
Mediterranean
deeper
than
its
foundations
;
nor
were
the
distant
landscapes
on
the
Cornice
road
,
nor
the
hills
and
bay
of
Genoa
the
Superb
,
more
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
and
his
matchless
castle
were
disembarked
among
the
dirty
white
houses
and
dirtier
felons
of
Civita
Vecchia
,
and
thence
scrambled
on
to
Rome
as
they
could
,
through
the
filth
that
festered
on
the
way
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
The
Storming
of
the
Castle
in
the
Air
 
<EOS>
The
sun
had
gone
down
full
four
hours
,
and
it
was
later
than
most
travellers
would
like
it
to
be
for
finding
themselves
outside
the
walls
of
Rome
,
when
Mr
Dorrit
's
carriage
,
still
on
its
last
wearisome
stage
,
rattled
over
the
solitary
Campagna
.
 
<EOS>
The
savage
herdsmen
and
the
fierce
-
looking
peasants
who
had
chequered
the
way
while
the
light
lasted
,
had
all
gone
down
with
the
sun
,
and
left
the
wilderness
blank
.
 
<EOS>
At
some
turns
of
the
road
,
a
pale
flare
on
the
horizon
,
like
an
exhalation
from
the
ruin
-
sown
land
,
showed
that
the
city
was
yet
far
off
;
but
this
poor
relief
was
rare
and
short
-
lived
.
 
<EOS>
The
carriage
dipped
down
again
into
a
hollow
of
the
black
dry
sea
,
and
for
a
long
time
there
was
nothing
visible
save
its
petrified
swell
and
the
gloomy
sky
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
though
he
had
his
castle
-
building
to
engage
his
mind
,
could
not
be
quite
easy
in
that
desolate
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
far
more
curious
,
in
every
swerve
of
the
carriage
,
and
every
cry
of
the
postilions
,
than
he
had
been
since
he
quitted
London
.
 
<EOS>
The
valet
on
the
box
evidently
quaked
.
 
<EOS>
The
Courier
in
the
rumble
was
not
altogether
comfortable
in
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
As
often
as
Mr
Dorrit
let
down
the
glass
and
looked
back
at
him
(
which
was
very
often
)
,
he
saw
him
smoking
John
Chivery
out
,
it
is
true
,
but
still
generally
standing
up
the
while
and
looking
about
him
,
like
a
man
who
had
his
suspicions
,
and
kept
upon
his
guard
.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
Mr
Dorrit
,
pulling
up
the
glass
again
,
reflect
that
those
postilions
were
cut
-
throat
looking
fellows
,
and
that
he
would
have
done
better
to
have
slept
at
Civita
Vecchia
,
and
have
started
betimes
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
for
all
this
,
he
worked
at
his
castle
in
the
intervals
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
,
fragments
of
ruinous
enclosure
,
yawning
window
-
gap
and
crazy
wall
,
deserted
houses
,
leaking
wells
,
broken
water
-
tanks
,
spectral
cypress
-
trees
,
patches
of
tangled
vine
,
and
the
changing
of
the
track
to
a
long
,
irregular
,
disordered
lane
where
everything
was
crumbling
away
,
from
the
unsightly
buildings
to
the
jolting
road
---
now
,
these
objects
showed
that
they
were
nearing
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
a
sudden
twist
and
stoppage
of
the
carriage
inspired
Mr
Dorrit
with
the
mistrust
that
the
brigand
moment
was
come
for
twisting
him
into
a
ditch
and
robbing
him
;
until
,
letting
down
the
glass
again
and
looking
out
,
he
perceived
himself
assailed
by
nothing
worse
than
a
funeral
procession
,
which
came
mechanically
chaunting
by
,
with
an
indistinct
show
of
dirty
vestments
,
lurid
torches
,
swinging
censers
,
and
a
great
cross
borne
before
a
priest
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
an
ugly
priest
by
torchlight
;
of
a
lowering
aspect
,
with
an
overhanging
brow
;
and
as
his
eyes
met
those
of
Mr
Dorrit
,
looking
bareheaded
out
of
the
carriage
,
his
lips
,
moving
as
they
chaunted
,
seemed
to
threaten
that
important
traveller
;
likewise
the
action
of
his
hand
,
which
was
in
fact
his
manner
of
returning
the
traveller
's
salutation
,
seemed
to
come
in
aid
of
that
menace
.
 
<EOS>
So
thought
Mr
Dorrit
,
made
fanciful
by
the
weariness
of
building
and
travelling
,
as
the
priest
drifted
past
him
,
and
the
procession
straggled
away
,
taking
its
dead
along
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
their
so
-
different
way
went
Mr
Dorrit
's
company
too
;
and
soon
,
with
their
coach
load
of
luxuries
from
the
two
great
capitals
of
Europe
,
they
were
(
like
the
Goths
reversed
)
beating
at
the
gates
of
Rome
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
was
not
expected
by
his
own
people
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
;
but
they
had
given
him
up
until
to
-
morrow
,
not
doubting
that
it
was
later
than
he
would
care
,
in
those
parts
,
to
be
out
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
when
his
equipage
stopped
at
his
own
gate
,
no
one
but
the
porter
appeared
to
receive
him
.
 
<EOS>
Was
Miss
Dorrit
from
home
?
 
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
within
.
 
<EOS>
Good
,
said
Mr
Dorrit
to
the
assembling
servants
;
let
them
keep
where
they
were
;
let
them
help
to
unload
the
carriage
;
he
would
find
Miss
Dorrit
for
himself
.
<EOS>
So
he
went
up
his
grand
staircase
,
slowly
,
and
tired
,
and
looked
into
various
chambers
which
were
empty
,
until
he
saw
a
light
in
a
small
ante
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
curtained
nook
,
like
a
tent
,
within
two
other
rooms
;
and
it
looked
warm
and
bright
in
colour
,
as
he
approached
it
through
the
dark
avenue
they
made
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
draped
doorway
,
but
no
door
;
and
as
he
stopped
here
,
looking
in
unseen
,
he
felt
a
pang
.
 
<EOS>
Surely
not
like
jealousy
?
 
<EOS>
For
why
like
jealousy
?
 
<EOS>
There
was
only
his
daughter
and
his
brother
there
:
he
,
with
his
chair
drawn
to
the
hearth
,
enjoying
the
warmth
of
the
evening
wood
fire
;
she
seated
at
a
little
table
,
busied
with
some
embroidery
work
.
 
<EOS>
Allowing
for
the
great
difference
in
the
still
-
life
of
the
picture
,
the
figures
were
much
the
same
as
of
old
;
his
brother
being
sufficiently
like
himself
to
represent
himself
,
for
a
moment
,
in
the
composition
.
 
<EOS>
So
had
he
sat
many
a
night
,
over
a
coal
fire
far
away
;
so
had
she
sat
,
devoted
to
him
.
<EOS>
Yet
surely
there
was
nothing
to
be
jealous
of
in
the
old
miserable
poverty
.
 
<EOS>
Whence
,
then
,
the
pang
in
his
heart
?
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
uncle
,
I
think
you
are
growing
young
again
?
"
   
<EOS>
Her
uncle
shook
his
head
and
said
,
"
Since
when
,
my
dear
;
since
when
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
,
plying
her
needle
,
"
that
you
have
been
growing
younger
for
weeks
past
.
 
<EOS>
So
cheerful
,
uncle
,
and
so
ready
,
and
so
interested
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
child
---
all
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
me
,
uncle
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
done
me
a
world
of
good
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
so
considerate
of
me
,
and
so
tender
with
me
,
and
so
delicate
in
trying
to
hide
your
attentions
from
me
,
that
I
---
<EOS>
well
,
well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
treasured
up
,
my
darling
,
treasured
up
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
in
it
but
your
own
fresh
fancy
,
uncle
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
cheerfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
well
!
<EOS>
"
murmured
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
paused
for
an
instant
in
her
work
to
look
at
him
,
and
her
look
revived
that
former
pain
in
her
father
's
breast
;
in
his
poor
weak
breast
,
so
full
of
contradictions
,
vacillations
,
inconsistencies
,
the
little
peevish
perplexities
of
this
ignorant
life
,
mists
which
the
morning
without
a
night
only
can
clear
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
freer
with
you
,
you
see
,
my
dove
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
since
we
have
been
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
,
alone
,
for
I
do
n't
count
Mrs
General
<EOS>
;
I
do
n't
care
for
her
;
she
has
nothing
to
do
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
Fanny
was
impatient
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't
wonder
at
it
,
or
complain
of
it
,
for
I
am
sensible
that
I
must
be
in
the
way
,
though
I
try
to
keep
out
of
it
as
well
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
am
not
fit
company
for
our
company
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
William
,
"
said
the
old
man
admiringly
,
"
is
fit
company
for
monarchs
;
but
not
so
your
uncle
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Frederick
Dorrit
is
no
credit
to
William
Dorrit
,
and
he
knows
it
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
here
's
your
father
,
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
William
,
welcome
back
!
 
<EOS>
My
beloved
brother
,
I
am
rejoiced
to
see
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
(
Turning
his
head
in
speaking
,
he
had
caught
sight
of
him
as
he
stood
in
the
doorway
.
)
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
with
a
cry
of
pleasure
put
her
arms
about
her
father
's
neck
,
and
kissed
him
again
and
again
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
was
a
little
impatient
,
and
a
little
querulous
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
find
you
at
last
,
Amy
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Really
I
am
glad
to
find
---
<EOS>
hum
---
any
one
to
receive
me
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
I
appear
to
have
been
---
ha
---
so
little
expected
,
that
upon
my
word
I
began
---
ha
hum
---
to
think
it
might
be
right
to
offer
an
apology
for
---
ha
---
taking
the
liberty
of
coming
back
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
so
late
,
my
dear
William
,
"
said
his
brother
,
"
that
we
had
given
you
up
for
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
stronger
than
you
,
dear
Frederick
,
"
returned
his
brother
with
an
elaboration
of
fraternity
in
which
there
was
severity
;
"
and
I
hope
I
can
travel
without
detriment
at
---
ha
---
any
hour
I
choose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
surely
,
"
returned
the
other
,
with
a
misgiving
that
he
had
given
offence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
William
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Amy
,
"
pursued
Mr
Dorrit
,
as
she
helped
him
to
put
off
his
wrappers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
it
without
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
ha
---
need
not
trouble
you
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
Could
I
have
a
morsel
of
bread
and
a
glass
of
wine
,
or
<EOS>
---
hum
---
would
it
cause
too
much
inconvenience
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
father
,
you
shall
have
supper
in
a
very
few
minutes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
a
reproachful
frost
upon
him
;
"
I
---
ha
---
am
afraid
I
am
causing
inconvenience
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
General
pretty
well
?
"
   
"
Mrs
General
complained
of
a
headache
,
and
of
being
fatigued
;
and
so
,
when
we
gave
you
up
,
she
went
to
bed
,
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
Mr
Dorrit
thought
that
Mrs
General
had
done
well
in
being
overcome
by
the
disappointment
of
his
not
arriving
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
his
face
relaxed
,
and
he
said
with
obvious
satisfaction
,
"
Extremely
sorry
to
hear
that
Mrs
General
is
not
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
During
this
short
dialogue
,
his
daughter
had
been
observant
of
him
,
with
something
more
than
her
usual
interest
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
seem
as
though
he
had
a
changed
or
worn
appearance
in
her
eyes
,
and
he
perceived
and
resented
it
;
for
he
said
with
renewed
peevishness
,
when
he
had
divested
himself
of
his
travelling
-
cloak
,
and
had
come
to
the
fire
:
"
Amy
,
what
are
you
looking
at
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
see
in
me
that
causes
you
to
---
ha
---
concentrate
your
solicitude
on
me
in
that
---
hum
---
very
particular
manner
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
know
it
,
father
;
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
It
gladdens
my
eyes
to
see
you
again
;
that
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
's
all
,
because
---
ha
---
that
's
not
all
.
 
<EOS>
You
<EOS>
---
hum
---
you
think
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
an
accusatory
emphasis
,
"
that
I
am
not
looking
well
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
looked
a
little
tired
,
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
mistaken
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
I
am
not
tired
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
hum
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
much
fresher
than
I
was
when
I
went
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
inclined
to
be
angry
that
she
said
nothing
more
in
her
justification
,
but
remained
quietly
beside
him
embracing
his
arm
.
<EOS>
As
he
stood
thus
,
with
his
brother
on
the
other
side
,
he
fell
into
a
heavy
doze
,
of
not
a
minute
's
duration
,
and
awoke
with
a
start
.
   
<EOS>
"
Frederick
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
his
brother
:
<EOS>
"
I
recommend
you
to
go
to
bed
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
William
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
wait
and
see
you
sup
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Frederick
,
"
he
retorted
,
"
I
beg
you
to
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
ha
---
make
it
a
personal
request
that
you
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
You
ought
to
have
been
in
bed
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
very
feeble
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
said
the
old
man
,
who
had
no
wish
but
to
please
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Frederick
,
"
returned
Mr
Dorrit
,
with
an
astonishing
superiority
to
his
brother
's
failing
powers
,
"
there
can
be
no
doubt
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
painful
to
me
to
see
you
so
weak
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
It
distresses
me
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
find
you
looking
at
all
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
fit
for
this
sort
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
You
should
be
more
careful
,
you
should
be
very
careful
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
to
bed
?
"
asked
Frederick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Frederick
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
do
,
I
adjure
you
!
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
brother
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
be
stronger
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
all
pleased
with
your
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
dear
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
After
dismissing
his
brother
in
this
gracious
way
,
he
fell
into
a
doze
again
before
the
old
man
was
well
out
of
the
room
:
and
he
would
have
stumbled
forward
upon
the
logs
,
but
for
his
daughter
's
restraining
hold
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
uncle
wanders
very
much
,
Amy
,
"
he
said
,
when
he
was
thus
roused
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
less
---
ha
---
coherent
,
and
his
conversation
is
more
---
hum
---
broken
,
<EOS>
than
I
have
---
ha
,
hum
---
ever
known
.
 
<EOS>
Has
he
had
any
illness
since
I
have
been
gone
?
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
---
ha
---
see
a
great
change
in
him
,
Amy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
observed
it
,
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Greatly
broken
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Greatly
broken
.
 
<EOS>
My
poor
,
affectionate
,
failing
Frederick
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Even
taking
into
account
what
he
was
before
,
he
is
---
hum
---
sadly
broken
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
supper
,
which
was
brought
to
him
there
,
and
spread
upon
the
little
table
where
he
had
seen
her
working
,
diverted
his
attention
.
   
<EOS>
She
sat
at
his
side
as
in
the
days
that
were
gone
,
for
the
first
time
since
those
days
ended
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
alone
,
and
she
helped
him
to
his
meat
and
poured
out
his
drink
for
him
,
as
she
had
been
used
to
do
in
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
happened
now
,
for
the
first
time
since
their
accession
to
wealth
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
to
look
at
him
much
,
after
the
offence
he
had
taken
;
but
she
noticed
two
occasions
in
the
course
of
his
meal
,
when
he
all
of
a
sudden
looked
at
her
,
and
looked
about
him
,
as
if
the
association
were
so
strong
that
he
needed
assurance
from
his
sense
of
sight
that
they
were
not
in
the
old
prison
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Both
times
,
he
put
his
hand
to
his
head
as
if
he
missed
his
old
black
cap
---
though
it
had
been
ignominiously
given
away
in
the
Marshalsea
,
and
had
never
got
free
to
that
hour
,
but
still
hovered
about
the
yards
on
the
head
of
his
successor
.
   
<EOS>
He
took
very
little
supper
,
but
was
a
long
time
over
it
,
and
often
reverted
to
his
brother
's
declining
state
.
 
<EOS>
Though
he
expressed
the
greatest
pity
for
him
,
he
was
almost
bitter
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
that
poor
Frederick
---
ha
hum
---
drivelled
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
word
to
express
it
;
drivelled
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
melancholy
to
reflect
what
Amy
must
have
undergone
from
the
excessive
tediousness
of
his
Society
---
wandering
and
babbling
on
,
poor
dear
estimable
creature
,
wandering
and
babbling
on
---
if
it
had
not
been
for
the
relief
she
had
had
in
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
Extremely
sorry
,
he
then
repeated
with
his
former
satisfaction
,
that
that
---
ha
---
superior
woman
was
poorly
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
in
her
watchful
love
,
would
have
remembered
the
lightest
thing
he
said
or
did
that
night
,
though
she
had
had
no
subsequent
reason
to
recall
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
She
always
remembered
that
,
when
he
looked
about
him
under
the
strong
influence
of
the
old
association
,
he
tried
to
keep
it
out
of
her
mind
,
and
perhaps
out
of
his
own
too
,
by
immediately
expatiating
on
the
great
riches
and
great
company
that
had
encompassed
him
in
his
absence
,
and
on
the
lofty
position
he
and
his
family
had
to
sustain
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
she
fail
to
recall
that
there
were
two
under
-
currents
,
side
by
side
,
pervading
all
his
discourse
and
all
his
manner
;
one
showing
her
how
well
he
had
got
on
without
her
,
and
how
independent
he
was
of
her
;
<EOS>
the
other
,
in
a
fitful
and
unintelligible
way
almost
complaining
of
her
,
as
if
it
had
been
possible
that
she
had
neglected
him
while
he
was
away
.
   
<EOS>
His
telling
her
of
the
glorious
state
that
Mr
Merdle
kept
,
and
of
the
court
that
bowed
before
him
,
naturally
brought
him
to
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
So
naturally
indeed
,
that
although
there
was
an
unusual
want
of
sequence
in
the
greater
part
of
his
remarks
,
he
passed
to
her
at
once
,
and
asked
how
she
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
well
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
going
away
next
week
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Home
?
"
asked
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
After
a
few
weeks
'
stay
upon
the
road
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
will
be
a
vast
loss
here
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
vast
---
ha
---
acquisition
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
To
Fanny
,
and
to
---
hum
---
the
rest
of
the
---
ha
---
great
world
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
thought
of
the
competition
that
was
to
be
entered
upon
,
and
assented
very
softly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Merdle
is
going
to
have
a
great
farewell
Assembly
,
dear
,
and
a
dinner
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
been
expressing
her
anxiety
that
you
should
return
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
invited
both
you
and
me
to
her
dinner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
---
ha
---
very
kind
.
 
<EOS>
When
is
the
day
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
day
after
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Write
round
in
the
morning
,
and
say
that
I
have
returned
,
and
shall
---
hum
---
be
delighted
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
walk
with
you
up
the
stairs
to
your
room
,
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
looking
angrily
round
;
for
he
was
moving
away
,
as
if
forgetful
of
leave
-
taking
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
not
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
no
help
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
your
father
,
not
your
infirm
uncle
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
checked
himself
,
as
abruptly
as
he
had
broken
into
this
reply
,
and
said
,
"
You
have
not
kissed
me
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
We
must
marry
---
ha
---
we
must
marry
YOU
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
went
,
more
slowly
and
more
tired
,
up
the
staircase
to
his
rooms
,
and
,
almost
as
soon
as
he
got
there
,
dismissed
his
valet
.
 
<EOS>
His
next
care
was
to
look
about
him
for
his
Paris
purchases
,
and
,
after
opening
their
cases
and
carefully
surveying
them
,
to
put
them
away
under
lock
and
key
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
what
with
dozing
and
what
with
castle
-
building
,
he
lost
himself
for
a
long
time
,
so
that
there
was
a
touch
of
morning
on
the
eastward
rim
of
the
desolate
Campagna
when
he
crept
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
sent
up
her
compliments
in
good
time
next
day
,
and
hoped
he
had
rested
well
after
this
fatiguing
journey
.
 
<EOS>
He
sent
down
his
compliments
,
and
begged
to
inform
Mrs
General
that
he
had
rested
very
well
indeed
,
and
was
in
high
condition
.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
did
not
come
forth
from
his
own
rooms
until
late
in
the
afternoon
;
and
,
although
he
then
caused
himself
to
be
magnificently
arrayed
for
a
drive
with
Mrs
General
and
his
daughter
,
his
appearance
was
scarcely
up
to
his
description
of
himself
.
<EOS>
As
the
family
had
no
visitors
that
day
,
its
four
members
dined
alone
together
.
 
<EOS>
He
conducted
Mrs
General
to
the
seat
at
his
right
hand
with
immense
ceremony
;
and
Little
Dorrit
could
not
but
notice
as
she
followed
with
her
uncle
,
both
that
he
was
again
elaborately
dressed
,
and
that
his
manner
towards
Mrs
General
was
very
particular
.
 
<EOS>
The
perfect
formation
of
that
accomplished
lady
's
surface
rendered
it
difficult
to
displace
an
atom
of
its
genteel
glaze
,
but
Little
Dorrit
thought
she
descried
a
slight
thaw
of
triumph
in
a
corner
of
her
frosty
eye
.
   
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
what
may
be
called
in
these
pages
the
Pruney
and
Prismatic
nature
of
the
family
banquet
,
Mr
Dorrit
several
times
fell
asleep
while
it
was
in
progress
.
 
<EOS>
His
fits
of
dozing
were
as
sudden
as
they
had
been
overnight
,
and
were
as
short
and
profound
.
<EOS>
When
the
first
of
these
slumberings
seized
him
,
Mrs
General
looked
almost
amazed
:
but
,
on
each
recurrence
of
the
symptoms
,
she
told
her
polite
beads
,
Papa
,
Potatoes
,
Poultry
,
Prunes
,
and
Prism
;
and
,
by
dint
of
going
through
that
infallible
performance
very
slowly
,
appeared
to
finish
her
rosary
at
about
the
same
time
as
Mr
Dorrit
started
from
his
sleep
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
again
painfully
aware
of
a
somnolent
tendency
in
Frederick
(
which
had
no
existence
out
of
his
own
imagination
)
,
and
after
dinner
,
when
Frederick
had
withdrawn
,
privately
apologised
to
Mrs
General
for
the
poor
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
most
estimable
and
affectionate
of
brothers
,
"
he
said
,
"
but
---
<EOS>
ha
,
hum
---
broken
up
altogether
.
<EOS>
Unhappily
,
declining
fast
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Frederick
,
sir
,
"
quoth
Mrs
General
,
"
is
habitually
absent
and
drooping
,
but
let
us
hope
it
is
not
so
bad
as
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
however
,
was
determined
not
to
let
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fast
declining
,
madam
.
 
<EOS>
A
wreck
.
 
<EOS>
A
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
Mouldering
away
before
our
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Good
Frederick
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
left
Mrs
Sparkler
quite
well
and
happy
,
I
trust
?
"
said
Mrs
General
,
after
heaving
a
cool
sigh
for
Frederick
.
   
<EOS>
"
Surrounded
,
"
replied
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
by
---
ha
---
all
that
can
charm
the
taste
,
and
---
hum
---
elevate
the
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Happy
,
my
dear
madam
,
in
a
---
hum
---
husband
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
was
a
little
fluttered
;
seeming
delicately
to
put
the
word
away
with
her
gloves
,
as
if
there
were
no
knowing
what
it
might
lead
to
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
"
Mr
Dorrit
continued
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fanny
,
Mrs
General
,
has
high
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Ambition
---
hum
---
purpose
,
consciousness
of
---
ha
---
position
,
determination
to
support
that
position
---
ha
,
hum
---
grace
,
beauty
,
and
native
nobility
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
said
Mrs
General
(
with
a
little
extra
stiffness
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Combined
with
these
qualities
,
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
<EOS>
Fanny
has
---
ha
---
manifested
one
blemish
which
has
made
me
---
hum
---
made
me
uneasy
,
and
---
<EOS>
ha
---
I
must
add
,
angry
;
but
which
I
trust
may
now
be
considered
at
an
end
,
even
as
to
herself
,
and
which
is
undoubtedly
at
an
end
as
to
---
ha
---
others
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
what
,
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
with
her
gloves
again
somewhat
excited
,
"
can
you
allude
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
at
a
loss
to
---
"
   
"
Do
not
say
that
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
interrupted
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
's
voice
,
as
it
died
away
,
pronounced
the
words
,
"
at
a
loss
to
imagine
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
which
Mr
Dorrit
was
seized
with
a
doze
for
about
a
minute
,
out
of
which
he
sprang
with
spasmodic
nimbleness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
refer
,
Mrs
General
,
to
that
---
ha
---
strong
spirit
of
opposition
,
or
---
hum
---
I
might
say
---
ha
---
jealousy
in
Fanny
,
which
has
occasionally
risen
against
the
---
ha
---
sense
I
entertain
of
---
hum
---
the
claims
of
---
ha
---
the
lady
with
whom
I
have
now
the
honour
of
communing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
returned
Mrs
General
,
"
is
ever
but
too
obliging
,
ever
but
too
appreciative
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
have
been
moments
when
I
have
imagined
that
Miss
Dorrit
has
indeed
resented
the
favourable
opinion
Mr
Dorrit
has
formed
of
my
services
,
I
have
found
,
in
that
only
too
high
opinion
,
my
consolation
and
recompense
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Opinion
of
your
services
,
madam
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
,
"
Mrs
General
repeated
,
in
an
elegantly
impressive
manner
,
"
my
services
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
your
services
alone
,
dear
madam
?
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
presume
,
"
retorted
Mrs
General
,
in
her
former
impressive
manner
,
"
of
my
services
alone
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
to
what
else
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
with
a
slightly
interrogative
action
of
her
gloves
,
"
could
I
impute
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
To
---
ha
---
yourself
,
Mrs
General
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
hum
.
 
<EOS>
To
yourself
and
your
merits
,
"
was
Mr
Dorrit
's
rejoinder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
will
pardon
me
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
"
if
I
remark
that
this
is
not
a
time
or
place
for
the
pursuit
of
the
present
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
will
excuse
me
if
I
remind
him
that
Miss
Dorrit
is
in
the
adjoining
room
,
and
is
visible
to
myself
while
I
utter
her
name
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
will
forgive
me
if
I
observe
that
I
am
agitated
,
and
that
I
find
there
are
moments
when
weaknesses
I
supposed
myself
to
have
subdued
,
return
with
redoubled
power
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
will
allow
me
to
withdraw
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
we
may
resume
this
---
ha
---
interesting
conversation
,
"
said
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
at
another
time
;
unless
it
should
be
,
what
I
hope
it
is
not
---
hum
---
in
any
way
disagreeable
to
---
ah
---
Mrs
General
.
"
<EOS>
"
Mr
Dorrit
,
"
said
Mrs
General
,
casting
down
her
eyes
as
she
rose
with
a
bend
,
"
must
ever
claim
my
homage
and
obedience
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
General
then
took
herself
off
in
a
stately
way
,
and
not
with
that
amount
of
trepidation
upon
her
which
might
have
been
expected
in
a
less
remarkable
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dorrit
,
who
had
conducted
his
part
of
the
dialogue
with
a
certain
majestic
and
admiring
condescension
 
---
much
as
some
people
may
be
seen
to
conduct
themselves
in
Church
,
and
to
perform
their
part
in
the
service
---
appeared
,
on
the
whole
,
very
well
satisfied
with
himself
and
with
Mrs
General
too
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
return
of
that
lady
to
tea
,
she
had
touched
herself
up
with
a
little
powder
and
pomatum
,
and
was
not
without
moral
enchantment
likewise
:
<EOS>
the
latter
showing
itself
in
much
sweet
patronage
of
manner
towards
Miss
Dorrit
,
and
in
an
air
of
as
tender
interest
in
Mr
Dorrit
as
was
consistent
with
rigid
propriety
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
the
evening
,
when
she
rose
to
retire
,
Mr
Dorrit
took
her
by
the
hand
as
if
he
were
going
to
lead
her
out
into
the
Piazza
of
the
people
to
walk
a
minuet
by
moonlight
,
and
with
great
solemnity
conducted
her
to
the
room
door
,
where
he
raised
her
knuckles
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Having
parted
from
her
with
what
may
be
conjectured
to
have
been
a
rather
bony
kiss
of
a
cosmetic
flavour
,
he
gave
his
daughter
his
blessing
,
graciously
.
 
<EOS>
And
having
thus
hinted
that
there
was
something
remarkable
in
the
wind
,
he
again
went
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
He
remained
in
the
seclusion
of
his
own
chamber
next
morning
;
but
,
early
in
the
afternoon
,
sent
down
his
best
compliments
to
Mrs
General
,
by
Mr
Tinkler
,
and
begged
she
would
accompany
Miss
Dorrit
on
an
airing
without
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
was
dressed
for
Mrs
Merdle
's
dinner
before
he
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
presented
himself
in
a
refulgent
condition
as
to
his
attire
,
but
looking
indefinably
shrunken
and
old
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
as
he
was
plainly
determined
to
be
angry
with
her
if
she
so
much
as
asked
him
how
he
was
,
she
only
ventured
to
kiss
his
cheek
,
before
accompanying
him
to
Mrs
Merdle
's
with
an
anxious
heart
.
   
<EOS>
The
distance
that
they
had
to
go
was
very
short
,
but
he
was
at
his
building
work
again
before
the
carriage
had
half
traversed
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
received
him
with
great
distinction
;
the
bosom
was
in
admirable
preservation
,
and
on
the
best
terms
with
itself
;
the
dinner
was
very
choice
;
and
the
company
was
very
select
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
principally
English
;
saving
that
it
comprised
the
usual
French
Count
and
the
usual
Italian
Marchese
---
decorative
social
milestones
,
always
to
be
found
in
certain
places
,
and
varying
very
little
in
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
The
table
was
long
,
and
the
dinner
was
long
;
and
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
overshadowed
by
a
large
pair
of
black
whiskers
and
a
large
white
cravat
,
lost
sight
of
her
father
altogether
,
until
a
servant
put
a
scrap
of
paper
in
her
hand
,
with
a
whispered
request
from
Mrs
Merdle
that
she
would
read
it
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
had
written
on
it
in
pencil
,
"
Pray
come
and
speak
to
Mr
Dorrit
<EOS>
,
I
doubt
if
he
is
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
hurrying
to
him
,
unobserved
,
when
he
got
up
out
of
his
chair
,
and
leaning
over
the
table
called
to
her
,
supposing
her
to
be
still
in
her
place
:
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
Amy
,
my
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
action
was
so
unusual
,
to
say
nothing
of
his
strange
eager
appearance
and
strange
eager
voice
,
that
it
instantaneously
caused
a
profound
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Amy
,
my
dear
,
"
he
repeated
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
go
and
see
if
Bob
is
on
the
lock
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
at
his
side
,
and
touching
him
,
but
he
still
perversely
supposed
her
to
be
in
her
seat
,
and
called
out
,
still
leaning
over
the
table
,
"
<EOS>
Amy
,
Amy
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
feel
quite
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
's
the
matter
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
particularly
wish
to
see
Bob
.
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
turnkeys
,
he
's
as
much
my
friend
as
yours
.
 
<EOS>
See
if
Bob
is
in
the
lodge
,
and
beg
him
to
come
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
All
the
guests
were
now
in

,
and
everybody
rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
father
,
I
am
not
there
;
I
am
here
,
by
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
here
,
Amy
!
 
<EOS>
Good
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Good
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Call
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
has
been
relieved
,
and
is
not
on
the
lock
,
tell
Mrs
Bangham
to
go
and
fetch
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
gently
trying
to
get
him
away
;
but
he
resisted
,
and
would
not
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
child
,
"
he
said
petulantly
,
"
I
ca
n't
be
got
up
the
narrow
stairs
without
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Send
for
Bob
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Send
for
Bob
---
best
of
all
the
turnkeys
---
send
for
Bob
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
confusedly
about
him
,
and
,
becoming
conscious
of
the
number
of
faces
by
which
he
was

,
addressed
