:
   
"
Ladies
and
gentlemen
,
the
duty
---
ha
---
devolves
upon
me
of
---
hum
---
welcoming
you
to
the
Marshalsea
!
 
<EOS>
Welcome
to
the
Marshalsea
!
 
<EOS>
The
space
is
---
ha
---
limited
---
limited
---
the
parade
might
be
wider
;
but
you
will
find
it
apparently
grow
larger
after
a
time
---
a
time
,
ladies
and
gentlemen
---
and
the
air
is
,
all
things
considered
,
very
good
.
<EOS>
It
blows
over
the
---
ha
---
Surrey
hills
.
 
<EOS>
Blows
over
the
Surrey
hills
.
<EOS>
This
is
the
Snuggery
.
 
<EOS>
Hum
.
 
<EOS>
Supported
by
a
small
subscription
of
the
---
ha
---
Collegiate
body
.
 
<EOS>
In
return
for
which
---
hot
water
---
general
kitchen
---
and
little
domestic
advantages
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
are
habituated
to
the
---
ha
---
Marshalsea
,
are
pleased
to
call
me
its
father
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
accustomed
to
be
complimented
by
strangers
as
the
---
ha
---
Father
of
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
,
if
years
of
residence
may
establish
a
claim
to
so
---
ha
---
honourable
a
title
<EOS>
,
I
may
accept
the
---
hum
---
conferred
distinction
.
 
<EOS>
My
child
,
ladies
and
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Born
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
not
ashamed
of
it
,
or
ashamed
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
pale
and
frightened
;
but
she
had
no
other
care
than
to
soothe
him
and
get
him
away
,
for
his
own
dear
sake
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
between
him
and
the
wondering
faces
,
turned
round
upon
his
breast
with
her
own
face
raised
to
his
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
her
clasped
in
his
left
arm
,
and
between
whiles
her
low
voice
was
heard
tenderly
imploring
him
to
go
away
with
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Born
here
,
"
he
repeated
,
shedding
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bred
here
.
 
<EOS>
Ladies
and
gentlemen
,
my
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Child
of
an
unfortunate
father
,
but
---
ha
---
always
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
,
no
doubt
,
but
<EOS>
---
hum
---
proud
.
 
<EOS>
Always
proud
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
become
a
---
hum
---
not
infrequent
custom
for
my
---
ha
---
personal
admirers
---
personal
admirers
solely
---
to
be
pleased
to
express
their
desire
to
acknowledge
my
semi
-
official
position
here
,
by
offering
---
ha
---
little
tributes
,
which
usually
take
the
form
of
---
ha
---
voluntary
recognitions
of
my
humble
endeavours
to
---
hum
---
to
uphold
a
Tone
here
---
a
Tone
<EOS>
---
I
beg
it
to
be
understood
that
I
do
not
consider
myself
compromised
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Not
compromised
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
beggar
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
I
repudiate
the
title
!
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
far
be
it
from
me
to
---
hum
---
to
put
upon
the
fine
feelings
by
which
my
partial
friends
are
actuated
,
the
slight
of
scrupling
to
admit
that
those
offerings
are
---
hum
---
highly
acceptable
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
they
are
most
acceptable
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
child
's
name
,
if
not
in
my
own
,
I
make
the
admission
in
the
fullest
manner
,
at
the
same
time
reserving
---
ha
---
shall
I
say
my
personal
dignity
?
 
<EOS>
Ladies
and
gentlemen
,
God
bless
you
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
exceeding
mortification
undergone
by
the
Bosom
had
occasioned
the
withdrawal
of
the
greater
part
of
the
company
into
other
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
The
few
who
had
lingered
thus
long
followed
the
rest
,
and
Little
Dorrit
and
her
father
were
left
to
the
servants
and
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Dearest
and
most
precious
to
her
,
he
would
come
with
her
now
,
<EOS>
would
he
not
?
 
<EOS>
He
replied
to
her
fervid
entreaties
,
that
he
would
never
be
able
to
get
up
the
narrow
stairs
without
Bob
;
<EOS>
where
was
Bob
,
would
nobody
fetch
Bob
?
 
<EOS>
Under
pretence
of
looking
for
Bob
,
she
got
him
out
against
the
stream
of
gay
company
now
pouring
in
for
the
evening
assembly
,
and
got
him
into
a
coach
that
had
just
set
down
its
load
,
and
got
him
home
.
   
<EOS>
The
broad
stairs
of
his
Roman
palace
were
contracted
in
his
failing
sight
to
the
narrow
stairs
of
his
London
prison
;
and
he
would
suffer
no
one
but
her
to
touch
him
,
his
brother
excepted
.
 
<EOS>
They
got
him
up
to
his
room
without
help
,
and
laid
him
down
on
his
bed
.
 
<EOS>
And
from
that
hour
his
poor
maimed
spirit
,
only
remembering
the
place
where
it
had
broken
its
wings
,
cancelled
the
dream
through
which
it
had
since
groped
,
and
knew
of
nothing
beyond
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
heard
footsteps
in
the
street
,
he
took
them
for
the
old
weary
tread
in
the
yards
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
hour
came
for
locking
up
,
he
supposed
all
strangers
to
be
excluded
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
time
for
opening
came
again
,
he
was
so
anxious
to
see
Bob
,
that
they
were
fain
to
patch
up
a
narrative
<EOS>
how
that
Bob
---
many
a
year
dead
then
,
gentle
turnkey
---
had
taken
cold
,
but
hoped
to
be
out
to
-
morrow
,
or
the
next
day
,
or
the
next
at
furthest
.
   
<EOS>
He
fell
away
into
a
weakness
so
extreme
that
he
could
not
raise
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
still
protected
his
brother
according
to
his
long
usage
;
and
would
say
with
some
complacency
,
fifty
times
a
day
,
when
he
saw
him
standing
by
his
bed
,
"
My
good
Frederick
,
sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
very
feeble
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
tried
him
with
Mrs
General
,
but
he
had
not
the
faintest
knowledge
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Some
injurious
suspicion
lodged
itself
in
his
brain
,
that
she
wanted
to
supplant
Mrs
Bangham
,
and
that
she
was
given
to
drinking
.
 
<EOS>
He
charged
her
with
it
in
no
measured
terms
;
and
was
so
urgent
with
his
daughter
to
go
round
to
the
Marshal
and
entreat
him
to
turn
her
out
,
that
she
was
never
reproduced
after
the
first
failure
.
<EOS>
Saving
that
he
once
asked
"
if
Tip
had
gone
outside
?
<EOS>
"
the
remembrance
of
his
two
children
not
present
seemed
to
have
departed
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
child
who
had
done
so
much
for
him
and
had
been
so
poorly
repaid
,
was
never
out
of
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
he
spared
her
,
or
was
fearful
of
her
being
spent
by
watching
and
fatigue
;
he
was
not
more
troubled
on
that
score
than
he
had
usually
been
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
he
loved
her
in
his
old
way
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
in
the
jail
again
,
and
she
tended
him
,
and
he
had
constant
need
of
her
,
and
could
not
turn
without
her
;
and
he
even
told
her
,
sometimes
,
that
he
was
content
to
have
undergone
a
great
deal
for
her
sake
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
her
,
she
bent
over
his
bed
with
her
quiet
face
against
his
,
and
would
have
laid
down
her
own
life
to
restore
him
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
been
sinking
in
this
painless
way
for
two
or
three
days
,
she
observed
him
to
be
troubled
by
the
ticking
of
his
watch
---
a
pompous
gold
watch
that
made
as
great
<EOS>
a
to
-
do
about
its
going
as
if
nothing
else
went
but
itself
and
Time
.
 
<EOS>
She
suffered
it
to
run
down
;
but
he
was
still
uneasy
,
and
showed
that
was
not
what
he
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
roused
himself
to
explain
that
he
wanted
money
to
be
raised
on
this
watch
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
pleased
when
she
pretended
to
take
it
away
for
the
purpose
,
and
afterwards
had
a
relish
for
his
little
tastes
of
wine
and
jelly
,
that
he
had
not
had
before
.
   
<EOS>
He
soon
made
it
plain
that
this
was
so
;
for
,
in
another
day
or
two
he
sent
off
his
sleeve
-
buttons
and
finger
-
rings
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
an
amazing
satisfaction
in
entrusting
her
with
these
errands
,
and
appeared
to
consider
it
equivalent
to
making
the
most
methodical
and
provident
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
After
his
trinkets
,
or
such
of
them
as
he
had
been
able
to
see
about
him
,
were
gone
,
his
clothes
engaged
his
attention
;
and
it
is
as
likely
as
not
that
he
was
kept
alive
for
some
days
by
the
satisfaction
of
sending
them
,
piece
by
piece
,
to
an
imaginary
pawnbroker
's
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
for
ten
days
Little
Dorrit
bent
over
his
pillow
,
laying
her
cheek
against
his
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
she
was
so
worn
out
that
for
a
few
minutes
they
would
slumber
together
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
awake
;
to
recollect
with
fast
-
flowing
silent
tears
what
it
was
that
touched
her
face
,
and
to
see
,
stealing
over
the
cherished
face
upon
the
pillow
,
a
deeper
shadow
than
the
shadow
of
the
Marshalsea
Wall
.
   
<EOS>
Quietly
,
quietly
,
all
the
lines
of
the
plan
of
the
great
Castle
melted
one
after
another
.
 
<EOS>
Quietly
,
quietly
,
the
ruled
and
cross
-
ruled
countenance
on
which
they
were
traced
,
became
fair
and
blank
.
   
<EOS>
Quietly
,
quietly
,
the
reflected
marks
of
the
prison
bars
and
of
the
zig
-
zag
iron
on
the
wall
-
top
,
faded
away
.
 
<EOS>
Quietly
,
quietly
,
the
face
subsided
into
a
far
younger
likeness
of
her
own
than
she
had
ever
seen
under
the
grey
hair
,
and
sank
to
rest
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
her
uncle
was
stark
distracted
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
my
brother
!
 
<EOS>
O
William
,
William
!
 
<EOS>
You
to
go
before
me
;
you
to
go
alone
;
you
to
go
,
and
I
to
remain
!
 
<EOS>
You
,
so
far
superior
,
so
distinguished
,
so
noble
;
I
,
a
poor
useless
creature
fit
for
nothing
,
and
whom
no
one
would
have
missed
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
did
her
,
for
the
time
,
the
good
of
having
him
to
think
of
and
to
succour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Uncle
,
dear
uncle
,
spare
yourself
,
spare
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
was
not
deaf
to
the
last
words
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
did
begin
to
restrain
himself
,
it
was
that
he
might
spare
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
care
for
himself
;
but
,
with
all
the
remaining
power
of
the
honest
heart
,
stunned
so
long
and
now
awaking
to
be
broken
,
he
honoured
and
blessed
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
O
God
,
"
he
cried
,
before
they
left
the
room
,
with
his
wrinkled
hands
clasped
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
seest
this
daughter
of
my
dear
dead
brother
!
 
<EOS>
All
that
I
have
looked
upon
,
with
my
half
-
blind
and
sinful
eyes
<EOS>
,
Thou
hast
discerned
clearly
,
brightly
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
hair
of
her
head
shall
be
harmed
before
Thee
.
 
<EOS>
Thou
wilt
uphold
her
here
to
her
last
hour
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
know
Thou
wilt
reward
<EOS>
her
hereafter
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
remained
in
a
dim
room
near
,
until
it
was
almost
midnight
,
quiet
and
sad
together
.
 
<EOS>
At
times
his
grief
would
seek
relief
in
a
burst
like
that
in
which
it
had
found
its
earliest
expression
;
but
,
besides
that
his
little
strength
would
soon
have
been
unequal
to
such
strains
,
he
never
failed
to
recall
her
words
,
and
to
reproach
himself
and
calm
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
utterance
with
which
he
indulged
his
sorrow
,
was
the
frequent
exclamation
that
his
brother
was
gone
,
alone
;
that
they
had
been
together
in
the
outset
of
their
lives
,
that
they
had
fallen
into
misfortune
together
,
that
they
had
kept
together
through
their
many
years
of
poverty
,
that
they
had
remained
together
to
that
day
;
and
that
his
brother
was
gone
alone
,
alone
!
   
<EOS>
They
parted
,
heavy
and
sorrowful
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
not
consent
to
leave
him
anywhere
but
in
his
own
room
,
and
she
saw
him
lie
down
in
his
clothes
upon
his
bed
,
and
covered
him
with
her
own
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
sank
upon
her
own
bed
,
and
fell
into
a
deep
sleep
:
<EOS>
the
sleep
of
exhaustion
and
rest
,
though
not
of
complete
release
from
a
pervading
consciousness
of
affliction
.
 
<EOS>
Sleep
,
good
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
Sleep
through
the
night
!
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
moonlight
night
;
but
the
moon
rose
late
,
being
long
past
the
full
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
high
in
the
peaceful
firmament
,
it
shone
through
half
-
closed
lattice
blinds
into
the
solemn
room
where
the
stumblings
and
wanderings
of
a
life
had
so
lately
ended
.
 
<EOS>
Two
quiet
figures
were
within
the
room
;
two
figures
,
equally
still
and
impassive
,
equally
removed
by
an
untraversable
distance
from
the
teeming
earth
and
all
that
it
contains
,
though
soon
to
lie
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
One
figure
reposed
upon
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
,
kneeling
on
the
floor
,
drooped
over
it
;
the
arms
easily
and
peacefully
resting
on
the
coverlet
;
the
face
bowed
down
,
so
that
the
lips
touched
the
hand
over
which
with
its
last
breath
it
had
bent
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
brothers
were
before
their
Father
;
far
beyond
the
twilight
judgment
of
this
world
;
high
above
its
mists
and
obscurities
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Introduces
the
next
 
<EOS>
The
passengers
were
landing
from
the
packet
on
the
pier
at
Calais
.
<EOS>
A
low
-
lying
place
and
a
low
-
spirited
place
Calais
was
,
with
the
tide
ebbing
out
towards
low
water
-
mark
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
more
water
on
the
bar
than
had
sufficed
to
float
the
packet
in
;
and
now
the
bar
itself
,
with
a
shallow
break
of
sea
over
it
,
looked
like
a
lazy
marine
monster
just
risen
to
the
surface
,
whose
form
was
indistinctly
shown
as
it
lay
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
meagre
lighthouse
all
in
white
,
haunting
the
seaboard
as
if
it
were
the
ghost
of
an
edifice
that
had
once
had
colour
and
rotundity
,
dropped
melancholy
tears
after
its
late
buffeting
by
the
waves
.
 
<EOS>
The
long
rows
of
gaunt
black
piles
,
slimy
and
wet
and
weather
-
worn
,
with
funeral
garlands
of
seaweed
twisted
about
them
by
the
late
tide
,
might
have
represented
an
unsightly
marine
cemetery
.
 
<EOS>
Every
wave
-
dashed
,
storm
-
beaten
object
,
was
so
low
and
so
little
,
under
the
broad
grey
sky
,
in
the
noise
of
the
wind
and
sea
,
and
before
the
curling
lines
of
surf
,
making
at
it
ferociously
,
that
the
wonder
was
there
was
any
Calais
left
,
and
that
its
low
gates
and
low
wall
and
low
roofs
and
low
ditches
and
low
sand
-
hills
and
low
ramparts
and
flat
streets
,
had
not
yielded
long
ago
to
the
undermining
and
besieging
sea
,
like
the
fortifications
children
make
on
the
sea
-
shore
.
   
<EOS>
After
slipping
among
oozy
piles
and
planks
,
stumbling
up
wet
steps
and
encountering
many
salt
difficulties
,
the
passengers
entered
on
their
comfortless
peregrination
along
the
pier
;
where
all
the
French
vagabonds
and
English
outlaws
in
the
town
(
half
the
population
)
attended
to
prevent
their
recovery
from
bewilderment
.
<EOS>
After
being
minutely
inspected
by
all
the
English
,
and
claimed
and
reclaimed
and
counter
-
claimed
as
prizes
by
all
the
French
in
a
hand
-
to
-
hand
scuffle
three
quarters
of
a
mile
long
,
they
were
at
last
free
to
enter
the
streets
,
and
to
make
off
in
their
various
directions
,
hotly
pursued
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,
harassed
by
more
anxieties
than
one
,
was
among
this
devoted
band
.
 
<EOS>
Having
rescued
the
most
defenceless
of
his
compatriots
from
situations
of
great
extremity
,
he
now
went
his
way
alone
,
or
as
nearly
alone
as
he
could
be
,
with
a
native
gentleman
in
a
suit
of
grease
and
a
cap
of
the
same
material
,
giving
chase
at
a
distance
of
some
fifty
yards
,
and
continually
calling
after
him
,
"
<EOS>
Hi
!
 
<EOS>
Ice
-
say
!
 
<EOS>
You
!
 
<EOS>
Seer
!
 
<EOS>
Ice
-
say
!
 
<EOS>
Nice
Oatel
!
"
   
<EOS>
Even
this
hospitable
person
,
however
,
was
left
behind
at
last
,
and
Clennam
pursued
his
way
,
unmolested
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
tranquil
air
in
the
town
after
the
turbulence
of
the
Channel
and
the
beach
,
and
its
dulness
in
that
comparison
was
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
He
met
new
groups
of
his
countrymen
,
who
had
all
a
straggling
air
of
having
at
one
time
overblown
themselves
,
like
certain
uncomfortable
kinds
of
flowers
,
and
of
being
now
mere
weeds
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
all
an
air
,
too
,
of
lounging
out
a
limited
round
,
day
after
day
,
which
strongly
reminded
him
of
the
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
taking
no
further
note
of
them
than
was
sufficient
to
give
birth
to
the
reflection
,
he
sought
out
a
certain
street
and
number
which
he
kept
in
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
Pancks
said
,
"
he
murmured
to
himself
,
as
he
stopped
before
a
dull
house
answering
to
the
address
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
his
information
to
be
correct
and
his
discovery
,
among
Mr
Casby
's
loose
papers
,
indisputable
;
but
,
without
it
,
I
should
hardly
have
supposed
this
to
be
a
likely
place
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
dead
sort
of
house
,
with
a
dead
wall
over
the
way
and
a
dead
gateway
at
the
side
,
where
a
pendant
bell
-
handle
produced
two
dead
tinkles
,
and
a
knocker
produced
a
dead
,
flat
,
surface
-
tapping
,
that
seemed
not
to
have
depth
enough
in
it
to
penetrate
even
the
cracked
door
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
the
door
jarred
open
on
a
dead
sort
of
spring
;
and
he
closed
it
behind
him
as
he
entered
a
dull
yard
,
soon
brought
to
a
close
by
another
dead
wall
,
where
an
attempt
had
been
made
to
train
some
creeping
shrubs
,
which
were
dead
;
and
to
make
a
little
fountain
in
a
grotto
,
which
was
dry
;
and
to
decorate
that
with
a
little
statue
,
which
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
The
entry
to
the
house
was
on
the
left
,
and
it
was
garnished
as
the
outer
gateway
was
,
with
two
printed
bills
in
French
and
English
,
announcing
Furnished
Apartments
to
let
,
with
immediate
possession
.
<EOS>
A
strong
cheerful
peasant
woman
,
all
stocking
,
petticoat
,
white
cap
,
and
ear
-
ring
,
stood
here
in
a
dark
doorway
,
and
said
with
a
pleasant
show
of
teeth
,
"
Ice
-
say
!
 
<EOS>
Seer
!
 
<EOS>
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,
replying
in
French
,
said
the
English
lady
;
he
wished
to
see
the
English
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enter
then
and
ascend
,
if
you
please
,
"
returned
the
peasant
woman
,
in
French
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
both
,
and
followed
her
up
a
dark
bare
staircase
to
a
back
room
on
the
first
-
floor
.
<EOS>
Hence
,
there
was
a
gloomy
view
of
the
yard
that
was
dull
,
and
of
the
shrubs
that
were
dead
,
and
of
the
fountain
that
was
dry
,
and
of
the
pedestal
of
the
statue
that
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Monsieur
Blandois
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
pleasure
,
Monsieur
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thereupon
the
woman
withdrew
and
left
him
to
look
at
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
pattern
of
room
always
to
be
found
in
such
a
house
.
 
<EOS>
Cool
,
dull
,
and
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Waxed
floor
very
slippery
.
 
<EOS>
A
room
not
large
enough
to
skate
in
;
nor
adapted
to
the
easy
pursuit
of
any
other
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
Red
and
white
curtained
windows
,
little
straw
mat
,
little
round
table
with
a
tumultuous
assemblage
of
legs
underneath
,
clumsy
rush
-
bottomed
chairs
,
two
great
red
velvet
arm
-
chairs
affording
plenty
of
space
to
be
uncomfortable
in
,
bureau
,
chimney
-
glass
in
several
pieces
pretending
to
be
in
one
piece
,
pair
of
gaudy
vases
of
very
artificial
flowers
;
between
them
a
Greek
warrior
with
his
helmet
off
,
sacrificing
a
clock
to
the
Genius
of
France
.
   
<EOS>
After
some
pause
,
a
door
of
communication
with
another
room
was
opened
,
and
a
lady
entered
.
 
<EOS>
She
manifested
great
surprise
on
seeing
Clennam
,
and
her
glance
went
round
the
room
in
search
of
some
one
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
Miss
Wade
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
your
name
that
was
brought
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
Excuse
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
already
had
experience
that
my
name
does
not
predispose
you
to
an
interview
;
and
I
ventured
to
mention
the
name
of
one
I
am
in
search
of
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
she
returned
,
motioning
him
to
a
chair
so
coldly
that
he
remained
standing
<EOS>
,
"
what
name
was
it
that
you
gave
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
the
name
of
Blandois
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Blandois
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
name
you
are
acquainted
with
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
,
"
she
said
,
frowning
,
"
that
you
should
still
press
an
undesired
interest
in
me
and
my
acquaintances
,
in
me
and
my
affairs
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
the
name
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
you
have
to
do
with
the
name
?
 
<EOS>
What
can
I
have
to
do
with
the
name
?
 
<EOS>
What
can
you
have
to
do
with
my
knowing
or
not
knowing
any
name
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
many
names
<EOS>
and
I
have
forgotten
many
more
.
 
<EOS>
This
may
be
in
the
one
class
,
or
it
may
be
in
the
other
,
or
I
may
never
have
heard
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
acquainted
with
no
reason
for
examining
myself
,
or
for
being
examined
,
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
allow
me
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
I
will
tell
you
my
reason
for
pressing
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
I
admit
that
I
do
press
it
,
and
I
must
beg
you
to
forgive
me
if
I
do
so
,
very
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
The
reason
is
all
mine
,
I
do
not
insinuate
that
it
is
in
any
way
yours
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
she
returned
,
repeating
a
little
less
haughtily
than
before
her
former
invitation
to
him
to
be
seated
:
to
which
he
now
deferred
,
as
she
seated
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
at
least
glad
to
know
that
this
is
not
another
bondswoman
of
some
friend
of
yours
,
who
is
bereft
of
free
choice
,
and
whom
I
have
spirited
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
hear
your
reason
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
to
identify
the
person
of
whom
we
speak
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
let
me
observe
that
it
is
the
person
you
met
in
London
some
time
back
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
remember
meeting
him
near
the
river
---
in
the
Adelphi
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
mix
yourself
most
unaccountably
with
my
business
,
"
she
replied
,
looking
full
at
him
with
stern
displeasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
entreat
you
not
to
take
it
ill
.
 
<EOS>
By
mere
accident
.
"
<EOS>
"
What
accident
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Solely
the
accident
of
coming
upon
you
in
the
street
and
seeing
the
meeting
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
speak
of
yourself
,
or
of
some
one
else
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
it
was
in
the
open
street
,
"
she
observed
,
after
a
few
moments
of
less
and
less
angry
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fifty
people
might
have
seen
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
signified
nothing
if
they
had
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
do
I
make
my
having
seen
it
of
any
moment
,
nor
(
otherwise
than
as
an
explanation
of
my
coming
here
)
<EOS>
do
I
connect
my
visit
with
it
or
the
favour
that
I
have
to
ask
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
to
ask
a
favour
!
 
<EOS>
It
occurred
to
me
,
"
and
the
handsome
face
looked
bitterly
at
him
,
"
that
your
manner
was
softened
,
Mr
Clennam
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
content
to
protest
against
this
by
a
slight
action
without
contesting
it
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
referred
to
Blandois
'
disappearance
,
of
which
it
was
probable
<EOS>
she
had
heard
?
 
<EOS>
However
probable
it
was
to
him
,
she
had
heard
of
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
look
round
him
(
she
said
)
and
judge
for
himself
what
general
intelligence
was
likely
to
reach
the
ears
of
a
woman
who
had
been
shut
up
there
while
it
was
rife
,
devouring
her
own
heart
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
uttered
this
denial
,
which
he
believed
to
be
true
,
she
asked
him
what
he
meant
by
disappearance
?
 
<EOS>
That
led
to
his
narrating
the
circumstances
in
detail
,
and
expressing
something
of
his
anxiety
to
discover
what
had
really
become
of
the
man
,
and
to
repel
the
dark
suspicions
that
clouded
about
his
mother
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
She
heard
him
with
evident
surprise
,
and
with
more
marks
of
suppressed
interest
than
he
had
seen
in
her
;
still
they
did
not
overcome
her
distant
,
proud
,
and
self
-
secluded
manner
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
finished
,
she
said
nothing
but
these
words
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
yet
told
me
,
sir
,
what
I
have
to
do
with
it
,
or
what
the
favour
is
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
be
so
good
as
come
to
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
assume
,
"
said
Arthur
,
persevering
,
in
his
endeavour
to
soften
her
scornful
demeanour
,
"
that
being
in
communication
---
may
I
say
,
confidential
communication
?
---
with
this
person
---
"
   
"
You
may
say
,
of
course
,
whatever
you
like
,
"
she
remarked
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
not
subscribe
to
your
assumptions
,
Mr
Clennam
,
or
to
any
one
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
that
being
,
at
least
in
personal
communication
with
him
,
"
said
Clennam
,
changing
the
form
of
his
position
in
the
hope
of
making
it
unobjectionable
,
"
you
can
tell
me
something
of
his
antecedents
,
pursuits
,
habits
,
usual
place
of
residence
.
 
<EOS>
Can
give
me
some
little
clue
by
which
to
seek
him
out
in
the
likeliest
manner
,
and
either
produce
him
,
or
establish
what
has
become
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
favour
I
ask
,
and
I
ask
it
in
a
distress
of
mind
for
which
I
hope
you
will
feel
some
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
have
any
reason
for
imposing
conditions
upon
me
,
I
will
respect
it
without
asking
what
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
chanced
to
see
me
in
the
street
with
the
man
,
"
she
observed
,
after
being
,
to
his
mortification
,
evidently
more
occupied
with
her
own
reflections
on
the
matter
than
with
his
appeal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
knew
the
man
before
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
before
;
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
him
before
,
but
I
saw
him
again
on
this
very
night
of
his
disappearance
.
 
<EOS>
In
my
mother
's
room
,
in
fact
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
him
there
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
read
in
this
paper
all
that
is
known
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
handed
her
one
of
the
printed
bills
,
which
she
read
with
a
steady
and
attentive
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
more
than
I
knew
of
him
,
"
she
said
,
giving
it
back
.
   
<EOS>
Clennam
's
looks
expressed
his
heavy
disappointment
,
perhaps
his
incredulity
;
for
she
added
in
the
same
unsympathetic
tone
:
"
You
do
n't
believe
it
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
it
is
so
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
personal
communication
:
it
seems
that
there
was
personal
communication
between
him
and
your
mother
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
you
say
you
believe
her
declaration
that
she
knows
no
more
of
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
sufficiently
expressive
hint
of
suspicion
was
conveyed
in
these
words
,
and
in
the
smile
by
which
they
were
accompanied
,
to
bring
the
blood
into
Clennam
's
cheeks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
sir
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
cruel
pleasure
in
repeating
the
stab
,
"
I
will
be
as
open
with
you
as
you
can
desire
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
confess
that
if
I
cared
for
my
credit
(
which
I
do
not
)
,
or
had
a
good
name
to
preserve
(
which
I
have
not
,
for
I
am
utterly
indifferent
to
its
being
considered
good
or
bad
)
,
I
should
regard
myself
as
heavily
compromised
by
having
had
anything
to
do
with
this
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
he
never
passed
in
at
MY
door
---
never
sat
in
colloquy
with
ME
until
midnight
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
took
her
revenge
for
her
old
grudge
in
thus
turning
his
subject
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
Hers
was
not
the
nature
to
spare
him
,
and
she
had
no
compunction
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
he
is
a
low
,
mercenary
wretch
;
that
I
first
saw
him
prowling
about
Italy
(
where
I
was
,
not
long
ago
)
,
and
that
I
hired
him
there
,
as
the
suitable
instrument
of
a
purpose
I
happened
to
have
;
I
have
no
objection
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
it
was
worth
my
while
,
for
my
own
pleasure
---
the
gratification
of
a
strong
feeling
---
to
pay
a
spy
who
would
fetch
and
carry
for
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
paid
this
creature
.
<EOS>
And
I
dare
say
that
if
I
had
wanted
to
make
such
a
bargain
,
and
if
I
could
have
paid
him
enough
,
and
if
he
could
have
done
it
in
the
dark
,
free
from
all
risk
,
he
would
have
taken
any
life
with
as
little
scruple
as
he
took
my
money
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
at
least
,
is
my
opinion
of
him
;
and
I
see
it
is
not
very
far
removed
from
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Your
mother
's
opinion
of
him
<EOS>
,
I
am
to
assume
(
following
your
example
of
assuming
this
and
that
)
,
was
vastly
different
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
mother
,
let
me
remind
you
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
was
first
brought
into
communication
with
him
in
the
unlucky
course
of
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
appears
to
have
been
an
unlucky
course
of
business
that
last
brought
her
into
communication
with
him
,
"
returned
Miss
Wade
;
"
and
business
hours
on
that
occasion
were
late
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
imply
,
"
said
<EOS>
Arthur
,
smarting
under
these
cool
-
handed
thrusts
,
of
which
he
had
deeply
felt
the
force
already
,
"
that
there
was
something
---
"
   
"
Mr
Clennam
,
"
she
composedly
interrupted
,
"
recollect
that
I
do
not
speak
by
implication
about
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
,
I
say
again
without
disguise
,
a
low
mercenary
wretch
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
such
a
creature
goes
where
there
is
occasion
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
not
had
occasion
for
him
,
you
would
not
have
seen
him
and
me
together
.
"
   
<EOS>
Wrung
by
her
persistence
in
keeping
that
dark
side
of
the
case
before
him
,
of
which
there
was
a
half
-
hidden
shadow
in
his
own
breast
,
Clennam
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
spoken
of
him
as
still
living
,
"
she
added
,
"
but
he
may
have
been
put
out
of
the
way
for
anything
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
For
anything
I
care
,
also
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
further
occasion
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
heavy
sigh
and
a
despondent
air
,
Arthur
Clennam
slowly
rose
.
   
<EOS>
She
did
not
rise
also
,
but
said
,
having
looked
at
him
in
the
meanwhile
with
a
fixed
look
of
suspicion
,
and
lips
angrily
compressed
:
   
<EOS>
"
He
was
the
chosen
associate
of
your
dear
friend
,
Mr
Gowan
,
was
he
not
?
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
ask
your
dear
friend
to
help
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
denial
that
he
was
a
dear
friend
rose
to
Arthur
's
lips
;
but
he
repressed
it
,
remembering
his
old
struggles
and
resolutions
,
and
said
:
   
"
Further
than
that
he
has
never
seen
Blandois
since
Blandois
set
out
for
England
,
Mr
Gowan
knows
nothing
additional
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
chance
acquaintance
,
made
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
chance
acquaintance
made
abroad
!
"
<EOS>
she
repeated
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Your
dear
friend
has
need
to
divert
himself
with
all
the
acquaintances
he
can
make
,
seeing
what
a
wife
he
has
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
his
wife
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
anger
with
which
she
said
it
,
the
more
remarkable
for
being
so
much
under
her
restraint
,
fixed
Clennam
's
attention
,
and
kept
him
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
It
flashed
out
of
her
dark
eyes
as
they
regarded
him
,
quivered
in
her
nostrils
,
and
fired
the
very
breath
she
exhaled
;
but
her
face
was
otherwise
composed
into
a
disdainful
serenity
;
and
her
attitude
was
as
calmly
and
haughtily
graceful
as
if
she
had
been
in
a
mood
of
complete
indifference
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
I
will
say
is
,
Miss
Wade
,
"
he
remarked
,
"
that
you
can
have
received
no
provocation
to
a
feeling
in
which
I
believe
you
have
no
sharer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
ask
your
dear
friend
,
if
you
choose
,
"
she
returned
,
"
for
his
opinion
upon
that
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
scarcely
on
those
intimate
terms
with
my
dear
friend
,
"
said
Arthur
,
in
spite
of
his
resolutions
,
"
that
would
render
my
approaching
the
subject
very
probable
,
Miss
Wade
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hate
him
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Worse
than
his
wife
,
because
I
was
once
dupe
enough
,
and
false
enough
to
myself
,
almost
to
love
him
.
<EOS>
You
have
seen
me
,
sir
,
only
on
common
-
place
occasions
,
when
I
dare
say
you
have
thought
me
a
common
-
place
woman
,
a
little
more
self
-
willed
than
the
generality
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
I
mean
by
hating
,
if
you
know
me
no
better
than
that
;
you
ca
n't
know
,
without
knowing
with
what
care
I
have
studied
myself
and
people
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
reason
I
have
for
some
time
inclined
to
tell
you
what
my
life
has
been
---
not
to
propitiate
your
opinion
,
for
I
set
no
value
on
it
;
but
that
you
may
comprehend
,
when
you
think
of
your
dear
friend
and
his
dear
wife
,
what
I
mean
by
hating
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
give
you
something
I
have
written
and
put
by
for
your
perusal
,
or
shall
I
hold
my
hand
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
begged
her
to
give
it
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
went
to
the
bureau
,
unlocked
it
,
and
took
from
an
inner
drawer
a
few
folded
sheets
of
paper
.
 
<EOS>
Without
any
conciliation
of
him
,
scarcely
addressing
him
,
rather
speaking
as
if
she
were
speaking
to
her
own
looking
-
glass
for
the
justification
of
her
own
stubbornness
,
she
said
,
as
she
gave
them
to
him
:
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
may
know
what
I
mean
by
hating
!
 
<EOS>
No
more
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
,
whether
you
find
me
temporarily
and
cheaply
lodging
in
an
empty
London
house
,
or
in
a
Calais
apartment
,
you
find
Harriet
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
may
like
to
see
her
before
you
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Harriet
,
come
in
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
called
Harriet
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
call
produced
Harriet
,
once
Tattycoram
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
is
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said
Miss
Wade
;
"
not
come
for
you
;
he
has
given
you
up
<EOS>
,
---
I
suppose
you
have
,
by
this
time
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Having
no
authority
,
or
influence
---
yes
,
"
assented
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
come
in
search
of
you
,
you
see
;
but
still
seeking
some
one
.
<EOS>
He
wants
that
Blandois
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
whom
I
saw
you
in
the
Strand
in
London
,
"
hinted
Arthur
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
know
anything
of
him
,
Harriet
,
except
that
he
came
from
Venice
---
which
we
all
know
---
tell
it
to
Mr
Clennam
freely
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
more
about
him
,
"
said
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
satisfied
?
"
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
inquired
of
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
no
reason
to
disbelieve
them
;
the
girl
's
manner
being
so
natural
as
to
be
almost
convincing
,
if
he
had
had
any
previous
doubts
.
 
<EOS>
He
replied
,
"
I
must
seek
for
intelligence
elsewhere
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
going
in
the
same
breath
;
but
he
had
risen
before
the
girl
entered
,
and
she
evidently
thought
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
quickly
at
him
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Are
they
well
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
stopped
herself
in
saying
what
would
have
been
"
all
of
them
;
"
glanced
at
Miss
Wade
;
and
said
"
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
were
,
when
I
last
heard
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
way
,
let
me
ask
you
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
true
that
you
were
seen
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
?
 
<EOS>
Where
does
any
one
say
I
was
seen
?
<EOS>
"
returned
the
girl
,
sullenly
casting
down
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Looking
in
at
the
garden
gate
of
the
cottage
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Miss
Wade
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
never
been
near
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
wrong
,
then
,
"
said
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
went
down
there
the
last
time
we
were
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
one
afternoon
when
you
left
me
alone
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
did
look
in
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
poor
-
spirited
girl
,
"
returned
Miss
Wade
with
infinite
contempt
;
"
does
all
our
companionship
,
do
all
our
conversations
,
do
all
your
old
complainings
,
tell
for
so
little
as
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
harm
in
looking
in
at
the
gate
for
an
instant
,
"
said
the
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
saw
by
the
windows
that
the
family
were
not
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
go
near
the
place
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
wanted
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
Because
I
felt
that
I
should
like
to
look
at
it
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
each
of
the
two
handsome
faces
looked
at
the
other
,
Clennam
felt
how
each
of
the
two
natures
must
be
constantly
tearing
the
other
to
pieces
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Miss
Wade
,
coldly
subduing
and
removing
her
glance
;
"
if
you
had
any
desire
to
see
the
place
where
you
led
the
life
from
which
I
rescued
you
because
you
had
found
out
what
it
was
,
that
is
another
thing
.
 
<EOS>
But
is
that
your
truth
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Is
that
your
fidelity
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Is
that
the
common
cause
I
make
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
worth
the
confidence
I
have
placed
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
worth
the
favour
I
have
shown
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
no
higher
than
a
spaniel
,
and
had
better
go
back
to
the
people
who
did
worse
than
whip
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
speak
so
of
them
with
any
one
else
by
to
hear
,
you
'll
provoke
me
to
take
their
part
,
"
said
the
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
back
to
them
,
"
Miss
Wade
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
back
to
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
very
well
,
"
retorted
Harriet
in
her
turn
,
"
that
I
wo
n't
go
back
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
very
well
that
I
have
thrown
them
off
,
and
never
can
,
never
shall
,
never
will
,
go
back
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
alone
,
then
,
Miss
Wade
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
prefer
their
plenty
to
your
less
fat
living
here
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
exalt
them
,
and
slight
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
else
should
I
have
expected
?
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
known
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
so
,
"
said
the
girl
,
flushing
high
,
"
and
you
do
n't
say
what
you
mean
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
mean
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
reproaching
me
,
underhanded
,
with
having
nobody
but
you
to
look
to
.
 
<EOS>
And
because
I
have
nobody
but
<EOS>
you
to
look
to
<EOS>
,
you
think
you
are
to
make
me
do
,
or
not
do
,
everything
you
please
,
and
are
to
put
any
affront
upon
me
.
<EOS>
You
are
as
bad
as
they
were
,
every
bit
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
be
quite
tamed
,
and
made
submissive
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
say
again
that
I
went
to
look
at
the
house
,
because
I
had
often
thought
that
I
should
like
to
see
it
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
ask
again
how
they
are
,
because
I
once
liked
them
and
at
times
thought
they
were
kind
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Hereupon
Clennam
said
that
he
was
sure
they
would
still
receive
her
kindly
,
if
she
should
ever
desire
to
return
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
said
the
girl
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
do
that
.
<EOS>
Nobody
knows
that
better
than
Miss
Wade
,
though
she
taunts
me
because
she
has
made
me
her
dependent
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
know
I
am
so
<EOS>
;
and
I
know
<EOS>
she
is
overjoyed
when
she
can
bring
it
to
my
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
good
pretence
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Wade
,
with
no
less
anger
,
haughtiness
,
and
bitterness
;
"
but
too
threadbare
to
cover
what
I
plainly
see
in
this
.
 
<EOS>
My
poverty
will
not
bear
competition
with
their
money
.
<EOS>
Better
go
back
at
once
,
better
go
back
at
once
,
and
have
done
with
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
looked
at
them
,
standing
a
little
distance
asunder
in
the
dull
confined
room
,
each
proudly
cherishing
her
own
anger
;
each
,
with
a
fixed
determination
,
torturing
her
own
breast
,
and
torturing
the
other
's
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
a
word
or
two
of
leave
-
taking
;
but
Miss
Wade
barely
inclined
her
head
,
and
Harriet
,
with
the
assumed
humiliation
of
an
abject
dependent
and
serf
(
but
not
without
defiance
for
all
that
)
,
made
as
if
she
were
too
low
to
notice
or
to
be
noticed
.
   
<EOS>
He
came
down
the
dark
winding
stairs
into
the
yard
with
an
increased
sense
upon
him
of
the
gloom
of
the
wall
that
was
dead
,
and
of
the
shrubs
that
were
dead
,
and
of
the
fountain
that
was
dry
,
and
of
the
statue
that
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Pondering
much
on
what
he
had
seen
and
heard
in
that
house
,
as
well
as
on
the
failure
of
all
his
efforts
to
trace
the
suspicious
character
who
was
lost
,
he
returned
to
London
and
to
England
by
the
packet
that
had
taken
him
over
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
way
he
unfolded
the
sheets
of
paper
,
and
read
in
them
what
is
reproduced
in
the
next
chapter
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
The
History
of
a
Self
-
Tormentor
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
misfortune
of
not
being
a
fool
.
 
<EOS>
From
a
very
early
age
I
have
detected
what
those
about
me
thought
they
hid
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
been
habitually
imposed
upon
,
instead
of
habitually
discerning
the
truth
,
I
might
have
lived
as
smoothly
as
most
fools
do
.
   
<EOS>
My
childhood
was
passed
with
a
grandmother
;
that
is
to
say
,
with
a
lady
who
represented
that
relative
to
me
,
and
who
took
that
title
on
herself
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
no
claim
to
it
,
but
<EOS>
I
---
being
to
that
extent
a
little
fool
---
had
no
suspicion
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
some
children
of
her
own
family
in
her
house
,
and
some
children
of
other
people
.
 
<EOS>
All
girls
;
ten
in
number
,
including
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
lived
together
and
were
educated
together
.
   
<EOS>
I
must
have
been
about
twelve
years
old
when
I
began
to
see
how
determinedly
those
girls
patronised
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
told
I
was
an
orphan
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
orphan
among
us
;
and
I
perceived
<EOS>
(
here
was
the
first
disadvantage
of
not
being
a
fool
)
<EOS>
that
they
conciliated
me
in
an
insolent
pity
,
and
in
a
sense
of
superiority
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
set
this
down
as
a
discovery
,
rashly
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
them
often
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
hardly
make
them
quarrel
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
succeeded
with
any
of
them
,
they
were
sure
to
come
after
an
hour
or
two
,
and
begin
a
reconciliation
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
them
over
and
over
again
,
and
I
never
knew
them
wait
for
me
to
begin
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
always
forgiving
me
,
in
their
vanity
and
condescension
.
 
<EOS>
Little
images
of
grown
people
!
   
<EOS>
One
of
them
was
my
chosen
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
loved
that
stupid
mite
in
a
passionate
way
that
she
could
no
more
deserve
than
I
can
remember
without
feeling
ashamed
of
,
though
I
was
but
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
what
they
called
an
amiable
temper
,
an
affectionate
temper
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
distribute
,
and
did
distribute
pretty
looks
and
smiles
to
every
one
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
there
was
not
a
soul
in
the
place
,
except
myself
,
who
knew
that
she
did
it
purposely
to
wound
and
gall
me
!
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
I
so
loved
that
unworthy
girl
that
my
life
was
made
stormy
by
my
fondness
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
constantly
lectured
and
disgraced
for
what
was
called
"
trying
her
;
"
in
other
words
charging
her
with
her
little
perfidy
and
throwing
her
into
tears
by
showing
her
that
I
read
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
loved
her
faithfully
;
and
one
time
I
went
home
with
her
for
the
holidays
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
worse
at
home
than
she
had
been
at
school
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
crowd
of
cousins
and
acquaintances
,
and
we
had
dances
at
her
house
,
and
went
out
to
dances
at
other
houses
,
and
,
both
at
home
and
out
<EOS>
,
she
tormented
my
love
beyond
endurance
.
 
<EOS>
Her
plan
was
,
to
make
them
all
fond
of
her
---
and
so
drive
me
wild
with
jealousy
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
familiar
and
endearing
with
them
all
---
and
so
make
me
mad
with
envying
them
.
<EOS>
When
we
were
left
alone
in
our
bedroom
at
night
,
I
would
reproach
her
with
my
perfect
knowledge
of
her
baseness
;
and
then
she
would
cry
and
cry
and
say
I
was
cruel
,
and
then
I
would
hold
her
in
my
arms
till
morning
:
loving
her
as
much
as
ever
,
and
often
feeling
as
if
,
rather
than
suffer
<EOS>
so
,
I
could
so
hold
her
in
my
arms
and
plunge
to
the
bottom
of
a
river
---
where
I
would
still
hold
her
after
we
were
both
dead
.
   
<EOS>
It
came
to
an
end
,
and
I
was
relieved
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
family
there
was
an
aunt
who
was
not
fond
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubt
if
any
of
the
family
liked
me
much
;
but
I
never
wanted
them
to
like
me
,
being
altogether
bound
up
in
the
one
girl
.
 
<EOS>
The
aunt
was
a
young
woman
,
and
she
had
a
serious
way
with
her
eyes
of
watching
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
an
audacious
woman
,
and
openly
looked
compassionately
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
After
one
of
the
nights
that
I
have
spoken
of
,
I
came
down
into
a
greenhouse
before
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
(
the
name
of
my
false
young
friend
)
had
gone
down
before
me
,
and
I
heard
this
aunt
speaking
to
her
about
me
as
I
entered
.
<EOS>
I
stopped
where
I
was
,
among
the
leaves
,
and
listened
.
   
<EOS>
The
aunt
said
,
"
Charlotte
,
Miss
Wade
is
wearing
you
to
death
,
and
this
must
not
continue
.
"
 
<EOS>
I
repeat
the
very
words
I
heard
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
what
did
she
answer
?
 
<EOS>
Did
she
say
,
"
It
is
I
who
am
wearing
her
to
death
,
I
who
am
keeping
her
on
a
rack
and
am
the
executioner
,
yet
she
tells
me
every
night
that
she
loves
me
devotedly
,
though
she
knows
what
I
make
her
undergo
?
"
 
<EOS>
No
;
my
first
memorable
experience
was
true
to
what
I
knew
her
to
be
,
and
to
all
my
experience
.
 
<EOS>
She
began
sobbing
and
weeping
(
to
secure
the
aunt
's
sympathy
to
herself
)
,
and
said
,
"
Dear
aunt
,
she
has
an
unhappy
temper
;
other
girls
at
school
,
besides
I
,
try
hard
to
make
it
better
;
we
all
try
hard
.
"
   
<EOS>
Upon
that
the
aunt
fondled
her
,
as
if
she
had
said
something
noble
instead
of
despicable
and
false
,
and
kept
up
the
infamous
pretence
by
replying
,
"
But
there
are
reasonable
limits
,
my
dear
love
,
to
everything
,
and
I
see
that
this
poor
miserable
girl
causes
you
more
constant
and
useless
distress
than
even
so
good
an
effort
justifies
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
poor
miserable
girl
came
out
of
her
concealment
,
as
you
may
be
prepared
to
hear
,
and
said
,
"
Send
me
home
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
never
said
another
word
to
either
of
them
,
or
to
any
of
them
,
but
"
Send
me
home
,
or
I
will
walk
home
alone
,
night
and
day
!
"
 
<EOS>
When
I
got
home
,
I
told
my
supposed
grandmother
that
,
unless
I
was
sent
away
to
finish
my
education
somewhere
else
before
that
girl
came
back
,
or
before
any
one
of
them
came
back
,
I
would
burn
my
sight
away
by
throwing
myself
into
the
fire
,
rather
than
I
would
endure
to
look
at
their
plotting
faces
.
   
<EOS>
I
went
among
young
women
next
,
and
I
found
them
no
better
.
 
<EOS>
Fair
words
and
fair
pretences
;
but
I
penetrated
below
those
assertions
of
themselves
and
depreciations
of
me
,
and
they
were
no
better
.
<EOS>
Before
I
left
them
,
I
learned
that
I
had
no
grandmother
and
no
recognised
relation
.
 
<EOS>
I
carried
the
light
of
that
information
both
into
my
past
and
into
my
future
.
 
<EOS>
It
showed
me
many
new
occasions
on
which
people
triumphed
over
me
,
when
they
made
a
pretence
of
treating
me
with
consideration
,
or
doing
me
a
service
.
   
<EOS>
A
man
of
business
had
a
small
property
in
trust
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
be
a
governess
;
I
became
a
governess
;
and
went
into
the
family
of
a
poor
nobleman
,
where
there
were
two
daughters
---
little
children
,
but
the
parents
wished
them
to
grow
up
,
if
possible
,
under
one
instructress
.
 
<EOS>
The
mother
was
young
and
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
first
,
she
made
a
show
of
behaving
to
me
with
great
delicacy
.
 
<EOS>
I
kept
my
resentment
to
myself
;
but
I
knew
very
well
that
it
was
her
way
of
petting
the
knowledge
that
she
was
my
Mistress
,
and
might
have
behaved
differently
to
her
servant
if
it
had
been
her
fancy
.
   
<EOS>
I
say
I
did
not
resent
it
,
nor
did
I
;
but
I
showed
her
,
by
not
gratifying
her
,
that
I
understood
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
pressed
me
to
take
wine
,
I
took
water
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
happened
to
be
anything
choice
at
table
,
she
always
sent
it
to
me
:
but
I
always
declined
it
,
and
ate
of
the
rejected
dishes
.
 
<EOS>
These
disappointments
of
her
patronage
were
a
sharp
retort
,
and
made
me
feel
independent
.
   
<EOS>
I
liked
the
children
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
timid
,
but
on
the
whole
disposed
to
attach
themselves
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
nurse
,
however
,
in
the
house
,
a
rosy
-
faced
woman
always
making
an
obtrusive
pretence
of
being
gay
and
good
-
humoured
,
who
had
nursed
them
both
,
and
who
had
secured
their
affections
before
I
saw
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
almost
have
settled
down
to
my
fate
but
for
this
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Her
artful
devices
for
keeping
herself
before
the
children
in
constant
competition
with
me
,
might
have
blinded
many
in
my
place
;
but
I
saw
through
them
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
pretext
of
arranging
my
rooms
and
waiting
on
me
and
taking
care
of
my
wardrobe
(
all
of
which
she
did
busily
)
,
she
was
never
absent
.
 
<EOS>
The
most
crafty
of
her
many
subtleties
was
her
feint
of
seeking
to
make
the
children
fonder
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
lead
them
to
me
and
coax
them
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
to
good
Miss
Wade
,
come
to
dear
Miss
Wade
,
come
to
pretty
Miss
Wade
.
 
<EOS>
She
loves
you
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wade
is
a
clever
lady
,
who
has
read
heaps
of
books
,
and
can
tell
you
far
better
and
more
interesting
stories
than
I
know
.
<EOS>
Come
and
hear
Miss
Wade
!
"
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
engage
their
attentions
,
when
my
heart
was
burning
against
these
ignorant
designs
?
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
wonder
,
when
I
saw
their
innocent
faces
shrinking
away
,
and
their
arms
twining
round
her
neck
,
instead
of
mine
?
 
<EOS>
Then
she
would
look
up
at
me
,
shaking
their
curls
from
her
face
,
and
say
,
"
They
'll
come
round
soon
,
Miss
Wade
;
they
're
very
simple
and
loving
,
ma'am
;
do
n't
be
at
all
cast
down
about
it
,
ma'am
"
---
exulting
over
me
!
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
thing
the
woman
did
.
 
<EOS>
At
times
,
when
she
saw
that
she
had
safely
plunged
me
into
a
black
despondent
brooding
by
these
means
,
she
would
call
the
attention
of
the
children
to
it
,
and
would
show
them
the
difference
between
herself
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Wade
is
not
well
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
make
a
noise
,
my
dears
,
her
head
aches
.
 
<EOS>
Come
and
comfort
her
.
 
<EOS>
Come
and
ask
her
if
she
is
better
;
come
and
ask
her
to
lie
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
nothing
on
your
mind
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
take
on
,
ma'am
,
and
be
sorry
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
became
intolerable
.
 
<EOS>
Her
ladyship
,
my
Mistress
,
coming
in
one
day
when
I
was
alone
,
and
at
the
height
of
feeling
that
I
could
support
it
no
longer
,
I
told
her
I
must
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
bear
the
presence
of
that
woman
Dawes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wade
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
Dawes
is
devoted
to
you
;
would
do
anything
for
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew
beforehand
<EOS>
she
would
say
so
<EOS>
;
I
was
quite
prepared
for
it
;
I
only
answered
,
it
was
not
for
me
to
contradict
my
Mistress
;
I
must
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
Miss
Wade
,
"
she
returned
,
instantly
assuming
the
tone
of
superiority
she
had
always
so
thinly
concealed
,
"
that
nothing
I
have
ever
said
or
done
since
we
have
been
together
,
has
justified
your
use
of
that
disagreeable
word
,
"
Mistress
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
must
have
been
wholly
inadvertent
on
my
part
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
tell
me
what
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
I
had
no
complaint
to
make
,
either
of
my
Mistress
or
to
my
Mistress
;
but
I
must
go
.
   
<EOS>
She
hesitated
a
moment
,
and
then
sat
down
beside
me
,
and
laid
her
hand
on
mine
.
 
<EOS>
As
if
that
honour
would
obliterate
any
remembrance
!
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Wade
,
I
fear
you
are
unhappy
,
through
causes
over
which
I
have
no
influence
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
smiled
,
thinking
of
the
experience
the
word
awakened
,
and
said
,
"
I
have
an
unhappy
temper
,
I
suppose
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
say
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
an
easy
way
of
accounting
for
anything
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
;
but
I
did
not
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
wish
to
approach
is
something
very
different
.
 
<EOS>
My
husband
and
I
have
exchanged
some
remarks
upon
the
subject
,
when
we
have
observed
with
pain
that
you
have
not
been
easy
with
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Easy
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
such
great
people
,
my
lady
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
unfortunate
in
using
a
word
which
may
convey
a
meaning
---
and
evidently
does
---
quite
opposite
to
my
intention
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
She
had
not
expected
my
reply
,
and
it
shamed
her
.
)
<EOS>
"
I
only
mean
,
not
happy
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
difficult
topic
to
enter
on
;
but
,
from
one
young
woman
to
another
,
perhaps
---
in
short
,
we
have
been
apprehensive
that
you
may
allow
some
family
circumstances
of
which
no
one
can
be
more
innocent
than
yourself
,
to
prey
upon
your
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
let
us
entreat
you
not
to
make
them
a
cause
of
grief
.
 
<EOS>
My
husband
himself
,
as
is
well
known
,
formerly
had
a
very
dear
sister
who
was
not
in
law
his
sister
,
but
who
was
universally
beloved
and
respected
.
   
<EOS>
I
saw
directly
that
they
had
taken
me
in
for
the
sake
of
the
dead
woman
,
whoever
she
was
,
and
to
have
that
boast
of
me
and
advantage
of
me
;
I
saw
,
in
the
nurse
's
knowledge
of
it
,
an
encouragement
to
goad
me
as
she
had
done
;
and
I
saw
,
in
the
children
's
shrinking
away
,
a
vague
impression
,
that
I
was
not
like
other
people
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
that
house
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
After
one
or
two
short
and
very
similar
experiences
,
which
are
not
to
the
present
purpose
,
I
entered
another
family
where
I
had
but
<EOS>
one
pupil
:
a
girl
of
fifteen
,
who
was
the
only
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
The
parents
here
were
elderly
people
:
people
of
station
,
and
rich
.
 
<EOS>
A
nephew
whom
they
had
brought
up
was
a
frequent
visitor
at
the
house
,
among
many
other
visitors
;
and
he
began
to
pay
me
attention
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
resolute
in
repulsing
him
;
for
I
had
determined
when
I
went
there
,
that
no
one
should
pity
me
or
condescend
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
wrote
me
a
letter
.
 
<EOS>
It
led
to
our
being
engaged
to
be
married
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
year
younger
than
I
,
and
young
-
looking
even
when
that
allowance
was
made
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
absence
from
India
,
where
he
had
a
post
that
was
soon
to
grow
into
a
very
good
one
.
 
<EOS>
In
six
months
we
were
to
be
married
,
and
were
to
go
to
India
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
stay
in
the
house
,
and
was
to
be
married
from
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
objected
to
any
part
of
the
plan
.
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
avoid
saying
he
admired
me
;
but
,
if
I
could
,
I
would
.
<EOS>
Vanity
has
nothing
to
do
with
the
declaration
,
for
his
admiration
worried
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
no
pains
to
hide
it
;
and
caused
me
to
feel
among
the
rich
people
as
if
he
had
bought
me
for
my
looks
,
and
made
a
show
of
his
purchase
to
justify
himself
.
 
<EOS>
They
appraised
me
in
their
own
minds
,
I
saw
,
and
were
curious
to
ascertain
what
my
full
value
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
resolved
that
they
should
not
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
immovable
and
silent
before
them
;
and
would
have
suffered
any
one
of
them
to
kill
me
sooner
than
I
would
have
laid
myself
out
to
bespeak
their
approval
.
   
<EOS>
He
told
me
I
did
not
do
myself
justice
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
did
,
and
it
was
because
I
did
and
meant
to
do
so
to
the
last
,
that
I
would
not
stoop
to
propitiate
any
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
concerned
and
even
shocked
,
when
I
added
that
I
wished
he
would
not
parade
his
attachment
before
them
;
but
he
said
he
would
sacrifice
even
the
honest
impulses
of
his
affection
to
my
peace
.
   
<EOS>
Under
that
pretence
he
began
to
retort
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
hour
together
,
he
would
keep
at
a
distance
from
me
,
talking
to
any
one
rather
than
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sat
alone
and
unnoticed
,
half
an
evening
,
while
he
conversed
with
his
young
cousin
,
my
pupil
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
all
the
while
,
in
people
's
eyes
,
that
they
thought
the
two
looked
nearer
on
an
equality
than
he
and
I.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sat
,
divining
their
thoughts
,
until
I
have
felt
that
his
young
appearance
made
me
ridiculous
,
and
have
raged
against
myself
for
ever
loving
him
.
   
<EOS>
For
I
did
love
him
once
.
 
<EOS>
Undeserving
as
he
was
,
and
little
as
he
thought
of
all
these
agonies
that
it
cost
me
---
agonies
which
should
have
made
him
wholly
and
gratefully
mine
to
his
life
's
end
---
I
loved
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
bore
with
his
cousin
's
praising
him
to
my
face
,
and
with
her
pretending
to
think
that
it
pleased
me
,
but
full
well
knowing
that
it
rankled
in
my
breast
;
for
his
sake
.
 
<EOS>
While
I
have
sat
in
his
presence
recalling
all
my
slights
and
wrongs
,
and
deliberating
whether
I
should
not
fly
from
the
house
at
once
and
never
see
him
again
---
I
have
loved
him
.
   
<EOS>
His
aunt
(
my
Mistress
you
will
please
to
remember
)
<EOS>
deliberately
,
wilfully
,
added
to
my
trials
and
vexations
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
her
delight
to
expatiate
on
the
style
in
which
we
were
to
live
in
India
,
and
on
the
establishment
we
should
keep
,
and
the
company
we
should
entertain
when
he
got
his
advancement
.
 
<EOS>
My
pride
rose
against
this
barefaced
way
of
pointing
out
the
contrast
my
married
life
was
to
present
to
my
then
dependent
and
inferior
position
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppressed
my
indignation
;
but
I
showed
her
that
her
intention
was
not
lost
upon
me
,
and
I
repaid
her
annoyance
by
affecting
humility
.
 
<EOS>
What
she
described
would
surely
be
a
great
deal
too
much
honour
for
me
,
I
would
tell
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
I
might
not
be
able
to
support
so
great
a
change
.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
a
mere
governess
,
her
daughter
's
governess
,
coming
to
that
high
distinction
!
 
<EOS>
It
made
her
uneasy
,
and
made
them
all
uneasy
,
when
I
answered
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
They
knew
that
I
fully
understood
her
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
the
time
when
my
troubles
were
at
their
highest
,
and
when
I
was
most
incensed
against
my
lover
for
his

in
caring
as
little
as
he
did
for
the
innumerable
distresses
and
mortifications
I
underwent
on
his
account
,
that
your
dear
friend
,
Mr
Gowan
,
appeared
at
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
intimate
there
for
a
long

,
but
had
been
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
He
understood
the
state
of
things
at
a
glance
,
and
he
understood
me
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
the
first

I
had
ever
seen
in
my
life
who
had
understood
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
in
the
house
three
times
before
I
knew
that
he
accompanied
every
movement
of
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
coldly
easy
way
with
all
of
them
,
and
with
me
,
and
with
the
whole
subject
,
I
saw
it
clearly
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
light

of
admiration
of
my
future
husband
,
in
his
enthusiasm
regarding
our
engagement
and

,

hopeful

on
our

to
his
own

---
all
equally
hollow
,
and
jesting
,
and
full
of
mockery
<EOS>
---
I
saw
it
clearly
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
me
feel
more
and
more
resentful
,
and
more
and
more
contemptible
,
by
always
presenting
to
me
everything
that

with
some
new

upon

,
while
he
pretended
to
exhibit

in
its
best
aspect
for
my

and
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
like
the
dressed
-
up
Death
in
the
Dutch
series
;
whatever
figure
he
took
upon
his
arm
,
whether

was
youth
or

,

,
whether
he
danced
with

,

,
played

,
or

with

,
he

ghastly
.
   
<EOS>
You
will
understand
,
then
,
that
when
your
dear
friend
complimented
me
,
he
really
condoled
with
me
;
that
when
he
soothed
me
under
my

,
he
laid
bare
every

I

;
that

my
"
faithful
swain
"

"

in

,

the

that

,
"
he
touched
my
old
misgiving
that
I
was
made
ridiculous
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
not
great
services
,
you
may
say
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
acceptable
to
me
,
because
they
echoed
my
own

,
and

own

.
 
<EOS>
I
soon
began
to
like
the
society
of
your
dear
friend
better
than
any
other
.
   
<EOS>
When
I

(

I

,

)
that

was
growing
out

this
,
I
liked
this

.
 
<EOS>
Had
I
not
been
subject
to
jealousy
,
and
were
the
endurances
to
be
all
mine
?
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
know
what
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
delighted
that
he
should
know

;
I
was

that
he
should
feel
keenly
,

I

.
   
<EOS>
More
than

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
tame
in

with
Mr
Gowan
,
who
knew
how
to
address

on

,
and
how

.
   
<EOS>
This
went
on
,
until
the
aunt
,
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

worth

;
she

meant
nothing
;
but
she

from

,

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
I

?
 
<EOS>
She
could
always

,
she

,
for
my
meaning
nothing
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
I
thanked

,
but
said
I
would

.
 
<EOS>
Her

would
probably

,

I

none
.
   
<EOS>
Other

followed
,
and

,

<EOS>
Did

?
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
bought
,
body
and

.
 
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
think
that
her
distinguished
nephew
had
gone
into
a
slave

and

wife
.
   
<EOS>
It

probably

,
sooner

,
to
the
end
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,
that
I

an

.
 
<EOS>
On

old

,

,
but
exposed

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Mr

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Your

friend
followed
me
to

,
and
was
very
droll
on
the
severance

the

;
though

,

,

(

)
,

house
-
flies

.
<EOS>
He

before

,

,

;
but
---

,

!
<EOS>
---
   
<EOS>
Your

amused

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

,
<EOS>
and

.
   
<EOS>
It

found
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

---

.
 
<EOS>
I

:

found

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Your

,
I

,
was
not

,

.
   
<EOS>
In

I
found
a
girl
,
in
various

of
whose
position
there
was
a
singular

my
own
,
and
in

I
was

to
see
much
of
the

and

,

,

,

,

,

I
have

.
 
<EOS>
I
often

,

,
that
she
had
"
an

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Well

what
was
meant
by
the

,

with

what

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

no

.
   
<EOS>
We
have
been
together
ever
since
,
sharing
my
small
means
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
Road
so
late
?
 
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
had
made
his
unavailing
expedition
to
Calais
in
the
midst
of
a
great
pressure
of
business
.
 
<EOS>
A
certain
barbaric
Power
with
valuable
possessions
on
the
map
of
the
world
,
had
occasion
for
the
services
of
one
or
two
engineers
,
quick
in
invention
and
determined
in
execution
:
practical
men
,
who
could
make
the
men
and
means
their
ingenuity
perceived
to
be
wanted
out
of
the
best
materials
they
could
find
at
hand
;
and
who
were
as
bold
and
fertile
in
the
adaptation
of
such
materials
to
their
purpose
,
as
in
the
conception
of
their
purpose
itself
.
 
<EOS>
This
Power
,
being
a
barbaric
one
,
had
no
idea
of
stowing
away
a
great
national
object
in
a
Circumlocution
Office
,
as
strong
wine
is
hidden
from
the
light
in
a
cellar
until
its
fire
and
youth
are
gone
,
and
the
labourers
who
worked
in
the
vineyard
and
pressed
the
grapes
are
dust
.
 
<EOS>
With
characteristic
ignorance
,
it
acted
on
the
most
decided
and
energetic
notions
of
How
to
do
it
;
and
never
showed
the
least
respect
for
,
or
gave
any
quarter
to
,
the
great
political
science
,
How
not
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
it
had
a
barbarous
way
of
striking
the
latter
art
and
mystery
dead
,
in
the
person
of
any
enlightened
subject
who
practised
it
.
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
the
men
who
were
wanted
were
sought
out
and
found
;
which
was
in
itself
a
most
uncivilised
and
irregular
way
of
proceeding
.
 
<EOS>
Being
found
,
they
were
treated
with
great
confidence
and
honour
(
which
again
showed
dense
political
ignorance
)
,
and
were
invited
to
come
at
once
and
do
what
they
had
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
they
were
regarded
as
men
who
meant
to
do
it
,
engaging
with
other
men
who
meant
it
to
be
done
.
   
<EOS>
Daniel
Doyce
was
one
of
the
chosen
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
foreseeing
at
that
time
whether
he
would
be
absent
months
or
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
preparations
for
his
departure
,
and
the
conscientious
arrangement
for
him
of
all
the
details
and
results
of
their
joint
business
,
had
necessitated
labour
within
a
short
compass
of
time
,
which
had
occupied
Clennam
day
and
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
slipped
across
the
water
in
his
first
leisure
,
and
had
slipped
as
quickly
back
again
for
his
farewell
interview
with
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
Him
Arthur
now
showed
,
with
pains
and
care
,
the
state
of
their
gains
and
losses
,
responsibilities
and
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
Daniel
went
through
it
all
in
his
patient
manner
,
and
admired
it
all
exceedingly
.
 
<EOS>
He
audited
the
accounts
,
as
if
they
were
a
far
more
ingenious
piece
of
mechanism
than
he
had
ever
constructed
,
and
afterwards
stood
looking
at
them
,
weighing
his
hat
over
his
head
by
the
brims
,
as
if
he
were
absorbed
in
the
contemplation
of
some
wonderful
engine
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
beautiful
,
Clennam
,
in
its
regularity
and
order
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
plainer
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
approve
,
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
as
to
the
management
of
your
capital
while
you
are
away
,
and
as
to
the
conversion
of
so
much

it
as
the
business
may
need
from
time
to
time
---
"
His

stopped

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
that
,
and
as
to
everything
else
of
that
kind
,
all
rests
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
continue
in
all
such

to
act
for
both

,
as
you
have
done
hitherto
,
and
to
lighten
my
mind
of
a
load
<EOS>
it
is
much

from
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Though
,
as
I
often

you
,
"
returned

,
"
you
unreasonably
depreciate
your
business

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
,
"
said
Doyce
,
smiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
perhaps
not
.
 
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
I
have
a
calling
that
I
have
studied
more
than
such
matters
,
and
that
I
am
better
fitted
for
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
perfect
confidence
in
my
partner
,
and
I
am
satisfied
that
he
will
do
what
is
best
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
a
prejudice
connected
with
money
and
money
figures
,
"
continued
Doyce
,
laying
that
plastic
workman
's
thumb
of
his
on
the
lapel
of
his
partner
's
coat
,
"
it
is
against
speculating
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
have
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
I
entertain
that
prejudice
,
only
because
I
have
never
given
my
mind
fully
to
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
should

call
it
a

,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Doyce
,
it
is
the
soundest
sense
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
think
so
,
"
returned
Doyce
,
with
his
grey
eye
looking
kind
and
bright
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
so
happens
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
that
just
now
,
not
half
an
hour
before
you
came
down
,
I

saying

to
Pancks
,
who
looked
in

.
 
<EOS>
We
both
agreed
that
to
travel
out
of
safe
investments
is
one
of
the
most
dangerous
,
as
it
is
one
of
the
most
common
,
of
those

which
often
deserve
the

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pancks
?
<EOS>
"
said
Doyce
,
tilting
up
his

at
the
back
,
and

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
,
aye
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
cautious
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
very
cautious
fellow
indeed
,
"
returned
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
a
specimen
of
caution
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
both
appeared
to
derive
a
larger
amount
of
satisfaction
from
the
cautious
character
of
Mr
Pancks
,
than
was
quite
intelligible
,
judged
by
the
surface

their

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Daniel
,
looking
at
his
watch
,
"
as
time
and
tide
wait
for
no
man
,
my
trusty
partner
,
and
as
I
am
ready
for
starting
,
bag
and
baggage
,
at
the
gate
below
,
let
me
say
a
last
word
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
grant
a
request
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any
request
you
can
make
---
Except
,
"
Clennam
was
quick
with
his
exception
,
for
his
partner
's
face
was
quick
in
suggesting

,
"
except
that
I
will
abandon
your
invention
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
request
,
and
you
know

is
,
"
said
Doyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
No
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
positively
,
No
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
I
have

,
I
will
have
some

,
some

,
something
in
the
nature
of

,
from
those

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
,
"
returned
Doyce
,
shaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
my
word
for
it
,
you
never
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
I
'll
try
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
do
me
no
harm
to
try
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
certain
of
that
,
"
rejoined
Doyce
,
laying
his
hand

on

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
done
me
harm
,
my
friend
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
aged
me
,
tired
me
,
vexed
me
,
disappointed
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
does
no
man
any
good
to
have
his
patience
worn
out
,
and
to
think
himself
ill
-
used
.
<EOS>
I
fancy
,
even
already
,
that
unavailing
attendance
on
delays
and
evasions
has
made
you
something
less
elastic
than
you
used
to
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Private
anxieties
may
have
done
that
for
the
moment
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
but
not
official
harrying
.
 
<EOS>
Not
yet
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
hurt
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
wo
n't
grant
my
request
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
,
No
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
ashamed
if
I
submitted
to
be
so
soon
driven
out
of
the
field
,
where
a
much
older
and
<EOS>
a
much
more
sensitively
interested
man
contended
with
fortitude
so
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
there
was
no
moving
him
,
Daniel
Doyce
returned
the
grasp
of
his
hand
,
and
,
casting
a
farewell
look
round
the

-
house
,
went
down
-
stairs
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Doyce
was
to
go
to
Southampton
to
join
the
small
staff
of
his
fellow
-
travellers
;
and
a
coach
was
at
the
gate
,
well
furnished
and
packed
,
and
ready
to
take
him
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
workmen
were
at
the
gate
to
see
him
off
,
and
were
mightily
proud
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
luck
to
you
,
Mr
Doyce
!
<EOS>
"
said
one
of
the
number
.
<EOS>
"
Wherever
you
go
,
they
'll
find
as
they
've
got
a
man
among
'em
)
a
man
as
knows
his
tools
and
as
his
tools
knows
,
a
man
as
is
willing
and
a
man
as
is
able
,
and
if
that
's
not
a
man
,
where
is
a
man
!
"
<EOS>
This
oration
from
a
gruff
volunteer
in
the
back
-
ground
,
not
previously
suspected
of
any
powers
in
that
way
,
was
received
with
three
loud
cheers
;
and
the
speaker
became
a
distinguished
character
for
ever
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
three
loud
cheers
,
Daniel
gave
them
all
a
hearty
"
Good
Bye
,
Men
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
coach
disappeared
from
sight
,
as
if
the
concussion
of
the
air
had
blown
it
out
of
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
as
a
grateful
little
fellow
in
a
position
of
trust
,
was
among
the
workmen
,
and
had
done
as
much
towards
the
cheering
as
a
mere
foreigner
could
.
 
<EOS>
In
truth
,
no
men
on
earth
can
cheer
like
Englishmen
,
who
do
so
rally
one
another
's
blood
and
spirit
when
they
cheer
in
earnest
,
that
the
stir
is
like
the
rush
of
their
whole
history
,
with
all
its
standards
waving
at
once
,
from
Saxon
Alfred
's
downwards
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
had
been
in
a
manner
whirled
away
before
the
onset
,
and
was
taking
his
breath
in
quite
a
scared
condition
when
Clennam
beckoned
him
to
follow
up
-
stairs
,
and
return
the
books
and
papers
to
their
places
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
lull
consequent
on
the
departure
---
in
that
first
vacuity
which
ensues
on
every
separation
,
foreshadowing
the
great
separation
that
is
always
overhanging
all
mankind
---
Arthur
stood
at
his
desk
,
looking
dreamily
out
at
a
gleam
of
sun
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
liberated
attention
soon
reverted
to
the
theme
that
was
foremost
in
his
thoughts
,
and
began
,
for
the
hundredth
time
,
to
dwell
upon
every
circumstance
that
had
impressed
itself
upon
his
mind
on
the
mysterious
night
when
he
had
seen
the
man
at
his
mother
's
.
 
<EOS>
Again
the
man
jostled
him
in
the
crooked
street
,
again
he
followed
the
man
and
lost
him
,
again
he
came
upon
the
man
in
the
court
-
yard
looking
at
the
house
,
again
he
followed
the
man
and
stood
beside
him
on
the
door
-
steps
.
        
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
;
     
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
first
time
,
by
many
,
that
he
had
recalled
the
song
of
the
child
's
game
,
of
which
the
fellow
had
hummed
@
verse
while
they
stood
side
by
side
;
but
he
was
so
unconscious
of
having
repeated
it
audibly
,
that
he
started
to
hear
the
next

.
        
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
;
     
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
<EOS>
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
Cavalletto
had
deferentially
suggested
the
words
and
tune
,
supposing
him
to
have
stopped
short
for
want
of
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
the
song
,
Cavalletto
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
Bacchus
,
yes
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
They
all
know
it
in
France
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
it
many
times
,
sung
by
the
little
children
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
time
when
it
I
have
heard
,
"
said
Mr
Baptist
,
formerly
Cavalletto
,
who
usually
went
back
to
his
native
construction
of
sentences
when
his
memory
went
near
home
,
"
is
from
a
sweet
little
voice
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
voice
,
very
pretty
,
very

.
 
<EOS>
Altro
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
last
time
I
heard
it
,
"
returned
Arthur
,
"
was
in
a
voice
quite
the
reverse
of
pretty
,
and
quite
the
reverse
of
innocent
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
more
to
himself
than
to
his
companion
,
and
added
to
himself
,
repeating
the
man
's
next
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
Death
of
my
life
,
sir
,
it
's
my
character
to
be
impatient
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
EH
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Cavalletto
,
astounded
,
and
with
all
his
colour
gone
in
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
where
I
have
heard
that
song
the
last
time
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
his
rapid
native
action
,
his
hands
made
the
outline
of
a
high
hook
nose
,
pushed
his
eyes
near
together
,
dishevelled
his
hair
,
puffed
out
his
upper
lip
to
represent
a
thick
moustache
,
and
threw
the
heavy
end
of
an
ideal
cloak
over
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
While
doing
this
,
with
a
swiftness
incredible
to
one
who
has
not
watched
an
Italian
peasant
,
he
indicated
a
very
remarkable
and
sinister
smile
.
   
<EOS>
The
whole
change
passed
over
him
like
a
flash
of
light
,
and
he
stood
in
the
same
instant
,
pale
and
astonished
,
before
his
patron
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
name
of
Fate
and
wonder
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
what
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
Do
you
know
a
man
of
the
name
of
Blandois
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Mr
Baptist
,
shaking
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
just
now
described
a
man
who
was
by
when
you
heard
that
song
;
have
you
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
said
Mr
Baptist
,
nodding
fifty
times
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
was
he
not
called
Blandois
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Mr
Baptist
.
 
<EOS>
"
Altro
,
Altro
,
Altro
,
Altro
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
reject
the
name
sufficiently
,
with
his
head
and
his
right
forefinger
going
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Clennam
,
spreading
out
the
handbill
on
his
desk
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Was
this
the
man
?
 
<EOS>
You
can
understand
what
I
read
aloud
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Altogether
.
 
<EOS>
Perfectly
.
"
   
"
But
look
at
it
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
Come
here
and
look
over
me
,
while
I
read
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
approached
,
followed
every
word
with
his
quick
eyes
,
saw
and
heard
it
all
out
with
the
greatest
impatience
,
then
clapped
his
two
hands
flat
upon
the
bill
as
if
he
had
fiercely
caught
some
noxious
creature
,
and
cried
,
looking
eagerly
at
Clennam
,
"
It
is
the
man
!
 
<EOS>
Behold
him
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
of
far
greater
moment
to
me
"
said
Clennam
,
in
great
agitation
,
"
than
you
can
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
where
you
knew
the
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
releasing
the
paper
very
slowly
and
with
much
discomfiture
,
and
drawing
himself
back
two
or
three
paces
,
and
making
as
though
he
dusted
his
hands
,
returned
,
very
much
against
his
will
:
   
<EOS>
"
At
Marsiglia
---
Marseilles
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
prisoner
,
and
---
Altro
!
 
<EOS>
I
believe
yes
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
an
,
"
Mr
Baptist
crept
closer
again
to
whisper
it
,
"
Assassin
!
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
fell
back
as
if
the
word
had
struck
him
a
blow
:
so
terrible
did
it
make
his
mother
's
communication
with
the
man
appear
.
<EOS>
Cavalletto
dropped
on
one
knee
,
and
implored
him
,
with
a
redundancy
of
gesticulation
,
to
hear
what
had
brought
himself
into
such
foul
company
.
   
<EOS>
He
told
with
perfect
truth
how
it
had
come
of
a
little
contraband
trading
,
and
how
he
had
in
time
been
released
from
prison
,
and
how
he
had
gone
away
from
those
antecedents
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
at
the
house
of
entertainment
called
the
Break
of
Day
at
Chalons
on
the
Saone
,
he
had
been
awakened
in
his
bed
at
night
by
the
same
assassin
,
then
assuming
the
name
of
Lagnier
,
though
his
name
had
formerly
been
Rigaud
;
how
the
assassin
had
proposed
that
they
should
join
their
fortunes
together
;
how
he
held
the
assassin
in
such
dread
and
aversion
that
he
had
fled
from
him
at
daylight
,
and
how
he
had
ever
since
been
haunted
by
the
fear
of
seeing
the
assassin
again
and
being
claimed
by
him
as
an
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
related
this
,
with
an
emphasis
and
poise
on
the
word
,
"
assassin
,
"
peculiarly
belonging
to
his
own
language
,
and
which
did
not
serve
to
render
it
less
terrible
to
Clennam
<EOS>
,
he
suddenly
sprang
to
his
feet
,
pounced
upon
the
bill
again
,
and
with
a
vehemence
that
would
have
been
absolute
madness
in
any
man
of
Northern
origin
,
cried
"
Behold
the
same
assassin
!
 
<EOS>
Here
he
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
his
passionate
raptures
,
he
at
first
forgot
the
fact
that
he
had
lately
seen
the
assassin
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
remembering
it
,
it
suggested
hope
to
Clennam
that
the
recognition
might
be
of
later
date
than
the
night
of
the
visit
at
his
mother
's
;
but
Cavalletto
was
too
exact
and
clear
about
time
and
place
,
to
leave
any
opening
for
doubt
that
it
had
preceded
that
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
,
"
said
Arthur
,
very
seriously
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
man
,
as
we
have
read
here
,
has
wholly
disappeared
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
it
I
am
well
content
!
"
<EOS>
said
Cavalletto
,
raising
his
eyes
piously
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
thanks
to
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
Accursed
assassin
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
returned
Clennam
;
"
for
until
something
more
is
heard
of
him
<EOS>
,
I
can
never
know
an
hour
's
peace
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
Benefactor
;
that
is
quite
another
thing
.
 
<EOS>
A
million
of
excuses
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Cavalletto
,
"
said
Clennam
,
gently
turning
him
by
the
arm
,
so
that
they
looked
into
each
other
's
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
certain
that
for
the
little
I
have
been
able
to
do
for
you
,
you
are
the
most
sincerely
grateful
of
men
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
swear
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
could
find
this
man
,
or
discover
what
has
become
of
him
,
or
gain
any
later
intelligence
whatever
of
him
,
you
would
render
me
a
service
above
any
other
service
<EOS>
I
could
receive
in
the
world
,
and
would
make
me
(
with
far
greater
reason
)
as
grateful
to
you
as
you
are
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
where
to
look
,
"
cried
the
little
man
,
kissing
Arthur
's
hand
in
a
transport
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
where
to
begin
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
not
where
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
courage
!
 
<EOS>
Enough
!
 
<EOS>
It
matters
not
!
 
<EOS>
I
go
,
in
this
instant
of
time
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
to
any
one
but
me
,
Cavalletto
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Al
-
tro
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
And
was
gone
with
great
speed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
makes
a
Conditional
Promise
,
respecting
her
Dreams
 
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
with
the
expressive
looks
and
gestures
of
Mr
Baptist
<EOS>
,
otherwise
Giovanni
Baptista
Cavalletto
,
vividly
before
him
,
Clennam
entered
on
a
weary
day
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
he
tried
to
control
his
attention
by
directing
it
to
any
business
occupation
or
train
of
thought
;
it
rode
at
anchor
by
the
haunting
topic
,
and
would
hold
to
no
other
idea
.
 
<EOS>
As
though
a
criminal
should
be
chained
in
a
stationary
boat
on
a
deep
clear
river
,
condemned
,
<EOS>
whatever
countless
leagues
of
water
flowed
past
him
,
always
to
see
the
body
of
the
fellow
-
creature
he
had
drowned
lying
at
the
bottom
,
immovable
,
and
unchangeable
,
except
as
the
eddies
made
it
broad
or
long
,
now
expanding
,
now
contracting
its
terrible
lineaments
;
so
Arthur
,
below
the
shifting
current
of
transparent
thoughts
and
fancies
which
were
gone
and
succeeded
by
others
as
soon
as
come
,
saw
,
steady
and
dark
,
and
not
to
be
stirred
from
its
place
,
the
one
subject
that
he
endeavoured
with
all
his
might
to
rid
himself
of
,
and
that
he
could
not
fly
from
.
 
<EOS>
The
assurance
he
now
had
,
that
Blandois
,
whatever
his
right
name
,
was
one
of
the
worst
of
characters
,
greatly
augmented
the
burden
of
his
anxieties
.
 
<EOS>
Though
the
disappearance
should
be
accounted
for
to
-
morrow
,
the
fact
that
his
mother
had
been
in
communication
with
such
a
man
,
would
remain
unalterable
.
 
<EOS>
That
the
communication
had
been
of
a
secret
kind
,
and
that
she
had
been
submissive
to
him
and
afraid
of
him
,
he
hoped
might
be
known
to
no
one
beyond
himself
;
yet
,
knowing
it
,
how
could
he
separate
it
from
his
old
vague
fears
,
and
how
believe
that
there
was
nothing
evil
in
such
relations
?
<EOS>
Her
resolution
not
to
enter
on
the
question
with
him
,
and
his
knowledge
of
her
indomitable
character
,
enhanced
his
sense
of
helplessness
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
the
oppression
of
a
dream
to
believe
that
shame
and
exposure
were
impending
over
her
and
his
father
's
memory
,
and
to
be
shut
out
,
as
by
a
brazen
wall
,
from
the
possibility
of
coming
to
their
aid
.
 
<EOS>
The
purpose
he
had
brought
home
to
his
native
country
,
and
had
ever
since
kept
in
view
,
was
,
with
her
greatest
determination
,
defeated
by
his
mother
herself
,
at
the
time
of
all
others
when
he
feared
that
it
pressed
most
.
 
<EOS>
His
advice
,
energy
,
activity
,
money
,
credit
,
all
his
resources
whatsoever
,
were
all
made
useless
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
been
possessed
of
the
old
fabled
influence
,
and
had
turned
those
who
looked
upon
her
into
stone
,
she
could
not
have
rendered
him
more
completely
powerless
<EOS>
(
so
it
seemed
to
him
in
his
distress
of
mind
)
than
she
did
,
when
she
turned
her
unyielding
face
to
his
in
her
gloomy
room
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
light
of
that
day
's
discovery
,
shining
on
these
considerations
,
roused
him
to
take
a
more
decided
course
of
action
.
   
<EOS>
Confident
in
the
rectitude
of
his
purpose
,
and
impelled
by
a
sense
of
overhanging
danger
closing
in
around
<EOS>
,
he
resolved
,
if
his
mother
would
still
admit
of
no
approach
,
to
make
a
desperate
appeal
to
Affery
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
could
be
brought
to
become
communicative
,
and
to
do
what
lay
in
her
to
break
the
spell
of
secrecy
that
enshrouded
the
house
,
he
might
shake
off
the
paralysis
of
which
every
hour
that
passed
over
his
head
made
him
more
acutely
sensible
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
result
of
his
day
's
anxiety
,
and
this
was
the
decision
he
put
in
practice
when
the
day
closed
in
.
   
<EOS>
His
first
disappointment
,
on
arriving
at
the
house
,
was
to
find
the
door
open
,
and
Mr
Flintwinch
smoking
a
pipe
on
the
steps
.
 
<EOS>
If
circumstances
had
been
commonly
favourable
,
Mistress
Affery
would
have
opened
the
door
to
his
knock
.
 
<EOS>
Circumstances
being
uncommonly
unfavourable
,
the
door
stood
open
,
and
Mr
Flintwinch
was
smoking
his
pipe
on
the
steps
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
   
<EOS>
The
smoke
came
crookedly
out
of
Mr
Flintwinch
's
mouth
,
as
if
it
circulated
through
the
whole
of
his
wry
figure
and
came
back
by
his
wry

,
before
coming
forth
to
mingle
with
the
smoke
from
the
crooked
