and
the
mists
from
the
crooked
river
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
any
news
?
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
no
news
,
"
said
Jeremiah
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
of
the
foreign
man
,
"
Arthur
explained
.
   
<EOS>
"
\I\
mean
of
the
foreign
man
,
"
said
Jeremiah
.
   
<EOS>
He
looked
so
grim
,
as
he
stood
askew
,
with
the
knot
of
his
cravat
under
his
ear
,
that
the
thought
passed
into
Clennam
's
mind
,
and
not
for
the
first

by
many
,
could
Flintwinch
for
a
purpose
of
his
own
have
got
rid
of
Blandois
?
 
<EOS>
Could
it
have
been
his
secret
,
and
his
safety
,
that
were
at
issue
?
 
<EOS>
He
was
small
and
bent
,
and
perhaps
not
actively
strong
;
yet
he
was
as
tough
as
an
old
yew
-
tree
,
and
as
crusty
as
an
old
jackdaw
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
man
,
coming
behind
a
much
younger
and
more
vigorous
man
,
and
having
the
will
to
put
an
end
to
him
and
no
relenting
,
might
do
it
pretty
surely
in
that
solitary
place
at
a
late
hour
.
   
<EOS>
While
,
in
the
morbid
condition
of
his
thoughts
,
these
thoughts
drifted
over
the
main
one
that
was
always
in
Clennam
's
mind
,
Mr
Flintwinch
,
regarding
the
opposite
house
over
the
gateway
with
his
neck
twisted
and
one
eye
shut
up
,
stood
smoking
with
a
vicious
expression
upon
him
;
more
as
if
he
were
trying
to
bite
off
the
stem
of
his
pipe
,
than
as
if
he
were
enjoying
it
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
he
was
enjoying
it
in
his
own
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
able
to
take
my
likeness
,
the
next
time
you
call
,
Arthur
,
I
should
think
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
drily
,
as
he
stooped
to
knock
the
ashes
out
.
   
<EOS>
Rather
conscious
and
confused
,
Arthur
asked
his
pardon
,
if
he
had
stared
at
him
unpolitely
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
my
mind
runs
so
much
upon
this
matter
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
I
lose

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hah
!
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
do
n't
see
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
,
quite
at

,
"
why
it
should
trouble
YOU
,
Arthur
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
very
shortly
and
decidedly
:
<EOS>
much
as
if
he
were
of
the
canine
race
,
and
snapped
at
Arthur
's
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
nothing
to
see
those
placards
about
?
 
<EOS>
Is

nothing
to
me
to
see
my
mother
's
name
and

hawked

down
in
such

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
,
scraping
his
horny

,
"
that
it
need
signify
much
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tell

what
I
do
see
,
Arthur
,
"
glancing

;
"
I
see
the
light
of
fire

in
your
mother
's
room
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
has
that
to
do

it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
I
read
by
it
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
screwing
himself
at
him
,
"
that
if
it
's
advisable
(
as
the
proverb
says
it
is
)
to
let
sleeping
dogs
lie
,
it
's
just
as
advisable
,
perhaps
,
to
let
missing
dogs
lie
.
 
<EOS>
Let
'em
be
.
 
<EOS>
They
generally
turn
up
soon
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
turned
short
round
when
he
had
made
this
remark
,
and
went
into
the
dark
hall
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
stood
there
,
following
him
with
his
eyes
,
as
he
dipped
for
a
light
in
the
phosphorus
-
box
in
the
little
room
at
the
side
,
got
one
after
three
or
four
dips
,
and
lighted
the
dim
lamp
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
while
,
Clennam
was
pursuing
the
probabilities
---
rather
as
if
they
were
being
shown
to
him
by
an
invisible
hand
than
as
if
he
himself
were
conjuring
them
up
---
of
Mr
Flintwinch
's
ways
and
means
of
doing
that
darker
deed
,
and
removing
its
traces
by
any
of
the
black
avenues
of
shadow
that
lay
around
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
the
testy
Jeremiah
;
"
will
it
be
agreeable
to
walk
up
-
stairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
mother
is
alone
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
alone
,
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Casby
and
his
daughter
are
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
They
came
in
while
I
was
smoking
,
and
I
stayed
behind
to
have
my
smoke
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
second
disappointment
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
made
no
remark
upon
it
,
and
repaired
to
his
mother
's
room
,
where
Mr
Casby
and
Flora
had
been
taking
tea
,
anchovy
paste
,
and
hot
buttered
toast
.
 
<EOS>
The
relics
of
those
delicacies
were
not
yet
removed
,
either
from
the
table
or
from
the
scorched
countenance
of
Affery
,
who
,
with
the
kitchen
toasting
-
fork
still
in
her
hand
,
looked
like
a
sort
of
allegorical
personage
;
except
that
she
had
a
considerable
advantage
over
the
general
run
of
such
personages
in
point
of
significant
emblematical
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
Flora
had
spread
her
bonnet
and
shawl
upon
the
bed
,
with
a
care
indicative
of
an
intention
to
stay
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Casby
,
too
,
was
beaming
near
the
hob
,
with
his
benevolent
knobs
shining
as
if
the
warm
butter
of
the
toast
were
exuding
through
the
patriarchal
skull
,
and
with
his
face
as
ruddy
as
if
the
colouring
matter
of
the
anchovy
paste
were
mantling
in
the
patriarchal
visage
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
this
,
as
he
exchanged
the
usual
salutations
,
Clennam
decided
to
speak
to
his
mother
without
postponement
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
long
been
customary
,
as
she
never
changed
her
room
,
for
those
who
had
anything
to
say
to
her
apart
,
to
wheel
her
to
her
desk
;
where
she
sat
,
usually
with
the
back
of
her
chair
turned
towards
the
rest
of
the
room
,
and
the
person
who
talked
with
her
seated
in
a
corner
,
on
a
stool
which
was
always
set
in
that
place
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Except
that
it
was
long
since
the
mother
and
son
had
spoken
together
without
the
intervention
of
a
third
person
,
it
was
an
ordinary

of
course
within
the
experience
of

to

.
   
<EOS>
Therefore

now

,

that

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

itself
a
jewel
of
benevolence
or
wisdom
,
yet
he
made
it
an
exemplar
of
both
that
one
would
have
liked
to
have
a
copy
of
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
24
.
<EOS>
The
Evening
of
a
Long
Day
 
<EOS>
That
illustrious
man
and
great
national
ornament
,
Mr
Merdle
,
continued
his
shining
course
.
 
<EOS>
It
began
to
be
widely
understood
that
one
who
had
done
society
the
admirable
service
of
making
so
much
money
out
of
it
,
could
not
be
suffered
to
remain
a
commoner
.
<EOS>
A
baronetcy
was
spoken
of
with
confidence
;
a
peerage
was
frequently
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
Rumour
had
it
that
Mr
Merdle
had
set
his
golden
face
against
a
baronetcy
;
that
he
had
plainly
intimated
to
Lord
Decimus
that
a
baronetcy
was
not
enough
for
him
;
that
he
had
said
,
"
No
---
a
Peerage
,
or
plain
Merdle
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
reported
to
have
plunged
Lord
Decimus
as
nigh
to
his
noble
chin
in
a
slough
of
doubts
as
so
lofty
a
person
could
be
sunk
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
Barnacles
,
as
a
group
of
themselves
in
creation
,
had
an
idea
that
such
distinctions
belonged
to
them
;
and
that
when
a
soldier
,
sailor
,
or
lawyer
became
ennobled
,
they
let
him
in
,
as
it
were
,
by
an
act
of
condescension
,
at
the
family
door
,
and
immediately
shut
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
Not
only
(
said
Rumour
)
had
the
troubled
Decimus
his
own
hereditary
part
in
this
impression
,
but
he
also
knew
of
several
Barnacle
claims
already
on
the
file
,
which
came
into
collision
with
that
of
the
master
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
Right
or
wrong
,
Rumour
was
very
busy
;
and
Lord
Decimus
,
while
he
was
,
or
was
supposed
to
be
,
in
stately
excogitation
of
the
difficulty
,
lent
her
some
countenance
by
taking
,
on
several
public
occasions
,
one
of
those
elephantine
trots
of
his
through
a
jungle
of
overgrown
sentences
,
waving
Mr
Merdle
about
on
his
trunk
as
Gigantic
Enterprise
,
The
Wealth
of
England
,
Elasticity
,
Credit
,
Capital
,
Prosperity
,
and
all
manner
of
blessings
.
   
<EOS>
So
quietly
did
the
mowing
of
the
old
scythe
go
on
,
that
fully
three
months
had
passed
unnoticed
since
the
two
English
brothers
had
been
laid
in
one
tomb
in
the
strangers
'
cemetery
at
Rome
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Sparkler
were
established
in
their
own
house
:
a
little
manSion
,
rather
of
the
Tite
Barnacle
class
,
quite
a
triumph
of
inconvenience
,
with
a
perpetual
smell
in
it
of
the
day
before
yesterday
's
soup
and
coach
-
horses
,
but
extremely
dear
,
as
being
exactly
in
the
centre
of
the
habitable
globe
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
enviable
abode
(
and
envied
it
really
was
by
many
people
)
,
Mrs
Sparkler
had
intended
to
proceed
at
once
to
the
demolition
of
the
Bosom
,
when
active
hostilities
had
been
suspended
by
the
arrival
of
the
Courier
with
his
tidings
of
death
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
,
who
was
not
unfeeling
,
had
received
them
with
a
violent
burst
of
grief
,
which
had
lasted
twelve
hours
;
after
which
,
she
had
arisen
to
see
about
her
mourning
,
and
to
take
every
precaution
that
could
ensure
its
being
as
becoming
as
Mrs
Merdle
's
.
 
<EOS>
A
gloom
was
then
cast
over
more
than
one
distinguished
family
(
according
to
the
politest
sources
of
intelligence
)
,
and
the
Courier
went
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Sparkler
had
been
dining
alone
,
with
their
gloom
cast
over
them
,
and
Mrs
Sparkler
reclined
on
a
drawing
-
room
sofa
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
hot
summer
Sunday
evening
.
 
<EOS>
The
residence
in
the
centre
of
the
habitable
globe
,
at
all
times
stuffed
and
close
as
if
it
had
an
incurable
cold
in
its
head
<EOS>
,
was
that
evening
particularly
stifling
.
   
<EOS>
The
bells
of
the
churches
had
done
their
worst
in
the
way
of
clanging
among
the
unmelodious
echoes
of
the
streets
,
and
the
lighted
windows
of
the
churches
had
ceased
to
be
yellow
in
the
grey
dusk
,
and
had
died
out
opaque
black
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
,
lying
on
her
sofa
,
looking
through
an
open
window
at
the
opposite
side
of
a
narrow
street
over
boxes
of
mignonette
and
flowers
,
was
tired
of
the
view
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
,
looking
at
another
window
where
her
husband
stood
in
the
balcony
,
was
tired
of
that
view
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
,
looking
at
herself
in
her
mourning
,
was
even
tired
of
that
view
:
though
,
naturally
,
not
so
tired
of
that
as
of
the
other
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
like
lying
in
a
well
,
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
,
changing
her
position
fretfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
Edmund
<EOS>
,
if
you
have
anything
to
say
,
why
do
n't
you
say
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
might
have
replied
with
ingenuousness
,
"
My
life
,
I
have
nothing
to
say
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
the
repartee
did
not
occur
to
him
,
he
contented
himself
with
coming
in
from
the
balcony
and
standing
at
the
side
of
his
wife
's
couch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
Edmund
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
more
fretfully
still
,
you
are
absolutely
putting
mignonette
up
your
nose
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
in
absence
of
mind
---
perhaps
in
a
more
literal
absence
of
mind
than
is
usually
understood
by
the
phrase
---
had
smelt
so
hard
at
a
sprig
in
his
hand
as
to
be
on
the
verge
of
the
offence
in
question
.
 
<EOS>
He
smiled
,
said
,
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
my
dear
,
"
and
threw
it
out
of
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
make
my
head
ache
by
remaining
in
that
position
,
Edmund
,
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
,
raising
her
eyes
to
him
after
another
minute
;
"
you
look
so
aggravatingly
large
by
this
light
.
 
<EOS>
Do
sit
down
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
and
took
a
chair
on
the
same
spot
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
did
n't
know
that
the
longest
day
was
past
,
"
said
Fanny
,
yawning
in
a
dreary
manner
<EOS>
,
"
I
should
have
felt
certain
this
was
the
longest
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
did
experience
such
a
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
your
fan
,
my
love
?
"
asked
Mr
Sparkler
,
picking
up
one
and
presenting
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
"
returned
his
wife
,
more
wearily
yet
,
"
do
n't
ask
weak
questions
,
I
entreat
you
not
.
 
<EOS>
Whose
can
it
be
but
mine
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
thought
it
was
yours
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
should
n't
ask
,
"
retorted
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
little
while
she
turned
on
her
sofa
and
exclaimed
,
"
Dear
me
,
dear
me
,
there
never
was
such
a
long
day
as
this
!
"
 
<EOS>
After
another
little
while
,
she
got
up
slowly
,
walked
about
,
and
came
back
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
<EOS>
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
flashing
with
an
original
conception
,
"
I
think
you
must
have
got
the
fidgets
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Fidgets
!
"
repeated
Mrs
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
adorable
girl
,
"
urged
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
try
your
aromatic
vinegar
.
<EOS>
I
have
often
seen
my
mother
try
it
,
and
it
seemingly
refreshed
her
.
   
<EOS>
And
she
is
,
as
I
believe
you
are
aware
,
a
remarkably
fine
woman
,
with
no
non
---
"
   
"
Good
Gracious
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Fanny
,
starting
up
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
beyond
all
patience
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
most
wearisome
day
that
ever
did
dawn
upon
the
world
,
I
am
certain
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
looked
meekly
after
her
as
she
lounged
about
the
room
,
and
he
appeared
to
be
a
little
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
tossed
a
few
trifles
about
,
and
had
looked
down
into
the
darkening
street
out
of
all
the
three
windows
,
she
returned
to
her
sofa
,
and
threw
herself
among
its

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
Edmund
,
come
here
!
 
<EOS>
Come
a
little
nearer
,
because
I
want
to
be
able
to
touch
you
with
my
fan
,
that
I
may
impress
you
very
much
with
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
That
will
do
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
close
enough
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
do
look
so
big
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
apologised
for
the
circumstance
,
pleaded
that
he
could
n't
help
it
,
and
said
that
"
our
fellows
,
"
without
more
particularly
indicating
whose
fellows
,
used
to
call
him
by
the
name
of
Quinbus
Flestrin
,
Junior
,
or
the
Young
Man
Mountain
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ought
to
have
told
me
so
before
,
"
Fanny
complained
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
returned
Mr
Sparkler
,
rather

,
"
I
did
n't
know
It
would
interest
you
,
or
I
would
have
made
a
point
of
telling
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
For
goodness
sake
,
do
n't
talk
,
"
said
Fanny
;
"
I
want
to
talk
,
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Edmund
,
we
must
not
be
alone
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
take
such
precautions
as
will
prevent
my
being
ever
again
reduced
to
the
state
of
dreadful
depression
in
which
I
am
this
evening
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
answered
Mr
Sparkler
;
"
being
as
you
are
well
known
to
be
,
a
remarkably
fine
woman
with
no
---
"
   
"
Oh
,
good
GRACIOUS
!
"
cried
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
was
so
discomposed
by
the
energy
of
this
exclamation
,
accompanied
with
a
flouncing
up
from
the
sofa
and
a
flouncing
down
again
,
that
a
minute
or
two
elapsed
before
he
felt
himself
equal
to
saying
in

:
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
my
dear
,
that
everybody
knows
you
are
calculated
to
shine
in
society
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Calculated
to
shine
in
society
,
"
retorted
Fanny
with
great
irritability
;
"
yes
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
And
then
what
happens
?
 
<EOS>
I
no
sooner
recover
,
in
a
visiting
point
of
view
,
the
shock
of
poor
dear
papa
's
death
,
and
my
poor

's
---
though
I
do

from

that
the
last
was

release
,
for
,

you
are
not
presentable
you
had
much

die
---
"
   
"
You
are
not
referring
to
me
,
my
love
,
I
hope
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
humbly
interrupted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
Edmund
,
you
would
wear
out
a
Saint
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
not
expressly
speaking
of
my
poor
uncle
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
looked

at

,

dear
girl
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
,
"
that
I

a

.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
have
put

,
"
observed
Fanny
with

her

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
do
that
,
my
love
,
"
urged
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Fanny
took
a
good
deal
of
time
:
lying
back
with
her
eyes
shut
,
and
her
eyebrows
raised
with
a

as
if
she
had
utterly
given
up
all
terrestrial

.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
without
the
slightest

,
she
opened

again
,
and
recommenced
in
a
short
,

:
   
<EOS>
"
What
happens
then
,
I
ask
!
 
<EOS>
What
happens
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
find
myself
at
the
very
period
when
I
might
shine
most
in
society
,
and
should
most
like
for
very

reasons
to
shine
in
society
---
I
find
myself
in
a
situation
which
to
a
certain

disqualifies
me
for
going
into
society
.
 
<EOS>
it
's
too
bad
,
really
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
it
need
keep
you
at
home
.
"
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
you
ridiculous
creature
,
"
returned
Fanny
,
with
great

;
"
do
you
suppose
that
a
woman
in
the

youth

,
can

,

such

,

as
to

every

her

?
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
suppose
such
a
thing
,
your

is

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
submitted
that
he
had
thought
"
it
might

got
over
.
"
<EOS>
"
Got
over
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Fanny
,
with
immeasurable
scorn
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
a
time
,
"
Mr
Sparkler
submitted
.
   
<EOS>
Honouring
the
last
feeble
suggestion
with
no
notice
,
Mrs
Sparkler
declared
with
bitterness
that
it
really
was
too
bad
,
and
that
positively
it
was
enough
to
make
one
wish
one
was
dead
!
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
she
said
,
when

in
some

from
her
sense
of
personal

-
usage
;
"
provoking
as
it
is
,
and
cruel

,
I

must

submitted
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Especially
as
it
was
to
be
expected
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
"
returned
his
wife
,
"
if
you
have
nothing
more
becoming
to
do
than
to

to
insult
the
woman
who
has
honoured
you
with
her
hand
,
when
she
finds
herself
in
adversity
,
I
think
YOU
had
better
go
to
bed
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
was
much
afflicted
by
the
charge
,
and
offered
a
most
tender
and
earnest
apology
.
 
<EOS>
His
apology
was
accepted
;
but
Mrs
Sparkler
requested
him
to
go
round
to
the
other
side
of
the
sofa
and
sit
in
the
window
-
curtain
,
to
tone
himself
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Edmund
,
"
she
said
,
stretching
out
her
fan
,
and
touching
him
with
it
at
arm
's
length
,
"
what
I
was
going
to
say
to
you
when
you
began
as
usual
to
prose
and
worry
,
is
,
that
I
shall
guard
against
our
being
alone
any
more
,
and
that
when
circumstances
prevent
my
going
out
to
my
own
satisfaction
,
I
must
arrange
to
have
some
people
or
other
always
here
;
for
I
really
can
not
,
and
will
not
,
have
another
such
day
as
this
has
been
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
's
sentiments
as
to
the
plan
were
,
in
brief
,
that
it
had
no
nonsense
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
added
,
"
<EOS>
And
besides
,
you
know
it
's
likely
that
you
'll
soon
have
your
sister
---
"
   
"
Dearest
Amy
,
yes
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mrs
Sparkler
with
a
sigh
of
affection
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Darling
little
thing
!
 
<EOS>
Not
,
however
,
that
Amy
would
do
here
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
was
going
to
say
"
No
?
"
<EOS>
interrogatively
,
but
he
saw
his
danger
and
said
it
assentingly
,
"
No
,
<EOS>
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
;
she
would
n't
do
here
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Edmund
.
 
<EOS>
For
not
only
are
the
virtues
of
the
precious
child
of
that
still
character
that
they
require
a
contrast
---
require
life
and
movement
around
them
to
bring
them
out
in
their
right
colours
and
make
one
love
them
of
all
things
;
but
she
will
require
to
be
roused
,
on
more
accounts
than
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Roused
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
,
Edmund
!
 
<EOS>
Your
habit
of
interrupting
without
having
the
least
thing
in
the
world
to
say
,
distracts
one
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
be
broken
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Speaking
of
Amy
;
---
my
poor
little
pet
was
devotedly
attached
to
poor
papa
,
and
no
doubt
will
have
lamented
his
loss
exceedingly
,
and
grieved
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
so
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
felt
it
dreadfully
.
 
<EOS>
But
Amy
will
no
doubt
have
felt
it
even
more
,
from
having
been
on
the
spot
the
whole
time
,
and
having
been
with
poor
dear
papa
at
the
last
;
which
I
unhappily
was
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Fanny
stopped
to
weep
,
and
to
say
,
"
Dear
,
dear
,
beloved
papa
!
<EOS>
How
truly
gentlemanly
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
contrast
to
poor
uncle
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
From
the
effects
of
that
trying
time
,
"
she
pursued
,
"
my
good
little
Mouse
will
have
to
be
roused
.
 
<EOS>
Also
,
from
the
effects
of
this
long
attendance
upon
Edward
in
his
illness
;
an
attendance
which
is
not
yet
over
,
which
may
even
go
on
for
some
time
longer
,
and
which
in
the
meanwhile
unsettles
us
all
by
keeping
poor
dear
papa
's
affairs
from
being
wound
up
.
 
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
however
,
the
papers
with
his
agents
here
being
all
sealed
up
and
locked
up
,
as
he
left
them
when
he
providentially
came
to
England
,
the
affairs
are
in
that
state
of
order
that
they
can
wait
until
my
brother
Edward
recovers
his
health
in
Sicily
,
sufficiently
to
come
over
,
and
administer
,
or
execute
,
or
whatever
it
may
be
that
will
have
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
could
n't
have
a
better
nurse
to
bring
him
round
,
"
Mr
Sparkler
made
bold
to
opine
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
a
wonder
,
I
can
agree
with
you
,
"
returned
his
wife
,
languidly
turning
her
eyelids
a
little
in
his
direction
<EOS>
(
she
held
forth
,
in
general
,
as
if
to
the
drawing
-
room
furniture
)
,
"
and
can
adopt
your
words
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
have
a
better
nurse
to
bring
him
round
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
times
when
my
dear
child
is
a
little
wearing
to
an
active
mind
;
but
,
as
a
nurse
,
she
is
Perfection
.
 
<EOS>
Best
of
Amys
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
,
growing
rash
on
his
late
success
,
observed
that
Edward
had
had
,
biggodd
,
a
long
bout
of
it
,
my
dear
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
Bout
,
Edmund
,
"
returned
Mrs
Sparkler
,
"
is
the
slang
term
for
indisposition
,
he
has
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
is
not
,
I
am
unable
to
give
an
opinion
on
the
barbarous
language
you
address
to
Edward
's
sister
.
<EOS>
That
he
contracted
Malaria
Fever
somewhere
,
either
by
travelling
day
and
night
to
Rome
,
where
,
after
all
,
he
arrived
too
late
to
see
poor
dear
papa
before
his
death
---
or
under
some
other
unwholesome
circumstances
---
is
indubitable
,
if
that
is
what
you
mean
.
 
<EOS>
Likewise
that
his
extremely
careless
life
has
made
him
a
very
bad
subject
for
it
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
considered
it
a
parallel
case
to
that
of
some
of
our
fellows
in
the
West
Indies
with
Yellow
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
closed
her
eyes
again
,
and
refused
to
have
any
consciousness
of
our
fellows
of
the
West
Indies
,
or
of
Yellow
Jack
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
Amy
,
"
she
pursued
,
when
she
reopened
her
eyelids
,
"
will
require
to
be
roused
from
the
effects
of
many
tedious
and
anxious
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
And
lastly
,
she
will
require
to
be
roused
from
a
low
tendency
which
I
know
very
well
to
be
at
the
bottom
of
her
heart
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
ask
me
what
it
is
,
Edmund
,
because
I
must
decline
to
tell
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
going
to
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
thus
have
much
improvement
to
effect
in
my
sweet
child
,
"
Mrs
Sparkler
continued
,
"
and
can
not
have
her
near
me
too
soon
.
<EOS>
Amiable
and
dear
little
Twoshoes
!
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
settlement
of
poor
papa
's
affairs
,
my
interest
in
that
is
not
very
selfish
.
 
<EOS>
Papa
behaved
very
generously
to
me
when
I
was
married
,
and
I
have
little
or
nothing
to
expect
.
 
<EOS>
Provided
he
had
made
no
will
that
can
come
into
force
,
leaving
a
legacy
to
Mrs
General
<EOS>
,
I
am
contented
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
papa
,
dear
papa
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
wept
again
,
but
Mrs
General
was
the
best
of
restoratives
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
soon
stimulated
her
to
dry
her
eyes
and
say
:
   
"
<EOS>
It
is
a
highly
encouraging
circumstance
in
Edward
's
illness
,
I
am
thankful
to
think
,
and
gives
one
the
greatest
confidence
in
his
sense
not
being
impaired
,
or
his
proper
spirit
weakened
---
down
to
the
time
of
poor
dear
papa
's
death
at
all
events
---
that
he
paid
off
Mrs
General
instantly
,
and
sent
her
out
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
applaud
him
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
forgive
him
a
great
deal
for
doing
,
with
such
promptitude
,
so
exactly
what
I
would
have
done
myself
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
was
in
the
full
glow
of
her
gratification
,
when
a
double
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
odd
knock
.
 
<EOS>
Low
,
as
if
to
avoid
making
a
noise
and
attracting
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Long
,
as
if
the
person
knocking
were
preoccupied
in
mind
,
and
forgot
to
leave
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
this
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
Not
Amy
and
Edward
without
notice
and
without
a
carriage
!
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
room
was
dark
,
but
the
street
was
lighter
,
because
of
its
lamps
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
's
head
peeping
over
the
balcony
looked
so
very
bulky
and
heavy
<EOS>
that
it
seemed
on
the
point
of
overbalancing
him
and
flattening
the
unknown
below
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
one
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Sparkler
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
see
who
---
stop
though
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
this
second
thought
he
went
out
into
the
balcony
again
and
had
another
look
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
back
as
the
door
was
opened
,
and
announced
that
he
believed
he
had
identified
"
his
governor
's
tile
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
mistaken
,
for
his
governor
,
with
his
tile
in
his
hand
,
was
introduced
immediately
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Candles
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
,
with
a
word
of
excuse
for
the
darkness
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
light
enough
for
me
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
candles
were
brought
in
,
Mr
Merdle
was
discovered
standing
behind
the
door
,
picking
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
'd
give
you
a
call
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
rather
particularly
occupied
just
now
;
and
,
as
I
happened
to
be
out
for
a
stroll
,
I
thought
I
'd
give
you
a
call
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
was
in
dinner
dress
,
Fanny
asked
him
where
he
had
been
dining
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
I
have
n't
been
dining
anywhere
,
particularly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
have
dined
?
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
---
no
,
I
have
n't
exactly
dined
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
passed
his
hand
over
his
yellow
forehead
and
considered
,
as
if
he
were
not
sure
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Something
to
eat
was
proposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
I
do
n't
feel
inclined
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
have
dined
out
along
with
Mrs
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
I
did
n't
feel
inclined
for
dinner
,
I
let
Mrs
Merdle
go
by
herself
just
as
we
were
getting
into
the
carriage
,
and
thought
I
'd
take
a
stroll
instead
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Would
he
have
tea
or
coffee
?
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
looked
in
at
the
Club
,
and
got
a
bottle
of
wine
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
period
of
his
visit
,
Mr
Merdle
took
the
chair.which
Edmund
Sparkler
had
offered
him
,
and
which
he
had
hitherto
been
pushing
slowly
about
before
him
,
like
a

man
with
a
pair
of
skates
on
for
the
first
time
,
who
could
not
make
up
his
mind
to
start
.
 
<EOS>
He
now
put
his
hat
upon
another
chair
beside
him
,
and
,
looking
down
into
it
as
if
it
were
some
twenty
feet
deep
,
said
again
:
"
<EOS>
You
see
I
thought
I
'd
give
you
a
call
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Flattering
to
us
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
for
you
are
not
a
calling
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
no
,
"
returned
Mr
Merdle
,
who
was
by
this
time
taking
himself
into
custody
under
both
coat
-
sleeves
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
not
a
calling
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
too
much
to
do
for
that
,
"
said
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
"
Having
so
much
to
do
,
Mr
Merdle
,
loss
of
appetite
is
a
serious
thing
with
you
,
and
you
must
have
it
seen
to
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
be
ill
.
"
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
well
,
"
replied
Mr
Merdle
,
after
deliberating
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
well
as
I
usually
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
as
well
as
I
want
to
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
master
-
mind
of
the
age
,
true
to
its
characteristic
of
being
at
all
times
a
mind
that
had
as
little
as
possible
to
say
for
itself
and
great
difficulty
in
saying
it
,
became
mute
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Sparkler
began
to
wonder
how
long
the
master
-
mind
meant
to
stay
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
speaking
of
poor
papa
when
you
came
in
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
Quite
a
coincidence
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
Fanny
did
not
see
that
;
but
felt
it
incumbent
on
her
to
continue
talking
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
saying
,
"
she
pursued
,
"
that
my
brother
's
illness
has
occasioned
a
delay
in
examining
and
arranging
papa
's
property
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
;
"
yes
.
 
<EOS>
There
has
been
a
delay
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
it
is
of
consequence
,
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
,
"
assented
Mr
Merdle
,
after
having
examined
the
cornice
of
all
that
part
of
the
room
which
was
within
his
range
:
"
not
that
it
is
of
any
consequence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
only
anxiety
is
,
"
said
Fanny
,
"
that
Mrs
General
should
not
get
anything
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
wo
n't
get
anything
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
Fanny
was
delighted
to
hear
him
express
the
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
,
after
taking
another
gaze
into
the
depths
of
his
hat
as
if
he
thought
he
saw
something
at
the
bottom
,
rubbed
his
hair
and
slowly
appended
to
his
last
remark
the
confirmatory
words
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Not
she
.
 
<EOS>
Not
likely
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
topic
seemed
exhausted
,
and
Mr
Merdle
too
,
Fanny
inquired
if
he
were
going
to
take
up
Mrs
Merdle
and
the
carriage
in
his
way
home
?
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
answered
;
"
I
shall
go
by
the
shortest
way
,
and
leave
Mrs
Merdle
to
---
"
here
he
looked
all
over
the
palms
of
both
his
hands
as
if
he
were
telling
his
own
fortune
---
"
to
take
care
of
herself
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
she
'll
manage
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Probably
,
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
then
a
long
silence
;
during
which
,
Mrs
Sparkler
,
lying
back
on
her
sofa
again
,
shut
her
eyes
and
raised
her
eyebrows
in
her
former
retirement
from
mundane
affairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
however
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
,
"
I
am
equally
detaining
you
and
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
'd
give
you
a
call
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charmed
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Fanny
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
am
off
,
"
added
Mr
Merdle
,
getting
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Could
you
lend
me
a
penknife
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
an
odd
thing
<EOS>
,
Fanny
smilingly
observed
,
for
her
who
could
seldom
prevail
upon
herself
even
to
write
a
letter
,
to
lend
to
a
man
of
such
vast
business
as
Mr
Merdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
acquiesced
;
"
but
I
want
one
;
and
I
know
you
have
got
several
little
wedding
keepsakes
about
,
with
scissors
and
tweezers
and
such
things
in

.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
have
it
back
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Edmund
,
"
said
Mrs
Sparkler
,
"
open
(
now
,
very
carefully
,
<EOS>
I
beg
and
beseech
,
for
you
are
so
very
awkward
)
<EOS>
the
mother
of
pearl
box
on
my
little
table
there
,
and
give
Mr
Merdle
the
mother
of
pearl
penknife
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
;
"
but
if

have

with

darker

,
I

should
prefer
one
with

darker

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tortoise
-
shell
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
;
"
yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
should
prefer
tortoise
-
shell
.
"
   
<EOS>
Edmund
accordingly
received
instructions
to
open
the
tortoise
-
shell
box
,
and
give
Mr
Merdle
the
tortoise
-
shell
knife
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
doing
so
,
his
wife
said
to
the
master
-
spirit
graciously
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
forgive
you
,
if
you
ink
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
undertake
not
to
ink
it
,
"
said
Mr
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
The
illustrious
visitor
then
put
out
his
coat
-
cuff
,
and
for
a
moment
entombed
Mrs
Sparkler
's
hand
:
wrist
,
bracelet
,
and
all
.
<EOS>
Where
his
own
hand
had
shrunk
to
,
was
not
made
manifest
,
but
it
was
as
remote
from
Mrs
Sparkler
's
sense
of
touch
as
if
he
had
been
a
highly
meritorious
Chelsea
Veteran
or
Greenwich
Pensioner
.
   
<EOS>
Thoroughly
convinced
,
as
he
went
out
of
the
room
,
that
it
was
the
longest
day
that
ever
did
come
to
an
end
at
last
,
and
that
there
never
was
a
woman
,
not

devoid
of
personal

,
so
worn
out
by
idiotic
and
lumpish
people
,
Fanny
passed
into
the
balcony
for
a
breath
of
air
.
 
<EOS>
Waters
of
vexation
filled
her
eyes
;
and
they
had
the
effect
of
making
the
famous
Mr
Merdle
,
in
going
down
the
street
,
appear
to
leap
,
and
waltz
,
and
gyrate
,
as
if
he
were
possessed
of
several
Devils
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
The
Chief
Butler
Resigns
the
Seals
of
Office
 
<EOS>
The
dinner
-
party
was
at
the
great
Physician
's
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
was
there
,
and
in
full
force
.
 
<EOS>
Ferdinand
Barnacle
was
there
,
and
in
his
most
engaging
state
.
 
<EOS>
Few
ways
of
life
were
hidden
from
Physician
,
and
he
was
oftener
in
its
darkest
places
than
even
Bishop
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
brilliant
ladies
about
London
who
perfectly
doted
on
him
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
as
the
most
charming
creature
and
the
most
delightful
person
,
who
would
have
been
shocked
to
find
themselves
so
close
to
him
if
they
could
have
known
on
what
sights
<EOS>
those
thoughtful
eyes
of
his
had
rested
within
an
hour
or
two
,
and
near
to
whose
beds
,
and
under
what
roofs
,
his
composed
figure
had
stood
.
 
<EOS>
But
Physician
was
a
composed
man
,
who
performed
neither
on
his
own
trumpet
,
nor
on
the
trumpets
of
other
people
.
 
<EOS>
Many
wonderful
things
did
he
see
and
hear
,
and
<EOS>
much
irreconcilable
moral
contradiction
<EOS>
did
he
pass
his
life
among
;
yet
his
equality
of
compassion
was
no
more
disturbed
than
the
Divine
Master
's
of
all
healing
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
,
like
the
rain
,
among
the
just
and
unjust
,
doing
all
the
good
he
could
,
and
neither
proclaiming
it
in
the
synagogues
nor
at
the
corner
of
streets
.
   
<EOS>
As
no
man
of
large
experience
of
humanity
,
however
quietly
carried
it
may
be
,
can
fail
to
be
invested
with
an
interest
peculiar
to
the
possession
of
such
knowledge
,
Physician
was
an
attractive
man
.
<EOS>
Even
the
daintier
gentlemen
and
ladies
who
had
no
idea
of
his
secret
,
and
who
would
have
been
startled
out
of
more
wits
than
they
had
,
by
the
monstrous
impropriety
of
his
proposing
to
them
<EOS>
"
Come
and
see
what
I
see
!
"
<EOS>
confessed
his
attraction
.
 
<EOS>
Where
he
was
,
something
real
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
half
a
grain
of
reality
,
like
the
smallest
portion
of
some
other
scarce
natural
productions
,
will
flavour
an
enormous
quantity
of
diluent
.
   
<EOS>
It
came
to
pass
,
therefore
,
that
Physician
's
little
dinners
always
presented
people
in
their
least
conventional
lights
.
 
<EOS>
The
guests
said
to
themselves
,
whether
they
were
conscious
of
it
or
no
,
"
Here
is
a
man
who
really
has
an
acquaintance
with
us
as
we
are
,
who
is
admitted
to
some
of
us
every
day
with
our
wigs
and
paint
off
,
who
hears
the
wanderings
of
our
minds
,
and
sees
the
undisguised
expression
of
our
faces
,
when
both
are
past
our
control
;
we
may
as
well
make
an
approach
to
reality
with
him
,
for
the
man
has
got
the
better
of
us
and
is
too
strong
for
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
Physician
's
guests
came
out
so
surprisingly
at
his
round
table
that
they
were
almost
natural
.
   
<EOS>
Bar
's
knowledge
of
that
agglomeration
of
jurymen
which
is
called
humanity
was
as
sharp
as
a
razor
;
yet
a
razor
is
not
a
generally
convenient
instrument
,
and
Physician
's
plain
bright
scalpel
,
though
far
less
keen
,
was
adaptable
to
far
wider
purposes
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
knew
all
about
the
gullibility
and
knavery
of
people
;
but
Physician
could
have
given
him
a
better
insight
into
their
tendernesses
and
affections
,
in
one
week
of
his
rounds
,
than
Westminster
Hall
and
all
the
circuits
put
together
,
in
threescore
years
and
ten
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
always
had
a
suspicion
of
this
,
and
perhaps
was
glad
to
encourage
it
(
for
,
if
the
world
were
really
a
great
Law
Court
,
one
would
think
that
the
last
day
of
Term
could
not
too
soon

)
;
and
so
he
liked
and
respected
Physician
quite
as
much
as
any
other
kind
of
man
did
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
's
default
left
a
Banquo
's
chair
at
the
table
;
but
,
if
he
had
been
there
,
he
would
have
merely
made
the
difference
of
Banquo
in
it
,
and
consequently
he
was
no
loss
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
,
who
picked
up
all
sorts
of
odds
and
ends
about
Westminster
Hall
,
much
as
a
raven
would
have
done
if
he
had
passed
as
much
of
his
time
there
,
had
been
picking
up
a
great
many
straws
lately
and
tossing
them
about
,
to
try
which
way
the
Merdle
wind
blew
.
 
<EOS>
He
now
had
a
little
talk
on
the
subject
with
Mrs
Merdle
herself
;
sidling
up
to
that
lady
,
of
course
,
with
his
double
eye
-
glass
and
his
jury
droop
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
certain
bird
,
"
said
Bar
;
and
he
looked
as
if
it
could
have
been
no
other

than
a

;
"
has
been
whispering
among
us
lawyers
lately
,
that
there
is
to
be
an
addition
to
the
titled

of
this
realm
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
?
"
said
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
not
the
bird
been
whispering
in
very
different
ears
from
ours
---
in
lovely
ears
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
looked
expressively
at
Mrs
Merdle
's
nearest
ear
-
ring
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
mine
?
"
asked
Mrs
Merdle
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
say
lovely
,
"
said
Bar
,
"
I
always
mean
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
never
mean
anything
,
I
think
,
"
returned
Mrs
Merdle
(
not

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
cruelly
unjust
!
"
said
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
the
bird
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
last
person
in
the
world
to
hear
news
,
"
observed
Mrs
Merdle
,
carelessly
arranging
her
stronghold
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
admirable
witness
you
would
make
!
"
said
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
jury
(
unless
we
could
empanel
one
of
blind
men
)
could
resist
you
,
if
you
were
ever
so
bad
a
one
;
but
you
would
be
such
a
good
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
ridiculous
man
?
"
asked
Mrs
Merdle
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
Bar
waved
his
double
eye
-
glass
three
or
four
times
between
himself
and
the
Bosom
,
as
a
rallying
answer
,
and
inquired
in
his
most
insinuating

:
   
"
What
am
I
to
call
the
most
elegant
,
accomplished
and
charming
of
women
,
a
few
weeks
,
or
it
may
be
a
few
days
,
hence
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
your
bird
tell
you
what
to
call
her
?
"
answered
Mrs
Merdle
.
<EOS>
"
Do
ask
it
to
-
morrow
,
and
tell
me
the
next
time

see
me
what
it
says
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
led
to
further
passages
of
similar
pleasantry
between
the
two
;
but
Bar
,
with
all
his
sharpness
,
got
nothing
out
of
them
.
<EOS>
Physician
,
on
the
other
hand
,
taking
Mrs
Merdle
down
to
her
carriage
and
attending
on
her
as
she
put
on
her
cloak
,
inquired
into
the
symptoms
with
his
usual
calm
directness
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
this
true
about
Merdle
?
"
   
"
<EOS>
My
dear
doctor
,
"
she
returned
,
"
you
ask
me
the
very
question
that
I
was
half
disposed
to
ask
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
To
ask
me
!
 
<EOS>
Why
me
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
honour
,
I
think
Mr
Merdle
reposes
greater
confidence
in
you
than
in
any
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
he
tells
me
absolutely
nothing
,
even
professionally
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
heard
the
talk
,
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
know
what
Mr
Merdle
is
;
you
know
how
taciturn
and
reserved
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
I
have
no
idea
what
foundation
for
it
there
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
it
to
be
true
;
why
should
I
deny
that
to

?
 
<EOS>
You
would
know
better
,
if
I
did
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Physician
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
whether
it
is
all
true
,
or
partly
true
,
or
entirely
false
,
I
am
wholly
unable
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
most
provoking
situation
,
a
most
absurd
situation
;
but
you
know
Mr
Merdle
,
and
are
not
surprised
.
"
   
<EOS>
Physician
was
not
surprised
,
handed
her
into
her
carriage
,
and
bade
her
Good
Night
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
for
a
moment
at
his
own
hall
door
,
looking
sedately
at
the
elegant
equipage
as
it
rattled
away
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
return
up
-
stairs
,
the
rest
of
the
guests
soon
dispersed
,
and
he
was
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Being
a
great
reader
of
all
kinds
of
literature
(
and
never
at
all
apologetic
for
that
weakness
)
,
he
sat
down
comfortably
to
read
.
   
<EOS>
The
clock
upon
his
study
table
pointed
to
a
few
minutes
short
of
twelve
,
when
his
attention
was
called
to
it
by
a
ringing
at
the
door
bell
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
of
plain
habits
,
he
had
sent
his
servants
to
bed
and
must
needs
go
down
to
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
down
,
and
there
found
a
man
without
hat
or
coat
,
whose
shirt
sleeves
were
rolled
up
tight
to
his
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
moment
,
he
thought
the
man
had
been
fighting
:
the
rather
,
as
he
was
much
agitated
and
out
of
breath
.
<EOS>
A
second
look
,
however
,
showed
him
that
the
man
was
particularly
clean
,
and
not
otherwise
discomposed
as
to
his
dress
than
as
it
answered
this
description
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
come
from
the
warm
-
baths
,
sir
,
round
in
the
neighbouring
street
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
the
matter
at
the
warm
-
baths
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
please
to
come
directly
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
that
,
lying
on
the
table
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
into
the
physician
's
hand
a
scrap
of
paper
.
 
<EOS>
Physician
looked
at
it
,
and
read
his
own
name
and
address
written
in
pencil
;
nothing
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
closer
at
the
writing
,
looked
at
the
man
,
took
his
hat
from
its
peg
,
put
the
key
of
his
door
in
his
pocket
,
and
they
hurried
away
together
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
came
to
the
warm
-
baths
,
all
the
other
people
belonging
to
that
establishment
were
looking
out
for
them
at
the
door
,
and
running
up
and
down
the
passages
.
 
<EOS>
"
Request
everybody
else
to
keep
back
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
the
physician
aloud
to
the
master
;
"
and
do
you
take
me
straight
to
the
place
,
my
friend
,
"
to
the
messenger
.
   
<EOS>
The
messenger
hurried
before
him
,
along
a
grove
of
little
rooms
,
and
turning
into
one
at
the
end
of
the
grove
,
looked
round
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Physician
was
close
upon
him
,
and
looked
round
the
door
too
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
bath
in
that
corner
,
from
which
the
water
had
been
hastily
drained
off
.
 
<EOS>
Lying
in
it
,
as
in
a
grave
or
sarcophagus
,
with
a
hurried
drapery
of
sheet
and
blanket
thrown
across
it
,
was
the
body
of
a
heavily
-
made
man
,
with
an
obtuse
head
,
and
coarse
,
mean
,
common
features
.
 
<EOS>
A
sky
-
light
had
been
opened
to
release
the
steam
with
which
the
room
had
been
filled
;
but
it
hung
,
condensed
into
water
-
drops
,
heavily
upon
the
walls
,
and
heavily
upon
the
face
and
figure
in
the
bath
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
was
still
hot
,
and
the
marble
of
the
bath
still
warm
;
but
the
face
and
figure
were
clammy
to
the
touch
.
 
<EOS>
The
white
marble
at
the
bottom
of
the
bath
was
veined
with
a
dreadful
red
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
ledge
at
the
side
,
were
an
empty
laudanum
-
bottle
and
a
tortoise
-
shell
handled
penknife
---
soiled
,
but
not
with
ink
.
   
<EOS>
"
Separation
of
jugular
vein
---
death
rapid
---
been
dead
at
least
half
an
hour
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
echo
of
the
physician
's
words
ran
through
the
passages
and
little
rooms
,
and
through
the
house
while
he
was
yet
straightening
himself
from
having
bent
down
to
reach
to
the
bottom
of
the
bath
,
and
while
he
was
yet
dabbling
his
hands
in
water
;
redly
veining
it
as
the
marble
was
veined
,
before
it
mingled
into
one
tint
.
   
<EOS>
He
turned
his
eyes
to
the
dress
upon
the
sofa
,
and
to
the
watch
,
money
,
and
pocket
-
book
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
A
folded
note
half
buckled
up
in
the
pocket
-
book
,
and
half
protruding
from
it
,
caught
his
observant
glance
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
it
,
touched
it
,
pulled
it
a
little
further
out
from
among
the
leaves
,
said
quietly
,
"
This
is
addressed
to
me
,
"
and
opened
and
read
it
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
no
directions
for
him
to
give
.
 
<EOS>
The
people
of
the
house
knew
what
to
do
;
the
proper
authorities
were
soon
brought
;
and
they
took
an
equable
business
-
like
possession
of
the
deceased
,
and
of
what
had
been
his
property
,
with
no
greater
disturbance
of
manner
or
countenance
than
usually
attends
the
winding
-
up
of
a
clock
.
<EOS>
Physician
was
glad
to
walk
out
into
the
night
air
---
was
even
glad
,
in
spite
of
his
great
experience
,
to
sit
down
upon
a
door
-
step
for
a
little
while
:
feeling
sick
and
faint
.
   
<EOS>
Bar
was
a
near
neighbour
of
his
,
and
,
when
he
came
to
the
house
,
he
saw
a
light
in
the
room
where
he
knew
his
friend
often
sat
late
getting
up
his
work
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
light
was
never
there
when
Bar
was
not
,
it
gave
him
assurance
that
Bar
was
not
yet
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
this
busy
bee
had
a
verdict
to
get
to
-
morrow
,
against
evidence
,
and
was
improving
the
shining
hours
in
setting
snares
for
the
gentlemen
of
the
jury
.
   
<EOS>
Physician
's
knock
astonished
Bar
;
but
,
as
he
immediately
suspected
that
somebody
had
come
to
tell
him
that
somebody
else
was
robbing
him
,
or
otherwise
trying
to
get
the
better
of
him
,
he
came
down
promptly
and
softly
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
clearing
his
head
with
a
lotion
of
cold
water
,
as
a
good
preparative
to
providing
hot
water
for
the
heads
of
the
jury
,
and
had
been
reading
with
the
neck
of
his
shirt
thrown
wide
open
that
he
might
the
more
freely
choke
the
opposite
witnesses
.
 
<EOS>
In
consequence
,
he
came
down
,
looking
rather
wild
.
<EOS>
Seeing
Physician
,
the
least
expected
of
men
,
he
looked
wilder
and
said
,
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
asked
me
once
what
Merdle
's
complaint
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Extraordinary
answer
!
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
I
had
not
found
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
did
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
it
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
"
said
Bar
,
starting
back
,
and
clapping
his
hand
upon
the
other
's
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
have
I
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
in
your
face
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
went
into
the
nearest
room
,
where
Physician
gave
him
the
letter
to
read
.
 
<EOS>
He
read
it
through
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
much
in
it
as
to
quantity
;
but
it
made
a
great
demand
on
his
close
and
continuous
attention
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
sufficiently
give
utterance
to
his
regret
that
he
had
not
himself
found
a
clue
to
this
.
 
<EOS>
The
smallest
clue
,
he
said
,
would
have
made
him
master
of
the
case
,
and
what
a
case
it
would
have
been
to
have
got
to
the
bottom
of
!
   
<EOS>
Physician
had
engaged
to
break
the
intelligence
in
Harley
Street
.
<EOS>
Bar
could
not
at
once
return
to
his
inveiglements
of
the
most
enlightened
and
remarkable
jury
he
had
ever
seen
in
that
box
,
with
whom
,
he
could
tell
his
learned
friend
,
no
shallow
sophistry
would
go
down
,
and
no
unhappily
abused
professional
tact
and
skill
prevail
(
this
was
the
way
he
meant
to
begin
with
them
)
;
so
he
said
he
would
go
too
,
and
would
loiter
to
and
fro
near
the
house
while
his
friend
was
inside
.
 
<EOS>
They
walked
there
,
the
better
to
recover
self
-
possession
in
the
air
;
and
the
wings
of
day
were
fluttering
the
night
when
Physician
knocked
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
A
footman
of
rainbow
hues
,
in
the
public
eye
,
was
sitting
up
for
his
master
---
<EOS>
that
is
to
say
,
was
fast
asleep
in
the
kitchen
over
a
couple
of
candles
and
a
newspaper
,
demonstrating
the
great
accumulation
of
mathematical
odds
against
the
probabilities
of
a
house
being
set
on
fire
by
accident
When
this
serving
man
was
roused
,
Physician
had
still
to
await
the
rousing
of
the
Chief
Butler
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
that
noble
creature
came
into
the
dining
-
room
in
a
flannel
gown
and
list
shoes
;
but
with
his
cravat
on
,
and
a
Chief
Butler
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
morning
now
.
 
<EOS>
Physician
had
opened
the
shutters
of
one
window
while
waiting
,
that
he
might
see
the
light
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Merdle
's
maid
must
be
called
,
and
told
to
get
Mrs
Merdle
up
,
and
prepare
her
as
gently
as
she
can
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
dreadful
news
to
break
to
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
Physician
to
the
Chief
Butler
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
,
who
had
a
candle
in
his
hand
,
called
his
man
to
take
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
approached
the
window
with
dignity
;
looking
on
at
Physician
's
news
exactly
as
he
had
looked
on
at
the
dinners
in
that
very
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Merdle
is
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
wish
,
"
said
the
Chief
Butler
,
"
to
give
a
month
's
notice
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Merdle
has
destroyed
himself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
the
Chief
Butler
,
"
that
is
very
unpleasant
to
the
feelings
of
one
in
my
position
,
as
calculated
to
awaken
prejudice
;
and
I
should
wish
to
leave
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
not
shocked
,
are
you
not
surprised
,
man
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
Physician
,
warmly
.
   
<EOS>
The
Chief
Butler
,
erect
and
calm
,
replied
in
these
memorable
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
Mr
Merdle
never
was
the
gentleman
,
and
no
ungentlemanly
act
on
Mr
Merdle
's
part
would
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
anybody
else
I
can
send
to
you
,
or
any
other
directions
I
can
give
before
I
leave
,
respecting
what
you
would
wish
to
be
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
When
Physician
,
after
discharging
himself
of
his
trust
up
-
stairs
,
rejoined
Bar
in
the
street
,
he
said
no
more
of
his
interview
with
Mrs
Merdle
than
that
he
had
not
yet
told
her
all
,
but
that
what
he
had
told
her
she
had
borne
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
Bar
had
devoted
his
leisure
in
the
street
to
the
construction
of
a
most
ingenious
man
-
trap
for
catching
the
whole
of
his
jury
at
a
blow
;
having
got
that
matter
settled
in
his
mind
,
it
was
lucid
on
the
late
catastrophe
,
and
they
walked
home
slowly
,
discussing
it
in
every
bearing
.
<EOS>
Before
parting
at
the
Physician
's
door
,
they
both
looked
up
at
the
sunny
morning
sky
,
into
which
the
smoke
of
a
few
early
fires
and
the
breath
and
voices
of
a
few
early
stirrers
were
peacefully
rising
,
and
then
looked
round
upon
the
immense
city
,
and
said
,
if
all
those
hundreds
and
thousands
of
beggared
people
who
were
yet
asleep
could
only
know
,
as
they
two
spoke
,
the
ruin
that
impended
over
them
,
what
a
fearful
cry
against
one
miserable
soul
would
go
up
to
Heaven
!
   
<EOS>
The
report
that
the
great
man
was
dead
,
got
about
with
astonishing
rapidity
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
he
was
dead
of
all
the
diseases
that
ever
were
known
,
and
of
several
bran
-
new
maladies
invented
with
the
speed
of
Light
to
meet
the
demand
of
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
concealed
a
dropsy
from
infancy
,
he
had
inherited
a
large
estate
of
water
on
the
chest
from
his
grandfather
,
he
had
had
an
operation
performed
upon
him
every
morning
of
his
life
for
eighteen
years
,
he
had
been
subject
to
the
explosion
of
important
veins
in
his
body
after
the
manner
of
fireworks
,
he
had
had
something
the
matter
with
his
lungs
,
he
had
had
something
the
matter
with
his
heart
,
he
had
had
something
the
matter
with
his
brain
.
 
<EOS>
Five
hundred
people
who
sat
down
to
breakfast
entirely
uninformed
on
the
whole
subject
,
believed
before
they
had
done
breakfast
,
that
they
privately
and
personally
knew
Physician
to
have
said
to
Mr
Merdle
,
"
You
must
expect
to
go
out
,
some
day
,
like
the
snuff
of
a
candle
;
"
and
that
they
knew
Mr
Merdle
to
have
said
to
Physician
,
"
A
man
can
die
but
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
about
eleven
o'clock
in
the
forenoon
,
something
the
matter
with
the
brain
,
became
the
favourite
theory
against
the
field
;
and
by
twelve
the
something
had
been
distinctly
ascertained
to
be
"
Pressure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Pressure
was
so
entirely
satisfactory
to
the
public
mind
,
and
seemed
to
make
everybody
so
comfortable
,
that
it
might
have
lasted
all
day
but
for
Bar
's
having
taken
the
real
state
of
the
case
into
Court
at
half
-
past
nine
.
 
<EOS>
This
led
to
its
beginning
to
be
currently
whispered
all
over
London
by
about
one
,
that
Mr
Merdle
had
killed
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Pressure
,
however
,
so
far
from
being
overthrown
by
the
discovery
,
became
a
greater
favourite
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
general
moralising
upon
Pressure
,
in
every
street
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
people
who
had
tried
to
make
money
and
had
not
been
able
to
do
it
,
said
,
There
you
were
!
 
<EOS>
You
no
sooner
began
to
devote
yourself
to
the
pursuit
of
wealth
than
you
got
Pressure
.
 
<EOS>
The
idle
people
improved
the
occasion
in
a
similar
manner
.
 
<EOS>
See
,
said
they
,
what
you
brought
yourself
to
by
work
,
work
,
work
!
 
<EOS>
You
persisted
in
working
,
you
overdid
it
.
 
<EOS>
Pressure
came
on
,
and
you
were
done
for
!
 
<EOS>
This
consideration
was
very
potent
in
many
quarters
,
but
nowhere
more
so
than
among
the
young
clerks
and
partners
who
had
never
been
in
the
slightest
danger
of
overdoing
it
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
one
and
all
,
declared
,
quite
piously
,
that
they
hoped
they
would
never
forget
the
warning
as
long
as
they
lived
,
and
that
their
conduct
might
be
so
regulated
as
to
keep
off
Pressure
,
and
preserve
them
,
a
comfort
to
their
friends
,
for
many
years
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
at
about
the
time
of
High
"
Change
,
Pressure
began
to
wane
,
and
appalling
whispers
to
circulate
,
east
,
west
,
north
,
and
south
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
they
were
faint
,
and
went
no
further
than
a
doubt
whether
Mr
Merdle
's
wealth
would
be
found
to
be
as
vast
as
had
been
supposed
;
whether
there
might
not
be
a
temporary
difficulty
in
"
realising
"
it
;
whether
there
might
not
even
be
a
temporary
suspension
(
say
a
month
or
so
)
,
on
the
part
of
the
wonderful
Bank
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
whispers
became
louder
,
which
they
did
from
that
time
every
minute
,
they
became
more
threatening
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
sprung
from
nothing
,
by
no
natural
growth
or
process
that
any
one
could
account
for
<EOS>
;
he
had
been
,
after
all
,
a
low
,
ignorant
fellow
;
he
had
been
a
down
-
looking
man
,
and
no
one
had
ever
been
able
to
catch
his
eye
;
he
had
been
taken
up
by
all
sorts
of
people
in
quite
an
unaccountable
manner
;
he
had
never
had
any
money
of
his
own
,
his
ventures
had
been
utterly
reckless
,
and
his
expenditure
had
been
most
enormous
.
 
<EOS>
In
steady
progression
,
as
the
day
declined
,
the
talk
rose
in
sound
and
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
a
letter
at
the
Baths
addressed
to
his
physician
,
and
his
physician
had
got
the
letter
,
and
the
letter
would
be
produced
at
the
Inquest
on
the
morrow
,
and
it
would
fall
like
a
thunderbolt
upon
the
multitude
he
had
deluded
.
 
<EOS>
Numbers
of
men
in
every
profession
and
trade
would
be
blighted
by
his
insolvency
;
old
people
who
had
been
in
easy
circumstances
all
their
lives
would
have
no
place
of
repentance
for
their
trust
in
him
but
the
workhouse
;
legions
of
women
and
children
would
have
their
whole
future
desolated
by
the
hand
of
this
mighty
scoundrel
.
 
<EOS>
Every
partaker
of
his
magnificent
feasts
would
be
seen
to
have
been
a
sharer
in
the
plunder
of
innumerable
homes
;
every
servile
worshipper
of
riches
who
had
helped
to
set
him
on
his
pedestal
,
would
have
done
better
to
worship
the
Devil
point
-
blank
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
the
talk
,
lashed
louder
and
higher
by
confirmation
on
confirmation
,
and
by
edition
after
edition
of
the
evening
papers
,
swelled
into
such
a
roar
when
night
came
,
as
might
have
brought
one
to
believe
that
a
solitary
watcher
on
the
gallery
above
the
Dome
of
St
Paul
's
would
have
perceived
the
night
air
to
be
laden
with
a
heavy
muttering
of
the
name
of
Merdle
,
coupled
with
every
form
of
execration
.
   
<EOS>
For
by
that
time
it
was
known
that
the
late
Mr
Merdle
's
complaint
had
been
simply
Forgery
and
Robbery
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
the
uncouth
object
of
such
wide
-
spread
adulation
,
the
sitter
at
great
men
's
feasts
,
the
roc
's
egg
of
great
ladies
'
assemblies
,
the
subduer
of
exclusiveness
,
the
leveller
of
pride
,
the
patron
of
patrons
,
the
bargain
-
driver
with
a
Minister
for
Lordships
of
the
Circumlocution
Office
,
the
recipient
of
more
acknowledgment
within
some
ten
or
fifteen
years
,
at
most
,
than
had
been
bestowed
in
England
upon
all
peaceful
public
benefactors
,
and
upon
all
the
leaders
of
all
the
Arts
and
Sciences
,
with
all
their
works
to
testify
for
them
,
during
two
centuries
at
least
---
he
,
the
shining
wonder
,
the
new
constellation
to
be
followed
by
the
wise
men
bringing
gifts
,
until
it
stopped
over
a
certain
carrion
at
the
bottom
of
a
bath
and
disappeared
---
was
simply
the
greatest
Forger
and
the
greatest
Thief
that
ever
cheated
the
gallows
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
Reaping
the
Whirlwind
 
With
a
precursory
sound
of
hurried
breath
and
hurried
feet
,
Mr
Pancks
rushed
into
Arthur
Clennam
's
Counting
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
Inquest
was
over
,
the
letter
was
public
,
the
Bank
was
broken
,
the
other
model
structures
of
straw
had
taken
fire
and
were
turned
to
smoke
.
<EOS>
The
admired
piratical
ship
had
blown
up
,
in
the
midst
of
a
vast
fleet
of
ships
of
all
rates
,
and
boats
of
all
sizes
;
and
on
the
deep
was
nothing
but
ruin
;
nothing
but
burning
hulls
,
bursting
magazines
,
great
guns
self
-
exploded
tearing
friends
and
neighbours
to
pieces
,
drowning
men
clinging
to
unseaworthy
spars
and
going
down
every
minute
,
spent
swimmers
floating
dead
,
and
sharks
.
   
<EOS>
The
usual
diligence
and
order
of
the
Counting
-
house
at
the
Works
were
overthrown
.
 
<EOS>
Unopened
letters
and
unsorted
papers
lay
strewn
about
the
desk
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
these
tokens
of
prostrated
energy
and
dismissed
hope
,
the
master
of
the
Counting
-
house
stood
idle
in
his
usual
place
,
with
his
arms
crossed
on
the
desk
,
and
his
head
bowed
down
upon
them
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
rushed
in
and
saw
him
,
and
stood
still
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
minute
,
Mr
Pancks
's
arms
were
on
the
desk
,
and
Mr
Pancks
's
head
was
bowed
down
upon
them
;
and
for
some
time
they
remained
in
these
attitudes
,
idle
and
silent
,
with
the
width
of
the
little
room
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
the
first
to
lift
up
his
head
and
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
persuaded
you
to
it
,
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
Say
what
you
will
.
   
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
say
more
to
me
than
I
say
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
say
more
than
I
deserve
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
Pancks
,
Pancks
!
"
returned
Clennam
,
"
do
n't
speak
of
deserving
.
<EOS>
What
do
I
myself
deserve
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better
luck
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
"
pursued
Clennam
,
without
attending
to
him
,
"
who
have
ruined
my
partner
!
 
<EOS>
Pancks
,
Pancks
,
I
have
ruined
Doyce
!
 
<EOS>
The
honest
,
self
-
helpful
,
indefatigable
old
man
who
has
worked
his
way
all
through
his
life
<EOS>
;
the
man
who
has
contended
against
so
much
disappointment
,
and
who
has
brought
out
of
it
such
a
good
and
hopeful
nature
;
the
man
I
have
felt
so
much
for
,
and
meant
to
be
so
true
and
useful
to
;
I
have
ruined
him
---
brought
him
to
shame
and
disgrace
---
ruined
him
,
ruined
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
agony
into
which
the
reflection
wrought
his
mind
<EOS>
was
so
distressing
to
see
,
that
Mr
Pancks
took
hold
of
himself
by
the
hair
of
his
head
,
and
tore
it
in
desperation
at
the
spectacle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Reproach
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Reproach
me
,
sir
,
or
<EOS>
I
'll
do
myself
an
injury
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
---
<EOS>
You
fool
,
you
villain
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
---
<EOS>
Ass
,
how
could
you
do
it
;
<EOS>
Beast
,
what
did
you
mean
by
it
!
 
<EOS>
Catch
hold
of
me
somewhere
.
   
<EOS>
Say
something
abusive
to
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
All
the
time
,
Mr
Pancks
was
tearing
at
his
tough
hair
in
a
most
pitiless
and
cruel
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
never
yielded
to
this
fatal
mania
,
Pancks
,
"
said
Clennam
,
more
in
commiseration
than
retaliation
,
"
it
would
have
been
how
much
better
for
you
,
and
how
much
better
for
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
me
again
,
sir
!
"
cried
Pancks
,
grinding
his
teeth
in
remorse
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
me
again
!
"
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
never
gone
into
those
accursed
calculations
,
and
brought
out
your
results
with
such
abominable
clearness
,
"
groaned
Clennam
,
"
it
would
have
been
how
much
better
for
you
,
Pancks
,
and
how
much
better
for
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
me
again
,
sir
!
"
exclaimed
Pancks
,
loosening
his
hold
of
his
hair
;
"
at
me
again
,
and
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,
however
,
finding
him
already
beginning
to
be
pacified
,
had
said
all
he
wanted
to
say
,
and
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
wrung
his
hand
,
only
adding
,
"
Blind
leaders
of
the
blind
,
Pancks
!
 
<EOS>
Blind
leaders
of
the
blind
!
 
<EOS>
But
Doyce
,
Doyce
,
Doyce
;
my
injured
partner
!
"
 
<EOS>
That
brought
his
head
down
on
the
desk
once
more
.
   
<EOS>
Their
former
attitudes
and
their
former
silence
were
once
more
first
encroached
upon
by
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
been
to
bed
,
sir
,
since
it
began
to
get
about
.
 
<EOS>
Been
high
and
low
,
on
the
chance
of
finding
some
hope
of
saving
any
cinders
from
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
All
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
All
gone
.
 
<EOS>
All
vanished
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
returned
Clennam
,
"
too
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
filled
up
a
pause
with
a
groan
that
came
out
of
the
very
depths
of
his
soul
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
yesterday
,
Pancks
,
"
said
Arthur
;
"
only
yesterday
,
Monday
,
I
had
the
fixed
intention
of
selling
,
realising
,
and
making
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
as
much
for
myself
,
sir
,
"
returned
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Though
it
's
wonderful
how
many
people
I
've
heard
of
,
who
were
going
to
realise
yesterday
,
of
all
days
in
the
three
hundred
and
sixty
-
five
,
if
it
had
n't
been
too
late
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
steam
-
like
breathings
,
usually
droll
in
their
effect
,
were
more
tragic
than
so
many
groans
:
while
from
head
to
foot
,
he
was
in
that
begrimed
,
besmeared
,
neglected
state
,
that
he
might
have
been
an
authentic
portrait
of
Misfortune
which
could
scarcely
be
discerned
through
its
want
of
cleaning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
,
had
you
laid
out
---
everything
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
got
over
the
break
before
the
last
word
,
and
also
brought
out
the
last
word
itself
with
great
difficulty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
took
hold
of
his
tough
hair
again
,
and
gave
it
such
a
wrench
that
he
pulled
out
several
prongs
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
looking
at
these
with
an
eye
of
wild
hatred
,
he
put
them
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
course
,
"
said
Clennam
,
brushing
away
some
tears
that
had
been
silently
dropping
down
his
face
,
"
must
be
taken
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
What
wretched
amends
I
can
make
must
be
made
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
clear
my
unfortunate
partner
's
reputation
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
retain
nothing
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
resign
to
our
creditors
the
power
of
management
I
have
so
much
abused
,
and
I
must
work
out
as
much
of
my
fault
---
or
crime
---
as
is
susceptible
of
being
worked
out
in
the
rest
of
my
days
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
impossible
,
sir
,
to
tide
over
the
present
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
tided
over
now
,
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
The
sooner
the
business
can
pass
out
of
my
hands
,
the
better
for
it
.
<EOS>
There
are
engagements
to
be
met
,
this
week
,
which
would
bring
the
catastrophe
before
many
days
were
over
,
even
if
I
would
postpone
it
for
a
single
day
by
going
on
for
that
space
,
secretly
knowing
what
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
All
last
night
I
thought
of
what
I
would
do
;
what
remains
is
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
entirely
of
yourself
?
"
said
Pancks
,
whose
face
was
as
damp
as
if
his
steam
were
turning
into
water
as
fast
as
he
dismally
blew
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
some
legal
help
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
had
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
Rugg
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
not
much
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
do
it
as
well
as
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
fetch
Rugg
,
Mr
Clennam
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
could
spare
the
time
,
I
should
be
much

to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
put
on
his
hat
that
moment
,
and
steamed
away
to
Pentonville
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
gone
<EOS>
Arthur
never
raised
his
head
from
the
desk
,
but
remained
in
that
one
position
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
brought
his
friend
and
professional
adviser
,
Mr
Rugg
,
back
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
had
had
such
ample
experience
,
on
the
road
,
of
Mr
Pancks
's
being
at
that
present
in
an

state
of
mind
,
that
he
opened
his
professional
mediation
by
requesting
that
gentleman
to
take

of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
crushed
and
submissive
,
obeyed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
not
unlike
what
my
daughter
was
,
sir
,
when
we
began
the
Breach
of
Promise
action
of
Rugg
and
Bawkins
,
in
which
she
was
Plaintiff
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
takes
too
strong
and
direct
an
interest
in
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
His
feelings
are
worked
upon
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
getting
on
,
in
our
profession
,
with
feelings
worked
upon
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
pulled
off
his
gloves
and
put
them
in
his
hat
,
he
saw
,
in
a
side
