or
two
,
that
a
great
change
had
come
over
his
client
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
perceive
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
"
that
you
have
been
allowing
your
own
feelings
to
be
worked
upon
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
pray
do
n't
,
pray
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
These
losses
are
much
to
be
deplored
,
sir
,
but
we
must
look
'em
in
the
face
.
"
<EOS>
"
If
the
money
I
have
sacrificed
had
been
all
my
own
,
Mr
Rugg
,
"
sighed
Mr
Clennam
,
"
I
should
have
cared
far
less
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
rubbing
his
hands
with
a
cheerful
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
singular
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
generally
found
,
in
my
experience
,
that
it
's
their
own
money
people
are
most
particular
about
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
people
get
rid
of
a
good
deal
of
other
people
's
money
,
and
bear
it
very
well
:
very
well
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
comforting
remarks
,
Mr
Rugg
seated
himself
on
an
office
-
stool
at
the
desk
and
proceeded
to
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Clennam
,
by
your
leave
,
let
us
go
into
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
see
the
state
of
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
is
simple
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
is
the
usual
plain
,
straightforward
,
common
-
sense
question
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
we
do
for
ourself
?
 
<EOS>
What
can
we
do
for
ourself
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
the
question
with
me
,
Mr
Rugg
,
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
it
in
the
beginning
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
,
what
can
I
do
for
my
partner
,
how
can
I
best
make
reparation
to
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
sir
,
do
you
know
,
"
argued
Mr
Rugg
persuasively
,
"
that
you
are
still
allowing
your
feeling
to
be
worked
upon
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
the
term
"
reparation
,
"
sir
,
except
as
a
lever
in
the
hands
of
counsel
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
excuse
my
saying
that
I
feel
it
my
duty
to
offer
you
the
caution
,
that
you
really
must
not
allow
your
feelings
to
be
worked
upon
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Rugg
,
"
said
Clennam
,
nerving
himself
to
go
through
with
what
he
had
resolved
upon
,
and
surprising
that
gentleman
by
appearing
,
in
his
despondency
,
to
have
a
settled
determination
of
purpose
;
"
you
give
me
the
impression
that
you
will
not
be
much
disposed
to
adopt
the
course
I
have
made
up
my
mind
to
take
.
 
<EOS>
If
your
disapproval
of
it
should
render
you
unwilling
to
discharge
such
business
as
it
necessitates
,
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
and
must
seek
other
aid
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
represent
to
you
at
once
,
that
to
argue
against
it
with
me
is
useless
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
sir
,
"
answered
Mr
Rugg
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Since
the
business
is
to
be
done
by
some
hands
,
let
it
be
done
by
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
my
principle
in
the
case
of
Rugg
and
Bawkins
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
my
principle
in
most
cases
.
 
<EOS>
"
   
Clennam
then
proceeded
to
state
to
Mr
Rugg
<EOS>
his
fixed
resolution
.
<EOS>
He
told
Mr
Rugg
that
his
partner
was
a
man
of
great
simplicity
and
integrity
,
and
that
in
all
he
meant
to
do
,
he
was
guided
above
all
things
by
a
knowledge
of
his
partner
's
character
,
and
a
respect
for
his
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
He
explained
that
his
partner
was
then
absent
on
an
enterprise
of
importance
,
and
that
it
particularly
behoved
himself
publicly
to
accept
the
blame
of
what
he
had
rashly
done
,
and
publicly
to
exonerate
his
partner
from
all
participation
in
the
responsibility
of
it
,
lest
the
successful
conduct
of
that
enterprise
should
be
endangered
by
the
slightest
suspicion
wrongly
attaching
to
his
partner
's
honour
and
credit
in
another
country
.
<EOS>
He
told
Mr
Rugg
that
to
clear
his
partner
morally
,
to
the
fullest
extent
,
and
publicly
and
unreservedly
to
declare
that
he
,
Arthur
Clennam
,
of
that
Firm
,
had
of
his
own
sole
act
,
and
even
expressly
against
his
partner
's
caution
,
embarked
its
resources
in
the
swindles
that
had
lately
perished
,
was
the
only
real
atonement
within
his
power
;
was
a
better
atonement
to
the
particular
man
than
it
would
be
to
many
men
;
and
was
therefore
the
atonement
he
had
first
to
make
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
his
intention
was
to
print
a
declaration
to
the
foregoing
effect
,
which
he
had
already
drawn
up
;
and
,
besides
circulating
it
among
all
who
had
dealings
with
the
House
,
to
advertise
it
in
the
public
papers
.
 
<EOS>
Concurrently
with
this
measure
(
the
description
of
which
cost
Mr
Rugg
innumerable
wry
faces
and
great
uneasiness
in
his
limbs
)
,
he
would
address
a
letter
to
all
the
creditors
,
exonerating
his
partner
in
a
solemn
manner
,
informing
them
of
the
stoppage
of
the
House
until
their
pleasure
could
be
known
and
his
partner
communicated
with
,
and
humbly
submitting
himself
to
their
direction
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
through
their
consideration
for
his
partner
's
innocence
,
the
affairs
could
ever
be
got
into
such
train
as
that
the
business
could
be
profitably
resumed
,
and
its
present
downfall
overcome
,
then
his
own
share
in
it
should
revert
to
his
partner
,
as
the
only
reparation
he
could
make
to
him
in
money
value
for
the
distress
and
loss
he
had
unhappily
brought
upon
him
,
and
he
himself
,
at
as
mall
a
salary
as
he
could
live
upon
,
would
ask
to
be
allowed
to
serve
the
business
as
a
faithful
clerk
.
   
<EOS>
Though
Mr
Rugg
saw
plainly
there
was
no
preventing
this
from
being
done
,
still
the
wryness
of
his
face
and
the
uneasiness
of
his
limbs
so
sorely
required
the
propitiation
of
a
Protest
,
that
he
made
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
offer
no
objection
,
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
argue
no
point
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
carry
out
your
views
,
sir
;
but
,
under
protest
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
then
stated
,
not
without
prolixity
,
the
heads
of
his
protest
.
<EOS>
These
were
,
in
effect
,
because
the
whole
town
,
or
he
might
say
the
whole
country
,
was
in
the
first
madness
of
the
late
discovery
,
and
the
resentment
against
the
victims
would
be
very
strong
:
those
who
had
not
been
deluded
being
certain
to
wax
exceedingly
wroth
with
them
for
not
having
been
as
wise
as
they
were
:
and
those
who
had
been
deluded
being
certain
to
find
excuses
and
reasons
for
themselves
,
of
which
they
were
equally
certain
to
see
that
other
sufferers
were
wholly
devoid
:
not
to
mention
the
great
probability
of
every
individual
sufferer
persuading
himself
,
to
his
violent
indignation
,
that
<EOS>
but
for
the
example
of
all
the
other
sufferers
he
never
would
have
put
himself
in
the
way
of
suffering
.
 
<EOS>
Because
such
a
declaration
as
Clennam
's
,
made
at
such
a
time
,
would
certainly
draw
down
upon
him
a
storm
of
animosity
,
rendering
it
impossible
to
calculate
on
forbearance
in
the
creditors
,
or
on
unanimity
among
them
;
and
exposing
him
a
solitary
target
to
a
straggling
cross
-
fire
,
which
might
bring
him
down
from
half
-
a
-
dozen
quarters
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
To
all
this
Clennam
merely
replied
that
,
granting
the
whole
protest
,
nothing
in
it
lessened
the
force
,
or
could
lessen
the
force
,
of
the
voluntary
and
public
exoneration
of
his
partner
.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
,
once
and
for
all
,
requested
Mr
Rugg
's
immediate
aid
in
getting
the
business
despatched
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
that
,
Mr
Rugg
fell
to
work
;
and
Arthur
,
retaining
no
property
to
himself
but
his
clothes
and
books
,
and
a
little
loose
money
,
placed
his
small
private
banker's
-
account
with
the
papers
of
the
business
.
   
<EOS>
The
disclosure
was
made
,
and
the
storm
raged
fearfully
.
 
<EOS>
Thousands
of
people
were
wildly
staring
about
for
somebody
alive
to
heap
reproaches
on
;
and
this
notable
case
,
courting
publicity
,
set
the
living
somebody
so
much
wanted
,
on
a
scaffold
.
 
<EOS>
When
people
who
had
nothing
to
do
with
the
case
were
so
sensible
of
its
flagrancy
,
people
who
lost
money
by
it
could
scarcely
be
expected
to
deal
mildly
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Letters
of
reproach
and
invective
showered
in
from
the
creditors
;
and
Mr
Rugg
,
who
sat
upon
the
high
stool
every
day
and
read
them
all
,
informed
his
client
within
a
week
that
he
feared
there
were
writs
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
take
the
consequences
of
what
I
have
done
,
"
said
Clennam
.
<EOS>
"
The
writs
will
find
me
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
the
very
next
morning
,
as
he
was
turning
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
by
Mrs
Plornish
's
corner
,
Mrs
Plornish
stood
at
the
door
waiting
for
him
,
and
mysteriously
besought
him
to
step
into
Happy
Cottage
.
<EOS>
There
he
found
Mr
Rugg
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
'd
wait
for
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
go
on
to
the
Counting
-
house
this
morning
if
I
was
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
,
Mr
Rugg
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
as
many
as
five
out
,
to
my
knowledge
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
too
soon
over
,
"
said
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
them
take
me
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
getting
between
him
and
the
door
,
"
hear
reason
,
<EOS>
hear
reason
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
take
you
soon
enough
,
Mr
Clennam
,
I
do
n't
doubt
;
but
,
hear
reason
.
 
<EOS>
It
almost
always
happens
,
in
these
cases
,
that
some
insignificant
matter
pushes
itself
in
front
and
makes
much
of
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
find
there
's
a
little
one
out
---
a
mere
Palace
Court
jurisdiction
---
<EOS>
and
I
have
reason
to
believe
that
a
caption
may
be
made
upon
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
be
taken
upon
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
asked
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'd
be
taken
on
a
full
-
grown
one
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
as
well
to
keep
up
appearances
.
 
<EOS>
As
your
professional
adviser
,
I
should
prefer
your
being
taken
on
a
writ
from
one
of
the
Superior
Courts
,
if
you
have
no
objection
to
do
me
that
favour
.
 
<EOS>
It
looks
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Rugg
,
"
said
Arthur
,
in
his
dejection
,
"
my
only
wish
is
,
that
it
should
be
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
go
on
,
and
take
my
chance
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another
word
of
reason
,
sir
!
"
cried
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
this
is
reason
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
may
be
taste
;
but
this
is
reason
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
be
taken
on
a
little
one
,
sir
,
you
would
go
to
the
Marshalsea
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
know
what
the
Marshalsea
is
.
 
<EOS>
Very
close
.
 
<EOS>
Excessively
confined
.
 
<EOS>
Whereas
in
the
King
's
Bench
<EOS>
---
"
Mr
Rugg
waved
his
right
hand
freely
,
as
expressing
abundance
of
space
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
be
taken
to
the
Marshalsea
than
to
any
other
prison
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
say
so
indeed
,
sir
?
"
returned
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
this
is
taste
,
too
,
and
we
may
be
walking
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
offended
at
first
,
but
he
soon
overlooked
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
walked
through
the
Yard
to
the
other
end
.
 
<EOS>
The
Bleeding
Hearts
were
more
interested
in
Arthur
since
his
reverses
than
formerly
;
now
regarding
him
as
one
who
was
true
to
the
place
and
had
taken
up
his
freedom
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
them
came
out
to
look
after
him
,
and
to
observe
to
one
another
,
with
great
unctuousness
,
that
he
was
"
pulled
down
by
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Plornish
and
her
father
stood
at
the
top
of
the
steps
at
their
own
end
,
much
depressed
and
shaking
their
heads
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
visibly
in
waiting
when
Arthur
and
Mr
Rugg
arrived
at
the
Counting
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
an
elderly
member
of
the
Jewish
persuasion
,
preserved
in
rum
,
followed
them
close
,
and
looked
in
at
the
glass
before
Mr
Rugg
had
opened
one
of
the
day
's
letters
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
looking
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
?
 
<EOS>
Step
in
---
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
I
think
this
is
the
gentleman
I
was
mentioning
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
gentleman
explained
the
object
of
his
visit
to
be
"
a
tyfling
madder
ob
bithznithz
,
"
and
executed
his
legal
function
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
accompany
you
,
Mr
Clennam
?
"
asked
Mr
Rugg
politely
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
go
alone
,
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Be
so
good
as
send
me
my
clothes
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
in
a
light
airy
way
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
and
shook
hands
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
his
attendant
then
went
downstairs
,
got
into
the
first
conveyance
they
found
,
and
drove
to
the
old
gates
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
I
little
thought
,
Heaven
forgive
me
,
"
said
Clennam
to
himself
,
"
that
I
should
ever
enter
thus
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chivery
was
on
the
Lock
,
and
Young
John
was
in
the
Lodge
:
either
newly
released
from
it
,
or
waiting
to
take
his
own
spell
of
duty
.
<EOS>
Both
were
more
astonished
on
seeing
who
the
prisoner
was
,
than
one
might
have
thought
turnkeys
would
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
The
elder
Mr
Chivery
shook
hands
with
him
in
a
shame
-
faced
kind
of
way
,
and
said
,
"
I
do
n't
call
to
mind
,
sir
,
as
I
was
ever
less
glad
to
see
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
younger
Mr
Chivery
,
more
distant
,
did
not
shake
hands
with
him
at
all
;
he
stood
looking
at
him
in
a
state
of
indecision
<EOS>
so
observable
that
it
even
came
within
the
observation
of
Clennam
with
his
heavy
eyes
and
heavy
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
afterwards
,
Young
John
disappeared
into
the
jail
.
   
<EOS>
As
Clennam
knew
enough
of
the
place
to
know
that
he
was
required
to
remain
in
the
Lodge
a
certain
time
,
he
took
a
seat
in
a
corner
,
and
feigned
to
be
occupied
with
the
perusal
of
letters
from
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
They
did
not
so
engross
his
attention
,
but
that
he
saw
,
with
gratitude
,
how
the
elder
Mr
Chivery
kept
the
Lodge
clear
of
prisoners
;
how
he
signed
to
some
,
with
his
keys
,
not
to
come
in
,
how
he
nudged
others
with
his
elbows
to
go
out
,
and
how
he
made
his
misery
as
easy
to
him
as
he
could
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
was
sitting
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
floor
,
recalling
the
past
,
brooding
over
the
present
,
and
not
attending
to
either
,
when
he
felt
himself
touched
upon
the
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
by
Young
John
;
and
he
said
,
"
You
can
come
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
got
up
and
followed
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
gone
a
step
or
two
within
the
inner
iron
-
gate
,
Young
John
turned
and
said
to
him
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
a
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
got
you
one
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
heartily
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
turned
again
,
and
took
him
in
at
the
old
doorway
,
up
the
old
staircase
,
into
the
old
room
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
stretched
out
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Young
John
looked
at
it
,
looked
at
him
---
<EOS>
sternly
---
swelled
,
choked
,
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
find
I
ca
n't
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
thought
you
'd
like
the
room
,
and
here
it
is
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Surprise
at
this
inconsistent
behaviour
yielded
when
he
was
gone
<EOS>
(
he
went
away
directly
)
to
the
feelings
which
the
empty
room
awakened
in
Clennam
's
wounded
breast
,
and
to
the
crowding
associations
with
the
one
good
and
gentle
creature
who
had
sanctified
it
.
 
<EOS>
Her
absence
in
his
altered
fortunes
made
it
,
and
him
in
it
,
so
very
desolate
and
so
much
in
need
of
such
a
face
of
love
and
truth
,
that
he
turned
against
the
wall
to
weep
,
sobbing
out
,
as
his
heart
relieved
itself
,
"
O
my
Little
Dorrit
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
The
Pupil
of
the
Marshalsea
 
<EOS>
The
day
was
sunny
,
and
the
Marshalsea
,
with
the
hot
noon
striking
upon
it
,
was
unwontedly
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
Arthur
Clennam
dropped
into
a
solitary
arm
-
chair
,
itself
as
faded
as
any
debtor
in
the
jail
,
and
yielded
himself
to
his
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
unnatural
peace
of
having
gone
through
the
dreaded
arrest
,
and
got
there
,
---
the
first
change
of
feeling
which
the
prison
most
commonly
induced
,
and
from
which
dangerous
resting
-
place
so
many
men
had
slipped
down
to
the
depths
of
degradation
and
disgrace
by
so
many
ways
,
---
he
could
think
of
some
passages
in
his
life
,
almost
as
if
he
were
removed
from
them
into
another
state
of
existence
.
<EOS>
Taking
into
account
where
he
was
,
the
interest
that
had
first
brought
him
there
when
he
had
been
free
to
keep
away
,
and
the
gentle
presence
that
was
equally
inseparable
from
the
walls
and
bars
about
him
and
from
the
impalpable
remembrances
of
his
later
life
which
no
walls
or
bars
could
imprison
,
it
was
not
remarkable
that
everything
his
memory
turned
upon
should
bring
him
round
again
to
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
was
remarkable
to
him
;
not
because
of
the
fact
itself
,
but
because
of
the
reminder
it
brought
with
it
,
how
much
the
dear
little
creature
had
influenced
his
better
resolutions
.
   
<EOS>
None
of
us
clearly
know
to
whom
or
to
what
we
are
indebted
in
this
wise
,
until
some
marked
stop
in
the
whirling
wheel
of
life
brings
the
right
perception
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
comes
with
sickness
<EOS>
,
it
comes
with
sorrow
,
it
comes
with
the
loss
of
the
dearly
loved
,
it
is
one
of
the
most
frequent
uses
of
adversity
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
to
Clennam
in
his
adversity
,
strongly
and
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
I
first
gathered
myself
together
,
"
he
thought
,
"
and
set
something
like
purpose
before
my
jaded
eyes
,
whom
had
I
before
me
,
toiling
on
,
for
a
good
object
's
sake
,
without
encouragement
,
without
notice
,
against
ignoble
obstacles
that
would
have
turned
an
army
of
received
heroes
and
heroines
?
 
<EOS>
One
weak
girl
!
 
<EOS>
When
I
tried
to
conquer
my
misplaced
love
,
and
to
be
generous
to
the
man
who
was
more
fortunate
than
I
,
though
he
should
never
know
it
or
repay
me
with
a
gracious
word
,
in
whom
had
I
watched
patience
,
self
-
denial
,
self
-
subdual
,
charitable
construction
,
the
noblest
generosity
of
the
affections
?
 
<EOS>
In
the
same
poor
girl
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
,
a
man
,
with
a
man
's
advantages
and
means
and
energies
,
had
slighted
the
whisper
in
my
heart
,
that
if
my
father
had
erred
,
it
was
my
first
duty
to
conceal
the
fault
and
to
repair
it
,
what
youthful
figure
with
tender
feet
going
almost
bare
on
the
damp
ground
,
with
spare
hands
ever
working
,
with
its
slight
shape
but
half
protected
from
the
sharp
weather
,
would
have
stood
before
me
to
put
me
to
shame
?
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
always
as
he
sat
alone
in
the
faded
chair
,
thinking
.
 
<EOS>
Always
,
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Until
it
seemed
to
him
as
if
he
met
the
reward
of
having
wandered
away
from
her
,
and
suffered
anything
to
pass
between
him
and
his
remembrance
of
her
virtues
.
   
<EOS>
His
door
was
opened
,
and
the
head
of
the
elder
Chivery
was
put
in
a
very
little
way
,
without
being
turned
towards
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
off
the
Lock
,
Mr
Clennam
,
and
going
out
.
 
<EOS>
Can
I
do
anything
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Many
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
excuse
me
opening
the
door
,
"
said
Mr
Chivery
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
could
n't
make
you
hear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
knock
?
"
<EOS>
"
Half
-
a
-
dozen
times
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rousing
himself
,
Clennam
observed
that
the
prison
had
awakened
from
its
noontide
doze
,
that
the
inmates
were
loitering
about
the
shady
yard
,
and
that
it
was
late
in
the
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
thinking
for
hours
.
<EOS>
"
Your
things
is
come
,
"
said
Mr
Chivery
,
"
and
my
son
is
going
to
carry
'em
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
sent
'em
up
but
for
his
wishing
to
carry
'em
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
he
would
have
'em
himself
,
and
so
I
could
n't
send
'em
up
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
could
I
say
a
word
to
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
come
in
,
"
said
Arthur
;
for
Mr
Chivery
's
head
was
still
put
in
at
the
door
a
very
little
way
,
and
Mr
Chivery
had
<EOS>
but
one
ear
upon
him
,
instead
of
both
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
native
delicacy
in
Mr
Chivery
 
---
true
politeness
;
though
his
exterior
had
very
much
of
a
turnkey
about
it
,
and
not
the
least
of
a
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Chivery
,
without
advancing
;
<EOS>
"
it
's
no
odds
me
coming
in
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
,
do
n't
you
take
no
notice
of
my
son
(
if
you
'll
be
so
good
)
in
case

find
him
cut
up
anyways
difficult
.
<EOS>
My
son
has
a
"
art
,
and
my
son
's
"
art
is
in
the
right
place
.
 
<EOS>
Me
and
his
mother
knows
where
to
find
it
,
and
we
find
it
sitiwated
correct
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
mysterious
speech
,
Mr
Chivery
took
his
ear
away
and
shut
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
gone
ten
minutes
,
when
his
son
succeeded
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
your
portmanteau
,
"
he
said
to
Arthur
,
putting

carefully
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
kind
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
that
you
should
have
the
trouble
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
gone
before
it
came
to
that
;
but
soon
returned
,
saying
exactly
as
before
,
<EOS>
"
Here
's
your
black
box
:
"
which
he
also
put
down
with
care
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sensible
of
this
attention
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
we
may
shake
hands
now
,
Mr
John
.
"
   
<EOS>
Young
John
,
however
,
drew
back
,
turning
his
right
wrist
in
a
socket
made
of
his
left
thumb
and
middle
-
finger
and
said
as
he
had
said
at
first
,
"
I
do
n't
know
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
No
<EOS>
;
I
find
I
ca
n't
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
stood
regarding
the
prisoner
sternly
,
though
with
a
swelling
humour
in
his
eyes
that
looked
like
pity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
are
you
angry
with
me
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
and
yet
so
ready
to
do
me
these
kind
services
?
 
<EOS>
There
must
be
some
mistake
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
done
anything
to
occasion
it
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
mistake
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
,
turning
the
wrist
backwards
and
forwards
in
the
socket
,
for
which
it
was
rather
tight
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
mistake
,
sir
,
in
the
feelings
with
which
my
eyes
behold
you
at
the
present
moment
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
at
all
fairly
equal
to
your
weight
,
Mr
Clennam
---
which
I
am
not
;
and
if
you
were
n't
under
a
cloud
---
which
you
are
;
and
if
it
was
n't
against
all
rules
of
the
Marshalsea
---
which
it
is
;
those
feelings
are
such
,
that
they
would
stimulate
me
,
more
to
having
it
out
with
you
in
a
Round
on
the
present
spot
than
to
anything
else
I
could
name
.
"
<EOS>
Arthur
looked
at
him
for
a
moment
in
some
wonder
,
and
some
little
anger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
mistake
,
a
mistake
!
"
 
<EOS>
Turning
away
,
he
sat
down
with
a
heavy
sigh
in
the
faded
chair
again
.
   
<EOS>
Young
John
followed
him
with
his
eyes
,
and
,
after
a
short
pause
,
cried
out
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Freely
granted
,
"
said
Clennam
,
waving
his
hand
without
raising
his
sunken
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
worth
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
furniture
,
sir
,
"
said
Young
John
in
a
voice
of
mild
and
soft
explanation
,
"
belongs
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
the
habit
of
letting
it
out
to
parties
without
furniture
,
that
have
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
an't
much
,
but
it
's
at
your
service
.
 
<EOS>
Free
,
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
think
of
letting
you
have
it
on
any
other
terms
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
welcome
to
it
for
nothing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
raised
his
head
again
to
thank
him
,
and
to
say
he
could
not
accept
the
favour
.
 
<EOS>
John
was
still
turning
his
wrist
,
and
still
contending
with
himself
in
his
former
divided
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
between
us
?
"
said
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
decline
to
name
it
,
sir
,
"
returned
Young
John
,
suddenly
turning
loud
and
sharp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
's
the
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
looked
at
him
again
,
in
vain
,
for
an
explanation
of
his
behaviour
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
while
,
Arthur
turned
away
his
head
again
.
<EOS>
Young
John
said
,
presently
afterwards
,
with
the
utmost
mildness
:
   
<EOS>
"
The
little
round
table
<EOS>
,
sir
,
that
's
nigh
your
elbow
,
was
---
<EOS>
you
know
whose
---
I
need
n't
mention
him
---
he
died
a
great
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
I
bought
it
of
an
individual
that
he
gave
it
to
,
and
that
lived
here
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
individual
was
n't
any
ways
equal
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Most
individuals
would
find
it
hard
to
come
up
to
his
level
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
drew
the
little
table
nearer
,
rested
his
arm
upon
it
,
and
kept
it
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
may
not
be
aware
,
sir
,
"
said
Young
John
,
"
that
I
intruded
upon

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>
I

---
"
   
"

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Oblivious

<EOS>
The

;

<EOS>
Alone

.

<EOS>
Young

.

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
An
Appearance
in
the
Marshalsea
 
<EOS>
The
opinion
of
the
community
outside
the
prison
gates
bore
hard
on
Clennam
as
time
went
on
,
and
he
made
no
friends
among
the
community

.
 
<EOS>
Too

the

,
who
got
together
to

;
too

poor

of

;
he

own

,
and
was

.
 
<EOS>
Some
said
he
was
proud
;
some

;
some

,
for
that

was
a
poor

dog
who

.
 
<EOS>
The

were

of

,
but

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
It

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

;

inexperienced
and
sanguine
,
and
had
<EOS>
---
I
hope
you
'll
not
object
to
my
saying
---
some
simplicity
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Some
simplicity
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
felt
what
a
pity
it
was
,
and
I
went
out
of
my
way
to
hint
to
you
(
<EOS>
which
really
was
not
official
,
but
I
never
am
official
when
I
can
help
it
)
<EOS>
something
to
the
effect
that
if
I
were
you
,
I
would
n't
bother
myself
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
you
did
bother
yourself
,
and
you
have
since
bothered
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
do
n't
do
it
any
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
likely
to
have
the
opportunity
,
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
You
'll
leave
here
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
leaves
here
.
<EOS>
There
are
no
ends
of
ways
of
leaving
here
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
do
n't
come
back
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
That
entreaty
is
the
second
object
of
my
call
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
do
n't
come
back
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
honour
,
"
said
Ferdinand
in
a
very
friendly
and
confiding
way
,
"
I
shall
be
greatly
vexed
if
you
do
n't
take
warning
by
the
past
and
keep
away
from
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
the
invention
?
"
said
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
good
fellow
,
"
returned
Ferdinand
,
"
if
you
'll
excuse
the
freedom
of
that
form
of
address
,
nobody
wants
to
know
of
the
invention
,
and
nobody
cares
twopence
-
halfpenny
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
in
the
Office
,
that
is
to
say
?
"
   
"
Nor
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
is
ready
to
dislike
and
ridicule
any
invention
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
no
idea
how
many
people
want
to
be
left
alone
.
   
<EOS>
You
have
no
idea
how
the
Genius
of
the
country
(
overlook
the
Parliamentary
nature
of
the
phrase
,
and
do
n't
be
bored
by
it
<EOS>
)
tends
to
being
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Believe
me
,
Mr
Clennam
,
"
said
the
sprightly
young
Barnacle
in
his
pleasantest
manner
,
"
our
place
is
not
a
wicked
Giant
to
be
charged
at
full
tilt
;
but
only
a
windmill
showing
you
,
as
it
grinds
immense
quantities
of
chaff
,
which
way
the
country
wind
blows
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
believe
that
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
it
would
be
a
dismal
prospect
for
all
of
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
Do
n't
say
so
!
"
returned
Ferdinand
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
humbug
,
we
all
like
humbug
,
we
could
n't
get
on
without
humbug
.
   
<EOS>
A
little
humbug
,
and
a
groove
,
and
everything
goes
on
admirably
,
if
you
leave
it
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
hopeful
confession
of
his
faith
as
the
head
of
the
rising
Barnacles
who
were
born
of
woman
,
to
be
followed
under
a
variety
of
watchwords
which
they
utterly
repudiated
and
disbelieved
,
Ferdinand
rose
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
agreeable
than
his
frank
and
courteous
bearing
,
or
adapted
with
a
more
gentlemanly
instinct
to
the
circumstances
of
his
visit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
fair
to
ask
,
"
he
said
,
as
Clennam
gave
him
his
hand
with
a
real

thankfulness
for
his
candour
and
good
-
humour
,
"
whether
it
is
true
that
our
late
lamented
Merdle
is
the
cause
of
this
passing
inconvenience
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
one
of
the
many
he
has
ruined
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
been
an
exceedingly
clever
fellow
,
"
said
Ferdinand
Barnacle
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
,
not
being
in
the
mood
to
extol
the
memory
of
the
deceased
,
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
consummate
rascal
,
of
course
,
"
said
Ferdinand
,
"
but
remarkably
clever
!
 
<EOS>
One
can
not
help
admiring
the
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Must
have
been
such
a
master
of
humbug
.
 
<EOS>
Knew
people
so
well
---
got
over
them
so
completely
---
did
so
much
with
them
!
"
 
<EOS>
In
his
easy
way
,
he
was
really
moved
to
genuine
admiration
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Arthur
,
"
that
he
and
his
dupes
may
be
a
warning
to
people
not
to
have
so
much
done
with
them
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Clennam
,
"
returned
Ferdinand
,
laughing
,
"
<EOS>
have
you
really
such
a
verdant
hope
?
 
<EOS>
The
next
man
who
has
as
large
a
capacity
and
as
genuine
a
taste
for
swindling
,
will
succeed
as
well
.
 
<EOS>
Pardon
me
,
<EOS>
but
I
think
you
really
have
no
idea
how
the
human
bees
will
swarm
to
the
beating
of
any
old
tin
kettle
;
in
that
fact
lies
the
complete
manual
of

.
 
<EOS>
When

can

got

that
the

made
of
the

,
in
that

whole

of

.
 
<EOS>
No

are
here
and

,
"
said

"

,

;

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
Good

!
 
<EOS>
I
hope

,
next
,
this

will

.
 
<EOS>
Do

come
a

beyond
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
the
way
out

.
 
<EOS>
Good
day
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With

words
,
the
best
and
brightest
of
the
Barnacles
went
down
-
stairs
,
hummed

the
Lodge
,
mounted
his
horse
in
the
front
court
-

,
and
rode

to
keep
an
appointment
with
his
noble
kinsman
,
who
wanted
a
little
coaching
before
he
could
triumphantly
answer
certain
infidel
Snobs
who
were
going
to
question
the
Nobs
about
their

.
   
<EOS>
He
must

passed
Mr
Rugg
on

,
for
,
a

afterwards
,
that
ruddy
-

shone
in
at

,
like

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
to
-

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

I

do

-

,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
thank

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
's
enjoyment
of

was
like
a

's

in
pickling
and

,
or

's

,

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
still

,

,

,
"

,

,
"
to

Detainers

.
 
<EOS>
They
have
fallen

,

;
as

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

:

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

,
"

Rugg
,
"
as
we

reasonably

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
when

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
As

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
 
<EOS>
Public

,

<EOS>
,
"
said

Rugg
,
"
has

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

the
Bench
is
almost

,
and
if

general

is

that

,
why
---
really
---
"
   
"
I

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
But
is
it
good
taste
,
is
it
good

?
 
<EOS>
That
's

Question
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
was
so
soothingly

as
to
be
quite
pathetic
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
almost
going
to
say
,
is
it
good
feeling
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
an
extensive
affair
of
yours
;
and
your

here
where
a
man
can
come
for
a
pound
or
two
,
is
remarked
upon
as
not
in
keeping
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
in
keeping
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
tell
you
,
sir
,
in
how
many
quarters
I
heard
it

.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
comments
made
upon

last
night
in
a
Parlour
frequented
by
what
I
should
call
,
if
I

there
now

myself
,
the
best
legal
company
---
I
heard
,
there
,
comments
on

that
I

.
 
<EOS>
They
hurt
me
on
your

.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
only
this
morning
at

.
 
<EOS>
My
daughter
(
but
a
woman
,
you
'll
say
:
yet

a

,
and

,
as
the
plaintiff
in
Rugg
and
Bawkins
)

her
great

;
her
great

.
   
<EOS>
Now
under

,
and
considering
that
none

us
can

above

,
would
n't
a

that

be
---
 
Come
,

,
"
said
Rugg
,
"
I
will

it
on
the

,
and

,
amiable
?
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
's
thoughts
had
once
more
wandered
away
to
Little
Dorrit
,
and
the
question
remained

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
myself
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
hoping

had
reduced

indecision
<EOS>
,
"
it
is
a
principle
of
mine
not
to
consider
myself
when
a
client
's

are
in
the
scale
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
knowing
your
considerate
character
and
general

to

,
I
will
repeat
that
I
should
prefer
your

in

Bench
.
   
<EOS>
Your
case
has
made
a
noise
;
it
is
a

to
be
professionally

in
;
I
should
feel

a

with

,

Bench
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
that
influence
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
merely
state
the
fact
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
So
errant
had
the
prisoner
's
attention
already
grown
in

and
dejection
,
and
so
accustomed
had
it
become
to
commune
with
only
one

within
the

-

,
that
Clennam
had
to

a
kind

before

could

,
recall

of
his

,
and
hurriedly

,
"
I
am
unchanged
,
and
unchangeable
,
in
my
decision
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
let
it
be
;
let
it
be
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
,
without
concealing
that
he
was
nettled
and
mortified
,
replied
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Beyond
a
doubt
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
travelled
out
of
the
record
,
sir
,
I
am
aware
,
in
putting
the
point
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
really
,
when
I
herd
it
remarked
in
several
companies
,
and
in
very
good
company
,
that
however
worthy
of
a
foreigner
,
it
is
not
worthy
of
the
spirit
of
an
Englishman
to
remain
in
the
Marshalsea
when
the
glorious

of
his
island
home
admit
of
his

to
the
Bench
,
I
thought
I
would
depart
from
the
narrow
professional
line
marked
out
to
me
,
and
mention
it
.
 
<EOS>
Personally
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
"
<EOS>
I
have
no
opinion
on
the
topic
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
,
"
returned
Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
None
at
all
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
,
I
should
have
been
   
unwilling
,
some
minutes
ago
,
to
see
a
client
of
mine
visited
in
this
place
by
a
gentleman
of
a
high
family
riding
a
saddle
-
horse
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
,
I
might
have
wished
to
be
now
empowered
to
mention
to
another
gentleman
,
a
gentleman
of
military
   
exterior
at
present
waiting
in
the
Lodge
,
that
my
client
had
never
intended
to
remain
here
,
and
was
on
the
eve
of
removal
to
a
superior

.
 
<EOS>
But
my
course
as
a
professional
machine
is
clear
;
I
have
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
your
good
pleasure
to
see
the
gentleman
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
waiting
to
see
me
,
did
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
take
that
unprofessional
liberty
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Hearing
that
I
was
your
professional
adviser
,
he
declined
to
interpose
before
my
very
limited
function
was
performed
.
 
<EOS>
Happily
,
"
said
Mr
Rugg
,
with
sarcasm
,
"
I
did
not
so
far
travel
out
of
the
record
as
to
ask
the
gentleman
for
his
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
have
no
resource
but
to
see
him
,
"
sighed
Clennam
,
wearily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
it
IS
your
good
pleasure
,
sir
?
"
retorted
Rugg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Am
I
honoured
by
your
instructions
to
mention
as
much
to
the
gentleman
,
as
I
pass
out
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
?
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
my
leave
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His
leave
<EOS>
he
took
accordingly
,
in
dudgeon
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
of
military
exterior
had
so
imperfectly
awakened
Clennam
's
curiosity
,
in
the
existing
state
of
his
mind
,
that
a
half
-
forgetfulness
of
such
a
visitor
's
having
been
referred
to
,
was
already
creeping
over
it
as
a
part
of
the
sombre
veil
which
almost
always
dimmed
it
now
,
when
a
heavy
footstep
on
the
stairs
aroused
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
ascend
them
,
not
very
promptly
or
spontaneously
,
yet
with
a
display
of
stride
and
clatter
meant
to
be
insulting
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
paused
for
a
moment
on
the
landing
outside
his
door
,
he
could
not
recall
his
association
with
the
peculiarity
of
its
sound
,
though
he
thought
he
had
one
.
 
<EOS>
Only
a
moment
was
given
him
for
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
His
door
was
immediately
swung
open
by
a
thump
,
and
in
the
doorway
stood
the
missing
Blandois
,
the
cause
of
many
anxieties
.
   
<EOS>
"
Salve
,
fellow
jail
-
bird
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
want
me
,
it
seems
.
 
<EOS>
Here
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
Before
Arthur
could
speak
to
him
in
his
indignant
wonder
,
Cavalletto
followed
him
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
followed
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
of
the
two
had
been
there
since
its
present
occupant
had
had
possession
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
breathing
hard
,
sidled
near
the
window
,
put
his
hat
on
the
ground
,
stirred
his
hair
up
with
both
hands
,
and
folded
his
arms
,
like
a
man
who
had
come
to
a
pause
in
a
hard
day
's
work
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
never
taking
his
eyes
from
his
dreaded
chum
of
old
,
softly
sat
down
on
the
floor
with
his
back
against
the
door
and
one
of
his
ankles
in
each
hand
:
<EOS>
resuming
the
attitude
(
except
that
it
was
now
expressive
of
unwinking
watchfulness
)
in
which
he
had
sat
before
the
same
man
in
the
deeper
shade
of
another
prison
,
one
hot
morning
at
Marseilles
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
it
on
the
witnessing
of
these
two
madmen
,
"
said
Monsieur
Blandois
,
otherwise
Lagnier
,
otherwise
Rigaud
,
"
that
you
want
me
,
brother
-
bird
.
 
<EOS>
Here
I
am
!
"
<EOS>
Glancing
round
contemptuously
at
the
bedstead
,
which
was
turned
up
by
day
,
he
leaned
his
back
against
it
as
a
resting
-
place
,
without
removing
his
hat
from
his
head
,
and
stood
defiantly
lounging
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
villain
of
ill
-
omen
!
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
purposely
cast
a
dreadful
suspicion
upon
my
mother
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
Why
have
you
done
it
?
   
<EOS>
What
prompted
you
to
the
devilish
invention
?
"
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
after
frowning
at
him
for
a
moment
,
laughed
.
<EOS>
"
Hear
this
noble
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
Listen
,
all
the
world
,
to
this
creature
of
Virtue
!
 
<EOS>
But
take
care
,
take
care
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
possible
,
my
friend
,
that
your
ardour
is
a
little
compromising
.
 
<EOS>
Holy
Blue
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
possible
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Signore
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Cavalletto
,
also
addressing
Arthur
:
"
for
to
commence
,
hear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
received
your
instructions
to
find
him
,
Rigaud
;
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
truth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
go
,
consequentementally
,
"
---
it
would
have
given
Mrs
Plornish
great
concern
if
she
could
have
been
persuaded
that
his
occasional
lengthening
of
an
adverb
in
this
way
,
was
the
chief
fault
of
his
English
,
---
"
first
among
my
countrymen
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
them
what
news
in
Londra
,
of
foreigners
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
go
among
the
French
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
go
among
the
Germans
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
part
of
us
know
well
<EOS>
the
other
,
and
they
all
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
!
<EOS>
---
no
person
can
tell
me
nothing
of
him
,
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
Fifteen
times
,
"
said
Cavalletto
,
thrice
throwing
out
his
left
hand
with
all
its
fingers
spread
,
and
doing
it
so
rapidly
that
the
sense
of
sight
could
hardly
follow
the
action
,
"
I
ask
of
him
in
every
place
where
go
the
foreigners
;
and
fifteen
times
,
"
repeating
the
same
swift
performance
,
"
they
know
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
But
!
---
"
At
this
significant
Italian
rest
on
the
word
"
But
,
"
his
backhanded
shake
of
his
right
forefinger
came
into
play
;
a
very
little
,
and
very
cautiously
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
After
a
long
time
when
I
have
not
been
able
to
find
that
he
is
here
in
Londra
,
some
one
tells
me
of
a
soldier
with
white
hair
---
hey
?
---
not
hair
like
this
that
he
carries
---
white
---
who
lives
retired
secrettementally
,
in
a
certain
place
.
 
<EOS>
But
!
---
"
with
another
rest
upon
the
word
,
"
who
sometimes
in
the
after
-
dinner
,
walks
,
and
smokes
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
necessary
,
as
they
say
in
Italy
(
and
as
they
know
,
poor
people
)
,
to
have
patience
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
patience
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
where
is
this
certain
place
.
 
<EOS>
One
.
 
<EOS>
believes
it
is
here
<EOS>
,
one
believes
it
is
there
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
well
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
here
,
it
is
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
wait
patientissamentally
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
find
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
watch
;
then
I
hide
,
until
he
walks
and
smokes
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
soldier
with
grey
hair
---
<EOS>
But
!
---
"
a
very
decided
rest
indeed
,
and
a
very
vigorous
play
from
side
to
side
of
the
back
-
handed
forefinger
---
"
he
is
also
this
man
that
you
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
noticeable
,
that
,
in
his
old
habit
of
submission
to
one
who
had
been
at
the
trouble
of
asserting
superiority
over
him
,
he
even
then
bestowed
upon
Rigaud
a

,
after
thus

.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
well
,
Signore
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
in

,
addressing
Arthur
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
waited
for
a
good
opportunity
.
 
<EOS>
I
writed
some
words
to
Signor
Panco
,
"
an
air
of
novelty
came
over
Mr
Pancks
with
this

,
"
to
come
and
help
.
 
<EOS>
I
showed
him
,
Rigaud
,
at
his
window
,
to
Signor
Panco
,
who
was
often
the
spy
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
slept
at
night
near
the
door
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
we
entered
,
<EOS>
only
this
to
-
day
,
and
now
you
see
him
!
 
<EOS>
As
he
would
not
come
up
in
presence
of
the
illustrious
Advocate
,
"
such
was
Mr
Baptist
's
honourable
mention
of
Mr
Rugg
,
"
we
waited
down
below
there
,
together
,
and
Signor
Panco
guarded
the
street
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
this
recital
,
Arthur
turned
his
eyes
upon
the
impudent
and
wicked
face
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
met
his
,
the
nose
came
down
over
the
moustache
and
the
moustache
went
up
under
the
nose
.
 
<EOS>
When
nose
and
moustache
had
settled
into
their
places
again
,
Monsieur
Rigaud
loudly
snapped
his
fingers
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
;
bending
forward
to
jerk
the
snaps
at
Arthur
,
as
if
they
were
palpable
missiles
which
he
jerked
into
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Philosopher
!
"
said
Rigaud
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
,
"
returned
Arthur
,
without
disguising
his
abhorrence
,
"
<EOS>
how
you
dare
direct
a
suspicion
of
murder
against
my
mother
's
house
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dare
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ho
,
ho
!
 
<EOS>
Hear
him
!
 
<EOS>
Dare
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
dare
?
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
my
small
boy
,
but
you
are
a
little
imprudent
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
that
suspicion
to
be
cleared
away
,
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
be
taken
there
,
and
be
publicly
seen
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
<EOS>
,
moreover
,
what
business
you
had
there
when
I
had
a
burning
desire
to
fling
you
down
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
frown
at
me
,
man
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
enough
of
you
to
know
that
you
are
a
bully
and
coward
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
no
revival
of
my
spirits
from
the
effects
of
this
wretched
place
to
tell
you
so
plain
a
fact
,
and
one
that
you
know
<EOS>
so
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
White
to
the
lips
<EOS>
,
Rigaud
stroked
his
moustache
,
muttering
,
"
By
Heaven
,
my
small
boy
,
but
you
are
a
little
compromising
of
my
lady
,
your
respectable
mother
"
---
and
seemed
for
a
minute
undecided
how
to
act
.
 
<EOS>
His
indecision
was
soon
gone
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
himself
down
with
a
threatening
swagger
,
and
said
:
   
"
Give
me
a
bottle
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
buy
wine
here
.
 
<EOS>
Send
one
of
your
madmen
to
get
me
a
bottle
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
talk
to
you
without
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
or
no
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Fetch
him
what
he
wants
,
Cavalletto
,
"
said
Arthur
,
scornfully
,
producing
the
money
.
   
<EOS>
"
Contraband
beast
,
"
added
Rigaud
,
"
bring
Port
wine
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
drink
nothing
but
Porto
-
Porto
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
contraband
beast
,
however
,
assuring
all
present
,
with
his
significant
finger
,
that
he
peremptorily
declined
to
leave
his
post
at
the
door
,
Signor
Panco
offered
his
services
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
with
the
bottle
of
wine
:
which
,
according
to
the
custom
of
the
place
,
originating
in
a
scarcity
of
corkscrews
among
the
Collegians
(
in
common
with
a
scarcity
of
much
else
)
,
was
already
opened
for
use
.
   
<EOS>
"
Madman
!
 
<EOS>
A
large
glass
,
"
said
Rigaud
.
   
<EOS>
Signor
Panco
put
a
tumbler
before
him
;
not
without
a
visible
conflict
of
feeling
on
the
question
of
throwing
it
at
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
"
boasted
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
a
gentleman
,
and
always
a
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
A
gentleman
from
the
beginning
,
and
a
gentleman
to
the
end
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
Devil
!
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
must
be
waited
on
,
I
hope
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
part
of
my
character
to
be
waited
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
half
filled
the
tumbler
as
he
said
it
,
and
drank
off
the
contents
when
he
had
done
saying
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
<EOS>
"
smacking
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
very
old
prisoner
that
!
 
<EOS>
I
judge
by
your
looks
,
brave
sir
,
that
imprisonment
will
subdue
your
blood
much
sooner
than
it
softens
this
hot
wine
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
mellowing
---
losing
body
and
colour
already
.
 
<EOS>
I
salute
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
tossed
off
another
half
glass
:
holding
it
up
both
before
and
afterwards
,
so
as
to
display
his
small
,
white
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
business
,
"
he
then
continued
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
shown
yourself
more
free
of
speech
than
body
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
used
the
freedom
of
telling
you
what
you
know
yourself
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
yourself
,
as
we
all
know
you
,
to
be
far
worse
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Add
,
always
a
gentleman
,
and
it
's
no
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Except
in
that
regard
,
we
are
all
alike
.
 
<EOS>
For
example
:
you
could
n't
for
your
life
be
a
gentleman
;
I
could
n't
for
my
life
be
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
How
great
the
difference
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
go
on
.
 
<EOS>
Words
,
sir
,
never
influence
the
course
of
the
cards
,
or
the
course
of
the
dice
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
?
 
<EOS>
You
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
also
play
a
game
,
and
words
are
without
power
over
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Now
that
he
was
confronted
with
Cavalletto
,
and
knew
that
his
story
was
known
---
whatever
thin
disguise
he
had
worn
,
he
dropped
;
and
faced
it
out
,
with
a
bare
face
,
as
the
infamous
wretch
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
son
<EOS>
,
"
he
resumed
,
with
a
snap
of
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
play
my
game
to
the
end
in
spite
of
words
;
and
Death
of
my
Body
and
Death
of
my
Soul
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
win
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
to
know
why
I
played
this
little
trick
that
you
have
interrupted
?
 
<EOS>
Know
then
that
I
had
,
and
that
I
have
<EOS>
---
do
you
understand
me
?
 
<EOS>
have
---
a
commodity
to
sell
to
my
lady
your
respectable
mother
.
 
<EOS>
I
described
my
precious
commodity
,
and
fixed
my
price
.
 
<EOS>
Touching
the
bargain
,
your
admirable
mother
was
a
little
too
calm
,
too
stolid
,
too
immovable
and
statue
-
like
.
<EOS>
In
fine
,
your
admirable
mother
vexed
me
.
 
<EOS>
To
make
variety
in
my
position
,
and
to
amuse
myself
---
what
!
 
<EOS>
a
gentleman
must
be
amused
at
somebody
's
expense
!
<EOS>
---
I
conceived
the
happy
idea
of
disappearing
.
<EOS>
An
idea
,
see
you
,
that
your
characteristic
mother
and
my
Flintwinch
would
have
been
well
enough
pleased
to
execute
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Bah
,
bah
,
bah
,
do
n't
look
as
from
high
to
low
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
repeat
it
.
 
<EOS>
Well
enough
pleased
,
excessively
enchanted
,
and
with
all
their
hearts
ravished
.
 
<EOS>
How
strongly
will
you
have
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
threw
out
the
lees
of
his
glass
on
the
ground
,
so
that
they
nearly
spattered
Cavalletto
.
 
<EOS>
This
seemed
to
draw
his
attention
to
him
anew
.
 
<EOS>
He
set
down
his
glass
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
fill
it
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
born
to
be
served
.
 
<EOS>
Come
then
,
you
Cavalletto
,
and
fill
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
looked
at
Clennam
,
whose
eyes
were
occupied
with
Rigaud
,
and
,
seeing
no
prohibition
,
got
up
from
the
ground
,
and
poured
out
from
the
bottle
into
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
The
blending
,
as
he
did
so
,
of
his
old
submission
with
a
sense
of
something
humorous
;
the
striving
of
that
with
a
certain
smouldering
ferocity
,
which
might
have
flashed
fire
in
an
instant
(
as
the
born
gentleman
seemed
to
think
,
for
he
had
a
wary
eye
upon
him
)
;
and
the
easy
yielding
of
all
to
a
good
-
natured
,
careless
,
predominant
propensity
to
sit
down
on
the
ground
again
:
formed
a
very
remarkable
combination
of
character
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
happy
idea
,
brave
sir
,
"
Rigaud
resumed
after
drinking
,
"
was
a
happy
idea
for
several
reasons
.
 
<EOS>
It
amused
me
,
it
worried
your
dear
mama
and
my
Flintwinch
<EOS>
,
it
caused
you
agonies
(
my
terms
for
a
lesson
in
politeness
towards
a
gentleman
)
,
and
it
suggested
to
all
the
amiable
persons
interested
that
your
entirely
devoted
is
a
man
to
fear
.
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
he
is
a
man
to
fear
!
 
<EOS>
Beyond
this
;
it
might
have
restored
her
wit
to
my
lady
your
mother
---
might
,
under
the
pressing
little
suspicion
your
wisdom
has
recognised
,
have
persuaded
her
at
last
to
announce
,
covertly
,
in
the
journals
,
that
the
difficulties
of
a
certain
contract
would
be
removed
by
the
appearance
of
a
certain
important
party
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
yes
,
perhaps
no
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
,
you
have
interrupted
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
what
is
it
you
say
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Never
had
Clennam
felt
more
acutely
that
he
was
a
prisoner
in
bonds
,
than
when
he
saw
this
man
before
him
,
and
could
not
accompany
him
to
his
mother
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
undiscernible
difficulties
and
dangers
he
had
ever
feared
were
closing
in
,
when
he
could
not
stir
hand
or
foot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
my
friend
,
philosopher
,
man
of
virtue
,
Imbecile
,
what
you
will
;
perhaps
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
pausing
in
his
drink
to
look
out
of
his
glass
with
his
horrible
smile
,
"
you
would
have
done
better
to
leave
me
alone
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
At
least
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
you
are
known
to
be
alive
and
unharmed
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
you
can
not
escape
from
these
two
witnesses
;
and
they
can
produce
you
before
any
public
authorities
,
or
before
hundreds
of
people
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
will
not
produce
me
before
one
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
snapping
his
fingers
again
with
an
air
of
triumphant
menace
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
Devil
with
your
witnesses
!
 
<EOS>
To
the
Devil
with
your
produced
!
 
<EOS>
To
the
Devil
with
yourself
!
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
Do
I
know
what
I
know
,
for
that
?
 
<EOS>
Have
I
my
commodity
on
sale
,
for
that
?
 
<EOS>
Bah
,
poor
debtor
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
interrupted
my
little
project
.
 
<EOS>
Let
it
pass
.
 
<EOS>
How
then
?
 
<EOS>
What
remains
?
 
<EOS>
To
you
,
nothing
;
to
me
,
all
.
 
<EOS>
Produce
me
!
 
<EOS>
Is
that
what
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
I
will
produce
myself
,
only
too
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
Contrabandist
!
   
<EOS>
Give
me
pen
,
ink
,
and
paper
.
"
   
<EOS>
Cavalletto
got
up
again
as
before
,
and
laid
them
before
him
in
his
former
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
,
after
some
villainous
thinking
and
smiling
,
wrote
,
and
read
aloud
,
as
follows
:
   
"
To
MRS
CLENNAM
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wait
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Prison
of
the
Marshalsea
.
<EOS>
"
At
the
apartment
of
your
son
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Madam
,
---
I
am
in
despair
to
be
informed
to
-
day
by
our
prisoner
here
(
who
has
had
the
goodness
to
employ
spies
to
seek
me
,
living
for
politic
reasons
in
retirement
)
,
that
you
have
had
fears
for
my
safety
.
   
<EOS>
"
Reassure
yourself
,
dear
madam
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
well
<EOS>
,
I
am
strong
and
constant
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
greatest
impatience
I
should
fly
to
your
house
,
but
that
I
foresee
it
to
be
possible
,
under
the
circumstances
,
that
you
will
not
yet
have
quite
definitively
arranged
the
little
proposition
I
have
had
the
honour
to
submit
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
name
one
week
from
this
day
,
for
a
last
final
visit
on
my
part
;
when
you
will
unconditionally
accept
it
or
reject
it
,
with
its
train
of
consequences
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppress
my
ardour
to
embrace
you
and
achieve
this
interesting
business
,
in
order
that
you
may
have
leisure
to
adjust
its
details
to
our
perfect
mutual
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meanwhile
,
it
is
not
too
much
to
propose
(
our
prisoner
having
deranged
my
housekeeping
)
,
that
my
expenses
of
lodging
and
nourishment
at
an
hotel
shall
be
paid
by
you
.
"
<EOS>
Receive
,
dear
madam
,
the
assurance
of
my
highest
and
most
distinguished
consideration
,
                  
"
RIGAUD
BLANDOIS
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
friendships
to
that
dear
Flintwinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
kiss
the
hands
of
Madame
F.
"
   
When
he
had
finished
this
epistle
,
Rigaud
folded
it
and
tossed
it
with
a
flourish
at
Clennam
's
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hola
you
!
 
<EOS>
Apropos
of
producing
,
let
somebody
produce
that
at
its
address
,
and
produce
the
answer
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cavalletto
,
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
this
fellow
's
letter
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
,
Cavalletto
's
significant
finger
again
expressing
that
his
post
was
at
the
door
to
keep
watch
over
Rigaud
,
now
he
had
found
him
with
so
much
trouble
,
and
that
the
duty
of
his
post
was
to
sit
on
the
floor
backed
up
by
the
door
,
looking
at
Rigaud
and
holding
his
own
ankles
,
---
Signor
Panco
once
more
volunteered
.
 
<EOS>
His
services
being
accepted
,
Cavalletto
suffered
the
door
to
open
barely
wide
enough
to
admit
of
his
squeezing
himself
out
,
and
immediately
shut
it
on
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Touch
me
with
a
finger
,
touch
me
with
an
epithet
,
question
my
superiority
as
I
sit
here
drinking
my
wine
at
my
pleasure
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
"
and
I
follow
the
letter
and
cancel
my
week
's
grace
.
 
<EOS>
You
wanted
me
?
 
<EOS>
You
have
got
me
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
like
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
"
returned
Clennam
,
with
a
bitter
sense
of
his
helplessness
,
"
that
when
I
sought
you
,
I
was
not
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
the
Devil
with
you
and
your
prison
,
"
retorted
Rigaud
,
leisurely
,
as
he
took
from
his
pocket
a
case
containing
the
materials
for
making
cigarettes
,
and
employed
his
facile
hands
in
folding
a
few
for
present
use
;
"
I
care
for
neither
of
you
.
<EOS>
Contrabandist
!
 
<EOS>
A
light
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Cavalletto
got
up
,
and
gave
him
what
he
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
something
dreadful
in
the
noiseless
skill
of
his
cold
,
white
hands
,
with
the
fingers
lithely
twisting
about
and
twining
one
over
another
like
serpents
.
 
<EOS>
Clennam
could
not
prevent
himself
from
shuddering
inwardly
,
as
if
he
had
been
looking
on
at
a
nest
of
those
creatures
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hola
,
Pig
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rigaud
,
with
a
noisy
stimulating
cry
,
as
if
Cavalletto
were
an
Italian
horse
or
mule
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
The
infernal
old
jail
was
a
respectable
one
to
this
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
dignity
in
the
bars
and
stones
of
that
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
prison
for
men
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
?
<EOS>
Bah
!
 
<EOS>
A
hospital
for
imbeciles
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
smoked
his
cigarette
out
,
with
his
ugly
smile
so
fixed
upon
his
face
that
he
looked
as
though
he
were
smoking
with
his
drooping
beak
of
a
nose
,
rather
than
with
his
mouth
;
like
a
fancy
in
a
weird
picture
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
lighted
a
second
cigarette
at
the
still
burning
end
of
the
first
,
he
said
to
Clennam
:
   
<EOS>
"
One
must
pass
the
time
in
the
madman
's
absence
.
 
<EOS>
One
must
talk
.
<EOS>
One
ca
n't
drink
strong
wine
all
day
long
,
or
I
would
have
another
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
handsome
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Though
not
exactly
to
my
taste
,
still
,
by
the
Thunder
and
the
Lightning
!
 
<EOS>
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
I
felicitate
you
on
your
admiration
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
neither
know
nor
ask
,
"
said
Clennam
,
"
of
whom
you
speak
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Della
bella
Gowana
,
sir
,
as
they
say
in
Italy
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
Gowan
,
the
fair
Gowan
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
whose
husband
you
were
the
---
follower
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
?
 
<EOS>
Follower
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
insolent
.
 
<EOS>
The
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
sell
all
your
friends
?
"
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
took
his
cigarette
from
his
mouth
,
and
eyed
him
with
a
momentary
revelation
of
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
put
it
between
his
lips
again
,
as
he
answered
with
coolness
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
sell
anything
that
commands
a
price
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
your
lawyers
live
,
your
politicians
,
your
intriguers
,
your
men
of
the
Exchange
?
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
live
?
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
come
here
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
sold
no
friend
?
 
<EOS>
Lady
of
mine
!
 
<EOS>
I
rather
think
,
yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
turned
away
from
him
towards
the
window
,
and
sat
looking
out
at
the
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
Effectively
,
sir
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
"
Society
sells
itself
and
sells
me
:
and
I
sell
Society
.
 
<EOS>
I
perceive
you
have
acquaintance
with
another
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Also
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
A
strong
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
see
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
they
call
her
?
 
<EOS>
Wade
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
received
no
answer
,
but
could
easily
discern
that
he
had
hit
the
mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
went
on
,
"
that
handsome
lady
and
strong
spirit
addresses
me
in
the
street
,
and
I
am
not
insensible
.
 
<EOS>
I
respond
.
 
<EOS>
That
handsome
lady
and
strong
spirit
does
me
the
favour
to
remark
,
in
full
confidence
,
"
I
have
my
curiosity
,
and
I
have
my
chagrins
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
more
than
ordinarily
honourable
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
I
announce
myself
,
"
Madame
,
a
gentleman
from
the
birth
,
and
a
gentleman
to
the
death
;
but
NOT
more
than
ordinarily
honourable
.
 
<EOS>
I
despise
such
a
weak
fantasy
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
she
is
pleased
to
compliment
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
difference
between
you
and
the
rest
is
,
"
she
answers
,
"
that
you
say
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
For
she
knows
Society
.
 
<EOS>
I
accept
her
congratulations
with
gallantry
and
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
Politeness
and
little
gallantries
are
inseparable
from
my
character
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
makes
a
proposition
,
which
is
,
in
effect
,
that
she
has
seen
us
much
together
;
that
it
appears
to
her
that
I
am
for
the
passing
time
the
cat
of
the
house
,
the
friend
of
the
family
;
that
her
curiosity
and
her
chagrins
awaken
the
fancy
to
be
acquainted
with
their
movements
,
to
know
the
manner
of
their
life
,
how
the
fair
Gowana
is
beloved
,
how
the
fair
Gowana
is
cherished
,
and
so
on
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
rich
,
but
offers
such
and
such
little
recompenses
for
the
little
cares
and
derangements
of
such
services
;
and
I
graciously
---
to
do
everything
<EOS>
graciously
is
a
part
of
my
character
---
consent
to
accept
them
.
 
<EOS>
O
yes
!
 
<EOS>
So
goes
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
mode
.
"
   
<EOS>
Though
Clennam
's
back
was
turned
while
he
spoke
,
and
thenceforth
to
the
end
of
the
interview
,
he
kept
those
glittering
eyes
of
his
that
were
too
near
together
,
upon
him
,
and
evidently
saw
in
the
very
carriage
of
the
head
,
as
he
passed
with
his
braggart
recklessness
from
clause
to
clause
of
what
he
said
,
that
he
was
saying
nothing
which
Clennam
did
not
already
know
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whoof
!
 
<EOS>
The
fair
Gowana
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
lighting
a
third
cigarette
with
a
sound
as
if
his
lightest
breath
could
blow
her
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Charming
,
but
imprudent
!
 
<EOS>
For
it
was
not
well
of
the
fair
Gowana
to
make
mysteries
of
letters
from
old
lovers
,
in
her
bedchamber
on
the
mountain
,
that
her
husband
might
not
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
not
well
.
 
<EOS>
Whoof
!
 
<EOS>
The
Gowana
was
mistaken
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
earnestly
hope
,
"
cried
Arthur
aloud
,
"
that
Pancks
may
not
be
long
gone
,
for
this
man
's
presence
pollutes
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
But
he
'll
flourish
here
,
and
everywhere
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
with
an
exulting
look
and
snap
of
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
always
has
;
he
always
will
!
"
 
<EOS>
Stretching
his
body
out
on
the
only
three
chairs
in
the
room
besides
that
on
which
Clennam
sat
,
he
sang
,
smiting
himself
on
the
breast
as
the
gallant
personage
of
the
song
.
        
<EOS>
"
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
!
     
<EOS>
Who
passes
by
this
road
so
late
?
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
   
<EOS>
"
Sing
the
Refrain
,
pig
!
 
<EOS>
You
could
sing
it
once
,
in
another
jail
.
<EOS>
Sing
it
!
 
<EOS>
Or
,
by
every
Saint
who
was
stoned
to
death
,
I
'll
be
affronted
and
compromising
;
and
then
some
people
who
are
not
dead
yet
,
had
better
have
been
stoned
along
with
them
!
"
        
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
Compagnon
de
la
Majolaine
!
     
<EOS>
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
"
tis
the
flower
,
          
<EOS>
Always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
Partly
in
his
old
habit
of
submission
,
partly
because
his
not
doing
it
might
injure
his
benefactor
,
and
partly
because
he
would
as
soon
do
it
as
anything
else
,
Cavalletto
took
up
the
Refrain
this
time
.
<EOS>
Rigaud
laughed
,
and
fell
to
smoking
with
his
eyes
shut
.
   
<EOS>
Possibly
another
quarter
of
an
hour
elapsed
before
Mr
Pancks
's
step
was
heard
upon
the
stairs
,
but
<EOS>
the
interval
seemed
to
Clennam
insupportably
long
.
 
<EOS>
His
step
was
attended
by
another
step
;
and
when
Cavalletto
opened
the
door
,
he
admitted
Mr
Pancks
and
Mr
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
was
no
sooner
visible
,
than
Rigaud
rushed
at
him
and
embraced
him
boisterously
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
yourself
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
,
as
soon
as
he
could
disengage
himself
,
which
he
struggled
to
do
with
very
little
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
no
<EOS>
;
I
do
n't
want
any
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
in
reference
to
another
menace
of
attention
from
his
recovered
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
what
I
said
to
you
about
sleeping
dogs
and
missing
ones
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
come
true
,
you
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
as
imperturbable
as
ever
,
to
all
appearance
,
and
nodded
his
head
in
a
moralising
way
as
he
looked
round
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
the
Marshalsea
prison
for
debt
!
"
said
Mr
Flintwinch
.
"
<EOS>
Hah
!
 
<EOS>
you
have
brought
your
pigs
to
a
very
indifferent
market
,
Arthur
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
Arthur
had
patience
,
Rigaud
had
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
his
little
Flintwinch
,
with
fierce
playfulness
,
by
the
two
lapels
of
his
coat
,
and
cried
:
   
"
To
the
Devil
with
the
Market
,
to
the
Devil
with
the
Pigs
,
and
to
the
Devil
with
the
Pig
-
Driver
!
 
<EOS>
Now
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
the
answer
to
my
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
make
it
convenient
to
let
go
a
moment
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
,
"
<EOS>
I
'll
first
hand
Mr
Arthur
<EOS>
a
little
note
that
I
have
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
his
mother
's
maimed
writing
,
on
a
slip
of
paper
,
and
contained
only
these
words
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
is
enough
that
you
have
ruined
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Rest
contented
without
more
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
is
my
messenger
and
representative
.
 
<EOS>
Your
affectionate
MC
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
read
this
twice
,
in
silence
,
and
then
tore
it
to
pieces
.
<EOS>
Rigaud
in
the
meanwhile
stepped
into
a
chair
,
and
sat
himself
on
the
back
with
his
feet
upon
the
seat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Beau
Flintwinch
,
"
he
said
,
when
he
had
closely
watched
the
note
to
its
destruction
,
"
the
answer
to
my
letter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Clennam
did
not
write
,
Mr
Blandois
,
her
hands
being
cramped
,
and
she
thinking
it
as
well
to
send
it
verbally
by
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
screwed
this
out
of
himself
,
unwillingly
and
rustily
.
"
<EOS>
She
sends
her
compliments
,
and
says
she
does
n't
on
the
whole
wish
to
term
you
unreasonable
,
and
that
she
agrees
.
 
<EOS>
But
without
prejudicing
the
appointment
that
stands
for
this
day
week
.
"
   
<EOS>
Monsieur
Rigaud
,
after
indulging
in
a
fit
of
laughter
,
descended
from
his
throne
,
saying
,
"
Good
!
 
<EOS>
I
go
to
seek
an
hotel
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
,
there
his
eyes
encountered
Cavalletto
,
who
was
still
at
his
post
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Pig
,
"
he
added
,
"
I
have
had
you
for
a
follower
against
my
will
;
now
,
I
'll
have
you
against
yours
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
my
little
reptiles
<EOS>
,
I
am
born
to
be
served
.
 
<EOS>
I
demand
the
service
of
this
contrabandist
as
my
domestic
until
this
day
week
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
answer
to
Cavalletto
's
look
of
inquiry
,
Clennam
made
him
a
sign
to
go
;
but
he
added
aloud
,
"
unless
you
are
afraid
of
him
.
"
<EOS>
Cavalletto
replied
with
a
very
emphatic
finger
-
negative
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
master
,
I
am
not
afraid
of
him
,
when
I
no
more
keep
it
secrettementally
that
he
was
once
my
comrade
.
"
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
took
no
notice
of
either
remark
until
he
had
lighted
his
last
cigarette
and
was
quite
ready
for
walking
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Afraid
of
him
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
then
,
looking
round
upon
them
all
.
"
<EOS>
Whoof
!
 
<EOS>
My
children
,
my
babies
,
my
little
dolls
,
you
are
all
afraid
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
give
him
his
bottle
of
wine
here
;
you
give
him
meat
,
drink
,
and
lodging
there
;
you
dare
not
touch
him
with
a
finger
or
an
epithet
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
his
character
to
triumph
!
 
<EOS>
Whoof
!
   
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
king
's
knights
he
's
the
flower
,
And
he
's
always
gay
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
adaptation
of
the
Refrain
to
himself
,
he
stalked
out
of
the
room
closely
followed
by
Cavalletto
,
whom
perhaps
he
had
pressed
into
his
service
because
he
tolerably
well
knew
it
would
not
be
easy
to
get
rid
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
after
scraping
his
chin
,
and
looking
about
with
caustic
disparagement
of
the
Pig
-
Market
,
nodded
to
Arthur
,
and
followed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
still
penitent
and
depressed
,
followed
too
;
after
receiving
with
great
attention
a
secret
word
or
two
of
instructions
from
Arthur
,
and
whispering
back
that
he
would
see
this
affair
out
,
and
stand
by
it
to
the
end
.
   
<EOS>
The
prisoner
,
with
the
feeling
that
he
was
more
despised
,
more
scorned
and
repudiated
,
more
helpless
,
altogether
more
miserable
and
fallen
than
before
,
was
left
alone
again
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
A
Plea
in
the
Marshalsea
 
<EOS>
Haggard
anxiety
and
remorse
are
bad
companions
to
be
barred
up
with
.
 
<EOS>
Brooding
all
day
,
and
resting
very
little
indeed
at
night
,
will
not
arm
a
man
against
misery
.
 
<EOS>
Next
morning
,
Clennam
felt
that
his
health
was
sinking
,
as
his
spirits
had
already
sunk
and
that
the
weight
under
which
he
bent
was
bearing
him
down
.
   
<EOS>
Night
after
night
he
had
risen
from
his
bed
of
wretchedness
at
twelve
or
one
o'clock
,
and
had
sat
at
his
window
watching
the
sickly
lamps
in
the
yard
,
and
looking
upward
for
the
first
wan
trace
of
day
,
hours
before
it
was
possible
that
the
sky
could
show
it
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Now
when
the
night
came
,
he
could
not
even
persuade
himself
to
undress
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
burning
restlessness
set
in
,
an
agonised
impatience
of
the
prison
,
and
a
conviction
that
he
was
going
to
break
his
heart
and
die
there
,
which
caused
him
indescribable
suffering
.
 
<EOS>
His
dread
and
hatred
of
the
place
became
so
intense
that
he
felt
it
a
labour
to
draw
his
breath
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
sensation
of
being
stifled
sometimes
so
overpowered
him
,
that
he
would
stand
at
the
window
holding
his
throat
and
gasping
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
a
longing
for
other
air
,
and
a
yearning
to
be
beyond
the
blind
blank
wall
,
made
him
feel
as
if
he
must
go
mad
with
the
ardour
of
the
desire
.
   
<EOS>
Many
other
prisoners
had
had
experience
of
this
condition
before
him
,
and
its
violence
and
continuity
had
worn
themselves
out
in
their
cases
,
as
they
did
in
his
.
 
<EOS>
Two
nights
and
a
day
exhausted
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
back
by
fits
,
but
those
grew
fainter
and
returned
at
lengthening
intervals
.
 
<EOS>
A
desolate
calm
succeeded
;
and
the
middle
of
the
week
found
him
settled
down
in
the
despondency
of
low
,
slow
fever
.
   
<EOS>
With
Cavalletto
and
Pancks
<EOS>
away
,
he
had
no
visitors
to
fear
<EOS>
but
Mr
and
Mrs
Plornish
.
 
<EOS>
His
anxiety
,
in
reference
to
that
worthy
pair
,
was
that
they
should
not
come
near
him
;
for
,
in
the
morbid
state
of
his
nerves
,
he
sought
to
be
left
alone
,
and
spared
the
being
seen
so
subdued
and
weak
.
 
<EOS>
He
wrote
a
note
to
Mrs
Plornish
representing
himself
as
occupied
with
his
affairs
,
and
bound
by
the
necessity
of
devoting
himself
to
them
,
to
remain
for
a
time
even
without
the
pleasant
interruption
of
a
sight
of
her
kind
face
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Young
John
,
who
looked
in
daily
at
a
certain
hour
,
when
the
turnkeys
were
relieved
,
to
ask
if
he
could
do
anything
for
him
;
he
always
made
a
pretence
of
being
engaged
in
writing
,
and
to
answer
cheerfully
in
the
negative
.
 
<EOS>
The
subject
of
their
only
long
conversation
had
never
been
revived
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
Through
all
these
changes
of
unhappiness
,
however
,
it
had
never
lost
its
hold
on
Clennam
's
mind
.
   
<EOS>
The
sixth
day
of
the
appointed
week
was
a
moist
,
hot
,
misty
day
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
though
the
prison
's
poverty
,
and
shabbiness
,
and
dirt
,
were
growing
in
the
sultry
atmosphere
.
 
<EOS>
With
an
aching
head
and
a
weary
heart
,
Clennam
had
watched
the
miserable
night
out
,
listening
to
the
fall
of
rain
on
the
yard
pavement
,
thinking
of
its
softer
fall
upon
the
country
earth
.
 
<EOS>
A
blurred
circle
of
yellow
haze
had
risen
up
in
the
sky
in
lieu
of
sun
,
and
he
had
watched
the
patch
it
put
upon
his
wall
,
like
a
bit
of
the
prison
's
raggedness
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
heard
the
gates
open
;
and
the
badly
shod
feet
that
waited
outside
shuffle
in
;
and
the
sweeping
,
and
pumping
,
and
moving
about
,
begin
,
which
commenced
the
prison
morning
.
 
<EOS>
So
ill
and
faint
that
he
was
obliged
to
rest
many
times
in
the
process
of
getting
himself
washed
,
he
had
at
length
crept
to
his
chair
by
the
open
window
.
 
<EOS>
In
it
he
sat
dozing
,
while
the
old
woman
who
arranged
his
room
went
through
her
morning
's
work
.
   
<EOS>
Light
of
head
with
want
of
sleep
and
want
of
food
(
his
appetite
,
and
even
his
sense
of
taste
,
having
forsaken
him
)
<EOS>
,
he
had
been
two
or
three
times
conscious
,
in
the
night
,
of
going
astray
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
heard
fragments
of
tunes
and
songs
in
the
warm
wind
,
which
he
knew
had
no
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
he
began
to
doze
in
exhaustion
,
he
heard
them
again
;
and
voices
seemed
to
address
him
,
and
he
answered
,
and
started
.
   
<EOS>
Dozing
and
dreaming
,
without
the
power
of
reckoning
time
,
so
that
a
minute
might
have
been
an
hour
and
an
hour
<EOS>
a
minute
,
some
abiding
impression
of
a
garden
stole
over
him
---
a
garden
of
flowers
,
with
a
damp
warm
wind
gently
stirring
their
scents
.
 
<EOS>
It
required
such
a
painful
effort
to
lift
his
head
for
the
purpose
of
inquiring
into
this
,
or
inquiring
into
anything
,
that
the
impression
appeared
to
have
become
quite
an
old
and
importunate
one
when
he
looked
round
.
<EOS>
Beside
the
tea
-
cup
on
his
table
he
saw
,
then
,
a
blooming
nosegay
:
a
wonderful
handful
of
the
choicest
and
most
lovely
flowers
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
had
ever
appeared
so
beautiful
in
his
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
them
up
and
inhaled
their
fragrance
,
and
he
lifted
them
to
his
hot
head
,
and
he
put
them
down
and
opened
his
parched
hands
to
them
,
as
cold
hands
are
opened
to
receive
the
cheering
of
a
fire
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
had
delighted
in
them
for
some
time
,
that
he
wondered
who
had
sent
them
;
and
opened
his
door
to
ask
the
woman
who
must
have
put
them
there
,
how
they
had
come
into
her
hands
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
was
gone
,
and
seemed
to
have
been
long
gone
;
for
the
tea
she
had
left
for
him
on
the
table
was
cold
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
drink
some
,
but
could
not
bear
the
odour
of
it
:
so
he
crept
back
to
his
chair
by
the
open
window
,
and
put
the
flowers
on
the
little
round
table
of
old
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
first
faintness
consequent
on
having
moved
about
had
left
him
,
he
subsided
into
his
former
state
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
the
night
-
tunes
was
playing
in
the
wind
,
when
the
door
of
his
room
seemed
to
open
to
a
light
touch
,
and
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
a
quiet
figure
seemed
to
stand
there
,
with
a
black
mantle
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
draw
the
mantle
off
and
drop
it
on
the
ground
,
and
then
it
seemed
to
be
his
Little
Dorrit
in
her
old
,
worn
dress
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
tremble
,
and
to
clasp
its
hands
,
and
to
smile
,
and
to
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
He
roused
himself
,
and
cried
out
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
he
saw
,
in
the
loving
,
pitying
,
sorrowing
,
<EOS>
dear
face
,
as
in
a
mirror
,
how
changed
he
was
;
and
she
came
towards
him
;
and
with
her
hands
laid
on
his
breast
to
keep
him
in
his
chair
,
and
with
her
knees
upon
the
floor
at
his
feet
,
and
with
her
lips
raised
up
to
kiss
him
,
and
with
her
tears
dropping
on
him
as
the
rain
from
Heaven
had
dropped
upon
the
flowers
,
Little
Dorrit
,
a
living
presence
,
called
him
by
his
name
.
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
my
best
friend
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
do
n't
let
me
see
you
weep
!
<EOS>
Unless
you
weep
with
pleasure
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
Your
own
poor
child
come
back
!
"
<EOS>
So
faithful
,
tender
,
and
unspoiled
by
Fortune
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
sound
of
her
voice
,
in
the
light
of
her
eyes
,
in
the
touch
of
her
hands
,
so
Angelically
comforting
and
true
!
   
<EOS>
As
he
embraced
her
,
she
said
to
him
,
"
They
never
told
me
you
were
ill
,
"
and
drawing
an
arm
softly
round
his
neck
,
laid
his
head
upon
her
bosom
,
put
a
hand
upon
his
head
,
and
resting
her
cheek
upon
that
hand
,
nursed
him
as
lovingly
,
and
GOD
knows
as
innocently
,
as
she
had
nursed
her
father
in
that
room
when
she
had
been
but
<EOS>
a
baby
,
needing
all
the
care
from
others
that
she
took
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
could
speak
,
he
said
,
"
Is
it
possible
that
you
have
come
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
And
in
this
dress
?
"
   
"
I
hoped
you
would
like
me
better
in
this
dress
than
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
always
kept
it
by
me
,
to
remind

:
though
I
wanted
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
alone
,
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
brought
an
old
friend
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
saw
Maggy
in
her
big
cap
which
had
been
long
abandoned
,
with
a
basket
on
her
arm
as
in
the
bygone
days
,
chuckling

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
only
yesterday
evening
that
I
came
to
London
with
my
brother
.
 
<EOS>
I
sent
round
to
Mrs
Plornish
almost
as
soon
as
we
arrived
,
that
I
might
hear
of
you
and
let

I
had

.
<EOS>
Then
I
heard
that
you

here
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
happen

think

me
in

night
?
 
<EOS>
I
almost
believe
you
must
have
thought
of
me
a
little
.
<EOS>
I
thought
of
you
so

,
and
it
appeared
so
long
to
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
of
you
---
"
he
hesitated
what
to
call
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
perceived
it
in
an

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
spoken
to
me
by
my
right
name
yet
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
my
right
name
always
is
with

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
of
you
,
Little
Dorrit
,
every

,
every

,
every

,
since
I
have
been
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
saw
the
bright
delight
of
her
face
,
and
the
flush
that
kindled
in
it
,
with
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
He
,
a
broken
,

,
sick
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
here
before
the
gates
were
opened
,
but
I
was
afraid
to
come

to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
done
you
more
harm
than
good
,
at
first
;
for
the
prison
was
so
familiar
and
yet
so

,
and
it
brought
back
so
many
remembrances
of
my
poor
father
,
and
of
you
too
,
that
at
first
it
overpowered

.
 
<EOS>
But
we
went
to
Mr
Chivery
before
we
came
to
the
gate
,
and
he
brought

in
,
and
got
john
's
room
for
us
---
my
poor
old
room
,
you
know
---
<EOS>
and
we
waited
there
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
brought
the
flowers
to
the
door
,
but
you
did
n't
hear
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
looked
something
more
womanly
than
when
she
had
gone
away
,
and
the
ripening
touch
of
the
Italian
sun
was

upon

.
<EOS>
But
,
otherwise
,
she
was
quite

.
 
<EOS>
The
same
deep
,
timid
earnestness
that
he
had
always
seen
in
her
,
and
never
without
emotion
,
he
saw
still
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
a
new
meaning
that
smote
him
to
the
heart
,
the
change
was
in
his
perception
,
not
in
her
.
   
<EOS>
She
took
off
her
old
bonnet
,
hung
it
in
the
old
place
,
and
noiselessly
began
,
with
Maggy
's
help
,
to
make
his
room
as
fresh
and
neat
as
it
could
be

,
and
to
sprinkle
it
with
a
pleasant
-
smelling
water
.
 
<EOS>
When
that
was
done
,
the
basket
,
which
was
filled
with
grapes
and
other
fruit
,
was
unpacked
,
and
all
its
contents
were
quietly
put
away
.
 
<EOS>
When
that
was
done
,
a
moment
's
whisper
despatched
Maggy
to
despatch
somebody
else
to
fill
the
basket
again
;
which
soon
came
back
replenished
with
new
stores
,
from
which
a
present
provision
of
cooling
drink
and
jelly
,
and
a
prospective

of
roast
chicken
and
wine
and
water
,
were
the
first
extracts
.
 
<EOS>
These
various
arrangements
completed
,
she
took
out
her
old
needle
-
case
to
make
him
a
curtain
for
his
window
;
and
thus
,
with
a
quiet
reigning
in
the
room
,
that
seemed
to
diffuse
itself
through
the
else
noisy
prison
,
he
found
himself
composed
in
his
chair
,
with
Little
Dorrit
working
at
his
side
.
   
<EOS>
To
see
the
modest
head
again
bent
down
over
its
task
,
and
the
nimble
fingers
busy
at
their
old
work
---
though
she
was
not
so
absorbed
in
it
,
but
that
her
compassionate
eyes
were
often
raised
to
his
face
,
and
,
when
they
drooped
again
had
tears
in
them
---
to
be
so
consoled
and
comforted
,
and
to
believe
that
all
the
devotion
of
this
great
nature
was
turned
to
him
in
his
adversity
to
pour
out
its
inexhaustible
wealth
of
goodness
upon
him
,
did
not
steady
Clennam
's
trembling
voice
or
hand
,
or
strengthen
him
in
his
weakness
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
inspired
him
with
an
inward
fortitude
,
that
rose
with
his
love
.
 
<EOS>
And
how
dearly
he
loved
her
now
,
what
words
can
tell
!
   
<EOS>
As
they
sat
side
by
side
in
the
shadow
of
the
wall
,
the
shadow
fell
like
light
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
not
let
him
speak
much
,
and
he
lay
back
in
his
chair
,
looking
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
Now
and
again
she
would
rise
and
give
him
the
glass
that
he
might
drink
,
or
would
smooth
the
resting
-
place
of
his
head
;
then
she
would
gently
resume
her
seat
by
him
,
and
bend
over
her
work
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
shadow
moved
with
the
sun
,
but
she
never
moved
from
his
side
,
except
to
wait
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
went
down
and
she
was
still
there
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
done
her
work
now
,
and
her
hand
,
faltering
on
the
arm
of
his
chair
since
its
last
tending
of
him
,
was
hesitating
there
yet
.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
his
hand
upon
it
,
and
it
clasped
him
with
a
trembling
supplication
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
I
must
say
something
to
you
before
I
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
put
it
off
from
hour
to
hour
,
but
I
must
say
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
too
,
dear
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
put
off
what
I
must
say
.
<EOS>
"
She
nervously
moved
her
hand
towards
his
lips
as
if
