stop
him
;
then
it
dropped
,
trembling
,
into
its
former
place
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
going
abroad
again
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
is
,
but
I
am
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
attached
to
me
,
and
he
is
so
grateful
to
me
now
---
so
much
too
grateful
,
for
it
is
only
because
I
happened
to
be
with
him
in
his
illness
---
that
he
says
I
shall
be
free
to
stay
where
I
like
best
,
and
to
do
what
I
like
best
.
 
<EOS>
He
only
wishes
me
to
be
happy
,
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
   
There
was
one
bright
star
shining
in
the
sky
.
 
<EOS>
She
looked
up
at
it
While
she
spoke
,
as
if
it
were
the
fervent
purpose
of
her
own
heart
shining
above
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
understand
,
I
dare
say
,
without
my
telling
you
,
that
my
brother
has
come
home
to
find
my
dear
father
's
will
,
and
to
take
possession
of
his
property
.
 
<EOS>
He
says
,
if
there
is
a
will
,
he
is
sure
i
shall
be
left
rich
;
and
if
there
is
none
,
that
he
will
make
me
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
have
spoken
;
but
she
put
up
her
trembling
hand
again
,
and
he
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
use
for
money
,
I
have
no
wish
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
of
no
value
at
all
to
me
but
for
your
sake
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
be
rich
,
and
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
always
be
much
worse
than
poor
,
with
you
distressed
.
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
lend
you
all
I
have
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
give
it
you
?
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
show
you
that
I
have
never
forgotten
,
that
I
never
can
forget
,
your
protection
of
me
when
this
was
my
home
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Clennam
,
make
me
of
all
the
world
the
happiest
,
by
saying
Yes
.
<EOS>
Make
me
as
happy
as
I
can
be
in
leaving
you
here
,
by
saying
nothing
to
-
night
,
and
letting
me
go
away
with
the
hope
that
you
will
think
of
it
kindly
;
and
that
for
my
sake
---
not
for
yours
,
for
mine
,
for
nobody
's
but
mine
!
<EOS>
---
you
will
give
me
the
greatest
joy
I
can
experience
on
earth
,
the
joy
of
knowing
that
I
have
been
serviceable
to
you
,
and
that
I
have
paid
some
little
of
the
great
debt
of
my
affection
and
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
what
I
wish
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
visit
you
here
where
I
have
lived
so
long
<EOS>
,
I
ca
n't
think
of
you
here
where
I
have
seen
so
much
,
and
be
as
calm
and
comforting
as
I
ought
.
 
<EOS>
My
tears
will
make
their
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
keep
them
back
.
 
<EOS>
But
pray
,
pray
,
pray
,
do
not
turn
from
your
Little
Dorrit
,
now
,
in
your
affliction
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
,
pray
,
I
beg
you
and
implore
you
with
all
my
grieving
heart
,
my
friend
---
my
dear
!
<EOS>
---
take
all
I
have
,
and
make
it
a
Blessing
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
star
had
shone
on
her
face
until
now
,
when
her
face
sank
upon
his
hand
and
her
own
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
grown
darker
when
he
raised
her
in
his
encircling
arm
,
and
softly
answered
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
darling
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
my
child
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
not
hear
of
such
a
sacrifice
.
 
<EOS>
Liberty
and
hope
would
be
so
dear
,
bought
at
such
a
price
,
that
I
could
never
support
their
weight
,
never
bear
the
reproach
of
possessing
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
with
what
ardent
thankfulness
and
love
I
say
this
,
I
may
call
Heaven
to
witness
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
you
will
not
let
me
be
faithful
to
you
in
your
affliction
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
,
dearest
Little
Dorrit
,
and
yet
I
will
try
to
be
faithful
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
in
the
bygone
days
when
this
was
your
home
and
when
this
was
your
dress
,
I
had
understood
myself
(
I
speak
only
of
myself
)
better
,
and
had
read
the
secrets
of
my
own
breast
more
distinctly
;
if
,
through
my
reserve
and
self
-
mistrust
,
I
had
discerned
a
light
that
I
see
brightly
now
when
it
has
passed
far
away
,
and
my
weak
footsteps
can
never
overtake
it
;
if
I
had
then
known
,
and
told
you
that
I
loved
and
honoured
you
,
not
as
the
poor
child
I
used
to
call
you
,
but
<EOS>
as
a
woman
whose
true
hand
would
raise
me
high
above
myself
and
make
me
a
far
happier
and
better
man
;
if
I
had
so
used
the
opportunity
there
is
no
recalling
---
<EOS>
as
I
wish
I
had
,
O
I
wish
I
had
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
if
something
had
kept
us
apart
then
,
when
I
was
moderately
thriving
,
and
when
you
were
poor
;
I
might
have
met
your
noble
offer
of
your
fortune
,
dearest
girl
,
with
other
words
than
these
,
and
still
have
blushed
to
touch
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
it
is
,
I
must
never
touch
it
,
never
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
besought
him
,
more
pathetically
and
earnestly
,
with
her
little
supplicatory
hand
,
than
she
could
have
done
in
any
words
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
disgraced
enough
,
my
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
not
descend
so
low
as
that
,
and
carry
you
---
<EOS>
so
dear
,
so
generous
,
so
good
---
down
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
GOD
bless
you
,
GOD
reward
you
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
past
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
took
her
in
his
arms
,
as
if
she
had
been
his
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Always
so
much
older
,
so
much
rougher
,
and
so
much
less
worthy
,
even
what
I
was
must
be
dismissed
by
both
of
us
,
and
you
must
see
me
only
as
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
this

upon
your
cheek
,
my
child
---
who
might
have
been
more
near
to
me
,
who
never
could
have
been
more
dear
---
a
ruined
man
far
removed
from
you
,
for
ever
separated
from
you
,
whose
course
is
run
while
yours
is
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
courage
to
ask
to
be
forgotten
by
you
in
my
humiliation
;
but
I
ask
to
be
remembered
only
as
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
bell
began
to
ring
,
warning
visitors
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
her
mantle
from
the
wall
,
and
tenderly
wrapped
it
round
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
other
word
,
my
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
A
hard
one
to
me
,
<EOS>
but
it
is
a
necessary

.
 
<EOS>
The
time
when
you
and
this
prison
had
anything
in
common
has
long
gone
by
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
!
 
<EOS>
you
will
never
say
to
me
,
"
she
cried
,
weeping

,
and
holding

,
"
that
I
am
not
to
come

!
 
<EOS>
You
will
surely
not

me
so
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
say
it
,
if
I
could
;
but
I
have
not
the
courage
quite
to
shut
out
this
dear
face
,
and

all

its

.
 
<EOS>
But
do
not
come
soon
,
do
not

often
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
now
a
tainted
place
,
and
I
well
know
the
taint
of
it
clings
to

.
 
<EOS>
You
belong
to
much
brighter
and
better
scenes
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
to
look
back
here
,
my
Little
Dorrit
;
you
are
to
look
away
to
very
different
and
much
happier
paths
.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
GOD
bless
you
in
them
!
 
<EOS>
GOD
reward
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Maggy
,
who
had
fallen
into
very
low
spirits
,
here
cried
,
"
Oh
get
him
into
a
hospital
;
do
get
him
into
a
hospital
,
Mother
!
 
<EOS>
He
'll
never
look

hisself
again
,
if
he
an't

into
a

.
 
<EOS>
And
then
the
little
woman
as
was
always
a
spinning
at
her
wheel
,
she
can
go
to
the

with
the
Princess
,
and
say
,
what

the
Chicking
there

?
 
<EOS>
and
then
they
can
take
it
out
and
give

to

,
and
then
all
be

!
"
   
<EOS>
The
interruption
was
seasonable
,
for
the
bell
had
nearly
rung
itself
out
.
 
<EOS>
Again

wrapping
her
mantle
about
her
,
and
taking
her
on
his
arm
(
though
,
but
for
her
visit
,
he
was
almost
too

to
walk
)
,
Arthur
led
Little
Dorrit
down
-

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
the
last
visitor
to
pass
out
at
the
Lodge
,
and
the
gate
jarred
heavily
and

upon

.
   
<EOS>
With
the

that
it
sounded
into
Arthur
's
heart
,
his
sense
of
weakness
returned
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
toilsome
journey
up
-
stairs
to
his
room
,
and
he
re
-
entered
its
dark
solitary
precincts
in
unutterable
misery
.
   
<EOS>
When
it
was
almost
midnight
,
and
the
prison
had
long
been
quiet
,
a
cautious
creak
came
up
the
stairs
,
and
a
cautious
tap
of
a
key
was
given
at
his
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Young
John
.
 
<EOS>
He
glided
in
,
in
his
stockings
,
and
held
the
door
closed
,
while
he
spoke
in
a
whisper
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
against
all
rules
,
but
I
do
n't
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
determined
to
come
through
,
and
come
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
's
the
matter
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
waiting
in
the
court
-
yard
for
Miss
Dorrit
when
she
came
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
'd
like
some
one
to
see
that
she
was
safe
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
thank
you
!
 
<EOS>
You
took
her
home
,
John
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
her
to
her
hotel
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
that
Mr
Dorrit
was
at
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dorrit
walked
all
the
way
,
and
talked
to
me
so
kind
,
it
quite
knocked
me
over
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
think
she
walked
instead
of
riding
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
John
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
talk
about
you
.
 
<EOS>
She
said

me
,
"
John
,
you
was
always
honourable
,
and
if
you
'll
promise
me
that
you
will
take
care
of
him
,
and
never
let
him
want
for
help
and
comfort
when
I
am
not
there
,
my
mind
will
be
at
rest
so

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

her
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'll
stand
by
you
,
"
said
John
Chivery
,
"
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
,
much
affected
,
stretched
out
his
hand
to
this
honest
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Before
I
take

,
"

John
,

,
without

the
door
<EOS>
,
"
guess

message
Miss
Dorrit
gave

.
"
   
<EOS>
Clennam
shook

.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Tell
him
,
"
"

John
,
in

,
"
"
that
his
Little
Dorrit
sent

.
"
 
<EOS>
Now
it
's

.
 
<EOS>
Have
I
been
honourable
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will

Miss
Dorrit
I
've

honourable
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
my
hand
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
'll
stand
by
you
forever
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
hearty

,
he
disappeared
with
the
same
cautious
creak
upon
the
stair
,
crept
shoeless
over
the
pavement
of
the
yard
,
and
,
locking
the
gates
behind
him
,
passed
out
into
the
front
where
he
had
left
his
shoes
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
same
way
had
been
paved
with
burning
ploughshares
,
it
is
not
at
all
improbable
that
John
would
have
traversed
it
with
the
same
devotion
,
for
the
same
purpose
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
Closing
in
 
<EOS>
The
last
day
of
the
appointed
week
touched
the
bars
of
the
Marshalsea
gate
.
 
<EOS>
Black
,
all
night
,
since
the
gate
had
clashed
upon
Little
Dorrit
,
its
iron
stripes
were
turned
by
the
early
-
glowing
sun
into
stripes
of
gold
.
 
<EOS>
Far
aslant
across
the
city
,
over
its
jumbled
roofs
,
and
through
the
open
tracery
of
its
church
towers
,
struck
the
long
bright
rays
,
bars
of
the
prison
of
this
lower
world
.
   
<EOS>
Throughout
the
day
the
old
house
within
the
gateway
remained
untroubled
by
any
visitors
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
when
the
sun
was
low
,
three
men
turned
in
at
the
gateway
and
made
for
the
dilapidated
house
.
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
was
the
first
,
and
walked
by
himself
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
was
the
second
,
and
jogged
close
after
him
,
looking
at
no
other
object
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
was
the
third
,
and
carried
his
hat
under
his
arm
for
the
liberation
of
his
restive
hair
;
the
weather
being
extremely
hot
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
came
together
at
the
door
-
steps
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
pair
of
madmen
!
<EOS>
"
said
Rigaud
,
facing
about
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
yet
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
mean
to
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
.
<EOS>
Giving
him
a
dark
glance
in
acknowledgment
of
his
answer
,
Rigaud
knocked
loudly
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
charged
himself
with
drink
,
for
the
playing
out
of
his
game
,
and
was
impatient
to
begin
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
finished
one
long
resounding
knock
,
when
he
turned
to
the
knocker
again
and
began
another
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
not
yet
finished
when
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
opened
the
door
,
and
they
all
clanked
into
the
stone
hall
.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
,
thrusting
Mr
Flintwinch
aside
,
proceeded
straight
up
-
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
His
two
attendants
followed
him
,
Mr
Flintwinch
followed
them
,
and
they
all
came
trooping
into
Mrs
Clennam
's
quiet
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
its
usual
state
;
except
that
one
of
the
windows
was
wide
open
,
and
Affery
sat
on
its
old
-
fashioned
window
-
seat
,
mending
a
stocking
.
 
<EOS>
The
usual
articles
were
on
the
little
table
;
the
usual
deadened
fire
was
in
the
grate
;
the
bed
had
its
usual
pall
upon
it
;
and
the
mistress
of
all
sat
on
her
black
bier
-
like
sofa
,
propped
up
by
her
black
angular
bolster
that
was
like
the
headsman
's
block
.
   
<EOS>
Yet
there
was
a
nameless
air
of
preparation
in
the
room
,
as
if
it
were
strung
up
for
an
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
From
what
the
room
derived
it
---
every
one
of
its
small
variety
of
objects
being
in
the
fixed
spot
it
had
occupied
for
years
---
no
one
could
have
said
without
looking
attentively
at
its
mistress
,
and
that
,
too
,
with
a
previous
knowledge
of
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
Although
her
unchanging
black
dress
was
in
every
plait
precisely
as
of
old
,
and
her
unchanging
attitude
was
rigidly
preserved
,
a
very
slight
additional
setting
of
her
features
and
contraction
of
her
gloomy
forehead
was
so
powerfully
marked
,
that
it
marked
everything
about
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
are
these
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
wonderingly
,
as
the
two
attendants
entered
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
these
people
want
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
are
these
,
dear
madame
,
is
it
?
"
returned
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Faith
,
they
are
friends
of
your
son
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
do
they
want
here
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Death
,
madame
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
do
well
to
ask
them
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
told
us
at
the
door
,
not
to
go
yet
,
"
said
Pancks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
know
you
told
me
at
the
door
<EOS>
,
you
did
n't
mean
to
go
,
"
retorted
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
,
madame
,
permit
me
to
present
two
spies
of
the
prisoner
's
---
madmen
,
but
spies
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
wish
them
to
remain
here
during
our
little
conversation
,
say
the
word
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
nothing
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
wish
them
to
remain
here
?
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
to
do
with
them
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
dearest
madame
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
throwing
himself
into
an
arm
-
chair
so
heavily
that
the
old
room
trembled
,
"
you
will
do
well
to
dismiss
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
your
affair
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
my
spies
,
not
my
rascals
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
You
Pancks
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
bending
her
brows
upon
him
angrily
,
"
you
Casby
's
clerk
!
 
<EOS>
Attend
to
your
employer
's
business
and
your
own
.
 
<EOS>
Go
.
 
<EOS>
And
take
that
other
man
with
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
Mr
Pancks
,
"
I
am
glad
to
say
I
see
no
objection
to
our
both
retiring
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
done
all
we
undertook
to
do
for
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
His
constant
anxiety
has
been
(
and
it
grew
worse
upon
him
when
he
became
a
prisoner
)
,
that
this
agreeable
gentleman
should
be
brought
back
here
to
the
place
from
which
he
slipped
away
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
is
---
brought
back
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
will
say
,
"
added
Mr
Pancks
,
"
to
his
ill
-
looking
face
,
that
in
my
opinion
the
world
would
be
no
worse
for
his
slipping
out
of
it
altogether
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
opinion
is
not
asked
,
"
answered
Mrs
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
not
to
leave
you
in
better
company
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Pancks
;
"
and
sorry
,
too
,
that
Mr
Clennam
ca
n't
be
present
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
my
fault
,
that
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
his
own
,
"
she
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
mean
mine
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
<EOS>
for
it
was
my
misfortune
to
lead
him
into
a
ruinous
investment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
Mr
Pancks
still
clung
to
that
word
,
and
never
said
speculation
.
)
<EOS>
"
Though
I
can
prove
by
figures
,
"
added
Mr
Pancks
,
with
an
anxious
countenance
,
"
that
it
ought
to
have
been
a
good
investment
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
gone
over
it
since
it
failed
,
every
day
of
my
life
,
and
it
comes
out
---
regarded
as
a
question
of
figures
---
triumphant
.
 
<EOS>
The
present
is
not
a
time
or
place
,
"
Mr
Pancks
pursued
,
with
a
longing
glance
into
his
hat
,
where
he
kept
his
calculations
,
"
for
entering
upon
the
figures
;
but
the
figures
are
not
to
be
disputed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
ought
to
have
been
at
this
moment
in
his
carriage
and
pair
,
and
I
ought
to
have
been
worth
from
three
to
five
thousand
pound
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
put
his
hair
erect
with
a
general
aspect
of
confidence
that
could
hardly
have
been
surpassed
,
if
he
had
had
the
amount
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
These
incontrovertible
figures
had
been
the
occupation
of
every
moment
of
his
leisure
since
he
had
lost
his
money
,
and
were
destined
to
afford
him
consolation
to
the
end
of
his
days
.
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
enough
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Altro
,
old
boy
,
you
have
seen
the
figures
,
and
you
know
how
they
come
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Baptist
,
who
had
not
the
slightest
arithmetical
power
of
compensating
himself
in
this
way
,
nodded
,
with
a
fine
display
of
bright
teeth
.
   
<EOS>
At
whom
Mr
Flintwinch
had
been
looking
,
and
to
whom
he
then
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
it
's
you
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
remembered
your
face
,
but
I
was
n't
certain
till
I
saw
your
teeth
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
yes
,
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
this
officious
refugee
,
"
said
Jeremiah
to
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
who
came
knocking
at
the
door
on
the
night
when
Arthur
and
Chatterbox
were
here
,
and
who
asked
me
a
whole
Catechism
of
questions
about
Mr
Blandois
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
,
"
Mr
Baptist
cheerfully
admitted
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
behold
him
,
padrone
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
found
him
consequentementally
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
have
objected
,
"
returned
Mr
Flintwinch
,
"
to
your
having
broken
your
neck
consequentementally
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
whose
eye
had
often
stealthily
wandered
to
the
window
-
seat
and
the
stocking
that
was
being
mended
there
,
"
I
've
only
one
other
word
to
say
before
I
go
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Clennam
was
here
---
but
unfortunately
,
though
he
has
so
far
got
the
better
of
this
fine
gentleman
as
to
return
him
to
this
place
against
his
will
,
he
is
ill
and
in
prison
---
ill
and
in
prison
,
poor
fellow
---
if
he
was
here
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
taking
one
step
aside
towards
the
window
-
seat
,
and
laying
his
right
hand
upon
the
stocking
;
"
he
would
say
,
"
Affery
,
tell
your
dreams
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
held
up
his
right
forefinger
between
his
nose
and
the
stocking
with
a
ghostly
air
of
warning
,
turned
,
steamed
out
and
towed
Mr
Baptist
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
-
door
was
heard
to
close
upon
them
,
their
steps
were
heard
passing
over
the
dull
pavement
of
the
echoing
court
-
yard
,
and
still
nobody
had
added
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
and
Jeremiah
had
exchanged
a
look
;
and
had
then
looked
,
and
looked
still
,
at
Affery
,
who
sat
mending
the
stocking
with
great
assiduity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Flintwinch
at
length
,
screwing
himself
a
curve
or
two
in
the
direction
of
the
window
-
seat
,
and
rubbing
the
palms
of
his
hands
on
his
coat
-
tail
as
if
he
were
preparing
them
to
do
something
:
"
Whatever
has
to
be
said
among
us
had
better
be
begun
to
be
said
without
more
loss
of
time
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
So
,
Affery
,
my
woman
,
take
yourself
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
a
moment
Affery
had
thrown
the
stocking
down
,
started
up
,
caught
hold
of
the
windowsill
with
her
right
hand
,
lodged
herself
upon
the
window
-
seat
with
her
right
knee
,
and
was
flourishing
her
left
hand
,
beating
expected
assailants
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
wo
n't
,
Jeremiah
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
wo
n't
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
wo
n't
!
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
go
!
<EOS>
I
'll
stay
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
hear
all
I
do
n't
know
,
and
say
all
I
know
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
at
last
,
if
I
die
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
<EOS>
,
I
will
,
I
will
,
I
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
,
stiffening
with
indignation
and
amazement
,
moistened
the
fingers
of
one
hand
at
his
lips
,
softly
described
a
circle
with
them
in
the
palm
of
the
other
hand
,
and
continued
with
a
menacing
grin
to
screw
himself
in
the
direction
of
his
wife
;
gasping
some
remark
as
he
advanced
,
of
which
,
in
his
choking
anger
,
only
the
words
,
"
Such
a
dose
!
"
were
audible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
nearer
,
Jeremiah
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Affery
,
never
ceasing
to
beat
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
come
a
bit
nearer
to
me
,
or
I
'll
rouse
the
neighbourhood
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
throw
myself
out
of
window
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
scream
Fire
and
Murder
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
wake
the
dead
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
where
you
are
,
or
I
'll
make
shrieks
enough
to
wake
the
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
determined
voice
of
Mrs
Clennam
echoed
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
Jeremiah
had
stopped
already
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
closing
in
,
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
Let
her
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
,
do
you
turn
against
me
after
these
many
years
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
if
it
's
turning
against
you
to
hear
what
I
do
n't
know
,
and
say
what
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
broke
out
now
,
and
I
ca
n't
go
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
determined
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
do
it
,
<EOS>
I
will
,
I
will
,
I
will
!
 
<EOS>
If
that
's
turning
against
you
,
yes
,
I
turn
against
both
of
you
two
clever
ones
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
Arthur
when
he
first
come
home
to
stand
up
against
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
it
was
no
reason
,
because
I
was
afeard
of
my
life
of
you
,
that
he
should
be
.
 
<EOS>
All
manner
of
things
have
been
a
-
going
on
since
then
,
and
I
wo
n't
be
run
up
by
Jeremiah
,
nor
<EOS>
yet
I
wo
n't
be
dazed
and
scared
,
nor
made
a
party
to
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
,
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
,
I
wo
n't
,
I
wo
n't
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
up
for
Arthur
when
he
has
nothing
left
,
and
is
ill
,
and
in
prison
,
and
ca
n't
up
for
himself
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
<EOS>
,
I
will
,
I
will
,
I
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
,
you
heap
of
confusion
,
"
asked
Mrs
Clennam
sternly
,
"
that
in
doing
what
you
are
doing
now
,
you
are
even
serving
Arthur
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
nothing
rightly
about
anything
,
"
said
Affery
;
"
and
if
ever
you
said
a
true
word
in
your
life
,
it
's
when
you
call
me
a
heap
of
confusion
,
for
you
two
clever
ones
have
done
your
most
to
make
me
such
.
 
<EOS>
You
married
me
whether
I
liked
it
or
not
,
and
you
've
led
me
,
pretty
well
ever
since
,
such
a
life
of
dreaming
and
frightening
as
never
was
known
,
and
what
do
you
expect
me
to
be
<EOS>
but
a
heap
of
confusion
?
 
<EOS>
You
wanted
to
make
me
such
,
and
I
am
such
;
but
I
wo
n't
submit
no
longer
;
no
,
I
wo
n't
<EOS>
,
I
wo
n't
,
I
wo
n't
,
I
wo
n't
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
was
still
beating
the
air
against
all
comers
.
   
<EOS>
After
gazing
at
her
in
silence
,
Mrs
Clennam
turned
to
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
and
hear
this
foolish
creature
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
object
to
such
a
piece
of
distraction
remaining
where
she
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
,
madame
,
"
he
replied
,
"
do
I
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
question
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
,
"
she
said
,
gloomily
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
little
left
to
choose
now
.
 
<EOS>
Flintwinch
,
it
is
closing
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Flintwinch
replied
by
directing
a
look
of
red
vengeance
at
his
wife
,
and
then
,
as
if
to
pinion
himself
from
falling
upon
her
,
screwed
his
crossed
arms
into
the
breast
of
his
waistcoat
,
and
with
his
chin
very
near
one
of
his
elbows
stood
in
a
corner
,
watching
Rigaud
in
the
oddest
attitude
.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
,
for
his
part
,
arose
from
his
chair
,
and
seated
himself
on
the
table
with
his
legs
dangling
.
<EOS>
In
this
easy
attitude
,
he
met
Mrs
Clennam
's
set
face
,
with
his
moustache
going
up
and
his
nose
coming
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
Madame
,
I
am
a
gentleman
---
"
   
"
Of
whom
,
"
she
interrupted
in
her
steady
tones
,
"
I
have
heard
disparagement
,
in
connection
with
a
French
jail
and
an
accusation
of
murder
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
kissed
his
hand
to
her
with
his
exaggerated
gallantry
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perfectly
.
 
<EOS>
Exactly
.
 
<EOS>
Of
a
lady
too
!
 
<EOS>
What
absurdity
!
 
<EOS>
How
incredible
!
 
<EOS>
I
had
the
honour
of
making
a
great
success
then
;
I
hope
to
have
the
honour
of
making
a
great
success
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
kiss
your
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Madame
,
I
am
a
gentleman
(
I
was
going
to
observe
)
,
who
when
he
says
,
"
I
will
definitely
finish
this
or
that
affair
at
the
present
sitting
,
"
does
definitely
finish
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
announce
to
you
that
we
are
arrived
at
our
last
sitting
on
our
little
business
.
<EOS>
You
do
me
the
favour
to
follow
,
and
to
comprehend
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
kept
her
eyes
fixed
upon
him
with
a
frown
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Further
,
I
am
a
gentleman
to
whom
mere
mercenary
trade
-
bargains
are
unknown
,
but
to
whom
money
is
always
acceptable
as
the
means
of
pursuing
his
pleasures
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
me
the
favour
to
follow
,
and
to
comprehend
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Scarcely
necessary
to
ask
,
one
would
say
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Further
,
I
am
a
gentleman
of
the
softest
and
sweetest
disposition
,
but
who
,
if
trifled
with
,
becomes
enraged
.
 
<EOS>
Noble
natures
under
such
circumstances
become
enraged
.
 
<EOS>
I
possess
a
noble
nature
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
lion
is
awakened
---
that
is
to
say
,
when
I
enrage
---
the
satisfaction
of
my
animosity
is
as
acceptable
to
me
as
money
.
 
<EOS>
You
always
do
me
the
favour
to
follow
,
and
to
comprehend
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
answered
,
somewhat
louder
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
let
me
derange
you
;
pray
be
tranquil
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
said
we
are
now
arrived
at
our
last
sitting
.
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
recall
the
two
sittings
we
have
held
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
necessary
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Death
,
madame
<EOS>
,
"
he
burst
out
,
"
it
's
my
fancy
!
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
clears
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
sitting
was
limited
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
the
honour
of
making
your
acquaintance
---
of
presenting
my
letter
;
I
am
a
Knight
of
Industry
,
at
your
service
,
madame
,
but
my
polished
manners
had
won
me
so
much
of
success
,
as
a
master
of
languages
,
among
your
compatriots
who
are
as
stiff
as
their
own
starch
is
to
one
another
,
but
are
ready
to
relax
to
a
foreign
gentleman
of
polished
manners
---
and
of
observing
one
or
two
little
things
,
"
he
glanced
around
the
room
and
smiled
,
"
about
this
honourable
house
,
to
know
which
was
necessary
to
assure
me
,
and
to
convince
me
that
I
had
the
distinguished
pleasure
of
making
the
acquaintance
of
the
lady
I
sought
.
 
<EOS>
I
achieved
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
my
word
of
honour
to
our
dear
Flintwinch
that
I
would
return
.
 
<EOS>
I
gracefully
departed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
face
neither
acquiesced
nor
demurred
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
when
he
paused
,
and
when
he
spoke
,
it
as
yet
showed
him
always
the
one
attentive
frown
,
and
the
dark
revelation
before
mentioned
of
her
being
nerved
for
the
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
gracefully
departed
,
because
it
was
graceful
to
retire
without
alarming
a
lady
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
morally
graceful
,
not
less
than
physically
,
is
a
part
of
the
character
of
Rigaud
Blandois
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
also
politic
,
as
leaving
you
with
something
overhanging
you
,
to
expect
me
again
with
a
little
anxiety
on
a
day
not
named
.
 
<EOS>
But
your
slave
is
politic
.
 
<EOS>
By
Heaven
,
madame
,
politic
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
return
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
not
named
,
I
have
again
the
honour
to
render
myself
at
your
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
intimate
that
I
have
something
to
sell
,
which
,
if
not
bought
,
will
compromise
madame
whom
I
highly
esteem
.
 
<EOS>
I
explain
myself
generally
.
 
<EOS>
I
demand
<EOS>
---
I
think
it
was
a
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
Will
you
correct
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
forced
to
speak
,
she
replied
with
constraint
,
"
You
demanded
as
much
as
a
thousand
pounds
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
demand
at
present
,
Two
.
 
<EOS>
Such
are
the
evils
of
delay
.
 
<EOS>
But
to
return
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
accordant
;
we
differ
on
that
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
playful
;
playfulness
is
a
part
of
my
amiable
character
.
 
<EOS>
Playfully
,
I
become
as
one
slain
and
hidden
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
it
may
alone
be
worth
half
the
sum
to
madame
,
to
be
freed
from
the
suspicions
that
my
droll
idea
awakens
.
 
<EOS>
Accident
and
spies
intermix
themselves
against
my
playfulness
,
and
spoil
the
fruit
,
perhaps
---
who
knows
?
 
<EOS>
only
you
and
Flintwinch
---
when
it
is
just
ripe
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
madame
,
I
am
here
for
the
last
time
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
!
 
<EOS>
Definitely
the
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
struck
his
straggling
boot
-
heels
against
the
flap
of
the
table
,
meeting
her
frown
with
an
insolent
gaze
,
he
began
to
change
his
tone
for
a
fierce
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
an
instant
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
advance
by
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
my
Hotel
-
note
to
be
paid
,
according
to
contract
.
 
<EOS>
Five
minutes
hence
we
may
be
at
daggers
'
points
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not
leave
it
till
then
,
or
you
'll
cheat
me
.
 
<EOS>
Pay
it
!
 
<EOS>
Count
me
the
money
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take
it
from
his
hand
and
pay
it
,
Flintwinch
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
He
spirted
it
into
Mr
Flintwinch
's
face
when
the
old
man
advanced
to
take
it
,
and
held
forth
his
hand
,
repeating
noisily
,
"
Pay
it
!
<EOS>
Count
it
out
!
 
<EOS>
Good
money
!
"
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
picked
the
bill
up
,
looked
at
the
total
with
a
bloodshot
eye
,
took
a
small
canvas
bag
from
his
pocket
,
and
told
the
amount
into
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
chinked
the
money
,
weighed
it
in
his
hand
,
threw
it
up
a
little
way
and
caught
it
,
chinked
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sound
of
it
,
to
the
bold
Rigaud
Blandois
,
is
like
the
taste
of
fresh
meat
to
the
tiger
.
 
<EOS>
Say
,
then
,
madame
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
turned
upon
her
suddenly
with
a
menacing
gesture
of
the
weighted
hand
that
clenched
the
money
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
strike
her
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
again
,
as
I
told
you
before
,
that
we
are
not
rich
here
,
as
you
suppose
us
to
be
,
and
that
your
demand
is
excessive
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
present
means
of
complying
with
such
a
demand
,
if
I
had
ever
so
great
an
inclination
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
!
"
cried
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
this
lady
with
her
<EOS>
If
!
 
<EOS>
Will
you
say
that
you
have
not
the
inclination
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
say
what
presents
itself
to
me
,
and
not
what
presents
itself
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
it
then
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
inclination
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
 
<EOS>
Come
to
the
inclination
,
and
I
know
what
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
no
quicker
,
and
no
slower
,
in
her
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
seem
that
you
have
obtained
possession
of
a
paper
---
or
of
papers
---
which
I
assuredly
have
the
inclination
to
recover
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
,
with
a
loud
laugh
,
drummed
his
heels
against
the
table
,
and
chinked
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
!
 
<EOS>
I
believe
you
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
paper
might
be
worth
,
to
me
,
a
sum
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
how
much
,
or
how
little
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
the
Devil
!
"
<EOS>
he
asked
savagely
.
"
<EOS>
Not
after
a
week
's
grace
to
consider
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
No
!
 
I
will
not
out
of
my
scanty
means
---
for
I
tell
you
again
,
we
are
poor
here
,
and
not
rich
---
I
will
not
offer
any
price
for
a
power
that
I
do
not
know
the
worst
and
the
fullest
extent
of
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
third
time
of
your
hinting
and
threatening
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
speak
explicitly
,
or
you
may
go
where
you
will
,
and
do
what
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
be
torn
to
pieces
at
a
spring
,
than
to
be
a
mouse
at
the
caprice
of
such
a
cat
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
at
her
so
hard
with
those
eyes
too
near
together
that
the
sinister
sight
of
each
,
crossing
that
of
the
other
,
seemed
to
make
the
bridge
of
his
hooked
nose
crooked
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
long
survey
,
he
said
,
with
the
further
setting
off
of
his
internal
smile
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
bold
woman
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
resolved
woman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
always
were
.
 
<EOS>
What
?
 
<EOS>
She
always
was
;
is
it
not
so
,
my
little
Flintwinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Flintwinch
,
say
nothing
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
for
him
to
say
,
here
and
now
,
all
he
can
;
or
to
go
hence
,
and
do
all
he
can
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
this
to
be
our
determination
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
him
to
his
action
on
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
did
not
shrink
under
his
evil
leer
,
or
avoid
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
it
upon
her
again
,
but
she
remained
steady
at
the
point
to
which
she
had
fixed
herself
.
 
<EOS>
He
got
off
the
table
,
placed
a
chair
near
the
sofa
,
sat
down
in
it
,
and
leaned
an
arm
upon
the
sofa
close
to
her
own
,
which
he
touched
with
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
was
ever
frowning
,
attentive
,
and
settled
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
your
pleasure
then
,
madame
,
that
I
shall
relate
a
morsel
of
family
history
in
this
little
family
society
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
with
a
warning
play
of
his
lithe
fingers
on
her
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
something
of
a
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
touch
your
pulse
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
suffered
him
to
take
her
wrist
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Holding
it
,
he
proceeded
to
say
:
   
"
<EOS>
A
history
of
a
strange
marriage
,
and
a
strange
mother
,
and
a
revenge
,
and
a
suppression
.
<EOS>
---
Aye
,
aye
,
aye
?
 
<EOS>
this
pulse
is
beating
curiously
!
 
<EOS>
It
appears
to
me
that
it
doubles
while
I
touch
it
.
 
<EOS>
Are
these
the
usual
changes
of
your
malady
,
madame
?
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
struggle
in
her
maimed
arm
as
she
twisted
it
away
,
but
there
was
none
in
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
face
there
was
his
own
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
lived
an
adventurous
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
an
adventurous
character
.
<EOS>
I
have
known
many
adventurers
;
interesting
spirits
---
amiable
society
!
 
<EOS>
To
one
of
them
<EOS>
I
owe
my
knowledge
and
my
proofs
---
<EOS>
I
repeat
it
,
estimable
lady
---
proofs
---
of
the
ravishing
little
family
history
I
go
to
commence
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
charmed
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
bah
!
 
<EOS>
I
forget
.
 
<EOS>
One
should
name
a
history
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
name
it
the
history
of
a
house
?
 
<EOS>
But
,
bah
,
again
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
so
many
houses
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
name
it
the
history
of
this
house
?
"
   
<EOS>
Leaning
over
the
sofa
,
poised
on
two
legs
of
his
chair
and
his
left
elbow
;
that
hand
often
tapping
her
arm
to
beat
his
words
home
;
his
legs
crossed
;
his
right
hand
sometimes
arranging
his
hair
,
sometimes
smoothing
his
moustache
,
sometimes
striking
his
nose
,
always
threatening
her
whatever
it
did
;
coarse
,
insolent
,
rapacious
,
cruel
,
and
powerful
,
he
pursued
his
narrative
at
his
ease
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
fine
,
then
,
I
name
it
the
history
of
this
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
commence
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
live
here
,
let
us
suppose
,
an
uncle
and
nephew
.
 
<EOS>
The
uncle
,
a
rigid
old
gentleman
of
strong
force
of
character
;
the
nephew
,
habitually
timid
,
repressed
,
and
under
constraint
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mistress
Affery
,
fixedly
attentive
in
the
window
-
seat
,
biting
the
rolled
up
end
of
her
apron
,
and
trembling
from
head
to
foot
,
here
cried
out
,
"
Jeremiah
,
keep
off
from
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
've
heerd
,
in
my
dreams
,
of
Arthur
's
father
and
his
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
talking
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
before
my
time
here
;
but
I
've
heerd
in
my
dreams
that
Arthur
's
father
was
a
poor
,
irresolute
,
frightened
chap
,
who
had
had
everything
but
<EOS>
his
orphan
life
scared
out
of
him
when
he
was
young
,
and
that
he
had
no
voice
in
the
choice
of
his
wife
even
,
but
his
uncle
chose
her
.
 
<EOS>
There
she
sits
!
 
<EOS>
I
heerd
it
in
my
dreams
,
and
you
said
it
to
her
own
self
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Flintwinch
shook
his
fist
at
her
,
and
as
Mrs
Clennam
gazed
upon
her
,
Rigaud
kissed
his
hand
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
Perfectly
right
,
dear
Madame
Flintwinch
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
genius
for
dreaming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
none
of
your
praises
,
"
returned
Affery
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
have
nothing
at
all
to
say
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
Jeremiah
said
they
was
dreams
,
and
I
'll
tell
'em
as
such
!
"
 
<EOS>
Here
she
put
her
apron
in
her
mouth
again
,
as
if
she
were
stopping
somebody
else
's
mouth
---
perhaps
jeremiah
's
,
which
was
chattering
with
threats
as
if
he
were
grimly
cold
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Our
beloved
Madame
Flintwinch
,
"
said
Rigaud
,
"
developing
all
of
a
sudden
a
fine
susceptibility
and
spirituality
,
is
right
to
a
marvel
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
So
runs
the
history
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
,
the
uncle
,
commands
the
nephew
to
marry
.
 
<EOS>
Monsieur
says
to
him
in
effect
,
"
My
nephew
,
I
introduce
to
you
a
lady
of
strong
force
of
character
,
like
myself
---
a
resolved
lady
,
a
stern
lady
,
a
lady
who
has
a
will
that
can
break
the
weak
to
powder
:
a
lady
without
pity
,
without
love
,
implacable
,
revengeful
,
cold
as
the
stone
,
but
raging
as
the
fire
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
what
fortitude
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
what
superiority
of
intellectual
strength
!
 
<EOS>
Truly
,
a
proud
and
noble
character
that
I
describe
in
the
supposed
words
of
Monsieur
,
the
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Death
of
my
soul
<EOS>
,
I
love
the
sweet
lady
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
's
face
had
changed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
remarkable
darkness
of
colour
on
it
,
and
the
brow
was
more

.
 
<EOS>
"
Madame
,
madame
,
"
said

,
tapping

,
as

his

a

<EOS>
,
"
I
perceive
I
interest

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Let

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

and
the

had
,
however
,
to
be

for
a
moment
with
the
white

,
before

could

on
;
he

effect
he
made

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,

,

lucid

Flintwinch
has

,

frightened

abases

:
"
My

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Monsieur
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

he
always

.
<EOS>
The

;

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hey
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud

,

,

<EOS>
"
Soon

.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
,
full

,

,
full

<EOS>
,

---

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
When

<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
After

;
always

,

.
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
had
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
Haha
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

What

you

?

?
<EOS>

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Under

,
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
Her

,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Our

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

---
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
How
,

?
 
<EOS>
You

?

<EOS>
She

,
"
Not

's

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are

.
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

<EOS>
,

"

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
Hear

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
He

.

<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

when

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
Have

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Can

?
 
<EOS>
Can

?
 
<EOS>
If

a

,

of

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Rigaud
pushed

;
pushed

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
not

what
it
is
,
"
she

,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
brought
up
.
 
<EOS>
Mine
was
no
light

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mine
were
days
of
wholesome

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
corruption
of
our

,
the
evil

,
the
curse
that
is
upon

,
the

that
surround
us
<EOS>
---
these
were
the
themes
of
my
childhood
.
<EOS>
They
formed
my
character
,
and
filled
me
with
an
abhorrence
of
evil
-
doers
.
<EOS>
When
old
Mr
Gilbert
Clennam
proposed
his
orphan

to
my
father
for
my
husband
,
my
father
impressed
upon
me
that
his
bringing
-
up
had
been
,
like

,
one

severe

.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
that
besides
the
discipline
his
spirit
had
undergone
,
he
had
lived
in
a
starved
house
,
where
rioting
and
gaiety
were
unknown
,
and
where
every
day
was
a
day
of
toil
and
trial
like
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
that
he
had
been
a
man
in
years
long
before
his
uncle
had

;
and
that
from
his

-

to

,

uncle
's

has

.
 
<EOS>
When
,
within
a

of
our

,
I
found
my
husband
,
at
that

when
my
father

,
to

Lord

by

in

,
was
I
to
doubt
that
it
had

,
and
that

that

?
 
<EOS>
Was
I
to
dismiss
in

---
not
my
own
wrongs
<EOS>
---
what
was
I
!
<EOS>
but
all
the
rejection
of
sin
,
and
all

war
against

,
in
which
I
had
been

?
"
 
<EOS>
She
laid
her

upon
the
watch

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
forget
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
initials
of
those
words
are
within
here
now
,
and
were
within
here
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
appointed
to
find
the
old
letter
that
referred
to
them
,
and
that
told

what
they

,

whose

,

were

,
lying

.
 
<EOS>
But

that

would

no

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
forget
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
spoke
to
me
like

.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
forget
the
deadly

,
do
not

the
appointed

,

appointed

.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
forget
.
 
<EOS>
Was
it
my
own
wrong
<EOS>
I
remembered
?
<EOS>
Mine
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
but
a
servant
and
a

.
 
<EOS>
What
power
could
I
have
over
them
,
but
that
they
were
bound
in
the
bonds
of
their
sin
,
and
delivered
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
More
than
forty
years
had
passed
over
the
grey
head
of
this
determined
woman
,
since
the
time
she
recalled
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
forty
years
of
strife
and
struggle
with
the
whisper
that
,
by
whatever
name
she
called
her
vindictive
pride
and
rage
,
nothing
through
all
eternity
could
change
their
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
,
gone
those
more
than
forty
years
,
and
come
this
Nemesis
now
looking
her
in
the
face
,
she
still
abided
by
her
old
impiety
---
still
reversed
the
order
of
Creation
,
and
breathed
her
own
breath
into
a
clay
image
of
her
Creator
.
 
<EOS>
Verily
,
verily
,
travellers
have
seen
many
monstrous
idols
in
many
countries
;
but
no
human
eyes
have
ever
seen
more
daring
,
gross
,
and
shocking
images
of
the
Divine
nature
than
we
creatures
of
the
dust
make
in
our
own
likenesses
,
of
our
own
bad
passions
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
forced
him
to
give
her
up
to
me
,
by
her
name
and
place
of
abode
,
"
she
went
on
in
her
torrent
of
indignation
and
defence
;
"
when
I
accused
her
,
and
she
fell
hiding
her
face
at
my
feet
,
was
it
my
injury
that
I
asserted
,
were
they
my
reproaches
that
I
poured
upon
her
?
 
<EOS>
Those
who
were
appointed
of
old
to
go
to
wicked
kings
and
accuse
them
---
were
they
not
ministers
and
servants
?
 
<EOS>
And
had
not
I
,
unworthy
and
far
-
removed
from
them
,
sin
to
denounce
?
 
<EOS>
When
she
pleaded
to
me
her
youth
,
and
his
wretched
and
hard
life
(
that
was
her
phrase
for
the
virtuous
training
he
had
belied
)
,
and
the
desecrated
ceremony
of
marriage
there
had
secretly
been
between
them
,
and
the
terrors
of
want
and
shame
that
had
overwhelmed
them
both
when
I
was
first
appointed
to
be
the
instrument
of
their
punishment
,
and
the
love
(
for
she
said
the
word
to
me
,
down
at
my
feet
)
in
which
she
had
abandoned
him
and
left
him
to
me
,
was
it
my
enemy
that
became
my
footstool
,
were
they
the
words
of
my
wrath
that
made
her
shrink
and
quiver
!
 
<EOS>
Not
unto
me
the
strength
be
ascribed
;
not
unto
me
the
wringing
of
the
expiation
!
"
   
<EOS>
Many
years
had
come
and
gone
since
she
had
had
the
free
use
even
of
her
fingers
;
but
it
was
noticeable
that
she
had
already
more
than
once
struck
her
clenched
hand
vigorously
upon
the
table
,
and
<EOS>
that
when
she
said
these
words
she
raised
her
whole
arm
in
the
air
,
as
though
it
had
been
a
common
action
with
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
was
the
repentance
that
was
extorted
from
the
hardness
of
her
heart
and
the
blackness
of
her
depravity
?
 
<EOS>
I
,
vindictive
and
implacable
?
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
so
,
to
such
as
you
who
know
no
righteousness
,
and
no
appointment
except
Satan
's
.
 
<EOS>
Laugh
;
but
I
will
be
known
as
I
know
myself
,
and
as
Flintwinch
knows
me
,
though
it
is
only
to
you
and
this
half
-
witted
woman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Add
,
to
yourself
,
madame
,
"
said
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
my
little
suspicions
that
madame
is
rather
solicitous
to
be
justified
to
herself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
need
to
be
,
"
she
said
,
with
great
energy
and
anger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Truly
?
"
retorted
Rigaud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
"
   
"
I
ask
,
what
was
the
penitence
,
in
works
,
that
was
demanded
of
her
?
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
child
;
I
have
none
.
 
<EOS>
You
love
that
child
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
shall
believe
himself
to
be
my
son
,
and
he
shall
be

by
every

to
be
my
son
.
 
<EOS>
To
save
you
from
exposure
,
his
father

to
see

with
you
more
;
equally

from
being

by

,

child
from
being
a

,
you
shall
swear
never
to
see
or
communicate
with
either
of

more
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
and
your
present
means
,
derived
from
my
husband
,
<EOS>
renounced
,
I
charge
myself
with
your
support
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
,
with
your
place
of
retreat
unknown
<EOS>
,
then
leave
,
if
you
please
,
uncontradicted
by
me
,
the
lie
that
when
you
passed
out
of
all
knowledge
but
mine
,
you
merited
a
good
name
.
<EOS>
"
That
was
all
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
to
sacrifice
her
sinful
and
shameful
affections
;
no

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
then
free
to
bear
her
load
of
guilt
in
secret
,
and
to
break
her
heart
in
secret
;
and
through
such
present
misery
(
light
enough
for
her
,
I
think
!
)
<EOS>
to
purchase
her
redemption
from
endless
misery
,
if
she
could
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
in
this
,
I
punished
her
here
,
did
I
not
open
to
her
a
way
hereafter
?
 
<EOS>
If
she
knew
herself
to
be
surrounded
by
insatiable

and
unquenchable

,
were
they
mine
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
threatened
her
,
then
and
afterwards
,
with
the
terrors
that
encompassed
her
,
did
I
hold
them
in
my
right

?
"
   
<EOS>
She
turned
the
watch
upon
the

,
and
opened

,
and
,
with
an
unsoftening

,
looked
at
the
worked
letters
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
did
not
forget
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
appointed
against
such
offences
that
the
offenders
shall
not
be
able
to
forget
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
presence
of
Arthur
was
a
daily

to
his
father
,
and
if
the
absence
of
Arthur
was

mother
,
that
was
the
just

.
 
<EOS>
As

be

me
,
that
the

an

,
and
that
it
was
the

the
Disposer
of
all

that
she
should
live
so
,
many

.
 
<EOS>
I
devoted

to
reclaim
the
otherwise
predestined
and
lost
boy
;
to

the

an

;
to

for
the

heavy

this

.
 
<EOS>
Was
that
a

?
 
<EOS>
Was
I
,
too
,

visited
with

of
the
original

I

?
 
<EOS>
Arthur
's

no

,
with

,
than
when

were

.
 
<EOS>
He
died
,

this

Do

.
 
<EOS>
I

NOT

,

<EOS>
I
read
in

,
that
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
so

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As

whatever

<EOS>
"
Come
,

!
 
<EOS>
Time

<EOS>
Come
,

,

!
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
Death

<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wretch

you
are
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Madame
,

.
 
<EOS>
Time

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
<EOS>
she

,

<EOS>
"
I
,

<EOS>

would

the

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

Not

's

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

"
   
"
Time

<EOS>
Take

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

"

<EOS>
Rigaud

<EOS>
"
One

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
What

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
That

,
"

"
Names
!
 
<EOS>
Call

.
 
<EOS>
No

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
Frederick
Dorrit
was

.
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Satan

Frederick

,

,

<EOS>
Then

.
 
<EOS>
Then
Arthur
's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Not

,
that

,
"

"

<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
,

,

so

<EOS>
"
You

it

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
I

,

<EOS>
But

)

,

<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
found
the
niece
before

;

what

,

better

her
far

.
"
 
<EOS>
She

,

"

:
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
The

---
jail
-

---

.
 
<EOS>
Shall

recall

?
 
<EOS>
The

-

that
never

,

.
 
<EOS>
Shall

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll

you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Affery
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dreamed
it
,
first

.
 
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,
if

come
a
-

,

!
 
<EOS>
The

as
this

spoken

,

's

;

,

<EOS>
I

,

---
Help
!
 
<EOS>
Murder
!
 
<EOS>
Save

Jere
-
mi
-
ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
After

<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
assault

!
<EOS>
Ha

,

!
 
<EOS>
Why

'll

.
 
<EOS>
All

<EOS>
Ha

,

!
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
I

He

<EOS>

I

So

,

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

,

,

,

<EOS>
For

I

"

"
---

his
sake
---
to
keep
it
without
breaking
the
seal
,
in
case
of
its
being
reclaimed
before
the
hour
of
shutting
up
to
-
night
---
if
it
should
not
be
reclaimed
before
the
ringing
of
the
prison
bell
,
to
give
it
to
him
;
and
it
encloses
a
second
copy
for
herself
,
which
he
must
give
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
trust
myself
among
you
,
now
we
have
got
so
far
,
without
giving
my
secret
a
second
life
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
its
not
bringing
me
,
elsewhere
,
the
price
it
will
bring
here
,
say
then
,
madame
,
have
you
limited
and
settled
the
price
the
little
niece
will
give
---
for
his
sake
---
to
hush
it
up
?
 
<EOS>
Once
more
I
say
,
time
presses
.
 
<EOS>
The
packet
not
reclaimed
before
the
ringing
of
the
bell
to
-
night
,
you
can
not
buy
.
 
<EOS>
I
sell
,
then
,
to
the
little
girl
!
"
   
<EOS>
Once
more
the
stir
and
struggle
in
her
,
and
she
ran
to
a
closet
,
tore
the
door
open
,
took
down
a
hood
or
shawl
,
and
wrapped
it
over
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
,
who
had
watched
her
in
terror
,
darted
to
her
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
caught
hold
of
her
dress
,
and
went
on
her
knees
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
,
do
n't
,
do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
?
 
<EOS>
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
You
're
a
fearful
woman
,
but
I
do
n't
bear
you
no
ill
-
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
do
poor
Arthur
<EOS>
no
good
now
,
that
I
see
<EOS>
;
and
you
need
n't
be
afraid
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
keep
your
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
out
,
you
'll
fall
dead
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
Only
promise
me
,
that
,
if
it
's
the
poor
thing
that
's
kept
here
secretly
,
you
'll
let
me
take
charge
of
her
and
be
her
nurse
.
<EOS>
Only
promise
me
that
,
and
never
be
afraid
of
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
stood
still
for
an
instant
,
at
the
height
of
her
rapid
haste
,
saying
in
stern
amazement
:
   
<EOS>
"
Kept
here
?
 
<EOS>
She
has
been
dead
a
score
of
years
or
more
.
 
<EOS>
Ask
Flintwinch
---
ask
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
They
can
both
tell
you
that
she
died
when
Arthur
went
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
worse
,
"
said
Affery
,
with
a
shiver
,
"
for
she
haunts
the
house
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
Who
else
rustles
about
it
,
making
signals
by
dropping
dust
so
softly
?
 
<EOS>
Who
else
comes
and
goes
,
and
marks
the
walls
with
long
crooked
touches
when
we
are
all
a
-
bed
?
 
<EOS>
Who
else
holds
the
door
sometimes
?
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
go
out
---
<EOS>
do
n't
go
out
!
<EOS>
Mistress
,
you
'll
die
in
the
street
!
"
   
<EOS>
Her
mistress
only
disengaged
her
dress
from
the
beseeching
hands
,
said
to
Rigaud
,
"
Wait
here
till
I
come
back
!
"
and
ran
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
They
saw
her
,
from
the
window
,
run
wildly
through
the
court
-
yard
and
out
at
the
gateway
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
few
moments
they
stood
motionless
.
 
<EOS>
Affery
was
the
first
to
move
,
and
she
,
wringing
her
hands
,
pursued
her
mistress
.
 
<EOS>
Next
,
Jeremiah
Flintwinch
,
slowly
backing
to
the
door
,
with
one
hand
in
a
pocket
,
and
the
other
rubbing
his
chin
,
twisted
himself
out
in
his
reticent
way
,
speechlessly
.
 
<EOS>
Rigaud
,
left
alone
,
composed
himself
upon
the
window
-
seat
of
the
open
window
,
in
the
old
Marseilles
-
jail
attitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
his
cigarettes
and
fire
-
box
ready
to
his
hand
,
and
fell
to
smoking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whoof
!
 
<EOS>
Almost
as
dull
as
the
infernal
old
jail
.
 
<EOS>
Warmer
,
but
almost
as
dismal
.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
she
comes
back
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
certainly
;
but
where
is
she
gone
,
and
how
long
will
she
be
gone
?
 
<EOS>
No
matter
!
<EOS>
Rigaud
Lagnier
Blandois
,
my
amiable
subject
,
you
will
get
your
money
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
enrich
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
lived
a
gentleman
;
you
will
die
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
You
triumph
,
my
little
boy
;
but
it
is
your
character
to
triumph
.
 
<EOS>
Whoof
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
hour
of
his
triumph
,
his
moustache
went
up
and
his
nose
came
down
,
as
he
ogled
a
great
beam
over
his
head
with
particular
satisfaction
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Closed
 
<EOS>
The
sun
had
set
,
and
the
streets
were
dim
in
the
dusty
twilight
,
when
the
figure
so
long
unused
to
them
hurried
on
its
way
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
immediate
neighbourhood
of
the
old
house
it
attracted
little
attention
,
for
there
were
only
a
few
straggling
people
to
notice
it
;
but
,
ascending
from
the
river
by
the
crooked
ways
that
led
to
London
Bridge
,
and
passing
into
the
great
main
road
,
it
became
surrounded
by
astonishment
.
   
<EOS>
Resolute
and
wild
of
look
,
rapid
of
foot
and
yet
weak
and
uncertain
,
conspicuously
dressed
in
its
black
garments
and
with
its
hurried
head
-
covering
,
gaunt
and
of
an
unearthly
paleness
<EOS>
,
it
pressed
forward
,
taking
no
more
heed
of
the
throng
than
a
sleep
-
walker
.
<EOS>
More
remarkable
by
being
so
removed
from
the
crowd
it
was
among
than
if
it
had
been
lifted
on
a
pedestal
to
be
seen
,
the
figure
attracted
all
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Saunterers
pricked
up
their
attention
to
observe
it
;
busy
people
,
crossing
it
,
slackened
their
pace
and
turned
their
heads
;
companions
pausing
and
standing
aside
,
whispered
one
another
to
look
at
this
spectral
woman
who
was
coming
by
;
and
the
sweep
of
the
figure
as
it
passed
seemed
to
create
a
vortex
,
drawing
the
most
idle
and
most
curious
after
it
.
   
<EOS>
Made
giddy
by
the
turbulent
irruption
of
this
multitude
of
staring
faces
into
her
cell
of
years
,
by
the
confusing
sensation
of
being
in
the
air
,
and
the
yet
more
confusing
sensation
of
being
afoot
,
by
the
unexpected
changes
in
half
-
remembered
objects
,
and
the
want
of
likeness
between
the
controllable
pictures
her
imagination
had
often
drawn
of
the
life
from
which
she
was
secluded
and
the
overwhelming
rush
of
the
reality
,
she
held
her
way
as
if
she
were
environed
by
distracting
thoughts
,
rather
than
by
external
humanity
and
observation
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
having
crossed
the
bridge
and
gone
some
distance
straight
onward
,
she
remembered
that
she
must
ask
for
a
direction
;
and
it
was
only
then
,
when
she
stopped
and
turned
to
look
about
her
for
a
promising
place
of
inquiry
,
that
she
found
herself
surrounded
by
an
eager
glare
of
faces
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
are
you
encircling
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
,
trembling
.
   
<EOS>
None
of
those
who
were
nearest
answered
;
but
from
the
outer
ring
there
arose
a
shrill
cry
of
"
'Cause
you
're
mad
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
as
sane
as
any
one
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
find
the
Marshalsea
prison
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
shrill
outer
circle
again
retorted
,
"
Then
that
'
ud
show
you
was
mad
if
nothing
else
did
,
'cause
it
's
right
opposite
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
short
,
mild
,
quiet
-
looking
young
man
made
his
way
through
to
her
,
as
a
whooping
ensued
on
this
reply
,
and
said
:
"
Was
it
the
Marshalsea
you
wanted
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
going
on
duty
there
.
 
<EOS>
Come
across
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
laid
her
hand
upon
his
arm
,
and
he
took
her
over
the
way
;
the
crowd
,
rather
injured
by
the
near
prospect
of
losing
her
,
pressing
before
and
behind
and
on
either
side
,
and
recommending
an
adjournment
to
Bedlam
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
momentary
whirl
in
the
outer
court
-
yard
,
the
prison
-
door
opened
,
and
shut
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
Lodge
,
which
seemed
by
contrast
with
the
outer
noise
a
place
of
refuge
and
peace
,
a
yellow
lamp
was
already
striving
with
the
prison
shadows
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
John
!
"
said
the
turnkey
who
admitted
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
father
;
only
this
lady
not
knowing
her
way
,
and
being
badgered
by
the
boys
.
 
<EOS>
Who
did
you
want
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
Is
she
here
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
man
became
more
interested
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
she
is
here
.
 
<EOS>
What
might
your
name
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Clennam
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Clennam
's
mother
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
young
man
.
   
<EOS>
She
pressed
her
lips
together
,
and
hesitated
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
better
be
told
it
is
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
"
the
Marshal
's
family
living
in
the
country
at
present
,
the
Marshal
has
given
Miss
Dorrit
one
of
the
rooms
in
his
house
to
use
when
she
likes
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
you
had
better
come
up
there
,
and
let
me
bring
Miss
Dorrit
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
signified
her
assent
,
and
he
unlocked
a
door
and
conducted
her
up
a
side
staircase
into
a
dwelling
-
house
above
.
 
<EOS>
He
showed
her
into
a
darkening
room
,
and
left
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
looked
down
into
the
darkening
prison
-
yard
,
with
its
inmates
strolling
here
and
there
,
leaning
out
of
windows
communing
as
much
apart
as
they
could
with
friends
who
were
going
away
,
and
generally
wearing
out
their
imprisonment
as
they
best
might
that
summer
evening
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
heavy
and
hot
;
the
closeness
of
the
place
,
oppressive
;
and
from
without
there
arose
a
rush
of
free
sounds
,
like
the
jarring
memory
of
such
things
in
a
headache
and
heartache
.
 
<EOS>
She
stood
at
the
window
,
bewildered
,
looking
down
into
this
prison
as
it
were
out
of
her
own
different
prison
,
when
a
soft
word
or
two
of
surprise
made
her
start
,
and
Little
Dorrit
stood
before
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
Mrs
Clennam
,
that
you
are
so
happily
recovered
as
---
"
   
Little
Dorrit
stopped
,
for
there
was
neither
happiness
nor
health
in
the
face
that
turned
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
recovery
;
it
is
not
strength
;
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
an
agitated
wave
of
her
hand
,
she
put
all
that
aside
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
packet
left
with
you
which
you
were
to
give
to
Arthur
,
if
it
was
not
reclaimed
before
this
place
closed
to
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
reclaim
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
took
it
from
her
bosom
,
and
gave
it
into
her
hand
,
which
remained
stretched
out
after
receiving
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
any
idea
of
its
contents
?
"
   
<EOS>
Frightened
by
her
being
there
with
that
new
power
Of
Movement
in
her
,
which
,
as
she
said
herself
,
was
not
strength
,
and
which
was
unreal
to
look
upon
,
as
though
a
picture
or
statue
had
been
animated
,
Little
Dorrit
answered
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Read
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
took
the
packet
from
the
still
outstretched
hand
,
and
broke
the
seal
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Clennam
then
gave
her
the
inner
packet
that
was
addressed
to
herself
,
and
held
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
The
shadow
of
the
wall
and
of
the
prison
buildings
,
which
made
the
room
sombre
at
noon
,
made
it
too
dark
to
read
there
,
with
the
dusk
deepening
apace
,
save
in
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
window
,
where
a
little
of
the
bright
summer
evening
sky
could
shine
upon
her
,
Little
Dorrit
stood
,
and
read
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
broken
exclamation
or
so
of
wonder
and
of
terror
,
she
read
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
finished
,
she
looked
round
,
and
her
old
mistress
bowed
herself
before
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
now
,
what
I
have
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
so
;
though
my
mind
is
so
hurried
,
and
so
sorry
,
and
has
so
much
to
pity
that
it
has
not
been
able
to
follow
all
I
have
read
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
tremulously
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
restore
to
you
what
I
have
withheld
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
Forgive
me
.
<EOS>
Can
you
forgive
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
and
Heaven
knows
I
do
!
 
<EOS>
Do
not
kiss
my
dress
and
kneel
to
me
;
you
are
too
old
to
kneel
to
me
;
I
forgive
you
freely
without
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
more
yet
to
ask
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
in
that
posture
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
unnatural
to
see
your
grey
hair
lower
than
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
rise
;
let
me
help
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
she
raised
her
up
,
and
stood
rather
shrinking
from
her
,
but
looking
at
her
earnestly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great
petition
that
I
make
to
you
<EOS>
(
there
is
another
which
grows
out
of
it
)
,
<EOS>
the
great
supplication
that
I
address
to
your
merciful
and
gentle
heart
,
is
,
that
you
will
not
disclose
this
to
Arthur
until
I
am
dead
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
think
,
when
you
have
had
time
for
consideration
,
that
it
can
do
him
any
good
to
know
it
while
I
am
yet
alive
,
then
tell
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
will
not
think
that
;
and
in
such
case
,
will
you
promise
me
to
spare
me
until
I
am
dead
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sorry
,
and
what
I
have
read
has
<EOS>
so
confused
my
thoughts
,
"
returned
Little
Dorrit
,
"
that
I
can
scarcely
give
you
a
steady
answer
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
should
be
quite
sure
that
to
be
acquainted
with
it
will
do
Mr
Clennam
<EOS>
no
good
---
"
   
"
I
know
you
are
attached
to
him
,
and
will
make
him
the
first
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
right
that
he
should
be
the
first
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
having
regarded
him
,
and
still
finding
that
you
may
spare
me
for
the
little
time
I
shall
remain
on
earth
,
will
you
do
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
GOD
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
stood
in
the
shadow
so
that
she
was
only
a
veiled
form
to
Little
Dorrit
in
the
light
;
but
the
sound
of
her
voice
,
in
saying
those
three
grateful
words
,
was
at
once
fervent
and
broken
---
broken
by
emotion
as
unfamiliar
to
her
frozen
eyes
as
action
to
her
frozen
limbs
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
wonder
,
perhaps
,
"
she
said
in
a
stronger
tone
,
"
that
I
can
better
bear
to
be
known
to
you
whom
I
have
wronged
,
than
to
the
son
of
my
enemy
who
wronged
me
.
<EOS>
---
For
she
did
wrong
me
!
 
<EOS>
She
not
only
sinned
grievously
against
the
Lord
,
but
she
wronged
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
Arthur
's
father
was
to
me
,
she
made
him
.
 
<EOS>
From
our
marriage
day
I
was
his
dread
,
and
that
she
made
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
the
scourge
of
both
,
and
that
is
referable
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
You
love
Arthur
<EOS>
(
I
can
see
the
blush
upon
your
face
;
may
it
be
the
dawn
of
happier
days
to
both
of
you
!
)
,
and
you
will
have
thought
already
that
he
is
as
merciful
and
kind
as
you
,
and
why
do
I
not
trust
myself
to
him
as
soon
as
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
not
thought
so
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
thought
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
can
be
quite
a
stranger
to
my
heart
,
that
springs
out
of
the
knowledge
that
Mr
Clennam
is
always
to
be
relied
upon
for
being
kind
and
generous
and
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
doubt
it
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
Arthur
is
,
of
the
whole
world
,
the
one
person
from
whom
I
would
conceal
this
,
while
I
am
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
kept
over
him
as
a
child
,
in
the
days
of
his
first
remembrance
,
my
restraining
and
correcting
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
stern
with
him
,
knowing
that
the
transgressions
of
the
parents
are
visited
on
their
offspring
,
and
that
there
was
an
angry
mark
upon
him
at
his
birth
.
<EOS>
I
have
sat
with
him
and
his
father
,
seeing
the
weakness
of
his
father
yearning
to
unbend
to
him
;
and
forcing
it
back
,
that
the
child
might
work
out
his
release
in
bondage
and
hardship
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
,
with
his
mother
's
face
,
looking
up
at
me
in
awe
from
his
little
books
,
and
trying
to
soften
me
with
his
mother
's
ways
that
hardened
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
shrinking
of
her
auditress
stopped
her
for
a
moment
in
her
flow
of
words
,
delivered
in
a
retrospective
gloomy
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
his
good
.
 
<EOS>
Not
for
the
satisfaction
of
my
injury
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
I
,
and
what
was
the
worth
of
that
,
before
the
curse
of
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
that
child
grow
up
;
not
to
be
pious
in
a
chosen
way
(
his
mother
's
influence
lay
too
heavy
on
him
for
that
)
,
but
still
to
be
just
and
upright
,
and
to
be
submissive
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
loved
me
,
as
I
once
half
-
hoped
he
might
---
<EOS>
so
frail
we
are
,
and
so
do
the
corrupt
affections
of
the
flesh
war
with
our
trusts
and
tasks
;
but
he
always
respected
me
and
ordered
himself
dutifully
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
does
to
this
hour
.
 
<EOS>
With
an
empty
place
in
his
heart
that
he
has
never
known
the
meaning
of
,
he
has
turned
away
from
me
and
gone
his
separate
road
;
but
even
that
he
has
done
considerately
and
with
deference
.
 
<EOS>
These
have
been
his
relations
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
have
been
of
a
much
slighter
kind
,
spread
over
a
much
shorter
time
.
<EOS>
When
you
have
sat
at
your
needle
in
my
room
,
you
have
been
in
fear
of
me
,
but
you
have
supposed
me
to
have
been
doing
you
a
kindness
;
you
are
better
informed
now
,
and
know
me
to
have
done
you
an
injury
.
 
<EOS>
Your
misconstruction
and
misunderstanding
of
the
cause
in
which
,
and
the
motives
with
which
,
I
have
worked
out
this
work
,
is
lighter
to
endure
than
his
would

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
not
,
for
any
worldly
recompense
I
can
imagine
,
have
him
in
a
moment
,
however
blindly
,
throw
me
down
from
the
station
I
have
held
before
him
all
his
life
,
and
change
me
altogether
into
something
he
would
cast
out
of
his
respect
,
and
think
detected
and
exposed
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
do
it
,
if
it
must
be
done
,
when
I
am
not
here
to
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
never
feel
,
while
I
am
still
alive
,
that
I
die
before
his
face
,
and
utterly
perish
away
from
him
,
like
one
consumed
by
lightning
and
swallowed
by
an
earthquake
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
pride
was
very
strong
in
her
,
the
pain
of
it
and
of
her
old
passions
was
very
sharp
with
her
,
when
she
thus
expressed
herself
.
<EOS>
Not
less
so
,
when
she
added
:
   
"
Even
now
,
I
see
YOU
shrink
from
me
,
as
if
I
had
been
cruel
.
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
could
not
gainsay
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
tried
not
to
show
it
,
but
she
recoiled
with
dread
from
the
state
of
mind
that
had
burnt
so

and
lasted
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
It
presented
itself
to
her
,
with
no
sophistry
upon
it
,
in
its
own
plain
nature
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
,
"
said
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
what
it
was
given
to
me
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
set
myself
against
evil
;
not
against
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
an
instrument
of
severity
against
sin
.
 
<EOS>
Have
not
mere
sinners
like
myself
been
commissioned
to
lay
it
low
in
all
time
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
all
time
?
"
repeated
Little
Dorrit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
if
my
own
wrong
had
prevailed
with
me
,
and
my
own
vengeance
had
moved
me
,
could
I
have
found
no
justification
?
 
<EOS>
None
in
the
old
days
when
the
innocent
perished
with
the
guilty
,
a
thousand
to
one
?
 
<EOS>
When
the
wrath
of
the
hater
of
the
unrighteous
was
not
slaked
even
in
blood
,
and
yet
found
favour
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
,
Mrs
Clennam
,
Mrs
Clennam
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
"
angry
feelings
and
unforgiving
deeds
are
no
comfort
and
no
guide
to
you
and
me
.
<EOS>
My
life
has
been
passed
in
this
poor
prison
,
and
my
teaching
has
been
very
defective
;
but
let
me
implore
you
to
remember
later
and
better
days
.
 
<EOS>
Be
guided
only
by
the
healer
of
the
sick
,
the
raiser
of
the
dead
,
the
friend
of
all
who
were
afflicted
and
forlorn
,
the
patient
Master
who
shed
tears
of
compassion
for
our
infirmities
.
<EOS>
We
can
not
but
be
right
if
we
put
all
the
rest
away
,
and
do
everything
in
remembrance
of
Him
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
vengeance
and
no
infliction
of
suffering
in
His
life
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
confusion
in
following
Him
,
and
seeking
for
no
other
footsteps
,
I
am
certain
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
softened
light
of
the
window
,
looking
from
the
scene
of
her
early
trials
to
the
shining
sky
,
she
was
not
in
stronger
opposition
to
the
black
figure
in
the
shade
than
the
life
and
doctrine
on
which
she
rested
<EOS>
were
to
that
figure
's
history
.
 
<EOS>
It
bent
its
head
low
again
,
and
said
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
It
remained
thus
,
until
the
first
warning
bell
began
to
ring
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"
cried
Mrs
Clennam
starting
,
"
<EOS>
I
said
I
had
another
petition
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
one
that
does
not
admit
of
delay
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
brought
you
this
packet
and
possesses
these
proofs
,
is
now
waiting
at
my
house
to
be
bought
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
keep
this
from
Arthur
,
only
by
buying
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
asks
a
large
sum
;
more
than
I
can
get
together
to
pay
him
without
having
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
refuses
to
make
any
abatement
,
because
his
threat
is
,
that
if
he
fails
with
me
,
he
will
come
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
return
with
me
and
show
him
that
you
already
know
it
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
return
with
me
and
try
to
prevail
with
him
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
come
and
help
me
with
him
?
 
<EOS>
Do
not
refuse
what
I
ask
in
Arthur
's
name
,
though
I
dare
not
ask
it
for
Arthur
's
sake
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
yielded
willingly
.
 
<EOS>
She
glided
away
into
the
prison
for
a
few
moments
,
returned
,
and
said
she
was
ready
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
out
by
another
staircase
,
avoiding
the
lodge
;
and
coming
into
the
front
court
-
yard
,
now
all
quiet
and
deserted
,
gained
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
summer
evenings
when
there
is
no
greater
darkness
than
a
long
twilight
.
 
<EOS>
The
vista
of
street
and
bridge
was
plain
to
see
,
and
the
sky
was
serene
and
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
People
stood
and
sat
at
their
doors
,
playing
with
children
and
enjoying
the
evening
;
numbers
were
walking
for
air
;
the
worry
of
the
day
had
almost
worried
itself
out
,
and
few
but
themselves
were
hurried
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
crossed
the
bridge
,
the
clear
steeples
of
the
many
churches
looked
as
if
they
had
advanced
out
of
the
murk
that
usually
enshrouded
them
,
and
come
much
nearer
.
 
<EOS>
The
smoke
that
rose
into
the
sky
had
lost
its
dingy
hue
and
taken
a
brightness
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
beauties
of
the
sunset
had
not
faded
from
the
long
light
films
of
cloud
that
lay
at
peace
in
the
horizon
.
 
<EOS>
From
a
radiant
centre
,
over
the
whole
length
and
breadth
of
the
tranquil
firmament
,
great
shoots
of
light
streamed
among
the
early
stars
,
like
signs
of
the
blessed
later
covenant
of
peace
and
hope
that
changed
the
crown
of
thorns
into
a
glory
.
   
<EOS>
Less
remarkable
,
now
that
she
was
not
alone
and
it
was
darker
,
Mrs
Clennam
hurried
on
at
Little
Dorrit
's
side
,
unmolested
.
 
<EOS>
They
left
the
great
thoroughfare
at
the
turning
by
which
she
had
entered
it
,
and
wound
their
way
down
among
the
silent
,
empty
,
cross
-
streets
.
<EOS>
Their
feet
were
at
the
gateway
,
when
there
was
a
sudden
noise
like
thunder
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
that
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
make
haste
in
,
"
cried
Mrs
Clennam
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
in
the
gateway
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
with
a
piercing
cry
,
held
her
back
.
   
<EOS>
In
one
swift
instant
the
old
house
was
before
them
,
with
the
man
lying
smoking
in
the
window
;
another
thundering
sound
,
and
it
heaved
,
surged
outward
,
opened
asunder
in
fifty
places
,
collapsed
,
and
fell
.
 
<EOS>
Deafened
by
the
noise
,
stifled
,
choked
,
and
blinded
by
the
dust
,
they
hid
their
faces
and
stood
rooted
to
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
The
dust
storm
,
driving
between
them
and
the
placid
sky
,
parted
for
a
moment
and
showed
them
the
stars
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
looked
up
,
wildly
crying
for
help
,
the
great
pile
of
chimneys
,
which
was
then
alone
left
standing
like
a
tower
in
a
whirlwind
,
rocked
,
broke
,
and
hailed
itself
down
upon
the
heap
of
ruin
,
as
if
every
tumbling
fragment
were
intent
on
burying
the
crushed
wretch
deeper
.
   
<EOS>
So
blackened
by
the
flying
particles
of
rubbish
as
to
be
unrecognisable
,
they
ran
back
from
the
gateway
into
the
street
,
crying
and
shrieking
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
Mrs
Clennam
dropped
upon
the
stones
;
and
she
never
from
that
hour
moved
so
much
as
a
finger
again
,
or
had
the
power
to
speak
one
word
.
 
<EOS>
For
upwards
of
three
years
she
reclined
in
a
wheeled
chair
,
looking
attentively
at
those
about
her
and
appearing
to
understand
what
they
said
;
but
the
rigid
silence
she
had
so
long
held
was
evermore
enforced
upon
her
,
and
except
that
she
could
move
her
eyes
and
faintly
express
a
negative
and
affirmative
with
her
head
,
she
lived
and
died
a
statue
.
   
<EOS>
Affery
had
been
looking
for
them
at
the
prison
,
and
had
caught
sight
of
them
at
a
distance
on
the
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
up
to
receive
her
old
mistress
in
her
arms
,
to
help
to
carry
her
into
a
neighbouring
house
,
and
to
be
faithful
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
mystery
of
the
noises
was
out
now
;
Affery
,
like
greater
people
,
had
always
been
right
in
her
facts
,
and
always
wrong
in
the
theories
she
deduced
from
them
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
storm
of
dust
had
cleared
away
and
the
summer
night
was
calm
again
,
numbers
of
people
choked
up
every
avenue
of
access
,
and
parties
of
diggers
were
formed
to
relieve
one
another
in
digging
among
the
ruins
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
hundred
people
in
the
house
at
the
time
of
its
fall
,
there
had
been
fifty
,
there
had
been
fifteen
,
there
had
been
two
.
 
<EOS>
Rumour
finally
settled
the
number
at
two
;
the
foreigner
and
Mr
Flintwinch
.
<EOS>
The
diggers
dug
all
through
the
short
night
by
flaring
pipes
of
gas
,
and
on
a
level
with
the
early
sun
,
and
deeper
and
deeper
below
it
as
it
rose
into
its
zenith
,
and
aslant
of
it
as
it
declined
,
and
on
a
level
with
it
again
as
it
departed
.
 
<EOS>
Sturdy
digging
,
and
shovelling
,
and
carrying
away
,
in
carts
,
barrows
,
and
baskets
,
went
on
without
intermission
,
by
night
and
by
day
;
but
it
was
night
for
the
second
time
when
they
found
the
dirty
heap
of
rubbish
that
had
been
the
foreigner
before
his
head
had
been
shivered
to
atoms
,
like
so
much
glass
,
by
the
great
beam
that
lay
upon
him
,
crushing
him
.
   
<EOS>
Still
,
they
had
not
come
upon
Flintwinch
yet
;
so
the
sturdy
digging
and
shovelling
and
carrying
away
went
on
without
intermission
by
night
and
by
day
.
 
<EOS>
It
got
about
that
the
old
house
had
had
famous
cellarage
(
which
indeed
was
true
)
,
and
that
Flintwinch
had
been
in
a
cellar
at
the
moment
,
or
had
had
time
to
escape
into
one
,
and
that
he
was
safe
under
its
strong
arch
,
and
even
that
he
had
been
heard
to
cry
,
in
hollow
,
subterranean
,
suffocated
notes
,
"
Here
I
am
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
the
opposite
extremity
of
the
town
it
was
even
known
that
the
excavators
had
been
able
to
open
a
communication
with
him
through
a
pipe
,
and
that
he
had
received
both
soup
and

by
that
channel
,
and
that
he
had
said
with
admirable
fortitude
that
he
was
All
right
,
my
lads
,
with
the
exception
of
his
collar
-
bone
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
digging
and
shovelling
and
carrying
away
went
on
without
intermission
,
until
the
ruins
were
all
dug
out
,
and
the
cellars
opened
to
the
light
;
and
still
no
Flintwinch
,
living
or
dead
,
all
right
or
all
wrong
,
had
been
turned
up
by
pick
or

.
   
<EOS>
It
began
then
to
be
perceived
that
Flintwinch
had
not
been
there
at
the
time
of
the
fall
;
and
it
began
then
to
be
perceived
that
he
had
been
rather
busy
elsewhere
,
converting
securities
into
as
much
money
as
could
be
got
for
them
on
the
shortest
notice
,
and
turning
to
his
own
exclusive
account
his
authority
to
act
for
the
Firm
.
<EOS>
Affery
,
remembering
that
the
clever
one
had
said
he
would
explain
himself
further
in
four
-
and

hours
'
time
,
determined
for
her
part
that
his

off
within
that

with
all

,
was
the

sum
and
substance
of
his
promised

;
but
she
held
her
peace
,
devoutly
thankful
to
be
quit
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
seemed
reasonable
to
conclude
that
a
man
who
had
never
been
buried
could
not
be
unburied
,
the
diggers
gave

up
when
their
task
was
done
,
and
did
not
dig
down
for
him
into
the
depths
of

earth
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
taken
in
ill
part
by
a
great
many

,
who
persisted
in
believing
that
Flintwinch
was
lying

London

.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
their
belief
much
shaken
by
repeated
intelligence
which
came
over
in

time
,
that
an
old
man
who

the
tie
of
his

under
one

,
and
who
was

,

,

of
Mynheer

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
Going
 
Arthur
continuing
to
lie
very
ill
in
the
Marshalsea
,
and
<EOS>
Mr
Rugg
descrying
no
break

affording

of
his

,
Mr
Pancks
suffered

from
self
-

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

,

,

there

,

.
 
<EOS>
Solely

by

,
Mr

led
an

;
constantly

about
with

,

and

.
 
<EOS>
Down
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
<EOS>
there

scarcely
an

of

not

,
and
,

figures
are

,

broke

that

,
under

was

.
   
<EOS>
The
more

Mr

grew
in

,
the
more

of

.
 
<EOS>
In
their

his

assumed
an

which
boded
the
Patriarch
no
good
;
likewise
,
Mr
Pancks
had
on
several

looked
harder
at
the
Patriarchal
bumps
than
was
quite
reconcilable
with
the
fact
of
his
not
being
a

,
or
a

-

in
search
of

.
   
<EOS>
However
,

steamed
in

Dock
according
as

wanted

in
the
Patriarchal

,
and
business
had
gone
on
in
its

.
 
<EOS>
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
had
been
harrowed
by
Mr
Pancks
,
and
cropped
by
Mr

,

;

;

,

as

;

,

,

,
"
everything

all

---

,

,
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Dock

,
Pancks
,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr

,
"

<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Everybody

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
this

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
that
