Not
at
present
,
sir
,
not
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
,
"
said
the
Patriarch
,
finishing
his
mixture
,
and
rising
with
an
amiable
air
,
"
to
take
a
little
stroll
,
a
little
stroll
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
shall
find
you
here
when
I
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
If
not
,
sir
,
duty
,
duty
;
squeeze
,
squeeze
,
squeeze
,
on
Monday
;
squeeze
on
Monday
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
,
after
another
stiffening
of
his
hair
,
looked
on
at
the
Patriarchal
assumption
of
the
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
with
a
momentary
appearance
of
indecision
contending
with
a
sense
of
injury
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
also
hotter
than
at
first
,
and
breathed
harder
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
suffered
Mr
Casby
to
go
out
,
without
offering
any
further
remark
,
and
then
took
a
peep
at
him
over
the
little
green
window
-
blinds
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
,
"
he
observed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
where
you
were
bound
to
.
 
<EOS>
Good
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
steamed
back
to
his
Dock
,
put
it
carefully
in
order
,
took
down
his
hat
,
looked
round
the
Dock
,
<EOS>
said
"
Good
-
bye
!
"
and
puffed
away
on
his
own
account
.
 
<EOS>
He
steered
straight
for
Mrs
Plornish
's
end
of
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
and
arrived
there
,
at
the
top
of
the
steps
,
hotter
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
top
of
the
steps
,
resisting
Mrs
Plornish
's
invitations
to
come
and
sit
along
with
father
in
Happy
Cottage
---
which
to
his
relief
were
not
so
numerous
as
they
would
have
been
on
any
other
night
than
Saturday
,
when
the
connection
who
so
gallantly
supported
the
business
with
everything
but
money
gave
their
orders
freely
---
at
the
top
of
the
steps
Mr
Pancks
remained
until
he
beheld
the
Patriarch
,
who
always
entered
the
Yard
at
the
other
end
,
slowly
advancing
,
beaming
,
and
surrounded
by
suitors
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Mr
Pancks
descended
and
bore
down
upon
him
,
with
his
utmost
pressure
of
steam
on
.
   
<EOS>
The
Patriarch
,
approaching
with
his
usual
benignity
,
was
surprised
to
see
Mr
Pancks
,
but
supposed
him
to
have
been
stimulated
to
an
immediate
squeeze
instead
of
postponing
that
operation
until
Monday
.
 
<EOS>
The
population
of
the
Yard
were
astonished
at
the
meeting
,
for
the
two
powers
had
never
been
seen
there
together
,
within
the
memory
of
the
oldest
Bleeding
Heart
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
were
overcome
by
unutterable
amazement
when
Mr
Pancks
,
going
close
up
to
the
most
venerable
of
men
and
halting
in
front
of
the
bottle
-
green
waistcoat
,
made
a
trigger
of
his
right
thumb
and
forefinger
,
applied
the
same
to
the
brim
of
the
broad
-
brimmed
hat
,
and
,
with
singular
smartness
and
precision
,
shot
it
off
the
polished
head
as
if
it
had
been
a
large
marble
.
   
<EOS>
Having
taken
this
little
liberty
with
the
Patriarchal
person
,
Mr
Pancks
further
astounded
and
attracted
the
Bleeding
Hearts
by
saying
in
an
audible
voice
,
"
Now
,
you
sugary
swindler
,
I
mean
to
have
it
out
with
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
and
the
Patriarch
were
instantly
the
centre
of
a
press
,
all
eyes
and
ears
;
windows
were
thrown
open
,
and
door
-
steps
were
thronged
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
pretend
to
be
?
"
said
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
moral
game
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
go
in
for
?
 
<EOS>
Benevolence
,
an't
it
?
 
<EOS>
You
benevolent
!
"
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Pancks
,
apparently
without
the
intention
of
hitting
him
,
but
merely
to
relieve
his
mind
and
expend
his
superfluous
power
in
wholesome
exercise
,
aimed
a
blow
at
the
bumpy
head
,
which
the
bumpy
head
ducked
to
avoid
.
 
<EOS>
This
singular
performance
was
repeated
,
to
the
ever
-
increasing
admiration
of
the
spectators
,
at
the
end
of
every
succeeding
article
of
Mr
Pancks
's
oration
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
discharged
myself
from
your
service
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
that
I
may
tell
you
what
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
one
of
a
lot
of
impostors
that
are
the
worst
lot
of
all
the
lots
to
be
met
with
.
 
<EOS>
Speaking
as
a
sufferer
by
both
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
that
I
would
n't
as
soon
have
the
Merdle
lot
as
your
lot
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
driver
in
disguise
,
a
screwer
by
deputy
,
a
wringer
,
and
squeezer
,
and
shaver
by
substitute
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
philanthropic
sneak
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
shabby
deceiver
!
"
<EOS>
(
The
repetition
of
the
performance
at
this
point
was
received
with
a
burst
of
laughter
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
these
good
people
who
's
the
hard
man
here
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
tell
you
Pancks
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
confirmed
with
cries
of
"
Certainly
,
"
and
"
Hear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
tell
you
,
good
people
---
Casby
!
 
<EOS>
This
mound
of
meekness
,
this
lump
of
love
,
this
bottle
-
green
smiler
,
this
is
your
driver
!
"
said
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
to
see
the
man
who
would
flay
you
alive
---
here
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
look
for
him
in
me
,
at
thirty
shillings
a
week
,
but
look
for
him
in
Casby
,
at
I
do
n't
know
how
much
a
year
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
cried
several
voices
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
Mr
Pancks
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
Mr
Pancks
?
"
<EOS>
cried
that
gentleman
(
after
repeating
the
popular
performance
)
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
should
think
so
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
almost
time
to
hear
Mr
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
has
come
down
into
the
Yard
to
-
night
on
purpose
that
you
should
hear
him
.
 
<EOS>
Pancks
is
only
the
Works
;
but
here
's
the
Winder
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
audience
would
have
gone
over
to
Mr
Pancks
,
as
one
man
,
woman
,
and
child
,
but
for
the
long
,
grey
,
silken
locks
,
and
the
broad
-
brimmed
hat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
Stop
,
"
said
Pancks
,
"
that
sets
the
tune
to
be
ground
.
<EOS>
And
there
is
but
one
tune
,
and
its
name
is
Grind
,
Grind
,
Grind
!
<EOS>
Here
's
the
Proprietor
,
and
here
's
his
Grubber
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
good
people
,
when
he
comes
smoothly
spinning
through
the
Yard
to
-
night
,
like
a
slow
-
going
benevolent
Humming
-
Top
,
and
when
you
come
about
him
with
your
complaints
of
the
Grubber
,
you
do
n't
know
what
a
cheat
the
Proprietor
is
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
his
showing
himself
to
-
night
,
that
I
may
have
all
the
blame
on
Monday
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
his
having
had
me
over
the
coals
this
very
evening
,
because
I
do
n't
squeeze
you
enough
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
my
being
,
at
the
present
moment
,
under
special
orders
to
squeeze
you
dry
on
Monday
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
reply
was
given
in
a
murmur
of
"
Shame
!
"
<EOS>
and
"
Shabby
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shabby
?
"
snorted
Pancks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
should
think
so
!
 
<EOS>
The
lot
that
your
Casby
belongs
to
,
is
the
shabbiest
of
all
the
lots
.
 
<EOS>
Setting
their
Grubbers
on
,
at
a
wretched
pittance
,
to
do
what
they
're
ashamed
and
afraid
to
do
and
pretend
not
to
do
,
but
what
they
will
have
done
,
or
give
a
man
no
rest
!
 
<EOS>
Imposing
on
you
to
give
their
Grubbers
nothing
but
blame
,
and
to
give
them
nothing
but
credit
!
<EOS>
Why
,
the
worst
-
looking
cheat
in
all
this
town
who
gets
the
value
of
eighteenpence
under
false
pretences
,
an't
half
such
a
cheat
as
this
sign
-
post
of
The
Casby
's
Head
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Cries
of
"
That
's
true
!
"
<EOS>
and
"
No
more
he
an't
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
see
what
you
get
of
these
fellows
,
besides
,
"
said
Pancks
.
<EOS>
"
See
what
more
you
get
of
these
precious
Humming
-
Tops
,
revolving
among
you
with
such
smoothness
that
you
've
no
idea
of
the
pattern
painted
on
'em
,
or
the
little
window
in
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
call
your
attention
to
myself
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
an't
an
agreeable
style
of
chap
<EOS>
,
I
know
that
very
well
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
auditory
were
divided
on
this
point
;
its
more
uncompromising
members
crying
,
"
No
,
you
are
not
,
"
and
its
politer
materials
,
"
Yes
,
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
in
general
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
a
dry
,
uncomfortable
,
dreary
Plodder
and
Grubber
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
your
humble
servant
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
his
full
-
length
portrait
,
painted
by
himself
and
presented
to
you
,
warranted
a
likeness
!
 
<EOS>
But
what
's
a
man
to
be
,
with
such
a
man
as
this
for
his
Proprietor
?
 
<EOS>
What
can
be
expected
of
him
?
 
<EOS>
Did
anybody
ever
find
boiled
mutton
and
caper
-
sauce
growing
in
a
cocoa
-
nut
?
"
   
<EOS>
None
of
the
Bleeding
Hearts
ever
had
,
it
was
clear
from
the
alacrity
of
their
response
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
and
neither
will
you
find
in
Grubbers
like
myself
,
under
Proprietors
like
this
,
pleasant
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
a
Grubber
from
a
boy
.
 
<EOS>
What
has
my
life
been
?
 
<EOS>
Fag
and
grind
,
fag
and
grind
,
turn
the
wheel
,
turn
the
wheel
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
been
agreeable
to
myself
,
and
I
have
n't
been
likely
to
be
agreeable
to
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
a
shilling
a
week
less
useful
in
ten
years
'
time
,
this
impostor
would
give
me
a
shilling
a
week
less
;
if
as
useful
a
man
could
be
got
at
sixpence
cheaper
,
he
would
be
taken
in
my
place
at
sixpence
cheaper
.
 
<EOS>
Bargain
and
sale
,
bless
you
!
 
<EOS>
Fixed
principles
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
mighty
fine
sign
-
post
,
is
The
Casby
's
Head
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
surveying
it
with
anything
rather
than
admiration
;
"
but
the
real
name
of
the
House
is
the
Sham
's
Arms
.
 
<EOS>
Its
motto
is
,
Keep
the
Grubber
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Is
any
gentleman
present
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
breaking
off
and
looking
round
,
"
acquainted
with
the
English
Grammar
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
was
shy
of
claiming
that
acquaintance
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
matter
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
"
I
merely
wish
to
remark
that
the
task
this
Proprietor
has
set
me
,
has
been
never
to
leave
off
conjugating
the
Imperative
Mood
Present
Tense
of
the
verb
To
keep
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
thou
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
keep
always
at
it
.
<EOS>
Keep
we
or
do
we
keep
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
ye
or
do
ye
<EOS>
or
you
keep
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
keep
always
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
your
benevolent
Patriarch
of
a
Casby
,
and
there
is
his
golden
rule
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
uncommonly
improving
to
look
at
,
and
I
am
not
at
all
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
as
sweet
as
honey
,
and
I
am
as
dull
as
ditch
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
He
provides
the
pitch
,
and
I
handle
it
,
and
it
sticks
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said
Mr
Pancks
,
closing
upon
his
late
Proprietor
again
,
from
whom
he
had
withdrawn
a
little
for
the
better
display
of
him
to
the
Yard
;
"
as
I
am
not
accustomed
to
speak
in
public
,
and
as
I
have
made
a
rather
lengthy
speech
,
all
circumstances
considered
,
I
shall
bring
my
observations
to
a
close
by
requesting
you
to
get
out
of
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Last
of
the
Patriarchs
had
been
so
seized
by
assault
,
and
required
so
much
room
to
catch
an
idea
in
,
an
so
much
more
room
to
turn
it
in
,
that
he
had
not
a
word
to
offer
in
reply
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
be
meditating
some
Patriarchal
way
out
of
his
delicate
position
,
when
Mr
Pancks
,
once
more
suddenly
applying
the
trigger
to
his
hat
,
shot
it
off
again
with
his
former
dexterity
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
preceding
occasion
,
one
or
two
of
the
Bleeding
Heart
Yarders
had
obsequiously
picked
it
up
and
handed
it
to
its
owner
;
but
Mr
Pancks
had
now
so
far
impressed
his
audience
,
that
the
Patriarch
had
to
turn
and
stoop
for
it
himself
.
   
<EOS>
Quick
as
lightning
,
Mr
Pancks
,
who
,
for
some
moments
,
had
had
his
right
hand
in
his
coat
pocket
,
whipped
out
a
pair
of
shears
,
swooped
upon
the
Patriarch
behind
,
and
snipped
off
short
the
sacred
locks
that
flowed
upon
his
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
paroxysm
of
animosity
and
rapidity
,
Mr
Pancks
then
caught
the
broad
-
brimmed
hat
out
of
the
astounded
Patriarch
's
hand
,
cut
it
down
into
a
mere
stewpan
,
and
fixed
it
on
the
Patriarch
's
head
.
   
<EOS>
Before
the
frightful
results
of
this
desperate
action
,
Mr
Pancks
himself
recoiled
in
consternation
.
 
<EOS>
A
bare
-
polled
,
goggle
-
eyed
,
big
-
headed
lumbering
personage
stood
staring
at
him
,
not
in
the
least
impressive
,
not
in
the
least
venerable
,
who
seemed
to
have
started
out
of
the
earth
to
ask
what
was
become
of
Casby
.
 
<EOS>
After
staring
at
this
phantom
in
return
,
in
silent
awe
,
Mr
Pancks
threw
down
his
shears
,
and
fled
for
a
place
of
hiding
,
where
he
might
lie
sheltered
from
the
consequences
of
his
crime
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pancks
deemed
it
prudent
to
use
all
possible
despatch
in
making
off
,
though
he
was
pursued
by
nothing
but
the
sound
of
laughter
in
Bleeding
Heart
Yard
,
rippling
through
the
air
and
making
it
ring
again
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Going
!
 
<EOS>
The
changes
of
a
fevered
room
are
slow
and
fluctuating
;
but
the
changes
of
the
fevered
world
are
rapid
and
irrevocable
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Little
Dorrit
's
lot
to
wait
upon
both
kinds
of
change
.
 
<EOS>
The
Marshalsea
walls
,
during
a
portion
of
every
day
,
again
embraced
her
in
their
shadows
as
their
child
,
while
she
thought
for
Clennam
,
worked
for
him
,
watched
him
,
and
only
left
him
,
still
to
devote
her
utmost
love
and
care
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Her
part
in
the
life
outside
the
gate
urged
its
pressing
claims
upon
her
too
,
and
her
patience
untiringly
responded
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
Fanny
,
proud
,
fitful
,
whimsical
,
further
advanced
in
that
disqualified
state
for
going
into
society
which
had
so
much
fretted
her
on
the
evening
of
the
tortoise
-
shell
knife
,
resolved
always
to
want
comfort
,
resolved
not
to
be
comforted
,
resolved
to
be
deeply
wronged
,
and
resolved
that
nobody
should
have
the
audacity
to
think
her
so
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
her
brother
,
a
weak
,
proud
,
tipsy
,
young
old
man
,
shaking
from
head
to
foot
,
talking
as
indistinctly
as
if
some
of
the
money
he
plumed
himself
upon
had
got
into
his
mouth
and
could
n't
be
got
out
,
unable
to
walk
alone
in
any
act
of
his
life
,
and
patronising
the
sister
whom
he
selfishly
loved
<EOS>
(
he
always
had
that
negative
merit
,
ill
-
starred
and
ill
-
launched
Tip
!
)
<EOS>
because
he
suffered
her
to
lead
him
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
Mrs
Merdle
in
gauzy
mourning
---
<EOS>
the
original
cap
whereof
had
possibly
been
rent
to
pieces
in
a
fit
of
grief
,
but
had
certainly
yielded
to
a
highly
becoming
article
from
the
Parisian
market
---
warring
with
Fanny
foot
to
foot
,
and
breasting
her
with
her
desolate
bosom
every
hour
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
poor
Mr
Sparkler
,
not
knowing
how
to
keep
the
peace
between
them
,
but
humbly
inclining
to
the
opinion
that
they
could
do
no
better
than
agree
that
they
were
both
remarkably
fine
women
,
and
that
there
was
no
nonsense
about
either
of
them
---
for
which
gentle
recommendation
they
united
in
falling
upon
him
frightfully
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
too
,
here
was
Mrs
General
,
got
home
from
foreign
parts
,
sending
a
Prune
and
a
Prism
by
post
every
other
day
,
demanding
a
new
Testimonial
by
way
of
recommendation
to
some
vacant
appointment
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
Of
which
remarkable
gentlewoman
it
may
be
finally
observed
,
that
there
surely
never
was
a
gentlewoman
of
whose
transcendent
fitness
for
any
vacant
appointment
on
the
face
of
this
earth
,
so
many
people
were
(
as
the
warmth
of
her
Testimonials
evinced
)
so
perfectly
satisfied
---
or
who
was
so
very
unfortunate
in
having
a
large
circle
of
ardent
and
distinguished
admirers
,
who
never
themselves
happened
to
want
her
in
any
capacity
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
first
crash
of
the
eminent
Mr
Merdle
's
decease
,
many
important
persons
had
been
unable
to
determine
whether
they
should
cut
Mrs
Merdle
,
or
comfort
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
seemed
,
however
,
essential
to
the
strength
of
their
own
case
that
they
should
admit
her
to
have
been
cruelly
deceived
,
they
graciously
made
the
admission
,
and
continued
to
know
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
followed
that
Mrs
Merdle
,
as
a
woman
of
fashion
and
good
breeding
who
had
been
sacrificed
to
the
wiles
of
a
vulgar
barbarian
(
for
Mr
Merdle
was
found
out
from
the
crown
of
his
head
to
the
sole
of
his
foot
,
the
moment
he
was
found
out
in
his
pocket
)
,
must
be
actively
championed
by
her
order
for
her
order
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
She
returned
this
fealty
by
causing
it
to
be
understood
that
she
was
even
more
incensed
against
the
felonious
shade
of
the
deceased
than
anybody
else
was
;
thus
,
on
the
whole
,
she
came
out
of
her
furnace
like
a
wise
woman
,
and
did
exceedingly
well
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Sparkler
's
lordship
was
fortunately
one
of
those
shelves
on
which
a
gentleman
is
considered
to
be
put
away
for
life
,
unless
there
should
be
reasons
for
hoisting
him
up
with
the
Barnacle
crane
to
a
more
lucrative
height
.
 
<EOS>
That
patriotic
servant
accordingly
stuck
to
his
colours
(
the
Standard
of
four
Quarterings
)
,
and
was
a
perfect
Nelson
in
respect
of
nailing
them
to
the
mast
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
profits
of
his
intrepidity
,
Mrs
Sparkler
and
Mrs
Merdle
,
inhabiting
different
floors
of
the
genteel
little
temple
of
inconvenience
to
which
the
smell
of
the
day
before
yesterday
's
soup
and
coach
-

was
as
constant
as
Death
to
man
,
arrayed
themselves
to
fight
it
out
in
the
lists
of
Society
,
sworn
rivals
.
 
<EOS>
And
Little
Dorrit
,
seeing
all
these
things
as
they
developed
themselves
,
could
not
but
wonder
,
anxiously
,
into
what
back
corner
of
the
genteel
establishment
Fanny
's
children
would
be
poked
by
-
and
-
by
,
and
who
would
take
care
of
those
unborn
little
victims
.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
being
far
too
ill
to
be
spoken
with
on
subjects
of
emotion
or
anxiety
,
and
his
recovery
greatly
depending
on
the
repose
into
which
his
weakness
could
be
hushed
,
Little
Dorrit
's
sole
reliance
during
this
heavy
period
was
on
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
abroad
;
but
she
had
written
to
him
through
his
daughter
,
immediately
after
first
seeing
Arthur
in
the
Marshalsea
and
since
,
confiding
her
uneasiness
to
him
on
the
points
on
which
she
was
most
anxious
,
but
especially
on
one
.
 
<EOS>
To
that
one
,
the
continued
absence
of
Mr
Meagles
abroad
,
instead
of
his
comforting
presence
in
the
Marshalsea
,
was
referable
.
   
<EOS>
Without
disclosing
the
precise
nature
of
the
documents
that
had
fallen
into
Rigaud
's
hands
,
Little
Dorrit
had
confided
the
general
outline
of
that
story
to
Mr
Meagles
,
to
whom
she
had
also
recounted
his
fate
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
cautious
habits
of
the
scales
and
scoop
at
once
showed
Mr
Meagles
the
importance
of
recovering
the
original
papers
;
wherefore
he
wrote
back
to
Little
Dorrit
,
strongly
confirming
her
in
the
solicitude
she
expressed
on
that
head
,
and
adding
that
he
would
not
come
over
to
England
"
without
making
some
attempt
to
trace
them
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
Mr
Henry
Gowan
had
made
up
his
mind
that
it
would
be
agreeable
to
him
not
to
know
the
Meagleses
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
considerate
as
to
lay
no
injunctions
on
his
wife
in
that
particular
;
but
he
mentioned
to
Mr
Meagles
that
personally
they
did
not
appear
to
him
to
get
on
together
,
and
that
he
thought
it
would
be
a
good
thing
if
---
politely
,
and
without
any
scene
,
or
anything
of
that
sort
---
they
agreed
that
they
were
the
best
fellows
in
the
world
,
but
were
best
apart
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Meagles
,
who
was
already
sensible
that
he
did
not
advance
his
daughter
's
happiness
by
being
constantly
slighted
in
her
presence
,
said
"
Good
,
Henry
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
my
Pet
's
husband
;
you
have
displaced
me
,
in
the
course
of
nature
;
if
you
wish
it
,
good
!
"
<EOS>
This
arrangement
involved
the
contingent
advantage
,
which
perhaps
Henry
Gowan
had
not
foreseen
,
that
both
Mr
and
Mrs
Meagles
were
more
liberal
than
before
to
their
daughter
,
when
their
communication
was
only
with
her
and
her
young
child
:
and
that
his
high
spirit
found
itself
better
provided
with
money
,
without
being
under
the
degrading
necessity
of
knowing
whence
it
came
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
at
such
a
period
,
naturally
seized
an
occupation
with
great
ardour
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
from
his
daughter
the
various
towns
which
Rigaud
had
been
haunting
,
and
the
various
hotels
at
which
he
had
been
living
for
some
time
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
occupation
he
set
himself
was
to
visit
these
with
all
discretion
and
speed
,
and
,
in
the
event
of
finding
anywhere
that
he
had
left
a
bill
unpaid
,
and
a
box
or
parcel
behind
,
to
pay
such
bill
,
and
bring
away
such
box
or
parcel
.
   
<EOS>
With
no
other
attendant
than
Mother
,
Mr
Meagles
went
upon
his
pilgrimage
,
and
encountered
a
number
of
adventures
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
least
of
his
difficulties
was
,
that
he
never
knew
what
was
said
to
him
,
and
that
he
pursued
his
inquiries
among
people
who
never
knew
what
he
said
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
with
an
unshaken
confidence
that
the
English
tongue
was
somehow
the
mother
tongue
of
the
whole
world
,
only
the
people
were
too
stupid
to
know
it
,
Mr
Meagles
harangued
innkeepers
in
the
most
voluble
manner
,
entered
into
loud
explanations
of
the
most
complicated
sort
,
and
utterly
renounced
replies
in
the
native
language
of
the
respondents
,
on
the
ground
that
they
were
"
all
bosh
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
interpreters
were
called
in
;
whom
Mr
Meagles
addressed
in
such
idiomatic
terms
of
speech
,
as
instantly
to
extinguish
and
shut
up
---
which
made
the
matter
worse
.
<EOS>
On
a
balance
of
the
account
,
however
,
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
lost
much
;
for
,
although
he
found
no
property
,
he
found
so
many
debts
and
various
associations
of
discredit
with
the
proper
name
,
which
was
the
only
word
he
made
intelligible
,
that
he
was
almost
everywhere
overwhelmed
with
injurious
accusations
.
 
<EOS>
On
no
fewer
than
four
occasions
the
police
were
called
in
to
receive
denunciations
of
Mr
Meagles
as
a
Knight
of
Industry
,
a
good
-
for
-
nothing
,
and
a
thief
,
all
of
which
opprobrious
language
he
bore
with
the
best
temper
(
having
no
idea
what
it
meant
)
,
and
was
in
the
most
ignominious
manner
escorted
to
steam
-
boats
and
public
carriages
,
to
be
got
rid
of
,
talking
all
the
while
,
like
a
cheerful
and
fluent
Briton
as
he
was
,
with
Mother
under
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
in
his
own
tongue
,
and
in
his
own
head
,
Mr
Meagles
was
a
clear
,
shrewd
,
persevering
man
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
"
worked
round
,
"
as
he
called
it
,
to
Paris
in
his
pilgrimage
,
and
had
wholly
failed
in
it
so
far
,
he
was
not
disheartened
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
nearer
to
England
<EOS>
I
follow
him
,
you
see
,
Mother
,
"
argued
Mr
Meagles
,
"
the
nearer
I
am
likely
to
come
to
the
papers
,
whether
they
turn
up
<EOS>
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
Because
it
is
only
reasonable
to
conclude
that
he
would
deposit
them
somewhere
where
they
would
be
safe
from
people
over
in
England
,
and
where
they
would
yet
be
accessible
to
himself
,
do
n't
you
see
?
"
   
<EOS>
At
Paris
Mr
Meagles
found
a
letter
from
Little
Dorrit
,
lying
waiting
for
him
;
in
which
she
mentioned
that
she
had
been
able
to
talk
for
a
minute
or
two
with
Mr
Clennam
about
this
man
who
was
no
more
;
and
that
when
she
told
Mr
Clennam
that
his
friend
Mr
Meagles
,
who
was
on

to
see

,
had
an

in
ascertaining
something
about
the
man
if
he
could
,
he
had
asked
her
to
tell
Mr
Meagles
that
he
had
been
known
to
Miss
Wade
,
then
living
in
such
a
street
at
Calais
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
   
<EOS>
As
soon
afterwards
as
might
be
in
those
Diligence
days
,
Mr
Meagles
rang
the
cracked
bell
at
the
cracked
gate
,
and
it
jarred
open
,
and
the
peasant
-
woman
stood
in
the
dark
doorway
,
saying
,
"
Ice
-
say
!
<EOS>
Seer
!
 
<EOS>
Who
?
"
 
<EOS>
In
acknowledgment
of
whose
address
,
Mr
Meagles
murmured
to
himself
that
there
was
some
sense
about
these
Calais
people
,
who
really
did
know
something
of
what
you
and
themselves
were
up
to
;
and
returned
,
"
Miss
Wade
,
my
dear
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
then
shown
into
the
presence
of
Miss
Wade
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
some
time
since
we
met
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
clearing
his
throat
;
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
been
pretty
well
,
Miss
Wade
?
"
   
<EOS>
Without
hoping
that
he
or
anybody
else
had
been
pretty
well
,
Miss
Wade
asked
him
to
what
she
was
indebted
for
the
honour
of
seeing
him
again
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
in
the
meanwhile
,
glanced
all
round
the
room
without
observing
anything
in
the
shape
of
a
box
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
truth
is
,
Miss
Wade
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
in
a
comfortable
,
managing
,
not
to
say
coaxing
voice
,
"
it
is
possible
that
you
may
be
able
to
throw
a
light
upon
a
little
something
that
is
at
present
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Any
unpleasant
bygones
between
us
are
bygones
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
Ca
n't
be
helped
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
recollect
my
daughter
?
 
<EOS>
Time
changes
so
!
<EOS>
A
mother
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
his
innocence
,
Mr
Meagles
could
not
have
struck
a
worse
keynote
.
<EOS>
He
paused
for
any

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
the
subject
you
wished

on
?
"
<EOS>
she

,
after

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
returned
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
your

might
---
"
   
"
I

knew
,
"
she

with

"
that
my

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
said

Meagles
;
"
you
do

an
injustice
.
<EOS>
However
,
to
come

the
point
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
For
he
was
sensible

gained
nothing
by

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have

,

,

---
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
---
that

some

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

<EOS>
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
But

"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
It

her

,

<EOS>
So

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"
I

knew
anything
of
a
man

I

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now

"

"

!
 
<EOS>
Do

,

it
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

I

were
not
his

,
were

,
might
at

,
and
are

.
 
<EOS>
He
passed
through

going

,
and

,

<EOS>
Did

?
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Did

?
 
<EOS>
Did

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

"
   
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Tattycoram

well

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
She

"
Beaten
,

;

"
 
<EOS>
He

,

;
and

.
   
<EOS>
The

John
was

Father

Meagles

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dorrit
was
not

,

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Clennam
was

;
and
Maggy
and

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Dorrit
was

that

.
 
<EOS>
There

the
room
the

had

,
up

,

,

<EOS>
Mistrustful

without
preparation

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
Good

"

,
"

Miss

!
<EOS>
Why
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Tattycoram
!
"
   
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
And
in
Tattycoram
's

was
an

some

.
 
<EOS>
Such

had
Affery

seen
,
in

,

<EOS>
This

:
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

it

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Here

!
"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Here

!
"
   
<EOS>
Father

Mother
Meagles
never

headstrong

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

,
weeping

,
"
always
so

,

so

!
 
<EOS>
I
was

her

.
 
<EOS>
I

she

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>
when

,
that

all

;
and

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
I
made

out
that
they
triumphed

,

,

I

---
when

---

.
 
<EOS>
And
my

not

,

!
 
<EOS>
Such

!
 
<EOS>
But

?
 
<EOS>
For
I

I

,
"

;
"
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Miss
Wade

,

my
own
self
grown

---

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

,

,
"

,
in

,
"
for
I

as

.
 
<EOS>
I
only

,
that
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't

five
-

-

,
sir
,
I
'll
count

-

-

,
five
-

-

!
"
   
<EOS>
Another

of
the

,
and
Tattycoram
subsided
,
and
Little
Dorrit
came
in
,
and
Mr
Meagles
with

produced
the
box
,
and
her

was

.
   
<EOS>
The
secret
was
safe
now
!
 
<EOS>
She
could
keep
her
own

of
it
from
him
;
he

never
know
of
her

;
in

to
come
he
should
know
all
that
was
of
import
to

;
but
he
should
never
know
what
concerned
her
only
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
all
passed
,
all

,
all

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
Miss
Dorrit
,
"
said

Meagles
;
"
I
am
a
man

---
or

least

---
<EOS>
and
I
am
going
to
take

,

.
 
<EOS>
Had
I
better
see
Arthur
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
to
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
will

his

and

.
 
<EOS>
But

will

to
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
much

,

,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
and

.
<EOS>
Then
I

for

.
<EOS>
But
I
'll

when

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

room
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
,
looking
through
the
bars

the
window
,
saw
her
pass
out
of
the
Lodge
below
him
into

prison
-

.
<EOS>
He
said
gently
,
"
Tattycoram
,
come
to
me

,
my
good
girl
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
went
up
to
the
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
that
young
lady
who
was
here
just
now
---
that
little
,
quiet
,
fragile
figure
passing
along
there
,
Tatty
?
 
<EOS>
Look
.
 
<EOS>
The
people
stand
out
of
the
way
to
let
her
go
by
.
 
<EOS>
The
men
---
see
the
poor
,
shabby
fellows
---
pull
off
their
hats
to
her
quite
politely
,
and
now
she
glides
in
at
that
doorway
.
 
<EOS>
See
her
,
Tattycoram
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
tell
,
Tatty
,
that
she
was
once
regularly
called
the
child
of
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
born
here
,
and
lived
here
many
years
.
   
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
breathe
here
.
 
<EOS>
A
doleful
place
to
be
born
and
bred
in
,
Tattycoram
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
indeed
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
she
had
constantly
thought
of
herself
,
and
settled
with
herself
that
everybody
visited
this
place
upon
her
,
turned
it
against
her
,
and
cast
it
at
her
,
she
would
have
led
an
irritable
and
probably
an
useless
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
have
heard
tell
,
Tattycoram
,
that
her
young
life
has
been
one
of
active
resignation
,
goodness
,
and
noble
service
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
what
I
consider
those
eyes
of
hers
,
that
were
here
just
now
,
to
have
always
looked
at
,
to
get
that
expression
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
if
you
please
,
sir
.
"
   
"
Duty
,
Tattycoram
.
 
<EOS>
Begin
it
early
,
and
do
it
well
;
and
there
is
no
antecedent
to
it
,
in
any
origin
or
station
,
that
will
tell
against
us
with
the
Almighty
,
or
with
ourselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
remained
at
the
window
,
Mother
joining
them
and
pitying
the
prisoners
,
until
she
was
seen
coming
back
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
soon
in
the
room
,
and
recommended
that
Arthur
,
whom
she
had
left
calm
and
composed
,
should
not
be
visited
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
cheerily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
a
doubt
that
's
best
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
trust
my
remembrances
then
,
my
sweet
nurse
,
in
your
hands
,
and
<EOS>
I
well
know
they
could
n't
be
in
better
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
off
again
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
,
surprised
,
asked
him
where
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
"
I
ca
n't
live
without
breathing
.
 
<EOS>
This
place
has
taken
my
breath
away
,
and
I
shall
never
get
it
back
again
until
Arthur
is
out
of
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
that
a
reason
for
going
off
again
to
-
morrow
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
understand
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
we
three
will
put
up
at
a
City
Hotel
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
morning
,
Mother
and
Tattycoram
will
go
down
to
Twickenham
,
where
Mrs
Tickit
,
sitting
attended
by
Dr
Buchan
in
the
parlour
-
window
,
will
think
them
a
couple
of
ghosts
;
and
I
shall
go
abroad
again
for
Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
Dan
here
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
tell
you
,
my
love
,
it
's
of
no
use
writing
and
planning
and
conditionally
speculating
upon
this
and
that
and
the
other
,
at
uncertain
intervals
and
distances
;
we
must
have
Doyce
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
devote
myself
at
daybreak
to
-
morrow
morning
,
to
bringing
Doyce
here
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
nothing
to
me
to
go
and
find
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
an
old
traveller
,
and
all
foreign
languages
and
customs
are
alike
to
me
<EOS>
---
I
never
understand
anything
about
any
of
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
ca
n't
be
put
to
any
inconvenience
.
 
<EOS>
Go
at
once
I
must
,
it
stands
to
reason
;
because
I
ca
n't
live
without
breathing
freely
;
and
I
ca
n't
breathe
freely
until
Arthur
is
out
of
this
Marshalsea
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
stifled
at
the
present
moment
,
and
have
scarcely
breath
enough
to
say
this
much
,
and
to
carry
this
precious
box
down
-
stairs
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
got
into
the
street
as
the
bell
began
to
ring
,
<EOS>
Mr
Meagles
carrying
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
had
no
conveyance
there
:
which
rather
surprised
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
called
a
coach
for
her
<EOS>
and
she
got
into
it
,
and
he
placed
the
box
beside
her
when
she
was
seated
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
joy
and
gratitude
she
kissed
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
that
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
goes
against
my
feeling
of
what
's
right
,
that
YOU
should
do
homage
to
ME
---
at
the
Marshalsea
Gate
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
bent
forward
,
and
kissed
his
cheek
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
remind
me
of
the
days
,
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,
suddenly
drooping
---
"
<EOS>
but
she
's
very
fond
of
him
,
and
hides
his
faults
,
and
thinks
that
no
one
sees
them
---
and
he
certainly
is
well
connected
and
of
a
very
good
family
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
only
comfort
he
had
in
the
loss
of
his
daughter
,
and
if
he
made
the
most
of
it
,
who
could
blame
him
?
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
Gone
 
On
a
healthy
autumn
day
,
the
Marshalsea
prisoner
,
weak
but
otherwise
restored
,
sat
listening
to
a
voice
that
read
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
On
a
healthy
autumn
day
;
when
the
golden
fields
had
been
reaped
and
ploughed
again
,
when
the
summer
fruits
had
ripened
and
waned
,
when
the
green
perspectives
of
hops
had
been
laid
low
by
the
busy
pickers
,
when
the
apples
clustering
in
the
orchards
were
russet
,
and
the
berries
of
the
mountain
ash
were
crimson
among
the
yellowing
foliage
.
 
<EOS>
Already
in
the
woods
,
glimpses
of
the
hardy
winter
that
was
coming
were
to
be
caught
through
unaccustomed
openings
among
the
boughs
where
the
prospect
shone
defined
and
clear
,
free
from
the
bloom
of
the
drowsy
summer
weather
,
which
had
rested
on
it
as
the
bloom
lies
on
the
plum
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
from
the
seashore
the
ocean
was
no
longer
to
be
seen
lying
asleep
in
the
heat
,
but
its
thousand
sparkling
eyes
were
open
,
and
its
whole
breadth
was
in
joyful
animation
,
from
the
cool
sand
on
the
beach
to
the
little
sails
on
the
horizon
,
drifting
away
like
autumn
-
tinted
leaves
that
had
drifted
from
the
trees
.
<EOS>
Changeless
and
barren
,
looking
ignorantly
at
all
the
seasons
with
its
fixed
,
pinched
face
of
poverty
and
care
<EOS>
,
the
prison
had
not
a
touch
of
any
of
these
beauties
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
Blossom
<EOS>
what
would
,
its
bricks
and
bars
bore
uniformly
the
same
dead
crop
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
Clennam
,
listening
to
the
voice
as
it
read
to
him
,
heard
in
it
all
that
great
Nature
was
doing
,
heard
in
it
all
the
soothing
songs
she
sings
to
man
.
 
<EOS>
At
no
Mother
's
knee
but
hers
<EOS>
had
he
ever
dwelt
in
his
youth
on
hopeful
promises
,
on
playful
fancies
,
on
the
harvests
of
tenderness
and
humility
that
lie
hidden
in
the
early
-
fostered
seeds
of
the
imagination
;
on
the
oaks
of
retreat
from
blighting
winds
,
that
have
the
germs
of
their
strong
roots
in
nursery
acorns
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
tones
of
the
voice
that
read
to
him
,
there
were
memories
of
an
old
feeling
of
such
things
,
and
echoes
of
every
merciful
and
loving
whisper
that
had
ever
stolen
to
him
in
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
voice
stopped
,
he
put
his
hand
over
his
eyes
,
murmuring
that
the
light
was
strong
upon
them
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
put
the
book
by
,
and
presently
arose
quietly
to
shade
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
Maggy
sat
at
her
needlework
in
her
old
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
light
softened
,
Little
Dorrit
brought
her
chair
closer
to
his
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
will
soon
be
over
now
,
dear
Mr
Clennam
.
 
<EOS>
Not
only
are
Mr
Doyce
's
letters
to
you
so
full
of
friendship
and
encouragement
,
but
Mr
Rugg
says
his
letters
to
him
are
so
full
of
help
,
and
that
everybody
(
now
a
little
anger
is
past
)
is
so
considerate
,
and
speaks
so
well
of
you
,
that
it
will
soon
be
over
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Good
angel
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
praise
me
far
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
it
is
such
an
exquisite
pleasure
to
me
to
hear
you
speak
so
feelingly
,
and
to
---
and
to
see
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
raising
her
eyes
to
his
,
"
<EOS>
how
deeply
you
mean
it
,
that
I
can
not
say
Do
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
lifted
her
hand
to
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
here
<EOS>
many
,
many
times
,
when
I
have
not
seen
you
,
Little
Dorrit
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
been
here
sometimes
when
I
have
not
come
into
the
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
often
?
"
   
"
Rather
often
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
timidly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Every
day
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
,
after
hesitating
,
"
that
I
have
been
here
at
least
twice
every
day
.
<EOS>
"
He
might
have
released
the
little
light
hand
after
fervently
kissing
it
again
;
but
that
,
with
a
very
gentle
lingering
where
it
was
,
it
seemed
to
court
being
retained
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
it
in
both
of
his
,
and
it
lay
softly
on
his
breast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Little
Dorrit
,
it
is
not
my
imprisonment
only
that
will
soon
be
over
.
 
<EOS>
This
sacrifice
of
you
must
be
ended
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
learn
to
part
again
,
and
to
take
our
different
ways
so
wide
asunder
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
not
forgotten
what
we
said
together
,
when
you
came
back
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
O
no
,
I
have
not
forgotten
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
something
has
been
<EOS>
---
You
feel
quite
strong
to
-
day
,
do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
strong
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
hand
he
held
crept
up
a
little
nearer
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
feel
quite
strong
enough
to
know
what
a
great
fortune
I
have
got
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
glad
to
be
told
.
 
<EOS>
No
fortune
can
be
too
great
or
good
for
Little
Dorrit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
anxiously
waiting
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
longing
and
longing
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
sure
you
will
not
take
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
sure
you
will
not
take
half
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
dear
Little
Dorrit
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
looked
at
him
silently
,
there
was
something
in
her
affectionate
face
that
he
did
not
quite
comprehend
:
something
that
could
have
broken
into
tears
in
a
moment
,
and
yet
that
was
happy
and
proud
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
sorry
to
hear
what
I
have
to
tell
you
about
Fanny
.
<EOS>
Poor
Fanny
has
lost
everything
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
nothing
left
but
her
husband
's
income
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
papa
gave
her
when
she
married
was
lost
as
your
money
was
lost
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
same
hands
,
and
it
is
all
gone
.
"
   
<EOS>
Arthur
was
more
shocked
than
surprised
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
hoped
it
might
not
be
so
bad
,
"
he
said
:
"
<EOS>
but
I
had
feared
a
heavy
loss
there
,
knowing
the
connection
between
her
husband
and
the
defaulter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
all
gone
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
for
Fanny
;
very
,
very
,
very
sorry
for
poor
Fanny
.
 
<EOS>
My
poor
brother
too
!
"
<EOS>
"
Had
he
property
in
the
same
hands
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
And
it
's
all
gone
.
<EOS>
---
How
much
do
you
think
my
own
great
fortune
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
Arthur
looked
at
her
inquiringly
,
with
a
new
apprehension
on
him
,
she
withdrew
her
hand
,
and
laid
her
face
down
on
the
spot
where
it
had
rested
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
as
poor
as
when
I
lived
here
.
<EOS>
When
papa
came
over
to
England
,
he
confided
everything
he
had
to
the
same
hands
,
and
it
is
all
swept
away
.
 
<EOS>
O
my
dearest
and
best
<EOS>
,
are
you
quite
sure
you
will
not
share
my
fortune
with
me
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
Locked
in
his
arms
,
held
to
his
heart
,
with
his
manly
tears
upon
her
own
cheek
<EOS>
,
she
drew
the
slight
hand
round
his
neck
,
and
clasped
it
in
its
fellow
-
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
to
part
,
my
dearest
Arthur
;
never
any
more
,
until
the
last
!
   
<EOS>
I
never
was
rich
before
,
I
never
was
proud
before
,
I
never
was
happy
before
,
I
am
rich
in
being
taken
by
you
,
I
am
proud
in
having
been
resigned
by
you
,
I
am
happy
in
being

<EOS>

assure
you
he
is
making
out
his
case
like
a
house
a
-
fire
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
fallen
on

,
has
Dan
.
 
<EOS>
Where

do

done
and

man

,
<EOS>
that
man
's
off

;
but
where
they
do
want
things
done
and
find
a
man
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
wo

.
 
<EOS>
Let

,
Dan

without

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Happiness
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

Dan
.
 
<EOS>
I

Dan
is

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
He

,

I

<EOS>
-
know
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
No

"

<EOS>
"
That

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

(

's

,
"

,
"

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
to

,
about

.
 
<EOS>
I

Doyce
.
 
<EOS>
Ran

among
a

those

brown
dogs
in
women
's
nightcaps
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
YOU

!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
He
was

,
and
I
was
going

,
and
so
we
came

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Doyce
in
England
!
"

Arthur
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Mr
Meagles
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am

to

.
 
<EOS>
I

been
in
the

line
---
<EOS>
right
,

!
 
<EOS>
The
long
and

of
it

,
Arthur
,
we

this

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

---

!
 
<EOS>
And

I
can

!
"
   
<EOS>
Doyce
darted
in
from
behind
the
door
,
caught
Arthur
by

,
and
said
the
rest
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
only
three
branches
of
my
subject
,
my
dear
Clennam
,
"
said
Doyce
,
proceeding
to

,
with

,
on

,
"

they
're
soon
disposed

.
<EOS>
First
,
not
a
word
more
from
you
about
the
past
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
error
in
your

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
that
is
.
 
<EOS>
It
affects
the
whole
machine
,
and
failure
is
the
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
profit
by
the
failure
,
and
will
avoid
it
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
a
similar
thing
myself
,
in
construction
,
often
.
 
<EOS>
Every
failure
teaches
a
man
something
,
if

;
and
you
are
too
sensible

man
not
to
learn
from
this

.
 
<EOS>
So
much
for
firstly
.
 
<EOS>
Secondly
.
 
<EOS>
I

have

so

,
and

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thirdly
.
 
<EOS>
We

,
that
,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
so

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
I

;

,
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
There

,

,
and

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Am

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

Little

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
room
was
a

room
that
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Where
in
the
world
was

a

so
full

!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
love
,
"
said
Arthur
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
does
Maggy
light

?
 
<EOS>
We
shall

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

her

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

an
odd

.
 
<EOS>
I

to
burn
something
for

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Superstitious

?
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
So

,

Clennam

,

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Does

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can

(
if

do
n't

)
<EOS>
"
I
love
you
!
"

Little
Dorrit
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
said

,
and

away
.
   
<EOS>
They
passed
very
quietly
along
the
yard
;
for
no
one
was
there
,
though
many

were
stealthily

from

.
   
<EOS>
Only
one
face
,
familiar
of
old
,
was
in
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
both
accosted
it
,
and
spoken
many
kind

,
Little
Dorrit
turned
back
one

with
her

out
,

,
"
Good
-
bye
,
good
John
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
live
very
happy
,
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
Then
they
went
up
the
steps
of
the
neighbouring
Saint
George
's
Church
,
and
went
up
to
the

,
where
Daniel
Doyce
was
waiting
in
his
paternal
character
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
was
Little
Dorrit
's
old
friend
who
had
given
her
the
Burial
Register
for
a
pillow
;
full
of
admiration
that
she
should
come
back
to
them
to
be
married
,
after
all
.
   
<EOS>
And
they
were
married
with
the
sun
shining
on
them
through
the
painted
figure
of
Our
Saviour
on
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
went
into
the
very
room
where
Little
Dorrit
had
slumbered
after
her
party
,
to
sign
the
Marriage
Register
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
,
Mr
Pancks
,
(
destined
to
be
chief
clerk
to
Doyce
and
Clennam
,
and
afterwards
partner
in
the
house
)
,
sinking
the
Incendiary
in
the
peaceful
friend
,
looked
in
at
the
door
to
see
it
done
,
with
Flora
gallantly
supported
on
one
arm
and
Maggy
on
the
other
,
and
a
back
-
ground
of
John
Chivery
and
father
and
other
turnkeys
who
had
run
round
for
the
moment
,
deserting
the
parent
Marshalsea
for
its
happy
child
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
Flora
the
least
signs
of
seclusion
upon
her
,
notwithstanding
her
recent
declaration
;
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
was
wonderfully
smart
,
and
enjoyed
the
ceremonies
mightily
,
though
in
a
fluttered
way
.
   
<EOS>
Little
Dorrit
's
old
friend
held
the
inkstand
as
she
signed
her
name
,
and
the
clerk
paused
in
taking
off
the
good
clergyman
's
surplice
,
and
all
the
witnesses
looked
on
with
special
interest
.
<EOS>
"
For
,
you
see
,
"
said
Little
Dorrit
's
old
friend
,
"
this
young
lady
is
one
of
our
curiosities
,
and
has
come
now
to
the
third
volume
of
our
Registers
.
 
<EOS>
Her
birth
is
in
what
I
call
the
first
volume
;
she
lay
asleep
,
on
this
very
floor
,
with
her
pretty
head
on
what
I
call
the
second
volume
;
and
she
's
now
a
-
writing
her
little
name
as
a
bride
in
what
I
call
the
third
volume
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
all
gave
place
when
the
signing
was
done
,
and
Little
Dorrit
and
her
husband
walked
out
of
the
church
alone
.
 
<EOS>
They
paused
for
a
moment
on
the
steps
of
the
portico
,
looking
at
the
fresh
perspective
of
the
street
in
the
autumn
morning
sun
's
bright
rays
,
and
then
went
down
.
   
<EOS>
Went
down
into
a
modest
life
of
usefulness
and
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
Went
down
to
give
a
mother
's
care
,
in
the
fulness
of
time
,
to
Fanny
's
neglected
children
no
less
than
to
their
own
,
and
to
leave
that
lady
going
into
Society
for
ever
and
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
Went
down
to
give
a
tender
nurse
and
friend
to
Tip
for
some
few
years
,
who
was
never
vexed
by
the
great
exactions
he
made
of
her
in
return
for
the
riches
he
might
have
given
her
if
he
had
ever
had
them
,
and
who
lovingly
closed
his
eyes
upon
the
Marshalsea
and
all
its
blighted
fruits
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
quietly
down
into
the
roaring
streets
,
inseparable
and
blessed
;
and
as
they
passed
along
in
sunshine
and
shade
,
the
noisy
and
the
eager
,
and
the
arrogant
and
the
froward
and
the
vain
,
fretted
and
chafed
,
and
made
their
usual
uproar
.
     
<EOS>
